column2: Eighty-two-year-old James A. Hopkins, for fifty years attendant of Company K of the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard, will be honored tonight for his long service when his unit marches in review before him at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

"Topics of the Times," I note with considerable ruefulness, can discern no virture in that age-old habit -- reading in bed. The thought occurs to me that your learned essayist has not surveyed all aspects of a matter upon which he expatiates with more dogmatism than understanding.

LONDON, June 22 (UP) -- About 1,500 Thames River barge arid tugboat workers joined the wildcat strike of dock employes tonight. The bargemen voted to strike despite appeals from their union leaders and from Prime N[lnister Clement Attlee, who told 20,000 dock workers that their eight-day strike imperilled Britain's 'export drive and threatened further food cuts for rationed Londoners.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 22 -- Merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed denomination came closer to realization today when a Basis of Union plan was overwhelmingly adopted by delegates attending the biennial meeting here of the Congregational Christian General Council. The Evangelical and Reformed body has already approved the Basis of Union.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, reported yesterday that it had won wage increases totaling $100,000,000 a year for 450,000 members despite the union's refusal to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Law.

Federal aid to education is essential on every level if the democratic principle of equality of opportunity is to be maintained, Dr. Bryn J. Hovde, president of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, declared yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 22 -- A plea for the end of the political controversy over Zionism among Jews was made tonight by Dr. Abraham J. Feldman of Hartford, Conn., president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, at the opening of the annual convention of the group.

Displaying a facile familiarity with gangland vernacular, 17-year-old Edward Fennessey, admitted perpetrator of seven armed robberies, readily agreed under cross-examination yesterday in General Sessions that he knew he was a "rat" and a "squealer."

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Stan Musial's fifth consecutive single, with the bases loaded in the ninth, clinched a 5-2 victory for the Cardinals over the league-leading Braves tonight before a crowd of 29,064. That perfect batting performance boosted the National League's top slugger's average to .402 and gave Harry (The Cat) Brecheen his eighth pitching triumph of the season.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- United States exports to Europe declined in April despite the beginning of aid shipments under the European Recovery Program, the Census Bureau reported today.

Bond men said yesterday that the Equitable Life Assurance Society's move in outbidding banking syndicates by the equivalent of about 11 market points for the Philadelphia, Baltimore Washington Railroad's bond issue marked a new high level for Wall Street's book of tall stories.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Four former champions and the tournament medalist today stroked into the second round of the nineteenth Women's Western Open golf tourney as only one mild upset was recorded in the opening session.

With their five-month-old son asleep in a crib, a young disabled veteran and his wife, who said the lack of an apartment had kept them apart long enough, stationed themselves at 9 A. M. yesterday on the sidewalk outside the Vacancy Listing Bureau of the New York City Housing Authority, 153 East Fifty-seventh Street, "to gain the public's support."

LONDON, June 22 -- Britain's main hope of attaining a balance of trade between the sterling area and the United States does not lie in increasing exports of manufactured goods but in sending the United States more agricultural products and raw materials from the British colonies, Lord Trefgarne, chairman of the Colonial Development Corporation, declared today in Liverpool.

PEIPING, June 22 -- About 300,000 tons of coal, which accumulated during the recent fighting in the Tangshan coal mine area, started moving to southern industrial centers yesterday. This represents about a month's production of bituminous coal from the Kailan mines, on which the industries of Tientsin and Shanghai are almost completely dependent.

LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- A bundle of Latin temperament, Gianni Cucelli of Italy, supplied most of the excitement in the second day of the Wimbledon tennis championships today by eliminating Jaroslav Drobny, the high-seeded Czech star.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 22 -- Wading through a heavy downpour made the Nassau Country Club course seem harder and longer than it was to the hard-hitters who emerged victorious as the first round of match play in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship was completed today.

For more than a decade, the idea of one big union to represent the dozen groups affiliated with the Associated Actors and Artistes of America (Four A's) has been uppermost in the minds of some 60,000 members. The United States is said to be the only country where an over-all union doesn't prevail in the amusement field for the benefit of the membership.

T. Vincent Quinn, First Assistant United States Attorney General, who, for the last year, had been conducting an investigation of communism, was announced yesterday by the Democratic organization of Queens County as one of four candidates for Representative.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 23 -- While the Republicans in Philadelphia have been going through elaborate motions leading up to the balloting for the Presidential nominee, Britons have been getting an intensive education in United States politics from their newspapers.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- An extension of the ten-day restraining order forbidding maritime unions to strike before Thursday will be sought in Federal Court here tomorrow. Government counsel said this afternoon.

A fifteen-page affidavit filed yesterday with Federal Judge John W. Clancy by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, declared that the proposed injunction against a maritime strike "will not promote industrial peace" but merely serve to "aggravate instead of settle" the labor dispute.

SHANGHAI, June 22 -- Roger D. Lapham, director of the $400,000,000 China aid program of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, has decided to incorporate most of the activities and a large part of the personnel of the China Relief Mission into his operation.
JACKSON, Miss., June 22 (AP) -- States Righters were unopposed as Mississippi's Democrats elected thirty national convention delegates and nominated Presidential electors tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Following is the prepared text of the speech by Permanent Convention Chairman Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Speaker of the House of Representatives, to the Republican National Convention tonight:
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Following is the text of the speech by former President Herbert Hoover at the Republican National Convention:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- The feud between Lauren Bacall and Warner Brothers broke into the open again today with the disclosure that Miss Bacall has refused an assignment and has been suspended from salary for the second time in two months.

The one-horse stable of Herbert Akerberg, New York radio executive, delivered the goods in the main event of Aqueduct's rain-spattered proceedings yesterday. Blue Counselor, two-year-old colt purchased by Akerberg early in the year, scored by half a length in a $5,000 purse called the Banquet.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio worked overtime today making appearances and talks before Republican delegations from states from coast to coast.

Retail store sales promotion managers were warned yesterday to make a thorough analysis of all advertising and promotional functions before considering any action toward reducing such outlays. Robert J. Powderly, sales promotion director of Kresge-Newark, Inc., and chairman of the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's sales promotion division and display group, issued the warning in an address before the convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -- A report of the International Labor Office, concluding that workers had a much better prospect of improving incomes and living standards through "increases in productivity, combined with full employment," than through an increase in labor's share of national income was before the wages committee of the International Labor Conference as it began discussions today.

A speedy way to decorate unpainted furniture with colored decalcomanias was introduced yesterday at Spear Co., 22 West Thirty-fourth Street, where demonstrations of Decal-Art furniture will be held all week. Unpainted pieces by Aristo-Bilt, related in size and design so that they may be grouped into storage banks, were decorated with motifs suitable for nurseries, breakfast rooms and other informal settings.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 22 -- Gen. Markos Vafiades, leader of the Greek Rebel Army, has protested to Secretary General Trygve Lie, denying the Greek Government's accusations that his guerrilla forces abducted 10,000 children to neighboring Soviet satellite states.
Pennsylvania hard coal miners and their families have received $3,806,000 in benefits from the health and welfare fund set up by the anthracite operators and the United Mine Workers two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, June 23 -- The Republican Presidential nomination was in the near grasp early today of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and the most powerful competing forces in the party were gathered in running conferences intended to stop him.
Nuremberg's famed toymakers, back at work amid the rubble of their bomb-ravaged city, are producing "beautiful" playthings for export to the United States, it was reported here yesterday.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 22 -- Resources placed at the disposal of the United Nations by secondary powers well might "tip the balance" in resolving a threat of war, Robert G. Riddell of Ottawa, Canada, said today, in a plea for "commensurate recognition" at the Mount Holyoke College Institute on the U. N.

Mr. Blandings of current cinema fame might have met with fewer troubles in building his dream house if someone could have sent him a circular just released by the Small Homes Council of the University of Illinois.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York spent today "running" for the Republican Presidential nomination. Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan spent the day "being available" for the nomination.

In his recent letter Alfred Bilmanis takes issue with Winston Churchill's contentions concerning the internal structure of pre-war Latvia and its part during the war. If Mr. Churchill states in his memoirs that Latvia was violently anti-Communist and collaborated with Germany during the recent world conflict, it is a very mild statement indeed.

HANOVER, N. H., June 22 -- Robert K. Carr, Professor of Government at Dartmouth College, has been elected to the Joel Parker Professorship of Law and Political Science, Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president of the college, announced today. This chair on the Dartmouth faculty was last held by the late Prof. James P. Richardson.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- The Republican National Convention gave vent to its first spontaneous outburst tonight when Herbert Hoover, the nation's only living ex-President, appeared on the scene with a personal message to the delegates.

With the Tammany Hall district leaders preparing for a showdown on the designation of a candidate for Surrogate, the judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday that it had endorsed Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, as qualified for the post.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 22 -- Edwin Kohn of the Gun Hill Club and Dean Lucarini of Southern Dutchess shared honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney today at Knollwood Country Club. A field of seventy competed despite intermittent rains.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation had a consolidated net profit in the nine months ended on May 31 last of $24,466,105 after taxes and all charges, it was announced following a directors' meeting yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Pennsylvania's facade of unity fell apart today as Senator Edward Martin plumped for Thomas E. Dewey. The break means thirty-five to fifty additional votes for the New York Governor on the first ballot.

Young men, anxious to avoid twenty-one months service in the regular Army under the recently enacted draft act, are signing up in the New York National Guard at the rate of 2,000 a day, according to information received at headquarters in Peekskill.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- With Congress in the third day of adjournment, President Truman today placed in top Federal positions eleven men who have already been rejected or ignored by the Senate.

RYE, N. Y., June 22 -- The only player who has won the title five times in succession, Ellis Knowles of Apawamis, scored a 76 today in the historic United States senior golf championship over the Apawamis course and shared the lead at the completion of the first eighteen-hole round.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- States collected from motorists a record $1,186,000,000 in gasoline and other auto fuel taxes in 1947, the Federation of Tax Administrators reported here today.

Col. Sosthenes Behn, 66-year-old chairman and president of the $515,000,000 International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, will be succeeded tomorrow in the latter post by William H. Harrison, a vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was learned yesterday.
The New York Star, successor to PM, makes its first appearance today as a morning newspaper.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- Directors off the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation were asked today to look into the transfer of the lease of the Trentwood (aluminum) Rolling Mills, near Spokane, Wash., to the Permanente Metals Corporation.

Although most of the contracts covering 100,000 Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipyard workers expire today, officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, indicated yesterday that negotiations would continue and the workers would remain on the job.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- President Charles Seymour of Yale University today announced the proposed establishment of a scholarship and fellowship fund of at least $10,000,000 as a memorial to the 513 alumni who died in World War II.

The New York Historical Society will open today a special exhibition of seventy-five portraits of contemporary Americans by Enit Kaufman. The entire collection, eighty-seven in number, of prominent American scientists, artists, legislators and other public figures was presented to the society by the artist in 1947 and is to be preserved as a group portrait of the war and post-war years.

BOUND BROOK, N. J., June 22 -- A month-long experiment in self-education, embracing social, religious, civic, educational, labor and other groups, closed here tonight when "America's Town Meeting of the Air" was broadcast over a nation-wide network from Bound Brook High School before an audience of several hundred persons.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- A real kingmaker appeared here today in the person of Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania. Until he announced he would both support Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York for the Presidency and put his name before the Republican National Convention, the gathering was giving a daily exhibition of leading from weakness -- most unusual in a Republican assemblage of this scope.

Nine public school pupils who won prizes in the 1948 poster contest on the subject, "Keep Your Subway Clean," will receive their awards from Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri tomorrow at 3 P. M. in City Hall, it was announced jointly yesterday by the Board of Transportation and the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today suspended, for an investigating period of seven months, tariffs filed with it by the Newtex Steamship Corporation that would have inaugurated what competing steamship lines said was the first "store-door" pick-up and delivery service ever offered by a water carrier.

In a fall promotion that will feature a home-decorating service center, Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company will use color ads in Sunday rotogravure sections reaching fifty-six markets, seven magazines and a group of farm publications.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 22 -- The scourge of the West was loose again on the Hudson today as the University of Washington made the first sweep of the river since 1937 in the Poughkeepsie rowing regatta.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) Federal Judge J. Cullen Ganey today refused to issue a preliminary restraining order to prevent the seating of Mississippi's "regular" Republican delegation at the GOP convention here.

The costliness of hospital care, the inadequacy of accommodations and the extremely high cost of providing new hospital space are facts that continue to cause great concern among those familiar with them. Congress recently recognized these facts, to at least a limited extent, by passing an appropriation bill carrying cash and contract authority for $125,000,000 as grants to states for hospital construction on a matching basis.

The board of directors of the Motion Picture Export Association yesterday discussed at a special meeting "all phases" of the troubled Anglo-American film situation. The three-hour conference was adjourned without a decision being announced, but it was revealed that the board will meet again on Monday at 11 A. M. for an "all-day" session on problems arising from the recent British 45 per cent quota ruling.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 22 -- Pollution on the Westchester shores of the Hudson River and Long Island Sound is greater now than usual for this time of year, the County Health Department said today in listing certain areas as unsafe for swimming.

The Appellate Division yesterday reversed a ruling by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter that had annulled an order of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission authorizing the Hotel Martinique, Broadway and Thirty-second Street, to increase rent of its permanent residents 30 per cent.
PARSONS, Kan., June 22 (AP) -- Kansas farmers scanned dripping skies today for signs that the torrential rains were over and the wheat harvest could be pushed without further delay.

Commission salesmen whose activities are controlled "substantially" by employers will not be excluded from old - age insurance coverage under the new Social Security Law recently enacted over a Presidential veto, Andrew P. Federline, Washington counsel for the National Association of Women's and Children's Wear Apparel Association, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Lever Brothers Company, soap maker, by outright purchase has acquired John F. Jelke Company of Chicago, manufacturer of Good Luck margarine with annual sales of nearly $25,000,000, Charles Luckman, president, announced, in revealing the fourth major step in Lever Brothers' expansion program, within two years.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, June 24 -- With more than the usual amount of fanfare that customarily accompanies nominating speeches, the candidates for the nomination for President were placed before the Republican National Convention in a session that lasted long after midnight.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Unless Congress passes the $65,000,000 loan for the United Nations at a special session this year, construction of the New York headquarters of the world organization will be delayed one or two years, Trygve Lie told a press conference today.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company is now producing at the rate of $105,000,000 a year gross, before discounts, James DeCamp Wise, president, disclosed yesterday. Speaking at a convention of more than 1,250 company retailers representing thirty states in the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel, he added that his organization is the first in the carpet industry to "come anywhere near that figure."

LONDON, June 23 -- British authorities in Germany and Austria never will deny asylum to political refugees from behind the iron curtain, Lord Henderson, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State in the Foreign Office, assured the House of Lords today.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 -- Soap manufacturers were called upon today to either end direct selling of their products to retailers or discontinue present floor stock protection policies entirely.
ROME, June 23 -- The Catholic Church in Albania has been virtually suppressed by what Vatican circles describe as the methodical murdering and jailing of members of the episcopate and clergy.

Probably 75 per cent of thinking parents are opposed to lurid comic books but are helpless to end the increasing number of publications, Dr. Frederic Wertham, director of the Quaker Emergency Service Readjustment Center. 151 East Fifty-seventh Street, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The State Department has instructed the American Embassy in London to voice its concern with the British Foreign Office over the British plan to reserve 45 per cent of screen time in the British motion-picture houses for British films.

VIENNA, June 23 -- The Austrian Cabinet said today that Soviet occupation authorities created the impression that they considered Austrian investigation of "illegal and anti-democratic" activities a menace to Soviet security. It added that such a situation gave the appearance of being "open intervention in the internal institutions of the country."

DENVER, June 23 -- Federal aid for higher education is necessary as a defense measure, Dean Clifford Houston of the University of Colorado declared today at the opening of the American College Public Relations Association's convention.

Everything else that happens at the Republican National Convention this year, or at any major party convention in any year, is secondary to the choice of a Presidential candidate. Today the Republicans, buoyant with hopes of victory, approach this delicate and decisive task.

One hundred years of service to many thousands of New York families is being marked this year by the Community Service Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10. It is no surprise to anyone conversant with the good works of this organization to learn from its annual report that the 100th year has been the busiest of all.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California is beginning to figure more prominently in the calculations of the politicians along the smoky-room circuit.

WALGROVE SNOOD, who says he likes books but never has time to read them, sat down beside Kim Carruthers, the Great Reader, on the 5:58 for Niblickdale. They both spoke feelingly about the rain. Then Mr. Snood eyed Mr. Carruthers' bulging brief case beadily and asked: "Have you read any good books lately?"

In about the time it takes to say "Theodore F. Atkinson, Esq.," Eternal Flag was four lengths in front in the forty-second edition of the $24,475 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The filly made what looked like a jet-assisted take-off from the starting gate, and it led to a length victory.

MEXICO CITY, June 23 -- An experimental demonstration of mobile radio-telephone communication was carried out today by the Mexican Telephone and Telegraph Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone an Telegraph Corporation, at the general summer meeting here of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Myron C. Simon and Arthur I. Kraft have purchased an L-shaped plot on the east side of Steinway Avenue, 105 feet south of Broadway, in Astoria, Queens, from the L. S. Building Corporation and plan to improve it with a one-story taxpayer, on which work will be started at once.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23 -- Twelve newspaper men, among them Tillman Durdin, China correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, will receive Nieman Fellowships for study in the next academic year at Harvard University.

The three-story building at 23 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Cove, L.I., occupied as a meeting hall and headquarters of the James Northern Council of the Knights of Columbus and Lodge No. 1458 of the Benevolent Protective Order of Elks, has been sold by the Glen Cove Knights of Columbus Building Association, Inc., to the J.J.E. Realty Corporation.

Hank Behrman is back with the Dodgers. The obstacles that blocked the return of the right-handed fast-baller when the Brooks originally announced his recall from Montreal a couple of weeks ago having been removed, Behrman arrived in town yesterday, ready to do his bit to bolster Leo Durocher's short-handed pitching staff.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth did some torrid Texas sharp-shooting over gusty Skycrest Country Club today to trim a state running mate, Mrs. Bettye White of Dallas, 6 and 5. Her victory was the most convincing second-round triumph in the Women's Western Open golf tourney.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 23 -- As an aftermath of yesterday's battle between the Israeli Army and Irgun Zvai Leumi, the Government arrested seventy Irgunist members and Irgun Zvai Leumi announced that it would no longer recognize the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Forty-eight years ago a derby-hatted delegate attending his first Republican convention in this city, wandered the cobbled streets a little bewildered by criss crossing brass bands, by handle-bar mustached politicos shouting themselves hoarse for William McKinley, and by the red fire that lighted street parades after dark.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The North American Company today filed a plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the dissolution and liquidation of the North American Utility Securities Corporation as a step in compliance with the Holding Company

PASADENA, Calif., June 23 -- Unmanned balloons rising to a height of 100,000 feet have brought down the first evidence that the original cosmic radiations arriving from outer space contain the nuclei of atoms of various elements, such as carbon, calcium and silver, it was reported here today at the symposium on cosmic rays at the California Institute of Technology.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 23 -- United States opinion in world events has come to carry such weight that a "consistent foreign policy" is imperative, Mrs. Vera M. Dean told members of the Mount Holyoke College Institute on the United Nations today.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- Two Navy planes, flying in a seven-ship formation, crashed and burned today after colliding over the heavily populated East Side area of Detroit. The two pilots died in the crash.

To roulette wheels or gambling devices may be used at church bazaars in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Bishop Charles K. Gilbert told clerical and lay leaders yesterday. He said the ban by his predecessor, Bishop William T. Manning, retired, was still in effect.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Senator James P. Kem swung to Governor Dewey today, then took Missouri's Republican convention delegation to see the New Yorker.

The First Air Force is chosen for the defense of "the critical target area of the entire industrial northeast" of the United States, according to plans for its reorganization announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Robert M. Webster, commanding, from the headquarters at Fort Slocum, near New Rochelle.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Campaign managers for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey are relying heavily on psychological tactics to convince the Republican National Convention delegates that his nomination on an early ballot is inevitable.

The directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad approved here yesterday a program of debt readjustment under the Mahaffie act through which the road's maturities of bonds would be extended and its fixed charges would be reduced, according to an announcement made by C. A. Major, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Jamal el-Husseini, vice chairman of the Palestinian Arab Higher Committee, today protested to the Republican National Convention against its endorsement of the State of Israel and urged Americans to support the Arabs' demand for a single Palestinian state.

ROME, June 23 -- Fifteen persons were wounded with bullets and more than fifteen others injured in Naples today when police were obliged to use firearms in the worst outburst of rioting that Italy has experienced since the election in April.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Gov. Dwight H. Green, Illinois' favorite son, today freed his state's fifty-six delegates after the first ballot and said they would vote for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican Presidential nomination.
WARSAW, June 23 -- Eight Eastern European Foreign Ministers met here today to formulate the Soviet bloc's counter-measures to the recent six-power London agreements on the future of Western Germany.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 23 -- Recent Congressional action in approving a House-Senate compromise bill permitting slightly more than 200,000 displaced persons to enter this country was assailed here today by the general council of the Congregational Christian Churches as a "highly restrictive and ineffectual" measure.

Created to give fashion impetus to budget price manufacturers, fall hats by fifteen designers of the Millinery Fashion Bureau were presentetd yesterday to industry representatives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The models could be purchased for copying purposes.

Although there has been considerable progress in the development of techniques for distribution cost analysis, industry has not utilized them for improving the distribution system, it was pointed out yesterday by Howard C. Greer, vice president of Kingan Co., meat packers of Indianapolis.

HOECHST, Germany, June 23 -- Officials of the Joint Export-Import Agency here said today that they expected to reopen "in a few days" negotiations with the Belgian and Netherland Governments for the use of the ports of Rotterdam and Antwerp, traditional points of entry for shipping to Western Germany.

Attributing "the serious state of affairs in the world" to the antipathy between "the God-fearing power of democracy and the God-hating power of communism," Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, appealed yesterday for greater consideration of spiritual values in national and international affairs.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $80,000,000 of long-term convertible debentures. Gwilym A. Price, president, announced yesterday.

Big Eddy, on the West Branch of the Penobscot River up in Maine, has just produced Maine's largest fish of the season, a 15 1/2-pound landlocked salmon, the largest ever taken in the Moosehead region on rod and reel.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- A special master in chancery recommended today dismissal of a petition of the Majestic Radio and Television Corporation and Majestic Records, Inc., to reorganize under chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

Representatives of thirteen Congress of Industrial Organization unions, with an estimated membership of 250,000 in the metropolitan area, set machinery in motion yesterday for the formation of a new regional organization to replace the left-wing Greater New York CIO Council.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- The Red Cross was pictured today to its national convention as one of the few remaining agencies in the world through which it was possible to "keep the doors open" among nations with conflicting ideologies and aims.

SHANGHAI, June 23 -- The merging of two large Communist administrative regions in North China into a single military and political unit has been announced in broadcasts over the Communist North Shensi radio.

The Savings Bank Association of the State of New York, yesterday elected Albert B. Losel, president of the Peoples Savings Bank of Yonkers, N. Y., as chairman of the senior officers group IV. This group comprises all the savings banks in Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 19 points lower to 4 points higher yesterday, with the near months relatively easier than the distants contracts.

The plank on national defense in the Republican platform is one on which most Americans could stand. The question is whether several of the Republican leaders, especially in the House, can say as much.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's convention headquarters were the scene of feverish activity tonight as his managers exerted their maximum efforts to capitalize on the decision yesterday of Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania to forego his own candidacy and place the New York Governor in nomination and the gain today of votes from Indiana, New Jersey and Missouri.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) -- Victor Seixas of the University of North Carolina stroked his way into the quarter-finals of the national intercollegiate tennis championships today and William and Mary College sounded a threat to retain team honors.
LONDON, June 23 -- Continuance of the dock strike had a restraining influence on the stock market here today and business was cut to a minimum.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, majority leader of the House, took the lead in the backstage race for the Republican nomination for Vice President late today, but the contest was far from being over or won.
ATHENS, June 23 -- The advance of the Greek National Army in the Grammos mountain area continued during the last twenty-four hours, but at a slower pace, a military spokesman said tonight.

A painting by Police Lieut. James Francis Smith, who as a Western Union messenger in his youth carried a message from New York to South Africa, was presented yesterday by his widow, Mrs. Charlotte Smith, at the twenty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the Western Union Messenger School at 60 Hudson Street.
A study made of 148 manufacturing companies reveals that 28 per cent have a definite policy of decentralizing plant facilities, it was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Despite a hampering rain, United States Lines' officials embarked 1,002 passengers on the liner America yesterday -- one of the largest lists of the year -- plus myriad pieces of luggage, in time to permit the departure of the vessel at her scheduled hour of 4 P.M.

One of the greatest needs today in the field of printing is research on the legibility of type faces, Dr. M. Lyle Spencer, dean of the School of Journalism of Syracuse University, declared last night. He addressed ninety-four graduates to the New York School of Printing at commencement exercises held in Straubenmuller Textile High School and attended by 900 persons.

An assistant district attorney in the homicide bureau and Deputy Chief Inspector Conrad H. Rothengast, head of Manhattan East detective squads, were called as defense witnesses in the General Sessions trial of two men accused of slaying Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett forecast at a news conference today that the State Department would soon begin discussions through diplomatic channels with the nations belonging to the Western European Union.

The Board of Superintendents has banned the weekly magazine The Nation from the official periodical list of the New York public schools because of a series of articles that were allegedly anti-Catholic in content.

An advocate of the "central staging" method of play production, Jacob A. Weiser will carry out his theories this summer at the Ringside Theatre, Sea Girt, N.J. After witnessing its application sixteen years ago at the University of Washington, Mr. Weiser introduced the idea in the East, before the war, at Long Beach, L.I.

Oil pollution attributed to ships using New York Harbor is creating an "intolerable" situation along the beaches of Long Island, according to Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

A group of Tammany district leaders gave Mayor O'Dwyer and Frank J. Sampson, Tammany leader, a decisive rebuke yesterday afternoon when they designated General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente as the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County.

In all the flood of oratory released at the Republican Convention thus far, there is one speech that stands out above the others in its grasp of the great issue of our day. That is the speech of Herbert Hoover, who spoke above factional partisanship and personal ambition.

The State Athletic Commission next Thursday will institute a system of fingerprinting for licensees operating under its jurisdiction, it became known yesterday. The work will proceed under an amendment to the Walker Law governing boxing in this state, adapted recently by the Legislature at Albany.
PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, June 24 -- The cement and steel seams of the Municipal Convention Hall strained, at 2 o'clock this morning, to a spectacular demonstration for Harold Stassen.

Three card sharpers were fined and imprisoned and a fourth escaped with a fine when they appeared yesterday in Special Sessions for sentencing in connection with guilty pleas in connection with a gambling raid last Sept. 11 at the Marguery Hotel, 270 Park Avenue.

The Atlantic Danville Railway, which has been under lease to the Southern Railway since 1899, will resume operations as an independent line when turned back by the Southern around July 1, next year, it was announced in Norfolk, Va. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Retail prices of goods and services purchased by moderate-income families in large cities rose to a new peak last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The American Stage Equipment and Iron Works, Inc., has purchased the new building at 805 East 134th Street, the Bronx, from the Crosswood Realty Corporation. The building is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and included in the sale is an adjoining lot 25 by 100 feet.

Transfer of International Harvester Company's consumer relations department advertising from Aubrey, Moore Wallace, Inc., to the Chicago office of Young Rubicam, Inc., is another step in a post-war expansion program aimed at a broad approach to the consumer in various fields, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, backed for the Presidential nomination by his state's fifty-three votes, asked his delegation today to stand firm and criticized the decision of Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania to announce for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey before the first ballot was taken.

Among the people who have been convicted for taking bonuses for obtaining leases are some whose recommendations were effective to secure leases in some of the insurance companies' residential developments for the lower income bracket class.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that under a new regulation export licenses to ship certain types of commodities to European destinations will be issued hereafter for a validity period of six months instead of ninety days.

The State of Montana sold yesterday $3,000,000 of State Highway Treasury anticipation debentures due July 15, 1958 and callable July 15, 1953 to a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. at a bid of 100.516 for 1.90s. The bonds were reoffered at 101 3/8 to yield about 1.75 per cent to maturity.

Henry A. Wallace issued last night his yardstick for sizing up local Congressional candidates, but said the New Party was willing to compromise. He said his state organizations would be advised to throw their support to progressive candidates and "use as their measure a man's complete record."

The sale by Brooks Brothers, men's clothiers, of the five-story store and loft building which they formerly used for manufacturing at 239-41 East Forty-fourth Street, was announced yesterday. Charles B. Benenson is the new owner of the property, which was sold in a deal negotiated by Douglas Gibbons Co.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Prospect of agreement between the Screen Actors Guild and the motion picture producers on the troublesome question of actors' rights in films used for television appeared today when the actors and the producers announced that their negotiating committees had referred the television issue to a special subcommittee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith of Maine, whose victory in the Monday primary virtually assured her of becoming the nation's first Republican woman Senator, received an ovation on her arrival here late this afternoon.

NANKING, June 23 (UP) -- Supported by heavy artillery, 50,000 Communist troops tonight blasted strategic Kupehkow in Jehol Province, key town on the Government supply route from North China to central Manchuria.
Following are Associated Press and United Press summaries of the speeches made at the Republican National Covention last night in nominating candidates for President:

CHICAGO, June 23 -- An attempt to amend the constitution of the American Medical Association so that constituent associations could not exclude applicants from their membership except for "professional or ethical reasons" was rejected by the A.M.A. House of Delegates at its meeting here today.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- Two crack men's doubles teams from the United States got off to impressive starts in the Wimbledon tennis championships today, partly recompensing the huge crowd which eddied through the plant for an otherwise dull program.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 23 -- The second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship produced one major upset and several lose battles as it was completed over the Nassau Country Club course today.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and other high officials were spectators yesterday morning when 158 gambling machines were destroyed at the property clerk's warehouse, at Meeker and Morgan Avenues, Brooklyn.

Both sides rested yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Gus Fusaro, accused of swindling friends of $118,000 in stock investments. As the eighth trial day ended at 4 P.M., Judge Jacob Gould Schurman announced that he would submit only eight of the original forty-six-count indictment to the jury for consideration.

PARIS, June 23 -- The revised United States draft of the accord proposed with the European states receiving American aid has eliminated two provisions to which the Europeans had objected, it was learned today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 23 -- Fundamental changes in Zionist organizational life and in the character of the American Jewish community as a result of the new state of Israel were predicted tonight by Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, N. Y., before the Central Conference of American Rabbis.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Mrs. Arthur H. Vandenberg held a press conference this morning at which she carefully avoided questions about the political status of her husband.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Residents of the Soviet zone of Germany were pictured today by Oscar Weigert, a former Weimar Republic delegate attending his first International Labor Organization conference in sixteen years, as living under a regime no different from that of the Nazis.

Candy sales in 1948 will exceed $1,000,000,000, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, predicted yesterday. He spoke at a panel discussion during the sixty-fifth annual convention of the National Confectioners Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Contrary to rumors in the financial community this week, Col. Sosthenes Behn, president and chairman of the board of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, instead of relinquishing control of the communications of the system, is consolidating over-all domestic and foreign operations.

Ten New York public school pupils were honored yesterday for outstanding achievements with the presentation of $1,430 in prizes at ceremonies in the Board of Education building, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 -- As the light faded tonight off St. David's Head it became established that the 71-foot yawl Baruna had chalked up a dual victory by finishing first in the ocean race from Newport and by taking the honors in Class A.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 23 -- The delegates to the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were told today that President Truman had deliberately risked his political welfare to fight racial prejudice on every front.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Thomas E. Dewey's Presidential bandwagon still lurched onward tonight, though every sort of roadblock was being thrown in by coalitions seeking desperately to arrest its progress.

It was the sight of a little boy trying to fix a broken express wagon, said our visitor, that started him pondering on the decline of the Tinker -- not the itinerant mender of pots and pans, who has gone the way of the blacksmith, but the Mr. Fixit, the jack of all trades.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Passage of the revised Selective Service legislation has already resulted in filling the ranks of the National Guard beyond the levels originally fixed for the fiscal year 1949, officials estimated here today on the basis of partial reports from over the country.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- There are several smoke-filled rooms here in which Republican politicians, including candidates, are negotiating for the delegate votes that will add up to a majority for one of the contenders, a "receptive" party statesman or an authentic dark horse, but, if Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is the convention choice, then Room 807 at the Bellevue-Stratford will be the historic chamber of 1948.

Six hundred and five members of the class of '48 received degrees last evening at the ninety-fourth Hunter College commencement exercises in the college assembly hall, 695 Park Avenue. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, presented the diplomas.

"Howdy, Mr. Ice," the latest in the series of ice entertainments produced over a period of years by Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz, will be unfolded this evening at the Center Theatre. Featuring the nation's top skaters, the ice spectacle will contain choreography by Catherine Littlefield, who also has staged the show, and seven new songs written by Al Stillman and Alan Moran.
R.H. Schumacher, formerly with the Young Quinlan Company, Minneapolis, Minn., has been appointed assistant general manager of Charles of the Ritz' beauty salon division.

Tentative agreement on steps to facilitate reorganization of administrative practices in the Welfare Department was reached yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate. The board is scheduled to approve at today's meeting a new work relief program.

THE weatherman stopped Joe Louis yesterday. But he also stopped Jersey Joe Walcott. So no harm was done except to the ticket sellers, the fight fans and the boxing experts who will have to shadow box for an extra day. However, dat ole debbil rain did provoke one very disconcerting thought. Here it is for whatever it's worth.

The Port of New York Authority has rejected counter proposals from the City of Hoboken on its offer to lease and rebuild the municipality's piers and has also withdrawn a guarantee of $50,000 a year because of a change in cost estimates since the original offer, it was reported yesterday.

Dr. Lyman R. Bradley of New York University's Washington Square College, who was convicted last summer with ten others of contempt of Congress and sentenced to three months in jail and a fine of $500, has been suspended indefinitely from the university's faculty, it became known yesterday.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- The Senators stubbornly retired the Tigers three times after the bases were loaded today and finally defeated Detroit 2 -- 1, with two unearned runs. The Tigers left 15 stranded.

ATHENS, June 23 (AP) -- Greek Army troops pierced a guerrilla defense line along the Albanian border today and mounted a heavy assault against the southern portion of the semi-circular front, field dispatches said.

GENEVA, June 23 -- Col. William Hodgson, Australian member of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, today urged that group to request Secretary General Trygve Lie to invite Albania and Greece to discuss resumption of their diplomatic relations.

CLEVELAND, June 23 -- Tommy Henrich, affectionately called Old Reliable by his comrades, and Eddie Lopat, the chunky, blond-thatched southpaw who for a time wasn't believed to be carrying his weight in the American League pennant race, combined their talents tonight to give Bucky Harris' Bombers a smashing 5-to-1 victory over the Indians in eleven innings.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared today that the blitz being engineered for Governor Thomas E. Dewey had been stopped and the New Yorker would not get more than 400 votes on the second ballot.

NANKING, June 23 -- The Government military news service tonight announced the Government's loss of Kaifeng, capital of Honan Province, to the Communists at noon yesterday. The announcement came shortly after a Communist radio broadcast had claimed the Red occupation of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett suggested today that charges made in New York by the Nation Associates against the State Department and its policies toward Palestine should be regarded with considerable reserve at this stage.

City College conferred degrees upon a record high total of 3,098 graduates yesterday afternoon at the 102d commencement. Rain curtailed the scheduled ceremonies in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, to the shortest on record.

Continued buying in the rails yesterday gave the stock market its best push in two weeks. The advance was on a broad front and, as the session progressed it spread to every important section of the list and carried a number of important stocks to new highs.

LONDON, June 23 -- Troops moved into London's strikebound dock area today and started the flow of foodstuffs threatened with spoilage by an outlaw walk-out of stevedores and longshoremen. It was the third time in eighteen months that the Labor Government had been forced to call out the military in a London strike to assure the flow of supplies for the people.

Pinball machines were linked yesterday with juvenile delinquency and crime by Miles F. McDonald, District Attorney of Kings County. He testified before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora in a suit by four pinball manufacturers or distributors seeking to prevent Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander from seizing their machines.

An injunction barring maritime workers on the East and Gulf Coasts from carrying out a threat to strike was issued here yesterday by Federal Judge John W. Clancy. Under the Taft-Hartley Act, the injunction will be effective for eighty days from June 14, when the jurist granted a temporary restraining order, unless there is a settlement in the meantime.

Mayor O'Dwyer's office announced yesterday the resignation of Julius Kass as counsel for the city's Division of Labor Relations, effective July 1. Mr. Kass denied emphatically a rumor that his resignation was the result of Mayor O'Dwyer's dissatisfaction with a report he recently submitted covering labor relations and working conditions in the Department of Sanitation.

LONDON, June 23 -- Col. D. Clifton Brown, Speaker of the House of Commons, who recently rule that Members might make unkind remarks about the Spanish Government because Britain was not on entirely friendly terms with Spain, reproved a Member today for casting slurs upon the United States, a friendly power.
The New York National Guard membership was 40 per cent larger last night than it had been on Friday, before Congress passed the Selective Service Act.

Within two to three weeks after wage negotiations have been completed on contracts now being discussed, if not earlier, general price increases of from 5 to 10 per cent are expected in most manufacturing fields, and plans for these increases are well shaped now, industrial sources revealed here last night.

The Jack Benny half-hour Sundays at 7 P.M. on NBC will be held down this summer by "Let's Talk Hollywood," a quiz on motion pictures and stars, beginning July 4. Listeners will submit the questions to be presented to a panel of experts on the show, which will be moderated by George Murphy.

Formation of a nation-wide retail public service foundation designed to fit the needs of retail stores and to bring deserved credit for work achieved was urged yesterday by Samuel J. Cohen, sales manager of Lit Brothers department store, Philadelphia, at the Sales Promotion and Display Clinic of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A report of "considerable progress" toward writing a new agreement in the coal industry by miners and operators today led the White House to grant a twenty-four-hour extension to President Truman's Board of Inquiry.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 -- The Central Bank of Argentina moved today to bring the official bank rate for transfers here more into line with the free and black currency markets which today reached the unprecedented figure of 6.40 pesos to the dollar.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP) -- Herman Franks led a 14-hit Athletic attack, driving in five runs with a home run, triple and double, as Philadelphia swamped the St. Louis Browns, 12 to 1, tonight. Dick Fowler limited Brownie batters to six hits while his team-mates were scoring in seven of the nine innings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Isaac Brown, New York insurance man, won dismissal here today of a 1941 indictment that accused him of attempted murder in the first degree and assault in the first and second degree. He had previously been convicted and sent to Sing Sing prison but an Appellate Court had set aside the verdict and ordered a new trial.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- An examiner in the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission today recommended that the ICC deny a proposal of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company to issue debentures and common stock in exchange for outstanding preferred stock.

LAKE GEORGE, June 23 -- State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale today expressed concern over rising welfare costs and predicted that they would increase even more if the cost of living continued to climb.

In a reversal of a decision by the Supreme Court, the Appellate Division has lowered the assessed valuations on 111 and 115 Broadway for the tax years 1944 to 1946. The properties involved are the Trinity Building and the United States Realty Building, both twenty-one story structures.

LONDON, June 23 -- Speculation informed quarters here tonight entered on the possibility that the Warsaw conference of Soviet bloc Foreign Ministers might announce the setting up of a "Pan-German Government" in the Soviet zone.
HYDRO, Okla., June 23 (AP) -- At least seven persons are know dead in a flash flood that struck this west central Oklahoma town during the night.

Gross production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 5,492,350 barrels daily, a new record for the sixth successive week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The output represented a gain of 12,750 barrels from the 5,479,600 in the preceding week and compared with 5,114,500 in the week ended on June 21, 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- Confronted with the case of the chief of the Bikom tribe in the British Cameroons, who has 110 wives, the United Nations Trusteeship Council decided tentatively today to refer the complaint to the Human Rights Commission.

A first-mortgage loan of $1,650,000 at 4 per cent interest for fifteen years was made by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark to the New York Herald Tribune, Inc., on its twenty- story printing plant and general offices at 219-29 West Fortieth Street, extending through the block to 228-32 West Forty-first Street.

A sixty-mile boat tour of the city's inland waters yesterday gave more than a hundred members of the Park Association and friends a sweeping, misty view of the parks, parkways, housing developments, hospitals, prisons, small boat anchorages, coal hoppers, docks and industries that give beauty and utility to the shoreline.

The June 14 issue of THE TIMES contained a report of a meeting arranged by the Thirty-second Precinct Coordinating Council at which the Rev. Shelton Hale Bishop denounced the Park Department for its indifference in not providing adequate recreational facilities in Harlem.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Hank Sauer hit his 22nd home run of the season and Danny Litwhiler his fourth but Rookie Robin Roberts won his first major league game tonight as the Phillies defeated the Reds, 3-2.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The Franklin Association, representing Chicago area commercial printing firms, and Local 16 of the International Typographical Union of the American Federation of Labor, have agreed to a contract, ending months of negotiations.

Even though the people of our country do endure a great deal of injustice because of boss rule, an overdose is very much of a possibility, and without much further encroachment upon the welfare of our big rank and file voters there could without a doubt be an uprising of the general public against the continued abuse of such control.

The seventeenth annual commencement exercises of Yeshiva University will be held at 2:30 P.M. today in the school's Nathan Lamport Auditorium, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street. Eighty-two degrees and diplomas and two honorary degrees will be conferred by Dr. Samuel Belkin, president, who will preside.

The United States Navy plans to operate 277 major combatant ships in the fiscal year, 1949, starting July 1. Auxiliaries, small combatant vessels and supporting ships of various types, including landing craft, will total 486, or a grand total of 763 naval vessels.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 23 -- The American Home Economics Association, convening here, today urged all leading Presidential candidates at the Philadelphia Republican convention to declare their platform on public housing.
There appears to be some confusion in the public mind regarding the Vatican regulations on mixed marriages as applied in the case of King Michael of Rumania and Princess Anne of Denmark.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- United States delegates to the International Labor Organization conference on two occasions in committee sessions today withdrew proposed amendments to international conventions, or treaties, in the face of sharp opposition from foreign delegates.

An investigation by the House Labor Committee into Communist infiltration into New York department store unions was announced yesterday by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., chairman of the committee and co-author of the Taft-Hartley Law.

RYE, N.Y., June 23 -- Ellis Knowles of Apawamis took the lead today in the United States Senior golf championship by scoring a 74 in a heavy rain and raising his 36-hole aggregate to 150. This mark will be the target for the second half of the field that will begin play tomorrow.
BERLIN, June 23 -- The Communists reintroduced the strong-arm tactics of the early Nazi days into Berlin politics today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- The United Nations Security Council agreed today to take up the question of Franco Spain again on Friday. The meeting was scheduled as a result of a routine communication from Secretary General Trygve Lie, dated Dec. 12, transmitting the resolution adopted by the General Assembly last November.

Underwriting syndicates announced yesterday the effectiveness of offerings of three new issues of public utility securities, consisting of issues of straight convertible preferred stock priced at $22,045,000, and an issue of $3,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds.

The American Labor party has reached a formal decision to seek, through a referendum at the Nov. 2 election, a revocation of the city fare increase that is to go into effect next Thursday, it was announced last night by Paul L. Ross, vice chairman of the party's state committee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The Pennsylvania delegation gave 41 votes to Governor Dewey and 27 to Senator Taft in its first caucus roll call tonight. The vote represented a leadership split that is expected to have long-term consequences in the party's state organization.

Despite the failure of Congress to appropriate a $65,000,000 loan to build in this city a permanent United Nations headquarters, there seems to be a general expectation that the money will be forthcoming later. The trouble with that comfortable assumption is that "later" may be too late.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Capitol, the attraction is "Fort Apache," a Western adventure produced by John Ford and Merian C. Cooper and directed by Ford. Henry Fonda, John Wayne, Shirley Temple, Pedro Armendariz and John Agar head the cast of the Argosy Pictures production which is being released by RKO.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (UP) -- Common Pleas Court, in the first opinion of its kind here, ruled today that television broadcasts may not be reproduced for profit without the consent of the principals involved in the broadcasts.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 23 -- Three months ago Mrs. Vera David Lilienstern, who has been married since she was 18 years old, was just a housewife. Then a manufacturing idea came to her by chance. Today she was becoming a career woman, with the idea engulfing her life and also that of her husband, Richard, former New York clothing manufacturer and recently a marine.

VALHALLA, N.Y., June 23 -- Fifty-seven residents of the South Kensico Avenue area here complained today in petitions to local and Westchester County officials that "enormous snakes, snapping turtles and water rats" abound at a neighboring swamp owned by the county.

The Seeger Refrigerator Company, in an unaudited statement for the nine months ended on May 31, last, yesterday reported a net profit of $2,006,306, equal to $1.82 a share on 1,100,000 capital shares outstanding. This compares with the $1,072,233 or 97 1/2 cents a share cleared in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Harold E. Stassen swung his own energy and that of his organization today into the drive to eliminate Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as the leading contender for the GOP Presidential nomination.
Egyptian customs anthorities in Port Said seized Palestine-bound cargo from the American President liner President Monroe when the ship called there last month, it became known here yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 23 -- The Dominican Republic and El Salvador have ratified the constitution of the World Health Organization, it was announced today.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, was back in his training camp at Pompton Lakes, N.J., last night, his scheduled title fight against Jersey Joe Walcott, Camden (N.J.) challenger, postponed because of yesterday's rain.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 23 -- Al Brosch, defending champion from the Cherry Valley Club, shot 34, 35 -- 69, two under par, to set the pace during the first round of the twenty-fourth annual Long Island Golf Association open championship at the Garden City Country Club today.

Army's Jack Hammack, accepted as a late entry in the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships, is likely to find himself with a real battle on his hands from Roscoe Browne in the 440-yard event at Randalls Island Saturday.

Public relations administration is now taking its proper place as the concern of top management in modern banks, Robert Lindquist, vice president of the La Salle National Bank, Chicago, asserted yesterday. Speaking at a meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers at the Lawyers Club, Mr. Lindquist, who is president of the Financial Public Relations Association, declared that there was an increasing awareness of "the human function in banking."

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The Republican National Convention at its fifth session unanimously adopted today the party platform as presented by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, chairman of the committee on resolutions.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 23 -- Deprived of the rich plum of designing work on the 1948 program of veterans' hospital projects, members of the American Institute of Architects today went on record as condemning the Veterans Administration's plan to handle this $293,000,000 job directly, and voted to press for concerted action to get this program back into the hands of private architects.

BERLIN, Thursday, June 24 -- All railroad traffic between the Western zones and Berlin, over which most of the city's fuel and a large part of its food are transported, has been halted by the Soviet Military Administration and the blockade of the city except by air is now complete.

Richard Morford, executive director of the National Council of American Soviet Friendship, announced last night that legal action would be started this week to remove the council's name from a list of organizations listed as subversive by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

It takes only a minute to prepare Fantail frozen waffles, the latest product of Herrick Frozen Foods, Inc. Just pop them in a toaster and in sixty seconds they're golden brown and piping hot. When she planned them, Fanny Herrick had in mind the sultry days ahead when it would be too hot for much cooking.

The Republican National Convention has quite properly given a place near the top of the 1948 platform to its statement of the party's position on inflation. There is probably no domestic issue in which more Americans have a direct and personal interest than the one to which the authors of this section refer as that of "present cruelly high prices."

Meat prospects for next fall and next year, which up to now had been bleak because of the short corn crop last year, appeared better yesterday with the release of the report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics on the spring pig crop.

Public relations administration is now taking its proper place as the concern of top management in modern banks, Robert Lindquist, vice president of the La Salle National Bank, Chicago, asserted yesterday. Speaking at a meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers at the Lawyers Club, Mr. Lindquist, who is president of the Financial Public Relations Association, declared that there was an increasing awareness of "the human function in banking."

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- The Republican National Convention at its fifth session unanimously adopted today the party platform as presented by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, chairman of the committee on resolutions.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 23 -- Deprived of the rich plum of designing work on the 1948 program of veterans' hospital projects, members of the American Institute of Architects today went on record as condemning the Veterans Administration's plan to handle this $293,000,000 job directly, and voted to press for concerted action to get this program back into the hands of private architects.

BERLIN, Thursday, June 24 -- All railroad traffic between the Western zones and Berlin, over which most of the city's fuel and a large part of its food are transported, has been halted by the Soviet Military Administration and the blockade of the city except by air is now complete.

Richard Morford, executive director of the National Council of American Soviet Friendship, announced last night that legal action would be started this week to remove the council's name from a list of organizations listed as subversive by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.
The Esopus is still producing some really large rainbow trout, despite the inclement weather, and a number of fish ranging from 18 to 22 inches have been taken during the past few days.

New York City has millions of dollars invested in its beaches, and beyond the city borders are other shorefront areas, in which New Yorkers are intensely interested. It is inconceivable that city, state and federal governments should pursue a policy of shortsighted economy on sewage disposal and other contributors to water pollution that would invalidate the public's investment on these beaches, financially or as invaluable assets to health and recreation.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Members of the Mount Holyoke College Institute on the United Nations witnessed today the practical application of some of the theories to which they have been listening since Sunday on the campus at South Hadley, Mass.

Cautionary signals were hoisted yesterday on the stock market when profit-taking developed in the oils and the rails faltered in an attempt to exceed the two-year high mark. Considerable selectivity developed and the volume was well below that of Wednesday.

The Anderson-Prichard, Oil Corporation will redeem all of its 4 1/4 per cent convertible preferred stock at $51.75 a share on July 31. The called stock is convertible until July 30 at a conversion price of $22 a share.

ATHENS, June 24 -- The Greek Army consolidated positions today on Mount Pyrgos, a major height in the Konitsa sector of the Grammos front. Capture of the 4,000-foot peak from the Communist-led rebels was announced last night in Yanina by Vice Premier Constantin Tsaldaris.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Five seeded American players drove through to the round of sixteen in the Wimbledon men's single championships today, but a couple of them had to hike up their shorts and play serious tennis.

Contracts awarded last month for building construction in the thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains amounted to $970,789,000, a total second only to that of June, 1942, when building reached its wartime peak. The total for the same states six years ago was $1,190,264,000, made up principally of heavy engineering and industrial projects, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24 -- Negroes were told today that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was in politics primarily because the legislative program it advocated could best be translated into law by political action.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 -- King Abdullah's trip to Cairo and Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha's visit to Beirut and Damascus, Syria, have set in motion a round of intensive diplomatic activity that is expected to culminate in formulation of the Arab attitude toward Count Folke Bernadotte's mediation efforts.

"Cabin B-13," a series of original dramas by John Dickson Carr, will replace "Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts" on CBS for the summer, beginning Monday, July 5, from 8:30 to 9 P.M. Arnold Moss will narrate the programs, each of which will be a complete story in itself.

The National Better Business Bureau called on television-receiver manufacturers and dealers yesterday to cooperate in eliminating advertising and sales claims that create misleading impressions on the channel range of sets.

DENVER, June 24 -- American colleges and universities should put greater emphasis on the teaching of international affairs and world understanding, Dr. Ben M. Cherrington, director of the University of Denver Social Science Foundation, recommended here today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Subjects ranging from studies of the use of radar beams for internal therapeutic heating to recommendations for automobile redesign to reduce accidental death were discussed here today as doctors attending the ninety-seventh annual session of the American Medical Association met in sectional scientific groups.

The American Jewish Congress announced yesterday that it had asked President Truman to veto the Displaced Persons Bill "because it sets almost insuperable obstacles to the admission of any substantial number of those it intended to benefit."

KANSAS CITY, June 24 (AP) -- Skee Riegel, national amateur champion, had to pull his "Sunday Shot" on the eighteenth hole to eliminate unheralded Bob Kosten, Kansas City, in the quarter-finals of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)--The Navy announced today a contract for 98,500,000 barrels of Persian Gulf oil at a price of $182,850,000. Delivery will be made during the next five years.

Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, was criticized by the Association for Improvement of Mental Hospitals yesterday. David N. Fields, executive director, made public a letter sent to Governor Dewey, complaining of Dr. MacCurdy's failure to provide data on the use of the $91,000,000 annual budget of his department.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- "Well," said Senator Vandenberg, "I don't suppose anybody will believe me even now, but the truth is I'm pleased and relieved. Right now I'm drawing my first really relaxed breath in a year."

WARSAW, Friday, June 25 -- At the third and final session of the eight Eastern European Foreign Ministers' conference yesterday Rumania's Ana Pauker preside. Mr. Molotov had explained Russia's position and her concentrated action to counter the London decisions on Western Germany to an earlier meeting yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- A doughty veteran of thirty-five years of New York politics sat with his arms crossed, and his smile defiant, in the midst of the New York delegation today. There was not much conversation going on around him.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's first act after releasing his delegates to Governor Thomas E. Dewey tonight was to call the New Yorker and congratulate him on winning the Republican Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Ted Williams' home-run bat enabled Boston to split a double-header with the Chicago White Sox today.

The 9,804-ton Norwegian tanker Fenris caught fire early yesterday about 650 miles off Brest, France, and was abandoned by her crew when the fire raged out of control in the engine room, the Coast Guard reported here.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 24 (AP) -- Buffalo slammed four home runs, including two by Coaker Triplett, to defeat Jersey City, 12-6, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Little Giants had taken the opener, 6-5, on Buddy Blattner's second four-bagger of the game in the final frame.

Selective Service now is a fact. After a trip to Philadelphia, where it was signed by Senate President Vandenberg and House Speaker Martin, the bill passed by Congress last Saturday yesterday was signed into law by President Truman. For the second time in its history the United States is to induct young men into the armed services in a time of peace.

Extraordinary events occurred at Ebbets Field yesterday, the one of prime importance being that the Dodgers slapped the Pirates down in a double-header, 6 -- 2 and 8 -- 6, the second game held to seven and one-half innings because of darkness.

The open rift and battling between the Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Haganah in Israel were attacked yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury and now general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, who spoke at commencement exercises of Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

The most unusual school in the city public school system held a one-man graduation yesterday when George Sugarman, 15 years old, received his grammar school diploma from Public School 401X, at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, to the acclaim of the school's ten other students.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- A plea that the American Red Cross continue its fund raising and other activities independently, "much as we might like to help other welfare organizations out of their ditch," marked the closing session today of the organization's national convention.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and his party arrived back at his hotel headquarters at 9:54 P.M. and appeared before party workers in the main ballroom of the Bellevue Stratford.

STANTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- American Way, a 6-year-old from the Rokeby Stables of Paul Mellon of Pittsburgh, scored a two-length victory over his stablemate, Genancoke, today to capture the $10,000 added Georgetown Steeplechase Handicap at Delaware Park.

Nothing apparently having happened since 1940, the Center Theatre ice show continues without interruption, offering a new edition in the melting season. The new one is called "Howdy, Mr. Ice." It opened to sound effects over Manhattan last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, June 25 -- Harold E. Stassen was represented by a spokesman early today as being willing to submit to "a real draft" by the Republican National Convention for nom ination for Vice President. This spokesman added, however, that Mr. Stassen did not expect such a draft as he believed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey had another nominee in mind.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the issuance of $391,924 in budget notes to finance operation of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission for the eight months from July 1, 1948, to Feb. 28, 1949. The appropriation includes $12,500 for the service of outside "legal experts" to help handle in July and August a backlog of 2,700 cases of landlord applications for certificates of eviction against tenants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24 -- In an interview with Andrew Cordier, Executive Assistant to the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mrs. Harper Sibley, president of the United Council of Church Women, today pledged the organization's support of the United Nations and said it desired to mobilize 1,000,000 women for peace.

"BOOMLAY, boomlay, boomlay, boom," chanted Vachel Lindsay, eyes half shut, body swaying rhythmically as he stood on the platform of the college auditorium, as picturesque, eccentric and vital a figure as ever symbolized poetry in his own person.

Again there's talk of resuscitating vaudeville, this time on a huge scale. That brings to mind a mournful reference on the subject made by a former colleague, Lewis Nichols. In 1943 he pointed out: "One of the theatre's most depressing legends has it that vaudeville is dead."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent during the week ended June 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. At 165.3 per cent of the 1926 average, the Bureau's comprehensive index was only 0.1 per cent below the mid-January post-war peak and slightly more than 1 per cent below the May, 1920, high point.

Although two members expressed disapproval, the Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to adopt a public school library list of periodicals from which the Board of Superintendents had banned The Nation because of alleged anti-Catholic contents.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 24 -- In a serious appraisal of the Berlin situation and the attendant policy in Germany, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, concluded today that the Russians were exerting their "final pressure to drive us out of Berlin."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission will open a consolidated hearing here on July 12 on applications filed by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Houston, Tex.; the City Gas Company of New Jersey and the Revere Natural Gas Company of Jefferson, Pa.
