WASHINGTON June 24 -- The McCall Corporation of New York, magazine publisher, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an additional 87,167 shares of no par value common stock that will be offered first to company stockholders at the rate of one new share for each six shares held.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24--Connecticut's delegation to the Republican National Convention almost, but not quite, achieved the role here today that the key California and Texas delegations held in the nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt by the Democrats in 1932.

The National Confectioners Association, representing 1,252 manufacturers, yesterday went on record opposing "any specific allocation of funds" under the European Recovery Program to enable European nations to purchase cocoa beans.

RYE, N.Y., June 24 -- Taking up the task of improving on the score of 150 posted yesterday by Ellis Knowles of Apawamis in the United States Senior golf championship, John F. Riddell of Garden City today came in with the best round thus far in the current 44-year-old tourney by tallying a 73.

The handkerchief industry will do more than pay lip service to the proposed fair-trade practice code presented for approval of the Federal Trade Commission, according to Arthur M. Klurfeld, secretary of the Handkerchief Industry Association.

The Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company sold at competitive bidding yesterday an issue of $7,000,000 of collateral trust bonds due on July 1, 1968, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of about 3.74 per cent.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, received the Grand Cross of the Military Order of Italy yesterday morning from Alberto Tarchiani, Ambassador from Italy to the United States. The award which makes General Eisenhower a "Knight, Grand Cross of the Military Order of Italy" was presented in his office in Columbia's Low Memorial Library.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24 -- Petitions complaining about conditions in the British-administered territory of Tanganyika split the Trusteeship Council today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Newspaper men, delegates and visitors melted in Convention Hall heat today. They christened the place, with some bitterness, "The Steam-heated Iron Lung."

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- Yale will seek its first Varsity rowing victory over Harvard since 1935 when they meet here tomorrow for the eighty-third time in the oldest of intercollegiate sporting competitions. Inaugurated in 1852 on Lake Winnipesaukee, the regatta will observe the seventieth anniversary of its transfer to New London in 1878.
A threat of disruption of the nation's shipping as a protest against the Federal anti-strike injunction was made here yesterday by left-wing members of the National Maritime Union, CIO.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- A woman delegate in the New York State contingent shared the emotional surge that came over Governor Dewey's family tonight when he was named Republican candidate for President. She was Mrs. George Z. Medalie of 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, representing the Twentieth Congressional district.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The three leading groups opposed to the nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for President this afternoon forced a recess of the Republican National Convention until 7:30 this evening after Governor Dewey had received 515 votes on the second ballot, within 33 votes of the 548 needed to nominate.

LONDON, June 24 -- A new series of questions about Col. J.D. Tassoyev, Soviet Army officer alleged by the Russians to have been abducted from Bremen, brought to London and maltreated by British agents here, was put to the Government today by William Gallacher, Communist, and other members of Parliament.

Establishment at New Brunswick N.J., of a $1,000,000 laboratory that will become the "bureau of standards" for the chemicals and special materials used in the national atomic energy program was announced yesterday.

Communist propaganda has scored an important success in the United States in its systematic efforts to brand the Greek Government as "monarcho-Fascist," Alexis Kyrou, permanent Greek delegate to the United Nations, said at a reception given in his honor yesterday by the board of trustees of Athens College.

Two thousand persons attended last night in the St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, a "farewell" meeting for the eleven leaders of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee who have been fined and sentenced to three to six months in prison for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Retiring but intelligent, Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey gets across some of her own ideas in her husband's speeches. Her advice is respected and appreciated in strategy councils.

LONDON, June 24 -- Parliament will hold a special short session starting Sept. 14 to pass the Parliament Bill a second time, Herbert Morrison, Labor party leader, announced in the House of Commons today.

The writings of Benito Mussolini, which Farrar, Straus has scheduled for October publication, have been translated by Frances Frenaye and are being edited by Dr. Max Ascoli, Italian writer and scholar. The book is tentatively titled "Mussolini's Memoirs."

The only meat that should cost more at the butcher shop today is pork. Yesterday the City Department of Markets reported price advances of 2 to 4 cents a pound in both fresh and smoked cuts. Loin roast, for example, is up 2 cents to an average of 65 a pound, while ready-to-eat hams, at about 73 cents, show a 4-cent increase.

After a two-hour argument, a Federal statutory court of three judges reserved decision yesterday on the question of whether the Constitution was violated by the section of the Taft-Hartley act requiring union officers to file non- Communist affidavits.

CAMP EDWARDS, Mass., June 24 -- Civilian workers and a contingent of 300 soldiers today began preparing this World War II military training post for possible use under the nation's new draft program and for the summer tour of duty of National Guards units.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 24 (AP) -- Mrs. J. Carson's Orange Sun won a $5,000 claiming affair for 3-year-olds on a card composed of eight claiming races at Monmouth Park today over a track still sloppy from several days of rain. Bimelotta was second and Kel's Love third.

Advancing for the third consecutive weekly period, commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $17,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. According to the information issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, borrowing by finance companies accounted for part of the increase, although a variety of small amounts was included.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Neither Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey nor Mrs. Robert A. Taft was on the scene this afternoon during the balloting for the Republican choice for the Presidency. Instead of venturing into the steaming Convention Hall, the wives of the two leading aspirants for the nomination watched the proceedings in their hotel rooms by television.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner of Charlotte, N.C., and Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, took the lead today in the opening round of the $10,650 Inverness four-ball golf matches as sixteen pros tore the course apart with a 48-birdie barrage.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 24 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist party nominee for President, declared tonight that peacetime military conscription was "the greatest positive blow to American civil liberties."

The nine public school pupils whose posters on the theme "Keep Your Subway Clean" won joint awards from the Board of Transportation and the Board of Education received their prizes yesterday from Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri at ceremonies held at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- During the week ended June 23 member bank reserve balances decreased $591,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LONDON, June 24 -- Great Britain's most crucial economic problem -- coal -- was the subject of an inconclusive debate in the House of Commons today. By choosing facts to suit themselves, the Conservatives first and Government supporters afterward presented contrasting pictures of the industry that will make or break the British economy.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The British slapped an economic sanction on the entire Soviet zone today as infantry marched and tanks maneuvered in the streets of Berlin and the battle to retain the Western Allies' positions in the city neared its climax.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 19 were 21 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

The State of Massachusetts sold yesterday issues of airport, water supply and other public improvement bonds totaling $22,500,000 and maturing from 1948 to 1977 to a banking group headed by Chase National Bank, at interests costs of 1.2676 per cent and 1.683 per cent.

JUST by way of changing the subject slightly, let's pretend that there never were such things as the Louis-Walcott fight or postponements. But it's still rather difficult to get away from the beak-busting business entirely. So we'll just switch records a bit and play the other side. It's an old melody but a very intriguing one and it seems particularly pertinent because it also involves a fighter who was 34 years old.

The cornerstone-laying ceremonies yesterday for two huge union motor truck terminals, one in Manhattan to cost $9,000,000 and the other in Newark to cost $7,000,000, call attention anew to the revolution in transport that has occurred since the coming of the automobile.
A blueprint for changing the face of the entire downtown Manhattan area surrounding the Civic Center was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

ROME, June 24 -- (Religious News Service) -- The Vatican will send an official observer to the first assembly of the World Council of Churches, which opens in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, on Aug. 22, officials of the Holy See have announced here.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- General Clay's statement that the Western powers could not be thrown out of Berlin by methods short of war brought the terse comment at the State Department today that the General was in control of the situation.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP) -- Top-speeded Victor Seixas of the University of North Carolina led the way into the semi-finals of the National intercollegiate tennis championships today after a round of bitter battles and one marked upset.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America today won a smashing victory in forcing bituminous coal operators to agree on a wage increase of $1 a day for 400,000 mine workers and a doubling of their payments into the welfare fund.
CLEVELAND, June 24 -- The Indians finally got around to playing their big ace today but the Yankees had the trumps for it.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 24 -- A letter from Floyd G. Merlette Jr., township treasurer, recommending that the base salary for his part-time job be reduced from $1,600 to $1,090.90 was ordered filed today for consideration of the township committee by George M. Turk finance chairman.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 24 -- Three Long Island stars and one from Westchester battled their way into the semi-finals of the forty-fifth women's metropolitan golf championship over the Nassau Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 19 were 906,774 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 174 cars, or .02 per cent fewer than in the preceding week; 5,478 cars, or 0.6 per cent more than in the corresponding week last year, and 48,351 cars, or 5.6 per cent more than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Thomas Edmund Dewey, one of the leading exponents of a bipartisan foreign policy designed to contain communism and to strengthen nations friendly to the United States, will take to the hustings as an experienced campaigner.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 24 -- Sufficient uniforms and equipment are available for men rushing to join the New York National Guard, staff headquarters at Camp Smith announced today in confirming that enlistments are running high throughout the state, judging from telegrams received from local units.

LITTLETON, N.H., June 24 -- A landslide tonight cascaded down Mount Lafayette near the stone profile of "the Old Man of the Mountain" and buried heavily traveled Route 3 under fifty feet of earth. State police said they thought no one had been buried beneath it.
New York got its warmest weather of the year yesterday as the temperature rose to 89 degrees at 6 P.M. five notches above the previous high mark of 84 on May 12.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 24 (UP) -- The secretary of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty said today that all Hungarian Catholic deputies who had supported the nationalization of church schools had been excommunicated.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Princely State of Hyderabad will appeal to the United Nations against the Dominion of India, charging that India's policy is causing danger to international peace, it was learned authoritatively here today. This will saddle the United Nations with another problem similar to that of Kashmir, for which a mediation commission now has been formed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Before the roll of states could be called for the nomination of a candidate for President at tonight's session of the Republican National Convention in the Municipal Auditorium, the opposition to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey collapsed completely.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Senator Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today that he would continue to press the St. Lawrence seaway issue -- while admitting he had no "illusions" as to the task involved.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- With four vacancies in its ranks and another impending, the board of directors of Montgomery Ward Co. will assemble tomorrow morning for its monthly meeting. In addition to a review of the developments in the company's management in the last two weeks, it is expected that the board will act to fill the vacancies in its ranks.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The United States may soon have three more "free ports" in addition to those it now has at New York, New Orleans and San Francisco.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24--Text of the speech made by Governor Dewey to the Republican convention delegates tonight:

LONDON, June 24 -- In a five-point program for the unification of Germany issued tonight through the Moscow radio, the eight Eastern European Foreign Ministers proposed the formulation of a German peace treaty providing for the withdrawal of occupation troops within one year of signature.

Samuel Reiter felt "perfectly healthy" yesterday. He also was too busy to take off more than a few minutes for a ceremony in Pennsylvania Station celebrating his fifty years with the company, where he rose from messenger, telegrapher and ticket seller to district passenger agent.

BERLIN, June 24 -- More than 75,000 Berliners appealed today for the world's help in their struggle against the advance of communism Their political party leaders predicted this appeal would be followed by a formal request to the United Nations to see that the city remained under quadripartite control.

With Walker Cooper back in action and Larry Jansen pitching six-hit ball the Giant performed right smartly in turning back the Cubs, 3 -- 2, in the first game of a double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals flew into second place in the National League pennant chase tonight, a half-game in back of the leading Boston Braves, whom they thumped, 11 -- 2, on eleven hits in a game delayed 36 minutes by rain. Many in the crowd of 16,122 booed the Tribesmen, who made five errors.

Up to 15,000 tons a month of reinforcing steel can now be supplied by Belgian mills to reduce extreme scarcities here now described by leading construction firms as extremely critical, Marcel Loeb, European steel mill representative, 30 Church Street, revealed here yesterday.

Leaders of fourteen left wing unions of the Congress of industrial Organizations served notice yesterday that they would fight effrts by right wing forces to have the charter of the Greater New York C Council lifted.
A near-cloudburst which deluged the Yankee Stadium commencing at 7:40 o'clock last night forced a second postponement of the scheduled fifteen-round heavyweight championship bout ...

Each new piece of Danish silverware shown yesterday by H. Nils at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel has been designed to receive continual use as well as admiring glances. The latest works, from a long-handled honey spoon to a graceful coffee pot with a non-drip spout, have been carefully planned by leading Danish architects and sculptors who work closely with the country's famous silversmiths.

The count of coliform bacteria in the bathing water in Sea Gate, at Coney Island, and at South Beach on Staten Island has been running "relatively high" recently, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard warned yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Thomas E. Dewey was nominated tonight by the Republicans for the Presidency of the United States.

ALBANY, June 24 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond reported today that law-enforcement officers in states which had newspaper confidence laws were unanimous in the belief the statutes had worked out well and had not obstructed justice or hampered the officers in performing their duties.

A members' annual exhibition at the National Arts Club, a group of the lesser examples by many well-known German expressionists at the Tribune Subway Gallery and a group of paintings and sculpture by members at the Chinese Gallery are among the summer art shows that opened this week.
LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- Australia had scored only 258 for the loss of seven wickets at the close of play at Lords cricket ground today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers today called on the Federal Trade Commission to conduct an investigation into the economic effects of quantity discounts in the food industry.

Mrs. Alexandra Melas, for many years interested and participating in all the activities of Near East Foundation in Greece, is in the United States in the interest of a new child-welfare organization in Greece led by Queen Frederika.

LONDON, June 24 -- Condemning the removal of Greek children to neighboring Communist-dominated countries, the British Government declared today that the countries that had replied to the Greek Gov ernment's appeal for the return of the children "do not appear to show a due appreciation of their international responsibilities."
NANKING, June 24 -- The Government's loss of Kaifeng, the first provincial capital in China proper to fall to the Communists, provoked a critical session of the new Legislative Yuan today.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- The Rev. Lloyd E. Galloway of Los Angeles and Mrs. Elbert A. Read of Shenandoah, Iowa, were elected assistant moderators today at the final session of 2,000 delegates of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 19 carried an article by Robert Trumbull on "Red Surge in Asia Alerts New Delhi," in which the author unfortunately inserted the Vietnam Government of Ho Chi-Minh in the group of Communist-influenced countries of Asia. I quote: "The fugitive Vitnamese Government of the Ho Chi-Minh in French Indo-China is receiving aid through China in their guerrilla warfare against the French, according to French sources."
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- A dark horse and three former champions -- headed by Mrs. George Zaharias -- today climbed into the semi-finals of the Western Open women's golf tournament.
After showing some early strength, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased toward the close yesterday and final prices were 5 to 14 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The back-to-the-farm movement apparently has halted.

Restrictions on imports of assembled pens and automatic pencils imposed earlier this year by foreign countries have "hit the industry hard," James V. Carmichael, president of Scripto, Inc., Atlanta, Ga., and newly elected president of the Fountain Pen and Mechanical Pencil Manufacturers Association, said yesterday at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 24 (AP) -- This country is producing "too many lawyers and too few mechanics," Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner of New York State, said today.
OWOSSO, Mich., June 24 (AP) -- About the only excited person in this small industrial city tonight was Mrs. Anne Thomas Dewey 69-year-old mother of the Republican Presidential nominee.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The draft act requiring military service of men from 19 through 25 years of age became law at 5:40 P.M. today when President Truman signed the measure without comment.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 24 -- Mrs. Walter Reynolds of Knollwood posted 43, 40 -- 83 to annex the weekly one-day tournament staged by the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Whippoorwill Club today. She won by three strokes.

Hezekiah Cobb has an idea for the improvement of a sport which assembles a prodigious number of spectators, represents a huge investment, employs thousands of men and produces a handsome public revenue.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The State Department today called upon the Russian satellite countries of Eastern Europe to return the thousands of Greek children kidnapped in Greece by guerrillas and sent to those nations allegedly for indoctrination in Soviet ideology.

Ennis Gray, George Appel and Henry Laskau will set new meet records in the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at Randalls Island tomorrow and several other standards probably also will fall, it was predicted yesterday by John W. Price, meet chairman, after a careful survey of the banner field of 335 athletes.

LONDON, June 24 -- The British Government, which exerted its influence on the Arab states to obtain the cease-fire in Palestine, will likewise urge the Arabs to prolong the truce in order to give the United Nations Mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte, more time to negotiate for permanent peace, authoritative sources stated today.

With three foreign airlines just starting their familiarization flights for pilots at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, indicated in a speech last night that it might be late in 1949 before other foreign and domestic lines would be permitted to move to the airfield.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The Dewey campaign strategy paid of tonight.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during May totaled 197,809,186 lines, an increase of 14.8 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Gains were recorded in all categories, with automotive up 16.1; retail, 15.9; classified, 15.4; general, 10.2, and financial, 8.7.

Please allow me to correct an erroneous statement in a United Press dispatch in your issue of June 19, dated from Tel Aviv June 18. Your correspondent, writing about the Israeli nationals detained in a camp in Kenya, states that, "The men concerned, mostly convicted of terrorist acts, were sent to Kenya, on the East African coast, for safekeeping."

Undistributed Shares Tag-ends of two recent issues of preferred stock have been sold out by the marketing syndicates. The thrice-priced issue of 80,000 shares of Kansas City Power and Light Company 4 per cent stock declined yesterday in the free market below 98 before stabilizing at about that price.

Miss Barbara Welkins of New Rochelle, defending champion, paced the field into the quarterfinals of the New York State women's tennis championships at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club in Queens yesterday. She defeated Miss Beatrice McClintock of Glen Head, L.I., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.
JERUSALEM, June 24 -- Slightly more than 100 American citizens left Jerusalem today for the United States. Some will stay there only temporarily.
LONDON, June 24 -- The latest developments in Berlin, together with continuation of the dock strike acted as a brake on business in the stock market here today and trading again was dull.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24 -- A set of resolutions described as comprising a liberal platform of social action in accord with "the principles of prophetic Judaism" was adopted today by the Central Conference of American Rabbis at its annual convention.

"Romance on the High Seas," a musical featuring Jack Carson, Doris Day, Don DeFore and Janis Paige, which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Michael Curtiz directed and Alex Gottlieb produced the Warner Brothers release, which was filmed in Technicolor.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 24--The Soviet Union entered a formal protest today against a General Assembly hearing of Chile's charges that Russian wives of diplomats stationed in Moscow were prevented from leaving the country with their husbands.
GEORGETOWN, Del., June 24 (AP) -- The Van Tress Hatchery, of Maryville, Calif., was named winner today of the "Chicken of Tomorrow" contest -- world series of the billion-dollar broiler industry.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 (AP) -- Baruna, the 71-foot yawl owned by Henry C. Taylor of New York, is the Queen of the sixteenth Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race.

The two-story garage building at 43-17 Fifty-second Street, Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Rose Silverberg to the 42-17 Fifty-second Street Corporation, of which Alfred Sheer is president. The purchaser occupies the premises as a service station for Dodge and Plymouth automobiles.

A sub-committee of the Industrial Union of Marine and Ship-building Workers of America is scheduled to hear charges tonight that Waldemar Woods, president of Local 60 of the union, in Perth Amboy, N.J. disrupted union affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, told the .graduates of the Armed Forces IndustrialCollege today that the United States must have a "work or fight" law immediately upon the occurrence of any future national emergency or war.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 24 -- The American Home Economics Association must help "build better homes for better nations," Dr. Marie Dye, dean of the School of Home Economics at Michigan State College, East Lansing, said here today on assuming the presidency of the association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will produce a new screen version of Vina Delmar's novel of the Nineteen Twenties, "Bad Girl," with Jeanne Crain and Dan Dailey in the leading roles, it was learned today. The story was originally filmed by Fox in 1931, with Sally Eilers and James Dunn.

ALBANY, June 24 -- New York City real estate taxes rank among the lowest in the state, when adjusted according to a system designed to permit comparison. This was reported today by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, on the basis of its fifth annual compilation of "full value" taxes in sixty-five cities and boroughs.

PASADENA, Calif., June 24 -- Leading physicists from many parts of this country and abroad listened with fascination today to a 30-year-old Harvard Professor of Physics expound a new theory through the symbols of higher mathematics, about the interactions of energy and matter, the two basic phenomena in which the physical universe is manifested to man.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24 -- The defending titleholder from neighboring Cherry Valley, Al Brosch, continued to show the way in the Long Island Golf Association's twenty-fourth Open championship. At the end of two rounds he had an aggregate of 140, his second round of 34, 37 matching par today at the Garden City Country Club.

Sales of the United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on March 31 established a new high record and yielded the second largest earnings since 1929, Glenn L. Haskell, president, informed shareholders in the annual report issued yesterday.
An extra of 25 cents on the common stock, payable on July 30, has been voted by the Davison Chemical Corporation. The next regular 25 cents quarterly dividend is payable on June 30.

We know of no good reason why able-bodied men and women on home relief rolls should not contribute services in return for the checks paid to them out of tax funds. There are said to be about 10,000 persons now on relief in New York City who are employable on work relief projects.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- Foreign enemies of the Marshall Plan have sought unsuccessfully to persuade the workers of western Europe that their interests are "being sacrificed to provide bigger and better markets for the United States," George A. Isaacs, British Minister of Labor and National Service, asserted here today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Continued wet weather in parts of the Southwest and reports that the Government purchased about 1,500,000 sacks of flour on over-night bids strengthened the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, and closing trades were 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 24 -- The Provisional Government of Israel passed its first important political crisis tonight when it received a vote of confidence from the State Council. The possibility that dissident groups might overthrow the Government as an aftermath of Tuesday's rebellion was thus averted.

PEIPING, June 24 (AP) -- Yenching University students today urged their president-on-leave, Dr. John Leighton Stuart, to quit as United States Ambassador to China and resume his old post. Dr. Stuart talked with four members of the student self-governing body.

Banners and certificates were awarded yesterday by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to ten public schools whose students devised projects to improve health and sanitation conditions in their neighborhoods.

PARIS, June 24 -- The Soviet assertion of the right to rule all of Berlin, rather than clash over currency, is the issue in the Russian-Western crisis in the former German capital, according to an official spokesman the French Foreign Ministry.

The total of the winning bids for the 117 paintings of the State Department's erstwhile collection of American art, just sold as "surplus" by the War Assets Administration, was $79,658, an increase of more than $23,000 over the amount paid by the State Department for this controversial group in 1946, it was announced yesterday.

Accusing the police of having coerced and beat him during a twelve-hour session of questioning in the District Attorney's office last March 15, Santo (Sal) Bretagna testified yesterday that a detective inspector threatened "to throw me out" a sixth-floor window if he did not confess the fatal shooting of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner.

The Lester Manor Stable's Fugit, a once-upon-a-time Kentucky Derby nominee, returned to the racing wars at Aqueduct yesterday and gained an on-the-wire victory in a field of five 3-year-olds in a $5,000 sprint. So close was the finish between Fugit and the Sunshine Stable's Control that both were led into the winner's enclosure while the photo was being processed.

Before leaving here yesterday for Europe the Duke of Windsor said he had watched telecasts of the Republican Convention on Tuesday and Wednesday nights and had found it "very exciting" and "very interesting."

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- Ferris Fain's triple and Barney McCosky's double were good for four eighth-inning runs which enabled the Athletics to nose out the Browns tonight, 6 to 5. The Browns made but three hits off three Philadelphia pitchers but were benefited by thirteen bases on balls.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The checking of communism in Europe is more important than the unification of their country to the Germans in Berlin and the United States zone. More than 90 per cent of those Germans are opposed to unity under Russian leadership, according to polls taken recently by the Information Control Division of the United States Military Government.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today three proposed revisions of its registration requirements under the Securities Act of 1933.
LONDON, June 24 -- Prime Minister Attlee is expected to announce to the House of Commons on Monday that an Imperial Conference will be held in London in October, it was learned today.

Before leaving here yesterday for Europe the Duke of Windsor said he had watched telecasts of the Republican Convention on Tuesday and Wednesday nights and had found it "very exciting" and "very interesting."

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- Ferris Fain's triple and Barney McCosky's double were good for four eighth-inning runs which enabled the Athletics to nose out the Browns tonight, 6 to 5. The Browns made but three hits off three Philadelphia pitchers but were benefited by thirteen bases on balls.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The checking of communism in Europe is more important than the unification of their country to the Germans in Berlin and the United States zone. More than 90 per cent of those Germans are opposed to unity under Russian leadership, according to polls taken recently by the Information Control Division of the United States Military Government.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today three proposed revisions of its registration requirements under the Securities Act of 1933.
LONDON, June 24 -- Prime Minister Attlee is expected to announce to the House of Commons on Monday that an Imperial Conference will be held in London in October, it was learned today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey accepted the nomination tonight and immediately appealed to the party and the country for unity on the basis of a new spiritual faith.

The construction of huge motor truck terminals in Newark and lower Manhattan, authorized several years ago to relieve traffic congestion and avoid duplication of transportation serving the metropolitan area, was hailed yesterday by city and Port Authority officials and business representatives at ceremonies marking the laying of cornerstones for both structures.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The development of a new group of ion exchange resins, described as making possible "revolutionary" expansion of the usefulness of this basic process, was disclosed today by research chemists at the Resinous Products and Chemical Company's laboratories.

BUENOS AIRES, June 24 -- president Juan Peron today invited industrialists and business men from all parts of the country to help in stabilizing the nation's economy, currently afflicted with a dollar shortage that it is now plain the Marshall Plan will not alleviate.

An estimate of $27,000,000 was placed yesterday on the cost of a dozen projects outlined in the plan announced on Thursday by the City Planning Commission for an integrated Civic Center in Manhattan and rehabilitation of streets and structures in the surrounding area.

LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) -Batting weakly on an easy-paced wicket against good bowling, England scored only 207 for nine in reply to Australia's 350 when stumps were drawn at the end of the second day in the second test cricket match today.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Joe Coleman doubled for two runs in the second inning and then pitched Philadelphia to a 4-1 victory over the White Sox before 10,094 persons tonight. The victory, Coleman's eighth against five losses, pulled the Athletics to within one length of first place Cleveland.

Young Nigerian women are demanding more voice in the selection of husbands as a result of American motion pictures shown occasionally in the West African country, according to the Rev. Peter Moore, missionary priest, who arrived here yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

QUEBEC, June 25 (Canadian Press) -- Canada cannot afford to continue buying twice as much goods in the United States as Americans are buying here, Edgar G. Burton, president of the Robert Simpson Company, Ltd., Toronto, said today in an address before the Newspaper Advertising Executives of America.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., June 25 -- Officers and a cadre of enlisted men of the Seventy-seventh Division, commanded by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, gathered here today in preparation for a two-day command post exercise, or CPX, tomorrow and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the New party, charged tonight that President Truman did not actually believe in the platform of civil rights which the Chief Executive outlined recently in a message.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -Gov. Earl Warren stands to lose $5,000 a year in salary if he iselected Vice President.

ROME, June 25 -- An announcement from Cairo that Idriss elSenussi had proclaimed himself Prince Sovereign of Cyrenaica in Italy's former colony of Libya, North Africa, caused resentment in some circles today.
DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States and Canada this week will total 93,290 units, Ward's automotive reports estimated today.
SHANGHAI, June 25 -- Chinese price and currency inflation gyrated to dizzy new heights here today.

Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican nominee for Vice President, has been prominent on the national political scene since 1936 when he attended the Republican National Convention of that year as California's "favorite son."

W. E. Burner Co., members of the New York Curb Exchange, will admit as partners next Thursday, Sidney F. Ward, E. L. Gruver and William W. Kennedy, according to the weekly bulletin published by the Curb Exchange yesterday.

Among those who did not follow the fight last night were 10,000 who heard William Kapell, pianist, and Fritz Reiner conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium. They were rewarded with an all-Russian program, including Kabalevsky's "Colas Breugnon" Overture, Prokofieff's "Classical Symphony," Tchaikovsky's Fourth Symphony and, as the second half of the program, Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine, reported by wireless to the Security Council tonight that Egypt's action in halting an Israeli food convoy was contrary to the "letter and spirit" of the truce.

THE Mediterranean is a very hot subject. Yet William Reitzel handles it very Coolly. This is probably a desirable approach at a time when the moment you mention Greece, Turkey, Yugoslavia, Spain, Italy, Palestine, Egypt, Syria, Algeria and other lands around that sea people begin caterwauling like heatstruck delegates at a political convention.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- With Jim Russell, Tommy Holmes and Al Dark bashing homers, the topplace Braves overwhelmed the Pirates, 12 -- 3, tonight before a crowd of 25,587. Lefty Warren Spahn contributed towards his sixth pitching victory by clouting a pair of two baggers and scoring twice.

Prof. Maurice Finkelstein issued an emphatic denial yesterday that political influence had been brought to bear on any case before the City Rent Commission, to whose chairmanship he succeeded when Paul L. Ross resigned in protest against Mayor O'Dwyer's action to end five-cent transit fares.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- On the "first team" that won Gov. Thomas E. Dewey the Republican nomination for President are fifteen "regulars" and a somewhat larger number of "second stringers" who are called on for occasional or special services.
With electrifying suddenness lightning struck last night at the Yankee Stadium. And it wasn't Jersey lightning.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Directors of Montgomery Ward Co., at their regular meeting today, took the first step in filling vacancies on the executive staff resulting from the series of resignations among top executives.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -Gov. Earl Warren of California declared today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's proposal to have the Vice President act as an assistant President with Cabinet status was a major factor in his decision to accept second place on the Republican ticket.
Twenty thousand laundry workers, affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, followed the example of thousands of other unionists and withdrew yesterday from the Greater New York CIO Council.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 25 -- The imminent establishment of a tripartite Western Military Government organization to act as a control agency over the projected Western German Government was announced today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -The Phillies bunched two of their six hits off Hank Borowy and Andy Dobernic in the first inning for one run and three in the seventh for another tally as they defeated the Cubs, 2 -- 1, tonight behind the clever hurling of Dutch Leonard.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 25 (AP) -Golfdom's golden boys, colorful Jimmy Demaret add national open-PGA champion Ben Hogan, grabbed a commanding lead today in their quest to make it three straight in the $10,650 Inverness best-ball matches.

Herbert Brownell Jr., youngest of the behind-the-scenes triumvirate which helped Governor Dewey win the Republican Presidential nomination, "grew up" in politics with Mr. Dewey in Manhattan, The Associated Press said yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 25 -The Israeli Government announced tonight that Mrs. Golda Myerson had been appointed Israel's representative to the Soviet Union.

Lin Yutang, whose new novel, "Chinatown Family," will be brought out in October by John Day, has been appointed Chief of the Section of Arts and Letters of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

The one-story taxpayer building containing twenty-two stores at 1427-47 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Minnie Hirsch to the 1435 Webster Corporation, an investment group represented by Jules Shank, attorney. The property occupies an irregular plot about 275 by 69 feet.

The bill enacted by Congress for the admission of 205,000 displaced persons to the United States and which President Truman has just signed is a most shocking triumph for the forces of bigotry and intolerance in this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- News of the selection of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as the Republican Presidential nominee, with Gov. Earl Warren as his running mate, was received at United Nations headquarters today with mixed feelings.

PARIS, June 25 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the French Assembly decided today to propose a general debate next week on the agreement being negotiated with the United States covering French obligations under the foreign aid act.

The Giants never do things halfway. Rebounding from one of its worst performances of the season the day before, Mel Ott's perplexing club polished off the Reds, 7 -- 0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday in an exhibition that was little short of perfection.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Nearly a billion dollars in increased operating expenses and payroll taxes since January, 1947, led the Class I railroads of the country to tell the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the 45 per cent increase in payments for carrying United States mail they requested Feb. 19, 1947, must now be made a 65 per cent increase.

Before recessing for the summer the Supreme Court handed down opinions this week dealing with three of the more controversial sections of the Taft-Hartley Act, but in only one case has the issue been finally disposed of. The Court declined to rule on the two others. Its action on the sections requiring financial reports and non-Communist affidavits came in connection with an appeal by the CIO National Maritime Union.

Next Wednesday will be the last day of school for 830,000 New York public school children whose summer vacations will continue until Sept. 13, when classes resume, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -The first clearcut reaction on the West Coast to Gov. Earl Warren's acceptance of the Republican nomination for Vice President was astonishment.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Mrs. Earl Warren and her daughters won the unanimous approval of the closing session of the Republican National Convention.

Four practical steps to reduce distribution costs have been taken by a wide variety of manufacturers, D. W. Northup, president of The Henry G. Thompson Son Company, New Haven, revealed here yesterday following his completion of an industry-wide survey of economic practices.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 25 (AP) -- Packing the thrills into the ninth inning when they scored all their runs, Southern California's Trojans turned back Yale, 3 to 1, to win the opening game of the National Collegiate A.A. baseball championship final series today.

Local 1199, Retail Drug Store Employes Union, CIO, has voted to go on strike against the Liggett-Rexall and Whelan drug store chains in the New York area any time after July 1, it was announced last night.
MEXICO CITY, June 25 (AP) -The Government oil monopoly, Pemex, announced today the Texas Company had agreed to lend $30,000,000 for development of the oil industry in Mexico.
Joe Louis has had his last fight. That is what the Brown Bomber declared in his dressing room immediately after his conquest of Jersey Joe Walcott.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -President Juan D. Peron and Miguel Miranda, economic boss of Argentina, have been informed that a percentage of any dollars spent here under the Marshall Plan will have to be returned to the United States to pay off past debts, such as outstanding letters of credit, business remittances and dividends, it was confirmed today.

Sixty khaki-clad youthful members of Brith Trumpeldor -- supporters of Irgun Zvai Leumi -- invaded the offices of the Provisional Government of Israel, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday and for an hour and forty minutes staged a memorial meeting for Irgunists who had died.

Modernization work, including the raising of the store to the sidewalk level and installation of a new front, will be done on the building at 56 West Fifty-seventh Street which has been leased for twenty-one years with renewals to Louis Rubin, operator of the Mayflower, Chandler and other restaurants.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Truman believes the Republicans' nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey improved Democratic chances of retaining the Presidency in the November elections, White House callers reported today. He was represented as being "definitely encouraged about the whole political situation."
DETROIT, June 25 -- A gathering of 42,372 fans had occasion tonight to celebrate two victories for the price of a single admission.

LONDON, June 25 -- The broad lines of the program on which the Conservative party will fight the next general election were completed tonight with the publication of the party's Policy for agriculture, entitled "The Agricultural Charter."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- The United Nations Security Council refused today to reopen debate on Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime in Spain.

Life insurance owned in the United States on June 30 will exceed $196,000,000,000, according to an estimate by the Institute of Life Insurance. This represents an increase of $8,000,000,000 in the halfyear and is estimate at $17,000,000,000 more than the June 30, 1947, figure.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 25 -Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley and Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook reached the final round of the forty-fifth Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship over the Nassau Country Club course today.

HEADQUARTERS OF GREEK SECOND CORPS, On the Northern Front, June 24 (Delayed) (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that the Greek Army forces "are trying to find a soft spot in guerrilla lines." If they succeed, he added, the summer offensive "should be over in short order."
ATHENS, June 25 -- In fighting on the northeast flank of the rebels, Grammos Mountain stronghold the Greek Army today reported the capture of a number of key positions.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -Officials of the National and Delta Airlines were reported today to be working on a possible merger of the two systems. The networks cover an area extending from Cuba and Texas in the South to New York, Michigan and Illinois.
In his letter distinctly in favor of the Arabs in their war with the Zionists, Stephen B.L. Penrose Jr. says: "I would emphasize that this is a political, not a religious, matter."

Burton W. Marvin, 35 years old, associate professor of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, has been named the first dean of the William Allen White School of Journalism at the University of Kansas. His appointment, which is effective Sept. 1, was announced jointly yesterday by Dean E. W. Malott, chancellor of the University of Kansas, and Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia School of Journalism.

Once a year at this time the contract between the United Mine Workers and the soft coal mine owners expires. And once a year John L. Lewis, as leader of the nation's Number One labor monopoly, takes the occasion to exact a tribute from the American people under open or implied threat of stopping the flow of coal to the country's industries and homes.

MADISON, N.J., June 25 -Playing over fairways freely sprinkled with water, Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood splashed out an 89 over the Braidburn Country Club links today to top a field of forty-six in a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -At least five members of Thomas E. Dewey's Albany staff may get top jobs in Washington if the New York Governor is elected President. They are:

ROME, June 25 -- Italian Communist leaders Palmiro Togliatti and Pietro Secchia returned to Rome from the Warsaw conference of Russian satellite Foreign Ministers today while the Communist and pro-Communist press was busy assuring all Italians that Russia had "offered the hand of friendship" to the Western democracies.

BERLIN, June 25 -- Frau Mertens went to the grocery store today but she could not get any potatoes. Some of her neighbors registered to buy at other shops were lucky; they were able to get some dehydrated potatoes.

Signing of the new bituminous wage contract failed to stimulate the stock market yesterday and, as caution became more evident, prices of shares returned to the approximate level of a week ago. Losses in the Stock Exchange ranged well beyond a point before some semblance of steadiness in the afternoon reduced inroads.

The meeting of the board of directors of the Motion Picture Export Association to review the strained relations between the American film industry and the British Government has been postponed from Monday to Thursday at the headquarters of the Motion Picture Association, 28 West Forty-fourth Street.

Hunt Stromberg Jr., co-producer of the recent revival of "Sally," which starred Willie Howard, will be active again on Broadway in the fall. The project remains unidentified at the moment, but Mr. Stromberg, in a letter from London, does volunteer the intelligence that Guy Bolton is writing the show and that Eugene Banks will be associated with him in the production.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- Two strikes involving 25,000 aluminum workers in two unions and set for Sunday midnight were averted here today when the Aluminum Company of America and the unions reached a common two-year agreement, granting a 10 to 16 cents hourly increase.

Extremely light buying marked the fifty-seventh annual summer furniture market which entered its closing stage yesterday in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue. The market ends officially at 1 P.M. today but the small amount of business expected this morning will not appreciably alter the over-all poor showing of the event, according to both retailers and wholesale salesmen.

Staff officers or the New York National Guard, in a rough count, estimated last night that the rush for deferments under provisions of the new Selective Service Act had swelled the emergency force to 27,000 officers and enlisted men, or 4,000 more than the quota provided for by budget.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement on the displaced persons bill:

In the semi-final bout at Yankee Stadium last night Curtis Sheppard of Baltimore stopped Alfredo Lagay of the Argentine in 2:07 of the third with a left to the body. At the end of the second round he floored Lagay with a right to the jaw, the punch carrying so much force that it caused a fracture.

Miss Betty Shields successfully defended her Metropolitan A.A.U. women's senior 200-meter backstroke swimming championship, feature of the twilight water carnival held yesterday at the Raven Hall Bathing Park in Coney Island. Miss Shields won by five yards from her Women's Swimming Association colleague, Miss Gloria Rosky, in 3:03.4.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Harold E. Stassen today seemed definitely "on the outside looking in." He will campaign for the Dewey ticket. He told the convention that yesterday. He said so to Governor Dewey over the telephone this morning, when he accepted the latter's invitation to make a public appearance at Dewey headquarters, to demonstrate party unity, and he intends to be in every way a party regular.

Your editorial of June 23 "Peace at Last in Luzon?" showed you have a good grasp of Philippine affairs, but you have not given a complete picture of the peace situation in that proud and restless land. I happen to be an American soldier who lived in the Philippines for more than three years during and after the liberation and I was in constant contact with both politicians and "small fry" over there.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 25 -- A disagreement between the United Nations Security Council and the Trusteeship Council over the strategic areas in the Pacific developed today and appeared likely to lead to another double veto by the Soviet Union.

Technically approved ways of incorporating television and radio sets into room schemes so that they will be convenient to use but not too obvious between-times are shown in three room settings in the new center that Lord Taylor opens today.

VIENNA, June 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, commander of the United States Forces in Austria, asked the Soviet command today in a prepared statement whether its actions meant that it was encouraging the illegal seizure of power by the Communists.
The Queens Chamber of Commerce urged city officials yesterday to renew New York's offer of Flushing Meadow Park to the United Nations as a site for the future world capital.

The Republican party has avoided a costly blunder, and in so doing has taken advantage of an opportunity to strengthen its position greatly. The predicted nomination of Representative Halleck of Indiana as the party's Vice Presidential candidate would have represented a bare-faced and disastrous compromise with the extreme isolationist faction of the House Republicans.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The possibility that study of cancer in plant life may throw light on the mysterious changes which cause a normal living cell to become a malignant and spreading growth within the human body was expressed here today by Dr. Philip R. White of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- There is an indication of "fraud" in the collapse of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today.

High profits being made by textile manufacturers, as revealed in their earnings statements, offer them a cushion against a price drop if and when the market reaches the saturation point. This was the belief expressed by members of the Association of Buying Offices, Inc., at their last meeting of the season yesterday in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LONDON, June 25 -- Import restrictions in foreign markets have compelled the British Government to reverse itself and permit the sale in home markets of consumer goods originally intended for export. Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, revealed the change in policy at a luncheon gathering of thc Institute of Export today.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP) -- Revised demands which run up to an aggregate of 28 cents an hour were presented to the Ford Motor Company today by union representatives of the concern's 110,000 hourly rated employes.

The proposed local law to impose an automobile use tax of $5 a year on passenger cars and $10 a year on trucks met with unanimous opposition yesterday at a public hearing before the finance committee of the City Council. Spokesmen for business organizations, automobile clubs and the trucking and taxicab industries assailed the measure as financially unnecessary, inequitable, unsound and discriminatory.

Daniel J. Harrington, who obviously has a way with commuters, had a special graduation ceremony yesterday tendered by a group of his long-time passengers. Mr. Harrington, 19 years a conductor on the Long Island Rail Road, Oyster Bay branch, has been promoted by the road to be special deputy assistant trainmaster, a trouble-shooting job handling commuter complaints.
EAGLE PASS, Tex., June 25 (UP) -- A roaring wall of water today engulfed about half of this city and its Mexican neighbor, Piedras Negras, just across the Rio Grande. There were no known fatalities.

New York's final track and field meet of the Olympic year will take place at Randalls Island today. A record field of 335 athletes will compete for twenty-one Metropolitan A.A.U. titles, with the district association pledged to send outstanding performers to Milwaukee next week for the national championships and semi-final Olympic tryouts.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Appraising the impact on American consumers of current high prices of meat and the shortage of livestock products, Dr. L. A. Maynard, director of the School of Nutrition, Cornell University, said tonight that the country's low-income group "faces a real nutritional problem."

PEIPING, China, June 25 -- Dr. J. Leighton Stuart indicated today that he did not intend to resign nor has he pressed his resignation as United States Ambassador to China, which he submitted eighteen months ago as a matter of routine when Secretary of State Marshall assumed office.

ROME, June 25 -- Most Italian newspapers carry reports of the Republican convention but only a few of the most internationally minded give news of Governor Dewey's nomination prominence. This is due in part to the fact that the majority of Italians do not understand the American political system and begin to get interested only when both candidates are nominated and the presidential race is well under way.

LONDON, June 25 -- The stock markets here stood up well today to the latest developments in Berlin. Brokers expected heavy falls in prices of shares at the opening but found that investors, by now hardened to bad news, were not selling.

RYE, N.Y., June 25 -- Heeding the advice of his caddy, John F. Riddell Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club "settled down," as he said later, and played the last six holes of the Apawamis Club course in two under par to win the United States Senior golf championship by one stroke with a final total of 149.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -Charles Vidor will produce and direct "Sirocco," a screen version of Josef Kessel's French novel, "Coup de Grace," for Columbia in the fall, it was learned today. Vidor acquired the screen rights to the story from Anatole Litvak and Cary Grant last April.

Daniel Marzani, winner of a $10,000 steeplechase stake at Delaware Park on Thursday, took a hurdles fixture of the same value at Aqueduct yesterday astride Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' H Hour. The race was the Amagansett, and H Hour won it by a little more than a length after Marzani had sent him into the lead moving to the far turn the second time.

NANKING, June 25 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek has summoned top military leaders to Sian, Shensi provincial capital, for an emergency conference on how to drive the Communists out of Central China, official sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Bilateral agreements setting forth the terms and conditions for the application of the European Recovery Program will be signed beginning Monday with the first of the sixteen European countries concerned as well as with Western Germany, it was learned authoritatively today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -New Jersey Republicans almost wound up their convention business today in a fight.
Milwaukee County, Wis., will receive bids on July 26 on $3,350,000 of various purpose bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948 and due Feb. 1 from 1949 to 1954.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Despite numerous protests on the subject to Congress, the Department of Agriculture had to announce potato support prices at 90 per cent of parity again today.
Jersey Joe Walcott blamed referee Frank Fullam for the eleventh-round knockout. The beaten challenger, a big swelling over his left eye, spoke rationally in his dressing room after the bout.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -Gov. Earl Warrern, of California was nominated by acclamation today as the Republican candidate for Vice President of the United States.

A general conference of all maritime unions to "unite against the shipowners to protect job security" was urged yesterday by eighteen members of the national council of the National Maritime Union, CIO, meeting in the union's headquarters at 346 West Seventeenth Street.

Interest in the market for new capital will be centered next week on the sale of $90,000,000 of New York Telephone Company refunding bonds due in 1981. The transaction is to come up at competitive sale on Tuesday. The Louisville Nashville Railroad will receive bids on Wednesday on $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 2003.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday afternoon that he would investigate reports that three Tammany district leaders had received $1,000 each to vote for Judge Francis L. Valente of General Sessions as the Democratic designee for Surrogate of New York County.

LONDON, June 25 (AP) -- Lennart Bergelin, long-legged Swede with a boarding house reach, pulled one of the classic upsets of Wimbledon tennis history today when he defeated Frank Parker of Los Angeles in a gripping five-set struggle on the center court.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 25 -The world is too much with us and God is too little with us, Rabbi Samuel Thurman of St. Louis told the Central Conference of American Rabbis tonight in a plea for a return to spiritual values as the one permanent cure for the ills of humanity.

ALBANY, June 25 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved an application of the Household Finance Corporation, 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, for permission to change its place of business at 138-140 East Fifty-ninth Street to 138-140 East 59th Street and 735 Lexington Avenue.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- An overbought condition was disclosed in the grain markets today and scattered liquidation through commission houses showed a lack of aggressive support.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- William Goldman, a theatre owner, asked Federal District Court today to force Warner Brothers and ten other movie producers and distributors to give up ownership of theatres in the Philadelhia district.

During a recent visit to June Dairy's warehouse in Jersey City, the delegate from News of Food stopped off in the butter laboratory. Up until now, the only Government-graded butter sold in retail stores in the metropolitan area has been this company's brand of Grade AA, as certified by an inspector from the United States Department of Agriculture.

Pulitzer scholarships with a total value of $34,000 were awarded yesterday to ten boys to be graduated soon from New York public high schools, it was announced by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, told twenty-eight visiting foreign students yesterday that "if the world is to get along, we must base our understanding on definite knowledge." The students will leave soon for a twenty-four-day tour of the country.

The American Committee for the World Council of Churches, at its headquarters, 297 Fourth Avenue, issued a call yesterday urging the churches of the United States to ring their bells on Sunday, Aug. 22, to mark the opening of the first assembly of the World Council in Amsterdam, Holland.

Col. Lemuel Q. Stoopnagle, who answers to the name of F. Chase Taylor when the roll is called, will star in a new Mutual network comedy and audience-participation show scheduled to make its debut on Friday, July 2, in the 9:30 to 9:55 P.M. time period.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The displaced persons bill to admit 205,000 refugees into this country became law this afternoon, but in signing it President Truman denounced the measure as a mockery.

While waiting for Economic Cooperation Administration dollars to stimulate sales abroad, textile exporters are experiencing further contraction of business as additional foreign markets cease purchasing goods, it was pointed out yesterday.

The first auction sale of jewelry, silver and other personal property that will provide funds for the United Nations program of aid to Europe's nonrepatriable victims of Nazi persecution, ended yesterday, realizing $188,435. In six sessions that began on Monday, the ParkeBernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, holding its last sale of the season, disposed of a small but valuable portion of Nazi booty shipped to this country from Germany and Austria.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of Governor Earl Warren's speech today accepting the Republican nomination for Vice President:
LONDON, June 25 -- The nomination of Governor Dewey of New York as the Republican candidate for President has aroused here a mixture of mild disappointment and some optimism.

Entering the contest with four no-hit, no-run games to his credit this season, Bill Loes just missed pitching a fifth yesterday as he hurled Bryant High to a 1-to-0 victory over Tottenville in the city Public Schools Athletic League final at Brooklyn College Field.

Former United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, counsel for Harry Ferguson, the Irish inventor and industrialist, charged in Federal Court yesterday that a former close associate of Mr. Ferguson had "sordidly betrayed" him by turning over to the Ford Motor Company "highly confidential" trade secrets.
SAPULPA, Okla., June 25 (UP) -One of the proudest mothers-inlaw in the country hung a picture of Tom Dewey in her living room today.

RHODES, June 24 (Delayed) -Count Folke Bernadotte and his staff have begun the definite formulation of proposals for settling the Palestine question, it was announced at the mediator's headquarters here tonight. How long it will take to complete this phase of the work is still unknown.

Would you think, after all the rain, that the woods could be lit by the match of a careless camper? Last week, however, picnickers burned ten acres on the slopes of Bear Mountain. Henceforth, say the park officials, such nature hobnobbers will be confined to designated areas where patrolmen with an eye for smoke can control the itch that scars a forest.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 25 -- In a killing finish to one of the great boat races of any and all seasons, Harvard slammed across the winner over the Yale varsity eight by a scant twenty feet today, to sweep the Thames in their eighty -third dual rowing regatta.

Steel pipe shortages here have established an all-time record, leading distributors reported yesterday. However, it was emphasized that by paying a premium, often amounting to 100 per cent above regular market levels, immediate deliveries can be obtained on large quantities of pipe from newly established sales organizations which have sizable inventories here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 25 -The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America closed its sessions today reporting that no solution for the economic difficulties of the southern countries of the Continent can be expected until an exhaustive survey of these difficulties is made, country by country, and the results submitted to a second period of sessions, scheduled to take place in Havana early in 1949.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 25 -The nomination of Governor Dewey by the Republican party has not altered the political position of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People because of the organization's "nonpartisan position," association leaders said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -President Truman today presented Congressional Medals of Honor to three heroes of World War II. They won the nation's highest tribute for risking their lives under intense German and Japanese fire.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -The Department of Commerce authorized today export of $12,000,000 worth of railway equipment to Poland in a move to get more coal from that Sovietdominated country for the sixteen European Recovery Program nations.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday the text of letters sent to Mayor O'Dwyer and Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri protesting against the use of city employes as ticket salesmen in connection with the celebration of the city's Golden Anniversary.

Five-month-old Barbara Kasick of 24 Bay Eighth Street, in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, was drowned yesterday when her mother. Mrs. Ann Kasick, 24, who had been bathing her in a combination sink and washtub, fainted.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -The Agriculture Department announced today August grain export allocations totaling 980,500 long tons (37,295,000 bushels).

ROME, June 25 -- The possibility of Italian airlines connecting Europe and North America has been opened by the Italo-British aeronautical agreement signed in Rome today. The lines contemplated by the agreement include one from Italy to New York via Ireland and Newfoundland and another to Bermuda via Lisbon and the Azores.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- In his first press interview since his nomination, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said today that one of the cardinal principles of his administration, if elected, would be to help China combat Communist influences within its borders.
LONDON, June 25 -- Striking clockworkers shouted defiance at their official union leaders tonight and indicated that they would continue the outlaw strike that had the Port of London paralyzed.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 25 -The Egyptians violated the truce on two counts today by strafing a United Nations plane and refusing by force to permit an Israeli convoy to pass through their positions to colonies in the Negeb as agreed under the truce terms.
GENEVA, June 25 -- A five-day effort to begin a cooperative attack on one of Europe's worst industrial bottlenecks ended in failure today.

The Holland America Line motor ship Westerdam will arrive here on Monday from Rotterdam with a new skipper on her bridge, Capt. Barend C. Visser, a sailor since 1909 and a master for the last twelve years.

Gus Fusaro, $47-a-week elevator starter accused of squandering nearly $250,000 entrusted to him by friends for investing in the stock market, was found guilty last night by a General Sessions jury on five counts of an eightcount indictment.

For several months the boys of the East River Drive Park Amphitheatre had been saving up for a television set. But when their director, Sam Lottner, told them about the group of blinded ex-service men who, under the sponsorship of Mrs. John Elliott and Mrs. Carl Sadowsky, had been learning to bowl at the Capitol Health Center, 1680 Broadway, the boys immediately voted to donate their savings for the purchase of a trophy.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -With the Republican National Committee scheduled to meet tomorrow morning to elect a new chairman, no decision on a successor to Carroll Reece of Tennessee had been reached this evening.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25 -Dr. Stanton, 7-year-old pacer owned and driven by W. L. Fraser, suffered his first defeat of the Eastern campaign tonight when he finished third behind Indian Land and Little Judy in the Nebraska, a $5,000 free-for-all pace before 12,745 at Roosevelt Raceway.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -Pitcher Early Wynn drove in the tying and winning runs tonight with a seventh-inning single as the Washington Senators beat the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 3 to 2. Wynn gave up only six hits as the faltering Indians lost their ninth game in the last thirteen starts.

Jean B. de Chadenedes, 64 years old, a retired stock investment broker, was killed yesterday at 11:35 A.M. when he fell or jumped from the fifteenth-floor terrace of a friend's apartment at 812 Park Avenue, the police of the East Sixty-seventh Street station reported.

Lumber production for the week ended June 19 was 4.5 per cent above the preceding week, but 3.5 per cent below the like week last year. Shipments were up 1.7 per cent and orders 3.5 per cent, compared with a year ago, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Big Ralph Branca ran the Dodgers' winning streak to four games and his own consecutive skein of triumphs to seven as his mates nosed out the Cardinals, 3 -- 2, under the Ebbets Field lights last night.

TOKYO, June 25 -- The Japanese press and public generally expressed qualified satisfaction tonight over the nomination of Governor Dewey as the Republican candidate for the Presidency. The large Tokyo dailies, which receive American news reports, predicted that his election was assured and found that this augured as well as could be expected for the future of Japan.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A device for simulating radarscope images whereby radar may be used for commercial and educational purposes was one of 432 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

Federal Judge John C. Knox dened yesterday the petition for naturalization of Niccolo Tucci, 40 years old, a writer who, according to immigration authorities, admitted that he was once in charge of Fascist propaganda in this country.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander scored a victory in his pinball crusade yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, after a two-week hearing, denied an injunction to three pinball manufacturers and distributors to prevent the Police Commissioner from seizing their machines.

An intrepid civilian crew from the Navy tanker Mission San Juan boarded the burning and abandoned Norwegian tanker Fenris about 650 miles off the French coast yesterday, put out the fire, and now has the vessel in tow bound for the Azores, it was reported here.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 25 (Ap) -Chet Laabs hit his twenty-first and twenty-second homers of the season tonight as the Bisons divided a twin bill with Jersey City. The Herd won the opener, 5 -- 3, but the Jerseys came back to take the nightcap, 4 -- 3.

The New York Airlines Committee, representing eleven air carriers serving the New York area, charged yesterday that Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, made two errors in an address he delivered Thursday night before the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways.
Because he has the punch that has made him one of the greatest heavyweights ever to hold the title, Joe Louis, the ring's Brown Bomber, still is the world champion.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active and weak yesterday, with final prices 10 to 65 points net lower.

The Bolshevist and Nazi revolutions brought back to Europe many of the terrors of the darker ages which modern civilization had prided itself on having left behind, in particular the practice of wholesale massacres, extermination or deportation of whole populations, concentration camps and slavery.

Retail trade here this week made a fair increase despite several cold and rainy days early in the week and humid and wet days during the latter part. Department store sales were estimated about 9 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 17 per cent.

WARSAW, June 25 -- Western diplomats in Warsaw were agreed today that the proposals of the conference of Foreign Ministers of the Soviet bloc provided no basis for renewed discussions on Germany between the East and West.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Armed services started today to put into actual operational effect the new Selective Service system that President Truman signed into law yesterday. Hastily pushed through in the closing hours of the Congressional session, its provisions are not widely understood in Army, Navy and Air Force circles.

Another court battle between industrialist Henry J. Kaiser and Cyrus S. Eaton, principal stockholder in Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking firm, was indicated yesterday after their representatives had failed to agree to a demand by Otis that the Permanente Metals Corporation of Oakland, Calif., a Kaiser affiliate, return to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation the aluminum rolling mill near Spokane, Wash., recently transferred to Permanente by the automotive concern.

Children in the East Harlem section may expect this summer greatly improved recreational facilities and instruction in parks, playgrounds and swimming pools in this area of more than 200,000 population. These improvements will result from the efforts of local school and community leaders who met June 16 to discuss the situation, and also from a meeting yesterday of the Citizens Continuation Committee appointed at the first conference.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, Syracuse, N.Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for simplification of its corporate structure and eventual dissolution.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- John L. Lewis and the Commercial Coal Operators today signed a one-year agreement on the last effective working day of the 1947 contract. While the contract technically expires on June 30, the ten-day vacation period at midnight tonight ushered in a cessation of coal digging until July 5.
BERLIN, June 25 -- About 2,250,000 Germans in the Western sectors of Berlin came face to face with the grim specter of starvation today as the siege of those sectors began in earnest.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 -Golden Hill of the J.A. Hale Stable in Greenwich, consistent conformation hunter title winner, scored in the opening day competition of the annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today. The Hale entry gained the lead in the championship competition here and a strong margin for the threeshow honors of the Fairfield County circuit.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 25 -- Prudent financial housekeeping on a national scale to meet mounting domestic and foreign obligations was advocated tonight by W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of the National City Bank of New York.

PASADENA, Calif., June 25 -Analysis of the light of distant stars through the 100-inch telescope of the Mount Wilson Observatory has led to the discovery that giant stars of certain types, particularly young stars, are veritable cosmic magnets, revolving in space at tremendous speeds and acquiring positive electrical potentials as high as 100,000 billion volts.

OTTAWA, June 25 -- Canadian comment on the Republican party's choice of Governor Dewey as its candidate is mixed but on the whole friendly. It is felt that during his term of office as Governor Mr. Dewey in all his dealings with his neighbors in Quebec and Ontario has been both cooperative and constructive.

The possibility that the city may move to take over and operate the six bus systems in Queens now under private operation was revived yesterday as the private operators faced threats of a strike next Thursday.
