Unions representing employes of the six companies are demanding pay rises of 24 cents an hour, effective on that date.

DENVER, June 25 -- Establishment of a series of community colleges throughout the United States, to provide educational opportunities to all who want training beyond the high school level, was advocated today by Dr. Norman P. Auburn, vice president of the University of Cincinnati and dean of administration.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Dr. James G. McDonald, the United States first diplomatic representative to the State of Israel, called on President Truman today and said he regarded it as a privilege to help toward bringing peace and justice to Palestine.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -Gov. Earl Warren of California was chosen for nomination as Vice President before the Republican national convention was called to order today. While delegations milled around the steaming auditorium, and the galleries waited impatiently an hour and a half for something to happen, it was happening, far from their view, at a conference of leaders.
The Kroger Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $6,140,214 in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 12, after taxes and all charges, it was reported yesterday.

GLACE BAY, N.S., June 25 (Canadian Press) -- The United Mine Workers (Canadian Congress of Labor) District 26 said today it had definite information "concerning the probability of American interests acquiring control of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation."

Joe Louis weighed 213 1/2 pounds and Jersey Joe Walcott scaled 194 3/4 when the pair weighed in on Wednesday. There were no other trips to the scales through the postponements of the bout at the Yankee Stadium.

LONDON, June 25 -- An exchange of views on relationships between the Anglican communion and the Lutheran Orthodox churches, some of which are behind the Iron Curtain, will take place in London next week on the eve of the eighth Lambeth Conference, the advisory assembly of Anglican bishops and archbishops.

LONDON, June 25 -- In an atmosphere of tension a meeting of the British Cabinet, the second within twenty-four hours, was held today to consider measures to counter the Soviet efforts to harry the Western Allies out of Berlin. Two other meetings of the chief Ministers have been held in the meantime.

The thirty-four-page alleged confession of Santo (Sal) Bretagna, in which he admitted shooting Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner at the prompting of Willie (Farbie) Rosenberg, was read into the court record yesterday after three days of defense maneuvers to bar it.

A rather serious conflict of opinion and personalities has developed between the major domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority over the terms for use of New York International Airport. This has also spilled over into the foreign-flag lines, although their united front was recently broken and there are hopes that further agreements may be in the offing.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 25 -Finishing with a round of 33, 36, 69, two strokes under par, Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Golf Club captured his third straight Long Island open golf championship at the Garden City Country Club today with a 72-hole score of 282.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 25 -Dr. Mark Hollis, Assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, suggested today that an underwriters' testing laboratory be set up to work on problems of public health.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The Republican National Convention held a final session lasting one hour and twenty-nine minutes, during which it selected Gov. Earl Warren of California as its Vice Presidential nominee and heard him accept the nomination.

PARIS, June 25 -- Informed observers said today that the Soviet bloc's proclamation for four-power action on Germany was propaganda directed at the Germans, but expressed a belief that the Soviet Union intended to create in its zone of Germany a separate state.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 25 (AP) -A criticism that Israel made no mention of God in declaring its independence was found today to have been based upon an omission imposed by the censorship.

BRUSSELS, June 25 -- King Leopold of Belgium, writing from exile in Switzerland, offered in a letter to Premier Paul-Henri Spaak made public tonight to abdicate if a majority of the Belgian people were opposed to his return.

ONE of America's foremost contemporary artists has written this book designed to make drawing pleasurable and constructive for the layman and provide sound basic knowledge for the art student at the same time. The opening discussion outlines the basic drawing materials This is followed by illustrations of charcoal, color, pen, stylus, matchstick, pencil and brush techniques along with suggestions for the most effective use of each.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 25 (Delayed) -- A provisional truce line running eleven miles through the Biblical Vale of Ajalon, where Joshua commanded the sun and moon to stand still to enable him to defeat the Midianites, was mapped here today by the United Nations mediator's staff to permit peaceful crop gathering by Arabs and Jews.

VIENNA, June 26 -- United States occupation authorities frankly warned the Austrian public today that they feared the Soviet Union might be hoping to stage a coup in Austria similar to those in neighboring states. An article in the Wiener Kurier, official German-language newspaper of the United States forces in Austria, reviewed at length the alleged record of Soviet opposition to the strengthening of the Austrian police to consolidate the authority of the Austrian Government.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Three women were named today by the Republican National Committee to positions of responsibility and power in the party. They were Mrs. Charles P. Howard of Massachusetts, who succeeded Mrs. Dudley C. Hay of Michigan as secretary of the committee and Mrs. Horace H. Sayre of Oklahoma and Mrs. Katharine Kennedy Brown of Ohio, who were re-elected vice-chairmen of the committee.

FARMINGDALE, L.I. June 26 -- George A. Nolte of Mount Vernon was elected today president of the Southern New York Volunteer Firemen's Association as the organization ended its fifty-third annual convention with a tournament here. Mr. Nolte succeeds James McInnes Jr. of Syosset.

THE theatre, which may have grown lean over the years, has an undisputed knack for surviving its own obituaries. Now, while still weathering the cinematic onslaught, to say nothing of the boredom from within promoted by some of its own mal-practitioners, the New York stage faces the prospect of being done to death by the tax collector.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 26 -- More than $1,500,000 worth of raw cotton has been purchased in the United States by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund for shipment to twelve European countries and China, it was announced here today.

RECENTLY, in these columns, John Lehmann, English writer and publisher, drew some comparisons between the mood and work of young writers on the two sides of the Atlantic. He had the impression that among the Americans there was evidence of "keen experiment and exploration of new territory," while in England, though during the latter part of the war there had been some promising ferment, there had been little subsequent development.

THIS is a critical month in the fruit garden, yet it happens to be also a time when care and interest are likely to lag. For with dozens of other garden chores to be done the fruit garden may be neglected. This is especially the fate of bush and other small fruits in summer. A little planning, however, will correct this.

THIS book is the fruit of a kind of heroic living in the spirit very rare today. Professor Tillich, German-born and educated, now a member of the faculty of the Union Theological Seminary, is a great theologian, certainly one of the most decisive thinkers in modern Christendom.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 26 -- Baseball's old "break up the Yankees" cry may have a golfing counterpart of "break up those Texans" if Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret continue their best-ball dominance of the nation's play-for-pay field. Continued on Page' 5, Co!,,mn 2
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 26 (AP) -- Official summary of Western Germany's currency conversion laws.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 26 -- The Israeli Government charged today that the Egyptians had attacked Kfar Darom settlement below Gaza. It was not a large-scale attack and no further details were received here.

Bone preserved in a frozen state for weeks is of "definite value" in bone-grafting operations, say Dr. Leonard F. Bush of Danville, Pa., and Dr. C. Zent Garber of New York in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Experiments with chinchilla rabbits have shown that human bone can be preserved apparently indefinitely in a freezer at minus 20 to 30 degrees centigrade.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 26 -- New York State's largest regiment, the 165th Infantry, formerly the Sixty-ninth of Manhattan, will move into Camp Smith here tomorrow afternoon to open the season's training of the New York National Guard.

In your editorial of May 6, "The U.S.A. and the U.N.," you line up with Secretary Marshall against those who seek to amend the United Nations Charter, even though you reject the better half of his argument. The movement toward Charter amendment has grown to sizable proportion and some projects have eached the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

TORONTO -- The thousands of lakes and rivers of eastern Canada that are within short distances of the international boundary invite the intrepid vacationist on countless canoe trips, some of them leading deep into the wilderness.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 26 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Vulcan's Forge, carrying top weight of 126 pounds, forged from behind to defeat D.A. Rosenbaum's Reborn, a 45-1 shot, by a neck in the $25,000 added Providence Stakes today before a crowd of 20,000 at Narragansett Park.

The picture story, "The U.S. -- Moscow Version." showing the Soviet movie version of a New York newspaper office, had the usual reporter with telephone cradled to ear, man with hat tilted back on head, deep-thinking editor smoking pipe.

WHEN I was in New York last year I had occasion to take a taxi to Grove Street. The driver didn't know the way and I had to direct him. I made bold to tell him that in some cities taxi drivers know their way.

PAWLING, N.Y., June 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told 3,000 friends and neighbors at a welcome home celebration tonight that he would like to bring to Government a revival of the generosity of spirit, fairness and tolerance typical of those who live on farms and in small towns.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- With both Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Gov. Earl Warren of California predicting victory at the November election at the meeting, the Republican National Committee today elected Representative Hugh D. Scott, Jr., of Philadelphia, a Navy veteran, chairman of the committee.

Peace and the success of the United Nations will be assured if the world follows the lessons learned from the sacrifice of four chaplains who gave up their lives aboard a sinking troopship, acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri and Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, declared here yesterday.

In Geneva the United Nations gives evidence of how nations are rallying to constructive work in the humanitarian field. Delegates of more than fifty nations are gathered there -- members and nonmembers of the U.N. -- for its first World Health Assembly. The word "world" was deliberately chosen and has great significance.
SOUND can be added to amateur 16mm film by a new service offered by Fotosonic, Inc., 132 West Forty-third Street. Films to be sound-serviced must be made at twenty-four frames a second.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies' prize rookie, Richie Ashburn, stole the show and the ball game today as the Phillies subdued the Chicago Cubs by a 3-2 score.

GOOD vision is always important to motorists and it may well mean the difference between life and death for many drivers who will be starting out in the next few days on Fourth of July week-end junkets. It is well to include a check-up of the eyes as well as of the car before setting out on a long trip.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 26 -- Staging a surprise victory, Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook won the forty-fifth Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship by defeating Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, 3 and 2, in the 36-hole final over the Nassau Country Club course today.

THE World's Fair of Music -- with emphasis on the development of music as an art while not overlooking its value as a business -- will start at the Grand Central Palace on Monday, July 19, and end on July 25.

IS your child going to camp for the first time this year? If so, better make sure that raincoat and rubbers have been checked off on the list of equipment. We hear that these -- and long trousers -- are invariably needed, and are more often omitted from children's camping gear than any other articles.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Armed with a law they consider inadequate and an appropriation they believe too small, Government officials were planning this week to try to carry out the provisions of the bill passed in the last crowded hours of Congress to admit to the United States about 200,000 displaced in the next two years.

AS a nation we still feel culturally immature. We are inclined to be somewhat apologetic about our semantic wranglings, our hesitancy to accept new and difficult forms. Europeans, we feel, take such things in their stride.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- There is nothing in the Republican foreign policy platform or in the record of the men elevated into new positions of power here this week to suggest that any attempt would be made by the new Republican team to change the present trend of American foreign policy.

Everybody has emotions, but ask a psychologist what an emotion is, how it arises and how the body deals with it and you receive as many answers as there are answerers. There is only one point of agreement: emotion involves the autonomic nervous system, which is the part of the total nervous system that automatically or mechanically controls such functions as heartbeat, breathing and the like.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 26 -- James W. Paul and J.R. Sheffield, Meadow Brook, led the way into the semi-final round of the Piping Rock member-guest golf tournament today by defeating Eugene D. Wadsworth and Augustus Wadsworth from Elkwanok, Manchester, Vt., 2 and 1, in the feature of the quarter-final today.

Armies can now predict disease and non-combat casualties and measure manpower and material needs well into the future through the application of wartime actuarial techniques, E.A. Lew and F.A. Weck of New York. Metropolitan Life Insurance Company mathematicians, pointed out in a paper presented before the Centenary Assembly of the Institute of Actuaries of London.

JUST twelve years ago this week in this Review: The most widely read American novel of the decade, "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell, occupied P. 1, where J. Donald Adams wrote: "This is beyond doubt the most remarkable first novel produced by an American writer * * * a book of uncommon quality."

THE importance of the Mediterranean Sea and the lands which border it has been analyzed in the past in terms of the single geographical unit it comprises. The Belgian scholar Pirenne has painstakingly traced the relationship of seapower in the famous inland sea to commercial links of Europe and Asia and to the life of empires established in Rome and Constantinople.

FATHER WALSH, Regent of the School of Foreign Service in Georgetown University, witnessed personally the opening years of the bolshevik revolution. He visited Germany at the end of the Nazi revolution, when he acted as consultant in the office of the American Chief of Counsel in Nuremberg.

Helpless, hapless and hopeless were the Giants against Johnny Vander Meer and the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Twenty-four hours brought quite a difference as the team, that had blanked the Cincinnati outfit the day before, itself was subjected to a whitewashing that drew jeers from 13,750 fans.

PARIS, June 26 -- Emphasizing the consequences for American foreign policy if Governor Dewey is elected President next November, the Parisian press, representing various shades of opinion, expressed confidence today, in editorials, that the present program of cooperation with and aid to Europe would not be weakened.

MOTHS fluttered frantically about the ring under the great lights, caroming crazily off the head and shoulders of both Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott. For ten dreary rounds the moths did about as much damage to the contestants as the fighters did to each other. If this were not the worst fight ever staged, it came mighty close to it, a grotesque parody of the Manly Art of Modified Murder.

ANYONE who, as a child, has ever tended a barnyard pet will know in advance how Tivo must feel when the time comes to part with his hand-fed turkey, Peepelo. But Tivo, a Mexican boy of the hills, innocently nurtures Peepelo from chick to roaster-size in order to have something to take to market.

LONDON, June 26 -- Plans were being discussed here today by representatives of the United States, Britain and France for the next move in Berlin. It has been recognized in the last few days that the present situation of the Western powers in Berlin is untenable and that the situation is incapable of solution on a local level there.

LONDON, June 26 -- One of the greatest tennis crowds ever -- estimated at more than 30,000 -- packed into Wimbledon's stands and grounds today to watch the list of survivors in men's singles reduced to eight.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- At least 100 police, aided for a time in their hunt by six planes, were closing in tonight on a mob of gunmen who entrenched themselves in a quarry in Western Springs, a suburb.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 (AP) -- Egyptian Prime Minister Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha told correspondents in Cairo last night that his Government would reply today to protests on both incidents submitted by Count Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator.

Although the farm legislation enacted in the closing minutes of the adjourned Eightieth Congress contains many intricate and technical provisions intended to correct some of the faults of the existing law, generally it continues the price-support program with a bit more discretionary power given to the Secretary of Agriculture.

A large number of out-of-town buyers remained in wholesale apparel markets here last week to complete their fall purchasing, which included orders for special sale merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 26 -- An investment in the training of religious leaders whether they be Catholic, Protestant or Jewish is not the unrewarding dream of impractical idealists but the life-giving and carefully conceived vision of realistic modern man, Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College -- Jewish Institute of Religion, said tonight.
ALHAMBRA, Calif., June 26 (AP) -- Lloyd La Beach, the Panama flyer, held a new world track record today for 220 yards around a turn.

COMPARED with pre-war years, the 1948-49 music season in New York will be big, but advance reports indicate the peak of the post-war boom has passed. There is no threat of a severe recession, but an informal survey of recitals lined up for the season shows a slight slackening.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Some seventy-six members of the United States Navy and Marine Corps have been assigned to duty with the United Nations truce mission in Palestine, the Navy said today.

G.O. Basham, chief trial examiner for the Maritime Commission, has recommended the dismissal of a complaint brought against the Matson Navigation Company by the Honolulu Consumers Council which had charged that the line's rates between United States mainland ports and Hawaii were "unlawful,'' it was announced yesterday.
Because The New York Times Magazine customarily runs enlightened articles on questions of public interest, I was a bit taken back by Geoffrey Gorer's "Political Behavior in the Human Female."

An Industrial Fair will open Aug. 1 to continue for the entire month, it was announced yesterday by the New York Museum of Science and Industry, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, in conjunction with the New York City Golden Anniversary celebration.

PASADENA, Calif., June 26 -- Development of the most precise "atomic yardstick" so far devised for measuring the wave lengths of the infinitesimally small rays emanating from the nuclei and radioactive atoms, was described here today before the meeting of the American Physical Society.

THAT trip you've been looking forward to all spring and saving up for all winter may end up as a pleasant summer joyride, but for the stewards, hostesses and pursers who go along as nursemaids to the traveling public it's just a sweet little headache with all expenses paid.

HOWARD CLEWES' novel is about a new breed of partisans -- not the meaty Hemingway figures but men struck down by apathy and provincialism. "Thus Am I Slayn" is the other side of the bell. Given a classic enough situation (eleven partisans trapped at the foot of a cliff in the Dolomites by a regiment of Nazis), Mr. Clewes has added a touch of Middletown in the Mountains.

General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente disclaimed yesterday any knowledge of the purported payment of $1,000 each to three district leaders to influence his designation for Surrogate by Tammany Hall.

SINGAPORE, June 26 -- The flood of communism is spilling south from China over the rich lands of Southeast Asia. Senior British officials assert that the Communists have launched a major offensive in the area.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 26 -- Thirty boats were entered in the first day of the Noroton Race Week this afternoon, off Noroton Harbor in Long Island Sound.

STANTON, Del., June 26 (AP) -- Page Boots, flying the colors of Royce G. Martin's Woodvale Farm, made a clean sweep of the open 3-year-old stakes at Delaware Park today by racing to an easy five-length triumph in the $17,500 added Leonard Richards Stakes.
ATHENS, June 26 -- All rebel counter-attacks launched for the purpose of regaining high ground in the Konitsa sector have been beaten back, today's General Staff communique said.

I was very much interested in the picture article, "The Battle for the Presidency -- A Poster History," but may I point out that the date under the Cleveland and Stevenson poster should have been 1892 rather than 1884? The Democratic candidate for Vice President in 1884 was Thomas A. Hendricks of Indiana.

MURDER is planned, and then the plan is temporarily abandoned because Ione Garrison is not sure which of two persons she wants to kill. One of the two, Amanda Garth, senses the reason for this uncertainty and sets out deliberately to foster it.

DIRECTOR Billy Wilder and his scenarist-producer partner, Charles Brackett are "very much interested in doing Charles Jackson's book, 'The Outer Edges' ", Wilder divulged last week after returning from a two-month trip to France.

THE silhouette, color and form of flower arrangements change with the bloom in the garden, thus forestalling repetition of the same pattern. Just now, for example, the garden abounds in spike forms with pastels predominating, which means that deep containers are dusted off and put into use for the summer.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 26 -- Mike Cestone of Crestmont and F. F. Boehm, who won the qualifying medal yesterday with a 5 under par 68, defeated Sidney Wilson of Spring Brook and E. A. Sharkey 1 up at the nineteenth hole today in the first round of the Bill Hatt Memorial member-guest tournament at the Canoe Brook Country Club.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 26 (AP) -- A new United States record was in the books today and two new champions had been crowned in the Women's National swimming and diving championships.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis professional, erased a four-hole deficit on the final six holes to defeat Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, 1 up, on the thirty-seventh green of a hectic overtime battle for the women's Western open golf championship today.
I wonder how many of your readers fell for the badinage on "Resistentialism" in The Times Magazine under the title, "Thingness of Things."

One hundred proud mothers entered their babies yesterday after-noon in the Chinese Community Club annual baby show in Columbus Park, Mulberry and Park Streets. After the weeping and wailing of many tiny voices had subsided, Louis Payne Chan, 5 months old, of 138 Forsythe Street, received first prize as the "cryingest" baby in the contest.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard issued yesterday to his staff of 6,000 field workers and supervisors a comprehensive statement of basic policy governing the total operation of the Department of Welfare in connection with public assistance.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- A third member of the rubber industry's "big four," the B.F. Goodrich Company, granted a wage increase of 11 cents an hour today. That raised to 68,000 the number of rubber workers receiving the same rise.

FORT DIX, N.J. HERE at Dix the clay-dirt drill fields and classic two-story barracks are ready for the men soon to be drafted into the "new" Army. The long warehouses are filled with equipment; an officer says that they can turn out a hundred men an hour, fully clothed, without any trouble.
Summer sessions of the four municipal colleges will probably have a record attendance of 20,000 students, it was learned yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., June 26 (AP) -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, said today that a mobile striking force of eighteen infantry and armored divisions is planned for the Army by 1949.
SHANGHAI, June 26 -- Shanghai markets continued their high speed inflationary trend here today in the sharpest break in the economic situation, yesterday and today, since V-J Day.

IN this book Curt Sachs, one of our more formidable musicologists, has left the field of original research to undertake what amounts to a job of popularization and interpretation. He has written a short outline of music history, designed for college students and laymen.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 26 -- The failure of Congress to approve the $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for its East River capital is regarded here as one of the most disheartening of the many blows that have been struck at the world's struggling peace organization.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

AN unexpected event for this late moment in a dwindling season, and ranking with many of the first-rate attractions of that season, is the current Lilienfeld Gallery selection of portraits. Mr. Lilienfeld has cast his net wide enough to cover a period of six centuries and this show of twenty items demonstrates how impressive work by masters of lesser reputation can be at best.

The Security Bureau, Inc., an organization of maritime industry companies formed to combat waterfront thievery, has recommended as "sound protective policy'' that a record be made of every person who has access to steamship piers, including truck drivers delivering cargo.

AS the Republican Party was busy choosing its candidates in Philadelphia last week, its opposite number was not trying too hard to conceal a broad grin about several business control amendments which had been tacked on to the Selective Service Act in the last-minute rush to adjourn Congress.
This looks like Barnegat year for yachtsmen. Cruising seasons seem to have characteristics, but no one knows why Lake Champlain will be popular one year, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket another year.

SOME years ago this reviewer took a summer Sunday off to opine that there is no such thing as a "summer picture," in the popular understanding of that phrase. Either a picture is a good one or it isn't, we soberly observed, and the season has little influence on an audience's tolerance.

LUTON, England, June 26 -- In vigorous but measured terms Winston Churchill told an audience of 100,000 here today that the issues raised by the present situation in Berlin were "as grave as those we now know were at stake at Munich ten years ago."

SHANGHAI, June 26 (UP) -- Government military dispatches said today that Government troops had followed up their capture of Kaifeng by storming into Taian, on the Tientsin-Pukow railway, and engaging the Communists in severe street fighting.

UNDER the name of the New York City Ballet Company, the Ballet Society will provide the official ballet of the New York City Opera Company season at the City Center next fall. The plan is to give two evenings of ballet each week for the eight weeks of the regular season, and possibly to add one or even two weeks of ballet alone immediately afterward.

President Truman should have refrained from signing the displaced persons bill, which he himself called "anti-Semitic," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

BEREA, Ohio, June 26 (AP) -- Harrison Dillard, who came to Baldwin-Wallace as a virtually unknown athlete, put on a smashing show today as he made his farewell appearance as a college runner on his home cinders.

ALTHOUGH the air route across the Atlantic has what is probably the best safety record of any airway in the world, the pilots and air crews who fly the big commercial airliners over it take nothing for granted. They are all "safety minded" to a high degree.

The Brooklyn bubble burst at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Cardinals not only snapped the Dodger winning streak at four games by beating the Brooks, 6 -- 3, but dumped them back into sixth place, a notch below the Phils.
LONDON -- The spearhead of the American tourist invasion has already arrived in England. Most of the rest of the 100,000 expected touring American cousins will be in soon.

FOR some reason which Jim Colton is unable to fathom, all of his friends appear to dislike the girl with whom he has fallen in love. Her name is Manderin Jones, and she becomes a disturbing influence in Jim's life before and after their marriage.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- The United Nations was pictured tonight by Byron Price, its assistant secretary-general, as an agency which in three years had accomplished far more in international cooperation "than has been achieved in any like period since the world began."

In the Letters columns of June 6, C. Ragosine suggests that Abdullah's Arab fighters might fare better in the field if they did not boil their coffee so long. As the son of a former church choir leader, I question this.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 26 -- The marriage of Miss Jane Bartlett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis A. Bartlett of North Stamford, to Donald E. Heisinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Heisinger of Glenbrook, Conn., took place this afternoon in the North Stamford Congregational Church.

ATHENS, June 26 (AP) -- Guerrilla forces attacked an important supply line of the Greek Army today and destroyed part of the Elasson-Kozane highway in northwestern Greece, a General Staff communique reported.

Joe Louis was in retirement in more ways than one yesterday. The situation surrounding the world heavyweight title was, as a consequence, clouded in more confusion than has been experienced in the past twenty years, or since Gene Tunney gave up the crown after knocking out Tom Heeney in eleven rounds.

IN Hollywood two pictures constitute a trend and announcements from-studio publicity departments magnify the trend into an avalanche because all estimated production programs are sizable multiples of the attainable.

Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Meditator in Palestine, is doing "a remarkably fine job," Harold Evans, Philadelphia Quaker lawyer, reported yesterday at La Guardia Field on his return by plane from the Middle East.
THE following is submitted for the consideration of detractors of the art of "soap opera" writing.

Three members of the dental profession in this country were honored yesterday with the rank of Officer in the Order of Orange-Nassau, conferred on behalf of Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands at a ceremony in the Netherlands Consulate General at 10 Rockefeller Plaza.
MOST of the recent books on contract bridge seem to be American editions of new British works. The latest to come to this column is a book on the play of the cards by Terence Reese.
WARSAW, June 26 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Zygmund Modzelewski told Parliament tonight that Poland's western frontiers were the borders of peace for the whole world.

A 34-year-old colored man who was born in a log cabin in Alabama, and until he put on boxing gloves and climbed into a ring knew nothing but poverty, retired yesterday as the undefeated heavyweight champion of the world. Joe Louis, born Barrow, leaves behind a spotless record of sportsmanship in an activity that very often has little of that commodity to offer.
EARLY summer seedlings in the great garden of the literary life:

Wheat ripens on the high plains of the West, those plains which reach from Texas all the way into Canada. Wheat stands in fields that touch the horizon on all sides, the ripening breadstuff of America and much of the world. Harvest is under way in the south and moving north.

A collection of books from Czechoslovakia, the second gift from that country's Government to the New York Public Library, will be added this week to the Czechoslovak section at the Webster Branch Library, 1465 York Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The selection of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as the Republican standard bearer means a hard-hitting, vigorous campaign for the Presidency in which President Truman's Administration will be under constant attack from now until November.

THE first sudden death in the Bullard family appears to be suicide, and perhaps it is, although Dick Acton feels that there is something phony about it. The second death is unquestionably murder. The Actons, Dick and Kit, are paying guest at the Bullard home on Cape Cod during Dicks vacation.

THE desert, Judy and Jon's father had said, was no place for children in summer, but those two quickly proved him wrong during the vacation they spent on a Navajo reservation in New Mexico. With innate good manners and some coaching from their ethnologist parents they made friends with Yellow Singer's children and fitted easily into the Indian pattern of life.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Cutting loose with a bristling attack that included Long John Lindell's third homer in as many days, routed Virgil Trucks inside of four rounds and concluded with Yogi Berra blasting another circuit clout, the Yankees today swiftly made amends for their setback at the hands of Hal Newhouser last night.
SHA_NGHAJ[, June 26 (@ -- Chinese Communist troops knifing southward out of Manchuria today were reported to be attacking one North China port and the railway that links it to Tientsin and Peiping.

NEW ORLEANS, June 26 (AP) -- Foreign business men will soon be able to make buying tours of most of the United States merely by visiting one building in New Orleans. On Thursday, July 1, exhibits of some 500 lines of goods will begin moving into the modernistic five-story $1,400,000 structure of the International Trade Mart.

BERLIN, June 26 -- Storm signals are flying in Berlin. Political thunderheads which have been piling up since the breakdown of the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting last December have burst and all Germany and Berlin in particular is lashed by a major political struggle.

H.F. Weismuller has been promoted to general manager of the Pigments Department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to succeed J.F. Daley, transferred to the Organic Chemicals Department, effective July 1. Dr. D.H. Dawson will be advanced from sales director to succeed Mr. Weismuller as assistant general manager.
ATHENS, June 20 (Delayed) -- Civil war and hunger took 75 cents out of every dollar the American taxpayer has thus far contributed to the aid of Greece.
BERLIN, June 26 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Commander in Chief in Germany, was arrested for speeding tonight in the United States sector.

FOUR men who were identified with developments in aeronautics in the nineteenth century are portrayed on airmail stamps which Liechtenstein has in preparation for release in July. One of them, Otto Lilienthal (1848-1896), German engineer, on 1-franc sepia, is a philatelic familiar. The other three, new to philately's gallery, are:

TO see Shelley plain has been exceedingly difficult. His life and opinions have aroused vituperation and adulation; the variety of forms his poetry assumed has veiled its unity; the luxuriance of its imagery has obscured its meaning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., elected chairman of the Republican National Committee today, is a veteran of the second World War, having served overseas with the United States Navy, which he left with the rank of commander.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 26 (AP) -- Yankee Hill, a 4-year-old colt owned by Laddie Sanford, outdistanced some of the top sprinters in the East to win the $10,000 added Oceanport Handicap today at Monmouth Park.

BEFORE she could read, Esther Warner made a fanciful journey down the west coast of Africa, when her mother spread out a map in their Iowa farmhouse and recited such exotic names as Gold Coast, Ivory Coast, the Congo, the Bight of Benin.

BRITISH socialism per se seems a drear and dreadful business to many people. For Susan Kerby, British socialism, carried to its utopian fruition, seems a fate worse than death or taxes. She prefers monarchy -- or better still, theocracy.

The Navy tanker Mission San Juan, which is towing the fire-swept Norwegian tanker Fenris, has advised that it is proceeding toward Ponta Delgade, the Azores, at four knots and should reach that port some time on Thursday, a spokesman for Tankers Company, Inc., 17 Battery Place, agents for the naval craft, announced yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, June 26 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea has informed the Korean National Assembly by letter that it "takes note of the fact that a National Assembly was constituted on May 31 by elected representatives of the Korean people."

New Yorkers with similar educational backgrounds make similar types of grammatical errors, according to Norman Lewis, supervisor of reading and grammar courses for the adult education department of the City College of New York.

BUENOS AIRES, June 26 -- Miguel Miranda, chairman of the National Economic Council, whom all United States negotiators have found a harder man to deal with than President Peron, insisted today that he was indifferent to the non-arrival of Economic Cooperation Administration dollars this year and hinted that Argentina might be forced to cut food production rather than be forced into selling cheap.

DENVER, June 26 -- A code of ethics, to govern public relations directors in their dealings with colleges, the press, radio and other means of communication, was adopted at the final sessions of the American College Public Relations Conference today. The code is designed to advance the cause of American colleges and universities, and guide the conduct of the 750 members of the association.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, one of the national chairmen of the United Jewish Appeal's campaign for $250,000,000, announced yesterday that in the six months prior to the establishment of Israel the Jews in Palestine contributed $19,680,000 for immigration, defense, upbuilding and aid to survivors in Europe.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26 -- Despite an easterly breeze that disintegrated, tumbled in strength and scattered, but eventually congealed into a southerly, the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's championship series regatta was held on Long Island Sound today.

The National Biscuit Company has just completed a personnel administration decentralization program which will insure that personnel practices and policies emanating from its headquarters at 449 West Fourteenth Street will be carried out in more than 300 manufacturing plants and sales agencies throughout the country, Harry T. Eggert, vice president in charge of personnel relations, disclosed last week.

The Council for the Advancement of the Americas was formed yesterday by a group of fifty-odd individuals, mostly left wing trade unionists, in all-day meetings in the Pennsylvania Hotel. The primary stated purpose of the organization "is to help make the people of the United States recognize their own direct responsibility for all the fear, hunger, repression and terror in Latin America."

Dr. Harry Alvin Millis, who died in Chicago on Friday at the age of 75, will be remembered as Chairman of the National Labor Relations Board during the war years. But this is only part of his long and distinguished record. He was a professor of economics, whose students learned from him to find and revere the truth and to apply it to the public welfare.
THE other day an interviewer asked, "Isn't it remarkable, Miss Tamiris, how the dance has caught on practically overnight?" My answer to that was "Yes, it is remarkable, but it's been a long night."

LOTTE LEHMANN is not only a superb singing and acting artist but also a woman of other talents and intelligence. It is, therefore, not necessary to look for a ghost as the writer of this book, which is written almost in the way that she would talk -- with the same seriousness, alternating with dashes of humor, devotion to her art and understanding of its many facets, and with her rare generosity of spirit.

LONDON, June 26 -- The Government began today to mass 1,000 troops in London's dock area to take over the unloading of ships on Monday. Meanwhile the unofficial strike that already has lasted thirteen days showed few if any signs of ending.

Increasing use of air transportation for the shipment of commercial cargoes has intensified the efforts of bankers and airline operators to devise a negotiable airway bill of lading. Such a bill, which would enable the shipper to transfer title to the goods, would facilitate bank financing of air shipments.

APRODIGIOUS publishing job by Knopf is the recently published "Joseph and His Brothers" ($5). Thomas Mann's pyramid-like work consisting of "The Tales of Jacob," "Young Joseph," "Joseph in Egypt" and "Joseph the Provider" -- a corpus of writing that is, in effect, Mr. Mann's examination of the ancient Hebrew history in the light of modern psychological criteria.
SINGAPORE, June 26 (Reuters) -- Four more murders -- two in Johore and two in Selangor -- have brought the death roll in the Malaya troubles during the last twenty-four hours to nine.

BELGRADE, June 26 -- Railroad and road communications between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria have been severed and thousands of peasant families made homeless by floods along the Morava and Nishova Rivers between the town of Nish and the Bulgarian frontier.

WITH a long weekend just ahead of us, it's time to plan a meal outdoors. The stage may be a beach or backyard; the "stove" a simple campfire a la Boy Scout or one of those elaborate grills that seem to look at home only on a penthouse terrace.

AMERICAN HERB SOCIETY officers for 1948-49 were elected at the organization's annual meeting at the New York Botanical Garden last week. Taking office in September, they will serve until September, 1949.

TELEVISION fixed its inquisitive eye on the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia last week and turned in its most impressive performance yet at reporting a major news event. The concerted effort of the video industry reflected thoroughness in preparation and alertness in coverage.

With school tuna now being taken, broadbill swordfish sighted off-shore, and several white marlin seen but not hooked, the letters should begin arriving this week from irate anglers who demand that certain charter boat captains be blacklisted for incompetence, unsatisfactory conduct, or plain dishonesty.

Despite rainy days and humid weather, department store sales last week showed an increase of about 9 per cent. Excessively hot weather at the end of the week stimulated summer apparel purchases. Homefurnishings volume was dull with the exception of seasonal items such as refrigerators and portable, radios.

The real earnings of the average American worker in nonfarm industry have risen 68 per cent over the last half century, according to estimates of money and real earnings for each year of the period that became available yesterday.

As a memorial to alumni who died in World War II, Yale University is planning to establish a fund of "at least $10,000,000" to endow scholarships and fellowships. At present 40 per cent of the total undergraduate student body are classified as "aid" students.

Only one nation within the geo-political sphere of Soviet Russia has thus far escaped total annexation, and that is little Finland. But she lives in a state of continual vigilance to forestall Communist revolts that would lead to incorporating her into the U.S.S.R.

Three thousand Bronx children experienced yesterday the same excitement and frolic their parents enjoyed at the beginning of the century during the second annual "June walk" of the North Bronx Democratic Club held in a glen in Seton Falls Park, 233d Street and Dyer Avenue, the Bronx.

With competition for the consumer's dollar continually becoming more pronounced, progressive retailers are taking steps to rid themselves of careless business habits acquired during the war years. Unnecessary expenses are being eliminated, operating efficiency is being increased, undesirable merchandise is being cleaned out of inventories and the wants of the consumer are being used as a basing point for the entire store operation.

Just now, when the air is full of the din of politics, escapist activities become more necessary than ever. Where to turn? "Get yourself a bird book and a pair of binoculars," said the bird-wise friend. "You will find it lots of fun."

THIS is not the first compilation of the stories, traditions, legends, wit, wisdom and folk songs of the Jewish people to appear in English. It certainly is one of the most ambitious and comprehensive. Ironically and sadly it is issued at a time when the originators of this wealth, or rather their heirs, have virtually disappeared from the globe.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The startling war-born idea of using women in the military services reached a full cycle last week when the enlistment and commissioning of women in the Regular Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps became law.
ED HERLIHY has the biggest "family" in New York, the sixty youngsters who make up the personnel of the "Children's Hour" on WNBC, Sunday from 10:30 to 11:30 A.M.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 26 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Helpers, largest AFL union in membership, made it plain today that Mr. Green was not speaking for the teamsters politically and could not dictate the big union's policy regarding the Dewey-Warren ticket.

About 12,000 physicians turned up in Chicago last week to attend the annual meeting of the American Medical Association, which lasted five days. It was not a meeting that brought out exciting medical and surgical news. Probably most of the physicians and surgeons in attendance learned more from the manufacturers' exhibits on Navy Pier than from the papers that were presented.

THOSE who imagine that contemporary Eire is a mixture of James Joyce and John Jameson, of farmers and pixies, will be pleasantly surprised by Olivia Robertson's hilarious, if too wordy, account of it in "Field of a Stranger."

TELEPHONES of the airline, railroad and bus reservation offices kept giving the busy signal last week, additional proof that the Fourth of July rush is about to begin. Operating officials were as busy as the reservation clerks, rounding up extra equipment of all vintages to meet the anticipated record-breaking demand of the long, three-day weekend.

In The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, Tracy .B. Augur, past president of the American Institute of Planners, suggests that if we break up our large cities into clusters of small towns separated by a few miles of open country, much could be done to reduce the destruction that atomic-bombs could wreak.

IN his fifty-fourth year Count Folke Bernadotte of Sweden is slight of figure, erect in bearing and has the manner of a diplomat of the old school. His blue eyes gleam with sincerity and purpose but not with the blazing fire of a zealot. He is a tolerant man. His graying hair grows far back from his forehead, emphasizing the intellectual character of his countenance.
CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- The league-leading Cleveland Indians bounced back into winning strides today as Bob Muncrief blanked the Washington Senators with three singles for a 5 to 0 triumph.

No attempt was made yesterday to resume the search among refuse on a city garbage scow for a package said to contain $1,000,000 worth of narcotics. William Stevenson, superintendent of the garbage dump at Fresh Kills, Staten Island, where the scow is docked, said it was unlikely the sifting of garbage would continue unless an order to do so was received from the Federal Government.
Here are opinions of Governor Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for the Presidency, on important issues as expressed in his speeches and public statements in the past year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 26 -- A fire captain was killed and four rescue workers were injured this afternoon while fighting a spectacular fire in an old frame hotel half a mile from the heart of this resort city. The fire started at 3:20 P.M. and brought out every piece of apparatus here and some from adjacent communities. Seventy-five guests escaped unharmed.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 26 -- Another tie-up of overseas vessels has started in Auckland and is thought in shipping circles here to mark the beginning of an "inevitable showdown" between the Government and the Waterside Workers Union.

MORMONS and Mormon communities have provided material for a rather large body of contemporary writing, fiction and non-fiction. Blanche Cannon's book is a novel which develops around the events leading up to and occurring on a Sunday morning in Lakeville, Utah, in 1900.
Dr. Bayard Dodge is retiring as president of the American University in Beirut, Lebanon, after holding that office for twenty-five years, it was reported here yesterday.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 26 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans took the National Collegiate baseball title West for the second straight year as they whipped Yale, 9 to 2, in the deciding game of their three-game series today. Yale had evened the series by winning the opener of today's doubleheader, 8 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor declared after a fifteen-minute call on President Truman today that the federation would never support the Republican ticket of Governors Dewey and Warren.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 26 (AP) -- With the British Open Golf championship tournament only two days off, America's Frank Stranahan was more feared and respected than any amateur since Bobby Jones achieved his grand slam in 1930.

PARIS, June 26 -- The proposal of W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at large for the Marshall Plan, that European nations benefiting from the program should themselves agree upon allotments, will be discussed when the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation assembles here July 8.

GENEVA, June 26 -- Now that the European Governments and the Economic Cooperation Administration are face to face with the problems involved in making the recovery program work, several relatively neglected aspects of the European economic picture are beginning to be studied more seriously.

SOME weeks ago there were no complete recordings of Brahms' German Requiem available; now there are two. The Victor version was discussed in this column a fortnight ago. The Columbia recording has arrived and its turn is in order.

"SOUTH WIND BLOWS" concerns the lynching of a young Negro and the Mississippi people who were concerned with it. The fact that lynching is a commonplace of the Southern literary scene in the twentieth century does not reduce its status as the most barbarous and perverted of the many facets of what we presumptuously call American civilization,

ALFRED MORANG'S "Adventure in Drawing" is a study planned for student and teacher alike. As the author says, "Drawing is the art of surrounding an idea with a line in order to communicate that idea to the observer." With this in mind, the author has taken the difficult task of presenting the two sides of drawing, realistic and abstract, and gone on to show the union between the two.

FOR his latest novel, Mr. Sender has turned again to the Spanish Civil War, to the early days of it, when everything anyone could believe in seemed to be at stake (one way or the other) in the suburbs of Madrid, before we all got used to seeing capitals seized half a dozen at a time.

ROME, June 26 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italy's Communist chief, just back from a trip behind the "iron curtain," declared tonight that the nation's 2,500,000 Communists would wage an all-out fight against the European Recovery Program.

Preliminary results of psychological and aptitude tests given to 400 selling employee of Bloomingdale's indicate that the store is well on the way toward developing a standardized objective method of determining fitness of applicants for sales positions, James P. Mitchell, vice president in charge of personnel and industrial relations, disclosed in an interview last week.

Although garment manufacturers will have a wider variety of fabrics for fall lines than has been available for some years, they are faced with the prospect of high textile prices for initial fall requirements, it was pointed out last week. Suppliers at primary and converting levels are holding firm even though manufacturers' orders reflect considerably less yardage than was bought at this point a year ago.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 26 -- The Navy today lifted a small corner of the veil of secrecy shrouding one of its most closely guarded lines of research -- the aiming of guided missiles by "automatic celestial navigation."

LORD MACAULAY would have liked to review such a book as this * * * in, say, fifty thousand words, using the text only as pretext for his own treatise on the subject. It would be hard to conceive of a nobler subject than the essential unity of this civilization, which outlives nations and transcends disunities.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 -- Trader Bedford, black gelding owned by Arthur M. Nardin of New York City, today maintained a slight lead in the jumping competition at the Fairfield County horse show on the grounds of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 26 -- Playing. sub-par golf for sixteen holes, Carl Hoffman and Harold O'Brien of North Hempstead eliminated the medalists, Ed Luchs and George Stuhr Jr. of the Garden City Country Club, 3 and 2, in the quarter-final round of the Sands Point member-guest alternate shot tournament today.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., June 26 -- The Seventy-seventh Infantry Division theoretically was on the west bank of the Seine River, between Vernon and Pacy-sur-Eure, tonight, prepared to force a crossing at dawn, when the reserve officers and enlisted men under command of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler ended the first day of their "paper war" command post exercise here.

RUMSON, N.J., June 26 -- Amber Boy Lancer of Stonywall, a 3-year-old brown standard poodle belonging to Lyla D. Murphy of Basking Ridge, N.J., came up through the classes to take his first best-in-show in the annual all-breed event of the Monmouth County Kennel Club today.

THIS generous volume contains forty-five stories, sketches and excerpts from novels-in-progress by thirty-eight young American authors who have attended professional writing courses at Manhattan's aggressively experimental New School for Social Research.

PETER PAINTER of the Miami Beach police has an idea that Mike Shayne knows more than he should about the theft of a bracelet of star rubies belonging to Mrs. Mark Dustin. All that Mike knows is that he saw Dustin buy the bracelet for a staggering sum of money and overheard Mrs. Dustin's plans to wear it for the first time on a certain occasion.

BERTOLT BRECHT'S poetry immediately suggests various attitudes which one might adopt toward it. This is disconcerting, because there is something, compelling about each of these attitudes, and, once adopted, it is very difficult to see Brecht in any other way.

PARIS, June 26 -- Replying to questions from the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Assembly today Foreign Minister Bidault said the French Government was willing to join in negotiations concerning Berlin or the future of Germany but would not take the initiative for such talks.

DULUTH, Minn., June 26 -- Toward the end of next week, Pickands, Mather Co. of Cleveland will write a supplementary chapter in metallurgical history when its new $1,700,000 plant at Aurora, fifty miles north of here, starts quantity production of iron pellets fashioned from magnetic taconite ores of the great Mesabi Range.
BERLIN, June 26 (AP) -- American soldiers in an armored car and a jeep chased Marshal Sokolovsky for two miles tonight before they arrested him for speeding.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 26 -- A third law on currency reform in Western Germany was announced today by the United States, British and French Military Governors. It proclaims a conversion rate of one new Deutsche mark for ten old Reichsmarks.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 -- This one-time frontier gateway to the West has a dream that could make it one of the world's most beautiful cities.

DENVER, June 26 -- Public relations leaders of 300 American colleges and universities agreed here this week that higher education can play a vital postwar role in reducing the tensions that have divided the world.

GARDENS achieve a very individual look when pointed up with well-chosen accessories. These are so varied in form and use that no two settings need be alike. The majority of these added features are as practical as they are attractive.

I AM amazed! For once a motion-picture producer has the courage and artistic integrity to produce a picture ("The Time of Your Life") off the beaten track, to faithfully transpose a prize-winning play into a fine human picture and you say it "sinks very slowly in its own sand right up to its cauliflower ears."

Stymie, the people's choice, scored one of the most sensational victories of his remarkable 123-race career yesterday. He took the $28,800 Aqueduct Handicap for the second year in succession and put the name of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs on the roster of winning owners in the stake for the fourth time.

Discussing further the exemption from income tax of United States citizens residing in foreign countries, it should be noted primarily that a citizen, regardless of his place of residence, within or without the United States, is generally taxable on all his income without regard to the place of its origin.

BERLIN, June 26 -- United States airpower throughout Europe is being mobilized for a great shuttle service into besieged Berlin. United States aircraft, which four years ago brought death to the city, will bring life in the form of food and medicines to the people of the Western sectors, whose food supplies have been cut off by the Russians.

To revise regulations to conform with the Gearhart amendment to the Social Security Act, passed by Congress recently over President Truman's veto, conferences are scheduled in Washington during the coming week between the Federal Security Agency's Bureau of Old Age and Survivors Insurance and the Treasury Department's Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Heavy industries were still trying to find out, at the end of the week, the exact meaning of the plant seizure and felony punishment provisions of the industrial allocation sections of the Selective Service Act of 1948.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- Naming Russia as the only possible aggressor against Canada, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton in a speech in the House of Commons this week set down this country's present defense aims and objectives as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Truman signed today the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act but with "regret" because of its "serious defects."

Retail activity last week was very good despite rainy weather, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Moderate price dress, sportswear and umbrella departments reported highest sales.

BELGRADE, June 26 -- The Yugoslav press injected a perhaps significant element into the Greek question today as the Greek Government forces in their Grammos drive appeared to draw closer to the Albanian frontier. Front-page headlines of the official paper, Politika, covering six reports concerning Greece, charged:

DURING the last days of March, 1945, the Allies launched their final and greatest offensive in the war against the Germans. The Rhine crossing for the first time made the Wehrmacht reel like a punch-drunk boxer -- unable either to duck or parry -- and Supreme Commander Dwight Eisenhower's prediction that the war would be won east of the swift, muddy river was becoming a fact.
The ten New York State teachers colleges that now prepare students for general elementary school teaching are to offer intensive training programs for college graduates.

THERE'S dirty work afoot at the suburban home of Mike Sommerville, ex-jazzman, now owner of a musical instrument factory. No explanation is forthcoming from his wife, Marge regarding events in which she seems to be involved.

Collective bargaining as now practiced is a failure. The promises made by its sponsors are completely untrue. It is the way to economic war and revolution rather than to labor peace and prosperity as promised.

A nation-wide campaign for noncompliance with the draft law unless President Truman issues an executive order against segregation was announced yesterday by A. Philip Randolph, chairman of the newly organized League for Non-Violent Civil Disobedience Against Military Segregation.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- West Coast aircraft manufacturers, holding the bulk of the Government's new air-defense contracts, swung into their billion-dollar task this week amid a disquieting flurry labor unrest.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Winding their way through miles of scientific and technical exhibits on Chicago's huge Navy Pier, 12,000 physicians and 18,000 exhibitors and guests during this last week of the 101st annual meeting of the American Medical Association saw literally a "World's Fair of Medicine."

Herman T. Stichman, Governor Dewey's Commissioner of Housing, predicted yesterday that the next Congress would pass legislation providing for Federal grants-in-aid to states to encourage public housing.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Tiny Bonham kept seven hits well scattered and Frankie Gustine connected safely four times for eight bases as the Pirates trounced the top-place Braves by 7 -- 1 tonight before 31,490 fans. The setback reduced Boston's lead to a half-game over the Cardinals.
TEL AVIV, June 26 -- Moshe Shertok, Foreign Minister of Israel, summed up the situation in this six-weeks-old state when he said, "We just go from one crisis to another."

ROME, June 26 -- The communique issued at the end of the Warsaw conference by the Soviet bloc shows that Moscow insists on attempting to achieve unilateral aims instead of participating in international cooperation for Europe's reconstruction, I'Osservatore Romano said tonight.

There are 3,500,000 persons in Berlin -- 2,250,000 in the sectors occupied by the Western powers, the rest in the Russian sector. Last week, in their war-wrecked city that was once the Continent's largest capital, Berliners were caught squarely in the middle of the most critical phase in the struggle between Russia and the West for control of all Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Iewis B. Hershey, wartime draft head, said tonight that registrations under the new peactime draft law probably would begin Aug. 16. He said that the 19-through-25 draft would be put in operation as soon as President Truman signed the law granting the money.

AMATEUR photographers who are disappointed by the preponderance of bad weather this year should not despair. Overcast skies, rainy days, and fog or mist can be more useful for some picture subjects than good sunlight, open skies and a clear atmosphere.

VIVID spikes of bloom appear this month on the dark green plants of Russell lupines. In a season when other flowers may look bedraggled and beaten, these perennials have retained crisp, colorful flowers and have straight, sturdy upright branches.

BERLIN. AFTER a century and three-quarters during which his status varied from a joke to a nuisance, the American in Europe finds himself clothed with a new dignity. He is, whether he likes it or not, a political force. For today there are more Americans in Europe than ever before in peacetime and they are more closely linked than ever before with the economic, political and cultural life of the Continent.

In the spring of 1946 Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York laid his plans to win the Presidential nomination in June, 1948. The Governor knew he faced a formidable task. He had been beaten for the Presidency by Franklin Roosevelt in 1944, and never in its history had the GOP renominated a Presidential also-ran.

Every bill which shall have passed the House of Representatives and the Senate shall * * * be presented to the President of the United States; if he approve, he shall sign it, but if not, he shall [veto it].

The New York Housing Authority is planning to float bonds to finance without cash subsidy a $200,000,000 housing program for veterans covering fifteen or sixteen projects and 17,000 apartments, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the Authority said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 --After the era of limitless forests when West Coast timber owners logged off their lands without regard to future needs, this part of the country is viewing with concern the subject of forest resources and is doing something about it.

AS a writer of satiric and comic stories, Evelyn Waugh remains unmatched among modern writers. Had "Decline and Fall" "Vile Bodies," "Scoop." "A Handful of Dust" and "Put Out More Flags" never been written, "The Loved One" alone would validate the claim. Mr. Waugh brings important equipment to an important arid almost deserted field.

Paul Blanshard, former Commissioner of Accounts, whose articles in The Nation criticizing alleged policies of the Roman Catholic Church led the Board of Superintendents to ban the magazine from the public school library list of periodicals, charged yesterday that the board's action resulted from "censorship" by "the Catholic hierarchy."

LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) -- Australia gained a 478-run lead over England in the second test cricket match at Lords today, the third day of the five-day match. The tourists added a second-innings score of 343 for four wickets by close of play to their first innings total of 350, to which England had replied with 215.

The Board of Transportation received yesterday the first of 100 vending machines to be used inside subway stations to dispense 2-cent transfers to surface lines. The machines, which are of the pedestal type, have a capacity of 6,000 transfers each.

WASHINGTON. THE American people are today in the midst of one of those exhilarating periods in which self-government is their chief interest. In the drama of national party conventions the traditional excitement and intensity are heightened by ultra-modern touches of television, radio and newspaper coverage that seem to bring the selection of Presidential nominees right into the home of almost every American family.

Putting forth their best efforts in a final tune-up for the national championships and semi-final Olympic tryouts at Milwaukee next week, New York's track and field athletes broke four meet records yesterday in the fifty-ninth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. championships.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26 -- (AP) Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, said today that "without freedom of the press our whole system of political freedom would disappear."
LUTON, June 26 (AP) -- Winston Churchill today warned Britain to sheer away from appeasement in the Berlin crisis with Russia.

The Surrogate's Court of New York County is considered one of the most powerful bodies in the state. It has virtually complete jurisdiction over wills, estates and guardians, controls the passage of wealth from one generation to the next. Approximately every fifty years all the money and property in the county pass through the hands of the Surrogates.

ATHENS, June 26 -- The twin aims of United States Mediterranean policy appear to be progressing with more conscious coordination today in Greece than at any time since that policy first hesitantly emerged in the form of the Truman Doctrine.
MULCHING is on the calendar of chores for the next week or so. Nearly all of the tall-growing perennial flowers, roses, shrubs, fruits and vegetables will grow well if given this treatment.

THE announcements of the the forthcoming Berkshire Music Festival and of the opening of Dr. Koussevitzky's Berkshire Music Center, which is scheduled for next Wednesday, have a particular significance at this stage in the conductor's career.

THE summer camping season is on, and thousands of young readers will be looking for baseball books to tuck into their suitcases and duffel bags as they head for the country. Each of these books will prove satisfying to such young people, to the stay-at-homes and to their fathers.

PERENNIAL asters are good plants to acquire now if a lack of bloom is expected in the late summer and fall. They are to be found at local nurseries, and when set out, even at this late date, will make enough headway during the warm months to provide quite a display from September to November.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 26 -- High praise for President Truman m2rked today's session of the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

PORTLAND Ore. -- Down the long picturesque course of the Columbia River recently swept the most damaging flood crest in the history of the Pacific Northwest. How will this affect the summer's travel and recreation in a region famous for its outdoor appeal?

THIS solid, informative and very readable history of the American novel is an excellent contribution to modern scholarship. There are about a dozen similar works in circulation today, all the way from Carl Van Doren's standard survey, "The American Novel," to George Snell's recent interpretative study, "The Shapers of American Fiction."

IN this absorbing biographical narrative of the Zulu woman Christina, the first of sixty-five wives of the monarch Solomon, Rebecca Hourwich Reyher, an experienced American journalist, has created an effective picture of everyday life in a Zulu community.
The President's signature last week of the draft and of the service appropriation bills for the fiscal year starting July 1 set in motion the largest peacetime armaments program in our history.

Miss Barbara Wilkins of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Mrs. Elfi Carroll of Forest Hills, L.I., seeded first and third, respectively, yesterday reached the final of the New York State women's tennis championships at the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club in Queens.

THIS generous collection reveals both the strength and the weakness of Miss Brown's writing for young children. A few of these forty-two stories and poems are so tenuous that they would blow right off the page were it not for the author's characteristic manipulation of words and rhymes.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Wheat prices continued to slide toward the Government loan level today. Hedging pressure was one factor in the downturn, as were trade reports of much better than expected yields from the rapidly expanding Kansas harvest.

THE big tiger leaped a fence of steel wire, spitting and roaring, and crashed into a pit in the floor of the stage not meant for him at the moment. The spry little woman with yellow hair bound up in a net and wearing a Tahitian shirt tucked into black slacks didn't hesitate an instant.

SEVENTEEN years (and twenty-one pictures) later, the blonde bombshell that came out of Germany and the UFA studios via "The Blue Angel" to captivate the American male allowed that she had come to some conclusions about life and Hollywood.

WHEN, in 1795, Kant published his famous essay "Zum Ewigen Frieden," "Towards Eternal Peace," he was expressing the faith of a revolutionary, optimistic, all-conquering middle class in the possibility of permanent peace based on both reason and mutual interest.

The Republican National Convention may have created a deceptive appearance of unity when it gave its unanimous endorsement to Governor Thomas E. Dewey for the Presidency and followed this up, at Governor Dewey's suggestion, by the nomination, by acclamation of Governor Earl Warren of California for the Vice Presidency.

Television made its convention debut in 1940 when Wendell Willkie was nominated by the GOP. This year the proceedings were more elaborate. There were instructions such as "take the toothpick out of your mouth," "keep your clothes neat," "don't take off your shoes."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Charges of treachery and secret deals with the enemy were leveled at the Provisional Government of Israel today by the American League for a Free Palestine, an organization closely associated with Irgun Zvai Leumi, dissident Zionist political group in Palestine.

Three hundred relatives of war dead from the New York area attended ceremonies yesterday on Pier 3 at the Brooklyn Army Base honoring war dead brought back to this country from France on the transport Greenville Victory. The 11 A.M. service followed the docking of the ship with 3,700 bodies.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 26 -- Irving (Moon) Mondschein, New York University star now campaigning in the colors of the Pioneer Club, gained the jump over a field of nineteen rivals today as the first half of the National A.A.U. decathlon championship was completed at Foley Field.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- The second-place Athletics beat the White Sox, 4 -- 2, before a ladies' day crowd of 5,577 persons today. They remain a game behind pace-setting Cleveland in the American League. It was the Mackmen's fifth straight victory and their sixth triumph in seven games against Chicago.

America's leading billion dollar industries using aluminum are now looking to Canadian sources to make up the growing deficiencies in domestic aluminum production now being created by cut-backs in power supplies to American producers, metal refiners revealed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Democrats will name their last national convention delegates next week. There are signs of weakening in the opposition to President Truman's nomination.

Influences which have been at work for nearly two decades transforming the high-grade investment market from a liquid public exchange into a special trade accommodation for professional investing institutions were felt last week with special intensity in the financial marketplace.

INFINITE variety produced from a multiplicity of uniform units is the essence of all modular systems, whether applied to bricks, to window panes, or to furniture. The modular idea is simply that of combining pieces having certain standard dimensions in common. An individualized design such as a Hepplewhite sideboard may be reproduced in a score of variations but the general aspect and the function remain substantially the same.

Interest in financial markets was diverted last week from stocks and the emphasis was placed on politics. As a result, prices moved irregularly for the greater part of the period. While sentiment for equities varied widely, there was no lack of confidence.

Two concerns are planning two series of anthologies dealing with regional Americana. Dutton will bring out on Nov. 12 "The Virginia Reader: A Treasury of Writings From the First Voyages to the Present," collected by Francis Coleman Rosenberger.

The delegates to the Republican convention did not give much thought to the crisis in Berlin. They talked of the Soviet threat, of the possibility of trouble, but in the detached, absent-minded way of people who did not really believe in it. Berlin was far away from Philadelphia -- as far as Philadelphia must have seemed to the besieged Americans in our easternmost outpost in Europe.

In its first change of ownership since 1900, the five-story apartment house for ten families at 413 East Ninetieth Street was sold by Linus C. Molz to investors who will occupy one of the apartments. It was held at $15,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $7,000, taken back by the seller for eight years at 4 1/2 per cent.

It took seven months, but Irene Selznick, producer of "A Streetcar Named Desire," has been sustained by the American Federation of Musicians in her appeal from the union's decision that she hire three extra musicians. The original ruling last December classified "Streetcar" as a play with music requiring eight musicians instead of the five it uses for atmospheric and bridging effects.

BERLIN, June 27 (AP) -- British transport officials said today that four barges loaded with flour for the German population had arrived and another twenty were "in the pipeline." They said they had no explanation why the Russians were permitting a few barges to pass after a thorough inspection at the zonal boundary and yet were halting all land traffic.

ROME, June 27 -- The bells of Rome's 400 churches tolled today while Italian Government officials and high church dignitaries gathered under the portico of San Lorenzo Outside the Walls for the unveiling of a five-ton block of white marble designed to be a permanent memorial to what I'Osservatore Romano called the generosity and charity shown by Pius XII soon after the first bombing of Rome on July 19, 1943.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 27 -- Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, co-chairman of the American Zionist Emergency Council, received today the 1948 Brith Sholom National Annual Award for Humanitarianism at the opening session of the forty-second annual convention here of the Independent Order Brith Sholom.

PEIPING, June 26 (Delayed) -- Goaded on by the inflation and the needs of his big family, 88-year-old Chi Pai-shih, "The Chinese Gauguin," is turning out mile-a-minute masterpieces here on a mail order basis and selling them by the square foot.

Stand on the bank of a river, brook or creek and watch the land's rich, brown blood sweep onward to the sea. Not in the northland where the hills are wooded, not where sloping fields and pastures are thick with strong-stemmed grasses. Not where plows turn ribbons of soil on the curve following the natural contours and where intervening bands of green check the running water.
As if the Cardinals weren't tough enough, the Dodgers yesterday had to cope with darkness and rain -- and they lost on all counts.
