A pioneer attempt to measure the effects of various psychological counseling techniques in helping individuals cope with their emotional problems was announced yesterday by the Jewish Family Service, nationally known for its development of casework technique.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP) -- With Johnny Sain keeping eight hits well scattered, the Boston Braves romped to a 9-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today before 17,648 fans and held their slim lead over the Cardinals in the flag race.

DETROIT, June 27 -- The Yankees, with Tommy Byrne tossing a crackling two-hitter, brought their second western tour of the year to a triumphant close today by drubbing Steve O'Neill's Tigers, 7 to 0, before a gathering of 35,840 on-lookers who did not seem to relish any part of it.

Actors Equity will launch a campaign tomorrow among all members of the theatrical industry for the support of a series of economic surveys to improve the fortunes of "this most desperately threatened theatre business." The proposed studies, covering a two-year period, might cost as much as $360,000.

Formal pension and retirement plans were found to be in operation in 97 per cent of companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board, the organization announced over the weekend. The board said that approximately seven out of every ten reporting concerns have a compulsory retirement policy.

ROME, June 27 -- Social reforms can be achieved only if they are based on the law of God and on Christian principles and if they are carried out by men who truly are animated by the Christian spirit, Pope Pius XII said today.

One hundred and fifty thousand workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry will start a two-week vacation Friday, it was announced yesterday by Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 27 -- John White again sailed the Shillelah to victory in the second division Star Class race at the Noroton Yacht Club today.

PARIS, June 27 -- There were indications today that the French Government hoped that the consultations among the Western powers over the Berlin struggle would lead to one more attempt to negotiate with the Soviet Union at the Foreign Ministers level and that the three Western Allies would suggest this to Moscow.

MATSUSHIMA, Japan, June 27 -- All combat units of the United States Army of Occupation in Japan are being progressively transformed into airborne or "air transported" troops to extend their potential range of action and striking power.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 27 -- Home runs produced the key tallies this afternoon as the Buffalo Bisons split a double-header with the Newark Bears.

One of the most irritating specimens of homo sapiens, said our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn as he dropped by this corner the other day, seating himself and removing a set of earplugs he was wearing, is the townsman who says that the country is a nice place to visit but that he wouldn't care to live there because it's too quiet.

LONDON, June 27 -- The gravity of the situation in Berlin is almost completely overshading financial markets. Coming on top of the serious dock strike in London and of many other factors making the investment outlook extremely cloudy, the stock markets have followed a steadily downward course from which there appears to be no immediate prospect of release.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Bob Mathias, 17-year-old Tulare, Calif., high school student, became the national A.A.U. decathlon champion today and earned the right to head the United States Olympic team of three all-around athletes in London this summer.

The Supreme Court in 1944 decided that insurance was interstate commerce. On July 1 the insurance industry becomes subject to the anti-trust laws, except to the extent that it is regulated by state authority.

ROME, June 27 -- The left-wing Socialist party, which suffered a crushing defeat in the general election last April, opened its twenty-seventh party congress this morning in Genoa, where the Italian Socialist party was founded fifty-six years ago.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 27 -- The city of Asbury Park was proud of its mile-long display of state flags, unfurled yesterday to the sea breezes in a "Salute to the States" ceremony on the boardwalk. They were taken down for the night, but at 6 A.M. today Joseph Barr, boardwalk superintendent, assembled his men to raise the banners in what is to be a permanent display.

In your editorial of June 12 you state that "the major question now to be faced is whether the United Public Workers, Local No. 1, which boast of its large influence among welfare employes, will cooperate sincerely in the mandatory search for efficiency. The truth is that our organization's efforts to improve the department's functioning have been rejected by the present and past Commissioners.

Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, strongly denounced yesterday the American League for a Free Palestine -- supporters of Irgun Zvai Leumi -- asserting that the League and its officials "have incited rebellious elements to mutiny against the Government of Israel."

LONDON, June 27 -- Only Communists or fellow-travelers denounce the United States by asserting that it seeks to gain control over Europe, Prime Minister Attlee said today in an address to a huge mass meeting at Skegness in Lincolnshire.

The colorful midsummer festival of the Central Committee of Finnish Societies of Greater New York in Central Park Mall was cut short yesterday afternoon by rain. Many of the 2,500 spectators stayed on to hear the music and speeches, ducking under trees and umbrellas.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A report that wheat crop prospects are less favorable in the Soviet Union than last year despite increased acreage was made today by the Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations of the Department of Agriculture.

BERLIN, June 27 -- As privation closed around the people of the Western sectors of Berlin Bishop Otto Dibelius, ranking Protestant prelate in this city, leveled a bitter attack on those who endangered the food supplies of the people and severed their connections with the Western world.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The position of president of Montgomery Ward Co., which has been held by three persons in eight years, will not be filled under the present executive arrangement, it has been learned authoritatively.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., June 27 -- Once upon a time, long before the coming of the Gift Shoppe or even the artists, this town was famous for its fishermen and fish stories. And on very special occasions the Portuguese fishermen still contribute a new bit of lore for the wide eyes of youngsters just learning to scamper up the foremast.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., June 27 -- The Seventy-seventh Infantry Division completed today its two-day command post exercise -- a river crossing against heavy enemy resistance. The crossing was theoretical, but the 450 reserve officers and 100 enlisted men who participated in the "CPX" made all the plans, wrote the messages, transmitted orders and information and kept the records that would be involved in the actual operation.

The inability to find adequate housing is an added source of conflict for young married couples, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, assistant chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

GREENVILLE, S.C., June 27 -- The controversial issue of granting party primary voting privileges to Negroes in the South is being highlighted in this state with overtones which make it the focal point of socio-political interest in Dixie.

Plans will be initiated this week for an industry-wide meeting before the Federal Trade Commission in August to consider adoption of Fair Trade Rules for promotion and sale of shrink-resistant compounds for woolens, and for fabrics and end use products treated with these compounds, the American Wool Council announced over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, today described the selection of Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania as his Republican counterpart as another victory of "high-tariff loving Joe Grundy" (Joseph R. Grundy, former Senator from Pennsylvania) at last week's Republican convention.
TIENTSIN, China, June 20 (Delayed) -- The city fortifications are being strengthened here.

LONDON, June 27 -- In recent weeks the note circulation of the Bank of England has been more stable than at any time since the decline first started nearly a year ago. Since August 1947, there has been a fall of more than 172,000,000, but it would seem that most of the abnormal factors responsible for this movement have now spent themselves and that a truer trend of circulation is now becoming apparent.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 27 -Walter F. White, executive secretary, of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today criticized Governor Dewey as having played politics with civil rights measures. He spoke at the association's convention.
GENEVA, Monday, June 28 (AP) -- While coal production declined throughout Europe in May, Britain exported more than 1,000,000 metric tons during the month, for the first time since the war.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 27 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis concluded today its fifty-ninth annual convention, which was marked by a revolt against secularization of Jewish community life.

LONDON, June 27 -- Plans for the joint defense of Western Europe, which the military experts of Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have been discussing here for the last ten weeks, are being seriously impaired by a lack of close coordination with United States military thinking, according to informed sources.

ATHENS, June 27 (AP) -- A Greek Government communique today said Communist-led guerrillas had been beaten off by regular army troops as the rebels attempted to cut off the Yanina-Preveza road on the southwest flank of the Army's Grammos offensive.

A three-day seminar for the 161 men and women who will direct the summer playstreet and playground program of the Police Athletic League will open today at the PAL headquarters annex, Second Avenue and Second Street, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, director of the league, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- Edgar H. Rossbach, whose unexplained resignation as United States Attorney for New Jersey on May 24 was followed by reports that his retirement had been requested and that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a representative of the Attorney General's office were making inquiries here, announced today that he would discuss the situation in an interview tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 27 -- Commanders of Israel's new Zavah Haganah (Army of Defense), most of them members of the old Haganah, swore allegiance today to the Army and the State, and for the first time officially came above ground.

The many brief references in the press to the inaction of the Eightieth Congress on civil fights legislation do not expose the abjectness of its surrender on this issue. The failure of the Democratic Administration to implement the recommendations of the President's Committee on Civil Rights was conclusively shown in a letter from former Solicitor General Henry Epstein published on May 9.

LONDON, June 27 -- The unofficial dock strike, which has paralyzed London's vast port, enters its third week tomorrow. The Government has now massed 6,000 soldiers, sailors, marines and airmen to unload the 152 ships tied up by the refusal of the dockers to obey their union leaders, but no one can say tonight whether they will be needed or not.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 27 -- A privately financed, low-cost Negro housing project that is believed to be the largest single development of its kind ever approved in the South was dedicated in formal ceremonies today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 27 -- A goal by Charley Leonard in the closing minute of play enabled the Brookville polo team to defeat Jericho, 8-7, on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club today. In another game, on the No. 4 field, Wheatley Hills and Old Westbury played to a 10-10 deadlock.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Athletics swept a double-header, 6 -- 5 and 6 -- 2, from the White Sox before 14,003 fans today. In pulling within 11 percentage points of first-place Cleveland, Carl Scheib allowed eleven hits in winning his fourth straight game in the opener before Dick Fowler gained his fifth triumph with an eight-hit performance in the curfew game.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 27 -- One thousand women gathered here today for the opening tomorrow of the twenty-seventh annual convention of Quota Club International. Sessions will continue through Tuesday.

With the current uncertainty of what lies ahead for retail stores, retailers are faced with the somewhat contradictory problem of building up sufficient aggressiveness to meet competition and still remain conservative enough in their stocks and merchandising plans to guard against being "badly hurt" in the event of swift changes in the economic picture.

Little Greenwich Mews Playhouse was sold out on Saturday night when the Lemonade Opera Company gave its double bill of "La Serva Padrona" and "Hansel and Gretel." Florence Forsberg and William Diehl, both new to the company, sang the name roles in the latter opera.

WESTERLY, R.I., June 27 -- More than 250 delegates to the Seventh Annual Tri-state Conference on Savings Bank Life Insurance were told at the closing session at Watch Hill here today that 264 of the nation's 533 savings banks now are selling life insurance and have in force policies for a record high aggregate of $475, 000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- There was an estimated $5,000,000 of added spending here during the Republican National Convention.

While the good burghers of the Flatlands section of Brooklyn slept yesterday morning, leisurely burglars invaded the kitchens in a row of one-family two-story houses and sat down to an early breakfast. Their meal consisted of roast chicken, spinach and cantaloupe.

LONDON, June 27 -- The next move of Britain, the United States and France to break the Berlin deadlock will be a joint diplomatic protest to the Soviet Union, it was learned here today. The protest is expected to be made some time this week.

Not since thousand-plane raids on Germany and Japan has the Air Force planned for an air armada like the one that will fly over New York on President's Day at the opening July 31 of the City's Golden Jubilee Air Show at Idlewild.

Unusual among summer confections, Festive fruit candies appear for the first time in retail stores today. They are jellied sweets that preserve exactly the savor of the fresh fruit that they resemble in shape. Usually such products are synthetically flavored.

A protest has been made to authorities in Singapore by the Textile Export Association of the United States, 271 Church Street, which charged that recent changes in Malayan regulations governing textile imports will tend to favor Japanese textiles to the detriment of American goods, it was disclosed over the week-end.
President Truman's quick approval of the draft act last week means that thousands of young Americans will be heading to training camps next September instead of college campuses.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Ted Williams and another round-tripper by Bobby Doerr powered the Boston Red Sex to a 6-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns after Joe Dobson had blanked the Browns, 2 to 0, on two hits in the first game of a double-header today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 27 -- Most German officials of the Bizonal Economic Administration support the idea of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, that the Western Allies should stay in Berlin despite any Russian action short of war.

If Christians "lived up to" their faith, the world soon would be convinced that Christianity was superior to communism, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist. Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday in his sermon there.

New York, the city of contrasts, finds little difficulty in achieving the impossible. Apartments are as scarce as hens in Manhattan -- teeth or no teeth. Yet, as the 8,000 units in Stuyvesant Town become available every day is moving day. There haven't been so many vans on the streets since the pre-war days when everybody moved rather than spring-clean.

Because the number of visitors at late night sailings of luxury liners has caused serious congestion, officials of Cunard White Star announced yesterday that a strict limit would be placed on future visiting at sailing time.

Vidov Dan, national Serbian holiday dedicated to the country's heroes of the last 500 years, was celebrated yesterday in the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street. King Peter II, exiled monarch of Yugoslavia who attended the service with his wife, Queen Alexandra, hold the congregation that "we wait the birth of a new day on which shall rise the sun of freedom to our suffering people."

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week continued to move irregularly. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from a decline of 70 points to an advance of 25 points.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Postponement to Sept. 15 of the enforcement of a new interpretation on overtime pay, resulting from a Supreme Court decision, was announced today by William R. McComb, administrator of the Department of Labor Wage and Hour Division.

The New York Shipping Association has called on the city's longshoremen to open a wage discussion under the existing contract in view of the Supreme Court's decision on "overtime on overtime" litigation.
ATHENS, June 27 -- A Yugoslav note to the Greek Government, published here today, indicated a flat refusal to return children allegedly abducted by the Greek guerrillas.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 27 -- Progress toward peace must be achieved on a spiritual basis, and it was on that basis that the United Nations was making real progress in preventing war, Warren R. Austin, chief United States representative to the United Nations, told a large congregation in the First Congregational Church here this morning.

The Citizens Committee on Displaced Persons issued a statement yesterday strongly condemning "the discriminatory features in the displaced persons legislation enacted in the last hours of Congress." The statement also called for "the earliest possible action to change the bill from a threat to democracy to a humanitarian measure worthy of the greatest nation on earth."

A 36-year-old woman charged yesterday that eleven youths had raped her after beating into unconsciousness her escort, Herman Graulich, 49. The attack took place at 3 A.M. in the deserted area facing the sea wall back of Believue Hospital at East Twenty-eighth Street.
Democratic labor leaders acknowledged yesterday that they had virtually abandoned hope of rounding up enough labor votes for President Truman to keep New York in the Democratic column this November.
There will be no formal ceremony to man the opening of New York International Airport at Idlewild on Thursday, the date set for its first operation.

One of the three men who allegedly stole $500 from the cashier of the Old Knick Music Hall, a night club at 1034 Second Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, was captured in West Fiftieth Street near Broadway shortly after 2 o'clock this morning after a wild pursuit across town.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 27 (AP) -- Miss Zoe Ann Olsen of Oakland, Calif., today captured the three-meter springboard diving championship for the third year in a row.

MIDDLE RIVER, Md., June 27 -- Guy Lombardo served a stern and formal warning this afternoon on Danny Foster, Dan Arena, Clell Perry, Mel Crook and every other Gold Cup driver in sight that he means business for 1948 and no foolin'.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 27 -- Ch. Bodie's Temptation, a 2-year-old Welsh terrier that Mrs. Edward P. Alker has been campaigning recently, gained her first best in show today in the event of the Staten Island Kennel Club, revived after two years and transplanted from its native heath to the MacWilliam Stadium here.

A sharp increase in fire hazards, insanitary conditions and other menaces to safety and health in the city's tenement and apartment houses has led the Department of Housing and Buildings to institute a new procedure beginning July 1 that will place a more direct responsibility on landlords for early correction of violations, it was announced yesterday.
Just before Congress adjourned, at an early hour on Sunday a week ago, the House and Senate reached agreement on a compromise agricultural aid bill.

The boating season is getting under way and reports of mishaps and tragedies already are coming in, making doubly valuable the timely advice and safety rules offered recently by the Greater New York Safety Council. "It is foolhardy," said Frank L. Jones, president of the Council, "to go out in a boat, whether as owner or guest, without assurance that the craft is safe and its equipment meets at least the minimum legal requirements.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- President John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers may have to go to court to defend the union-shop clause in his 1948 soft-coal contract, it was disclosed today.

More than $500,000 worth of former naval supplies, hardware and equipment in seventy-seven commercial lots will be opened to spot bids by all types of buyers at a sale to open at 10 A. M. today by the War Assets Administration at its Customer Service Center, Eastchester Road and Haswell Street, in the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has acquired screen rights to "Violet," a 1942 novel by Whitfield Cook, and has assigned the property to Robert Sisk, producer, for preparation as a prospective Margaret O'Brien vehicle.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -The Phillies and Cubs split a double-header today, the Cubs taking the opener, 6 -- 2, and the Phils annexing the nightcap, 7 -- 4, with the contest called after eight innings because of the Sunday curfew.

The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Saturday night at the Lewisohn Stadium, was conducted by Paul Lavalle, who had appeared twice before in the series in previous seasons. Vivian Della Chiesa, soprano, and Mac Morgan, baritone, who had not been heard at these concerts heretofore, were the soloists on a motley schedule of serious and popular offerings, which attracted an audience of 9,500 persons.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Improvements in financial appropriations for schools and in teachers' salaries, and security have resulted in the last year in various states from the efforts of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, a survey by that organization showed today.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 27 -- Representatives from five nations in the Soviet bloc and the new State of Israel were among the delegations to the second plenary assembly of the World Jewish Congress, which opened here today.

PAWLING, N.Y., June 27 -- Governor Dewey is planning an active and vigorous campaign as the Republican candidate for President despite the feeling among many party leaders and other political observers that his election is almost certain if President Truman is nominated by the Democrats to oppose him, as appears likely.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, which has been tore by internal strife for several years, will end on Wednesday what is probably the most important election in its history The Balloting of the union's 60,000 membership started on April 1

Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, his wife and three daughters arrived in New York yesterday on a sightseeing trip. Their main object, they said, is to see several Broadway shows.
PARIS, June 27 -- Two problems are under urgent study by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and by the Harriman mission in Paris.

SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., June 27 (UP) -- James Roosevelt, a frequent critic of the Truman Administration, was elected Democratic national committeeman today, succeeding Edwin W. Pauley. An expected battle failed to materialize when the California delegation to the Democratic National Convention organized.

Wounded veterans who still are patients in government hospitals need to be kept occupied. Their restoration to strength and health may be more rapid if this occupation is something that helps to fit them for a vocation or to give them a worth-while hobby to develop further when they return to normal community life.

The reason the United States is engaged in a diplomatic struggle with the Soviet Union, according to Andrei Y. Vishinsky's and A. S. Lozovsky's "Diplomatic Dictionary," is that the old world does not want to give way to the new without a fierce struggle using all kinds of weapons, bombs, provocative notes and ideological distortions of history.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- A potential vast production force and market are being overlooked, if not ignored, by American business in allowing Negro educational facilities to lag, Dr. Rufus E. Clement, president of Atlanta University, today told leaders in the United Negro College Fund campaign.

ZURICH, June 27 -- Liquidation of German assets in Switzerland, as provided for by the Washington agreement of May 25, 1946, is brought no nearer by the replacement in Germany of the old Reichsmark by the new Deutschemark, according to competent authorities in Berne.
I respectfully direct your attention to question No. 14 in the "Fifteen News Questions" appearing in THE TIMES on June 20.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 27 (AP) -- Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret won the Inverness four-ball matches by the greatest margin in the classic's eleven-year history today, and picked up a $3,500 check for four days of play against fourteen other play-for-pay stars.
The corridors of Carnegie Hall were the scene of shouted arguments and threatened fisticuffs last night during an intermission in a performance of Johann Strauss' operetta "The Gypsy Baron."

In training for the first East-West match for the National Challenge Cup in St. Louis on July 6, Brookhattan of this city, Eastern finalist, defeated an American Soccer League eleven composed of New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia players, 5 to 1, at Sterling Oval, Bronx, yesterday.

WINDSOR, Ont., June 27 -- Although new car shipments to Canadian dealers have been sharply cut this year by Government restrictions, Packard Motor Car Company of Canada, Ltd., is about to launch the heaviest service advertising campaign it has ever placed in Canadian newspapers, Fred C. Williams, general manager of the company, announced here today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Bulgaria's Minister to Washington, Dr. Nissim J. Mevorah, reported today that Bulgaria and Greece had tried but failed to agree on a means of resuming diplomatic relations.

When National League President Ford Frick arrives at his desk this morning he will find a telegram of protest from Mel Ott. Twice before this season Master Mel demurred on umpires' decisions, but because they involved discretion, both were denied.
Five new films, including an importation from Russia, will have premieres in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Department of the Air Force disclosed tonight that three squadrons of C-54 Skymasters, passenger and cargo-carrying aircraft, were being dispatched to Germany to increase air facilities for taking supplies into the United States sector of Berlin. Normally this would be thirty-nine planes.

Tammany leader Frank J. Sampson, and all the district leaders and co-leaders who attended the meeting at which General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente was designated as the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County will begin today a parade before one of the county's regular June grand juries.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 27 (AP) -- Hard-working Frank Stranahan, one of the best amateur golfers to come down the world's fairways since Bobby Jones, tested every club in his bag on the practice range today to sharpen his bid for the British open golf championship.
Failure of the European Recovery Program would bring a "strong drift to the East" in Europe, George H. Gardner, chief of the United States Relief Mission at Trieste, declared here yesterday.
For many years the City of New York has been plagued with an atmosphere burdened by excessive dirt, gases fumes, vapor, smoke, etc.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 27 -- Dr. G.B. Harrigan and Gordon Stott of North Hills rallied on the back nine to defeat Ferdinand Mayer and Ray Peterson of Plandome, 2 and 1, in the final of the Sands Point member-guest alternate shot tournament today.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- There was no let-up in steel demand last week. In most areas, this one included, steel requirements were still quite a distance ahead of supply. Steel sales people here look for no change in the tight picture for some time to come.

Both accumulated profits and the use of liquid assets have been used to a large extent in the financing of business during the last two years of record industrial activity, an analysis of the developments in business finance contained in the Federal Reserve Bulletin for June discloses.

Although prices of most of the fall soft goods lines were said to be in the higher brackets, spokesmen for the wholesale garment markets here last week forecast a substantial retail sales volume this fall, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- There was no let-up in steel demand last week. In most areas, this one included, steel requirements were still quite a distance ahead of supply. Steel sales people here look for no change in the tight picture for some time to come.

Both accumulated profits and the use of liquid assets have been used to a large extent in the financing of business during the last two years of record industrial activity, an analysis of the developments in business finance contained in the Federal Reserve Bulletin for June discloses.

Customers may now drop in at Modernage to look for a new sofa or buy an ashtray without having to duck under ladders. In the store a four-room house designed by Paul W. McCobb and furnished with Martin Feinman's Multiplex furniture has been completed and opens to the public today.

Action by Argentina in raising the peso value of the dollar and easing some restrictions on transfer of dollar earnings to this country was described by foreign trade spokesmen here last week as largely a "Peronist maneuver" to improve Argentina's bargaining position in negotiations for offshore purchases by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

AMSTERDAM, June 27 -- A new committee is engaged in investigating state intervention in business. The aim of this group, under an independent chairman, is to bring about almost complete ending of rationing at short notice.

With Mayor O'Dwyer scheduled to hold a public hearing on Wednesday on legislation increasing city taxes on general and financial business, the New York Board of Trade condemned the proposed increase yesterday as unjust and unnecessary.

TENNENT, N.J., June 27 -- The 170th anniversary of the Battle of Monmouth was commemorated this afternoon at services attended by 1,500 civilians and 400 soldiers from Fort Monmouth. The ceremony was held on the grounds of the Old Tennent Church, center of the Revolutionary War engagement and the site of a monument to the Continentals who lost their lives on June 28, 1778.

During the past week the foreign exchange market was only moderately active, with most transactions reported being mainly routine. Spot pound sterling maintained a steady tone at $4.03 3/16 @ 4.03 1/4. Discounts for "forwards" followed the lead of spot and moved within a narrow fractional range.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -- Golden Hill, noted chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., won the Fairfield County circuit conformation hunter grand championship by earning 71 points.

The Rev. W. Andrew James, pastor of the Purley Congregational Church, Surrey, England, spoke yesterday at the 11 A.M. service at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street. He asserted that the English people, "who thought only of motor cars and big houses before the war, are now beyond the five-finger exercises of memorizing Christian popularisms and are building new industries, new churches -- a new country on ruined premises."

" Winner Take All" is the latest regular radio series to win time in television, Thursday night at 9:30 o'clock being set for its debut as a weekly feature on the CBS video network. Bud Collyer will be master of ceremonies of the television version of the audience-participation program.

Events tonight: Gershwin program, Alexander Smallens, conductor, Todd Duncan, baritone, June McMechin, soprano, Earl Wild, piano, Eva Jessye Choir, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 o'clock: "La Serva Padrona" and "Hansel and Gretel," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 141 West Thirteenth Street, 8:30; Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, the Mall, Central Park, 8:30.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,526,819,022. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
Robert H. Seltzer, formerly with Bristol-Myers Company, has been appointed general sales manager of Windsor House, Ltd., maker of men's toiletries.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 27 -- The Sea Cliff Theatre will open tomorrow night a summer season of twelve weeks, with Buddy Ebsen, in "John Loves Mary," a comedy by Norman Krasna. Thomas G. Ratcliffe Jr. and William Hunt are sponsors of the project.

The overriding hope for a decent world of tomorrow are the children of tomorrow. And the truth is that over thirty million children and nursing mothers in Europe alone, and many millions more in the Far East, need emergency aid of every kind. That means, in the words of the health experts, "milk, more milk, and still more milk," then fats and cod liver oil and body-building meats.

Rubber consumption in May amounted to 87,826 tons, compared with 85,281 in April, an increase of about 3 per cent, according to a preliminary estimate released over the week-end by the Rubber Manufactures Association.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 27 -- One hundred and thirty-eight sailing craft, the top number of the season, took part today in the championship of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, its sixty-sixth annual regatta.

An experimental month - long program of musical therapy will start July 7 to benefit children and adult psychiatric patients at Kings County Hospital, the New York City Department of Hospitals and Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, announced yesterday.

The First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. announced jointly yesterday that the underwriting group which they head is proceeding with plans for a public offering this week of 600,000 shares of Permanente Metals Corporation's capital stock, despite possible litigation involving an affiliated company of Permanente.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Foreign Policy Association said today in a report on British rule in West Africa that "more and more" Africans would show increasing interest in Russia as they became better educated.

NEW DELHI, India, June 27 -- While Nawab Zain Yar Jung, Hyderabad's Agent General in New Delhi, was preparing today to reopen negotiations with the Indian Government, several disquieting developments were reported in the badly strained relations between the independent Princely State and the Indian Union.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Home runs by Allie Clark and Joe Gordon enabled the Cleveland Indians to defeat the Washington Senators, 4 to 1, today for an even split of a double-header before 35,980 fans. That meant the Indians retained a slender lead in the American League race, for Washington took the opener, 5 to 2.

Otis Co., investment banking house of Cleveland, announced yesterday that it would file suit in an effort to compel the Permanente Metals Corporation of Oakland, Calif., to return to the KaiserFrazer Corporation an aluminum plant leased to Permanente Metals by Kaiser-Frazer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -Enterprise has borrowed Barbara Bel Geddes from RKO for the leading role in "The Luckiest Girl in the World," a screen adaptation of Libby Block's 1946 novel, "Wild Calendar," which will go before the cameras July 8.

Ruth Gordon has decided to star in her own play, "The Leading Lady," which her husband Garson Kanin, is producing and directing. The actress has been more than a possibility for the title role, but the understanding was that she would go in only if the right actress was not available.

PRAGUE, June 28 -- The Communist Information Bureau denounced today Marshal Tito's leadership of Yugoslav Communists. The international Communist organization declared that Belgrade's Premier and other top members of the party must hew to the Moscow line or get out.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 28 -Thirty-eight paraplegic soft coal miners, all handicapped as a result of injuries suffered in collieries in the Appalachians, arrived here today for rehabilitation. They came cross-country by rail.

Hot weather recreation for 3,000,000 New York City children was promised by Superintendent of Schools William Jansen yesterday in announcement that 314 school playgrounds, 27 athletic fields and 44 swimming pools would be open during July and August.
LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) -Australia's cricketers today played themselves into a practically impregnable position in their second test match against England at Lords.

Reports which have just come to hand of the first session of the South Pacific Commission in Sydney, Australia, during May show that a good start has been made toward setting up a working group and outlining a program of research and information on that area of the world.

ROSLYN, L. I., June 28 -- Henry Ciuci of the Fresh Meadow Club shot an individual round of 70, par for the course, to finish 32, 33, 65 with Howard Fraser Jr., North Hills, and gain two of four places in a deadlock for first position in the amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Engineers Golf Club-today.

With the threat of a strike on Thursday morning still hanging over six privately owned Queens bus lines, Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri said last night that he hoped two labor disputes on the lines could be cleared up today.

The Health Department declared yesterday that not a single case of jaundice following a blood transfusion had been reported to it recently. The statement was made after publication of a report that jaundice, a liver malady that manifests itself by a yellowness of the skin, was being spread by infected blood plasma pools.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 28 (AP) -- Running the fastest six furlings of the meeting -1:10 2/5 -Galt Davis' Joshua today won his second straight race at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The advisory council of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will hold its first annual meeting from July 19 to 23 at its headquarters here, it was announced today by John J. McCloy, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., June 28 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, today submitted to both sides the highly tentative suggestions that he hoped would "lay a basis for a solution of the Palestine question," it was announced tonight.

Magistrate John E. Prendergast ruled yesterday in Lower Manhattan Court that "a prima facie case has not been made out" against three men charged with simple assault by Dr. Max Yergan, executive director of the Council on African Affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -Nearly 19,000,000 veterans received a disappointing answer to the $100 question today: It will be more than a year before refund checks are mailed out to holders of national service life insurance policies, the Veterans Administration announced.

Illuminable came on in the stretch to win the Frigate purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The five-anda-half-furlong feature event attracted a field of seven 2-year-old colts, with Illuminable, owned by E. P. Taylor, established the third choice behind B. F. Whitaker's favored Prince Quest and the King Ranch's Swap Out.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 -- Despite superficial harmony at the California Democrats' pre-convention conference this last week-end, there were indications tonight that a number of the state's delegates favored opposition to Presidenth)0*0*0*iTruman's nomination right from the start.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 28 -Final trials to select the representative United States six-meter sloop in the Olympic yachting competition to he held at Torbay, England, in August were started today by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 28 -Within Yugoslavia, internal problems, which have received little advertisement, are seriously bothering Marshal Tito's regime. An intense effort is being made to clean up some of these before Yugoslavia's Communist party -hitherto a quasi-clandestine organization -- stages its first public congress, revealing to the world, among other things, the ranking of its personal hierarchy.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 28 (AP) -- Fred Wampler of Purdue University and Tom Lambie of the host Stanford school, fired three-underpar 68s today to pace the field in the first qualifying round of the national collegiate golf championship.

Fletcher D. Richards, who had been president of Campbell-Ewald Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday, with Henry T. Ewald, chairman of the board, Campbell-Ewald, Inc., of Detroit, that the New York advertising agency had changed its name to Fletcher D. Richards, Inc.

MOSCOW, June 28 -- The newspaper Moscow Bolshevik demanded today that the city administration cope with fiftyfive independent taxi operators alleged to have made a practice of overcharging visitors from the country.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today allocated 12,120,000 pounds of fresh meat for commercial export during July, August and September, compared with 16,876,000 pounds for the same period last year.

BERLIN, June 28 -- A general conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on Germany, leading into a discussion of all major issues outstanding between East and West, is the unspoken objective of the present Russian pressure in Berlin.

Local Republicans, elated over appearances of Republican harmony and Democratic disunity, have begun to fight to win nominations for local office in districts where formerly candidates were implored to make the race for the good of the party.

The investigation begun yestday into charges that "bribes" were passed to members of the Tammany executive committee to influence them to vote for Judge Francis L. Valente for the Democratic nomination for aurrogate brought to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office several Tammany district leaders, headed by Tammany Leader Frank J. Sampson.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was weak early yesterday but closed at the best levels of the day, 10 points lower to 4 points higher than Friday's final prices.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 28 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, the Toledo amateur who wants to emulate the golfing deeds of Bobby Jones, had to take a back seat with the other "name" golfers today as oneh)0*0*0*iA. S. Tibbles, a virtually unknown pro from a suburban London course, set the pace with a 67 score in the British open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Grain marketsh)0*0*0*ion the Board of Trade showed today a heavy undertone in the early trading, with July wheat off around 1 cent, corn down 2 1/2 cents and oats off 1 1/2 cents. A late rally came when short covering in wheat brought few offerings.

BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Army and Navy amateur boxing teams dominated the opening action tonight in the final Olympic tryouts by qualifying five and four representatives respectively for the semi-finals before a slim crowd in the Boston Garden.

A business man being questioned in a routine proceeding by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein was recognized yesterday as a notorious stock swindler wanted, under an alias, in California for a securities fraud.

Two of Brooklyn's most active criminal lawyers have been cited by the Brooklyn Bar Association for "professional misconduct, malpractice, fraud, deceit and conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice," it became known yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -American official circles here are incensed at the peremptory and resentful tone taken by Indian spokesmen in demanding favored treatment by the United States in supplying capital goods and equipment to this country.

CINCINNATI, June 28 -- Showing a new line of twenty-five console, portable and table model radios, the Crosley Division, Avco Manufacturing Corporation, opened a three-day national distributor meeting here today. A third model in the Crosley line of television receivers was also displayed a mahogany finish table set with a twelve-inch screen.

The appeal of Daniel Lamont for an owner's license in 1948 was turned down by a board consisting of the three members of the New York State Racing Commission and two stewards of The Jockey Club, it was announced yesterday. The ruling was made at a joint meeting of the two bodies on June 19, but was not revealed until yesterday.
Small pillboxes and calots with shallow brims vied for interest with modified picture hats in Lenesta's fall millinery show, held yesterday afternoon in the salon at 15 East Fifty-third Street.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will begin production of table model television receiver with a sixteen-inch direct view cathode ray tube, giving a picture thirteen inches by ten inches, Benjamin Abrams, president, revealed yesterday.

" It's Always Albert," a situation comedy dealing with a wouldbe composer, will be offered over CBS at 8:30 P.M. Fridays, beginning this week. Arnold Stang will have the title and the supporting company will include Jan Murray and Pert Kelton.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- The Miami veteran, Gardnar Mulloy, and young Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., carried American hopes into the semi-final round of the Wimbledon tennis championships with sparkling victories today as two of their teammates, Tom Brown and Budge Patty, bit the dust on the center court.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Attorneys of the National Labor Relations Board, acting under orders of General Counsel Robert N. Denham, recommended today that an NLRB trial examiner find officers of the International Typographical Union guilty of unfair labor practices in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Your editorial of June 25 rightly points to the need for establishing adequate Western communication lines to Berlin. The fact that the Western Powers did not insist on an international highway and rail corridor to Berlin at the beginning of occupation in 1945 turned the city into a trap for the Allies.

Recreation and relaxation without leaving the city can be enjoyed by New Yorkers this summer, thanks to the extensive variety of facilities and equipment to be found in the network of local parks. Activities are available for all ages. They range from archery to zoos, with the cost for use of facilities extremely inexpensive.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company and an underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., have come to agreement that the forthcoming issue of 1,000,000 shares of the company's new preferred stock will be priced at 26 1/2, to yield 4.72 per cent.

WARSAW, June 28 -- Foreign Minister Zygmund Modzelewski reiterated today that the Warsaw conference of the Slav bloc Foreign Ministers had not taken any steps toward the formation of an East German government in the Soviet zone of occupation.

When the Brooklyn Football Dodgers of the All-America Conference open camp at Plattsburg, N.Y., on July 22, among the aspirants for a regular's job will be Bob Chappuis. One of the alltime greats in Michigan gridiron history Chappuis has been signed to a two-year Brooklyn contract. He was introduced to the press at a conference yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, in a detailed outline today of plans for the draft, said that calls would probably go to 225,000 to 250,000 men, with the rate of inductions reaching about 30,000 a month.
h)0*0*0*iLONDON, June 28 -- Sentiment in the stock market here today was undermined again by the situation in Berlin and the spread of the dock strike here. Prices in all sections suffered a setback.
Rear Admiral William S. Parsons, Navy Director of Atomic Defense, said last night that most persons had an exaggerated idea of the potency of atomic bombs.
Tampa, Fla, announced yesterday that it would receive bids July 15 on $3,500,000 of water revenue bonds dated March 1, 1948, and due Sept. 1 from 1949 to 1977.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The general reaction in Washington today to the Communist Information Bureau's split with Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia was much like the reaction of Winston Churchill to the sudden arrival of Rudolf Hess in Scotland during the war.

A general upward price movement in copper and brass products developed here yesterday. The American Brass Company raised its prices 1 to 1 1/2 cents a pound, copper and brass wholesalers announced increases for extras on orders of less than 100 pounds, and other producers indicated they can be expected to follow suit.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- A field of eighty-eight proamateur teams competed in the Westchester County Golf Association's one-day tournament at Fenway Golf Club today. The homeclub unit of Herman Barron, one of the nation's leading money-winners for several seasons, and Lloyd Ribner, club champion, squeezed out a one-stroke verdict with a best-ball round of 31, 32 -- 63.

PASADENA, Calif., June 28 -Studies of the light of distant galaxies that started its journey to the earth 200,000,000 years ago, traveling at a steady speed of 186,000 miles per second, suggest that we may be seeing for the first time the evolution of stars as the progress from birth to maturity and death.

Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner, has affirmed the right of parents and other interested persons not employed by a public school system to prefer disciplinary charges against a principal, teacher or other school employe, the United Parents Associations, 289 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday.

Demand for sheet aluminum has soared, but delivery quotas for some New York warehouse distributors have been cut 25 per cent for July and about 33 per cent for August and September, trade sources revealed here yesterday.

PRAGUE, June 28 -- The congress for the establishment of an international theatre and arts institute, meeting here under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, accepted today a charter drawn up in Paris last July by a committee of experts.
Another book about Franklin D. Roosevelt by a member of his cabinet has been scheduled for publication next year. It is Harold L. Ickes' "My Twelve Years With F.D.R." It will be published by Harper.

Intelligent and consistent use of the "American code" of personnel administration by more leaders of business. Government and education rather than the ability to produce material things in ever increasing quantity, is the means of finally winning the "hot and cold running war against totalitarian communism," it was declared last night by Thomas G. Spates, vice president for personnel management of the General Foods Corporation.

PRAGUE, June 28 (AP) - Following is the major part of the text of the Communist Information Bureau's statement on Yugoslavia, as translated from the text published in the Czechoslovak newspaper Rude Pravo:
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Continuing price pressures on all dairy products are likely to take the record price of milk even higher, a Department of Agriculture official said today.
BERLIN, June 28 -- Communist plans for calling a general strike of Berlin workers to protest the Western currency reform have been postponed indefinitely.

A husband and wife agreed yesterday in Bronx County Court that they had minds of their own and would not be swayed by each 'other's arguments. In fact, they agreed not to discuss certain things even in the privacy of their home during the next day or so.

BENJAMIN HENRY JESSE FRANCIS SHEPARD, a strangely gifted man with a wig and darkly dyed mustaches, led one of the most colorful lives of any of this country's forgotten minor writers. He was a pianist who played his fantastic improvisations before the nobility and gentry of England, France, Germany and Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The proposal of the Long Island Lighting Company, Mineola, L.I. to issue and sell to four commercial banks for cash $8,000,000 of 2 1/4 per cent unsecured promissory notes was described today as a" disastrous kind of financing which this company has followed ever since the incumbency of the present management."

Michael Wilding, the British actor seen here in "An Ideal Husband," has been engaged by Alfred Hitchcock for a leading role in "Under Capricorn," the second production to be turned out by Transatlantic Pictures, the Alfred Hitchcock-Sidney Bernstein independent company.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28 -- Although the status of the hard of hearing in the United States has improved greatly, there is much yet to be done, especially for children and adults in rural communities, Miss Betty Wright of Washington, field service director of the American Hearing Society, said today.

PAWLING, N.Y., June 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican candidates for President and Vice President, respectively, are to hold a strategy conference at Mr. Dewey's 300-acre dairy farm here tomorrow.

PARIS, June 28 -- France and the United States, after a week of arduous negotiations here and in Washington tonight, in a formal ceremony at the Quai D'Orsay signed the bilateral accord fixing details for the execution of the European Recovery Program in France.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 28 -- A lockout by official decree was how R. J. O'Donnell, a waterside union leader, today describedh)0*0*0*ithe creeping paralysis on the Auckland docks, where, it is alleged, the Government is endeavoring to force the issue with the union through a ruling of the Waterfront Industry Commission.

ALBANY, June 28 -- Members of the Communist party as well as "fellow travelers" should be dismissed from the public school teaching staff, the New York City Board of Education contended today in a brief filed here with Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education.

TRENTON, N.J., June 28 -- The New Jersey Senate confirmed tonight all but one of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's nominations to high state judicial and administrative positions. However, the Judiciary Committee failed to release for a Senate vote the appointment of Supreme Court Justice Frederic R. Colie of Millburn, a Republican, to the new Superior Court, which begins to function on Sept. 15.

BERLIN, June 28 (AP) -- The United States and Britain tried today to work an aviation miracle by flying food to 2,500,000 Berliners over the Soviet land blockade. After United States planes had flown a shuttle service to the city all day, United States authorities announced the service was being put on a twenty-four-hour-a-day schedule.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- Marshal Tito and his deputies in the Politburo and Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party were in complete control of the situation to night. Judging by the calm prevailing at party headquarters and government offices, they are likely to retain this hold against the powers of the Communist Information Bureau.

Maximilian's showing of new fur styles at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday stressed models with narrowed natural shoulders, sleeves and silhouettes with less bulk, small-waisted coats with flowing graceful skirts and a handsome array of stoles and jackets.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- While the trustees of the miners' welfare fund of 1947 held their first harmonious meeting here today, "captive": The operators conferred on "next steps" in their campaign to support their abstention from the few bituminous coal contract.
An agreement between the Seafarers International Union, AFL, and nine ship lines, under which the controversial union hiring hall is to be retained, was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -Agreements "closely similar" to those signed with the United States today by France, Italy and Ireland under the European Recovery Program will be signed this week by most of the rest of Western Europe it was announced by the State Department.

WARSAW, June 28 -- News of Tito's criticism by the Communist Information Bureau left official Warsaw amazed and shocked tonight. Communist officials made no-attempt to minimize the blow to Communist unity in Eastern Europe.

In these days of fast travel it is surprising to learn that Virginia Warren, age 19, and Nina Warren, age 14, both of Sacramento, California, hadn't visited New York City until Sunday, and that Dorothy Warren, 17, same address, made her first visit only a few days ago.

Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, predicted yesterday that the delegates to the Democratic National Convention would not take seriously the boom for General Dwight D. Eisenhower as a possible candidate for President.

Roscoe Pound, 78-year-old Dean Emeritus of Harvard Law School, was honored last night at the yearly dinner of the Annual Survey of American Law, a project of the New York University School of Law. The 1947 edition of the publication, edited by Prof. Alison Reppy of the N.Y.U. Law School, was dedicated to the "schoolmaster of the American bar," as Dean Pound has been termed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- Vassili Dendramis, Greek Ambassador to Washington, today issued a statement declaring that "if tomorrow Bulgaria wishes to resume diplomatic relations with Greece all that remains to be done is for Bulgaria to name the diplomatic representatives she wishes to send to Greece -- that is all there is to it."

LONDON, June 28. -- As the London dock strike passed its fifteenth day with signs that sympathy strikes were beginning to spread to Liverpool, the Merseyside and other vital port areas, King George VI, on the advice of the British Government proclaimed a "state of emergency" throughout the United Kingdom tonight.

Without neglecting the European aid program the United States should give equal assistance and leadership to the Far East, "the only frontier left for America." Paul V. McNutt, former High Commissioner and later Ambassador to the Philippines, declared yesterday at the Lexington Hotel.

SINGAPORE, June 28 (Reuters) -- Highest British political and military chiefs in Malaya conferred in Kuala Lumpur today to plan new operations against extremists whose terror campaign reached new heights over the week-end.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28 -- The decision of the Lebanese and Syrian Governments to recommend that the political commission of the Arab League reject all proposals for an extension of the Palestine truce was reliably disclosed today following meetings between the Lebanese and Syrian Premiers, Riad es Solh and Jamil Mardam Bey.

Of all the vain talk in the world, there is none more foolish than that line -- credited to George Herbert and widely believed -- "One hour's sleep before midnight is worth three after." This has been sheer nonsense since the middle of the seventeenth century.

President Truman's signature of the Foreign Aid Appropriation bill yesterday came one year and twenty-three days after Secretary Marshall announced his "Plan" in a speech at Cambridge, Mass. Actually, Secretary Marshall did not so much propose a plan as suggest that one be drawn up by the European nations, not excluding Russia and her satellites.

With a Congressional committee prepared to begin hearings in Washington tomorrow on alleged evasions of the Taft-Hartley law by left-wing store unions in this city, the situation here grew increasingly complicated yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 28 -Many decisions handed down by acting county judges in Nassau County may be invalidated as the result of an action brought before Justice Francis Hooley in Supreme Court here today.

BERLIN, Tuesday, June 29 -The Russians announced the first break in their iron curtain around the Soviet zone occupation early this morning, a few hours after Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Marshall Vassily D. Sokolovsky, the United States and Soviet commanders in chief, had conferred at the latter's Berlin headquarters.
With bland assurance, Santo (Sal) Bretagna took the witness stand yesterday and denied that he shot Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner last Jan. 13.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- The $55,000 bequeathed by the late Clifford B. Harmon, Westchester real estate operator and aviation enthusiast, for continuation of the annual Harmon international air trophies constitutes a valid charitable trust, Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths ruled here today.

The Soviet Union has dismissed two social insurance executives for failing to prevent widespread misuse of welfare funds and has ordered all Government factories and other enterprises to pay their debts to such funds by July 1, according to published Soviet information that became available here yesterday.
A broad increase in compensation benefits in this state for workmen and their dependents was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Insurance Robert E. Dineen.

Ten garage operators adjudged guilty of increasing rates to customers without proper notification to the Department of Licenses have been warned that repetition of the offense would bring a drastic fine or possible revocation of license, it was learned yesterday.
HONOLULU, June 28 -- This Territorial capital on the Island of Oahu suffered only minor damage today from a sharp earthquake that shook Honolulu and its environs at 1:41 A.M., Honolulu time.

TOKYO, June 28 -- Attempts by Moscow to obtain control of Japan's Orthodox Church with its 35,000 communicants appear to have been frustrated, although Soviet Russians continue to cling grimly to a building within the Tokyo Cathedral compound.

LONDON, June 28 -- Moscow's loss has been the democracies' gain. This is the first reaction in informed quarters here where news of the denunciation of Yugoslav Communist leaders by the Communist Information Bureau is being hailed with unashamed glee to night.
PARIS, June 28 -- The French Government has proposed to Washington and London that the three powers consult "at Cabinet level" regarding the Berlin impasse, it was learned tonight.

Disdainful longshoremen hissed and booed yesterday as they swung a ponderous, black armored car, once used by Adolf Hitler, from the hold of the Swedish American liner Stockholm at West Fifty-seventh Street.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 28 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, head of the Catholic church in this country, has been enjoined by the Hungarian Government from addressing any more public gatherings against the nationalization of the church schools.

An opposition Croup in Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, voted yesterday to bring impeachment charges against the local's entire slate of officers "unless they reform their attitude" in the next two weeks.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, is considering the question of placing the Berlin dispute between the Soviet Union and the Western Allies before the Security Council, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson, world welterweight champion, successfully defended his title tonight by defeating Bernard Docusen, New Orleans challenger, in a blistering fifteenround battle in Comiskey Park, home of the Chicago White Sox.

ROME, June 28 -- The economic cooperation agreement between the United States and Italy concerning the application of the European Recovery Program was signed shortly before seven o'clock this evening in the Palazzo Chigi, the seat of the Foreign Ministry, by Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza for Italy and Ambassador James Clement Dunn for the United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild president, Harry Martin of Memphis, Tenn., today assailed "Tory members of Congress" for what he termed "a year of tragic reaction."

The Giants and Yankees announced yesterday that they will play a benefit game under the Polo Grounds lights on Monday night, Aug. 16. With the Mayor William O'Dwyer Trophy, now in possession of the Yankees, at stake, a substantial portion of the receipts will go to sandlot baseballh) 0*0*0*iagencies.

BELGRADE, June 28 -- Workers digging the foundation for a cooperative institute at Tekija, near the Danube, discovered several days ago an antique copper vase filled with jewelry, golden ornaments and silver coins minted toward the close of the first century A. D.

The widest losses in four months appeared yesterday in the stock market, although support accorded the aviation and some oil shares in the late trading enabled the list to steady somewhat. Inroads on the Stock Exchange which reached 3 points in the noon hour were generally reduced by a point before the close of trading and the combined averages showed a net retreat of 1.44 points.

The proposed code and set of standards for marketing research has met with such favorable reaction from members of the American Marketing Association and the Market Research Council that it probably will be adopted by these groups before the end of the year, it was predicted yesterday by Don West, research director of McCalls and head of the volunteer committee that drafted the code.
ATHENS, June 28 (AP) -- Greek Army troops lashed out near the Albanian border today in a renewed offensive against the Communist Rebels, military sources said.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 28 -The racial issue is "the scales on which our American democracy is being weighed in a world that is relentlessly being forced to choose its ideology," Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president of Fisk University, declared today in opening the annual Institute of Race Relations.
An obscure occupant of a Brooklyn rooming house hall bedroom turned out, after his death yesterday, to be a man of means, who had willed his property to the Soviet Government.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- The Trusteeship Council dealt two sharp setbacks today to the Soviet Union in its role of special protector of the Colonial peoples in the United Nations.
Crosstown streets in mid-Manhattan turned red shortly after 8 o'clock last night, and pedestrians in and near Times Square stopped by the hundreds to observe the phenomenon.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) Steers, heifers and hogs ran up today to new high price marks for recent months in fairly active livestock trading High-choice Colorado-fed heifers matched the record of $38 a hundredweight set on Jan. and high-choice steers at $39.10 were the b since Jan. 26. Butcher hogs went to $29.25, the best in regular trade since Oct 17.

The present active United States Merchant Marine is at its lowest post-war mark, with only 600 more vessels now in service than were engaged when this country entered World War II, according to statistics released yesterday by the Maritime Commission.

While Gov. Earl Warren of California, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, remained in his Hotel Pennsylvania suite answering letters yesterday, his wife and three daughters went sightseeing. They were conducted on their tour by one of Governor Dewey's bodyguards in a state car.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 28 -- The annual get-together of dads and their young golfing stalwarts took place today at the Garden City Golf Club with the staging of the twenty-ninth Father and Son Golf Association championship.

ROME, June 28 -- Arguments for and against, continued collaboration between the Left-Wing Socialists and the Communists became acrimonious today as the twentyseventh national congress of that branch of the Socialist party entered its second day.

Police and Federal authorities unearthed yesterday nearly $1,000,000 worth of morphine and heroin buried among 1,000 tons of garbage. The discovery of the narcotics, in a water-soaked burlap bag containing three dozen jars, was made after Department of Sanitation men had worked since last Tuesday sifting the cargo of a garbage scow, much of it by hand.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 29 -- A violent earthquake and fire wiped out 70 per cent of the western Honshu city of Fukui and leveled surrounding towns, a United States Military Government team reported today.

CLASS is beginning to tell as the pennant races approach the traditional Fourth of July half-way mark and the Boston Red Sox, like Joe Louis, are apparently priming themselves for a late-round knockout punch. The baffled and baffling Bosox spent the early part of the campaign picking themselves up off the floor.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 100,000 shares of $5 par value capital stock at $15 a share was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Old North State Insurance Company, Greenville, N.C.

LONDON, June 28 -- Quiet confidence that the Russians will be forced to back down in the Berlin situation appeared to be growing today in official quarters here. However, fear of war has, for the first time, struck the average Londoner and, presumably, all Britons.

Recently you were kind enough to print a contribution from me in which I pointed out the fallacy inherent in the pacifist slogan, "War never settled anything." I showed that war had settled a number of important questions, and that some of them had been settled right.

Orders currently being placed for men's work clothes reflect the slower trend of retail sales evident in the first half of the year, according to exhibitors at the first Work Clothes and Sportswear Show in the New Yorker Hotel.

Current operating earnings of the 9,002 state banks doing a commercial banking business in the United States increased 8.6 per cent in 1947, yet net income decreased 15 per cent under 1946 totals, according to a study of the State Bank Division of the American Bankers Association made public here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The engineer, firemen and switchmen unions have demanded a wage rise of 16 cents an hour on top of the 15 1/2 cents an hour which an emergency board has recommended.

DUBLIN, June 28 -- Ireland was one of the first to sign today the economic cooperation agreement with the United States. In a brief ceremony at Iveagh House in St. Stephen's Green Sean MacBride, Irish Minister for External Affairs, and George A. Garrett, the United States Minister, affixed their signatures to the agreement.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 28 (AP) -- Second seeded Gilbert Bogley of Washington's Landon School, won a quick, straight set ??ory from Don Curtis of St. ??y's, Menasha, Wis., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, today in the opening of the National Interscholastic Tennis Tournament.

Stockholders of the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation have approved a proposal to increase the company's capital stock and to reclassify, the outstanding common stock, W. T. Stevenson, executive vice president, announced yesterday after the stockholders meeting in Wilmington, Del.

The prediction for many days in the near future will be "hot and humid." This is the kind of typically New York summer weather that calls for plenty of tall, cool drinks. Thoughtful is the housewife who greets family and friends as they come in the door with a frosty glass of iced tea or lemonade.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28 -Senior Federal Judge Guy L. Fake said here today that he "understands" that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has finished an investigation of charges that a $500 bribe was offered to a Federal probation officer, by Edgar H. Rossbach, who resigned without explanation on May 24 as United States Attorney for New Jersey.

ROME, June 28 -- The Cominform's censure of Marshal Tito created a very deep impression today in political circles that were waiting to see whether it would lead to a change in the Yugoslavia's hostile attitude toward Italy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28 -- The Independent Order Brith Sholom called today on the United States Government to lift its embargo on arms to Israel immediately "in accordance with the will of the American people to fully implement its laudable recognition of Israel."

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The Federal Trade Commission is the most powerful organization in the United States, Lowell B. Mason, one of the commissioners, asserted today. At a press conference preceding his address to members of the National Small Business Men's Association he said the commission under present laws could issue a complaint against virtually any business in the country, regardless of whether it was violating a law.

Fog delayed passenger shipping as much as four hours yesterday and also forced the Army transport Lawrence Victory, carrying 5,400 war dead, to anchor at Quarantine while memorial services were conducted a few miles away at the Brooklyn Army Base.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A roiling controversy in industrial ranks over the provisions in the draft law applying to industry, particularly in regard to steel, were brought into the open today by Representative Walter C. Ploeser.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Truman signed the foreign-aid appropriation bill today and, with more than $6,000,000,000 at its disposal, the United States formally embarked on the greatest economic rehabilitation project the world has ever known.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 28 -Winners of today's Star Class race at the Noroton Yacht Club were Stan Ogilvy sailing Flame, in the first division, and Whitman Hastings' Downbeat in the second division.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28 (UP) - Joe Verdeur, swimming flash from Philadelphia, set a new world's record of 2:30 tonight for the 200-meter breast-stroke during a record-assault meet at Yale University's Payne Whitney pool.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 28 -- More influential status should be given to the Jews of the world before the United Nations, A. L. Kubowitzki, secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, said today in an address at the second plenary assembly of the congress.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries, reported yesterday for the nine months ended May 29 a net profit of $11,646,921, or $18.47 a share on the outstanding common stock. This compared with a net profit of $10,945,655, or $17.27 a share, for the nine months ended May 31, 1947.

Sales of Brooklyn and New York department stores increased 10 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Army today issued in conjunction with Secretary Kenneth C. Royall's statement on the draft, the following pertinent questions and answers relative to the procedure which will be employed:
Lowering of the national flag tomorrow evening at the Brooklyn Naval Hospital will mark the passing of a 110-year institution that grew with the nation and its wars.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- On the second day of the Republican National Convention at Philadelphia last week the widespread prophecies that there would be protracted balloting, even a deadlock, before the Presidential candidate was chosen began to be hastily withdrawn by many of the forecasters who made them.

THE TIMES recent editorial "By Any Other Name" quoted H. A. Glover: "Only positive action by Congress can make labor monopolies unlawful and Congress will act only when the American people wake up and * * * make their demands heard in Washington."

The American Sugar Refining Company announced yesterday that tomorrow it will advance the price of refined sugar by 1/4cent a pound in all its marketing area except Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont and Rhode Island.

While Prague, with all its crimson trappings, was celebrating the shotgun marriage between Czechoslovakia's Communists and Socialists, a political divorce between the same parties appeared to be shaping up in Italy. The Socialists, still led by the fellow-traveling Pietro Nenni, are holding their twenty-seventh congress in Genoa.

To help make well-designed, lowcost furniture a reality, six designresearch teams, composed of some of the country's leading designers and laboratories, will aidh)0*0*0*ithe International Furniture Competition, it was announced yesterday by the Museum of Modern Art and the Museum Design Project, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 28 -- The Dominican Republic offered today to admit thousands of homeless European children and to house them in a special community modeled after Father Flanagan's "Boys Town."

Tenants should share the responsibility for preventing and remedying violations of the multiple dwelling regulations here, Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday in a letter to Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.

Consumer Cooperatives may be exempted from payment of excise taxes on jewelry, cosmetics and similar merchandise covered by the excise tax law if the Attorney General rules favorably on a War Department brief filed last week. This brief asks that post exchanges be exempted from the tax payment because the law is worded to cover "retailer' only.
The camp exodus for youngstersh)0*0*0*ibegan in earnest yesterday, railroad and bus terminals reported.

When New Yorkers start paying their higher transit fares at 12:01 o'clock tonight -- 10 cents on subways, 7 cents on city-owned buses and 12 cents for a combination ride -- they will only do what the people of other large cities across the country already have had to do, some for a long time.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 29 -- Freda Kirchwey, president of the Nation Associates, today submitted to Secretary General Trygve Lie and to President Truman a memorandum charging that King Farouk of Egypt, whose forces invaded the Negeb after the termination of the British mandate on May 15, collaborated with the Nazis during the war.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Ten of eleven plants of the International Harvester Company, employing 30,000 production and office workers, were struck today as a contract between the company and the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers Union, CIO, expired.

A broad coalition of the other political parties has been decided upon to prevent the re-election to Congress of Leo Isacson, American Labor party member of the Eightieth Congress from the Twenty-fourth Bronx district. It was Mr. Isacson's surprising victory in a special election this spring that first disclosed to politicians the weakness of the Truman Presidential candidacy in urban areas and the potential strength of nominees running on the Wallace ticket.
