LONDON, June 29 (Reuters) -- Australia today defeated England by 409 runs in the second cricket test match at Lords Ground. The tourist also won the first game at Nottingham for a 2-0 lead in the series of five matches.

Pistol Pete Reiser and Bruce Edwards were back in the Brooklyn line-up last night but the return of these ailing regulars failed to produce the salutory effect on the feeble Dodger attack anticipated by Manager Leo Durocher and a crowd of 22.811 at Ebbets Field.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Robert N. Denham, General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, today issued his second complaint against the United Mine Workers of America.

PRAGUE, June 29 -- The three committees of the Constitutional Congress of the International Theatre Institute met today to consider reports on preliminary arrangements made during the last year. The following countries, it was disclosed, had formed national centers: Austria, Belgium, Brazil Chile, China, Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the United States.
ROME, June 29 -- Pope Pius today urged Italian Catholic workers to frustrate attempts by trade union leaders to transform economic questions into a class struggle.

Quotations on secondary aluminum ingot have been withdrawn by one of the leading refiners because in aluminum scrap, "the market no longer exists in the sense that supplies are available at reasonable prices," E.L. Newhouse, Jr., president of the Federated Metals Division of American Smelting and Refining Company announced here yesterday.

Ezio Pinza, the Metropolitan Opera bass-baritone, will make his debut on the Broadway stage this season in the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical play based on James A. Michener's Pulitzer Prize novel, "Tales of the South Pacific."

Not since the great general strike of 1926 has a British Government called on the King to issue a proclamation of national emergency. But a sixteen-day dockers' strike which threatened to tie up every port in Britain forced a reluctant Labor Government to do just that.

Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, issued a statement yesterday replying to attacks on the organization by Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, N.Y., before the Central Conference of American Rabbis on June 23 in Kansas City, Mo.

ROME, June 29 -- British and American military authorities today reinforced all road blocks on the border of the Yugoslav-occupied zone of the Free Territory of Trieste. This was described as merely a routine precautionary measure.

Warning that he would not be influenced by the American Legion post in the Fire Department, Commissioner Frank J. Quayle promoted yesterday twenty-five captains to battalion chiefs. The ceremony took place at Engine Company 31, at 87 Lafayette Street.

Highland Motors, Inc., Kaiser and Frazer distributor for the West Hudson area of Northern New Jersey, has leased the property at 821-831 Passaic Avenue, East Newark, N.J., from the East Newark Realty Company through Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- This city, thanks to a $20,000,000 bond issue authorized by the voters last November, is buying much new transit equipment and converting some of its street car lines to motor bus and trolley coach operation.
The State Law Revision Commission held an open hearing here yesterday on proposals to enact a state law giving newspaper men the right to protect their confidential sources of information.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- In the thirteen-month period ended last March 21, the cost of trolley, subway and elevated train rides in Philadelphia jumped from two for 15 cents to 10 cents each.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Secretary of State Marshall, in a note today to Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, rejected a Russian note of protest of June 9 against an alleged "warmongering" article in Newsweek magazine as calling for no action here because of the principle of freedom of the press.

While Tammany district leaders continued to pass in a steady flow before the June grand jury, investigating charges that some of them had been bribed to cast votes for Francis L. Valente for Surrogate of New York County, the Democratic organization placed in circulation yesterday the petitions formally designating Judge Valente for that post.

CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) -- A fourteenth-inning pinch single by Howie Schultz, scoring Ted Kluszewski from third, gave the Cincinnati Reds a 6-5 victory over the Pirates tonight in a wild game witnessed by a crowd of 23,233. Bill Meyer, Pittsburgh manager, and three other Pirates were ejected by Umpire Bill Stewart in the fourteenth for protesting a play.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,822 compared with 3,077 last week and 1,091 in the similar week last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 798 arrivals yesterday against 1,574 last Tuesday.

Traditional symptoms of a heat wave -- the glassy eye, lagging step and clinging clothes -- were epidemic in the city yesterday on the hottest day this year. The temperature broke into the nineties for the first time this summer and did not stop climbing until it reached 92.1 degrees in the early evening.

A campaign to increase traffic safety by reducing the motorist's burden of worries was recommended yesterday at the annual meeting of the Automobile Club of New York at its headquarters, 28 East Seventy-eighth Street.

A derivative stockholders' suit filed in Federal Court yesterday against the Tucker Corporation and its president, Preston T. Tucker, charged that as a result of mismanagement the company had failed to produce any automobiles and had dissipated a large part of its cash with the result that it was in danger of insolvency and liquidation.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association will begin its long awaited survey of retailer recommendations for changes in home furnishings market dates early next month, David H. Woog, home furnishings group manager, announced yesterday.

ATHENS, June 29 (AP) -- A press dispatch said tonight that two guerrilla brigades have severed one of the Greek Army's main supply links. United States construction men working on the road were forced to flee.

PAWLING, June 29 -- Governor Dewey disclosed today, as he met with Governor Earl Warren for the first time since the Republican convention in Philadelphia, that he is keeping in close touch with the Berlin situation, which he said is "very grave."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29 (AP) -- A group of candidates for the United States Olympic swimming team, racing against time in the Yale pools today, bettered two world and two national records.

With fares on the New York City Transit System scheduled to increase at midnight tonight to 10 cents on subways and elevated lines and 7 cents on city-owned buses and trolley cars, the city's transit officials worked overtime last night on final preparations to minimize confusion on the first day of the changeover.

DETROIT, June 29 -- Detroit's municipally owned and operated public transportation system was acquired from private interests in 1922 at a cost of about $26,000,000. It was composed exclusively of surface street car lines and the fare then was 5 cents.

LONDON, June 29 -- London's dock workers voted today to return to work tomorrow, ending a sixteen-day strike that has paralyzed the port of London. In voting to end their outlaw walk-out, the strikers bowed to a Government threat to invoke its broad emergency powers to get port traffic moving.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 29 -- The germs of the disunity among the Communist party hierarchy that has erupted so explosively in Yugoslavia exist also in Hungary, although as yet in milder form.

Emigre anti-Communist Czechoslovak leaders in the United States and abroad have joined together to overthrow the Prague dictatorship and already formally have notified the United States State Department of their intentions, Dr. Stefan Osusky, former Czechoslovak diplomat, disclosed yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., June 29 -- Observations of a region in the heavens where stars are believed to be in the process of formation, were described here today at the joint meeting of the American Astronomical Society and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific at the California Institute of Technology.
The Public Service Commission granted yesterday an increase of 4.16 per cent over present commutation rates on the Long Island Rail Road.

I have been reading with a great deal of interest the well-informed, well-written articles contributed recently by your special correspondent, Herbert L. Matthews, during his tour of Britain, and, naturally, I was very glad to see that he was able to devote some time to my own little country, Wales.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- Towing a scow and a dredge, a tug headed out through the Golden Gate yesterday on a 12,000-mile voyage to Okha, a port on the West Indian coast 250 miles northwest of Bombay.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP) -- Fireballer Bobby Feller of the Indians showed his old-time form today as he scattered eight hits while beating the Tigers and Hal Newhouser, 6 to 2.

FUIKUI, Japan, Wednesday, June 30 (AP) -- The estimated toll in Fukui's earthquake disaster was placed today by United States Military Government officials at 3,155 dead and 7,520 seriously injured. The number of damaged buildings was placed at 30,721.

WARSAW, June 29 -- Tightlipped Polish Communist officials gave no hint tonight of how Marshal Tito's defiance of the Cominform would be met. The anxiety of this country's party leaders, however, who have always been an accurate barometer of the Kremlin atmosphere, was as plain to see as was the bitterness exploded in the party's newspaper editorial this morning.
James G. McDonald, United States representative to Israel, expressed last night his faith that its leaders would "win through" in their struggle to establish the new country.

BERLIN, June 29--Marshal Sokolovsky, Soviet commander in chief, expressed the "hope" today that the railroad from Western Germany into Berlin soon would be re-opened before the city's food stocks had been exhausted. He emphasized that every effort was being made to repair the line in a calm and conciliatory letter to Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor.

Thirty agents of the New York State Division of Taxation on a special mission in New Jersey have been putting a crimp into the eleventh-hour activities of cigarette-runners, it was disclosed yesterday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 29 -- For the second time in three years, Mr. and Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won the Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial husband-and-wife tournament played under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at Siwanoy today.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, the biggest carrier in the Atlantic trade, arrived here yesterday with 1,988 passengers.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP) -- Frankie Sodano of Philadelphia, the 17-year-old National A.A.U. flyweight champion, became the first member of the United States Olympic boxing team tonight, gaining a split decision over Henry Gault of Spartansburg, S.C., in a spirited final bout at the Boston Garden.

While rumors circulated in financial and industrial circles that the steel industry soon would abandon its economic experiment of stabilized wages and prices, the Pittsburgh Steel Company of Pittsburgh announced yesterday that constantly increasing manufacturing costs have compelled it to raise its prices on certain oil country tubular goods by 26.8 per cent.

Mandatory allocations of industrial products in the Selective Service Act may undo in the steel industry all of the work done by the Steel Producers Advisory Committee cooperating with the Office of Industry Cooperation for voluntary allocation, L.B. Keplinger, president, Steel Shipping Container Institute, Inc., warned here yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- Within the last year there have been two changes in the fare structure of the Public Service Company, the major transit line here.

Official "clarification" of Argentina's recent change in the value of the peso was issued yesterday by the Banco Central de la Republica Argentina in a cable message to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "Official market rates of exchange in force for negotiations of currency proceeds of Argentine exports, which as is known are 335.82 pesos per $100 for regular products and 398.01 pesos for non-regular products, have not been modified," the message explained.

Nathan Wilson has sold the five-story apartment building with stores at 751 Ninth Avenue to Earl Douglas Hansen. The property, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, is one of seven store and apartment buildings at 745-753 Ninth Avenue and 404-406 West Fifty-first Street, forming an "L" around the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, which Mr. Wilson recently acquired from the heirs of the estate of Andrew Ewald.

New York's third generation of subway moles, meekly submitting to the ten-cent fare due tonight at midnight, are a sadder and more harried species than the first eager underground riders who stormed the kiosks when the subways opened at 7 o'clock the night of Oct. 27, 1904.

A total of 354,000 television sets were in use throughout the country as of June 15, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by Audience Research, Inc., headed by Dr. George H. Gallup. An estimated 314,000 receivers were installed in homes land 40,000 in bars and other public places.

Moving to correct unfair trade practices in the needle trade industry, the Federal Trade Commission may be encouraging violations of the Robinson-Patman Act, according to trade spokesmen yesterday. They were commenting upon the recommendation of the FTC trial examiner issued on Monday that a cease-and-desist order be issued for alleged trade practices in the women's coat and suit industry.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- The Washington Senators snapped the Philadelphia Athletics' seven-game winning streak tonight, winning by 5 -- 3 as Mark Christman drove in four runs with a homer, triple and single.
WASHINGTON, Jane 29 -- Plans for the new $40,000,000 Clinical Research Center of the National Institutes of Health were announced today by Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator.

Tomorrow morning New Yorkers will begin paying ten cents underground and seven cents on the surface for their rides on, the city-owned transit system. It is the first general departure from the nickel fare, hallowed in politics, since the horse-car days of 1853.

Leading figures in atomic energy development told 700 science students in the city's public high schools yesterday that they would live to see the atomic age become fully developed and that they would play a role in the changes in daily life that atomic energy would bring about.

The music of George Gershwin still sets the record at the Lewisohn Stadium, but it doesn't seem to draw quite the way it used to. Last year the attendance at the annual Gershwin concert fell below 19,000 for the first time in eight years.

Mrs. Gladys Siegel, 43-year-old real estate broker who had pleaded guilty to gouging $19,350 in illegal rental fees, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to sixty days in the workhouse. She was the first woman to be jailed as a result of the recent investigation into "widespread" bonus demands for apartment leases.
LOS ANGELES, June 29 -- Los Angeles lost the last vestige of a five-cent fare two years ago and is now close to having a ten-cent minimum within its basic central zone, six miles in radius.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 30 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea will notify the Korean National Assembly today that the commission has approved unanimously the May 10 elections held here under the commission's observation. The commission has already so notified the United Nations.

The Man Whose Wife Has Gone Away for a Week or Two is, without question, a man to be pitied. Tradition has it that the Man Whose Wife Has Gone Away for a Week or Two may expect to lead the life of the proverbial Riley.

LONDON, June 29 -- The break-up of the dock strike here together with the Cominform's denunciation of the Yugoslav Communist party brought about a welcome change of sentiment in the stock market here today.

NANKING, June 29 -- The prospects of employment for this year's college graduates in Nationalist China are the bleakest in the history of modern education in this country. Educators fear that many graduates will slip into Communist areas to join the Reds because they are unable to find jobs in Government territory.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Daniel J. Tobin, veteran chief of nearly 1,000,000 teamsters, had a long talk with President Truman today but made no political commitments.

Completely encircled by a sweltering crowd of 70,941, the Yankees last night met the challenge of the onrushing Red Sox in the Stadium in a manner that to Joe McCarthy, steaming in the Boston dugout, must have appeared long familiar but this time strikingly distasteful.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 29 -- Robert K. Carr, who served as executive secretary of President Truman's Committee on Civil Rights, told delegates at the second session of the fifth annual Institute of Race Relations tonight that "the high moral tone of the American people as a nation" is the most important weapon in the fight to guarantee civil liberties for minority groups.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 29 -- Dr. Joachim Prinz, chairman of the American delegation to the World Jewish Congress, told the second plenary session of the congress here today that although some forces in the United States were a menace to the democratic system there was the fullest freedom for fighting those forces, a certain guarantee that the forces of reaction would not triumph.

One of the many organizations that strive to provide wholesome vacations for New York City boys far from the hot and steaming city streets is the Boys' Club of New York. For boys too young to travel back and forth be tween local beaches the club operates William Carey Camp, atop the high sandy cliffs of Long Island Sound, ninety miles outside of New York City.

Los Angeles, Calif., sold yesterday bond issues totaling $18,200,000 and maturing from 1949 to 1988 to a banking syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company at an interest cost of 2.468077 per cent. The bid was 100.014 for 4 1/2S, 2s and 2 1/2S.

The New York Telephone Company borrowed $90,000,000 yesterday on bonds maturing in 1981 at an interest cost of 2.968 per cent. The bonds were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate of sixty-five banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. at a bid of 100.67 for interest of 3 per cent.

Spats performed like a dandy at Aqueduct yesterday. The card was a featureless one, but the showing made by Spats proved satisfactory enough to the 17,535 fans who backed her into favoritism and who were rewarded by seeing the 3-year-old daughter of Cravat register an eight-length triumph in a mile and a sixteenth claiming race.

LONDON, June 29 -- America's four top-ranking women tennis stars swept easily through their quarter-final singles matches at Wimbledon today, thus assuring an all-American contest for the prized British women's championship.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 29 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator on Palestine, was reported tonight to have suggested that Jerusalem be placed under Arab control rather than under an international administration, as provided in the General Assembly partition resolution.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The original manuscript prepared by Abraham Lincoln for the only argument in which he ever appeared before the Supreme Court was placed in the court library today.

PARIS, June 29 -- In the debate which will start Friday and be continued next week the French Assembly is expected to ratify the convention which instituted the permanent organization for European cooperation and the bilateral accord with the United States for execution of the European Recovery Program.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 29 (AP) -- A reliable Arab source said tonight that Count Folke Bernadotte's proposals for a Palestine settlement "imply the existence of a Jewish state, which the Arabs could never accept."

BUENOS AIRES, June 29 -- Although Argentina is unlikely to receive any dollars from Marshall Plan purchases during 1948, President Juan Peron last night declared that the Argentine economy was as sound as ever.

ALBANY, June 29 -- The state's long range plan for hospital construction, estimated to cost more than $750,000,000, has been approved by the Federal Public Health Service, Dr. Robert T. Lansdale, chairman of the state Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission, said today.

The plan for induction, training and use of the men provided for in the Selective Service Act, as outlined by Army Secretary Royall, proves two things. First, that the augmented Army will still be a defensive force and not an offensive one. The increments are to go only to continental forces in order to provide a mobile strength of twelve divisions, six of which will be from the National Guard.
CHICAGO, June 29 -- Philip B. Perlman, Solicitor General of the United States, called on the lawyers of the country today to make their voices heard on methods of controlling Communist infiltration.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The cost of food shipments under the European Recovery Program may be increased as much as $8,275,000 or the shipments themselves cut by 12 1/2 per cent as a result of the failure of the United States to join the International Wheat Agreement, a study of available figures showed today.

Export standards of Colombian coffee, loosely enforced by the Government of Colombia, during the war years, are expected to be resumed and facilitated by new dependable sample types some time in September, it was stated in an interview yesterday by an official of the National Coffee Association.

Issues of new stock valued at $34,500,000 will be placed on the market today. The financing includes a flotation of new preferred stock of Pacific Gas and Electric Company and the first public financing of the Permanente Metals Corporation. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- James F. Masterson, an attorney, of Philadelphia, who filed a stockholders' suit against the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation as a result of its recent $10,000,000 common stock offering, refused today for the second time to answer certain questions of the Securities and Exchange Commission with respect to the litigation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29 -- Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts, retired, of Philadelphia, president of the Pennsylvania Bar Association, suggested today an amendment to the United States Constitution to curb centralizing tendencies in our National Government.

Heat wilted neither the paper daisy chain nor the forty-two youngsters in whose moist hands it was borne yesterday into the auditorium of the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center. The eighteen girls and twenty-four boys also donned pink and blue caps and gowns for a preview of the graduation exercises for the largest kindergarten class ever to participate in activities in the building at 419 West Thirty-eighth Street.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister, tonight warned Britain that "malicious and venomous attacks" such as Winston Churchill's recent statements on the Hyderabad issue must be curbed by the British Government "if they wish India to maintain friendly relations with Great Britain."
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Quiet efforts are being made here to keep the Presidential campaign from interfering with the effective prosecution of American foreign policy.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the attraction is "A Foreign Affair," a comedy-drama starring Marlene Dietrich, Jean Arthur and John Lund. Billy Wilder directed and Charles Brackett produced the Paramount offering from a screen play written by the Messrs.

CLEVELAND, June 29 -- Higher fares, which went into effect a week ago, poured an additional $60,000 into the treasury of the Cleveland transit system in the seven-day period just ended and halted eighteen months of deficit operation in which the system went into the red to the extent of $2,600,000, company officials announced today.

The National City Bank of New York was named defendant yesterday in a suit for $2,236,647 filed in Supreme Court by the Compania General de Tabacos de Filipinas, which alleged that it was compelled to pay that sum twice as the result of the Japanese invasion and occupation of Manila in January, 1942.
ATLANTA, June 29 (AP) -- A rift occurred in the Georgia Ku Klux Klan today when two large Klaverns withdrew from the "original Southern Klans, Inc."

William Z. Foster, chairman of the National Committee of the Communist Party of the United States, and Eugene Dennis, general secretary, issued a statement yesterday denouncing the Communist party of Yugoslavia, which, they said, had begun "to pursue a policy which could only result in the restoration of a capitalist state in Yugoslavia under the domination of imperialism."

The Borden Farm Products Company has sold the three-story building occupying the blockfront on Fort Hamilton Parkway between Sixtieth and Sixty-first Streets in Brooklyn to the Rogers Motor Company, Inc., of which Irving Rogers is president.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Higher production and lower taxes are the two immediate goals which industry must set in its battle against spiraling wages and prices, L.E. Wilson, president of Everite Pump and Manufacturing Company, Lancaster, Pa., said today.

MOSCOW, June 29--Pravda devoted its entire second page today to the Cominform resolution condemning the Yugoslav regime of Premier Marshal Tito. There was no editorial comment. No other Moscow paper printed the resolution. Pravda is the organ of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission, it was learned today, has recommended that President Truman sign the controversial bill extending the members' terms for only two years instead of the varying terms of one to five years urged by the President.

Four types of city transportation passes will be issued to New York public school children to permit them to make their school trips at reduced fares, it was reported yesterday at the Board of Education.

Why is the Communist hierarchy giving world-wide publicity to the charges of heresy and insubordination against Marshal Tito? This is the most interesting of the flood of questions let loose by the fantastic bill of indictment issued by the Cominform against the Yugoslav dictator.

Sally Victor, the modern, has gone Victorian -- at least in part. The animated collection that she presented yesterday in her showroom at 18 East Fifty-third Street was reminiscent of that bygone era of gracious living.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- Gross revenues of the nation's railroads may reach a record $10,000,000,000 this year, but net income is expected to be below that of twenty years ago, the president of the Association of American Railroads said today.

The gap which has opened up in the Russo-Communist bloc at the moment when Moscow is engaged in a great test of strength with the Western Powers at Berlin has assumed increased importance as a result of the decision of the Yugoslav Communist party to defy the ban of excommunication hurled against it by the Communist International and to reject its criticism in strong terms.
Edwin Lord has resigned as executive vice president of Jerry Rossman Corporation and after July 1 will join Charles W. Carvin Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 29--Spokesmen for Class 1 railroads and for the unions of firemen, engineers and switchmen conferred jointly at the White House today for the first time since May 8 in an effort to settle the dispute which led to Government seizure of the carriers.
CHICAGO, June 29 -- The Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, Auxiliary Bishop of Chicago, accused Congress today of obliging the National Association of Manufacturers in enacting the Taft-Hartley Law.

The Board of Transportation has fixed various transfer points on the city's network of transportation systems where passengers may take advantage of a combined fare of 12 cents for a combination ride between surface lines -- both city and privately owned -- and the rapid transit lines, when the increased fare rates become effective at midnight tonight

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The last nickel transit ride in Chicago was in 1918, on a street car. The fare on these vehicles now is 13 cents. On the subway-elevated system the fare is 15 cents, or 20 cents if the ride carries outside the 212 square miles of the city proper.

LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the Yugoslav Communist party's communique on the Communist Information Bureau's charges against it, as recorded from the Belgrade radio by Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news agency:

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Grain markets ranged between periods of weakness and strength on the Board of Trade today, closing irregular with wheat 1/4 cent a bushel lower to 3/8 cent higher than yesterday. Corn was 1/4 cent up to 1 1/4 cents dow and oats were 1/4 cent up to 1/2 cent down, with the July futures inclined to show the most strength.
Eight one-pound packages of heroin were found yesterday hidden in the recesses of the tail assembly of an Air France plane that had arrived here Monday from Paris.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 29 -- It began to look this morning as if the four necessary races for a winner to become the United States representative in the Olympic six-meter yachting at Torbay, England, in August, never could be carried through.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Boston's publicly owned transportation system operates a network of subway, trolley and bus lines on the basis of the ten-cent fare and the universal transfer. Children get to ride for a nickel during certain seasons.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that registration statements covering $50,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 327,534 shares of common and 75,000 shares of preferred stock were filed with it by five companies.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- In less binding language than was suggested by the United States, Great Britain proposed today sweeping reforms in its economic and fiscal affairs as a participant in the European Recovery Program, from which it would receive about $4,000,000,000 in American aid by July, 1952.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The bill providing retirement benefits for members of civilian military reserve components became law with President Truman's signature today.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 29 -- Dan Ogilvy, sailing Flame, won the first leg of the championship division today at the Noroton Yacht Club. Hilary Smart, in Hilarius, was second and John White, in Shillalah, was third.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Officials of the St. Johnsbury Lake Champlain Railroad who have managed it since 1925 today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize a new corporation, St. Johnsbury Lamoille County Railroad, to take over the ninety-two-mile railroad by purchasing it from the Boston Maine for $225,000.

TRIESTE, June 29 -- Trieste is watching events in Yugoslavia with keen interest and it is firmly believed here that, whatever their turn, they will seriously influence the immediate future of the Free Territory.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Truman will have only twenty-six delegate votes pledged to him from below the Mason-Dixon line for the Presidential nomination at the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The country's ability to cope with limited petroleum supplies, now and in the coming winter, was viewed with cautious but definite optimism today by Government officials and industry spokesmen.

The newly erected one-story taxpayer at 120-128 Main Street, Hempstead, L.I., was acquired by Joseph Albert from Jack Goldblatt and Irving Breslow through the purchase of the stock of Woods Building, Inc. Thomas G. Sarris was the broker. The property, which occupies a plot 120 by 195 feet, was sold for cash above two mortgages totaling $190,000.

Mrs. Sylvia Weiner, widow of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, former Louis (Lepke) Buchalter gangster slain in their apartment last Jan. 13, testified yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Santo (Sal) Bretagna and Willie (Farbie) Rosenberg, accused of the slaying. She was called to the witness stand by Abraham Gellinoff, attorney for Rosenberg.

A partial recovery was negotiated yesterday by the market on the Stock Exchange after the severe setback of Monday but the high temperature took its toll from business. The railroad issues returned to the spotlight and claimed the major share of attention while some of the recently strong oils came under realizing.

The Triangle Chevrolet Company has purchased the property at 335 Gold Street, Brooklyn, which it has occupied for many years as an automobile showroom and service department. Barnet Berch and Winifred Freedman were the sellers. Saul H. Freedman was the broker and the attorneys were Arthur S. Bruckman for the sellers and Franklin C. Haven for the buyer.

LIMA, Peru, June 29 (AP) -- President Jose Luis Bustamante Rivero declared last night that Peru was in a state of "acute national crisis." He said he would assume extraordinary powers to rule by decree.
Cotton futures became highly irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 18 points higher to 14 points lower than the day before.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 29 -- Washington and Harvard, winners at Poughkeepsie and New London, were the favored crews on the eve of tomorrow's Olympic rowing trials for eight-oared shells.

The World Trade Corporation, the New York State Agency which has submitted a plan to rehabilitate the New York waterfront, has offered to amend its original proposal so as to release borrowing power for other essential city purposes, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Sixteen jet fighter planes will fly from Michigan to England and Germany next month in a pioneer training operation, the United States Air Force announced today.

"Science, Servant of Man," by Dr. I. Bernard Cohen of Harvard University, will be published by Little, Brown on Aug. 18. Subtitled "A Layman's Primer for the Age of Science," the book deals with the relation of scientific discovery to our daily lives, well-being and national security.

Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., announced yesterday the declaration of a 70-cent dividend payable to common stockholders on July 26. A similar amount was paid in April and 56 1/4 cents each in January, 1948 and October, 1947, making a total for the fiscal year ending on July 31 of $2.52 1/2, compared with $2.25 distributed in previous fiscal year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- The disclosure that three and possibly four major RKO projects have been canceled on the eve of filming produced a flood of conjecture today, which the studio made no move to stem, that Howard Hughes, new controlling stockholder in the company, has initiated a shakeup in studio management.

Frederick N. Myers, candidate for the presidency of the National Maritime Union, CIO, demanded yesterday that an accountant be employed to audit the union's books, according to a statement made by Ferdinand C. Smith, NMU national secretary, after a closed meeting of eighteen members of the organization's national council.

Anyone who has visited a biscuit company and sampled crackers just as they come from the assembly line knows how superior they are to those that have been allowed to stand around for a few weeks. The older product may not be exactly rancid, but it has developed a quality most of us call "off-flavor."

LAKE SUCCESS, June 29 -- Ceylon was recommended for membership in the United Nations today by the Security Council's Committee on the Admission of New Members with the tfull support of nine countries. Delegates for the Soviet Union and the Ukraine, however, said they would abstain until the Council itself took up the question.

There's more than a ten-cent subway fare going into effect at one minute after midnight tonight, a lot more as far as a certain substantial portion of the population is concerned. Just about the time the first dimes are dropping into the new turnstiles, those with black bass on their minds will be making their first legal casts into the bottomless dark and maybe picking up a bird's nest of backlash in their eagerness.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 29 -- The United States divided the United Nations Trusteeship Council today by proposing that the administering powers should give the Council prior notice before initiating any administrative union affecting trust territories.

STANFORD, Calif., June 29 (UP) -- San Jose State College of California won the 1948 National Collegiate golf championship today, the defending champion, Louisiana State University, taking second place.

"I TOOK money only from those who could afford it," says Joseph R. Weil, "The Yellow Kid," distorting the truth only about as much as usual, for Weil is by universal agreement the greatest confidence man in American history. Those who should know, his fellow con men, always admitted Weil's exalted rank, and the "Yellow Kid" himself proudly boasts in his autobiography, "'Yellow Kid' Weil,"* that he was always in a class by himself.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Johnny Schmitz, hooking up in a brilliant mound duel with Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, interrupted the first-place drive of the St. Louis Cardinals today when he hurled the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 triumph before 17,158.

Twenty-four graduates of the city's high schools received art scholarships valued at $10,215 yesterday from the School Art League of New York. The thirty-ninth annual presentation was held in the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

The signing by the President of the Selective Service Act, which includes the Elston Court-Martial Bill, has finally effected some of the long-needed changes in military justice. To the extent that some of the deficiencies in the Army court-martial system will thus be eliminated, this development is highly salutary, and will be welcomed by all who are concerned with the problems of military justice.

After several, months of preservation work at the New York Naval Base, Brooklyn, the 52,000-ton battleship New Jersey was shifted yesterday to the Bayonne (N.J.) Naval Annex, where she will become part of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet.

LONDON, June 29 -- Britain will be the "sole judge" of the measures it adopts to speed economic recovery, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today in presenting details of the bilateral agreement qualifying this country for United States aid under the European Recovery Program.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 29 (AP) -- The Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championships moved through two rounds in men's and women's singles today at the Montclair Athletic Club with the help of twenty-two defaults.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 29 -- The Central Committee of Yugoslavia's Communist party tonight defied the Communist Information Bureau powers led by the Soviet Union and called upon party members to close their ranks around this country's leaders headed by Marshal Tito.

Today marks the end of the financial year for the United States Government, and by virtue of this fact June 30, 1948, seems destined to hold a memorable place in American fiscal history. For tonight the Treasury will close its books with the largest annual surplus in the history of this (and any other) country.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 29 (AP) -- Nine American golfers, led by long-hitting Jimmy Thomson, stayed in the running for the British open golf championship today by qualifying for the last seventy-two holes of medal play.

With liquor sales off an estimated 40 per cent in this city and 30 per cent throughout the rest of the country because of high prices, major distillers were reported yesterday to be preparing for a "battle of brands" for the sluggish consumer market.

BERLIN, June 29 -- Perhaps the most important aspect of Moscow's denunciation of Marshal Tito is that the action was announced by Col. Gen. Andrei Zhdanov's Communist Information Bureau at the precise moment when the foreign policy of the Soviet Union, directed by Foreign Minister Molotov, was facing a major test in the battle of Berlin and expected the customary unbroken support of Russia and her satellite states.

The two five-story apartment houses at 818-822 Hewitt Place, the Bronx, accommodating twenty-eight families, have been sold by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company to Rose Appelman for cash above a mortgage of $42,500. Lewis B. Freeman and Samuel J. Kessler were the brokers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 29 -- Trygve Lie, Secerary General of the United Nations, tonight dropped his tentative proposal to place the dispute between the Western Powers and the Soviet Union over Berlin before the Security Council.

Arduilio Suisi, 40 years old, secretary-treasurer of Local 89 of the Chefs, Cooks and Assistants Union, American Federation of Labor, was released in $1,000 bail yesterday after his arrest on a deportation warrant charging he was an alien affiliated with an organization that advocated the overthrow of the government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The American Embassy in Moscow in a note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Office and given out by the State Department today urged that the Soviet command in Korea be instructed to resume deliveries of electric power to South Korea immediately and to participate with the United States command in negotiations looking to a settlement.

Reporting on operations of the Bulova Watch Company in the fiscal year ended with March, John H. Ballard, president, informed stockholders in the annual statement released for today that the volume of business and earnings again established new high records.

The constitutionality of the section of the Taft-Hartley Act requiring union officers to file non-Communist affidavits if they desired their organizations to use the facilities of the National Labor Relations Board was upheld yesterday in a 2-to-1 decision of a Federal statutory court here.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Selective Service authorities have decided finally, it was said at their headquarters today, to call up men for the stop-gap draft according to the dates on which they were born.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The vehicle for the first major Republican thrust in the next Congress -- to back the party's 1948 platform civil rights pledges -- probably will be the compromise anti-lynching bill that died in the Senate adjournment nine days ago.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education for fourteen years, resigned today because, he said, he could no longer afford to remain in Federal service.

LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- In the Wimbledon semi-finals on Thursday, Mrs. du Pont will play Miss Hart and Mrs. Todd will renew an old rivalry with her fellow Californian, Miss Brough. Miss Brough and Mrs. du Pont will be favored to reach Saturday's final.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's note rejecting a Russian protest against an article in Newsweek magazine:

Should the State Education Commissioner render a decision unfavorable to the Board of Higher Education in the case of a teacher discharged for alleged membership in the Communist party, the board will appeal the verdict to the Appellate Division in Albany.

The best-laid plans of the Salvation Army to get its first batch of 1,200 campers off to New Jersey went slightly astray yesterday. Bus troubles and delays complicated the leave-taking at its headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street, but it had a happy ending.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $12,129,390 after taxes and all charges for the six months ended on April 30, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., board chairman.

Formation of a new fourteen-man committee on magazines and farm papers, headed by Guy Richards, vice president of Compton Advertising, Inc., was announced yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies. The group, which combines functions of two former committees on magazines and on the agricultural press, will deal with operating problems in the designated fields, it was stated.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 29 -- Mr. du Pont and his sister, Mrs. Irenee du Pont, founded St. Andrew's School for Boys near Middletown in conjunction with the late Bishop Philip Cook. His great-grandfather, Eleuthere Irenee du Pont, built the first powder mill that was the beginning of the du Pont business in 1802 on Brandywine Creek.
Despite the luxury of the furs, there was an air of practicality about the collection presented by Esther Dorothy yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, June 29 -- 1 Plagued by bad weather, the visiting tennis professionals, Jack Kramer, Bobby Riggs, Pancho Segura and Dinny Pails, will play twice indoors next week, Promoter Jack Harris announced today. The matches will be held in Luna Park, which is the Madison Square Garden of Buenos Aires.

SOMEWHERE IN RUSSIAN-OCCUPIED GERMANY, June 16 (By Air Mail via Berlin) -- "Some time ago, American correspondents came to interview me about conditions in our plant. A Russian officer was with them. Naturally, I could not tell them the truth.

Willie Beltram, 139, the Bronx, and Joey Carkido, 140 1/4, Youngstown, Ohio, fought an eight-round draw in the main bout at the Coney Island Velodrome before 2,500 fans last night. In the six-round semi-final, Charlie Titone, 124 1/2, Brooklyn, received the decision over George Wright, 128 1/2, Long Island City.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Efforts were concentrated today on reaching a settlement of the Berlin crisis through direct negotiations among the powers immediately concerned.
MT. POCONO, Pa., June 29 (AP) -- A three-state project to add 2,000,000,000 gallons to the daily water supply of New York, Philadelphia and northeastern New Jersey cities was proposed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- Formation of an Asian Federation of Labor embracing trade unions with millions of members in six countries was disclosed here today by Asian delegates to the International Labor Organization Conference.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will reopen negotiations here tomorrow between maritime unions and a committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators, Howard, Durham, regional director of the service, said last night.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Government's budget surplus soared to $8,809,174,412 on June 25 -- an historic high point which may never be reached again, the Treasury reported today.

PARIS, June 29 -- The Yugoslav Communist party's defiant reply to the Kremlin's indictment surprised experts of the Soviet Union here. They had taken for granted that Moscow's authority would prevail. They had assumed that Premier Stalin would not have moved against Marshal Tito and his regime without having made adequate advance preparations to deal with any resistance and to get rid of a rebellious Tito.

Volume of the wood household furniture industry for the first six months of the current year is running at the rate of $1,750,000,000 annually at factory prices, according to the twenty-eighth annual industry survey released yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for furniture manufacturers.

THE Yankees were just concluding their batting practice at the Stadium yesterday and the Red Sox bench jockeys were warming up to their task with considerable vigor. Vic Raschi was taking a cut at the ball when Ted Williams, who had been commenting quietly on the preferences of every hitter, casually remarked, "Gee, he's a big, strong guy."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30 -- A Bolivian mother of two children won today the $750 annual fellowship award of the Quota Club International. This will make it possible for her to attend an American college for one year.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total since March. However, the volume of business was the largest for a corresponding month in three years, and sales of 168,315,502 shares, for the first six months of 1948, were the heaviest for a similar period since 1946.

WASHINGTON, June 30 - Differences between segments of the oil industry over the assignment of eagerly sought steel for petroleum production appeared today in testimony before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Appointment today of a new secretary general of the International Emergency Food Council strongly indicated a continuation of the allocation system for foods in a short world supply.

The White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, with 2,234 passengers aboard, sailed for Cherbourg and Southampton at 12:05 A.M. today, as scheduled, after crew members and police had given the big liner a thorough examination in a fruitless search for a time bomb.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The role that Carroll Reece, outgoing Republican National Chairman, will fill in the party's 1948 campaign, remained uncertain today. The possibility is still in prospect that he may run for the United States Senate from his native Tennessee.
Two realty holdings in widely scattered sections of Manhattan that had been in the same family ownership passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

ROME, June 30 -- The new situation that has been created in Yugoslavia was thoroughly examined in a long Cabinet meeting this morning. The first indication that all is not well behind the "iron curtain" was received with satisfaction in Government circles which are nevertheless most uneasy about what the future developments are likely to be.
LONDON, Thursday, July 1 -Sweeping changes that may revolutionize land and property values throughout Britain took effect at midnight at the Town and Country Planning Act of 1947 became operative.
LONDON, June 30 -- The House of Commons, with the exception of one Communist member, frankly and doggedly faced the specter of war over Berlin today and agreed that Britain must not surrender.

Heat-plagued men and women of Gotham poured through changedover subway turnstiles after midnight last night, meekly as sheep turn into a familiar fold, dropping dimes instead of nickels without protest.

A fall millinery collection that stressed wearability and versatility was offered by Irene yesterday at her salon, 16 East Fifty-second Street. The youthful small hats associated with the name of this designer got a new interpretation from her wig crowns, shirred treatments and forward brims.

A General Sessions jury was told yesterday by the prosecution that it would be a "mockery" if the panel failed to bring in a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree against two men accused of fatally shooting Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner last Jan. 13.

A National Labor Relations Board election which two courts refused to halt left obscure last night the collective bargaining desires of 310 workers in two New York warehouses of the F.W. Woolworth Company.

CHICAGO, June 30 - The Government should exhaust voluntary steel allocation methods of the Office of Industry Cooperation of the Department of Commerce before resorting to use of the "draft industry" provisions of the Selective Service Act to overcome critical shortages, steel merchants urged in a resolution passed by the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., during a national directors meeting here today.

Charges that George Polk, Columbiah)0*0*0*iBroadcasting System news commentator, was "murdered by the orders of the Greek Fascist Government" were made in an open letter to newspapers here yesterday by the Arts, Sciences and Professions Council, 49 West Forty-fourth Street.

Following up their defiance of the Russian-dominated Communist International, Marshal Tito and his aides have now issued another blast which represents nothing less than an open revolt not only against Russian domination but against the whole imperialistic and expansionist policy pursued by Russia since its pact with Hitler.

TOKYO, June 30 -- Leaders of Japan's three governmental parties today reached a decision on a record national budget for 1948. This had been held up since its introduction to the Diet early this month because of dissension withing the coalition.

A thorough reorganization of the main office administrative set-up of the Department of Welfare, separating administration and policy making from social work and logically grouping all related functions, was announced yesterday by Commissioner Robert M. Hilliard.

A six-point national program of merchandising, quality control and sales promotion, which will benefit more than 1,000 molding plants making products amounting to more than $10,000,000 annually, was disclosed here yesterday by W. R. Dixon, assistant sales manager of the plastics division of Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich.

LONDON, June 30 -- London's docks, strikebound for 16 days, were operating normally today as more than 19,000 stevedores and longshoremen reported for duty. Reports from Merseyside indicated that the 2,000 waterfront workers in Liverpool and Birkenhead, who had walked out Monday in sympathy with their London colleagues, also had resumed work.

THESE are the armistice days between national political conventions -- the hot cannonading meant to prove that this Republic's salvation depends pretty crucially on the selection of one ambitious character or another will start up again shortly in Philadelphia. Anyway, we can all breathe quietly for a while, the weather permitting.

h)0*0*0*iTelevision receiver sales volume in different types of retail outlets, which recently rose as much as 35 per cent as a direct result of the combined effect of the Republican National Convention and the LouisWalcott fight, will chalk up further gains shortly because of interest in the Democratic National Convention which opens July 12 in Philadelphia, store executives predicted yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 30 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party of Yugoslavia today struck another blow at the Communist Information Bureau [Cominform] with a demand for a Balkan federation consisting of Bulgaria, Albania and Yugoslavia.

HAIFA, Israel, June 30 -- The Union Jack was lowered today in Palestine, marking the end of the British occupation, a month ahead of schedule. It was the first time that the flag had ceased to fly here since Nov. 2, 1917, when General [Viscount] Allenby made his triumphal entry into Jerusalem.

Norman Mailer's bestselling war novel, "The Naked and the Dead" is to be made into a play by Lillian Hellman for Kermit Bloomgarden, who plans to put it on the Broadway stage in the fall. A first novel by the author. "The Naked and the Dead" is a story of an imaginary battle in the Pacific, pointing up the brutality of modern war.
LONDON, June 30 -- With the more reassuring news from Berlin and the return to work by the dock workers, the new account made a cheerful start in the stock market here today.

A maximum temperature of 87 degrees -- five degrees below the mark of 92 on Tuesday -- brought the city some slight relief from the heat of the previous day during the daylight hours yesterday, and cooling showers last night aided further by bringing the thermometer down to a low of 71 degrees at midnight.

The basing point system of making prices will be abandoned by the largest cement producer on July 7. Blaine S. Smith, president of Universal Atlas Cement Company, announced yesterday that on that date prices f.o.b. the shipping point will become effective.

Another biennial design period in machine printed wallpapers will be ushered in today with the release of twenty-three new patterns by F. Schumacher Co. to be available immediately through decorators. In accord with the custom of introducing new patterns once every two years other manufacturers of machine printed papers will start showing their lines to dealers today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A group representing all the Rumanian political exiles in this country and elsewhere is very fearful that the Kremlin plans a coup in August through which Rumania will become a member of the Soviet Union, to be followed by the rest of the Balkan countries if the plan is successful.

They were all saying at the Aqueduct race track yesterday that My Request was born in the wrong year. They were all saying this after the chestnut son of Requested had scored a handy victory in the twenty-first running of the Shevlin Stakes, and they all meant, of course, that only the fact that Citation and Coaltown are in his age group prevents My Request from being the standout 3-year-old of 1948.

A complaint of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, and five of its six national officers was issued yesterday by Charles T. Douds, regional director here of the National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Douds set July 12 as the date for a hearing on charges that were filed by an employers' group representative on June 11.

The coalition between the Democratic, Republican and Liberalh)0*0*0*iparties in the Bronx for joint nomination of State Senator Isadore Dollinger to oppose Representative Leo Isacson, American Labor party member, for re-election in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District, was denounced yesterday by Representative Vito Marcantonio, State Chairman of the Labor party, and Leon Straus, its Bronx County chairman.

At one minute after midnight this morning, New York International Airport at Idlewild was officially "open." However, the six scheduled foreign flag air carriers and two other carriers that have signed leases with the Port of New York Authority, will not begin to land and take off passengers andh)0*0*0*icargo there for at least a week.

PARIS, June 30 -- The French Government, which last week held aloof, now considers it is formally engaged in consultations with the two other Western powers on the Berlin impasse. Officials here said Washington and London had acceptedh)0*0*0*ithe French proposal for talks at the Cabinet level, and that discussions between Mr. Bevin and the French and United States Ambassadors in London today were the result.

The "Watch on the Hudson" maintained by New York State tax agents netted another eighty alleged cigarette smugglers yesterday, the last day before New Jersey's new tax of 3 cents a pack equalizes the price of cigarettes onh)0*0*0*iboth sides of the river.
Negotiators in the hard coal industry moved closer to full agreement yesterday, with John L. Lewis expected to duplicate the victory he won last week in the soft coal fields.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs lashed out from their lowly cellar position with unexpected fury today when they made it two straight over the St. Louis Cardinals with a decisive 9-1 victory.

Crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new peak of 5,493,900 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was the seventh consecutive week of record output.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 30 - The Turkish Government would like to crystallize her present extremely friendly relations with the United States in a formal alliance "if this should prove legally possible from an American viewpoint."

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) President Truman said today that the Communist defeat in the Italian election last April confirmed this nation's "faith" that its foreign aid programs would help preserve freedom in the world.

Two new shows are announced by CBS to serve as summer replacements for the hour-long "Radio Theatre" on Monday evenings. The first, to be heard at 9:30 P.M., will be "Mr. Tutt," based on the stories of the late Arthur Train.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30 - President Juan Peron, whose political opponents found that they were unable to buy a minute of radio time during the electoral campaign last February and March, today espoused the cause of freedom of the air.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Bill Voiselle, a New York cast-off, who had not gone the route in six weeks, failing to finish nine straight times, outlasted and outpitched Larry Jansen, Montia Kennedy and Sheldon Jones as he hurled the Braves to a 3-1 victory over the Giants tonight.
Joe McCarthy and his Red Sox apparently aren't ready by any means to have themselves counted out of the American League's 1948 flag race.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -Dore Schary resigned today as vice president in charge of production at RKO, eight weeks after Howard Hughes' acquisition of shareholding control of the company. Mr. Schary's resignation was attributed to Mr. Hughes' interference in studio production policies, the reported difference between Mr. Hughes and Mr. Schary having resulted earlier this week in the cancellation of four RKO films scheduled for immediate production.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 30 -The 2,000-meter course record of 6:04:8 set by the University of Washington champions in winning here in 1936 was broken by six eight-oared crews today as the United States Olympic rowing trials started on Carnegie Lake.

The Long Island Rail Road Company took yesterday the formal step required to make effective today the 4.16 per cent increase in commutation rates that the Public Service Commission had authorized on Tuesday. The step consisted of filing with the Commission a sheaf of tariffs listing the new commutation rates between all points on lines.
PASO ALTO, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- Favorites, including the defending titleholder, racked up victories today in the first round of the 1948 National Collegiate golf tournament at Stanford.

Unmindful of the sizzling heat which had thoughts resting most anywhere except on a football grid iron, the Yankee football club staged an elaborate luncheon in the Stadium Club yesterday to reveal that they have just acquired the services of Wilson (Buddy) Schwenk, veteran backfield ace of the Baltimore Colts and ranked as one of the outstanding passers in the pro ranks.

Inheritance taxes will take $7,036,729 of the $9,748,125 net estate left by Mrs. Emily Thorn Vanderbilt Sloane White, 94 years old, who died at Lenox, Mass., on July 28, 1946, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. She was the widow of Henry White, former Ambassador to France and Italy, and a daughter of William H. Vanderbilt.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Employes' insistence upon another 16 cents an hour on top of the 15 1/2 cents award by a Presidential emergency board deadlocked negotiations today at the White House for settlement of the railway labor dispute involving the unions of firemen, engineers and switchmen.

The American market, now "on the heights of a great advance in business," is capable of infinite development. Earl O. Shreve, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at its annual awards luncheon yesterday in the Commodore Hotel.

MANILA, June 30 -- The Philippine Congress has now approved appropriations totaling more than half a billion pesos. [The peso is fixed at two to the dollar.] This is double the amount that the late President Manuel A. Roxas estimated as the national income for the fiscal year ending twelve months from today.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 30 (AP) Two British golfers and ah)0*0*0*iBelgian pro shot 69s today to set the first-round pace in the British open championship, three strokes ahead of Lawson Little, the closest of nine American competitors.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 30 -- Marshal Tito returned to Belgrade today from an island retreat off the Adriatic coast where he directed the struggle against the Communist Information Bureau powers.

ROME, June 30 -- Communications were threatened today by the gasoline workers' strike, which started this morning on a national scale. A food shortage developed in Milan as a result of a food workers' strike, and a general strike was declared in the Province of Pisa.

LONDON, June 30 -- Reports of arrests of prominent Communists in Bucharest, Rumania, reached London today. Gheorghe GheorghiuDej, First Vice President and secretary general of the Workers party, was one of those mentioned.
Mrs. Earl Warren and her daughters were initiated yesterday into the mysteries of the modern mass interview.

PARIS, June 30 -- Government circles were reluctant today to make anything like an official comment on the breach between Premier Stalin and Marshal Tito, but these circles expressed the conviction that the Western Allies would make a great mistake if they assumed that Marshal Tito's refusal to accept Soviet stricturesh)0*0*0*ion the Yugoslav-Communist conduct implied that he would refuse to follow the Soviet foreign policy or would become friendly to the West.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 - The annual convention of the American Newspaper Guild will debate tomorrow whether a newspaper is justified in discharging a reporter who admits he is a Communist.

Most manufacturers and wholesalers prefer to handle their foreign buying through firms that specialize in importing, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board, releasedh)0*0*0*iyesterday.

The stock market emerged yesterday from its indecision and pushed forward under late buying to score the best rise in three weeks. The rails and oils spearheaded the rally, which raised the combined averages by slightly more than a point, with exaggerated increases in a few scattered issues.

Before the European Recovery Plan becomes fully operative each of the sixteen participating countries must enter into bilateral conventions with the United States setting forth their commitments in that vast cooperative enterprise. Congress has set July 3 as the last day for the signing of such agreements.

" Man-Eater of Kumaon," an adaptation of the book by Jim Corbett featuring Sabu, Wendell Corey. Joanne Page and Morris Carnovsky, which arrives at the Winter Garden, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Universal International release was produced by Monty Shaff in association with Frank P. Rosenberg.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) The army announced today a complicated system of priorities under which it would hand out pay for periodic training drills to members of its organized reserve corps. The total amount allowed by Congress for training army reserves in the fiscal year beginning tomorrow is $12,000,000.

New chairs and tables just added to the modern group designed by William Armbruster carry out the architect-designer's belief that furniture for homes as well as officesh)0*0*0*ivirtually should be indestructible without looking bulky.

One of the least creditable items in the record of the Eightieth Congress was the refusal of the Republican leaders of the Senate to give their consent to the President's reappointment of David E. Lilienthal and his four colleagues as members of the United States Atomic Energy Commission for the terms provided by existing law.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The United States Air Force and Britain's Royal Air Force are planning to supply food for the Western sectors of Berlin entirely by air if the present Soviet restrictions on freight movement into the city are maintained, an unimpeachable source said tonight.

CHICAGO, June 30 Grain markets fluctuated irregularly on the Board of Trade today in trading featured by professional operations in corn and oats, both of which were sharply higher at one time with the July taken rather freely against sales of September.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, June 30 The three Western Military Governors agreed today on all points of their Governments' instructions to create a Western German government with a seat in Frankfort until such time as a government for all Germany is made possible by Russian cooperation.

ALBANY, June 30 -- Welcomed back to Albany as the next "President of the United States," Governor Dewey told 5,000 persons at a ceremony on the Capitol steps today that America faced heavy responsibilities in leading the world to a "better and more lasting peace."

ALBANY, June 30 -- Election of a fourth Bronx County judge in the election next November would be unconstitutional, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today in a formal opinion requested by Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- In a final decision reaffirming a previous ruling, the Federal Communications Commission announced today that the licensee of a radio station while at liberty to deny the use of his facilities to candidates for political office may neither censor for libelous content any of their broadcasts, nor be sued for damages.
Swelled by a sharp increase in financing for public utility corporations, new bonds and stocks offered publicly here in June reached the highest totals for several months.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- An ample supply of merchandise in all brackets will be available for merchants attending the summer home furnishings market to be held here at the American Furniture Mart and at the Merchandise Mart for two weeks starting July 5.

BERLIN, June 30 -- German Communists were engulfed today in a wave of purges and attempted purges spreading Westward from Moscow. It is now fully evident that the Kremlin is attempting an international police operation as drastic and as far-reaching as the internal house cleaning that culminated in the Moscow treason trials.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 30 -The Women's Long Island Golf Association tried a new kind of tournament today over the Rockaway Hunting Club course. It was a match against par on a point system with full handicaps. Points were awarded as follows: 1 for bogies or one over par, 2 for par, 3 for birdies and 4 for eagles.

FUKUI, Japan, Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- Rain and a new light earth shock added today to the woes of this stricken area of western Japan, where thousands were believed killed or injured by Monday's great earthquake.

A decision that would permit certain builders to insist on overtime work by bricklayers, and increase wage rates in such cases to $3.20 or more an hour, was announced yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations.

Five persons were injured and ten arrested yesterday morning in a disturbance in front of the office and warehouse of an automobile accessories chain store at 314 Scholes Street, Brooklyn, when nonstrikers attempted to enter the plant being picketed by 500 persons.

SHANGHAI, June 30---The extent of last week's runaway priceand currency inflation here waspartly measured by a jolting official acknowledgment today in theform of a 110 per cent increase inthe city government's J',,ne cost ofliving index for workers.
The Pennsylvania Hotel, the third largest in this city, was purchased yesterday from the Pennsylvania Railroad Company by the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., for an undisclosed cash consideration.

Reflecting improvement in sales, the consolidated net earnings of Colonial Mills, Inc., for the six months ended with last May increased to $4,517,759 from $3,384,915 earned in the semi-annual period of the previous year, it was reported yesterday.

BUDAPEST, June 30 -- Having nationalized more than 80 per cent of Hungarian industry and usurped the right of churches to share in the education of Hungarian youth, communism is now preparing to collectivize Hungarian agriculture.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The May sales of manufacturers as compared with April declined $650,000,000 to an aggregate of $16,500,000,000 and inventory book values at the end of the month reached $29,500,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

William C. Bolenius, who has been president of the Wisconsin Telephone Company was elected yesterday vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in charge of the personnel relations department. He succeeds Cleo Craig, who as placed in charge of the department of operation and engineering, succeeding William H Harrison, whose resignation from A. T. T. to become President of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was announced last week.

Congressional failure to approve the $65,000,000 loan for construction of the United Nations headquarters in New York City is a sad commentary on the state of American public affairs. It illustrates the confusion of a majority of our legislators, who for the sake of playing politics are willing to jeopardize earlier commitments to the cause of world peace and cooperation, symbolized by the United Nations.

A biography of Frederic Francois Chopin, by Herbert Weinstock, has been scheduled for publication early next year by Knopf. "Chopin: The Man and His Music" will mark the centenary of the composer's death. Mr. Weinstock is the author of "Tchaikovsky" and "Handel."

h)0*0*0*iThe Louisville Nashville Railroad sold an issue of $30,000,000 fifty-five year first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of about 3.82 per cent to a syndicate of sixty-three underwriting houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the only bidder for the issue.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- Right hander Bob Lemon of the Indians tossed the first no-hit, no-run game of the major league season as he blanked the Tigers, 2 to 0, tonight. It was his eleventh victory of the season and his fifth shutout.

The clinking of dimes dropped into the subway turnstiles today will mark the first departure from a 5-cent fare tradition that had withstood forty-four years of assault in the courts and the political arena.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Illinois Power Company, Decatur, Ill., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 690,098 shares of no par value common stock. It proposes to call for redemption its outstanding 345,049 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $50 par value, redeemable at $52.50 a share plus accrued dividends.

Mme. Eleanor Elverson Patenotre, 78-year-old widow of a French Ambassador to the United States, and her son, Raymond, a former French Cabinet member, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of evading $2,183,347 in taxes.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30 -- Five lions and an elephant escaped death here early this morning as firemen battled a blaze on the end of the Million Dollar Pier, a quarter-mile at sea.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- Circus Clown, a light bay colt 3-year-old owned by W. J. Walden and trained by T. Root, made a strong stretch rally at Monmouth Park today to capture the $10,000 added Select Handicap by one and one-quarter lengths before 11,494 spectators.
ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- Paul Lehner hit a homer in the fifth inning and singled home the winning run in the eighth to lead the Browns to a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox tonight.

Mayor O'Dwyer signed yesterday the local law doubling the excise taxes on general and financial business. The law, which becomes effective today, imposes a tax of one-fifth of 1 per cent upon gross receipts of general businesses and one of two-fifths of 1 per cent upon the gross incomes of financial businesses.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 30 (UP) -- Dr. Alex Easterman, secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, said today that "democracy in the United States is at present being swept by unprecedented currents of anti-Semitism."
Completed discussion of economic part of report on administration of Tanganyika.
Tanned, but tired from his ninehour airplane trip from San Juan, Puerto Rico, Mayor O'Dwyer returned to New York at 6:22 A.M. yesterday to tackle one of his busiest days at City Hall.

Wall Street launched yesterday its first concerted campaign to impress upon the nation the mechanics of the American securities business, the part that financial institutions play in the building and expansion of industry, and the importance of the free market in competitive enterprise.

By way of a change from fishing, part of today's space is devoted to ducks. Ducks Unlimited provides the material in an item about an experiment it is conductingh)0*0*0*iwith the hope that duck shooting in the northeastern states can be improved.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -Leon Jouhaux, French anti-Communist labor leader, won an ovation and a seat at the International Labor Organization conference today during a plenary session at which he was challenged as a delegate by Communist groups for whom he voiced "pity."
All day and far into the night, railroad and bus terminals were filled with cheering youthful campers as the summer exodus reached its peak yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Modifications in rent control regulations to facilitate relief for landlords operating at a loss or under financial hardship were announced today by Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expediter in charge of rent administration.

Stores are so well stocked this year with tools for outdoor cookery that probably everyone is pretty well equipped by now. But for those who must make last-minute purchases for a Fourth of July picnic, here is a selection of gadgets that will come in handy around the campfire or the backyard grill.
ATHENS, June 30 (AP) -- Minister of War George Stratos said tonight that Greek Army units had beaten back guerrilla forces in a hard struggle and restored communications along the YaninaPreveza road.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- More than fifty prospective witnesses seeking to advise or plead on dozens of phases of the 1947 platform of the Democratic party were already listed tonight for the hearings that will begin at 10 o'clock next Wednesday morning in Philadelphia.

The backsliding Dodgers suffered their fourth straight defeat yesterday. While 6,687 refugees from the downtown heat hooted derisively, Ben Chapman's hustling Phillies scored a dozen times in the first four innings to rout the erstwhile Flatbush Favorites, 13 -- 4, at Ebbets Field.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 30 (AP) -- A bloodstained plane, its pilot killed and two other crewmenh)0*0*0*iwounded, landed at Istanbul airport tonight with twenty Bulgarians aboard.
The Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday a net income of $3,172,855 after all deductions for the first five months of this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -Argosy Productions, the John Ford-Merian Cooper production company, has engaged Cyril Humeh)0*0*0*ito prepare a screen adaptation of Ernest William Hornung's novel of Australian cowboy life, "Stingaree," published at the turn of the century.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 - This nation of 4,000,000 inhabitants on the Soviet Union's doorstep will elect its new single-chamber Diet (Parliament) for the next three years tomorrow and Friday. The election promises to be fair and democratic.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 30 -- Britain's administration of the trust territory of Tanganyika was critically scrutinized by the Unitedh)0*0*0*iNations Trusteeship Council today.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 30 (AP) The Bulgarian Government said today "the sound foundations of our relations with Yugoslavia are unshaken" by the Cominform blast against Yugoslav Premier Marshal Tito.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30 (AP) Chet Laabs and Johnny Groth hit two-run homer in the eighth inning to give Buffalo a 4-3 victory over Newark in the second game of a double-header tonight after theh) 0*0*0*iBears had won the opener, 9 -- 4.
