It is with no little concern that I note the letter of Thomas G. Morgansen in your issue of June 23, wherein he says, "The time-honored practice of reading in a reclining position, it seems to me, deserves to be cultivated rather than discouraged."
With a whoop that rang through the streets of New York 866,000 boys and girls poured from their public school classrooms yesterday with the bright prospects of a long summer vacation.

HENLEY-ON-THE-THAMES, England, June 30 (AP) -- Kent School of Connecticut and Princeton University stroked to easy victories today in preliminary heats of the Thames Challenge Cup at the opening of the 109-year-old Henley Royal Regatta.

The feud between the KaiserFrazer Corporation and Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, raged more furiously yesterday as the automotive concern announced that it had applied to the United States District Court here to increase the damage claim in a pending suit against Otis.
The coming visit to the United States of the President of Venezuela, Romulo Gallegos, prompts me to make a few brief comments which may interest the readers of your highly esteemed newspaper.

On receipt of news that Lieut. Gov. Goodwin J. Knight had had a serious abdominal operation in a Los Angeles hospital, Gov. Earl Warren of California, Republican nominee for Vice President, cut short his visit to New York yesterday.

A year of "strains and tensions - economic, ideological and emotional" were reflected in the public service advertising campaigns carried on by the Advertising Council, Inc., during the twelve-month period ended in March, 1948, according to the organization's sixth annual report, issued yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 30 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported to the Security Council today that on Monday and Tuesday he "presented to Arab and Jewish authorities in Cairo and Tel Aviv, respectively, three brief papers setting forth in outline my views and suggestions for a possible approach to the peaceful adjustment of the future situation of Palestine."

PARIS, June 30 -- After having rejected the Government's military budget this morning, the Finance Commission of the National Assembly ireversed itself tonight and reported favorably on it following testimony by Pierre-Henri Teitgen, Minister of the Armed Forces.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared all-out political war yesterday on a majority of the Tammany Hall district leaders in reprisal for their having designated General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente as the organization's candidate for Surrogate of New York County.

Uniform accounting rules, the first in the history of the fire and casualty insurance business, were promulgated yesterday by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance. Providing for the uniform classification of expense accounts, the rules are designed to produce a major improvement in expense statistics of fire and casualty insurers

After thirty-five years of work with sufferers from tuberculosis, Fred M. Stein, president of the Committee for the Care of the Jewish Tuberculous of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, retired yesterday at the age of 75.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Employes of four of New York's largest department stores will walk out when current union contracts expire Feb. 1 in a strike inspired by their "left-wing" leaders to evade provisions of the Labor-Management Relations (Taft-Hartley) Act, a Congressional subcommittee was told today.

Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on July 14 an issue of $2,000,000 of water and sewer bonds dated July 1, 1948, and due July 1 from 1949 to 1988.

The body of Col. David Marcus, the former New York City Commissioner of Correction who died in Palestine on June 10 as he led the Israeli forces to Jerusalem, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday on a chartered airliner. Several members of his immediate family, an honor guard of the Police Department and the Col. David Marcus Memorial Committee were present at the airport.

The reserve requirements plan, recently presented to the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report by representatives of the Federal Reserve System, was directed "primarily to a reconsideration of the basis for commercial bank reserve requirements," theFederal Reserve Bank of New York explained yesterday.
Gilbert Robbins has purchased the five-room dwelling at 12 Audrey Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., from Dell Builders. Finnerty's Real Estate was the broker.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closed 7 to 30 points net lower, with the most weakness in the July position.

Mayor O'Dwyer signed yesterday, after a brief public hearing, a local law banning throughout the city pinball machines and other "gaming devices." The law, passed by the City Council by a narrow margin and later adopted unanimously by the Board of Estimate, becomes effective today.
CEDAR KEY, Fla., June 30 (AP)h)0*0*0*i-- At least six persons were drowned, two were saved and six others are missing from the 38foot boat Hazel, which exploded on a fishing trip Sunday.

A generally improved employment situation for Negro workers was reported yesterday by the department of industrial relations of the Urban League of Greater New York, 204 West 136th Street. The fields studied included clerical work and the building trades.

The pamphlet binders group of the New York Employing Printers Association, comprising 260 local producers of pamphlet binders with an annual volume of $14,000,000, yesterday gave preliminary approval to seven proposed trade-practice rules.

Print cloth prices continued firm with active business reported in 80 squares, according to Worth Street sources yesterday. Prices at 25 cents per yard for spot deliveries were up 1/2 cent over last week. Commission men said that all indications pointed to increased activity after the Fourth.

Constantin A. Fotitch, last Ambassador of the Yugoslav monarchy to the United States, said yesterday that he believed the heart of the rift between Marshal Tito and Moscow was the reluctance of the Yugoslav leader to collectivize the farms.
Blair Co., Inc., has announced the election of Frank Lynch as a vice president. He has been with the firm twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 23:

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 30 -- The Russians, supported by delegates from Eastern European countries, mustered sufficient votes today to carry a proposal that only the European nations of the thirtyfour countries attending the International Radio Wavelength Distribution Conference here should have voting rights in the parley.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 30 -- The New Jersey, one of the most powerful fighting units in the Navy, was inactivated today in decommissioning ceremonies that relegated the veteran of a dozen Pacific engagements to the New York Group of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 30 -It will be the Long Island Sound sloop Llanoria as the United States representative in the largest class of Olympic yachting, that to be held in Torbay, England, in August.

MOUNT WILSON OBSERVATORY, Calif., June 30 -- Discovery in the Milky Way galaxy of tens of thousands of new stars, including more than 700 giant stars from a hundred to more than a thousand times larger than our sun, was reported here today at the joint meeting of the American Astronomical Society and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.

GENEVA, June 30 The report of the United Nations special committee investigating the Greek conflict was signed here today by the committee members, with the Australians filing reservation that the committee had paid too much attention to investigating the situation and not enough to attempting to conciliate the differences between Greece and her northern neighbors.

In preparation for a possible nation-wide walkout of 30,000 workers, the association of Communication Equipment Workers, CIO, will start a "cold strike" today against telephone exchanges in forty-three states.

Simultaneously with the ground breaking for its new textile school, the Philadelphia Textile Institute Foundation next month will starth) 0*0*0*ia drive to raise an additional $788,000 for the project, it was announced yesterday by Charles W. Carvin, chairman of the development fund.
SEOUL, Korea, June 30 -- The United Nations Temporary Commissionh)0*0*0*ion Korea today announced its unanimous approval of the general elections held here on May 10 under its observation.

LONDON, June 30 -- Bob Falkenburg smashed served and chopped his way to a straight three-set victory over Gardner Mulloy in the semi-finals of the men's singles at Wimbledon today and thereby injected into this hitherto lusterless tournament a fresh note of tennis brilliance.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN. Germany, June 30 -- A significant difference of opinion between Ambassador W. Averell Harriman and bipartite authorities was reported today over the question of establishing an Economic Cooperation Administration Commission in Germany similar to those being assigned by the United States to other Marshall Plan aid recipients.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was conducted by Alexander Smallens last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, and Carl Stern, first 'cellist of the organization during its summer series, was the soloist. After the first half of the program the concert was discontinued because of the heavy rain, and it was announced that holders of stubs of tickets for yesterday evening's event could use them again for tonight's concert.

Every citizen must practice democracy daily before the United States can assume spiritual leadership over the rest of the world, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declaredh)0*0*0*iyesterday. At a luncheon of the dress division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, she said the role of this country depended on how we treated each other in our own communities.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, has received from the Navy the Distinguished Public Service Award for outstanding service during the war in the field of shipping. Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, retiring commandant of the Third Naval District, as his final official act in that post presented the award yesterday at a luncheon at India House, Hanover Square.
New York abandoned last night the nickel fare, which had prevailed on its rapid transit lines ever since the city's first subway opened on Oct. 27, 1904.
STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -William G. Helis, Ennobled and the Elmendorf Farm's Whiffenpoof ran a dead heat for first in the $10,000 added Dover Stakes at Delaware Park today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- Charles Oliver of the United States Military Academy and Perth Amboy, N.J., won an easy 6-1, 6-0 third-round victory today over Harold Fellenbaum of Elizabethtown in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships.

CHICAGO, June 30 Concerned over recent progress of oleomargarine producers in capturing part of the butter business resulted today in a meeting here of a new organization named the North American Dairy Cattle Research Foundation which is seeking to lower milk production costs so that butter prices might compete with oleo prices.

Within the past few weeks there have been several news items in connection with the measures being taken to relieve subway congestion. These have included a recommendation by the Mayor that work hours should be staggered and reports on the extension of local stations now being made at a cost of about $13,000,000 to accommodate ten-car instead of six-car local trains.

WASHINGTON, June 30 - James K. Vardaman Jr., a Governor of the Federal Reserve System, endorsed today without reservation a proposal by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank, that Congress study the overhaul of the credit and monetary policies of the Government.

Thomas V. Gaffney, 62 years old, the chief bookkeeper of the Police Department, announced yesterday that he would retire after a vacation starting today. He has served in the office of the chief clerk of the department for forty-one years.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 -Implementation of a Federal civil rights program appears certain within the next two years regardless of which major political party wins the national election, Dr. Robert K. Carr declared today at the annual meeting of the Institute of Race Relations.

HAVANA, June 30 -- The controversy between the sugar producers and the workers that has been threatening to paralyze the entire industry was tentatively settled today by an agreement that will be put into effect by a Presidential decree.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Truman criticized the Republicandominated Congress tonight in signing three bills. Public power and reclamation, paternalism toward island possessions and conflicts between the legislative and executive branches of the Government were among the issues which Mr. Truman raised in scathing terms.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Western European nations were warned by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, again today that any shipments of war potentials into the Soviet sphere would be regarded here as sufficient reason for cutting off American aid.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander warned yesterday that sudden death and injury menaced motorists, pedestrians and children particularly, during the Fourth of July holiday week-end unless strict obedience to traffic rules and common sense prevailed.
BOSTON, June 30 -- Robert H. Best, 52-year-old former American newspaper man convicted of being a Nazi radio propagandist during the war, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for treason.
The Republic of Bolivia made public here today the terms of a proposed resumption of debt serviceh)0*0*0*ion an adjusted basis on its four issues of dollar bonds totaling $56,278,000.

Prince Bertil of Sweden called the United States a "source of hope" to his country and pledged last night that Sweden would persevere in its resolve to maintain its independence "come dark days, come bright."

Patrick Francis Solan, a short, mild-mannered man who embarrassed New York detectives thirty years ago by solving a sensational murder case a few hours after he had been assigned to it by railroad officials, retired yesterday as superintendent of building maintenance for Grand Central Terminal.

The backseat driver has been pilloried needlessly. The butt of cartoonists and the subject for the vitriolic wit of smooth essayists, she has been scorned and denounced and rapped sharply over the knuckles of her once fair hand.

While the United States has exported in the last twelve months the largest quantity of wheat in itsh) 0*0*0*ihistory, the chances are that this record will hold for some years. Exports of wheat and flour in the season ended last midnight approximated 475,000,000 bushels.

Secretary Marshall has replied firmly, and at the same time almost too patiently, to a Russian protest of June 9 against an article which appearedh)0*0*0*iin Newsweek magazine on May 17. This article, as Mr. Marshall explained, did not urge war against Russia or any other country, but was "postulated on an assumed act of aggression against the United States."

Corporate bonds on the list of investments legal for savings banks and trust funds in this state were increased $3,000,000,000 net in the year ending today and reached more than $14,000,000,000, the highest level on record, according to an announcement issued for today by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks.
LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) -Don Bradman rattled up 84 not out today for the Australian cricket tourists, who began a three-day match with Surrey.

The resignation of Dr. John W. Studebaker as United States Commissioner of Education adds another to the long list of valued leaders who have had to leave the Federal service because they were not paid enough to live on. Dr. Studebaker's case is particularly striking both because of the long sacrifice he made to serve the nation and the high talents he brought to his office.

h)0*0*0*iThe operating expense of Beth Israel Hospital at Livingston Place and Sixteenth Street in 1947 was $1,767,652, the highest in the hospital's fifty-eight years, Charles. H. Silver, the president, said yesterday in his annual report.

John C. Hines, formerly regional manager in Philadelphia, has been appointed sales manager of AC Spark Plug Company. Wilson S. Isherwood continues as vice president of the company and general sales manager of the AC Spark Plug division of General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States reiterated today its firm intention not to be driven from Berlin by the Soviet blockade which it said "raises basic questions of serious import with which we expect to deal promptly."

Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, Commander of the First Army at Governors Island, and Byron Price, wartime head of censorship, were among thirty-seven persons honored yesterday for valuable services to the British Empire in World War II.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 26, 1948, totaled 888,582 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Andy Pafko pounded out a home run with two mates aboard to hand the St. Louis Cardinals their third straight defeat by the Chicago Cubs today, 4 to 3.

A broad investigation of reported excessive prices and inferior materials in homes sold to veterans in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware was promised yesterday by John J. Pendergast, Acting Regional Housing Expediter.

SHANGHAI, July 1 -- Official American quarters here today anticipated the conclusion of a bilateral United States agreement with China on the utilization of Economic Cooperation Administration funds just before the July 3 deadline.

The first customer of New York International Airport at Idlewild yesterday, thirteen hours after the world's biggest airport officially opened, was Donald M. Lowe, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority Soon after 1 P.M. he startled Miss Christina Murray, air traffic controller of the Civil Aeronautics Administration in the tower, with a request for landing instructions.

CORNELIUS JOHNSON had been delayed slightly in transit. The National A.A.U. track and field championship was being held at Princeton in 1936, the week before the final Olympic tryouts at Randalls Island Stadium. The situation, in effect, parallels that of this year when the Nationals will be staged today and tomorrow in Milwaukee with the Olympic trials slated a week later for Evanston, Ill. At any rate, Johnson was late.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- With present accommodations for fifteen human research patients suffering from cancer, a laboratory described as "unique" was opened today by the University of California.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 1 -- A New Jersey entrant, Pat Mucci of Preakness Hills, led the field of 127 competitors in the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association over the Wheatley Hills course today with a sub-par round of 71.

Certain as gamblers can be that the odds favor them, hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, facing a 1948 record of weather-ruined week-ends, were ready to start out today for a Glorious Fourth. Amazingly enough, the Weather Bureau last night gave encouragement to stubborn high hopes.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 29 (Delayed) -- An estimated 300,000 persons, one-fourth of Mukden's population, are slowly starving to death because of the Communist blockade and the lack of effective rationing.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Department-store sales in the week ended June 26 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board decided today to look further into the $10,000,000 loan which Howard Hughes made to Trans-Continental and Western Air, Inc., (TWA) last year. It ordered a hearing, it announced, to see whether a provision of the loan permitting the money to be converted into common stock is in the public interest.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 1 -- The three Western Military Governors, at a meeting today, authorized the Minister-Presidents of the eleven states of Western Germany to begin the formation of a federal government. The Germans delayed their response.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Southern Democrats were represented tonight as preparing to wage their party platform fight at Philadelphia beyond the focal civil rights issue and into the field of labor.
TRENTON, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- Confusion marked the beginning of New Jersey's three-cent-a-package cigarette tax today.
NANKING, July 1 -- The American Advisory Group headquarters announced today extension of its activities to include a new training center for Chinese troops in Kwangtung.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 1 -- Jerusalem, both old and new, would fly the Arab flag but would include local Zionist autonomy, under the recommendations made by Count Bernadotte, it was learned tonight from reliable sources. As far as Jerusalem itself is concerned, it is virtually certain that few Zionists would agree to such a proposal.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Gov. Earl Warren, who left his native California two weeks ago as a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, returned today to his surprised constituents as the party's nominee for Vice President and promised to wage "an active mobile campaign."

Mechanical trouble with subway turnstiles into which dirty or wet or bent dimes had been inserted caused widespread difficulties during the rush hour last night, but otherwise the first day of increased fares on the city's transit system went off fairly smoothly.

The American Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $28,960,815 for the twelve months ended with last March, compared with $27,718,816 for the similar period of the previous year. Gross operating revenues increased to $164,556,536 from $144,621,982.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, announced today that the company he formed two years ago to manufacture a rear-engined automobile would suspend operations temporarily to permit the Securities and Exchange Commission to examine all of the financial and production records of the enterprise.

BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- President Juan Peron's speech yesterday extolling the freedom of expression of thought touched off criticism in Congress today, and two Opposition parties followed up with a demand that the Argentine press and radio get the benefit of it if the President was sincere.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- The record of the Eightieth Congress was denounced as "reactionary" and its attitude toward the high cost of living was condemned as "do nothing" in a report adopted unanimously today by the American Newspaper Guild in annual convention here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- Britain defended her administration of the United Nations trust territory of Tanganyika before the Trusteeship Council today when questions were raised about the existence of certain African practices alleged to be akin to slavery.

LAST April, when John Prebble's "The Edge of the Night"* was published, I was looking unaccountably the other way. In the light of history and the long view no great harm was done, for Mr. Prebble's novel is not a major masterpiece. It isn't even an artistically successful work of fiction. Nevertheless, it is an interesting novel marked by some excellent writing and some effective reporting.
WASHINGTON, July 1--President Truman declared today that he definitely will not withdraw as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Laughing off the inquiry as ...

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 1 -- A Hungarian international fair described by Commerce Minister Sandor Ronai as "the first representative show of Hungarian nationalized industry" has just closed here. It was limited to countries of the Eastern bloc, and the greatest single exhibit was Russia's.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The national hospital construction program, under which the first project was approved only six months ago, now numbers 347 projects in forty-two states, the Public Health Service announced today.

State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale hailed yesterday the plan outlined for the reorganization of the administration of New York City's Department of Welfare as "a step in the right direction."
A six-point code of minimum editorial standards has been adopted by the publishers of about 15,000,000 of the 50,000,000 comic books sold monthly in this country, it was announced yesterday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 1 -- Pollution more than four times greater than last year resulted today in a ban on swimming and bathing and the closing of all beaches on the Hudson River under the control of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.8 per cent during the week ended June 26 to set a new post-war high point, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. At 166.7 per cent of the 1926 average, the bureau's comprehensive index was 0.7 per cent above the peak reached after World War II -- mid-January, 1948 -- and only 0.3 per cent below the May, 1920, high point.

In recent months we have repeatedly called attention to the great importance to the people of New York County of obtaining the services of an outstanding Surrogate to replace Surrogate Delehanty, who will retire at the end of this year. Candidates to be voted on at the coming November election are now being selected by the various political parties.

LONDON, July 1 (UP) -- Yugo- I slavia a/so has split with Albania, I it was disclosed tonight. As a re-I suit, Yugoslavia now is almostI ringed with hostile Communist [ parties, including those of Bulgaria, Rumania, Hungary and Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman asserted today, in reluctantly approving a Republican-sponsored housing measure, that it was another instance in which "the Eightieth Congress has failed miserably to meet the urgent needs of the people."

Mayor O'Dwyer broke completely yesterday with Tammany Hall as it now exists and threatened the formation of a new, non-predatory political organization to rival it in New York County. "Leave the present Tammany Hall down in the gutter where it belongs," the Mayor declared.

A few quality bedroom furniture producers entering the Chicago home furnishings market on a strict quota basis will be forced to accept orders from new accounts on the second or third day, several retailers predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- President Truman has signed appropriations of $5,819,659,851 to run various Government bureaus, including the Veterans Administration and the Atomic Energy Commission, through the fiscal year beginning today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 1--All Arab quarters predicted today that the Arab League Political Committee would reject the suggestions of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, for solving the Palestine problem, which it was reported, involve the creation of a "dual state," with an Arab-Israeli Central Council to "coordinate" foreign policy, defense and economics.

Tammany Hall's social and patriotic arm, the Society of Tammany, or Columbian Order, dropped a notch in its social standing last night. Mayor O'Dwyer's battle cry against Tammany district leaders who opposed his candidate for Surrogate, Vincent R. Impellitteri, left its mark.
The State Department will assume sole responsibility for all international radio programs sent out by "The Voice of America" after Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- On the numerous occasions during the past year when Senator Vandenberg was discouraging friends who wanted to make him President, the Senator always included one strong argument against the idea. Now, the very first week after the Republican National Convention at which Governor Dewey was nominated, the force of his argument is being demonstrated.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- The quarter-final round of the eastern intercollegiate tennis championship was filled today and in the process three more seeded players joined Yale's Jack Geller in the spectators gallery.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The determination of the Western Allies to remain in Berlin is expected here to be asserted emphatically in the near future either through the joint note being drafted in London by United States, British and French diplomats or in some other form should that be considered desirable in the light of last-minute developments.

Settlement of the dispute over the union shop in the "captive" coal mines operated by the principal steel companies was discussed yesterday by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and Harry M. Moses, head of the coal-producing properties of the United States Steel Corporation.

Fewer children will go to the country this summer because of the camp shortage, Mrs. Mortimer H. Hess, president of the Jewish Vacation Association, declared yesterday. The association, she explained, acts as a consultant service on communal and community camping problems.

Grand Union The Grand Union Company has declared a dividend of 25 cents on the new common stock payable on Aug. 27. The dividend is contingent on approval of a 2 1/4-for-1 split, proposed by directors on June 18. Shareholders will vote on the proposal on July 28.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics rallied in the ninth for all of their runs as they defeated the Washington Senators, 3 -- 2, tonight with Ferris Fain's double driving in two runs and Elmer Valo's single the winning tally.

The city administration did an excellent job on the overnight change-over to a higher fare on the transit system. The planning was well thought out, and considerable ingenuity was shown in the mechanics of preparing for last-minute turnstile change and barrier removal.

YANINA, Greece, July 1 -- Some of the United States Army officers who are observers and advisers with the Greek Army in the Grammos offensive say they are reminded of the warfare in the Philippines against the Japanese. Others recall the battles fought progressively in 1943-45 along the spine of the Italian peninsula and the slow taking apart of the Nazis' Gothic line.
A pre-dawn vigil was begun yesterday at 4:45 A.M. when Rosalie Halbren of this city became the first person to appear at Columbia to register for the university's forty-ninth annual summer session.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 1 (AP) -- Following are the texts of three Western Allied proposals read to the German Minister-Presidents of the three Western zones of Germany today:

MANILA, July 1 -- The Philippines will enter its third year as an independent republic on Sunday assured of a comfortable nestegg totaling nearly $100,000,000 from the United States in compliance with various legal commitments.

"The Play's the Thing" will set a Broadway precedent this summer by moving out of the Booth to play a three-week engagement at the Central City (Col.) Play Festival and then returning to the same playhouse to resume its run, it was learned yesterday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 1 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today with a fine one over women's par 37, 40 -- 77. Finishing three strokes back, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood posted 40, 40 -- 80.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 1 -- Charles Poletti, former Governor of New York, arrived here today on a mission for the Italian Government and a group of Italian industrialists offering bizonal Germany a one-year rental of 3,000 freight cars, which are short in this country.

New York International Airport is open for business. Some six years of travail and great expenditures of funds lie behind this simple announcement of a historic occasion in the city's progress which will be formally celebrated later this month. Idlewild, a vast, 5,000-acre tract, nine times as large as La Guardia Airport, was begun in April, 1942.

After a brief ceremony at Third Naval District headquarters in 90 Church Street yesterday morning Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, commandant of that area since November, 1944, took leave of his associates and entered upon the final stages of retirement in a career which included participation in the invasion of North Africa in World War II.

LONDON, July 1 -- Miss Doris Hart, 23-year-old Miami University undergraduate, today dethroned Mrs. Margaret du Pont of Delaware from her position as Wimbledon's women's singles tennis champion, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3. Miss Hart will now face Miss Louise Brough, victor over Mrs. Patricia Todd, in the women's singles Final on Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The United Packinghouse Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a resolution adopted today at the final session of a four-day annual convention, refused to support Henry A. Wallace's third-party movement.
LONDON, July 1 -- The Russian move in withdrawing from the Berlin Kommandatura brought the three Western Allies face to face again today with the necessity of making further grave decisions.

Fred Allen, whose program was numbered among the top ten shows for most of the season, dropped to thirty-eighth place in the last Hooper popularity rating, made public yesterday. The fall in the comedian's standing was attributed by the Hooper organization to the rise of "Stop the Music," which has attracted national attention by its prizes, often running into five figures.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application of the Equitable Gas Company, Pittsburgh, proposing its recapitalization. As part of its program, Equitable plans to issue and sell at competitive bidding $14,000,000 of 25-year first mortgage bonds.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed somewhat irregular, 9 points higher to 4 points lower.

A syndicate of investors has purchased from David S. Meister, operator, the five-story building at 797 Madison Avenue, between Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, containing a restaurant, travel agency and apartments. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is assessed for $75,000 and rents for $10,000 a year.

The proposed local law to control garage and parking lot rentals and rollback rates to the levels of 15 per cent above the levels of Oct. 31, 1946, would lead to a general strike of teamsters, the General Welfare Committee of the City Council was told yesterday.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser got the Detroit Tigers back onto the victory trail today as he made a relief appearance to trim the Cleveland Indians, 9 to 5, in a free-hitting game.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 1 -- President Sarah Gibson Blanding of Vassar College today conferred the B.A. degree upon 118 seniors, the last to complete their college course here in three years, under a wartime accelerated plan. At an earlier commencement, May 18, the college had conferred degrees upon 177 students graduating at the end of a normal four-year program.

Mrs. Golda Meyerson, 50 years old, newly appointed Israeli Ambassador to Russia, who arrived in this country on May 19 for a speaking tour, was injured last night in a taxicab collision at Flatbush and Eighth Avenues, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Two bids for the lease of the famous Government-owned Belasco Theatre were submitted to the Federal Works Agency today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- The Republic of Indonesia appealed to the United Nations Security Council today to try to break the deadlock in the East Indies or appoint a mediator.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks, timed to meet the next reduction of its bill issue on July 8. Under the call the banks will be required to provide 10 per cent of such balances as of the close of business on June 30, payable on the July date.

"High John the Conqueror," a first novel by John W. Wilson, will be published by Macmillan Oct. 19. It is a story of an uneducated Southern Negro and his life as a farmer in the Brazos country of Texas. Mr. Wilson, a veteran of Okinawa and a graduate student at Southern Methodist University, is the winner of the first annual Dallas Daily Times Herald Award for Creative Writing.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The strange case of Marshal Tito and Communist Information Bureau continues to interest and delight Washington.
FUKUI, Japan, July 1 (AP) -- Rain pelted funeral pyres in Fukui today, adding to the misery of the thousands made homeless by earthquakes and fires.

The congregation of Christ Lutheran Church will hold a specially called business meeting Wednesday at 8 P.M. in the chapel of the Presbyterian Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street, to vote on the question of signing a contract for its new edifice.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Veterans of the second World War who join reserve units in the early stages of the Army expansion program virtually are assured of choice of service at the highest grades they attained in active duty, an authoritative Army spokesman pointed out today.

Japanese Christians contributed more than $300,000 toward a proposed Christian University in the vicinity of Tokyo, according to an announcement yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Carl D. Kriete, former president of Miyagi College, Japan.

The president of a stock company took the unusual action yesterday of joining with the State Attorney General in asking the Supreme Court to ban the sale of securities in his company on the ground that its affairs were being mismanaged.

Marketing for the holiday weekend should not be difficult today, for reports on most foods indicate plentiful supplies. Meat, with the exception of pork, is more than ample to meet the lagging demand, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
A gift of $1,618,171, made for philanthropic purposes by Arthur Curtiss James, remains part of the estate of the late Mrs. Vera Scott Cushman, Surrogate William T. Collins ruled yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- Warner Brothers has assigned Charles Hoffman to write a photoplay under the title "Charge It, My Love" as a prospective vehicle for Ronald Reagan and Eleanor Parker, who were last seen together in "The Voice of the Turtle."

BERLIN, July 1 -- The Russians withdrew today from the Allied Kommandatura for Berlin, the last operative quadripartite governing body in Germany, and completed the division of the city between the East and West.

BERLIN, July 1 -- To finance the activities of the Communist party in the Western zones, the Soviet Military Administration is planning to acquire large amounts of Western zone currency through black market dealings in this city, reliable German sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Central Vfaine Power Company, Augusta, ]Vie., filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $5,000,000 of first and general mortgage bonds, series Q, due 1978.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Grain markets showed strength in the early trading on the Board of Trade today but corn and oats reacted from the best prices under profit taking and pressure from traders who bought early. Wheat held within a range of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel and closed 1/8 to 1/2 cent higher.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 -- For the first time since it was built fifty-three years ago the Breakers, famous villa built by Cornelius Vanderbilt, was open to the public today.

The forces of resistance aroused by the new Russian imperialism -- forces which have already produced the West-European Union on the one hand and the Yugoslav defection from the Russian bloc on the other -- have likewise produced a new Western unity in respect to Germany.

Considerable publicity was given in the papers and over the radio in reference to probable new procedure to be instituted by the Department of Housing and Buildings to put "teeth" in the Multiple Dwelling Law by summoning the owner to court if a violation is not corrected in sixty days.

CINCINNATI, July 1 (AP) -- Fritz Ostermueller pitched the Pirates to a 5-2 victory over Cincinnati today and to within a half-game of the second-place St. Louis Cardinals in the National League pennant chase.
Three taxpayer parcels constituted the bulk of the realty trading in the Bronx in transactions there reported yesterday by brokers.

VIENNA, July 1 -- Austria's tiny Communist party took a very firm line today against the Yugoslav claims for annexation of part of the Austrian province of Carinthia. The official party paper, Volkestimme, which blew hot and cold on the issue of frontiers as long as the Soviet Union was backing the Yugoslav claims, stated:
BISMARCK, N.D., July 1 (UP) -- Catholic nuns and priests have been prohibited from teaching in North Dakota's public schools, nearly complete returns for the state's primary election showed today.

Three developments indicated that a large-scale shift to f.o.b. mill pricing methods may take place in many industries in addition to the cement business, leading industrial executives revealed here yesterday.

The Downing Building, a fifteen-story office and mercantile structure at 106-08 Fulton Street and 14 Dutch Street tenanted largely by firms in the jewelry trade, has been sold by the trustees of Columbia University to a corporation headed by Joseph and Mollier Schlesinger. It forms an "L" around the corner of Fulton and Dutch Streets and is assessed for $450,000.

In the first statement of condition since its acquisition of the Continental Bank Trust Company of New York, the Chemical Bank Trust Company yesterday reported as of June 30, 1948, deposits of $1,360,694,693, and total assets of $1,515,183,172.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Dr. Perrin H. Long, Professor of Preventive Medicine at Johns Hopkins University, will preside over a meeting here on July 6 of the special advisory committee from the medical and allied professions to plan medical aspects of civil defense in event of an attack on this country, the office of the Secretary of Defense announced today.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP)--Two ancient veterans of the links--51-year-old Joe Kirkwood and 46-year-old Gene Sarazen--stepped out today to show the young fry a thing or two in the $15,000 Motor City open.

Twelve navigators of Pan American Airways picketed before the main entrance of the International Air Terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon in what they said was a protest against the airline's refusal to arbitrate issues involved in a contract renewal.

National and international expansion of public health programs will place increasing demands on the pharmaceutical, biological and related industries, while at the same time offering them greater opportunities for important service, it was predicted yesterday by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

The big loser in the April elections in Italy was the Socialist party. Under the leadership of Pietro Nenni, it became the wagging tail of the Communists, and thereby lost its unity, its independence, its program and its prestige. In the resounding defeat of the coalition it lost its political influence to the dissidents who fell away before the election and are now an important part of the Government.

Bernard Price, 154 Nassau Street, who owns a water tank manufacturing business in Weehawken, N.J., and a World War II veteran, has become the first American manufacturer of steel products to buy all of his steel requirements in Belgium, importers here said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, in a message on the eve of the fifty-first annual convention here of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted that the establishment of the Republic of Israel "is a good omen for the free world as well as for its striving for justice and liberty everywhere."

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 -- Military personnel of this seaport area gave a surprise farewell to Admiral Raymond A. Spruance today as he left Newport to enter retirement after forty-five years of distinguished naval service.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States pledged redoubled efforts today in its drive for a more efficient and less expensive Government during the period of the next Congress. Earl O. Shreve, the chamber's president, stated that his organization could render "no greater service to business men and citizens generally" than to work for a reorganized Government whose costs can be borne "without undue burden on our economy."

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1 (AP) -- Ernest Dubray of Lowell High School, San Francisco, Calif., entered the semi-finals of the national interscholastic tennis tournament today with a 9-7, 6-4 triumph over Bill Long of Newton High School, Elmhurst, N.Y.
It is a peculiar but well-attested fact, as even the most literal scientist will admit, that there is much more weather in the country than there is in the city.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 1 -- A man came from his car today, walked down the bank to the edge of Kensico Reservoir, saw a bass a couple of feet from a concrete wall, hooked on a minnow, made a short cast, waited awhile, then hooked the bass and netted it. The entire operation took a little more than a minute. The fish appeared to weigh a pound and a half to two pounds.

LONDON, July 1--British officials appeared today to have reached the conclusion that the Western powers had better not try to interfere in the conflict between Belgrade and Moscow. It is a family quarrel within the Communist fold, according to the understanding here.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, July 1 -- The country will face an acute shortage of elementary teachers when schools reopen this September, educators attending the National Conference on the Education of Teachers warned today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman ended an anxious moment for American industry today as he disavowed any intention at this time of placing the Government once again in control of the distribution of steel.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- There is not a person in this country who has not been benefited by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today at the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the bureau.

With the opening of the Democratic national convention at Philadelphia twelve days away, activities aimed at the nomination of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas for the Presidency were stepped up here yesterday by liberal Democrats working through three organizations. Leaders of the groups said they intended to combine their efforts during the convention at headquarters at the Sylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- While guns boomed a salute and an all-service guard of honor rendered honors, President and Mrs. Truman and a large number of officials welcomed President Romulo Gallegos of Venezuela and Senora Gallegos upon their arrival here today for a twelve-day state visit.

The living standard inequities brought on by inflation are undermining the social and civic responsibility of the middle classes and are creating the seeds of economic depression, warns the July Monthly Bank Letter of the National City Bank, published today.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 1 -- On the fourth day since Francis Higgins, 28-year-old burglary inmate, was missed during the 5:30 P.M. prisoner count on Monday, he was found today by guards in a two-foot-wide manhole inside the walls of Sing Sing.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- A charge that Western "freedom of speech" meant "freedom for the reactionaries to slander" was made before the International Labor Conference today by Tseko Etropolski, Bulgarian Government delegate.

Loans to finance companies were the principal factor in a rise of $12,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks last week. According to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the week ended on Wednesday, such loans actually were higher than indicated but the total was offset by repayments.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company's report for 1947, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $475,414, compared with $273,940 in 1946. Gross operating revenues of $6,645,934 compared with $6,515,545 in the previous year.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Knee-deep in trouble all the way, Clint Hartung managed to stay even with Johnny Sain and the Braves until the seventh inning in the finale at Braves Field today. Then the New York righthander got himself into another jam, but this time there was no escape.

Inside the United States people are employed, money is plentiful. So it seems and so we will continue to inhale the lethal dope of "continued prosperity" -- until another crisis jolts us into feverish activity to do something about it. Then we dig into our enormous potential and again bring forth a miracle of readjustment.

With the departure of buyers for home, slowed-up activity in New York's wholesale markets yesterday portended the approach of the holiday week-end. Orders placed in the last week-were mainly for midseason dresses and sportswear, according to trade sources, with heavy emphasis on merchandise for promotional events.

A peace-time record total of 36,577,000 net tons of shipping passed through the Suez Canal last year, according to the directors' report delivered at the annual general meeting of the Suez Canal Company, held last month in Paris.
Paterson, N.J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids July 13 on $2,200,000 of emergency housing bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948, and due Aug. 1 from 1949 to 1973.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- Princeton University's lightweight crew and Kent School of Connecticut knifed into the quarter-finals of the Thames Challenge Cup competition today.

John Ellis, Navy veteran, was designated yesterday for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District to oppose Representative Vito Marcantonio, State and New York County Chairman of the American Labor party.

Paul L. Ross, former chairman of the City Rent Commission, charged in a complaint filed in Federal court yesterday that the section of the National Housing and Rent Act permitting the Federal Housing Expediter to grant rent increases in "hardship" cases was unconstitutional.

Before the season's second-smallest paid attendance at Ebbets Field, 5,602, yesterday, the Phils completed a sweep of the three-game series by beating the Brooks, 4 -- 2, behind the eight-hit pitching of the superannuated Schoolboy Rowe.

Negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation, the industry's leading producer, and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, on the question of a wage increase have been reopened and the union is seeking an increase of "at least 12 1/2 or 13 cents an hour," a high union official said yesterday.

ROME, July 1 -- A clear trend away from a policy hitherto followed of blind, unquestioning collaboration with the Communists was evidenced at the close of the twenty-seventh Socialist party congress in Genoa this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Army reaffirmed its confidence today in the Twenty-seventh Infantry Division, New York National Guard, which figured in a stormy wartime controversy, by awarding a unit citation to the 105th Regiment of the division.

PASADENA, Calif., July 1 -- Studies revealing the existence of a new electrical shell around the earth at a height of about 250 miles were described here today at the joint meeting of the American Astronomical Society and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific by Dr. Donald H. Menzel of the Harvard University observatory.

Construction has started on thirty homes in the Cold Spring Terrace development north of Jericho Turnpike, east of East Gate Drive, Cold Spring Hills, L.I., it was reported yesterday by John L. Loesel, president of Cold Spring Hills, Inc.

Exploiting an ancient precept that he who gets in the first damaging blow quite often wins the battle, the Yankees let the Red Sox have both barrels in the opening round of the series finale at the Stadium yesterday before 25,295 paying clients and 7,000 wildly cheering youngsters.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United States is proceeding on the assumption that the ten-power conference on freedom of navigation of the Danube River will be held in Belgrade on July 30 as scheduled, regardless of the developments surrounding Marshal Tito, the State Department said today. All preparations are being made here on that basis, it was added.

PARIS, July 1 -- Pierre Henri Teitgen, Minister of the Armed Forces, told the National Assembly today that the Government had no idea of abandoning the territory of Metropolitan France in case of war, and said he would resign if military planning tended in that direction.
William J. Thomas has been appointed general sales manager of the Babcock Wilcox Tube Company. He formerly was assistant general sales manager.
WASHINGTON July 1 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation said today production of new freight cars soon may receive another setback.

The era of the self-service laundry has now progressed to the point where housewives may take damp-dry clothes from a half-hour laundry to a nearby Ironette store and press the family wash on electric ironers. A self-service ironing store, believed to be the first devoted exclusively to reducing the drudgery of pressing, is now open at 63-08 Thirty-ninth Avenue, in Woodside, Queens.

Pickets paraded before the main entrance to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night protesting a concert featuring Leonard Bernstein, as conductor and piano soloist, and Frances Magnes, violinist. The concert was sponsored by the Palestine Resistance-Defense Fund and the pickets stated they represented the Labor Zionist Organization of America -- Paole Zion.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 9.5 per cent in June, compared with the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MILWAUKEE, July 1 -- A banner field of 525 athletes, including all the top United States Olympic prospects except Mel Patton and Chuck Fonville, and further distinguished by the presence of Jamaica's Herbert McKenley and Panama's Lloyd La Beach, was ready tonight for the sixtieth National A.A.U. track and field championships.

Coincident with the announcement that Robert W. Wolcott, its chairman, has just left for Germany at the request of Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer to facilitate the flow of German scrap metal to the United States, the domestic Joint Steel, Foundry and Scrap Industries Committee for Expediting Iron and Steel Scrap disclosed yesterday that the nation urgently needs 3,000,000 tons of German scrap.

Almost eight tons of blood plasma, drugs, hospital equipment and food, 350 items in all, left La Guardia Field for Israel last night aboard a plane chartered by Hadassah the women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Committee warned today that the fuel oil outlook for New England and the New York area next winter showed only the slimmest margin of safety. Continued conservation by consumers is essential, the subcommittee said.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 1 -- Jews throughout the world were called upon today by the assembly of the World Jewish Congress to resist any attempt to "diminish the sovereignty or to reduce the territory" of the State of Israel.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 30 (Delayed) -- About 300,000 Nationalist troops are entrenched in the isolated Mukden quadrangle, which has one-sixth of Manchuria's population and about 1 per cent of its area. Aided by air-lifted supplies from China proper, these troops are maintaining the Government's foothold by relying on the small remains of what was once a wealthy industrial and agricultural economy.

Stockholders of the First National Bank Trust Company, Bayshore, L.I., have subscribed to the whole offering of 4,000 shares of the bank's common stock at $50 a share, R.H. Johnson Co., underwriters, announced yesterday.
Governor Dewey said last night that he hoped that Colonel Marcus' death in action would stimulate the United Nations to bring peace in Palestine.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- The Soviet Union served formal notice today of its intention to veto the application of Ceylon for admission to membership in the United Nations.

WEST POINT, July 1 -- Col. David Marcus, who died as commander of Israeli forces at Jerusalem three weeks ago, returned here today on his last journey twenty-eight years to the day after he arrived as a "plebe" from Brooklyn.
Operations of the Superior Oil Company of California in the nine months ended with last May resulted in a net income of $13,498,263 after all charges, it was reported yesterday.

CANTERBURY, England, July 1 -- The greatest of all Lambeth Conferences, in which 330 Bishops and Archbishops of the Anglican Communion are taking part, held its opening religious service today have in the ancient "Mother Church" of Canterbury.
PARIS, July 1 -- Premier Robert Schuman in an address to the nation tonight announced the start of a price-reduction campaign to avert the necessity for wage increases before autumn.

Nostalgic memories of days not spent within constant sight of paved streets. hard sidewalks, large brick and stone buildings, are stirred afresh when I read those bucolic editorials that appear almost every day in the southeast section of the part devoted to editorials proper.

Preliminary work has begun on the drafting of a platform for the Democratic National Convention, and a list of more than fifty prospective witnesses has been compiled. Presumably the party will have little difficulty with its foreign-policy planks. Here it can be expected confidently to give a strong endorsement to the whole Truman-Marshall program.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A three-man emergency fact-finding board appointed by President Truman ended hearings today in the disputes between National Air Lines and its pilots, clerks and mechanics.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 1 (AP) -- Henry Cotton turned the British open golf championship into a British picnic today with a record-breaking 66 for a 36-hole total of 137 that left the seven remaining Americans far in the ruck at the halfway mark.

"Hatter's Castle," Paramount's adaptation of the A.J. Cronin novel, with Robert Newton, Deborah Kerr, James Mason and Emlyn Williams heading the cast, will have its local premiere this morning at the Ambassador. I. Goldsmith produced and Lance Comfort directed the drama.

The planned expansion of the Israeli ports of Tel Aviv and Haifa will cost close to $40,000,000 and in Tel Aviv alone will permit the handling of 750,000 tons of cargo a year and 1,000 passengers a day, Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, said yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 1 (UP) -- A new issue of the Journal of the Communist Information Bureau was published here today and it was believed that the entire headquarters had been established in Bucharest in a Communist boycott of Marshal Tito.

The 300 Protestant ministers who recently advocated that the youth of America defy the draft law have rendered their faith a disservice, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of the Christian Herald magazine and a member of the President's Civilian Advisory Commission on Universal Military Training, said yesterday.

In his letter printed June 29 Horst Mendershausen recommends breaking the stranglehold of the Russians on Berlin by sending "Army patrols of the Western Powers to the strategic points along the Helmstedt-Berlin railroad and highway lines, and to move in repair and maintenance crews under military protection to establish a pontoon bridge over the Elbe and other facilities where necessary."

I read with interest your editorial entitled "Inflation and Farm Prices." I note that you say that "as everyone knows from the experience of the last decade, farm prices lead the inflation procession; they do not follow it."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 1 -- Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, Foreign Minister of the Ukraine, who took over today as chairman of the Security Council for July, plans to attack the "suggestions" advanced this week by Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, usually reliable sources said tonight.

Evidence of an increase in the number of industrial development advertising campaigns, which totaled 156 last year, was reported yesterday by the J.R. Pershall Company, Chicago advertising agency. On the basis of a recent study, the agency learned that expenditures for this type of campaign amounted to $1,929,794 in eighty-two publications during 1947.
Twelve police officers were raised in rank by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander at a ceremony in his office yesterday noon. Nine received new assignments.

Pre-holiday influences were at work yesterday in the stock market and, with scant interest in evidence, prices drifted narrowly throughout the session and closed irregularly lower. Even the oils were somewhat neglected and only a few stocks showed variations beyond fractions. The price averages fell 0.30 point on the day.

MT. KISCO, N.Y., July 1 -- The sixth annual Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Counties Golf Association, a match play against par in which three-fourths of individual handicap is allowed, was won by Mrs. Joseph Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A special House investigating committee asserted today that by "conservative estimate" 823 Federal officials and employes had netted $10,000,000 to $20,000,000 in unhidden commodity speculation in 1946 and 1947.

As the machinery for tallying the expected 45,000 votes of members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was set in motion yesterday morning by the Honest Ballot Association, Howard McKenzie, NMU vice president, made public a letter to the organization demanding the removal of George J. Abrams from his post as supervisor of the ballot counting.

LONDON, July 1 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin's grave warning in the House of Commons yesterday on the Berlin situation effectively checked business in the stock market here today and prices eased all around.

Julius Kayser Co. has reduced the price of its 51 gauge, 15 denier nylon hosiery to $14 a dozen to permit lowering of the retail price from $2.25 a pair to $1.95, it was announced yesterday. The new retail price will become effective Aug. 1.

A program composed chiefly of Italian operatic music was presented last night at the Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra before an audience of 14,000. Alfredo Antonini, who had not appeared previously at these concerts, was the conductor.

A feature as such was lacking at Aqueduct yesterday but there was a race for 2-year-old fillies that may have served as a criterion for future activity among the young runners. The event was the Nahma, a five-and-a-half-furlong burst that attracted a field of eight, and which was won by the Sanmar Stable's Pompous, a promising daughter of Roman and Your Grace.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 1 -- Harvard, Yale and the West Side Rowing Club of Buffalo, a surprise winner over Wisconsin, joined Washington, Cornell, California and Princeton in the semi-finals of the United States Olympic rowing trials for eight-oared crews today. Tomorrow, these seven will slug it out over the 2,000-meter course on Cargenie Lake to qualify three for Saturday's final.

Santo (Sal) Bretagna and Willie (Farbie) Rosenberg, who had been on trial since June 21 for the murder of Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, were found guilty yesterday by a General Sessions jury in the first degree. The verdict carries a mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Governor Dewey drew a sharp distinction today between the phases of American foreign policy that have been the subject of bipartisan collaboration and those on which Republican leaders have not been consulted in advance. He indicated that those in the latter class would be the subject of major criticism in the Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Associate Justice T. Alan Goldsborough, in the United States District Court, agreed today to the Government's request to make permanent the temporary injunction he had issued banning a strike by the engineers' and firemen's brotherhoods and the Switchmen's Union of North America. He will sign the order at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 1--The Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party, maneuvering for position against the combined attack from the other Soviet-bloc states, singled out ...
New Yorkers stood up bravely yesterday in spirit and in flesh in their first tests as ten-cent underground riders, but the subways' mechanical gadgetry proved weak.

Religious instruction under released time plans in religious vacation schools and other classes was received in the last year by 1,078,436 Roman Catholic public school children in 13,671 special religion classes or schools, according to the 126th Catholic directory just published by P.J. Kenedy Sons.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Commerce Department reported today $6,080,000,000 worth of new construction work in the first five months of this year, a gain of more than one-third over the same period of 1947.

ROME, July 2 -- All Italy was tied up from noon to midnight today by a general strike that was described by the Italian Confederation of Labor as a "first measure" to obtain increased wages for skilled industrial workers.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -The Pennsylvania Railroad today announced the awarding of three scholarships available to children of railroad employes.

Seventy delegates and official observers representing 3,000,000 members of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts in twenty-four countries will attend the World Conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts at Cooperstown, N.Y., from Aug. 13 to 23.

RICHMOND, Va., July 2 -- Virginia's twenty-six delegates to the forthcoming Democratic National Convention were instructed today to vote and work for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination. If President Truman should be selected the Virginia State Central Committee would have power by two-thirds vote to call a resumed state convention here and put its weight behind some other candidate.

Spurred by the recent action of the Magnavox Company, which granted a 34 per cent trade discount on its new television receiver line, retailers will intensify efforts to secure larger profit margins from volume manufacturers, Alexander Lewi, chairman of the television subcommittee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's vendor relations committee, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Saturday, July 3 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, demanded the lifting of the Soviet land blockade of Berlin in a letter to Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander, early today.

A meeting yesterday morning of the Honest Ballot Association committee on labor elections resulted in a decision to adhere to the committee's original plans for handling the vote count in the elections of the National Maritime Union that closed at midnight Wednesday.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $125,000,000 of new bonds designed to refund debt of the old New York City Tunnel Authority, and to finance the completion of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and an adjacent municipal parking garage project.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- American Buslines, Inc., of Chicago, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve an issue of $1,500,000 of debentures, 100,000 shares of cumulative preferred and 349,930 shares of common stock, all shares of no par value.

New Stages, Inc., the downtown group which made good with JeanPaul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute," is about to acquire the rights to the late Thomas Wolfe's 'Mannerhouse," it was learned yesterday. Contracts with the estate of the distinguished American novelist are expected to be signed over the week-end.
Four passenger ships sailed yesterday for Europe and South America and seven more are scheduled to leave today on similar services in one of the busiest week-ends of the summer shipping season.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- Two home runs by Joe Gordon, each with Manager Lou Boudreau on base, enabled the Cleveland Indians to take an 8-to-6 slugfest from the St. Louis Browns tonight and retain their slender hold on first place.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Truman was informed today that the shipping industry will be canvassed immediately to determine possibilities for committing $178,000,000 for new merchant ships under present subsidies, rather than proposed larger subsidies which Congress failed to approve.
A fake accident claim racket that defrauded the Third Avenue Transit Corporation of $15,000 in the last sixteen months was bared last night by the Bronx District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal today named Harold B. Hinton as assistant to the Secretary, Office of Public Information, to coordinate public relations in the national defense establishment. Mr. Hinton will take a leave of absence from his assignment in the Washington bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, of which he has been a member since 1932.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The White House denied today that George Allen, former White House intimate, was seeking, as President Truman's agent, another declaration from General Eisenhower that he would not enter the Presidential race.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Governor Dewey said today that this country was committed to make a $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations to finance the construction of its headquarters in New York and expressed belief that "the commitment will be carried out."

In the midst of the greatest massexodus from the city for the longFourth of July week-end which historyhas recorded, New Yorkers, like thepeople of other great American cities,are today confronted also with greaterhazards, at least on the strgets androads, tltn ever before.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- Charles Oliver, of the United States Military Academy showed his No. 1 seeding was no fluke today by smashing into the semifinal round of the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship with a 6-0, 6-0 conquest of John Moses of Yale.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- The White House has taken steps to persuade Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to issue a public statement over the week-end irrevocably removing himself as a possible Democratic Presidential nominee. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch said today.
LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -The Australian cricket tourists defeated Surrey today by ten wickets and gained their sixteenth successive victory of the trip.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- With Lefty Lou Brissie turning in an artistic six-hitter, the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 2, tonight before 33,989 fans. It was the Mackmen's ninth triumph in their last ten starts and their fourth in a row at Fenway Park this season.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 2 (AP) -- The Federation of Malaya Government announced today removal of a forty-year-old special duty on unsmelted tin ore destined for smelters outside the British Empire.

Independence Day will be observed by the churches of all faiths tomorrow. Bells in the steeples will be rung, sermons on our American heritage, freedom, will be preached, military and patriotic organizations will hold special services, and at all altars prayers will be offered for the improvement of international relations.
Evansville, Ind., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on July 14 on $1,500,000 of school bonds dated July 15, 1948, and due semi-annually from July 1, 1949, to July 1, 1963.

WICHITA, Kan., July 2 (AP) -Unheralded Richard (Dick) Price Of Wichita sank a fifteen-foot putt on the seventeenth hole for a 3-and-1 victory over the defending champion, Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., in the third-round play of the Western amateur golf tournament today.

" Black Ivory," a new novel by Norman Collins, will be published Aug. 12 by Duell, Sloan Pearce. Set in the early nineteenth century, the book deals with the adventures of a 14-year-old boy along the Ivory Coast. Mr. Collins is the author of "Dulcimer Street."

Busloads of cheering youngsters departed yesterday for upstate camps. While the railway exodus on camps specials bound for distant points decreased, and train personnel concentrated on the adult holiday week-end crowd, the coach camp cavalcade reached a new high.

The favorite's number went up on the board in the top spot when the Sanford Stud Farms' Britannicus III led five other jumpers from start to finish of the $10,000 added Forget Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. A 2-to-1 investment, the French-bred 5-yearold gelding made good by a length at the end of the "about two miles" of running and hurdling.

HELSINKI, Finland, Saturday, July 3 -- The Finnish Communists appear to have suffered a crushing defeat in the Diet elections, for which the balloting ended last night and the counting of votes is now in process.

Second-day operation yesterday of the New York City Transit System under the higher fare schedule was much smoother than on Thursday, with less turnstile trouble, fewer questions, and a wider acceptance by the public, transit officials reported last night.
ATHENS, July 2 (AP) -- Greek Army troops plugged away at dogged rebel defenders in northern Greece today as the Government's Grammos offensive showed signs of gaining momentum.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Judge William J. Campbell in United States District Court today ordered the Tucker Corporation to open its financial and production records for examination by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Charles R. Denny has been elected executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, Niles Trammell, president of NBC, announced yesterday after a regular monthly meeting of the board. The directors chose Gustav B. Margraf, Washington legal representative, to succeed Mr. Denny as vice president and general attorney.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -United States exports declined in May for the second consecutive month. This drop came despite increased shipments under the European Recovery Program, then in its second active month.

That tumult and shouting you hear still echoing through New York was the sound of 866,000 school children bursting from their classrooms. Forgotten already are reading, writing and 'rithmetic. Like a vast herd of frolicsome colts, these youngsters are flocking now to the pastures of vacation land.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary of State Marshall revealed today in a prepared statement that the United States had demanded of the Soviet Union the immediate return of twenty-eight naval frigates and three ice breakers that were turned over to the Russians during the war under Lend-Lease.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a revision of certain of its divisional functions in an effort to increase operating efficiency.

The Rev. Dr. John Short, pastor of the Richmond Hill Congregational Church, Bournemouth, England, will be the preacher tomorrow at the 11 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. worship and at both services on the other Sundays of this month in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

In describing Latvia's position Boris J. Lurie, who professes to be a former Latvian citizen although he has never registered with the Latvian Legation or consulates, seems to have forgotten that there existed a Latvia before 1934. The "Politiska Parvalde," or Political Police, so disliked by him, was hated by Communists and Fascists also.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Army today asked business men to give their employes leaves of absence for military training or active duty with reserve organizations.

The seven-week strike of 215 grave diggers and other members of Local 293, United Cemetery Workers, CIO, at the Green Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn, ended yesterday when 180 members of the local ratified a contract at a meeting held in White Eagle Hall, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-third Street Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- Following is the text of the proposed international convention concerning freedom of association and protection of the right to organize, as approved this evening by the International Labor Conference Committee dealing with these subjects:

Police experts conceded yesterday that William C. MacLaren is the finest safecracker around. Shortly thereafter, they began legal proceedings to return MacLaren to jail for practicing his craft without permission.

New York International Airport at Idlewild collected its first airplane revenue yesterday when Capt. Fred Smith, manager of Island Air Ferries, paid $3.43 for landing a DC-3 at the world's largest commercial airfield on a familiarization flight.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 2 -Shipowners all over the world are watching with apprehension the fight of the Auckland Waterside Workers Union to have hatch covers on all overseas vessels lifted by winches instead of by hand.
In the absence of decisive word from Washington, the city's consumers have won at least the first round in the current milk-price controversy, it became certain yesterday.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, July 2 -- Answering the question "What makes a good teacher?" school leaders attending the National Conference on the Education of Teachers outlined a ten-point credo for effective teaching.

Tommy Byrne threw everything he had into a desperate bid to move the Yankees near the top of the American League last night before 34,375 fans at the Stadium, but his best wasn't quite good enough and the Yankees went down to defeat at the hands of the Senators in twelve tingling innings.

Bailey B. Burritt executive director of the National Health Council, who served for many years prior to 1944 as senior executive director of the Community Service Society of New York, has resigned from all activities in the public health field, it was announced yesterday by Philip R. Mather, president of the council.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- Reports by Philadelphia banks for the first six months of this year showed today higher deposits, gains in surpluses and larger undivided profits.

TRENTON N.J., July 2 -Spencer Miller Jr., New Jersey Highway Commissioner, who has been a hold-over since his term expired April 29, received a temporary reappointment today from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. Mr. Miller lives in South Orange.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The American Newspaper Guild today established a pattern, including a five - day, thirty - five - hour week among its objectives, for future collective bargaining and denounced the action of The Washington Star in discharging a reporter because he admitted he was a Communist.
