Although a percentage comparison between department store sales this week and the corresponding week last year is difficult because of variations in the number of business days, heavy demand for summer merchandise was evident for the first time because of "normal" summer weather.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 2 -Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Deputy Chief of Staff, pictured the Army tonight as a progressive, advance guard of democracy and asserted that "false charges of militarism" threatened its fine record and national security.

MONTREUX Switzerland, July 2 -- Charges that the delegation from the United States is trying to rig the new constitution of the World Jewish Congress to assure perpetual control by Jewish groups in the United States have been made by Eastern European delegations at closed committee sessions of the Congress Assembly, it was learned today.
That resounding crash that echoed through the environs of Flatbush last night was the headlong dive of the 1947 champion Dodgers into the National League cellar.

Encouraged by good weather the last couple of days and with a long holiday week-end ahead, the fishing brethren can be expected to do the most furious stirring of lake, bay and ocean waters of the entire season starting before dawn today.

Meyer Troysky of 911 Fox Street, the Bronx, received yesterday from the Police Department property clerk a yellow metal bracelet with stones valued at $250 that he had found Feb. 1 in a snow bank. Mr. Troysky was not cheerful about it, however.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Wellinformed Democrats predicted today that if Governor Dewey was elected President in November a likely result would be a rush by Democratic state administrations to ratify the Republican-proposed constitutional amendment barring third terms.
Dwight B. Eldred has been named assistant sales manager of the United States tires division of the United States Rubber Company. He formerly was central division manager at Chicago.

Activity and strength in the railroad issues produced yesterday an abrupt reversal of form in the stock market. The pre-holiday influences prevalent on Thursday were brushed aside by followers of the carriers which bid favorite stocks up as high as 8 points in Nickel Plate, although the combined averages showed an increase of only approximately a point.
LONDON, July 2 -- Still under the influence of the uncertainties in Berlin, most sections of the stock market here today were weaker.

Charybdis of the East River Fleet, City Island, owned by Herbert Hild, yesterday won the opening test of the United States Star Class Olympic tryouts sponsored by the Sheepshead Bay Yacht Club. A fleet of seven craft participated in the ten and one-half mile race, the first of five to decide the boat to represent this country in the Olympics.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, a delegate to the Democratic-National Convention from the Seventeenth Congressional District, urged yesterday that General Dwight D. Eisenhower be drafted by the convention for the nomination for President.

Lumber production for the week ended June 26 was 3 per cent above the preceding week and 6.8 per cent above last year. Shipments were up 11.3 per cent and orders 9.5 per cent compared with a year ago, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Cotton futures yesterday closed 2 to 18 points net lower influenced by further evening-up in July futures prior to the last trading day for that month on the New York Cotton Exchange on July 14.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 2--Washington was a tenth of a second too late. By that thin margin the champions of Poughkeepsie lost to California today and so missed the boat that will take either the Golden Bears, Harvard or Princeton to London as the crew to represent the United States in the Olympic Games.

Gray iron castings are now being quoted 1/2 cent a pound higher than in the first half of the year, foundry executives revealed here yesterday. The increase, which became effective July 1, was made because of higher labor and material costs, coupled with reflection of an approximate increase of $2 per ton in average costs of heavy cast scrap, now being purchased at about $64 to $66 per ton in the New York area.
BOLIVAR, Mo., July 2 (AP) -Bolivar rushed through a state of "orderly confusion" today as it completed preparations for the day its 3,000 residents expect to be the biggest in its 112-year history.

The proper study of New Yorkers is New York. These two new books -- "New York: The World's Capital City,"* by Cleveland Rodgers and Rebecca B. Rankin, and "New York City," by the Editors of Look -- provide suitable and entertaining enlightenment. After all, we shouldn't leave it entirely up to Mr. Whalen to toot the wreathed horn.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 2 -With a record volume of motor traffic rushing into the lower Catskill region today, the guiding precept of thousands of motorists was "come haste to the holiday."

Advancements in agriculture plus speedy transportation are said to have done away with "seasons" in produce. We savor green peas in January as well as June; leafy salads are almost as usual in winter as summer.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 2 (AP) -- Henry Cotton coasted to his third British open golf championship by a five-stroke margin today, fourteen years after he first rocketed to international fame by ending American domination of the event in 1934.

Two films, one an import from Russia, will open in local theatres today. At the Gotham the new attraction will be the Republic melodrama, "I, Jane Doe," with Ruth Hussey, John Carroll and Vera Ralston heading the cast. John H. Auer directed from a screen play by Lawrence Kimble.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Foreign oil investments in Venezuela will remain undisturbed, and the present production of 1,300,000 barrels daily is capable of being stepped up to the high total of 4,000,000, Romulo Gallegos, President of the Latin American republic, said today.

DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- Age gave way to stamina today in the $15,000 Motor City open golf tournament as tall E. J. (Dutch) Harrison charged in with a four-underpar 33, 34 -- 67 for sole possession of the halfway lead with 137 for thirty-six holes.

Sales of grills, thermos, bottles, ice jugs and other picnic and barbecue equipment have boomed for the last few days, with the peak reached yesterday, according to housewares buyers. One large department store buyer reported that his volume is up at least 60 per cent compared with last week and added that the long Independence Day week-end and improved weather are responsible for most of the gain.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -Retail sales in May totaled $10,670,000,000, a drop of 2 per cent from April, the Department of Commerce estimated today. Compared with May, 1947, however, sales this year were up 6 per cent.

TOKYO, July 2 -- The decision of the eleven-nation court trying Hideki Tojo, former dictator of Japan, and other Japanese war criminals will be reached on a basis of "logic and common sense," Sir William Webb, the presiding justice, told Tokyo correspondents today.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The Government today named nearly 500 eye specialists throughout the nation as defendants in its price-fixing suit against Bausch Lomb Optical Company, Rochester, N.Y., and three subsidiaries.

Plans for the new $5,500,000 Brooklyn Remand Shelter and City Prison, to replace the old City Prison (Raymond Street Jail), were filed yesterday in the Brooklyn Building Department, Borough President John Cashmore announced.

Hailing President Truman's decision not to exercise the power to allocate steel distribution that was accorded him in the Ploeser rider to the draft law, spokesmen of the domestic steel industry said yesterday that the nation's economy could be harmed more than helped by mandatory Federal controls over steel.
The movement to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic nomination for President and to prevent the nomination of President Harry S. Truman gained impetus yesterday in several quarters.
BERLIN, July 2 -- She did not want to talk to any reporter about the meeting. She was not interested in politics -- she was an actress.

BUDAPEST, July 2 -- The arrest here yesterday of Father Odon Lenard, secretary of Catholic Action, and three other priests for "inciting against democracy" was the latest move by Hungarian communism against what it alleges to be a plot between the United States and the Vatican to undermine its dominant position in Hungary.

ROME, July 2 -- The Senate voted its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth Government and its plans for reconstruction late this evening by 184 votes to 67, with four abstentions. The vote of almost three to one in the Government's favor was a severe blow to the Communists, who had hoped that a considerable proportion of independent Senators would support them.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A dissolution plan of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation, New York, was conditionally approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The country's "captive" mine operators, producing 60,000,000 tons of coal, one-tenth of the nation's annual tonnage, today filed unfair labor practice charges against John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers Union which he heads.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, and although the markets made good rallies at times the close was at the bottom with wheat off 1 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel. Corn lost 3/4 to 3 3/8 cents, July leading, and oats were down 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, today expressed the hope that the truce in Palestine, which is scheduled to expire on July 9, could be extended "if necessary."

Sheldon (Lone Rider) Morris walked the sun-warmed pavement in front of his home at 1080 Putnam Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday with a newly acquired Panhandle swagger. He talked big -about high mountains and Rangers and roughing it on cots and hobnobbing with big gun-toting state troopers in the Lone Star State of Texas.

Vacation is a respite served up by the boss, usually once a year and usually in summer, and is supposed to be relished, at least by the recipient and the resort owner. Whether the "office" likes it or not depends in large part on the nature of the business -- whether there is a sizable summer slackening or, conversely, one's fellow-toilers must "take up the slack" and get up more steam 'midst sizzling temperatures.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 2 -- Most of the proposals of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, will be rejected by the Israeli Government because they are incompatible with the original pattern designed by the Security Council, according to informed sources here today.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- With the establishment of the Republic of Israel, a number of basic propositions must be made clear to the Jewish people, principally that Jews outside of Israel "have no political rights or obligations other than they enjoy as citizens of the land in which they live," Dr. Simon Greenberg, provost and acting president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, asserted here tonight.

The nation's securities markets, banks, financial institutions and commodity exchanges will be closed on Monday in celebration of the 172d anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence. Proclaimed a national holiday, the actual signing took place in Philadelphia on July 4, 1776.

LONDON, July 2 -- Repayment of dollar loans made by the United States to Britain in connection with the European Recovery Program would begin in 1956 and extend over a period of at least twenty-five years, under a projected arrangement being discussed by the two countries, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The National Security Resources Board is something new in American Government. For the first time the American people now have a toplevel civilian agency planning in time of peace for economic mobilization in case of war, entirely separate from and independent of the military forces, but cooperating closely with them.
BERLIN, July 2 -- The Western zones of Germany should achieve a "tolerable" standard of living within a year, William H. Draper Jr., Under Secretary of the Department of the Army, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -Samuel Goldwyn announced today that he will produce a new screen version of Robert W. Chambers' 1901 novel, "Cardigan," late this year, with Cathy O'Donnell and Farley Granger in the leading roles.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretaryof State Marshall indicatedtoday that action would come outof the current consultations inLondon among United States andBritish and French diplomats onthe Russian blockade of Berlin.

" Tito! Tito! Vogliamo Tito!" Down the length of the Istrian peninsula this legend was painted in sprawling letters on the walls of the little houses in all the villages. No doubt it was painted over the words "Duce! Duce!" perhaps by the same hands. Anyway, it was a familiar stereotype to the people who shivered inside the houses.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- The People's Front of Belgrade dispatched a telegram to Premier Stalin today that in effect asked the Soviet leader to disavow all the Communist parties of Eastern Europe, including his own, and to reinstate the Yugoslav party in high favor.

Weekly short-wave radio programs designed to help counteract communistic propaganda pertaining to the operation of the Marshall Plan in Europe will be beamed abroad, starting Monday, by the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Leaders of left-wing New York units of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union were put on notice today that they would be required to testify under oath whether they are Communists or face prosecution for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Representative Charles A. Eaton, Republican, of New Jersey, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, confirmed today that he and Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had been consulted at every step of the development of United States policy in Berlin.

The publication of the details with regard to the Columbia University report on the Puerto Rican situation, as published in your newspaper recently, does not bring forth any facts which are new to informed sources with regard to the Puerto Rican problem in the City of New York.

In a move to put the joint ANAAAAA economic understanding program on a permanent basis, its committee has appointed a subcommittee to study offers of sponsorship from major organizations, it was announced yesterday by Don Belding, joint committee chairman.

Mayor O'Dwyer, having threatened to supplant Tammany Hall with a new civic-minded organization, is planning to go beyond that and weld the five separate county organizations into an integrated, united city democracy, it was learned yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer is in fine fighting form; apparently, and we say all power to him in a battle to the finish for a cleaned-up Democratic organization in New York and for the good government of the city. His own experience is proof that these collateral aims cannot be accomplished by periodic outbursts of righteous indignation, sincere as this indignation was in the past.

PARIS, July 2 -- The three-power talks in London have not reached agreement, authorized circles here said today. The discussions are still going on regarding whether a note should be sent to the Soviet Union by the three Western Allied powers.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 -- On the basis of the best Government and private figures, the United States is seeking to show Argentina that several dollar markets would open up promptly if her artificial price-raising measures were lifted, it was learned today.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 (AP) -- A peppery 150pound eight from Princeton University and the defending champions from Kent School of Connecticut gained the semi-finals in the Thames Cup event today at the Henley Royal Regatta.

Glen McDaniel was elected a vice president of the Radio Corporation of America to serve on the president's staff, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, president and board chairman, announced yesterday after the directors' meeting. David C. Adams, assistant general counsel of the National Broadcasting Company, was elected vice president and general attorney of RCA Communications, Inc., to succeed Mr. McDaniel, it was announced by H. C. Ingles, president of RCA Communications.
The Brown - Forman Distillers Corporation reported yesterday in its consolidated annual statement covering the fiscal year ended on April 30 a net income of $5,300,335 on net sales of $43,433,853.

PARIS, July 2 -- The reports of three committees today urged the National Assembly to ratify the sixteen-power economic cooperation convention and bilateral accord with the United States as the foreign affairs debate began. It is expected to last well into next week.

Fifty county and city public school superintendents who are visiting New York as members of a coast-to-coast "flying classroom" heard themselves criticized yesterday for not using modern methods to teach pupils the fundamentals of international relations.

President Truman has signed the "socalled housing bill," as he truthfully called it, with a message which could not have been sharper if he had vetoed it. This bill does not carry out, and was not intended to carry out, the purposes of the long-pending Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill.

HILLSBORO, Ill., July 2 -When Mrs. Paul Ondrey had tried about every method of beating the critical water pipe shortage, she sat down and wrote to President Truman. This caused neighbors to tease her. It also produced results.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- An appeal will be made to the White House tomorrow for aid in preventing a threatened strike of production workers in four plants in Illinois and Iowa which would cause a general shutdown of industry in St. Louis and a drastic reduction in commercial and residential services.

After Oct. 1 the short-wave broadcasts to other countries that have been sent out for the last year by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company under government contract are to revert to full State Department operation and control.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 2 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council heard the United States' administration of the Philippines praised by the Philippine member of the Council today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Truman vetoed today a social security bill affecting blind persons on the ground that it would reduce benefits for thousands of the blind who were unable to work in order to help a smaller number who were employable.
I am a dog, a 4-year-old poodle, and have heard about Bertha Kent Lion's letter to you.

The Interstate Sanitation Commission has begun legal proceedings to compel New York City to stop polluting the harbor and adjacent waters, including bathing beaches, with sewage, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The largest budget surplus in the history of the Government, $8,419,469,843.81, was recorded for the fiscal year 1948, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 2 -Medal honors in the twenty-ninth annual Robert Todd Lincoln Cup tourney at the Ekwanok Country Club today went to Ray Billows, former New York State champion, with a two-over-par 72.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- An injunction forbidding a maritime strike on the West Coast for eighty days, specifically until Sept. 2, was issued today by Federal Judge George B. Harris.

When negotiation and mediation failed last spring to produce an agreement on wages and working conditions regarded by them as satisfactory, three of the nation's railroad brotherhoods -the engineers, firemen and switchmen -- announced that they would go on strike on May 11.

LONDON, July 2 -- A brilliantly erratic Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., put on a great spurt of tennis to gain an amazing victory in the Wimbledon singles final today over the Australian star, John Bromwich. The five-set struggle was won by 7 -- 5, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5.
Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson declared here yesterday that "aggression against the peaceful peoples of the world has not yet expired."
RHODES, July 2 -- Count Bernadotte will meet the Arab leaders in Cairo tomorrow at their invitation to discuss his suggestions for settling the Palestine problem, he announced here today.

Although umbrella sales have increased substantially in the metropolitan area as the result of rainy weather, business throughout the nation has been desultory, according to trade sources yesterday. Buyers coming into the New York market have covered their umbrella needs only for the first part of the fall season and have indicated that they will place additional orders as needed.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 2 -Invincible Herbert McKenley of Jamaica, taking his last preOlympic tune-up in the National A.A.U. track and field championships, broke the world record for 400 meters by whirling one circuit of Marquette University's track in 0:45.9 in his trial heat today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 2 -- There is a definite wartime atmosphere in the dramatic air lift to penetrate the Soviet land blockade of Berlin and keep more than 2,000,000 persons in the Western sectors of the city fed.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The American Federation of Labor expressed official disapproval today of the cost-of-living pay raise formula negotiated by the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- All of the oil borrowed by New York State from the Navy to relieve a fuel shortage last winter will be returned early this month, the Navy announced today.

Under sunny skies one of the greatest holiday mass movements in the city's history surged yesterday through railroad and airport gates and over every highway that led to somewhere out of town over the Fourth of July.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -The Boston Braves mixed twelve hits with four expensive errors and defeated the Phillies, 7 -- 3, in the first game of the series tonight. Bob Elliott hit his seventh home run of the season in the first inning with one on.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2 -- Dr. Harold Stonier, executive manager of the American Bankers Association, told 300 members of the Graduate School of Banking here tonight that the United States was committed to the most dangerous course of action in its history.

The thirteenth national convention of the Socialist Workers Party (Trotskyists), meeting at Irving Plaza Hall, nominated yesterday Farrell Dobbs land Grace Carlson for President and Vice president, respectively. The action marked the first Presidential ticket of the American Trotskyist movement.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman tonight announced the appointment of John H. F. Haskell, New York financier, to head the European recovery mission to Sweden.
ALBANY, July 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley told the Empire Girls' State today that "too many young people nowadays want only security."

I regret to see many newspapers throughout the country describing the Jews as rejoicing that at long last they have a homeland -- a country of their own. I hope you will give me space to protest as strongly as I can against any such picture of American Jews. I know no Jews who have been born in this country who have any desire of any other homeland than the United States.

An assertion by Henry A. Wallace, third party candidate for President, that the absence of a national Communist party ticket would cost him 3,000,000 votes was being interpreted in some quarters yesterday as a virtual dumping by him of Communist support.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 2 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood won the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with 40, 38 -- 78 over the rolling Somerset Hills course today.

MACON, Ga., July 2 -- The Georgia State Democratic Convention joined the "Draft Eisenhower for President" movement today by approving resolutions calling upon President Truman to withdraw from the race and urging General Dwight D. Eisenhower to consent to his nomination.

Because of a delay in obtaining export licenses, steel pipe originally intended for use in construction of the trans-Arabian pipeline has been released to the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex., and will be used to carry fuel to the eastern part of the United States, Burt E. Hull, president of the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, announced yesterday.

The Bronx Zoo put on display a king cobra that arrived by air at La Guardia Field shortly after noon yesterday. The length of the snake -- variety Hamadryas Hannah, largest of all the cobra group -- was estimated at "more than thirteen feet."
PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs were handed a 5-1 decision over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, the Bucs committing four errors -- three of them by.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2 -Goose Bay, 4-year-old son of Volomite, owned by Saunders Mills of Toledo, Ohio, and driven by Ralph Baldwin won the third annual national racing derby for a purse of $25,000 before a crowd of 23,303 at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

SUFFERN, N.Y., July 2 -- Organized labor was reported in virtual command today of the Rockland County Democratic organization after labor leaders had guaranteed financial aid to Democratic aspirants for local, state and national offices.

The methods a Honduras father is reputed to believe justified by way of keeping his 16-year-old daughter "morally and mentally straight" were censured in Felony Court yesterday when a 45-yearold boiler room attendant was held in $500 bail for grand jury action on the charge he horsewhipped his daughter.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A bill amending the Civil Service Retirement Act to provide annuities for Federal employes in hazardous police work became law today when President Truman signed it.

CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds clubbed three homers tonight as they defeated the erring St. Louis Cardinals, 7 -- 3, tumbling the Redbirds to their fourth straight loss. The Cardinals committed six errors.
Joe Louis, the old profilewrecker, now wants to become a par-wrecker in a serious way.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- Lanlast, Mrs. W. W. Vaughan's 7-year-old gelding, took the featured six-furlong Barnegat Purse at Monmouth Park today before a crowd of 11,000 persons. Valhalla was second with War Trophy third.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 2 -- Failure to sign the non-Communist affidavits required by the TaftHartley law today cost Waldemar Woods his job for at least three years as president of the Perth Amboy local of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Progress toward a possible compromise on a civil rights plank in the Democratic platform was reported today in responsible quarters of the Northern and Southern wings of the party.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 (Delayed) -- Despite the difficulties caused by the present uneasy world situation, which forces Turkey to expend an excessively large part of her budget on national defense measures, this country is determined not only to defend its frontiers but to push its industrial development and protect and expand its democratic ideals and aspirations.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- A significant step toward obtaining world-wide guarantees of the right of workers and employers to organize, with protection against dissolution of their organizations by governmental edict, was taken here this evening at the thirtyfirst session of the International Labor Conference.

ONCE again the home gardener is readying for his annual battle against the Japanese beetle invasion. If signs noted by advance scouts are any indication of how the fight will shade up, this year promises to be a banner one for the beetles.

THIS volume is a symposium by professionals of a variety of disciplines from literature to engineering. All the contributors are concerned with the problem of power, particularly with the social consequences of the struggle for power and its exercise in society for aggressive purposes.

Service on the municipal transit lines was virtually 100 per cent efficient yesterday as the public displayed increasing familiarity with the 10-cent-fare set-up on the rapid transit lines and the 7-cent fare on municipal street cars and buses.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 3 -- Governor Dewey returned this evening to his dairy farm at Quaker Hill, near by, intent on getting three or four weeks of rest before he starts his campaign as the Republican candidate for President.

An audience of more than 17,000 went to Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Mischa Elman and the Philharmonic-Symphony. It was the largest Saturday night house of the season, and marked a departure from the policy of light music on those nights.
OF those most immediately concerned, who can best judge the suitability of a star's talents to a particular role?

The nation's shipping industry suffered a severe blow when companion Senate legislation to the two ship subsidy bills introduced by Representative Alvin F. Weichel of Ohio failed to pass before Congress adjourned. But the industry nevertheless managed to get favorable action on a number of important bills, local steamship company officials asserted yesterday.

As financial markets passed the half-year mark last week, general business activity continued at peak levels, but prices were influenced largely by the confused foreign political situation. Strength in the railroad shares, with prices reaching the highest point in nearly two years, offset the earlier downward trend in the industrial group. Stocks closed irregularly higher in restricted trading.

IN this story, Mr. Creed makes out a good case for fifteenth-century Florence as the City of Opportunity of its day. He even credits it with a form of democracy. This is not accomplished without poetic license. Florence becomes a fictional place, Vicenda, "a typical background" of "early, radiant Italy."

PAUL VALERY was a superb poet, but he was not the "man of mind" he aspired, and his admirers took him, to be. His approach to all things was that of a litterateur in essence -- more specifically, that of a French litterateur, determined by the traditional categories of French rationalism.

LONDON, July 3 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, welcomed to Lambeth Palace this morning the 330 Bishops of the Anglican Communion from all over the world who have come to attend the Lambeth Conference here.

At 10 o'clock last Thursday morning President Truman, at his desk in the Oval Room of the White House, held his first press conference in a month. He looked fit and cheerful. He smiled frequently, and occasionally laughed. He answered questions promptly and briefly.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- With sore-armed Dick Fowler keeping seven hits scattered, the hard-driving Philadelphia Athletics reeled off their tenth victory in eleven starts by trouncing the Boston Red Sox today, 8 -- 2.

Marking "Freedom Sabbath" yesterday, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, listed four documents as the proclamations for Americans upon which life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are based: the Decalogue, or Sermon at Sinai; the Sermon on the Mount, the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States.

DETAILS of repertoire have still to be settled, but most of the nation's orchestras have already made their plans for next season. Business managers have made out their prospectuses and press agents have sent out their releases.

Detectives of the Forgery Squad reported that they had broken up a clever swindle yesterday with the arrest of Fred Philip Train, a distinguished-looking 38-year-old accountant who was booked on charges of forgery and larceny.

Some 172 years ago last spring a convention was about to be held in Philadelphia. It was not as big as the Republican National Convention held this year, nor the Democratic National Convention which will assemble a week from tomorrow. It did, however, create a small demand for furnished
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Corn prices tumbled on the Board of Trade today as splendid weather spread over the Midwest and a private forecast of a crop of more than three billion bushels was made.

An automobile containing four adults and seven children collided with a trolley car at 12:45 P.M. yesterday at the intersection of Meeker and Graham Avenues, Brooklyn. Five of the passengers in the auto were injured seriously and hospitalized.

SYRIA'S series promised in commemoration of the re-election of President Shukri al-Quwwatli has reached Tribune Stamp Company. His portrait is on 25-piastres wine-red and airmail 50pi gray-violet and green; Parliament Building is on postage 12.50pi black and sepia and air 12.50pi blue and violet.

LONDON, July 3 -- Vexing currency problems involved in the promotion of European trade formed one of a number of questions discussed here today at a four-hour conference of top level officials of the British Treasury and of the Economic Cooperation Administration.
BERLIN, July 3 -- The Western powers announced tonight a limited introduction of the new Deutsche mark into the economy of this city.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota, announced today that he would seek re-election next November in order to complete the party's post-war tax program with a $4,000,000,000 reduction in 1950.
LABOR unions are ready to use everything from baby-sitters to buses to get out the vote this fall -- if they can only decide whom they are going to be for.

HOBOKEN has a unique television fan in Parkey Radigan, a local tavern owner. At 5 o'clock on Tuesdays and Thursdays, the time set for Bob Smith's "Howdy Doody" Show, and at 6 o'clock, when the "Small Fry Club" comes in view, the beer taps are closed, adults are ushered away and the tavern at Seventh and Clinton Streets is turned over exclusively to the younger generation for a period of television viewing.

Chief Steward Percy G. Burrage is the only White Star Line man still in a chief's berth in the North Atlantic trade and it is fitting enough that he is in charge of the catering personnel on the only ship still flying the White Star flag in this service -- the Britannic.

THE true blue of veronica, commonly known as speed-well, is a valuable garden aid. Blue flowers are the peace-loving inhabitants of the border. They live harmoniously with every neighbor, subduing the vividness of colors that would clash if left side by side.
BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Catholic Broadcasters Association was founded today at a meeting in St. John's Seminary attended by more than 100 clergymen and laymen from various parts of the country.

Queens is asking to be classified as a separate county and not as a part of New York City for hospital planning purposes. Borough President James A. Burke, in a letter to Robert T. Lansdale, chairman of the State Joint Hospital Planning Committee, announced yesterday that Queens could not expect Federal and state aid until 1990 unless the borough was reclassified on a separate county basis.

Two institutes for the training of lay leaders for the "Great Books" movement will be held at Beloit, Wis., Aug. 2-6 and at Appleton, Aug. 23-27. The program is intended to train leaders in the techniques of organizing and conducting local discussion groups on the literary masterpieces which form the basis of the reading and discussion plan.

EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., July 3 -- A few splinters of glass and three smudges of a black pigment proved enough evidence here today for Suffolk County authorities, working with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to announce the solution of a week-old automobile death.
BERLIN. LUCIUS CLAY, said a British general, "looks like a Roman emperor and sometimes acts like one."

BURIED amid Tecumseh's clippings and assorted notes for most of last week, the man from Department of Trends emerged long enough the other night to report that the coming season should see at least five plays of French derivation on the local boards.

What is more beautiful than a clear, blue sky? Humid, sultry days may make the question more poignant, but deep blue skies make fine days in any season. Not skim-milk blue, which is a sky full of moisture that neither goes up nor comes down; but the blue of flax flowers fresh at dawn, which marks a sky to be lived with and enenjoyed.

YARMOUTH, N.S. -- From Yarmouth to Digby and points east, from Chester to White Point Beach, Nova Scotia is ready for what it expects will be its biggest tourist season to date. Even Wedgeport, which does not stage its Tuna Tournament until Sept. 8 to 11, has already painted its fleet of deep-sea fishing boats a sky-blue picked out in white and gold, in readiness for the event of the fishermen's year.

Thirteen months ago, Secretary of State Marshall, proposing the "plan" that first bore his name and later became the European Recovery Program, said: "There must be some agreement among the countries of Europe as to the requirements of the situation and the part those countries themselves will take."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3 (AP) -- Charles Olives, the hard-hitting cadet from the United States Military Academy, and Dick Savitt, Cornell's captain, swept into the final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championships today, but each had to go to four sets.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- This old Quaker city, almost recovered from the excitement of the Republican National Convention and now in the midst of the annual meeting of Elks, braced itself today for the coming Democratic National Convention, opening here at noon Monday, July 12.
MILWAUKEE, July 3 -- Harrison Dillard today sacrificed his eighty-two race winning streak at the altar of his ambition to be a double scorer -- and perhaps a double victor -- at the Olympics.

NEXT to sitting in the cab of a giant Q4 freight locomotive with your hand on the throttle, reading this exciting book on railroading is heartily recommended as an excellent way to learn what it feels like to be an engineer.

Paintings and collages by youngsters, executed in English rehabilitation centers after rescue from Nazi concentration camps, will be shown in the summer exhibition of work by children of eleven nations that opens Tuesday in the Central Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

A Japanese cousin of quinine is among several new drugs now being tested by American chemists as possible weapons against tuberculosis, Dr. Alfred Burger of the University of Virginia said at the opening of the First National Medicinal Chemistry Symposium, sponsored by the Medicinal Division of the American Chemical Society at the University of Michigan.

THE American public, collectors and museums have been increasingly interested in the highly decorative and jewel-like pictures of Siena, particularly those of the fifteenth century. John Pope-Hennessy's survey of a century of Sienese paintings, devoted to the work of twelve painters, including Sassetta. Giovanni di Paolo, Vecchietta, Francesco di Giorgio and Neroccio, deals with the work of artists especially well represented in American galleries.

The New York Personnel Management Association has just begun a comprehensive study of skill deficiencies and undesirable job attitudes common among recent high school graduates employed as office workers in many business organizations in the city, Ernest De La Ossa, chairman, disclosed in an interview last week.

Most buyers completed their fall purchasing here last week and the number of buyers in wholesale apparel markets is expected to decline even further after the holiday week-end, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. The sales outlook for fall dresses and suits, the report continued, is bright.

The "new" philosophy of Resistentialism, i.e "Things Are Against Us," discussed by Paul F. Jennings in "Thingness of Things," has been, in a way, presented already in the social satire "Auch Einer" ("Just One") (1879) by Friedrich Theodor Vischer (1807-1887), famous author of "Aesthetics," and professor in Tuebingen and Zurich.

THIS is a valuable study of Negro literature from the Civil War to the present day, although it is more of a hand-book than a history. It presents a body of material that is essential for us to know; it is intelligent and scholarly in its approach.
BOLIVAR, Mo., July 3 -- Sprayed with DDT and praying for a bright, sunny day, this Ozarks town began a gay Pan-American and Independence fiesta today while awaiting two Presidents.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3 -- A "quickening of tempo" of business activity in the upper Midwest was detected in the monthly review of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank. It found department stores sales, bank debits and employment setting new records for May Bank debits rose to 311 per cent of the 1935-39 average, the report showed, a climb of 29 points over the 282 figure in April, in the face of a normal seasonal decline.

SANTA CATALINA ISLAND, Calif. -- This "West Coast Bermuda" is the only place on the globe which California will admit has a better climate than the state proper. Twenty-two miles out in the blue Pacific, Catalina is 15 degrees warmer in winter than the mainland, and 15 degrees cooler in the summer.

American delegates to the International Transportworkers Federation meeting at Oslo, Norway, on July 19 will propose a worldwide boycott of Panamanian-flag merchant vessels, Harry O. Lundeberg, president of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, announced yesterday, prior to his departure aboard the Swedish American liner Stockholm.

On the basis of the record for the first six months, the Department of Health estimated yesterday that there would be approximately 146,000 births in the city this year as compared with the all-time record of 1947 when 171,174 babies were born here.

Driven from a ship in a predawn fire, seamen and the wife and two children of the ship's master were rescued early yesterday when the Swedish freighter Dagmar Salen burned off the mouth of Delaware Bay.

With two additional industries moving toward f.o.b. mill pricing systems, industrial executives in a wide variety of lines were studying possibilities for improvement of net profits through abandoning delivered and zone pricing systems, as the week ended, industrial engineers revealed here yesterday.

RELEASE of four more United States postage stamps during 1948 has been authorized at Washington during the past week. These will bring to twenty-six the total thus far assured, including the ones already in circulation, during this election year.

George R. Donahue, president of the New York Chapter of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists, emphasized yesterday afternoon that the responsibilities of Roman Catholic members of trade unions included the organizing of unorganized wage earners and leading them in building a sound social order.

THE United States Air Force announcement last week that sixteen of its Lockheed F-80 jet fighters would fly the Atlantic within the next few days may have had more significance for commercial air transport than was at first indicated.

TIRES get tired, too, the Rubber Manufacturers Association warns motorists. They get tired, especially in hot weather, of ill-treatment, abuse, neglect, improper inflation; and then there results "an untold number of premature tire failures and a waste of millions of dollars of car owners' money."

A YOUNG lady in South Had ley, Mass., seat of a female institution of learning, report giving a copy of "The Sun Also Rise" to a classmate, who in turn reported after a journey to Chicago that the book stirred the curiosity of a lady seated next to her on the train.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser gained his eleventh victory today as he pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 6-2 triumph over the Chicago White Sox before a crowd of 4,984.
THE longest run in the history of the legitimate theatre will start its sixteenth year here with its 5,620th consecutive performance on Tuesday.

ALBANY, July 3 -- A collection of unique manuscripts recently acquired by the New York State Library discloses new facts about the War of Independence as it was fought in the Mohawk Valley and about the life of Gen. Nicholas Herkimer, Dr. Charles Francis Gosnell, State Librarian, announced today.
ROME, July 3 (AP) -- Dispatches from Bologna, Italy's railroad capital, said tonight that there was danger of a national railway strike.

THIS book should become a standard work in more than one respect. In it Professor Doob of Yale University organizes a vast, amorphous and fluctuating body of material so masterfully that it becomes finite, articulate and firm.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., July 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hale of Greenwich, Conn., today retired the Goldens Bridge Hunt Challenge Trophy as their entry in the breeding division annexed the championship at the annual colt and horse show sponsored by the Goldens Bridge Hounds Club at Meadow Lane Farm.

THIS summer finds Boston welcoming seventy-three students from seventeen European countries who are studying at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The story of their coming is the story of the cooperation between a radio station and a university.

IN case a tour of the Hollywood studios happens to be among your vacation objectives, a study of the definitions in this glossary of on-the-set language will help you to act quite blase if a voice calls out, "Kill that baby." That would be simply a command -- from either a director, camera man or chief electrician -- to extinguish a small-size spotlight.

Loans and advances by factoring companies have increased sharply with the return of wholesale consumer goods purchases to a seasonal pattern, it was pointed out last week by Jarvis Cromwell, president of William Iselin Co., commercial bankers.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 3 -- The Golden Bears of California sped down the mirror-like 2,000-meter course on Carnegie Lake today, bound for London and the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Diplomatic informants said tonight that the Ambassadors of five Western European countries in the Brussels treaty had been asked to meet with State Department officials Tuesday to discuss future relations between the United States and the European organization.

Reading the Declaration of Independence today one is reminded of the schoolgirl who saw "Hamlet" for the first time -- she said she thought it was a beautiful play but that she was surprised that so great an author as Shakespeare should use so many familiar quotations.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 3 -- Holiday motor traffic that began last evening and continued all night filled New Jersey highways with vehicles of every type today and set a new peak with a volume estimated at 10 per cent above the corresponding period last year.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 3 -- A new second chamber of the lower house of the States General (Parliament) will be elected by a general election next Wednesday when the people of the Netherlands will vote on four proposed amendments to the Constitution.

THE visitor in the American zone of Germany who looks for significant creative work is liable to receive a shock. He will find that most of the post-war work now being written and published is like the rubble he sees everywhere in the big cities and towns, like the eviscerated houses that yawn spectrally into the summer-sheen.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The strength of the Dewey-Warren Republican ticket was conceded in Democratic circles this week, reinforcing the Administration's belief that President Truman's best hope for re-election was to run against Congress instead of his nominated opponent.

DUBLIN, Ireland, July 3 -- The United, States loomed large on the Irish political scene today after the Dail Eireann had unanimously approved both the convention signed in Paris on April 16 and the agreement signed in Dublin on June 28, which effectively link this country with the European Recovery Program.

CHICAGO -- This city will again play host to the nation with an exposition approaching in variety and grandeur its Century of Progress Exposition of 1933-34, a fact which warrants a look at the city's resources from the vacationist's point of view.

An increasing number of American banking and industrial organizations with foreign branches, particularly in Latin America, is hiring pre-trained personnel to facilitate quick adjustment to the economic and cultural life in which their new employes will participate.

BOSTON, July 3 -- Veterans of the Fourth Armored Division, which spearheaded General Patton's drive through France and Germany, adopted today a resolution calling on the Army Chief of Staff to reactivate the famous division.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 3 -- The 165th Infantry Regiment, the former Sixty-ninth of Manhattan, will be host to relatives and friends of members at Camp Smith here tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3 -- Paul Apold, veteran Argentine newspaper man, has been selected by the wife of President Juan D. Peron to run Democracia, the morning newspaper most closely associated with the work and personality of the First Lady, it was learned last night.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Bewitch, juvenile filly champion of 1947, proved to be the queen of seventeen other fillies and mares in the $29,850 Modesty Stakes at Arlington Park today.

The movement to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic nomination for President went into high gear yesterday when nineteen party leaders, including Mayor William O'Dwyer, sent telegrams to the 1,592 delegates to the Democratic National Convention, inviting them to attend a caucus to be held in Philadelphia on July 10.

MISS KATHARINE TAUBE and Dr. Enid Sater, equipment specialists of the United States Department of Agriculture, have converted the pressure saucepan into a pressure canner for vegetables. Their motives for doing so are plain.

The month-old hammer slaying of Mabel King, 68-year-old Flushing, Queens, housekeeper, was solved yesterday when a handyman born in Dutch Guiana signed a thirty-four-page statement admitting his guilt, the police said.

Selection of the United States Olympic track and field squad will be completed this week on the basis of results in the final tryouts, to be held Friday evening and Saturday afternoon in Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium at Evanston, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.

THERE never yet has been an election which satisfied everyone, unless it should be in Russia, where defeated candidates simply don't exist. A single ballot slate suffices for the Soviet utopia, but in this country we just don't know any better. In our capitalistic ignorance we hold Republican and Democratic conventions and even let crackpots run for high office.

PARIS, July 3 -- The apparent futility of the Western leaders' talk with Soviet Commander Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky regarding the lifting of the blockade of Berlin was believed here likely to strengthen the United States case for a strong three-power warning to Moscow.

The American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, published yesterday its "Silver Anniversary Report." The foundation was organized "over twenty-five years ago to give blind people more equitable treatment in a world where everything in life is planned for people with sight."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 3 -- By signing a formal compact in Cincinnati Wednesday, the Governors of seven states marked a turning point in the history of anti-pollution efforts in the Ohio River Valley. The first Ohio River Valley water sanitation compact was signed by the Governors of Kentucky, Indiana, West Virginia, Ohio, Illinois, Pennsylvania and Virginia.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, July 3 -- Leading American educators proposed today that the funds available for training institutions for teachers be doubled in order to improve the instruction offered.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 3 -- The success of the western Allied proposals to the Germans that they form a western government may well rest with the success of the West's effort to break the siege of Berlin according to reliable German political observers.

IT was love at first sight when Davey saw Pete in the circus ring. Grandfather, wise and generous, saw it and yielded to the boy's unspoken longing. Thus a perfect partnership between a lonely farm boy and a blind horse was formed.

Retail sales volume rose to a high level last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sportswear, beach accessories and lingerie departments reported exceptional business.

That doesn't mean the revival of a phenomenon which had been extinguished before, but its reappearence on the scene after its apparent death in the wake of defeat.

OTTAWA, July 3 -- The task of selecting a successor to Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King has begun to appear to those who must make the decision an infinitely more delicate and difficult business than it seemed when it was still a remote future problem.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 -- The 150-pound crew from Prince on University won the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta today, writing a happy ending to a trip that was conceived as a joke.

Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, ambassador of the Netherlands to Washington, made a plea here yesterday for the United States and the nations of Western Europe to stand together to resist those who would subvert their liberties.

Shipments to Europe under the foreign-aid program soon will carry a slogan stating that the materials are "From the liberty-loving people of America to the liberty-loving people of Europe." This slogan, which will be accompanied by a special symbol, is part of a program being jointly prepared by the Economic Cooperation Administration and the Advertising Council to tell Europeans how the aid program works, and to counter Communist propaganda.

MONTREAL, July 3 (AP) -- With his team trailing by three runs in the last of the ninth and two men out, Oscar Grimes came in as a pinch-hitter and blasted a grand slam homer to give the Montreal Royals a 13-12 victory today over the Jersey City Giants.

With the steel industry's anti-inflation campaign an admitted failure, the stage is being set for general advances in steel wages and prices, industry and union spokesmen made known last week. Major steel companies now are expected to grant wage increases within the next two weeks and to follow up with price rises shortly thereafter, it is said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 3 -- Eliezer Kaplan, Minister of Finance in the Provisional Israeli Government, today accused Great Britain of having committed "a simple and shameless default" by impounding sterling balances held in London by the former British administration in Palestine.

To many parents nothing is newer than the prolonged supervision of children's goings and comings -- how prolonged we recently learned when the Parents League of New York polled its members on the subject: "Freedom -- How Much for Our Children?"

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, July3 -- Higher professional standards for teachers, including a five-year training period, were proposed here last week by four hundred teachers, civic leaders and educational authorities, representing the leading school and lay organizations of the country.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- A corn crop of more than three billion bushels was forecast today by C. M. Galvin, crop expert for the commission house of James E. Bennett Co. It was the first private or Government estimate made on the new corn crop.

The construction and planning program of the New York City Housing Authority has been expanded almost 150 per cent in the last year, according to a report to Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the local housing body.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- President Truman asserted tonight that the Republic of Israel "must find its rightful place in the United Nations." He added that the United States, individually and as a member of the United Nations, is determined to cooperate in achieving "peace, safety from aggression and economic progress" in the Middle East.

As master of ceremonies for the past few weeks on the Texaco Star Theatre (8:00 Tuesday nights over the NBC video chain), the nimble-witted child of the Rialto has displayed all the ad lib accoutrements of the great presiding officers of the Palace Theatre days. Register Mr. B. as television's first real smash!

Commenting on my article about King Abdullah and the Arab Legion, C. Ragosine, in his letter to the editor, writes under a mistaken impression. He says that the "Arabs persist in boiling coffee, sugar and water for a long time."

The action of Mayor O'Dwyer in joining the group of party leaders who are seeking to block the nomination of President Truman by the Democratic National Convention is joined closely with his determination to bring about a reorganization of the Democratic party in New York City, it was learned yesterday.

GENEVA, July 3 -- Europe has become very much concerned over the prospect that America might interfere in the domestic policies of European Governments under the European Recovery Program. That, of course, is precisely what the Cominform said the United States would do.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman today signed the Agricultural Act of 1948. It recognized, he said the importance of price support programs "as vital elements in our agricultural and national prosperity."

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 3 -- The industrial eyes of the South are focused on the proposed construction of a natural gas pipe line system that would serve this area on a scale which its proponents predict would bring regional "economic freedom."

DALLAS, Tex., July 3 -- Whether or not Texas will have enough cotton pickers next fall to harvest its 1948 cotton crop depends largely upon unusual negotiations by a group of individuals with Mexico.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 3 (AP) -- After squeezing through on the inside at the head of the stretch, D.A. Rosenbaum's Reborn came on to win the $10,000 added Governor's Handicap from the Mount Desert Stable's Willing Spirit by a half length today before 21,722 at Narragansett Park.
