The Zenith Radio Corporation, in its annual statement, issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended with last April, disclosed a net profit of $3,484,515 after taxes and all charges.

FROM London comes the excellent news that Alicia Markova, together with Anton Dolin, will be a member of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in September when that company returns to the Metropolitan Opera House after an absence of six years.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Australian sprinter John Treloar ran away from Britain's Olympic hopefuls today to win the 100-yard dash in 9.8 seconds at the Amateur Athletic Association championships.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, steady going South African star, strayed off the beam into the rough six times today but still played well enough for a 1 under par 34, 36 -- 70 that tied Dutch Harrison of Albuquerque, N.M. for the three-quarters lead in the $15,000 Motor City open golf championship.

The long smoldering feud between Marriner S. Eccles, demoted this past winter as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Amadeo Peter (A. P.) Giannini, the banking giant of the Pacific Coast, has finally erupted into open warfare.

The CIO's Economic Outlook for June views with alarm "some very basic shifts * * * in our economy which are exceedingly dangerous." It points out that in 1939 65.3 per cent of national income went to wages and only 8.9 per cent to profits, whereas in 1947 only 61.5 per cent went to wages and 13.8 per cent to profits.

AS a newly elected member of the board of directors of the American National Theatre and Academy, was naturally curious to see just what the organization is accomplishing and where it is headed. At first glance, ANTA appears to be active on a great series of fronts of diverse nature.

A new device for administering dry powdered penicillin in the upper respiratory tract and lungs has been developed by Drs. Louis Krasno, Mary Karp and P.S. Rhoads of Chicago, in collaboration with the Abbott Laboratories. The device is a discharge chamber with interchangeable mouthpiece and nosepiece.

Statistics seem to confirm what long has been suggested by the record of sales and redemptions of Government savings bonds -- that the rising cost of living is cutting into the income of individuals available for savings and may be weakening as well the individual's willingness to save.

The first positive proof that there is a chemical element technetium has been obtained through atomic research at Oak Ridge, Tenn., G.W. Parker, J.W. Reed and J.W. Rush reported at the closing session of the American Chemical Society's national symposium on physical and inorganic chemistry.

Hyman Palatnik, secretary-treasurer of the International Jewelry Workers Union, AFL, announced yesterday that he had sent a letter to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, urging her to reconsider her decision not to run for public office and become a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Vice President.
STANTON, Del., July 3 -- With a track record smashing performance, Stymie today swung into the home stretch of a campaign designed to make him the first millionaire thoroughbred.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 3 -- The United Nations announced today the names of the winners of the international essay competition on "The Role of the Individual in the United Nations."

Spurred by sales of seasonal apparel during the hottest days recorded so far this summer, department store sales last week rose about 25 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Retailers, however, had the advantage of an extra shopping day this year as the Fourth of July fell on Friday in 1947.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Frankie Gustine of the Pirates boosted his lead to 11,432 votes over Chicago's Andy Pafko today in the close race for the National League third base assignment in the All-Star baseball game at St. Louis July 13.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Reports from larger stores disclosed a wide variation in retail sales activity last week. While the Los Angeles area was down 5 per cent and Seattle down 1 per cent, the San Diego area showed an 11 per cent gain and Oakland was up 10 per cent. Accordingly, the entire district stood only one per cent above the same week of 1947.

Hilary Smart's Hilarius from the Central Long Island Sound Fleet was leading the fleet of seven Star Class craft at the conclusion of the second day's competition in the United States Olympic tryouts yesterday. For the second straight time, the trim little boat finished runner-up with the result that Hilarius is now in front with a total of twelve points.

Entries for the New York Athletic Club's Block Island race close at noon on Wednesday with F.W. Horenburger, 572 Madison Avenue, New York 22, or with Rear Commodore Bob Smith, 10-46 Utopia Parkway, Beachhurst, L. I.

Plans to widen Grand Central Parkway between Horace Harding Boulevard and Kew Gardens, Queens, to speed traffic over the Van Wyck Expressway, main north-south link to New York International Airport at Idlewild, were announced yesterday by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.
ATHENS, July 3 -- A first sure sign of the breaking of rebel resistance to the Greek Army in its Grammos offensive appeared today in news of the capture by army units of the town of Eptachorion.

LONDON, July 3 -- Miss Louise Brough, American woman's champion, climbed to the pinnacle of the tennis world today by winning three championships at Wimbledon -- singles, women's doubles and the mixed doubles.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -- Here is a comparison of the postal rates scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1, 1949, as a result of President Truman's approval of the Federal Employe Pay Bill, with those now in force:

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission issued complaints today against six book companies, including the Book-of-the-Month Club, alleging "deceptive use of the word 'free' in their advertising."

"CHINESE modern," we thought, had faded out with ration books, rayon stockings and imitation rubber elastic, none of which was noticeably mourned. Somehow the pagoda tops and promiscuous fretwork of the Chinese modern formula seemed to recall backgrounds designed for sloe-eyed heroines of the silent screen -- neither modern nor Chinese.

A 38-year-old deaf-mute was killed yesterday, apparently by electrocution, while wiring a friend's apartment at 712 East 237th Street, the Bronx. A police emergency crew removed the body from a small space between the hanging ceiling and top of the second floor apartment where the victim had crawled to string wire for a wall switch.

MUKDEN, July 2 (Delayed) -- Sixty tons of food is being air-dropped daily into isolated Changchun to help to feed 70,000 Nationalist troops clinging to the city behind some of the strongest defenses in China.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Coast Guard announced tonight a stepped-up recruiting program aimed at bringing about 700 new men into the service each month.

THE out-of-town summer season got under way in serious fashion late last week with the opening exhibition, the first of five, by members of the Woodstock Artists Association at their gallery in Woodstock, N.Y. Included is work by quite a number of artists transferring their exhibition activities temporarily from New York galleries.

FOR Beany, the last straw in an already impossible Saturday is the news that her father is going to Arizona for his health and is leaving the family in her hands. She decides that the best way to protect her brother and sisters is to see that they "don't stick their necks out for trouble."
HELSINKI, Finland, July 3 -- The Communist-run Popular Democratic Union has lost its position as the largest group in the Finnish Parliament and is now a poor third.

IPSWICH, Mass., will celebrate its Seventeenth Century Day next Saturday by opening twenty-one of its historic houses and churches, the earliest dating from 1660, for public inspection under auspices of the Ipswich Historical Society and the Ipswich Garden Club.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- With criticism of Congress for inadequacy and unsound business management, President Truman signed today a measure increasing on July 1 the pay of most Federal employes.

New Yorkers easily counted in the millions started yesterday a three-day celebration of the Fourth of July. Even if the celebration included only a glancing observance of the 172d anniversary of the Declaration of Independence every citizen was exercising the occasional right to a rain-less week-end.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:A compromise draft bill was passed. For a span of approximately six months the public was confronted with pro and con contentions regarding peacetime military conscription. When this bill was finally being enacted there were numerous proposals as to the best methods for insuring the future safety of the United States.

LONDON, July 3 -- Of all the "people's democracies" within the Soviet sphere Yugoslavia was modeled most closely on the Russian pattern. No country had gone further along the road toward the elimination of the "bourgeoisie" and free enterprise and none was more hostile in words and deeds to the Western powers.
IN defensive play it is usually wise to seek a chance to overtrump declarer; then, When a chance to overtrump is offered, a perverse refusal of it is often the best play.
ATLANTA, July 3 (AP) -- Herman Talmadge officially became a candidate for Governor of Georgia today, thus seeking the office from which he was removed by the State Supreme Court fifteen months ago.

BELGRADE, July 3 (AP) -- Yugoslavia today retorted to Albania's rupture of relations with an acid note, terming Albania's action "unprecedented," "brutal" and Continued on Page 2, Column 2 "grossly insulting" and a violation of international law.

JUST nine years ago this week in this Review: "Security: Can We Retrieve It?" by Sir Arthur Salter was the Page 1 question, while the drums of jeopardy in Europe muttered "No." The reviewer, James Truslow Adams, said that Sir Arthur saw "the only way out, the League machinery having broken down, to be peaceful negotiation between equals with equal strength, or war.". . .

TOKYO, July 3 -- With politics turned into a tangle of personalities and scandals, the Japanese public has turned with relief to the question of whether bamboo is wood and whether a baseball player may use a bat made thereof.

The Tammany Society of New York founded in 1786, was named after an Indian chief who welcomed William Penn to America. The Society's original aims were "social and patriotic." It soon started dabbling in politics. From 1850 on -- as the equivalent of the New York County (Manhattan) Democratic Committee -- it was a power in New York and national politics.

With more than 20 per cent of the total value of aid to sixteen European nations under the European Recovery Plan expected to consist of petroleum and its products, the question of price is giving immediate concern to both Government authorities and oil company executives.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 3 -- Erik Kaeyer, an architect who designed several schools and assisted in the drawing of plans for public housing developments here, died yesterday afternoon of a heart ailment while at Jones Beach, L.I. His age was 51.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration neared today its target for the first three months of its global assistance activities as it announced new grants of $31,963,147 for four European countries and the western occupation zones of Germany.

In the early fall of 1939, just after the outbreak of World War II and the division of Poland between Germany and Russia, Winston Churchill described the policy of the Kremlin in these words: "It is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma."
BABYLON, L.I., July 3 -- Ideal sailing conditions prevailed today as the three-day invitation regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association got under way.

SINCE dahlias revel in rainy weather, the record rainfall that followed the first plantings in early June has forced plants to make good growth. These early-set plants should be well-rooted now, and although the tops may be soft, they will gain strength and firmness with sunny and drier weather.

Although your political map of the United States was distorted to accord with the electoral rank of the states, many a Texan must have winced with disbelief to see his state in microcosm. On that map, even minuscule Ohio was larger than the mighty sovereign state of Texas.

IT is hard to say precisely how much the remembrance of things past invades the restless present, how much one's current delight in a picture or in a performance is affected by memories. But this we can say for certain: two screen things that happened last week were brightened for this reviewer because they struck nostalgic chords.

ALBANY, July 3 -- State education officials revealed today that New York and New Jersey have arrived at a "gentleman's agreement" under which endorsement of New Jersey medical licenses by New York will be expedited.

To free men all over the world the red, square-towered Independence Hall in Philadelphia long has been a symbol of freedom, independence and the dignity of man. However, to the disabled patients of the big Kennedy Veterans Administration Hospital at Memphis, Tenn., there is a new "Independence Hall."

PARIS, July 3 -- Supporting the present Third Force Government before the Socialist National Congress here today, former Premier Paul Ramadier said that Republican France had two enemies -- the Communists and the forces of Charles de Gaulle.

It is not yet time for Americans to throw their hats in the air and cheer liberty-loving Marshal Tito and the Communist party of Yugoslavia. Nevertheless the quarrel between Tito's Communists and the other Communists which broke out into the open last Monday has some hopeful connotations.

If President Truman accepts the power to allocate steel distribution that was accorded to him in the Ploeser rider to the draft law, the nation's economy will be harmed more than helped, steel industry leaders maintain.

THESE books, so alike in their charm and quality, are yet quite different. One is a true story, delightfully told, of the boyhood of the author who came here years ago as a lecturer. The second is a collection of folk and hero tales.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman signed today the bill amending the Trading With the Enemy Act to deal with war claims, because, he said, he was "in hearty accord with its basic objectives."

BERLIN, July 3 -- The United States and British Military Governments of Germany are prepared to start moving an increasingly large tonnage of food and raw materials through Antwerp and Rotterdam, it was learned authoritatively today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- The Princely State of Hyderabad, with 82,000 square miles and 16,000,000 inhabitants, has tightened its belt to withstand India's all-out economic offensive. A Hyderabad spokesman said today that the state was self-sufficient in food

Willard Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, and Hawthorne Arey, vice-president of the Export-Import Bank, were among the 1,600 passengers who sailed yesterday on the American Export liner Saturnia for Gibraltar and Naples.
Negotiators for the Pennsylvania anthracite coal operators and the United Mine Workers arrived last night at an agreement averting a threatened strike of 78,000 hard coal miners.
Carl Rose did a laudable job of information cartooning with his amusing "The U.S. -- A Political Map" in your magazine June 20.

A Greek freighter, placed in jeopardy for more than eighteen hours as a result of overloading, drew a large crowd yesterday to the Bay Ridge and Staten Island waterfronts as she listed to her port side at an angle of 40 degrees.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The new headquarters of Selective Service at 1712 G Street was getting a "face-lifting" this week as the nation prepared to register, commencing in August, some 9,500,000 young men.

WHAT clues to the temper of writers and readers does the literary dossier, at mid-year, have to offer? As in any year, variety is the soul of the book list. Most titles elude the trend-seeker's net, and some merely confirm tastes already noted; for instance, the invincible drawing power of the costume romance, trade-marked by the decolletee damsel on the jacket.

BERLIN, July 3 -- The Communist party of Germany tonight joined that of the Soviet Union in attacking the Communist party of Yugoslavia and bitterly condemned Yugoslavs in Germany for distributing propaganda against the Cominform's communique on the Yugoslav party's sins.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (UP) -- Joe Louis, retired world heavyweight champion, fired a 77 in the qualifying round of the City Golf Association's National invitational tournament at the Seneca Golf Club today.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Corn Belt, which is currently producing agricultural products for human consumption at a rate about 50 per cent above the level following World War I, has grown into such a pillar of strength in America's economy that its farmers "will be able to ride through an unfavorable period on their own resources."

KANSAS CITY, July 3 (AP) -- What started out to be a well-regulated wheat harvest in the midlands is turning out to be a catch-as-catch-can affair. Unseasonal rains, catching the wheat just as it was ripening, did it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 -- A careful examination of the evidence today pointed to the permissible conclusion that Andrija Hebrang and Sretan Zujovitch, former high Government officials, were the principal agents of the Communist Information Bureau in a conspiracy to overthrow Marshal Tito.

Russia will obviously attempt to build up its influence in the Far East and the democratic nations should stand firm, Col. Philippe Livry-Level, member of the French National Assembly and chairman of its aviation committee, asserted yesterday at La Guardia Field.

BERLIN, July 3 -- German national feeling, which began to stir a month ago with the publication of the London decisions, has developed with surprising rapidity in the midst of the struggle for Germany centered around the East-West battle of Berlin.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 3 -- Seven pages of Arab League counter-proposals were handed to Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, this afternoon in reply to his

PRESCRIPTION ( apparently foolproof) for a best seller: Take a Catholic or Protestant clergyman, or a rabbi, add a psychoanalyst and a law professor, mix with experts on anthropology, economics, sociology, let them speak out about the Kinsey report, shake well, rush the whole concoction through, slap a label on it, and it will sell like a popular patent medicine.

While his playmates were learning to play soft-ball and other athletic games, Tommy Brownell at the age of 13 was busy with a set of iron horseshoes, near his home in Gloversville, N.Y., tossing "ringers" at a stake, forty feet away.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Anti-Communist labor federations of Latin America and Asia established liaison today with a view to developing, with the aid of the American Federation of Labor, a world-wide body of "free trade unions" as a rival to the World Federation of Trade Unions, which has a large Communist membership.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 3 -- Since his birth in a Croatian hamlet fifty-eight years ago Josip Broz, now known to the world as Marshal Josip Broz-Tito or just plain Tito, has had a career which equals in meteoric drama that of Garibaldi or Ataturk, or, for that matter, of Joseph Vissarionovitch Djugashvili, better known as Stalin.

CONGRESS has got around at last to doing something about the neglected twelve-acre patch of land off the starboard bow of Manhattan on which for sixty-odd years the Statue of Liberty has stood guard over our harbor and held aloft her torch to greet all comers, whether returning home folk or strangers.

WNYC, the New York City station, will commemorate the start of its twenty-fifth year of public service broadcasting with an all-day celebration on Thursday, with Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials taking part. A highlight of the day's programming will be a re-enactment of the first broadcast by the station on July 8, 1924, to be included in a special documentary show from 8 to 9 P.M.

LAWRENCE, Kan., July 3 (AP) -- The University of Kansas defied a Big Seven Conference ruling today by deciding to permit five athletes -- held ineligible under a reinterpretation of the rules -- to compete this fall.

In a letter published on your editorial page of June 6 entitled "Art as Mirror of Time" the writer absolves degeneration of the arts, proclaims it as a natural "spirit of our age" and proceeds to say that the creators of chaotic pictures are the great artists because they "sing best the songs of chaos."

JUST now summer theatres are breaking out in bosky dell, by mountain tarn, in abandoned silos, refurbished stables and haylofts, on the ends of piers, all the way from La Jolla, Calif., to Ogunquit, Me.

IN 1893, the year of his death, Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky wrote with joy and confidence to his favorite nephew of the idea "for a new Symphony. This time with a programme; but a programme of a kind which remains an enigma to all -- let them guess it who can."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 3 (AP) -- Round Hill, the large estate of the late Col. E.H.R. Green at Dartmouth, Mass., has been presented to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, President Karl T. Compton announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman declared in an address on the grounds of the Washington Monument today that the United States asks only "for peace with justice in the world" and that "the United Nations be made to work for that purpose."

THOUGH harassed as a private citizen, Mr. Chaplin has had rare freedom in his profession: the freedom not only to act in his own very special style but to conceive, write and direct the "dramas" he acts. Thus in the films of Mr. Chaplin we have something unique in the history of culture: an important dramatist's works permanently available in performance as directed and acted by the dramatist himself.

A PICTURE of two members of a high school band in the front row of a dark and empty auditorium, won for Bailey Donnally Jr., 18, of Deatsville, Ala., the grand prize of $500 in the $3,500 1948 National High School Photographic Awards.

IS there a distinctive Irish accent in poetry? I think Mr. Farren proves that there is by his very first quotations. One is Curran's: "If sadly thinking, with spirits sinking, Could, more than drinking, my cares compose * * *." The other is Tom Moore's: "At the mid hour of night when stars are weeping I fly to the lone vale we loved when youth shone warm in thine eye * * *."

For all the recent uncertainties regarding the fiscal future, it now appears fairly definite that there will be no deficit Federal financing in the new fiscal year that started on July 1. According to the best financial opinion as the year opened on Thursday, it seems that the high level of national income will be continued, with tax receipts maintained in sufficient volume to cover expenditures.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, July 3 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America, with its giant shining new plant along the bank of the Mississippi River east of here, has shown what can be done with its own product. This sprawling sheet and metal mill was virtually built of aluminum, with the exception of concrete foundations and structural steel.

Mindful of the slow start New York made in war employment in World War II, the City Commerce Department is seeing to it that New York gets in on the ground floor in contract opportunities under the current national defense and European recovery programs.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- With Eddie Robinson hitting a home run and a triple and Bob Feller keeping Brownie batters under control, the Cleveland Indians held their own in the American League race today by defeating St. Louis, 8 to 2.

UNFAMILIAR kinds of clematis deserve consideration when a vine is needed. The well-known varieties with large flowers are almost incredibly lovely, but some kinds less frequently seen may be even more intriguing.

THE Scotsman Ivor Brown. who here presents to American readers his third and fourth books on words, is surely the most graceful of contemporary verbalists. The beauty of his quiet comment soothes minds too often assaulted today by prose restless with surface excitement.

THIS book consists of sixteen essays by recognized medical and musical authorities on the use of music in medical therapy, many of which have been published elsewhere in various professional journals. The widespread use of musical therapy (both for listening and for active participation) in military and naval hospitals during the recent war pointed up the need for some authoritative and scientific study of the inter-relationships between music and human ills, particularly in emotional disturbances.

The world's leading money-winning mare was the heroine of the forty-eighth edition of the seven furlong Carter Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. William L. Brann's Gallorette won it with a magnificent charge through the stretch, earned $20,550, shot her record total to $392,535 and rewarded her supporters at the rate of $10.50 for each $2 invested at the "straight" windows.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 3 -- Apparently out of the running at the turn into the stretch, the Andes Stable's 5-year-old Beauchef staged a whirlwind finish to take first money in the Long Branch Handicap at Monmouth Park today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 3 -- Thousands of visitors poured into the capital in colorful native garb and Sokol uniforms for the top gymnastic exercises of the eleventh Sokol meeting tomorrow.

In a letter to Johan J. Smertenko, who resigned as vice chairman of the American League for a Free Palestine eighteen months ago, Maj. Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, acknowledged he was in error last Sunday when in a public address he associated Mr. Smertenko with the League and criticized him for membership in it.

New England's educational institutions, with their facilities still overtaxed by post-war enrollments, are planning major building and expansion campaigns to enable them to meet the "challenge of future eras." Most college commencements last month were marked by announcements of multimillion-dollar drives in this direction.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Trade in Western Europe is on the decline because most of the countries are too poor to buy from each other.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, July 3 (AP) -- The Weirton Steel Company has reached an agreement with the independent union representing its 10,000 employes to increase wages within the next ten days. The new scale, however, was not made known.

IN this extensive study, the result of twenty years' research, Mrs. Drinker makes an interesting contribution to the literature of musicology. It is perhaps unfortunate that Mrs. Drinker sets down her story in a tone so reminiscent of latter-day suffragette tracts.
TOKYO, July 3 -- A new split in Japan's Socialist party, the largest in the coalition Government of Premier Hitoshi Ashida, appeared today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 3 -- The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that the Albanian Government had ordered the expulsion of all Yugoslav advisers, technicians and teaching staffs and had canceled by unilateral action two long-term trade agreements and the trade protocol integrating the economies of the two countries.

In an effort to combat "private property tendencies" and "idleness" among Russian collective farmers, the Soviet Government has issued a decree putting farm wage payments on an individual and group piecework basis, it was learned yesterday.

Bartley C. Crum, former member of the Anglo-American Commission of Inquiry for Palestine and chairman of the national council, Americans for Haganah, yesterday sent to President Truman a telegram suggesting that Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations mediator of the current Israeli- Arab dispute, withdraw portions of his peace proposal for Palestine.

THE second Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod ended in triumph here the other day after five days in which Welshmen and foreign visitors had a veritable orgy of choir singing. The festival is now unquestionably going to be an established annual feature in this country, where community singing comes as easily as breathing the free air.
NANKING, July 3 -- The bilateral agreement between China and the United States on the utilization of Economic Cooperation Administration funds was signed here this afternoon.

DORE SCHARY, production chief at RKO for the last eighteen months, and Howard Hughes, who bought a controlling interest in the company eight weeks ago, came to a parting of the ways last week, despite previous studio announcements that Hughes was in total accord with the production management.

Eight thousand beach-goers in the Bronx were delayed for periods up to three hours yesterday as the result of a dispute between bus drivers of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union of America, CIO, and the Surface Transportation System.

President Truman has added another to what is becoming a long list of reluctant signatures of bills passed by the Eightieth Congress. We believe he is justified, both in the signature and in the reluctance, in the case of the measure extending for two years the present terms of the members of the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The conclusion of all mature cynics in Washington is that things are never quite so good or quite so bad as most people in the capital think they are.

Paul F. Jennings' story from Paris concerning Pierre-Marie Ventre's new philosophy of Resistentialism was, at least, highly amusing. In his list of philosophers who perceived the hostility of Things he neglected to mention one of the greatest who spoke of "the innate perversity of inanimate things."
Detailed discussions looking toward the setting up of a new Democratic organization in New York County to supplant Tammany Hall were held yesterday between Mayor O'Dwyer and Frank J. Sampson.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- The rampaging Boston Braves smacked down the Philadelphia Phillies, 11 -- 6, today and stretched their National League lead to four full games.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Truman assailed Congress today for mixing politics and atomic energy as he signed a bill to extend for two years the present terms of Chairman David E. Lilienthal and the four other members of the Atomic Energy Commission.

During the last month back orders continued to build up at the same rate as during May, and are now close to the February level, according to Robert C. Swanton, director of purchases for the Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation of New Haven, Conn., and chairman of the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

The full-scale international ice patrol of the North Atlantic sea lanes, maintained by cutters of the United States Coast Guard, ended on Friday after a relatively mild iceberg season, officials of the service reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Stockpiling of scarce materials needed for war production is one of the most important current and long range assignments of the National Security Resources Board. In cooperation with other governmental agencies, the board has prepared a current availability balance sheet of strategic and critical materials and products.

BERLIN, July 3 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, chief of the Soviet Military Administration, refused today at a meeting with Western leaders to lift the land blockade of Berlin now or even to set a date when normal rail, highway and water traffic into the city from the west would be resumed.

DEBUSSY wrote only one string quartet, but like nearly everything he composed, this score is filled with character, originality of thought and impeccable craftsmanship. For those who know the chamber music repertory and admire the elegance, color and poetry of Debussy's genius there is no need to expatiate on the qualities of the Quartet in G minor, Op.10.

THERE long has been an energetic dispute about what constitutes summer reading Those firm classicists to whom learning is a twelve-month affair hold out for Ovid, while the classicists who nod in July dart happily into "Forever Amber" et seq.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 3 (AP) -- Radioactive iodine from the Oak Ridge atomic ovens was in use here for the first time today in treatment of a thyroid cancer. A neuro-surgeon and physicist watched carefully for its effects on a woman 48 years old whose cancer of the thyroid has invaded the spinal cord and vertebral column.

SHANGHAI, July 3 -- High Chinese military officers are dumping billions of army payroll dollars into Shanghai speculation, Pan Kungchan, chairman of the Municipal Council, charged yesterday. He said military speculators were "ruining China's economy."
It took the Yankees quite a time before they finally got around to putting the Senators in their proper place at the Stadium yesterday.

Sid Gordon collected an automobile, traveling bag, a set of golf clubs and sundry other articles from Brooklyn and Plainfield friends, then helped himself to two home runs and practically had won the game from the Dodgers single-handed at Ebbets Field yesterday.

On Monday President Truman is expected to unveil at Bolivar, Mo., a statue to the man for whom that town was named -- the Venezuelan Simon Bolivar, liberator of four South American countries -- Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru -- and founder of a fifth, Bolivia.

THE perennial problem of the artist and his sales, submerged somewhat during the season by the sheer number of exhibitions, comes to the fore again at the end of the year when accounts are cast up and inventories are taken.

Two men, said to be leaders of a ring engaged in mulcting the Third Avenue Transit Corporation of thousands of dollars through a fake accident claim racket, were arraigned yesterday on charges of grand larceny in Bronx Magistrates Court.

TOMORROW is a great day in the life of Aneurin Bevan, 50-year-old Minister of Health in Britain's Socialist Government. For tomorrow the new National Health Service, the most ambitious health organization ever sponsored by any Government, comes into being. On that day Britain nationalizes health, and Bevan, firm believer in nationalization as a cure for all the world's ills, will be almost content.

THE first pictorial record of the exodus of Jews from Europe to Palestine via the underground railway entitled "The Illegals," is evidence that a feature film can be turned out for $25,000 and that filming is not necessarily a prosaic procedure, according to its writer-director-producer, Meyer Levin.
JERUSALEM, July 4 -- Mortars, cannon and machine guns were fired sporadically for twelve hours last night and today in the first major rupture of the United Nations cease-fire in the Holy City.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -With pay checks totaling $985,300, Charles P. Skouras, movie theatre owner, led the Treasury's first listing tonight of America's top money earners of 1946.

Endorsement of the proposal for establishment of a special monetary commission, given last week by James K. Vardaman Jr., one of the governors of the Federal Reserve Board, has rallied life insurance company leaders to intensify their efforts to achieve monetary reforms.
AALBORG, Denmark, July 4 -- A record complement of 3,000 Danish-born Americans joined 50,000 Danes here today in ceremonies celebrating America's Independence Day.

The world desperately needs men who will stand by moral principles, the Rev. Alan Walker, minister of the Waverly Methodist Church, Sydney, Australia, declared yesterday at the morning service at the Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, July 4 -- American Independence Day in London provided the historic irony of an American clergyman preaching the sermon in St. Paul's Cathedral to bishops of the Anglican communion gathered from all over the world.

WESTBURY, L.L., July 4 -- Smooth is the word for Alan Corey's Meadow Brook combination. With a two-goal handicap at the start, the deft-stroking four chalked up its second straight National Polo League success today by halting Bostwick Field, 10 to 5, before 2,000 fans at Bostwick Field.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved moderately downward last week in more or less featureless trading. At the cessation of activities on Friday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 21 to 41 points from the level of the previous week, with the most pronounced net recessions in the nearer months.

VIENNA, July 4 -- W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador for the Economic Cooperation Administration and his inspection party arrived here today to go over the figures and be briefed on the situation in Austria and Vienna's plans for carrying out the Austrian section of the European Recovery Program.

AMSTERDAM, July 4 -- Considerable pressure by interested parties has been brought to bear lately on the Netherlands Government to help in restoring partly the Dutch pre-war position as the world market of many staple commodities, according to information received here.

The world's lightweight championship fight between Ike Williams, the current titleholder, and Beau Jack, former champion, will be broadcast by WOR and Mutual at 10:15 P.M. Monday, July 12. Russ Hodges will do the blow-by-blow description from Shibe Park, Philadelphia. Jay Jackson will assist with the between-the-rounds patter.

BALTIMORE, July 4 -- Chess players from many states and from Canada and Puerto Rico arrived today for the annual meeting of the United States Chess Federation which begins tomorrow at the Lord Baltimore Hotel.

RHODES, Greece, July 4 -- Count Bernadotte, returning from Cairo talks with Arab leaders, declared tonight that he considered that "the door still is open" for further efforts to settle the problem of the Holy Land.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Long Island Sound's wind, if there is such a thing any more, failed today in the second of the championship regattas over the holidays.

In the Berlin blockade logistics work better than logic. It is easier for the Western powers to supply the Germans by air than to reason with the Russians. It will be easier to keep the airlines moving with their unprecedented loads, moreover, than to keep the situation static. It cannot go on as it is.

Dr. Fritz Baade being an informed economist of recognized reputation, the letter from him written from Kiel, Germany, which THE NEW YORK TIMES published June 20, furnishes interesting internal evidence of the correctness of his thesis that German authorities are grievously uninformed concern

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- Dutch Harrison and Ben Hogan were all locked up in a tie today for the $2,600 top prize of the Motor City open golf championship with 72 holes in 275, nine shots under par. Hogan, who closed with his second straight 66, and Harrison, who finished with a 4-under-par 67, will play it off over 18 holes tomorrow.
COPENHAGEN, July 4 (Reuters) -- An American company, spending money at the rate of $1,000,000 a year is "going through Denmark with a tooth comb" in an all-out attempt to find oil.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 4 -- Formation of what was said to be the first air arm of a Sheriff's Brigade in the state was announced here today by Sheriff J. Henry Mock of Rockland County. Organized on a voluntary basis, it will patrol the county's highways, waterways and forests and give aid in storms, air disasters and other emergencies.

New York's commemorative interest in the Declaration of Independence is evidenced in the form of two outstanding memorials: the bronze plaque affixed to the west wall of the City Hall and the flag staff which constitutes a noteworthy feature of Union Square.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- With a modern major league record-matching outburst of 14 runs in a single inning the Boston Red Sox broke a 5-5 tie in the seventh to gain a hollow 19-5 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics today before 24,363 fans.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- Union Electric Company officials announced tonight that a strike of production workers set for Tuesday at 7 A.M. appeared certain, but negotiators for both sides continued efforts tonight to avert the shutdown.

JERUSALEM, July 4 -- Msgr. Gustavo Testa, Roman Catholic Apostolic Delegate, entered the Tomb of David on Mount Zion last week. He was the first Christian dignitary to go inside this Moslem-guarded chamber in 500 years.

Miriam Reines, 12 years old, an infantile paralysis victim since infancy, lay flat on her back yesterday afternoon in the children's ward of the Hospital for Special Surgery, 321 East Forty-second Street. A plaster cast covered her right side from her toes to her chest.

WARSAW, July 4 -- Rade Pribicevic, Yugoslav Ambassador to Poland, cut short a holiday in the country to return to Warsaw during the week-end for conferences with Foreign Minister Zygmund Modzilewski, it was learned today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 4 -- The Israeli Government will give a negative reply to the peace proposals of Count Bernadotte, but at the same time will leave the door open for future discussion, according to informed sources here.

The battle being waged among the Star Class craft for the right to represent the United States in the Olympics is still wide open. This was indicated yesterday when the third day of racing produced a winner different from the ones that had crossed the finish line first in the preceding two sessions.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., July 4 -Sun Beau, chestnut gelding from the Sterling Smith Stables, Ravenna, Ohio the jumper champion in last week's Westport event, took top honors in today's program at the annual Goldens Bridge horse show.
BABYLON, L.I., July 4 -- The Great South Bay's famed southwesterly breeze again was in evidence today as the second day of competition in the three-day regatta got under way at full sail.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 4 -- The army, navy and air force of the Turkish Republic are being modernized and retrained by United States officers and men. Their objectives are not only to increase greatly this country's potential capacity to defend herself but also to permit her to reduce her enormous standing army and then ease the strain on the national economy.

WICHITA, Kan., July 4 (AP) -James McHale of Philadelphia staved off a late rally by Harold Paddock Jr. of Aurora, Ohio, for a 1-up victory today in the semifinal round of the Western amateur golf tournament. He will meet Robert (Skee) Riegel for the title tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- The ancient pitching arms of Rip Sewell and Elmer Riddle put Pittsburgh into second place today as the Pirates swept a twin bill from the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 1 and 6 to 2.

The operation of wartime canteens for the benefit of soldiers and sailors during leisure hours led to the opening of teen-age canteens in many parts of the nation to keep children entertained while parents were in defense activities. Most of the teen-age organizations fulfilled their purpose; but many

United Nations officials must be relieved by Governor Dewey's straightforward statement on Friday that he stands behind this country's commitment to grant a $65,000,000 loan for the building of the world capital on the East River site in this city. The agreement signed on March 23 of this year

Pravda, Moscow's official Communist party newspaper, which for two years has been discovering signs of a "developing" economic crisis in the United States in spite of production indexes that have been soaring to unprecedented heights, now is beginning to hedge on its forecast.

UTICA, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing. Federal Security Administrator, outlined plans last night for a nation-wide hospital unit system that would put outlying agricultural areas within reach of modern medical centers.

Having succeeded in arranging a truce in the Holy Land which, despite initial difficulties, has been fairly well observed, Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations mediator, has now submitted certain proposals for carrying out the second and far harder part of his task, which is "to promote a peaceful adjustment of the future situation in Palestine.

As soon as a man can read and write, he should own a letter file. Rigid academicians will protest that it is as a boy he learns to read and write, and within strict limits of definition that is true. But when the boy first owns a letter file, he becomes a man, and he will remain a man so long as he keeps the file.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- Strong denunciations of British Foreign Office policy in connection with the current truce in Palestine by ranking Zionist leaders and by Senator Claude E. Pepper, and a plea for immediate de jure recognition of Israel by the United States Government were made at the sessions of the annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America here today.

Quiet roads wind around low mountains' sloping shoulders and meander along the sides of upland ridges. From open places one has a downhill view of boulder-dotted pastures and creek-traversed meadows. The roads dip down to shady ravines where brooks come tumbling along over white quartz
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Marvin Rotblatt, 20-year-old Chicago-born left-handed pitcher from the University of Illinois made his big league debut with the White Sox today.

You merit a meed of praise for having given a proper place on your front page to the dispatch from Provincetown, Mass., telling the story of Frank Cabral's dive from the body of the whale. A worth-while deep-sea story is front-page stuff. There is, however, in this tale an underlying note of skepticism

PEARL HARBOR, T.H., July 4 -- Midshipmen on their annual summer training cruise had ringside seats yesterday for a mock "sneak" attack on this strategic mid-Pacific base, but the defenses of the island had improved greatly since the Navy station was attacked by the Japanese in 1941.

NINE days from now the American Olympic team will march proudly up the gangplank of the S.S. America, heading for the London Olympics and its date with destiny. But here's the catch. It's quite possible that some of the athletes who have qualified for the biggest international show of them all will be sitting mournfully at the end of the pier, waving goodbye to their more fortunate team-mates.

Heretofore restricted to newspapers in China and Japan and overseas editions of American magazines, a long-range campaign in national magazines is being planned by Northwest Airlines to attract tourists and vacationists to the Orient.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 4 -- Another war represents the only possible means by which Czechoslovakia may be shaken from the Soviet grip, in the opinion of a prominent Czech editor, Ferdinand Peroutka. M. Peroutka is in the United States zone of Germany following a narrow escape from his own country.

W.D. Crane, manager of the Bethlehem Steel Company's Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, shipyard, has completed fifty-three years of service with the company and its predecessors but has no intention of retiring.

In the days of the housing pinch, when people must double, triple and quadruple up, you must expect the fire and health hazards to follow a parallel progression. In New York, according to the Division of Housing, violations in tenement and apartment houses last year were 284 per cent over those reported in 1941.
Four new films, including an importation from France, will open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PARIS, July 4 -- Resolutions defending Socialist doctrine but permitting the party to support the Schuman Cabinet's coalition were adopted at the end of the Socialist National Congress in Paris today.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, July 4 -- This train with its mission of Latin-American amity has as a guest Dr. John M.C. Crane, a co-founder of the Simon Bolivar Foundation, who said this afternoon that he expected to publish for prospective use in the Presidential campaign a pictorial book about President Truman.

A total of 1,180 vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more were under construction or on order in the eleven principal maritime countries of the world at the end of the first quarter of 1948, according to a survey released yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

While many students are happily seeking a summer refuge from books and term papers, two Columbia University geology students are preparing to spend their vacation getting information on the share of the earth and the origin of mountains.

During the summer, according to one estimate, the refrigerator in the average home is opened eighty times a day. It is this constant use, rather than contrariness, that causes the mechanism, especially if it is one of the older models, to break down sometimes when it is needed most.

Although outhit by a wide margin, the Yankees outsmarted and outscored the Senators yesterday at the Stadium, where the home side annexed the odd game of the set, 6 -- 5. The 27,701 fans on hand were treated to a see-saw struggle that produced the winning run in the eighth, an inning in which Gil Coan made one of the greatest acrobatic catches in diamond history.

Americanism is "the preservation of God's order in government," Msgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared in an Independence Day sermon at solemn mass yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

The attainment of church membership has been made "too easy" and "too cheap," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, declared yesterday morning in his sermon.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, July 4 -- This train, which recently took President Truman on his pre-convention speaking tour, has been converted into a Pan-American special for a unique mission of Latin-American amity.

The Red tide receding from Western Europe seems now to be seeping back under the edge of the Iron Curtain. Latest election returns from Finland, in which the Communist front dropped from first to third place in the national Diet, indicate that the Finns are stubbornly determined to maintain and perhaps enlarge the limited freedom they still possess.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The White Sox exploded eighteen hits for thirty-three total bases in walloping Detroit, 12 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header before 23,128 persons today. They lost the opener, 6 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Planning for the strategic relocation of industry as protection against atomic and other bombing attacks is one of the major objectives of the National Security Resources Board.

Through recent figures compiled by the Board of Education, the public has been brought face to face with the school problem soon to exist as a result of New York City's record number of births of the past few years. Last year 171,174 birth certificates were filed here, the largest number
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senator Theodore F. Green, Democrat, of Rhode Island, today charged "stop-Truman" leaders with trying to split the Democratic party.

Compromise efforts appeared yesterday to be under way to settle the bitter battle between the majority of Tammany Hall and Mayor O'Dwyer over the nomination of a Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County. There was no immediate way of assessing the chances of success of the peace feelers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -Samuel Goldwyn, Hollywood film producer, has made public a strong criticism of the new British film quota system in which he said, "I venture to predict that with the new quota * * * motion picture attendance in Great Britain will drop off so badly that (British producers) will look back fondly on the days when attendance was off by only ten millions, which they say it has dropped recently."

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- The Phillies, behind tight pitching by Blix Donnelly and Rookie Robin Roberts, jolted the front-running Braves twice today by scores of 7 -- 2 and 5 -- 2. Donnelly limited the Braves to four hits in the opener while Roberts, a $25,000 bonus hurler from Michigan State, captured his third straight decision in the curfew encounter.

The Port of New York had 1,393 vessel entrances or clearances in June, an increase of 123 ships in the month and 156 above June, 1947, according to the monthly report of Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs here.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society paid all cash for the fifteen-story office building at 1 and 3 East Forty-second Street, the seven-story offices at 4 East Forty-third Street and a one-third interest in a ten-foot right-of-way adjoining 4 East Forty-third Street on the west, according to details of the recent transaction disclosed by Tankoos, Smith Co., the brokers.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 4 -- After having lent himself willingly enough to terrorization of the ownership class by "spontaneous" mass demonstrations, the Hungarian worker now is beginning to feel in his own person the impact of the communism he has helped install.

New York International Airport at Idlewild, planned by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia as the great air transport center from which the small planes of private flyers should be kept as far away as possible, yesterday became a sort of aviation country club.
On Saturday Gerard Barton, a radio engineer of North Bergen, N.J., became the proud owner of a gleaming new 34-foot cabin cruiser valued at $8,000.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Grain prices moved downward last week on the Board of Trade, feed grains showing the most weakness, with July oats selling at a new low since early May and reflecting the expectation of a fair movement of the new crop in about two weeks if weather conditions are favorable.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen broke a five-game Cardinal losing streak today by setting the Reds down, 8 -- 1, in the nightcap of a doubleheader. The Reds, with Johnny Wyrostek and Hank Sauer providing the fireworks, won the first game, 8 -- 6.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4 -The new colors of the 165th Infantry Regiment (the old 69th) were blessed today by Auxiliary Bsihop Stephen J. Donahue of New York as a part of the Independence Day observance at Camp Smith here.
MONTREAL, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- The reluctance of one of Mexico's star tennis players to practice has given Canada its brightest chance of winning a Davis Cup tie in many a year.

MONTREAL, July 4 -- (Canadian Press) -- The British Government, on the recommendation of a special Cabinet subcommittee, has made a contract to purchase twenty Canadair IV airliners, built here by Canadair, Ltd., for use by the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

In commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Spanish-American War, the United Spanish War Veterans opened here yesterday a four-day national convention with observances at St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -Enterprise Studios have acquired "Hotbed in Cuba" a screen story by Virginia Kellogg about the career of Elaine Townsend, the 29year-old woman who operates the Grande Casino Nacional outside Havana.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -Officials of the National Audubon Society's Greenwich Nature Center here, whose more than 400 acres abound with wild life, have recently become concerned over the death of many birds, apparently from eating insects killed by powerful insecticides.
LONDON, July 4 -- Thirty-nine persons perished today in a mid-air collision between a Royal Air Force York transport plane and a Swedish DC-6 airliner near Northolt Airport, outside London.

Only the Giants and Dodgers could produce what was unfolded before 28,770 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Brooks staged a four-run ninth-inning rally to nose out the boys from Coogan's Bluff by a 13-12 count.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, July 4 -- When the report of Frank Hague's defection reached the Truman party tonight, the President declined to comment, but a member of his staff pictured him as being unperturbed by the development and still confident that he would be nominated on the first ballot, as he predicted last Thursday.

" Lysistrata '48," Gilbert Seldes' new, modern-dress version of the Greek comedy, has been added to the 1948-49 production program of the Theatre Guild after a week's tryout at the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse with June Havoc in the title role.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 4 -- Fifty leaders of the Democratic party, including a number who recently have become actively identified with the "Draft-Eisenhower" movement within that party, announced here today that they intend to press for the inclusion of President Truman's civil rights program in the party's 1948 platform.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- The Newark Bears brought their longest losing streak of the year home with them today, then saw it extended to six games when Lloyd Gearhart unloaded a two-run triple in the tenth inning off Frank Lamanna to give Jersey City a 7-5 triumph in the opener of a five-game series.

CLEVELAND, July 4 -- Stirred by reports of deteriorating school conditions, spokesmen for the country's 1,000,000 teachers today pledged a vigorous, all-out campaign to raise the standards of public school education throughout the United States.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 4 -- The Yugoslav Communist party today served notice to the Communist and non-Communist worlds that there would be no change in the fundamental principles of Yugoslav foreign policy.
John J. Fitzgerald, formerly manager of the retail department of Goodall Fabrics, Inc., has been appointed sales manager of Shulman Abrash, Inc., fabrics.

LONDON, July 4 (UP) -- American failures in the British open golf tournament at Muirfield, Scotland, last week brought suggestions today that the prize money be increased to the point where it would attract the real big names of golf-dom -- Ben Hogan included.

LENOX, Mass., July 4 -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky urged the United States today to supplement its material aid to Europe with evidence of its cultural achievements so that Europeans would cease feeling that this country had nothing to export but "the power and value of the dollar."
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -The big steel companies, faced with a strike in their "captive" coal mines Tuesday, have only a 41day supply of coal on hand, the National Coal Association reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Philadelphia clubs captured three championships today in the opening events of the seventy-fourth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the Schuylkill River.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- The National Education Association, reporting on a survey of the North Syracuse public school system, charged today that the dismissal of William E. Stanley, a teacher, was "vindictive reprisal" for his activities in behalf of teachers.
There were just two incidents in the foreign exchange market sufficient to develop a ripple of interest. Otherwise, business was on a small scale and rates uniformly maintained.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- If Cleveland follows the Fourth of July tradition and wins the American League pennant, the Indians will surprise Manager Lou Boudreau's three rival pilots in the western half of the junior circuit.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 4 -- The position of Jewish displaced persons in the United States zone of Germany has become dangerous, partly as the result of a Nazi whispering campaign to the effect that United States troops are anti-Jewish, according to information placed before the World Jewish Congress assembly here.

MERIDEN, N.H., July 4 -Harry Carlson, Democratic National Committeeman from New Hampshire, denied today that he had quoted Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as saying he would accept a nomination for the Presidency from the Democratic National Convention "if it was an honest draft."

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The home furnishings industry anticipates a volume of business this year of nearly $10,000,000,000 at the retail level, a spokesman for the Merchandise Mart said today in revealing the results of surveys of consumer buying plans for household durables.

THE middle-drawer English novelist is usually a hardy perennial. Most of the elders of the species -- like their dean, Mr. Maugham -- seem to find writing a healthy profession. Busy as contented beavers in their lairs -- stone towers in Kent, blue-stucco villas on the Cap d'Antibes, latticed cabanas in California -- they often seem to have gone on writing forever.

One thing seems now to be a distinct probability, if not a certainty, in the event that the Republican party is returned to power next November. That is a re-examination and overhauling of the nation's banking and credit machinery.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,133,742,022. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- The letdown in steel output this week because of the Fourth of July holiday will be short-lived and not as sharp as it has been in other years. Some plants will work their raw steel departments straight through. Others will keep shut-downs to a minimum.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A "very serious" note to the Soviet Union, protesting the blockade of ground shipments to the Western sectors of Berlin, has been drafted in London by representatives of the United States, Great Britain and France. The note has been or will be cleared here with Secretary of State Marshall.

MILWAUKEE, July 4 -- A postmeet highlight of the National A.A.U. track and field championships yesterday was the revelation today that Gilbert Dodds, America's one hope against the swift Swedes in the Olympic 1,500 meters, nearly was ruled off the track on a minor technicality.

When a small house is duplicated many times in a community, the natural urge of a new home owner often is to make changes in the exterior to distinguish his own dwelling. Instead of adding window boxes or changing the color of a doorway, which might spoil the planned look of the community, however, a furniture designer who recently bought a typical veteran's house concentrated on the interior to express his individuality.

BERLIN, July 4 -- Nearly 3,000 tons of food were flown into Berlin in twenty-two hours today by 362 United States and British planes in the most striking demonstration yet of the Western 'powers' ability to hurdle the Russian land blockade of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, said today in a Fourth of July broadcast to veterans that this nation's strength depended upon the unity of its people. He spoke by transcription on the Veterans Administration program "The Veteran Wants to Know."

An inventory of public construction needs by Dr. E. Jay Howenstine Jr., a Government economist, indicates that an investment of oughly $120,000,000,000 is required to bring public physical facilities up to reasonably adequate standards. The figure is based on 1947 prices.

The singing of patriotic hymns, the playing of the National Anthem and the intoning of a special prayer marked the observance of the Declaration of Independence anniversary yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic nomination for President is increasing among delegates to the Democratic National Convention, it was disclosed yesterday by a survey of the situation in each of the forty-eight states by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Top-seeded Cadet Charles Oliver of the United States Military Academy outran, and outlasted Dick Savitt of Cornell, No. 2 in the draw, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 10, 6 -- 1, to win the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship today.
PARIS, July 4 -- France's Indo-China Bank, which lost its privileges last year as a bank of issue, has begun an effort to expand as a great international banking firm.
A swarm of bees took advantage of the good weather yesterday and visited Yorkville.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 -Slowed-down bus schedules and considerable annoyance over the handling of pennies were caused by the higher bus and trolley fares that went into effect in northern New Jersey at 4 A.M. today. The new schedule increased the rate from 5 to 7 cents a zone, up to 35 cents.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today that labor would have full opportunity, both here and abroad, to take part in the European Recovery Program.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- Citation, Calumet Farm's top speedster, will make his first start since he took the Belmont Stakes to win the Triple Crown when he races in Arlington Park's $50,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Buddy Behrens of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., battled Irvin Dorfman of New York through sixty-four games today before winning the men's singles championship of the Tri-State tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The greatest baseball fan poll in history closes tomorrow night. The final count may reach a staggering 4,000,000 votes in the 21-day battle of ballots to name the starting American and National League line-ups for the fifteenth annual All-Star game in St. Louis July 13.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 4 -- The anniversary of Gen. George Washington's visit to this community in 1775 when on his way from Philadelphia to Boston to take command of the patriot army was celebrated in pageantry and music here today as the feature of a Fourth of July program.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., the medalist, moved into the final of the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup tournament over the Ekwanok Country Club course today. He will have as his opponent tomorrow 35-year-old Gene Wadsworth of Piping Rock, who learned his golf as a youngster on these mountain surrounded links.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 4 -A six-point program for the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs was outlined here tonight by Miss Sally Butler of Indianapolis, national president of the organization. Miss Butler spoke at the opening session of the 1948 biennial convention.

ATHENS, July 3 -- Following up gains made in hard-fought battles of the last three days, Greek Army troops were converging tonight on the center of rebel resistance in the Mount Grammos area. The army's attack in a wide arc around the Grammos massif showed every sign of being general and of mounting vigor.

Reliance on physical force and the threat of domination by "totalitarian church organizations claiming a monopoly of truth," were described yesterday by the Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker, a member of the staff of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, as "two potential yokes of bondage" confronting the American people.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 4 -Frank Hague, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, addressing a hastily summoned meeting of the state's delegates and alternates to the national convention, withdrew today his recent endorsement of President Truman as the Democratic candidate and urged the drafting of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 4 -- A survey of a representative group of exporters fails to sustain the popular belief that higher prices can be charged foreign buyers for American-made goods because scarcities abroad are greater and that consequently larger profits are earned on foreign sales than on domestic ones.

BOSTON, July 4 -- Members of the New England Council are hopeful of an early return visit by officials of the Maritime Provinces to further the progress made at Digby, N.S., last week during a "friendly invasion" of northeastern Canada.

LONDON, July 4 -- The security markets here remain in a highly sensitive and nervous condition. Such a rallying tendency as has been shown in them in the past few days has been due to technical conditions and not to any return of confidence.

LONDON, July 4 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin accused the Soviet Union today of deliberately starving 2,500,000 Germans in the Western sectors of Berlin in an attempt to influence the Western Powers' policy toward Germany. He bluntly declared that "we are unable to accept" the steps that had been taken recently in Berlin "to try to force us out."

ROSLYN, L.I., July 4 -- Union Free School District 3, an exponent of the so-called progressive education system, will take another step in that direction if the voters approve one of the two propositions to be voted upon next Wednesday.

Charges that Economic Cooperation Administration officials are encouraging continued dealings with foreign government purchasing missions because it is "the easiest way of handling the business" were made here last week by exporters and trade association spokesmen.

ZURICH, July 4 -- Exporters describe the new monetary regulations issued by the Central Bank of Argentina on June 23 as "a virtual moratorium," at least as far as regulations concern payments to hard currency countries like Switzerland and the United States.

The thirty-five-member scale committee of the United Mine Workers unanimously approved yesterday the agreement reached late Saturday night by John L. Lewis, union president, and anthracite operators, raising wages for Pennsylvania hard coal miners $1 a day. The operators, according to Thomas Kennedy, vice president of the union, already had signed the agreement.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Following is the text, made public today, of suggestions presented by the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, Count Folke Bernadotte, to Arabs and Jews on June 28, and a statement by the Mediator:
PEIPING, July 4 -- The military stalemate in Manchuria has increased the burdens of Gen. Fu Tso-yi, Nationalist commander in North China.

BERLIN, July 4 -- With all the splendor and pomp the Catholic Church possesses, the Catholic community of this city was consecrated today by Konrad Cardinal von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin, in a special ceremony at the Waldbuhne Stadium, attended by approximately 25,000 persons.

BOLIVAR, Mo., July 4 -- The calendar listed today as Independence Day but this Ozarks community was not free of the most tyrannical dictator ever to threaten a celebration. Hanging over the town was the threat of rain.
PARIS, July 4 -- In Paris, in Lyon, in Normandy and in dozens of other places French and Americans joined today in observance of America's Independence Day.

PANAMA, July 4 -- The Panamanian Government suspended constitutional guarantees at 8 A.M. today after political clashes last night in which three persons were killed and twenty-five wounded. President Enrique A. Jimenez conferred with his Cabinet and the permanent legislative council of the National Assembly and with the approval of those bodies he declared "a state of siege."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 4 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported to the Security Council today that he had recommended the cession of Jerusalem to the Arabs as part of his proposals for a settlement in the Holy Land.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., July 4 (UP) -- Every police and sheriff's officer this citrus-belt city could muster was called out tonight to defend the town against more than 1,000 motorcyclists who caused heavy damage last night.

Although modern science may obscure God, man can still find a strong faith that will be a force in history, the Rev. Dr. John Short, pastor of the Richmond Hill Congregational Church, Bournemouth, England, declared yesterday. He spoke at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, where he is the guest preacher for this month.

New Yorkers celebrated yesterday the 172d anniversary of the nation's independence by flocking by the millions to the beaches and the country. At the same time the city was host to an influx of visitors, who crowded its restaurants and amusement places.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 4 (AP) -- The losses suffered by the Communist-dominated Popular Democrats in last week's national election were a shock even to their opponents.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Retired Army officers have been ordered to submit, for Army review, any articles they may write for publication on post-war military subjects, the Department disclosed today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (UP) -- Larry Adler, the harmonica king, finally became a legitimate musician today.

LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -Sir Edward Gent, who was killed in the plane collision near Northolt Airport today, was on his way here for governmental "consultations" over the handling of the unrest that has swept Malaya in the past month.

NEW DELHI, July 4 -- Preparations for reforms in the Hyderabad Government are going forward while the political relations between the independent Princely State and India remain stalemated. A new Constituent Assembly, giving the state's Hindu population equal representation with the Moslem ruling class, is to be instituted early next year.

LONDON, July 4 -- Yugoslavia has invited all Communist parties to attend the fifth congress of Yugoslavia's Communist party in Belgrade July 21, Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news agency, said tonight. It was felt that Yugoslavia had thus set the stage for an Eastern European showdown on her policies.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- More than 4,000 witnessed a July Fourth ski jump today at this famous northern New York winter sports center.

The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists, meeting for its fourth annual convention in the Gramercy Park Hotel, criticized the Eightieth Congress yesterday for failing to enact a higher minimum wage.
A submarine that sank 91,419 tons of Japanese shipping during the war is among six Navy vessels open to the public yesterday and today here in observance of Independence Day.

Detailed allocation of funds for Federal aid to airports, made public here yesterday by D. W. Rentzel, administrator of Civil Aeronautics, showed that New York and New Jersey fields would receive $3,599,000 of $35,098,459 appropriated, while Connecticut would get only $222,000 for improvement of the New Haven Airport.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Trade union summer school sessions, with courses in "effective political action" and "facts to combat" the economic statements of the National Association of Manufacturers, will be held throughout the nation, the CIO announced today.

Allegiance to the United States rather than to the United Nations was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Edward Lodge Curran at the forty-third annual Independence Day celebration of the Knights of Columbus of Brooklyn and Long Island.

RYE, N. Y., July 5 -- At long last, there was wind today and the third of the scheduled holiday championship series regattas on Long Island Sound, that of the American Yacht Club, went like a breeze and with one.
The Giants this morning are out of the second division, thanks to a neighborly turn by the Dodgers. But they still are trying to win their first game from the eccentric Bin Voiselle.
A ricocheting bullet brought about four arrests and, according to a story told by the police yesterday, ended at the very beginning a crime career by four youths.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Held to six hits and defeated, 3 -- 1, by Mickey Haefner in the first game of a double-header here today, the Philadelphia Athletics mauled five Washington pitchers for 14 hits and a 12-5 victory in the second game before a crowd of 23,044.

IF you are to believe Ted Williams -- and sometimes it's wise to accept his enthusiastic statements with at least a couple of grains of salt -- the main reason for his return to the .400 brackets this season is Vernon (Junior) Stephens, the broad-shouldered young man who bats immediately in back of him in the Red Sox batting order.

Members of the majority group in Tammany Hall continued yesterday to indicate their willingness to name a compromise candidate for Surrogate of New York County in place of their own designee, Judge Francis L. Valente, and the choice of Mayor O'Dwyer, Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri.
JERUSALEM, July 5 -- Jerusalem's cease-fire was broken in another sector last night and this morning, and Israeli forces here have begun digging in for an expected all-out resumption of total war.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 5 -- For the third time since the inception of the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup tournament, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie has earned the right to have his name inscribed as the winner of the trophy.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- Unwonted prosperity has descended upon the Dodgers. This sweltering afternoon they found the Phillies fairly exuding the spirit of brotherly love and long before the Brooks had completed the double-header sweep a majority of the 32,892 cash customers were rooting for them.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., July 5 -- A fireworks display in Waterfront Park closed tonight the three-day celebration of the incorporation of this village, after a forenoon program by Boy Scout groups, and an afternoon parade and program of addresses.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 5 (AP) -- Marylanders, who boast of their racing enthusiasm, will be able to watch horses run night and day for the first time in history, starting tomorrow.

NANKING, July 5 -- The Young China party, returning to the coalition, will fill four Ministerial posts in the Chinese Cabinet. The party hopes eventually to get twelve seats in the Legislative Yuan through the resignation of Kuomintang incumbents.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People expressed fear yesterday for the survival of President Truman's civil rights program in the Democratic platform in view of the coalition of anti-Truman Democrats of the North with Southern Democrats.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 5 -- All of the main peace proposals submitted to the Israeli government by Count Bernadotte were rejected tonight at an emergency meeting of the State Council. No negative votes but four abstentions were recorded.

Actors Equity Association, which is scheduled to resume today negotiations with the League of New York Theatres for a new contract. was charged yesterday by one of its prominent members, Paul Hartman, co-star of "Angel in the Wings," with being "very impractical" in its demands.
NEW DELHI, India, July 5 -- The Hyderabad Government accused India today of two breaches of faith with the independent Princely State.

The annual ten-day vacation of the nation's soft-coal miners came to an end yesterday, and the men were scheduled to return to the pits today. But there is a strong likelihood that some 40,000 of them may decide to prolong their holiday indefinitely. These 40,000 are the workers employed in the so-called "captive" mines, operated by the big integrated steel companies.

Oscar C. Schmitt, president of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that the United States Air Forces have authorized the activation by the company of the former Walworth plant located at Washington Park in St. Clair County, Ill.
The bee invasion of New York continued yesterday.
BOLIVAR, Mo., July 5 -- The weather stole the show today as this Ozark community entertained two Presidents.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- A three-run rally in the ninth inning spurred by Ted Kluszewski's tying homer and two Pittsburgh errors gave the Reds a 6-to-4 victory over the Pirates in the nightcap of their holiday double-header today.
