RHODES, July 5 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, has asked for an extension of the truce in Palestine, which is scheduled to expire Friday, he revealed today.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 5 (AP) -- Adeline Hanover, one of the current Hambletonian favorites, was an easy winner today in the Coaching Club Trotting Oaks Stake at Historic Track.

TOKYO, July 5 -- The new military rate for conversion of dollars into yen that goes into effect tonight is far more realistic than any that the occupation authority has set with Washington's assistance since the war ended. In fact it falls well within the range where Japan could establish a workable commercial exchange rate if permitted to do so.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The post-war rate of increase of businesses in operation has been slowed by increasing failures and a decline in the number of new companies organized, Joseph K. Wexman, executive director of the Management Institute for Smaller Business, said today.

That was a very gloomy Thursday, the first of this month, when a man was reminded again that his was a losing fight against the economic system. That was a gloomy Thursday, the first of the month, the day of the bills.
PEIPING, July 5 (AP) -- City officials tonight clapped on a 9 P. M. curfew, closed all places of amusement and said that martial law would be strictly enforced, after a day of student rioting.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 5 (AP) -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Executive Committee of the World Jewish Congress, told the congress today that attacks by western zoneGermans against Jewish displaced persons were expected at any moment.

LONDON, July 5 -- The text of the joint British - French - United States protest note to Moscow concerning Berlin received a final revision in London today and probably will be dispatched within the next forty-eight hours.

With the city's transit system scheduled for its first real weekday test under the higher fares this morning, transit officials expressed confidence yesterday that subway, surface and elevated lines would operate smoothly.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 6 -- American industry met a new question of continued production rates early today as the captive coal mines -- those owned and operated by steel companies for their own requirements -- passed at midnight into a strike-bound state.

LONDON, July 5 -- The greatest Lambeth Conference in history attended by 330 Bishops of the Anglican Communion from all over the world began here this morning. Seventy-six Protestant Episcopal Bishops from the United States headed by Dr. Henry K. Sherrill, Presiding Bishop, are taking part in this first Lambeth Conference in 18 years.

BERLIN, July 5 -- The German Communists today demanded that Berlin be included in the economy of the Soviet zone. They indicated that if the Western sectors of the city did not agree, the Russian sector would be forced to unite with the Eastern zone of occupation, thus completing the economic isolation of the three areas garrisoned by the United States, Great Britain and France.

James Monteleone bought the four - story twenty - four - family apartment house at 89-32 138th Street, northwest corner of Ninetieth Avenue, in Jamaica, Queens, from Werney Sons, Inc. The building occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet. Zager, Fields, Zimmerman, Skodnick Segall were attorneys for the purchaser, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.

My Request, owned by Ben F. Whitaker of Dallas, ran the greatest race of his distinguished career at Aqueduct yesterday. In 2:02 for the mile and a quarter, time that was only three-fifths of a second away from the track and stake records, he ran off with the thirty-first edition of the $57,300 Dwyer Stakes.
CINCINNATI, July 5 (UP) -- W. Horace Schmidlapp was informed tonight that Carole Landis, his wife, had been found dead.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- Universal - International has acquired screen rights to "Night Watch," a forthcoming novel by Robert Buckner about melodramatic adventure in present-day Palestine, and Buckner, who is under contract to the studio, will write the film adaptation and produce it this fall.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 5 -- Formal consideration was given to the cabled request of Count Bernadotte for the prolongation of the truce in Palestine at a meeting tonight of the Arab League's Political Committee, composed of the Premiers of the principal Arab states.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The legal staff of the National Security Resources Board is completing the draft of a proposed Emergency Powers Act for use in case of war or other emergency. Most of its twenty-five titles have been finished.

BALTIMORE, July 5 -- First to win a game in the annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Lord Baltimore Hotel tonight was Martin Southern of Knoxville, Tenn., president of the Southern Chess Association.

LONDON, July 5 -- Unofficial strikes in the coal mines were condemned today by Will Lawther, president of the National Union of Mineworkers, in an address to the union's annual conference in Whitley Bay, Northumberland, today. The union will discuss all this week problems in Britain's coal industry.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 5 -- A new play, "Sundown Beach," by the novelist Bessie Breuer, was presented under difficulties tonight in the Country Playhouse here while a severe thunderstorm was sweeping this section of Connecticut.

A plea to drop the term "juvenile delinquent," except where a court legally classifies youngsters as such, and substitute "problem children" was made yesterday by Donald S. Stralem, chairman of the board of the George Junior Republic.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The last-place Chicago White Sox swept a double-header from St. Louis, 3 -- 2 and 5 -- 4, before 15,895 fans here today.

A four-hit pitching performance by Dave Barnhill featured yesterday's Negro National League double-header at the Yankee Stadium as the New York Cubans blanked the Newark Eagles, 2 -- 0, in the second game before 7,000 persons.

While still lacking most of the comforts and even necessities of life as we know them, the Norwegian people nevertheless continue their long-cherish tradition of giving a helping hand to Europe's needy. Organizers of the U. N. Children's Appeal in Norway report that a total of 10,000,000 kroner, about $2,000,000, has already been collected.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Citation and Jockey Eddie Arcaro teamed up again today to capture the $56,100 Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park before 46,490 spectators, largest crowd in the history of the track.

Simon Bolivar, who was commemorated by two Presidents yesterday at the Missouri town named in his honor, was less fortunate than his nearest North American counterpart, George Washington. He died in exile at the early age of 47; he saw disunity sweep the continent in which he had fought for union; he saw new tyrannies rising in the ashes of the old.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Most anti-Truman Democrats conceded defeat tonight in their efforts to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and some of them immediately trained their sights on Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 5 -- "A cessation of the present American attempt to recreate Western Germany in the American image" was advocated by James P. Warburg, banker and author, tonight at the Mount Holyoke College Institute on the United Nations.

Members of the United Spanish War Veterans and auxiliary units, here for their forty-fifth annual New York State convention, continued yesterday observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the war with Spain.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 5 -- The United States program to rearm Turkey is moving at a satisfactory pace. By September most of the materiel ordered for the Army, Navy and Air Force as well as for road improvement will have arrived.

STANTON, Del., July 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Miss Request beat C. V. Whitney's Mackinaw by a half length in a rousing finish of the $17,500 added Delaware Oaks, feature event of the final program at the 30-day Delaware Park race meeting today.

It was a strange Monday in New York yesterday. Instead of enervating the usual rushing work day throngs, the rays of a powerful sun spent themselves on streets that were virtually deserted because of the Independence Day holiday.

LONDON, July 5 -- Praise for United States generosity in voting billions of dollars to help Europe was expressed by Government and Opposition sides of the House of Commons tonight in a lively debate on the European Recovery Program.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) -- Gardner Larned of Chicago, defending champion in the Western tennis championship, withdrew today because of his wife's illness.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- A world-wide effort to set up national employment services as a means of achieving and maintaining "full employment" in all countries was furthered here today by the adoption of a proposed convention, or treaty, by the International Labor Conference.

PARIS, July 5 (AP) -- Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., who won the All-England tennis championship last week, said in an interview today, he thought Wimbledon referees, linesmen and spectators were "the most partial I've ever seen in my life."

The competition to decide the Star Class craft which will represent the United States in the Olympics has narrowed down to a tri-cornered race with Hilarius the leader. Hilary Smart's Hilarius of the Central Long Island Sound fleet, after two successive seconds, came through yesterday with a second straight triumph in the fourth day of the five-day competition sponsored by the Sheepshead Bay Yacht Club.

Wreckers will start work this morning razing the old buildings on the Broadway blockfront and part of the Seventh Avenue block between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets, where the 1407 Broadway Realty Corporation, of which S. M. Hirsch is president, will erect a forty-story and office building.

NEWARK, N. J., July 5 (AP) -- Newark withheld the fireworks to the last minute today, scoring six runs in the final inning of the night cap to defeat Jersey City, 8 -- 7, and snap a losing streak that had reached seven games when the Jerseys won the opener, 5 -- 3, before 6,371 fans at Ruppert Stadium.
The Security Bureau, Inc., an organization of maritime industry concerns, yesterday urged its rope- buying members to consider having all lines tape-marked to cut rope losses in this port.

The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, AFL, in a message to the Government of Canada issued yesterday from national headquarters at Indianapolis, has protested the proposed importation of skilled labor from Europe into Canada.

The public offering of 600,000 shares of Permanente Metals Corporation's capital stock made on June 30 by the First Boston Corporation, Deal Witter Co., and a nation-wide group of investment banking firms will be closed tomorrow and the financing will be consummated in accordance with plans, the underwriters announced yesterday.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 5 -- A constitution providing increased influence for small nations in the affairs of the World Jewish Congress was approved unanimously today at the final session of the second plenary assembly of the congress.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 5 -- Despite a brief revolt by Alabama's five delegates and by thirteen others from scattered states, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs voted overwhelmingly today to support early passage of the Equal Rights Amendment in the next session of Congress and to work for its prompt ratification in State Legislatures.

BOLIVAR, Mo., July 5 -- Presidents Truman and Romulo Gallegos of Venezuela joined today in honoring the celebrated South American liberator Simon Bolivar in an example of Pan Americanism which, the United States Chief Executive said, showed that "we can succeed in establishing the same type of cooperation" among all countries to bring peace to the world.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UP) -- James Roosevelt, a leader in the "draft Eisenhower" movement, said tonight that the General's statement "clearly indicates that he will not serve as a patisan President but will answer a call to national duty."

As a friend of the United Nations and an advocate of Indo-American collaboration, I am greatly concerned over the fact that the United Nations handling of the dispute between India and Pakistan has greatly prejudiced the status of the U. N. as an impartial body, so far as India is concerned.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- The republic of Israel will not agree to any infringement of its sovereignty such as control of its immigration and foreign policy, and will resist yielding Jerusalem to King Abdullah, Aubrey Eban, Israeli representative at the United Nations, declared here tonight.

A hundred Brooklyn tavern owners, members of their families and customers ferried yesterday to the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island to start a national membership drive of the Sons of the Whiskey Rebellion, an organization of tavern keepers and customers dedicated to fight the return of prohibition and "oppose oppressive liquor taxes."

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 5 -- Fifteen thousand persons attending the South's annual joint celebration here today of Independence Day and the date on which Vicksburg fell to the Union Army forces in the Civil War heard Mississippi's junior Senator, John C. Stennis, declare that he would "welcome a chance to vote for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower."

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- The nation's automobile plants probably will produce close to 90,000 vehicles this week. That volume, despite the closing of all plants today for the Independence Day observance, will reflect an increased production tempo through most of the industry.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, July 5 -- Police held tonight for investigation an American of the Jewish faith who had been arrested when he arrived here by air from Cairo without a Trans-Jordanian visa.

For four and a half years a grieving Far Rockaway father waited for the body of his physician son, Major Myron R. Halsbond of the Army Medical Corps, to be brought home from England so that it could be buried in the family plot.

CLEVELAND, July 5 -- A dramatic story, told today by a quiet-spoken rural school supervisor, drove home to teachers who are attending the convention here of the National Education Association the meaning of low education standards that are currently found in the country.
LIMA, Peru, July 5 (UP) -- The Peruvian Government suspended constitutional guarantees today because of a revolt by Army garrisons at Puno and Juliaca, in southern Peru.

A hold-up in which the loot was a box of reducing pills, followed by the shadowing of a suspect first on the street, next along a catwalk of the Third Avenue elevated structure, and finally aboard a bus, resulted yesterday afternoon in the arrest of a prisoner booked at the East Thirty-fifth Street police station as Francis J. Wilson, 45 years old, of 238 East Thirty- fourth Street.
The Long Island Rail Road made news again yesterday, but this time it was good news for some riders.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 5 -- It has become a crime to listen to "The Voice of America" broadcasts in Hungary, or at least to repeat to others what one has learned therefrom. In recent weeks five persons have been arrested for this offense, according to Budapest newspapers.

With more than 1,000 cases involving charges of misconduct, incompetence or negligence among merchant marine personnel pending, Coast Guard representatives urged yesterday that competent Civil Service examiners be appointed as soon as possible to hear the cases.

When it comes to flavoring, we home cooks need "culinary courage," according to a Hungarian-American, Nandor Szasz. Our food is abundant and excellent; its only lack is skillful seasoning. We're afraid to take advantage of the spices and herbs available.

BERLIN, July 5 (AP) -- The Russians tonight put out their broadest hint yet that their seventeen-day Berlin blockade was aimed at starting new four-power talks on Germany. The Soviet - licensed Nacht-Express said that if successful talks were held, "the situation in Berlin will be automatically clarified," adding: "The Western powers must again take up the conversations on Germany where they left them at Potsdam."

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 5 -- President Truman carried forward the theme of his Bolivar address in an impromptu back-platform talk he made when his train stopped here. A crowd of about 2,000 persons gathered.

CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) -- Home runs by Eddie Lake and Pat Mullin supplied the Detroit Tigers with a four-run eighth inning today and a 7-to-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the second game of a double-header before 59,042 fans.
TENAFLY, N. J., July 5 -- The bird population of this area may have to seek new clinical facilities if Mrs. Herbert E. Carnes of Kenwood Road continues to be in demand on the lecture platform.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 5 -- In a smashing counterattack on Hungarian, Bulgarian and Czech Communist leaders, the Yugoslav Communist party bluntly laid down the proposition today that the powers of the Communist Information Bureau could not and would not succeed in isolating Yugoslavia and that the entire decision rested with the Yugoslav people.

BERLIN, July 5 -- A tightening of the Soviet zone's economy in the hands of a few Communist leaders was disclosed yesterday when Walter Ulbricht, economic chief of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party announced the establishment of a control committee charged with fulfullment of the zone's new two-year production plan.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- The Cardinals swept a rain-shortened double-header from the Cubs before 30,000 dampened fans today, 6 -- 3 and 5 -- 2. The second game was called after five and one-half innings.

Under beneficent skies, New Yorkers came home yesterday from their Fourth of July weekend after three days at seashore and country. They started the homeward trek late in the afternoon and early evening as if loath to take leave of both the excellent weather and their vacations-in-miniature.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor party, announced yesterday that another attempt would be made on Thursday to obtain a court order directing the City Council to fill the vacancy caused by the death last November of Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist.

For "holding to a course that has brought hope and courage to all who cherish freedom," Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg has been chosen as the winner of the 1948 Freedom Award, it was announced yesterday.

An appeal to President Truman to recall Congress for the purpose of enacting in its "entirety" the Taft - Ellender - Wagner housing bill marked yesterday's final session of the three-day convention of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., in a further expansion, bought the three-story apartment and store building at 95 Bedford Avenue, northeast corner of North Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, from Catherine Quinn. The adjoining building at 97 Bedford Avenue was acquired last year by the firm, whose plant is at 105 Bedford Avenue.

The municipal broadcasting station, WNYC, will enter its twenty-fifth year of public service Thursday with addresses by Mayor O'Dwyer and other city officials and saluted from other stations in this area.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- A strike of electrical workers which would have paralyzed industry throughout a large Mississippi Valley area was temporarily averted tonight when the men voted to extend the strike deadline until next Monday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 (AP) -- Stepfather, upsetting the heavily backed On Trust and six other contenders, finally hit pay dirt for movie magnate Harry Warner today with a surprise victory in the $50,000 American Handicap before 52,634 fans at Hollywood Park.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration told Congress today that no foreign-aid funds were being used by Great Britain to help Arab countries in the Middle East.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 5 -- Harrison W. Fry, education editor of the Philadelphia Bulletin, was elected president of the Education Writers' Association at the annual meeting held in conjunction with the National Education Association Conference.

The Chadir Realty Company has purchased the gasoline service station at 138-42 Seventh Avenue, southwest corner of West Nineteenth Street, from Vanderbilt Distributors, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by Ackman Brothers, with Seymour R. Candee as co-broker.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- First quarter dollar shipments of the children's and infants' outerwear industries amounted to $106,000,000, an increase of 11 per cent and 20 per cent above sales in the fourth and first quarters of 1947 respectively, to reach the highest quarterly figure of the last two years, it was announced today by the Bureau of Census, Department of Commerce.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Furniture makers are displaying an answer to the housewife's two big post-war problems -- a smaller home and lack of household help.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 5 (AP) -- Charles Edison, former Democratic Governor of New Jersey and Secretary of the Navy under Franklin D. Roosevelt, announced today that he would vote for Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President.

ATHENS, July 5 (AP) -- Greek Army troops tried four times to storm the important Kleptis heights in rugged northern Greece today, but were turned back by savage rebel resistance, the General Staff reported.
On one of the fourteen decks of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, which is at sea today, a stocky, jovial passenger is taking more than a casual interest in his surroundings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- The executive committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen announced today it has rejected the entry of Theo A. Dubois, Canadian sculler, for the Olympic rowing tryouts at Princeton, N. J., starting next Thursday.

Hubert M. Finnerty, president of the Afghan Corporation, reports that the first two houses in the corporation's building program are nearing completion at 208 Second Street and 211 Eastland Avenue in Pelham Manor, N. Y. The houses, each containing six rooms and on a plot 100 by 125 feet, are priced at $31,500.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 5 (AP) -- An 80-year-old United States citizen declined in a public statement today to run for the Presidency of Korea. Dr. Philip Jaisohn of Media, Pa., who returned to his native Korea a year ago as a United States Military Government counselor, thanked those conducting a boom for him, but said: "Even if the position is offered I will not accept it.
It appears to me that Edward H. Neary's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 29 has set up the proverbial straw man and then most satisfactorily knocked him down.

PANAMA, July 5 (AP) -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, who apparently won the Presidency of Panama six weeks ago on the basis of complete but unofficial returns, appeared publicly today in the Canal Zone, where he had taken refuge. That territory is under United States jurisdiction.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 5 -- Fifteen United States and Australian scientists in expedition into Arnhemland, in the Northern Territory, are establishing a second base camp behind Melville Bay in the northeast tip of Arnhemland on the Gulf of Carpentaria.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- Except for "a remote possibility" of President Truman's withdrawal from the Presidential race, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will not run for President, the General's brother, Earl, an engineer with a power company in Charleroi, Pa., said today.

Following is the text of President Truman's address at the dedication of the Simon Bolivar statue in Bolivar, Mo., as recorded and transcribed by the THE NEW YORK TIMES, and of an official translation of part of the address by President Romulo Gallegos:
LONDON, July 5 -- The British Government rushed tonight to the defense of a national hero, Earl Mountbatten, who was orally attacked by Gulam Mohammed, the Pakistani Minister of Finance.

Great Britain is now fully launched on the most ambitious social-security plan the world has ever seen. It will mean profound changes in British life, for every citizen can claim government benefits "from the cradle to the grave."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- Carole Landis, film actress, was found dead in her home today, apparently a suicide. Her age was 29.

Peruvian International Airways became yesterday the first airline to schedule flights at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. Beating out Air France, first to sign a lease at the new field and planning to make its first flight on Bastille Day, July 14, Peruvian said yesterday it would land its first DC-4 from Santiago, Chile, via Lima, Panama, Havana and Washington, about 4 P. M. on Friday.

Resources of The National City Bank of New York on June 30 totaled $4,995,679,834, compared with $4,850,380,620 on March 31 and $5,044,245,923 on June 30, 1947, the Bank discloses in its quarterly statement to be published today.

LONDON, July 5 -- Business in the stock market here today remained at an absolute minimum and the general tendency was dull. Although there was little selling, jobbers who were playing for safety widened prices pending developments in Berlin.

The departure of out-of-town buyers before the holiday week-end contributed to a slow-down in wholesale apparel markets here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

TORONTO, July 5 (Canadian Press) -- Industrials strengthened in dull trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange today. Golds showed a firmer tone and base metals and western oils weakened. Closing of United States markets today for the Independence Day holiday held down trading.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., defeated E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Albuquerque, N. M., by one stroke in their playoff today for the first Motor City open golf championship at the Meadowbrook Country Club.

Hand-woven fabrics created by a designer who started her professional career only ten months ago have been appearing in rapid succession in the studios and workrooms of a number of leading designers of contemporary furniture.

THE "Negro problem," as Lilian Smith reminded us some years ago, is a white problem at heart: a legion of novelists, taking that reminder in earnest, have wrestled with it valiantly since the publication of "Strange Fruit." For the most part, they have failed to win a clean-cut decision. Sometimes the antagonist was the American Fascist, in a variety of cos tumes.

Film Classics, Inc., will hold its first world-wide sales meeting at the Astor Hotel on July 30, 31 and Aug. 1, it was announced by B. G. Kranze, vice president and general sales manager. Heading the business agenda will be sales policy talks by Kranze on the thirty-four new pictures scheduled for release during 1948-49 by Film Classics, half to be filmed in Cinecolor, with which Film Classics is affiliated.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 311-317 West Eighty-ninth Street has been sold by Benjamin Knobel to the Rurob Real Estate Company, Inc. Pearce Mayer were the brokers and the attorneys were Joseph Howard Katz for the seller and Jack Laxer for the buyer.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 -- In a finish as torrid as the weather itself, Raise You, owned by Cortright Wetherill, gained the victory by a pert nose in the Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today.

BABYLON, L. I., July 5 -- Eddie Ketcham lost out in the Star Class championship as the three-day invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club came to a close today when the spreader on his Draco II broke and he was unable to finish the race.

Twelve girls and four boys, June graduates of New York and suburban high schools, were yesterday named winners of scholarships worth $800 each plus free tuition at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Two air-conditioned cars on a northbound train gave 150 young campers a foretaste of mountain weather yesterday as the first contingent left Grand Central Terminal at 9:30 A. M. for Fox Lair, Police Athletic League camp in the Adirondack Mountains.
A Workshop in Educational Leadership, conducted by the New York University School of Education, will open today and continue until Aug. 13, Dean Ernest O. Melby announced yesterday.

Robert Helfenbein, formerly production manager of the upholstery and drapery department of Cohn-Hall-Marx Company, has been appointed to direct manufacturing and mill operations of Golding Brothers Company, Inc., decorative fabrics.
General Dwight D. Eisenhower has not changed his mind about running for President. He is not a candidate and could not accept nomination for any public office.

WICHITA, Kan., July 5 (AP) -- Robert (Skee) Riegel of Glendale, Calif., won the Western amateur golf championship today by defeating James McHale of Philadelphia, 3 and 1, in the final of the week-long tournament.

PEIPING, China, July 5 -- Five refugee Manchurian students were killed and thirteen wounded this evening on Legation Street, in the center of the diplomatic quarter, when troops fired into marching student groups.
BOSTON, July 5 -- The Yankees celebrated the holiday today by taking two tremendous steps in the American League flag race, but both were in the wrong direction.

OTTAWA, July 5 (Canadian Press) -- The discussions opening in Washington tomorrow will constitute the first official step taken by the countries of the Western Hemisphere toward associating themselves with the countries of the Western Union -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- in defense arrangements against the spread of communism across Europe.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 5 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, conveyed today to the United States, Belgium and France a request that they provide a guard force of 1,000 men to supervise the demilitarization of parts of Jerusalem and Haifa if the present truce in Palestine were not extended when it expired Friday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- Morris Fleischer of the Maccabi A. C., Brooklyn, 1945 titleholder, captured the National A. A. U. twenty-kilometer walk title again today in 2:10:07.

NORTH SALEM, N. Y., July 5 -- The Conformation Hunter Championship, feature event on today's closing program of the annual three-day horse and colt show sponsored by the Goldens Bridge Hounds Club, went to Mrs. M. E. Whitney's Safety Call, ridden by Mrs. David Rose.

WINNIPEG, July 5 (AP) -- Oats and barley futures showed a firm tone on buying by processors and shippers today on the Grain Exchange here. Buying was stimulated by reports of lack of good moisture in some areas on the Prarie Grain Belt.
LONDON, July 5 -- Britain's Socialist Government put into effect today a "cradle to grave" social security system that is declared to be the most comprehensive in the world.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The United States Employment Service said today that the manpower supply was almost as tight as at the wartime peak.

Two books about New York have been scheduled for publication by two concerns. Columbia University Press will bring out in August "The Greater City: New York, 1898-1948," written by five authorities at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer. It is edited by Allan Nevins and John A. Krout; Carl Carmer, Thomas C. Cochran and Margaret Clapp are the other authors. Ziff-Davis will publish on July 21 "New York: Confidential," by Jack Lait and Lee Mortimer.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 5 -- There is a strong feeling today that the Olympic Track and Field committee will have to amend its plans to take only one extra sprinter to London to fill out the United States 400-meter relay team.

A former luxury resort hotel in the town of Pouges-les-Eaux, near Orleans, France, has been converted into a Jewish refugee children's center and named in honor of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, the Joint Distribution Committee, 270 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday.

The first group of organized Marine Corps reservists from the metropolitan area to leave here this year for summer training will depart Saturday on the Navy transport Oskaloosa for Camp Lejeune, N. C.

CHELTENHAM, England, July 5 -- Since its first production just 220 years ago, "The Beggar's Opera" never, apart from a gap in the nineteenth century, has been long absent from the English, nor for that matter, from the American stage.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- A record vote of more than four million baseball fans today named players from six National and five American League clubs to the starting line-ups for the All-Star game at St. Louis next Tuesday.

When General Eisenhower sent his now famous letter to the publisher of a New Hampshire newspaper some five months ago a strong movement was under way to "draft" him for the Republican nomination. This movement was on the point of reaching boom proportions.

Net sales of the Murray Corporation of America in the nine months ended with last May soared Ito $66,465,738 from the $48,959,763 volume a year earlier, but earnings declined, according to the report issued yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 6 -- The United Nations Security Council decided this afternoon to meet at 11 A. M. tomorrow to draft an urgent appeal to Israel and the Arab League asking them to extend the truce in Palestine. The truce began on June 11 and is scheduled to expire at 2 A. M.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The interior designer, who before the war has been compared to "Oscar of the Waldorf," has now changed his role to that of consumer's agent, according to Paul MacAlister. director of interior decoration for Montgomery Ward Company.

SEOUL, Korea, July 6 -- An investigation into Communist activity in the fourteen public hospitals in Seoul has been ordered by the American authorities. Threats of reprisals by the Reds against Korean nurses who are participating in the American-supervised training program were made known today by the metropolitan police chief, T. S. Chang.

Leaders of left-wing store unions in this city indicated yesterday that they would follow the example of the ten Hollywood actors and producers who refused to tell a Congressional investigating committee whether they were Communists.

The New York Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids July 15 on bond issues totaling $18,225,000 to take care of the permanent financing of the Jacob Riis City Houses. The issue will consist of $11,025,000 of city-guaranteed obligations maturing on July 1 from 1949 to 1997, and $7,200,000 of Federal Housing bonds deriving from that part of the project that was financed temporarily on a Federal-aid basis.
A change in the timetable of milk price advances proposed by leading dairy groups was recommended yesterday by the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington.

Arthur Meyer has been named sales manager of the shirting division of Verney Corporation of New York and assistant to Dan C. Lippman. He formerly was general sales and merchandise manager of Allen Snyder, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 6 -- The United Nations Security Council agreed tonight to cable its Good Offices Committee for full information on trade restrictions in Indonesia after hearing a complaint by the Indonesian Republic charging the Dutch with conducting a blockade of strangulation.

LONDON, July 6 -- The bilateral agreement qualifying Britain for United States aid in the European Recovery Program was signed here tonight an hour after the House of Commons had voted overwhelming approval of the pact.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- A persistent paid propaganda outside the country is trying to sow mistrust of Argentina, President Juan Peron told 4,000 officers of the armed forces last night. According to the President, the campaign, which he described as "niggardly," is being carried on by "international trusts."

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said tonight that 1948 lumber production, "despite considerable earlier optimism, is not now expected to exceed appreciably the high levels of 1947."
The Tammany Hall rebels began last night a determined drive to oust Frank J. Sampson as their leader, in defiance of the wishes of Mayor O'Dwyer.

The British Government has begun an informal investigation of excessive American distribution costs of some British dinnerware lines, an executive of an important local buying office with foreign purchasing connections disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced proposed changes in its proxy rules today and gave interested persons until July 30 to return their views and comments on the revisions.

The first step in the long and difficult process of rearming Western Europe was taken yesterday in Washington, when representatives of the newly formed Western European Union met with Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett.

The stock market received yesterday a fresh lift which pushed prices to close to the year's high, but a lag in buying during the afternoon only left fractional gains. The market was bolstered by a new demand for the rails and, although thinly spread, the momentum carried over to the steels and some of the oils.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 6 (AP) -- Although a late afternoon shower held up play for 30 minutes, the first round in the annual Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tournament was completed today with no upsets.

"Cain and Abel," the first in a !trilogy dramatizing the ideal of Z brotherhood, will be presented by the Jewish Theological Seminary ~as part of its regular program, "The Eternal Light," at 12:30 P..~f. next Sunday over NBC. On successive Sundays there will be offered "Jacob and Esau," and "Joseph and Benjamin."

The trim United States Lines freighter American Manufacturer was berthed at Pier 59, North River, yesterday with a collection of paintings that might well grace the walls of a nautical museum or an art gallery.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 6 -- The continuous campaign to dilute the veto will be handed directly to the United Nations General Assembly in the fall by the Little Assembly, which the Soviet Union has boycotted from its adoption.

A sore-armed pitcher, who had not worked since June 20, set down the Giants with four hits last night as Vern Bickford, the Braves' 27-year-old right-handed rookie, handed the home side a 4-3 defeat at the Polo Grounds. Only a three-run homer by Johnny Mize averted a shut-out.
PARIS, July 6 (AP) -- The French Foreign Ministry reported today that there was evidence of a Moscow-inspired plot to force the United States, France and Britain out of Berlin.

At noon today the city will give its official reception to Romulo Gallegos, president of Venezuela. The ceremony at City Hall will follow a parade along the traditional route of welcome up Broadway from Bowling Green.

LONDON, July 6 -- Although Britain, the United States and France have simultaneously informed the Soviet Union that there can be no four-power talks on Germany until the Soviet restrictions on Berlin transport are removed, Foreign Secretary Bevin told German Social Democratic leaders in London today that he "never" would abandon his efforts to win German unity.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has declined to serve as delegate-at-large from Indiana to the Democratic national convention, a post he had occupied in the last four Presidential elections.
The casual hat returned yesterday in the fall millinery showing presented by Emme at L'Aiglon Restaurant. The designer's shop is at 21 East Fifty-sixth Street.
PARIS, July 6 -- The French National Assembly tonight unanimously ratified acceptance by France of jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice at The Hague in international disputes.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Following Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement that he would not accept a nomination for public office, President Truman was returning to Washington today more confident than ever that he would be nominated for the Presidency on the first ballot of the Democratic National Convention.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 589, against 1,822 last week and 1,156 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 120 arrivals yesterday compared with 798 last Tuesday.

ROME, July 6 -- The Cabinet this morning approved a plan drawn up by Labor Minister Amintore Fanfani for dealing with unemployment, which has increased considerably in recent months and now totals 2,300,000.
PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski's ninth-inning two-run double with the bases loaded and two out tonight led the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-to-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

MUNICH, July 6 -- By the heft of a shopping bag, by the squeak of brand new shoes, by the potent symbol of the fuller dinner plate, the currency reform in Germany's western zones is to date considerably better than a pronounced success. It is the most effective aspirin yet administered for the world's worst economic headache.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- The fifth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party, in light of recent events, will give the Yugoslav leaders an opportunity to organize a demonstration of national unity and prove to the Cominform leaders and to the Russians in particular that the Communist party is united behind them.

"John Hancock: Patriot in Purple," by Herbert S. Allen, will be published by Macmillan on July 26. It is a biography of "one of the most neglected and maligned of outstanding figures in the annals of America" and a re-creation of a period in "man's struggle for political equality."
PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) -- Protesting lack of a contract, 40,000 coal miners employed at steel-company-owned pits stayed away from work today. Steel production started an immediate decline.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- The Soviet Government today joined the United States, British and French Governments in asking the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry to issue invitations to Danubian States to participate in a conference to be held in Belgrade beginning July 30.

The letter of Anthony Vangly, secretary of the Vietnam - American Friendship Association, published several days ago, is rather at odds with facts regarding the Vietnam Government, and Ho Chi-Minh, who heads it. To deny that the Vietnam Government is Communist controlled is like denying that Ho Chi-Minh is a Communist.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 6 -- Governor Dewey has decided to invade North Carolina in the Presidential campaign in an effort to swing its thirteen electoral votes into the Republican column and crack the Democratic "Solid South," it was disclosed today.

"Canon City," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Eagle-Lion dramatization of the prison break last year at Colorado State Penitentiary features Scott Brady, Jeff Corey, Stanley Clements, DeForest Kelley, Ralph Byrd and the warden of the prison, Roy Best.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Andy Schuttinger's Justice and J. M. Roebling's Macbeth dominated the running of the High Quest Purse at Monmouth Park today by finishing first and second respectively, over four other classy routers.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP) -- Eddie Waitkus scored on a wild pitch by Al Papai and Bill Nicholson slammed a home run in the eighth inning to give the Chicago Cubs a 12-to-10 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

BERLIN, July 6 -- Heavy Soviet fighter plane activity within the air corridors from the Western zones to Berlin produced warnings today to the United States and British pilots flying food to the blockaded city. It also stirred fears that the Russians might be attempting to impede the Anglo-American air supply by making the airways unsafe.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- All the travail the Brooklyn front office suffered in bringing Hank Behrman back to the Dodgers was forgotten tonight when the lanky and sometimes lackadaisical right-hander pitched the Brooks to their fifth straight triumph and gave the Phils no runs whatever.

It was pretty difficult to find a piece of water that wasn't decorated by numbers of fishermen earnestly plying their avocations over the holiday week-end. That went for beaches and boats, off-shore and inshore and in the fresh-water areas.

HEWLETT BAY PARK, L. I., July 6 -- Two robbers were allowed to escape with $1,000 and jewelry after they had been stopped, at revolver - point, by the family chauffeur, at the home of Philip G. Whitman, 195 Meadowview Avenue, early this morning.

Hilary Smart's trim-lined Hilarius yesterday was chosen to represent the United States in the Star Class Olympic yachting regatta scheduled for early next month at Torquay, Devon, England. The Central Long Island Sound craft yesterday finished the five-day Olympic tryouts, sponsored by the Sheepshead Bay Yacht Club, with a winning total of 32 points.

PARIS, July 6 -In diplomatic circles here it was said today that the notes sent to Moscow by the United States, Britain and France represented an assertion of rights and a warning to the Soviet Union, rather than any even implied invitation to negotiate.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 6 -- A compromise deemed necessary to placate delegates to the World Jewish Congress Assembly from countries where Communist influences are strong resulted today in the creation of new headquarters.

Best Co. has succeeded in having an Omaha ordinance, which imposed a tax on traveling representatives of out-of-state concerns, held invalid by the Nebraska Supreme Court, it was reported yesterday by Philip LeBoutillier, president of the company.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- Morris E. Lipsett of Jamestown, N. Y., the junk dealer who bought the liner Normandie and the battleship New Mexico, returned today on the President Cleveland from the Philippines, where he had spent two months arranging to scrap 80,000 tons of bombs he bought for $700,000.

Morton Pennypacker, 70-year-old historian of Southampton, L. I., ended a search of two decades yesterday in a dim-lit tomb in downtown Brooklyn's Fort Greene Park, and then unfolded a Revolutionary War tale of espionage, suffering and mystery.

LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- London newspapers fired hot rebuttals today at Bob Falkenburg, the American tennis player who won the men's singles title at the Wimbledon championships and then accused both officials and spectators of partiality.

NEW DELHI, India, July 6 -- The Indian Government will issue a White Paper tomorrow, tracing what it calls a "bloodless revolution" in the former semi-independent native Princely States that checkered the map of the Indian sub-continent.
Judson Hotel, landmark on Washington Square South, reopened yesterday as a residence for women at New York University's Washington Square Center.

BOSTON, July 6 -- Both their wits and their fingers seemingly numbed by an extraordinarily frigid blast that blew in from the sea, the Yankees tumbled down to their third straight defeat at the hands of the Red Sox tonight as Joe McCarthy's onrushing forces, behind the slick five-hit pitching of Joe Dobson, bagged the series finale, 2 to 1.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- Dizzy Trout shut out the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 0, and hit a home run into the upper deck of the left field stands tonight to help his own cause as the Detroit Tigers sewed up the game with three-run clusters in the fourth and fifth innings.
LONDON, July 6 -- British Government bonds and leading industrials were best in a generally quiet stock market here today.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, announced yesterday that the utility had filed an amendment to its plan of reorganization with the Securities and Exchange Commission to provide, principally, greater benefits to holders of the preferred stock issue.

A part of the estate of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt, comprising 258 acres of land fronting 3,960 feet on the east side of the Albany Post Road, directly opposite the Roosevelt Library and homestead in Hyde Park, N. Y., has been purchased by the Val-Kill Company, Inc., a corporation organized recently by Elliott Roosevelt.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 6 -- Police wielding clubs broke up a crowd of 3,000 Czechs shouting "We want Benes for President" in Prague's main square just before midnight tonight.

A "supreme effort" must be made to move displaced persons and refugees out of Central Europe before their discontent leads to the rise of a racial political movement like naziism, the Rev. Dr. Stewart W. Herman, executive secretary of the newly-established Lutheran World Federation Immigration Service, warned yesterday.

BERLIN, July 6 -- The first important step in the breaking up of the German administration of this city was taken by Soviet authorities today when it was disclosed that the Western sectors had been cut off from the city's treasury.

Loans outstanding with the Chase National Bank on June 30 totaled $1,461,069,553, the greatest amount reported on any quarterly date in seventeen years, the bank disclosed in its statement of condition issued today. It compares with $1,405,956,869 on March 31, and $1,203,007,457 on June 30, 1947.
Abraham Cahan, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, was optimistic about the future of the new state of Israel yesterday in his annual birthday interview. He will be 88 years old today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 6 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, conferred with Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, for two hours tonight on the proposed extension of the Palestine truce. He will meet the political committee of the League at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow and probably will return to Rhodes thereafter to await the Arab and Jewish replies.

Advertising and promotion budgets for home permanent wave kits, already in the multi-milllion dollar class, will rise even higher by the end of this year when Lever Brothers Company challenges the leadership of the Toni Company, it was predicted here yesterday by cosmetic trade sources.

Turning in the best figures of the meeting for the distance of five and a half furlongs, Hugh McL. Fenwick's Greek Blond won the featured Stefanita Purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The undefeated daughter of Heliopolis and Peroxide registered the fourth straight victory of her career as she scampered home in the sparkling time of 1:05 1/5, beating the favored Retama of the King Ranch by a length.

CLEVELAND, July 6 -- Three thousand delegates attending the National Education Association convention called upon President Truman to reconvene the Eightieth Congress to pass Federal aid to the Education Bill.

The "draft Eisenhower" movement was dying hard yesterday. Its principal backers, in various parts of the country, argued that General Eisenhower, despite his statement of late Monday night, could be nominated for President on the Democratic ticket by a genuine draft, and Frank Hague of New Jersey called on President Truman to place General Eisenhower in nomination himself, to avoid a disastrous party defeat in November.
This letter is written in almost shamefaced appreciation of the loyal way the members of this city's library staff continue to carry on in spite of churchmouse budgets and out-of-date salaries.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt ordered the release from jail today of James A. Sullivan, former Vice Mayor of Yonkers on a certificate of reasonable doubt pending the outcome of an appeal from his recent conviction in Westchester County Court on three felony charges involving forgery.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 6 (AP) -- The convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs deferred action today on a $75,000 stained glass memorial to past national presidents. It put off a decision until 1950.

The cheers for Tito in the Sokol parade in Prague mean more than any demonstration on the part of his cohorts at home. The Sokol Festival is the Czech olympiad, expanded through the years to take in representatives of all the Slav nations, including this year a contingent of husky youth from the Soviet Union.

A third man was arrested yesterday in connection with the investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office of fake accident claims against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation. The prisoner was Armendo LaMonte, 2009 Gleason Avenue, the Bronx, who was charged with grand larceny.

Discord between Moscow and the Government of Marshal Tito was evident before the Soviet Union openly criticized the Yugoslav leader, it was asserted yesterday at La Guardia Field by Cavendish Cannon, United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, upon his arrival at the airport aboard a Pan American World Airways Clipper from Lisbon.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6 (AP) -- Top-seeded Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, dropped his first two games today before defeating Ralph Burns, Indianapolis, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, in the second-round of men's singles of the Western tennis championships at the Woodstock Club.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The plight today of the curious assortment of machine Democrats from the big cities, Southern state leaders and New Dealers who joined in the movement to "draft" Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is this:

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- The Zionist Organization of America ended its fifty-first annual convention here today with a session of its newly elected national executive committee which began considerations of large-scale plans to mobilize the resources of American Jews in support of the economic development of the republic of Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Democratic high command looked today upon Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's restatement of his unavailability for public office as clinching President Truman's nomination by a one-sided margin on the first ballot.

With vacation periods and curtailed operations cutting down output this month, cotton mills are expected to liquidate a good portion of their available inventories, it was pointed out in Worth Street yesterday. Easing of inventory pressure, mill men said, will tend to stabilize prices at somewhere near the current level, even though purchasing volume may prove disappointing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Linda Darnell will play the leading role in "Waltz Into Darkness" and that John M. Stahl will direct the film this fall, from the 1947 novel by William Irish. George Jessel, producer of "Waltz," will begin preliminary work on the picture after he returns from a trip to Europe.

Pierre Monteux made his first appearance of the season last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Those who were there again, after being driven home by the rain Monday before the program started, were well repaid for the second trip. It was a beautiful concert.
BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- An exhibition of seventy pictures produced by children of the New York City public schools, which was opened to the public today, has drawn interested crowds.
TRIESTE, July 6 (AP) -- The first open rebellion against Premier Marshal Tito in the Yugoslav Communist party was reported here today.

Actors Equity nanded an ultimatum to the League of New York Theatres yesterday, threatening to break off contract negotiations today unless the managers grant its demands for increases in minimum wages and rehearsal pay.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Millers' National Federation, a trade association of the milling industry, denied today that the absence of an international wheat agreement would increase the cost of food shipments under the Economic Cooperation Act.

The present annual corporate report should be replaced by a different method of reporting, according to Daniel J. Hennessy, president of the Controllership Foundation, who asserts that most statements of the general type now issued by corporations fail in their purpose to inform stockholders.
The cotton futures market closed 15 to 34 points net lower yesterday, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange moderately active.

Business cycles may be compared with cancer. In each, normal cells in a healthy body assume a wild state and begin to multiply in geometric progression, with unspeakable consequences. In addition to this erratic behavior, the business cycle is cursed with a functional malady that aggravates the condition and accelerates the disintegrating processes of its prosperity phase.

BALTIMORE, July 6 -- Dr. John B. McCord of Oakham, Mass., at 78 one of the oldest players participating in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, tonight led the way into to the third round with a quick triumph over John M. Palmer Jr. of Norfolk, Va.
PARIS, July 6 -- Shipments of notable quantities of arms by sea into Albania in the last few days were reported today from authoritative diplomatic sources in the Balkan peninsula.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., July 6 -- Vincent Kristian Asciutto, 13 years old, son of a dress manufacturer, was critically injured by gunshot here today in his home. His mother, Mrs. Signe Helen Larsen Asciutto, 47, was arrested by the state police on a charge of deliberately firing a rifle at the boy.

The summer camping season for children moved into its second phase yesterday. While last week's camp rush was mainly to send youngsters to out-of-town camps, the post-Fourth of July week-end camp rush yesterday was primarily for children who would "camp" in and near New York City.
NANKING, July 6 -- The Communist radio announced tonight that Red troops had won a major victory in eastern Honan and southwest Shantung after encircling three Nationalist armies.

Litigation is still ahead in the New Orleans civic struggle over rationalizing railroad terminal facilities. Bankers who last April bought $15,000,000 of the Louisiana city's union railroad terminal bonds have canceled the transaction because an unqualified legal opinion as to the validity of the issue was not forthcoming within the sixty days that have since passed.

TED WILLIAMS, the boy philosopher of the Boston Red Sox, remarked one day last week that there wouldn't be any .400 hitters in the major leagues this season. At that precise moment Master Ted was thumping away at a gaudy .415 clip and his words were viewed with a slight amount of suspicion. But in the interval it would seem as though Williams were trying hard to prove his theory.

BUTLER, Pa., July 6 (UP) -- American Bantam Car Company announced today that it had purchased the Newgren Company of Toledo, Ohio, a subsidiary of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company of Monroe, Mich. The Newgren Company manufactures farm equipment.

Mary Goodfellow has the knack of making a hat that is easy to wear. In the collection presented in her showroom at 600 Madison Avenue yesterday were brims and crowns that could be worn, and successfully, by women of many types and ages.

Several years ago some sports writer who depended, apparently, more on his memory than on the record book started the fiction that the two teams which were leading the major leagues on July 4 generally wound up in the World's Series in October. Why he picked July 4 is not now known.

Resources, deposits, loans and capital funds of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York were higher on June 30 than at the close of the first quarter, according to the statement of condition published today. On June 30 resources were $2,799,933,625, compared with $2,760,369,125 on March 31 and $2,808,162,975 at the end of June last year.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 6 (AP) -- The last vote-fraud conspiracy case growing out of the 1946 primary election here was dismissed today at the request of the Federal Government.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 6 -- It was considered likely today that Israel might consent to a prolongation of the truce and the demilitarization of Jerusalem and the port area of Haifa, if there were sufficient guarantees to insure their respective safety.

LONDON, July 6 -- The reception hall of London's stately Mansion House, official residence of the Lord Mayor, looked like an American super market at noon today. Stacked in center of room, in American grocery-store style, were pyramids of canned goods sent from New London, Conn., to needy citizens of the British capital for which New London was named.

In three notes described as the strongest served on Moscow since the end of the war, the United States, Britain and France have now formally protested against Russian policies in Berlin and have demanded a lifting of the blockade which is designed to drive us from the German capital.

PEIPING, July 6 -- The death toll of students in yesterday's tragic shooting by the troops into a student demonstration mounted today to seven. At least twenty-one students have been arrested. Another twenty-one are still hospitalized with gunshot and shrapnel wounds.

Improvement in American life demands that the individual citizen assume the responsibility to defend with his life the liberty and rights enjoyed by Americans, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia, declared yesterday in welcoming summer students to the university.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Avery Brundage today notified the committees controlling the American Olympic team that it will be "necessary to curtail the squads unless funds are subscribed before the ship sails for London July 14."

LONDON, July 6 -- The first major foreign oil concession granted to American interests in more than a decade has been obtained by the American Independent Oil Company in the neutral zone between Kuweit and Saudi Arabia on the Persian Gulf, the center of the richest oil region in the Middle East.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- Two Russian women have filed suits to divorce United States sergeants they married during the war. Newspapers published today notices of actions by Antonina Phillips against William V. Phillips, 212 George Street, Pen Argyl, Pa., and by Marina S. Yaross against Alan Yaross, 12400 Edmunton St., Cleveland.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 6 (AP) -- Miss Stella Walsh, the Polish-born Cleveland girl who has been winning women's track events over parts of two decades, did it again tonight as she captured three titles in the annual women's A. A. U. national track and field, championships.

A general truck strike of far greater intensity than the tie-up that choked the city's commerce for two months in the fall of 1946 is likely when present contracts expire Aug. 31, three associations of truck owners warned in a joint statement last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- The fundamental issue that precipitated the decision of the Communist Information Bureau to overthrow Marshal Tito and the Yugoslav Communist leadership was the question of the horizontal organization of the Communist world based on the principle of mutual agreements as opposed to the existing order of things based on a vertical organization and compulsion.

Prospect of long-delayed face-lifting operations around the base of the Statue of Liberty has reminded one whose mind runs backward against time in its flight to tell us something about the island on which the famous statue stands -- an island on which -- he said -- most New Yorkers never set foot.

Representatives of Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, resumed negotiations yesterday, with an all-day meeting at the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service offices, 341 Ninth Avenue.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 6 -- Finnish Communists think they should have the key Ministry of the Interior, controlling the police force in the new Government, Mrs. Hertta Kuusinen-Leino, member of the Cabinet and Finland's leading woman Communist, said today.

Operations on the city transit system were reported normal yesterday by Board of Transportation officials as the higher-fare system met its first normal weekday test in the morning and evening rush hours.

A reduction of 4 cents a pound in parcel post rates on overseas relief packages went into effect yesterday, making it possible for Americans to increase their personal foreign aid within fixed budgets. The new rate is 10 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States note protesting the Russian blockade of Berlin and demanding that it be lifted immediately was handed to Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, at 11:30 A. M. today by Secretary of State Marshall.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey sent word to the National Education Association today denying he asked other Governors to "break the teachers' lobby" and promising to discuss Federal aid to education in his campaign for President.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Lou Brissie survived a two-run Washington rally in the eighth inning tonight to move the Philadelphia Athletics within 10 percentage points of first place with a 5-3 victory over the Senators.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Floor covering manufacturers are allocating virtually their entire production this year, while a third of the nation's furniture companies are operating on a quota basis, industry leaders stated today at meetings held in the Merchandise Mart and at the American Furniture Mart in conjunction with the two-weeks summer homefurnishings market which opened yesterday.

Containers in varying sizes, brands or colors can be systematically sorted into individual groups, regardless of their original order, by a new automatic segregator which is now being used in a wide variety of industries, Food Machinery Corporation, Riverside, Calif., announced here yesterday.

The Economic Cooperation Administration is planning supplemental regulations to meet the price cause of section 202 of the ECA Appropriations Act, it was learned here yesterday. The clause, of major importance to foreign traders and banks, is interpreted as a ban on authorization of ECA purchases within or without the United States of bulk commodities at prices higher than the prevailing market in the United States.
ROME, July 6 -- Despite the breach between Belgrade and Moscow, the situation of the Roman Catholic Church in Yugoslavia is expected to remain critical, Vatican circles said today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 6 (AP) -- Former President Eduard Benes was cheered today by 80,000 persons marching through Prague in the Sokol Congress parade. There were no cheers for his Communist successor, President Klement Gottwald.
The United States Weather Bureau here is issuing two weather forecasts a day now instead of four, it was announced yesterday when the new schedule went into effect.
AKRON, Ohio, July 6 (AP) -- Two major producers today announced increases in the prices of tires and tubes.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall plans to have a conversation soon with John Foster Dulles about continuing the bipartisan approach to American foreign policy, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- Local leaders of the movement to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic nomination for President refused today to accept his Monday night statement as final and will continue their efforts to draft him.

Prompt action by three young men standing at the rail was credited by the police yesterday morning with saving the life of Mrs. Concetta Falco, 30 years old, of 41 White Plains Avenue, Rosebank, S. I., after she had leaped from the stern of the municipal ferryboat Miss New York, on its way from St. George, S. I., to Manhattan.

For two successive days now New York has been under invasion by bees: thousands of them, first in Yorkville and then in Brooklyn. This is the season of the year when all good little bees ought to be hard at work in the country, dutifully gathering honey and not soldiering around in a big city.

A freakish thunderstorm, which appears to have concentrated its fury on Westchester County, put out of commission two electric locomotives of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad about 5 P. M. yesterday when they were struck by lightning as they were hauling 800 commuters to their homes in Connecticut.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- With Polish, Czechoslovak and South African delegates abstaining, the International Labor Conference today approved its proposed convention of an international treaty guaranteeing freedom of association and the right of workers and employers to organize.
Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard vacated yesterday a writ of habeas corpus obtained last week by 119 men and women in an attempt to block their deportation to Germany as dangerous enemy aliens.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 6 -- Announcement was made today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, of the appointment of Cornelius Brett Boocock, headmaster of the Scarborough School, Scarborough-on-Hudson, N. Y., and a Rutgers alumnus, as Dean of Men at the university. He will take office this summer.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Liquidation continued today in July corn on the Board of Trade, the price breaking the 8-cent daily limit at one time under the weight of offerings from longs. Numerous stop-loss orders were uncovered, and for a short time the future was offered at the maximum decline without trading, but later short covering developed and a rally followed with the close showing a net loss of only 4 1/2 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Government scientists using equipment developed to discover enemy wireless stations during the war have uncovered and dismantled a 'ham" station through which an unnamed 17-year-old boy was sending fake and disturbing messages to the Bolling Air Force base here, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

One of the mysteries of astrophysics is the "red shift" of the light that comes to us from nebulae on the outskirts of the known universe, two hundred million and more light-years away. By "red shift" the astrophysicist means that all the lines of the spectrum are moved toward the red by an amount which increases with the distance.

A plan to ship automotive equipment to Israel was announced yesterday by Harris J. Klein, attorney, as chairman of Trucks for Israel, Inc., an organization formed in memory of Col. David Marcus former New York City Commissioner of Correction who was killed in the Palestine fighting.

Fruit breads are timely now, because they complement a variety of warm-weather dishes. Sliced very thin and spread with butter, cream cheese or some other filling, they are appropriate with luncheon salads, afternoon tea or, in sandwiches, to take along on a picnic.
TOKYO, July 6 -- An accusation of perjury was leveled today against Premier Hitoshi Ashida as political tension mounted, following the adjournment of the Diet at midnight last night.

The Seventy-first Infantry, New York National Guard, commemorated last night the fiftieth anniversary of the participation of the Seventy-first New York Volunteers in the Battle of San Juan Hill by re-enacting the famous attack on the Cuban blockhouse in its armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
LONDON, July 6 -- The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party has refused an invitation to the Yugoslav Communist party's annual assembly, opening July 21, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, will ask the United States District Court by the end of the week for an injunction restraining the strike of 40,000 "captive" miners which began today, according to well informed sources.

The second phase of the Olympic rowing trials will get under way today over the 2,000-meter course on Carnegie Lake at Princeton. The University of California qualified last week as the eight-oared crew to represent the United States at London.

Advertising in the eight major New York City daily newspapers totaled 12,721,518 lines during June a gain of 6.12 per cent over the like period of 1947, according to an analysis of Media Records yesterday. All categories showed gains, except general, which was down 2.24 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The National Security Resources Board has been organized to meet not only the requirements of the present "preparedness" situation but also those of a possible wartime emergency. In addition to the administrative staff, there are three staff agencies.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 6 (AP) -- A downpour of rain, which stopped everything at the track but the horses, halted just in time for a slim crowd of about 6,000 to see W. J. Walden's Circus Clown triumph today in the Philadelphia Handicap at Havre de Grace.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 6 (AP) -- Acting on urgent orders, United States warships sailed out of Istanbul and Naples harbors under forced draft today with their destination a mystery.

Delegates of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, representing ports from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va., met here yesterday for a preliminary discussion of terms for a new contract.

The action taken yesterday in the British House of Commons on the bilateral ERP treaty between the United Kingdom and this country was hardly calculated to lend comfort to those who had foreseen a bitter controversy over the terms of that agreement. Previously introduced and warmly defended by Sir Stafford Cripps, the measure was overwhelmingly passed by a vote of 409 to 12.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 6 -- Boo Morcom, slim New Hampshire graduate who is rated a sure thing to win one of the three Olympic pole-vaulting berths in the final tryouts here Friday and Saturday, today broke the stick that carried him on countless flights over fourteen feet during the last three years.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July 6 -- President Truman congratulated the teachers of the country today for their activities contributing toward rehabilitation of a war-devastated world and "the inauguration of a new era of international peace and good-will."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The charting of a pattern for United States political and military support of the Western European Union was begun today at a conference held by Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett in his office with diplomatic representatives of all but one of the European countries concerned and with Canada.

PORTLAND, Me., July 6 (AP) -- The Sunnyside Mining and Milling Co., property from which millions of dollars worth of lead, zinc, gold and silver were taken earlier in the century, will be sold at public auction at Denver, Col., on July 15.

Private financiers and economists do not generally share the opinion that official pegging should maintain Government bonds above par, according to a poll of banking opinion in the nation which is summed up in the current issue of Banking.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator Claude Pepper of Florida called on the Democratic party today to transform itself temporarily into a national movement, draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as a "national" and hence "nonpartisan" Presidential candidate and promise him substantial control of the party's national convention opening in Philadelphia next week.

Such children's television programs as the Howdy Doody marionette show and the Small Fry Club have been without fifteen of their most enthusiastic followers for the last two weeks. Yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court Mrs. Lillian Haspel sought to do something about it.

Until enabling legislation is obtained, the Fire Department will cease organizing a reserve corps of civilian volunteers, in compliance with a recent decision of the corporation counsel. Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle said yesterday.

The three-day Fourth of July week-end brought violent death to at least 571 persons, according to a survey by The Associated Press, which said the overall safety showing was the poorest since 1941 and the third worst in 20 years.

Railroad travel into and out of New York was still heavy yesterday as holiday visitors departed and the final contingents of New Yorkers, away for the Fourth of July week-end, returned to their homes and jobs.

Boardman Robinson once did a cartoon showing a family starting on a vacation trip, while the cat, looking after the car from the deserted door step, says mournfully, "Good-by, I hope you'll have a fine time." It was a sharp commentary on what too often happens to dogs and cats.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 6 -- Harry Barnes, president of the Waterside Workers Union, to whom use of the Government-controlled radio has been denied, said tonight that his statement on the Mountpark dispute at Auckland had been recorded and, in the event of trouble, the disks would be flown to Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's Organization in San Francisco, to be relayed along the Pacific Coast.

Modern store interiors are being planned to guide consumers to the best selling locations by subtle suggestions in the form of tricks in design, displays, lighting effects, directional markings and other influences that "hypnotize" the shopper into going where the retailer wants him to go.
New issues of railroad equipmenttrust serial certificates totaling $13,100,000 were awarded at competitive sales yesterday to banking syndicates, as follows:

The National League named only six pitchers to its All-Star baseball squad yesterday but picked four slugging third basemen in hopes of overpowering the American League in the annual game at St. Louis next Tuesday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 7 (AP) -Miss Anna Eleanor Boettiger, eldest granddaughter of the late President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, was married to Van H. Seagraves of Oregon City, Ore., today at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 7 -- Organization of a new import firm to help out in the rehabilitation program for Japan was announced here today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 7 -- A revolt against James Roosevelt's leadership in opposition to the nomination of President Truman broke out today aboard the train carrying Southern California's contingent of delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Wheat resumed leadership in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today moving up rapidly as the result of broad buying by mills and elevator interests, and closing trades were about the top with gains of 2 1/2 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -It appeared probable today that "The Robe," Frank Ross' long-delayed project at RKO, will be made at another studio as a consequence of the RKO reorganization under Howard Hughes' ownership.

Lloyd J. Kitazono, 24 years old, of 3120 Broadway, was taken yesterday to the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center for treatment for serious injuries to the eyes as the result of an explosion in the chemistry laboratory at City College, where he is a student.

Withdrawal by the Western powers from their sectors of Berlin under pressure by the Russians would enable Soviet propagandists to report a "major triumph" to nations behind the Iron Curtain, Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, declared here yesterday.

In letters to the editor column in THE TIMES of July 4 I note where Mr. Marinstein of Brooklyn asks, "I believe the statute is unfair. Those of us who serve will not be entitled to any educational benefits or mustering out pay. Could there be any justification for this gross injustice to the countless youths of our nation who will serve?"
Sigmund Janas, president of Colonial Airlines, threatened last night to hale the Port of New York Authority to court.
