LONDON, July 7 -- Better conditions were expected in the stock market here today following the signing last night of the treaty giving effect to the European Recovery Program here, but the Berlin situation kept buyers cautious. Until the Soviet reply to the three-power note of protest is known, jobbers still fear selling, and prices, as a consequence, were uncertain, and business restricted.

Sixth choice in an open session of shopping at the mutuel windows, a 2-year-old colt named The Admiral surprised many of the 23,598 shoppers at Aqueduct yesterday by winning the $24,475 Tremont Stakes by about a neck after an up-and-at-'em run through the stretch.

South Jamaica, Queens, buried a friend yesterday and 500 persons came to the funeral. They attended services for Teddy, a brown and white setter-collie, who had run and played in the neighborhood for eighteen years, since he was a pup.

NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE, England, July 7 -- A fervent plea to delegates from all mine fields to give Britain 200,000 tons more coal a week was made this morning by Foreign Secretary Bevin to the annual conference of the National Union of Mineworkers at Whitley Bay, a near-by seaside resort.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 7 -- Despite vigorous public criticism of the Western Allies' proposals, German political leaders appeared tonight to be ready to accept the authorization to initiate a Western German government.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7 -- Unless the Brazilian Price Control Board modifies its demands, United States motion-picture producers will declare a lockout and refuse to deliver films to exhibitors, a headline in a newspaper here today warned.

A facsimile telegraph sender and receiver, designed to increase the speed of telegrams and cut operating costs, has been developed by engineers of the Western Union Telegraph Company, it announced yesterday.

The Interstate Sanitation Commission pressed the city administration yesterday to commit itself to a schedule of yearly expenditures that would end pollution by sewage of most of New York Harbor and adjacent waters "within a reasonable time."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 30:

Newspapers outgained magazines and radio in national advertising during May, it was reported yesterday by Printers Ink. The increase over the like period of last year was placed at 12 per cent, and the gain over April at 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Members of organized reserve units requiring at least thirty-five scheduled drills or training periods a year will be exempt from the peacetime draft, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Justice Department may institute criminal investigation of railroad men who as wartime Army and Navy officers approved questionable rates for the transportation of war supplies, a Congressional subcommitee was told today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 7 -- The general election in the Netherlands today resulted in widespread losses for the Communist party, amounting to a drop of at least 25 per cent in the popular vote. The trend as a whole has swung moderately to the right.

DETROIT, July 7 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser of the Detroit Tigers, bidding for a pitcher's berth on the American League All-Star team, blanked the St. Louis Browns, 6 to 0, tonight as he scattered seven hits.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 7 -- The latest techniques in surgery will be demonstrated for medical men in Poland and Finland during the next eight weeks by an international team of specialists, it was announced here today by the United Nations World Health Organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 7 -- The Syrian Government has protested the appointment of James G. MacDonald as United States diplomatic representative to the Provisional Government of Israel on the ground that this was a violation of the truce in Palestine, it was disclosed today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7 (UP) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla organized a Cabinet of "national concentration" representing the Radical, Liberal and Traditionalist Conservative parties.

Ten-inch direct view cathode ray tube stockpiles will be exhausted with six weeks and television receiver manufacturers will be working from production alone, James H. Carmine, vice president for distribution, Philco Corporation, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Representatives of thirty-six countries today abandoned an international agreement that would have put a ceiling price of $2 a bushel on certain wheat exports during the year starting Aug. 1.
The metering of all water supplied to the city's 150,000 multiple dwellings was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer by his Executive Committee on Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan today praised the work of women reserves in war and in peace at the ceremony of swearing the first six enlisted women into the regular Navy under the provisions of the Women's Armed Services Integration Act passed by the last Congress.
BERNSLEY, England, July 7 -- Peter, a mongrel, was convicted two years ago of bothering chickens and was sentenced to death.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -Several "gray market" steel brokers already have rushed in to pay taxes on unreported income, Representative Macy, Republican, of New York, said today, and there are more to come.

Because veterinarians decided she was dying of a broken heart brought on by loneliness, Queenie, a 3-year-old collie is on her way today to East Long Beach, Calif., to join her 17-year-old master, Benjamin Schneider. Accompanying Queenie on the trip is the boy's other pet, Rusty, a 2 and 1/2-year old alley cat.

ABOARD THE CARRIER BOXER OFF HAWAII, July 7 (UP) -- The aged battleship New York, survivor of two world wars and two atomic bombs, capsized and sank unexpectedly under rocket and light bomb attack off the Hawaiian Islands today before the Navy could test its modern post-war weapons on the fleet's "Grand Old Lady."

The joint Congressional committee authorized by Congress to make a study of the Pacific islands now under United States control, including the former Japanese mandates, has been meeting in Washington this week to select its staff and to mark out the itinerary for its trip, which will begin after the November elections.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (AP) -Unseeded Arnold Saul of Los Angeles, University of Southern California's No. 1 tennis player and basketball high scorer of two years ago, upset fourth-seeded Herbert (Buddy) Behrens of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today in the third round of the Western tennis championships at the Woodstock Club.

Charges that the higher gas rates of the Long Island Lighting Company have resulted in increases of 50 per cent and more in customers' bills were heard yesterday by the Public Service Commission, which is conducting hearings into company rates.

"The Babe Ruth Story" will have its world premiere at the Astor Theatre on Monday, July 26, with all proceeds from the initial showing going to the Babe Ruth Foundation, recently formed to aid under-privileged children throughout the country.

A nation-wide promotion on the wide-spread collar shirt is being planned for the latter part of October by manufacturers of men's shirts, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rapp, vice president of the Men's Tie Foundation. Tentative plans call for the promotion to run for a week and to feature shirts with windsor knot neckties.
LIMA, Peru, July 7 -- A three-day rebellion of Army garrisons at Puno and Juliaca, in southern Peru, has been put down completely, telephoned reports from Cuzco said tonight.

Another chapter in a touching story told over the radio last December will be added before Supreme Court Justice James B.M. McNally today when he acts on a petition for the appointment of a guardian for a child whose father, an ex-convict, is said to have spent $9,000 contributed to his family by sentimental radio listeners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 7 -- The United Nations Security Council, after a discussion lasting throughout the day, appealed urgently this afternoon to Israel and the members of the Arab League to agree to an extension of the truce in Palestine. The vote was 8 to 0, with the Soviet Union, the Ukraine and Syria abstaining.
Fiesta spirit broke the midsummer doldrums in New York's financial district yesterday as the city gave its traditional welcome to Romulo Gallegos, first popularly elected President of Venezuela.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Andy Pafko, newly named as the National League All-Star third baseman, made three errors as the Cubs floundered to a 10-3 defeat at the hands of the Cincinnati Reds today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- In the efforts to create a reliable defense understanding between North America and Western Europe, Canada is playing an important and perhaps decisive role.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 7 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association tried a novel tournament called the family string event at the Creek Club course today.
The winning touch is still eluding the Yankees and pretty soon the matter could become serious.
Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday an interim report on the city's milk-price inquiry alleging collusion among major milk companies here.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The notes to Russia 'from the United States, Great Britain and France protesting against the Soviet blockade of their sectors in Berlin were written in forceful language. Morally and practically, and as a statement of the relations that should exist among victorious allies, the case they present is strong.
ALBANY, July 7 (AP) -- The Appellate Division today upheld the removal of 533 persons from registration rolls of the American Labor party in Albany County.

Maxie Rosenbloom, erstwhile light heavyweight boxing champion, will undertake a network radio show on July 23 over the facilities of NBC. Booked for the 10 o'clock spot on Friday evenings, the former pugilist will participate in a situation comedy piece, with Benny Rubin, the comedian, and Patricia Bright, song satirist and impersonator, serving in the supporting cast.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 7 -- Yugoslav students at the Marxist Leninist Institute in Moscow, in a dramatic gesture of revolt against the Communist Information Bureau, have sent a telegram to the Yugoslav Central Committee pledging their support to Marshal Tito and to the Yugoslav Communist party.

"Raw Deal," an Eagle-Lion melodrama starring Dennis O'Keefe, Claire Trevor and Marsha Hunt, will have its local premiere this morning at the Victoria Theatre. Anthony Mann directed and Aubrey Schenck produced the Edward Small presentation from a screen play by Leopold Atlas and John C. Higgins.

The New York price for bulk cement, delivered in New York harbor, is $2.96 a barrel compared with a former price of $2.82, cement mill spokesmen revealed here yesterday in disclosing new price lists which will become effective tomorrow, the date set by the Supreme Court for compliance with its ruling against the basing point system of pricing.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July 7 -- Proposals in various parts of the country to base teachers' salaries on rating scales rather than on training and experience were attacked at the opening session today of the annual conference of the American Federation of Teachers.

NEWARK, N. J., July 7 (AP) -Clarence Marshall's four-hit pitching plus a couple of timely blows by Jay Difani and Johnny Lucadello carried Newark to a 7-2 triumph over Jersey City tonight and enabled the Bears to strengthen their grip on second place.

Stays of deportations granted by the Federal courts and by immigration authorities have reduced to seventy the number of persons scheduled to be sent to Germany today as dangerous enemy aliens, assistant United States Attorney Harold J. Raby said last night.

CHICAGO, July 7 (UP) -- The Plains States bulged with harvested wheat today and some of it spilled over on the ground for lack of storage space. Elevators were reported crammed with the golden grain in the big producing states of Kansas and Nebraska.

A new book by F.O. Matthiessen, entitled "From the Heart of Europe," will be brought out Sept. 9 by the Oxford University Press. It is a journal of the author's thoughts and impressions during a stay last summer and fall in Salzburg, Prague and other European cities.

Truck owners of the metropolitan area were accused yesterday by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, of having "jumped the gun" with their joint "warning" that this port area faced a general truck strike when present contracts with the union expired on Aug. 31.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower dashed the hopes but failed to dampen the enthusiasm last night of 5,000 admirers who milled around the residence of the new president of Columbia University at 60 Morningside Drive chanting "We want Eisenhower."

Just a year ago at this time the public was receiving its first inkling that all was not well with the corn crop, the Number One source of feed for livestock, dairy animals and poultry. The first official Government report, released the second week of July, pointed to a yield of 2,600,000,000 bushels for the season, or 400,000,000 under the Department of Agriculture's goal and almost 700,000,000 below the bumper 3,288,000,000 crop of 1946.

BELGRADE, July 7 -- Milovan Djilas, a member of the Yugoslav Politburo and propaganda chief of the Central Committee, has been elected to represent the Second Proletarian Partisan Division to the Fifth Party Congress. M. Djilas is one of the principal Yugoslav leaders banned by the Cominform and has been the spokesman of the Yugoslav Communist party in the bitter polemic exchange with the leaders of other Comiform parties.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note delivered by the State Department yesterday to the Polish Ambassador:

In the face of warnings that they would be cited for contempt of Congress, three leaders of a New York store and warehouse workers' union refused yesterday to tell a House investigating committee whether they were Communists or members of organizations listed by the Department of Justice as subversive.
CAIRO, July 7 (AP) -- Egypt and other Arab countries plan to withdraw from the Olympic Games in London late this month if the Zionist flag is flown, an Egyptian Foreign Office source said today.
The fashion field held a double-header yesterday when two millinery showings were held in well-known houses.

TEL AVIV, July 7 -- The Israeli Government is willing to prolong the truce if there is a possibility that certain major points, like immigration and the status of Jerusalem, can be resolved during the cessation period. Whether this possibility exists would have to be decided by Count Bernadotte, who knows the attitude of both Israel and the Arabs.

JERUSALEM, July 7 -- Four and possibly five Britons are being held in custody by Irgun Zvai Leumi in Jerusalem following their capture at a local electricity powerhouse this morning upon allegations that they had "communicated with enemies of the Israeli forces."

BOSTON, July 7 -- A former Massachusetts Lieutenant Governor, Francis E. Kelly, a delegate-at-large to the convention, plans to present to the Democratic National Convention Resolutions Committee a plan for a Federal sweepstakes drawing as a tax reduction measure.

Directors of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the new common stock, payable on July 29. On June 29 the company distributed an additional share for each share held. Previous cash payments were $1.50 each in August and December, 1947.

The nation's production of crude oil last week averaged 5,483,800 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented a decline of 10,100 barrels from the daily average of 5,493,900 in the previous week and compared with 5,065,200 daily in the week ended July 5, 1947.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary-General of the Arab League, announced after a meeting of the full Political Committee of the Arab League late tonight that "there will be no extension of the truce in Palestine."

PARIS, July 7 -- The French National Assembly ratified today the bilateral agreement with the United States on the European Recovery Program De Gaullists and some Conservatives abstained from the voting and Communists opposed ratification.

The first campaign blast at Governor Dewey in his new role of Republican Presidential nominee was fired here yesterday by the Democratic State Committee. In a formal statement Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick analyzed the Dewey administration, declaring that the Governor himself had chosen to compare his record with that of Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic predecessor.

What is known to newspapers and travelers as "Hampton trouble" -- there are five Hamptons in Suffolk County -- caused THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an article published yesterday, to refer to Morton Pennypacker, 70-year-old historian, as a resident of Southampton.

BERLIN, July 7 -- Everybody, from Heinrich Nohr the neighborhood bookmaker to Franz Schubert who runs the "Femina," one of the city's most expensive night clubs, agreed that the two currency reforms had blitzed business in Berlin.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday that as of June 30, the close of its fiscal year, assets were $97,775,665, equal to $50.22 a share, compared with $47.53 at the beginning of the fiscal year. Net asset value was $48.46 on March 31, the end of the company's third quarter.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 7 (AP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., led four other seeded stars into the quarter-final round of the annual Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tennis tournament today with a straight-set victory over August Ganzenmuller of Sea Cliff, L. I.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 -- Forty-five educators met today at Adelphi College, near here, to attend a seminar sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and the Department of Public Information of the United Nations.
CLEVELAND, July 7 (AP) -- The pennant-chasing Indians today signed that old veteran, Leroy (Satchel) Paige, as a relief pitcher.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- A sharp clash over Governor Dewey's stand on education today turned an otherwise peaceful National Education Association convention of 3,500 of the nation's top school leaders into a bitter political battleground. New York State delegates attacked and defended the Governor's educational record.
RHODES, July 7 -- Hope of avoiding further war in Palestine shrank today with reports of two fresh truce breaches reaching the Rhodes headquarters of the United Nations Mediator Count Bernadotte.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, reiterated today the High Command's decision that the Air Force would be responsible for strategic bombing of land centers in any future war.
BOSTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Senators cut loose with a five-run rally with one out in the ninth to overtake the Red Sox for a 7-6 victory tonight before a crowd of 33,957.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 7 (AP) -- Dr. William Haber, United States Military Government adviser on Jewish affairs, denied today that there was any threat of anti-Semitic rioting in the United States zone of Germany.

Forty-five thousand Atlantic Coast longshoremen will demand substantial wage increases, a pension fund, longer vacations and other improvements in working conditions when they meet with employing stevedore companies for contract negotiations on Monday.

The record of President Truman in carrying on the "great humanitarian and social aims laid down by Franklin D. Roosevelt," and his own "far-seeking program for the future" were praised last night by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 7 -Yale, Princeton and the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia were the heavy qualifiers today in the opening heats of the United States Olympic rowing trials for fours, pairs and double sculls. The races were held over the 2,000-meter Carnegie Lake course on which California's eight-oared crew last Saturday won the boat ride to London.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was slightly irregular yesterday and final prices were 10 points higher to 8 points lower.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The economic mobilization policies of Chairman Arthur M. Hill and his staff of the National Security Resources Board are based upon what they term the theory of economic readiness.

CLEVELAND, July 7 (AP) -- The Indians exploded six runs in the first inning and coasted to a 10-2 victory over the White Sox tonight as Bob Feller notched his ninth triumph against nine losses. The triumph enabled the Indians to retain their slim first-place margin in the American League.

BERLIN, Thursday, July 8 -Despite the acrobatics of Soviet fighter planes, radio jamming and Russian warnings that transports that strayed outside the air corridors would be forced down. 382 United States, British and French planes flew into Berlin yesterday with supplies for the blockaded city.

The "draft-Eisenhower" movement lost rather than gained ground for the second successive day yesterday, following the declaration by the general on Monday night that he "could not accept" nomination for any office including the Presidency.
Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate backed by the New party, has resigned as contributing editor of The New Republic, liberal weekly, the magazine announced yesterday.

Visitors from thirty-nine states, Canada, Mexico, and twelve other foreign countries swelled attendance yesterday at the Store Modernization Show in Grand Central Palace to about 3,000, approximately double that of opening day.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of steel, will abandon the basing-point system of price quotation in the near future. It will adopt the f.o.b. method of computing prices at its mills and shipping points or, at customer's election, on a delivered basis reflecting full transportation costs from shipping point to destination, Benjamin F. Fairless, president, announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council denounced in no uncertain terms today the compulsory-marriage and multiple-marriage customs of the Bikom tribe of the British Cameroons.
SINGAPORE, July 7 -- Britain has thrown Army, Navy and Air Force units into a military campaign to smash a Communist attempt to seize power in Malaya.

Edward A. Alexander, in a letter in your issue of June 26, defends the Mundt-Nixon bill, and not only advocates its passage, but more. From the tenor of his letter, it is apparent that he doubts the constitutionality of some of its provisions, so he suggests that the Constitution be amended to cure its defects: in other words, to make the Constitution fit the bill.
The Dominion Textile Company, Ltd., reported yesterday in its statement for the fiscal year ended on March 31, net profit of $2,834,832, after taxes and all charges.

PEIPING, China, July 7 -- Gen. Fu Tso-yi, Government commander in North China, charged in a statement released today that "subversive elements" had fired the first shot that touched off Monday night's incident in which seven students were killed when Government troops fired into a crowd of demonstrators.

Dr. H. Houston Merritt, a pioneer in epilepsy research, has been appointed Professor of Neurology and executive officer of the Department of Neurology of Columbia's Faculty of Medicine and director of the neurological service of the Neurological Institute of Presbyterian Hospital.
St. Patrick's Cathedral, which recently underwent a complete exterior "face lifting," will now acquire a "new look" on the interior. The work on the inside renovating has just been started.

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Keeping up with Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, the title holder, fourteen other contenders for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation were tied with 2-0 scores at the completion of play in the second round at the Lord Baltimore Hotel today.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 7 -- The full personnel of the United States Olympic track and field squad will not be determined until after the final tryouts here Friday and Saturday, but there is enough evidence on hand today to indicate fairly closely how our athletes will fare at London.

LONDON, July 7 -- Combining business with pleasure, William Alexander Clarke Bustamente, leader of the majority party in Jamaica's Legislature and Minister of Communications, arrived at Liverpool today in a banana ship with his limousine and "sealed" orders from his party.

Formation of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City, with an initial membership of 170 working newspapermen, was announced last night. The organization, designed to promote the social and professional activities of reporters, is an outgrowth of the old associations of New York Police Headquarter reporters and New York district reporters.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 7 (UP) -- Albania has expelled ninety- four Yugoslav railroad workers after treating them "like criminals," and others hate been arrested or maltreated, dispatches to Belgrade newspapers asserted today.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today the appointment of City Magistrate James M. Fawcett of 140 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, as a Supreme Court Justice to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of John H. McCooey.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -The United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that an honorably discharged veteran's refusal to join a union which holds a closed shop contract was "just cause" for firing him.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -James R. Lewis, 47 years old, of Deming, N.M., was appointed chairman of the Federal Petroleum Board today by Secretary of Interior Julius A. Krug.

As the Tammany feud over the nomination for Surrogate continued yesterday, the New York County Republican Executive Committee named former Justice George Frankenthaler as its candidate for the post. Thomas J. Curran, county leader, in making the announcement, predicted the election of Mr. Frankenthaler for the bench now held by a Democrat, James A. Delehanty, who will retire on Dec. 31.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 7 (AP) -Sidney Hanover, a bay gelding by Dean Hanover-Charm Hanover and owned by H.L. Herrin, Charlotte, N.C., won the $10,000 Titan free-for-all trot at the Historic track today as a new three-heat world's record was set for a halfmile track.

The way the black bass season has been going hereabouts since it opened a week ago, a reminder about the law may be superfluous but is passed along herewith because the New York State Conservation Department sent it out.

NANKING, July 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Teng Wen-yi, official Government military spokesman, stated tonight that Government forces had inflicted 50,000 casualties on the Communists in a two-week battle on the plains of eastern Honan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 7 -- Despite the opposition of three members of the Big Five, the United Nations Little Assembly decided today to ask for the elimination of the use of the "double veto" in the Security Council.

Two impatient foster grandparents gave New York a chance yesterday to share with Seattle, Wash., the story of an Army major and his wife and the two twin daughters they had adopted in Germany last May.
MOSCOW, July 7 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette published today an "open letter to the American people" by Howard Fast, author sentenced to prison for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Civilian and military agencies of the Government laid before a Congressional committee today their arguments for the administrative control of American possessions in the Pacific and the Pacific islands under the trusteeship of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The "one-package" resolution encompassing the proposed $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for its permanent headquarters in New York will be reintroduced early in the next Congress, according to Representative Charles A. Eaton, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

The stock market underwent a setback yesterday although pressure was only moderate. A halfhearted move upward, was frustrated after the oils had exhibited some strength. Except for changes of a point or more in some of the thin-market and high-price issues on the Stock Exchange, fractional alterations prevailed then and the combined averages declined 0.24 point on the day.
Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday that it will receive bids July 29 on $6,000,000 of municipal light and power bonds due Aug. 1 from 1953 to 1973 and callable Aug. 1, 1958.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- After a discussion on the problem of peace in the Middle East with President Truman today, Henry Morgenthau Jr., said he was hopeful that the uneasy truce there would continue.

There was frenzy in Flatbush last night when the season's record Ebbets Field crowd of 35,500 paid fans saw the Dodgers pull a thriller out in the eleventh inning to beat the league-leading Braves, 4 -- 3, run their winning streak to six games and move into fifth place.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 7 (AP) -- The Government ordered an investigation of the Sokol Congress today as Czechs again staged popular demonstrations for former President Eduard Benes.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 7 -- The June Grand Jury of Westchester filed with county officials today a valedictory complaining that the grand jury meeting room in the court house here is imperfect in acoustics and lighting -- and intimating that the place has something of a "Tobacco Road" appearance.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., July 7 (AP) -- The three-year-old daughter of a forest ranger was carried into the woods and killed by a bear in Marquette National Forest west of here today. The child, Carol Ann Pomrankey, was found a quarter of a mile from her parents' cabin by a posse of farmers and woodsmen.

Doorbell ringing soon will be on the increase around the nation. The Fuller Brush Man, genial purveyor of articles for scrubbing, is being joined by the Fuller Brush Woman, whose stock will be for glamorizing of the flesh rather than the floor and the furniture.

The final stage of the factional fight within the ranks of the National Maritime Union, CIO, opened yesterday as the Honest Ballot Association began tallying some 43,000 votes cast in the union's national elections. The results of the election, however, will not be known for at least two weeks.

LONDON, July 7 -- In language of icy formality, the British Gov ernment reminded Poland in a diplomatic note made public tonight that she was stabbed in the back by the Soviet Union in 1939 when she was under attack from Nazi Germany.

PARIS, July 7 -- The French note to Moscow, which will be published tomorrow, says the Paris Government is ready to strive for a settlement of the Berlin impasse by any available means. Among these means, the note mention Article 33 of the United Nations Charter, which deals with the obligation to seek a settlement by conciliation and arbitration in any international dispute.

The Board of Transportation issued a bulletin yesterday transmitting to its 33,000 employes Mayor O'Dwyer's commendation for their excellent job in adapting structure and equipment of the municipal transit lines to the requirements of the increased fare that became effective last Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA July 7 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, said today that President Truman and his close friends accepted General Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement that he "could not accept nomination for any public office" as "definite and final" and that no further statement from him was needed to remove him as a possibility for the Democratic nomination for President.
Public welfare work in New York has lagged a decade behind the times, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard charged yesterday.

A new code designed to furnish added health protection for children in such recreational summer activities as day camps is being planned under the guidance of the New York City Department of Health, it was announced yesterday.

THERE was a brief item in the paper the other day saying that some survivors of the Fourth Armored Division had been talking things over in Boston. Maybe they knocked back a few sherry cobblers or a cup of calvados together. At any rate the item caught my eye because I had been reading Jon Godden's new novel, "The House by the Sea."*

In the rush of adjournment of the Eightieth Congress, a bill was passed which received little public attention because of the overshadowing importance of other matters. This is the bill providing for domestic air parcel post. It adds a new and eventually important service to the many now performed by the airline network.

The eighteen-member subcommittee now preparing the first draft of the Democratic platform at Philadelphia plans to hear arguments today on the question of what to do about a plank on civil rights. Mayor Humphrey of Minneapolis leads a group that would like a strong and unequivocal declaration.

YANINA, Greece, July 7 -- The Greek Army's drive on the last great rebel stronghold in the Grammos Mountains has gone into low gear. The official explanation is that a slower tempo has been ordered during a period of re-grouping.

Henri Matisse and other internationally famous artists will soon have a hand in decorating living room walls in a limited number of homes. Their designs, to be printed on wallpaper by the silk screen process in limited editions, were announced yesterday by Katzenbach Warren, 49 East Fifty-third Street. Other contributors will be Joan Miro, Alexander Calder and Matta (Roberto Matto Echaurren).

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company postponed yesterday until July 2l a scheduled sale of $20,000,000 of new preferred stock on account of uncertainties prevailing in the current market for new preferred stock.
The United Nations was asked yesterday to investigate labor conditions in satellite nations of Soviet Russia, including the charge that in four countries "laborers are literally worked to death."

ROME, July 7 -- Two thousand workers seized the strike-paralyzed Motta confectionery plant in Milan today and police, supported by five tanks, evicted them with tear gas. Several workers were injured in the fight.
The status of German-owned properties and loot held by neutral countries is of immediate concern to the victims of German aggression and deserves the attention of the American people.

Characterizing the coming fall fashions as both charming and sensible, Miss Kay Sullivan, former president of the Fashion Group, summarized the style highlights of the autumn season in a talk yesterday before the organization at the Astor Hotel.

No Economic Cooperation Administration purchases are likely in Argentina until prices quoted in that country are in line with world market levels and a friendly climate is created there for private American business, it was predicted yesterday at the round-table meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LONDON, July 7 (AP) -- Britain announced its track and field team for the Olympic Games today and Jack Crump, the manager, said "it will be one of the best trained and coached teams that has represented Britain."

The split between the right and left wings of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city was widened last night when fifty-five right-wing leaders in nineteen unions challenged the Greater New York CIO Council to make public the number of unionists still affiliated with the council.

While it is not to be taken as the discouragement of other special interests, the greatest drink in the world undoubtedly is coffee. Certain climates hold out for wine, but in all truth the grapes might just as well be eaten raw, without all the tedious bother of distillation.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -Food stores easily get a bigger part of the retail dollar now than any other business, but automobiles and filling stations are steadily increasing their share.
A mushroom product appears that, canned though it be, seems to have all the fragrance and flavor of mushrooms picked straight from the moist earth on an early morning.

Establishment of a small international police or guard force as a first practical step toward developing adequate strength to back up the decisions of the Security Council of the United Nations was urged yesterday by the Women's Action Committee for Lasting Peace.
Service plans for the 30,000 men a month who will be drafted commencing next Sept. 22 contemplate eight weeks of basic training followed by advanced training in tactical units.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Retailers are "leaning backward" in their conservative handling of the inventory situation, Thomas E. Maley, president of the House-wares Club of Chicago, said today at a meeting of leaders in the houseware and appliance fields at the Merchandise Mart during the summer home-furnishings market.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- Larry Jansen may not have been pitching up to his capabilities lately -he hadn't lasted the route since June 2 -- but tonight at Shibe Park he was every inch an ace. Yielding only two singles, one of which was decidedly scratchy, Jansen faced only twenty-eight Phillies as he hurled the Giants to a 7-0 victory before 13,198 fans.

Pierre Monteux made his second appearance of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, conducting a program composed of Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony, the Prelude to Wagner's "Lohengrin" and MacDowell's Piano Concerto in D minor, with Vera Franceschi as soloist.
A.J. Ferolie has been appointed grocery products sales manager of Airline Foods Corporation of New York. He formerly was district sales manager of Wilson Co., Inc.

The possibility of a break in contract negotiations between Actors' Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres was averted yesterday when the groups agreed to continue bargaining talks, it was learned last night. The development was in direct contrast to Equity's earlier position this week wherein the union threatened to stop negotiations with the League unless the managers granted the desired increases in minimum wages and rehearsal pay.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The State Department, in a note given out today, rejected Poland's protest of June 18 against the plan for Germany evolved by the recent six-power London conference. Great Britain in a parallel note also turned down the Warsaw protest, reminding the Poles that they were stabbed in the back by the Soviet Union in 1939 while they were being attacked by Germany.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner and Wally Westlake teamed up with a double and a single, respectively, in the ninth inning to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-to-1 triumph over the St Louis Cardinals tonight. Bob Chesnes held the Redbirds to six hits in his mound battle with Al Brazle.
LONDON, July 7 -- A committee of the Metal Exchange Committee has submitted a scheme to the Minister of Supply, George Strauss, for reopening of the London Metal Exchange, it was announced today.

Mme. Eleanor Elverson Patenotre, 78-year-old widow of a French Ambassador to the United States, and her son, Raymond, 48, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to an indictment charging them with evading $2,183,347 in income taxes in connection with the sale in March, 1930, of a majority interest in The Philadelphia Inquirer.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- A charge that longshore officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations had promoted "planned and deliberate" slowdowns in three ports was made today by the Waterfront Employers Association of the West Coast.

PARIS, July 7 -- A split developed tonight between the Government and the Socialist Parliamentary group, normally one of the Cabinet's principal supporters in the National Assembly. After a successful Socialist move to reduce the military credits.
The truce in Palestine ends tomorrow, and the best argument for prolonging it is to think back to the crackling tension of four weeks ago and compare it with the calmer atmosphere of today.

Americans are sending fewer food and clothing parcels to Europe than they did a year ago, Paul Comly French, executive director of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, reported yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 7 (AP) -- Delegates to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs biennial convention came out today for a more active part in politics and a demand for equal rights for women.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- A vanguard of Democratc platform writers went to work today amid declarations, even by irate Southerners, that the stop-Truman drive had been stopped itself.

Unrest has been spreading in Malaya since the end of the war. But in the last two months it has reached such a pitch that Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner, has been compelled to evoke emergency powers to suppress it. In a current broadcast he attributes the agitation to Communist maneuvers.

LONDON, July 8 -- British Government bonds, with gains of as much as an eighth, were best in an otherwise subdued stock market here today. Elsewhere industrial leaders gained a few pence where changed.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Countries receiving Marshall Plan aid must use some of their United States dollars for buying and selling within Western Europe. Announcing this today, the Economic Cooperation Administration said the move was designed to stimulate European trade.

Perhaps it is true that figures don't lie, but if Tommy Henrich is a .250 hitter Willie Pep is the heavyweight champion of the world. Currently, the statisticians would have us believe that Henrich averages one safety in four trips to the plate.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 8 -- United States Army, Navy and Air Force units went into action in Haifa today to evacuate the United Nations truce mission from Palestine.

AUGUSTA, Me., July 8 -- Gov. Horace A. Hildreth "emphatically denied" today published reports that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, "or any Governor, made a motion to break up the teachers' lobby" during the recent Governors' conference at New Castle, N. H. Governor Hildreth was presiding officer at the conference.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 8 -Discovery of a new super nova or exploding star was announced today by Dr. C. Donald Shane, director of Lick Observatory of the University of California. Dr Nicholas U. Mayall made the finding by accident on Tuesday night when, engaged in other studies, he photographed a spiral nebula in the Constellation Cygnus.

LONDON, July 8 -- Winston Churchill and his Conservative party colleagues in Parliament decided today to oppose the introduction into British criminal law of two degrees of murder that are commonly distinguished in United States jurisprudence.
An unlighted barge adrift in the Hudson River off 235th Street broke into two parts early yesterday morning when it was struck by the tanker William H. Ferguson, bound downstream from Albany.
An enthusiastic and confident lot of City Hall reporters journeyed to Travers Island yesterday for their annual outing and softball game with members of Mayor O'Dwyer's Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A sober and well-informed United States view of the Communist Information Bureau-Yugoslav dispute is that the next sixty days are the critical ones for Marshal Tito in his struggle to remain leader of the Yugoslav nation and Communist party as a supporter but not a puppet of the Kremlin.
NEWARK, Ohio, July 8 (AP) -- The Pharis Tire and Rubber Company, which has been shut down since May 1, will remain closed indefinitely, Furber Marshall, president, said today.

Erection of the Zenger Memorial at the nations shrine to the freedom of the press at St. Paul's Church, East Chester, in Westchester County, has been deferred until maintenance of the building is guaranteed by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

The Furriers Joint Council of New York, which is involved in litigation with the Associated Fur Manufacturers over charges of contract violation by the union, called on the manufacturers yesterday to take steps toward reestablishment of contractual relations in the industry.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8 -- Making her first appearance in links competition in two years, Mrs. H.J. Nevil Jr. of Hudson River won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

The national elections in the Netherlands, in addition to showing another Communist recession, were an expression of the national will to achieve a settlement of the colonial problem, and especially a settlement with the Republic of Indonesia. The Beel Cabinet, whose supporters were returned to power, is committed to carrying out the provisions of the Renville Agreement and to establishing a United States of Indonesia.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- President Truman sent a message today to the 3,500 delegates attending the National Education Association convention, promising his vigorous support in the teachers' campaign for Federal aid to education.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday declined 3 to 17 points net.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- During the week ended July 7, member bank reserve balances increased $195,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -Dana Andrews will leave next week for England to play the leading male role in "Brittania Mews" opposite Maureen O'Hara, Twentieth Century-Fox announced today. The film, based on Margery Sharpe's 1946 novel, is scheduled to go before the cameras in London on July 26, with Jean Negulesco directing.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) -- Colonial Secretary Arthur Creech Jones told the House of Commons today that Britain was "mobilizing in all possible ways" to put down the revolt in Malaya.

An emergency call for registered nurses to fight an epidemic of infantile paralysis in North Carolina was issued yesterday by the American Red Cross. By evening, five nurses had volunteered and two departed immediately for the affected areas.
PRAGUE, July 8 (AP) -- President Klement Gottwald held the Soviet Army up to Czechoslovakia today as the model of a strong peoples' democratic force.

BERLIN, July 8 -- Plans for breaking the siege of Berlin by imports from dollar-hungry Soviet satellite states are being pushed by United States Military Government officials, authoritative sources revealed today.

In another column of this newspaper there is a report of detailed plans being made by a newly formed group of educational institutions and other organizations to welcome and to make feel at home here the 3,000 students from other countries who yearly attend metropolitan schools and colleges.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- An unprecedented movement of wheat to storage and market in the Middle West, amid indications of the second largest wheat crop in the country's history, has swamped railroad yards and brought the prospect of elevators filled to overflowing and large quantities of wheat stored on the ground.

Wall Street is still talking about the Public Service Electric Gas Company's $20,000,000 preferred stock financing fiasco. Under the sealed-bid-and-deadline type of competition required by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it often has been the fate of a money borrower to be left stranded with no offers, but it is rare for the lenders to be left stranded with no borrower, as happened this time.

The personnel of the team that will represent the United States in the international tuna competition against Cuba, the British Empire, Mexico and the Argentine was announced yesterday by S. Kip Farrington Jr., chairman of the executive committee for the tournament. The fifth annual contests will be held at Wedgeport, N. S., from Sept. 8 to 11.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 8 (AP) -- An operating budget of about $500,000 for the fiscal year which began July 1 was approved by the Florida State Advertising Commission here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Eureka Corporation, Ltd., Toronto, Ont., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 675,000 shares of $1 (Canadian) par value common stock and 405,000 common stock purchase warrants. There will be no underwriters.

The Public Administrator petitioned Surrogate William T. Collins yesterday to revoke letters of administration in the estate of Ignace Jan Paderewski, famous piainist and first Premier of the Republic of Poland, who died here on June 29, 1941.

Mount Sinai Hospital's 1947 annual report, issued yesterday, shows that operating costs for the year were $4,215,081, while receipts from patients were $2,383,508, leaving a difference of $1,831,573 as the total philanthropic expense for the year."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The first shipload of European displaced persons given refuge in this country by a law passed in the closing hours of Congress, are expected to arrive here early next month, official sources revealed today.

Kay Thompson and the Williams Brothers, whose satiric song-and-dance routines made them last season's rage of the night clubs, plan to star in a custom-built revue called "Happily Ever After," opening on Broadway in late November or early December, it was learned yesterday.

Frank A. Sampson will be deposed as leader of Tammany Hall at a special meeting of that organization's executive committee tomorrow. In his place Borough President Hugo L. Rogers will be elected. In addition, the majority group in Tammany, which has the votes to depose Mr. Sampson as leader, plans to keep General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente in the race for Surrogate, against Mayor O'Dwyer's selection, City Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- Two of America's finest tennis stars, Edward Moylan of San Francisco, defending champion and third seeded, and William F. Talbert of New York City; seeded second, reached the semi-final round of the Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tournament today.

"The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet," which was a CBS attraction the last several seasons, will be heard next fall at 6:30 P.M. Sundays over NBC. The present occupant of the period, "Hollywood Star Preview," will shift to 8 P.M. Saturdays on NBC.

Representative Eaton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, says that a "one-package" resolution embodying the proposed $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for its permanent headquarters in New York will be introduced by him as soon as Congress meets again.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- The question of liberty of expression in Argentina may be thrown directly into President Juan Peron's lap by the Inter-American Association of Broadcasters, before which the President had extolled freedom of the air in his opening speech.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 8 -- Approximately 200 athletes, the best in America, tonight were tensely awaiting the final Olympic track and field tryouts, which will open tomorrow with a streamlined twilight session at Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Department of Commerce began a nation-wide drive today against racketeering in export licenses and other devices for circumventing foreign trade controls, threatening violators with seizure of shipments, fines or imprisonment or a combination of such penalties.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 8 -- The Palestine war was virtually on again tonight. The United Nations Mediator gave up hope of stopping it and tried instead to spare Jerusalem's holy places from destruction.

Despite the generally good business outlook, the situation in the men's clothing field calls for caution, according to the survey issued yesterday by Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell Sons Co. He pointed out that although representative clothing manufacturers have sold up from 85 to 100 per cent of their capacity for fall, marginal producers have sold only from 50 to 60 per cent.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest producer of steel, and the Wheeling Steel Corporation announced yesterday that they are preparing to follow the lead of the United States Steel Corporation in abandoning the basing-point system of quoting prices.

Supreme Court Justice James B. McNally reserved decision yesterday in a petition for the appointment of a guardian for the 10-year-old son of an ex-convict charged with having squandered much of a $13,500 fund contributed to the family by radio listeners.

COBLENZ, Germany, July 8 -The eleven Minister-Presidents of the Western German states appointed three committees today to prepare their counter-proposals to the Western Allies' suggestions for the establishment of a Western German government.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 8 -- The first steps toward calling a world conference to try to cut the veto power from the United Nations Charter were taken today by the Philippine Republic and Argentina.
The revival of Selective Service, better known as the draft, puts back into the language several words describing the young man taking his first steps in the process of military preparedness.

C. V. Whitney's Khyber Pass won for the first time this season and paid his board bill for the year at Aqueduct yesterday. In a Class C race called the Little Neck Handicap, he took $3,265 of the $5,500 added purse by overhauling Maine Chance Farm's Perfect Bahram deep in the stretch and pulling away to a three-quarters-of-a-length decision.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The tentative program for the Democratic National Convention next week is as follows:
Elfrida Derwent in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 5 pleads for deferment of college students under the new draft.

Industrial leaders now blame the Supreme Court cement case decision against the basing-point system for higher prices which loom in a wide variety of fields, a canvass of leading companies revealed here yesterday.

A reconstruction of the "Little Red House," where Nathaniel Hawthorne wrote "The House of Seven Gables," will become a permanent adjunct to the Berkshire Music Center, Tanglewood, Mass., in a ceremony on the afternoon of July 24, it was announced yesterday.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, July 8 -Though he went over par at the last two holes, 17-year-old Billy Edwards of Hempstead finished with a fine 74 to lead the qualifiers in the metropolitan junior golf championship at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today.

CAIRO, July 8 -- Egyptian and other Arab armies in Palestine prepared tonight to start shooting again at 8 A. M., local time, tomorrow in line with the Arab rejection of Count Bernadotte's request for an extension of the truce.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that peace was a shaky thing so long as half the children of the world were hungry and "searching for the garbage heaps." He urged food conservation in this country and further support of the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The consensus of the party leaders already here for the Democratic National Convention is that President Truman is virtually certain of nomination for president on the first ballot. The movement to draft Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared to be expiring rapidly as more delegates arrived.

Esther Drucker of Queens, owner of 200 shares of common stock of Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, filed an action in Federal court yesterday, charging that Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the company, and other officers, had enriched themselves at the expense of stockholders through allegedly fraudulent transactions with the Graham-Paige Motor Corporation and Permanente Metals Corporation.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July 8 -- The need for better trained and more adequately paid teachers to strengthen the public school system of America, was stressed here today in addresses and reports at the second day's session of the thirty-first annual conference of the American Federation of Teachers.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Heavy operations against cash wheat featured trading in that grain on the Board of Trade today. Mills bought freely to remove hedges against sales of flour to the family trade, while cash interests sold against the record movement of new wheat in the Southwest, and prices were off 1 5/8 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel at the close.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- A research program to prevent damage to railroad freight cargoes will be started this month by the carriers and freight car manufacturers, officials of the Association of American Railroads said today.

The Federal Water and Gas Corporation will file an amended plant for its liquidation with the Securities and Exchange Commission on or before July 17, Christopher T. Chenery, president, announced yesterday.

A prowler, who allegedly invaded the lobby of the Cranlyn Arms Apartments at 80 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, and knocked down the night superintendent was shot and killed early today by one of two policemen who responded to a telephone call for help.
CHICAGO, July 8 (UP) -- The Government has dropped its charges against thirteen individuals and five corporations accused of illegally receiving 500,000 gallons of molasses, it was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- United States shippers will be paid higher rates for carrying cargo under the European Recovery Program than will foreign-flag companies.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, July 8 -- The Government and the National Coal Board pleaded with representatives of the miners today for more coal and for a greater sense of the workers' responsibilities under nationalization. The National Union of Mineworkers is holding its annual conference at the near-by resort of Whitley Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Department store sales reached a new peak in June, after allowance for the usual seasonal change, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The seasonally adjusted index was estimated at 311 per cent of the 1935-39 average.
ROME, July 8 -- Italy's Communist labor bosses agreed today to sit down with big business and discuss terms to end the threat of a general strike.

President Romulo Gallegos of Venezuela visited the grave of Franklin D. Roosevelt at Hyde Park, N. Y., yesterday noon and then returned to the city to be honored at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Dreams of sudden wealth were shattered for thousands of Americans yesterday when Federal operatives here seized eighty-two cartons of Irish Hospitals Sweepstake tickets that had been smuggled aboard the United States liner America at Cobh, Eire.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The reckless and ruthless attempt of some Democratic leaders to frighten the President out of his determination to run for a full term has already had one adverse consequence. This is the growing certainty abroad that Mr. Truman will be relieved by the people next November of the conduct of foreign affairs since, if nominated, he will lead a shattered party against one that is unified.

Seven hundred truck-owners who met last night in the Pennsylvania Hotel gave unanimous authorization to the employers' labor committee to reject in their entirety the contract proposals sent to 4,000 employers in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area by eleven locals of the Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- The Government tonight claimed exceptional successes for the first six months of this year's targets under the five-year plan.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -Persons who are "directly or indirectly" members of the Communist party today were barred from membership in the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks.
Jantzen Knitting Mills, Inc., voted a 20-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on Aug. 1, representing an increase of 5 cents over the previous quarterly rate.
Alfred J. Carter has been appointed merchandise manager of Harriet Hubbard Ayer. He formerly was with the Schering Corporation for three years as sales manager.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Customers are looking for quality and they have the money to pay for it, curtain and fabrics industry leaders said today.
PARIS, July 8 -- Americans in France are beginning to complain of "spot checks" during which letters addressed to the United States are inspected to determine whether they contain bank checks.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 8 -- The truce ended in fact today although technically it does not terminate until tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock local time [2 o'clock, Friday, Eastern Daylight time]. Meanwhile this capital and other parts of Israel girded themselves for a resumption of the war.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Two United States warships tonight took aboard United Nations truce personnel in Palestine at the port of Haifa, signaling collapse of the truce between the Arab and Israeli forces. Available information here indicated that possibly 200 persons, mostly United States citizens, were involved in the operation, plus the recoverable portions of a large and valuable amount of communications material.

The anti-Truman forces which had been backing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination, or Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas as a substitute, appeared last night to be headed for complete disintegration.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- Wally Ris, national champion water sprinter from Chicago and the University of Iowa, won the first berth on the United States Olympic swimming team today in the 100-meter free-style race at the final American trials.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The United States, Britain and France have indicated to the Soviet Union that they may take the Berlin situation before the United Nations, it was learned today.

Formation of a special committee to fight for the restoration of The Nation to the New York public schools was announced yesterday by Miss Freda Kirchwey, editor and publisher of the weekly magazine. Archibald MacLeish, author and poet and former assistant Secretary of State, has accepted chairmanship of the committee.

A legal fight was begun yesterday to block the city's plan to build seven schools with $12,000,000 of housing funds. In a suit filed in Supreme Court, George Conrad Diehl, a consulting architect, asked that the City Controller be enjoined from charging against the city's housing debt limit bonds or notes intended to finance the modernization or construction of school buildings.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- While the draft-Eisenhower movement continued to peter out, President Truman mended political fences today in the old-fashioned way and he talked for seventy-five minutes with Gov. Mon C. Wallgren of Washington, who said he would take the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination if it came his way.

BARCELONIA, July 8 -- Catalonia, which is the financial and industrial capital of Spain, is in the midst of the most serious economic slump it has known since Generalissimo Francisco Franco's advent to power.

LONDON, July 8 -- Prime Minister J.B. Chifley of Australia, who has started extensive economic discussions with the British Government, emphasized today that the British Dominions expected to be consulted before Britain undertook any customs arrangements with her partners in the Western Union or the European Recovery Program that might affect the policy of preferential tariff rates within the empire.

PARIS, July 8 -- Goods entered and left France today without customs inspection and without duty charges, as a strike of employes of the Finance Ministry tied up the collection of taxes and otherwise disrupted the operations of the finance administration.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Truman received today a memento of his earliest days in politics. It was a reminder of the Democratic National Convention which on July 4, 1900, nominated William Jennings Bryan for President in Kansas City.

CHICAGO, July 8 (UP) -- The inability of miler Gil Dodds to run in Saturday's final tryouts for the United States Olympic team automatically eliminates him from the squad, an Olympic spokesman said today.

LONDON, July 8 -- Britain announced tonight that she had withdrawn from the new International Wheat Agreement because the United States had not ratified the pact. A statement issued here explained that without the inclusion of the United States, which was responsible for 37 per cent of the total guaranteed exports under the agreement, the plan would not be workable.

Seven Brooklyn high school students, whose extracurricular activities included stealing state and Federal checks from mailboxes, were found guilty yesterday by Judge Harold M. Kennedy in the United States District Court in Brooklyn of juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The White House announced today that an agreement had been reached in the long standing dispute between the class one railroads and the unions of engineers, firemen and switchmen.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was considering the adoption of rules which would require the filing of monthly and quarterly as well as annual reports by unlisted companies which register securities under the Securities Act of 1933.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Missouri has more applications on file for rural electrification loans this ficsal year than any other state, the Rural Electrification Administration said today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Department of Agriculture officials today predicted another big grain-exporting year in this country, despite the failure of the International Wheat Agreement.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Stanley (Bucky) Harris, manager of the American League team in the All-Star game at St. Louis next Tuesday, is determined to keep the 10-4 ratio victory march over the National Leaguers rolling.

Your editorial of July 4 entitled "A Decent Respect -- " states that all the colonies except New York had voted for independence on or before July 2, 1776, and that "New York, of course, came in a few days later," This raises an interesting and much-overlooked point.

Two mishaps to Long Island Rail Road trains about to leave Pennsylvania Station disrupted schedules on that line and on the Pennsylvania Railroad for five hours yesterday, delaying or canceling seventy-seven trains.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The 1948 Democratic platform-writing committee was informed today by Negro leaders that the proposed North-South compromise on a civil fights plank would be "wholly unsatisfactory" to millions of voters for whom they spoke.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- West Coast longshoremen were accused today by the Waterfront Employers Association of "spiraling" the longshore handling costs on foreign-aid lumber by means of their alleged "slowdown" in the Puget Sound area.

Burton K. Wheeler, former Democratic Senator from Montana, maintained here yesterday that he never had been an isolationist, and urged that the United States "stand up" to Russia in the current dispute over the Soviet blockade of Berlin.
VIENNA, July 8 -- Austria has founded a seagoing merchant marine with the aid of $300,000 from the United States and with forty Austrian seafaring men.

Figures showing that in 1947 the City Sheriff and his staff executed 27 per cent more assignments than in 1946, and turned in to the city treasury a greater sum than that for any year since 1934, were supplied to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by Sheriff John J. McCloskey.

ABOARD U.S.S. BOXER OFF PEARL HARBOR, July 8 -- The grand old battleship New York, which went through two world wars and two atomic bomb tests, lies at the bottom of the Pacific forty miles southwest of here today.

Pigtails are coming back. But quality still counts more than quantity, judging by Arlene Pellino, who had only the 2 1/2 years since she was born to raise the five-inch braids that won for her yesterday the title of "Miss Pigtails of 1948."

A group of fifty-seven German undesirable aliens was deported yesterday aboard the United States Army transport General William M. Black, which left Pier 12, Stapleton, S.I. about 5 P.M. for Bremerhaven, Germany. Also aboard the transport were forty-two Polish citizens who were leaving this country voluntarily.

BERLIN, July 8 -- A bleak austerity, broken only by the comforting drone of transport planes laden with food and fuel, settled over the Western sectors of Berlin today when drastic cuts in electric power resulting from the coal shortage caused by the Soviet land blockade of the city were ordered by the three Western commandants.
ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP) -- Scoring five runs after two were out in the first inning, the Pittsburgh Pirates went on to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 to 4, tonight and sweep the two-game series.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 8 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative on the United Nations Security Council, at an emergency meeting of the Council today warned the Arab states that if they refused to agree to an extension of the truce in Palestine, the United States would support action under Chapter VII of the Charter.

Demand in the wholesale meat market was broader this week than in some time, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. With supplies light, the expected took place. Prices shot up sharply, with increases varying from $2 to $6 a hundredweight on cow and steer beef, veal, spring lamb and fresh pork.
CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- The Indians turned their batting power on an old team-mate, Al Gettel, today and drove their way to a 14-to-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

Your editorial of June 29 on the South Pacific Commission contains a pregnant hint in suggesting that the secretary general of the commission be chosen from "a country whose Government is not directly interested in the area as a mandate power or a colonial administrator."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 8 (AP) -- Vini Rurac of Rumania played the best tennis so far in the sixtieth Western tennis championships to defeat Arnold Saul of Los Angeles in the quarter-finals, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -The Screen Actors Guild and the Motion Picture Producers have agreed on terms of a new twenty-nine month industrial contract covering employment of actors to replace the present agreement expiring July 31, it was announced today.

Pierre Monteux continued his admirable work as conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium last night in a concert which featured the voices of Jennie Tourel and Martial Singher. With the exception of Beethoven's "Egmont" Overture and Brahms' Second Symphony, which led off, the program was devoted to French music.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) -Rex Harrison, film actor, by deposition today testified that he had no information concerning a reported second note in the Carole Landis suicide case.

BOSTON, July 8 (UP) -- Gil Dodds, the world indoor mile king and America's chief hope in the Olympic 1,500-meter event, automatically eliminated himself as a contender today by withdrawing from the trials at Evanston, Ill., Saturday.

Representative Vito Marcantonio charged in Supreme Court yesterday that the City Council had refused wilfully to fill the vacancy in the Council caused By the death of Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist, who died on Nov. 6, 1947.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A House subcommittee will ask Attorney General Tom C. Clark to reconcile conflicting explanations of why the Justice Department failed to order a criminal investigation of rate-making activities of railroad men serving as wartime Army and Navy officers.

The "Greater New York Council for Foreign Students," designed as a cultural aid organization, is now being set up with the support of more than forty educational institutions, Mrs. John L. Mott, its executive secretary, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A 1948 cotton crop about 10 per cent above last year's -- but smaller than the trade expected -- was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

NANKING, July 8 -- The independent newspaper Hsin Min Pao, the second largest newspaper in Nanking, was permanently suppressed tonight by the Interior Ministry on charges of "propagandizing for rebels" and conducting "organized opposition" to the Communist suppression campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Administration was assailed today for "hand-to-mouth budgeting and bad management" in its fiscal affairs. Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, in a report on the appropriations record of the second session of Congress, alleged "irresponsible budgetary practices," principally through "disjointed after-thoughts on the part of the agencies" by means of supplemental requests for funds.

MANCHESTER, England, July 8 (Reuters) -- England scored 231 runs for the loss of seven wickets in a comparatively poor start today in the third cricket test match against Australia. The tourists won the first two matches.
ATLANTA, July 8 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs quit her title as the world's No. 1 amateur woman golfer today to join the professional ranks.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 8 -- Governor Dewey weighed today the need for a clarification of his views on state aid to education and teacher salaries as a result of attacks on his handling of these two questions made at the convention of the National Education Association in Cleveland.

Consolidated net operating earnings of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and affiliate for the second quarter of 1948 after taxes and all charges amounted to $1,372,828 or 24 cents a share, it was reported yesterday.
RHODES, July 8 -- Count Bernadotte said here this afternoon that "both parties will be losers."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Sharply lower prices for most grains mainly offset small increases in meat and nonferrous metals during the week ended July 3. As a result, the average of primary market prices remained unchanged, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- John F. Shelley, California labor leader and chairman of that state's delegation to the Democratic National Convention, emerged today as a well-sponsored candidate for Secretary of Labor. The White House said, however, no decision has been made and the field for the Cabinet post is wide open.

The Underwood Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries, manufacturers of typewriters and other office and business equipment, cleared $2,525,298 after all charges, including $2,112,418 provision for taxes in the first six months of this year, it was reported yesterday.

Six more union leaders exposed themselves to contempt citations in a stormy hearing yesterday before the Congressional subcommittee investigating Communist influence in New York locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO.

Jack Fraidin has purchased the two-story building at 867 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, from William F. Broistedt for cash above a mortgage of $10,500. The property, at the southeast corner of Carroll Street, contains five stores and two apartments and is assessed at $21,000.

TOKYO, July 8 -- Occupation officials are giving hesitant and inconclusive answers to charges by the Association of Economic Organizations that Japan's new anti-monopoly law is certain to discourage foreign investments here unless greatly modified.

The stock market found a slightly surer footing yesterday, when the railway issues attracted good support. Losses suffered on Wednesday on the Stock Exchange were eliminated and a slight advance was scored, although gains generally were in fractions.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 8 -John B. Kelly Jr., Penn sophomore from the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia, rowed his first race in the Olympic trials on Carnegie Lake's 2,000-meter course today and won leisurely by five lengths.

Seventy-nine paintings by contemporary American artists, on loan by four New York museums and one private collector, are en route to Venice, Italy, where they will be shown in an international exhibition, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 8 -- In response to the Soviet blockade of Berlin, the Western occupation powers have imposed an embargo of their own. The British-Foreign Office stated today that 149 German peacetime plants and installations available for shipment to the Soviet Union as reparations could not be delivered as long as the Berlin blockade was maintained.

A year ago when the Taft-Hartley Act had been law for only a few days, Mr. Lewis and his lawyers succeeded in wresting a contract from the coal operators which ingeniously circumvented the law's provisions. But on that occasion his path was made comparatively easy by two circumstances.

In choosing former Justice George Frankenthaler as their nominee for New York County Surrogate the Republicans have picked an able and distinguished candidate. In the coming campaign they will have not only the advantage of Judge Frankenthaler's solid record and wide experience but the inspiration of complete harmony and quiet confidence.

THE big stampede will get under way today, a stampede down that winding trail which originally was blazed by Coroebus of Elis in 776 B.C. It was he who was the first Olympic champion, and countless thousands have followed in his footsteps down through the ages. It's always been a tortuous and treacherous trail that's liberally strewn with pitfalls.
Beginning in September, Bensdorp, Inc., one of the oldest and largest Dutch cocoa and chocolate producing companies in the world, will operate in the New York area, it was learned here yesterday.

The Djurgarden soccer team of Stockholm ended its United States and Canadian tour on a triumphant note last night when it defeated the American League All-Stars, 3 -- 1, in an international contest at Ebbets Field. A crowd of 6,000 saw the Swedish squad register its fifth victory out of six engagements here but only after a rugged, thrilling game.

David H. Joseph, City Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last twenty-one years, has been appointed assistant managing editor. Robert E. Garst, for many years night city editor and more recently assistant night managing editor, has been named as City Editor effective July 19.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- The Jewish community of Jerusalem was gearing itself late today to renewed vigorous war effort. Its task was greatly fortified by an accumulation of food and a fuel stockpile, but water reserves available into city were such as could last "only for a certain period," according to the chairman of Jerusalem's Jewish Emergency Committee, Dr. Bernard Joseph, 49, formerly of ,Montreal, who has practiced law here for twenty-five years.

An analysis of the political forces in this state will be brought out by Knopf on Aug. 16. It is "Politics in the Empire State," by Warren Moscow, a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff, who covered Albany for many years and now covers national politics.
SINGAPORE, July 8 (AP) -- British forces fighting a reputed Communist rebellion killed two Communist leaders today in a fight with guerrillas in central Johore. One British officer was wounded.

NEW DELHI, India, July 8 -- Press comments on the United Nations Kashmir Commission on Kashmir have taken a more moderate tone since Chairman Ricardo Siri of Argentina wrote to Prime Minister Nehru that the Commission "confidently expects to explore the subjects with Governments of India and Pakistan to constructive and mutually satisfactory conclusions."
