PARIS, July 8 -- A dispatch of the French news agency France-Presse from Berlin tonight said the French commander there had taken steps to enable the families of French officials and soldiers in Berlin to leave that city on a week's notice.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Greyhound Corporation and its subsidiary bus companies are planning a $3,760,000 project to rebuild 376 buses so they may be continued in use for the next three years. The corporation said it was impossible to purchase a sufficient number of new buses.

Higher prices on men's clothing for spring will constitute a "very dangerous trend," Louis Rothschild, executive director of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, said here yesterday. Clothing levels are already high, he stated, and further advances would bring major difficulties in their wake.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) --- William H. Wenneman, who resigned on June 29 as vice president in charge of finance for the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, claimed today that Robert R. Young, chairman of the board, would not let the road's officers use their "best judgment" in correcting "unfavorable conditions."
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Elwell (The Whip) Blackwell recovered his 1947 form here today when he hurled the Cincinnati Reds to their fourth straight victory by shutting out the Chicago Cubs, 4 to 0.

Largely affected by repayments of the New York Telephone Company's loans, following the recent sale of its bond issue, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, declined $9,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

MUNICH, Germany, July 8 -For lack of orders, coal mines in the Oberpfalz area of Bavaria ground to a standstill today. Sixteen hundred miners were dismissed without indication as to whether or when the collieries would be reopened.

A United States Treasury check for $13,841,032, representing the full amount of the United States contribution to United Nations operating expenses for the 1948 fiscal year, was handed yesterday morning to Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations, by Philip C. Jessup, acting United States representative at the seat of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America were ordered today to show cause next Wednesday why they should not be temporarily enjoined from seeking to compel the "captive" coal mine operators to enter into a union-shop agreement.

Two extremes of millinery for the coming autumn were presented to the Fashion Group at luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. One group was a collection of twenty French hats, flown from Paris for the occasion. The other represented the popular priced American milliners.

The small hat received first place in the collection presented by Laddie Northridge yesterday at his salon at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street. Small peaked brims that arched above the face were the number one silhouette.

Mrs. Nancy Fletcher Choremi, daughter of the United States Consul General to Casablanca, was found guilty by Magistrate Arthur Markewich in Women's Court last night of loitering for the purpose of committing an act of prostitution.

First scheduled operations and first air cargo operations across the Atlantic from New York International Airport at Idlewild, the 4,900-acre field on the shores of Jamaica Bay, Queens, will start today.

An extraordinary demand for summer dresses, developed during the recent hot spell, has been met successfully by several New York popular price dress houses, it was learned yesterday. Late orders for thousands of garments were anticipated, according to the manufacturers, and cuttings on reorders are still in progress but on a reduced scale.

PARIS, July 8 -- The Executive Committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation has agreed that European governments should themselves determine the allocation among them of European Recovery Program credits, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson announced today details of the new William Allen White and United States-Canada friendship commemorative postage stamps.

WARSAW, July 8 -- The Polish harvest this year will be one of the finest in the country's history, and in some areas the yield will be double last year's, Agriculture Minister Jan Dab-Kociol said today. With the gathering of this harvest, which began today, Poland will be self-sufficient in food, he stressed.
A large collection of Swedish fabrics soon to be available to American homemakers will go on exhibition today in the decorator showroom of Knoll Associates, 601 Madison Avenue.

Italy is making remarkable progress toward recovery, but the de Gasperi Government has to cope with staggering problems in the industrial as well as in the agricultural field to consolidate its victory at the polls. The Communists are still strong; they still control the General Federation of Labor, and are asserting their power by ordering a new wave of strikes and threatening a general walk-out.

BOSTON, July 8 (AP) -- Lefty Mel Parnell kept eight hits well scattered while hurling the Boston Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Washington Senators tonight before 26,996 fans. Early Wynn, the Senators' starting pitcher, had to retire in the second inning when Birdie Tebbetts lashed a single off his right ankle while driving in Bobby Doerr with Boston's second run.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- Detroit Tiger Third Baseman George Kell, who has been named as a starter on the American League All-Star team, suffered a sprained ankle today while the Tigers were trimming the St. Louis Browns, 12 to 2.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor and co-author of the Taft-Hartley law, announced yesterday that he was considering sponsoring an amendment to the law under which workers ousted from unions for Communist affiliations also could be ousted from their jobs.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- A 1949 budget for the International Labor Organization of $5,215,539, an increase of more than 11 per cent above authorized expenditures for this year, was presented today to the International Labor Conference by the finance committee. It will be acted on tomorrow or Saturday morning, with adjournment of the conference due early Saturday afternoon.

An extremely misleading impression is created by your statement of July 3 that Farrell Dobbs and Grace Carlson, the Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates of the Socialist Workers party, were "imprisoned in 1941 in the Minneapolis 'sedition' trial for conspiring to create insubordination in the armed forces."

Walter Florell, the milliner, presented in his showroom at 29 East Fifty-third Street yesterday morning a collection that included dressed up casuals, "mirage berets," "decoys," "moustache du chat," "jockeys," "marble heads" and "mood hats."
Jim Russell in particular and the Boston Braves in general saw to it that the winning streak of the Dodgers did not extend beyond six games at Ebbets Field yesterday.

A slight decline in attendance marked the third day of the Store Modernization Show now being held in the Grand Central Palace with an attendance of approximately 2,000 visitors. Attendance for the previous day had been 3,000.

More than a dozen of the best-known cruising craft got away from Execution Rock last night in the New York Athletic Club's 106-mile Block Island race, and if the southerly breeze lasted through the night, the winner should arrive at West Harbor this afternoon.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9 -- One of the most modern newspaper publishing plants of its type in the country was opened today for a pre-view inspection tour by seventy-seven selected guests at the invitation of Barry Bingham, president of the 122-year-old Courier-Journal.

Roger R. Raulin, well known to thousands of American travelers before World War II as Commissaire Principal of passenger ships of the French Line, has been named managing director of the company for Great Britain, it was announced here yesterday. He has been with the company for twenty-seven years.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that the grand jury had found no evidence to confirm the report that three Tammany district leaders had taken $1,000 each for their support of General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente as the Democratic candidate for Surrogate.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) -The north central jurisdictional conference of the Methodist Church filled its last vacancy by electing Dr. Hazen G. Werner as a Bishop on the twenty-second ballot tonight.

One can't think of the American people refusing to help sick and hungry children. One can't think it even after the distressing report published in this newspaper yesterday that less than $12,000,000 out of a $60,000,000 quota has been donated in this country, after months of effort, to the joint appeal of American Overseas Aid and the United Nations Appeal for Children.

LONDON, July 9 -- Although the British Government is engaged in colonial development on an unprecedented scale, a committee of Parliament declared today that the effort was not good enough. The committee said the development program was inadequately financed, poorly planned and proceeding too slowly.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 9 (AP) -- Dr. K. Frances Scott, Associate Professor of Hygiene at Smith College, Northampton, Mass., was elected president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in convention here today.

MOSCOW, July 9 (UP) -- Pravda printed today letters said to have come from New York, St. Louis, Chicago and San Francisco to show what it described as the "average" American's disgust with such things as "rigged elections, capitalist slavery" and other aspects of life in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a further statement made public here today, ended completely any slight remaining chance of blocking the nomination of President Truman on the first ballot of the Democratic National Convention by declaring that "no matter under what terms, conditions or premises a proposal might be couched," he would refuse to accept the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Drastic personnel reduction at RKO, ordered by Howard Hughes, new controlling owner of the company, got under way today with dismissals in most departments running from 50 to 75 per cent.

Negotiating committees representing the National Maritime Union, CIO, and a group of Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators met again yesterday in an effort to settle contract disputes that threaten to tie up shipping when the present Federal injunction barring a maritime strike expires on Sept. 2.

TRENTON, N.J., July 9 -- Public indifference to law enforcement in New Jersey, especially to "off-track" horse race betting, was criticized sharply today by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper. He said police officers in some localities were lax or unable to cope with large-scale gambling enterprises.

The Board of Health instructed Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard yesterday to issue public warnings of "polluted" beaches "not recommended for bathing" and to call an immediate meeting of the board for emergency action if evidence of disease appeared traceable to any licensed beach.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday at a City Hall press conference that he would support President Truman and asserted that there was no doubt now that Mr. Truman would receive the nomination. He went beyond that to predict that the Democrats would win New York State in the Presidential election.
The Heir, owned by Mrs. Corliss Sullivan and trained by her son, Rigan McKinney, cut loose with a late spurt to win the $11,550 Lion Heart Steeplechase before 20,911 onlookers at Aqueduct yesterday.

Attendance picked up yesterday at the Store Modernization Show, which closes today in Grand Central Palace, with an estimated 3,000 visitors. Although exhibitors at the show stated that their main objective was to create a demand for future sales, many reported excellent orders.

By using new machine tools, three units can do the work of five old ones when new plants are built under the national decentralization program recommended by national defense authorities, Tell Berna, general manager, the National Machine Tool Builders Association, Cleveland, declared in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

I read with amazement Alexander Hirschhorn's letter which appeared in your columns July 7. I could hardly believe that such naivete and complacency existed in this day and age. It seems almost incomprehensible that anyone, in the light of the experience gained in the last twenty years, could look forward to another depression or assume that it would provide the cure-all for our economic and social ills.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -- Following is the text of the United States note on the Berlin blockade handed to Soviet Ambassador Alexander Panyushkin by Secretary of State George C. Marshall today. The wording of the British note was virtually identical.
NEWARK, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Ten thousand men of the Fiftieth Armored Division and attached units of the New Jersey National Guard will depart tomorrow for two weeks of intensive field training.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United Nations, to which the United States is the heaviest financial contributor, was accused today of duplication and "lack of coordination" in its subsidiary efforts and of excessive spending in some cases.

Because they went completely to pieces before the season's largest National League crowd last night at the Polo Grounds, the Giants this morning are teetering again on the brink of the second division.

NEWCASTLE-ON-TYNE, England, July 9 -- The National Union of Mineworkers ended its annual conference at Whitley Bay today after listening to one more appeal, this time to accept more European volunteer workers. The manpower shortage is one of the gravest problems in Britain's most vital industry.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- The fight over civil rights within the Democratic party finally exploded into the open tonight when a Southerner, Aubrey Williams, told Democratic leaders they would not lose Southern voters by supporting President Truman's civil rights program.

The four apartment buildings at 118, 126, 130 and 134 Corbin Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., accommodating eighty-four families, have been sold by Sarah E. Stickler to the Rubert Corporation. The property, which produces a gross annual income of approximately $41,000, was acquired in 1946 by the present seller.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association is taking concerted action in its fight to win for all retailers the right to use the Lifo (last-in-first-out) method of inventory valuation retroactively from 1941.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast "near record" citrus fruit production.

T. Edward Hambleton and Alfred R. Stern, sponsors of "Ballet Ballads," decided yesterday against continuing the attraction's run after tonight's performance at the Music Box. In explanation, Mr. Hambleton said that " the losses were running so heavy that it was impossible to guarantee profits to potential investors."

The House subcommittee investigating Communist influence in New York store unions voted unanimously yesterday to cite nine left-wing union leaders for contempt of Congress. All nine, in three turbulent days of testimony, had refused to tell the committee whether they ever had been members of the Communist party.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 9 -- The United Nations Little Assembly upset the plans of the major powers today by a sudden decision to ask the Paris General Assembly to consider a world conference for revision of the Charter adopted at San Francisco three years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The State Department tonight denounced Hungary for arresting persons for listening to broadcasts of "The Voice of America."

ROME, July 9 -- Sixteen thousand men of the Breda Engineering Works in Milan staged a sit-down strike today when the management announced that 2,120 had been dismissed because there was no work for them.
The United States Lines will conduct an investigation into the attempted smuggling of more than two tons of illicit lottery tickets on board the big liner America, it was reported last night.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Sole Parate, flashing the silks of H.M. Espigh, romped home two lengths in advance of Briar White to win the Enquirer Purse, featured attraction at Monmouth Park today. Harold Harter was third.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Colo., July 9 -- The American Federation of Teachers in convention here recorded itself today in favor of a program of Federal aid to education which it considers essential if equal opportunity is to be given children in every community in the United States to obtain a good public school education.

COBLENZ, Germany, July 9 -- The Minister-Presidents of Western Germany accepted today Western Allied authorization to initiate a regime but refused to call it a government or its basic law a constitution.
Two travelers whose ages total 185 years, both on their first trips by air arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday within ten minutes of each other.

ROCHESTER, July 9 (AP) -Father Divine and two of his "heavens" won a court victory here today. The Appellate Division, Fourth Department, in a unanimous decision reversed lower court orders favoring four first cousins of a follower of the New York cultist who had left most of her estate to the sect.

The stock market yesterday exceeded the previous high of the year with individual issues raised as much as about 2 points. Spurred by the settlement of the railway wage dispute and by the higher passenger fares granted to Eastern railroads, buyers on the Stock Exchange centered their attention on the carriers, and these were carried to the highest rate since mid-1946.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund announced today that he would leave for Europe next week for discussions with financial experts of the Netherlands, England, France, Italy and Belgium.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 9 -- Cases of infantile paralysis in North Carolina reached 468 today, by far the largest ever reported this early in the year. The number continues to mount steadily but Dr. J. W. R. Norton, state health officer, declined to predict whether this year's total would reach the 675 recorded in 1945, or the 878 reported in 1944, the state's two worst years.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States' note of protest to the Soviet Government against the land blockade of Berlin asserted Washington's readiness to enter into four-power negotiations there for the settlement of the disputes over the administration of the city but insisted as a prerequisite upon the immediate lifting of the Soviet blockade.

Eleven fire companies, two Coast Guard cutters and the fireboat William J. Gaynor, stationed in Brooklyn, were called out yesterday noon to extinguish a two-alarm fire in hold No. 2 of the freighter American Miller, a C-2 class 7,000-ton ship owned by the United States Line, at Pier 17, Stapleton, S. I.
A familiar refrain, but echoing from the past, turned up yesterday in a century-old letter belonging to Mary A. Benjamin, dealer in autographs and manuscripts, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 3 totaled 757,366 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 131,216 cars, or 14.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week: 128,162 cars, or 20.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 77,591 cars, or 11.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

STOCKHOLM, July 9 -- Sweden was well on way toward the European zone final round in Davis Cup tennis after today's play against the British team. Sweden's stars, Lennart Bergelin and Torsten Johansson, gained 2-to-0 lead for their country by downing Britain's Tony Mottram and Geoffrey Paish in the opening singles matches.

Two alleged robbers were captured last night after a short chase by two detectives when they left a private home on the East Side from which, the police charged, they had stolen six miniature paintings.

BOSTON, July 8 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky, the Boston Braves' sparkplug second baseman who suffered a broken right ankle in last night's game against the Brooklyn Dodgers, tonight was placed on the disabled list and will be ineligible to play for a sixty-day period.

Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina appealed to President Truman last night not to compete for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency. He conceded that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's refusal to seek the nomination might have left the field so favorable for President Truman that he would be nominated on the first ballot, but argued that this would spell certain defeat for the Democratic party in November.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- Aided by a fourteen-hit attack, Righthander Johnny Sain became the National League's first eleven-game winner by hurling the top-plate Boston Braves to a 13-2 victory over the Phillies tonight before 27,050 fans. While hitting safely in his twenty-first consecutive game, Al Dark, the Tribesmen's shortstop, tripled, doubled, singled and stole home.

The American, British and French notes to the Soviet Government do not differ as much in content or in tone as advance reports indicated. All demand the immediate restoration of road and rail traffic between Berlin and Western Germany. All declare that the former German capital is not a part of the Soviet zone but an international zone of occupation.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A Presidential emergency board today found the National Air Lines, Inc., guilty of violating the Railway Labor Act in a dispute with employes represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, and the International Association of Machinists.

From the standpoint of the American railroads, yesterday brought what must have seemed the most encouraging grist of news in many a long month. The day began with publication of the official announcement that the year-old stalemate between the carriers and three of the operating brotherhoods had finally been broken.
John S. Conant has been appointed general purchasing agent of Willys-Overland Motors. He formerly was consultant in industrial operations and management with Technical Managers, Inc.

Miss Eunice Noda will be the first Nisei woman to go as a missionary to Japan from a Protestant church in the United States. The congregation that will assume her financial support will be the First Reformed Church, known as the Community Church, Lefferts Boulevard and Kew Gardens Road, Kew Gardens, Queens.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- Following is the text of the Arab reply to the proposal of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nation Mediator for Palestine, for prolongation of the truce, as sent today in a cablegram by Count Bernadotte to the Secretary General:

To make way for a modern automobile parking station, William Katz, operator of a group of parking stations in lower Manhattan, has leased from Emma E. and Rosa M. Batchelor the property at 29-33 West Twenty-fifth Street, extending through the block to 26 West Twenty-sixth Street, through Raymond E. Ryan, Inc., broker.
NEW DELHI, India. July 9 -- The Hyderabad Agent General here replied today to a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Dr. Taraknath Das, Indian educator in New York, published on Tuesday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- The National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions asked the United Nations Human Rights Commission today to take up the case of the eleven members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee who have refused to open their organization's books to the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Ten youths were dismissed yesterday in the youth part of Felony Court on charges they had raped a 36-year-old woman when Magistrate Philip Thurston was informed that the complainant could not be located. The ten and a younger boy, who had been held as a juvenile delinquent, were arrested last June 27 on the complaint of the woman, who said they had attacked her and had beaten her male companion unconscious.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- Victorio D. Carpio, representative of the Philippines, charged today in the United Nations Trusteeship Council that Belgium had failed to provide wider education for the natives of Ruanda-Urundi for fear that they would be encouraging revolution.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Permission was granted to Eastern railroads by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to increase passenger fares by an average of 17 per cent, which will mean an additional $61,000,000 annually to the carriers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Prospective planks for the 1948 Democratic platform were put behind closed doors tonight. When finally completed and polished, it was indicated, they would include strong, resolute pledges and also material intraparty compromise.

Writers of the Americas were urged yesterday by President Romulo Gallegos of Venezuela, himself a novelist, to lay the groundwork for "collective cooperation" between nations and ease the current "anguish" of threatening war.

BERLIN, July 9 -- The Russians tightened their iron grip on Berlin tonight by announcing that in the future no vehicular traffic of the Western Allies could leave the city for the Western zones without a special pass granted by the Soviet Military Administration.

Retail trade here this week showed a decrease, due mainly to having one less business day than the corresponding period last year. Department store sales were estimated as about 13 per cent under the same week last year. Sales last week were up 38 percent.

The situation in Japan is not ripe for General Electric to make a decision at this time on re-establishing its activities in Japan, W.R. Herod, president of the International General Electric Company, said in an interview here yesterday.

On Tuesday, the day following General Eisenhower's second formal disclaimer of any desire or intention to run for public office, Senator Pepper of Florida came forward with an extraordinary proposal. This was that the Democratic party transfer itself temporarily into a "national" movement, draft General Eisenhower as a "non-partisan" candidate and invite him to write his own platform and name his own Vice Presidential candidate.

One of the tragedies of the last pre-war years and the early days of the Second World War was that so many of the lessons of the First World War had to be relearned the more difficult way, by trial and error. If another national emergency should arise, this country should have a workable plan that can be put into effect immediately.

The United States is in danger of losing still another propaganda battle. This time, however, the penalties of loss will be far more tangible and immediate and, possibly, irreparable. The present phase of the cold war is being fought in the publishing houses of Austria.

The lightweight championship fight between Ike Williams and Beau Jack on Monday will be televised over at least seven stations on the Eastern seaboard, it was disclosed yesterday. The promoters of the bout, to be staged in Shibe Park, Philadelphia, have agreed to delay the start of the engagement until the completion of Senator Alben W. Barkley's keynote address to the Democratic Convention.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Four hundred and ninety-two inventions were patented this week, an increase of 103 over the awards in last week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- Stewart (Skip) Alexander from Lexington, N.C., took a two-stroke lead today in the opening round of the $10,000 third annual Columbus Open golf tournament with a scintillating 32, 32 -- 64. This score included seven birdies and eleven pars.

The bulk of glassware volume during the fall and winter season will be in domestic rather than imported merchandise, representatives of several stores and one large buying group declared yesterday. The trend away from quantity purchases of imported items was attributed to high prices and declines in style and quality in most instances.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 9 -- The Egyptians struck by air today and the Iraqis by land as the Palestine war resumed after a month's truce. Iraqi troops at Ras el Ein shelled the Petah Tiqva outskirts less than ten miles from here, while the Egyptians dive-bombed at two points in the city, killing two children and wounding ten others.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- A suit for $1,558,000 against the directors of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation was filed today in the State Superior Court by Mrs. Hazel C. Fleming of Carmel, a stockholder.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Dean Alexander Ormsby of the John Marshall College School of Law said today that action was under way to remove objections that had caused the State Supreme Court to bar the school from accreditation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 9 -- The text of the flat refusal by the seven members of the Arab League to agree to an extension of the truce in Palestine "under present conditions" was made public today. It was communicated to the Security Council by Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP) -- Errors by Danny Litwhiler and Tommy Stallcup permitted the St. Louis Cardinals to score two unearned runs in the eighth inning and take a 6-to-4 decision from the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

DETROIT, July 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers ran their victory streak to five straight tonight as they beat the Chicago White Sox, 4 to 2, behind Freddie Hutchinson's six-hit pitching. The White Sox scored two runs in the top of the ninth on Aaron Robinson's homer with one aboard.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9 -- For the second time in two days, the police ejected from City Hall this afternoon a family of five who have been protesting their inability to find living quarters by staging a "sit-in" vigil in an anteroom of Mayor James T. Kirk's office.

THE Niblickdale train was crowded with week-enders (wan-faced among the mummy-colored regulars) when Walgrove Snood, athirst for the latest news of books he would never read, sat down in the seat that Kim Carruthers had held for him against all interlopers.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Accusing the Securities and Exchange Commission of conducting a "national smear forum" in connection with its investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, Cyrus S. Eaton of Cleveland asked the Federal District Court here today to halt further public inquiry into the matter.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today called the failure of the United States to ratify the international wheat agreement "an outstanding example of the irresponsibility of Congressional leaders."

SALT LAKE CITY, July 9 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board has sole and exclusive jurisdiction to certify collective bargaining agents for employes of firms engaged in interstate commerce, Federal District Judge Tillman D. Johnson ruled today.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- The semi-final bracket in the annual Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tennis tournament was filled today when top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., and fifth-seeded Tom Brown of San Francisco reached the round of four with hard-fought victories.

All steel mill products subject to export control, with the exception of material not generally salable in the domestic market, have been added to the list of commodities which may be authorized for shipment under one blanket license to two or more consignees in any one foreign country, the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

Changes in wage rates ranging from two reductions to increases involving several hundred thousand office and factory workers in various industries in the Middle Atlantic States were reported yesterday in a new monthly tabulation of general wage changes in the region released by the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

JAMESBURG, N.J., July 9 -- Mrs. T.U. Lyman of Maplewood won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association by touring the Forsgate County Club course today in 41, 37 -- 78.
You published a letter from D.K. Laidlaw, in which he set forth a plan for revamping the present subway service.

Three news films are scheduled to open in local theatres today. "Fury at Furnace Creek," a Twentieth Century-Fox western, starring Victor Mature, Reginald Gardiner and Albert Dekker and directed by Bruce Humberstone, will arrive at the Globe.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The National Security Resources Board today named a group of experts to study power problems affecting expansion of aluminum production in the United States.

RHODES, July 9 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator on Palestine, tonight appealed to the Arab countries and Israel to accept a further ten-day cease-fire while he makes a flying trip to Lake Success to continue his peace efforts.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson hammered his eleventh homer of the season into the right field bleachers with Andy Pafko on base in the sixth inning to give the Chicago Cubs a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before a ladies' day crowd of 23,609 today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Army has completed plans to convert a large part of the country's surplus potato crop into flour for relief feeding in the occupation areas, Secretary Kenneth C. Royall announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad system today presented to the Interstate Commerce Commission for its approval a plan for extending its outstanding bonds under a recent amendment to the Interstate Commerce Act permitting adjustment of railroad securities with the consent of holders, so as to avoid court proceedings.

EVANSTON, ILL., July 9 - Attaining a peak in the twilight of his twelve-year career as a topnotcher that he never reached in his youthful prime, 31-year-old Barney Ewell tonight equaled the world record of 10.2 seconds for 100 meters in rocketing to a conclusive upset triumph over Mel Patton in the final Olympic track and field tryouts.

LONDON, July 9 -- With the resumption of hostilities in Palestine, an unofficial but authoritative forecast was made today that the British Government would not support the Arabs in their renewal of the war and that the British embargo on arms to the Arab states would be sustained.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 9 -- Fishermen on reservoirs of New York's Croton watershed north of here became alarmed today when they saw "thousands" of dead fish floating on the water. Watershed engineers received hurried telephone calls from persons at the Muscoot, Amawalk, Cross River and Croton reservoirs.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 9 (Reuters) -- The Political Committee of the Arab League has approved a plan for the establishment "as soon as possible" of a provisional government in Palestine, it was disclosed tonight.

WINNIPEG, July 9 (Canadian Press) -- A protest has been forwarded to Trade Minister Clarence D. Howe against the forced subsidization of domestic wheat consumption by Western wheat growers, Cecil Lamont, president of the Northwest Line Elevators Association, said today.
JERUSALEM, July 9 (AP) -- A rabbi and an Arab Legion commander clasped one another today n a brotherly farewell five minutes before the truce ended in Jerusalem.

Education, in attempting to care for kindergarten-age children, is facing "a dilemma that is becoming a magnified tragedy," Dr. Roma Gans, Professor of Education at Columbia's Teachers College, declared yesterday. She spoke to 1,000 students in the college's Horace Mann Auditorium.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Grain prices ranged lower on the Board of Trade today, with hedging sales depressing wheat as much as 3 cents a bushel early, and liquidation in July corn forced the price of that delivery off 4 3/4 cents before there was a good rally.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Yugoslav-United States dispute over American claims for payment of the lend-lease account and for reimbursement for nationalized property against Yugoslav demands for the release of $55,000,000 in "frozen" Yugoslav assets moved a step nearer solution today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 9 -- Larry Carpenter Jr., the 19-year-old star who won the Baltusrol Golf Club championship last Sunday, took a hard-fought match from Paul Kelly, Hackley School basketball and golf captain, to reach the semi-final round of the Metropolitan junior championship on the Briar Hills course today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 15 points lower to 2 points higher yesterday. It opened 6 to 13 points lower, and then sold off to losses of 10 to 31 points on active liquidation in July and some Southern selling attributed to continued favorable weather in the cotton states.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- One man was injured painfully and several autos were stoned today in a picket line disorder at the gate of the Welin Davit and Boat Company.

Ten young men and women marched at 8 o'clock last night in front of the home of Columbia's president, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, at 60 Morningside Drive, to urge him "not to be a draft dodger.'' They remained for fifteen minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- James Roosevelt, prime mover in behalf of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic Presidential nomination, informed Eisenhower-for-President headquarters tonight "I am now convinced General Eisenhower would not serve if nominated by the Democratic party."

The year edges toward midsummer and husbandmen watch heading grains and that most valuable of all native grasses -- corn. Sprawling potato vines cover the field; the long arms and big leaves of squashes and pumpkins make a leafy jungle at the side of the garden; pole beans are green exclamation marks above the beets, carrots and turnips.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- Owing mainly to the vacation of the coal miners, business in the Pittsburgh district declined about 12 per cent last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The index last week was 170.9 per cent of the 1935-39 average.
DETROIT, July 9 (AP) -- An Andover Academy boy and a California school girl -- each 17 years old - outclassed their fields today to win No. 1 berths on the American Olympic swimming and diving teams.
Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District No. 27 will receive bids July 21 on $510,000 of bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948, and due Aug. 1 from 1949 to 1978.

Wool goods manufacturers will seek to obtain legislation making it mandatory to label rayon suitings in the same manner as wool fabrics, it was learned yesterday. Preliminary steps, however, will be taken to call to the attention of the Federal Trade Commission misleading claims concerning the performance of spun rayon fabrics used in men's clothing.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- Federal legislation to end lynching and "other abuses" of human rights was termed "our clear duty" by Representative Kenneth Keating tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- For the first time since the International Labor Organization came into being in 1919, the "guaranteed wage" became today the subject of action at one of its annual conference sessions.

The labor relations policies of R. Hoe Co., Inc., printing press and saw manufacturer, have been cited as conspicuously successful by Princeton University's Industrial Relations Section, it was announced yesterday. Other concerns having efficient labor dealings, as shown in a study by the section, are Alexander Smith and Sons Carpet Company, Yonkers; Brown Instrument Company, Philadelphia, and H. Daroff and Sons of Philadelphia.

THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Newspaper Guild of New York signed a new contract yesterday providing wage increases of 10 per cent or more for all news, editorial, commercial and other employes covered by Guild contracts.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 9 -- Max Pavey of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, holder of the National speed championship, gained his fourth consecutive victory in the open tournament of the United States Federation at the Lord Baltimore Hotel tonight and went into the lead ahead of Isaac I. Kashdan, the open titleholder.
BERLIN, July 9 -- The Soviet Military Administration has ordered the city treasurer to discontinue immediately payments to cover the occupation costs of the Western Allies.
LONDON, July 9 -- News from Palestine, Malaya and Berlin combined today to keep business down to a minimum in the stock markets here. Markings this week have been the lowest in nearly two years.
KANSAS CITY, July 9 (AP) -- The Future Homemakers of America decided today to hold four regional meetings next year instead of a national convention.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 9 -- The haste of Congress to adjourn, without ratifying the International Wheat Agreement, spoiled "all chances" of any future pact so favorable to the United States. Norris E. Dodd, director-general of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that a record corn harvest and the second biggest wheat crop in the nation's history, are indicated for 1948. Prospects for other crops, it added, also are very good.

Contrary to some representations, small business organizations in the United States do not want Federal controls and priorities to assure them an adequate supply of steel, Fred A. Virkus, chairman of the Conference of Small Business Organizations, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States, in cooperation with Great Britain and working through the United Nations, is seeking to bring about a cessation of the renewed fighting in Palestine, Secretary of State Marshall said today.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Displaced persons will begin entering the United States in about six months, Watson B. Miller, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, said today.

Mary E. Roche has purchased the two-story dwelling at the northeast corner of Grove Place and Allon Street, Oceanside, L.I., from George Ramayon for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $7,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- Carl Scheib's pinch hit in the ninth inning scored Elmer Valo with the run that gave the Philadelphia Athletics an 8-7 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight. The Mackmen tied the score a moment earlier on a double by Ferris Fain and two outs.
A slender young detective, whose beguiling appearance made thieves overlook him to their sorrow, resigned yesterday from the Police Department to answer the Navy's call to duty.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Donkeys gave the Democrats a headache here today. The Bellevue-Stratford Hotel headquarters of the Democratic National Convention, put up a collapsible rubber donkey on its Walnut Street marquee while the Democratic City Committee was installing a papier-mache creation over the Broad Street marquee.

Many things may be said in favor of July -- the blue sea, the clear sky and in a somewhat more practical mood, the abundance of fine fresh fruit that's offered. Apropos of it, there's a new powdery substance on the market to keep fruit from turning that unappetizing shade of brown that appears on certain varieties almost as soon as they are cut.

MANCHESTER, England, July 9 (Reuters) -- Australia had scored 126 for three wickets by the close of play today on the second day of the third cricket test match at Old Trafford in reply to England's first innings total of 363. The Australians won both previous games in the five-match series.
At meetings yesterday of the Kings County Democratic and Republican Executive Committees candidates were selected for the forthcoming elections.

Under a new direct reduction process, iron ore can be converted to practically pure, uncontaminated iron by using anthracite or natural gas as fuel instead of metallurgical coke, H.A. Brassert, president, H.A. Brassert Company, iron and steel engineers, disclosed here yesterday in an interview.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 9 (AP) -- In Tel Aviv, Moshe Shertok, Israeli Foreign Minister, announced that he had received the appeal from Count Bernadotte.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 9 -- Led by Count Eigil Knuth, the main body of the largest Danish expedition ever sent to Greenland for scientific exploration, left Denmark today in two Catalina flying boats.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Democratic apathy and outright defeatism over the expected renomination of President Truman plus the conceded strength of the Dewey-Warren ticket led Republican congressional campaigners today to revise upward their estimate of probable gains in the House of Representatives.

Observance of the first annual "National Cranberry Week," Oct. 18-23, will be backed with extensive advertising and promotion, it was announced yesterday by the National Cranberry Association. According to plans, the advertising campaign will center on tieins with such related products as fresh and canned chicken and various meats.

LONDON, July 9 -- Contributions and withdrawals by sterling area members of the Empire's "dollar pool" will be as secret under European Recovery Program as hitherto, officials indicated today. In making up the balance sheet of estimated dollar and commodity requirements under the Marshall Plan for the year ending next July 1, the British have set up the sum the United Kingdom needs and then designated the "rest of sterling area" as a lump sum.
Three transatlantic liners sailed for European ports yesterday with 2,795 passengers.

American philanthropic gifts "have taken a decided downward path, and present indications are that they will fall far below last year's level which was less than $3,000,000,000," the National Stewardship Institute of the Golden Rule Foundation announced yesterday.
PEIPING, July 9 -- Marching at slow funeral pace and singing a newly composed dirge, 8,000 Peiping and Manchurian students today protested the shooting of Manchurian refugee students Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Back on the beam with a performance that clicked at all points, the Yankees tonight rolled right over the Senators to romp off with the opener of a three-game series by a score of 9 to 0.
CLEVELAND, July 9 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns got away to a three-run first inning and went on to defeat the league-leading Cleveland Indians, 5 to 3, tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The highest civilian employment total in history was announced today by the Census Bureau when it reported that 61,296,000 persons had been working last month.

The music and spectacle of Verdi's "Aida" were blended with the roar and spectacle of a city evening when the Salmaggi Opera Company opened a two-night run at the Triboro Stadium, Randalls Island, last night.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough talked over the "captive" coal mine strike with attorneys for both sides today, leading to speculation on an out-of-court settlement of the four-day-old shutdown in mines owned by the steel industry.

"Great Paintings in America" has been scheduled for publication in October by Coward-McCann. Fiske Kimball, director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, has been the editor and has written the introduction. Lionello Venturi, art critic and Professor of History of Art at the University of Rome, has written an interpretation of each painting and of the artist's work in general.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Countries participating in the European Recovery Program would be required to take a substantial part of their American aid in the form of recoverable loans through the Export-Import Bank under a regulation being prepared by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Railroads which had been seized by the Government to avert a strike on May 10, were returned to their owners today. The Secretary of the Army, Kenneth C. Royall, who had been assigned by President Truman to operate the roads, turned them back less than twenty-four hours after the settlement arranged at the White House of the dispute between the carriers and spokesmen for 125,000 engineers, firemen and switchmen.

Annie Nathan Meyer has frequently made use of the letters column of THE NEW YORK TIMES to correct what she considers a grave error in thinking about the relations between the new Jewish state and American Jewry. But her crusade is directed against a straw man she herself made.

PARIS, July 9 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein declared today that France and Britain, backed by the United States, could defeat any aggressor who dared to threaten "the things we prize."

CLEVELAND, July 9 -- Calling Federal aid the "primary need of public education," 3,500 delegates attending the closing session of the National Education Association convention voted ,unanimously to seek passage of a bill in Congress to provide Government support for the nation's schools.

Operations of the General Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with last May resulted in a net profit of $1,713,367 after taxes and all deductions, it was reported yesterday.

An old acquaintance of visitors to New York -- the Police Information Booth in Times Square at Forty-third Street -- was torn down yesterday, while dazed out-of-towners and a few less-sophisticated natives glanced anxiously about, looking for a patrolman with a guidebook.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 (UP) -- Queenie, a dog that couldn't live without the boy who raised her, slowly wagged her tail as she was reunited with her youthful master today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- Gilmore Nunn who, as the representative of the National Association of Broadcasters, will cast the vote of the United States group at the Inter-American Association meeting here said today that there could be no compromise with the principle of freedom of the air.

Underwriting houses will be occupied next week with a variety of interesting merchandise. The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company will come to market for the first time to raise $55,000,000 on long-term debentures. The bidding will take place on Tuesday.

PARIS, July 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the French note to the Soviet Union on the situation in Berlin, in the form of a letter from French Foreign Minister Bidault to Soviet Ambassador Alexander Bogomolov (it is a translation of the official French text):

There is a man hereabouts who has cooked up a violent dislike of Anthony Trollope. Not because of anything in that eminent Briton's novels, he hastens to explain. Indeed, he adds, he has thought well of Trollope as a writer for years and has long intended to read at least "Barchester Towers" as soon as he can get around to it.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 9 -- Four-oared crews bettered all recorded Olympic times repeatedly today in the race for London on Carnegie Lake's 2,000 meter course.

John M. Cannella, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity since Jan. 1, 1946, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as Commissioner of the Department of Licenses to succeed Benjamin Fielding, whose resignation became effective July 1.

PARIS, Saturday, July 10 -- The French Cabinet was called into session late last night in an effort to settle the strike of employes of the Finance Ministry and prevent a threatened walkout in several other civil services. It was still meeting early this morning.

Regular scheduled flights of commercial airliners from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, were started yesterday afternoon when a Santiago-to-New York passenger plane of Peruvian International Airways put down on the broad runways of the 4,900-acre field.

ALL those long faces you are seeing around town these days belong to Broadway producers and, as they say in Shubert Alley, they're likely to get longer before they get shorter. To put it briefly, the hot weather, abetted by the long holiday week-end, put theatre business on a high-speed toboggan last week which has left everyone on the Rialto with a bad case of heebie-jeebies.

THIS volume consists of sixteen short stories, ranging from the settlement of Maine to the Civil War. Nine have Revolutionary War settings; the others deal with Philadelphia and Ben Franklin at the time of the adoption of the new Constitution, naval warfare, Indian fighting in Georgia and on the New England frontier, and getting a message from Grant to Lincoln during the Wilderness campaign.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Construction work in June boomed to a new peak in dollar volume, the Bureau of Labor statistics reported today.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 10 -- Although their erstwhile homes are now a mass of floating kindling, the 18,900 refugee residents of flooded Vanport have no prospect of obtaining permanent housing in the immediate future. Same are living in trailers parked on baseball diamonds and fairgrounds. Others still are doubling up with friends.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 10 -- Governor Dewey, if elected President in November, is planning to work closely with Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley on the preparation of the 1949 state budget and legislative program, it was learned today.
I have read with great interest Leonard Buder's article in THE TIMES of June 27, "New Yorkers Errors in Speech."

In your issue of June 13 you published a letter from Wolfgang Stresemann, son of the late German statesman. This letter questions the veracity of a statement of mine to Sumner Welles, to the effect that Gustav Stresemann, then German Minister of Foreign Affairs, approached me in 1924, when I was head of the French Government, and proposed an alliance between France and Germany from which England would be excluded.

BURR McCLURE, at 14, has chosen his lifework, that of a plant explorer. He is fired by stories of Fairchild, Meyer and others who ranged the world, bringing home new fruits, grains, vegetables and trees, and introducing them into general use.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, attacked what he declared was the motive for the United States Steel new pricing system in a statement tonight.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 10 -Whether New Zealand will be plunged next week into a general shipping tieup that might have its repercussions throughout the South Pacific, now depends on the ability of the Government and the Waterside Workers' union to compose differences over terms of settlement proposed today in the dispute concerning the ship Mountpark at Auckland.

AS might have been expected when the members of the American Herb Society met in New York last month, these experts paid special heed to plants that were out of the ordinary. At the New York Botanical Garden and in private herb gardens visited during the meeting, the uncommon varieties were noted.

In a major move to curb "confusing practices" likely to destroy public confidence in the television industry, the Association of Better Business Bureaus' advertising standards committee completed work last week on a comprehensive code for the advertising and selling of television receivers.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 10 -Petitions were in circulation in Suffolk County yesterday designating Democratic and Republican candidates for offices to be filled at the general election in November. The primary election will be held Aug. 24.
ST. LOUIS, July 10 -- Injuries and hot words today seared the American League's chances against the National League in major league baseball's annual All-Star game here Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, July 11 (UP) -- A group of last ditch anti-Truman delegates planned today to offer the Democratic convention a "liberal," probably Senator Claude Pepper of Florida, in a move to "prevent a unanimous nomination" of President Truman.

MANCHESTER, England, July 10 (Reuters) -- England had scored 174 runs for three wickets in its second innings at the end of the third day's play in the third cricket test match against Australia at the Old Trafford ground today.

John F. Ryan, former executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, was appointed yesterday as co-director of the New York State Wallace for President Committee. With him as co-director was named Paul Trilling, former state director of the Progressive Citizens of America.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Everything in Washington has slowed down except the pace of great events. The feverish Potomac summer is on us, and a lot of weary officials are looking to the Blue Ridge and the sea, but the hurry of fundamental issues will not subside.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- An angry and divided California delegation to the Democratic National Convention avoided a direct showdown today both on whether it would support President Truman on the first ballot or ask the resignation of James Roosevelt as national committeeman for his part in the "Stop Truman" movement.

A two-year course of study in American civilization will be offered this fall at New York University's Washington Square College, Dean Thomas Clark Pollock announced yesterday. The new course will be an alternative to the general programs now offered to junior and senior students in arts and science.

TORONTO -- Accommodations at eastern Canadian resorts during July and most of August will be sufficient to take care of even the increasing flow of visitors. A survey shows that while inquiries are greater than last year or the year before, reservations are not as heavy, and there is no trouble expected in putting up all visitors this summer.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spray tomato plants with Bordeaux mixture or some copper compound as protection against late blight. . . . Keep down weeds by cultivating regularly. Hand pulling will be necessary within rows of annuals and around rose bushes. . . . Cut off the blossom remains on peonies, hybrid lilacs and rhododendron as well as on annual flowers. . . .

FUTURE generations are bound to say of World War II that never did so few write so much about so many. To the mounting tide of more or less official chronicles of that vast global conflict, the United States Air Force has just added the first of seven volumes, the remainder to appear at the rate of one every six months.

IS there a critical age and a critical temper? What is criticism? Is it parasitic, taking all its sustenance from the creative body? Or is it an art, autotelic and independent? If art consists in an ordering of experience, and criticism consists in an ordering of the experience of experience, where then is the difference, except in degree of distance from life?
NANKING, July 10 -- The sustained Communist offensive to whittle down the Government's military strength on the approaches to central China continued with unabated fury today in western Shantung.
President Romulo Gallegos of Venezuela is due to end his six-day visit to this city today, when he flies southward from LaGuardia Field at 10 A.M.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, who appears to have found himself after a slow start with the Boston Red Sox, won his seventh straight game today shutting out the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 to 0.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- Four American water aces swam about as slow as they could today in 200-meter free style sprint heats at the United States Olympic team trials at River Rouge Park.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN last week signed Congressional bills directing the issuance of two more stamps during 1948. This brings the total for this year's program to twenty-eight, including those already released. One of the new measures approved means postal honor for Mrs. Juliette Low, founder of the Girl Scouts of America.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- Divided into many factions and openly despondent of victory, more than 1,500 Democratic delegates moved into Philadelphia this weekend to stage Chapter Two of that quadrennial spectacle peculiar to American politics which is called a national convention.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has inaugurated its physical search into the Tucker Corporation, and the conclusion which it places on its findings may determine the future of this postwar automotive manufacturer.
COLUMBUS, July 10 -- Dr. Harrold was Professor of English at Ohio State University and an international authority on the life and works of John Cardinal Newman.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- During this period of depression in the Democratic party, Mr. Truman's close associates derive comfort and hope from a sort of talisman which hangs in the corridor outside his office. The talisman has even inspired a slogan which they like to repeat: "He's always licked in May and elected in November." They profess the conviction that these words foretell the Truman story this year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -Following is the official program for Monday, the first day of the Democratic national convention -the time is daylight saving:

EVANSTON, Ill., July 10 -- America's athletes threw down the gauntlet to the rest of the world with a series of tremendous performances in the final tryouts for the United States Olympic track and field team which concluded today before an enthralled crowd of 25,000 at Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium.

The uncertainties that have been clouding the market for new preferred stocks turned into a thick fog of confusion last week following another and new kind of breakdown in the sealed-bid-and-deadline system for raising money in the public market place.

BOSTON, July 10 -- Peacetime conversion of the war-born auxiliary police department is paying off dividends in suburban Arlington, Mass., through a youth recreation program supervised by the men who served in that branch of civilian defense.

CINCINNATI, July 10 -- The veterans housing situation is "a national disgrace," but it will be improved in the near future. Ray H. Brannaman of Denver, national commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, told the twenty-eighth annual encampment of the Ohio VFW here tonight.
tivity during the Fourth of July week-end.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- Sufficient time has elapsed to determine the general outline of the fundamental issues that precipitated the crisis in Soviet-Yugoslav relations.
JERUSALEM, July 10 (AP) -- The Old City of Jerusalem came under heavy Israeli mortar fire today. More than 100 shells rained down on the walled area.

Close contests in the races for county commander and the five posts as county vice commanders were indicated yesterday as 3,000 delegates and alternates prepared to gather at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, for the thirtieth annual convention of the Kings County American Legion next Friday and Saturday.

Prospects of a record domestic corn yield and a near peak wheat production, together with the outlook for increased crops of cereals in other countries, definitely show that the crisis in food supplies all over the world is nearing an end. However, because of the various Government controls, both here and abroad, there is little chance of prices declining to levels prevailing before the war.

PAUL VINCENT CARROLL, playwright-author, and Sir Alexander Korda, as industrious a movie-maker as any, are joining forces for the filming of a Carroll story titled "Saints and Sinners," it was learned last week.

NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -The British monopoly on the rich shipping trade between Britain and India ended yesterday with inauguartion at Calcutta of the India-United Kingdom-Continent service of the India Steamship Company.

The United States Public Health Service reports that in 1947 more than 100 million persons in this country needed better water supplies and sewage-disposal facilities. The cost of making the necessary improvements would be a staggering $7,834,581,000. Yet this huge sum is considered "the minimum which should be spent to reduce the incidence of such diseases as dysentery, diarrhea and typhoid."

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 10 -- An investigation that began earlier in the day when bathers found the body of Lloyd I. MacMullan, 21 years old, of Norristown, Pa., in an automobile that had been parked for four days near the beach here, ended tonight with an official finding of suicide by barbiturate poisoning.

THE emotional force of this first novel by a young Southern woman is so powerful that some readers will find it painful to accept all of its disclosures. But, whatever the author may at present lack in esthetic finesse, she possesses an intimate knowledge of her material.
SAID one man to another on the commuters' train, "I hear our wives see each other at the herb society's meetings."

At 10:35 A.M. yesterday Sergeant Harry Kavanaugh of the Morrisania police station at 159th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, received an anonymous telephone call. A male voice said that two babies had been abandoned in front of the station house. Then the man hung up.

THE picture-buying boom, which was a phenomenon of the war years, slacked off this season. Sales signified by red stars on paintings in one-man shows were few and far between. Although dollar intake stayed up, the volume of sales, on the whole, showed a sharp decline. Fewer people were buying art.

PARIS, July 10 -- Striking employes in the French Government's Finance departments were joined today by those in the Ministry of National Economy, after proposals framed at an all-night meeting of the Cabinet had been disapproved by most workers in the governmental services.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 10 -Antonio F. Rotelli, a wealthy onetime Italian immigrant, said today that he would use "Whitehall," one of Narragansett Pier's estates, as a summer home for his large family. He bought the showplace at public auction this week for $60,000, the only bid offered.

As a non-citizen who has been commuting between Great Britain and the United States for eight years and who has watched with fascinated interest the progress of three American elections, may I ask for enlightenment on a point which seems trifling but which may prove to be significant?

THE fifty-seventh annual convention and trade show of the Photographers Association of America will be held Aug. 23-27 at the Stevens Hotel, Chicago. More than 120 exhibitors will use 215 booths to show the latest products in photographic equipment and supplies.

WITH highway building programs lagging ten years behind, requirements throughout the country, the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Road Builders Association, which opens in Chicago on Friday, will seek solutions to the problems that have delayed construction.

THE traditional guillotine blade is replaced with a pulley-type cutting wheel in the Nikor Safety Trimmer, a paper cutting board designed on a new principle. The device is introduced by Hinsdale Smith Jr., who is also the inventor of the Nikor steel developing tanks.

BUENOS AIRES, July 10 -- The Interamerican Broadcasters Association adopted today "in principle" a fifteen-point program declaring that broadcasting was "of public interest," but not a "public service."

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -With the collapse of the opposition to the nomination of President Truman because of the refusal of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to run if nominated and the statement of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas that he was not a candidate for the Presidential nomination, the Truman forces today took complete command of the situation.

The mood in which the Democrats will meet in national convention at Philadelphia tomorrow will be in marked contrast to that in which the Republicans assembled in the same city and the same hall three weeks ago. The Republicans felt sure of victory. The Democrats do not.

WE have long suspected a trend to move fiction out of the pure entertainment division -- and what could be more indicative than that even the so-called "woman's story" is becoming permeated with purpose? In Mrs. Roberts' latest novel, for instance, the divorce of Marcia is ushered in with all the suitable conventional accompaniments: heartbreak, hurt pride, fear and frustration.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 10 -- Tentative preparations are now being made in Cyprus for the possible emergency evacuation of United States citizens from the Arab states of the Middle East, should development of the newest phase of the Palestine war inflame opinion in those countries further against the United States.

NO doubt it is a very good thing for the community that the Government has soaked up all the surplus money and checked inflation. But it means an uncomfortable time for the theatre managers. The public no longer goes to the theatre because it has money in its pockets that won't buy goods; there is not much money about, there are many sporting events to be seen and the public begins to pick and choose.

LOS ANGELES -- Although the "six-month summer" in Southern California and the Southwest is still in its early stage, developments have been sufficient to delineate plainly the economic problem of the region's resort entrepreneurs.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 10 -- Memorial exercises were held this afternoon for Capt. Emilio Carranza, Mexican aviator, at the monument on the site in the Burlington County pine woods where he crashed on July 10, 1928. He was returning to Mexico after a good-will flight to the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Truman was accused today, in an official Republican campaign document, of foreign policy "reversals, vacillation, fumbling and bungling" for which the Democrats must bear full responsibility.

BRYAN FOY and an entourage of publicists and newspaper men came to the Colorado State Penitentiary here last week to show his new Eagle Lion picture. "Canon City," to the inmates, including eight of the twelve convicts who staged the bloody prison break of last December 30, on which the semi-documentary film is based.
LONDON, July 10 -- United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas will fly to Berlin tomorrow to gather first-hand information on the impasse there.
The 26,454-ton liner America, the queen of this country's merchant marine, may be purchased from the Government by the United States Lines, it was reported last night in Washington.

IRWIN STARK'S book is a first novel. The chief character is a young white man teaching in a Negro school in New York's Black Belt. The island of the title is that morally isolated area surrounded by the white populations of America's largest city.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 10 -- Secret Service agents reported today that they had uncovered a plot to assassinate President Jose Figueres and President-Elect Otilio Ulate. They said the plotters had planned to shoot down a plane carrying President Figueres, Senor Ulate and the staff of a good-will mission to El Salvador next Monday.

THE corruption of the Renaissance Papacy has long presented a stumbling block to any cinematic treatment of the Borgia family, because the Production Code requires that "ministers of religion in their character as ministers of religion shall not be used as comic characters or villians."

A BIOGRAPHY has long been needed that would do justice to Francis Lieber, the versatile and energetic nineteenth-century German scholar who became one of America's most influential political thinkers. Now, thanks to Professor Freidel's work in crystallizing a vast amount of research into a readable volume, we can estimate Lieber's varied services to his adopted country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10 -- With a record entry competing for the eight championships to be awarded tomorrow, the twenty-third Harrison horse show got under way today at the Kentucky Riding Stables off the Hutchinson River Parkway here.

THE author of this meaty and timely little volume is a conservative, opposed like most of the rest of us to Communist infiltration of government and other key agencies of American life. But he is also opposed to fighting this infiltration by attacking the wrong people and by impairing our civil liberties.

ROME, July 10 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, said today in the Chamber of Deputies that "this is the century of collaboration, not of war" and promised peace if the "imperialist race" was stopped. He spoke in the debate on the European Recovery Program.

Among the deficiency bills rushed through the closing minutes of the recent Congress were two for approximately the same sum. One was an item of $492,000 allocated to fight the Golden Nematode, a bug that attacks Long Island potatoes.

The first picture in your layout, "For the Draft of '48," bears a caption that is (unintentionally, I am sure) extremely ironic. The photo it describes shows a non-com herding together a batch of inductees, both Negro and white.

AS an ex-County Judge and present member of the Board of Managers of a State Home for Boys, I agree with Bernard Iddings Bell ("The School Can't Take the Place of the Home") when he says that too many parents are all too willing to transfer their child-rearing duties to the schools.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers scored early and then held on tight against numerous Chicago White Sox threats to win their sixth ball game in a row today, 5 -- 4.

DETROIT, July 10 -- Joe Verdeur of Philadelphia and California's Miss Ann Curtis, 22-year-old collegians, bettered Olympic records today in tests at River Rouge Park for berths on the United States swimming team, leaving next week for the 1948 games in London.

NEXT to a fireplace, we daresay, the blind at the window is the most romantic of all the architectural devices that go into a house. To the passerby it clouds in mystery the face of the insider looking out. Inside it stencils the walls and floors with a pattern of sunlight or casts a cool shadow that makes the temperature seem 10 degrees lower.

THREE modest new group shows of relatively lightweight order, organized intelligently with the summer heat in mind that at the same time manage to provide a fair measure of delight notwithstanding, are current in local galleries.
During the next two weeks, the women golfers of the metropolitan district, particularly in Westchester and Long Island, will have four tournaments in which to compete.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- Tourist travel in the Pacific Northwest is approximately 25 per cent below the 1947 level. Resort proprietors ascribe this to: (1) the fact that high prices seem to be pinching more tightly than ever, (2) adverse publicity resulting from the Columbia River floods and (3) the lateness of the summer season because of the spring snowstorms and chilling rains.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10 -The camp tour of the 165th (old Sixty-ninth) Infantry Regiment will end tomorrow at Camp Smith here.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Coast Guard headquarters have preferred a charge of misconduct against Joseph C. Boudreaux, third mate of the steamship Angus McDonald, as a result of a melee aboard ship last month.

Bus service in the Queens area served by the Triboro Coach Corporation was interrupted yesterday afternoon when drivers and mechanics quit work to force reinstatement of a driver discharged last Thursday. The coach employes are members of the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, AFL.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- The principal problem facing New York State Democratic leaders here is how they can best minimize the dissatisfaction within their delegation over the prospective nomination of President Truman. They appeared today to be attempting to solve it by not hurrying their delegates to the scene.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 10 -- The National Education Association brought to a close this week one of the most important school meetings held in recent months. By unanimous action, three thousand teachers, super-intendents and college officials, representing the nation's teaching profession, called on President Truman to summon a special session of Congress to approve the Taft bill for $300,000,000 in Federal aid to education.

The launching by the Allied Military Governments on June 18 of a system of monetary reform for the three western zones of Germany precipitated a crisis after more than three years of stagnation. As the first step toward ending economic paralysis in western Germany it was undoubtedly necessary to initiate this reform.
A thousand persons attended ceremonies yesterday to mark the construction of houses for three families left homeless by a gas explosion on May 4 in the North Cunningham area of Flushing Queens.

Would you kindly explain why Mr. Dustin, in your "Graduation Day" picture story, ostensibly going over details of the evening exercises with his graduating class, seems to be engaged in a blackboard demonstration involving the volume of a 113 cubic foot parallelopiped?

LONDON, July 10 -- A plan entailing penalties for nations that use funds made available under the European Recovery Program to purchase goods obtainable in Europe from the United States is scheduled to emerge this week-end from the technical committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ANDRE GIDE once remarked that books which solve a problem, which "conclude," have the best chance for immediate success. "But twenty years later, the conclusion destroys the book." The present volume, first published in 1902, long out of print in America and now reissued, is more immediately alive today than it could ever have been in 1902 -- or 1922.

Harry La Montagne's filly Conniver, who gets bigger and better as the months roll by, just about clinched the most-improved-horseof-the-year title at Aqueduct yesterday when she romped off with first money of $20,150 in the $29,450 Vagrancy Handicap.

SOME shrubs do bloom in July. So many flower in spring that we tend to think of the display as ending with the last mockoranges in late June. For the gardener who wants to make his plantings look interesting in summer the selection is limited but excellent.

The first scheduled outbound flight of a passenger airliner from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, took off thirty-one minutes late yesterday because of the delay in the arrival of the coach carrying passengers from Manhattan.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The dependable old Tempo VI carried Guy Lombardo to a slow but easy victory today in the Henry Ford Memorial Trophy race.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 10 -Here to engage in a series of international tennis matches with American and Canadian collegiate squads in keeping with custom in force before the war, a combined Oxford and Cambridge squad made the first appearance on its tour today by opposing a team from the Rockaway Hunting Club in a two-day match on the club's courts.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 10 -- For the first time in the memory of living voters, a Mississippi member of the United States Senate can return to Washington for another term without the necessity of having to campaign either for renomination or re-election in his state.

Bolivar, Mo., is a little Ozarks community of 3,000 population. Polk County courthouse is located there. State Highway No. 64 runs through the town. A public park is situated across a street from a big chicken hatchery. Of the ten towns in the United States bearing the name of Simon Bolivar, the South American patriot and liberator (1783-1830), this is the largest.
