LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- A move is under way to discard the unsuccessful privately run United States campaign for $60,000,000 aid to needy children of the world and to replace it with a special United Nations drive, beginning perhaps on United Nations Day, Oct. 24, it was disclosed here today.

A hit in Paris as "Les Mains Sales" ("Dirty Hands"), a hit in London as "Crime Passionel" ("Crime of Passion"), the new play by Jean-Paul Sartre, high priest of existentialism, will be seen in New York next season as "Red Gloves." On these pages are scenes from the London version of a drama about a Hamlet-like young man who becomes involved with communism in a mythical European country called Illyria.

ONE of the most baffling aspects of the relations of the United States and the Soviet Union is the belief of most Americans m the sagacity, inflexibility and political omniscience of the Political Bureau (Politburo), a group of fourteen men headed by Stalin.

A COMMITTEE on International Friendship has been formed at Columbia University to assist students and others going abroad this summer. At present more than 120 prospective travelers, most of them college students, are taking special orientation programs designed to help them get the most out of their European vacations.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 10 -- Breeze was all 138 skippers and skipperettes, with their willing-working crews, waited for today in the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. A real sailing one, not rough but snappy, came out of the southwest.

IN 1945 the certificated airlines of the United States flew 22,00,00 ton-miles of cargo. This year, it is estimated, the certificated and non-certificated airlines of this country will fly between 185,000,000 and 200,000,000 ten-miles of freight.
Retail activity was good last week, according to a report made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Beachwear, sportswear and fabric departments reported high sales.

THIS is a fifth -- and largest -- edition of a book that covers, by means of charts and photographs, the range of model railroad building from steam locomotives to signal circuits. Virtually every type of locomotive and car essential to model railroad building is to be found in this volume.

WHAT happens to a war after it is over? It is stripped of its insignia, converted to civilian uses, worn to pieces in Saturday gardens or Sunday golfing. It vanishes, item by item, into the attic, the basement, the bureau drawer, the cedar chest.

NEW YORK State resort operators were happy last week for the first time since Memorial Day. The July 4 week-end proved so big as to compensate for a poor June and give promise of a good summer after all.

BERLIN, July 10 -- The over-all long-term aim of Soviet foreign policy in Germany is simple enough. It is to win the political domination of a virile, able, technically efficient people and the natural resources of their country. But any evaluation of present Russian political tactics in Germany and in contact with the United States, Britain and France over Germany must distinguish between this aim and the immediate objectives of Russia in Germany.

"THE WELL OF COMPASSION" is a subjective novel about a young Negro painter's marriage to a self-seeking white girl, written, as the author himself says, by "a white man married to a white woman." Without pretending to be able to speak for any but the non-Negro reader, it is a fine, compassionate and immensely moving book.

DAYLILIES by the million will be seen at the annual meeting of the Midwest Hemerocallis Society in Shenandoah, Iowa, today. Visits to daylily gardens near by are the main event, but a small indoor show featuring new varieties is also included.

The feature of the new park the Parks Department intends to make on the site of the old Tombs will be space for off-street parking of 140 cars belonging to officials on business in the adjoining Civic Center, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 -- "The Naval War College adheres to no dogmas and no fixed set of rules by which campaigns or battles can be won," Rear Admiral Charles R. Brown, Chief of Staff, told the 154 members of the incoming class as the college opened its sixty-fifth year here today.

READERS of movie advertisements often suspiciously inquire whether reviewers are actually responsible for some of the "quotes" attributed to them in the ads. There seems to be a wide impression that sometimes these "quotes" are plain made up or, at best, are taken out of context from the original reviews.

WHILE Robin Maugham, veteran of the Eighth Army, nephew of the novelist, was attached to Middle East Intelligence, he conceived the notion of setting up an Arab center where soldiers incapacitated for combat could be trained to lead guerrilla resistance should the Nazis break through into the Middle East.

WITH the arrival of the "dog days," a relentless sun beating down on a strip of ground situated against the foundation of a house, garage or near a wall will reduce most plants placed there to a desolate, forlorn appearance.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Corn was the target for selling on the Board of Trade today following yesterday's forecast of a record crop by the Department of Agriculture. Wheat and oats weakened, but losses were not particularly large at any time.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Attendance at the Merchandise Mart and the American Furniture Mart during the first week of the summer home furnishings market was described by officials today as "satisfactory." However, they are hopeful that the second week's attendance would make a better comparative record than the first.

ONLY the light-headed can question the fact that we are faced with a world crisis. Three years after V-J Day the major peace treaties remain unsettled, and Russia and America are wrapped in a power struggle out of which anything, including a third world war, may develop.

TO those interested actively or passively in the unsettled world of today -- and who is not? -- there can hardly be a more important subject for study than history. And to the many who have curious minds there can be little as entertaining and revealing as the narrative of great men and crises of the past.

The belief that the strikes that have prevailed in Italy since the recent elections are because of political conflict was declared erroneous yesterday by Giuseppe Di Vittorio, general secretary of the Italian General Confederation of Labor, who was the guest of the Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
ATHENS, July 10 (AP) -- The Greek Government made fresh demands today for United States military assistance as the Grammos Mountain operation against the guerrillas was reported as bogged down.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A gradual, undramatic price rise, diagnosed by the economic doctors as "creeping inflation," has set in and promises to keep the consumer in the fixed-income, rising-costs pincers for as far ahead as one can see.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- With the Democratic National Convention virtually certain to nominate President Truman for his present post, the race for Vice President is wide open, and neither the President nor Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the national committee, has indicated who the candidate would be.

BOSTON -- New England's summer vacation season is expected to surpass last year's peak turnout, according to estimates compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. Based on reports from 400 operators, the figures show an increase of 8 per cent in advance reservations for July over last year at tourist lodging places.

A few minutes before noon last Tuesday, in his office in the State Department building, Secretary George C. Marshall handed a note to Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Ambassador from Moscow. The note was strong. It demanded that the Russian blockade of Berlin be lifted immediately.

CAIRO, July 10 -- Arabs and Israeli forces are fighting inside Palestine again but they are still talking peace. Count Folke Bernadotte has called the results of his negotiations during the twenty-eight days of the truce a "temporary reverse." Both sides have declared their willingness to continue to negotiate with him. What are the prospects?

PRINCETON, N.J., July 10 -- John B. Kelly Jr., of the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia, staged a procession down Carnegie Lake's 2,000-meter course today to qualify as the United States representative in the Olympic single sculls at London.
YOUR review of my CBS "Toast of the Town" television show, in last Sunday's issue, is in error on so many points that I must challenge it.

MONTE was a real grizzly and he fought hard to keep his freedom in the Colorado Mountains. He was a comical bear, imitating Harvey, the man who brought him up. A Hollywood producer saw him do his funny tricks and was determined to have him by hook or by crook, mostly crook.

The drafted men of 1948 will find the Army's eight weeks' basic training -- their introduction to the military life -- not much different, at least in subjects taught, from the training given during the latter part of the war.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 10 -- Israel told the United Nations today that it was ready to heed the urgent appeal made yesterday by Count Bernadotte for a ten-day cease-fire if the Arabs would also lay down their guns. The Arab League, however, has stated flatly that any continuation of the truce would be "most onerous."

The texts of the three-Power notes to Russia on the Berlin situation, made public Friday night, contain no surprises. Our own note, substantially identical with the British note and supported in somewhat modified language by the French, recites known facts about the Berlin agreement, expresses a determination to abide by that agreement, suggests four-Power negotiations in Berlin and offers to refer existing "disagreements, if any," to the United Nations.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 10 -- The spiked shoe brigade dug into the Dyche Stadium cinders this broiling afternoon and the luckier members leaped all the way to London, the most prodigious broad jump in history. This broke the old Olympic record which was held by Finn MacCool, the broth of a boy who used to leap across the Irish Sea without even ruffling his hair.

AN ordinary clothespin and a pocket knife time and again have been the only tools used to make several plants grow where only one had grown before. It is no secret that a long cane of a climbing rose or a runner from the base of a wistaria vine can be pegged down and will, in time, root at that point.
Only one of the eight seeded entrants saw action as the annual men's New York State tennis singles championship tournament got under way yesterday on the courts of the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

THERE'S a treat in store for all who like their intrigue against a background of international espionage, sinister gemmerchants and lovely, mysterious ladies. Bob Graydon, a mining engineer, escapes from Malaya in a prau and is rescued a week later by British military in Ceylon.

THE "living wall of green" that every gardener wants his hedge to become can be attained with timely care. Before the hedge begins to look straggly or overgrown or overrun with weeds, it should be put in shape.

The Democrats of New York City, like the Democrats of the nation as a whole, last week were undergoing internal strife. There was open warfare between Mayor William O'Dwyer, who is a Brooklyn man, and Tammany Hall, which is the New York County (Manhattan) Democratic Committee.

KANSAS CITY, July 10 (AP) -- The Big Seven Conference faculty committee today gave the University of Kansas two weeks to retract its stand on league eligibility rules or face cancelation of all athletic events with member schools.

A special graduate program of studies of the United Nations and world affairs, which will tap the resources of the city's "international community," will be undertaken next fall by the Graduate School of New York University.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 10 -- America's powerful Navy, moving in the Mediterranean, serves as a police force to prevent local incidents from breaking into major wars, Vice Admiral Arthur W. Radford declared today.

A further expansion in loans and discounts, reductions in holdings of Government securities and increases in cash resources were the principal changes in assets for the fifteen largest banks here in the second quarter of the year, the condition statements of the institutions as of June 30 disclosed last week.

FRUIT trees need some care this month. It is important work, but will not take any great amount of time. Attended to promptly, it will protect and improve the crop and still leave the gardener plenty of leisure for relaxing in the old apple tree's inviting shade.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 10 -- Although Turkey during World War II managed to maintain her de jure neutrality until after the Yalta Conference and her de facto neutrality through VJ-Day, subsequent changes in the world balances of power and ideology have had an effect in that country comparable to that in many belligerent lands.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- A White House draft of a 1948 Democratic platform conforming to specific views of President Truman on the issues to go before the electorate was ready for presentation to the national convention's pledge-writing body tonight.

The basing-point method of selling steel is a price system that has evolved over the last fifty years. At first there was only one basing point -- Pittsburgh -- but as the country's industrial machine grew, many points were added.

IN any survey of contemporaneous American opera Kurt Weill is a composer to be reckoned will. The American premiere of his short and unpretentious folk opera, "Down in the Valley," to be mounted next Wednesday under the auspices of the Music Department of Indiana University, will be watched with more than ordinary interest.

Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight, will face Roman Alvarez of the East Side in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. The program will be the first of a series of summer cards at the Eighth Avenue arena, which will be open for boxing on every available Thursday until September.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July 10 -- Dr. Floyd W. Reeves, former member of the President's Advisory Committee on Education, told the American Federation of Teachers today that the safety of the United States, and of democracy throughout the world, demanded a comprehensive defense program on many fronts in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- The South's most openly hostile pre-convention thrust against President Truman's nomination was abandoned today before the sessions had begun. Senator Olin D. Johnston of South Carolina, a leader in the Southern rebellion against the President's civil-rights program, declined even to attempt a long-threatened maneuver to have the Democratic National Committee ask Mr. Truman to withdraw.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 10 -- Detroit will have the official sanction and backing of the U.S. Olympic Association in bidding for the 1956 Olympic Games, President Avery Brundage announced today. The 1952 games already have been awarded to Helsinki, Finland.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (Religious News Service) -- Two churches in the tiny town of Heiligenkreuz, Austria -- one Roman Catholic, the other Lutheran -- have bells in their steeples as a result of efforts by Joseph Pandl, maitre d'hotel of Pittsburgh's Duquesne Club.

ANY woman should be interested for at least one reason in this novel about Elinor Gail, actress: she never seems to age. Her lovely face and golden hair remain the same -- no wrinkles, no gray. When most women of her age are using every device to counterfeit the bloom of youth, Nellie Gail uses a pencil to put faint lines around her eyes to add years to her appearance.

ANN BARLEY had been graduated from the Yale Drama School, played in stock, written soap operas, worked on news magazines. In the fall of 1945 she breaks her engagement and makes an appointment -- with herself -- to adopt a child.
Mayor O'Dwyer addressed to President Truman and ranking Democratic leaders yesterday his own recommendations for the party platform to be adopted by the Democratic National Convention.

The preliminary work on the tabulation of the 43,000 ballots cast in the national elections of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was completed yesterday, and the actual tallying of the votes for the union's 131 elective posts will begin tomorrow, George J. Abrams of the Honest Ballot Association, which is handling the election, said last night.

The tenth annual Gaelic Mod, a literary, musical and sports congress of Celtic clans, will be held at St. Ann's, Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, from July 28 to 31, inclusive, according to announcements reaching here last week.

The minimal editorial standards for comic books, announced by Phil Keenan in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 2, are minimal indeed. Though the publishers have been frightened into making these negative concessions in the face of increasingly active criticism, they show no responsible interest in the tremendous positive influence they exert on the youthful imagination and in the life values the comic books teach.

YOU are an attractive miss of 22, owner of a handsome chest now embellished by a white sweater with the American shield upon it. You are doing an intricate figure on skates before the judges and several thousand spectators on the Olympic rink at St. Moritz, Switzerland. Mountains to the right: grand palace hotels to the left.

LONDON, July 10 -- Winston Churchill, stanch opponent of appeasement of Germany in the years before the World War, said today that if the Western powers should yield to the Soviet Union in the Berlin crisis they would lose their best chance of escaping a third world war.

Marriage education should be taught in the public schools, according to a survey conducted by students at Florida State University. The students, interviewing 1,000 doctors, ministers, rabbis, principals, teachers, newspaper editors and Rotary and Lions Club members, found that those questioned overwhelmingly favored marriage and sex education.

Energetic Dr. Walter Freeman of Washington, D.C., has organized a committee of surgeons and neurologists who have in turn made arrangements for an International Conference on Psychosurgery to be held in Lisbon from Aug. 3 to Aug. 7. Representatives of the more important European and South American countries will be on hand to discuss prefrontal lobotomy, an operation on the frontal lobes of the brain, with which we do our thinking and predicting.
PORTLAND, Me., July 10 (AP) -- The birthplace of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow has been ransacked by youngsters, police said tonight.

AS the story of the daughter of new-rich Irish Catholics, who falls in love with the son of old-rich Anglo-Saxon Protestants, "Lace Curtain" undertakes a more difficult task than the best sellers about intolerance in whose steps it follows.
BERLIN, July 10 -- The Soviet Military Administration vigorously protested tonight against United States and British "violations" of air safety rules while flying supplies into this besieged city.
TEL AVIV, July 10 (UP) -- Israeli warplanes hammered Arab troop concentrations in Syria and southern Palestine today.

WHOOPEE! Summer's here, and 37,000,000 motorists, with their bags, their bundles, their kin and kinder, are taking to the open road. I know, because my friend, the garageman down on the main highway, has moved a cot into his office and kissed his wife good-by until after Labor Day. The open season is on. Twenty-four hours a day the state troopers will be calling him to haul the wrecks off the highway.

NEGOTIATIONS between the Metropolitan Opera and the unions of its employes are not yet completed, but plans are being made for next season nevertheless. One is a revival of Verdi's "Falstaff," which was last heard during the 1943-44 season in an English version conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham.

JERUSALEM, July 9, (Delayed) -- As Arab artillery resumed mortar shelling of the Jewish section of Jerusalem promptly on the stroke of noon, double summertime, today, after a two-hour extension of the month-long truce, word came of a new operational agreement between Israeli army authorities and Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Fighters for Freedom of Israel, formerly known as the Stern group.

HERE is the story of the contribution of Hungarians to the history and development of the United States. It is part of the Peoples of America series, edited by Louis Adamic. Naturally, a good deal of space is devoted to the history and traditions of the Hungarian homeland and to the visit to the United States of the famous Hungarian national hero, Kossuth, a century ago.

SALZBURG, Austria -- This little Alpine city, the birthplace of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, will hold its world-famous music festival from July 28 to Aug. 31 with the brilliance of pre-war years. Included in the program will be performances by Artur Rodzinski and Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

THOSE two archaeologists, Tim Mulligan and Elsie Mae Hunt, who, so far as their record shows, are more interested in murder than in kitchen middens, go to visit their old friend Tommy Milton, now a professor in a freshwater college.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, said tonight that the Federal Government should discharge 630,000 civilian workers, or three of every ten on its payroll. This could be done without reducing Government efficiency and would mean a saving of $2,000,000,000 a year, he maintained.

THE widow, relict of the late Sam Gay, is Gay in name only. Not that she is unduly distressed by her husband's violent death; quite the contrary. She admits that she hated him, which is not at all surprising, for Sam was not an estimable character.

HELSINKI, July 10 -- The Finnish people have just chosen their unicameral Parliament for the next three years, and above 80 per cent of the voters rejected the Communist candidates and their supporters, the Unified Socialists.

Adoption last week by several major steel companies of the f.o.b.-mill pricing system that the industry has vigorously opposed for the last quarter-century, represented a gamble by the steel industry that unfavorable public and industrial reaction eventually will spur Congress to legalize the basing-point method of computing prices -- the practice just discarded, under protest, by both the cement and the steel industries.
On May 21, 1832, a meeting of 344 Democrats from the twenty-four United States opened in Baltimore. It was the first national convention of a major political party.

"HE that will write well in any tongue must follow this counsel of Aristotle, to speak as the common people do, to think as wise men do; and so should every man understand him, and the judgment of wise men allow him."

Today is the anniversary of the most famous duel ever fought in this country. On the morning of July 11, 1804, two men met under the heights at Weehawken, and as the shots echoed across the Hudson, Alexander Hamilton lay fatally wounded and his opponent, Aaron Burr, had started along the path from public esteem to public disgrace.

LONDON, July 10 -- Distrust and fear of Germany cast a shadow upon both sides of the Iron Curtain. To the people of Poland and Czechoslovakia no less than to the people of France and the Benelux nations (Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg) a politically and economically strong Germany is synonymous with an aggressive, militant Germany.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- A saucy little filly from the East named Pail of Water streaked to a length-and-a-half victory in the $51,600 Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park today in making her strongest bid for the 1948 juvenile filly championship.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- New procurement authorizations amounting to more than $26,000,000 were announced today by Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, for the week ending July 7, bringing the total to date to $788,914,690.

ALTHOUGH the Democrats, who open their convention tomorrow in Philadelphia, are given little chance in the election next November, their campaign may have an important effect upon business. According to this theory, the cost of living is by no means a minor issue, and developments last week emphasized that there is a boiling resurgence of inflation which will make prices even more of a problem.

So far as this department knows, the writers of pulp science fiction have not exploited the carnivorous powers of the sea anemone, a gorgeously colored marine animal grouped with the corals as Zoantharia, which means "animal flowers." Dr. E. Gudger of the American Museum of Natural History regards both species as enemies of small fishes; for both catch and devour the living prey.

The Communist Information Bureau, international Communist agency to which the Communist parties of Europe are "responsible," has sent out instructions to the Communist parties of the world to model their organizational forms and rules on those of the Soviet Communist party, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, July 10 -- The conflict between Moscow and Marshall Tito has led specialists in Russian and Communist affairs here to predict a widespread purge of the Communist ranks, both in the satellite countries and in Russia where, they say, there is also a "deviation" from the orthodox line.

BERLIN, July 10 -- The Soviet Military Administration has introduced in Soviet sector high schools a compulsory course to describe alleged terroristic tactics by the Western Allies in repressing the expression of the "people's will" for a unified Germany through the People's Congress.

DANVILLE, Va., July 10 -- Maceo Conrad Martin, Negro banker of Danville, today appeared as petitioner in the Federal Court of Richmond for an injunction demanding that the state-owned recreational parks be made available to Negroes.

COLORADO SPRINGS -- Some of the finest scenic drives in the west can be found through the mountains of the Colorado Rockies, but the astonishing fact is that the majority of auto tourists to this area never venture beyond the fringes of the nation's highest, widest and most spectacular mountain mass.

The announcement that the annual "Oscar" awards would be extended to the best foreign film seen each year in the United States has come from Jean Hersholt, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. And, all things considered, not a moment too soon.

The General Managers Association of the railroads serving the port of New York have been studying the waterfront rehabilitation program of the Port of New York Authority and will report this week to the Board of Estimate committee on port plans.

For the first time since 1944 the Parke-Bernet Galleries, the country's leading auctioneers, failed to reach the $6,000,000 mark for a season's gross receipts from the sale of furniture, jewelry, silver, paintings and other art objects.

MEXICO CITY, July 10 (UP) -Colombia, Ecuador, Panama and Venezuela are on the verge of setting up an economic union that will bring them "industrial independence," Ecuadorean Ambassador Alberto Puig Arosemena said today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 10 -- For the first time in twenty years, the Metropolitan junior golf title was won twice in a row by the same youngster when 17-year-old Billy Edwards of Hempstead, L.I., captured the final over the Briar Hills Golf Club course by a 5-and-3 margin.

THE Bach Aria Group was organized and is being maintained by William H. Scheide at considerable personal expense because he is convinced that an important and illuminating aspect of Bach's art is largely neglected.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -William R. McComb, Wages and Hours Administrator, today set up new standards of governing premium overtime payments. They become effective Sept. 15.

Off and on I have lived a good fair bit in London and have certainly polled the London taxi service about which Mervyn Jones writes in "Cabbie and Hackie: A Contrast." It is good enough, but the service rendered vis-a-vis New York, or perhaps more comparably Boston and its irregularly laid out streets, is definitely not worth the fantastically elaborate training course and exams taken by the cabbies.

THE poet, novelist and dramatist, Ernst Wiechert -- together with the philosopher, Karl Jaspers, and the economist, Alfred Weber -- belongs to that elite group of German intellectuals who are earnestly trying to re-educate their people, to cleanse them of the heritage of nazism.

FRAKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 10 -- Western Allied sources said today they were disappointed in the results of the Coblenz conference at which the Minister-Presidents of Western Germany approved the formation of a western regime, but declared against formal recognition of it as a government.
LIMA, Peru, July 10 (UP) -- An undisclosed number of persons was arrested today for promoting a two-hour organized disturbance in public markets and other places.
After twelve long years of waiting, another shipload of America's finest will head out of New York harbor this week, bound for the renewal of the greatest sports show on earth, the Olympic Games.

Permit me to call your attention to the fact that your answer to question six in the "Impact of Fathers" quiz is incorrect. The Father of Music is not Palestrina, as you indicate, but Jubal. ". . . Jubal: he was the father of all such as handle the harp and organ." -- Genesis 4:21.
Louis Biuhm of New York fills in the picture on a report as follows:

WHEN the water gets too rough for swimming the resourceful photographer turns his camera on the dramatic and varied possibilities of rolling wave and breaking surf. He tries to anticipate exciting incidents in the action and to compose them as well as he can.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson, who homered to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday, came through again for the Chicago Cubs today with a triple with two mates abroad in the eighth inning for a 4-2 victory and two straight in the series.

LUCY CHAPIN, budding home economist, decides to specialize in nutrition education. Employed by Mark Co., she becomes a "Mary Marden" (the firm name for their particular Betty Crocker) in a test kitchen. She learns that following a recipe expertly is not enough; she must be a speaker, a writer and an inventor as well.

GENEVA, July 10 -- The list of countries to be represented on the executive board of the World Health Organization, half of the European members of which are slated to come from Communist-dominated countries, was presented today for approval to the Assembly of the organization over the United States' protest, voiced in committee.

A wholesale trade advisory committee will be created by the Department of Commerce within the next two months, Nelson A. Miller, chief of the Marketing Division, Office of Domestic Commerce, Department of Commerce, disclosed here yesterday in an interview.

A somewhat broader background for the genesis of Thomas L. Stokes' "Smoke-Filled Room" is cited in V.O. Key Jr.'s "Politics, Parties and Pressure Groups," page 209, in which he quotes from the John Adams' diary, February, 1763:

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Voice of America, by October, will be operating as a unit under the complete, direct control of the State Department. Officials are confident that its programming, with an enlarged budget and under a new organization set-up, will meet the criticisms directed at it by Congress at the recent session.

THE last ten years of Francis Thompson's short life were devoted largely to journalistic writing -- book reviews and critical essays. Indeed, his reviews are critical essays. As librarian and curator of the Thompson Collection at Boston College, Father Connolly has devoted a large part of the last decade to the stupendous task of identifying unsigned reviews in Academy, Athenaeum, Merry England and the Franciscan Annals.

MATTITUCK, L.I., July 10 -- A plane that crashed in Mattituck Inlet this afternoon was identified tonight as a Navy aircraft and a volunteer Navy reserve officer and a member of the enlisted reserve were listed as missing. Their names were Ensign Warren C. Bosch, 24 years old, of 1929 Menahan Street, Brooklyn, the pilot, and Aviation Machinist's Mate, 3d Class, Bernard J. Glass, 23, of 60-31 Fifty-ninth Avenue, Maspeth, Queens.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP) -- Josefina Guerrero. Filipino war heroine, arrived in America today to receive a strange reward.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 10 -The Singer Manufacturing Company here, manufacturers of sewing machines, leads all other industries in this area for employes of long service, it was made known today with a compilation of records of the Singer Veteran Employes Association, whose membership consists of 427 persons who have worked for the company for an aggregate of more than 17,080 years.

Hollyhocks bloom in New England dooryards. Not only in New England, to be sure; but especially there, for they are as typical of the New England dooryard garden as stock and candytuft and peonies. They stand tall and straight in the fence corner and along the stone wall, their bright blooms as open-faced as a Seth Thomas clock, their colors fresh as ribbons for a fair.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer held the St. Louis Cardinals to five hits through six innings, then worked out of a three-run seventh-inning uprising to salvage a 4-to-3 victory for the Cincinnati Reds tonight. Grady Hatton's sixth-inning homer proved the winning run.

SOME birds can rise instantly from the ground, while others need an extended running or swimming start rather like the take-off of an airplane. A person who is interested might ask himself what makes the flight of an owl completely soundless while that of certain types of geese is marked by a loud flapping of wings.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 9 -- Two of the country's top-ranking tennis stars will meet in the final round of the annual Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tennis tournament tomorrow.

RADIO and television coverage of the Democratic National Convention scheduled to get under way in Convention Hall, Philadelphia, at noon tomorrow, will be essentially the same as that of the Republican meeting.

ADMITTING that stubbornness is a doubtful virtue in most cases and particularly so in a bridge game, one may nevertheless insist that if a bridge player decides to be stubborn at all he may as well be very, very stubborn.

Handling by the Office of International Trade of export licenses for chemicals continues a "sore spot" among exporters here, both on the grounds of difficulty in obtaining licenses and the "low-price views" which were said to govern OIT in the granting of licenses.

WHEN the International Society for Contemporary Music was founded more than twenty-five years ago, the main objective was the cultivation of "contemporary music of value without regard to the nationality, political opinions or religion of the composer" and the society set out "to protect and encourage especially those tendencies which are experimental and difficult of approach."

ONE never knows what may become useful in detective work. In the case of Don Paulson it is ornithology. For years he has made the study of bird life his hobby, and has thus acquired the habit of close observation, which stands him in good stead when it becomes necessary for him to probe the secret of three murders.

Before the atomic bomb was tested on July 1, 1946, at Bikini, dried corn seed in twenty-five moisture-proof packages, each containing from 1,500 to 2,500 seeds enclosed in canvas rolls, were distributed on twenty-two ships anchored at distances up to 1,500 yards of the target. Control samples were kept outside the target area on a ship and also at Beltsville, Md.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 10 (AP) -- King Ranch's Flash Burn, a disappointment in recent starts, ran last to the turn of the $15,000 added Omnibus Handicap, but turned on the steam in the final quarter to turn back George D. Widener's Lucky Draw by a neck at Monmouth Park today.

Although mill and converter inventories of gray goods are at peak levels and fabric requirements for the fall season have not yet been determined, strong demand for rayon filament yarns will continue for the next four months, it was predicted last week by yarn producers.
The U.S.S. Marquette steamed slowly out of Haifa harbor last Thursday night. She was evacuating United Nations truce observers from Palestine.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- Selection of a running mate for President Truman became a wide-open race today with the announced withdrawal of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas on whom the Democratic high command had counted to strengthen the national ticket.
The article, "Facts About Our Fabulous Underground," by Ira Freeman and Beatrice Oppenheim, failed to mention the New York subway's most unusual group of employes, the Transit Police.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (UP) -- More women will take part in next week's Democratic National Convention than ever participated before in a political conclave in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Scanning the country's bituminous and anthracite fields, John L. Lewis seems to be carrying on the role of "monarch of all he surveys" (although the injunction hearing ordered against him in the "captive" mine situation might prove a deterrent to his complete satisfaction).

AN original revue, probably the scarcest commodity in radio, has put in an appearance on NBC's Thursday night schedule (8:30 o'clock) with results both generally refreshing and encouraging. The thirty-minute offering is Leonard Sillman's "New Faces of 1948," being the latest edition of a venture which Mr. S. started on Broadway twelve years ago.

Your publication of Oliver La Farge's "Plea for a Square Deal for the Indians" is a distinct public service. The American Indians desperately need help and consideration and are not yet in a position to speak fluently for themselves.

APROPOS of bringing up a teenage daughter -- and how times have changed since he was a boy -- one father tells us. "Once you could say 'Nice people don't do that.' But nowadays nice people do do that." This dilemma of vanished standards is one shared by many parents.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 10 (AP) -- Fundamental rights of Americans, embodied in the Declaration of Independence, "must not be dishonored by lip service," New Jersey Democratic candidates for Congress declared today.

THE Sunset Route of the Southern Pacific, a ribbon of steel winding 2,000 miles across plains, mountains and deserts in five states from New Orleans to Los Angeles, at last is to have fast streamliner service.

JOPLIN, Mo. -- Construction of the Bull Shoals Dam on the White River in north central Arkansas is giving the Ozark Mountain vacationland a double-headed boom: Tourists are coming here in great numbers to see the world's largest belt conveyor track being built to speed construction of the $47,000,000 project.

CAMERA fans at times make mistakes without being able to analyze just what is wrong. This book should help such fans, since it records the actual development of a shutter fan amateur to finished photographer. Furthermore, "right and wrong" snapshots with explanatory captions point out the pitfalls and tend to develop a sense of analysis.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, reported yesterday that Jews in the United States contributed more than 75 per cent of a total sum of $125,172,517 spent in Palestine during 1946 and 1947 for immigration and national development.
Mel Ott shook up his Giants' line-up for the second skirmish of the Brooklyn series at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but he didn't quite get the "shimmy" out of his tottering pitching staff.

Warehouse steel prices are being raised immediately a minimum of 5 per cent and a maximum of 10 per cent, with many variations in between, leading steel distributors revealed during a canvass of New York price changes resulting from the shift in mill pricing methods last week.

If there were any remaining Congressional doubts that "The Voice of America" is being heard in Eastern Europe and that it is having an effect on the listeners, the Hungarian Government's violent reaction to it should be proof enough. Hungarians listen to the United States broadcasts now at their peril.

The long holiday week-end and plant closings during summer vacations accounted for the letdown in activity in wholesale apparel markets here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey Werring and Howell Company, resident buying office. Retailers awaited deliveries of back-to-school and fall merchandise before placing commitments, it was said.

IN this third and final volume of "American Democracy and the World War" Prof. Frederic L. Paxson of the University of California attempts to survey and to clarify the general confusion of the years 1918-23. American life was passing through a painful transition not only from war to peace but also from old standards to new and, indeed, from one industrial era to another.

NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -- India's annual agony of waiting for the monsoon -- a period when the life or death of millions hangs on the vagaries of winds and temperature -- ended happily yesterday with the falling of the rains.

THOSE of us who create and run quiz programs face an odd situation. First, we note that our shows have excellent Hooper ratings. Then we examine the radio columnists' critiques and find ourselves accused of corrupting public taste.

TOURS -- Southwest of Paris, across the great rich plains of the Beauce, is the Valley of the Loire, which, most visitors agree, is accurately called the Garden of France, along with its better known names -- the Chateau Country and Touraine.

CITY folks rarely understand what disasters and what delights weather can bring to the farmer. In their physically limited and protected lives, rain means merely that the buses and streetcars will be overcrowded, or a hot spell means only that they will be uncomfortable and will grumble, louder perhaps than the most discontented farmer.

DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- Employes of the Ford Motor Company have voted 90 per cent in favor of a union shop, it was announced today after the largest National Labor Relations Board election of its kind.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 10 -- Pending such time as the Political Committee of the Arab League meets again, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, as Secretary General of the League, today rejected the most recent request of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, for a ten-day truce in Palestine beginning at noon, Greenwich Mean Time, today.

BRUSSELS, July 10 -- Marcel Cerdan regained his European middleweight championship tonight by defeating Cyrille Delannoit of Belgium on points in a gruelling 15-round fight before 15,000 fans at the Palais des Sports. It was a close decision and the crowd booed the three officials, whose verdict was unanimous.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10 (AP) -- George Schoux, the young professional of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was far ahead of the field at the half-way mark in the third annual $10,000 Columbus open golf tourney today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10 -- The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Veterans Hospital, being built in Crugers Park, south of here, is now 35 per cent completed. Workmen are pushing construction of the thirty-one buildings, which will have a 1,984-bed capacity, at top speed in order to permit the interior work on the structures to proceed during cold weather this fall and winter.

PENDLETON, Ore., July 10 -Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas doffed his favorite cowboy hat today and lapsed into Western talk when questioned about running for President on the Democratic ticket.

A POLICEMAN'S lot is not a happy one. The white (and dark) man's burden must always be heavy. And man's debt to man will be forever in arrears -- from West Africa to the West End, from Brooklyn to Bucharest. Generations of novelists have wrestled with these melancholy truisms.

IN this book two authorities in the field of home decorating have compiled a volume embodying all the tricks necessary for cutting decorating costs without sacrificing principles of gracious living. Well over 1,000 drawings and photographs supplement the text in demonstrating practical decorating ideas.
SHANGHAI, July 10 -- the swift rise in Shanghai prices and currency inflation threatens the Government's latest efforts to control the chaotic economic situation.
KANSAS CITY, July 10 -- The casual visitor won't see it but there is a fire smoldering on the rich prairies and plains of the country's breadbasket.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 10 -- The climate and soil of Dixie are providing a testing ground for plant seedlings and roots brought from the far corners of the world to be used for commercial and ornamental purposes in all sections of the country.

Although bank earnings, as indicated by the June 30 condition statements published last week, compare favorably with those of the first half of 1947, there is little prospect that the level can be maintained unless lending rates are improved further, according to banking observers.

The old-fashioned trolley car continues to disappear from the New York scene as the Third Avenue Transit Corporation early yesterday morning replaced the old machines with new modern Diesel buses on four more of its lines in the Bronx.

THE more cynical section of the populace long has speculated about what happens at the end of the testimonial dinner. After the waiters have cleared, do the patrons go on to the Automat or the Stork, and does the guest of honor rush off to resume beating his wife?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- The International Labor Conference ended its 1948 session this afternoon with an assertion by its President, Justin Godart of France, that the organized working class of the world would not use its freedom of association for political purposes.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the acquisition of two properties to add to Port Newark in furtherance of the bi-state agency's program for immediate restoration of the seaport to unified public ownership and operation.

Restricted by a short trading period, prices of stocks continued to back and fill last week as traders followed the cautious policy adopted prior to the long July 4 holiday. With domestic and foreign problems still unsolved, it was not surprising that financial markets kept within narrow limits -- firming up one day and easing the next.
PARIS, July 10 -- Marcel Bernard, French Davis Cup player, today eliminated Bob Falkenburg, Wimbledon tennis champion, from the Paris international tourney, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

MEXICO CITY, July 10 -- United States Ambassador Walter Thurston personally delivered to Foreign Minister Jaime Torres Bodet this morning, a note expressing deepest regrets over the strong anti-United States campaign conducted in the Mexican Press against the presense of the United States Army rescue crews in Mexico in connection with the recent airplane crash July 2.

JERUSALEM, July 10 (UP) -- The Holy City rocked under one of the heaviest bombardments of the Palestine war today as the Israeli forces introduced their secret "King David" heavy mortar and the Arabs laid down a barrage with twenty-five-pounders.
TETERBORO, N.J., July 10 -- Two large hangars at the Teterboro Airport were destroyed by fire tonight, with a loss unofficially estimated at more than $500,000.

I HAVE just returned from that country within a country -- the State of Texas. There the skies are bluer, the steaks bigger and better, and (in Austin anyway) the flagpole that flies the Lone Star is a few inches taller than the one that flies the Stars and Stripes.

Hall Co., European Representatives for American Publishers, has sent a notice to the credit departments of book publishers, requesting that they "read carefully the following letter just received from Orbis of Prague." which begins: "We have duly received your letter and beg to inform you that now you can deliver only to Orbis, Ltd., but not to other previous importers in Czechoslovakia."

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 10 -- Thirty business and industrial plants in Union County, including the vast Esso Standard Oil Refinery and the General Motors Corporation plant in Linden, have won certificates of merit for beautifying their sites, it was announced today by the Garden Club of New Jersey, a sponsor of the industrial beautification program conducted throughout the state in April and May.

Retail trade here was active last week, but comparison with a year ago suffered because of the shift of the July 4 holiday. Department store sales were estimated as showing a decrease of about 13 per cent under 1947 for this reason.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Big Bill Voiselle hurled the league-leading Boston Braves to a 4-3 victory over the Phillies tonight before 25,023 fans. Shortstop Alvin Dark hit safely in his twenty-second consecutive game for the Tribesmen.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 10 -Striking before dawn today Israeli forces cut deeply into Arab territory on the central front, capturing Lydda airport, near-by Wilhelma, which was an Arab Legion stronghold, and six other villages. The Arabs launched counter-attacks later in the day but tonight the situation appeared to be under control.

LAST autumn the civilized world turned its attention for a moment, at least, to the 400th anniversary of the birth of Cervantes, Spain's universal genius of letters. That perpetual miracle, "Don Quixote," has been called the first modern novel and the most seminal piece of fiction, long or short, ever written.

MANILA, July 10 -- A policy of industrial and commercial protectionism for the new Philippine Republic was laid down by President Elpidio Quirino today. He spoke, informally, at Malacanan Palace at a reception for eighteen visiting American businessmen who came here to explore the opportunities for increased United States-Philippine trade.

The largest registration for the summer session in the history of New York University was announced yesterday by Elwood C. Kastner, registrar and supervisor of admissions. Mr. Kastner said that 22,800 persons would be enrolled for classes this summer at the university.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP) -- The newly announced pricing policy of the United States Steel Corporation was expected to threaten seriously Pittsburgh's claim to being the world's steel capital.

THE indefatigable and indestructible Tommy Hambleton is at it again. This time he is loaned to the Home Office by Foreign Office Intelligence in order that he may help solve the mystery of a series of successful prison breaks which have baffled Scotland Yard.
One of these days New York City will have a chain of public yacht basins. Commissioner Robert Moses's Parks Department has assured it and can point to plans and blueprints.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A rather anemic looking band of Yankees that had no Joe DiMaggio roaming in centerfield was hard pressed to assert its superiority over the sixth-place Senators today.

Robert J. Hubbard, chairman of the water safety department of the Brooklyn Red Cross, declared yesterday that the annual drowning rate was rising steadily and appealed to bathers to apply to the Red Cross for information on water safety.

The first international Poliomyelitis Conference will be held tomorrow through Saturday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It will be sponsored by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, several Federal agencies and various scientific societies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- Yugoslav Communist leaders are today in more defiant mood than ever before. Any doubts as to their efficient determination to stand their ground against the Communist Information Bureau have vanished.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 10 -- Hearing on a speeding charge against Elliott Roosevelt was adjourned tonight by Justice George C. Deitz of the Town of Poughkeepsie to next Saturday. The adjournment was obtained by Joseph A. McCabe, appearing as counsel.

An immediate reorganization of the Department of Health to provide more effective executive control and direction was recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer by his Executive Committee on Administration in a report made public yesterday. The plan would regroup the eighteen separate bureaus and divisions into five new major units, each with a top-level administrator.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- Pravda declared today that a reported Communist plot to begin street fighting in Berlin was a "forgery" and "born in the innermost recesses of the British Embassy in Paris."

NEWARK, N.J., July 11 -- Two small, white-haired New Jersey women celebrated their 100th birthdays today. The families of the centenarians gathered at their homes -- one here and the other at Hightstown.
BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., July 11 -- "Economy" in operating correctional institutions costs more in the long run, Miss Henrietta Additon, superintendent of Westfield State Farm, asserted today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- Senator Claude Pepper of Florida announced tonight his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination on a liberal and progressive platform and claimed sufficient votes for himself and others in the anti-Truman fold to prevent the President's nomination on the first ballot.

CHICAGO, July 11 (UP) -- Andy Pafko belted his thirteenth home run of the season to return Russ Meyer a 1-0 victor over the Pittsburgh Pirates today before 29,683. It gave the Cubs a sweep of the three-game series. Meyer allowed only two hits.

Among two million New Yorkers who went to beaches yesterday to bask in the sun or seek relief in the water from the heat thath) 0*0*0*ireached 85 degrees, hundreds of thousands traveled farther than usual to escape the sewage pollution that has been found worst nearest the city's harbor.

LONDON, Monday, July 11 -British newspapers in special dispatches from Philadelphia and in editorials present today a picture of the Democratic party gravely disunited and apathetically accepting Harry S. Truman for want of a better Presidential candidate.

A goal of approximately 40 per cent of total commercial exports of steel has been set as the quota for merchant exporters out of total authorized quotas in all categories, Morris Rosoff, general counsel, the National Association of Steel Exporters, revealed here yesterday.

VIENNA, July 11 -- Austria has responded to United States requests by lowering her estimate of food needed for the first European Recovery Program year but has increased her estimate of the total amount of aid she will need to meet the deficit between imports and exports.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 11 -- Johnny Humm Jr. and Dr. Ray Bowles of Cherry Valley played two under par golf for seventeen holes to defeat L. W. McKeown and Mal Galletta, North Hills, 2 and 1 in the final of the Rockville member-guest tournament today.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Yankees brought themselves up to the halfway mark of the American League flag race, marked by the all-star game interruption, in rather bedraggled fashion today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) The Red Sox and Athletics split a wild-scoring doubleheader today, the Red Sox winning the opener, 9 - 8, in ten innings and the Mackmen coming back to take the nightcap, 7 -- 5. The second contest, in which Dick Fowler notched his eighth victory, ended after seven and a half innings because of the Pennsylvania Sunday curfew law.
ATHENS, July 11 (AP) -- The Greek Army was believed today to be regrouping for a fresh assault on the Communist rebels in the Grammos Mountains.

A National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, will open this morning in the Government agency's offices at 2 Park Avenue. A hearing on similar charges against the American Radio Association, also CIO, is scheduled to start Thursday morning.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- Stocks of lard continue to pile up as the result of a comparatively slow domestic and foreign demand.

With a four-run drive in the fifth inning featuring their fourteenhit attack, the Philadelphia Stars defeated the New York Cubans, 8 -- 3, in a Negro National League test which was the second game of a double-header at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
PARIS, July 11 - The French Petroleum Company, at its annual meeting, has authorized an increase in the capital from 5,222,000,000 to 15,666,000,000 francs.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 11 (AP) -h) 0*0*0*iRichard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles repeatedly passed Jack Tuero, New Orleans, with shots from the base line to win the sixtieth Western tennis singles championship today, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

Ceremonies commemorating Bastille Day were held yesterday on the Mall in Central Park in advance of France's national holiday, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, which comes on July 14, this Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11--An overwhelming majority of the estimated 10,000,000 young Americans who will cast their first ballots in a Presidential election next fall will support the Democratic ticket, Roy G. Baker of Sherman, Tex., president of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, predicted today.

Despite warnings that supplies will be withheld if television price cutting is not stopped, many small retailers and several radio and appliance chains throughout the city continue the practice, department store radio buyers declared last week.

The Democratic convention opens at a moment of world suspense. People everywhere are watching the United States, not to see what is going to happen at Philadelphia, for that is a foregone conclusion, but to see what we will do next to meet the rising pressure that is focused on Berlin.

Love, director of the evening and extension division of the City College School of Business.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -Democratic delegates wandered deserted streets today without disturbing their Sabbath stillness. They seemed like so many mourners.
Tammany Hall is expected to "draft" Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan today as its new leader.
STOCKHOLM. July 11 (AP) -Sweden and Czechoslovakia, who have dominated European tennis since World War II, will meet for the European Zone Davis Cup championship.

More than 1,000 delegates registered yesterday for the first International Poliomyelitis Conference, and the registration is expected to exceed 1,800 for the sessions which open today and continue through the week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Awards for heroism in the line of duty were made to 298 members of the Police Department in general orders issued yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 11(AP) -- Jersey City and Syracuse divided a double-header today. The Giants took the opener, 10 -- 9, with the Chiefs coming back to capture the nightcap, 6 -- 5, before 6,240.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 11 -- The strategically situated towns of Ramleh and Lydda, which were constant threats to the Tel Aviv area and control the Tel AvivJerusalem road, were surrounded tonight by Israeli forces.

John Kieran will perform for television under the title, "Kieran's Kaleidoscope," which is to be a series of films on natural history. Mr. Kieran will be the annotator. It has not yet been decided as to what video network will be engaged locally for the series.

The Bankers School of Public Relations, to be conducted during the week of July 26 at Syracuse University, Syracuse, N.Y., hash)0*0*0*iadded a group of practical authorities from industry to its faculty, it was announced over the weekend by Albert L. The Newspaper Guild of New York announced yesterday its withdrawal from the Greater New York CIO Council because of the council's "persistent refusal to abide by national CIO policy." The announcement was based on the action of the guild's six elected officers in voting to disaffiliate from the council.

The United Fruit Company, operator of passenger and cargo ships on the three coasts, has accepted delivery of the 5,000-ton fruit-carrying vessel Morazan, completing a $72,000,000 expansion program that began five years ago.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- William F. Talbert of New York won the annual Spring Lake Bathing and Tennis Club invitation tennis tournament today when top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami was forced to default in the final round.

Dr. Arthur Prudden Coleman, assistant Professor of Polish Language and Literature at Columbia University since 1928, announced yesterday that he had offered his resignation to the university in protest against its acceptance of a grant from the Polish Government for the founding of a new chair of Polish studies.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11--James A. Farley, former national chairman, declared today that he was "thoroughly disgusted" with the party leaders around the country who at one stage of the game or another identified themselves with the "stop Truman" movement.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 11 -- In an amazing demonstration of navigation know-how over a 104mile course from Execution Light, Carl E. Schuster's 36-foot Carlan was found today to have won the Cruiser Championship of America Trophy and other honors in the New York Athletic Club's annual Block Island distance races.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 11 -Harold L. Tuttle secretary and trust officer of the Bank of Huntington and Trust Co., the oldest banking institution in the town of Huntington, has been elected president of the bank to succeed Addison W. Sammis, former president, who died several weeks ago.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP)--Bob Lemon hurled his sixth shutout and thirteenth victory of the season today, holding the St. Louis Browns to three hits as the Cleveland Indians won the nightcap of a doubleheader, 5 to 0, before 39,940 fans.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 11 -- A natural low-nicotine tobacco developed by the Kentucky Agricultural Experiment Station in cross-breeding experiments dating back to 1933 may prove to be the answer to some medical objections against smoking.

Public housing bonds will be prominent in municipal financing this week. A scheclule of sales estimated by Daily Bond Buyer to total $82,164,191 will be topped by the sale of $28,116,000 of temporaryh) 0*0*0*iloan notes by fourteen local housing authorities on Tuesday, and by the sale of $18,225,000 of New York City Housing Authority bonds on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -Rear Admiral Donald B. Beary, Commander of the Twelfth Naval District and of the Naval Base at San Francisco, has received additional duty as Commander of the Western Sea Frontier and of the Pacific Reserve Fleet.

The National Battery Company made new high records in dollar volume of sales, units produced and net profit in the fiscal year ended with April 30, last, A. H. Daggett, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- The Israeli Government today accused Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, of "minimizing" Arab acts of aggression and hampering appropriate action by the international organization.

The Rumanian government, which is preparing to liquidate thewell-to-do peasants, and last week instituted forced grain collections, is joining other Eastern European Soviet satellite states in installing the agricultural system that prevails in the Soviet Union.

QUANTICO, Va., July 11 (UP) - A twelve-man team was chosen today to represent this country in the rifle and pistol firing at the London Olympic games.

Prices continued to work toward moderately lower levels last week in the domestic cotton market. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net I declines of 11 to 56 points on the l week, with most pronounced weakness in the spot month.

PARIS, July 11 -- Premier Robert Schuman, in a speech to the Popular Republican Federation of the Lille District, today called for a reinforcement of the backing of his Government to meet the political and labor difficulties facing it this week.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- The Tigers finished off their seventh straight victory today with a snappy ninth-inning double play that cut short a three-run White Sox rally and left the tally at 5 4.

BERLIN, July 11 -- More than 10,000 Berliners roared defiance of the Soviet Union today and pledged their intention of making this city "the Stalingrad of German liberty" in the most impressive mass meeting held since the beginning of the Soviet blockade.

LONDON, July 11 -- The delay in disposing of Italy's former colonies in Africa makes it appear that another disagreement and deadlock between the big powers is in prospect and that the issue may be thrown into the United Nations General Assembly, as was the Palestine problem.
MOSCOW, July 11 (AP) -- Pravda, the official newspaper of the Communist party, today attacked a group of United States and Canadian officials for "arms brandishing."

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July ll -- A group of New York school teachers attending the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers accused Governor Dewey today of lack of understanding or statesmanship in regard to legislation affecting public education.

Stimulation of European business recovery through further relief from international double taxation by treaty arrangements between the recovery-program nations and the United States, as well as among the European nations themselves, was proposed over the week-end in a survey issued by the National Foreign Trade Council.

The semi-annual report of the International Shoe Company, mailed yesterday to its 11,000 stockholders, disclosed a net profit of $6,949,461 for the six months ended on May 31, last. The profit is equivalent to $2.04 a share. It compares with $8,234,197 or $2.42 a share for the corresponding period of the previous year and with $14,002,017 or $4.11 a share shown for the full year ended on Nov. 30, 1947.

BAHAY PARE, Philippines. July 11 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino came to this remote village in the heart of Central Luzon's rice paddies today to receive a token surrender of arms from the Hukbalahap peasant guerrillas, but he did not get it.
TEL AVIV, July 11 (AP) -- Israel reported heavy fighting around Mishmar, hay Yarden, a Syrianheld bridgehead a few hundred yards west of the Syrian border below Lake Hule.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 The southern revolt against President Truman's nomination collapsed utterly tonight as an effective force in the Democratic National Convention.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Notices soon will be sent to about 2,700 eye specialists who were named defendants in the Government's anti-trust suits against two big optical companies, an official spokesman said today.

CHICAGO. July 11 -- Grain prices sold last week at a new low on the current downturn on the Board of Trade, July corn suffering from general liquidation, dropped below $2 a bushel for the first time since last February and, at the low, showed a loss of around 27 cents from the high of the previous week.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 11 -- With Gil Dodds and Chuck Fonville out of the picture, Harrison Dillard sidetracked from the hurdles into the sprints and other favorites nursing wounded reputations. Mal Whitfield emerged as the mighty man of Uncle Sam's greatest Olympic track and field squad, fifty of whose members headed for New York today on the first leg of their journey to London.

Barkley remained the odds-on favorite.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -Columbia has announced that production will be delayed no longer on "Born Yesterday," the Garson Kanin comedy to which the studio acquired screen rights last September for $1,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11 -- Yugoslav Army officers studying in the three highest military academies of the Soviet Union have taken up the standard of revolt against the Commu nist Information Bureau that first was raised last week by Yugoslav students at the MarxistLeninist University in Moscow.

Jay Howenstine Jr., government economist, writing in the American Economic Review, journal of the American Economic Association.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Bucky Harris, still steaming over the defection of Bob Feller from the American League ranks, which the Yankee skipper will direct in the annual All-Star game in St. Louis Tuesday, revealed today he would start Hal Newhouser, Detroit southpaw ace.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany. July 11 (AP) -- The United States Air Force identified todayh)0*0*0*ithe three Americans who were the first to lose their lives in the air supply of Berlin. The three, killed when a C-47 transport en route from Wiesbaden to Berlin with food, crashed near here Thursday, were:

CAIRO, Egypt, July 11 -- The provisional Palestine administration established by the Arab league Friday is not intended to deal with political questions but with essential local services, it was said today.

A heart-warming story of twentyfive years of never-ceasing work to brighten the lives of blind Americans is recounted in "Silver Anniversary Report," just issued by the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., at 15 West Sixteenth Street, New York 11. In the quarter-century of the Foundation's existence the lives of more than 200,000 sightless persons have been touched, directly or indirectly, by its ever-expanding services.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Even though some steel mills last week had to reduce output because of the shut-down in the captive coal mines, in addition to the Fourth of July holiday, the drop in output from the week before was not large.

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, July 12 -- With the Democratic National Convention scheduled to convene at 11:30 this morning in the Municipalh) 0*0*0*iAuditorium, William O. Douglas, associate justice of the Supreme Court, is scheduled to be nominated for Vice President if he is willing to accept.

LONDON, July 11 -- How to characterize the Tories has been exercising the leaders of the Labor party and the Government in the last few weeks. Today's contribution was from Sir Hartley Shawcross, the Attorney General.

PRAGUE, July 11 (UP) -- The Czechoslavak Communists got orders today to tighten up on membership applications and improve the quality of party membership. The party presidium order was a reaction to Cominform criticism of loose discipline in the Yugoslav Communist party.
TOKYO, July 11 -- Japan's economy has survived a year of administrative fumbling and has reached the half-way mark in 1948 in considerably better shape than a year ago.

Group activities for 125 boys and girls between 13 and 15 will begin today at the Salvation Army Red Shield Neighborhood Center, 216 West 124th Street. The youngsters, who all come from overcrowded areas, have been designated by teachers and case workers as presenting problems in behavior and social adjustment.

Dorland, Inc., will not renew its contract with the United States Army for recruiting advertising in the First Army area, according to Atherton Pettengell, president. The contract for the fiscal year 1947-48 expired on June 30 and in compliance with Government regulations the 1948-49 contract must be opened to bids.

RYE, N.Y., July 11 -- T. G. Burke and his guest from Sleepy Hollow, Hughes Dallas, fell victim to the ancient medalist jinx in the final of the annual member-guest tournament at the Apawamis Club today, being defeated in the championship flight by Richard Harris and Joseph McBride, of Arcola, 5 and 3.

The autobiography of Walter Evans Edge, three times Governor of New Jersey, will be published this fall by Princeton University Press. Entitled "A Jerseyman's Journal," the book recounts his career in business, politics and diplomacy.

FREEVILLE. N.Y., July 11 -The George "Junior Republic founded here in 1895 to help "problem" boys and girls reorient themselves, today observed its annual Founder's Day. A feature of the exercises was dedication of a new all-steel swimming pool; awards also were presented to two "citizens" for outstanding achievement.

Products of textile mills represented by Wellington Sears Company will be quoted, effective today, on an f.o.b. plant basis with no freight allowance, Richard G. Conant, president, announced today. Mr. Conant explained that the change will result in no increase cost to customers and will result in reduction in some localities.

A strike vote is being taken among communications employesh)0*0*0*iof Transcontinental and Western Air, Mil Senior, international vice president of the Airline Communication Employes Association, affiliated with the American Communications Association, CIO, announced yesterday.

The Christian church, through, its moral influence, must take the leadership in the world's search for righteousness, Canon Bernard C. Newman said yesterday in his sermon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

The First (Community) Church of Kew Gardens, Lefferts Boulevard and Kew Gardens Road, Queens, held a special "recognitionh)0*0*0*iservice" yesterday morning for Miss Eunice Noda. She will be the first Nisei woman to serve as a missionary in Japan from a Protestant church in the United States.

BALTIMORE. July 11 -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, playing inh)0*0*0*idefense of his title in the annual open championship tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, today topped the list of seventy-four contenders at the conclusion of the fifth round.

At the low end of the pasture where boggy swamp and thin upland soil come together is an interesting verdure strip. Within a short distance sandy loam changes to peaty muck; cattails take over for the hardhack and highbush blueberries for the clumps of wiry juniper.

Rex Harrison, the film star, is a clear prospect for the role of King Henry VIII in Maxwell Anderson's new drama, "Anne of the Thousand Days," to be produced this season by the Playrights' Company in association with Leland Hayward.
PIERMONT, N.Y., July 11 -- A prize-winning bloodhound puppy found a missing woman in twelve minutes here today after hundreds of residents of this town had searched in vain for thirty-eight hours.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 11 Eighty per cent of this island's population, now nearing 500,000, are Greek by language, religion, tradition, custom and aspiration. A large majority of them desperately long for union with that agglomeration of isles and mountainous peninsula of which Athens is the capital.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration moved today to induce American capital to share in the European Recovery Program with a guarantee of dollars in exchange for foreign currencies acquired in the proceeds of private investments in ERP countries.

BOSTON, July 11 (UP) -- Connie Ryan, filling in for the crippled Eddie Stanky, collected three hits and drove in as many runs as the Boston Braves swept a three-game series from the Philadelphia Phils. 9 4, today before 14,245 fans. The victors enabled the Tribesmen to extend their National League lead to five-and-a-half games.

Every now and then someone takes the critics of John L. Lewis to task for their failure, as it usually is phrased, to "give credit where credit is due." It is all very well, these persons say, to denounce Mr. Lewis for his cantankerousness, but we should not permit his bad manners to blind us to his great achievements on behalf of the miners.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11 -- A B-17 bomber, believed to be on its way to Israel by way of the Azores, took off from the Westchester County Airport at Rye Lake at 3:45 P.M. today without filing a flight plan, as required for planes leaving this country.

DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco and Jimmy McLane, the slim Andover Academy schoolboy from Akron, Ohio, came through as double winners today in the final American Olympic swim team trials.
A strong upturn in the production of small-size, individualserving cans, in preparation for the fall packing season, was reported last week by the Can Manufacturers Institute, Inc.

BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP) -Twenty-four white persons and negroes were lifted and carried off in patrol wagons today when they defied police orders to break up an inter-racial tennis outing by sittingh or lying down on the courts in a city park.

AMSTERDAM, July 11 -- The Netherlands election results were received with satisfaction by trade and financial quarters which stressed that the Netherlands had repudiated extremism by refusing communism and ultra-reactionism.

For more years than we care to remember many of us have been trusting to fenced-in runways to get us to where we are going when we move about our city mole-wise underground - as, like most of our fellowcitizens, we often do move.

The attractions that drew an audience of more than 18,000, the largest of the season, to Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night included Jarmila Novotna. Metropolitan Opera soprano: Donald Johnston, baritone, winner of the recent American Theatre Wing contest: the Philharmonic-Symphony and a welter of favorite melodies.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11 - Eight championship rosettes were awarded as the two-day twentythird Harrison Horse Show came to a close this afternoon at the Kentucky Riding Stable's ring alongside the Hutchinson River Parkway.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 11 -Mrs. Maude Beasley, 22 years old, of Reading, Pa., was rescued this afternoon by a Coast Guard boat in the ocean a mile off Cape May after her husband, William J. Beasley, 25, and Joseph Stark, 30, also of Reading, drowned in a boat accident.

The nation "that deals with falsehood and with dishonesty and with corruption has lost its way and is headed for shipwreck," the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, former Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, warned yesterday in a sermon on "God the Giver" at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

A two-stage program for rehabilitation of the city's piers over a ten-year period will be submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer early this week by Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

Desserts in the summer should be decorative enough to tempt lagging appetites. It's equally important, when the weather is hot, that they be simple to prepare. A fruit and cheese tart devised in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen fills the bill exactly. A pastry shell is layered with cream cheese flavored with rum, then topped with fruit and whipped cream.

KONITSA, Greece, July 11 -- The gray stone village of Monastiri in the Molista district, a seven-hour uphill march from Konitsa, is one of 120 tiny communities that have been redeemed by the Greek Army during the current campaign for Grammos.
ALBANY, July 11 (AP) -- Practicing nurses in New York who do not have state licenses were urged today by the Education Department here to take immediate steps to obtain them.
BISMARCK, N. D., July 11 (AP) -- Clothed in civilian dress, Catholic nuns may teach in North Dakota pub}ic schools next fall despite recent passage of a measure intended to stop them.

The Rev. Dr. John Baillie, Professorh)0*0*0*iof Divinity at the University of Edinburgh, Scotland, preached yesterday morning service in the Broadway. Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street on "The Meaning of the Incarnation."

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 11 (AP) Five prisoners, who were awaiting trial on felony charges, escaped from the Ulster County jail today after bludgeoning two keepers with pipes that had been ripped from the jail's plumbing system.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 11 -- Henry A. Wallace, third-party candidate for President, sounded the death knell for the Democratic party in a speech here today before members of the Progressive party of West Virginia.
