As the Progressive party's candidate, he spoke at the final session of its founding convention.

A Canadian-United States drill competition between air cadet units will be held for the first time on Aug. 7 at New York International Airport at Idlewild in connection with the air show marking the city's golden jubilee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 11 -- Over the last three months the British Government has been negotiating an agreement with King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan to make available to him 500,000 (approximatelyh)0*0*0*i$2,000,000) in hard currency -dollars or the equivalent -for the remainder of 1948, usually reliable sources said today.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP) - Johnny Wyrostek's first inning triple led to the only run of the game as Ken Raffensberger pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a one-hit 1 to 0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

LONDON, July 11 -- Events of the past week confirmed the stock markets here in their now apparently chronic apathy and heaviness. It is really upon the Soviet Union that everyone is waiting, although once again Palestine is throwing its shadow over the international situation.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 11 (AP) -- A Cabinet member said tonight the Egyptian Council of Ministers had approved Prime Minister Mamoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha's decision to reject any prolongation of the Palestine truce.
LONDON, July 11 - Representatives of the Western Allies areh)0*0*0*ispending an agitated week-end working out plans for any contingency that may arise when Moscow answers their notes on Berlin.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11 -- Delegates from fourteen Western Hemisphere countries told the Argentine Broadcasters Association this morning that radio freedom had been virtually abolished here.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Mel Patton and Harrison Dillard were sitting on cots at the Great Lakes headquarters for the Olympic squad a couple of nights ago. Nervously they massaged the muscles of their legs. The potential Olympians were getting more and more keyed up as the final tryouts approached. The atmosphere in the room hung heavy with suspense as nerves grew brittle, almost to the breaking point.

PARIS. July 11 -- France has invited the United States, Britain and the Benelux countries, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg,h)0*0*0*ito meet in Paris at the end of July to prepare for the application of the recommendations of the London conference on Western Germany.

On June 6 you gave publicity in your news columns to the unwarranted statement of Dr. Robert Knight, who denounced electro-shock therapy and vigorously assailed what he calls "the strong-arm cure." Such statements can do great harm to those persons suffering with mental illness, who thus become confused over what is the best therapeutic regimen for them to submit to in order to save them from prolonged ravages and misery of chronic melancholia.
Four new films are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Communist International, now operating under the name of the Russian-dominated Cominform, has issued a new manifesto decreeing a new party line which not only explains some of the strains and stresses within the Communist front itself but is also of fundamental importance to all nations wrestling with the Russian problem.

CARVILLE, La., July 11 (AP)--Mrs. Josefina Guerrero, who was known as Joey to the countless G.I.'s she helped fight the Japanese in her native Philippines, arrived at the Carville National Leprosarium here today. She is the first foreigner ever to be accepted as a patient.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Capitulating after three months of resistance, the United States Steel Corporation announced today that a wage increase would be granted to about 170,000 members of the United Steel Workers, CIO, "sometime this week."
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11 -There were so many flip-flops taken today by the class championship aspirants in the Yacht Racing Association they were difficult to enllmerate. Time meant naught.

Despite the deplorable crash last month at Mount Carmel, substantial progress is being made by the domestic and overseas airlines of the United States in the field of safety. The National Safety Council, for example, recently cited American Airlines for its record in 1947, which sets a new high for a single carrier in aviation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11 (AP) Lloyd Mangrum, 33-year-old former National open champion from Chicago, closed like Citation today to win the third annual $10,000 Columbus open golf tourney by a angle stroke in a fine stretch drive.

WESTBURY, L.I., July ll -George Oliver, nine-goal star, brought his Blind Brook quartet out of the cellar of the National Polo League today as it clicked off seven goals in the second half to whip Westchester, 13 to 7, at Bostwick Field.

Aside from a sharply increased demand for summer dresses, wholesale garment markets here last week were quiet, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Retailers reported a rapid turnover of summer apparel and sportswear.

With Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach showing the way to the seeded players, the New York State tennis championship moved through another crowded day at the Seminole Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

For home planners who must think of wintertime comfort at the height of summer, a new electrically operated heater, is available. In appearance it is a glass panel framed in aluminum, to be set in the wall or attached to it.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- The American Olympic swimming and diving teams selected here in four-day trials for the games opening in London July 29 (in the order of their final qualifying):

Michael Murphy, 42-year-old taxicab driver, was found slain behind the wheel of a cab on 108th Street, just east of Fifth Avenue, early yesterday morning. The police reported that he had been strangled with a noose fashioned from an apron string.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 11 The fifth international tennis match between the combined OxfordCambridge University forces and the Rockaway Hunting Club for the Prince of Wales Cup, a series that dates back to 1924 and was resumed this year after a lapse since 1937, finished in a 6-6 deadlock today on the Hunting Club courts.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- The first and secret draft of the 1948 Democratic party platform neared completion late tonight, but even before its final plank was written it was headed toward assault by both Northern liberals and Southern conservatives.
ATHENS, July 12 (AP) -- Greek Army troops pushed forward into the southeastern flank of the Grammos Mountain area today in a renewed offensive against the Communist-led rebels.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Diplomatic officials said today that Sgt. James M. McMillin Jr., who quit his Moscow Embassy post rather than return to the United States, has rebuffed a proposal by his father for a personal interview.

JERUSALEM, July 12 -- Elements of the Israeli Sixth Brigade stormed and occupied today Khirbet Masmil, which was defended by strong forces of Trans-Jordanian regular and Iraqi irregular troops with a sprinkling of local Arab volunteers.

PAWLING, New York, July 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today the reappointment of Pierrepont B. Noyes of Oneida as chairman of the Saratoga Springs Commission and the filling of six vacancies in the membership of the commission.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 12 -- Once upon a time the National League regarded the All-Star game as a jolly sort of picnic which was of the same approximate importance as the annual outing of the Twelfth Ward. The only thing missing was a keg of beer at third base. The boys showed up on time, perfunctorily went through their paces and remarked afterward, "A real sporting try, old bean."

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- In a union-management dispute over the laying off of two men, 6,000 workers staged a virtual "sitdown" strike this afternoon at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's plant in near-by Lester.

Increases in sales, in the number of new customers and in store traffic, as well as the number of persons "looking over" flatware patterns, were achieved by retail jewelers during the two weeks of "The 1948 Silver Parade." This was announced yesterday by A. E. Hasse, executive director of the Jewelry Industry Council, which coordinated the promotion.

Production of steel by the domestic industry was nearly 722,000 tons greater in the first half of 1948 than in the corresponding six months of last year and the operating rate for the first two weeks of the second half of 1948 is also running ahead of last year's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 12 -- Following is the text of the statement by Justice William O. Douglas declining to accept nomination for public office:

It is good to see the Democrats at Philadelphia taking the question of their 1948 platform seriously enough to quarrel over it. There is a good deal of cynicism these days about party platforms. It is said that almost nobody reads them and that of the few who do no one believes them.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 12 -- The modern Arab village of Ramleh, a key point on the Tel Aviv-Jerusalem road and a center of strength on the central Palestinian front for Trans-Jordan's Arab Legion, surrendered unconditionally today to Israeli forces.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 12 -- Following is the text of the conclusions of a report, made public today, by Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, to the Security Council:

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Following the lead taken by the Americans for Democratic Action, the Democrats for Douglas today dropped their efforts to obtain the Presidential nomination of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 12 -- Close coordination of persistent advertising with merchandising activities is essential for producing sales results in promotion of major appliances, Stewart Roberts, director of advertising and sales promotion for Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., told field managers today at the concern's semi-annual sales conference here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The state of things as between the Democrats and the Republicans in 1948 can be counted by each party's convention gifts. The Republican women gave away between $20,000 to $30,000 in face creams, dresses, bags and sweetmeats.

A master plan for the rehabilitation of the city's waterfront was made public yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. It includes the construction in the next ten years of eleven new piers or platform structures and sheds for three piers and extensive modernization of old city-owned piers.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 12 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the Willow Brook Golf Club, the newly crowned metropolitan champion, led the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship qualifiers today with a two-under-par 38, 34 -- 72 at Wheatley Hills.

An issue of $115,000,000 of Federal Home Loan Banks consolidated non-callable 1.65 per cent notes, due July 22, 1949, will be offered to investors today through Everett Smith, fiscal agent. A nation-wide selling group of securities dealers will participate in the offering.
A 33 per cent increase in the capacity of Halloran Veterans Administration Hospital on Staten Island will be made by the end of the year, David P. Page, Deputy VA Administrator, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Attacks on the Republican majority in the Eightieth Congress and on Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for President, as the candidate of Joseph R. Grundy, high tariff Pennsylvania industrialist, featured the opening session of the Democratic National Convention in the Municipal Auditorium today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 12 -- The Communist party of Yugoslav Macedonia has now accused the Bulgarian and the Albanian Communist parties of seeking to annex Yugoslav territory. This accusation is by far the most serious new element in the quarrel between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Communist Information Bureau because in effect the Yugoslav Macedonian Communists are for the first time accusing other Communist-led states of imperialist designs upon Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Grain markets were somewhat unsettled on the Board of Trade today, but prices averaged higher, with corn in the lead. The latter closed 1/4 to 4 1/2 cents higher, July leading. Wheat was 5/8 cent lower to 3/8 cent higher, the former on July, which broke in the last few minutes of trading.

LAST month when Herbert Hoover appeared before the Republican convention at Philadelphia he received a tumultuous ovation. It should not have been remarkable that a Republican convention greeted a Republican ex-President with enthusiasm, yet most newspapers, Republican and non-Republican (though for different reasons), thought the incident remarkable enough to report under a prominent heading on page one.

Garry Moore has decided to resign as master of ceremonies for "Breakfast in Hollywood," the post which he took over after the death of Tom Breneman, according to word released here yesterday by Mr. Moore's spokesman. His resignation, it was said, will become effective upon the choice of a successor.

Following is the text of the keynote speech by Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention, as recorded and transcribed last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Battling Nelson is still a tough man to count out.

The stock market swung into further new high ground for the last two years by a small margin yesterday, although some opposition, encountered during the afternoon, kept most gains in a fractional range. The railroad issues again provided the spur for the strength, but failed to fare as well as some other sections at the finish.

The 100th anniversary of the founding of The Associated Press was observed last night in the broadcast by Station WNBC of a play, "Break the News," dramatizing highlights in the history of the oldest world-wide news-gathering agency.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 12 -- Informed that week-end traffic on the Taconic State Parkway at Yorktown now is so dense that even fire engines cannot cross the thoroughfare on the Underhill Road grade crossing, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors petitioned the state today to proceed at once with construction of a bridge carrying the road over the parkway.

As a result of an investigation of retail credit practices started yesterday by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, the National Retail Dry Goods Association will make a national survey of credit operations in their member stores.

Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator for Palestine, arrived here yesterday aboard the KLM plane Flying Dutchman to report to the United Nations Security Council. He predicted confidently that peace would settle upon Palestine.
BERLIN, July 12 -- The United States is meeting the challenge of the protracted Soviet blockade of this city by building out of the ruins of Berlin a new runway at the Tempelhof air base.
I hope that you will allow me the use of a few lines to pay tribute to the service being rendered in these critical times by General Lucius Clay.

Bruck Mills, Ltd., of Montreal, Canada, announced yesterday that stockholders had approved conversion of the authorized 150,000 common shares into 150,000 Class A no par and 300,000 Class B no par shares.

After a plant-wide vacation which began with the Independence Day week-end the 170 employes of the Magnus Harmonica Corporation started work yesterday in their new quarters at 439-51 Frelinghuysen Avenue, Newark, N. J.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Sensational advances in wholesale prices of meat, especially at New York, stimulated broad demand for livestock today. Hog prices soared 25 to 75 cents to a new July record of $30.50, which equaled the high established last September. Cattle at $40 and lambs at $32 were on par with the July records of last week.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- In his "keynote" speech at tonight's session of the Democratic National Convention Senator Barkley extolled the record of the fourteen years of Democratic control of the Federal Government and attacked the record of the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky was fast showing his heels to rival contenders for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination tonight after Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland withdrew from the contest and carried Gov. William Preston Lane of that state along with him.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Shipping companies operating between the United States mainland and Alaska cannot expect the same favorable financial arrangements that have been accorded to them during the past few years, Grenville Mellen, Maritime Commissioner, said today.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 12 -- Jerome Kohn had for many years been identified with the tobacco business in this area. He was formerly connected with the Hartman Tobacco Company, and more recently had been treasurer of the Kohn Brothers Tobacco Company.

As the athletes who will make up the United States Olympic team started pouring into New York yesterday, overworked officials took time out from the hurried business of registering and processing them for their departure tomorrow on the United States Liner America to name our official entry for the London Games in the 400 and 1,600-meter relay races.

The right of the officers of the Newspaper Guild of New York to withdraw the union from affiliation with the left-wing Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was challenged yesterday by Saul Mills, secretary of the council and a member of the guild's executive committee.

Still seeking some trace of the more than $200,000 that Bernard Striar of 645 Baretto Street, the Bronx, obtained from friends and relatives, Assistant District Attorney Michael Delagi questioned the former Air Force lieutenant at length yesterday.
LONDON, July 12 -- Britain gave King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan today a foretaste of the sanctions he might incur if he persisted with other Arab League leaders in prosecuting the war in Palestine.
Elliott G. Rutter, formerly with Goodman Greenhut, has been named assistant merchandise manager of the neckwear division, Wilson Brothers, Chicago, haberdashery manufacturer.
Another book about Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal will be brought out by Devin-Adair on July 30. It is "The Roosevelt Myth," by John T. Flynn, who wrote "Country Squire in the White House."

PARIS, Tuesday, July 13 -- Premier Robert Schuman and his somewhat divided Cabinet completed early this morning its work of apportioning some 32,000,000,000 francs among 2,000 categories of state employes. It was hoped the system of allocating funds under the reclassification plan announced yesterday would prevent a general strike of civil servants.

The Washington Post All-Stars routed the Brooklyn Eagle All-Stars, 12 -- 2, before 12,427 at Ebbets Field last night. Played for the benefit of the Brooklyn Amateur Baseball Foundation, the game was the first in a home-and-home series.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Schreiber ruled yesterday that he was unable to find any restriction in the will of the late Henry Clay Frick to prevent the trustees of the Frick Collection from accepting donations to the collection from the public generally.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., July 12 -- A dire picture of the public education system in the United States was drawn here today by John M. Eklund, newly elected president of the American Federation of Teachers.
The Swedish American liner Gripsholm and the Gdynia America liner Sobieski brought a total of 1,635 passengers here from European ports yesterday.

LONDON, July 12 -- The Berlin tension, coupled with the slump in savings and Sir Stafford Cripps' warning that imports may have to be cut despite European Recovery Program aid brought business almost to a standstill in the stock market here today.
Florence Reichman gives a century of millinery a modern fillip in her fall and winter collection, shown for buyers and the press yesterday at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Negotiating committees for Atlantic Coast longshoremen and the New York Shipping Association exchanged contract proposals yesterday. The longshoremen were said to have asked a wage increase of 50 cents an hour and the employers a change in the method of reckoning overtime pay.

Pan American Trust Company is planning to increase its capital $1,000,000 and begin an intensive promotional campaign to extend operations, it was disclosed yesterday. It is understood that 20,000 shares, all to be sold in the United States, will be offered for public subscription within the next few months.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The Commercial Telegraphers Union, AFL, asked the Federal Communications Commission today to investigate alleged mass violations of the Federal Communications Act by the Western Union Telegraph Company.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 12 -- In a covering letter to a series of counter-proposals to the Allies' authorization for the initiation of a Western Government in Germany, the Minister-Presidents emphasized that "the character of the state" must be carefully avoided, it was learned today.
The Arts, Sciences and Professions Council in a resolution published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 12 charges the Greek Government and the Greek police for the murder of George Polk.

The London Conference proposals for a unified regime for Western Germany have been accepted by the Premiers of the West-German states in principle but have hit a snag in the working out of details which will require further negotiations between the Germans and the occupying Powers.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcast reviewing differences between Moscow and Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia:

A National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, opened yesterday with the denial of a motion by the union's counsel to adjourn the hearing for thirty days.

Twenty jet planes, probably the world's ablest fighters, fourteen of them United States Shooting Stars and six of them British Vampires, were poised this morning to meet in Greenland today in the first crossing of the Atlantic by such aircraft.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 13 -- Democratic orators opened their party's national convention yesterday with slashing attacks on the "reactionary" record of the Republican Congress as the key issue of 1948. As the evening session of the convention adjourned at 12:07 A. M. until noon today major interest centered on selection of a running mate for President Truman.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 13 -- The special eighteen-member committee set up to approve the first draft of the 1948 Democratic platform was believed early today to have decided to urge the party to pledge itself to outright repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act.

BATU ARANG, Malaya, 12 (AP) -- Between seventy and 100 armed Communist insurgents raided Malaya's only coal mine today. They killed five Chinese and put out of commission -- at least temporarily -- much vital mine machinery.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The program for the Democratic National Convention tomorrow is as follows -- the time is daylight saving:

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The most strategic spot in Philadelphia today is the big green leather chair just inside the door at the Bellevue-Stratford. It stands at the main entrance to Democratic headquarters halfway between the bar and the elevators, and in the course of an afternoon a man in the chair can see more persons and pick up more misinformation than in any other spot in town.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- In an acrimonious atmosphere seldom associated with the event, the rival clans of the American and National Leagues assembled here today for baseball's midsummer classic, the All Star game, which will get under way tomorrow at 1:30 P. M., Central daylight time, at Sportsman's Park, before a crowd of 35,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 -- Alarmed over reduced sardine catches during recent years, the California sardine industry disclosed today that it was planning voluntarily to impose restrictions on the catch during the coming season.
SEOUL, Korea, July 12 -- The National Assembly today adopted the Constitution of "The Democratic Republic of Korea."

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 12 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall made a five-hour inspection of the Signal Corps training school and its research and development facilities here today, traveling to and from Washington by plane for the purpose.

LONDON, July 12 -- United States Navy headquarters here was informed tonight that the crew of the 7,176-ton American steamship William Carson had mutinied in the Atlantic, north of the Azores, and that the ship had sent an urgent message for immediate aid.

Actors Equity Association yesterday turned down the League of New York Theatres offer of a $15 increase in all minimums, but indicated willingness to pare down its original wage demands provided the managers agree to certain non-economic aspects of the new contract, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- All parties involved flatly refused to discuss today a report that Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and unsuccesful Republican Presidential candidate, had been offered the presidency of the University of Pennsylvania.

TRENTON, N. J., July 12 -- Frank D. Holmes Jr., who had been under criticism for his purchase of property near a state beach protection project he had approved, resigned today as State Director of Navigation.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- Hog and cattle prices shot to new high levels today at the National Stock Yards in East St. Louis. This may mean that housewives will find four or five more cents tacked onto meat bills within a day or two.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Beau Jack's bid to make ring history crashed tonight against the paralyzing punches of Ike Williams, Trenton, N. J., fighter who holds the world lightweight championship.

Summer sausage is what Europeans call the spicy, minced meat products that are enclosed in casings and specially cured to increase their keeping quality. In this country, too, we make frequent use during the hot weather of at least two varieties or summer sausage, salami and cervelat.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 12 -- The question of the Republican party's stand on Federal aid to education is expected to figure prominently in any discussion of campaign issues between Governor Dewey and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, it appeared today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The revolt in the New York State delegation against the Truman nomination which had been so loud a few weeks ago, died down to a whisper today, and the chances were slightly more than even that not even the whisper would be heard when the balloting actually took place.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (UP) -- After some "straight talk" from Commissioner A. B. Chandler, major league players today moved to take into their own hands the problem of major leaguers refusing to appear in All-Star games.

With apparel chains leading, sales of mail order and chain store companies increased 16.4 per cent in June as compared with the same month last year, according to a compilation covering forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, accepted yesterday the resignation of Dr. Arthur Prudden Coleman, assistant Professor of Polish language and Literature at Columbia for twenty years. Dr. Coleman announced on Sunday that he had submitted his resignation as a protest against the acceptance of a grant from the Polish Government for the founding of a new chair of Polish studies.

Left-wing store unions in this city took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out their threat to strike and picket as a means of fighting the citation of nine of their leaders for contempt of Congress.

Calling Representative Vito Marcantonio "the leading mouthpiece of the Moscow party line," John Ellis, Republican candidate in the Eighteenth Congressional District, gave a preview yesterday of his campaign to remove the state chairman of the American Labor party from the Congressional post that he has held ten years.

SINGAPORE, July 12 (UP) -- A British report from Batu Arang said that today's attack was the best organized since the guerrilla terrorist campaign got under way a month ago. One group blockaded the village police station, while others held European residents in their quarters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 12 -- Luis Carlos Prestes, general secretary of the outlawed Brazilian Communist party has fled the country, according to the Diario da Noite. He is reported to have escaped by plane.

The estimated floating supply of new municipal bonds in the market has diminished in a week by about $15,000,000, according to the Blue List, bringing the inventory down to about $95,000,000. Continued brisk selling out of big accounts like those of Los Angeles and Massachusetts is a factor in cutting down the inventory as well as the downward repricing of some slow-moving issues.

Walter E. Poor, chairman of the board of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., laid the cornerstone yesterday for the first of a series of buildings designed to serve the company as a research and development campus on a fifty-five-acre tract facing Little Neck Bay, near Fort Totten, Bayside.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 12 -- Emerging from over two years of retirement in golf, Mrs. Harry J. Nevil Jr. of Hudson River, the former Margaret Nichols, won the qualifying medal in the fourth Tri-County women's championship with 39, 42 -- 81 over the difficult Century Country Club course today.

The second discordant meeting in two weeks of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, resulted yesterday in a fresh protest to James C. Petrillo, the union's international president, against alleged disregard by the local officers of decisions reached at membership meetings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- The New York Police Department will be the dramatic core of the film to be produced next year by Samuel Goldwyn, the producer disclosed yesterday, after having outlined his plans to Mayor William O'Dwyer in a telephone conversation over the week-end.

OCEANPORT, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- Joe W. Brown's Brown Mogul, who ran coupled with a stablemate, Flareback, outraced A. J. Fralinger's Jetsam in the stretch of the Osmand Purse, sixth and featured race at Monmouth today, and crossed under the tape three-parts of a length in advance of his nearest rival.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- David J. Coddaire, of Haverhill, Mass., was sworn in today as a member of the Maritime Commission.

The American merchant fleet includes 1,175 privately owned and operated ships, according to figures released yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping. The total shows an increase of 172 vessels in the last six months.

The brotherly spirit that binds New York policemen came squarely into conflict yesterday with the housing emergency, when one policeman was obliged to evict another from a house in Brooklyn. There was understanding on both sides, though the tenant's family had to be sheltered, for the night, among relatives and neighbors, and his furniture was moved on to the sidewalk, and thence to a garage for temporary storage.

DETROIT, July 12 -- For the first time since the attempt on his life in April, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, came back actively into union negotiations today with a threat of a strike by 108,000 hourly rated employes of the Ford Motor Company.
LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- The vanguard of women Olympic athletes moved into their newly opened housing center in suburban Wimbledon today and promptly discovered that it doesn't cater to vanity.
LONDON, July 12 -- Joe Simms walked across the River Thames this evening -- in the water, that is. He walked in the water, not on it.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 12 -- The Swiss Government has requested neutral arbitration on the question of German assets in Switzerland because it feels that the United States, Britain and France are trying to use high pressure methods, an official spokesman said today.

A record total of 6,956,000 pounds of food, clothing, medicine and other relief material was shipped to needy Jews in sixteen European countries in the first six months of 1948, it was announced yesterday by Supplies for Overseas Survivors of the Joint Distribution Committee.

William De Goode, real estate operator, has purchased the former L. Mundet Son manufacturing plant at 46-65 and 52-68 South Eleventh Street, 450-60 Berry Street and 579-81 Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn. The sale was negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company.

LONDON, July 12 -- Britons can look forward to an early end to the bread rationing that has been in effect for two years, John Strachey, Minister of Food, told the House of Commons today. He said that he was not in position to make a formal announcement today, but that the lifting of bread restrictions could not be long delayed.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough, in the United States District Court, today pressed for a direct and voluntary settlement of the "union shop" dispute in the "captive" mine coal industry. Such an arrangement would end the strike of 40,000 miners which began on July 1.

Target Films, Inc., a local independent producing group, has completed its first film, "Strange Victory," it was announced by the company yesterday. The feature-length documentary, written and directed by Leo Hurwitz and produced by Barnet Rosset Jr., which was filmed in and around New York in its entirety, deals with the problems of, and discrimination against, minority groups.

TENAFLY, N. J., July 12 -- Mrs. Herbert E. Carnes, bird chairman of the New Jersey State Garden Club and leading woman bird-bander, may be forced by public demand to continue to use the bird sanctuary in her gardens at Kenwood Road here as a clinic for additional sick and injured birds.

Arguments opposing the recent banning of The Nation from the New York public school system will be heard today at 10 A. M. by the Board of Superintendents in a meeting at Board of Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 12 -- Raymond A. Ioanes, chief of the United States Military Government's food branch, said today that despite the "extraordinary" air lift, the present rations in Berlin can be maintained only for another month.

BERLIN, July 12 -- More than 60 per cent of the judges and 76 per cent of the prosecutors in Bavarian courts are former Nazi party members, an official United States Military Government report disclosed today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 12 (AP) -- Two National A. A. U. records were bettered and a new American half mile medley relay mark was set as 60-odd of the nation's top women athletes competed for an as-yet-undetermined number of United States Olympic team berths in the final track and field tryouts tonight at Brown University stadium.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 12 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported to the Security Council tonight that it had a choice between two courses of action on the Holy Land: to stop the Arab states from employing force, in which case "a Jewish state" would remain in existence, or not to take action, leaving the issue to be settled "on the field of battle."

LONDON, July 12 (UP) -- The British Navy today assigned a destroyer and a frigate to help carry the Olympic flame on the sea stretches of its traditional journey from Greece to the scene of the games.
Cotton futures held within a comparatively narrow range yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed 6 points lower to 3 points higher than last Friday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Official governmental silence on the schism between the Soviet Government and Yugoslavia was qualified recently, it was learned today, by a "Voice of America" broadcast to the world. In that broadcast it was pointed out that the Soviet-dominated Communist Information Bureau was trying to discipline Yugoslavia for perfecting the very techniques invented by the Soviet regime.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, still uncertain what role he would fill in the 1948 campaign and the incoming Eighty-first Congress, headed for New York tonight for a conference with Governor Dewey that may clear up the situation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- President Truman, humiliated by many of the most important Democratic leaders and battered by Congressional majorities which included a large group of Democrats, is emerging at the national convention here as the only figure of continental size in his party.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- William P. Baskin, Democratic chairman in South Carolina, has called a special conference of state party officials for 3 P. M. tomorrow in Columbia, S. C.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 12 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Gunther's five-under-par 73 won the ace Memphis, Tenn., golfer medalist honors today in the qualifying round of the thirty-third annual Southern women's championships.

Add one more to the list of unsuccessful counter-attacks against inflation under private auspices. One of the boldest and most soundly conceived of all these ventures became history yesterday with the announcement that United States Steel had agreed to grant another wage rise to its 170,000 employes.
CANBERRA, Australia, July 12 (AP) -- Immigration Minister Arthur A. Calwell rejected today suggestions that Australia admit Asiatics under her quota system.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and National Tube Company, subsidiaries of United States Steel, annuonced today their new f. o. b. mill pricing plan would go into effect at midnight tonight.

LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- Fifty men who have been charged with being spies and terrorists aided by "agents of the Vatican" were brought to trial today at Zagreb, Yugoslavia, according to a broadcast by Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news service, recorded here.

ROME, July 12 -- The Chamber of Deputies ratified this afternoon the Italian-United States bilateral agreement on the European Recovery Program by a vote of 297 -- 96. The agreement still requires ratification by the Senate.

Edward and Florence Gleason, who on Saturday left two of their children in front of the Morrisania police station, walked into it yesterday and were arrested on a charge of abandonment. They had with them their third child, Maureen, 4 years old.

The promotion later this month, of a deputy chief of the Fire Department to fill the vacancy created last autumn by the retirement of Chief Harold J. Burke was indicated yesterday by Commissioner Frank J. Quayle.

PASADENA, Calif., July 12 -- Plans for the distribution of 5,000,000 garments in an Aid-to-Europe project of the National Council of Catholic Women heads the agenda of the annual convention of the Catholic Daughters of America which opened tonight with a dinner at the Huntington Hotel.

While sixty boys and girls in their teens began to enjoy summer in New York with the help of the Salvation Army Red Shield Neighborhood Center, fourteen other "youngster" left the Home of Old Israel to spend two weeks of their "second childhood" in the country.

A group of rebellious district leaders ousted Frank J. Sampson as the Tammany Hall chieftain yesterday in a move that Mayor O'Dwyer had dared them to try only two weeks ago. In Mr. Sampson's place, the leaders elected Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan.

Your Mallory Browne's superb coverage of the Trusteeship Council's meetings at Lake Success is next best to attendance. It brings out a disquieting tendency for the Council to exceed its proper functions, to sidestep them on slight or ambiguous grounds, to deny hearings, to allow extraneous matters to affect the examination of petitions. Permit me to stress three cases.

A year ago I returned after more than seven years' residence in Europe to a United States perplexingly transformed in many ways, either for better or worse. The most disturbing thing which has come to my notice is the recent announcement of the Hon. John McCormack of Massachusetts that he believed his religion (Roman Catholic) would not count against him if he were nominated for Vice President on the Democratic ticket.

"Tanglewood on Parade," a large-scale, four-hour benefit program, will be staged by the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., on Aug 3, it was announced yesterday. Maurice Evans and Cornelia Otis Skinner will appear in Shakespearean excerpts and Serge Koussevitzky will conduct.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Brig. Gen. Herman H. Hanneken, famous Marine Corps bandit catcher, has retired at the age of 55 years, the Marine Corps announced here today.

Stockholders of the John B. Stetson Company approved yesterday a long-term loan of $3,000,000 to be repaid over a 15-year period with an option to increase the borrowing to $4,000,000 before June 30, 1949.

The medical needs of India are nurses, trained mid-wives and missionary doctors more interested in medicine than in proselytizing, Dr. Snushila Nayar, a phpysician from that country, said here yesterday. She was interviewed in the New York Infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth Street, where she started a nation-wide tour of six months to study the medical care of women and children among the poor in this country.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 12 -- The 80th Congress, which completed its regular session June 20, was described today as "the most sympathetic to the problems of business men of any Congress during the past several years."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Prices paid by consumers for food, clothing, rent and related items increased 2.1 per cent during the first five months of 1948, according to a report of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, which will be made public tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, July 12 -- George Kramer, 19-year-old player from New York, soared into the lead of the United States Chess Federation's open tourney with victory in the seventh round over Dr. Ariel Merigarini, also of New York.

Plans for a new warehouse in the Bronx for Gristede Brothers, Inc., of 1881 Park Avenue, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The two-story structure will be on the southwest side of Bronxdale Avenue, about 612 feet northwest of Tremont Avenue. It is estimated to cost $905,000. David Levy is the architect.

When a hippopotamus reaches the age of 30, he is considered to be on the brink of senility. At 35 he is mighty old. And when he becomes 45, as Pete of the Bronx Zoo does today, he moves quietly into a mellow old age, almost unbelievable for a hippo, and does not want to be bothered by any nonsense.

Jack Geller of Scarsdale, recently graduated Yale University ambidextrous tennis player, became the first competitor to reach the quarter-finals of the New York State title play which continued until darkness yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Pierre Monteux, entering his second week as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium, divided last night's program between two massive and popular compositions, Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony in E minor, and Beethoven's Fifth (Emperor) Piano Concerto, with Claudio Arrau as soloist.

In a tingling tussle through the stretch, Earl Sande's Stage Kid raced to victory over the Argentine-bred Brisket at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the six-furlong Apawamis the pair thrilled a crowd of 21,087 by waging a bitter closing duel that ended with the Sande 4-year-old gaining the award only after inspection of the photograph.

BUENOS AIRES, July 12 -- As the Government-controlled press sought today to refute charges that the Argentine radio lacked freedom, all signs indicated that the regime had been acutely embarrassed by the report of the Inter-American Broadcasting Association.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Prices paid by consumers for food, clothing, rent and related items increased 2.1 per cent during the first five months of 1948, according to a report of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, which will be made public tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, July 12 -- George Kramer, 19-year-old player from New York, soared into the lead of the United States Chess Federation's open tourney with victory in the seventh round over Dr. Ariel Merigarini, also of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The Texas delegation, the most powerful from the South, began tonight a counter-attack against extreme Southern rebels intended to fragment or destroy a possible Southern bolt against President Truman in November.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- The Browns out-homered the Phillies today to win the annual memorial game at Abner Doubleday Field, 7 -- 5. Seven home runs were clouted in the fray.

TOKYO, July 12 -- The United States moved today to require foreign correspondents here to fill in questionaires similar to those used when persons apply for Army jobs. The correspondents must sign certificates admitting the Army's right to fire them.
A strike of fifty Westchester County bus drivers snarled commuting schedules yesterday for 5,000 residents of Yonkers, Tuckahoe, Bronxville and New Rochelle.

Prices held firm yesterday at April levels as the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers offered lines for September-October delivery. Later price advances were not ruled out in view of the calf leather and labor situations. The shoes retail at $18.95 to $24.95, with $22.95 cited as the probable chief retail price for the early fall.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 12 -- The Soviet Union complained to the United Nations today that Britain and Belgium were draining the wealth of their African trust territories to enrich themselves.
Brisk but short-term buying prevailed yesterday at the fall curtain and drapery show being held this week at the Hotel New Yorker.

In the first month of the 1948 phase of "Operation Ragweed," the city's perennial drive to eliminate the plant that causes 85 per cent of hay fever, nearly 700 acres of weed were destroyed, the city Health Department reported yestrday.

The remarkable feats of five indestructible Chinese brothers who survived the extreme penalty of the law to live happily ever after held a group of youngsters enthralled yesterday in a story hour in the playground at Ninety-seventh Street and Riverside Drive.

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky saw the dawn of a new era sixteen years ago when he was the keynote orator at the Democratic National Convention which nominated Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidency. He was then approaching his fifty-fifth birthday.
Operations of the United Fruit Company for the six months ended on July 3 resulted in estimated earnings of $27,025,000, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday.

We hasten to express our appreciation of and accord with the sentiments expressed in your editorial "Vacations at Home," in THE TIMES of June 29. Several years ago the Broadway Association instituted a "Make New York Your Vacation City" campaign, which was directed as much at New Yorkers as it was at vacation-bent people in other cities.

Since man is what he is, there can be only divergence in what he considers as true perfection. To some it is the white sail in moonlight, to others the pale blonde in night club light, and to others still, the Republican party.

Officials of the Government of Israel disclaimed knowledge here yesterday of the war surplus B-17 that took off Sunday afternoon on a mysterious flight from the Westchester County Airport and was impounded four hours later by Canadian officials at Dartmouth Field, near Halifax, N. S.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The women of the New York delegation, delegates and wives of delegates, were hosts at a tea this afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton in honor of Mrs. Alice Campbell Good of Brooklyn, Democratic National Committeewoman and widow of the late Congressman William H. Good.

Infantile paralysis is becoming less infantile, striking older age groups more frequently among nations with a higher standard of living, according to a world-wide survey of the disease presented yesterday at the opening sessions of the first international poliomyelitis conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PANAMA, July 12 -- President Enrique Jimenez was removed from office tonight by the National Assembly, which had elected him to the Presidency, and the Controller General, Enrique Obarrio, was named as President. The Assembly reconstituted its authority as a Constitutional Congress before taking action, as it had formerly divested itself of that function.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 11 per cent last week under the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It was pointed out that the comparison was affected by a holiday that resulted in five business days this year against six last year.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The White House is making preparations for President Truman to go to Philadelphia to accept the Democratic nomination for President, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Commerce Department reported today that sales of retail grocers totaled $2,348,000,000 in May, a gain of 4 per cent over April and 9 per cent over May of last year.

LONDON, July 12 -- As another day passed without a Russian reply to the Western Allies' protests regarding Berlin, officials in London began asking themselves how long the three powers should be expected to wait.

News of the opening tomorrow of a "country fair" on the city's steamy sidewalks is worth more than passing notice. Down in neighborly Greenwich Village folks are getting ready for the bucolic event, to be co-sponsored by the Greenwich Village Association and the community's weekly newspaper, The Villager.

There will be a total of seventy-eight international flights a week into and out of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, by the end of the month, Port of New York Authority officials predicted yesterday.

Stockholders of Philip Morris Co. Ltd., Inc. were informed by O. Parker McComas, executive vice president, at their annual meeting held yesterday in Richmond, Va. that sales for the first five months of 1948 were substantially higher than those of last year.
When the rebellious district leaders named Borough President Hugo E. Rogers to succeed Frank J. Sampson as the head of Tammany Hall, Mayor O'Dwyer suffered a political reverse.

Bryant Avenue between 167th Street and Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, was blockaded at 10 A. M. yesterday for a half an hour with crates, boxes and chairs to prevent the 167th Street crosstown bus from turning into the short block.

Every friend of Palestine or of world peace is disheartened by the failure of the truce in Palestine. Since it appears to be the Arabs who have refused to prolong the truce, while the Israelis have declared themselves willing to extend it, the temptation is strong to insist that the U. N. now crack down on the Arabs and make them behave.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- The Matson Navigation Company is negotiating for the sale of its passenger liner Matsonia to the Panamanian Line, Inc., of Panama, it was disclosed today.
Only one match was completed in yesterday's New York State tennis championships program before heavy rains flooded the courts at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 -- Declaring that sales and profits "have come too easily the past few years," Chester E. Young of Fairview, Okla., president of the National Retail Hardware Association, said today that the day of large profits with little effort was just about over.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- It hadn't occurred to Vic Raschi that he was the first pitcher to win his own All-Star game with a base hit.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Official sources said today that the Navy did not order the lay-off of two employes at the Westinghouse plant at Lester, Pa., where workers struck briefly in protest.
DUNN, N. C., July 13 (AP) -- A courtmartialed Texas soldier who escaped from an Army prison camp at Fort Jay on Governors Island, N. Y., has surrendered, Sheriff W. E. Salmon said today.

Pointing out that millinery merchandising at the retail level lacked an overall promotional, educational and training program, Max Robb, vice president and general merchandise manager of Lit Brothers, Philadelphia, urged yesterday the establishment of a millinery institute to set up sales clinics in all department and specialty stores.

LONDON, July 13 -- The plan for the voluntary socialization of land, apparently hastily contrived by the Polish Communists, seems to be an effort to meet the dilemma presented to the Communist parties in the Soviet satellite countries by the Cominform's criticism of the delay in the collectivizing of agriculture in Yugoslavia.

Salad dressings play a part in almost every day's menu during the summer. It's important, therefore, to master the making of two or three different kinds that will enhance a cold dish of mixed vegetables, meat, some kind of fish, poultry or fruit.

The Korean National Assembly elected on May 10 by the South Koreans has moved a long step toward establishment of a Government with adoption of a Constitution that appears to borrow both from the American and the European systems. There will be a President and a Vice President, but also a Premier.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Grain markets reacted after an early showing of strength on the Board of Trade today, wheat losing 1/2 to 1 3/8 cents. July corn acted tight and gained l 3/8 cents while the distant months were unchanged to 1 1/2 cents lower, the latter on September.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 13 -- Because of fundamental differences between the viewpoints of Gem Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, and Paul G. Hoffman, head of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, the German bizonal area is the only recipient of European Recovery Program funds that thus far has not signed the required bilateral treaty with the United States, it was learned today.

PANAMA, July 13 -- President Enrique Jimenez today repeated his determination to continue in office until Oct. 1, the date for the legal expiration of his term. He also expressed assurance that the Supreme Court would declare illegal the action of twenty-six members of the National Assembly in designating Henrique Obarrio as President.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- Johnny Sain's topnotch pitching for the Boston Braves was rewarded tonight with a new contract for the remainder of the season and a more tempting agreement for 1949. 1949.

TRIESTE, July 13 (UP) -- The pro-Tito and pro-Communist Information Bureau factions within the Trieste Communist party Central Committee broke openly today, each expelling "rebel elements" and accusing the other of "treason."

MANCHESTER, England, July 13 (Reuters) -- Australia retained the "Ashes," which they have held since 1934, when a combination of bad weather and stolid defense in the Australian second innings ended the third cricket test match in a tame draw at Old Trafford today.
In a further expansion move in the cotton textile center of lV[anhattan, Cannon Mills, Inc., has added to its holdings by the purchase of three more properties on Worth Street.

Although consumer credit currently outstanding is at a new record high of nearly $14,000,000,000, it is still relatively far below the pre-war peak in terms of national income and in terms of the number of borrowers, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Bankers Association.

GOOSE BAY, Labrador, July 13 (UP) -- Stormy weather over the North Atlantic tonight delayed the pioneering transocean flights of a squadron of fourteen United States jet fighter planes en route to Germany and of six British planes en route to Canada and the United States.

PASADENA, Calif., July 13 -- Love of the material things of life is responsible for broken marriages and many other contemporary evils which Catholic women are bound to combat vigorously, the Right Rev. William D. O'Brien told the biennial convention of the Catholic Daughters of America today.

PARIS, July 13 -- A wildcat strike of weather and radio services that had blocked traffic at all French airfields last night and today was settled early tonight, but Government employes in half a dozen department sremained out, still demanding negotiations with the Government.

Tower Properties, Inc., of which Edward Goldman is vice president, purchased from Tearly Realty, Inc., the four five-story apartment and store buildings at 1443-9 Madison Avenue, containing seven retail units and thirty-three apartments.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 13 -- Ras el Ein, source of Jerusalem's main water supply and last Arab outpost threatening the metropolitan Tel Aviv area, was captured during the early hours this morning after its Iraqi defenders had fought unenthusiastically and then fled into the hills.

LONDON, July 13 -- Licensing provisions making it virtually impossible for United States exporters of machine tools to sell to the Australian market are being drafted in Australia, it was learned authoritatively here today.

ROME, July 13 -- Another world war, caused by disagreement between the great powers, was regarded today as a possibility by Pope Pius XII, who clearly laid the blame for the present international tension on Russia.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 13 (UP) -- Arab leaders are gathering for talks that may determine whether the Palestine war will end in a few days, dispatches reported tonight.
TRENTON, N. J., July 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today a state inquiry into $657,000 of de falcations by a Newark police judge and bank executive would be extended to "several phases."

Two letters have appeared in THE TIMES during the past week calling for special exemptions of college men and others in the new draft. In the two years which followed V-J Day large numbers of young men used the exemption provisions then in force to avoid military service at a time when almost every Regular Army outfit was dangerously undermanned.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- H. C. Bonfig, vice president of the Zenith Radio Corporation, called today for the end of promiscuous price cutting and "chaotic dumping" of merchandise by radio dealers. He spoke before a meeting of the National Electrical Retailers Association here.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Any Hungarian protests of the State Department's denunciation of arrests for listening to broadcasts of the Voice of America in Hungary will be rejected, it was indicated today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- The New Deal still has a definite vote-getting appeal in New York State, and the coming campaign there will be waged by the Democrats in support of its principles, it was indicated here today by State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 -- A couple of National Leaguers were doing some verbal bag punching last night. "I'm really sorry the American League won't be at full strength tomorrow," said one of them, "because we'll get no credit for winning. Everyone will say we beat their junior varsity." He shouldn't have worried so much.

Television should soon become an actuality in Cuba, it was predicted here yesterday by Jose M. Garcia, vice president of Publicidad Inter-Americana, Havana. "We are trying to set up a station," he said, "and experiments are now being made in an effort to overcome the topographic difficulties, which are the main present obstacle to adequate televising."
LONDON, July 13 -- Activity in Saarbruecken and Austrian bonds featured a stock market that generally marked time pending Berlin developments.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Ebasco Services, Inc., New York, received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to undertake certain construction and engineering services, expected to cost about $20,000,000, for the Creole Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- The play-by-play of the All-Star baseball game at Sportsman's Park today follows:

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 13 -- The aid to the blind section of the Federal Social Security Act penalizes the visually handicapped person who strives to hold a steady job, members of the American Association of Workers for the Blind were told today.

As has been said before in this corner, what makes New York is the Port of New York -- though the people who come to New York to shop along Fifth Avenue or see the shows along Broadway -- or even to view the art in our museums and art galleries -- may not always think of our city in that light.

HAMILTON, Ont., July 13 (AP) -- Skee Riegel, United States amateur champion from Upper Darby, Pa., was eliminated today in the first round of the Canadian amateur golf championship. Despite a stout rally, Riegel was defeated by Ken Ward, 30-year-old Royal Canadian Air Force veteran, on the nineteenth hole.

On the eve of Bastille Day, the French national holiday, Henri Lesieur, North American manager for Air France, predicted yesterday that the French national airline's first flight from the New York International Airport at Idlewild would mark the end of the delays that have hindered the line's operations at La Guardia Field.

A fourth of the British dinnerware bought by consumers here in recent years has not passed through American trade channels and new legislation will permit "a tremendous increase in this by-pass," Dr. Robert F. Martin, executive secretary of the Vitrified China Association, declared last night.
LONDON, July 13 -- While the British Foreign Office waited grimly and vainly today for a Soviet reply to the protests on Berlin, the Board of Trade reopened trade discussions with the Russians.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Sales at the American Furniture Mart are running spotty, with buyers hesitant to do any heavy spending. Many buyers for retail stores are leaving the market without spending the full quotas allowed to them, officials said.

ATHENS, July 13 -- The Greek Army was today reported to be heavily engaged against well-entrenched rebel forces in the area west of Heptochorio. The Army's renewed offensive follows a week of comparative inactivity in which units were regrouped and resupplied with much-needed artillery ammunition.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 13 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Gunther of Memphis easily won her first-round match today in the Southern women's golf tournament at the Belle Meade Club course.
New York opened its war against mosquitos yesterday.

Bobby Clark, cast as the husband of the nation's first woman President, will star this November in "As the Girls Go," a musical comedy that Michael Todd will present as his first new production on Broadway in two and a half years.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky clinched the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination today with a belated nod from the White House that foreclosed the chances of his rivals. It remained only to call the roll of states and for the Senator to accept.

Great Britain has made an "amazing" recovery both in home production and exports, Chaim Raphael, senior economic information officer of the British Information Services, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

In his first discussion of specific issues likely to be raised in the approaching Presidential campaign, Governor Dewey called last night for a liberalization of the law providing for the admission of 205,000 displaced persons from Europe into the United States in the next two years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- The return of Dore Schary to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in an executive producer capacity second only to the position of Louis B. Mayer is expected to be announced officially within a week. Schary, who recently resigned as vice president in charge of production at RKO Radio Pictures after differing with the policy line of Howard Hughes, the new owner, has been conducting negotiations with top Metro officials for several days.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 13 -- Paul E. Kelly Jr. of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club and a resident of Ossining, N. Y., medalist in yesterday's qualifying round, came through two rounds of match play in the metropolitan junior open golf tournament at the Ridgewood Country Club course today to loom as a new favorite.

New issues of public utility debentures and bonds totaling $65,000,000 were awarded at competitive sale to banking syndicates yesterday, but a scheduled sale of $20,000,000 of new preferred stock failed of consummation because the issuing company -- the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota -- was unwilling to sell the stock at a dividend cost of about 4.76 per cent, the best bid received at the competitive sale.

WARSAW, July 13 -- Poland's Communists, apparently acting under the impact of the denunciation of Yugoslavia's agrarian policy by the Communist Information Bureau, have decided upon the "voluntary" socialization of the country's agriculture. This decision, announced today, was taken yesterday at a meeting of 500 leading members of the Polish Workers' [Communist] party.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 13 -- The Arab Higher Committee for Palestine charged here today that the spectacular beach battle near Natanya on June 21 between Haganah forces and the Irgun Zvai Leumi was only a mock fight intended to camouflage the landing of arms from the LST Altalena into Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Truman plans to "pour it on" in an extemporaneous acceptance speech when the expected Democratic nomination for the Presidency is given to him at the Democratic National Convention, it was learned today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's plant in near-by Lester resumed production late today after being shut down for twenty-four hours by a walkout of 6,500 workers.

Tuna continued to be caught on the off-shore grounds over the week-end, but wind and corresponding high seas slowed up the action, a check made yesterday indicated. The weather apparently was uneven. The reports from Freeport and Montauk were of considerable wind, especially on Sunday, but those sailing from Hampton Bays weren't bothered particularly.

Joint establishment of a television news service by The United Press and Fox Movietone News was announced yesterday by Spyros Skouras, president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, and Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press.

NEWARK, N. J., July 13 -- Judge P. James Pellecchia, 38-year-old chief Police Court Magistrate in this city, confessed today and pleaded guilty to the embezzlement of $657,000 from the Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel.

BALTIMORE, July 13 -- Max Pavey of New York, the national speed champion, captured the lead in the open tournament of the United States Chess Federation by defeating George Kramer of Queens in the eighth round tonight.

GENEVA, July 13 -- The United States, which failed to draw a three-year seat on the executive board of the World Health Organization, today lost the first round of its fight to get its contribution to the organization's budget reduced from 39.89 per cent to 25 per cent.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- The president of the American Feed Manufacturers Association today recommended that buying and selling of crops be done by the hundredweight instead of by the bushel.

The Wayside Home School for Girls, Inc., has sold a tract of twenty-five acres of land on the north side of Hempstead Avenue in Valley Stream, L. I., to the New Stratford Homes, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $41,091. The new owner will use the property for a housing development.

While the Golden Jubilee of Greater New York is being commemorated this summer, New Yorkers and visiting celebrators might well give a thought, a bow or an orchid to the Hudson River. An important factor in New York's greatness, it rates a share in the celebration, though its venerable age makes Greater New York -- or even New York dating back to New Amsterdam -- seem a mere infant.
BALTIMORE, July 13 (AP) -- Negroes started playing golf today on the three municipal courses from which they had been excluded.

The Australian Government is surveying all possible methods of increasing exports and is working closely with industry with regard to its export policy, J. A. Tonkin, assistant secretary of the Australian Department of Commerce and Industry, said in an interview here yesterday.

The American Committee for Yugoslav Relief, of which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman, announced yesterday that it was ending its activities. The decision was taken last Dec. 15, Zlatko Balokovic, president, said in a letter to its directors and sponsors, because the beard of directors felt at that time that circumstances no longer warranted the continuance of the wartime agency.

The cost of living still headed upward here yesterday as retail meat prices rose 2 to 6 cents a pound and retail coal prices were scheduled soon to reach the highest general levels in the city's history.

A note scrawled by Michael Murphy, 42-year-old taxicab driver, before he was strangled at the wheel of his cab early last Sunday resulted yesterday in the arrest of two suspects. The two were booked at the East 104th Street police station last night after they had admitted that they had "mugged" the chauffeur for $17, according to detectives.

The Long Island College Hospital, 340 Henry Street, Brooklyn, had a deficit of $76,154 for 1947, according to its annual report released yesterday by Tracy S. Voorhees, president of the hospital and Assistant Secretary of the Army.

The Counseling and Employment Service of the Children's Aid Society blamed heat and rain for the smaller than usual number of teenagers seeking summer jobs yesterday. But among the sixty boys and girls who visited the service at 105 East Twenty-second Street was Raymond Barcia, the 2,000th applicant interviewed since school closed on June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- John L. Lewis called off the "captive" mine strike today and ordered the 40,000 strikers back to work tomorrow morning.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null reserved decision yesterday in a suit brought by Alexander Hamilton, an officer of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, for an injunction restraining the demolition of the 140-year-old Aquarium in Battery Park, formerly known as "Castle Clinton."

Hailing the announcement that $300,000,000 of Economic Cooperation Administration funds can be used to guarantee currency exchange for United States capital invested abroad as "a step in the right direction," Mackenzie Stevens of Mackenzie Stevens Co., foreign business consultants, said yesterday that American business leadership must make clear to both Europeans and Americans the basis on which sound recovery can be achieved.

Thirteen local housing authorities have borrowed $27,664,000 on short-term notes maturing in February, 1949, at interest rates ranging from 1 per cent to 1.04 per cent, the Public Housing Administration announced yesterday. Notes aggregating $17,712,000 were bid in by the Chemical Bank Trust Company, and notes totaling $9,952,000 by the Central Hanover Bank Trust Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 13 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative, today introduced a resolution under which the Security Council would invoke Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter and would order Israeli and Arab forces to stop the fighting in Palestine within three days.

LONDON, July 13 -- Britain's nationalized coal industry showed a loss of 23,255,586 (slightly more than $93,000,000) in the first year of its operation, the National Coal Board announced today. The figure was contained in the board's accounting covering the calendar year of 1947.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 14 -- Pinning their November election hopes to a Truman-Barkley ticket, Democratic National Convention delegates heard more campaign oratory in sessions which began at noon yesterday and continued to 12:50 this morning.

The 108-member resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention has now approved the recommendation of a subcommittee calling for outright repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Act. In convention areas, according to a dispatch to this newspaper, news of the subcommittee's views on the labor plank had caused "surprise" and even "concern."
PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- A half-hour memorial for the nation's war dead and for their Commander-in-Chief, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, preceded tonight's session of the Democratic National Convention.

At least one publisher is properly observing Bastille Day this morning. "The Blood of Others,"* by Simone de Beauvoir is a novel from France, jacketed in red, white and blue, and filled with talk of liberty and freedom, of man's duty to himself and others; filled, too, with the atmosphere of Paris and French romance and passion.

Watchful Government officials brought about seizure yesterday of two Constellation planes at the Millville Airport, Millville, N. J., and promptly linked them with the mysterious B-17 bomber that has been detained since Sunday in Halifax, N. S. Both the State and Justice Departments were said to be interested in all three planes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- There was early this morning one sentence in the "civil rights" plank in the Democratic platform which, if it stands unmodified in the darft adopted by the Convention, will definitely repudiate the position of most of the Southern states delegates as assumed by their representatives in Congress.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco led the seeded players into the third round of the national clay court tennis championships today.

DETROIT, July 13 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automotive Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, walked out today on negotiations with the Ford Motor Company, saying that he "didn't feel like fighting theoretical windmills."
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 13 -- Following is the text of a resolution submitted by the United States today to the United Nations Security Council:
One man was killed, and minor damage, widely scattered, was done yesterday afternoon by a series of thunderstorms that ranged over most of the metropolitan area.

The legality of the Board of Superintendents action excluding The Nation from the library lists of the New York public schools was challenged yesterday by Miss Freda Kirchwey, editor and publisher of the weekly magazine, at a closed hearing held before the school officials.

LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- The battleship Missouri sent a message today that "everything is under control" aboard the United States freighter William Carson. The freighter flashed an SOS last night that her crew had mutinied.

Because of the inability of associated industrial members of the Frozen Foods Institute, Inc., to obtain sufficient steel for manufacture of cabinets, lockers, refrigerators and other industry equipment, they have bought the Sterling Steel Foundry Company in Braddock, Pa., Dr. G. Hodges Bryant, managing director of the institute, reported yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein denied yesterday a motion for a temporary injunction in a suit brought by the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., to restrain the Furriers Joint Council of New York, CIO, from allegedly violating a collective bargaining agreement.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 14 -- A 5,500-word Democratic platform for 1948 was completed early today for presentation to the party's national convention by noon.

Sylvester Veitch, trainer of C. V. Whitney's race horses, had a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon at Aqueduct yesterday. He sent out two runners and he got back two winners, the second being Khyber Pass in a $6,000 purse called the Horizon.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 14 -- The foreign affairs plank of the Democratic platform is in the usual tradition. That is to say, it is marked neither by accuracy nor humility and suggests that the world would certainly have declined into purgatory but for the genius of the party in power.

The threat of a Republican primary fight in the Eighteenth Congressional District, now represented by Vito Marcantonio, was dissipated abruptly last night when Peter W. Hoguet, chairman of the Citizens Committee to Defeat Marcantonio, withdrew his candidacy.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (UP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky today crowned and planted a kiss on Anita Kitz of New York as "sweetheart of the Young Democrats."

Shortly before 4 o'clock this afternoon, the white Olympic standard with its five interlocking circles will break out aboard the America, and the flagship of the United States Lines will set sail for London with the main body of one of the strongest teams this country has sent to the athletic wars.

The port's vast shipping industry, concerned over what the proposed city waterfront rehabilitation program would mean to them in the form of increased rentals, is preparing a report on the three plans under consideration, it was made known last night.
The New York Cotton Exchange experienced a fairly active day yesterday and final cotton futures prices were 12 to 25 points net higher.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- An effort to deliver extraordinary punishment to the Mississippi delegation, the most aggressive state in a movement to bolt President Truman in November, was beaten tonight in a harsh and bitter uproar in the Democratic National Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Speakers at the third session of the Democratic National Convention today continued to attack the record of the Republican-controlled Congress, and Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, charged that the Republican party was controlled by "a feudal four -- Taft, Taber, Martin and Halleck."

The war-time expansion of Canadian industry was concentrated in the branches of manufacturing making durable goods and on balance, it seems probable that nearly half of the Government's investment in war productive facilities has found peacetime use, according to the Bank of Nova Scotia's current Review.

Simon Brothers, builders, through their 870 Fifth Avenue Corporation, arranged with the Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford a permanent loan of $2,250,000 for fifteen years on the nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building under construction at the north corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.
PURCHASE, N. Y., July 13 -- The first round of match play today found all the favorites winning handily in the Tri-County women's golf championship being played over the Century Country Club course.

Children and youths under 20 should be confined to bed if they show signs of fever, regardless of cause, during a poliomyelitis epidemic, a pediatrician declared yesterday at the first international poliomyelitis conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Protests against the new Cuban import controls on American textiles were made yesterday to the State Department by the Textile Export Association of the United States. The National Foreign Trade Council also announced that it was studying the regulations and would file a formal protest against any violation of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement with Cuba.
