Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,136, compared with 589 last week and 1,488 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,029 arrivals yesterday against 120 last Tuesday.

Governor Dewey and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio discussed campaign issues and Congressional programs at a dinner conference last night in Mr. Dewey's suite at the Roosevelt Hotel. The discussions were exploratory, with no final decisions.

LONDON, July 13 -- British and American pressure on the Arab states to keep the peace in Palestine, which culminated in Britain's decision to postpone the payment of Trans-Jordan's military subsidy, brought forth an indignant protest today from the Arab Office in London.

William Elliot Griffis, who was the first American educator in the Orient, is the subject of a biography by William Vogel Jr. Entitled "Yankee Schoolmaster in Japan," it will be brought out in the fall by Howell, Soskin. One of Mr. Griffis' sons is Stanton Griffis, now United States Ambassador to Poland.

VIENNA, July 13 -- Sol Hurok, American impresario who has been visiting displaced persons camps under the auspices of the International Refugee Organization, said here today that he intends to arrange a tour of refugee artists in the United States and other countries. He said he had found many excellent musicians, actors and dancers in these camps.

Faced with prosecution for contempt of Congress, officers of Local 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, announced yesterday that they would ask the union's 11,000 members to endorse their refusal to tell a House investigating committee whether they were Communists.
The Greenwich Village Country Fair will start today with an old-and-new village parade around Washington Square, Mrs. Freda B. Hatch and Arnold G. Eckdahl, chairmen of the event, announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, July 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government has marketed a $150,000,000 issue of long-term. 3 per cent bonds privately in the United States, Finance Minister Abbott announced today.

Two little Polish girls traveling alone arrived here yesterday on the Gdynia America liner Batory. They were the victims of an anomalous immigration mix-up that separated them from other members of their Polish-American family.
OTTAWA, July 13 (AP) -- Settlement of the Canadian rail wage crisis before the Thursday morning strike deadline hinged tonight on the Federal Cabinet.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 13 -- Following are excerpts from Count Bernadotte's statement today before the United Nations Security Council:

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., July 13 -- Eight hundred guests inspecting the world's largest wind tunnel and a new supersonic wind tunnel at Ames Aeronautical Laboratory today were informed that supersonic tunnels several times larger than any in existence would be desirable in the interest of progress in aeronautical science.

Thirty-two United States citizens who had been interned by Lebanese authorities in May while on their way to Palestine from New York denied on their return here yesterday that they had intended to fight against the Arabs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Mayor O'Dwyer, who a week ago seemed scheduled to play a leading and anti-Truman role in the Democratic convention, paid a five-hour-and-twenty-minute visit to the general scene of its activities today, then headed back to New York.

Reflecting the improvement in sales, the consolidated net income of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last April increased to $19,614,698 from $15,053,306 earned in the preceding fiscal year, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 13 -- If the United States proposal to invoke Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter is adopted, this will be the first such drastic step that has been taken by the Security Council.

The National Labor Relations Board hearing into alleged unfair labor practices by the National Maritime Union, CIO, was adjourned to next Wednesday after the examination of the first witness just before noon yesterday in the board's offices at 2 Park Avenue.
CONVENTION HALL, Philadelphia, July 13 -- The Democratic national convention became so tumultuous tonight that a strong-arm squad of Philadelphia police finally was called in to restore order.
LONDON, July 13 (UP) -- The Olympic Organizing Committee was flooded today with hundreds of thousands of unsold tickets, mostly from the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Frederick B. Parkes 2d, a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, ruled today that the Taft-Hartley Act's ban on secondary boycotts applied to employes of railroads.

A strike that would cut off normal bus and trolley car service for 1,800,000 riders on lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation is likely to become effective at midnight Friday, City Councilman Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, warned last night.

In the issue of June 26 your paper published a news story on the case of Niccolo Tucci, a writer of Italian nationality, who, by decision of the Federal Court, has been denied American citizenship. The two-column headline described Mr. Tucci as a "Fascist propaganda ex-head here."

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- To insure a better tomorrow, with "peace and security, and a clear road ahead," women party workers must win a Democratic victory next November by creating enthusiastic interest in the Presidential campaign and getting everyone registered, Mrs. Charles F. Brannan, wife of the Secretary of Agriculture, declared here today.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 13 -- Ellis Knowles of the Apawamis Club, Rye, N. Y., won the Metropolitan seniors' golf championship for the second straight time today. He scored a par 72 at the Upper Montclair Country Club course to top a field of seventy-two by seven shots.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, July 14 -- The official text of the 1948 Democratic platform, as approved early today by the party's 108-member Resolutions Committee, subject to ratification of the convention later today, was as follows:
KANSAS CITY, July 13 (AP) -- The embargo on rail shipments of wheat to the Kansas City market probably will be lifted by the end of the week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 13 -- House Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts and Majority Leader Charles A. Halleck of Indiana were accused today of "dictatorial tactics" in blocking Federal aid to education in the Eightieth Congress.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service moved yesterday into the wage dispute between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, as the July 23 deadline nears. Under the present two-year contract between the parties, the union is entitled to strike if an agreement on a wage review is not reached by July 23.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Army and the Air Force, already short of nurses, will require 3,400 more than are currently enrolled to meet the needs of the projected 947,000-man Army and the 502,000-man Air Force authorized under the Selective Service Act, it was announced today.

As a result of the failure of all its previous efforts to establish peace in Palestine, the Security Council of the United Nations has now been called upon to invoke its powers of last resort and to issue a new and this time permanent cease-fire order, backed by the threat of sanctions against all who disobey it.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Bureau of the Budget has made certain recommendations which are expected to settle a fight between the Commerce and State Departments regarding duplication of effort in the field of international trade, it was learned today.

MEXICO CITY, July 13 -- Apparently unsolicited praise and support for Henry A. Wallace's Presidential candidacy was contained in a letter from former President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico, published today by the Communist newspaper Popular, together with Mr. Wallace's reply.

In an effort to further understanding of living conditions and agricultural problems of the Republics of Honduras and Guatemala, the United Fruit Company is sponsoring a tour of the two Middle American countries by a group of twenty-four agricultural experts from the United States Department of Agriculture and leading American colleges and universities, it was made known yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 13 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the Willow Brook Club, the medalist, led the way into the second of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship with a 1-up victory on the 20th hole over Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood, over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course today.

Rayon yarn and staple shipments in June totaled 90,700,000 pounds, an increase of 27 per cent over the corresponding month last year, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Deliveries in the first six months of 1948 amounting to 535,400,000 pounds, were 18 per cent greater than deliveries in the same period in 1947.

BALTIMORE, July 13 (AP) -- Babe Ruth came here today to take part in Interfaith Night festivities at Baltimore Stadium, but rain forced postponement of the annual charity event until tomorrow. The famous baseball player who learned the game on sand lots here will not be able to stay.

TRENTON, N. J., July 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today that he had ordered further investigation into the case of Frank D. Holmes Jr., who resigned as State Director of Navigation yesterday, after criticism of his purchase of a seashore residence near a $1,000,000 beach project he had approved.

LONDON, July 13 -- King George VI and Queen Elizabeth welcomed the bishops attending the Lambeth Conference this morning in a reception at Buckingham Palace. All 329 bishops from the world-wide Anglican communion were present.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 13 -- Political differences between eastern and western European countries came to the surface today and threatened to split the European congress to reallocate radio wave lengths.

Mrs. H. Stanley Goodwin, bridal consultant at Gimbel's, has also been appointed acting buyer of the bridal shop and moderate price evening shop. Lillian Alexander will assume charge of the maternity shop in addition to her present duties as buyer for the Girl Scout shop.

The small hat came off the undisputed fall favorite of the entire industry in the semi-annual show presented last night at the Astor Hotel by the Millinery Stabilization Commission and Millinery Fashion Bureau.

BERLIN, July 13 -- The United States and British Air Forces flew a record tonnage of supplies into besieged Berlin today. At the same time, the Soviet military administration clamped new travel restrictions on the hapless people of the city in the great trial of strength between Western air power and political determination and the inexorable tightening of totalitarian police measures.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 -- The American League's array of diamond luminaries, somewhat riddled by injuries, may not have been able to shine with all its customary glitter today.

Representatives of the U. N.'s International Children's Emergency Fund are gathering in Geneva to program additional help for this youngest human group which suffered the war's worst abuses. Governments which escaped the full brunt of war are in the position of loving these children neither wisely nor well.

A train of nine new subway cars started regular passenger service out of the IRT Main Street station in Flushing yesterday morning at 9:31 o'clock and made three round trips to Times Square during the day. At 5:58 P. M. it was put in the barn for the night.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- To keep himself from being identified with a possible southern bolt, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida withdrew late this afternoon as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "The Street With No Name," a Twentieth Century-Fox topical drama, featuring Richard Widmark, Mark Stevens and Lloyd Nolan.

The stock market surrendered yesterday a good portion of the gains made since the middle of last week and, buffeted by late selling, underwent the sharpest decline so far this month. Early gains in the rails generally were dissipated during the last hour when stock was thrown on the market as a result of the failure of the Interstate Commerce Commission to release its final freight rate decision.
City authorities acted yesterday to avert a threatened tie-up of bus and trolleycar service on lines of Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

Since the end of the Second World War the public has scarcely been aware of the organized efforts being made by various groups to entertain and serve men of the Armed Services in New York City. Minus the stress and emergency of warfare, such organizations perform their work without much publicity.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough, in the United States District Court, today dismissed a petition brought by the Government for an injunction against John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 14--The need for retaining educational control at local levels, from whatever source financial aid might come, was stressed today at the closing sessions of the two-day Harvard summer school conference on educational administration.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- Alex Banazek of Syracuse, who turned in a scorching 66 yesterday for the lost state amateur medal score in years, today was eliminated, 5 and 4, by Ed Sams of Lancaster.

LEWES, England, July 14 -- A four-day Mozart festival began here at Glyndebourne today under the direction of Sir Thomas Beecham. Such a combination of music and director in the lovely setting of Kentish South Downs drew music lovers from London and much further away.

Policemen in a commandeered launch went to the rescue of two men in a disabled seaplane as it drifted yesterday morning in the lower East River and seemed to be heading for a crash into a Brooklyn dock.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday of an issue of $2,000,000 of water main and sewer construction bonds of Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., maturing from July 1, 1949 to 1988. The bid was 100.075 for 4s, 3 1/2s and 3s, an interest cost of 3.049 per cent.

Six seeded players, headed by Billy Talbert and Don McNeill, reached the quarter-finals of the New York State tennis championships along with a pair of unranked players yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

The drama and feeling of spaciousness that a photomural adds to a room can now be had for walls in moderate-budget homes. Photographic wallpapers, available in strips like large scenic papers, have just been introduced by Rembrandt Products, Inc. Photographs suitable in subject and size for walls in average-size rooms have been selected for the new collection by wallpaper designer George Laszlo.

It was a smiling Bucky Harris who alighted at Penn Station late yesterday afternoon from his latest joust with his National League rivals. He seemed to have any number of good reasons to feel in good cheer.

British Securities The Bank of England's new restrictions on the switching of sterling securities by foreigners brought the discount market in such transactions here to a standstill yesterday pending clarification of the ends intended to be effected and the reasons therefor.

LONDON, July 14 -- The Soviet Union rejected the Western powers' demand for the lifting of the blockade of Berlin in notes to Washington, London and Paris delivered today by Soviet Ambassadors in those capitals.

Analysis of the Cuban order restricting purchase of American textiles has revealed no compensatory factors to brighten the pessimistic outlook for exporters here, according to trade sources yesterday.

The stock market made a feeble attempt yesterday to regain lost ground, but the recovery proved selective, although the rails and steels, together with a few of the oils, managed to register major gains. Only in scattered instances were advances of a point or more in evidence at the close, while the composite rate fell 0.04 point.

Henry Ejnar Graversen, 39-year-old merchant marine officer, was held in $50,000 bail to await trial Aug. 13 after he pleaded not guilty in Federal court yesterday to a charge of using the mails to defraud a woman of $17,700.

With food stockpiles in its Berlin warehouses reduced to about one week's supply, the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE), Inc. announced yesterday that its food packages would be flown into the blockaded city from Frankfort on the Main beginning this morning.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices rose 2 to 11 points on the day.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- A stockholder and a dealer today sued in Federal court here to have a receiver appointed for the Tucker Corporation. They alleged that the company, which has been planning a radically new automobile, "is in danger of financial collapse."

PARIS, July 14 -- Workers Force members in the Finance Ministry and a Communist-led labor union, after separate meetings today, both rejected Government proposals and announced they would continue to strike until they had obtained "complete satisfaction."

Higher coal prices on top of other cost increases probably will bring some price increases in specialty paper and board lines, as well as in other paper products, a member of Specialty Paper and Board Affiliates stated yesterday. Prices recently had shown signs of leveling off, he said, adding that the new increases may come on individual items rather than generally.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- Second-round play in the Southern women's golf tournament followed the form chart at Belle Meade Club course today.

President Truman has been nominated at Philadelphia on the first ballot, but the strange coalition of unlike forces held together through four elections by his predecessor has been badly split. Factionalism and disunity have developed within the Democratic party since it last met in national convention at Chicago.
Harry S. Truman was elevated to the Presidency by a series of accidents, against his on wishes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -President Truman arrived at Convention Hall at 9:41 o'clock tonight.

A new apparatus for developing and strengthening muscles in victims of infantile paralysis, which has doubled the power of the remaining healthy muscle fibers in limbs in the first four to eight weeks of treatment, was demonstrated yesterday at the first international poliomyelitis conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

F. W. Woolworth Co. warehouse employes who are members of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted last night at their headquarters, 13 Astor Place, to request the full membership of the union's Local 65 to authorize a strike against the company.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Federal District Court here today to dismiss a petition to enjoin the agency from conducting any further public investigation of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

CLEVELAND, July 14 -- An astonishing crowd of 64,877 jammed into big Municipal Stadium tonight to see the Dodgers and Indians meet in this city for the first time since 1920, when these teams were the world series contenders -- and received a great show.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Tom Brown of San Francisco and Jack Tuero of New Orleans, seeded No. 1 and 2 respectively, both were forced into deuce sets today before advancing to the quarterfinals of the national clay court tennis championships at the River Forest club.

After several weeks of negotiations, Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres, the organization of theatre owners, operators and producers, have agreed on a new basic contract. Although both sides refused to divulge the details of the new pact, it is understood that the performers obtained material increases in minimum pay.

John D. Benedito has been appointed manager of the newly-created extrusion and molding materials division, thermoplastics department of the Bakelite Corporation, unit of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

Governor Dewey, the Republican candidate for President, charged yesterday that the Democratic platform as adopted at Philadelphia contained "extremely partisan and provocative assertions concerning foreign affairs."

HAMILTON, Ontario, July 14 (AP) -- The defending champion, Frank Stranahan, of Toledo, Ohio, showed the way today as the field was narrowed to sixteen in the Canadian amateur golf championship. The young Ohio shotmaker, winner of the British amateur crown this spring, breezed through two matches to lead four Americans into the fourth round.
Lazard Freres Co., one of the oldest investment banking firms in the country, today is celebrating the one hundredth anniversary of its founding in New Orleans in July, 1848.

Right-wing unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced yesterday that they would not take part in a mass picketing demonstration called by CIO leftists to protest the House investigation into Communist influence in New York department store unions.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with a great deal of interest a letter written by Harry M. Prince, which appeared recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ROME, July 14 -- The promptness and firmness of the Italian Government today prevented what police officials said might have been a Communist attempt to plunge Italy into a civil war, following the attempted assassination of Palmiro Togliatti.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Closing of spreads between July corn and wheat featured trading on the Board of Trade here today. July corn was in good demand, advancing 3 1/2 cents to $2.08 1/2 a bushel, or 11 7/8 cents above the low last week, while July wheat was sold.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Chances for reopening the long-closed Belasco Theatre as a legitimate playhouse dimmed today as it became known that the Federal Works Administrator had rejected the two bids made for the government-owned building.

As New York and Paris celebrated Quatorze Juillet, the French holiday marking the fall of the Bastille in 1789, Air France started yesterday the first scheduled Atlantic service to and from the vast New York International Airport at Idlewild.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -Howard Lanim, leader of the sixty-piece band at the Democratic National Convention, reported tonight that he was twice approached by men who offered him "substantial sums" to strike up "Dixie" at certain strategic times during tonight's session in the Municipal Auditorium.

For the second time within a week, a city marshal, assisted by his aides, returned furniture yesterday to a five-room apartment on the second floor of a tenement at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, involving a landlord-tenant dispute over rent.

PASADENA, Calif., July 14 -Leaders of Catholic youth must teach their charges that "moral living is the only true key to real happiness," the Rev. Ralph Garvey of Brooklyn, national junior chaplain of the Catholic Daughters of America, said today.

In its first change of ownership since 1881, the eight-story and penthouse building at 3 Maiden Lane was sold by the United States Trust Company, as trustee of the Byam K. Stevens Estate to the Dormur Realty Corporation in a transaction reported yesterday by M. L. Hess, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -An Ohio manufacturer charged today there was a "smell of favoritism" about a Government proposal to set aside 59,000 tons of steel for construction of all-steel prefabricated houses.

The largest ocean liners of the American and British merchant fleets, the America of the United States Lines and the Queen Elizabeth of Cunard White Star, were among the ships passing through New York Harbor yesterday.
The nation's gasoline stocks decreased 1,197,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The vacant irregular plot about 88 by 320 feet on the south side of Mott Avenue near McBridge Street in Far Rockaway, Queens, has been purchased by Quinboro Builders, Inc., from Charles Charkin. The Lewis H. May Company was the brokers.

The United Parents Associations denied newspaper reports yesterday that it had been represented at Tuesday's hearing of the Board of Superintendents on the banning of The Nation from the New York public schools.

ROME, Thursday, July 15 -Palmiro Togliatti, Italy's Communist chief, was shot three times yesterday morning outside the Chamber of Deputies by a university student who fired four revolver bullets at him at point-blank range.
LONDON, July 14 (UP) -- Following is the text of the Moscow radio broadcast of the Soviet Government's reply to the United States note of July 6 protesting against the land blockade of Berlin:

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- The South arrived today at its second Appomattox. The non-Southern majority in the Democratic National Convention first rejected its proposed reassertion in the platform of the principle of states' rights and then specifically endorsed the Federal "civil rights" legislative program of President Truman.

Railroads serving the Port of New York have rejected a feature of the proposed waterfront rehabilitation program that would include consolidation of rail activities in a series of carfloat stations, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The mandatory sentence of death for courtmartial conviction of the crimes of murder and rape, military law throughout this country's history, will be abolished by the Army under new courtmartial procedures announced today, and to become effective next Feb. 1.

TRENTON, N. J., July 14 -- Emergency housing has been provided in New Jersey for 4,378 veterans and their families, it was announced today. State-supervised construction of 2,804 more home units is in progress under a program in which nearly $40,000,000 of a $41,000,000 program has been committed or spent.

The Liebert showroom, 19 West Fifty-seventh Street, was well filled yesterday afternoon, for it was the first time in four years that Helen Liebert has formally presented a millinery collection. It was a large one in which the designer presented many ideas.

Directors of the Curtiss-Wright Aircraft Corporation voted dividends of $2 a share yesterday on the company's common stock and $1 a share on its Class A stock and announced a tentative plan to make the same disbursements next year.

The Hebrew University on Mount Scopus in Jerusalem will not move, Dr. Alexander Geiger, head of the department of physiology, announced yesterday. At a news conference in the headquarters of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 9 East Eighty-ninth Street, he explained that by remaining there, the university would serve as an "anchor" for Jews in Jerusalem.
LONDON, July 14 -- Although the stock market here today still was awaiting news about the Soviet's reply to the three-power notes on the Berlin situation, there was a slight improvement in business.

With throngs of well-wishers crowding the pier, the main contingent of the United States Olympic team, numbering 260 athletes and forty-four authorized officials for thirteen sports, sailed yesterday aboard the S. S. America, bound for London, where the games of the XIV Olympiad of the modern era will be celebrated from July 29 to Aug. 14.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 14 -- A bilateral treaty between the bizonal area and the United Sates on the European Recovery Program was signed this morning after a compromise had been reached in the dispute over administering of the funds.

Paul F. Heard, executive producer for the Protestant Film Commission, has sign Edward Cahn to direct a feature film dealing with racial prejudice which is slated to go before the cameras on Aug. 2. The script is being written by Ivan Goff and Ben Roberts.

Chests of drawers made of fiberboard and often relegated to closets for storing accessories and out-of-season clothing are now being made in plain colors and simple designs so that they can take their place in any bedroom scheme. Two new series of storage pieces, one for nurseries and the other for bedrooms, dressing rooms or even college quarters, were shown yesterday by E-Z-Do Distributors, Inc., 261 Fifth Avenue.

DETROIT, July 14 -- Negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, CIO, moving toward a Thursday deadline, were terminated tonight when the union refused to accept the company's "final offer" and the company gave only short shrift to a counter proposal by the union.

TOKYO, July 14 -- A statement from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today renewed charges that the Soviet Union had failed to observe its agreement for the repatriation of Japanese war prisoners as provided by the Potsdam Declaration.

Directors of the Skelly Oil Company yesterday declared a 10 per cent common stock dividend payable Sept. 24. The dividend amounts to 98,135 shares of common which will increase the number of shares outstanding to 1,079,476 after the distribution.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Speakers at the fifth session of the Democratic National Convention, including A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, and James Roosevelt, eldest son of the late President and National Committeeman from California, demanded immediate repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.
Tweeds in rich colors and fine worsteds in stripes and solid colors won applause yesterday in the showing of John Walther, Inc., fabrics for fall at the Cottage of the Hampshire House.

CLAYTON, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -Three seaman lost their lives in the St. Lawrence River early today as the aftermath of an argument between two of the victims, Milton A. Wiltse, Jefferson County District Attorney, reported.

NEWARK, N. J., July 14 -While ex-Judge P. James Pellecchia, confessed embezzler of more than $630,000 from the Columbus Trust Company here, spent the day in the Essex County Jail with men he had sentenced there, Federal and State officials acted today to assure the bank's 7,000 depositors against loss.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -American exports to Russia dropped to $200,000 in May, the smallest amount in thirteen years, the Census Bureau announced today.

Paul A. Porter and John Harlan Amen will conduct the proceedings when the major planks in the political party platforms come up for examination during the next sixteen weeks of WJZ-ABC's "On Trial." The sessions will open Wednesday at 10:30 o'clock, when the moot court series switches to an evening period after having been heard Sundays at 12:30 P. M.

The National Urban League announced yesterday that since the beginning of its pilot placement project in January twenty skilled Negro workers had been employed by seventeen leading industrial and commercial concerns.
The Department of State has abolished its Shipping Division as a result of criticism from the Appropriations Committees of Congress, it was made known here yesterday.

The heart of Greenwich Village dropped the artists and Village personalities from the spotlight yesterday and let parading babies take over, as the Greenwich Village First Annual Country Fair opened a five-day run at the Avenue of the Americas and Waverly Place.

"Early Tales of the Atomic Age," by Daniel Lang, a collection of stories about the development of the atomic laboratories at Oak Ridge and Los Alamos, will be published by Doubleday Aug. 5. The stories are expansions of Mr. Lang's articles that appeared in The New Yorker. Carl Van Doren has supplied an introduction.

In 1941 Ben F. Whitaker's Requested won the six-furlong Great American Stakes in 1:12 2/5. Yesterday at Aqueduct, where the fifty-eighth edition of the sprint for 2-year-olds went to press, one of Requested's sons, bred and owned by the Dallas sportsman and named Prince Quest, also did 1:12 2/5, and it was good for first money by close to four lengths.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Democratic platform's labor plank failed to evoke any immediate comment from the country's top labor leaders today.

JERUSALEM, July 14 -- Two more strategic Arab villages, Maliha, three miles southwest of Jerusalem, and Sar'a, south of Bab el Wad, fell last night to Israeli forces in their continued drive to relieve the Holy City's 100,000 Jewish inhabitants from Arab pressure. Irgun Zvai Leumi units cooperated at Maliha.

The 139th annual report of the French Benevolent Society of New York and the French Hospital, made public yesterday, said that "in common with practically all voluntary hospitals, most of our efforts throughout the year 1947 were directed toward finding a solution for the financial problems imposed on us by greatly increased costs."

THE light-hearted, humorous and talkative Birdie Tebbetts is having a very good year for himself and is far and away the most competent workman behind the plate in the American League. One of his favorite enemy pitchers has been Vic Raschi of the Yankees and for no discernible reason. Be that as it may, though, the Red Sox catcher has always hit the big right-hander as if he owned him.

New issues of industrial, public utility and railroad securities consisting of $99,250,000 of bonds and convertible debentures and of $2,127,500 of common and preferred stock will be offered to investors today by underwriters as follows:

Supreme Court Justice Carroll petition brought by a group of weekly tenants of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, to void a 30 per cent rent increase authorized by the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Registration statements covering 465,000 shares of preferred and 400,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.
The western tip of Coney Island, including Sea Gate, and South Beach on Staten Island are "polluted" and "not recommended for bathing," Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the issuance of $3,500,000 of Chesapeake and Ohio fifth equipment trust of 1948, 2 3/8 per cent equipment trust certificates to be issued by the Bank of The Manhattan Company, and sold at 99.5101 and accrued dividends, to cover most of the cost of certain equipment.
Following is the text of Senator Alben W. Barkley's acceptance speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, July 14 -- The internal inflation in Britain has been checked, and reverse tendencies are becoming apparent in several domestic markets, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, stated today. He said at a news conference that the current conditions represented "only the first step" in the stabilization policies outlined by the Labor Government early in April.
ATHENS, July 14 -- Statements on the rebel radio today had many of the earmarks of a peace feeler similar to that put forward before the current military operations.

Messages from French officials and Mayor O'Dwyer were featured in a Bastille Day broadcast last night over Station WQXR. The greetings were heard in transcription form or read during a program sponsored by France Amerique, French weekly newspaper here, in cooperation with the French Broadcasting System in North America.

BERLIN, Thursday, July 15 -The Western Powers met the Soviet refusal to raise the siege of Berlin with a record number of air supply flights carrying a record tonnage and solid determination, generally expressed this morning, to keep the Western flags flying in the city.

The three marine hospitals in the New York area will hold open house tomorrow in observance of the 150th anniversary of the United States Public Health Service which operates these institutions as well as the United States Public Health Service Dispensary at 67 Hudson Street.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, First Army commander, made a tour of inspection today among National Guardsmen and Reservists training at this northern New York Military Reservation.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- The text of the 1948 Democratic platform adopted by the national convention today was as follows:

Serious shortages of electrical appliances using steel as a major component will occur in the fall, retailers predicted yesterday. They based the forecast on conversations with top producers who have been notified by steel suppliers that steel quotas for the last six months of the year will be cut.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky was nominated by acclamation early today as the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, leading even President Truman as the overwhelming choice of the delegates to the party's thirtieth national convention.

PARIS, July 14 -- With parades, fireworks and street dancing, the people of France today celebrated their national holiday, Bastille Day. While a large majority of the population simply had a good time at the expense of the Government, a great many took advantage of the day to further their political ends.
Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Democratic party's choice for Vice President, rose from a humble beginning to play a leading role in Congress during some of the gravest crises in American history.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman departed for his rendezvous with the Democratic National Convention at 7 P. M., Eastern daylight time, tonight to make his speech accepting the Presidential nomination at about 10 P. M., Eastern daylight time.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- Tass, the official Soviet news agency, made public today a new decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. raising rates for the agricultural tax, an income tax levied on noncollectivized incomes of Russian farmers.

Employers and union leaders of the trucking industry here formed tentative groups yesterday for negotiating 3,280 new labor contracts to head off possible strikes when existing agreements end Aug. 31.

St. Swithin, who annually threatens the populace with rain for forty days, when, as and if it should rain on his own particular day -- that being July 15 -- probably has been de-activated for this year, the Weather Bureau indicated yesterday.

MADRID, July 14 -- The Spanish Cortes stood and cheered President Juan D. Peron and Argentina repeatedly today as Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo reported on the 1,750,000,000 peso Franco-Peron commercial agreement. [The Argentine peso was quoted in New York yesterday at 20.20 cents.]

Two East Side structures changed hands for the first time since their erection when the six-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Fortieth Street and the adjoining four-story building at 441 Third Avenue were sold Estate of Catherine L. Lowther to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators.
The Peter Stuyvesant of the Hudson River Day Line cast off yesterday morning from Forty-first Street for Indian Point with 800 students and alumni of "The School of Another Chance."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Soviet Government replied today to the demand of the United States for the immediate lifting of the Berlin blockade with a note that was regarded here as leaving the Berlin situation unchanged.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 14 -- In an obvious double-barreled attempt to split the Arab armies on the northern and central fronts, Israeli armored units were moving on Nazareth after their infantry had captured important Arab strongholds on its northern flank.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- A hot, tired and politically weary New York State delegation cast 83 votes early this morning for the nomination of Harry S. Truman for President, and 15 votes for James A. Roe, the Queens Democratic County chairman who temporarily joined the ranks of Presidential contestants.

While many difficulties still beset the development of Japanese trade, indications are that the foreign trade division of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers will permit Japanese manufacturers to do direct selling under the supervision of Boeki-Cho, the Japanese Board of Trade, Walter M. Schapiro of the Joshua J. Schapiro Company, Inc., foreign traders here, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- Democratic delegates and galleries fliled with guests paid dignified tribute at 1:30 A. M. to President Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley as they came to Convention Hall platform to accept their nominations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -The signing of Dore Schary to a long-term contract, understood to be for seven years, as vice president in charge of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was confirmed today by Louis B. Mayer, head of the studio.

BOSTON, Mass., July 14 -- The announcement today that Howard S. Palmer, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, had requested retirement on Aug. 12, brought the disclosure that Frederic C. Dumaine, 82-year-old Boston financier, would take over control at that time.

The nomination of Senator Barkley as the Democratic candidate for Vice President is an effort to conciliate all factions of a not too united party. Senator Barkley is neither "left" nor "right." He does not speak for the South against the North or for the North against the South.

BERLIN, July 14 -- The first important break in the coalition Land [State] governments in the Soviet zone appeared in the making today as both the Christian Democratic and Liberal Democratic parties adopted surprisingly vigorous resolutions condemning the actions of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party.
OTTAWA, July 14 -- Canada's threatened railroad strike, due to begin tomorrow, has been called off.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A steadily increasing inflation -- with at least one brake on high prices due to loosen soon -- was reported today by a Congressional economic committee.
GENEVA, July 14 -- A committee was appointed by the World Health Organization today to consider the percentages of payments to be made by its member nations toward the organization's support.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Army will abolish on August 1 its complicated system of grading higher enlisted men and substitute a simple system of five types of non-commissioned officers ranging from private first class to master sergeant.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 (AP) -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake today approved an application by the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to submit a new plan of reorganization to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- The Democratic National Convention, by a roaring voice vote, committed its party today to what was called a straightaway Roosevelt-Truman platform for 1948. In scenes of emotional demonstration, with Southern Democrats pleading rather than demanding as Northern liberals were firmly in the saddle, the document was changed at only one point.
Canadian immigration authorities released yesterday nine Americans forced down Sunday near Halifax, N.S., in an Army surplus B-17 plane and levied a $100 fine on the ship for illegal entry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 14 -- Australia informed the United Nations Trusteeship Council today that the Papua-New Guinea Administration Union, which was born of necessity during the second World War, must be continued in the future for the good of both territories.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard dismissed yesterday a $300,000 anti-trust suit brought against organized baseball by Daniel L. Gardella, former New York Giant outfielder, but he indicated that there was a strong possibility the United States Supreme Court might reverse him and declare the baseball clubs and leagues to be engaged in interstate commerce.

The New York City Youth Board and the Board of Transportation are arranging free rides on the municipal transit lines for supervised groups of children visiting public parks and beaches, Nathaniel Kaplan, chairman of the youth agency, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 7: Decreases of $235,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $167,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $192,000,000 in United States Government deposits; and increases of $212,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks and $278,000,000 in borrowings.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 14 -- The Soviet Union and four other countries gave their support today to a United States proposal that the United Nations Security Council invoke Chapter VII of the Charter and order both sides to stop the fighting in Palestine.
Reporting on operations for the six months ended with June, the Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday a net income of $1,871,486 after taxes and all charges.

Coffee exports from Colombia have dropped considerably in recent weeks due mainly to current United States quotations being lower than the official registration price fixed by the Colombian Government. This was learned yesterday from a report made by the National City Bank of Medellin, Colombia, to the National Coffee Association.

Just as cooks argue that meat makes the meal, so merchandisers claim that meat makes the market. Yesterday at a preview of the Grand Union Company's newest store, at 4776 Broadway, just north of Dyckman Street, a representative of the concern said:

I. Foreign Policy So far as the paramount issue of foreign policy is concerned, the Democrats had one advantage over the Republicans in the drafting of a party platform. The Democrats at least knew who their candidate was to be, and could shape their plans accordingly. The Republicans had no such certain knowledge.

LONDON, July 14 -- A British Government spokesman asserted today that British authorities were doing their utmost to obtain a renewal of the truce in Palestine and voiced the "earnest hope" that the Arab League statesmen would change their minds about renewing the fight in the Holy Land.

KANSAS CITY, July 14 (AP) -- The University of Kansas got back in the good graces of the Big Seven Conference today by ending its defiance of an eligibility rule that had threatened to interrupt athletic relations with six other member schools.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 14 -- Dr. Aake Ording, director of the United Nations Appeal for Children, expressed confidence today that, despite the slow progress of the appeal drive in this country, the American people would give full support to the global drive to help 230,000,000 underfed children.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech by Gov. Phil M. Donnelly of Missouri nominating President Truman as the Democratic Presidential nominee:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 (UP) -- Counsel for Henry A. Wallace's third party today denied before the Ohio Supreme Court charges that five of the ten members of the Ohio-Wallace-for-President Committee were Communist or fellow travelers.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The problem of leadership will be one of the Army's biggest headaches in the expansion that will start with the first draft inductions on Sept. 22.

Dr. Oswald Glasberg, 49 years old, of 115 East Seventy-second Street, a plastic surgeon, and Dr. Paul Singer, 43, of 944 Park Avenue, a gynecologist, were found guilty of manslaughter in General Sessions Court at 11:30 o'clock last night after having been tried on charges of causing the death of Jane Ward, bakery heiress, by an abortion.
Following is the text of President Truman's acceptance speech as recorded and transcribed last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- President Truman accepted the Democratic Presidential nomination in a fighting mood this morning, predicted victory in November and announced that he would call Congress back into session on July 26 to deal with housing, education, civil rights and other controversial measures.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 14 -At least 180 of New Jersey's heat-tired business men began this afternoon to commute on the Central Railroad of New Jersey in air-conditioned comfort of their own buying.

Isidore Ginsberg, attorney and building materials broker who was described as the "most vicious of gray marketeers" at a Congressional inquiry last January, was sentenced to one to five years' imprisonment yesterday in Queens County Court after he had failed in an effort to set aside a conviction for grand larceny.
NEW HAVEN, July 14 (AP) -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced today that its president, Howard S. Palmer, has asked to be retired, effective on Aug. 12.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 14 -Upsets galore marked the second and third rounds of match play in the fourth Tri-County women's golf championship over the tough Century Country Club course today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 14 -At least 180 of New Jersey's heat-tired business men began this afternoon to commute on the Central Railroad of New Jersey in air-conditioned comfort of their own buying.

Isidore Ginsberg, attorney and building materials broker who was described as the "most vicious of gray marketeers" at a Congressional inquiry last January, was sentenced to one to five years' imprisonment yesterday in Queens County Court after he had failed in an effort to set aside a conviction for grand larceny.

The Appellate Division denied a motion yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board to restrain R.H. Macy Co. from paying a triple-time bonus of $243,994 to 3,000 employes who crossed the picket lines to work in the store during the drivers' strike in July, 1946, when that company transferred its delivery system to the United Parcel Service.

LONDON, July 14 -- New light is thrown on one of the most controversial strategical decisions of World War II in a report by Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson (now Field Marshal Lord Wilson) on the Italian campaign. It was issued today.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- The eleven states of the old Confederate South gave today to the nomination of President Truman only thirteen of their 278 votes in the Democratic national convention.

PARIS, July 14 -- A plan to use dollars to stimulate intra-European trade, which had been hailed as the greatest step yet in European cooperation, failed to be approved by the executive committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation after a long discussion today.

Progress of invention threatens soon to bring to an end what has been ever one of the most necessary and pleasant activities of the gardener. There are some who hail the development of a chemical weed-killer as a great boon to those who battle nature in several directions at once in order to grow flowers or vegetables, or both.

Spotty price increases were registered yesterday at several points along the city's meat supply-lines. New fuel advances also were announced. And three separately compiled price indices reporting on specific segments of the nation's economy reached new peaks.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 14 -- The Riverside Yacht Club entry, skippered by Miss Judy Webb, captured the second race of the series for the girls' yacht racing championship over the Pequot Club course today to take the lead in the five-race series.

Worshipers in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning were unaware that twenty-five policemen were searching the edifice on a telephoned warning that a bomb was set to explode there shortly before noon. After a fruitless two-hour search, the police were convinced that the call was from a crank.

BUFFALO, July 14 -- The Right Rev. Edward E. Swanstrom of New York City, chairman of the National Catholic Resettlement Council, said here today that council members were agreed that the law permitting the entrance of 205,000 displaced persons to this country "is not discriminatory as far as Catholics are concerned despite statements to the contrary in the press."

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- President Harry S. Truman won nomination for a full term in the Democratic National Convention early today and promptly made the Republican record in Congress the 1948 key issue by calling a special session of Congress to meet July 26 to challenge the GOP to keep its platform pledges.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 14 -- The Riverside Yacht Club entry, skippered by Miss Judy Webb, captured the second race of the series for the girls' yacht racing championship over the Pequot Club course today to take the lead in the five-race series.

Worshipers in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning were unaware that twenty-five policemen were searching the edifice on a telephoned warning that a bomb was set to explode there shortly before noon. After a fruitless two-hour search, the police were convinced that the call was from a crank.

BUFFALO, July 14 -- The Right Rev. Edward E. Swanstrom of New York City, chairman of the National Catholic Resettlement Council, said here today that council members were agreed that the law permitting the entrance of 205,000 displaced persons to this country "is not discriminatory as far as Catholics are concerned despite statements to the contrary in the press."

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, July 15 -- President Harry S. Truman won nomination for a full term in the Democratic National Convention early today and promptly made the Republican record in Congress the 1948 key issue by calling a special session of Congress to meet July 26 to challenge the GOP to keep its platform pledges.

Advertising in the eight major New York newspapers totaled 74,265,626 lines during the first six months of thin year, a gain of 5.24 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotives, up 29.43 per cent, and retail, 8.07.

Formation of the American-Indonesian Corporation has been approved by the Republic of Indonesia as part of the "republic's broad program to rehabilitate and develop Indonesian economy," it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Soemitro, financial and trade representative plenipotentiary here of the republic.

Slightly more than two-thirds of all companies cooperating in the latest survey of business practices conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board reported that physical output per man hour at their plants now exceeds that of a year ago, it was announced yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON L.I., July 14 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, three-time winner of the title, moved into the semifinals of the Women's Long Island Golf championship today by eliminating Miss Evelyn Odom of Wheatley Hills, finalist a year ago, by a 4-and-2 margin over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 14 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha returned to Cairo this afternoon after consultations with King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, the Premiers of Lebanon and Syria and other Arab leaders and immediately reported to King Farouk at Abdin Palace.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 -- Final breakdown in the defense of the steel industry against the "third round" of wage increases appeared imminent here today when the CIO United Steel Workers scheduled a meeting of the 171-member wage-policy committee for Friday to consider the "present wage situation."
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -Comparisons between the major planks of the 1948 Democratic and Republican platforms follow:
LACLEDE, Mo., July 15 (AP) -- This town of 700 in north central Missouri today mourned the death of its most famous son, General John J. Pershing.

PURCHASE, N. Y., July 15 -- Mrs. Richard P. Limburg of Century and Miss Kay Byrne of Westchester Hills will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Tri- County women's golf championship over the Century Country Club course tomorrow.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 15 -- Abdul Rahmam Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, proposed today a three-point formula for the establishment of a long-term truce in Palestine by placing the contested area within an international cordon sanitaire and thereby "freezing" the situation until a basis for a satisfactory permanent settlement can be obtained.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Atomic Energy Commission cleared Dr. Edward U. Condon today after a new investigation of the scientist under the commission's security standards.

Non-scheduled Puerto Rican traffic overflowed into New York International Airport at Idlewild yesterday when a twin-engined C-46 Curtiss Commando landed fifty-eight passengers from its large freight cabin. Many of them were children and infants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- A 29-year-old Norwegian Navy veteran, who volunteered to serve as a member of the United Nations guard detachment in Palestine, was killed on Tuesday afternoon, according to word received here from the Holy Land.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Mr. Truman, accepting on the spot early today the Presidential nomination of the Democratic National Convention, spoke as a politician and a party candidate rather than as President of the whole people in a critical time. His speech was an assumption of calculated risks.

In a surprise purchase reported to be in keeping with its long-range expansion and building plans for the blocks facing Washington Square, New York University has acquired the so-called "genius row" block on the south side of the square, it became known last night.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 15 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the Willow Brook Club, medalist with a 72, and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, the defending titleholder, were successful in the semi-final round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Wheatley Hills Club course today.

Blyth Co., Inc., will offer to investors today an issue of $13,500,000 of National Fuel Gas Company 3 per cent sinking fund debentures due on July 1, 1973 at 101.769 to yield about 2.90 per cent. The banking house bought the bond issue at competitive sale Wednesday at a bid of 101.27, the best of five submitted.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 15 -- The fully clad body of a man identified as Emanuel Kaplan, 59 years old, prominent textile manufacturer and industrial counsellor of 1112 Park Avenue, New York, was found floating in Long Island Sound today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- Invoking Chapter VII of the Charter for the first time in the history of the United Nations, the Security Council tonight ordered Israel and the seven member states of the Arab League to stop the fighting in Palestine within three days and in Jerusalem within twenty-four hours.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- Lefty Mel Parnell knocked in two runs with a double while pitching the Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Tigers in the floodlighted half of a day-night double-header tonight before 33,892 fans. A crowd of 14,403 saw Boston trounce Detroit, 13 -- 5, in the sunlight.

The warring factions in Tammany Hall returned from the Democratic National Convention yesterday with both sides in the mood to name a compromise candidate for Surrogate. Their fear was that former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican candidate, would have an easy road to victory if the Tammany chieftains and Mayor O'Dwyer continued their party feud.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment of several newspapers over the country on the national ticket and platform of the Democratic party and on President Truman's call for a special session of Congress:

" Key Largo," which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Warner Brothers adaptation of the Maxwell Anderson play stars Humphrey Bogart, his wife, Lauren Bacall, and Edward G. Robinson. John Huston directed and Jerry Wald produced the drama from a screen play written by Huston and Richard Brooks.

The Soviet reply to the protest notes of the Western Powers against the blockade of Berlin marks a further aggravation of the situation. For that reply not only flatly rejects the Western demand for an immediate lifting of the blockade but also advances contentions which can leave no further doubt regarding Russian intentions.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Sales of department stores for the week ended July 10 were down 4 per cent compared with the like period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. Percentage changes from corresponding periods of last year are indicated in the following table:

The need of Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street, for capital donations and legacies and for the establishment of memorial funds to enable it to carry on its great work is emphasized in the annual report of the institution. In 1947 receipts from patients totaling $2,383,508 failed by $1,831,573 to offset operating costs for the year of $4,215,081.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Congress was recalled for a special session at noon on Monday, July 26, in a proclamation which President Truman issued today. His action followed by about twelve hours his challenge to the Republicans to make good on the pledges of their convention platform.

It is difficult to understand the current problem of Yugoslavia -- the possible shifting from communism to democracy, from East to West -- without taking into account the country's historical background. Although, in my opinion, about 90 per cent of the population favors democratic freedom against Communist tyranny, how explain the fact that Tito and his group still retain their position ?

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Gen. John J. Pershing, Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in the first World War and sole bearer of the rank General of the Armies, died here early today in his quarters at Walter Reed General Hospital.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Although the airplane sound-speed "barrier" has been breached, practical operation in this realm will be impossible until better facilities for pilots are devised, some of the country's leading speed flyers informed the aviation industry tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Encouraged by President Truman's early morning fighting speech and with speakers predicting victory for the national ticket, the Democratic National Committee today re-elected Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island as chairman and all the other officers of the committee at a luncheon meeting in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A mass of tributes to General John J. Pershing, who died here early today, emphasized repeatedly President Truman's own statement, made in announcing the general's death, that "the nation will ever hold him in grateful remembrance."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- The Screen Directors Guild and the film producers have agreed on the terms of a new contract to replace the pact which expired last March. The contract, which covers the principal independent producers as well, runs for eight years with a no-strike clause and provides for 100 per cent guild shop through August, 1956.

It is peculiarly appropriate that the list of training divisions and units to be reactivated with the help of the draft include the designations of most of the Army's famous wartime airborne divisions.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- British Isles, a 4-year-old Irish-bred colt owned by William G. Helis of New Orleans, showed a fondness for the grass course by winning the $23,300 Grassland Handicap at Arlington Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Exports to countries getting aid through the Economic Cooperation Administration were about five times greater in value during May than United States imports from them.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended July 10, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index set a new post-war peak of 166.8 per cent of the 1926 average which was 1.2 per cent above four weeks ago and 12.5 per cent above the corresponding week of a year ago.

BUFFALO, July 15 (AP) -- Alec Stevenson of Niagara Falls withstood a sensational recovery by the defending titleholder, Dick Mayer of Mamaroneck, today to knock the champion from the state amateur golf tournament, 1 up, in nineteen holes.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 10, 1948, totaled 755,760 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,606 cars, or 0.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 51,357 cars, or 6.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 139,322 cars, or 15.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Opening of woolen and worsted lines for spring 1949 will be delayed this year, according to manufacturers, as the result of bids made for Army serges. Wool goods producers who have entered bids on 5,000,000 yards of serge said they could not take commitments until the awards were made.

Rear Admiral Arthur H. Dearing, Third Naval District Medical Officer, presented certificates of achievement to thirty-nine New York and New Jersey chemical and medical supply companies at a ceremony yesterday at 90 Church Street.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko vanished abruptly today from the diplomatic scene here.

The General Electric Company and its consolidated affiliates had a net income in the first six months of this year of $54,602,339, equal to $1.89 a common share, Charles E. Wilson, president, reported yesterday for publication today. The income is 28 per cent larger than the $42,802,075 or $1.48 a share earned in the initial half of last year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The arena for the South's protests against President Truman's nomination on a strong civil rights platform was transferred today from Philadelphia to Birmingham.

The Chemical Fund, Inc., which on July 6 completed its tenth year of operations, reports total net assets, as of June 30, of $25,683,934. This is equal to $14.39 a share on 1,743,599 outstanding shares, compared with $23,249,247 or $13.33 a share on March 31.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The body of General of the Armies John J. Pershing will lie in state in the rotunda of the Capitol on Sunday and Monday.

John Joseph Pershing, Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in the first World War, entered the military service -- in which he was to rise to the summit of distinction -- almost by accident, for he was planning to be a lawyer when he saw the announcement of an examination for admittance to West Point which changed his career.

Aroused by the failure of the city authorities to heed their pleas for relief from dumping malodorous garbage and other refuse in a Jamaica Bay inlet in the Marine Park district of Brooklyn, 150 men, women and children living in the vicinity of Avenue U and Flat-bush Avenues formed a human roadblock on Avenue U last night and for a short time prevented garbage trucks from going to and from the dump.

Joseph Kuhn, 39 years old, of 469 West 166th Street, waived examination for action of the Queens Grand Jury when arraigned yesterday in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood, on a felonious assault charge. The defendant, who was held in $5,000 bail, was accused of having shot three persons with a policeman's revolver.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Truman's proclamation on the death of General Pershing reads as follows:

BERLIN, July 15 -- The pilots engaged in "operation vittles" -- the airy supply of Berlin -- were happy today. It was practically the first time since June 22 that "Clay's pigeons" were able to fly for any length of time by visual flight rules rather than by instrument control.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week recovered somewhat from the relatively low level in the week ended July 3, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Practically all the gain was due to resumption of bituminous coal production in the commercial mines.

Accused of attempting to evict a tenant for the third time in a week, in defiance of a decision of the Office of Rent Control and a Municipal Court ruling. Stephen Toth, landlord of the building at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, was arraigned before Magistrate Henri Schwob in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

The six-story fifty-nine-family apartment house at 1650 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Jean Bromberg from Dora Kaufman. The property occupies a plot 100 by 151 feet near Avenue L. Katz Sacks were the brokers. Joseph H. Ginsberg was attorney for the buyer, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned downward yesterday, and final prices were 17 to 25 points net lower.

Directors of Texas Gulf Sulphur Company yesterday voted a dividend of 75 cents a share and an additional dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Sept. 15. Previous payments this year were 50 cents each in March and June and extras of 50 cents in March and 75 cents in June.
High production costs and tax uncertainties have combined to inspire a novel deal that cancels announced plans for opening a new musical comedy here in favor of putting it on first in London.

A 24-year-old Bronx rapist, convicted more than a month ago, was sentenced yesterday to serve from thirty-five to seventy years in jail on four separate counts of rape, robbery, burglary and assault. Bronx County Judge Samuel Joseph, in imposing sentence, described the man as a menace who "must be obliterated from our society."

General of the Armies John J. Pershing was 81 years old when the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor and Germany declared war on his country. He immediately offered his services "to the last ounce of my strength." In accepting, President Roosevelt told him: "You are magnificent.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- John L. Lewis today called upon Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to advocate repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law even though it means scrapping the Wagner Act which it amended.

LONDON, July 15 -- Unless they are wanted by United States authorities, the last two members of the German High Command who still are detained in this country as prisoners of war will be sent to Germany in a few days and released from captivity, the British War Office disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Navy Department announced today changes in fleet commands and key staff posts. A spokesman said that the transfers had no special significance and were merely the result of adjusting flag officers to periodic changes or replacements in their commands.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Del Ennis' thirteenth home run with Ralph Caballero on base provided Dutch Leonard the margin he needed to beat the Cardinals tonight, 3 to 1. It was the Red Birds' sixth defeat in seven games and snapped a 7-game losing streak for the Phillies.

BOSTON, July 15 -- Ten new and five members of the present board will constitute the directorate of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad after Frederic C. Dumaine Sr. takes over control at a stockholders meeting on Aug. 12, it was announced today.

Earning assets of the reporting New York member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $71,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The advance brought the total loans and investments to $18,613,000,000.

Brae Wood Estates, Inc., has purchased a tract of 114 acres in Lattingtown, L. I., from Treva C. Diebold as part of a $4,000,000 project of custom-styled luxury homes. The property, on Bayville Road and Sheep Lane, near the Piping Rock Country Club and adjoining Glen Cove, supplements an earlier purchase of thirty-six acres.
A 22-year-old model became "Miss Greenwich Village of 1948" last night when she won a beauty contest at the Greenwich Village First Annual Country Fair.

James Russell Lowell wrote about "a certain condescension" in foreigners. What he had in mind was the condescending attitude of the foreigners of his time toward Americans. Had he thought of it, he might appropriately have done another piece about a "certain condescension" among the adults of all times toward children.

A fight that Andy Niederreiter, the promoter, predicts will attract a gate of a half million dollars was signed by the Tournament of Champions, Inc., yesterday. Tony Zale, holder of the middleweight championship of the world, agreed through his managers, Sam Pian and Art Winch, to defend his crown against Marcel Cerdan of Casablanca in this country two months from now.
Millions of civilians in the Soviet Union are being organized into parachutist, glider pilot, aviation, sniper and other clubs under a reorganized national defense program, it became known yesterday.

BILLINGS, Mont. -- Continuing its efforts to bring processing plants to western states, the executive committee of the Rocky Mountain wool council has outlined a six-month program to develop a western wool industry and has established a $12,000 annual budget to pay for it.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, a vigorous House sponsor of public housing legislation, welcomed the President's call for a special session.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi of Englewood, N. J., blasted par by six strokes for a 66 today to take a three-stroke lead in the first eighteen-hole round of the seventy-two-hole $16,500 Dapper Dan invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A. Lee M. Wiggins has resigned as Under-Secretary of the Treasury to become chairman of the board of both the Atlantic Coast Line and the Louisville and Nashville Railroads.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Baffling Giant pitching and bruising Giant slugging were sprinkled not too wisely or well over a double-header with the Pirates today which drew 40,248 fans, including a record guest turnout of 14,197 screeching ladies, to Forbes Field.

PASADENA, Calif., July 15 -- The convention of the Catholic Daughters of America today adopted a resolution urging that civil rights be taken from "any citizen who acts as the agent of any foreign power or political party seeking the overthrow of the United States Government."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 15 -- Frank Strafaci of Pomonok opened his own tournament season in earnest today when he scored a 71 to win the Long Island amateur golf championship medal over the Rockville Country Club course.

Advertising officials here expressed concern over what is regarded as arbitrary action by the Bureau of Accounting in decreeing that all but "Help-wanted" advertisements are non-deductible in tax statements. The decision, it is felt, probably will have a serious effect on certain types of advertising, particularly public service campaigns and some forms of industrial advertising.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- An assertion that there would be no "political strikes to sabotage the Marshall Plan" was made today by James S. Kearney, president of the San Francisco local of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 15 -- The United States Olympic team stored its energy by resting quietly today. Drawing uniforms and equipment and emergency ship drill were the only demands made on the athletes' time. The voyage has been so harmonious and devoid of incident that Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic committee, at a press conference suggested that a champagne party might be helpful.

ROME, Friday, July 16 -- The general strike called by the Communists in the hope of causing Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government to resign was called off early this morning without achieving its purpose.

Since Mr. Truman chose to announce his intention to call a special session of Congress not in the manner in which such announcements are usually and properly made but in a political speech to a political convention, it is a fair assumption that this move was made at least in part for a political purpose.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 15 -- German counter-proposals to the six-power London decisions on western Germany were forced into the hands of a tripartite Western military government committee for further study today apparently at the insistence of Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, French Military Governor.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The Air Line Pilots' Association here today wired George T. Baker, president of National Air Lines, that its membership was willing to settle the five-and-one-half-month strike of all flight personnel in accordance with suggestions made July 10 by President Truman's fact-finding board.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 15 -- The pace slackened today in Palestine as both sides strengthened their positions and apparently bided their time, awaiting action by the United Nations Security Council. Neither side wants to be in the middle of an offensive if another truce is declared.

NEW DELHI, India, July 15 -- India's sterling balance with the United Kingdom will not be scaled down, Finance Minister Sir Shanmukham Cherty revealed tonight in announcing that a new sterling arrangement had recently been concluded by him with the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, in London.

A former home relief recipient who was removed from the public assistance rolls because he made no effort to get a job and slept until noon was warned yesterday by Magistrate Morris Ploscowe to find employment by Aug. 2.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The United States has sold to Great Britain all lend-lease military equipment in British possession in western Germany and overseas territories, the State Department disclosed today.

CHICAGO. July 15 -- The Illinois liquor mandatory Fair Trade Act under which liquor manufacturers are required to post minimum retail liquor prices was declared unconstitutional today by Judge Harry M. Fisher of the Cook County Circuit Court.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, fifth-seeded Los Angeles ace, and seventh-seeded Herbert Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., advanced to the semifinals of the national clay court tennis championships today.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Tucker Corporation and its president, Preston Tucker, were sued for $100,000 today by a lawyer who is involved in a receivership suit against the automobile manufacturing concern. The lawyer alleged false arrest.

Vegetables and fruits from nearby farms and salt water fish from the Atlantic are about the only foods that can be purchased economically this week-end. Certainly the thrifty housewife will steer away from meat counters, where she will find prices on most cuts from 2 to 11 cents a pound higher than they were last Friday.

TOKYO, July 15 -- The Allied censorship under which the Japanese press has been operating for almost three years was lifted today. Hereafter, although Japanese newspapers and news agencies will continue under Occupation regulation, they will not be required to submit material for Allied review before publication.

Popular-price dress manufacturers have made a strong comeback as the result of outstanding summer sales, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Midwestern cities as well as those on the Atlantic seaboard, manufacturers said, are still pressing for summer merchandise, but the majority of producers have ceased cutting.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the three months ended with June a net income of $52,190,000 after taxes and all charges on operating revenues of $57,270,000.
