The 35-year-old self-admitted "brains" behind the $493,000 swindle of finance companies by William B. Benjamin, convicted former war contractor, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a term of from three to four years in State Prison.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 15 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, said today the calling of a special session of Congress would not cause any change in the Dewey-Warren campaign plans. Campaigning will still begin some time early in September, he said.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- During the week ended July 14 member bank reserves balances increased $47,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- Following is the text of the United States resolution ordering Israel and Arab Governments to stop fighting in Palestine within three days, which was adopted tonight by the United Nations Security Council, with the votes paragraph by paragraph:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission indicated publicly today that its stabilization rule was not violated as a result of the large volume of stock purchased by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, when the latter stabilized the market in connection with its recent 900,000-share common stock offering.
As the recent runaway in meat prices apparently was slowing down yesterday, Commissioner of Markets Eugene G. Schulz made public a tabulation of the retail advances here since July 1.

" Some progress" toward the settlement of the dispute between the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and a committee representing forty-one Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators was reported yesterday by Howard E. Durham, regional director of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service, following a meeting at the service's headquarters, 341 Ninth Avenue.

A skilled psychological approach in the early convalescent stage of infantile paralysis is necessary to prevent the mental and emotional crippling that may develop along with physical crippling, delegates from thirty-eight countries attending the first international poliomyelitis conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were told yesterday.

Nearly 200 of the 1,000 boys and girls who spend their summer days on the play streets of the Twenty-third Precinct, got down to real competition yesterday on the asphalt of 101st Street between Park and Madison Avenues.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., of Pennsylvania, Republican national chairman, charged today that President Truman placed the nation's unity in jeopardy for personal political advantage in calling a special session of Congress.

LONDON, July 15 -- Jobbers started business in the stock market here today by marking prices down all around to prevent selling, following the Soviet's refusal to lift the Berlin blockade. But investors declined to sell and prices hardened again in some sections.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York made public yesterday a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer asking for a two months' postponement of the public hearing scheduled for Monday morning on the three proposals to rehabilitate the city's piers and other waterfront facilities.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 15 (UP) -- Operators of the American steamship William Carson heard indirectly today that the ship's radio operator "fell overboard" after he flashed the ominous signal, "crew is mutinous," across the high seas last Monday.

The appointment of Prof. John Carr Duff as chairman of the department of higher education at the School of Education, New York University, was announced yesterday by Dean Ernest O. Melby. The promotion is effective in September and until that time Professor Duff will continue to serve as assistant dean in charge of men, and veterans' coordinator.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 15 -- The household washer industry is now turning out as many washers every 100 minutes as it did in the whole year of 1909, it was declared here today by Harry S. Smith, vice president of the Burgess-Norton Manufacturing Company, Batavia, Ill.

GENEVA, July 15 -- European leaders of the effort to make Europe do its part in the European Recovery Program expect to receive from the United States Government within a very short time some stern conditions for future action.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 15 (UP) -- German steel magnates notified the British Military Government today that they no longer would cooperate in the dismantling of German industry.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- July corn again furnished the outstanding feature in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, advancing 4 cents at one time on continued short covering and closing of spreads with wheat and at the top of $.212 1/2 showed 15 7/8 cents above the low of last week.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Braves nosed out the Cubs, 2 to 1, in the opening game of a double-header today for their fifth straight victory before 38,339. However, they were held to a 1-1 tie in the nightcap which was halted by darkness after thirteen innings.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- The Russian-dominated Cominform today denounced Marshal Tito as a "betrayer of the working class" who ruled the Yugoslav Communists with a "regime of terror."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15 -- This industrial metropolis of the South prepared today to welcome a States Rights Democrats' convention Saturday which is expected to fire up political heat and noise rivaling the blast furnaces of near-by steel and iron mills.

NANKING, July 15 -- Uneasy over the developing Communist strength in the Han River valley, the Szechwan Provincial Council has urged the Central Government to send reinforcements to forestall a possible westward thrust by the Reds into that rice-producing province.

An investor has purchased from Stephen Jacoby and Jeanne J. Beckman the six-story building containing two stores and twenty-six apartments on a plot 45 by 100 feet at 174-76 Canal Street for cash over mortgages amounting to $50,000. This was the first sale since 1905 of the property, which is assessed for $72,000.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 15 -- The 142-foot ketch Atlantis, seagoing laboratory of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, sailed today for a two-month cruise north of the Azores to probe further into the mysteries of the longest mountain range in the world -- the sub-oceanic mid-Atlantic ridge.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 -- Louis L. Hill of Pottsville, Iowa, was elected president of the National Retail Hardware Association at the closing session of its forty-ninth congress at Haddon Hall Hotel.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 15 -- A captured German camera lens capable of getting on a single snapshot photographic detail within a 210-degree field of vision has been tested by the photographic branch of the Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories here, it was announced today.

LONDON, July 15 -- Winston Churchill gave his fellow members of the House of Commons a gruesome lesson today in how to murder your wife and escape hanging under the terms of the new law proposed by the British Government.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., July 15 -- Emery Thomas of the home club and Jack Mitchell of Essex County, two of the pre-tournament favorites, took a one-stroke lead at the end of the first round of the twenty-eighth annual open championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association at the Forest Hill Field Club today.
By nightfall tonight all but a scattered few of the 341 men and women athletes who compose the United States Olympic team will be en route to the games at London.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Ageless Leroy (Satchel) Paige scored his first major league victory tonight as the league-leading Indians swept a double-header from the Athletics, 6 to 1 and 8 to 5. Ken Keltner's twenty-first home run in the eighth inning broke a 5-5 tie in the second game and enabled Cleveland to increase its first-place margin to 2 1/2 games.

ATHENS, July 15 -- Reports tonight from the Greek First and Fifteenth Divisions, driving on the Grammos Mountain area from the east in the Nestorion-Eptachorion sector, said the rebels were in retreat along a ten-mile front.

A thorough reorganization of the Department of Sanitation, including establishment of an "Office of Operations" to coordinate the primary functions of street cleaning and waste disposal, is recommended in a report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer on May 21 by his Executive Committee on Administration.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, let it be known yesterday that his organization would support two Democratic candidates in Brooklyn rather than have the posts threatened by candidates of the American Labor party.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Sixty B-29 bombers will take off for Royal Air Force bases in Great Britain tomorrow in an intensified program to keep many of these strategic bombers close to Europe during the mounting crisis with the Soviet Union over Berlin, it was learned on good authority tonight.

0JERUSALEM, July 15 -- A lone Egyptian light bomber raided the Jewish residential areas of Jerusalem in the early hours of this morning in the first night air attack upon the Holy City. Unofficial casualty figures were one child killed and one person wounded. There was no damage of any significance reported.

James F. Twohy, former governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration, was elected chairman of the board of Investors Syndicate, nation-wide investment concern, following his election as a director at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday in Minneapolis.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 15 -- The number of qualified Negro voters in the South has tripled since 1940 and despite insistent demagoguery by white supremists it is "highly improbable" that this progress will wane, according to a report issued today by the Southern Regional Council.

Mrs. Howard Phipps, president of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, announced yesterday that the goal of the 1948 Girl Scout Contributors Campaign and Cookie Sale was $350,000. The campaign will be opened officially on Oct. 14, with a reception at the Plaza Hotel.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 15 (AP) -- An Israeli plane bombed Cairo tonight. It was the first Israeli air attack of the Palestine war on the Egyptian capital.

CINCINNATI, July 15 -- With Rex Barney pitching his third complete game and Pee Wee Reese leading the ten - hit assault with four straight blows, the Dodgers made a handsome start on their third Western invasion by beating the Reds, 5 -- 3, under the Crosley Field lights tonight.

LONDON, July 15 -- The next move in the dangerous diplomatic game with the Soviet Union over Berlin was the subject of intense and continuous discussion here today by a so-called standing committee representing the United, States, Britain and France.

Six hours after he and another physician had been found guilty of causing the death by abortion of a socially prominent young woman, Dr. Oswald Glasberg, 49-year-old plastic surgeon, died yesterday morning in his Tombs prison cell apparently a suicide by poison.
General Pershing's contributions to the military causes of his country began with the cavalry in the days of Indian fighting in the West and reached into the era of the atomic bomb.

With Frank Hiller pitching his first complete game, the Yankees hit the halfway mark in the American League race with a 4-2 victory over the Browns last night at the Stadium. Ably, in fact brilliantly, supported, Hiller yielded seven safeties, only one of which was damaging.

The news that Leroy Paige, the Negro pitcher of fabulous legend, has joined the Cleveland Indians will satisfy all lovers of the logical denouement. For years the major leagues have had the classic gentleman's agreement that barred Negro players from reaching the upper level of the national pastime.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- A campaign of sharp counter-attacks designed to prove that a Republican Congress will not keep its campaign promises and that Governor Dewey is not an effective leader of his party was mapped today by the Democratic nominees, President Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, who promised the Democratic national convention their message would be carried to every precinct.

The stock market got the severest jolt in five months yesterday when an avalanche of selling orders flooded the trading floor of the Stock Exchange in the final hour. Prices melted quickly, the heavy influx of offerings caused the ticker tape to fall behind floor transactions, and closing quotations showed losses as high as 9 points, with the composite rate down 2.13 points.

Ignoring last-minute efforts by national officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to halt the demonstration, hundreds of shouting members of left-wing CIO unions picketed Gimbels department store for two hours late yesterday afternoon.

Lauritz Melchior, the Metropolitan Opera Wagnerian tenor, was soloist at Lewisohn Stadium last night with Pierre Monteux and the Philharmonic - Symphony, drawing nearly 16,000 listeners to the moonlit concert.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey completed yesterday negotiations for the construction of eight additional super-tankers with a capacity of 228,000 barrels each, raising to fourteen the number of the new-type tankers the company has contracted for within the last six months, it was announced last night.

Farmers, gardeners and home owners were warned yesterday to begin protecting foliage against the annual Japanese beetle invasion, which is just beginning, because weather conditions have made this an ideal summer for the development of the voracious insects.

Export collections paid by Latin America as a whole during June were the slowest for any month since May of 1947, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to its latest export credit figures, supplied by twelve large New York banks, these collections have been progressively slower since February, the Federal Reserve said.
Three educators from Germany and Austria, first of a group of nine, arrived here yesterday by air for a year of study and observation in American teacher-training institutions.

Mayor O'Dwyer returned from the Democratic convention yesterday with praise for the ticket and the platform, and a "feeling" that the Democrats would win. He saw the nomination of Senator Alben W. Barkley as enhancing the party's chances for victory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, departed abruptly from the Security Council meeting tonight before it adjourned and began work on reestablishing the machinery for a truce in the Holy Land.

The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday three issues of long-term bonds totaling $18,225,000. Two of the issues totaling $11,025,000, maturing from July 1, 1949 to 1997, and carrying the guarantee of the city, were purchased by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at an interest cost of about 3.1079 per cent.

A somewhat slower production pace by so-called "marginal" manufacturers in the men's clothing industry will mark resumption of output here next Monday, it was reported here yesterday. Production has been entirely shut down this week and last because of observance of the first two weeks' vacation period in the industry.

The Rev. Dr. O. Frederick Nolde, director of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs, will leave La Guardia Field this afternoon by Trans-World Airlines plane for London to complete final arrangements for a world meeting of the commission at Woudschoten, Holland, on Aug. 17 and 18, it was announced yesterday.

Twenty-one aliens who were detained at Ellis Island by immigration authorities after arriving here from Beirut Tuesday on the American Export liner Marine Carp are due to leave for Palestine on the same ship tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Special enlistments of 18-year-old volunteers will be accepted by the Armed Forces under the new Selective Service Act, beginning next Wednesday, July 21, it was announced today.

NEWARK, N. J., July 15 -- Prosecutor Duane E. Minard questioned ex-Judge P. James Pellechia for four hours today, seeking to check his story that he embezzled more than $630,000 from his family's Columbus Trust Company to cover losses in betting on horse races.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Government today offered to farmers purchase agreements on 1948 crops of wheat, oats, barley, rye and grain sorghums as a means of price support.

Twelve-year-old Mickey Kivatisky came back to New York last night garbed in a ten-gallon hat, a blazing cowboy shirt, levis and kerchief to match -- still firm in his conviction that this town is "tops."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- President Truman's decision to call a special session of Congress on July 26 was welcomed here today by United Nations officials, who saw it as an eleventh-hour opportunity to obtain the proposed $65,000,000 loan to construct the East River world capital.

A strike, scheduled to start at 4 A. M. tomorrow against the Third Avenue Transit System and to spread within a few days to all privately operated buses and trolley cars in the city, was threatened yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

The luck that sometimes brings food to hungry youngsters in Europe brought a portable radio yesterday to one of the several hundred persons who paused to contribute to the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children.

Official launching of a service to localize national advertising, known now as the "Operator 25" plan, was announced yesterday by the Distribution Council of National Advertisers, Inc., following a board of directors' meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Carrying forward the right-wing offensive against leftists in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers has decided to set up a division to enroll social workers in opposition to the left-wing United Office and Professional Workers.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Government today offered to farmers purchase agreements on 1948 crops of wheat, oats, barley, rye and grain sorghums as a means of price support.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging announced today that a survey just completed revealed that 39 per cent of the companies queried had formal rules barring hiring of older workers.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- Argentine sentiment against the United States Economic Cooperation Administration's policy toward President Juan D. Peron, as enunciated by Administrator Paul G. Hoffman in Washington in May and by H. Struve Hensel, ECA consultant, here last month, was expressed for the first time in a Government broadcast last night.

The armored truck crews who transport and guard $100,000,000 in currency, bullion and payrolls daily got some more money for themselves yesterday through a two-year contract agreement between Local 820 of the Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and four armored concerns.

Don McNeill of Glen Oaks, L. I., was forced to dig back eight years for the game he used when winning the national singles championship before he was able to stop the great challenge of the unranked Leonard Steiner of Brooklyn in yesterday's quarter-finals of the New York State tennis championships at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

There will be $10,000,000 worth of industrial and military exhibits in the modern tents to be erected at New York International Airport at Idlewild for the air show marking the city's golden jubilee from July 31 to Aug. 8, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee for the event, announced yesterday.

DETROIT, July 15 -- A strike against the Ford Motor Company by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, at any time was authorized today by the National Ford Council of the union. The 100-man council, representing 108,000 hourly rated employes in forty-six plants, voted unanimously to reject an offer which the company termed "final."

Jack Palais, 23-year-old Coast Guard veteran, his wife and infant son camped yesterday in the lobby of Mid-Manhattan Magistrate's Court, 153 East Fifty-seventh Street, determined to remain there until an apartment could be obtained for them.

Jean Meter apparently learned her lesson well when she won for the first time in ten starts last week. E. M. O'Brien's 2-year-old filly was back in action at Aqueduct yesterday, and she led half a dozen other junior misses under the wire in a $4,000 purse called the Penitent.

The Telephone Hour will depart from its routine on Monday, July 26, and present an operatic program with seven soloists. Those participating will be Marilyn Cotlow, coloratura soprano; Polyna Stoska, soprano; Mary Davenport, contralto; Thomas Heyward, tenor; William McGrath, tenor; Kenneth Schon, bass, and a baritone yet to be selected.

Some marginal furniture producers who failed to write anything like satisfactory business at the Chicago home furnishings market will temporarily reduce prices, dealer spokesmen reported yesterday. Many small independent dealers who placed few if any orders at the market will order in quantity when the break occurs, they said.
LAKE VIEW, L. I., July 15 -- Mrs. Samuel G. Lockwood, mother of five children, fought a bitter battle in her home today to balk her husband's efforts to kill their 22-month-old daughter, Patricia.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 -- A scholarship fund in memory of his wife providing up to four years' college tuition for worthy graduates of Greenwich High School was established by the late Count Adolphe J. Palen-Klar of this place.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 15 -- Jean Niewenhuys, Belgian chairman of the Palestine Truce Commission, informed the United Nations Security Council today that the dissident group Irgun Zvai Leumi had not set free, despite his strong protests, five British residents arrested by it in Jerusalem on July 6.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Promotion and salesmanship are re-entering the furniture field in the wake of increased prices and falling demand, spokesmen for the annual summer furnishings show said today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- General Pershing was a familiar figure in the old State Department Building, a stone's throw across West Executive Avenue from the White House, until his last long illness confined him to Walter Reed General Hospital.

An outstanding property near the United Nations site on the East Side passed to new hands yesterday when the Continental Realty Investing Company sold its controlling stock interest in the 801 Second Avenue Corporation representing ownership of the fee of the twenty-two-story office and showroom building at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Forty-third Street.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 15 -- In a resolution that filled seven columns of the Communist newspaper Rabotnichesko Delo today, the Central Committee of the Bulgarian Communist party proposed a series of measures to preserve the party from the errors and weaknesses charged by the Communist Information Bureau against the Yugoslav Communists.

A net decrease of twenty in the number of vessels sold under the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946, as a result of the discontinuance of sales to foreigners and an excess of purchase cancellations over approvals, was announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission in its quarterly report.

Gross commercial revenues of Pan American Airways, Inc., in the first five months of 1948 were 16 per cent above the airline's intake in the corresponding period of last year, Juan T. Trippe, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday.

It seems almost a certainty that the "new look" will adorn our national administration by next January. It is generally agreed, however, that a change is altogether natural and necessary. The two-party system was, among other reasons, created for competitive purposes and for offering the American people political alternatives.

Withdrawal of the Newspaper Guild of New York from the Greater New York CIO Council was repudiated as "unauthorized and untrue" by the guild's representative assembly early yesterday. As policy-making body of the guild, the assembly adopted by a 38 to 16 vote a resolution directing the guild officers to continue affiliation with the council.

A former Negro Republican leader has been selected to deliver the keynote address at the third party convention that meets in Philadelphia July 23-25, the National Wallace for President Committee announced here yesterday.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 15 -- Governor Dewey withheld comment today on President Truman's call for a special session of Congress as he returned to his dairy farm to resume his vacation and preparation for the Presidential election campaign.

BERLIN, July 15 -- A potentially grave threat not only to the United States and British airlift into Berlin but also to the peace of the world is arising from increased Russian fighter activity in the three air corridors through which the Western sectors of this besieged city are supplied.
HAMILTON, Ont., July 15 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, defending champion, won two matches today to gain the semi-finals in the Canadian amateur golf tournament.

NANKING, July 16 (AP) -- The official Chinese military news agency announced today that the Mukden garrison had advanced fifty miles south, recapturing Liaoyang and approaching within five miles of Anshan, Manchurian steel center.

Flat oblong packages that fit readily into the ice cube compartment hold ten combinations of frozen meat with frozen vegetables. Enough for two large or three modest portions, these new Hygrade products, sold in the frozen food department at Gimbel's, range from 97 cents for chopped beef with mixed vegetables to $1.80 for three loin lamb chops with lima beans and carrots.

The Brooklyn Handicap, a horse race that rated the lead position on page one in New York newspapers of the Gay Nineties, is the main event today at Aqueduct. There have been fifty-nine runnings of it since 1887, and while it no longer takes precedence over news of Presidents, it's nevertheless one of the great events of the turf campaign.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Big and Little Steel capitulated to the rising cost of living today when the United States Steel Corporation and the Weirton Steel Company granted wage increases to 180,000 production workers, effective at once.

The 40,000 workers in the nation's "captive" coal mines who had been on strike, actually if not technically, since July 6, are once more back on their jobs. For this consummation credit is due primarily to Justice T. Alan Goldsborough, who, eschewing the weapon of the injunction, came down from his bench and personally mediated the controversy between operators and miners in his own judicial chambers.

On a daily average basis, with allowance for the holiday, lumber production last week was 21.3 per cent below the previous week and 4.7 per cent above the comparable week last year. Shipments rose 22.8 per cent above last year, while orders dropped 22.5 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Mansfield Spencer will observe tomorrow his thirty-ninth anniversary as pastor of the congregation, the Church of the Strangers, now worshiping in the assembly hall of The National Bible Institute, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 16 (UP) -- Fifty new cases of infantile paralysis were reported in North Carolina today, sending the total for the year to 658 cases in the country's worst polio outbreak. It was the biggest daily report in 1948.

MONTREAL, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Newsprint Association of Canada reported today apparent total consumption of newsprint in the United States in June was 427,529 tons, an increase of 37,310, or 9.6 per cent, over June, 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- Following is the text of a reply from the Provisional Government of Israel to the resolution yesterday of the United Nations Security Council ordering a reinstatement of the Palestine truce:

A derivative stockholder's suit was filed in Federal court yesterday asking the Sinclair Oil Corporation, 630 Fifth Avenue, and Harry F. Sinclair, its president, to account for $956,250 in profits Mr. Sinclair allegedly made through the sale of stock he had purchased from the concern.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Bennett E. Meyers, once a major general, now a convict in disgrace, was dismissed today from the United States Air Forces.
Andrei A. Gromyko, bound for home, called in the New York City Police Department yesterday to help him fight and almost win a last-hour shipboard battle to say nothing.

Yesterday's day-long meeting between representatives of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and a committee representing forty-one Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators resulted in little progress other than a few minor concessions on relatively unimportant issues of the dispute, Howard E. Durham, regional director of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service, said last night.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 16 (AP) -- Sammy Urzetta of Midvale, Rochester, and Lloyd Ribner of the Fenway Country Club, White Plains, won in the semi-finals of the 1948 New York State amateur golf championship today.

JERUSALEM, July 16 -- Tough Palmach [Striking Force] fighters of the defense army of Israel reported today the capture of a strategic heights named Khirbet Deir Amar, about ten miles west of Jerusalem, as the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion opened a heavy artillery bombardment of the Jewish areas of the city just outside the walled section of the Holy City.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 -- Arabs and Israel agreed tonight to stop fighting in the Holy City of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today granted temporary mail pay increases to Pan American Airways and American Overseas Airlines. The action will give them an estimated additional $7,000,000 this year.

Don McNeill of Glen Oaks, L. I., became a finalist in the New York State tennis championship for the fifth time yesterday when he outfought young Dick Savitt of East Orange, N. J. The Cornell player forced McNeill, 1940 national champion, through five hard-fought sets at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 -- Egypt is so disappointed with the attitude of the western democracies on the Palestine question that she wishes to avoid entanglement with any big power bloc and would seek to remain entirely neutral in the event of any clash between the Anglo-American and Soviet coalitions.

As one of the few major league clubs that did not change managers yesterday, it behooved the Yankees to solidify the position of Bucky Harris by beating the Browns at the Stadium. However, the normally imperturable skipper of the world champions must have suffered a mild case of jitters as he watched his charges drop a 10-4 decision to the seventh-place visitors.
CINCINNATI, July 16 -- "Durocher is out, Shotton is in."

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Procedures for the operation of the Economic Cooperation Administration were outlined today for members of the Illinois Manufacturers Association by James M. Cleary, special assistant to Administrator Paul G. Hoffman.

SINGAPORE, July 16 -- There is every indication that Malaya is entering only the first phase of the Communist effort to disrupt the country's economy before any attempt is made to seize political control. This may appear ambitious, but "political control," as far as the terrorists are concerned, means the overthrow of the Government.

LONDON, July 16 -- Commentators in Britain have not been so quick as some of their counterparts in the United States to mark down and write off President Truman as a candidate and campaigner. There is more than a little admiration expressed for him in newspapers that have most closely followed the Philadelphia story

CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 (AP) -- An Arab Legion communique today said that an Israeli attack on Bab el Wad, on the important Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway, was repulsed. It said the Israeli forces left eighty-seven dead on the battlefield.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- United Airlines announced today its intention to increase passenger fares 10 per cent effective Sept. 1 to offset rising costs. Present fares in the industry average just under 5 1/2 cents a mile, with 10 per cent added for extra fare service on DC-6s and Constellations.

ALBANY, July 16 -- The State Banking Department announced today it has approved an application from the Bakery Salesmen's Credit Union for permission to move its place of business from 13 Astor Place to 30 Jane Street, New York.

Tanning and hide trade circles showed considerable interest yesterday in reports that cattle hides may soon be sold on a large scale to the United States by Argentina. It was indicated that such sales may be one step to ease the Argentine dollar position, provided prices are in line with United States levels.
PORTLAND, Me., July 16 (AP) -- Three Philadelphia doctors advised today that persistent hoarseness always be investigated because it may be a symptom of cancer of the larynx.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The National Guard has more than tripled its strength in the past year, but it still has openings for about 20,000 youths who want to gain draft exemption, the Department of the Army announced today.

Mrs. Pauline Brumlik, mother of the first wife of Dr. Oswald Glasberg, 49-year-old plastic surgeon who committed suicide on Thursday in his Tombs prison cell, was taken to French Hospital, 324 West Thirtieth Street, last night suffering from an overdose of sleeping tablets, the police said.

A three-member panel of Federal mediators will sit next Tuesday with negotiators for the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, in an effort to expedite settlement of a wage review dispute, a spokesman for the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The two Westinghouse Electric Corporation workers whose suspension caused a twenty-four-hour strike of 6,500 employes last week, will get new jobs, not in connection with work on secret naval contracts.

When Raymond Massey departed for the British Isles two weeks ago his specific mission was to obtain an adaptor for "Hanging Judge," a "murder-will-out" novel by Bruce Hamilton, published recently by Harper Bros. Mr. Massey has returned now not only with two potential candidates for the assignment -- their identities for obvious reasons cannot be disclosed at the moment -- but with new project as well.

Thomas J. Dillon, president of the United States Steel Corporation, has sold Cedar Farm on Middlesex Road, opposite the Ox Ridge Hunt Club grounds, in Darien, Conn., to Haik Kavookjian of Highlands, N.J., for an indicated consideration of $70,000.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 16 (AP) -- A report has reached here, from sources that have proved accurate in the past, that General Markos, the Greek Communist guerrilla leader, promised Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia three areas of Greek Macedonia in payment for help to the Greek rebels.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 16 -- The State Board of Regents held its July meeting today as guests of Vice Chancellor John P. Myers of Plattsburg in an all-day session at which business of two ordinary days was consummated.

BERLIN, July 16 -- The people of the Western sectors of Berlin, massed in thousands, proclaimed tonight their resolution not to give in to Russian pressure and their refusal to accept food and fuel from the Soviet Military Administration as the price of approving communism.

A bonus for veterans of World War II was urged in a resolution adopted last night by the Kings County American Legion at the opening of its thirtieth annual two-day convention in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

Discovery of the exact location in the human brain of the two most vital life centers -- those controlling breathing and circulation -- was announced yesterday at the first international poliomyelitis conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -John J. Pershing was the only person, other than Washington, to have the title of "General of the Armies," Army source said today.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Tom Brown of San Francisco and Gardner Larned of Chicago, seeded No. 1 and 4, were upset today in the quarter-finals of the National Clay Court tennis championships.

BALTIMORE, July 16 -- With a hard-earned eleventh-round victory over George Kramer of Queens, 1945 champion of New York State, Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., had first place to himself at the close of tonight's session of the annual open tournament, sponsored by the United States Chess Federation.

The effort of the Italian Communists to use the attempted assassination of their leader by a young Sicilian nationalist to precipitate a political crisis that might have led (a few months ago) to armed revolt apparently has failed. The Italian workers and people refused to see in the act of a young madman sufficient reason for overthrowing a Government that they had elected by a large majority only a few weeks ago.

President Truman was called upon yesterday to set "a moral pace" for the special session of Congress by the issuance of an executive order to end racial segregation in the armed forces. The appeal came from the Committee Against Jim Crow in Military Service and Training, over the signature of A. Philip Randolph, leader of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, and Grant Reynolds, member of the New York State Commission of Corrections.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 16 -- The great industrial and commercial areas in Western Germany will be thrown open to investment by foreign interests for the first time since the end of the war as soon as details are worked out between United States and British authorities, Undersecretary of the Army William H. Draper said today.

ROME, July 16 -- Calm returned to most of Italy today after two days of rioting and bloodshed following the attempted assassination of Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti on Wednesday. The workers were back on their jobs almost everywhere at the usual hour this morning.

" America's Fifty Foremost Business Leaders," edited by B.C. Forbes, will be published on July 28 by B.C. Forbes Sons. It is a sequel to his book of thirty years ago about the fifty leaders of that generation. Mr. Forbes, editor and publisher of Forbes Magazine of Business, is the author of "Men Who Are Making America," "Little Bits About Big Men" and "Thoughts on the Business of Life."

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- Although the newspaper Prensa received last February exchange permits covering imports of nearly 34,000 tons of newsprint -- a year's supply -- a ruling of the Central Bank has been invoked so as to make the permits valueless.

A restraining order directing Stephen Toth, landlord of a building at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, to desist from his efforts to evict a tenant whom he allegedly has barred from his apartment on three separate occasions was signed in Federal Court yesterday by Judge William Bondy.

On Monday the Board of Estimate will hold a public hearing on the three plans for rehabilitation of the city's piers that now have been presented to the Mayor. The three plans are those of the Port of New York Authority, the World Trade Corporation and the city's own Department of Marine and Aviation, whose report was made public only Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Southern California Gas Company and Southern Counties Gas Company of California asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to increase the daily delivery capacity of their pipeline system from 305,000,000 to 405,000,000 cubic feet.
In a recent issue of THE TIMES was a short item of news: "Nuremberg is rising as a toy center again," based on an interview with a San Francisco toy dealer.
VANCOUVER, July 16 (CP) -- In early morning darkness the Cardena of the Union Steamships Line plowed into a reef today off False Bay near Lasqueti Island. 55 miles from here.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A pressurizing and temperature control system designed to provide and maintain comfortable conditions in the cabins of aircraft operating at all altitudes and in all types of weather was one of 403 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

LONDON, July 16 -- On at least one subject some progress in agreement between the western powers and the Soviet Union was made today. The Deputies of Big Four Foreign Ministers meeting in London decided upon a period in which they would hear the views of the governments interested in the disposition of the former Italian colonies.

ALBANY, July 16 -- The Court of Appeals dismissed today bribery indictments against former Assistant State Controller Charles H. Mullens, 63 years old, of Albany, and William Solomon, 53, former Tammany district leader.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Red Sox made it three in a row over the Tigers today as Right-hander Joe Dobson chalked up his eleventh pitching victory by a 5-3 margin. Junior Stephens ended the Boston scoring by poling his eighteenth homer into the left-center screen against Relief Pitcher Al Benton with none aboard in the eighth.

Whether summer entertaining means a cold drink served near the coolest window in the apartment or a buffet supper on the terrace, careful planning and perhaps a new serving accessory or two can help make it as pleasant and refreshing for the hostess as for her guests.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 16 -- A six-hour search for poisoned macaroons, believed stolen by youngsters, ended happily tonight in a warehouse cellar where an absent-minded exterminator had left them. Between noon, when Edward Spino, head of the Asiatic Exterminator Corporation, had reported the theft from his parked automobile, and their recovery at 6:30 P.M. fifty policemen hunted for the deadly cookies in hopes of averting a possible mass tragedy.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Grains closed lower on the Board of Trade today after an early showing of strength when July corn advanced 2 1/2 cents to a new high on the current movement. However, the latter broke 5 1/4 cents from the top late in the session on profit taking and all grains eased in sympathy.

Edward and Florence Gleason, who left two of their children, Michael, 3 years old, and Patricia, 18 months, in a baby carriage in front of the Morrisania Police Station last Saturday, were paroled yesterday, pending grand jury action on abandonment charges.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Frank Papish and Howie Judson rushed to the rescue of Marino Pieretti tonight to squelch a ninth-inning Washington rally as Chicago defeated the Senators, 3 -- 2. The victory snapped a seven-game losing streak for the White Sox.

A strike by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, scheduled to start at 4 A.M. today, was averted yesterday afternoon at a conference between company officials and union officers. The conference took place in the office of Theodore W. Kheel, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, in the Municipal Building.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The annual summer furniture show approached its final sessions today with some exhibitors expressing disappointment over sales.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16 -- Nazareth fell to Israeli forces tonight. This was not the cradle of Christianity but it was the scene of Christ's adolescence and has been revered as such by Christians the world over.

Henry Waldman, in your issue of July 8, asks at the end of his letter: "Have we a free enterprise system?" He answers his own question by saying: "The key industries and the public utilities are owned by huge corporations."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Widely separated Republican Congressional leaders began exchanging ideas by telephone today on how they will deal with the challenge flung at them in President Truman's call for a special session of Congress on July 26.

ATHENS, July 16 (UP) -- War Minister George Stratos said today that Greek requests for more fighting equipment, including medium bombers, artillery and heavy machine guns, had been approved by United States Army officials. Mr. Stratos said William H. Draper, United States Under-Secretary of the Army, and Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, Chief of Army Operations and Planning, who were in Athens recently, backed the requests.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- The Combined Tin Committee has allocated 28,685 long tons of tin for the last half of 1948, and more than half of it went to the United States. The United States allotment was 16,640 tons.

Since 1920 more than 250,000,000 illiterates in all parts of the world have been taught to read by phonetic methods, the Rev. Dr. Frank C. Laubach, pioneer literacy expert and foreign missionary, said yesterday at the headquarters of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, 156 Fifth Avenue.

The historic Brevoort Hotel, established 94 years ago at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street where it has been host to royalty and other notables, is to be closed to residents on July 31, it was announced last night.
Business and residential properties on the West Side featured realty transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- A survey by the Department of Labor indicates that men and women workers in the 45-or-older age group offer "distinct advantages" to employers over younger workers.

NANKING, July 16 -- The Ministry of Education said today that two gendarmes had been killed and more than 100 persons injured at Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province, when the authorities ousted student strikers who had barricaded themselves in several school buildings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 16 -- An order issued by the New York State Labor Relations Board concerning union membership of bus drivers and other employes of the Club Transportation Corporation of Yonkers would produce a "chaotic and unfair" labor situation if enforced, Supreme Court Justice James W. Bailey ruled here today.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 16 -- Although sales of home laundering appliances during 1948 are higher than in any period in history, millions of old pre-war models still remaining are being kept in use by the industry's sale of replacement parts and repairs.

With the Tammany Hall district leaders wrangling over a final choice for Surrogate, Thomas J. Curran, Republican county leader, sent out word yesterday that his organization would tand by its selection of former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler as the party designee and would not agree to a bi-partisan nomination for any other candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration ordered all its offices today to remain open Saturday, July 31, to provide one last chance for veterans to reinstate lapsed National Service Life Insurance policies.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 -- The immediate task facing the Southern states is to prevent Congress from passing civil rights legislation rather than the formation of a fourth political party, Gov. Ben T. Laney of Arkansas said here today.

Deviating from the customary reluctance of most utilities to admit a tight power supply, the Commonwealth Edison Company brought the subject into the open yesterday and said that on several occasions recently power demands on the system had equaled capacity.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., July 16 -- The Mitchel Air Forces Base here today observed its thirtieth anniversary as a United States Air Force installation. But, there was no official ceremony to mark the occasion.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- A blighted economy in this country through lack of modern routes to accommodate rapidly increasing essential motor transport was predicted today by J.T. Callaway, president of the American Road Builders Association, unless immediate remedies were applied.
Local baseball fans were completely stunned by the unheralded turn of events yesterday that featured the switch of Manager Leo Durocher from the Dodgers to the Giants.

Communists will work for the first phase of communism -- socialism -- through the third party movement headed by Henry Wallace, it was asserted yesterday by Simon W. Gerson, legislative representative of the New York State Communist party.
TOKYO, July 16 -- Before former Premier Hideki Tojo tried to commit suicide on Sept. 11, 1945, he prepared a "final message," urging the Japanese people patiently to await their chance to rise again.

DETROIT, July 16 -- The Ford Motor Company, facing a possible strike next week by 116,000 hourly-rated employes, announced today an immediate increase of nine per cent in wages for 25,500 white-collar workers.

Supreme Court Justice James B.M. McNally cleared the way yesterday for determination by the National Labor Relations Board of a question whether the automatic dismissal of five department store employes under a Committee of Industrial Organizations union shop contract, who had campaigned for the American Federation of Labor, was an unfair labor practice.

Douglas fir prices, now at record highs, will level off or drop slightly after Monday when virtually all West Coast mill vacations end, local distributors declared yesterday. They said that the huge increase in production resulting from the return of mill workers, combined with failure of the expected freight car shortage to materialize and the lack of activity by yards in the last two weeks will make for a softer market.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would approve a plan of retirement of the preferred stocks of the United Public Utilities Corporation, Wilmington, Del., if it was amended to provide for an increase in the cash contribution to the preferred stockholders of $171,751.

" Mickey," a comedy about the difficulties of adolescence scheduled to open at the Gotham, will be today's only new arrival on Broadway. An Eagle-Lion film produced by Aubrey Schenck and directed by Ralph Murphy, "Mickey" was adapted to the screen by Agnes Christine Johnson from Peggy Goodin's 1946 novel, "Clementine."

Summonses were issued yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court for three high city officials on charges of permitting a public nuisance to continue in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn. Department of Sanitation trucks are dumping garbage there as landfill.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to approve a series of proposals having as their main objective the direct entrance of the Santa Fe Railroad into St. Louis.

The Advertising Council reported yesterday that its fundraising efforts have passed the $225,000 mark, a sum equal to its total budget last year. The campaign, being directed by the council's new industry advisory committee, of which Charles E. Wilson, head of General Electric Company, is chairman, has a goal of $650,000.

CINCINNATI, July 16 -- Barney Shotton picked up the reins over the Dodgers today and his first three strategic moves paid off in a 4-2 triumph that lifted the Brooks into fourth place ahead of the team now piloted by Leo Durocher.
That swimming is a joyful recreation these hot days cannot be denied, but a question raised by a Jones Beach habitue we know makes us wonder whether the sport is as joyful as it once was.

Four men who described themselves as clerks and one who said he was a house painter were arrested yesterday after a detective had caught two of them trying to pawn a watch on West Forty-eighth Street and later uncovered $3,000 worth of jewelry, fur coats, clothing and other valuables in a furnished room occupied by one of them.
In its continuing effort to draw inactive officers back into service, First Army headquarters on Governors Island announced yesterday that maximum ages for those returning to duty had been raised.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16 -- States'-rights Democrats, meeting in caucus on the eve of their convention which is designed to solidify Southern resentment against President Truman and the civil-rights issue, made a gesture of political bravado today and also disclosed their major weakness as potential vote-getters.
BASEBALL doubtless has never seen a more electrifying triple play than that which flashed across the nation yesterday. It beats even the day they piled up three Dodgers on a single base.
French transatlantic cable repair ships will undertake the largest operation since the war when they sail within a few days to work on the 3,200-mile link between Orleans on Cape Cod and Brest.
President Truman's call for a special session of Congress brought repercussions yesterday on the meat-price front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Cole Porter and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. have been working quietly for the last month on an idea for a musical with a modern setting which they hope to have in shape for the cameras sometime next year.

VIENNA, July 16 -- The three Western Allies raised at today's meeting of the Allied Council in Austria the issue of the Soviet refusal to permit the restitution of certain Jewish property in the international zone to Jewish claimants or to return certain property of the Austrian Government.
CAIRO, July 16 (UP) -- Haj Amin el-Husseini, exiled Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, said today the Arabs should continue at all costs their war to prevent the establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Ben Chapman was dismissed as manager of the Phillies today in a sudden move that caught the entire team by surprise. Coach Allen (Dusty) Cooke, Chapman's close friend for 20 years, was named as his temporary successor.
GENEVA, July 16 -- The Committee on Administration and Finance of the World Health Assembly agreed provisionally today on a budget of $4,800,000 for 1948.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- A chartered plane from New York dropped Leo Durocher, President Horace C. Stoneham, Carl Hubbell farm club supervisor, and Garry Schumacher, Stoneham's assistant out of the sky here today. And, forthwith, Durocher, as new manager of the faltering Giants, outlined some of his plans.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 16 -- Officials of the Democratic Party in South Carolina will be required to keep enrollment books open till July 31 for both whites and Negroes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the week yesterday with quiet trading, and at prices 1 point lower to 7 points higher than Thursday's final levels.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 16 -- A detail of five armed military policemen from the Brooklyn Army Base, in charge of a tough-talking sergeant, escorted two trucks carrying lifeboats through a picket line at the plant of the Whelin Davit and Boat Company here this afternoon.

The citrus industry, now facing a slump because of record-high production, will be given a strong promotional shot-in-the-arm by the rapidly-expanding juice-vending machine outlet, it was predicted yesterday by A.W. Percival, president of Telecoin Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- An honor guard of about 3,500 uniformed members of the armed services and virtually every high-ranking official in the Government will escort General of the Armies John J. Pershing, who died yesterday, to his final resting place in Arlington National Cemetery on Monday.

MUNICH, July 16 -- The Civilian Employes Association of the Military Government of Bavaria today sent a cablegram to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall requesting a reversal of the dismissal of Paul W. Freedman, whose contract has been terminated without explanation.
LONDON, July 16 -- Although an implacable foe of Germany in the war Winston Churchill said today that the time was coming to bring the Germans back into the family of Europe.

The White Plains Housing Authority announced yesterday that it has borrowed from Salomon Brothers Hutzler $2,000,000 on temporary loan notes due on Feb. 2, 1949. The notes were sold to the banking house at 1 per cent interest, plus a premium of $41.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- About 292,000 Naval Reserve officers will receive permanent appointments of the highest rank they attained while on active duty. The authorization will become effective about Aug. 1.

Henry Ejnar Graversen, Danish seaman who allegedly juggled the affections of ten women over a two-year period, was sentenced to three years in prison yesterday when he pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman to using the mails to defraud one of them of $17,700 on his promise to marry her.

Francis B. Wilby, chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, filed plans in Washington yesterday for development of a 2,200,000-horsepower hydroelectric project on the St. Lawrence River.

After a period of indifferent success with new issues of public utility securities, underwriters will face a rather light schedule next week. On Tuesday, Equitable Gas Company will offer $14,000,000 of bonds and New England Power Company will take bids on $11,000,000.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 16 -- Overall ultimate success in world economic and political fields depends much on how well the leading nations can cooperate on the drafting of a global code for aviation. This thesis was stressed here today at a forum on Current Problems in International Law at the University of Michigan.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 17 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, chairman of the Korean National Assembly, signed this morning the Constitution of the Korean Democratic Republic Representatives of the United States Army and the State Department were at the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A flight of sixty United States Air Force B-29 Superfortresses left this country for bases in Britain today, tripling the United States force of heavy bombers in Europe.

Major crime in New York, which has been increasing steadily since 1943, was checked at last in 1947, the annual report of the Police Department showed yesterday. The incidence of crime dropped by 10.5 per cent compared with 1946 but still was 22.3 per cent higher than it was five years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The Department of Labor today formally approved the 1948 wage agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- An attempt by House leaders to settle the controversy over the Soviet blockade of Berlin was proposed today by Representative Sid Simpson, Republican, of Illinois. He sent a telegram to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., urging that priority be given to strained relations with Russia at the special session of Congress starting July 26.

MILWAUKEE. July 16 -- The country's first national opera festival opened here tonight as part of Wisconsin's centennial celebration. The festival brought singers from thirty-four states and Canada and was the first national music gathering to be held here since 1886, when the city was host to the Saengerfest.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., July 16 -- The fight against the spread of the Japanese beetle in New Jersey and adjoining states has been hampered this year by the heavy rains of late spring and early summer, according to Charles H. Hadley, chief of the United States Department of Agriculture beetle research station here.
The Board of Estimate's public hearing on "Proposals to Improve the Port of New York" will be broadcast in full by WNYC on Monday, starting at 10:30 A.M. Mayor O'Dwyer will preside.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi of Englewood, N.J., turned in his second consecutive six-under par 66 today to take a five-stroke lead in the $16,500 Dapper Dan invitation golf tournament.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals broke out of their hitting slump and spoiled the managerial debut of Allen (Dusty) Cooke tonight as they routed the Phillies, 8 to 2. Relief Pitcher Ted Wilks blanked the Phils for the last four innings and batted in three runs with a sixth-inning double.

The Norton Supply Company, specializing in the sale, rental and service of construction equipment and machinery, plans to move from the Bronx to Long Island City, Queens, where it has purchased a site for its new main metropolitan headquarters and distribution center.

Retail trade here this week showed a fair increase as business continues with a "healthy undercurrent," according to retailers. Department store sales were estimated as about 9 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were off 10 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- Bob Feller, booed in his first start since declining to play in the All-Star game, lasted only a third of an inning tonight as the Athletics beat the Cleveland Indians, 10 to 5. Lefty Lou Brissie gave up ten hits, including Ken Keltner's twenty-second homer with two on, in winning his ninth game of the season.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Braves today defeated the Cubs, 12 to 10, for their sixth straight victory and their eleventh in twelve games against the Bruins this season.
The City Rent Commission will scrutinize the sale of property on Washington Square to New York University by Anthony Campagna, it was announced last night.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 16 -- Federal aid to education is essential if the school crisis facing this country is to be solved, Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, chairman of the New York University Department of Higher Education, declared here today.

Prices on the stock market slumped again yesterday, a new selling wave forcing the average back to the mid-May level. Thus, within the span of a week, the market had surrendered all of the gains scored in two months. Losses approximated those of the previous session, ranging from 1 to 3 points, with the combined averages down 1.46 point.

The Metropolitan Opera Association operated with a net deficit of about $220,000 during the fiscal year which ended May 31, according to a joint statement by George A. Sloan, chairman of the board, and Charles M. Spofford, president. The figure includes the 1947-48 season in New York and on tour.

HONG KONG, Saturday, July 17 (AP) -- Twenty-three persons were reported today to have perished in the crash of a flying boat during its forty-mile flight from Macao to Hong Kong late yesterday. Cathay Pacific Airways officials reported the plane sank after a forced alighting about four miles east of Macao.

Six hundred and twenty-three open-market sales of real estate in the Bronx for the second quarter of this year amounted to $17,491,000 on total assessed valuations of $18,174,000, compared with 490 transactions totaling $16,204,000 on valuations of $16,221,000 in the first quarter of the year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 16 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, notified Israel and the seven members of the Arab League today that the new truce in the Holy Land, if accepted by both sides, would go into effect Sunday at 3 P.M. Greenwich Mean Time, or 11 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time.

The case of Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, has now reached a point where the Atomic Energy Commission considers him a good security risk, whereas the House Committee on Un-American Activities is still gunning for him.
In perhaps the most amazing managerial shake-up that the major leagues have ever experienced, the following three developments cracked down yesterday on a bewildered baseball world:

The setting, the music, the script and the pattern were so much alike that a spectator falling asleep in the Republican convention and waking up in the Democratic could not tell the difference. There was the same tropical atmosphere, the same effect of static in the stale political oratory that nobody listened to, the same restless shuffling among the, delegates, the same thumping and whistling and parades of cardboard faces.
Net income of Safeway Stores, Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries amounted to $3,200,507 after all deductions for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 12, according to a report issued yesterday.

PEIPING, July 16 -- The sound of artillery fire was heard here this morning as fighting broke out along a forty-mile stretch of the Peiping-Hankow railway below Changhsintien, twelve miles southwest of Peiping.
Paul W. Deubery has been promoted to Crosley director of industrial relations at the Avco Manufacturing Corporation. He formerly was manager of labor relations.
BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The question of allowing a music school amid the tranquillity of Beacon Street was argued today.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 16 -- Playing in tip-top form virtually all the way, Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. from Piping Rock defeated Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook to retain her laurels in the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship at the Wheatley Hills course today.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., July 16 (UP) -- This town which began as a whisper celebrated the third birthday of the atomic bomb, of which it is the home.

A 12-year-old shoe-shine boy kept the police of the 103d Precinct in Queens at bay for hours early yesterday with a cap pistol and a "no-talking" attitude. The runaway's actions, including a mock gun duel, were designed to prevent authorities from learning his name.

GENEVA, July 16 -- Economic plans serving as the basis of German claims for aid under the European Recovery Program greatly inflate the German requirements and badly underestimate the bizonal area's capacity to export to Western Europe, in the opinion of qualified experts here.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 16 -- In a day of upsets, Mark Flanagan of Riverhead, a mainstay of the Georgetown team twenty years ago, emerged with a full share of the honors after two rounds in the Long Island amateur golf championship at the Rockville Country Club today.

Business has been "inept" in its efforts to reach the public with the "true story" of industrial profits through newspapers, regarded as primary medium for this purpose, according to a survey reported yesterday by Modern Industry Magazine.

TRENTON, N.J., July 16 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court late today refused to quash indictments against George W. Frost, retired Chief of Police of Camden, and Police Captain Gustav Koerner of Camden charging misconduct in office as the result of the gambling inquiry conducted by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper.

LONDON, July 16 -- It became more than ever apparent today that the Western Allies have been rocked back on their heels by the Russian rejection of their demands concerning Berlin. Preliminary discussions on what to do about it seems to be shaping toward recourse to Article 33 of the United Nations Charter.

Aftab Ali, veteran labor leader from East Bengal, India, who represents Pakistan labor in the International Labor Office, appealed last night to his countrymen "not to jump their ships because New York City looks like heaven." His was delivered at the Pakistan League of America, 193 Eldridge Street, to build morale among Pakistan nationals now living in the metropolitan area.
Joe McNamee was guest catcher yesterday for the First Avenue Cardinals.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16 (UP) -- Arab and Jewish Governments moved suddenly tonight to obey the demand of the United Nations that fighting be stopped in Palestine. It was hoped that by the week end the guns would be silent all over the Holy Land and that Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, would be left free to attempt a permanent settlement of the Palestine problem.

Capt. Jean Le Manchec, master of the French liner De Grasse and a company veteran of twenty-nine years, will retire on the return of his ship to Havre, he announced yesterday when the liner arrived from Havre and Southampton with 721 passengers.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 16 -- Teachers are in a strategic position to indoctrinate pupils with a respect for law and order, according to A.E. Ostholhoff, Cincinnati agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He addressed 200 classroom teachers today, at Miami University, at their fifth national conference.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 16 -- John M. Hancock, New York industrial banker, urged tonight that the United States had "best go ahead" manufacturing all the atomic bombs it could produce since international control of that energy "clearly seems impossible" at the moment.

On her way through New York en route from Paris to Kansas City, Madame Helene Lyolene found time yesterday to sketch a word picture of Paris styles as seen in the smart restaurants and on the Faubourg St. Honore, the Place Vendome and Rue Matignon.

Once again the pollution of the Democratic organization in New York County has been exposed to light and air, thanks to Mayor O'Dwyer. This time, however, independent and civic-minded Democrats have the leadership of a Mayor with the courage and integrity to throw down the gauntlet to the undesirable element of the party.
A small local that broke away from the country's largest left-wing union early this year has won the right to hold a collective bargaining election in which the parent group will not be represented.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Warning that the Government would no longer be able to contribute substantially to the control of inflationary pressures by an excess of receipts over expenditures, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, called upon the banks of America today to increase their anti-inflationary efforts wherever possible.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- Survival of the shipping industry on the West Coast depends on the "stabilization" of maritime labor, officials of American President Lines told the thirty-fifth annual convention of Pacific Coast Port Authorities here today.
The Jewish People's Fraternal Order of 80 Fifth Avenue presented five ambulances for Israel yesterday to the Red lVlogen Dovid, the Israel equivalent of the Red Cross, it was announced.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Following is the statement of Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, in announcing today the grant of a wage increase:

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 16 -- Miss Kay Byrne of Westchester Hills won the Tri-County golf championship by 10 and 9 from Mrs. R.P. Limburg of the home club in the 36-hole final over the Century Country Club course today.
The letter published recently on our debt to Brazil is not only kindness on the part of Major Benjamin Namm -- it involves wisdom, in my opinion.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The long legal battle over the $5,000,000 Chancellor trust fund was ended today with a settlement of $75,000 cash and income from a $750,000 trust fund on Mrs. Charlotte Chancellor of Montecito, Calif.

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 16 -- The entire United States Olympic party gathered for the first time in the ship's ballroom this morning and heard words of advice from Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, and of welcome from Capt. John W. Anderson, commander of the America.

CINCINNATI, July 16 -- Old Barney Shotton, the calmest manager in the business, strolled into the Dodger clubhouse today and was greeted just as calmly by the Dodgers whose boss he had become for the second time.

Twenty-seven years ago last June, five days after their wedding, Annie and Leonard Uren of Redruth, a small mining town near Falmouth on England's Cornwall coast, parted at Southampton quayside. He was going to America. He told Annie he would send for her when he had built her a home in the new land.

Eighteen swimmers, three divers and twelve water polo players, with accompanying officials, took off for London and the Olympics last night in the final group departure of a United States squad that totals 341 athletes in seventeen sports.

LONDON, July 16 -- The overnight fall in prices on Wall Street and the continued tension over the Berlin situation added to a desire to keep books "all square" before the week-end caused selling in the stock market here today and prices closed at their lowest levels.

The annual report of the Camp Fire Girls, Inc., is at once an account or an excellent year's achievements and an appeal for financial aid. During the year the organization raised its national membership' by 46,000 girls, bringing its enrollment to 360,000, the largest in its history.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Following is the text of a statement made today by the United Steelworkers, CIO, concerning its wage agreement with the United States Steel Corporation:
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The first Marshall Plan loan was announced today -- $2,300,000 to Iceland to build up its fishing industry.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 16 -- Jack Mitchell of the Essex County Country Club took a one-stroke lead at the half-way mark in the New Jersey State open championship at the Forest Hill Field Club today with a two-round total of 136.

An "officer candidate school" to train men in a "fight against communism" will be established soon in Washington at the headquarters of the Catholic War Veterans, Anthony H. Forbes, recently elected president of the national group, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, July 16 -- German-model fighter plans, acquired from the Czechoslovak Government are being shipped from Czechoslovakia to Israel by a freighter air service of the Israeli Government, it was learned authoritatively today.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16 -- Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne adjourned today until July 26 a hearing to set bail for former Police Judge P. James Pellecchia, who is accused of embezzling more than $630,000 from his family's Columbus Trust Company to cover losses in betting on horse races.

PARIS, July 16 -- European governments participating in Marshall Plan credits will assume the responsibility of dividing those credits for the first year of the plan, the Council of the Organization for European Economic Recovery announced today.

THE narrow confines of the usual professional Broadway play and stage are not fitted to the dramatic needs and genius of the American people. They cannot contain our richness of tradition, our imaginative folk-life, our boundless enthusiasm and health, our singing and dancing and poetry, our lifted hearts and active feet and hands, even our multitudinous mechanical means for self-expression.

TWO important airlines expressed their faith in the future here last week in different ways. Croil Hunter, president of Northwest Airlines, said his company would end the year in the black, and that there was nothing in the low state of airline finances generally that good management and a more understanding attitude on the part of Federal authorities could not cure.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17--Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, appeared optimistic today when he left for his headquarters on Rhodes to resume negotiations for an Arab-Israeli agreement on the Holy Land.

THERE are at least three approaches to superstition -- the frankly believing, the rational and the whimsical -- and all of them, let it be said, are tinged with awe. Miss de Lys takes all these roads, and adds the psychological and historical.
The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that its campaign to date had brought $12,182,470, a record sum, but $4,000,000 less than the goal. Last year's collections amounted to $12,126,875.

THE great bronze door with its exquisitely carved panels, shown at the right, is the work of Lorenzo Ghiberti, fifteenth-century Italian sculptor. It is one of the three celebrated gilded bronze doors to the Baptistery of St. John the Baptist in Florence, which have just been restored to the splendor with which they dazzled Florentines some 500 years ago.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- In a make-shift uniform that reflected the haste with which he had shifted from the Dodgers, Leo Durocher today led his Giants on Forbes Field and celebrated his debut as their manager with a 6-to-5 victory over the Pirates before 16,071 cash customers.

Prices are expected to be among the subjects that will come up for serious discussion at the special session of Congress, called by President Truman to convene on July 26. Since both the Republican and Democratic parties emphasized in their recently adopted platforms the present high cost of living, there is a chance that some legislation designed to stop the rising trend of prices may be enacted.

THEY are still talking about the May Show in Cleveland. The annual exhibition of local artists and craftsmen drew over 95,000 visitors this year and more than $22,500 worth of objects were sold, many of them to the shoving ladies who queued up at the preview as if on a wartime nylon-stocking line.

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 17 -- Coaching assignments for track were made by Dean Cromwell today as the United States Olympic athletes reveled in another day of radiant weather at sea. The head coach will have direct charge of the 100, 200 and 400-meter races and the two relays. Emil Von Elling of N.Y.U. will supervise the steeplechase, hammer, discus, javelin, hop, step and jump.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- America's crop prospects add up to one of the most favorable world developments since the war ended.

AS EXPECTED the repercussions in the wake of the by now internationally famous Durocher-Shotton-Ott razzle-dazzle have been little short of super-dynamic. Jammed into a crucible sufficiently strong to withstand the pressure and you'd have enough force and energy to hit Mars from here on the fly.
IF high bush blueberry were not a wild plant, we undoubtedly would regard it more favorably. The fruit, of course, is properly appreciated, but the ornamental value of the shrub is neglected.

TO most Americans the word "sandwich" suggests our national snack, usually two or three slices of devitalized bread, enclosing such varied sundries as canned fish, fumed meat, ground peanuts, limp lettuce or marshmallows. To a large but not always discriminating number of antiques collectors "Sandwich" is a handy term for almost any glass made in the nineteenth century.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17 -- Following is "the declaration of principles" reported today by the Resolutions Committee of the States' Rights meeting:

Retail trade here was fairly active last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Activity was highlighted by clearances in sportswear, cotton dress and jewelry departments and promotions of fall coats and suits.

GARDINER, Me., July 17 -- Henry Richards of Gardiner, graduate of Harvard University and of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, celebrated his 100th birthday here today. In honor of the event, the Gardiner Library Association, of which he was one of the founders, is presenting an exhibition of his paintings at Library Hall.

THROUGH authorization from the Eightieth Congress, the Postoffice Department is establishing a precedent by issuing stamps with portraits of six American women within one calendar year and in addition with a stamp honoring Gold Star Mothers.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 17 -- As American as apple pie and ice cream, the summer session has now become an accepted collegiate tradition. Almost every college, large and small, conducts such a program.

BALTIMORE, July 17 -- With a draw in the twelfth and final round of the tournament for the National open championship of the United States Chess Federation, Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., with a score of 9 1/2 -- 2 1/2, today gained the title which was won last year by Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, at Corpus Christi, Tex.

THE pageantry of the Republican and Democratic conventions is over. Now comes the discipline, the semi-military marshaling of forces and the hard campaign work. It is all distinctively American, and in most respects it is all comparatively new. Though political parties are as old as our Government, the tremendous mechanism of national, state and local party organizations, pivoted upon local, state and national conventions, dates only from the second administration of Andrew Jackson.
