WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Soviet Government has decreed a 10 to 20 per cent cut in the prices of certain consumer goods sold in state stores, but the reductions apply generally to goods that are not important in the expenditure of the average Soviet wage earner, according to information released this week by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

AS the high priestess of the one-act play in America, Margaret Mayorga has been wading through scripts for more than a decade with the zeal and zest of a true votary of Thespis. She never tires in her appointed task, and each year's wading brings her her rewards.
VIENNA, July 17 -- The Soviet occupation forces have seized another Austrian policeman who was apparently investigating seditious activity.

ROBERT DARVAS is a Hungarian, long known to connoisseurs of bridge hands for his phenomenal gift for discovering unusual feats of play. In ordinary times these are quickly disseminated through the bridge world by bridge magazines and newspaper columns.

FOR one happy moment there last week, this reviewer was on the verge of thinking he'd seen the picture which must surely mark the end of gangster films. That was the moment in "Key Largo" when Humphrey Bogart fired several screaming shots into the groveling body of Edward G. Robinson, then turned triumphantly, a new man, to face the dawn.

Financial markets last week broke out of the trading rut in which they had been stymied nearly two months. Surprising all the prognosticators, who believed that the next market move would be at advancing prices, values melted away as a result of a Presidential recall of Congress for July 26 and a deteriorating foreign situation. On balance, stocks ended on a reactionary note, erasing all gains since mid-May.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina was unanimously chosen today by a group of rebellious Southern Democrats as a Presidential candidate to lead them in a fight to defeat President Truman in the November general elections.

The police reported yesterday that a woman patient at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, was killed accidentally by an electric shock Friday morning while she was in an "iron lung" and preparation was being made to use a bronchoscope on her.

ABOARD U.S.S. IOWA EN ROUTE TO PEARL HARBOR, July 17 (UP) -- Carrier planes from the U.S.S. Boxer made a surprise dawn "attack" today on the battleship Iowa and three escorting cruisers in maneuvers 800 miles from Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey was re-appointed Director of Selective Service by President Truman today. It was another step toward national preparedness as unrest in Europe continued.

SHALLOW containers offer an opportunity to make flower arrangements that look refreshingly different from those in medium and tall vases. This is especially true of annual flowers, which seem to be most abundant now, and have endless possibilities when arranged in this manner.
More than 10,000,000 veterans of World War II are allowing an estimated $100,000,000,000 of low-cost National Service Life Insurance to slip through their fingers.

HAGANAH, the military arm of Israel, is probably the world's most democratic army. It is the answer to a GI's dream. The soldier doesn't have to salute the officers, there are no "brass hats," and if the GI is so inclined he can refer openly to his commanding officer as a "fathead" without fearing court-martial.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- In a gloves-off talk before 500 aviation engineers, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, last night roundly criticized the administration of the country's armed forces in several major aspects.

THE sound, the sight, and the smell of a Nebraska farm are captured and then graphically reproduced in this unusual book. A series of elusive but none the less definite impressions come to you -- occasionally not unlike a stray pressed posy in a faded album, at other times it is a slow-paced cryptic phrase.
HONG KONG, July 17 -- Chinese charges that an uncooperative British administration in Hong Kong is intensifying China's economic ills were denied here today a British official:

Delegates from thirty-eight nations attending the first international poliomyelitis conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel voted unanimously at the closing session yesterday to establish a permanent World Congress on Poliomyelitis to carry on global war against the disease.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- Jerry McCarthy's Egretta scored an easy three-length victory over Allen T. Simmons' heavily-backed Eternal Flag in the $10,000 added Betsy Ross Stake for 2-year-old fillies today before 21,265 fans at Suffolk downs.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, in a telephone interview from his home in Concord, said today that the Senate Appropriations Committee, of which he is chairman, would take a "tough" look at the spending side of Mr. Truman's anti-inflation and social welfare program to be offered at the special session of Congress.
For months many American consumers have had this wistful hope about inflation: "Maybe it'll go away by itself."

LONDON, July 17 -- This is an uneasy week-end in Europe. Deep in the consciousness of everyone there lies the conviction that the time is fast approaching for a showdown between Western Europe and Soviet Russia.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 17 -- Men and women who once used McGuffey's famed readers as part of their schooling will gather at Miami University here -- where William Holmes McGuffey wrote most of the readers -- for their national convention July 24 and 25.
ROME, July 17 -- Most Italians suspected that the ominous peace which descended upon their country after the April 18 election was a mere lull before the storm.

WASHINGTON, July 17--A long line of trucks and howitzers rumbling into Washington this evening from Fort Bragg, N.C., signalized the peaceful mobilization of troops being gathered here to pay a peaceful final tribute on Monday to the No. 1 soldier of the United States, Gen. John J. Pershing.

LONDON, July 17 -- Delegates from 800 organizations representing trade unions, the Communist party and peace organizations cheered a message from Henry A. Wallace at the National Peace Conference, which was organized here today by The Daily Worker, organ of the British Communist party.

ANXIETY over job security was more acute here last week than at any time in recent years. Reason: large scale firings at several studios and prospective curtailment of employment at others as the result of reduced filming activity.
Direct service between long distance telephone switchboards in Chicago and individual numbers in New York will be started today, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday.

DIXON WECTER, chairman of the Research Group of the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif., has written a sound and scholarly review of those years of depression and recovery between 1929 and 1941 -- years which made so many marks, not all of them scars, upon the political, economic and social surface of American life.

One of the country's major retail groups has begun experiments in psychological testing of employes with the objective of selecting and placing them more efficiently and suitably, one of its personnel executives disclosed in an interview last week.

PRAGUE, July 17--The Czechoslovak Ministries of the Interior and of National Defense charged tonight that a group of Czechoslovak refugees, headed by an agent in the service of the United States counter-intelligence corps, had crossed the frontier to murder high political and military officials, including War Minister Ludvig Svoboda.

WHEN Charles Hollison, the wealthy paint manufacturer, is found with his head bashed in, the police are unable to uncover a real clue to the murderer. The most likely suspects are Hollison's son, Geoffrey, and his nephew, Arthur Cross.

LONDON, July 17 (UP) -- The United States Navy said today that the mutiny SOS radioed from the American freighter William Carson last Monday was sent by a radio man of "doubtful" sanity, who jumped overboard after he sent the message.

THE future of opera by television, in which Toscanini as well as the directors of the NBC are deeply interested, was discussed last week by Samuel Chotzinoff, general musical director of NBC, on his return from a trip abroad with Toscanini.

MANY motorists still think that the traffic court is an organized racket to get their money, or a comedy diversion with the judge starring in the role of comedian, according to a judicial summary by Judge Edward C. Fisher, who is a chairman of the traffic court division, National Safety Council, and member of the American Bar Association committee on improvement of traffic courts.

SOME weeks ago, a waiter at a London hotel left his job at noon on Saturday and a few hours later boarded the transatlantic plane at Prestwick, Scotland. Just over twenty-four hours later, he landed at Malton Airport near Toronto, Ontario, was checked in by immigration and customs officials, and applied that same day -- Sunday -- for a waiter's job at a Toronto hotel.

LYNWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Twelve thousand members of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church will end tomorrow the sect's annual West Coast camp meeting. The ten-day gathering, in a tent city, marked the one hundredth anniversary of the group's adoption of the Saturday Sabbath doctrine.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- To the thousands of visitors who pass through this little village at the southwestern tip of Cape Cod en route to Nantucket or Martha's Vineyard, Woods Hole is little more than a jumping-off place.

APART from the research of Katherine Dunham, some of the results of which she has presented to us in her dance compositions, the dances of the West Indies are still virtually unknown in the United States. In commercialized and diluted form, to be sure, the rumba and the conga have worked their way up to the night clubs and the musical comedy stage.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 17 -- A huge expansion of the nursery and kindergarten programs of the nation's public school system was advocated today by educators attending the annual Family Life Conference, sponsored by the New York University summer session.

CONTEMPORARY designers, as a rule, frown upon anything that smacks of camouflage. "Be honest," they say; "don't try to make something look like something else. You fool no one and in the process lose the natural beauty that even the humblest materials have to start with."

THE new Quota Act, by which British cinemas are required to devote 45 per cent of their first feature playing time to British films, and to show British films to the extent of 25 per cent of their remaining screen time, is causing not a little perturbation over here.

Household Finance Corporation has borrowed $25,000,000 on 3 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1964, B.E. Henderson, president of the corporation, announced yesterday. The debentures were sold in equal amount at par to Equitable Life Assurance Society and the New York Life Insurance Company. Proceeds were used to prepay short-term bank loans.

Dr. Joseph A. Gengerelli, associate professor of psychology in the University of California, wants to know how rats behave when their brains are electrically stimulated. Psychologists have wired rats to a source of electricity, pushed a button and then watched what happened.

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- Peace came to Jerusalem this morning with the forces of both Israel and the Arabs observing the cease-fire deadline of the United Nations Security Council. But it was ushered in with one of the greatest battles the Holy City has witnessed.

BILLINGS, Mont. -- Another summer program, of genuine Western rodeos and roundups, camping, fishing and visits to dude ranches awaits the travelers to Montana, third largest state in the Union and, by Eastern standards, still full of vestiges of the wild and woolly West.

This last week as a thousand delegates from thirty-eight nations sat in the scientific sessions, conferences and clinical demonstrations of the first International Poliomyelitis Conference here in New York, one of the most prominent orthopedic surgeons in the South was not present.
HONG KONG, July 17 (AP) -- Twenty-five persons, including at least six Americans. were killed late Friday in the crash of a Catalina flying boat four miles of Macao.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 17 -- Arab acceptance of a Palestine truce on the condition that its effects apply equally to Israel and Arabs was hinted at in informed political quarters tonight.
The Berlin airlift -- magnificent achievement in logistics though it is -- is a losing proposition.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi, mechanical man from Englewood, N.J., virtually wrapped up the $16,500 Dapper Dan invitation golf tournament today with his third sub-par round, a two under 70, which game him 202 for fifty-four holes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 -- There was a golden jubilee here today, such as always is reminiscent of the past and suggesting deterioration, but that of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week swelled with proof that sail yachting is enduring and still without growing pains.

There must be many readers of this and other newspapers who are honestly worried about the guarantees of free speech and a free press which are written into the First Amendment to the Constitution. We would like to refer these readers to an article entitled "Everything Worth Saying Should Be Said," written by Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn and published in today's issue of our Magazine.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 17 -- The Israeli Government has accepted a truce against the judgment of its military commanders who feel that they are winning and that it here is no point now in giving the Arabs the advantage.
Both rain and Sidney B. Wood failed to stop William F. Talbert from reaching the final round of the New York State tennis championship tournament yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 17--Under ideal weather conditions four seeded players won during the first and second rounds of the 1948 United States Army tennis championship tournament which started today at the United States Military Academy, with the top seeded First Lieut. Frank Mehner, European command ace, defeating T/5 Lionel Gordon, enlisted representative of the Second Army, 6--0, 6--2.
The thirtieth annual convention of the New York County organization of the American Legion closed yesterday afternoon at Manhattan Center with the election of officers.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The crisis between the East and the West, caused by the Soviet Union over Berlin, appears to be worsening rapidly. For the first time Western observers here sense a feeling among United States and British officials that the Russians are prepared to go to war over Berlin provided an overt act causing war can be forced on the Western powers.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations distributed to its membership today a voting guide to what it described as "one of the worst Congresses in this nation's history."

AS a writer of fantasies, Frank Baker has always skirted on poetic truths; combining fact with fancy, he has teased us with thoughts of the interchangeableness of past and present and the thin line separating dream and reality.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The 1948 potato crop already has cost the Government about $16,000,000 and will cost considerable more if production forecasts hold true.
Retail trade here continued active last week, with seasonal merchandise in good demand. Departmnt store sales were estimated at about 9 per cent over the corresponding week last year.
JUVENAL, the Roman satirist, nearly two thousand years ago, observed: "Two things only the people anxiously desire -- bread and circus games."

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 -- New factories and additions to old plants in the electric washer and ironer industry represent investments totaling $10,000,000, with some of the largest yet to be completed, Roy A. Bradt, president of the American Washer and Ironer Manufacturers Association, declared here today.
THE Second District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will hold "A Day at Bethpage" at the Bethpage Club House on Thursday. The event is open to members and non-members.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (UP) -- A proposal that would make eligible pass receivers easily identifiable was expected to spark heated discussion at the regular midsummer meeting of the National Football League tomorrow.

THE principal beneficence of a university should be that it stimulates an appetite for knowledge and understanding. You must not, of course, expect to receive education from your university; for a university that offered an orderly, finite and readily comprehensible scheme of education -- education as differenced from instruction -- could only exist as the political instrument of a despotic or total state.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Ineffective Washington pitching helped the White Sox to a 9-7 victory today. The Senators' hurlers gave eight walks and twelve hits.

THIS hard-hitting novel has meaning on a variety of levels: more elaborate than most recent works of fiction, it has a Victorian intricacy of plot. Casual events are maneuvered to produce consequences important for the story -- for crass casualty, as Mr. van Gelder sees it, can have serious, even tragical, consequences.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 17 -- United States authorities have strongly protested British efforts to outbid the United States for German scrap iron and steel, which is desperately short in both countries.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17 -- P. James Pellecchia, who resigned as a Newark police judge Tuesday after confessing he embezzled $657,000 from the Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel, was as addicted to dice games as he was to horse race betting, it was indicated today by New Jersey Attorney General, Walter D. Van Riper.

Because of a rapid increase in traffic, the Suez Canal Company has been forced to institute temporarily a convoy system for shipping passing through the canal, it was announced yesterday by the United States Navy Hydrographic Office.

LAST Monday was Sidney Lenz' seventy-fifth birthday, and his bridge-playing companions of other days assembled to honor the man who was called "the grand old man of bridge" as long ago as 1932. Joseph Rothschild, who arranged the party, was proud that he had Ely Culbertson sitting on the right of Mr. Lenz, and P. Hal Sims on his left.

Previous indications of a landslide here in favor of Joseph Curran, president, and his right-wing slate in the national elections of the National Maritime Union, CIO, were borne out when the counting of the New York votes was completed yesterday afternoon.

TREMBLES was the name of a minute shambles of a Montana ghost town that is now no longer on the map. North of it were the Three Buttes; south of it the turbulent, variable Yellowstone River rushed to join the Missouri.

DAVID GOLDKNOPF'S "Hills on the Highway" concerns a writer. His "hills" are the towering moral issues before the idealist -- the hills that grow less steep with each artistic compromise. Leonard begins writing "seriously" after he gets out of the army, but war stories are no longer topical, and his art has neither mass nor class appeal.

WORLD-OUT-OF-JOINT DIVISION: The following communique was received by Rinehart Co. from Peiping. China: "Kindly forward me the free catalogue of recent and forthcoming publications as advertised in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review."

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Wheat prices slipped further on the Board of Trade today, the July contract going well under the Government loan level for cash wheat here. Moderate hedging pressure was enough to knock prices down in view of limited milling and speculative demand.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 17 -- Making progress that exceeded the expectation of officers and staff headquarters, the 400 recruits of the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment of Manhattan prepared tonight to greet relatives and friends tomorrow after a week of intensive basic training at Camp Smith here.

AMATEURS shoot patterns chiefly as an expression of their delight with form and design based on accidental discoveries while hunting for subjects. The most frequently observed patterns are caused by shadows cast by ornamental iron or stone work and by other objects whose outlines result in interesting shadow shapes.

BELLES-LETTRES lately have been taking quite a mauling from the muscle men. Spurred by the confessions of doctors, lawyers, actors and curdled ex-Cabinet members, second base-men, singles' champions, prize fighters and divot diggers have laid down the tools of their trade and bared both their souls and their syntax, sometimes even their spooks, for varying fees.

Miss Betty Shields, Women's Swimming Association star, enjoyed a field day in the women's senior Metropolitan A.A.U. championships conducted yesterday in the Flushing Amphitheatre pool. Of the five titles decided, Miss Shields annexed three individual crowns and swam anchor on the winning 800-meter free-style relay four.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- The bats of Granville Hamner and his teammates proved to be good for one run more than the bats of Stan Musial and his mates today as the Phils nosed out the Cardinals, 11 to 10.

CALABASAS, Calif. -- Don L. Smith, 14, has a year in the hospital and three more operations ahead of him. But he figures that, thanks to all the people who responded to his appeal for travel literature, it's going to be an interesting and busy year.

The Democratic party came out of its Philadelphia convention morally stronger, if perhaps numerically weaker, than it went in. It came out with fire in its eye, in place of the glazed look of a week ago. The contrast between the two national conventions is dramatic.

LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Middlesex County had to fight hard for runs against some accurate Australian bowling, well supported by excellent fielding, in their three days cricket match which began at Lords cricket ground today. The Countymen were dismissed for 203 in their first innings and the Australians were six for no wickets when rain stopped play for the day.

ALICIA MARKOVA and Anton Dolin will make their first appearances here since their recent guest season with the Sadler's Wells Ballet in London on Tuesday at 2:30 and again at 8:30 in the World's Fair of Music at Grand Central Palace.

ANYTIME they're in the neighborhood of Lee Shubert's office Irving Berlin and Max Gordon make it their business to look in on Kitty Hall and perhaps urge her to tell once more of her first opportunity to act.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- Indian sources allege that nine battalions of regular Pakistani troops are engaged against Indian army forces in Kashmir. It is understood that this information has been placed before the United Nations Security Council commission that is here investigating India's complaint against Pakistan relative to the Kashmir issue.

SEVENTEEN-YEAR-OLD Rue Higginson with her skill at games and warm friendliness wanted to be a play director. Stern Aunt Laura said learning to play was nonsense. She agreed to lend Rue money for only one semester; unless Rue made A's in every subject, she should come home and be a sensible school teacher.

FRANK GANNETT calls his newspapers a group and not a chain; more important than the word is the fact that he owns or controls twenty-one newspapers and a half-dozen radio stations. That is the largest group of news journals under any one management.

NANKING, July 17 -- The Communist radio reported tonight that Red forces under Gen. Ho Lung had seriously crippled the military strength of Gen. Yen Hsi-shan. Governor of Shansi Province and had reduced his central Shansi pocket to four cities.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 17 -- Favored by a break in the weather after light rain which failed to hold up the competition's progress, the Eastern Clay Court Tennis championship got off to a flying start at Travers Island today. So briskly were the matches played that by the time the last racquet wielder retired from the court, the huge starting field was whittled almost in half.

Determined to meet the sharp competition now being offered them by other thrift institutions, in the face of a marked decline in the rate of public savings generally, savings bankers in this state are planning an intensive advertising campaign to "merchandise" their facilities. The campaign, it was learned yesterday, will be largely concentrated in newspaper media, and will be supported by the mutual savings banks of the state on a cooperative basis.

Retailers must take cognizance of the growing importance of fashion merchandising of women's hosiery as a means of increasing turnover and profits, according to Roy Tilles, president of Gotham Hosiery Company, Inc. The new concept of hosiery merchandising, he said in an interview last week, reveals a definite split from selling with emphasis on price to that of coordinating sales to fashion trends.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17 -- The South's legendary truculence and predilection for lost causes prompted an immediate reaction throughout Dixie this week when the Democratic National Convention overrode Southern delegates on the civil-rights issue and nominated President Truman.

ONCE again Broadway's avant garde is talking about the necessity of reducing theatre ticket prices. A week or so ago James Russo, one of the co-producers of "The Play's the Thing," was quoted as saying that the $4.80 ticket for straight plays was on the way out and the other night a producer of one of the town's better musicals, categorically stated that the $6 top for musicals would have to go.
We veterans at Ohio State University would like to know, after seeing the article and pictures on the "Draft of '48," what's so new about the "New Army"?

Conservation Commissioner Perry B. Duryea tells what is planned to improve fishing in this state in the current "New York State Conservationist." It's a short outline of the highlights which here is condensed even more because of space limitations. Mr. Duryea's program:

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board disagreed today with a Federal District Judge on what is commerce under the Taft-Hartley Law. His report, if sustained, will have an important bearing on Federal labor regulation of local building industry.

As the climax of what the Securities and Exchange Commission has described as "one of the most complex cases ever to come before the Commission," a group of bond holders of the Pittsburgh Railways Company on Thursday filed a petition with the United States District Court for the Western Disric of Pennsylvania asking for the removal of the trustee for the company, W.D. George.

LONDON, July 17 -- Upon his return from nearly a week in Berlin, Anthony Eden, deputy Opposition leader in the House of Commons, reported today that the "overwhelming majority of Berliners is earnestly insistent that the Western powers shall stay in Berlin."

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 17 -- Johnny Humm of Rockville Centre proved to be a dangerous putter both on and off the greens today as he reached the final of the Long Island amateur golf championship along with 40year-old Joe Feldman of Inwood, former New York State Public links champion, at the Rockville Country Club course.

Tityrus knew what to do when the weather got very hot. His friend Meliboeus found him stretched out beneath a beech tree -- "recubans sub tegmine fagi," says the text. He was playing on some sort of reed instrument and singing snatches of a song.

Two new, contrasting methods of providing medical and hospital care for large groups are on trial. One is the system of governmental health care, which is receiving its greatest test in Great Britain. The other is that of the voluntary, nonprofit agencies that are developing in this country.
DUBLIN -- Irish tourist officials are reluctant to estimate the number of Americans who will be in Ireland this year, but about 15,000 would be a good guess, most of them in Dublin.

What follows is a compilation of news items, exclusive of reports on the German crisis, from recent Russian newspapers and periodicals. Harry Schwartz, Assistant Professor of Economics at Syracuse University, selected the articles and prepared the summary.

THE gardener who avoids trouble as long as he possibly can usually waits to buy a duster or a sprayer until diseases and insect pests force a decision. He then finds himself faced with the questions of whether to dust or spray, and of choosing among the dozens of units available for applying pest-control materials.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 17 -- Accorded little chance against such standouts as Macbeth, Faraway, Newsweekly and others in a twelve-horse field, First Nighter registered an upset triumph in the Lamplighter Handicap, the $15,000 added race that served as the feature on the card at Monmouth Park today.

The promising results obtained in spastic conditions with a new synthetic, myanesin, are reported in The Journal of the American Medical Association by Drs. R. Plato Schwartz and Frank M. Berger of the University of Rochester. Myanesin is no sure cure for anything, but, it does seem to open a new approach to the treatment of neuromuscular incapacity at any age.

The steel industry's experiment with lowered prices and stabilized wages in an effort to lead an anti-inflation campaign had its official demise last week. Its end came on Friday as the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's leading steel producer and the initiator of the fight against spiralling costs, granted higher wages to 170,000 production workers and announced imminent price increases.

WEDNESDAY'S marathon of oratory an acrimony at the Democratic convention provided the most bizarre television show yet. For sheer wear on the televiewer's eyes and fortitude there was never anything like it -- an arduous grind that only in the early hours of Thursday morning captured anything like the spectator interest enjoyed by the Republican conclave.

THERE are many cartoonists whose output can be enjoyed weekly, or even daily. But H.T. Webster, whose work is here presented, is one of the very few who can survive being presented in such a massive dose. These are rarities among cartoon books for they may all be read at a sitting without impairing the enjoyment of even the last drawing.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles and Clarence Carter of San Francisco, seeded fifth and sixth, will meet tomorrow for the National Clay Court tennis championship.

WITH practically no new theatres built in Canada since before the second World War, the Dominion in the past year has seen the start of a theatre building boom which is now nearing its peak. Currently one hundred new theatres are under construction throughout the country, ranging from pre-fabricated theatres for rural communities to a new $2,000,000 showcase seating 2,400 persons in Toronto, the largest theatre built in this city since 1919.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The advisory board of the Inland Waterways Corporation today recommended four temporary measures to conserve the corporation's "dwindling financial resources."
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- A new arrangement with the British Broadcasting Corporation to make the "Voice of America" heard more clearly in Europe was announced today by the State Department.
NEW ORLEANS, July 17 -- New Orleans shipping officials are looking forward to the European Recovery Program to give impetus to declining export trade.

IT would be difficult for even the most talented author to make a physically deformed, mentally deficient, sexually repressed, traitorous individual into a sympathetic character. This enormity has been attempted in his second novel, "A Sigh for a Drumbeat," by Patrick Doncaster, who has also written an earlier novel, "The Devil Held the Aces."
BAY SHORE, L.I., July 17 -- A fleet of fifty-five craft turned out today for the two-day invitation regatta of the Bay Shore Yacht Club.
In reference to Mark Goodson's defense of radio give-away programs last week, may I submit the following remarks:

CINCINNATI, July 17 -- Rolling along as implacably as the ocean tides, Barney Shotton's Dodgers today flattened the Reds twice, 8 -- 4 and 10 -- 4, moved into third place ahead of the Cardinals and only five games behind the first-place Braves in the National League's lost column.

BERLIN, July 17 -- Following the pattern set in Soviet satellite states, the Soviet zone of Germany is being prepared for a central government by complete overhauling of the zonal Department of Interior, it was indicated today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A squad of twelve marines under a non-commissioned officer was ordered to the United States Consulate General in Jerusalem by the Navy today to supplement civilian guards that have been used there heretofore.

"The King's Gobbledygook," by Mervyn Jones, evokes memories (quite nostalgic, now) of other howlingly stuffy phrases in official use in wartime London. One of the worst was embodied in the letters "E.S.W." which faced people from low walls all over town.

With first reactions to fall merchandise indicating a good consumer response. New York garment manufacturers finished preparations last week to get into high speed production on existing orders. July vacation periods will interfere with plans to make the month count heavily in the third quarter delivery period, but manufacturers believe that they will make up for July deficiencies in August.

ATLANTA, July 17 (AP) -- A filling station operator and two auto parts salesmen from North Carolina captured the team championship of the twenty-third national public links tournament today with a score of 223. The winners of the Warren G. Harding Trophy are Aubrey D. Turrentine of Durham, Clarence Alexander and Avery Beck, of Raleigh.

TOKYO, July 17 -- A dozen Japanese newspaper men who covered the trial of Hideki Tojo and other accused major war criminals or edited reports of the trial have held a round table discussion in an attempt to assess the effects of the trial on the Japanese public.

Moses A. Leavitt, executive vice chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, major agency in the United States aiding distressed Jews abroad, announced yesterday the adoption of rehabilitation plans that were expected eventually to aid some 8,000 Jews in Italy and Rumania to attain economic independence and self-support.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 17 (AP) -- Gov. Strom Thurmond, states rights candidate for President, enters national politics after successfully inaugurating a program to modernize and streamline the government of South Carolina.

American holdings of about half a billion dollars worth of sterling securities stand to be more frozen than ever by reason of new transfer regulations of the Bank of England which will curb drastically the freedom of foreign investors to switch from one sterling security to another or to sell their holdings for dollars in a free market.

A group of golf players left the Metropolitan district yesterday to take part in the Eighteenth Annual Women's New York State golf championship, which starts tomorrow and continues through Saturday over the Onondaga Country Club course at Syracuse.

MONTREAL, July 17 (AP) -- An air search will begin at dawn tomorrow for P. Stevens Cornell of Freeport, L.I., N.Y., and another unidentified American, missing since June 26 in the densely wooded area near Mont Laurier, 125 miles northwest of Montreal.

THIS anthology, compiled by Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School, and Frances Brentano, editor and writer, is an interesting and unusual volume, containing more than 300 selections drawn from the religious prose and poetry of this century. The selections are arranged in four sections: poetry, short stories, drama and "affirmations."

The campaign of 1948 is on. President Truman launched it in Philadelphia in the small hours of Thursday morning. Accepting the Democratic nomination for President, he issued a challenge to the Republican Congress by summoning it into special session on July 26 to make good on the pledges of the GOP platform.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- The United Nations issued here today a preliminary edition of the first comprehensive bibliography of the world's literature on atomic energy, listing nearly 600 items on its political, economic and social aspects.
NEW YORK'S first big music show at Grand Central Palace opens tomorrow. From the look of things, it is going to become an annual feature of the city's life, like the flower and motor-boat shows.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 17 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth overcame an afternoon surge of Memphis' Miss Margaret Gunther today to win the thirty-third annual Southern women's golf title. The margin was 3 and 1.

Supreme Court Justice James B.M. McNally appointed a special guardian yesterday for the 10-year-old son of an ex-convict charged with having squandered much of a $13,500 fund contributed to the family by radio listeners.
At last, through the medium of THE TIMES Magazine, I have discovered that rare bird, the contented moviegoer.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Latin America's need for cars and road-building equipment to prevent the disintegration of motor transport throughout the Southern Hemisphere was emphasized today at the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Road Builders Association here.

Ray L. Trautman, wartime organizer and director of the Army Library Service, has been named a professor in Columbia's School of Library Service, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university, announced yesterday. He will resign as vice president and general manager of Omnibook Magazine to accept the professorship, effective Sept. 1.

Keuka College's unique "social responsibility" program, designed to prepare students for active participation in world affairs, will be formally launched this fall. The program aims at being more than just an academic offering -- it will be a campus way of life.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Democratic donkey was still on its feet when it moved out of Philadelphia this week-end. It had been stimulated by a shot of adrenalin administered by a confident, fighting President Truman, seeking election in his own right to a four-year term.
Soviet policy, despite its contrary phenomena, is not opportunistic but deterministic, moving within a well-defined pattern. What are its essentials?
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- The United States men's Olympic swimmers arrived in London by plane today and asked for heat.

VIENNA, July 17 -- The Austrian harvest is threatened with ruin, it was asserted today. The Ministry of Agriculture disclosed, though not officially as yet, that grain harvesting has halted completely. In many parts of the country grain already cut is standing in water.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Undefeated Mr. Busher today proved to the satisfaction of 25,455 race-goers at Arlington Park that he was the wonder horse of the nation's flashiest 2-year-olds.

The first nation to receive a loan from the Economic Cooperation Administration, under the Marshall Plan, is the Icelandic Republic. Since Iceland's population is just a little more than that of New Bedford or Utica, this loan of $2,300,000 for the fishing industry is important to the Icelanders.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 17 -- With an initial "class" of 1,250 Marine Corps reservists, most of them in their teens, the corps' largest amphibious training base here this week began a ten-week summer reserve training program for men from the western half of the country.

National Chief Commander F. Ritter Shumway of the United States Power Squadrons, who brought do wnto New York the other day from her Lake Ontario mooring near Rochester his flagship, the trim, sixty-three-foot auviliary schooner yacht Skookum III, to be on hand for this weekend's inter-squadron rendezvous at Port Jefferson, has two aims during his 1948 regime.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Shannon II, the pride of Australia, once again redeemed himself in the eyes of California turf fans when he captured the ninth running of the $100,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup today.
I MUST dissent from the views expressed by Mark Goodson in your last Sunday's issue, anent give-away shows.

SHANGHAI, July 17 -- It is now possible to travel by air from Shanghai to Nanking, a trip similar to that between New York and Washington, for less than one American dollar. But, despite the bargain rates, brought about by currency depreciation and the reluctance of the Legislative Yuan to hike fares, travel in China is becoming more and more onerous.

Discounting reports that he would be supplanted by a compromise candidate for Surrogate acceptable to Mayor O'Dwyer, General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente yesterday declared his intention of "fighting to the end" to keep the Tammany designation.

There is an awesome majesty about a July thunderstorm, particularly if one is safe under shelter; and an ideal shelter is a house on a hillside, facing a span of hills and valleys, for the drama of such a storm lies in its approach.
Readers of Kathleen Teltsch's report in THE TIMES of July 9 on the tragically inadequate support the U.N. appeal for children has found in the United States must have felt hopelessly depressed.

NORFOLK, Va., July 17 (AP) -- "Finis" was written to one of Norfolk's waterfront mysteries yesterday when the Panamanian flag was hoisted on the stern of the long flagless steamship. Col. Frederick C. Johnson.

NEW ORLEANS, July 17 -- In the sixty-day session just ended, the Louisiana's Legislature followed the 1930-1940 pattern set by the administration of the late Huey P. Long and his immediate successors. It gave Governor Earl K. Long, Huey's brother, all the new tax money and power he had requested.

THE arresting fact about Rosalind Murray's latest book is its great seriousness of aim. She has taken her title from the words spoken in Babylon by the prophet Baruch while Jerusalem was being burned by the Chaldeans: "O Israel. . . . Thou hast forsaken the fountain of wisdom. For if thou hadst walked in the way of God thou shouldest have dwelled in peace for ever."

Declaring that he was violating the Selective Service Act in so advising, A. Philip Randolph, chairman of the League for Non-Violent Civil Disobedience Against Military Segregation, called on young men of draft age last night to refuse to allow themselves to be "drafted into a Jim Crow Army."

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Using Joe Coleman's sparkling six-hit shutout as a springboard, the amazing Athletics bounced back today and defeated the Indians, 5 to 0. Coleman didn't allow any Indian batter to advance past first base.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UP) -- Leo Durocher today revealed that Branch Rickey asked him to resign as manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers July 4, but that he refused.
KANSAS CITY, July 17.--The Federal Court's dismissal of the last five vote-fraud conspiracy cases which grew out of the 1946 Kansas City primary indicates only a lull in that ballot-box battle.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17 (AP) -- Yugoslavia has banned the sale of the bulletins of the Communist Information Bureau, which have been blasting the regime of Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia.

THE 3 1/4 by 4 1/4 Kalart Camera, which features twin operating controls, will be on the camera counters tomorrow. First introduced five months ago, the camera was to be ready sometime in the fall, but increased production made possible delivery of the camera several months earlier than anticipated.

PARIS, July 17 -- The British Cabinet must, according to competent opinion here, decide how far Britain will go in supporting the plan for expanding intra-European trade that has been submitted to the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

The Air Force and the Navy are preparing to go all out in visual display of their air powers before both major candidates for the Presidency at the opening of the city's golden jubilee air show at New York International Airport at Idlewild a week from Saturday.

A NEW double 8mm black-and-white panchromatic film for amateur movie makers is announced by Kryptar Corporation. Kryptar 8mm Panchromatic Motion Picture Film is packaged in 25-foot (processed 50 feet) daylight loading rolls, has a daylight exposure index of 50, tungsten 32, and will be nationally available shortly.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Ralph Hamner, who was routed by the Braves Thursday before he could get a man out, came back today and slammed a four-hitter into the teeth of the league leaders to pace the Cubs to a 4-to-1 victory.

THIS bit of whimsy concerns a peach free named Miss Julia, which, acocrding to Georgia-born Grandfather Oglethorpe, exerts a benign influence on all who bring their problems to her. The only person in the town of Whistle, Ohio, who fails to appreciate Miss Julia is Miss Aurelia Peckham, a spinster neighbor who starts the entire community feuding by suggesting that the tree be cut down.

MEN have always been fascinated by prophecy. The flight of birds, the pattern of tea leaves, these and other portents have from age to age been solemnly interpreted and as solemnly accepted as heralding the shape of things to come.

THERE is something about Eugene V. Debs that still captures the imagination and warms the heart twenty-two years after his death. It cannot be the fact that he was a professional agitator; it must be the elusive element of his personality that allowed him bitterly to excoriate "the system" and its masters while extending the tenderest consideration to all manner of men.

The advance contingents of the Superfortresses dropping down out of the skies on the former Eighth Air Force bases in eastern England yesterday were, it is true, a visual show of United States air might. The flight of the two groups, totaling sixty planes, to Europe is, however, in our opinion, not a provocative gesture but an entirely legitimate deployment of United States air strength in an area where we have large commitments.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 17 -- Two thousand delegates to the fifth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party, which is to convene here Wednesday, will present an unbroken front against the international Communist' Information Bureau and stage a demonstration of undivided loyalty to Marshal Tito and his deputies.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Twelve "traits" distinguish the unsuccessful business executive of the executive "apt to be a failure at his job," according to Dr. Burleigh B. Gardner, executive director of Social Research, Inc., of Chicago.

IN the little Mexican village of Calisto are two Americans known as Robert Fitzgerald and Phil Temple. Fitzgerald, who faces a prison sentence if he returns to the United States, finds an opportunity to steal the papers of Temple and uses them to cross the border.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The Soviet Union raised the fear of physical interference with the United States and British air supply of Berlin tonight when Russian air force officials notified the Berlin air safety center that a small amout of night flying would take place in the air corridors between Berlin and the Western zones.

THE Government of the United States in the recent past has in many ways limited the freedom of public discussion. For example, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has built up, throughout the country, a system of espionage, of secret police, by which hundreds of thousands of our people have been listed as holding this or that set of opinions.

CHIEF GRAY MOUNTAIN brought terrible news to his people of a huge monster on the Missouri which churned swiftly up the peaceful river, belching black smoke. The Cheyenne braves put on their war paint and prepared to fight the river dragon while young Eagle Feather and his friend, White Owl, went scouting.
Deceptive use of the "consumer survey" approach by sales representatives was condemned last week in a policy statement by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc.

EXISTENTIALISM has been the object of both adulation and denunciation, but it has attracted relatively little studied criticism. Denunciation, it would seem, could hardly go beyond the sober venom of Croce's invective: "overstimulated, poisonous, perverse, tumid," while on the other hand, there is the assiduous, almost caressing, exposition which Jean Wahl, in volume after volume, has lavished on even the most casual and tangential utterances of existentialists.

A Latin America studies program has been established at the College of Arts and Sciences of the University of Florida for the fall term. Intended to acquaint North American students with Latin-American culture, the program emphasizes a broad knowledge of the languages, literature, history, geography, social conditions and economics of the area.

The financial coup of the post-war era has been accomplished with less ballyhoo than exploits a "quickie" movie. For shrewd, calculating stratagem, it rivals the corporate tugs-of-war that colored the infant days of American industrialism and has a ringing echo of the individualism of the New England of old, and, that is just where this drama is enacted.

WHAT is it that tells us when we read the stories in this volume that they are modern and French, and embody -- as Mr. Lehmann says in his introduction -- "the French spirit?" Their intellectual appeal? Their objectivity?

YOUNG BEN SAUNDERS inherits his pride in stevedoring from his father; he also inherits two thousand shares of stock in the mysteriously disreputable Puget Dock, once the pride of Seattle's waterfront. Ben is determined to clean up the dock, to bring back safe working conditions, to attract profitable shipping.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17 -- Observers in close touch with the underground machinations of Asian Communists believe that activities in Southeast Asia are proceeding along lines laid down by the Cominform and that an Asian Cominform will shortly be set up in Bangkok.

I was most annoyed at one sentence in Mark Goodson's article in defense of quiz give-away snows, to wit: "And most quiz shows are listened to not passively the way people listen to drama or music but actively as a game in which the listener participates."

Dogs, cats, a turtle and a gold fish were exhibited yesterday at a pet show at the Greenwich Village Country Fair, Avenue of the Americas at Waverly Place. Cloudy weather kept some contestants and spectators away. The overcast swies seemed to dampen even the spirits of the frisky pups, as twenty-eight pets were lined up to be judged by representatives of the Greenwich Village Association and the newspaper, The Villager.
HERE is something you may have heard, if you know anyone who has tried to adopt a child.

"WE'VE had enough dog trouble and we're not going to have any more," insisted Mrs. Palmer, but she had not counted on her children, Doug and Betsy, nor on the small ingratiating mongrel, Judy. Despite a litter of puppies, and a habit of making herself comfortable on any available bed, Judy became firmly entrenched in the family.

MACHINES like tractors and power mowers free the home gardener from time and energy consuming chores, enabling him to turn his attention to those aspects of his hobby that provide him with the most enjoyment.

Mark Goodson's emphasis last week on the high Hoopers being scored by give-away programs couldn't help but strike a note of alarm among those listeners who are old-fashioned enough to want to be entertained.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP)--The 116,000 Ford Motor Company production workers across the nation are finishing a strike vote this week-end.

Though your Fourth of July cover picture of the Statue of Liberty was merely the artist's conception, the enclosed photograph bears out the fact that Miss Liberty is indeed sightless. This should not be.

JOSEPH SHEARING fans, who have come to expect an annual import of literary henbane from England, have no cause for alarm. Neither her pen nor her knowledge of Old World toxicology shows any signs of fatigue.

James C. Varley, administration candidate, was elected commander of the Kings County American Legion for next year at the thirtieth annual county convention yesterday afternoon, as a "reform" group within the organization was defeated.

OLYMPIA, Greece, July 17 -- At noon today in these one-time sacred precincts an olive wood brand was lighted from the sun's rays. The flame was transferred to an ancient lamp and then to a torch placed in the hand of a young Greek athlete who started off on the first stretch of a 2,000-mile journey to London.

WHEN it's too warm to eat, as may happen about this season, then it's time to consider the chilled soups. Vichyssoise, which Chef Louis Diat of the New York Ritz first created from cream and potatoes and chives, is probably the most famous, but there are others, too.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Hogs were quoted at $20.25 to $29.25 on the livestock market today. All other classifications of livestock also were nominally steady.
ROME, July 17 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, who is still fighting for his life after being shot Wednesday, showed a slight but distinct improvement in the last twenty-four hours.

Tammany Hall (named after an Indian chief of the colonial days) is the executive committee of the New York County (Manhattan) Democratic Committee. This "high command," with headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue, is made up of seventy-seven Democratic district leaders. Some are men of high caliber and integrity.

DR. BAUER states in his preface that "the public * * * has not been given all the facts" about compulsory health insurance and that it "wants to know both sides of the question." If there is one issue that has been exhaustively discussed in the press, in books, in Government documents for the last fifteen years, it is that of making the best in medical science more generally available at low cost.

Bucky Harris, being in no position to quibble, accepted Lefty Ed Lopat's 4-0 triumph over the Browns yesterday at the Stadium, even if it was one of the most inelegant whitewashing jobs ever credited to a hurler. For, as the Yankee manager, assuming the role of quiz master, put it, "What is so rare as an eleven-hit shutout?
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Meat rationing and oleomargarine tax repeal were added today to the legislative bill-of-fare that Congress will look over when it returns a week from Monday.

CINCINNATI'S 400-room Terrace Plaza Hotel, the first big city hotel to be built in this country since the war, will welcome its first guest at 4 P.M. tomorrow. The Terrace Plaza is a new kind of hotel structure -- its lobby is on the eighth floor of the twenty-story building.

THESE occasional essays by Eric Linklater show the witty, slightly reckless author of such previous books as "Juan in America" in a sober, almost pedantic, light that may come us something of a surprise to his popular following on this side of the Atlantic.

A FRUSTRATED mother hen borrows an egg from Mrs. Quack, and -- to her chagrin -- finds that her adopted son is a water-loving duck. Although Horarce redeems himself in an exciting climax, he will not arouse the sympathy of very young readers: the author's style is rather abstruse -- particularly for the 3-to-6-year-old level, for whom the book is intended.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Whatever his fate may be in November, President Truman got in the first good punch of the 1948 campaign with his call for a special session of Congress.

Activity in wholesale garment markets here continued at slower pace last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Buyers' response to early offerings of fall apparel, the report stated, was encouraging and numerous reorders were received.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that "Peter Pan the Magic Man" would give ten performances this week at neighborhood park playgrounds in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The shows, a year-round feature of the department's recreation program, are designed to teach children in attractive form lessons on health, good citizenship and safety.

"SHANNON'S WAY" is not billed as a sequel to Dr. Cronin's last novel, "The Green Years." It may be read as an entity in itself, and judged on its own doubtful merits. As a sequel, it seems a pale coda to the first volume -- or, should we say, a tenuous suspension-bridge to other episodes in Robie's glum saga?

BERLIN, July 17 (AP) -- The official German newspaper of the British Military Government charged today that the Russians are holding more than 10,000 Germans in Buchenwald, former Nazi concentration camp.

A new and greatly expanded program aimed at improving export advertising agencies' service to their clients, as well as giving added support to the European Recovery Program, is being organized by the Export Advertising Association, Inc., it was learned last week.

THE three-day convention of the Henry Wallace third party in Philadelphia, scheduled to begin on Friday, will get full television and radio coverage. Television arrangements call for the cameras to cover proceedings both inside and outside of Convention Hall, while, in addition, a battery of electronic eyes will be set up at Shibe Park for the special rally and acceptance speeches on Saturday night.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 17 -- Jack Mitchell, Essex County Country Club professional, won the New Jersey State open golf championship for the third time today with a 72-hole score of 278, six-under par for the Forest Hill field Club Course.

CLIFTON, N.J., July 17 -- The ice-pick slaying here last night of Charles Yanowsky, notorious gangster, apparently had its inception in the bitter fight for control of the lucrative waterfront rackets in the port of New York, local police reported today.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Natchez sped to a new track record today in winning by three lengths the $15,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap, feature of the meeting's last card.

MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) -- With the United States and Britain undertaking the air supply of Berlin, some observers feel that the Russians may choose Air Force Day tomorrow to show the Western powers they are not alone in air prowess.

EL SALVADOR -- Economic prosperity founded on the third largest coffee trade in the world has made El Salvador indifferent in the past to tourist dollars, but recent large-scale building projects in this smallest of the Central American republics indicate a new interest of the Government in visitors from the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared tonight that the United States "will continue in its efforts to reach a solution" for the international control of atomic energy.

SCAMPTON, England, July 17 -- The first of sixty United States Army B-29 bombers, flying from the United States to British bases, touched down at this Royal Air Force field here shortly before 7 A.M. today. Unaware of the universal speculation about their trip, the weary crewmen were amazed to find several hundred villagers and Royal Air Force personnel and more than 150 newspaper reporters, radio commentators and camera men waiting to greet them.

Conniver, 4-year-old filly for whom there were no takers when she had a $7,500 price tag on her last fall, made a $39,300 run as Aqueduct's meeting ended yesterday. In a rip-roaring finish that had the 32,879 onlookers fairly sizzling with excitement, she headed Gallorette under the wire in the sixtieth edition of the famous Brooklyn Handicap, mile-and-a-quarter struggle in which the weights told the story in the last sixteenth.

OSCAR WILLIAMS is a rising anthologist not yet a captive of commerce. Because of the extreme "realism" of a few poems he selects, his newest anthology, "A Little Treasury of American Poetry," is not likely to gain acceptance by school and college authorities.

MANILA, July 17 -- Quezon City, namesake and dream capital of the late President Manuel Quezon, replaced Manila today as the official capital of the Philippines. President Elpidio Quirino signed the act effecting the change.
READING, Pa. -- The land of the "hex" sign and the shoofly pie has put out the official welcome mat for visitors, for this is Reading's bicentennial year.

SELECTED paintings by contemporary American artists are now in Italy as this country's part in the first big international art exhibition since the war. The occasion is the twenty-fourth Venice biennial which, according to reports, includes some two and a half miles of gallery walls.

Although most evidences of frontier days have long since been obliterated in this country, there are still more than 8,240,000 big game animals in the United States, according to a tabulation announced recently by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The census was taken in 1946 and compares with 6,598,422 for 1943.

The fifth annual Donaldson Awards for outstanding achievement in the theatre were announced last night. Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire" was named the best play and "Mister Roberts," by Thomas Heggen and Joshua Logan, as the "best first play to reach Broadway."
PORTLAND, Ore., July 17 -- The United States Fish and Wildlife Service started this week a fabulous program for preservation of the nation's greatest salmon runs.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 17 -- India asked Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations today to put back on the General Assembly agenda next September its complaint charging that South Africa is mistreating. Indian residents there and maintaining "jim crow" practices.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- Right-hander Virgil (Fire) Trucks, usually a soft touch for the Red Sox, turned in a sparkling four-hitter, all singles, today to give the Tigers their first victory in a four-game series with Joe McCarthy's forces, 3 -- 1.

ANCASTER, Ont., July 17 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, successfully defended his Canadian amateur golf championship today with a masterful display against Joe Stoddard of Hamilton.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The election of the Very Rev. Thomas P. McNamara, pastor of Corpus Christi Parish, New Orleans, as superior general of the Josephite Fathers, was announced here today. The election took place at the Sexennial General Chapter held at St. Joseph's Seminary.
Dedication ceremonies were held at La Guardia Field yesterday for an African airline, the Liberian International Airways, Ltd.

AKRON, July 17 -- What is described as the world's largest continuous production line for foamed rubber has been placed in operation here at the new plant for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, it was announced today.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP) -- Falling in line with the United States Steel Corporation in raising wages, with the promise of higher prices to come, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation today granted a 13-cent hourly increase to its 80,000 workers over the country.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York, demanded tonight that a House Labor Subcommittee "drop entirely" it's inquiry into alleged Communist infiltration into New York department store unions.

PARIS, July 17 -- Although benefiting from a very generous ration of gasoline, American automobilists in France are by necessity exposed to bitter criticism from jealous French drivers and an incredible amount of a peculiarly irritating French variety of red tape in obtaining gasoline coupons.

Seventy-one college students living in seven states, Canada and China, have received scholarships, David L. Cole, president of the Shapiro Foundation, 1441 Broadway, donor of the annual awards, announced yesterday. Fifteen of the recipients are residents of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Armed Services Petroleum Board informed the oil industry today that the military need for additional motor gasoline and aviation gasoline was "extremely urgent."
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board revealed today that Americans are not as prone to risk their savings in investments as had been supposed.

TOOLS that help to lighten garden work are especially acceptable these hot days. Some are frankly gadgets, not practical in the long run, but a few new tools are introduced each season which even the experienced gardener welcomes.

LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Minister of the Armed Forces of the Soviet Union, said tonight that Russia was "successfully developing our multi-engined and jet-propelled aviation," the Moscow radio said.

In Washington, in London, and in Paris there was mounting concern over relations between the West and the Kremlin. Berlin -- the bomb-wrecked former capital of Hitler's Reich -- was the vortex of the East-West struggle that has blocked the return of peace for three years. Now the moment for a showdown on Berlin seemed at hand.
At 11 A.M. last Thursday the eleven members of the U.N. Security Council filed into the Council chamber at Lake Success for a special meeting. At 9:58 Thursday night the meeting ended.

IN the Nineteen Twenties Remarque and Hemingway debunked war; Sinclair Lewis debunked M.D.'s. ministers, and almost everyone else; H.L. Mencken consigned religion to the hookworm belt; all the writers who mattered joined forces in debunking Mrs. Grundy and Queen Victoria.

ROCHESTER -- Among the scenic splendors of western New York which perennially delight visitors are the multitude of waterfalls which plunge down the region's countless gorges. From mighty Niagara to such miniature cascades as Pokey-Moonshine near Dansville, these falls are a not-to-be-missed feature of any trip through this part of the state.

Plans for the "new party" convention which will nominate Henry A. Wallace for President and Senator Glen H. Taylor for Vice President were announced yesterday by the National Wallace for President Committee.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 17 (AP) -- Sammy Urzetta of Rochester, the college boy with the rolled-up slacks, walked off with the state amateur golf final today, trouncing Lloyd Ribner of White Plains, 5 and 4.

PARIS, July 17 -- To avoid an unfavorable vote in the National Assembly Premier Robert Schuman demanded today a formal vote of confidence to prevent a ballot on a proposal for a reduction of military credits. The vote on the military appropriations cut would have entailed censure of Minister of the Armed Forces Pierre-Henri Teitgen.

LONDON (By Wireless). TODAY dramatic events are occurring in Central Europe. A conflict of currencies has led to the siege of Berlin. A meeting of Russian satellites at Warsaw to discuss Germany has been followed by revolt behind the curtain. What is Russian policy in Germany?

Seven hundred members of the "Fighting First" infantry battalion, Marine Corps organized reserves, boarded the Navy attack transport Okaloosa at Pier 26, North River and Beach Street, at 12:30 P.M. yesterday en route to Camp Lejeune, N.C., for two weeks of intensive training.

TOOLS that help to lighten garden work are especially acceptable these hot days. Some are frankly gadgets, not practical in the long run, but a few new tools are introduced each season which even the experienced gardener welcomes.

LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Minister of the Armed Forces of the Soviet Union, said tonight that Russia was "successfully developing our multi-engined and jet-propelled aviation," the Moscow radio said.

In Washington, in London, and in Paris there was mounting concern over relations between the West and the Kremlin. Berlin -- the bomb-wrecked former capital of Hitler's Reich -- was the vortex of the East-West struggle that has blocked the return of peace for three years. Now the moment for a showdown on Berlin seemed at hand.
At 11 A.M. last Thursday the eleven members of the U.N. Security Council filed into the Council chamber at Lake Success for a special meeting. At 9:58 Thursday night the meeting ended.

IN the Nineteen Twenties Remarque and Hemingway debunked war; Sinclair Lewis debunked M.D.'s. ministers, and almost everyone else; H.L. Mencken consigned religion to the hookworm belt; all the writers who mattered joined forces in debunking Mrs. Grundy and Queen Victoria.

ROCHESTER -- Among the scenic splendors of western New York which perennially delight visitors are the multitude of waterfalls which plunge down the region's countless gorges. From mighty Niagara to such miniature cascades as Pokey-Moonshine near Dansville, these falls are a not-to-be-missed feature of any trip through this part of the state.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17 -- A chain drugstore owner purchased today the fourteen-room French villa of John Jacob Astor here for less than half of its original purchase price. The showplace went under the hammer at an auction first to a liquor dealer for $72,000 but the final buyer was later identified as having bought the estate for $71,000.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The confused and devious course of post-war Germany took another dangerous turning during the past week when reluctance of German political leaders in the three Western zones to participate in the formation of a Western German state as such became evident.

GENEVA, July 17 (Delayed) -- The United States "has the responsibility and the will" to set the pace for the rest of the world in the global campaign for the United Nations Appeal for Children to speed the flow of life-giving milk, food, medicine, clothes and shoes to the world's 230,000,000 needy children, many of whom have never seen what milk looks like, Dr. Aake Ording, director of the appeal, declared in an interview today.

CINCINNATI, July 18 -- Of necessity Leo Durocher reversed himself today on Bobby Thomson as an outfielder, but the spark that the new Giant leader is trying to infuse in his club was only a faint glimmer part of the day and the New Yorkers gained the questionable distinction of checking the Reds' fourgame losing streak.

The purpose of worship is to be "captured by God," the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, former bishop of the Proestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, said yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

American philanthropy increased during the first six months of 1948 over the like period last year, according to a study made public yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, 150 Nassau Street, public relations and fund-raising counsel.

The Cunard White Star liner Parthia docked yesterday morning at Pier 54, North River, with 230 passengers and a crew member who was convalescing from a two-hour emergency major operation performed by the ship's surgeon with the assistance of the ship's nurse, seventeen hours after the vessel left Liverpool, England.
SODUS POINT, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- The cruiser Daphne, sailed by D.H.K. Detweiller of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, won the Toronto-Sodus yacht race today with a corrected time of 13:01.29.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., July 18 -Miss Eleanor Dunn of New York City, with a grand aggregate score of 1795 -- 105x's, won the two-day small-bore rifle-shooting tournament that ended today at the Gunners Club. With Miss Dunn's victory went the Hellcat Trophy and the honor of becoming the first woman to capture the cup.

The 1947 annual report of the Police Department, just submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer by Police Commissioner Wallander, shows that, while a long road must be traveled before New York can be considered a model city in its control of crime, this city has witnessed a sensible approach to law-enforcement problems over the past few years.

The dominant note of the business in the foreign exchange market last week was the marked strength of the far forward positions of the pound sterling. Demand was forceful enough to revive interest in the six and nine months' contracts which had not been a part of recent trading. Observers attributed this to recent developments affecting the pound which have brought about an altered perspective so far as devaluation of that unit is concerned.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -Mayors of port cities on the West Coast have been requested by resolution of port officials from British Columbia to San Diego to appoint impartial citizens' committees to formulate plans for waterfront peace.

LENOX, Mass., July 18 -- The main Berkshire festival of 1948 -- the three long week-ends of concert by the full Boston Symphony Orchestra -- will not start for eleven days, but the first public concert of the Tanglewood season took place in the theatre-concert hall this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Washington, in the doldrums during the recent party convention period, is expected to resume its central place in national political life this week as campaigning Republicans and Democrats map their courses in the special session of Congress that will open a week from tomorrow.

Appleton Century Crofts has ] signed a contract for "God's Un-] derground," by Father George, as told to Gretta Palmer. Father George, a priest who cannot reveal his identity, tells of his adventures in fighting the Nazis throughout the war in Eastern Europe and of the six months he later spent incognito in Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The American public personified by Washington residents intermingling with tourists who visit this city by the thousands at this season, paid a silent final tribute today to General of the Armies John J. Pershing, whose body lay in state in the flower-banked rotunda of the Capitol.

John W. McCaffrey, executive secretary of the New Jersey Brewers' Association, has been re-elected president of the New York Chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management. Hiram S. Hall, personnel director of Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, and Dr. Julius C. G. Seidl, head of the management department, Fordham University School of Business, were named vice presidents.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) -- Vic Ghezzi, Englewood, N.J., pro, came home with a 69 and 72-hole total of 271 to finish six strokes ahead of the field today for first money in the $16,500 Dapper Dan invitation golf tournament. The victory meant $2,600 to Ghezzi.

J.F. Lincoln's letter discussing the latent power of the consumer in industrial relations is a hopeful sign. However, it seems overoptimistic to believe that consumers will at any foreseeable time exert their power.
MADRID, July 18 (UP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today warned the Spanish people that they could expect no real peace for years to come.

International officers of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, will move this week for a membership showdown on the controversial "reciprocal discharge" clauses that left-wing department store locals in this city are seeking as a substitute for the union shop.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- The Cubs divided a doubleheader with the Phillies today, winning the opener, 3 -- 2, and then dropping the nightcap, 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 39,623.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 18 -- Plans have been completed for establishment of a new industry here with the signing of contracts for a $1,500,000 plant with an annual payroll of $300,000 a year The contracts were signed by the Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company and Beacon Textile Mills, Inc.

The Experimental Theatre, which has been overcoming obstacles since it began two, seasons ago, faces an imposing new one this year in the determination of some of the theatrical unions to stiffen the terms under which it has been operating, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 18 (UP) -- The Soviet planning commission in a report issued today said some branches of Soviet industry fell behind schedule in the second quarter of this year, but that industry as a whole exceeded the planned production quota by 6 per cent. Over-all production was up 24 per cent compared with the same period last year, the report said.
A new strike shutdown of the world-girdling airlines of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., was threatened last night.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce urged today that voluntary methods -- not force of law -- be used to check inflation.

Although sales and earnings of the American Car and Foundry and its subsidiaries declined in the fiscal year to April 30, the annual report to stockholders today revealed that the backlog of business swelled to a new peacetime high level of more than $280,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- The greatest menace to a free press lies in monopolistic control, particularly by governments of the organs of information, the United States delegation to the United Nations warned today in a report just made public.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 -- Gordon Lindsay Jr. and Fred Mayer of the Westchester County Club defeated James B. Knowles and Everett Hosley of New Haven, 4 and 3, to capture top honors in the annual member-guest invitation golf tournament held at the Greenwich Country Club today.

ALEI, Lebanon, July 18 (UP) -- Angrily, resentfully, anxiously, the leaders of the seven Arab countries bowed to the pressure of world opinion today and ordered their armies to cease fire in Palestine. As they did so, they denounced Great Britain, the United States, the United Nations and each other.

New York high school boys and girls enrolled in the Board of Education's cooperative education program earned $1,245,943 during the school year just ended, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday. The 4,017 young people studied and worked on alternate weeks at jobs that varied from floristry to automotive mechanics.

Through a concerted effort to curtail seasonal lay-offs, a constantly increasing number of employers are providing year-round work and pay. This was reported following more than 200 employment stabilization clinics held by local and state industrial and business groups in cooperation with the National Association of Manufacturers.

To the physicians who attended the First International Poliomyelitis Conference the reports of the authorities who read learned papers must have been gratifying. But the impatient man in the street who wants vaccines to prevent the virus from insinuating itself or chemicals that will check the virus after it has gained entrance reads in vain his newspaper's account of the proceedings.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 -- Although the best they could do was split a doubleheader with the Cardinals today the Dodgers found themselves in second place tonight, still retaining a fractional lead over the third-place Cards, while the Pirates had dropped to fourth place.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18 -There just doesn't seem to be any way to stop Cecil Smith. The ten-goal ace was all over Bostwick Field today as he led his unbeaten Texas four to its fourth straight National polo League triumph by halting Bostwick Field's quartet, 15 to 7, before 2,500 fans.
PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) -- The league-leading Braves swept a doubleheader from the Pirates today, taking the opener, 10 to 2, and the nightcap, 3 to 1.
One cannot but gain admiration for President Harry S. Truman after the ordeal he has gone through in the past few weeks at the hands of his own party members.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 -St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital here hopes that its fifteen-year program of research into convalescent therapy will provide shortcuts to recovery. Indications of progress toward that goal were reported today.
