Follow an old, hardback-bordered, rutted road across the sloping shoulder of an upland pasture. Twist and turn with the road as it winds through spruces and hemlocks around the brow of the hill. Deep in the woods where an area of evergreens was cut off you will find the raspberry glades.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Lard futures were under pressure on the Board of Trade here last week, with scattered liquidation developing as the result of revival of efforts to restore rationing because of high prices and also in sympathy with weakness in vegetable oils.

Friends of England who endeavor to defend her Palestinian policy against the charge of anti-Semitism -- certainly an over-simplification -- must be disturbed by her attitude toward restitution of property of Jews and other victims of Nazi aggression in the British zone of Germany.

An uninformed stranger in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday might have thought that the War between the States was about to be resumed. Fortunately, it was not. The rebel yells, the waving of Confederate battle flags and the parading of a portrait of a nationally respected soldier named Robert E. Lee did not imply secession -- not even the secession of the Solid South from the Democratic party.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 18 -- The Berlin crisis and the progress made in the joint defense plans are expected to be the main subjects of discussion at the two-day conference of the Foreign Ministers of the five Western European union nations -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- scheduled to open here tomorrow.

The Communist party, in a formal issuance yesterday of its party line, disclaimed any intention of trying to run the Wallace-for-President movement on its own, and also refused to let others in that movement run the Communists out of it.

The Saratoga Association for the Improvement of the Breed of Horses, which at the moment is primarily interested in improving its bank balance in order to have a cash cushion for the meeting on the old home grounds next month, begins a two-week stand at the Jamaica race course today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Liquor consumption has grown faster than population ever since repeal in 1933, the Treasury reported tonight. It said also that spending on whisky had risen more than the general income level since the war began.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,557,721,871. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 18 -- Henry A. Wallace picnicked this evening with 3,500 members and guests of the Independent Young Progressives of New Jersey on a farm near Anderson's Corner, five miles west of here.
MIDDLEBORO, Mass., July 18 (AP) -- Farmer John Brown had to call police today to protect his crops from hopeful hundreds seeking what Mr. Brown called his "master cells."
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Navy, the Bureau of Mines and at least two oil companies are boring into western Colorado's hills this summer in quest of oil-bearing shale.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, July 18 -- King Abdullah, armed only with a silver dagger, stood alone in a courtyard today and faced a mob of 1,000 civilians who had marched on the Royal Palace.

TOKYO, July l8 -- With Gen. Douglas MacArthur's occupation standing squarely, but anonymously, behind him, Takeo Kurusu, president of Japan's Economic Stabilization Board has issued a program of ten essentials to be carried out, "if Japan is to receive continued American aid and achieve economic self-support."

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Grain markets were decidedly unsettled on the Board of Trade last week, with wheat under pressure due to record movement of new and old crop grain to terminal markets. The July delivery sold at a new flow since last March, falling around 2 3/4 cents below September at the extreme, or a full carrying charge discount.

PEARL HARBOR, July 18 -- The radioactive battleship Nevada will be subjected to four days of highly secret naval tests beginning Monday, July 26, about fifty miles southwest of Pearl Harbor. The Honolulu Advertiser will say tomorrow. The experiments will involve the first major tests of certain "hush-hush" Navy weapons and explosives against a battleship.

Meat prices, which to the housewife symbolize more than any other single item, perhaps, what is happening to the cost of living, are again on the upward march. In those markets where meat is sold on the hoof, steers, which were quoted a month ago at $36 a hundredweight, are now bringing $40, while hogs have risen from below $25 to $30.50.

Activity in wholesale garment markets here last week centered on buying of popular-price coats, suits and dresses, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The volume of summer dress sales, which continued very high, showed signs of falling off as manufacturers' stocks neared depletion, it was said.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 18 -- Nine years ago after Johnny Humm of Rockville had won the Long Island junior crown for the third time he reached the Long Island amateur championship final only to bow to Ken Sheldon.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned tonight that banks should be cautious about further increasing real estate loans.

Large industrial concerns, leading colleges and universities, and all branches of the nation's armed forces will take part in the atomic energy exhibition at the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition at Grand Centtral Palace, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee in charge of the Golden Anniversary celebration announced yesterday.

The Coast Guard will give demonstrations of its rescue work with helicopters every day during the city's golden jubilee air show at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee for the show, announced yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 18 -- Eddie Ketcham had some more stiff competition today but his Draco II outsailed Wally Ross' Pyryne and Everett and Austin's Duet to win the Star series championship of the Bay Shore Yacht Club's two-day invitation regatta.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- More than 10,000,000 members of labor unions have won a third round of post-war wage increases, Government officials estimated privately today.
CORFU, Greece, July 18 (AP) -- The flaming Olympic torch left Greek soil today aboard a British frigate and headed for Italy after a 125-mile journey across Greek land and waters.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -The White Sox split a pair of games with the Athletics today, winning by 12 -- 11 in eleven innings and then losing, 6 -- 1, in the five-inning nightcap cut short by Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew law.
The best remedy for depression is faith, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken said yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Groups and individuals objecting to removal of The Nation from New York public school libraries are "clamoring for the dissemination of hate," the Rev. Gustav J. Schultheiss, executive director of the institutional commodity services of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Pattick's Cathedral.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- The Arab agreement to join Israel in heeding the Security Council's order for an indefinite truce in the Holy Land, coming after a similar agreement by Israel, was acclaimed here today as the United Nations' most impressive victory thus far.

Another important rift in the "iron curtain" occurred recently, it was learned yesterday, with the defection and escape from Czechoslovakia of Gen. Antonin Bohumil Hasal, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Czechoslovak Army, commander of the Czechoslovak forces in the West and military aide to the President of his country.
BERLIN, July 18 -- The imposition of world-wide economic sanctions against the Soviet Union was called for today as a reply to the Russian blockade of Berlin by land.

The establishment of a large medical center for injured coal miners, to be built at a cost of several million dollars, is being studied by the medical advisory board of the United Mine Workers of America Welfare and Retirement Fund, it was announced yesterday.

The triple attraction of Jose turbi, the Philharmonic-Symphony and the music of Tchaikovsky drew the season's largest audience of more than 19,000 to Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night. Mr. Iturbi led the orchestra in an impassioned reading of the "Pathetique" Symphony in the first half of the program and doubled as soloist and conductor in the famous B flat minor Piano Concerto in the second.

HUNTER, N. Y., July 18 -- The dream of two years' hard work was realized this afternoon when Camp Loyaltown, a non-sectarian camp for underprivileged boys, was dedicated. More than 1,000 persons filled the large auditorium, which is also the camp dining hall, and overflowed on to the spacious porches, which extend around three sides of the building.

LONDON, July 18 -- Business on the Stock Exchange has fallen to its lowest ebb for many years. There are numerous factors to explain this. We are still in a bear market, which in itself is enough to keep the public away. The holiday season also is in full swing and there is a pronounced dearth of the kind of news that normally stimulates interest.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Cleveland scored two runs in the twelfth inning to defeat Washington, 6 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header today after capturing the opener, 2 -- 1. Sam Zoldak, sixth Indians' pitcher, received credit for the second game, while Gene Bearden registered his eighth victory in the opener before a crowd of 28,631.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The emergence of a rump movement of Southern Democrats giving allegiance to states' rights candidates for President and Vice President focused attention today on the electoral system under which a body of electors from the several states, rather than the popular vote, governs the election to these high offices.

RHODES, July 18 -- Agreements by Arab League countries and Israel to the cease-fire in Palestine, which was ordered for 11 A.M. (Eastern Daylight Time) today. were received at the headquarters of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, here.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Dollar volume of radio and television equipment, including electron tubes, totaled $40,351,820 during the first quarter of 1948, according to a report issued here today by the Radio Manufacturers Association. Government purchases, mostly for radar equipment, accounted for almost half the sales, the report indicated.

The Third Naval District headquarters announced yesterday an important advance in the maintenance of large seaplanes by the Navy. Tests have confirmed the usefulness of a floating drydock for such big craft, it was said. The drydock is made up of strings of the pontoons that served as landing stages and for many other purposes during the war.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- A lasting alliance of women of North and South America to conduct an unremitting battle for peace was asked by Senora Maria Eva Duarte de Peron in answering questions submitted by this correspondent.
ROME, July 18 -- A purge of the Italian Communist party was announced today in l'Unita, party newspaper, by Pietro Sechia, member of the Communist directorate in charge of organization.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -Marshall Plan shipments involving a total cost of $26,562,534 were authorized tonight by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

Threatening weather, with showers at some resorts, cut attendance at beaches and parks far the city yesterday. The police reported that attendance at Coney Island, estimated at 900,000, fell below the million mark largely because a shower at 3:30 P.M. kept patrons of the beach and boardwalk away although the weather cleared within an hour.

BALTIMORE, July 18 -- Before leaving for his home in Dedham, Mass., today, Weaver W. Adams, who yesterday won the national open championship sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, announced his intention to play in the biennial tournament for the United States championship at South Fallsburg, N.Y., Aug. 10 to 31.
AMSTERDAM, July 18 -- Although profits of most Netherlands companies remain very satisfactory, there are complaints of increasing difficulties in export markets.

JERUSALEM, July 18 -- A large number of casualties was inflicted today among the Jewish population of Jerusalem when, during violation by both sides of the United Nations Security Council's truce order for the city, effective from 5:30 A.M., local time, Saturday, the Trans-Jordan Arab Legion batteries continued heavy shelling and machine-gunning of the Jewish-held New City.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 18 -- The fifth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia, scheduled to convene here Wednesday, will return to power every Yugoslav leader excommunicated by the Communist Information Bureau and will endorse every policy for which the Yugoslav leadership has been expelled from the Communist world.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 18 -- The creation of a Western German state will not endanger the position of "extraterritoriality" enjoyed by displaced persons, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared last week.

DETROIT, July 18 -- By a vote of 3,985 to 81, members of Ford Local 600, UAW-CIO, this afternoon approved strike action against the Ford Motor Company as a result of the failure of recent negotiations to bring a settlement. More than 57,000 Ford union employes were eligible to vote.
LONDON, July 18 -- The first phase of a national peace campaign launched by the British Communist party with the support of the National Peace Council culminated here tonight in a mass meeting.

The Cargocaire Engineering Corporation's system of dehumidification for dry cargo vessels has been applied successfully to the tanker field, Oliver D. Colvin, president of the company, made known yesterday. Mr. Colvin said the extension of the system to liquid carriers had been under study for the last three and a half years.

I wish to take exception to recent editorials on both the feasibility of another Congressional junket to the Pacific islands and the advantages, implied or otherwise, of civilian administration vis-a-vis naval administration.

Following moderate firmness, cotton prices in the domestic market turned easy last week and closed the period with slight net changes. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 4 to 10 points, with the only net decline being recorded in the nearby October delivery.
PARIS, July 18 -- While tension grows at Berlin there will be in the next few days two closely related manifestations of the United States policy of putting strength into Western Europe.

While many advertisers are having a "wonderful time" with free tie-ins on radio contest shows, the novelty of the "giveaway," craze is reaching the brittle stage, it was declared last week by experienced advertising observers. The contest "gimmick," while traditionally associated with hard times, they said, appears now to be headed for a boom-bust.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 18--A war-surplus B-17 bomber whose nine-man crew promised Canadian authorities that they would return at once to the United States flew instead over the Atlantic last night and landed in the Azores early today, presumably on the way to Palestine.

BRISTOL, England, July 17 (Reuters) -- The iVuethodist Conference today defeated by 256 votes to 185 a recommendation that women be allowed to enter the ministry. Several women delegates were among the most outspoken opponents of the proposal.

New light may be thrown on the pre-Columbian visits of the Norse Vikings to North America when Prof. Johannes Bronsted, curator of the Danish National Museum in Copenhagen, arrives in the United States late next month.

LONDON, July 18 -- News from Lincolnshire, where fifty-eight of the sixty United States superfortresses had arrived tonight, attested to the warm welcome the United States fliers were getting on their return to wartime haunts. Officers, crews and groundmen were still in quarantine but not isolated from the friendly world around them.

Intergovernmental action to remove barriers holding back increased trade between the United States and India and Pakistan, as well as to expand investment of American private development capital in those two countries, is urged in a sixty-page study of American commercial relations with the new Eastern nations, issued over the weekend by the committee for India and Pakistan of the National Foreign Trade Council.

If he could have his life to live over again, said our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn, he thought he might like to spend it as a librarian in some small New England town -- in Connecticut, say -- of about five hundred (winter census) souls.
PARIS, July 18 -- In negotiations today only small progress was made in smoothing difficulties to be met when a vote of confidence will be asked in the National Assembly tomorrow afternoon.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- The first two American Olympic squads to pitch camp at the site of the games have finished their first week of training and report that "everything is fine."

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- The Nizam of Hyderabad, whose claim to independence has been answered by the Dominion of India with a tight economic blockade of the landlocked state, protested in two sharp letters to Earl Mountbatten that Hyderabad was "being abandoned by its old ally, the British Government."

China's "disillusioned masses" are looking to Christianity for the solution to their problems, Bishop Ralph A. Ward of Nanking, China, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

A new world federation for mental health, dedicated to what social scientists consider the greatest enemy of mankind -- the worldwide mental illness that causes man to war on his fellow man -will be organized in London next month.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced yesterday that its application to the War Department for permission to construct the world's longest suspension bridge across the Nar-...

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 18 -- Copies of the messages from Egypt and Trans-Jordan, accepting the Security Council's order for an indefinite truce in the Holy Land, were transmitted here today from Rhodes.

PRAGUE, July 18 (UP) -- The Czechoslovak people waited uneasily today for the long-feared Government housecleaning of anti- Communists, which was expected to sweep all opposition parties off the nation's political scene.

LONDON, July 18 (UP) -- A new underground press is springing up in Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia. Copies of some of these illegal Czechoslovak pamphlets and newspapers reaching London contain strong criticisms of the new regime.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 -- Sails strapped taut against a soft southwest breeze and in a haze that hung over Long Island Sound persistently, 400 canvased creations competed today in the second regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.

One hundred and sixty radio commentators and fashion editors representing stations and newspapers all over the country will gather in New York today for the Eleventh National Press Week of the New York Dress Institute.

Several private shipping companies in New York have indicated a desire to modernize their piers under private financing if the Department of Marine and Aviation gets city authority to proceed with its port rehabilitation program, it was made known last night.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- With the steel wage movement started last week by the United States Steel Corporation and due to be embraced by other steel concerns, interest of industrial circles now centers on steel prices. Consumers have two sets of steel price advances to think about -- the higher quotations resulting from abandonment of the basing point system and the general increases looming for products at the mills.

A small gray pigeon invaded the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street, shortly before yesterday morning's service, swooped perilously close to the heads of many of the 1,000 worshipers and nearly halted the sermon of the guest preacher, the Rev. Dr. John Short, noted British clergyman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Dan Duryea, who rose to screen stardom playing weakling characters, has negotiated a readjustment of the seven-year exclusive-service contract which he entered into in December, 1946, with Universal-International.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 18 -- Tonight, more than two and a half hours after the truce time, there was still heavy fighting on the Syrian border around Mishmar hay Yarden, but this was the only major violation except for an Iraqi attack on Maanit, northeast of Hadera.

PARIS, July 18 -- The attention of financial and economic circles in France now is centered on the Government bill that asks authorization to take special measures by decree. It is said that the whole question of financial reform is involved and that in a large degree it will affect the future of the franc.

The Second Presbyterian Church which occupies large space in the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 360 Central Park West, southwest corner of Ninety-sixth Street, has obtained a mortgage loan of $900,000 for three years at 5 per cent on the property through the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header today, the Giants taking the opener, 3 -- 2, while the Bears bounced back to capture the nightcap, 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 7,196.
The Greenwich Village Country Fair marked its close for the year last night with a gala program featuring the installation of an honorary mayor of Greenwich Village.

TOKYO, July 18--The holding of a general election in Japan some time this autumn has become virtually inevitable, in the opinion of most Japanese political analysts. The result foreseen, according to all indications available at present, will be a sharp turn to the Right, rejecting the "revised capitalism" of Premier Hito-...

The American people need a better understanding of their own economic system, particularly a knowledge of how it works and "its sensational achievements in spite of its obvious shortcomings," Evans Clark, executive director of the Twentieth Century Fund, said yesterday in the annual report of the fund.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, has agreed to forego until next year its request for a social insurance program in plants of the United States Steel Corporation, it was learned today.

A new organization to be known as the American Council on Japan has been established under the sponsorship of a group of eminent individuals, most of whom have had long acquaintance with that country, it was announced yesterday.

Members of the majority bloc in Tammany Hall, at a conference yesterday, declined to consider suggestions thus far made that they withdraw General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente as their candidate for Surrogate on the Democratic ticket.

A new entrance to Macy's at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street and large picture windows alongside the IRT subway stairs are features of alterations now being made that will give the department store a floor area of 2,132,600 square feet.
Three new films will open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 18 (AP) -- Members of Uncle Sam's Olympic team attended services today.
Today is the one hundredth anniversary of the women's rights movement in this country. Reminders of this came yesterday from points as far apart as Geneva (Switzerland) and Seneca Falls, N.Y.
LONDON, July 18 -- Preliminary work has begun for dams and power stations in Uganda, Central Africa, that would produce the equivalent of nearly two-thirds of the electricity consumption in Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Club owners of the National Football League today voted Commissioner Bert Bell full power to deal with "any phase" of the annual all-star game between college stars and the N.F.L. champion.

The branch office of the Veterans Administration at 346 Broadway announced yesterday that it had issued for New York veterans a pamphlet warning them against inferior schools and advising them not to train for jobs that might not exist.

Overwhelmingly victorious in his election fight to oust left-wing elements from control of the National Maritime Union, Joseph Curran, president of the union, announced yesterday that he expected its 20,000 New York members to withdraw from the leftist Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Taking into consideration "the general inflationary trend," the State Insurance Department announced yesterday that automobile liability insurance for passenger car operators would be increased generally in the state by 10.2 per cent, effective today.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 18 -- Aggreement has been reached in London for the sale of New Zealand's exportable surplus of butter and cheese for the next seven years at enhanced prices, it was officially announced here today.

"Beyond very much question," declared The London Economist recently, "the most fundamental problem of the long run that faces the British economy is the rate at which it will create capital The only possibility of combining a balanced international account with ease and prosperity at home is by a great and sustained increase in production -- and that rests on the rate of capital creation more than anything else."

Although many of the 62,990 fans at the Stadium yesterday insisted there was less visibility at 2 P.M. than at 6:45, the nightcap of the twin bill between the Yankees and Tigers was called on account of "darkness" after six and a half innings.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18 -- Rebellious Southern Democrats, waving the flag of "white supremacy" and boasting an assured twenty Electoral College votes in Mississippi and Alabama, announced today that they would carry "a fighting campaign" to defeat President Truman into neighboring states.

Billy Talbert gained the New York State singles tennis championship yesterday when he defeated Don McNeill of Glen Oaks, N.Y., in the final-round match of the tournament at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills. Encountering sturdy opposition, Talbert, nevertheless, managed to prevail by the score of 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The State of Israel is prepared to construct the most compact system of modern highways in the world with over-all utility as the guiding requirement, according to David Sandler of Tel Aviv. He spoke today at the forty-fifth annual convention here of the American Road Builders Association as delegate from his home city.

Installation of what are said to be the largest steamship signs on the Port of New York waterfront was completed last week when the Holland-America Line and Red Star Line neon fixtures were put in full operation. The signs are on the ends of the Fifth and Sixth Street piers, Hoboken, N.J.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., July 18 -- Two hundred power and sail yachts from more than a score of Long Island, Connecticut and Hudson River squadrons began returning to home anchorages this afternoon, signalizing the close of the biggest Eastern rendezvous in United States power squadron history.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 18 -- Edward Moylan of Trenton, N.J., the country's sixth-listed star and seeded No. 3, won two matches easily today as he started play in the twentieth annual Eastern clay courts tourney on the Travers Island courts.

LONDON, July 19 -- The Board of Deputies of British Jews went on record at a meeting here today in support of the Israeli Government's rejection of the plan for Palestine proposed by Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator.

LONDON, July 18 -- The United States, Britain and France plan to answer the Russian note on Berlin by the end of this week, it was learned today. From present indications the second Western Allied note will not be an ultimatum but will aim at keeping the doors of conciliation open.

MACKINAC ISLAND, July 18 (AP) -- The sloop Nyala, one of the leaders in the annual Port Huron-Mackinac boat race, sent out distress calls today after her 98-foot mast snapped at deck level on Lake Huron.

The five-and-a-half-story apartment house for fifty-three families at 1562 Theriot Avenue, corner of Guerlain Street, in the Bronx, has been sold by Kimmelman Zauderer to a client of Fred M. Weitzner in a transaction negotiated by Max Laxer, broker. It is assessed for $165,000 and was acquired by the sellers in 1931.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 18 -- The United States has asked Great Britain and France to join in a plan to smash through the Russian blockade of Berlin by force if necessary, high Western Allied sources said today.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 18 (UP) -North Carolina opened another emergency hospital today as the total number of cases in the infantile paralysis outbreak rose to 679.

NANKING, July 18 -- Communist artillery began bombarding the gates of Taiyuan, capital of Shansi Province, today. Dispatches from Taiyuan said the Communists had entered the suburbs of the city and had started shelling after thousands of civilians had been evacuated.

CAIRO, July 18 (UP) -- The bitter Arab leaders, after a stormy meeting in Lebanon in which they accepted the cease-fire, sent a seven-page cablegram to Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General, demanding:
BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox spotted the Browns four-run leads in both games and then came from behind to sweep the double-header, 12 -- 5 and 7 -- 6, today before 28,563 fans.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 18 -- Shock and a wave of resentment against the great powers, Britain and especially the United States, was the immediate public reaction here to

ZURICH, July 18 -- In the matter of restitution of looted gold, Switzerland long ago fulfilled all obligations under the Washington agreement of May 25, 1946, and now definitely refuses to reopen the question, it was said on Friday by competent authorities in Berne.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 19 --Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of SouthCarolina, who was chosen on Saturdayas the Presidential candidateof the rebellious SouthernDemocrats, cracked down on his"white supremacy" followers todayin a surprise action.

In the face of a steady rise in the number of apprentices at work in the building trades, fear is expressed by David S. Miller, president of the Producers Council, that the new draft will cause serious withdrawals from the ranks of construction employes and reverse a trend that brought the number of apprentices to 131,000 during May for an increase of 30 per cent over the same month in 1947.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -Philadelphia's Athletics defeated the Chicago White Sox in both ends of a twi-night double-header tonight, with Dick Fowler pitching a seven-hitter to take the opener, 6 -- 0, and Phil Marchildon notching the decision in the nightcap, thanks to a three-run rally in the eighth inning that gave the Mackmen a 6-4 victory.

Unless the current rate of production cost increase is checked or reversed, wholesale druggists will be compelled to make a general upward revision of price schedules by the end of the year, E. Allen Newcomb, secretary of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, said yesterday.
This country appears likely to profit by one remarkable piece of good fortune relative to inflation.

A great deal has been written, not one word unfavorably, about the position of the village Square in American life. Very little has been written about the position of the ball park. Due to its place in history, as well as to the efforts of the historians, the Square now carries with it a connotation of elm trees, old houses and the Minute Men.

RHODES, July 19 -- Count Bernadotte, United Nations' Mediator returned today from Lake Success, where he conferred with the Security Council. He said the Palestine truce would be in effect for an indefinite period and that he would take no notice of conditions attached to the Arabs' acceptance of the truce.

New Liquor Ad Push Probable A new effort to push legislation designed to put drastic restrictions on liquor advertising is "more than a probability" at the special session of Congress, it was asserted yesterday by a reliable observer. The dry-sponsored measures failed by one vote to be reported out of the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce committee near the end of the last regular session.

SANTA MARIA, Azores, July 19 (AP) -- The war-surplus B-17 bomber that flew from Halifax to the Azores without permission of the United States or Canadian authorities is loaded with bombs, it was disclosed tonight. Also, one of its eighteen passengers has admitted he was on his way to Palestine.

A country-wide campaign to raise a minimum of $10,000,000 for the construction of an international, non - sectarian Christian University in Japan will be started by American Protestant church groups in the spring of 1949, it was announced yesterday.
The municipality of Tonawanda, N.Y., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 2 on various issues of bonds totaling $3,163,000, dated July 1, 1948, and due July 1 from 1949 to 1968.

The Broadway premiere of "Small Wonder." The revue with which George Nichols 3d is making his producing debut, will take place at the Coronet Theatre on Thursday evening, Sept. 16, it was learned yesterday. Also resolved is the problem of hiring a choreographer.

The shooting of Togliatti has all the earmarks of a good international incident, if the Communists in italy desire to make it so. By causing riots and then pitched battles the Reds can bring a serious situation about, the kind of situation that interests and calls in outside help. After that anything can happen.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- TheUnited States and Yugoslaviasigned agreements today settlingpost-war claims that had been indispute for more than a year.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The United States can spend as much as $1,761,600,000 for aiding the recovery of Europe in the next three months alone.
Cable reports to leading hide dealers here yesterday indicated the Government-controlled Argentine Institute for Trade Promotion (IAPI) was continuing firm on high prices.
CINCINNATI, July 19 -- The Durocher spark developed four-alarm proportions today as the Giants swamped the hapless Reds, 14 to 2, in the wildest hitting orgy the club has enjoyed this season.

The United States Army is carrying out in Germany today the most important peacetime job in the history of the service. Frederick Simpich, associate editor of the National Geographic Magazine, declared yesterday.
ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 19 (UP) -- Avery Brundage today branded as untrue the oft-told tale that Adolf Hitler snubbed Jesse Owens during the 1936 Games.
The New York Public Library began yesterday its first series of daily recorded concerts in the shade of Bryant Park.

BERLIN, July 19 -- Approximately 20 per cent of the industrial concerns in the United States sector of this city have completely halted operations in the last two weeks because of the shortage of electricity, Mason Wye, chief of the Manpower Allocation Section, disclosed today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn Department stores increased 7 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Gen. John J. Pershing today tookhis place among the graves in Arlington National Cemetery wherelie the soldiers who served under his command in the American Expeditionary Force of 1917-18.1He was buried on a gentle slopeonce included in the estate ofRobert E. Lee.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 19 -- The adage that a cowboy will tolerate interference with anything but his horse was confirmed here today as local authorities began a search for Red Simpson, 27-year-old resident of Rockwell, Okla.

A disappointed audience of 9,000 left the Lewisohn Stadium at 9 o'clock last night when thunder and lightning broke up the concert of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra twenty minutes after it had begun.

LONDON, July 19 (UP) -- America's sprint swimming stars faced a possible crisis today when the International Swimming Federation president said he would seek to have special breathing apparatus banned from the Olympic Games.

SOUTH KORTRIGHT, N.Y., July 19 -- Mrs. Alice T. McLean, turning her forty-five-room mansion and fourteen acres of her 7,000-acre estate over to writers, musicians and painters of the world and to displaced children of Europe, said here tonight that her plan for "International Valley," as it is now known, is to "give hope to the world by helping the coming generation."

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- There were delegates to the recent Democratic National Convention from the former Confederate states and from other sections who attended the party gathering of 1932 in a similar capacity. In both conventions a states' rights issue was posed over which there was division.

SYRACUSE, July 19 -- Between intermittent showers that greeted the late starters and overcoming tricky greens. Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the North Hempstead Country Club won the qualifying medal in the nineteenth annual women's New York State championship with a fine threeover par 38 -- 40.

" So Evil My Love," the Ray Milland-Ann Todd-Geraldine Fitzgerald drama produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount release, willh)0*0*0*ihave its local premiere at the Rivoli at 5 P.M. tomorrow, instead of Thursday morning, as previously announced, it was reported yesterday by Paramount.
America's first line of defense inithe atomic age---a world-wide in-!teUigence serv/ce---is today one ofithe weakest links in our nationalJsecurity.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that declines in shipments of crude foodstuffs and manufactured goods were responsible for a drop in United States exports in May.

With tension over the Berlin crisis mounting steadily, the Western Powers have now begun a series of conferences to seek a more effective solution of the problem than they have been able to find thus far. In Washington, President Truman has conferred with his top diplomatic and military advisers.

WASHINGTON, July ,19 -- There were three important meetings on the Berlin crisis today -- one at the White House between the President and his top diplomatic and military advisers; another in The Hague among Cabinet Ministers of he so-called "Brussels powers" and a third in Berlin among the military commanders of the Western powers.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Renewed protest against proposed construction of a bridge over the Narrows between Staten Island and Brooklyn was entered at the Department of the Army today by Representative Donald L. O'Toole, Democrat, of New York's Thirteenth (Brooklyn) District.
PRINCETON, N.Y., July 19 -Princeton University has awarded academic honors to 274 seniors who were graduated last month, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) -Danny Murtaugh's infield single off the glove of Pitcher Johnny Sain in the seventh, scoring Ralph Kiner from third, broke a scoreless tie to give the Pirates a 1-0 victory over the Braves tonight. Aged Fritz Ostermueller scattered seven hits in getting credit for the shutout, his sixth victory of the season.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A stressing of the value of good highways throughout the world for universal economic benefit was characterized today as one of the essential foreign missions of the United States. Thomas H. MacDonald, Commissioner of the Public Roads Administration, made this appeal in an address at the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Road Builders Association here.

MACKINAC ISLAND, July 19 (AP) -- The speedy Detroit cutter Blitzen held top honors today as the last of nearly fifty yachts straggled in to end the twentyfourth annual Port Huron to Mackinac Island race.

The widest losses since late 1946 were suffered yesterday on the stock market as offerings engulfed the machinery of the Stock Exchange and battered prices down to the lowest marks since last April. Average reductions in the industrials ranged beyond 5 points, with the over-all composite rate slashed almost 4 points.

Hospital facilities for the careh)0*0*0*iof premature infants are "urgently" needed in New York City, the Bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported yesterday. The council announced accordingly that it was recommending that these services be given the priority of a special project in future hospital planning.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington covering $50,000,000 thirty-year first mortgage bonds of Commonwealth Edison Company became effective today, Chairman Charles Y. Freeman announced.

The Adams Express Company, for the six months ended June 30, reports net assets of $43,106,508, equal to $29.71 a share on 1,450,500 common shares outstanding. This compared with $27.82 a share at the year-end, 1947.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -The starring role in "Born Yesterday" can be had by James Cagney if he wants it. Columbia is out to get a topnotch cast for this costly Broadway comedy hit by Garson Kanin, for which it paid $1,000,000. Cagney now is understood to be reading the play at his farm in Marthas Vineyard, Mass.

Despite an increase in sales and operating revenues of the OwensIllinois Glass Company and its subsidiaries during the twelve months ended with June, net earnings declined to $7,677,632 from $16,384,027 for the twelve months ended on June 30, 1947, according to the report yesterday of W. E. Levis, board chairman.
Five teen-aged boys were arrested yesterday on charges of homicide arising out of the Brooklyn gang-war killing last Thursday of Nathaniel Randolph, 16 years old, of 243 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Simultaneous with the establishment of headquarters in hotel rooms recently vacated by the Democrats, and earlier, by the Republicans, Henry A. Wallace's Third Party announced today the week's program for its "streamlined people's convention."

NEWARK, N.J., July 19 -- After a week-end lull, investigation of the affairs of P. James Pellecchia, former police judge who confessed to embezzling $657,000 from the Columbus Trust Company, was resumed here today with an announcement of a search for two witnesses.

The World's Fair of Music, first of a projected annual series, opened for a week's run at Grand Central Palace yesterday. The gala event displays all aspects of music from recording to live symphony performance from music publishing to a specially appointed disk jockey.
Bob Falkenburg, who won the tennis singles championship at Wimbledon, England, returned here yesterday with fair words on behalf of British officials and fans.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 19 -- In their counterproposals on the formation of their own government, the State chiefs of Western Germany expressed "their wish and their expectation that by decision of the Governments of France, Great Britain and the United States the state of war be ended," it is disclosed in the text of the document made available today.

LONDON, July 19 -- At a travel bureau in midtown London, they are offering these days one of the greatest transportation bargains of all time -- all the way to Australia, halfway around the world, for the equivalent of about $40.

RYE, N.Y., July 19 -- Mrs. John Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club established herself in a commanding position to annex the golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester today by carding a first-round 82 over the Westchester Country Club course.

Doubleday Co. announced yesterday the appointment of three new vice presidents as well as other personnel changes in the publishing concern. Ken McCormick, editor-in-chief: Tom Burns, sales manager, and George Hecht, general manager of the Doubleday Book Shops, have been named vice presidents.
New York had 4,060 fewer fires in 1947 than in the previous year, according to the annual Fire Department report filed yesterday with Mayor O'Dwyer by Commissioner Frank J. Quayle.

New York youths who wish to join the Army or Air Force under the special one-year enlistment program for 18-year-olds that will begin tomorrow, may enlist only at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, it was announced yesterday by Col Lathrop R. Bullene, commanding officer, Southern New York Army and Air Force Recruiting District.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The kickoff for the 1948 Presidential campaign will get under way six weeks earlier than is usual, it became apparent today, through the act of President Truman calling the Congress back into special session.

LONDON, July 19 -- Political events continued to undermine sentiment in the stock market here today and business was restricted. Only small selling was encountered, and brokers' fears that Friday's selling wave would gather momentum was not realized.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 20 -- A United States soldier was killed about 1 o'clock yesterday morning in an ambush set by North Koreans near the city of Kaesong, 400 yards south of the thirty-eighth parallel, the dividing line of the American and Soviet zones.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Legislation designed to eliminate discriminatory phases of the law to admit displaced persons from Europe will be introduced next Monday, the opening day of the special session of Congress, Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, announced today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 19 -- Every aspect of military cooperation among the powers of the Western European Union, including formation of a North Atlantic regional defense bloc with the United States and Canada, is being discussed at the conference here in closed session of the Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels Pact nations.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 -- As the Dodgers were washed out of their final game with the Cardinals by a violent rainstorm today Manager Barney Shotton made his first moves toward improving the team that recently has won rating as almost the strongest in the league.

BERLIN, July 19 Russianfighter planes swept across theBritish airfield at Gatow twice today,breaking all the air safetyrules that the Soviet Military Administrationhas been citing in itsprotests against the United States-British air supply of Berlin.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 20 -- Syngman Rhee, 74-year-old Korean statesman, was elected the first President of the Korean Republic this morning.

According to a statement made yesterday by one of his White House aides, President Truman is planning to present Congress with an anti-inflation bill soon after it convenes in special session next Monday. The measure, it is reported, will follow more or less closely the ten-point program advocated unsuccessfully by the Administration last November.

The need of a bridge across the Narrows between Brooklyn and Staten Island was apparent forty years ago. Good roads and the automobile have intensified that need. It is an anomaly that when he wants to cross Staten Island to New Jersey and thus speed southward or westward a New Yorker must spend half an hour on an anachronistic ferry.

LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) -- A fourth wicket partnership of 172 between Arthur Morris, who had a total score of 109, and Sam Loxton, who made 123, followed by fine bowling by Ray Lindwall and Bill Johnston today placed the Australians in a commanding position in their match against Middlesex, the champion County of English cricket.

United States investments in foreign countries reached $26,700,000,000, a new high record, last year, according to a study by Malton Abelson, analyst for the Department of Commerce, being published in the 1948 Britannica Book of the Year.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A possibilitythat 25-year-old registrants will be inducted first under the stop-gap draft persisted today, but Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said that it was still too early for men 19 through 25 years old to start making definite plans.

While Mickey Kivatisky, 12 years old, showed Joe McNamee, his 13-year-old guest from the West, some more of the "everything" he said the city had when he refused a vacation in the country, 517 other boys and girls boarded ten buses yesterday for a few weeks of fun far from the sidewalks of New York.

KYRENIA, Cyprus, July 19 -Because of the complicated politics in the Middle Eastern states and the basic differences between them, acceptance of the second truce, imposed by the United Nations in Palestine may weaken the Arab League as a force for Moslem Arab unity.

CHICAGO, July 19 Liquidation developed in the grain markets in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, July oats breaking the 6cent daily limit and sold at a new seasonal low at 80 5/8 cents, while July wheat was at a new low since last March.

First post-war showing of Japanese lamps and lamp accessories featured the opening yesterday of the summer New York Lamp Show in the New Yorker Hotel. The merchandise is offered for from sixty to ninety-day delivery.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard sharply contradicted yesterday the charge brought by the Bronx Council for Social Welfare that the New York Department of Welfare was moving toward "greater rigidity" instead of toward better facilities for treatment of the "emotionally unemployable."

NEW DELHI, India, July 19 -- A cease-fire in Kashmir is likely to be proposed by the United Nations Security Council commission within a few days. The mission is now in New Delhi investigating the possibilities of ending the ninemonths-old hostilities in the Northern Princely State.

LONDON, July 19 -- The British Government showed its determination about Berlin today in the House of Commons. Leftist members of Parliament tried to force the Foreign Office to agree to consultations with the Soviet Union and to allow the Russians to feed Berlin, but the replies were sharply negative.

We spent the tag end of our vacation on something of a busman's holiday, devoting several days to a check-up tour of the Narraguagus River up in Maine, where they have done a fine job of letting nature restore the Atlantic salmon.

Plans for a two-story branch bank at 2301 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, for the Williamsburgh Savings Bank of 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing land Buildings. The cost is given at $600,000.

The four-story building at 344 East Forty-ninth Street has been purchased by Beverly Cleaners, Inc., for use as a laundry. The seller was the Deposit Realty, Inc., of which Benjamin Gottfried is president. The Cross Brown Company and Henry B. Root, Inc., were the brokers and the attorneys were Scribner Miller for the seller and Abraham Zemlock for the buyer.

Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association met for the third time yesterday on new contract negotiations, They ran into a snag posed by the recent Supreme Court decision on overtime pay for the dock workers.
PADUCAH, Ky., July 19 Senator Alben W. Barkley received a warm welcome this afternoon when he arrived for his first visit at home since receiving the Democratic nomination for Vice President.

The writer of this reply to Prof. Millar Burrows' letter on Palestine published on July 14 has high regard for Dr. Burrows not only as an eminent Biblical scholar and archaeologist but also as a personal friend. He cannot follow him, however, on the Palestine issue.

Radical changes and improvements in office machines in the next few years were predicted yesterday by Irving Ritchie, president of the National Office Machine Dealers Association at the opening of its annual convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

KEFLAVIK, Iceland, July 19 -Despite bad weather the sixteen United States Air Force jet fighters bound for Germany for maneuvers landed here late this afternoon on schedule. Lieut. Col. David Shilling, commander of the group, said the fighters would be in Britain tomorrow if the weather got no worse.

A bid of $6,044,748 was the highest of five submitted yesterday to the Office of the Alien Property Custodian for the 77.37 per cent stock interest in the American Bosch Corporation, which was vested with the Alien Property Custodian in 1942 under the authority of the Trading with the Enemy Act.

Demand for fall fabrics in the rayon goods field has resulted in heavy orders to dyers and finishers, it was learned yesterday. Opening after a two-week vacation, dyers will have some goods out by the end of the week, but the first full flow will not reach the market until the beginning of August.

Horse racing fans once again permitted themselves to be the object of the pleasant delusion of being permitted a trip to the cool confines of up-state New York without leaving the geographical limitations of the city. The mild mesmerism, which annually takes the form of presenting a part of the meeting of the Saratoga Association at the Jamaica track, had its 1948 introduction yesterday when 21,887 traveled to the Baisley Boulevard oval.

Only one of the four seeded players competed yesterday as play in the women's Eastern clay court singles championship started at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx. She was Mrs. Norma Barber, fourth-ranking competitor, who triumphed over Miss Constance Dengel of Pelham, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

LONDON, July 19 -- The Olympic games scheduled to open here July 29 have proved a sufficient "draw" to end any doubt as to financial success of the venture, Sir Arthur Elvin, chairman and managing director of Wembley Stadium, said today.

PARIS, July 19 -- Under stress ofa Socialist revolt that split theGovernment coalition, the SchumanCabinet was overthrown tonightby a vote of 297 to 214. ThePremier and all his Ministers wentat once to the Elysee Palace tohand their collective resignation toPresident Vincent Auriol.
The market started 1 to 4 pointshigher and ten slumped in theafternoon to losses of 4 to 22points.

PALISADES, N.Y., July 19 -Dr. Jean P. Cooley, 54 years old, Associate Professor of Physics at New York University for twenty years, was found dead today on a woodland path near his home in the Heigh Ho Woods section of this village.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 The United States Steel Corporation is expected to announce within the next fortyeight hours price rises resulting from the thirdround wage increases granted production workers and coal miners, informed sources in the industry said today.

I have listened to radio forums and read accounts of the plight of the cities in attempting to meet the rising costs of running them, but not a solitary individual has had the courage to offer the only practical solution, one which would even go far in stimulating private construction.

SEOUL, Korea, July 19 -- At the invitation of an assistant liaison officer between the United States command here and the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea two Soviet officers dined last night with Jean Louis Paul - Boncour, French delegate to the commission and the present chairman of the commission.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- PresidentTruman will hand Congress anew anti-inflation bill for priorityaction after the special sessionconvenes next Monday, the WhiteHouse announced today.

Bassie Brown squinted in the sun late yesterday afternoon on the edge of the Governor Smith Housing Project in Cherry Hill east of Brooklyn Bridge, and with other resentful neighbors shook his head over the passing of the district's ancient rookeries.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The twentieth mechanical conference of the American Newspaper Publishers Association opened here today. On display at the convention headquarters were many types of machinery for use in newspaper plants.
SENECA FALLS, N.Y., July 19 -- This village which has gone down in feminist history as the site of the nation's first woman's rights convention showed today how much times have changed.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 19 (AP) -New York's crop of apples, pears, peaches and grapes is expected to be below average this year.

In line with a program to increase consumer confidence in cake products retailed through grocery stores, the Quality Bakers of America, a trade association whose members produced a cake volume in excess of $25,000,000 in wholesale valuation last year, will test a new marketing technique known as the "Cake-of-the-day" program.

Directors of Pacific Mills yesterday voted an inceared cash dividend of $1 a share plus a dividend of 5 percent in capital stock both on sept.15. In lieu of fractional shares an amount of cah will be paid calculate share.
VIENNA, July 19 -- Vienna is filled with reports today that Russian women and children are leaving on special trains for home. This movement has been under way for some time.

Collectors bent on finding antiques that might otherwise requiremiles of searching joined with lei.surely visitors at the opening yesterday of the second annual antiques show at the Hempstead ElksClub, 656 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, L. I.

Operations of the Economic Cooperation Administration will not give the American shipping industry enough assistance to readjust itself to normal post-war conditions, according to the monthly shipping survey of the Association of American Ship Owners.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- PanAmerican World Airways today asserted before the Civil Aeronautics Board that $10,000,000 in air mail payments would have been saved for this Government in 1947 if it (the airline) had been permitted to operate a domestic service between its overseas terminals.
JERUSALEM, July 19 -- Fifty Arab Legion troopers and fifteen Israeli soldiers were killed in the final stages of the Jerusalem battle.

DETROIT, July 19 -- Strike action against the Ford Motor Company by 116,000 hourly rated employes was authorized today by the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, but each side took immediate steps to resume the suspended negotiations tomorrow, to avert a walkout.
WASHINGTON. July 19 (AP) -The National Petroleum Council reported today that the United States now owns 42.9 per cent of the world's oil tankers.

GENEVA, July 19 -- The seventh session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council opened in Geneva today and immediately plunged into a debate on the most explosive political items on its program.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Information that the Securities and Exchange Commission has been trying to obtain from two Cleveland lawyers, with regard to the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, was given today to Judge James W. Morris of the Federal District Court here for private perusal.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 19 -- Despite the continuance of fighting in Palestine, qualified sources here viewed the situation calmly tonight. They pointed out that the earlier truce had not taken hold completely for several days.

Joseph P. Day, Inc., sold the taxpayer containing five stores at 1012-24 Brighton Beach Avenue, adjoining the Lincoln Savings Bank at the corner of Coney Island Avenue, Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, to the 1012 Brighton Corporation through Harry Duberstein, broker.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Thetactics of the Soviet Union in Berlinwere regarded so gravely inWashington today that PresidentTruman sought the counsel of hisprincipal diplomatic and militaryadvisers, while John Foster Dulles,lieutenant of Gov. Thomas E.Dewey, and Sir Oliver Franks, theBritish Ambassador, conferred atthe State Department.

Failure of the Social Service Employes Union, Local 19, CIO, to agree to an election among workers at the national board of the Y. W. C. A. caused the board yesterday to break off negotiations with the union.

Biggest and fastest yet of the commercial airliners, the long awaited Boeing Stratocruiser already is flying, Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, announced yesterday. The big double-decked plane for seventy-five passengers has been making passenger-comfort test flights from the Boeing factory in Seattle.

The Board of Superintendentshas reaffirmed unanimously its decisionnot to renew the New Yorkpublic school system's subscriptionsto the weekly magazine TheNation because two series of articlesallegedly attacked the religiousbeliefs of the Roman CatholicChurch.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 19 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and one of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's leading rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, is scheduled to visit Mr. Dewey at his 300-acre dairy farm here on Wednesday for a general political discussion.

ROME, July 19 -- Extraordinary precautions have been taken in Siena since yesterday's incidents, when shots were fired from the headquarters of the Communist Farm Workers Federation at the funeral of two carabinieri killed by Communists at Abbadia San Salvatore.

BERLIN, July 19 (AP) -- Ruhr steel production -- Germany's major expected contribution to the European Recovery Program -- hit a new post-war record in June The American Military Government announced this today in its semimonthly report on occupation affairs.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 -One of those always-wanted southerly breezes that used to spring up afternoons over Long Island Sound, but has shunned these waters this summer, came back today and saved the third session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.
Coney Island's Steeplechase Park was turned into a colosseum of hilarity yesterday by 7,500 orphan children from fifty-six orphanages in the metropolitan area.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 19 (AP) -- United States military authorities today denied charges that they had sent spies and assassins into Czechoslovakia and demanded an apology and a retraction from Czechoslovak officials.

ATLANTA, July 19 (AP) -- Wilfred Crossley of Brooklyn won his first-round match in defense of his national public links golf championship today, but the round proved a dead-end road for many other favorites.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -Bob Kennedy's eleventh-inning single with two out scored Larry Doby from second base to give the Cleveland Indians a 7-6 victory over Washington tonight. Kennedy saved the game for the Indians in the tenth when he speared Al Kozar's fly with one out and nipped Ed Stewart attempting to score from third with a crisp, accurate throw.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Navy Department denied flatly today that a ship carrying an atom bomb had ever "disappeared."

Despite the fact that total cash dividend payments on common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased 14.4 per cent during the first six months of this year, far greater uneveness of distributions occurred than the year previous.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Unless the general price level comes down, New Yorkers will see no sharp decline in the price of milk, experts of the Department of Agriculture predicted today.
Alan B. Helffrich has been appointed general sales manager of the printing, publication and converting paper division of the St. Regis Sales Corporation, subsidiary of the St. Regis Paper Company.

Demolition is scheduled to get under way this week on the two three-story dwellings at 355-57 East Nineteenth Street, which will be the site of the new Evangelical Lutheran Church of Christ. Plans have been prepared by Herbert E. Matz, architect, for the new edifice, which is to cost about $115,340.

Easy-to-prepare is the selling point for foods when it's too warm for serious cooking. We looked for items that fit into this comfortable category on a recent tour of city groceries. We found a number of appropriate products -- some that might do for tonight's dinner, others that could be kept on hand for future use.

Again the swift pace of air development makes a reality of what would have been thought incredible only a few years ago. Six jet-propelled Vampire fighters of the British Royal Air Force completed their transatlantic air trip last week by reaching Goose Bay, Labrador, after three hops across the northern seas.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 19--What appeared to be an early crisis in the Palestine truce developed today when Syrians recaptured a village southeast of Banyas. Israeli forces have vowed to take it back.

AFTER having read through fifty or so pages of Tatyana A. Kuzminskaya's memoirs this reviewer found himself thinking along the following lines: Anything, no matter how marginal or trivial, about Leo Tolstoy is worth attention. This reaction to the opening pages of "Tolstoy As I Knew Him" was an unwillingness to admit boredom and, as it turned out, the rationalization was unnecessary.

The right-wing international advisory board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted yesterday to file charges against the officers of one of the union's left-wing store locals in this city.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 19 -- Top-seeded Frankie Parker, of Los Angeles, No. 1 amateur tennis player of the land, and secondranked Billy Talbert, of New York, No. 4 nationally, both made their first appearance of the tournament on Travers Island, today as all but a few fourth-round brackets were filled in the twentieth annual Eastern Clay Courts championship.

The wholesale meat and butter markets weakened yesterday as the resistance of consumers to high prices was felt. Retail butchers, still well-stocked with left-overs as a result of housewives' indifference to meat at a record high, did not buy. Out-of-town merchants and purchasing agents for resorts, who helped push prices up last week stayed at home.
JACKSON, Wyo., July 19 -- The Jackson Hole Wildlife Park, a 1,500-acre preserve near Moran, just north of here, was opened formally today.

Petitions designating Francis A. Valente and Vincent R. Impellitteri as rival candidates for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate of New York County -- the principal local post at stake this fall -- were in readiness last night for filing with the Board of Elections before the final deadline late this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -General Hershey gave no details in his comment on priority in the draft, but the purpose of taking 25-year-old men first would be obvious. They will soon be past the law's age limit. If they are not taken quickly, they cannot be taken at all.

Twelve associates of John Purroy Mitchel, Mayor of New York from 1914 to 1917, paid tribute to his memory at his graveside yesterday afternoon. The observance was the twenty-ninth annual pilgrimage to the modest headstone in Woodlawn Cemetery, held each year on the former Mayor's birthday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -The Government called today upon Great Western Distributors, Inc., of New York, and four of its officials and employes to answer charges that they attempted to corner the egg market last December.
LONDON, July 19 (2P--I-Iundreds of Olympic competitorsflocked to the training field todayas summer weather returned aftertwo weeks of clouds and cold.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Emil "Dutch" Leonard was raked for eleven hits by the Cubs today, but managed to stagger through with the Phillies for a 5-4 victory that gave the invaders the rubber game of the series.

LONDON, July 19 - English literature's greatest allegory was put into drama, music and ballet tonight when John Bunyan's. "The Pilgrim's Progress" was given at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. The performance, which will run for two weeks, is sponsored by The London Daily Telegraph in commemoration of the 250th anniversary of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge.

TED ATKINSON was asked to tell the secret of his success as a jockey. "Fast horses," said Ted, "plus a hard-working agent." The same request was popped at Bobby Permane. "Luck," Bobby popped back, "and a good agent." "Go see Nick Huff," said Ted. "Go see Wayne Huff," said Bobby. So it was that the Messrs. Huff, father and son, jockey agents by trade, were asked to stand and deliver.

Station WHN, one of the city's older outlets, will change its call letters to WMGM when it moves in September to its new quarters at 711 Fifth Avenue. The station is affiliated with Metro-GoldwynMayer through common ownership by Loew's, Inc. WHN's frequency modulation station, WMGM, will be renamed WMGM-FM.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 19 -Maj. Gen. Cornelius W. Wickersham, Commanding General. Forty-second Infantry Division, New York National Guard, received tonight at a special review here the Order of the British Empire and the honorary rank of Commander.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr's first-inning grand-slam homer, off Fred Sanford, gave the Red Sox their first floodlight victory in four starts against the Browns, 4 -- 1, tonight before a 26,092 crowd. Mel Parnell kept six hits well scattered while gaining his sixth triumph.
The Victorian era provided the inspiration for various accessories in a showing of Aris gloves, Coro jewelry, Criterion belts and Glentex scarves yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 19 -- Following is the text of the reply by the eleven leading Germans of the United States, British and Franck zones to the authorization, transmitted by the three Western Military Governors on July 1, for initiating a German political organization, as decided by the six-power London conferences:

ABOARD THE S.S. AMERICA, July 19 -- Avery Brundage is leading America's Olympic team into action for the last time. The man who has been called a dictator will step down after heading the United States Olympic Association for twenty years.

Support of the city Departmentof Marine and Aviation as the officialagency to conduct the longawaited rehabilitation of the decliningwaterfront of the port wasoverwhelmingly voiced yesterdayby representatives of shipping andcivic associations.

The Yankees got a tough break in two places last night. When a sudden downpour washed away their contest with the Tigers, with some 35,000 fans in the stands, it was bitter enough to forfeit the finances involved, but, and this really hurt, the home team had a 3-0 lead when the rains came.

Some eighty-odd years ago an English explorer named Speke, stumbling through the equatorial forest, came upon the Lake Victoria source of the Nile. Thus was solved a mystery many centuries old. This week news was relayed from London that the British are doing preliminary work on two power dams at Owens Falls, a few miles down from the outlet.

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -The Government of India showed some perturbation today over the flight of an Australian pilot, Sydney Cotton, from Karachi, capital of Pakistan, direct to Hyderabad in defiance of an Indian order that he land at Bombay for customs inspection.

TOKYO, July 20 -- The Japanese Communist party demanded today the resignation of the Government of Premier Hitoshi Ashida over the attempted assassination last night of Kyuichi Tokuda, the party's general secretary at Saga, Kyushu.

At the insistence of Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods, four new members of the New York City Rent Advisory Board have been appointed to assure a "more balanced" representation of all interests in matters handled by this voluntary agency.

The National Education Association has announced the results of a study on "The Voter and the Non-Voter." It shows that the higher the education and economic level of the citizens the greater the proportional number going to the polls. This indeed presents, as the Association observes, an "unmistakable challenge to American educators and legislators", and it will have to be met by ever-increasing vigor and intelligence.
For what is believed to be the first time, the Board of Education will not have a quorum when it meets tomorrow in its headquarters at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

With a request for controls on consumer credit regarded as likely at the emergency session of Congress, the majority of retail credit men here yesterday expressed themselves as opposed to such legislation. A minority, particularly from smaller stores, contended that controls on credit had been a safeguard against "unscrupulous" methods of business and favored return for that season.
SENECA FALLS, N.Y., July 20 -- The dissolution of the woman's rights movement was proclaimed here today.

Senator Smith of New Jersey, an able and conscientious Republican, has announced that he will introduce a bill on Monday, as soon as the special session of Congress meets, to eliminate the discriminatory phases of the new law governing the admission of Displaced Persons to this country.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -Bob Chesnes, $100,000 pitcher from the Pacific Coast League, chalked up his fifth victory tonight as the Pirates crushed Philadelphia, 11 to 2. Six Pittsburgh runs were scored in the eighth inning.

A new standard radio station in the metropolitan area is scheduled to open in September, it was learned yesterday. It is WVNJ in Newark, operating with 5,000 watts power on 620 kilocycles, which will place it midway between WNBC and WMCA on the dial.

RYE, N.Y.,July 20 -- Mrs.John Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club, first-round leader by four strokes, increased her margin to six during the second lap of the Elizabeth Wheeler tournament for the women's golf championship of Westchester and Fairfield Counties at the Westchester Country Club today with a card of 164.

Describing the Advertising Council's three-months' old "United America" anti-discrimination campaign as one of its most successful, Ted Royal, campaign account executive, announced yesterday that twenty new ads will be issued next month.
THE HAGUE, July 20 (AP) -- The text of the communique of the Western European Union permanent council follows:

WEST POINT. N.Y., July 20 -Lieut. Frank Mehner of the European command and Lieut. Col. Sanford Webster of the Third Army, easily disposed of their quarter-final opponents in the United States Army tennis championship today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 20 -- Four seeded players advanced to the quarter-finals in the twentieth Eastern clay courts singles championship today at Travers Island. The other four contests in the round of 16 will be held tomorrow.
LONDON, July 20 -- A fiasco in Great Britain's efforts to keep pace with the United States in design and performance of civilian airliners was acknowledged officially by the Ministry of Supply today.

Starting a new method of showing textiles, the Infant Juvenile Manufacturers Association held yesterday a presentation of spring fabrics for its members in the McAlpin Hotel. Sales representatives of fourteen mills showed their lines in turn and described new innovations in patterns, constructions and finishes to about 100 manufacturers.
New designs in furniture and accessories and new ideas in decorating are complemented with original works by twenty-nine contemporary artists in the 1948 edition of "Contemporama" at Abraham Straus.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Commodities Exchange Authority reported today a "big increase" in trading in farm commodity futures in the fiscalyearthat ended on June 30, 1948.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Alexis, veteran campaigner from the Christiana Stable, set all the pace today in winning the mileand-sixteenth American Legion Post 754 Purse at Monmouth Park.

With the counting of the 43,000 ballots cast in the national elections of the National Maritime Union, CIO, now 70 per cent completed, Joseph Curran and his right-wing slate continued yesterday to hold an overwhelming lead, and the last vestige of hope for his opponents has been dissipated.

I. J. Fox put on a show yesterday in its Empire Salon that caused the spectators to rub their eyes in amazement. The major portion of the presentation consisted of twin fashions, though not identical twins. One of the doubles was of a precious and costly fur while its counterpart was of a more common variety geared to meet less extravagant tastes and pocketbooks.

David S. Meister, after a brief ownership, has sold the six-story store and apartment property at 3 Calver Street, Harrison, N. Y., to the Wobis Realty Corporation, represented by Spencer Iserman, attorneys. Irving S. Wolper was the broker.

Sharp disagreement with the report of Controller Lazarus Joseph on bus fares was expressed last night by Edmund Collins, vice president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation. On behalf of the companies, he issued a statement declaring that the report did not take account of important factors in the fare situation.

ATLANTA, July 20 (AP) -- Two major upsets continued the trend against favored players in the National Public Links tournament today, but the defending champion, Wilfred Crossley of Brooklyn, managed to eke out a victory in the second round.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 20 -The Windle Challenge Trophy went into the possession of Mrs. Robert Norton of Rock Spring today when she won the annual match-play-against-par tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club.

When I wrote my letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES on Kashmir, the Hyderabad situation and India's attitude toward the U.N. and the Anglo-American powers, it was my intention to present certain facts which should be taken into consideration by the American public and the authorities interested in promoting Indo-American friendship.

PRAGUE, July 20 (UP) -- Czechoslovakia's Olympic contestants today were tripping over hurdles which had nothing to do with sports, but partly with the suspicion that many would not return when the games are over.
Residential deals in the Flushing area predominated in the Queens realty transactions reported by brokers yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today after an early upturn. A return of liquidation in July corn and oats was the principal influence in bringing about a heavy close.

LONDON, July 20 -- British theatre critics were almost as enthusiastic today as the fans of Jack Benny who filled the Palladium last night to welcome him in person. The audience obviously knew every aspect of the comedian's material by heart and revelled in its translation from air to stage by Phil Harris, Mary Livingstone and Marilyn Maxwell.

DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis, commenting on reports he might return to the ring for a Sept. 22 bout with Gus Lesnevich, said today, "I don't know where those rumors come from. I've retired and that is all there is to it."

Reporting on operations of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company at a directors' meeting held in Toledo, Ohio, yesterday, John D. Biggers, president, announced that sales in the second quarter surpassed in dollar and unit volume those for any three-month period in the company's history.

An internal controversy over the management of New Stages, the downtown producing organization that brought "The Respectful Prostitute" to Broadway, is expected to reach a crisis tomorrow afternoon at a special meeting of the theatre company in its playhouse at 159 Bleecker Street.

LONDON, July 20 -- The complications of the international situation brought temporary confusion and dismay today in London, where the three-power discussions on the Berlin situation now were paralyzed.
