CORTLAND, N.Y., July 20 -Two messengers of the First National Bank were held up this morning at 10:50 by two men who escaped with $26,000 in cash and a stack of postal money orders.

One fireman was burned painfully and two probationary patrolmen overcome by smoke yesterday afternoon in a spectacular fire at Junius Street and Liberty Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
PEIPING, July 20 -- Government troops were reported today to have entered Anshan, steel center, fiftyfive miles southwest of Mukden. Fighting with Communists in the city was reported.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- Londoners blinked again today in a strange bright world, leading many to hope faintly that the weather was about to straighten itself out for the Olympic games.

President Truman issued yesterday the order for registration for the draft to begin Aug. 30, with actual inductions to begin on or after Sept. 22, as ordered by Congress. It would seem advisable now to announce the system under which the registrants are to be called to service, so that those subject to the draft can make their plans for school or business at least for the next few months.

Two new chemicals, one of which is said to have prevented paralysis and crippling in fifty human polio victims, and the other to have proved effective against a number of diseases caused by viruses and rickettsial, have been developed at Columbia University and the Lederle Laboratories, it was learned yesterday.

Several furniture manufacturers began yesterday to write post-market orders in good quantity, according to wholesale representa'tires. They said most orders were coming from small independent stores that were replenishing depleted stocks for fall selling.

Six of twelve high-ranking Communists indicted yesterday by a special Federal grand jury that has investigated Communist activity for more than a year were arrested here last night on charges of conspiring to overthrow the United States Government.

The school tuna, most of them running larger and tougher than in recent years, are still being brought in by most of the New Jersey and Long Island boats, and many of the skippers report that tuna are being hooked that are too big to handle on the regulation school tuna tackle.

MUNICH, July 20 -- In the packed, sweltering courtroom at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Frau Emmy Goering, former actress, widow of Marshal Hermann Goering, today staged the greatest performance of her career.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's proclamation issued today ordering Selective Service registration:
I was somewhat appalled by your editorial of July 3 saying that the shortwave broadcasts of CBS and NBC should be under "full State Department operation and control."
DUBLIN, July 20 -- Ireland will no longer be isolationist in the present situation in Europe, Foreign Minister Sean MacBride told the Dail Eireann tonight.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell ruled yesterday that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers had violated the anti-trust laws by exacting fees from theatres exhibiting motion pictures containing ASCAP music.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 20 -One of the few remaining pre-Revolutionary homesteads on the North Shore, residence of the Wright family for eight generations, has been sold to Comdr. James T. Baldwin, USNR, and Mrs. Baldwin, the former Miss Marie B. Heck, it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 --- John Ford and Merian C. Cooper, partners in Argosy Pictures, are certain that they have a potential star in Ben Johnson, former Oklahoma cowboy, so they are not waiting for box office returns to justify their conviction.

MONTREAL, July 20 -- Hector H. Racine, Montreal Baseball Club president, announced today that the Dodgers, because of the Jackie Robinson "incident" in a game here July 12, had waived their $8,000 share of the gate receipts.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 20 -- The executive committee of the American Association for the United Nations today urged the United States to submit the Berlin question to the United Nations "if it becomes clear" that direct negotiations have broken down.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, as of June 30, reports net assets of $50,505,431, equal to $11.94 a common share, according to an announcement yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the board. This compared with $46,040,596 on June 30, 1947, and $46,298,207, or $10.10 a common share on March 31, 1948.

LONDON, July 20 -- The sharp decline in prices in Wall Street, coupled with the fall of the French Cabinet caused jobbers to expect another drop in prices on the stock market here today. But no sooner had prices been lowered as a precaution than buyers began to come in following the news of the Soviet food movement to Berlin.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 20 -- A sharp rise in the cost of powdered milk plus an unexplained shortage of milk supplies in this country, may compel the Children's Emergency Fund to substitute other foods in its European feeding program for 4,500,000, worried officials of the United Nations relief agency said today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- A tentative draft of the Henry A. Wallace party platform tonight repudiated the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and pledged the third political group "to negotiations and discussions with the Soviet Union, in good faith, to find areas of agreement to win the peace."
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 (UP) -- President Mariano Ospina Perez today opened a regular session of Congress on the 129th anniversary of Colombia's independence from Spain.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Air Force, building to a seventygroup armada of the sky, is actively seeking youths as future pilots. Of all the types of personnel required, the pilot trainee is the one in most demand, recruiting officials said today.

PARIS, July 20 -- A British compromise proposal, designed to enable the Marshall Plan nations to agree on a method of expanding their mutual trade, was submitted to the council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation today.
An appeal for military, economic and ideological aid for China was made here yesterday by Dr. Chen Li-fu, vice president of the Chinese Legislative Yuan, or Parliament,

LONDON, July 20 (UP) -- Britain's food shortage caused among London's Olympic organizers a black market scare today. Special police were drafted to some Olympic camps to foil black market gangs bidding for big profits by speculating in the considerable food surpluses which cram the camp kitchens.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -An American League umpire, Bill McGowan, was suspended today pending investigation of charges that (a) he threw hard objects at ball players and (b) used objectionable language.
Eliminate Europe as "a bone-of contention" by withdrawing all armed forces from Western Europe. James P. Warburg, economist, proposed last night as a way of checking "the present drift toward war."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Officials of the Department of Justice either professed ignorance of the contents of the indictments handed down by a Federal grand jury in New York, or declined to discuss them, today.

The World Trade Corporation plans to confer with its investment bankers in the next few days on questions involving the city's influence in the corporation's management in the event it takes over the port rehabilitation project.

Paul H. Startzman is resigning his partnership in the industrial engineering firm of Drake, Startzman, Sheahan, Barclay, Inc., to become general manager in charge of operations of Oliver Iron and Steel Corporation, effective on Aug. 2.

The $300,000,000 office-machine marketing industry was praised yesterday by Henry Miller, director of trade practice conferences of the Federal Trade Commission, for its "public-spirited" adherence to the trade practice rules promulgated last spring.

NEWARK. N.J., July 20 -- Edward Molenof, special assistant United States Attorney General, today spent nearly an hour questioning P. James Pellecchia, who resigned a week ago as the Newark police judge after admitting he embezzled $630,000 from the Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel.

A 9.6 per cent increase in the price of finished steel products was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corpora tion. The new levels, effective today at all subsidiaries of the corporation, include an average increase of $8.09 a ton in the base price for major steel products. In addition, the new prices at mills or shipping points embrace a restoration of the average price reduction of $1.25 a ton made last April.

The American Retail Federation has submitted recommendations to improve the accuracy, completeness and usefulness of data gathered in the 1949 Census of Business, it was announced yesterday. Covering all statistical phases of the census as it applies to retailing, the recommendations were developed by the federation's census committee after four months of research.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 20 -- Complete identity of views exists among the five partners of the Western European Union in their attitude toward Germany, according to a communique issued today at the end of a twoday conference of Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Trapped between rising costs and shrinking attendance, the nation's entertainment industry has been squeezed steadily until it is now well on the way down to its pre-war status. The present decline, a survey indicates, is beyond that of last summer's lull and may be the most serious manifestation to date of a trend that set in eighteen months ago.

Nathan Milstein and Hans Schwieger diviced honors at last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra that attracted an audience of 12,700 to the Lewisohn Stadium. They collaborated on Brahms' Violin Concerto and each had part of the spotlight to himself.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Amid a flurry of charges hurled at the Securities and Exchange Commission today, the Cleveland investment banking concern of Otis Co. renewed its plea to the Federal District Court to halt any further public inquiry into the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.
The internal fight within Tammany Hall over the nomination of a Surrogate was deadlocked last night after a rapid series of dramatic developments which included the following:

CAIRO, July 20 -- Most shops in the central business district of Cairo were shuttered and police carrying bamboo staves patroled the downtown streets in force today following yesterday's department store bombing and the demonstrations related to the Palestine truce.

The $104,000,000 United Corporation, which is in transition from a public utility holding company to an investment company, reported yesterday that net income for the June quarter this year reached $1,814,141, $1,040,000 above the 1947 net of $773,198.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- With Jackie Robinson turning in some extraordinary support in two moments of stress, Rex Barney today pitched his first major league shut-out as the Dodgers took the opener from the Cubs, 5-0, and narrowed the lead of the pace-setting Braves to six and a half games.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 20 -- More than one hour ahead of schedule, the main body of the United States Olympic team docked late tonight aboard the flagship America of the United States Lines. The Americans will not disembark, however, until tomorrow morning, when most of the 260 athletes will leave in buses along with various officials for their training camp in a London suburb.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The Air Force announced today it had awarded a $7,000,000 contract to the Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Wood-Ridge, N.J., for production of two types of aircraft engines.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -In spite of a flat calm that had set in, most of the 345 competing craft in the fourth racing session of Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club managed to finish their courses today. They were able to do so with a little southerly breeze that came up in the nick of time to waft them home, better late than never.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,494, against 2,136 last week and 1,190 in the corresponding week a year ago; according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 663 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,029 last Tuesday.

BERLIN, July 20 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, and Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, his political adviser, are flying to Washington tonight for important conferences with President Truman, Secretary of State Marshall and Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall on the Berlin crisis.

The State of Connecticut sold yesterday a new issue of $1,750,000 World War II bonus bonds maturing from Aug. 1, 1949 to 1958, to a banking group consisting of Bankers Trust Company, MercantileCommerce Bank and Trust Company and Cooley Co.
LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- Los Angeles authorities today ordered 104 county employes to subscribe to a "loyalty oath" by Monday or lose their jobs for "insubordination."

LONDON, July 20 -- Appeals for courage and boldness were made here to churches of the Anglican communion today at a breakfast given by the Industrial Christian Fellowship in Church House, Westminster. They came from two different types of men -- the Right Rev. Dr. Henry K. Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, and Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer.

There is one area in which Mr. Truman would have a difficult time, we imagine, persuading the local citizenry this week that Government controls are needed to prevent a runaway inflation of prices. That is in Wall Street's investment and speculative community.

LONDON, July 20 -- Sheikh Hafez Wahba, Saudi Arabian Ambassador in London, said today that the "real reason" that some Arab League States accepted the renewal of the truce in Palestine was that they found themselves opposed by the world's three greatest powers, the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union.
A new freighter service between North Atlantic ports of the United States and Antwerp, Rotterdam, Bremen and Hamburg will be started this week by the Meyer Line of Oslo, Norway.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- The fifth party congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia will convene at 8 A.M. tomorrow in an undisclosed suburb.

As City Marshal David Leef supervised the eviction of two families from a tenement building at 2310 Second Avenue yesterday morning, Representative Vito Marcantonio renewed his charges of "complicity" between the City Rent Commission and the landlord in the case.
The list of designees who filed for the various nominations in the Democratic and Republican primaries follows, asterisks denoting incumbents:
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Officials of the State Department believe that several hundred subversive foreign agents have used the United Nations as a cover for their activities in this country.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- The Government radio and press last night and today seized upon the contents of a private letter and an airmailed dispatch of a United States correspondent, which had been intercepted "through a providential circumstance," as proof that "North American capitalist monopolies" were intervening in Argentina with intentions hostile to the country.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 20 -- Health officers, public health nurses, school nurse teachers, school physicians, sanitary engineers and milk sanitarians from all parts of the state assembled here today for a conference.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Truman started the draft today with a proclamation requiring 9,500,000 youths to register during seventeen designated days of August and September.

Appointments have been accepted by eleven leaders in American industry to serve on the honorary committee covering the "Salute to Alloy Steel," central theme of the National Metal Congress and Exposition in Philadelphia Oct. 25-29, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, July 20 -- In view of the confusion that the downfall of the Schuman coalition Cabinet has created in French politics, President Vincent Auriol began his consultations on a possible program before attempting to find a successor to former Premier Robert Schuman.

First reports from the five-power parley at The Hague suggested that the governments represented there were nervous lest the United States move too fast or too rashly to break the impasse in Berlin. These fears are groundless. The discussions that have been going on in Washington, while firm on maintaining our right to free access to the former German capital, are above all explorations of ways and means to avoid open conflict.
CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) -Home runs, accounting for six markers, turned the tide for the Reds today as they toppled the league-leading Braves, 9-6.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Herbert Brownell, manager of Thomas E. Dewey's Presidential campaign, declared today it would be impossible for a "rump" session of Congress, convened in an atmosphere of politics, to enact the Republican platform, drafted for adoption under a Republican President.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Soviet Union not only is increasing its pressure against the Western Allies in Berlin, but also is twisting the screws on its Communist associates in Central and Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -Attorney General Tom C. Clark said today that he has no facts to justify a criminal investigation of Army officers who negotiated the Government's wartime railroad freight rates.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 20 -There were continued violations of the truce today, with Israeli forces and the Syrians still tangling in the northern area, the Arabs under Fawzi el Kawukji shelling points around Jenin and Tulkarm and the Egyptians launching an armored column attack near Hatta in the Negeb area.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The Soviet Union was frustrated at every turn today in its effort to turn the United Nations Economic and Social Council into a forum in which the Russians could rise to new propaganda heights as champions of the world's downtrodden masses.
Harold E. Stassen, pre-convention contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, arrived here late yesterday afternoon. He will confer with Governor Dewey today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Some members of the National Labor Relations Board will seriously consider a request that a union be made to reimburse an employer for losses during an illegal strike, it was stated today by a board member, James J. Reynolds, Jr.

This is vacation itself. Not anticipation. Not retrospect. Just vacation. The black pencil moves across the yellow paper accompanied by a thin, dry rustle of sand. Beyond the dark rim of ocean lies Spain.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -The Australian cricket tourists beat Middlesex by ten wickets in their match which ended at Lords today. The final scores were Middlesex 203 and 135, the Australians 317 and 22 for no wickets.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Chicago's Railroad Fair, a $10,000,000 exhibition sponsored by thirty-eight American carriers to commemorate the one-hundredth anniversary of the coming of the railroads to Chicago, was formally opened today on a fifty-acre site in Burnham Park on the lake front.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The omnibus message loaded with controversial issues which President Truman has promised to send to the session of Congress next week will plead also for continued Republican support of the bipartisan foreign policy, the White House disclosed today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -The United Nations Commission on the Kashmir dispute decided today to ask Lake Success to send a high ranking military adviser to the commission.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 20 (AP) -- Rocket firing Royal Air Force Spitfires attacked from the air and ground troops slashed through the jungle today in a British drive to smash the Communist insurgent domination of the Guam usang area, 120 miles north of here.
TRENTON, N.J., July 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll moved today to reactivate a skeleton civilan defense corps because of "the gravity of the international situation."
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -President Truman got himself a 1948 professional football pass today, but the chances are that he won't use it.

Each of the five left-wing department store unions in this city will hold secret-ballot elections within the next sixty days to determine how their 22,000 members feel about the refusal of their officers to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -Relief pitcher Sid Hudson stymied a ninth-inning Cleveland rally to lift the Senators to a 2-1 victory over the league-leading Indians tonight. The victory snapped a 5-game Washington losing streak.

As a result of a message relayed to him by Elliot Wolheim, 30 years old, who operates an amateur radio station in his home at 3595 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. Charles S. Brown Jr., flew to Montreal yesterday to meet his son, Charles S. Brown 3d, who is seriously ill with acute anemia.

WASHINGTON, July 20--War Assets Administrator Jess Larson ordered WAA regional offices today to sell their remaining stocks of surplus personal property by the end of this year and to prepare to go out of business by Feb. 28, 1949.
Housewives will benefit today from the slump in the wholesale butter market as A, Safeway and Grand Union stores reduce their prices three cents a pound on all grades.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Pan American Airways would be potentially the largest domestic airline as well as the world's largest international air service if permitted to link thirteen major American cities with express airplane service, as it so desires, the Civil Aeronautics Board was told today by spokesmen for other airlines opposing Pan American's application.

With the New Jersey team appearing as the favorites, the twenty-third triangular matches that bring together the leading golfing amateurs from Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey will be held today over the Pomonok Country Club course, Flushing, L.I.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis, the only Negro general in the regular Army, bade farewell to fifty years of soldiering today with the personal felicitations of President Truman.
Play continued without incident yesterday in the Eastern women's clay court championships as the top four seeded entrants captured their matches easily at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The Association of American Railroads estimated today that railroad operating revenues last month were 17.6 per cent higher than in June, 1947.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The Power Authority of New York State asked the Federal Power Commission today for permission to start a cooperative international power project on the St. Lawrence River.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Export-Import Bank is considering an application by Cyrus S. Eaton for a loan of $5,000,000 to be used in developing an iron mine in Canada, it was learned here today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20 -Continuing to play the fine golf that enabled her to win the qualifying medal, Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the North Hempstead County Club defeated Miss Lorraine Barzee of Syracuse, 6 and 4, to lead the way into the second round of the New York State women's championship over the Onondaga Golf and Country Club course today.
New issues of public utility bonds aggregating $25,000,000 were sold by issuing companies to underwriting syndicates at competitive bidding yesterday.

One could awake from the sleep of a Rip Van Winkle, return to the city and after walking through the markets, guess without glancing at the dateline on the paper what month it was. Well supplied with fresh produce the year round, New York stores are superabundantly stocked in summer, especially from mid-July to mid-September.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted fourteen paint manufacturing concerns, including several of the world's largest, on a charge of rigging prices in violation of the United States Anti-Trust Laws. Twenty-one officials of the companies also were indicted.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported tonight that the shortage of paper and paperboard was almost over.

A non-winner in seven tries since he last ran at Jamaica in May, C. V. Whitney's Bright Sword put his number up on the top of the board in the main event of the Saratoga Association's proceedings at the Metropolitan Jockey Club's course yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 20 -- Officials of the United Nations said today that it was up to the State Department to back, with facts, the charges that foreign agents were using Lake Success as a wedge to enter the United States and roam around the country.

William Foster -- the "Z" used as a middle initial being self-inserted, as his parents gave him no middle name -- had been an active radical for nearly a half century and head of the Communist party since 1945 when he succeeded Earl Browder, deposed for what were termed "revisionist" activities.

Plans for a new dormitory building at 2521 Amsterdam Avenue were filed yesterday by Albert Goldhammer, architect, of 6 Varick Street, in behalf of Yeshiva University, Inc. The estimated cost is $200,000.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening today an exhibition made up of art selected from six New York private collections. Individually installed in gallery space on the ground floor, the selections are decidedly catholic in their diversity, and, aside from the personal tastes indicated, provide a not inconsiderable cross-section of the modern movement.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- RightHander Jack Kramer gave up seven hits, two of them homers, while gaining his eleventh victory of the season and his ninth in a row today while the Red Sox were sweeping a four-game series from the Browns, 8-3.

Mayor O'Dwyer awarded three plaques and fourteen citations yesterday to units with the best floats in the recent Golden Jubilee parade on Fifth Avenue. The ceremony took place in City Hall Plaza with several thousand persons present.

GENEVA, July 20 -- The twentysix-nation Executive Board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund approved in principle today the extension of limited aid to a selected group of German children.
SEOUL, Korea, July 20 -- The Korean National Assembly this afternoon elected Lee Si Yung, 79year-old anti-Japanese Korean patriot, Vice President of the Korean Republic.

Residents in and around the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, who during the last few months have been plagued by offensive odors from landfill in the area, took their troubles yesterday to the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Pearl Gevertz purchased for cash above a mortgage of $15,000 made by the Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Association the ranch-type residence at 12 Middle Neck Road in Flower Hill, L. I., from Rolling Land Views, Inc.
LONDON, July 20 -- Hanging as a penalty for all murders was kept on the British statute books by a 99-to-19 vote of the House of Lords tonight, and it looked as if it would remain for some time.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -Mario Pieretti, mite of a righthander, scattered six hits tonight as he pitched the White Sox to a 5-2 victory over the Athletics in the final of the five-game series at Shibe Park. The win was the Chicagoan's second of the series, but only their third in 14 games with Philadelphia this season.

Percy MacKaye, 73-year-old poet-dramatist, has been selected for the 1948 fellowship award of the Academy of American Poets, 1030 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Hugh Bullock, president of the academy. The award provides a stipend of $5,000 for one year.

HARWELL, England, July 20 -Britain's main atomic energy research center, a top secret enterprise since it opened in November, 1945, was opened to inspection by newspapermen today. The inspection included a close look at the establishment's original uranium pile and a glimpse of a new and more powerful pile capable of developing 6,000 kilowatts of energy, sixty times that of the original pile.
In the "News of the Week in Review" section of June 13 appears this paragraph:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The return of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States commander in Germany, to consult with President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall will enable these officials to talk personally with their chief representative in Berlin before making final decisions concerning the next step in the crisis provoked by the Russian blockade.
In a report of the Congress of the World Liberal Union, which took place in Zurich in May, I read:

JERUSALEM, July 20 -- The Security Council's Mediator, Count Bernadotte, faces what most observers here believe is his most difficult task in determining the future constitutional status of the city of Jerusalem. As things stand, the Arab League will never agree to its becoming Jewish.

The Benenson interests figured in two more major realty transactions in Manhattan yesterday. They acquired, a large apartment building in the Murray Hill section and sold a warehouse and distribution building in the Pennsylvania Station zone.
YORK, Pa., July 20 (AP) -- J. W. Gitt, publisher of The York Gazette and Daily, today announced he would publish a new weekly, The National Gazette, here.

The Port of Mobile has declared "friendly" war on New York. Officials of the Alabama State Docks and Terminals announced here yesterday that they were out to lure as much business from this port as possible.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 20 -- In a closed session with the eleven Minister Presidents of the trizonal area, the three Military Governors of Western Germany today repeated their July 1, proposals for the creation of a government.
A new sports phaeton, the Jeepster, was added yesterday to the Willys-Overland Motors line at a preview showing in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Republican leadership was confronted today with the problem of trying to prevent the new session of the Eightieth Congress from heading straight into a Senate filibuster against civil rights legislation.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was very quiet Tuesday, and final prices were 5 to 8 points net lower.

Rockaway Beach will weep for Coney Island tonight with an air waterfalls fireworks display to be called "Rockaways Salute to Coney Island -- A One-Time Great Beach." This bit of sarcasm, latest blow in the battle of the beaches, is part of the regular Wednesday evening fireworks exhibit held offshore at Beach Ninety-sixth Street and sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways.

Mayor O'Dwyer told members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday that the decrease in New York's crime rate reported on Saturday in the Police Department's annual report for 1947 was not "accidental," but the result of "hard work, cooperation, fine detection and courage."

Not long ago the Yankees were concentrating on catching the pace-setting Indians. Now they must concern themselves with protecting third place from the redhot Red Sox. For, following yesterday's 2-1 setback by the Tigers at the Stadium, the Yankees found themselves a mere length ahead of the onrushing Boston club.

Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett, in behalf of Mayor O'Dwyer, accepted yesterday a check for $284,623 from New York school children as their contribution to the American Overseas Aid-United Nations Appeal for Children.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., July 20 -- Disturbed by a published report that the United Nations Appeal for Children has not been making its quota, and that its publicity campaign was at a virtual standstill for lack of funds, three couples here today started a drive of their own in behalf of the appeal.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Relief from New York's ragged highway situation is indicated in increased confidence shown by contractors that economic conditions are becoming more stabilized. Charles H. Sells, Superintendent of Public Works of that state, said today at the annual convention of the American Road Builders Association.

Samuel Richardson, a Negro merchant of Harlem who had been prevented by a court injunction from occupying a house in Queens he had contracted to buy from its white occupants, announced yesterday preparations to move into the property following a decision Friday by the New York State Court of Appeals setting aside the lower court rulings.
LONDON, July 20 -- The United States strength of bombers and fighters in Europe was reinforced today by the arrival in the British Isles of sixteen Lockheed jet-engined Shooting Stars.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Registration statements covering $5,250,000 of first mortgage bonds and 500,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.
LONDON, July 20 -- The question before the House of Lords today was: Does a homing pigeon always want to go home?

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- If there are real political advantages to be won or lost in President Truman's hastily summoned session of Congress, the House members most on the spot are the sixty Republicans and twenty-nine Democrats who won their present seats by less than 55 per cent of the vote in 1946.

After applying unsuccessfully over a two-year period for a ruling by the Treasury Department to accept a grant by the Rockefeller Foundation, the American-Soviet Science Society has announced that it must stop aiding the interchange of ideas between United States and Russian scientists because of lack of funds.

Two new films will open firstrun theatres today. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "So Evil My Love," a period melodrama produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount release featuring Ray Milland, Ann Todd and Geraldine Fitzgerald. Lewis Allen directed from a screen play by Leonard Spigelgass and Ronald Millar and a novel by Joseph Shearing.

Some of the severe damage done on Monday to the stock market wasrepaired yesterday as prices recouped I to 2 points, w/th evenbetter gains in issues that have been hardest hit recently. Theabrupt change in sentiment in financial circles was creditedtothe near-term international political outlook.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate without recommendation exhaustive reports on the applications of thirteen private bus lines for higher fares. These clearly reflected his belief that the companies could show a profit if they received a one-cent increase.
Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway at a meeting held here yesterday elected Walter J. Touhy to the new post of first vice president and also to the board of directors.

Dr. Herbert J. Phillips, Associate Professor of Philosophy at the University of Washington, left La Guardia Field last night to answer a summons of the Washington State Legislature's Un-American Activities Committees.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Red Sox stormed from behind with a three-run rally in the ninth to sweep a day-night doubleheader from the White Sox, 10 -- 9, tonight after capturing the afternoon contest, 3 -- 1.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Wheat futures averaged higher on the Board of Trade today and corn and oats lower, liquidation by holders of July featuring trading in the latter grains. Oats lost 1 1/2 to 3 1/8 cents, July leading, and with September sold at a new seasonal low. Corn lost l/4 to 1 3/4 cents, the latter on September.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Reduction of traffic and population congestion in New York and other major cities was linked today to improvement and extension of rural highways by B.A. Winquest, president of the National Rural Letter Carriers Association.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 21 -- Widespread disaffection of high Czechoslovak Army officials was described in some detail today by Gen. Antonin Bohumil Hasal, who for four years until June 23, was chief of the Military Office of the President.

MUNICH, Germany, July 21 -Frau Emmy Goering was convicted this afternoon by a German denazification tribunal in Garmisch-Partenkirchen of having been a Nazi "activist." She was sentenced to one year in a labor camp, 30 per cent of her property was confiscated and she was barred for five years from participating in her professional stage career.

CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP) -- Warren Spahn pitched effective, seven-hit ball tonight as the Braves defeated Ewell Blackwell and the Reds, 6 -- 2, before a crowd of 27,153. It was the Boston left-hander's eighth victory as against seven losses.
Two major steel companies yesterday followed the United States Steel Corporation, which on Tuesday raised prices substantially to offset recent increases in costs.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall denied knowledge today of any case in which the security of the United States had been threatened by activities of a foreigner coming into the country for official duty with the United Nations.
It seems to me a tragic fallacy to say "the Russians don't want war." Why their provocative tactics, if not to make us shoot first?

The nation's gasoline stocks dropped last week an additional 2,247,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 100,701,000 barrels, compared with 102,948,000 a week earlier and $6,927,000 on July 19, 1947.

Prices of refrigerators, electric and gas ranges and some automatic washers will be increased within four weeks, an executive of a large distributing organization handling many top-name major appliances, declared yesterday. He said his suppliers cannot absorb higher costs of steel, the major component in these items.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -David O. Selznick and his producing company, Vanguard Films, Inc., were named defendants in a $2,175,000 damage suit filed today in Superior Court in Los Angeles by Trinity Films over cancellation of production on a picture called "If This Be My Harvest."

A story of the growth of Kansas City by Darrell Garwood, author of "Artist in Iowa," will be published by W. W. Norton on Sept. 15, under the title "Crossroads of America." The story is told in terms of the personalities that have made the city prominent, from Kit Carson and Fremont to the great days of The Kansas City Star and the rise and fall of the Pendergasts.

Four hundred college teachers throughout the nation and in foreign lands are seeking to raise in the next four weeks, $30,000 to save the last home of Henry David Thoreau, the famous American naturalist-poet, who died in 1862.
BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- The Government press and radio attacks on Herbert M. Clark, correspondent of The Chicago Sun-Times, with the same charges that he was an "international agent" and "plotter."

To fulfill her international responsibilities and have a voice in the critical decisions the Western Powers are obliged to take in Berlin, France must have a government. Further approaches to Moscow have to be held in suspense until the French political crisis is solved.

In an effort to avert a threatened strike at the Manhattan and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins, officials of the company and the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, conferred yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan offices of the store corporation, 521 Fifth Avenue.

Reporting on operations of the General Foods Corporation at a board meeting yesterday, Austin S. Igleheart, president, announced that net sales rose to $104,540,000 in the June quarter this year from the $85,840,000 volume transacted in the corresponding three months' period a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -The Browns pounded out twenty-one hits tonight as they defeated the Athletics, 17 to 5, before 8,797 fans and kept the Mackmen from closing in on the league-leading Indians.

JERUSALEM, July 21 -- A boundary agreement establishing the limits of the Jewish and Arab areas of Jerusalem during the truce was signet today near the spot where fighting raged only recently -- between the New Gate and the Damascus Gate of the walled Old City.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 14:

PEIPING, China, July 21 -- Government reinforcements pushing down the broken Peiping-Hankow Railway have recaptured Kaopeitien, an important communications point forty miles north of Paoting, Hopeh Provincial capital, it was officially announced tonight.

Two of the Tammany district leaders who recently opposed Mayor O'Dwyer in the selection of a Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County are on a list of eighty-four politically appointed city employes scheduled for pay rises ranging from $150 to $1,600 a year, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

Another chapter in the war between man and nature neared a climax yesterday, indicating relief for thousands of commuters and other passengers who, for the last two weeks, have been delayed five to twenty minutes on most of the more than 200 daily rush-hour trains in and out of Grand Central Terminal.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, July 21 (AP) -- The nude bodies of John E. Niebel, aged 50, superintendent of Mansfield Reformatory's Farm for twenty years, his wife, 52, and their daughter, Phyllis, 21, were found today in a cornfield, eight hours after they were kidnapped from their home.
ATLANTA, July 21 (AP) -- Wilfred Crossley's on-again, off-again putter was hot this afternoon as the defending National Public Links champion eliminated Michael Szwedko of Sharpsburg, Pa., 5 and 4.

A booth for the sale of tickets to air-show events celebrating New York City's Golden Jubilee was opened yesterday in Times Square, with the formal acceptance by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett of an F-84 Thunderjet.
The article in the July 4 issue of your paper about the extermination of 8 million rats is right as far as it goes. But it does not mention the root of the evil.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- Ghost No. 10, no ectoplasmic manifestation but a Weary Willie sort of a craft about the size of a massive minnow, began charging over the starting line just athwart the stern of the committee boat at 3:35 P.M. Forty-five minutes later she had sailed a total of sixty-five feet, or almost to the bow of the committee boat.

LONDON, July 22 -- Great Britain's adverse balance of trade narrowed only slightly in June despite a further substantial rise in exports that carried the country beyond the mid-year target set by the Government.

Terming the members of the Economic Cooperation Administration "investment brokers for recovery," Administrator Paul G. Hoffman and a staff of six left La Guardia Field for Paris yesterday. They will confer with European and American officials and coordinate their policies and procedures with those of the ECA headquarters in Washington.

By a vote of 2,461 to 455, members of one of the unions under fire in the House investigation of Communist influence in New York store unions, voted last night to endorse the refusal of their officers to tell the Congressional investigators whether they belonged to the Communist party.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 21 -The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today issued the following comment on it indictment, along with thirteen other companies in the paint, varnish and lacquer field, on a charge of conspiracy to fix prices of paints and wood finishes:

BERLIN, July 21 -- Russian authorities told this correspondent today to "go to the Allied Control Council" to get a permit to drive a car from Berlin to the Western zones. That council has not functioned since larch 20.

An educator proposed yesterday that every child be enrolled in a public school the day he is born and that the institution "really serve him," instead of having later deficiencies rectified by reformatories.

Net sales of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last January rose to $142,296,939 from $141,950,574 a year earlier, according to the annual report of Robert J. McKim, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company of Detroit, a major supplier of automotive parts, is reportedly negotiating with a large steel company to purchase part of the latter's property in the Pittsburgh area to shift some of its manufacturing operations close to the vicinity of its steel purchases.

An all-day meeting between negotiating committees of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, ended last evening with the company reportedly offering to match the five-cent an hour granted the union by other competing shipyards.

Retailers are preparing for the reorder phase of fall season purchasing which will be crystallized by the movement of women's apparel in forthcoming August promotions, it was pointed out yesterday by New York resident offices.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 21 -Miss Jean Davis of Cortland, a slim young 23-year-old physical education teacher, sprang the first upset of the nineteenth annual women's New York State golf championship today. She defeated Miss Hilda Swanson of the Drumlins Country Club, 1 up, over the Onondaga Golf and Country Club course to reach the quarter-final round.
PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) -Wage increases in the steel industry spread across the country today in the wake of advances started by United States Steel Corporation.

The Liberal party, which came into being in 1944 because of the assumption by left-wing elements of control of the American Labor party to which Liberal party members had previously adhered, began last night the task of tracing its steps back toward the Truman standard for the 1948 campaign.

Long Island's golfers scored a smashing victory in the triangular matches against Westchester and New Jersey over the Pomonok Country Club course, Flushing, yesterday and won the Stoddard Trophy for the first time since 1939 in the annual series that goes back to 1922.

Boxing will return to Madison Square Garden tonight after a lapse of almost two months when Kid Gavilan, contender for welterweight honors from Camaguey, Cuba, opposes Roman Alvarez of Brooklyn in the feature match booked for ten rounds.

The announcement by the United States Steel Corporation that its operating subsidiaries are raising the price of that basic commodity contains little that is new except the amount of the increase, $9.34 a ton. The decision to mark up prices, as President Benjamin F. Fairless points out, had been made inevitable some time earlier by mounting costs of production resulting from developments outside the company's control.

Several foreign nations among the sixteen recipient countries under the European Recovery Program have already violated regulations calling for a fifty-fifty division of cargo among foreign and American-flag ships, it became known yesterday.
For the first time since the end of World War II summer session attendance at New York's four municipal colleges failed this year to attain a new high, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Politicians and the two-horned African rhinoceros share the distinction of having the thickest skins worn by mundane creatures. Therefore, while practitioners of other trades might find embarrassing the occasion set for noon next Tuesday in the hall of the House of Representatives, it is not probable that the President or many of his hearers will experience this emotion.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -As salty as brine itself, some thousand junior sailors, including skippers, navigators and crews, set canvas today in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club race week.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An alliance between an extremely nationalistic Germany and Soviet Russia is an outstanding danger, according to a report to the United States Labor Department's Trade Union Advisory Committee on International Affairs by a labor mission that has just returned from Germany.
The Shell Union Oil Corporation, in its report for the first six months of this year, released today, announced a consolidated net income of $55,861,000 after taxes and all charges.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Charles F. Brannan Secretary of Agriculture, today answered a baking industry demand for government backing of an eat-more-bread campaign with a suggestion that cutting the price of bread might accomplish the desired result.

Another version of deceptive use of the research survey approach in door-to-door selling, reported to have given its victim a heart attack, was revealed in a complaint received yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau. The complainant reported that two men with a vacuum cleaner had "barged" into her home, announcing they had been sent by the Health Department to make a "survey" of home cleanliness.

"Deep Waters," originally scheduled to open at the Globe Theatre on Saturday, will have its local premiere there this morning. The Twentieth Century-Fox drama, starring Dana Andrews and Jean Peters, is an adaptation of the novel, "Spoonhandle," by Ruth Moore, and was directed by Henry King.

PARIS, July 21 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, is due in Paris tomorrow for a six-day survey of the European Recovery Program as it has taken shape in the organization for European Economic Cooperation and the corresponding United States missions to participating countries.

LONDON, July 21 -- The next note from the three Western Allies to Moscow on Berlin will agree to an extension of the four-power talks to include all of Germany, provided the Western Allies' rights to remain in Berlin are fully recognized and also provided that such talks are not held under the pressure of the Russian blockade of the former capital.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Sixty-five members and former members of the armed forces of the United States received British decorations today in recognition of their services during World War II.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The sudden eclipse of Dr. Heinrich Rau, President of the German Economic Commission in the Soviet zone, has started wide reports of an extensive purge in the Communist hierarchy governing the eastern zone.

RICHMOND, Va., July 21 (AP) -- William C. Chance, described as principal of the Parmele, N. C., High School for Negroes, filed in Federal District Court today a damage suit for $25,000 against the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company and A. S. Lambeth, one of its conductors, for alleged racial discrimination.

PARIS, July 2 -- The famous Parisian dressmaking establishment of Lucien Lelong is expected to close its doors at the end of the month following an announcement today that M. Lelong was resigning as director. The reason officially given was M. Lelong's ill health, which will prevent him from taking an active part in the Parisian haute couture for an indefinite period.

Justice James B.M. McNally dismissed yesterday a taxpayer's suit brought in the Supreme Court by Mrs. Bertha Melzer, of 2949 Brighton Third Street, Brooklyn, to compel the City Council to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Communist, who died on Nov. 6, 1947.

The extent to which the fires of nationalism continue to smolder under the red blanket cast over Eastern Europe by Russia is demonstrated anew by the remarkable spectacle in Belgrade which passes as the Fifth Congress of the Yugoslav Communist party.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Papa Redbird, at odds of 23 1/2 to 1, jolted 20,163 racing fans with the second of two shocks at Arlington Park today.

SEATTLE, July 21 (AP) -- A "contempt of Legislature" citation was ordered today against Herbert J. Phillips, a member of the University of Washington philosophy department who has been on the Columbia University summer faculty.
Last conducted in 1941, the national polo championship tournament is being revived this year, it was announced yesterday by the United States Polo Association.

With Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., following the example of United Air Lines in asking the Civil Aeronautics Board for approval of a 10 per cent increase in passenger fares, only American Airlines' attitude on increased fares among the big transcontinentals now remains doubtful.

Warehouse distributors of steel were busy yesterday trying to figure new and higher prices, which they expect to announce shortly. Indications are, it was said, that the new quotations of the United States Steel Supply Company, Newark subsidiary of United States Steel, would be ready within a day or two.

The new golden-yellow chemical named aureomycin, extracted from a soil mold, has been used successfully by physicians at Columbia University, Harlem Hospital, the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and other leading institutions to treat serious infections in human beings that do not respond to either penicillin or streptomycin.

Mary B. Powers, 72-year-old spinster, died of natural causes Tuesday evening in the five-room, $30-a-day suite at the Seymour Hotel, 50 West Forty-fifth Street, in which she had lived as a recluse for the last twenty-six years.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 21 -- Governor Dewey, Republican candidate for President, told reporters today following a three-hour conference with former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota that he was keeping in close touch with developments in the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad borrowed $4,050,000 yesterday on an issue of equipment trust certificates maturing serially from 1949 to 1963 at an interest cost of about 2.75 per cent. The certificates were sold at competitive bidding to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The full-rigged sailing ship Christian Radich, Norway's training vessel, is due here Saturday, the Royal Norwegian Information Services announced yesterday. The 192-foot craft is commanded by Capt. Sigurd A. Braekhus and carries a crew of ninety-nine boys whom the captain hopes to transform into killed sailors.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Gov. Dwight H. Green today reported that private enterprise would build 1,800 apartments on Chicago's south side with the state and city sharing the cost of clearing away slums to make ten square blocks available.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Marquette Cement Manufacturing Company notified its customers today it will continue the same pricing policy it has used in the past despite the action of some competitors in changing their pricing methods as a result of the recent Supreme Court cement basing point decision.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 21 -- Lieut. Col. Sanford Webster and Capt. Charles Daniel, Third Army, today won the doubles title in the United States Army tennis championships. They defeated Capt. Robert Scruton and Lieut. Bernard Petrie, Far Eastern Command, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

The National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, resumed yesterday morning before Trial Examiner Wallace E. Royster, at the board's regional headquarters, 2 Park Avenue, after a one-week adjournment.
Eight of the twelve Communists indicted by a Federal grand jury here on Tuesday, charged under the Smith Act with conspiring to overthrow the United States Government, were free under bond yesterday.

A charge of disorderly conduct against Stephen Toth, landlord of a building at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, for allegedly trying three times to evict a tenant in defiance of a decision of the Office of Rent Control and a Municipal Court ruling, was withdrawn in Bronx Magistrate's Court before Magistrate William E. Ringel yesterday after Mr. Toth promised to stop annoying the tenant.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 21 -- The Provisional Government of Israel not only will not agree to any temporary or permanent limitation on immigration but is prepared to accept "millions" of new citizens from among the Zionists of the world.

PARIS, July 21 -- Gen. Joseph Edouard Doumenc was reported to have been killed in an Alpine accident, according to advices to the gendarmerie in Briancon this afternoon. He had gone on an excursion on Blanc Glacier, and it was stated that he fell into a 40-yard-deep crevasse.

The threat voiced consistently in recent weeks by leaders of the American Labor party to decline to endorse Tammany's candidate for Surrogate and enter a strong contender of its own was made good last night.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States and Britain have not decided on what to do next in the Berlin situation, but they have decided on what not to do including:

ROME, July 21 -- Vittorio Valletta, president of the Fiat Automobile Company, today urged Italian industrialists to cooperate to insure the success of the Marshall Plan by using American aid only for "truly sound reconstruction projects."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- Several of the small foreign relief agencies in the United States may face a shut-down or drastic curtailment of their work as a result of the poor public response in this country to the joint campaign of the American Overseas Aid and the United Nations Appeal for Children (AOA-UNAC).

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Mrs. Arthur K. Atkinson Jr. of the Creek Club turned in a card of 40, 41 -- 81 to win low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Maidstone Club course today.

The much-sought-after Gertrude Lawrence, wanted for at least five projects this season, may give in to the blandishments of the Theatre Guild, according to informed sources. On Tuesday, Lawrence Langner and Theresa Helburn, co-administrators of the Guild, drove up to Dennis, Mass., where the actress is starring in "O Mistress Mine," to confer with her about appearing for them in the John van Druten dramatization of an E.F. Benson story.

RYE, N.Y., July 21 -- Mrs. John Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club gained the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy, emblematic of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Counties golf championship, by stroking a 41, 39 -- 80 over the Westchester Country Club course today for a three-round total of 244.

The other day a man stood at the corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street and, as a sudden shower broke, put up the umbrella he was carrying. Immediately a huge rent appeared in it. "Who invented these contraptions, anyway?" was his question, in expurgated form, as he sourly watched the rain pouring through the hole in the alpaca.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Democratic strategy for the coming session of Congress is to be mapped in a series of White House confernces in which leaders of the party, in and out of Congress, will discuss the issues with President Truman.

NANKING, July 21 -- As a result of the increasingly serious food shortage the Chinese Government is being forced to add an extra burden to the weighted-down shoulders of the very man whose support it is trying to win -- "Lao Pai-hsing," "Old Hundred Names," the Chinese peasant.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge said today that he was willing to permit South Koreans to negotiate with their countrymen in Russian-occupied North Korea for settlement of the long-standing electric power dispute.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 21 (UP) -- Guided only by a sextant and a wrist watch, twenty-nine fugitives from behind the Soviet Iron Curtain arrived here today in quest of a homeland after a forty-three-day crossing of the Atlantic Ocean in a 64-foot ketch.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 21 -- Librarians are close on the heels of painters here, as construction workers and book-movers hurry to complete and equip Princeton University's new $6,000,000 Harvey S. Firestone Library for opening at the start of the fall term in September.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Walter Masterson was slammed for twelve hits by Detroit today, but he scattered them sufficiently to notch is seventh victory as Washington defeated the Tigers, 6 -- 1.

Operations of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries in the second quarter of this year resulted in a consolidated net income of $24,041,851, equal to 83 cents a share on the 28,807,314 shares of capital stock outstanding, according to the report issued fort publication today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Federal District Court here refused today to review privately information regarding the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation which the Securities and Exchange Commission has been trying to obtain from two Cleveland lawyers.

A plan for the leasing of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad by the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad has been approved by directors of both carriers and probably will be submitted to special meetings of stockholders of the two roads early in October, John W. Davin, president of the Nickel Pate, and chairman of the Wheeling Lake Erie, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- There may be persons who doubt that the Dodgers seriously are driving toward another pennant, but they weren't among the 42,403 fans who jammed Wrigley Field today.

Delivery prices of products of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in this city were announced yesterday by James D. Mooney, the president, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The automotive units will be displayed there for three days beginning today.

PARIS, July 21 -- Andre Marie a member of the Radical party and Minister of Justice in two preceding Cabinets, was selected by President Vincent Auriol today to form a new French Cabinet. He was working for a Ministry that would include the greatest number of parties, except the Communists.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 21 (AP) -- Lester Manor Stable's Compliance, an invader from New York, surprised today when she was an easy winner of the third running of the Monmouth Oaks.
The John R. Thompson Company declared a dividend of 10 cents payable on Aug. 16. The company paid 15 cents in each of the three preceding quarters.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Three Russian military observers have appeared at Seattle to attend the North Pacific Regional Air Navigation meeting, arranged by the International Civil Aviation Organization, the American Aviation Daily reported here today.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 1 to 3 points lower than Tuesday's closing levels.

The Yankees, rising heroically to the exhortations of 67,133 onlookers, largest midweek crowd of the season, took a long stride forward at the Stadium yesterday as they whacked the front-running Indians in the opener of the afternoon's doubleheader.
As rain that started shortly after 9 o'clock last night in the city continued early today, reports of floods began to come in.
Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asked American Jews yesterday not to support any new groups soliciting funds for Israel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Public ownership of a large segment of American industry and finance was recommended today in a tentative draft of the New party platform on which former Vice President Henry A. Wallace will seek the Presidency.

Compilation of a nation-wide statistical survey which will serve as a merchandising guide to office machine dealers is being undertaken by the National Office Machine Dealers Association, it was made known yesterday by Earl DeGroot, Kalamazoo, Mich., who was elected president of the organization at its convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The stock market yesterday made a moderately successful bid to regain more of the ground surrendered in Monday's plunge, although opposition developed late in the afternoon and top prices were shaded. Only a few issues gained more than a point and the composite price rose 0.62 point.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Henry A. Wallace, Third Party Presidential candidate, today assailed the New York indictments of top Communist leaders as an unconstitutional attempt by the Truman Administration and "bipartisans" to create fear in order to stay in power.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 21 -- Jack Tuero, 22-year-old New Orleans ace, who is seeded fourth in the tournament, led the way into the semi-final round of the Eastern clay courts tennis championship at Travers Island today. He turned back Jack Geller of New Rochelle, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

Tomato picking is going on full force on near-by farms. Such an abundance of the "vegetable" (botanically it's a fruit) is arriving here, says the United States Department of Agriculture, that wholesale prices are exceedingly low.

The form charts were upheld yesterday in the women's Eastern clay courts championships at the New York Tennis Club as all four seeded players advanced into the semi-final round of the singles competition.

BODEN, Sweden, July 20 (Delayed) -- Up here near the Arctic Circle in the hub of Sweden's Boden Line protecting the country's northeastern flank against invasion from the East, the principal worry is not the Russians but the local Communists.

LONDON, July 21 -- In the absence of fresh news hearing on the international situation the rebound on Wall Street yesterday cheered the stock market here today. Although brokers said it was their quietest day for weeks, there was improvement in practically all sections.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- Addressing the opening session of the fifth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia, Marshal Tito today charged the Communist Information Bureau with seeking to provoke a civil war in Yugoslavia.
BERLIN, July 21 -- The Russians announced tonight through a German Communist that from Aug. 1 enough food would be available in the Soviet sector to feed the entire city.
Friction between Government Intelligence agencies is in a major degree responsible for the current study, headed by Allen W. Dulles, of the Government's intelligence organizations.
The United States Lines has offered to put up $25,000,000 toward the construction of a new superliner for American-flag service, it was disclosed last night.

Residents of Tudor City, residential development overlooking the East River at the end of East Forty-second Street, have been asked to sign petitions protesting a part of the city plan for the approaches to the proposed headquarters of the United Nations, it became known yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer appointed yesterday, with the unanimous consent of the Board of Estimate, a special committee to discuss with representatives of the Third Avenue Transit System the financial aspects of the eight-cent fare applications of its three constituent companies operating street cars and buses in Manhattan and the Bronx.

A gloomy landmark, the fortress-like old Tombs prison and the adjoining Criminal Courts Building -- standing empty on lower Manhattan's Centre Street since 1941 -- will be razed in six weeks, demolition engineers estimated yesterday.

Net income of the St. Regis Paper Company for the period from Jan. 1 to July 3 amounted to $8,744,935, compared with $7,696,147 in the first half of 1947, it was reported yesterday. Net sales in the respective periods amounted to $83,907,818 and $69,033,514.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Gen. John J. Pershing established a trust fund of not less than $150,000 for his sister, Miss Anna May Pershing, his will disclosed today.

RHODES, July 21 -- Assigning fifty-five United Nations observers for the new Palestine truce to their posts today, Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator, told them that they had to assure that the truce benefited neither Israel nor the Arabs.

The American Vegetarian party, which hopes to attract 5,000,000 votes in the coming election, announced yesterday a twelve-point platform written by Dr. John Maxwell, its Presidential Candidate. The 85-year-old Chicago naturopath will make his opening bid for the Presidency in a broadcast from Chicago in September.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21 (AP) -Earnings of Willys-Overland Motors increased 124 per cent during the nine-month period ended on June 30, president James D. Mooney reported to stockholders today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 21 -After three days of a rather noisy and complicated truce, both sides today quieted down and licked their wounds.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21 -- Six rooms in a modern pavilion which Bamberger's is featuring in its newly decorated furniture floor have been planned around paintings and drawings by such masters as Renoir and Van Gogh, lent from the collection of Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting.

All New York retail stores with home furnishings operations and manufacturers in every branch of the industry including radio will cooperate in Home Fashions Time from Oct. 4 to 9, Madelyn Smith, in charge of the promotional project for the Home Fashions League, disclosed yesterday.

To one American listening at 2 o'clock the other morning to the acceptance speech of President Truman, the impression received was that of hard-hitting words of honesty and sense spoken at last, after a great deal of mere old-fashioned oratory in both conventions, and, in the Republican convention many snide insinuations.

An old holding in Greenwich Village which has historic associations dating back to Revolutionary days changed hands yesterday with the sale of the three-story plant at 287-303 West Tenth Street to a client of Arthur Richtenthal and of Delson, Levin Gordon. The seller was Arthur E. Laskin.

Noble Impulse, a record-cracker in Maryland, didn't have to exert himself very much to win the forty-sixth running of the Albany Handicap at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. He took the lead soon after the start of the six-furlong dash and went easily along in first place for the rest of the way, making good by about three lengths.

The four-story apartment building at 37-76 Sixty-second Street, northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Avenue, Woodside, Queens, accommodating thirty-nine families, has been purchased by an investing group represented by the Harris Block Company which took title in the name of the Milwad Realty Corporation. Samuel and Rachel Feinsmith of Los Angeles, Calif., were the sellers.

LONDON, July 21 -- The main body of the American Olympic team, numbering 260 athletes, arrived today and quietly took up quarters at Uxbridge and other centers after traveling in buses from Southampton, where the group had debarked from the flagship America of the United States Lines early this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, saw no prospect today that anyone would be inducted into the armed forces under the new Draft Act before Oct. 1. He described this as "a conservative date," by which it was ascertained that he meant first inductions might even be later.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Because the inner defense went suddenly haywire in a bewildering seventh inning, the Giants muffed an inviting chance to move into third place tonight in Leo Durocher's debut as their leader at Sportsman's Park, before 19,354 onlookers.

The Civil Rights Congress, which furnished bail for seven of the Communist leaders arrested by Federal authorities, moved yesterday to plan a new program for the defense of "al labor, liberal and radical and new party organizations."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman will personally appear before Congress at 12:30 P. M. next Tuesday to demand prompt action on the many issues he named in his defiant speech at the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United Air Lines and Trans World Air Line joined today in testimony opposing the application of Pan American Airways for permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board to set up express domestic air service connecting the major air terminals from which it operates foreign services.

TOKYO, July 21 -- For the first time since March 2, 1946, individuals' bank accounts in Japan have returned to some semblance of normal. The Cabinet announced today that it was unfreezing first and second blocked accounts which were segregated in connection with conversion of the old yen into stamped "new yen."

The first Negro member of the Board of Education in thirty years was appointed yesterday when Mayor O'Dwyer named the Rev. John M. Coleman, rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, to serve a full seven-year term.
Issues of new public utility bonds totaling $25,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates, as follows:
Stamford, Conn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids July 28 on an issue of $2,016,000 school bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948, and due on each Aug. 1 from 1949 to 1968.
ROCHESTER, July 21 -- The gradual disappearance from the American scene of civic groups composed exclusively of women was foreseen here today.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced plans yesterday to increase by about 12 per cent the rents paid by more than 12,000 tenant families in Parkchester, its large apartment colony in the Bronx.

Francis Smith has purchased the five-story apartment house at 2355 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, from the Evanchild Realty Corporation, of which Helen Fitzgerald is president. The building contains ninety-eight rooms in suites of three to five rooms.
THE world is so full of so many anthoZogis --More than enough to ch. oke se'en fat colleges-. I think we should all be as happy a'cings If publishers stol?ped putting out the darned things.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An additional loan of $10,000,000 has been granted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Lustron Corporation, maker of prefabricated houses, it was disclosed today.
Elmer C. Gates has been appointed editor of the Bronx Real Estate and Building News, official magazine of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.

America has failed miserably to answer the cry of the sick and hungry children of the world. Ever since the United Nations fed the first child in Warsaw in November, 1947, the world has known that over 200,000,000 children are living on hunger rations, broken by diseases and lack of physical and mental care; that 30,000,000 of those children are in direst possible need of everything.

A letter from Lee Wulff indicates that the salmon fishing in Newfoundland is now approaching "perfection," with dry fly fishing at its peak and conditions on the rivers just right. Lee's young son, Allan, took and released thirteen grilse between 3 and 7:30 P. M. on Saturday, all taken on a dry fly. During the same period, Lee took and released four salmon and three grilse.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared today that the United States would use every resource of diplomatic negotiation and procedure for "an acceptable solution" of the Berlin crisis without war but that this country would not be coerced.
LONDON, July 21 -- Two more incidents were added to the long and resplendent tradition of the British Parliament today.

ODIHAM, England, July 21 -Sixteen sleek jet fighter planes of the United States Air Force landed here today to complete the first West-to-East jet plane crossing of the Atlantic. The planes covered the 4,288 miles from their base at Mount Clements, Mich., in 10 hours 40 minutes flying time.

One of the tricks that fashion plays on editors and models is to oblige the former to review and the latter to wear fur coats on the summer's hottest days. Yesterday, it was Arnold Constable's turn to exhibit its collection in the fur department.

The American Federation of Labor is rushing 1,000 CARE food packages to German trade union officials and their families in Russian-blockaded Berlin, Matthew Woll, member of the AFL's executive council, announced yesterday.

Lithopolis, Ohio, a village with a population of 358, will receive $2,565,788 from the estate of Mrs. Mabel Wagnall's Jones, composer and writer, who died March 22, 1946, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Under her will she had named as residuary legatee the Wagnalls Memorial there.

The directors of the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company at a meeting held yesterday in San Francisco decided to complete the construction of the trans-Arabian pipe line as rapidly as possible, according to an announcement made here.

A survey of about 8,000 Manhattan restaurants and bars serving distilled spirits just completed by the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers, Inc., shows a drop in bar sales of 40 per cent since June 1, compared with the corresponding period in 1947, Arthur Gillette, president, disclosed yesterday.

Deposits in the mutual savings banks of New York State increased 2.3 per cent in the first six months of 1948, but withdrawals increased at a more rapid rate than deposits, according to a report made yesterday by John Adikes, president of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.
The love scenes in 130 of the city's biggest movie theatre's will become a lot hotter if the engineers who run the theatre air-conditioning systems carry out a threat to strike tomorrow.

The Soviet press has been devoting much space these days to progress achieved in heavy industry, as well as to progress in increased production and cost reduction. But at the same time Russian newspapers have complained of poor quality and the wasteful consumption of raw materials by Soviet industry.

LONDON, July 21 -- A complicated three - way disagreement among the representatives of the four major powers who have investigated the aspirations of the people in Italy's former African colonies was disclosed today when their reports on Eritrea and Italian Somaliland became available for inspection.
DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The 2,000,000th passenger car of 1948 rolled from the auto industry's assembly lines today.

"America's Town Meeting" will join the list of regular television attractions later this summer, arrangements having been completed yesterday by the ABC network for the simultaneous presentation of radio and video versions of the discussion program.

A 48-year-old assistant vice president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, was sentenced yesterday to six months imprisonment as two fellow officials received suspended sentences. The bank was fined $2,500.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Members of the advisory council of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reached the midway point today in their week-long first annual meeting of the forty-six-nation bank.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 21 -The public's attitude toward mental illness, marked by misunderstanding, superstitution and fear, is a major stumbling block to vigorous mental health progress in this nation, it was charged tonight by Dr. Robert Felix, chief of the Mental Health Division of the United States Public Health Service.

The failure of Congress to extend the power of the Federal Housing Administration to insure loans for apartment construction under Title 608 may necessitate changes in the plans for Bell Park Gardens, 800-apartment veterans' mutual housing project in Queens, it became known yesterday.

Your editorial of July 9 on "Strangers in the City" has doubly heartened a stranger like myself. How right you are when you remark: "A great city can be the loneliest place in the world." It warms up one's heart to learn that more than forty educational organizations are helping to form the Greater New York Council for Foreign Students, and to know that the noble idea has received support from a newspaper like yours.
PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) -Johnny Blatnik's triple and Eddie Miller's single in the top half of the tenth gave the Phillies the run they needed today to whip the Pirates, 3 -- 2.

The vanguard of America's new army -- the nation's 18-year-olds -queued up by the thousands at recruiting stations across the country yesterday to enlist for the new short-term, one-year hitch.
