By so doing, at least 161,000 of them for whom the armed forces put out the welcome mat will avoid a twenty-one-month draft period later.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Attorney General Clark said today five leading manufacturers of cast iron pressure pipe have agreed to a court judgment which he said will end "illegal practices and restore competitive conditions in the industry."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 21 -- By an appeal to "hams" of the United Nations Amateur Radio Club, the world organization has recruited fifteen radio operators, repairmen and technicians who will set up a communications network that will be used in supervising the truce in Palestine.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -- Col. James P. Devereux, hero of Wake Island and four-year prisoner of the Japanese, will retire on Aug. 1, the Marine Corps said tonight.

LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- Wing Commander Donald Finlay, Great Britain's 40-year-old hurdler who will be competing in his third Olympic Games, will take the Olympic Oath on behalf of 4,000 competitors at the opening of the games at Wembley Stadium a week from tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -The Department of Justice asked today a Federal Court in Boston to dissolve the Boston Fruit and Produce Exchange on the ground that it has been used to control egg prices in New England.

ROME, July 22 -- The Italian Senate defeated tonight the motion of no confidence in the Government presented by the Communists immediately after the shooting of their leader, Palmiro Togliatti, July 14.

The acquisition of a substantial amount of Government securities helped further to improve the earning assets of the reporting New York member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended on Wednesday. The weekly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed an increase of $168,000,000 in total loans and investments, although loans both net and gross only accounted for $30,000,000.
MEXICO CITY, July 22 (AP) -- Mexico decided today to cheapen the peso. She has lost a long fight to keep it at 4.85 to the United States dollar, at which it has been pegged since 1940.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Selective Service Act of 1948 specifically exempts from induction into the armed services most veterans of World War II.

The Scandinavian Airlines System (SAS) became the third scheduled airline to begin operations at New York International Airport at Idlewild yesterday when one of its forty-passenger transatlantic airliners departed at 3:20 P.M., starting service from the 4,900-acre airport to Stockholm, Copenhagen and Oslo.

NEW DELHI, July 22 -- The United Nations Commission on India and Pakistan will send a two-man "advance party" to Kashmir to make a preliminary survey of the military situation there if India approves.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- In a survey of conditions within the Western occupation zones in Germany, a United Nations team reported today that the German people were suffering more from low morale and psychological breakdown than from lack of food or physical distress.

John Simonetti, Jamaica restaurateur and horse owner, has purchased a seven-room dwelling on a plot 140 by 200 feet on the south side of West Washington Street, 392 feet east of West Hills Road, in Huntington, L. I., from Hilda K. Saladino.
BERLIN, July 22 -- Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky and Herlin Rakovsky Schdarnov are directing the Soviet Union's military and political forces respectively in the battle of Berlin.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Minimum air freight rates were established by the Civil Aeronautics Board today on certain commodities which normally move from three states to the East and North.
The Ward Baking Company yesterday announced an increase in the quarterly dividend on the common stock, in addition to earnings higher than in the 1947 period.

The stock market extended its recovery yesterday, but in trading volume so small as to make the advance of questionable importance. Some gains of 1 to 2 points were made in scattered sections, but the main body of stocks only advanced fractions, with the composite rate rising 0.91 point on the day.

The boos and jeers of 300 employes of the Department of Sanitation rang in Mayor O'Dwyer's ears late yesterday afternoon as he left City Hall. The jeerers were members of Local 333 of the Sanitation Workers Union, a unit of the United Public Workers, CIO, which for the last three weeks has maintained a picket line at City Hall Park to protest the department's labor policy.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senate investigators were told today by Robert C. Alexander, assistant chief of the State Department's visa division, that some way must be found, in the interest of American security, to hold international organizations responsible for the activities of their representatives in this country.

The proposal to connect Brooklyn with Staten Island by bridging the Narrows has again been presented for public consideration, under the formidable auspices of Commissioner Moses. If the bridge, as is quite likely, should be disapproved by the War Department, it seems certain that the Triborough Authority will press for a tunnel instead.
What happens to the waistlines of City College students after they are graduated is a matter of concern to officials of the school's Department of Hygiene.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board warned today of the dangers inherent in the rapid increase of mortgage debt as it disclosed that during the last two and a half years $25,000,000,000 of home mortgage loans had been made, increasing the amount of such debt outstanding to a record level of almost $33,000,000,000 in June.

PAWLING, N. Y., July 22 -- At Governor Dewey's invitation, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and John Foster Dulles, Mr. Dewey's foreign policy adviser, are coming to Pawling Saturday evening to discuss the Berlin crisis with the Governor.
John Jacob Astor has rejected the bid of $71,000 made by James O'Donnell, chain drugstore owner of Middletown, R.I., for Chetwode, the Astor estate on Bellevue Avenue in Newport.

Consolidated net income of the Hayes Manufacturing Corporation for the nine months ended on June 130, last, rose to a new high level of $2,588,341, an increase of 66 per cent over the previous peak earnings of $1,553,034 shown for the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal year, Rensselaer W. Clark, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, visited President Truman today but the twenty-minute interview failed to clarify the CIO's role in the coming Presidential campaign. Mr. Murray said afterward that his organization had made no decision about supporting a candidate.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 22 -- Three metropolitan district players and one from upstate reached the semi-final round of the nineteenth New York State women's championship over the Onondaga Golf and Country Club course today.

Kid Gavilan did what was expected of him at Madison Square Garden last night. The Cuban welterweight won the decision by unanimous vote over Roman Alvarez of Brooklyn after a ten-round, bout that pleased a gathering of 5,921 fans.

Orchestra concerts at the World's Fair of Music at the Grand Central Palace were canceled yesterday, on the fourth day of the seven-day musical exposition, when the management found itself out of harmony with the sixty musicians on a question of wages.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 22 -- About 500 Czechoslovak war veterans of the British armed forces have returned to military service in England after having fled their country, it was reported here today by Pavel Tigrid, an official of the Czechoslovak Relief Committee for Political Refugees.

The Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday that net income for the first half of 1948 was $14,287,902, equal to $1.04 a common share, compared with $16,514,049, or $1.20 a share in the comparable 1947 period.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became slightly more active in the late trading yesterday and closed at about the best levels of the day, 17 to 22 points above Wednesday's close.
Thirty-one veterans of wartime flying, now more happily occupied around Boston selling wool, building homes and the like, took to the air yesterday on a mission over a city strange to many of them.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22 -- Col. Gen. Alexander Rankovitch, Minister of the Interior and a member of the Politburo, announced in today's session of the fifth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia that 89.9 per cent of the Army officers and 70 per cent of the noncommissioned officers were party members.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 22 (AP) -- Jockeys Sterling Young and Fred Pannell received what were believed to be minor injuries in two different races here today. Both were taken to Riverside Hospital, Red Bank, N. J., for more thorough examinations.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Highway facilities tapping Idlewild Airport in New York were cited today as a model for air terminals throughout the country by Jennings Randolph, president of the airport division of the American Road Builders Association.

Henry Wallace, third party aspirant for President, praised last night the action of business men within the party who earlier in the day had recommended the nationalization of many basic industries, but indicated that their views were somewhat in advance of his own.

The 100,000th visitor to "Mr. Blandings' Dream House" was checked through the display at Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street yesterday. She was Mrs. William H. Hamilton of Laurel Road, New Canaan, Conn.

LONDON, July 22 -- Whitney Straight, American-born managing director of the British Overseas Airways Corporation, said today that BOAC was "going flat out to tap the American traffic, which is so important from the dollar point of view."

Salary rises ranging from $150 to $1,600 a year were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate for eighty-four city officials in the exempt class, including two Tammany district leaders who opposed Mayor O'Dwyer's efforts to obtain for Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri the Democratic nomination for Surrogate of New York County.

PARIS, Friday, July 23 -- Andre Marie, new French Premier-designate, after a day of patient consultations, announced at 2:15 A. M. today that he would form a new Cabinet, and that before that he would submit his program for a confidence vote of the National Assembly tomorrow.

The European Recovery Program, as Administrator Paul G. Hoffman must have been reminded afresh yesterday when he arrived in Paris on his first survey trip, is not a simple matter of the United States putting up the money and sixteen European countries saying thank you in unison. Mr. Hoffman has the responsibility of seeing to it that the money gets results.

The television committee of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all actor unions, disclosed yesterday that it had launched an inquiry into the fees paid to actors appearing in "The Toast of the Town," the Ed Sullivan variety show carried by the CBS video network on Sunday nights.

The famous Childs Restaurant in Times Square, at 1485 Seventh Avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, which during the last forty-four years has catered to 35,000,000 persons, will cease to exist some time before Oct. 31.

A parcel of eighty lots in the Surrey Estates section of Queens has been purchased by Sabella-Demont, Inc., for improvement with forty bungalow and two-story dwellings. Henry J. Cozzi and Stephen Parisi were the sellers. H. A. Goldsborough was the broker and the Home Title Guaranty Company insured the title.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 22 -- Calories represent the most neglected aspect of nutrition, and research indicates that overweight is the most important nutrition problem of the adult, Leonard A. Maynard, director of the School of Nutrition, Cornell University, said at today's session of the New York State Health Officers and Public Health Nurses.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 22 -- United Nations observers, complete with secretariat, arrived in Palestine today to observe a "doubtful" truce. Their job is quite simple, but the accompanying dangers are great.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- The roster of delegates to the founding convention of the New party, although incomplete twenty-four hours before the opening session, contains so few names that are nationally known in the political field that it bears almost no resemblance to similar lists at conventions of the major political parties.

READING, Pa., July 22 (AP) -- Four par-busting pro golfers equaled a course record of 65 made only once in the twenty-six-year history of the Berkshire Country Club today to head a field of 146 professionals and amateurs in the first-round of the $15,000 Reading Open.

The first and second-seeded players fell by the wayside yesterday in the semi-final round of the Women's Eastern clay court singles championships at the New York Tennis Club. The two, Miss Nina Irwin and Miss Helen Germaine, both of New York, were the easy victims of Mrs. Elfi Carroll and Mrs. Norma Barber, respectively.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- John L. Lewis refused to modify the union shop clause as suggested by the "captive" mine operators because he felt that any change from the union provision of the commercial operators' contract would be taken by the union and the public as an abandonment of the union shop.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- Senator Glen H. Taylor, prospective Vice-Presidential nominee of the new party, asserted today that he expected the support of "pink" Communists but not the support of the "red" variety.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- A national youth convention to form a permanent national youth organization in support of the program and policies of Henry A. Wallace and Senator Glen H. Taylor will be held here next Sunday and Monday, following the national convention of the new party.

Expected shortages of heavy home appliances by fall will bring a "proportionate" decrease in retail advertising of these articles, but this should be offset by greater promotion of non-scarce products, it was stated yesterday by advertising officials in this field.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday plans for three more low-rent housing projects in its $200,000,000 program. They will provide 5,550 apartments at average monthly rentals of $16 a month a room for families earning a maximum of $3,984 a year.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 22 (AP) -- K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said at a news conference today prices of cars would increase as a result of increased steel prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- Israeli Government circles are discussing a possible exchange of minorities between Israel and the Arab area of Palestine, Arthur Lowrie, head of the Israeli United Nations office, disclosed today.

Stocks in New York City department stores June 30 showed an increase of 8 per cent over the corresponding day last year, it was disclosed by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. Apparel stores, chiefly in New York City, showed an increase of 2 per cent.

"This Is Israel," by I.F. Stone, has been scheduled for September publication by Boni Gaer. It is an account of his visit to Palestine, from his arrival one week before the declaration of statehood until the armistice. Mr. Stone is Washington columnist of The New York Star (formerly PM) and is the author also of "The Court Disposes" and "Business as Usual."
The Yankees may be riding fourth all by themselves the morning in the seething American League flag race, but they are, nevertheless, a little closer to the top than they were early yesterday.

By an even more overwhelming margin than was recorded Wednesday, members of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, CIO, voted last night to endorse the refusal of their leaders to tell a House Committee whether they were Communists.

Twenty-five girls risked sunstroke and strangulation yesterday in a rope-jumping contest of the Children's Aid Society. Although some individual scores of girls from other centers were higher, the Lower West Side team received a medallion for fifteen points of skilled skipping in its own playground at 219 Sullivan Street.
BERLIN, July 22 -- Marshal Sokolovsky said tonight that the Soviet Union was blockading Berlin because the United States made Russians get special permits to visit the United States zone.

LONDON, July 22 -- Hopes of an easing in the international tension following Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's report on the Hague Conference and the moderate views expressed on contents of the next three-power note to Moscow caused the stock market here today to finish with a strength lacking for weeks.

LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- Arthur Wint, who will represent Jamaica in the Olympic Games, set a new British record, subject to ratification, tonight running against leading British and Empire Olympic runners. Competitors included members of Olympic teams from South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.
NOJUMAZAKI, Japan, July 22 -- Japanese and Americans today were celebrating the eightieth anniversary of the opening of Japan's first lighthouse at this small island.

Hollis Powers Gale, 59 years old, of 68-60 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, applied yesterday before Surrogate William T. Collins for letters of administration in Mary B. Powers' estate that he estimated to be worth at least $1,000,000 in personal property.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 22 -- Moshe Shertok, Foreign Minister of the Provisional Government of Israel, stated today that the Tel Aviv administration was prepared to offer free port rights in both Haifa and Jaffa to other Middle Eastern countries requiring such facilities.

The School District of Philadelphia announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 11 for $12,000,000 of general obligation bonds dated Sept. 1, 1948 and due from 1950 to 1973. The issue is to finance construction of four elementary schools, a junior high school and a school for crippled children.

With estimates indicating that at least 6,000,000 yards of American cotton textiles are affected by the new Cuban import regulations, William deMin, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, and John W. Murray, executive secretary, will leave for Havana today to push the fight against the restrictions.

While the Air Reserve Squadron, flying down the Hudson, was provoking inquiries to newspaper offices from persons in office buildings all over town, the Air National Guard was demonstrating in Corona, L.I., its readiness to repel invaders on either the west or east coasts, or both.

CHICAGO, July 22 (UP) -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company slashed over-the-counter meat prices as much as 20 cents a pound today, and other major grocery chains were expected to do likewise.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 22 -- Third-seeded Edward Moylan of San Francisco rebounded from near defeat at the hands of the defending champion, Ladislav Hecht, to join Frank Parker and William F. Talbert in the semi-finals of the Eastern clay courts tennis championships today at Travers Island.
This week-end offers prospects for excellent salt and fresh water fishing, and in most areas you can almost pick the fish you want to take.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A United States Government official expressed belief today that the exchange value of the Mexican peso, now set at nearly 20 cents United States currency, would be cut to about 15 or 16 cents.

The Federal Wage-Hour Administration failed to support the position of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, on a stevedore wage-hour issue, Joseph P. Ryan, ILA president, reported yesterday after his return from a conference with Government officials in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Washington won in the long run today after Detroit scored enough runs in the first inning for an ordinary baseball game. The Tigers piled up six tallies in the opening frame, but the game went on to twelve innings and the Senators won, 9 -- 8.

Moscow, July 22 (AP) -- A hint of the reason behind Russia's refusal to enter the Olympic Games was contained today in a call by the new sports leader of the U.S.S.R. for Russian athletes who can win top places in international competition within the next few years.

MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported today that a meeting of Orthodox Church representatives here adopted a resolution accusing the Vatican of taking an active role in "instigating a new war."

PARIS, July 22 -- After his arrival in Paris at noon today, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, spent the afternoon discussing the Marshall Plan outlook with W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador-at-Large.

Construction of a special ramp to provide access to the 85-year- old Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled at 321 East Forty-second Street was considered likely yesterday as part of the city plan for the approaches to the proposed United Nations headquarters site.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 22 -- Prominent experts on international law, meeting here today at the University of Michigan's forum on current problems, called for an end of the dual position now held by the occupying powers in Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- The board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild has voted unanimously to reject a proposal that all its existing actors union groups be consolidated to form one giant industrial type union. The chief objection made by the guild

City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday his plans for immediate abatement of objectionable odors coming from garbage dumped on the site of Marine Park, Brooklyn.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (AP) -- Finland's political leaders prepared for the formation of a new Government tonight following the resignation of Premier Mauno Pekkala.

ATHENS, July 22 -- Greek National Army troops that attacked yesterday in the Lake Presba region, to the north of Mount Grammos, reported that they encountered far less resistance from the Communist-led rebels than they had expected.

Gov. Jesus T. Pinero of Puerto Rico asked the American people yesterday to take a positive view of his country, which he said was making great strides in building homes for the working people and in modern industrial developments destined to change the tide of the island from poverty to prosperity.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A summer, fall and winter almost free of strikes of national economic importance is the prospect now facing the country, a survey showed today.

The numerous conferences and discussions regarding the Berlin crisis appear to be crystallizing into a tentative agreement among the Western Powers to make another diplomatic approach to Moscow in an effort to find a compromise before considering more drastic steps.

VIENNA, July 22 -- The refusal of the Russian command to permit the release of scrap metal from the Eastern zone of Austria for the use of making steel in the Austrian steel industry, because the plants are in the British and American zones of occupation, is seriously hampering the industry.

Three chains cut butter prices earlier this week and at least one announced the first slash of meat prices in several months. But after the City Department of Markets had finished its regular Thursday survey of stores throughout New York, it dolefully announced that the over-all changes in both chains and independents amounted to little.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Stanley Bracken, president of the Western Electric Company, will meet in New York on Tuesday in an effort to head off a countrywide strike of about 25,000 communications workers.

Democratic State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick declared yesterday that Governor Dewey, the Republican Presidential nominee, "cannot shirk" giving leadership to his party in the forthcoming special session of Congress.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 22 -- Plans for financing Pacific Northwest hydro-electric development, without dependence upon annual Congressional appropriations, today drew attention of 500 delegates at the summer convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

Flags on public buildings and private residences were at half staff yesterday in Staten Island as a funeral service was conducted in St. Benedicta Roman Catholic Church, West New Brighton, for Pfc. Joseph Frederick Merrell Jr., the only Staten Island soldier to receivethe Congressional medal in thr Second World War.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the creation of eight new executive positions in the Department of Welfare, paving the way for Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard to take the first major step in his promised drastic reorganization of the city agency.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Secretary of State Marshall in a note given to the Hungarian Government today accepted assurances that Hungarians would not be persecuted or arrested for listening to broadcasts of the State Department's "Voice of America," but said developments would be watched with interest for the value of the assurances.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- Supporters of Henry A. Wallace are going to try to sing him into the Presidency. Every session of the national convention of the New party, which will convene tomorrow night in the Municipal Auditorium, will open with a "Sing for Wallace" program, lasting half an hour.

Devoting too much time to mechanical details has left the public school system in the United States with a "third-rate" leadership, Assistant Dean Francis C. Rosecrance of the New York University's School of Education said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Air Force said tonight it did not expect to maintain direct radio communication with the three B-29's from the United States, and that reports of arrival and take-off along the way might be considerably delayed in reaching here.
Only three of the twelve Communists indicted in Federal Court on Tuesday on charges of advocating overthrow of the United States Government by violence were unaccounted for yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Pan American Airways today asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve its program for domestic routes to link major "ports" in the United States as a defense measure. This argument was advanced, in rebuttal to opposition arguments, by Henry J. Friendly, vice president and general counsel of Pan American.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Evening-up operations in July wheat, corn and oats featured trading on the Board of Trade today. Price movements were irregular and the bulk of the trade was in small lots. Trading in July grain, soy bean and lard futures will cease at the close of tomorrow and any contracts remaining open thereafter can be closed only by a tender of the actual commodity.

An ancient craft that has all but expired in this country is slated to be revived, it was learned yesterday. Baron Erik Fleming, the Court Silversmith to King Gustav of Sweden, who came here recently with samples of his work and thirty years' experience, proposes to breathe new life into the craft.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- H. G. Bedwell's Daily Dip, at odds of 62 to 1, won the $27,800 Myrtlewood Stakes at Arlington Park today.

The public hearing on Monday by the Board of Estimate on the three pier rehabilitation plans that have been presented to the Mayor, and developments since then, have tended in some respects to clarify and in others to confuse the issue. That issue is which agency is best fitted to do the job and when it should begin.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 -- A survey of the relative purchasing power of the wage-earner in the Soviet Union, the United States and Argentina, published today by The Prensa, indicates that the latter two are better off than the Russian in terms of every commodity listed.

Several intelligence fiascos since the war, major service differences in our estimates of Russian strength and intelligence evaluations too much influenced by prejudice have hampered and are still hampering a sound intelligence analysis of the world situation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- The new party's platform committee was plunged into angry debate late today by a demand from non-Communist New Dealers that it demonstrate its independence of communism and totalitarianism by endorsing the European Recovery Program and by condemning all "police states" whether in Mississippi or Russia.
Decisive word about what the price of milk will be here during the rest of this year will come this afternoon from Washington, it was indicated yesterday.

The ceremonies in Central Park this morning at the statue of Simon Bolivar, commemorating the 165th anniversary of the birth of the man who freed much of South America from Spanish rule in the early part of the last century, will recall to students of American and world history how greatly our own revolution and its leaders influenced similar movements elsewhere.

Richard Harrity's one-act play, "Hope Is the Thing With Feathers," will appear on Broadway for the third time in six months when New Stages offers it on Aug. 9 as a new curtain-raiser to "The Respectful Prostitute" at the Cort Theatre.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Truman said at his weekly news conference today that he thought the chances for world peace were excellent.

Four organizations protested yesterday to the Board of Education over a delay in appointing a junior administrative director of the Youthbuilder program in the New York public schools despite the fact that the candidate for the $5,400-a-year post has been approved by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 22 -- The United States and British Military Governments stepped in today and ordered an increase in the price of coal in an effort to save the industry from bankruptcy as a result of the recent currency reform.

A plan of reorganization for the Central States Electric Corporation has been submitted to the trustees, Carl J. Austrian and Robert G. Butcher, by the 6 per cent preferred stockholders committee, it was announced yesterday.

Every oration and every editorial on the world situation for the past year has contained the assurance that we do not want war and will not have war. The speakers and writers were too fearful of the people's wrath to exclude some statement to that effect from their otherwise bellicose remarks.

TIFFIN, Ohio, Friday, July 23 (AP) -- The State Highway Patrol at Findlay said early today that a body found in a grove near Old Fort, Ohio, had been identified through pictures as that of Robert M. Daniels, aged 24, one of two men sought in the slaying of a Mansfield prison official, his wife and his daughter.

Coincident with its report of earnings for the first half of 1948, the Barnsdall Oil Company announced yesterday the declaration of an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend or 50 cents, both payable to common stockholders on Sept. 4.

LEEDS, England, July 22 (Reuters) -- England was in a strong position at the end of the first day's play in the fourth test cricket match against Australia today, having made 268 for the loss of only two wickets.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Dodger visions of a four-game sweep over the Cubs were rudely dissolved today by Johnny Schmitz, the Cub southpaw the Dodgers seem unable to beat.

Several steel companies, both large and small, joined yesterday in the industry's parade of higher prices. The advances followed the pattern set by the three leading producers earlier this week, with the rise averaging in each case around 11 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Sudore Gold Mines, Ltd., Toronto, Ont., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 500,000 shares of $1 par value common capital stock that will be offered publicly at $1 a share American funds.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of The Washington Post, announced today the appointment of a self-perpetuating committee of five persons who will hold full power of approval or veto over the disposition of voting shares in The Post subsequent to the control now exercised by Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Graham, Mr. Meyer's son-in-law and daughter.

THE day was one of curious happenings. For one thing, in the window of an oasis hard by Madison Square Garden there was a large photograph of a hockey team, a circumstance that certainly struck an odd note on the sweltering summer day. Closer inspection revealed the photograph to be not a new one at all.
PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- The Pirates nicked the Phillies for a 5-3 triumph today, but rain caused a 1-1 draw after five innings of their second game.

NEWARK, N. J., July 22 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation displayed today an active interest in the affairs of P. James Pellecchia, who resigned as a Newark police judge July 13 after admitting he embezzled $630,000 from the Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel.

First Flight, the Belmont Futurity winner of 1946, and the champion juvenile filly of that campaign, won horse-of-the-day honors at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. All-out in the stretch under Shelby Clark's vigorous whipping, the C. V. Whitney silks-carrier, now 4 years old, went ahead in the final yards to win a $5,500 handicap called the Volante.

Charitable and educational institutions receive legacies totaling $70,000 under the will of Mrs. Hattie Lehman Goodhart, widow of Philip J. Goodhart and sister of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, who died July 13 at the age of 88.

With automobile production reaching peak levels, suppliers of wide industrial fabrics are under continuous pressure for goods, Worth Street sources said yesterday. Wide sateens, twills, drills and napped goods stocks in the hands of motor vehicle manufacturers are sufficient to meet current needs only, it was pointed out, and it is apparent that the manufacturers are willing to buy ahead for the balance of the year's requirements.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 - -Because Montia Kennedy unexpectedly nose-dived and he didn't have another pitcher who could hold the line, Manager Leo Durocher missed a chance at Sportsman's Park today to send his Giants into the first division.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Moving to close its budget deliberations today, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, which supplies three-cent meals for about 5,000,000 needy youngsters in twelve European countries and China, voted a $1,000,000 allocation for Germany for a four-month period.

BERLIN, July 22 -- Under the strain of Russian actions the Berlin situation worsened perceptibly today. Soviet Yak fighters breached the rules of flight three times during the day. In themselves the infractions were not especially serious but the danger that an incident might result from them are more than serious.

LONDON, July 22 -- The Stars and Stripes were raised to the flagpole of Olympic Village at Uxbridge today by Mrs. Lewis Douglas, wife of the American Ambassador, as the United States team officially was welcomed to the games of the XIV Modern Olympiad.

Fifteen top leaders of the food industry from the ranks of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers met yesterday with faculty members of the Evening and Extension Division of the City College of New York to discuss the operation of a food industry training center to be started this fall.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- The General Electric Company announced today the development of a portable "electric weatherman" which automatically and continuously records wind directions and wind velocities.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 -- Instead of a competitive sailing regatta, the race week session at the Larchmont Yacht Club today was for the most part an idling sunbake. There was no wind until the approach of sunset. Then a little south-southwest air moved along those that had started so that they could finish in a jumble as congested as blackbirds in a pie.

In the face of desist orders from the national Congress of Industrial Organizations, the left-wing Greater New York CIO Council has scheduled a second mass picketing demonstration for next Thursday evening outside a large department store.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district reflected a sharp advance last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Pronounced increases were reported in industrial production, originating shipments and trade.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- With Junior Stephens, the American League's most-runs-batted-in slugger, blasting a homer in each game, the Red Sox broke their third-place tie with the Yankees today by sweeping a double-header from the White Sox, 3 -- 0 and 5 -- 3, for a victory run of eight straight.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- About 100 Americans rubbed elbows today with royalty, bishops, statesmen and the elite of British society. The occasion was Buckingham Palace's most festive garden party since the war's end.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 22 -- Long-term newsprint contracts have now been closed for more than 80 per cent of the projected Coosa River Newsprint Company tonnage, it was announced today by E. L. Norton, president, whose plant is now under construction at Childersburg, Ala.

LONDON, July 22 -- The British Government will enter the field of film financing in the near future, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today. With some heat he denied insinuations of opposition leaders that the Labor Government would try to influence the type or subject of movies that are produced.

The Citizens Union has informed Mayor O'Dwyer that after giving due weight to arguments in favor of the city's plan for operation of the waterfront, it still favors the plan of the Port of New York Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 17 totaled 892,527 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
DALLAS, July 22 (AP) -- The outlook for American cotton in the immediate future is better than for at least two decades, Secretary of Agriculture Brannan said here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Third baseman Hank Majeski singled with the bases loaded and two out in the twelfth inning tonight to give the Athletics an 8-7 victory over the Browns. The victory put the Athletics within a half game of the leading Indians in the American League pennant race.

While shoe production in June rose 11 per cent to an estimated total of 38,000,000 pairs, output this month is expected to show a larger-than-normal decline from the June level, according to figures issued yesterday by the Tanners Council of America.

The situation within Tammany Hall, which has had local politicians in a ferment for more than a month, reached a new crisis stage last night. At conferences lasting far into the night, last minute attempts were being made in advance of today's deadline for withdrawals by contesting candidates to reach agreement on a Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County acceptable to Mayor O'Dwyer and also to the dominant bloc in Tammany.

With the approval of Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle began yesterday a reorganization of the executive branch of the Fire Department. Extra money was appropriated for top personnel, some of whom will have a change of title, and the Mayor agreed to the appointment of a new department chief.

The Government closed its case yesterday afternoon in the National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, in the board's regional headquarters at 2 Park Avenue.

"Key Largo," Warner Brothers' adaptation of the Maxwell Anderson play starring Humphrey Bogart, Edward G. Robinson and Lauren Bacall, which starts its second week today at the Strand, is playing to record business, according to word from the company.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, July 22 -- At the conclusion of a two-day conference the eleven Minister-Presidents of Western Germany declared today they were "ready to assume full responsibility for ordering German affairs commensurate with the powers handed to us."

BALTIMORE, July 22 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association may bring about a test of Baltimore court rules under which five radio stations and a commentator have been cited for contempt because of their handling of crime news.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- New surveys both in Europe and the Far East show an urgent need for the continuation of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, Katharine F. Lenroot, United States member, told a press conference on her return today from the Geneva meeting of the executive board.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, declared today that the American people would be "willing to settle with the Republicans if they enact their 1944 platform" at the special session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Three United States Air Force B-29 Superfortresses set out today on an around-the-world flight. The flight is to instruct the crew in long-range flying technique and worldwide regional conditions, the Air Force announced here this evening.

A committee that would consider controversial reading matter and make recommendations to school authorities concerning its use in the New York public schools is favored in principle by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio granted a certificate of reasonable doubt yesterday to Malcolm A. Angus, assistant vice president of The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, who was sentenced on Wednesday to six months in prison for conspiring to issue false statements concerning the credit status of William B. Benjamin, convicted swindler.

An offer to invest $20,000,000 as its share of the cost of building two large, fast passenger liners for operation in the New York-East Coast of South America service was announced yesterday by Albert V. Moore, president of Moore-McCormack Lines.

The return of walnut and the extended use of the color of pumpkin are two outstanding impressions gleaned from a preview yesterday of Macy's midsummer furniture show, which will open officially Monday morning.

Hans Schwieger led the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a concert last night at the Lewisohn Stadium which attracted an enthusiastic audience of 9,500. The first half of the program was devoted to Arthur Benjamin's "Overture to an Italian Comedy," presented for the first time at these events, and Tchaikovsky's Fourth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- American manufacturing corporations had a net income after taxes of $2,600,000,000 during the fourth quarter of 1947, according to a quarterly report made public jointly today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission.

With the Marine Corps reporting enough enlistments to end the need for draftees in that service in 1949, recruiting officials of all branches of the armed forces made known that the rush of 18-year-olds seeking the short-term, one-year enlistment continued yesterday.

Miss Sarah Gibbs Pell, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H.G. Pell of Syosset, L.I., is a member of the debutante committee for the two Mayfair Assemblies, under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller. The first dance will be held at the St. Regis on Dec. 18.
DETROIT, July 22 -- A wage increase scaled upward from a base of 13 cents an hour removed today the danger of a strike at the Ford Motor Company.

RHODES, July 22 -- With the first truce observers for Palestine sent to their posts today, Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations' Mediator, announced tonight that he would confer here tomorrow with Vice Admiral Forrest P. Sherman of the United States Navy and proceed Saturday morning to Beirut, Lebanon, to confer with Arab League leaders.

AMERICANS today for the most part hold two notions about Germany's first author, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. Neither contributes to his stature in the right way; that is, neither stimulates a fresh or renewed interest in his works. The first notion holds that Goethe is the author of the spectacular "Faust," which one might read profitably, or one might hear (with music by Gounod), and there's the end of it.

Buying at the summer New York Lamp Show which entered closing stages in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday has been substantial but spotty. The show ends at 1 P. M. today and retailers and exhibitors agreed that this morning's activity will be slight.

The Police Department's Legal Bureau is preparing new legislation to supersede the present city ordinance requiring a police permit when a loudspeaker is used for a street rally, it was reported yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 -- To meet the country's immediate needs for more psychiatrists, Dr. Lawrence Kubie, the psychiatrist urged today the establishment of a new curriculum leading to a Doctorate in Medical Psychology.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Treasury today gave employers more time to turn in withholding taxes they collect from their workers.

A low-flying red and yellow private plane twice circled the United Nations' headquarters building at Lake Success, N.Y., yesterday afternoon and sped off after dropping a missile that exploded harmlessly in mid-air about 600 feet north of the structure.

W. Francis FitzGerald has been appointed to the new office of assistant managing director of the International Wool Secretariat. He formerly was assistant vice president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- Important changes in the organization of the Matson Navigation Company were announced here today by John E. Cushing, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 22 -- The United Nations charged today that Washington reports that Communist agents were using Lake Success as an open front door to the United States were "slander" and a blow at the prestige and efficiency of the world organization.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 22 -- The United States, which supplies 39 per cent of the United Nations budget, asked the General Assembly today to consider placing a lower ceiling on contributions.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Led by sharply higher prices for dressed meats, average primary market prices advanced 1.3 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

For at least two decades bold shipping men have proposed American liners which in size, speed and luxury were to surpass anything ever built in Europe. When Theodore Ferris discussed such vessels before the American Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in 1931 there was little thought of war but much thought of subsidies.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- A $1,211,094 estate was left by Harry K. Thaw, central figure in the shooting of Stanford White, architect, at the old Madison Square Garden forty-two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Truman let it be known today that in his opinion responsibility for accomplishment in the forthcoming session of Congress rested entirely upon its members.

Earnings of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the first half of this year more than doubled those of the corresponding six months of 1947, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Joseph N. Pew Jr., board chairman.

NANKING, July 22 -- President Chiang Kai-shek flew to Taiyuan today for an emergency conference with Gen. Yen Hsi-shan, Governor of Shansi province, whose capital is surrounded by 100,000 Communist troops. The trip stressed the critical position of General Yen, the last of China's warlords.

Beginning Aug. 15, the shipper's export declaration, which heretofore has served as a reporting device in tabulating export statistics, will become an export control document, it was announced yesterday by the Office of International Trade. As such, OIT stated, the declaration is subject to the full protection and penalties of the Export Control Law.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The numerous citizens who, because of native credulity or partisan inclination, accept in full the charges made by one candidate against another, after reading a sentence that appeared in certain American newspapers today may take 1948 campaign oratory with a large measure of salt.

For at least two decades bold shipping men have proposed American liners which in size, speed and luxury were to surpass anything ever built in Europe. When Theodore Ferris discussed such vessels before the American Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in 1931 there was little thought of war but much thought of subsidies.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- A $1,211,094 estate was left by Harry K. Thaw, central figure in the shooting of Stanford White, architect, at the old Madison Square Garden forty-two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Truman let it be known today that in his opinion responsibility for accomplishment in the forthcoming session of Congress rested entirely upon its members.

Earnings of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the first half of this year more than doubled those of the corresponding six months of 1947, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Joseph N. Pew Jr., board chairman.

Patrons at 128 of the city's biggest movie theatres are likely to get a warm reception today. The engineers who run the theatre cooling systems announced last night that they had decided to turn the heat on their employers by turning off the air conditioning this morning.

A ruling by Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran, based on the Federal Rent Law of 1947, was followed yesterday by a statement of the City Rent Commission pointing out that the conditions noted by Justice Corcoran had been modified under the 1948 Federal Rent Law.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- Six Vampire fighter planes of the Royal Air Force, which recently became the first jets to fly the Atlantic, will arrive at Andrews Air Force Base near here Sunday, the first stop on a two-week tour of air installations.

GENEVA, July 23 -- The executive board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund closed a busy session here today after having adopted a budget of $78,000,000 for operations during 1949.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 23 -- In the midst of a heavy rain two golfers tied with low nets of 64 in the thirteenth annual William Henry Beers Memorial tournament over the Fresh Meadow Country Club today and therefore will play another eighteen-hole round next Wednesday.
READING, Pa., July 23 (AP) -- Rod Munday, making a bid to keep the $15,000 Reading Open title at the York Country Club, and Freddy Haas Jr. were all even at 132 after the second round today.

Eighty-four vessels of the Postwar American Merchant Marine have won the right to fly the Naval Reserve Flag, signifying that the ships are suitable for use as naval auxiliaries, and that their masters and at least 50 per cent of their officers are Naval Reservists, the Third Naval District announced here yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 23 -- Army headquarters here today announced that Private Charles Labita, son of Mrs. Dorothy Bercher of 424 Melrose Street, Brooklyn, was the soldier who was shot to death by North Koreans in a border ambush early Monday morning.

Barring unforeseen developments in the national economic situation, sales for National Biscuit Company products during 1949 are expected to set an all-time record for the company, it was predicted here yesterday by W.S. Warner, vice president and sales manager.

A man whom the police accused mulcting families of convicted persons on promises of obtaining their release from prison was arrested yesterday and booked at the Elizabeth Street Station on charges of attempted grand larceny.
Ninety-eight teachers, from an eventual total of 112, will sail at noon today to trade jobs with an equal number of teachers from the British Isles.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 23 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Knoll Country Club won a one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Rock Spring Club today with a card of 42, 43--85 eight over women's par.

SINGAPORE, July 23 (UP) -- Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, passing through Singapore en route to London, announced today that he would deliver a personal report on the Malayan situation to Prime Minister Attlee.

The Bunker Hill Sullivan4 :Mining Concentrating CompanyI has declared a quarterly dividend/ of 25 cents a share, plus an extra I of 25 cents both payable on Sept./ [1. On June 1 the company paid a l quarterly dividend of 12 centsI plus an extra of 37% cents. I

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23 -- Rain, fog and again no wind blotted out what was to have been the fifth scoring event of Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Two squalls, with no wind in them, just thunder and down-pours, contributed to the cancellation of the program.

A new book by Jean Schick Grossman, author of "Do You Know Your Daughter?" which was published under the pseudonym of Alice Barr Grayson, will be issued by Appleton - Century - Crofts on Sept. 10. It is "Life with Family," an analysis of family life, offering suggestions for creating a happy atmosphere at home.

CAIRO, July 23 -- Egypt may repudiate the Anglo-Egyptian treaty if Britain recognizes the State of Israel and similar action may be considered by other Arab Governments at the forthcoming meetings of the Arab leaders.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP) -- The Cardinals bombarded Johnny Sain and Nels Potter for fifteen base blows tonight as they downed the league-leading Braves, 7 to 5, before 20,000 fans. Although hit freely, Al Brazle went the route for his seventh victory.

The new furniture that McCreery's is introducing Monday in newly decorated settings on the ninth floor combines dark frames of cordovan mahogany with drawer fronts and table tops of Korina, the naturally blond wood imported from the Belgian Congo.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- A Ladies' Day gathering of 19,006, including 9,446 of the shriller, weaker sex, assembled today for the Wrigley Field debut of Leo Durocher as Giant manager, and viewed a coming-out party festooned with appropriate ceremonies.

City housewives who like light softly draped curtaining until they have to go through the ordeal of washing, drying and stretching the curtains every few weeks to combat the ravages of city soot, can now have soft window treatments that promise less work to keep them fresh-looking.

The World's Fair of Music, born Monday at Grand Central Palace amid symphonic trumpetings, died abruptly yesterday, two days ahead of schedule, with two juke boxes groaning jazz elegies. Death was attributed to monetary malnutrition.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Unless the Republican Congressional leadership objects, hearings looking to experience-based revisions of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law will start next week.

News of the British plan to provide $20,000,000 in government financing for independent film production created some excitement among New York executives of the American industry, although their chief preoccupation is the already-established British exhibition quota, by which the English have sought to protect their industry against foreign competition.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 23 (UP) -- The Embassies of the United States, Britain, France and Italy have protested scores of incidents in which mobs attacked their citizens in Cairo, it was stated here today.

ORANGETOWN, N.Y., July 23 -- The discovery late yesterday of the body of the 64-year-old owner of an unused hotel in Sparkill, N.Y., had officials here bewildered today, with the possibility of a murder mystery included in their problems.

The Bronx Republicans and Democrats made wholesale switches of their candidates at the office of the Board of Elections yesterday to assure a complete American Labor party defeat at the polls on Nov. 2.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 24 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, for more than a quarter of a century champion of Korean independence, was inaugurated this morning as first President of the Korean Republic.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Tigers came from behind with a seven-run fourth inning to blast the Senators, 11-5 today.
In an effort to lure price-conscious consumers back to their butcher counters, several large chains announced yesterday that they would post new week-end specials in their windows this morning.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 23 -- One hundred and thirty-six refugees arrived here today from Berlin. Thirty-three of them were German Jews. They had visas for Palestine issued by Israel.

PARIS, July 23 -- Andre Marie, the Radical party's mediator of French internal discords, completed late tonight the statement that he expected would win a vote of confidence for him in the National Assembly tomorrow and lead to the formation of a Cabinet.

The letter of Charles Upson Clark, criticizing modern educational methods, has my full endorsement. Before retirement I served for many years in the New York City schools as grade teacher and later as a principal of elementary schools.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 24 (AP) -- Baylor O. Hickman's Valhalla scored an easy victory in the six-furlong Hirth Purse today at Monmouth Park.

Demonstrating the possibilities of vibrationless circular shuttle action, the French Fayolle-Ancet loom was demonstrated here yesterday at a press showing in the Long Island City weaving plant of Hafner Associates, Inc.

Strike activity in New York State for the first six months of this year was about half of that in the corresponding period of 1947, it was reported yesterday on the basis of preliminary statistics provided by the State Labor Department.

A nation-wide industrial survey of high prices, based on increased production and transportation costs, will be undertaken by the distribution committee of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. This was announced yesterday by Fenton B. Turck, chairman of the committee and president of Turck, Hill Co., industrial engineers.

Stephen J. Supina, the Ashford, Conn., man who on Thursday "bombed" the United Nations buildings at Lake Success, N.Y., gave himself up yesterday at a newspaper office in New Haven, Conn. He was held by the police there for Nassau County authorities, who are expected to bring him back here today.

Count Folke Bernadotte of Sweden, United Nations mediator in the Palestine crisis and president of the International Red Cross, is among those who have been mentioned for the presidency of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs.

Maj. Edwin H. Armstrong, pioneer radio inventor, announced yesterday that he had filed suit in the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., against the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiary, the National Broadcasting Company.

TOKYO, July 23 -- General Douglas MacArthur's letter denying civil servants the right to strike is being interpreted here as one of a series of occupation moves designed to bolster the tottering Government of Premier Hitoshi Ashida.

If U.N. attaches and employes from foreign parts have been abusing their privileges in this country, Secretary of State Marshall hasn't heard of it. This, in substance, is the Secretary's reply to charges made this week by some of his subordinates before a Senate subcommittee that a number of individuals who don't like our form of government are using U.N. as a subterfuge for propaganda, spying and subversion.
The report of the American Home Products Corporation covering the six months ended on June 30, last, showed yesterday a net profit of $4,390,146 after taxes and all deductions.
An agreement fixing the price of milk for the metropolitan area for the rest of this year was finally reached yesterday, it was learned last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- The United States led seven nations today in a concentrated criticism of the Union of South Africa's administration of South-West Africa -- one of the most controversial of dependent territories.

BERLIN, July 23 -- Despite gunnery and bombing practice by Soviet fighters in the air corridors from the west of Berlin, United States and British airmen set a new record for the airlift today when in the twenty-four hours ended at 6 P. M. they flew an estimated 2,811 tons of supplies into the blockaded city on 516 flights.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, Shreveport, La., has asked the Federal Power Commission for authority to increase the daily delivery capacity of the Big and Little Big Inch pipe lines between Lebanon, Ohio, and Windridge, Pa., by 235,000,000 cubic feet.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 -- Isa Nakleh, representative of the Palestinian Arab Higher Committee, today denounced "irresponsible talk" regarding the possibility of an exchange of minorities between Israel and the Arab states, including the Arab area of Palestine.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 -- The economic division of the Brazilian Foreign Office has drawn up a program for studies to be conducted here next month by a new United States trade and fiscal mission and a Brazilian commission, it was learned today.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 23 (AP) -- The 1,100 employees of the Allied Kid Company's four Wilmington plants today received bonus payments totaling $180,000, President employee, with one or more years service with the company, received a check for 120 per cent of one week's base pay, plus $6 for every year of service, he said.

Involved in the French political crisis is something more than the search for a working coalition of parties, each too weak to govern alone and all too divided to stick together long. The Schuman Government creaked along for nine months, and that is a long time in France.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 23 (UP) -- The Czechoslovak Army newspaper charged today that rumors that Czechoslovakia's Defense Minister had fled the country were started by "Czech and American plotters" trying to check up on an attempted assassination.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 -- A B-25 light bomber piloted by Maj. Gen. Robert M. Webster, Commanding General of the First Air Force, crashed and burned this afternoon as it overshot the runway] in making a landing at Newark Airport.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- Barney Shotton's Dodgers retained their hold on second place under the Forbes Field lights tonight, but they made it a "squeaker" when they nosed out the Pirates, 4--3.

In your editorial entitled "The Communist Indictments," which appeared in the issue of July 22, you take to task the National Committee of the Communist party for their characterization of the indictments under the Smith Act of 1940 as "an American version of the Reichstag fire." You assure the Communist party of a fair trial and "of an opportunity, if they choose to make use of it, to test the constitutionality of the law itself."

PAWLING, N.Y., July 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, canvassing the world outlook in a surprise "non-political" conference today, found themselves in agreement that the United States "must stand with absolute firmness in Berlin."

LEEDS, England, July 23 (Reuters) -- England was right on top at the end of the second day's play in the fourth cricket test match against Australia today scoring 496 first innings' runs, then capturing one good Australian wicket.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Charles P. Howard, Des Moines lawyer and publisher, asserted in the keynote speech at the Progressive party convention in the Municipal Auditorium tonight that in this year's presidential campaign "the choice is Wallace or war."

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 23 -- Rain caused the postponement of the Eastern clay courts tennis doubles championship tournament matches scheduled at Travers Island today. As a result a top-heavy schedule has been arranged for tomorrow.
PORT NORRIS, N.J., July 23 (AP) -- Slipping from the grasp of his 19-year-old son after their boat capsized in choppy waters, a Woodlynne, N.J., man drowned last night in Delaware Bay.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Francis A.C. Vosters of Merion, Pa., fourth-seeded, and Mrs. Virginia Wolfenden Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., advanced to the final round of the Pennsylvania and Eastern States grass court tennis championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 23 (UP) -- The three-month-old State of Israel announced in its first economic report today that it was doing a $1,000,000 a week export-import business with the United States and Europe.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- The Yugoslav Communist party leadership declared today that collectivization of land was not an urgent problem, and made it clear that it would continue its present agricultural policy -- based on the principle of private ownership -- of cooperatives made up of buyers, sellers and producers.

The first giant tuna entered in the Ipswich Bay Tuna Derby, which opened July 1, was the 343-pounder taken by Paul S. Bauer of Marblehead. The tuna, which is hardly a giant for Ipswich Bay, was taken trolling with a whole mackerel bait.

Eighty of New York's biggest and coolest movie theatres were without air-conditioning yesterday when the engineers who run their cooling systems went out on strike for a cool 15 per cent increase in wages for the next year.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that the monetary gold stock of the United States increased by $228,508,000 in June to a total of $23,532,459,000 at the end of that month.

The death of David Wark Griffith has ended the career of a man whose fame as a maker of motion pictures will not soon be eclipsed and who might be fairly reckoned one of the genuine artists of our times. For it was Griffith who first realized the eloquence and dramatic power which might be achieved in the infant and unrefined "flickers" back in the nickelodeon days.
Servicing of all Mexican dollar obligations in the United States will continue in full regardless of recent moves by the Mexican Government to cheapen the peso, it was announced yesterday.

King Peter of Yugoslavia urged caution yesterday in interpreting the recent differences between Marshal Tito and the Cominform, declaring that they were the result "purely of a mistake on Tito's part."
LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., July 23 -- The Republic of Indonesia called off today the long-drawn-out political talks with the Netherlands Government on the future of the islands of the East Indies.

Retail trade here this week showed little change because of warm weather, high humidity and rain. Aggregate sales of department stores were estimated as unchanged compared with the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Truman today drafted Paul A. Porter, last chief of the Office of Price Administration, to direct the battle for his new anti-inflation program, which will begin next week on Capitol Hill.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate investigation into alleged subversive activities by representatives of foreign governments in this country pointed at the embassy of the U.S.S.R. today.

Amid barbaric scenes and a general tension which suggested that 10 of the morning was none too early for a sherry or so, he finally left for camp. There had been provided a box lunch, into which he himself had placed numerous late inserts of chocolate, and since the day was hot this eventually should make an interesting mixture.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Eleven months, exactly, after the Taft-Hartley Law became effective, the National Labor Relations Board today issued its first decision in an unfair labor practice case against a union.

Two Filipino stewardesses, on the Orient route of Northwest Airlines ended a 10,000-mile flight yesterday with a visit to the Automat. They came to the United States officially to study domestic operations of the airline and to participate in the opening of the New York International Airport at Idlewild next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The American Airlines, Inc., joined the industry's move toward 10 per cent higher fares today, but eliminated the premium on luxury planes and introduced a low-rate "family" offer.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 23 -- The possibility loomed today that the Israeli Government might conduct negotiations with Soviet Russia for a supply of crude oil to be refined at Haifa.
Prices of scrap metal used in the making of steel were raised $2.50 a ton in Pittsburgh and Philadelphia yesterday. It was the sharpest price adjustment in six months.

Settlement of a wage dispute between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America. CIO, was reached early yesterday morning after a meeting that lasted almost eighteen hours.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Charging the American Government with having betrayed Palestine, Representative Leo Isacson, in a speech before the third-party convention, appealed tonight to President Truman to end the arms embargo to the new state of Israel.

TROY, N.Y., July 23 -- More than 1,500 delegates assembled here for the state convention of the Army and Navy Union heard tonight a state official class the New York apprentice and on-the-job-training programs for veterans as "the greatest opportunity offered today in this nation."

PARIS, July 23 -- France will soon have her first atomic energy pile in operation, according to a member of the French Atomic Energy Commission. It was also announced that large-scale mining of uranium and thorium was at present taking place in Madagascar and that it would begin shortly within France.

LONDON, July 23 -- The net profit of the British cable and wireless communications system during 1947, its first year of Government ownership, was 682,153 (about $2,728,612) compared with 953,387 in 1946, the last year of private ownership.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23 -- Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the defending champion, and Miss Kay Byrne of Westchester Hills will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the ninteenth annual women's New York State golf championship over the Onondaga Club course tomorrow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- The Yugoslav Communist party leadership disclosed today some of the unwritten history of Bulgarian-Yugoslav relations during the occupation of the Balkans by the Nazis. It accused the Bulgarian Communist leaders of treachery against the Yugoslavs and of cowardice against the enemy.

In a letter published in your issue of July 15, Charles Upson Clark casts a slur on the new educational methods in general and the New York public schools in particular that should not be permitted to pass unanswered.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Heavy evening-up operations in July grain contracts, trading in which ceased at the close today, resulted in violent price changes in the last few minutes of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade today. A rush of short covering in July wheat at the last found offerings light and the close was 4 1/2 to 9 5/8 cents higher, going to a premium of 3/8 to 5 5/8 cents over September.
There were no developments yesterday in the case of the twelve Communists indicted last Tuesday in Federal Court here on charges of advocating overthrow of the Government.

CLIFTON, N.J., July 23 -- A masked bandit who had hidden through the night in a Howard Johnson restaurant locked twenty-three persons, including fourteen employes and nine delivery men, in a thirty-degree refrigerating room this morning and escaped with between $3,000 and $4,000.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- The program for the Progressive party convention tomorrow is as follows -- the time is daylight saving:

VIENNA, July 23 -- A clash between the Economic Cooperation Administration and United States Military officials, similar to the dispute between Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Commander in Europe, and Washington officials over the handling of Marshall Plan aid in Germany, threatens to break out here. Austrian sources revealed today.

LONDON, July 23 -- Olympians of Jamaica, France and Italy were the chief objects of interest today at Uxbridge Village as the Americans reached that stage in their training where they appeared ready for some intensive final sessions in the next few days.

LONDON, July 23 -- President Truman's reassuring statement on the international situation gave stock brokers here today their brightest and busiest market in some weeks. Although the sharp improvement in prices was largely due to hurried covering by "bear" speculators, dealers also reported a broadening of genuine business.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- An examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board today recommended that the Trans-Pacific Airlines, Ltd., be permitted to carry passengers, property and mail for three years over routes among the islands in the Hawaiian group.

The stock market returned yesterday to the levels of last April, ending the week close to last Friday's final mark. The recovery slowed considerably, however, in the final session of the week and major gains were made by only a few key issues.

The times are too grave for Americans to view basic ethical and social issues from a narrow partisan point of view, Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, warned yesterday in an appeal sent to the heads of twenty-five Protestant denominations and other church leaders.
THE glowing words on the jacket of a book may sometimes be defined as a description of the story the publisher wishes the author had written. Not always, mind you. But sometimes.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 23 -Three Russian observers, first to attend a session of the International Civil Aviation Organization, continued to sit in today on technical sessions involving air navigation and weather problems for Alaska and the strategically important North Pacific areas. An inspection of the Boeing Airplane Company's plant here last night was canceled because of their presence.

LONDON, July 23 -- British officials and Members of Parliament heard arguments and pleas for the return of Italian colonies this week from a visiting Italian parliamentary delegation, it was learned today. The delegation, headed by Ivanoe Bonomi, president of the Senate, and Giovanni Gronchi, president of the Chamber of Deputies, returns to Rome tomorrow after-having talked with many Britons and emphasized that Italy was, after all, a Western European country.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A 1949 wheat acreage 8 per cent less than this year's plantings, but enough to produce another billion-bushel wheat crop, was recommended today by the Department of Agriculture.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Tammany Hall made political peace yesterday afternoon at the Gracie Mansion. As a result General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen is the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County.

James J. Munro of Richmond Hill, Queens, chairman of the Americanism committee of the Queens County American Legion, denounced Communist activities in the United States in an address last night at the thirtieth annual county convention of the Legion, held at Lost Battalion Hall, Elmhurst. The 1,200 persons present also heard addresses by Borough President James A. Burke and others.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A "no funds" answer is now being given to those who ask the Federal Government about benefits under the new War Claims Act, signed by President Truman on July 3.

BOSTON, July 23 -- Three airlines using the Logan International Airport for transatlantic flights learned today by word of mouth that they were being ousted from their quarters in the Massachusetts National Guard hangar on Monday. Official notices, it was learned, were placed in the mails late this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- The Progressive party convention opened here tonight with much the same trapping as the Republican and Democratic conventions that met in the same hall in recent weeks. But the cast was vastly different.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 (AP) -- Jockey Johnny Longden today hit and passed his goal of 100 winners for what is believed to be an American record for a single meeting.

VAN WERT, Ohio, July 23 -- Ohio's fourteen-day reign of terror by two ex-convicts, in which six persons were slain and two seriously wounded, ended today with one of the slayers dead and the other in custody making a boastful confession of their orgy of murder.

Thirteen charitable, religious and educational institutions inherit virtually all of the estate of Miss Margaret Henderson Elliot of 115 East Fifty-sixth Street, daughter of the late Daniel Giraud and Annie Henderson Elliot, who died June 19, at the age of 88.
For more than seven hours yesterday a stern-faced and angry Russian ship master defied port and health laws of the harbor as a result of a misunderstanding over rat protection.

The National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges of unfair labor practices against the National Maritime Union, CIO, closed yesterday afternoon with union witnesses insisting that elimination of its present employment practices could result only in "chaos" for the maritime industry.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23 (AP) -- Firing from a wheelchair, Jerry Emmons of Rochester, a wounded World War II veteran, scored 95 out of a possible 100 today to take Class C honors at the opening day of the eighty-seventh annual New York State championship trap shoot at near-by De Witt.

Responding to the Army's invitation to bid on 5,000,000 yards of 18-ounce serge, forty-seven wool manufacturers offered a total of 11,869,300 yards, it was learned yesterday at the bid opening in the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office, 111 East 16th Street.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) -- The Phillies put together a brilliantly executed triple play in the fourth inning and a fourteen-hit attack to defeat Cincinnati today, 6 to 1. It was the second triple play in the National League this season and the fifth in the majors.

Before 200 horrified onlookers, a 63-year-old Brooklyn housewife dangled for fifteen minutes yesterday from the fourth floor window of a Williamsburg tenement until she was rescued by her son and a neighbor.

The Simmons Company soon will increase prices of its metal beds and bed springs, G.D. Wrightson, senior vice president and general sales manager, disclosed yesterday. He emphasized that no across-the-board increase on the company's products is contemplated.
Gen Simon Bolivar, the Venezuelan whose genius liberated South America, was acclaimed yesterday as a revolutionary devoted to the fight for freedom.

The current survey of the nation's intelligence agencies, which have been beset by factionalism and friction, can lead only to one major conclusion: that adequate personnel is the key to adequate intelligence.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- British military and civilian orders to members of both the American and British armed services and to private citizens were awarded by Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador, on behalf of King George VI at a ceremony in the British Embassy this afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- New York City is on the verge of business paralysis because of high vehicular pressure and arterial congestion, and the appointment of a parking authority is the only practical remedy, Ladis H. Csanyi, former research engineer with the Borough President of Manhattan, said today.
