The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday a gift of several hundred thousand dollars from the Charles Hayden Foundation, which, together with special funds provided by the museum, will make possible the repurchase of Planetarium bonds held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Following the lead of CrownZellerbach Corporation, San Francisco, and Great Northern Paper Company, New York, the Abitibi Power Paper Company, Ltd., Toronto, yesterday advanced newsprint prices to a general average of $100 a ton.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board tried to establish in a hearing today that the United Mine Workers operated on a policy of "No contract, no work."

Wartime and post-war commodity price inflation passed an important milestone in the week ended July 17. In that week, according to official figures made public yesterday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of wholesale prices (which employs 1926 as its reference period and embraces more than 900 separate commodities) advanced to 168.9.

CENTRAL CITY, Col., July 23 -- The operatic phase of the seventieth anniversary festival in this colorful old mining town high in the Rockies ends tomorrow night with a performance of Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann." This nineteenth-century French opera has been alternating all month with an eighteenth-century work, Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte."
STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga., July 23 (AP) -- The invisible empire of the Ku Klux Klan tonight granted "citizenship" to some 700 "aliens" on a green field near Stone Mountain.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The draft under the new Selective Service Act will apply exclusively to young men under 26 years of age, and will not affect any older special groups, it was made clear at Selective Service headquarters here today.

A number of large-scale surveys and research studies now being conducted by health organizations and drug industry groups are expected soon to provide some new ideas for advertising and promotion of ethical drug products, it was learned yesterday.

I have heard of threatening inflation for ten years. In the face of those threats we have done little to stop it, but instead we have gone on inflation sprees. We are just having our third wage spree with its resultingly bad economic consequences.
GENEVA, July 23 -- The International Refugee Organization received today 20,000,000 Swiss francs [about $5,000,000] from the Swiss Government.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in futures was quiet yesterday and final prices were 1 to 6 points lower than on Thursday.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 23 -- America's schools and colleges should stress the value of the democratic way of life and help combat Communist infiltration in public life, Mrs. Roscoe C. O'Byrne, president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, declared today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- A platform calling for full assurance of civil liberties for Negro youth, the right to vote at 18, jobs at decent wages for youth in industry and freedom from war for all youth will be adopted by the new permanent National Youth Organization, leaders of the movement said here today.

ROME, July 23 -- An attempt to break the Communist hold on Italian labor will be made in September by the Catholic labor unions, which are planning to abandon the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor and establish an independent organization.

One reason which has sometimes been given for abandoning pet cats in the city when the family goes on vacation is that their marauding frightens away birds, so the potential assassins deserve to be left in town to shift for themselves -- a breach of contract which Simon Legree would never have tolerated.

PARIS, July 23 -- A basic issue that has divided the Marshall Plan nations for three months appeared settled tonight when a subcommittee of experts agreed on a plan to finance trade within Europe. This proposal is understood to have met the approval of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Federal Parole Board today acted to return to prison three additional ex-Capone gangsters whose paroles last year prompted an investigation by a House Committee. Similar action had previously been taken against a fourth man.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 23 -- A state of emergency was imposed by Cairo police as a precautionary measure today, and in the Iraq capital of Baghdad thousands demonstrated against the Palestine truce.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Henry A. Wallace, third-party candidate for President, arrived here today, was greeted enthusiastically by his supporters, and, at a tumultuous press conference in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, repeated his assertion that he would not repudiate any support which came to him on the basis of interest in peace, including Communist support.

Eddie Arcaro, who has been commuting between New York and Chicago in recent weeks, with a time-out now and then for morning works on the golf links, was prominent in the proceedings at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. After losing the decision in a neardead heat in the first race, he turned in a hustling along-the-rail ride with John S. Phipps' Mirabeau to win the main event of the gray and showery afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 23(AP) --The Department of Commerce announced today exporters will be given priorities to obtain 61,287 tons of nitrogenous fertilizer materials for shipment abroad in the next twelve months.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board said tonight that industrial production edged up slightly in June and neared the peacetime peak set in February.

The final break between the Italian Socialists and the Communists is followed by news from Rome that the General Confederation of Labor is splitting up. A secession movement similar to the schism that took place in France last winter is now in process in Italy, and if it assumes the same proportions and merges with the Catholic Workers Association, as expected, it will mean the end of Communist domination of the labor movement.

Struggling against shortage of materials, recurrent labor disputes, and inflationary financing troubles, no less than with rock, sand and water, builders of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel have completed 70 per cent of the greatest underwater tube in the United States and the second largest in the world.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 23 (AP) -- The number of cases in Delaware's infantile paralysis epidemic swelled to thrity today, an increase of three over yesterday.

Joseph Ryan, a banker with offices at 115 Broadway, was about to receive a summons yesterday for smoking in the Whitehall Street station of the BMT when the patrolman who was making out the slip suddenly dropped the summons book and pencil to the floor and ran off to arrest an alleged hold-up man.

Increasing cognizance of the need for developing mass production methods will prove a major long-range factor in developing Peru's exports, according to H.W. Kessel, who has represented foreign firms there for the last twenty-five years.

LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee closed the door of the games today on the new State of Israel, thereby halting the threat of a walkout by the Arab nations. This was done by rejecting the appeal of Israeli sports organizations to take over the invitation previously sent to the now obsolete Palestine Olympic Committee.

Canned tomato aspic that retains its form without refrigeration is an innovation that Sardik Food Products Corporation has just placed on the market. Tinned, jellied foods that do not melt at relatively high temperatures proved their value during the war when the armed forces included them in soldiers' rations -- especially in the tropics.
Mortimer Lowell Company, Inc., has doubled its quarters at 369 Lexington Avenue.

From the West Coast comes word that the world premiere of "April Fool," the Broadway-bound Norman Krasna-Groucho Marx comedy, will take place on Aug. 5 at Santa Barbara's 700-seat historic playhouse, the Lobero. Originally, Los Angeles had been named as the first testing site, but Russell Lewis and Howard Young, producers of "April Fool," recalled the good luck they had had with other premieres at the Lobero in the past.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- The resignation of N. Peter Rathvon as president of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation was submitted today to a board meeting of the company held in New York. Rumors that Mr. Rathvon would leave the company had been prevalent for weeks.

LONDON, July 23 (UP) -- Rival competitors from a dozen nations burst into thunderous applause today after watching the American swimming and diving teams turn in a brilliant exhibition during practice for the Olympics. Even workmen completing preparations at Wembley Stadium stretched their lunch hour to watch the Yanks in action.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- With Slugger Ted Williams back in the line-up after missing fifteen games the Red Sox won their ninth straight start with a 13-1 decision over the White Sox today to pull within a game and a half of the top-place Indians.

Before the rain fell yesterday afternoon, fifty youngsters roasted hot dogs over a fire at a "camp" on the roof of the Boys Club of New York, overlooking the crowded tenements of East Tenth Street. They were 4 to 8 years old, somewhat younger than their brothers and friends who are vacationing at the club's camp at Jamesport, L.I.
Boston, Mass.. announced yesterday that it would receive bids Tuesday on an issue of $5,000,000 tempera .ry loan notes dated Julyi 30 and due Nov. 10.

LONDON, July 23 -- With the approval of the London Government, British authorities in Malaya outlawed the Malayan Communist party and three of its satellites today, accusing them of responsibility for the campaign of political terrorism in the peninsula.

The Rialto Theatre will inaugurate a policy of double bill action films today with the joint opening of "Blonde Ice" with Leslie Brooks and Robert Paige and "Money Madness" with Hugh Beaumont and Frances Rafferty. Both pictures are being released by Film Classics, which has taken a lease on the Rialto in partnership with its owner, James Mage.

An agent of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the crew of a Harbor Squad launch combined their resources and patience late last night to rescue a black and white cat that had ventured onto the cross beams under the piling of an East River bulkhead at Ninety-fifth Street.

The city's peacetime draft machinery was officially set in motion yesterday with the formal appointment by President Truman of Col. Candler Cobb as director of Selective Service. The President at the same time named Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown as director for the State, Col. Edgar N. Bloomer, director for New Jersey and twelve other state directors.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor of Germany, expressed confidence today that a vastly expanded airlift of supplies into blockaded Berlin would sustain the city until negotiations "we will be and are carrying on" break the critical deadlock between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Banks here quoted nominal selling rates for the Mexican peso yesterday at 16.50 cents to 16.95 cents, against the rate of 20.59 cents which had prevailed prior to announcement that Mexico's Central Bank would withdraw from the market temporarily to allow the peso to reach its true value in unrestricted trading.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 23 -- At 11 o'clock this morning a caravan of cars rolled up the winding drive here of the former J. Rogers Maxwell estate, now occupied by members of the Soviet Union's United Nations delegation.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- A band of twenty-nine Baltic "pilgrims" seeking a haven from "Russian oppression" set foot on United States soil for the first time today after a forty-three-day Atlantic crossing. Almost immediately they found champions in two Massachusetts members of Congress.

BERLIN, July 23 -- The proposed establishment of a "free" university in the Western sectors of Berlin where students may find "uncorrupted sources of knowledge" was announced today by a German founding committee. At present the only university in this city is in the Soviet sector.

LONDON, July 23 (Reuters) -- First threat of any major row over the 1948 Olympics fizzled tonight when convoys of big red and green buses evacuated teams of numerous nations from the competitors' camps at Richmond and Uxbridge in the west London suburbs.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 23 -Rhode Island foundries were faced with the possibility of a shutdown today as the result of a shortage of pig iron more acute than at any time during the war.

ATLANTA, July 23 (AP) -- Ben Hughes of Portland, Ore., defeated Oliver Kay of Toledo, Ohio, 4 and 3, and Mike Ferentz of Long Beach, Calif., defeated Charley Barnes of Atlanta, 2 and 1, today in the semi-finals of the National Public Links tournament.

Warning that its "patience was wearing thin," the national Congress of Industrial Organizations ordered the left-wing Greater New York CIO Council yesterday to call off the demonstration it has scheduled against the Oppenheim Collins Company for next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Industrial devices shared honors with those designed for aircraft on the list of 438 inventions in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23 (UP) -- Alex Mustaikis, veteran pitcher of the Syracuse Chiefs today proposed a dime-a-ticket tax fund on minor league admissions to overcome the "woefully inadequate" financial returns to players participating in post-season playoffs.
NANKING, July 23 -- A half-year budget of nine hundred trillion Chinese dollars was approved today by the Legislative Yuan, China's parliament, in a closed session.
BERLIN, July 23 -- A serious clash between 2,000 Jewish displaced persons and seventy German policemen was averted today after a German policeman had shot and seriously wounded a young Jew.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 23 -- Dr. Ray Bowles and his son Tommy, from the Cherry Valley Club, clipped 4 strokes from par with a steady 34, 34--68 to win medal honors in the seventh annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest golf tournament as the qualifying round of play concluded today at the Wheatley Hills Club.

Brooklyn's earnest fight against three city commissions for alleged failure to control the unplesant odors from refuse dumped in Marine Park failed to move forward yesterday as Magistrate Abner C. Surpless postponed action on summonses against the city officials until next Thursday in Flatbush Court.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 23 (UP) -- Goar Mestre, president of the Inter-American Association of Broadcasters, charged today that Argentine radio stations "broadcast only the opinions of the Government" and that there was no freedom of expression over the air.

Plan for a three-stsory storage and manufacturing building at 140-60 Bank Street, 722-32 Washington Street and 347-57 West Eleventh Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for the Hearst Publishing Company, Inc., American Weekly department, owner, of 63 Vesey Street.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Enthusiastic, cheering followers of Henry A. Wallace opened the Progressive party's national convention tonight with a keynote declaration that the issue is "Wallace or war" amid accusations that the Democrats and Republicans plan to adopt an anti-Jewish policy in Palestine as soon as the election is over.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Government statistics issued today showed that the cost of living has reached a new high.
The Maritime Commission and the United States Lines announced yesterday that the steamship company had purchased the 26,454-ton liner America.

Several thousand fans and the Yankees were disappointed when rain washed out the finale against the Indians at the Stadium yesterday. However, the party of the second part, the Cleveland club, welcomed the downpour.

Stockholders suits delayed for nearly ten years the filing of an appraisal in the estate of Julius Goldman, retired lawyer and a founder of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, according to schedules in a transfer appraisal filed yesterday.

Aline B. Louchheim's "ABC (or XYZ) of Abstract Art" tells us indeed what the painters of abstract art are trying to do; but it does not tell us why they do it, or whether it is worth doing, or why an ordinary spectator should take the least interest in it.

THE dates have been set for the New York City Opera Company's fall season. It will run for eight weeks, the same as last year, with the first performance on Oct. 7. This is ten days later than previous openings, but the City Center is not available earlier.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 24 -- At least twenty major political questions will be brought before the third session of the United Nations General Assembly, which opens Sept. 21 in Paris, according to the provisional agenda, made public today.

THIS Long Island town of rambler-rose-covered fences and graceful elms, where the cottage stands that inspired "Home, Sweet Home," is celebrating its three hundredth anniversary with a variety of birthday parties.

IT is none too soon to gather and dry flowers for winter bouquets. Although the time for making these arrangements is still far off, they require such an unbelievable amount of material that collecting should start early.

WASHINGTON ISLAND, Wis. -- This green island in Lake Michigan, the oldest Icelandic settlement in North America in modern times, has an easy, relaxed tempo of life and is uniquely insulated from big-city bustle.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 24 -- In a thrilling and exciting, match, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley staved off a brilliant rally to retain her New York State golf title by defeating Miss Kay Byrne of the Westchester Hills Country Club, 2 and 1, in the 36-hole final over the Onondaga Golf and Country Club course today.

IN the days immediately preceding Lee's surrender, many members of the Confederate Government sought safety in flight from Richmond. Among the few who eluded Federal pursuit was the Secretary of State, Judah P. Benjamin. After leaving Jefferson Davis and his party, all of whom were later captured, Mr. Benjamin made his way to the Florida coast.

WHAT was called the Cold War, and has become the Battle of Berlin appeared to grow less tense last week as the Western Powers decided they were not to be "coerced" but would continue to negotiate. The war scare, therefore, has subsided somewhat and on the political front the Soviet elsewhere has sustained several hard setbacks.
A SPECTACULAR show of United States military air power will mark the first day of the International Air Exposition and the formal opening of New York International Airport at Idlewild next Saturday.

SOMEWHAT disturbed over unscheduled advance publicity, local distributors of Sir Laurence Olivier's film version of "Hamlet" are hopeful that the next few days will straighten out an embarrassing situation concerning "certain lines" in William Shakespeare's tragedy before it has its American premiere, here, Aug. 18, at the new Astor Theatre.
BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- There are increasing indications that the State Department and the Economic Cooperation Administration do not see eye-to-eye on Argentina.

An air crew may climb into an airplane parked in the sun and find that it is 130 degrees in the cabin. A few minutes later that airplane may be in air at 40 degrees below zero, flying a course over icy wastes. If forced down the crew will survive the cold only if warmly dressed.

EVE ARDEN, who can deliver a line with a decidedly sophisticated and acerbic wallop, finally has won a program of her own, a project which Radio Row was seriously remiss in not providing long before now.

FOR every Sinclair Lewis there is a Garth Hale to tell us that there exists in the land an incorruptible Methodist minister. A brand-new young man of the cloth, Paul Kent, is given a temporary appointment at the terribly important First Church, Bennet.

THE advice in the title is accepted by the author himself. Peter Cheyney tries scurrilous slander, unprovoked, as a mysterious cause for the breaking up of an engagement. Then he tries it again. The first victim is Nickie Gale, professional investigator.

THIS hard-boiled shocker begins with Alison, a product of finishing schools, married to Chico, tanned, good looking, wealthy and socially desirable. The marriage is a failure, and Chico after becoming drunk enough suggests divorce. Then there is Harry, a product of the slums, who goes from rackets to war contracts until someone talks. So Harry lams to Mexico.

The Girls Service League and the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children will be the joint beneficiaries of the performance of "Love Life," a new musical production with Nanette 'Fabray in the leading role, on the night of Oct. 14 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Mrs. Fraser M. Horn of the former organization and Miss Jessie Mann of the latter group head committees furthering the sale of tickets.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering a rule under the Securities Act of 1933 which would supplement the so-called "red herring" rule: encourage the dissemination of information in registration statements covering new security offerings to existing stockholders, and simplify the mechanics of such offerings.

AMERICA'S newest museum is already orphaned. Paul Parker resigned as director of the Des Moines Art Center in a disagreement with the trustees over acquisition policy and other matters The issues involved, as in other museums concerned with contemporary art, are implicit in the relation of the board of trustees to the director.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Henry A. Wallace, accepting the Progressive party nomination for President, tonight advocated American withdrawal from Berlin "in a search for peace" with the Soviet Union.

BUCKY HARRIS staggered into his plushlined cubicle down among the catacombs of the Yankee Stadium the other day, stunned and bewildered. What he had just gone through had almost been enough to leave a man bereft of his reason.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- The Athletics took over first place in the tight American League pennant race today with an 8-6 victory over the Tigers as the Red Sox dropped the Indians into third place.
INGLESWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) -- Jockey Johnny Longden completed the fifty-day meeting at Hollywood Park today with three winners and a record season's total of 105 trips into the victory circle.

A Czechoslovak general, who fled his country because he was in the anti-Communist camp, indicated the belief yesterday that Moscow engineered the February coup as a means of consolidating Russia's military position in the event of a war.

VIENNA, July 24 -- Moscow is running into some of the old fundamental troubles of the Habsburg Empire. Vienna ruled a great part of Eastern and Central Europe in other times under an entirely different system, but in a certain sense, for the world behind the Iron Curtain, Moscow today is what Vienna once was.

The New York City Housing Authority reduced the average cost of housing low-income families in its projects last year, despite increased operating costs and a large increase in its staff, according to its report for 1947, issued yesterday by James H. England, executive director.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has just adopted a comprehensive training program for supervisors below top executive status employed in its headquarters at 30 Rockefeller Plaza and 15 West Fifty-first Street, Ralph L. Mason, employe relations department manager, disclosed in an interview last week.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 24 -- The States' Rights Democrats and their "suggested" ticket have failed thus far to make a ripple in the Tennessee political pond.
Movie-going New Yorkers found eighty-three of their favorite theatres without air-conditioning yesterday but sat through double feature programs in apparently normal numbers.

The Yankees, it seems, still cannot help tripping over the rear guard in the American League's dizzy flag race while trying to focus on the front-runners. This failing again caught up with them yesterday as they split a doubleheader with the White Sox to the great torment of 30,012 onlookers at the Stadium.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 24 -- Stymie continues to find the last hundred thousand dollars the toughest. The 7-year-old son of Equestrian and Stop Watch, in his attempt to become the first horse in the history of the turf to win a million dollars, competed in the $25,000 added Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

Evidence of the necessity for general adoption of a recently proposed code to regulate use of research material in advertising was disclosed here last week by reputable market research officials. They presented it by citing some examples of research abuse, which are little known outside of marketing and advertising circles.

WITH the current political campaign marking the ninetieth anniversary of the Lincoln-Douglas debates, there is aptness in this reprint of Francis Grierson's "The Valley of Shadows" -- a book which was not a popular success when originally issued in 1909.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The Economic and Social Council's economic committee was told today by several members that high freight rates for ocean transportation were impeding world recovery.

FOR THIS WEEK: Pinch out any flower buds on late blooming varieties of chrysanthemums; it is too late now for September kinds. . . . Cut leaf herbs to dry for winter use before their flower heads open. . . . Mow lawn grass to a height of not less than two inches during summer. This also helps to check the spread of crabgrass.

A SERIES of curious happenings in various parts of England claim the attention of Waghorn of the C.I.D. in London. One incident involves the theft of two steel safes from a chemist's office. Two concern sudden deaths, which at first appear due to natural causes.
THESE two books are elegant footnotes to the constantly unfolding saga of Henry James. As the Master's reputation increases we may, I am sure, expect more and more of these acts of piety.

AT the summer session of Columbia University's music courses Edgar Varese is giving a seminar of lessons in composition and a series of lectures upon twentieth century aspects of music, illustrated by performances of the works of representative composers and discussions of the technic and esthetics of their art.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday afternoon arrested Irvin R. Schindler, pilot of the war-worn B-17 whose flights have been worrying officials of several countries since it turned up at the Westchester County Airport a month ago.

DETROIT, July 24 -- There follows a complete list of Chevrolet and Pontiac factory delivered prices, which was all that General Motors gave out today. Buick, Oldsmobile and Cadillac model increases have not been released. New prices will be announced by the various GM divisions.

LONDON, July 24 -- Britain's hopes of continued aid from the United States depend upon the recovery made in the coming months, Sir Stafford Cripps said today. Addressing a rally of the National Union of Mineworkers at Durham, the Chancellor of the Exchequer appealed for an immediate increase in coal production, an end to unauthorized strikes and to absenteeism.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- The Columbus Trust Company, from which former Police Judge P. James Pellecchia has confessed that he embezzled $630,000, went out of existence today. When it reopens for business on Monday it will be known as the Seventh Avenue branch of the United States Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Oil, sometimes used to quiet the troubled waters, has been introduced on the rough states' rights seas of the current political campaign with quite contrary effect.

THE United Nations, grappling with problems of international import, also have been quietly casting camera eyes on such far-flung places as India and Mexico as part of a series of eleven films to be made this year.

Paul Gray Hoffman, three and one-half months in the highly exacting lob of chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration -- the institutionalized Marshall Plan -- looks like a good bet to upset the tradition.

If a thing of beauty is a joy forever, as the poet says, then an attractive and well-kept garden around a railroad station must at least be something that leaves a long and favorable impression upon the traveler whose eye for beauty is quickened after passing through dreary stretches of scrub woods, railroad yards and factory areas.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Truman declared today that[ the United States would h01d fast[ to the atomic bomb and continueI its efforts to make it more dead-] ly while Russia persists in ob-r structing efforts for international] control of atomic energy,
PARIS, July 24 -- Andre Marie, former Minister of Justice, became Premier of France today when he received a formal vote of confidence from the National Assembly. The vote was 352-190.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 24 (AP) -- A former Czech espionage official, who allegedly returned here disguised as a British businessman, has been arrested on a charge of being a spy in foreign service, the Ministry of Interior said today.

LEEDS, England, July 24 (Reuters) -- After losing their three topflight batsmen for only 68 runs, Australia's cricketers made a fighting recovery on the third day of the fourth test match today and at the close of play were only 39 runs behind England's first innings' total of 496, with one wicket still to fall. They had 457 for nine wickets.

As the August days set apart for the Olympic festival approached, heralds were sent to all the Greek states to proclaim a sacred truce. Any war going on among the restless Greeks -- and there usually was one -- was suspended during the festival.
The Berlin tension eased somewhat last week as General Clay reported to Washington and President Truman described the chances for world peace as excellent.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Reflecting the effect of some "third-round" wage increases, average weekly earnings for the 13,000,000 production workers in factories increased by about $1 to an all-time record of $52.81 in mid-June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today in a preliminary estimate.

Soaring transportation costs that have increased more than 100 per cent during the last two years are cutting into store profits, Leonard Mongeon, manager of the traffic group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warned yesterday.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON made available last week the designs of the promised stamps commemorating the centennial of the establishment of Oregon Territory and the dedication of Mount Palomar Observatory in California. Each will be a 3-cent. The colors were not immediately announced.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The Dixie Cup Company's patent infringement suit against the Paper Container Manufacturing Company of Chicago, is scheduled for further proceedings in Federal Court.

After a two-year appraisal of its curriculum, the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, largest undergraduate school of business in the country, will revise its academic program to bring about a better balance of general and specialized studies.

ANYONE who saw a planting of lupines in full flower last month may seriously weigh the possibility of having some in his own garden next year. There is no better time than mid-July and the first week of August for sowing the seed.
JERUSALEM, July 24 -- The United Nations flag again went up over the King David Hotel today in a brief ceremony. Jewish authorities urged the Mediator to "bring peace to our country."

Both rare and historic examples of eighteenth century furniture will be auctioned on Wednesday at 8 P.M. in Ridgefield, Conn., for the benefit of the Connecticut Children's Aid Society. The collection, together with early glass and china, silver, brass and pewter, has been donated by dealers in the state, and contains, in some cases, items by some of New England's foremost cabinetmakers.

SINGAPORE, July 24 (UP) -- The Malay Federation Government today used its recently-voted emergency powers to take over a tin mine whose owners were suspected of financing Communist-led Malayan guerrillas.

Civic interests with heavy regional stakes in the uninterrupted development of the water, agricultural and hydro-electric potentials of the nation's interstate and international rivers are now looking for means other than the annual appropriations of Congress to assure continued availability of the required financial underwriting.

" QUIET" was the word most often heard to describe the summer home furnishings markets which opened simultaneously in Chicago and Grand Rapids on July 5 while the rest of the country celebrated a delayed holiday.

The rising trend of public interest in state parks throughout the nation is reflected in the results of a survey recently completed by the National Park Service showing that total attendance in the forty-three states reporting for 1947 was well over 100,000,000, the highest ever recorded.

High distribution costs in the drug industry, particularly increasing minimum freight rates, are further aggravating the problem of manufacturer and wholesaler losses through inefficient packing and shipping practices, it was stated yesterday by officials of the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

JACKSON, Miss., July 24 -- When Mississippi's delegates walked out at Philadelphia and then went on to the "Dixiecrat" convention at Birmingham, it was nothing more than what the average Mississippian expected.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 24 -- In a formal Statement tonight giving the Republican position on the Berlin crisis, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey insisted that the United States must not surrender its rights in the German capital under Soviet duress but must seek every means of peaceful settlement available to it.

THE demand of amateur photographers for color information beyond the simple fundamentals of the instruction leaflet is met in two books published recently. Ralph M. Evans explains the physical and psychological aspects in his "An Introduction to Color" (New York: John Wiley Sons, Inc., $6).
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Light winds and a record entry list today held the forty-first Chicago-to-Mackinac Island yacht race to a slow start.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 24 -- Pressure applied by Arabs, who fled from Palestine during the recent fighting may be the deciding factor in the recognition or non-recognition of the State of Israel, according to political experts here.
Marital difficulties topped the list of family troubles handled by Catholic Charities Diocese of Brooklyn during 1947, it was disclosed yesterday in the organization's annual report.

Financial markets were jolted out of their complacency last week by the new crisis over the Soviet blockade of Berlin, but recuperative powers proved sufficient thereafter to return prices by Friday to levels existing prior to the break. The rebound became a bit timid at the week's end and some uncertainty developed in view of the forthcoming special session of the Congress and President Truman's message scheduled for Tuesday.

HANGING baskets of plants were standard decoration for porches in summer a generation or so ago, and in certain places are still desirable. They can be planted by the gardener himself as well as the florist.

With the high cost of living expected to draw special attention from the Congress convening tomorrow, the oil industry is much concerned over what steps may be adopted toward fixing prices and allocating supplies of petroleum products.

MRS. HENRIETTA NESBITT, for thirteen years housekeeper for the Roosevelts in the White House, has added a charming and humorous book to the growing library of Rooseveltiana. No one could be in a better position to write a truly "inside" story -- and this Mrs. Nesbitt has done, with minimum wordage devoted to political and governmental controversies.

On Dec. 15, 1947, in London's Lancaster House, Secretary of State George C. Marshall brought to a close the Big Four Foreign Ministers' meeting on Germany with these blunt words: "The Soviet Government alone refuses to agree. * * * I suggest that the Council * * * now consider adjournment." The adjournment was voted.
Peak employment and record corporate earnings have resulted in a vast increase of the number of issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- As the result of a perfectly legal conspiracy pulled by American water sprint aces on the non-swimming high brass of the United States Olympic committee, the Americans have an even dozen contenders ready to swim in the four-man 800-meter free style relay at the London Olympics.

ELECTION fever will begin to shake the body of John Public any day now -- with the patient's temperature mounting steadily 'til November. Our book publishers, who can diagnose a symptom as well as anyone, are already announcing prescriptions, with more to come.

LONDON -- The summer tripper who has been arming himself for Europe with vitamin pills and canned goodies can relax. His sugar, rice, soap, tinned meats, butter and cooking fats will be thrice welcome as gifts if he can find a little extra space in his luggage, but he himself will be adequately served without resort to the black market.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 24 -- Two attempts by Premier L.J.M. Beel to broaden the base of the Netherland Government in keeping with the results of the recent election have failed, largely because Socialists decline to cooperate with moderate elements from the Right.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- When the Eightieth Congress returns to its duties Monday at the call of the President, chief interest will center in the response of the Republican majority to the task he asks done.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 24 -- Calling the organization of teachers along religious lines "undemocratic," Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, chairman of the Department of Higher Education of New York University, urged today that the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish teacher associations in New York City be disbanded.

The torpor of a Washington midsummer was missing from the White House last week. In the Oval Room, the President's office, there was a steady round of conferences, on national as well as international ques tions. Researchers dug into official records and newspaper files. Presidential advisers walked in and out, bearing typed memoranda. The atmosphere was tense and expectant.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- The satisfaction of going a full nine innings, denied him since last May 9, came to husky Dave Koslo at Wrigley Field today where, before a gathering of 39,484, the Giants split a twin bill with Cholly Grimm's tail-end Cubs.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 24 -- South Carolina's leading Democrats are sitting on the fence at the moment before committing themselves on the Thurmond-Wright ticket. Though their own Governor has been proposed for President at a States' Rights meeting in Birmingham, the regular Democrats have not yet got on the bandwagon.
High humidity and rain militated against expansion of retail trade here last week. Department store volume was estimated as about on a par with dollar sales a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Henry A. Wallace believes that the Truman Administration, with Republican help, is driving the nation down the road toward the catastrophes of war, depression and race trouble at home. He thinks that intervening events, as these prophecies are borne out, cannot fail to increase the vote cast for him as the Presidential candidate of the Progressive party, which was founded here over the week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- There is hardly anything more American than a baseball park. This afternoon Connie Mack's Athletics defeated Detroit in Shibe Park, where this is written, and took the lead in the torrid American League pennant race.
LONDON, July 24 (Reuters) -- Olympic teams today entered into friendly rivalry with British sportsmen and foreign competitors, but tonight there was one disappointed man.

MR. GREW has followed up "The Wild Dog of Edmonton" with another story of Dwight and his dog Whitepaw and their adventures in Western Canada. When the dog is shanghaied and forced to help pull a sled for an explorer headed for the Arctic, Dwight sets out to find him.

There are several hundreds of Americans now back home who may wonder if they are not still prisoners of war. They are civilians who were caught by the Japanese in the Philippines and on several Pacific islands, interned under horrible conditions for years and, when finally freed by American arms, sent back home ill and destitute to try and rebuild their shattered lives.

SELECTED examples from six private collections of contemporary art have been placed on view at the Museum of Modern Art. The paintings, sculpture and collages are not only indicative of the personal tastes of the collectors but also present, taken together, a miniature cross section of the modern movement.

MANY people in the British Isles think that our Third Program is dead but it definitely won't lie down. Some weeks ago it began broadcasting a series of academic talks, by various eminent authorities, entitled "The Soviet Idea."

New York International Airport at Idlewild will be next Saturday's "target" -- like a Berlin, a Tokyo or a Hiroshima -- in the minds of thousands of Air Force veteran pilots, commanders, communicators and planners, plus a group of Navy operators of carrier task forces.

RAIN fell incessantly, and appropriately enough, through this year's Grande Semaine. The mannequins duly appeared at the Grand Prix, and were drenched; Kirsten Flagstad sang at the Opera and Lily Pons at the Opera-Comique; the annual Conservatoire competitions were held amid the usual excitement.

LAKEWOOD, Me., July 24 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania today branded as an "absolute falsehood" a quotation attributed to him by Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky in the keynote speech at the recent Democratic National Convention.

The powerful seagoing tugboat Eugene F. Moran was undergoing a thorough overhaul in a Staten Island shipyard yesterday after completing a four and one-half month 15,000-mile tow to and from Buenos Aires, Argentina.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 24 -- North Carolina, the only Southern state without any representation whatever at the Birmingham convention of States' Rights Democrats, viewed the proceedings with detachment.

ALTHOUGH less numerous than a year ago, mystery programs continue to hold first place on the summer airwaves as the type or evening program most favored by commercial sponsors, according to the last fortnightly survey by C.E. Hooper's statisticians.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 24 (AP) -- Under a heavy gray sky, the Olympic flame was held in silent tribute for one minute today at the grave of Baron Pierre de Couvertin, founder of the modern Olympic Games.

WHEN it comes to foreign affairs, we, the people, are appallingly mis- and un-informed; we don't know our atoms from our experts. In 1946 (when the surveys on which this book is based were made) out of every hundred of us

MR. PUTNAM, translator extraordinary from the Romance languages, brings to this book -- which is actually much more than merely another "survey" -- exactly the right balance of enthusiasm and scholarship. The result is an eminently lively, readable piece of writing, which manages to be soundly informative in what it says and at the same time to pique rather than to satisfy the reader's interest in a rich subject.

Miss Jean Lloyd heads a group of debutantes of this season who are aiding in the plans for a fashion revue, to be known as the Head to Toe Fashion Show, to be given on Sept. 30 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the benefit of Union Settlement.

Starting this fall the free elective system will be virtually eliminated for all freshmen and sophomores attending Amherst College. All students will be required to take a "core program" which has been adopted as part of the new post-war Amherst plan.

In a highly regrettable error on the part of this writer, the name of "Mr. Otis" was connected in this column, in the issue of June 13, with certain charges made against the Securities and Exchange Commission in its investigation of the collapse of the Kaiser-Frazer stock offering of last winter.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 24 (AP) -- Stephen J. Supina, the ex-Army B-17 turret gunner who set off a home-made "bomb" over United Nations headquarters, was pictured today by his lawyer as one who "may be in need of medical attention."

The Russians are attempting through "assassination and terrorism" to sabotage the Marshall Plan in Asia with the purpose of "paralyzing the production of raw materials," Edwin F. Stanton, United States Ambassador to the Government of Siam, declared yesterday on his arrival here.

Merchandising effects of the 11 per cent rise in steel prices at the mill will vary considerably, depending upon the degree of absorption which manufacturers may or may not find possible or competitively advisable, it was reported here yesterday.

CAPRI -- There is an island in the Mediterranean where the tourist with simple tastes can still vacation for a song. It is Capri -- famed among the ancients for another kind of song, that of the Sirens whose home it was supposed to be.

AN extremely short-focus wide-angle lens, captured from the Germans, which includes more than four times the area covered by a lens of normal focal length, has been tested by the Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N.J., it was announced last week.

THERE is no more significant aspect of religious life today than the movement for Christian unity. It is a movement with important implications in world affairs beyond the specifically religious field. Much of the inspiration and leadership for the unity movement has come from the decennial gatherings of the Bishops of the Anglican Church in what is known as the Lambeth Conference.

LESS than a score of years ago there still lived in New York a man who was to many both a legend and a cult. Though an Oriental (he was a native of Lebanon) he preached no exotic religion. Though virtually venerated as a saint, he lived among the Greenwich Village artists and painted beautiful figures and remarkable portraits.

DAVID O. SELZNICK, who likes to work while the rest of Hollywood sleeps, was going from an interview to a late supper with his production staff in the studio commissary. The two secretaries outside his office and the gentlemen waiting at the table for the boss to show up and start both the meal and the conversation going were resigned to another all-night session.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 24 -- Prospective grain surpluses must be used to stimulate the production of meat, poultry and dairy products to achieve a stable agriculture and provide for Americans the diet they want, Governor Dewey told seventy-five farm editors at a luncheon conference today.
GRAPES ripening on the vine this month remind us that these plants deserve care. They ought to be inspected while the fruit is still small and green.

FROM the way the schedule is shaping up there are going to be more musicals in town this season than last in spite of the assorted alarums, squeals and whimpering that have been heard up and down the Main Stem this month. In fact, if only one of the tune shows opens in September as contemplated it will be one more than opened the same month a year ago.

RICHMOND, Va., July 24 -- The Thurmond-Wright ticket put forward by Southern Democrats at Birmingham found a reception in Virginia, this week ranging from cool to lukewarm. Late in the week not a single Democratic party leader of stature had endorsed the slate or even extended an encouraging word.

LONDON, July 24 -- Five days before the opening of the games of the XIV Olympiad in Wembley Stadium, the American team has been hit by an outbreak of illness and injuries. There is no sign of any alarm in the United States camp and the coaches and trainers take the situation lightly.

THE Festival of Contemporary British Music at Cheltenham, which has just come to an end, was the most important and successful of the series, which began three years ago with a modest program of orchestral music.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Strikers of the Boeing Airplane Company at Seattle won a major legal advantage today in an unusual report of a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

CHICAGO -- The convention of the American Road Builders Association, which closed yesterday, drew not only road construction authorities but also representatives from fifty-seven nations. They examined the 5,000 exhibits and then placed about $100,000,000 worth of orders.

IT is possible by examining vegetable plants this month to get an idea of their fertilizer needs. Little should be done immediately -- improving the nutritive content of the soil is a long-range business -- but requirements can be noted now, and action taken later.

Whenever, on any previous occasion in recent years, a third party has appeared upon the scene of American politics it has done so largely in response to the pressure of organized farm or labor groups which were dissatisfied with the economic conditions of the times and in revolt against what they considered to be the too conservative leadership of one or both of the two major parties.

Herman B. Forman of Howard Beach, Queens, an attorney, was elected commander of the Queens County American Legion yesterday at the second and final day of its annual convention, held at Lost Battalion Hall, 93-29 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Arlington Park, where racing reputations are born and buried, produced another startling upset in the $56,100 Arlington Handicap today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- The National Football League announced today a plan for a long-range master schedule, a program which had been under discussion for many years.

HOOLYWOOD. THE Protestant film Commission, Inc., with headquarters in New York City, is planning to become increasingly active in the production of films. According to Paul F. Heard, executive secretary and executive producer, the organization, which represents nineteen denominations and some 200,000 churches, now is working toward a goal of nineteen pictures, varying in length from a series of thirty-minute subjects to full-length features.

AMAGANSETT, L.I., July 24 -- Mardi Gras and history were blended today along the tree-lined streets of this sea-bound village to commemorate its tercentenary and tell of its progress in war and peace since the first white man encountered a puzzled member of the Montauket tribe.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24 -- At last there was a breeze over Long Island Sound, a real dry and frisky one. It came today in the final regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Golden Jubilee race week.

Well to the fore in the post-war construction boom, the air-conditioning industry is expected to reach a record business volume of more than $235,000,000 this year, according to midyear figures in manufacturing quarters.

The five peace-loving civilians who make up the United States Atomic Energy Commission were obliged to report yesterday that their greatest progress so far has been in the use of atomic fission as a destructive agent. They had no choice. The atom bomb is an element in our defense.

The warring factions within Tammany Hall agreed on General Sesions Judge John A. Mullen as the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County only because of fear that election of a Republican would be the first step toward a shift of power in the county to the Republican party, it was disclosed yesterday.
I believe David E. Lilienthal, in "For 'U.P.S.' -- Universal Public Service," is mistaken when he says that college-educated people will serve the Government best.

BORIS KARLOFF, last seen in these parts in the stage play "The Linden Tree," arrived in town the other day in a benign mood and announced that he will be available for theatrical or cinematic engagements during the coming season -- as long as nobody suggests Frankenstein's monster.

MIAMI, Fla., July 24 -- While rebellious Democrats pondered their next States' Right move, Florida's party leaders and major office holders appeared to be mostly within the fold of the Democratic party. Gov. Millard F. Caldwell, who voted with other Florida delegates against the nomination of President Truman, said he would campaign for the Truman ticket, but his campaigning would not be "enthusiastic."

A. H. Raskin, in "Labor Seeks a New Role in Politics," seems sure that if and when American labor forms a new political party of its own "it would almost certainly be shorn of the Socialist aims of the British Labor Party."

THE stoppage on the making of records by members of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, has been in force since the beginning of the year. It might be well to pass over an examination of the latest releases this morning and to glance at the general situation as it is today.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- The International Amateur Atheltic Federation will meet in London Aug. 9 and 10 to make an oft-postponed decision on "broken time" payments to athletes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Following is the official text of the 1948 platform of Henry Wallace's Progressive party as approved by the platform committee today:

JEAN WAHL, professor at the Sorbonne and at various times visiting professor in this country -- an academic rather than merely literary existentialist -- in "The Philosopher's Way" has written a textbook with a difference.

THIS is frankly a campaign document, written by a confessed disciple of Henry Wallace, devoid of any semblance of objectivity. It was published in mid-July, a week before the convention in Philadelphia, called to nominate Mr. Wallace for President of the new party which he has formed.

THERE is a favorite saying among showmen which they cluck to one another in parlous times -- to wit, that "there's nothing wrong with business that a couple of good pictures won't cure." It's a naturally popular saying because it nurtures the
BANGKOK, Siam, July 24 -- A plan to outlaw communism in Siam was revealed by Prime Minister Luang Pibul Songgram in an interview here today.

THE scene is Tanglewood, a gracious 400-acre estate between Lenox and Stockbridge in Massachusetts looking down on Lake Makheenac, which is cupped tranquilly by the rolling Berkshire Hills. Here Nathaniel Hawthorne lived a long time ago and wrote "The House of the Seven Gables" and imagined "Tanglewood Tales."

Denouncing the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 as "discriminatory, restrictive and anti-Semitic," a number of state and national Jewish organizations called upon Congress yesterday to rewrite the legislation at its forthcoming special session to permit a "fair share" of DP's to enter this country.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Traders who had expected the grain market to display firmness with the closing of July contracts got a disappointment today. All grains showed weakness at times and oats sank to new seasonal lows.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- Doing everything the hardest possible way, the rampaging Boston Red Sox caused an American League earthquake today by twice coming from behind to sweep a doubleheader from the Cleveland Indians, 6 -- 5 and 2 -- 1, today before an enthralled 34,129 crowd.

Apparently unable to effect a reconciliation with his wife, Lupercis Seda, 40, years old, shot and killed her yesterday, wounded his two daughters and then ended his own life in the family's apartment at 586 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx.

THE interest of this novel by Jon Godden, sister of Rumer Godden, is determined by its hermetic, personal quality. The author has confined it within an exterior plot of simple melodrama -- and, at the same time, has expanded it by an interior action of simple tragedy.

TRAIN travelers, buying tickets for their favorite weekend retreat yesterday, provided it was outside New York State, paid increased fares following the rise in rates that went into effect last Monday.

MR. SCHEINFELD, whose first novel this is, earlier wrote "You and Heredity," a popular study of eugenics. In his switch to fiction, he uses a semi-documentary, witty, pungent style. "Postscript to Wendy" is in the form of a letter from a young man to a sweetheart who committed suicide ten years before because of incurable cancer.

SOMEWHERE I had read that an alarming number of girl babies had appeared in the country, that the land was being inundated with small females. Was it an invasion? Were the armies of Eve descending on America, moving in through the breach made by the heroines of the Flapper Age? It would be an easy conquest. The men would succumb without a struggle.

The old master, Eddie Arcaro, gave an exhibition of the skill that has made him the nation's No. 1 jockey when he rode, larruped and kicked Mount Marcy to victory over the favored Better Self in the forty-first edition of the $23,250 Saranac Handicap at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. Master Eddie also used will power.

" IT has never been my way to say much about my private life. Rightly or wrongly, I believed this only concerned myself." So begins this autobiography by Henry Handel Richardson, so sadly truncated by her death on March 20, 1946.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 24 (AP) -- An 18-year-old New Yorker, Arthur Bisquier, today captured the national junior chess championship.

NANTUCKET, Mass. -- Known to the Indians as Far-Away-Land, this little island is now but an hour and a half by plane from New York City, but its name is still appropriate, for it is far away in atmosphere if not in distance.

Hundreds of New Yorkers and visitors to the city lined the lower plaza in Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon to watch four crack cadet drill teams of the Civil Air Patrol, each a winner in state and regional eliminations, compete in finals of a nation-wide contest to determine the CAP drill team championship.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that it had added 165,000 telephones and installed eighteen central offices in the city in the first half of the year, but still had more than 200,000 applications for service in the city.

HAVING dutifully served his time in Boston before seeking sanctuary in New York, Robert N. Linscott, the publishing man, has compiled a diverting reader that sets forth the solemn follies of New England's repository of culture. It begins with some piously fanatical quotations from Cotton Mather, although you can skip these if you have had enough of that flatulent divine.
The French Line has set up new arrangements to facilitate delivery of hand luggage to the rooms of passengers and also to aid visitors in finding departing relatives and friends on sailing days.

WHEN an author challenges the validity of a popular legend, he undertakes a weight-lifting job which would have sent Atlas to the chiropractor for the repair of his sacroiliac. The City of New York is one of our major legends.

BERLIN, July 24 -- The chain of events which in the past five weeks has produced the blockade of Berlin and what is potentially the most explosive crisis between East and West since the end of the Second World War has had another important effect.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) -- Feather-weighted Drumbeat captured the $50,000 Sunset Handicap today, silencing the big guns of On Trust, Shannon II and Olhaverry as Hollywood Park wound up its 1948 turf meeting, before 47,690 fans.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 24 -- The United States and British Military Governments are expected shortly to authorize the sale of industrial and nonindustrial properties of the vast I.G. Farben cartel in an attempt to liquidate the assets and pay off the creditors.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 24 -- The Israeli Government protested today against a charge by the chairman of the Truce Commission in Jerusalem that Israeli forces had ignored the "most elementary rules of international war." The commission is composed of Jerusalem consular representatives of the United States, France and Belgium.
Retail activity here was good last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sportswear, jewelry, lingerie and coats departments reported high sales.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- Hopes of averting a widespread maritime strike on September 2 hung by slender threads here today.
Following is the text of Henry A. Wallace's speech, accepting the Progressive party Presidential nomination, last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ON returning home to New York's fine summer heat and higher life, in what feels to me like a noonday surge of life, certain implacable friends are asking me if I am back from Hollywood to stay. The uneasy answer that "I didn't know I was

M. NELS makes his bow to American readers with his second novel, which appeared in Paris two years ago under the name "Poussiere de Temps" and won the Prix Interallie, one of the better known of the stupefying glut of French literary awards. Some may look to it to find out what is being done in French tiction outside the artier cults.

The white marlin season is now in full swing at Ocean City, Md., and those who have been anxious to add one of these jumping scrappers to their begin game fishing record will never be offered a better opportunity.

GENEVA, July 24 -- Considerable light is thrown upon the vexing question of whether the separation of the Ruhr and the Rhineland from the rest of Germany is economically feasible by a study prepared by a Geneva economist on the basis of hitherto unanalyzed German data.

I, FOR one, welcomed Maxine Wood's recent Sunday article about the opportunities offered the professional playwright in the university theatres. I'm certain many playwrights will be gratified that so much space on the drama page was given over to her comment.

Although orders for summer merchandise continued last week, activity in the wholesale garment market here centered on reorders of fall merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24 -- Yugoslav Macedonian leaders followed yesterday's attack by Lieut. Gen. Svetozar Vukmanovitch on Bulgaria by taking today an even more aggressive stand on the question of the control of Macedonia.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A proposal to take the soaring cost of living and anti-inflation curbs out of partisan politics was proposed to Congress today by Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP) -- The Phillies scored seven runs in the first four innings and made them stand up as they clipped the Reds 7 -- 5, before a crowd of 5,100.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 24 -- Pete Bostwick and Gilly Gilmore stroked eight goals between them to lead the Jericho Freebooters to a 10-to-8 victory over the Wheatley Hills poloists in a seven-period cut-in match on No. 4 field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

BERLIN, Sunday, July 25 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany; Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, his political adviser, and Charles E. Bohlen, State Department specialist on Russian affairs, arrived in Berlin at 1 o'clock this morning for the first of a series of conferences on the Berlin crisis.

TRUDY, whose eighth-grade activities were recorded in a previous book, "Trudy Terrill: Eighth Grader," enters now the larger world of high school, and she forecasts quite accurately what 11 and 12 year old readers will experience when they too reach this exalted state.

Andre Marie, 50, is a lawyer who first became a member of the French Parliament in 1928. During the war he was active in the resistance. He was imprisoned by the Nazis from 1943 to 1945 at the Buchenwald concentration camp -- and has been in poor health ever since. M. Marie is a leader of the Radical Socialist party.

HOW do the war novels now being published compare with those written after 1920 by young veterans of the other war? That must be a simple question to ask, for one hears it on every side, but it isn't simple to answer. It involves a series of comparisons: first, between the novels themselves, then between two wars with their different effects on writers, and, finally, between two literary generations.

LONDON, July 24 -- The British Government has not in any way changed its attitude toward the partition of Ireland, a spokesman for the Commonwealth Relations Office asserted today. Yesterday, Prime Minister John A. Costello of Ireland said in the Dail at Dublin that for the first time since 1922 there appeared to be "some hope" of ending the division of Northern and Southern Ireland.

ATLANTA, July 24 (AP) -- Mike Ferentz, the diminutive bartender from Long Beach, Calif., laid three perfect stymies which Ben Hughes of Portland, Ore., could not jump to win the twenty-third National Public Links golf tournament, 2 and 1, today.

NEW YORK is celebrating its fiftieth birthday with parades, expositions and general rejoicing. But for me the anniversary is marked by a spectral procession of famous New Yorkers I have met since that hectic night when the Greater City was born.

NANKING, July 24 -- Swollen by torrential rains and breaking through some dikes along its 800-mile course between Chungking and Nanking, the Yangtze River has already done heavy damage to rice crops in Central China.

PARIS, July 24 -- Paul G. Hoffman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today he believed the Europeans had not yet produced "enough evidence of the kind of economic cooperation that is needed" to insure the success of the Marshall Plan.

The Civil Aeronautics Board, it was learned yesterday, is preparing to crack down with criminal informations against cut-rate travel agencies that have been advertising fares of $99 and $88 between New York and the Pacific Coast as against the fares of $143.15 charged by the scheduled airlines.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 24 -- The snappiest and best-appearing troops at Camp Smith here this year, in the opinion of Regular Army officers assigned to National Guard training, are members of the 101st Military Police Battalion of Freeport, Bay Shore and Patchogue, L.I.

A new formula for more nutritious bread has been developed by the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene for institutional use. The formula includes 6 per cent full-fat soy flour and 8 per cent fat-free dry-milk solids. Similar formulas have been developed in Great Britain.

A CRITIC who dares to judge, by average standards, the work of those writers who have survived active participation in the French Resistance, treads on dangerous ground -- because, "from 1940 on," as Sartre has written, "we found ourselves in the midst of a cyclone * * * Our age would be explained, but no one could keep it from having been inexplicable to as.

LONDON. DIPLOMACY, like all the great professions, is an art. It deals primarily with human nature, and its approach to politics is through the avenue of humanity. It is the fashion to say that the great days of diplomacy are over. This is an error, but like many false conclusions it is based upon sound premises.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 24 -- Most newspapers here printed today the headline "United States Criticizes South Africa" over their reports of the statement by Francis B. Sayre, the United States delegate, in the United Nations Trusteeship Council on the South African Government's reply to the questionnaire about the mandated territory of South-West Africa.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 24 -- The United Nations Security Council truce for Palestine was imposed on the Arabs in a form suggesting that the Arabs were guilty of aggression and threatening sanctions if they did not comply. Nothing was done at Lake Success to soften the blow to the Arab states.

THIS book is more than the latest compact guide to New York. One of the "Look at America" series, it is a preview of the city for people everywhere who plan to come to New York. It has the advantage of an essay by a professional and articulate New Yorker, Frederick Lewis Allen, the editor of Harpers (itself a New York institution).

LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- A reconstruction of Nathaniel Hawthorne's little red house was dedicated at Tanglewood this afternoon and presented by the National Federation of Music Clubs to the Boston Symphony Orchestra to be used as a studio.
NEW ORLEANS, July 24 -- Signatures of 1,000 Louisiana voters can hold or release from their ties to the Democratic party the state's ten Presidential electors.

HERE is a fresh, amiable mystery set in Hollywood. In spite of two murders and a number of sinister circumstances, it manages to maintain a cheerful, amusing atmosphere. Bill and Sheep, just out of the Navy, are finishing their studies in Los Angeles, earning money on the side as waiters in the very de luxe Casa del Rosa.

BERLIN, July 24 -- The Soviet zone of Germany will be further cut off from Western ideas next month when a Communist monopoly will take over the distribution of all types of newspapers and magazines. Berlin newspaper distributors disclosed today.

While four national conventions are engaging our concentrated attention on the Presidential campaign at home, there is good cause for a cheer over the swiftly multiplying evidences of our presenting a common front abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Truman, cruising on the Potomac in his yacht, the Williamsburg, worked today on the message he will deliver to the reconvened Congress on Tuesday, while indications continued that he would give first emphasis to his anti-inflation program and Federal housing.

THERE is a New York for everyone -- and, now that New York is celebrating a metropolitan jubilee all its own, it is logical that still more books should appear, exploring those cities within a city, both past and present.

WASHINGTON -- The Economic Cooperation Administration officially took under its wing last week governmental activities in the field of European travel in recognition of the immense contribution to the European Recovery Program to be derived from travel by Americans on the Continent.

LONDON (By Wireless). AT the delta of the Nile begins the "mysterious East." It is a vast region of desert, mountains and steppes inhabited by nomads, town dwellers, farmers and traders of many races, loosely linked by a common language and religion.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A grandmother stumped the atomic scientists today with her questions on the mystery of life and the fleeting soul at death. They said, at a news conference of the Atomic Energy Commission, that they were coming closer to the solution of how life begins.

IN this nature study, set in Georgia in 1904, there are more passions threshing around than in a brace of French movies. The Thornblossom family is very proud and somewhat land poor; and when son Jon leases the sycamore grove to Sal Dawson and her father, the family's disapproval is just what you might expect.

PHILADELPHIA. BARRIERS of dislike and distrust exist everywhere in America. Unspoken or openly declared, prejudice is our number one problem in getting together and working together. Where does prejudice come from? What can we do about it?

DETROIT, July 24 -- The last effort in the auto industry to "hold the line" against price increase collapsed today when General Motors Corporation announced a rise of 8 per cent for all its passenger cars.

THE Dykes Medal Award, given by the Iris Society of Great Britain for outstandstanding iris hybrids, has been presented for Ola Kala. This is a yellow variety, introduced by Jacob Sass of Omaha, Neb., in 1943.

TOKYO, July 24 -- There has been a pronounced reaction to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's letter warning the Government that public servants do not have the right to strike or engage in "struggle tactics" intended to impede service.
ATLANTA, July 24 -- Democratic party leaders in Georgia seem in agreement that the fourth-party ticket of "Dixiecrats" cannot win majority support in this state in November.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Hogs were quoted nominally steady in a $20.50 to $30 range today, ending a week which saw prices advance 25 to 30 cents on heavy offerings and hold steady on light types. Cattle and sheep also were quoted nominally steady.

EVER since he became prominent as a military leader, General Eisenhower has been mentioned from time to time in the newspapers as a bridge player. His fondness for the game is not unusual; most warriors have found that a mock struggle, like a card game, is a welcome relief from the real struggle that is their vocation.

JAWAHARLAL NEHRU, Prime Minister of free India's new Government, is one of the world's great men. A biography of him for 11-to-15-year-old Americans fills a real need. This one is informative and useful but not really easy reading.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 24 -- With their sights trained on possible Davis Cup berths, Frank Parker, Los Angeles veteran, and Bill Talbert of New York came through with impressive victories today in the semi-final round of the Eastern Clay Courts tennis championships on the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island courts.

AMONG regular exhibition places, Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries this are the first in what may or may not be a series of collaborations by local galleries in the observation of the city's Golden Jubilee with a display devoted exclusively to New York vistas.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- A twenty-hit assault put the Browns on the long end of a 13-2 score today against the Senators. Three Washington pitchers were unable to stem the tide. St. Louis made a first-inning triple play against the Senators.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, dated June 25, Edouard Herriot states that Sir Daniel Stevenson did not participate in the meeting between M. Herriot and my father. This is disproved explicitly by Sir Daniel not only in a letter to my brother of March 30, 1940, but also in a letter which he wrote to the Mayor of Duesseldorf on Jan. 5, 1925, several months after the London conference.

DENVER, July 24 -- There was an American debut as well as a reunion for a famous musical family near here last night. Igor Stravinsky, world-famous composer, was guest conductor of the Denver Symphony Orchestra in an outdoor concert at the Red Rocks Theatre and he was joined for the occasion by his 38-year-old son, Soulima, a pianist soloist.

THE hero of Edward Liston's first-person novel is an airplane flight surgeon, and the story concerns his adventures in South America. The good doctor's curiosity is aroused by tales of a strange Singing Mountain. A trip of exploration catapults him into a lost civilization by way of a trapdoor ledge, whirlpools and subterranean caves.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- Aug. 2 is the opening date of the 1948 racing season at this spa in the foothills of the Adirondacks. Saratoga has served as a combination sporting and health center for more than 150 years.

PARIS, July 24 -- France is afraid. In the first place there is the traditional fear of the Germany of the future; but more immediately there is fear of Russian policy. This does not mean there is fear of the French Communists' coming into power, for that seems further off than at any time since the war.
Today the main flow of 25,000 members of the Lions International, expected here for their annual convention beginning tomorrow, is due to sweep into the city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Despite bitter protests from the floor, a committee headed by Representative Vito Marcantonio, 100 per cent follower of the Communist line in Congress, succeeded today in having adopted its rules for control of the Progressive party between conventions.

Marvin and Edwin F.R. Fitzgerald, all of the University of Wisconsin, have made it easier to measure viscosity and elasticity with a "twin transducer," a sort of electronic ear that listens to the bounce of rubber.
