PROBABLY no religious or charitable group in the country is more familiar to the public than the Salvation Army. It is equally probable that no similar group in our country has been subject to greater misunderstanding or plain ignorance.

By the time July reaches this stage, with August in the offing and June well behind, we seem pretty well engulfed in summer. The first bright burst of blossom is past. Gardens have settled down to business, if they are ever going to; or they have been taken over by the weeds.

The Ohio Edison Company has announced that it has filed with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio an application for authority to issue $12,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds and 285,713 common shares. Proceeds from the sale are to be used to pay for construction.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Peace is "bustin' out all over" here this week-end. Last week-end the talk was all of war, but this week, though nothing tangible has been produced to change the situation, the lady with the olive branch is getting a big official rush.

Over the last few years an excellent program of employment counseling and placement of the blind has been developed in one of the large up-state New York communities. Of the several hundred blind persons in that area, only four registered for employment are without jobs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- With a display of almost fanatical enthusiasm by both delegates and spectators, the national convention of the Progressive party this afternoon nominated Henry A. Wallace for President and Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho for Vice President.

For months a feud has been going on between Mayor William O'Dwyer, a Brooklyn man, and the dominant membership of Tammany Hall, the executive committee of the New York County (Manhattan) Democratic Committee. In recent weeks the feud has turned on the choice of the Democratic

A program for the production and domestic distribution of several important chemicals, tagged with radioactive elements for use in medical and industrial research, is announced by the United States Atomic Energy Commission. A chemical compound, such as table salt, is formed of two or more elements in fixed proportions.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: In the change-haunted mood of the early Nineteen Thirties a critic considering two books on the Southwest noted cheerfully that "the steamroller of change and standardization has left considerable areas only partially flattened out or not flattened out at all * * * at a time when there seems some promise (or danger) that the United States will become a cooperative commonwealth." . . .

READING, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- Freddy Haas Jr. complained about spectators and threw a bottle at a tree on the fourteenth hole, but he led the field in the $15,000 Reading open today with a 54-hole 16-under-par 200.

THE British lead in the development of turboprop (turbine-driven propeller with jet assist) types of aircraft may be overcome as the result of a $75,000,000 research and development program shared by the Air Force and the Navy as part of the seventy-group Air Force expansion.

FOUR days after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Hans Otto Storm, firmly established as one of the best of our novelists, was killed installing a radio transmitter in San Francisco for the Army, while following his profession of electrical engineering. He had won distinction in his scientific vocation as he had in his artistic avocation.

THE only dance performance in the summer season at the Lewisohn Stadium will take place on Saturday evening with Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and Ana Ricarda as the artists. Together Miss Markova and Mr. Dolin will present two Nocturnes of Chopin (Op. 27, No. 2, and Op. 48, No. 2), "Italian Suite" (Cimarosa), "Mephisto Waltz" (Liszt) and the grand pas de deux from "Don Quixote" (Minkus).

Mrs. Elfi Carroll of Forest Hills added the women's Eastern clay court singles championship to her recently won New York State title yesterday at the New York Tennis Club by defeating the veteran Mrs. Norma Barber, New York, 6 -- 4, 10 -- 8.

Despite efforts of regulatory bodies, pipe line companies and the gas utility operating systems to expedite relief of the gas shortage that looms for the winter of 1948-1949 along the eastern seaboard, there is little likelihood of any substantial increase in the flow of natural gas to this area.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 24 -- Rear Admiral James L. Holloway Jr. confirmed today that Navy's football team would play Southern California, "most likely in Baltimore Municipal Stadium in 1950."

LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- Gus Lesnevich is a firm 1 to 3 favorite to beat Freddie Mills in their world light-heavyweight title bout Monday night at White City Stadium, and many expect Gus to score a knockout.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) -- Terry Moore's long double, scoring Enos Slaughter from first base, gave the St. Louis Cardinals an exciting ten-inning victory over Bill Voiselle and the Boston Braves tonight, 4 to 3, before 23,989 fans. Slaughter had tied the score with a home run in the eighth.

The enlargement of present intelligence activities of the Government and the establishment of a Congressional "watch-dog" committee to study and inspect those activities continuously are two of the major reforms required in the reorganization and modernization of our intelligence procedures.

Keen, competitive calculations have highlighted the recent bids for Army Quartermaster business, it was pointed out in Worth Street last week. Mills bidding on Army business are quoting prices which are 5 to 10 per cent lower than for comparable goods sold in civilian markets, textile men said.

PARIS, July 25 -- Acting on the advice of Paul G. Hoffman, head of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, European leaders decided today that men of Cabinet rank from Marshall Plan countries should meet in Paris whenever urgent decisions regarding the economic cooperation program were necessary.
In his reply to Prof. Millar Burrow's letter with regard to the Palestine problem, the Rev. Earl Hollier Tomlin bases his arguments, as published in your issue of July 20, on three items.

For the first time since World War II, ships under construction throughout the world exceed 4,000,000 gross tons, according to a quarterly survey made public yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. More than half of the tonnage is being built in Great Britain and Ireland.
Joseph J. Thursh, formerly vice president and controller of Macy's, New York, has established his own firm as an independent retail consultant, with offices at 1450 Broadway.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 25 -- Continuing the winning pace that enabled them to eliminate the medalists, Viggo Hoppe and Robert Bailey of Brookville advanced through the second round today in the Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club by capturing a close match from George Motz and Fred Head Jr. of Plandome, 1 up.
MOSCOW, July 25 (AP) -- Several new jet fighter planes and bombers were unveiled by Russia today at the annual Soviet Air Show.

In a generally dull session last week cotton future prices in the domestic market moved within a narrow range and closed with only minor net changes. When the market closed on Friday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 1 to 12 points.

A plea for a resurgence of the "old-time faith in the incredible" was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William L. Stidger of the Boston University School of Theology. Dr. Stidger preached at the morning service in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

NEW HAVEN, July 25 -- Owing to expanded facilities and new machinery, installed at a cost of more than $500,000, A.C. Gilbert Company, manufacturer of toys, appliances and motors, expects to increase its total production this year 30 per cent above the total reached in 1947, it was announced here today by H.L. Trisch, vice president and general manager.

The special session of the Eightieth Congress, convening today at President Truman's call, is inevitably a part of this year's Presidential campaign. It would still be such even if Mr. Truman had not underlined the fact by announcing it in his acceptance speech at Philadelphia.

BOSTON, July 25 (AP) -- Boston's surging Red Sox, thanks to Bobby Doerr's towering triple with two mates on base and a home run by Dom DiMaggio, blanked the Indians, 3 -- 0, today to take first place in the American League over the Philadelphia Athletics.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 -- Just when the Dodgers seemed about to wind up their Western trip today with a blazing record of success by sweeping a double-header with the Pirates, they were bludgeoned by an Irish shillelah.

MADRAS, India, July 25 (Reuters) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, threatened Hyderabad tonight with war and extinction as a separate state if it failed to accede to the Dominion of India.

Massachusetts Investors Trust held net assets of $226,225,260 as of June 30, representing a net asset value per share of $27.27 on 8,295,048 shares then outstanding, it reported yesterday. This represents an increase of 9 per cent in net asset value per share from the figure of $25.01 on June 30 of last year, when 7,697,025 shares were outstanding.

Stymie, former $1,500 bargain counter plater who became the leading money-winning horse in the world, was retired from racing yesterday. Ironically, the tough old turf veteran collected exactly $1,500 in his last race.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 25 (AP) -- A large British military striking party under Royal Air Force cover swept the Semenyih area at dawn today, beginning an Army, Air Force and police sweep against terrorists.

BERLIN, July 25 -- It takes a harpsichordist to get in a good word for America in the Soviet licensed press. Ralph Kirkpatrick, American performer, today returned from the Soviet zone, which he had entered at the specific request of Russian cultural officials. Like his recitals in Berlin, his visit was a success.

American critics of the Marshall Plan may have taken some comfort from ECA Administrator Hoffman's statement in Paris on Saturday that Europe has not yet produced "enough evidence of the kind of economic cooperation that is needed" to make the plan work.

PARIS, Monday, July 26 (UP) -- Premier Marie chose a twenty-four-man right-of-center Cabinet early today, but renewed opposition from leading political parties blocked official announcement. The tentative Cabinet list follows:

LONDON, July 25 -- The war of nerves over Berlin, with its accompanying fear of real war, was forgotten by Britons on this first warm sunny Sunday for months. But everybody knows that a critical week lies ahead with London as focal center of fateful discussions.
RIMOUSKI, Quebec, July 25 (AP) -- A chartered Rimouski Airlines plane crashed and burned on a fogshrouded Gaspe Peninsula mountain top Saturday night killing all twenty-nine persons aboard.

Unmindful of the expense involved, the talented producers of "Tales of the South Pacific" have engaged Mary Martin to co-star with the Metropolitan Opera's Ezio Pinza -- what a combination! -- in the forthcoming musical variation based on James Michener's Pulitzer Prize omnibus of short stories This was announced yesterday by Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Leland Hayward and Joshua Logan, joint sponsors of the show.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Czechoslovakia and Finland, two countries within the orbit of the Soviet Union, were designated today as recipients of minor orders for material under the European Recovery Program to help Western European democracies regain their economic strength.

AMSTERDAM, July 25 -- The European Recovery Program aid is of enormous importance to the Netherlands because it enables imports on a scale required for further recovery and because it creates a deflationary trend. Cornelius A. Klaasse, manager of the Incasso, Bank and Amsterdamsche Bank, said in an interview yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., July 25 -- Paul A. Volcker, who became New Jersey's first city manager in 1925 when Cape May pioneered the way by adopting the manager plan of government and who has been township manager here since Teaneck adopted the plan in 1930, has announced his intention to retire in two years.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Jersey City and Baltimore divided a double-header before 5,384 today, the little Giants taking the opener, 8 -- 6, with the Orioles coming back to win the nightcap, 6 -- 4.

JERUSALEM, July 25 -- If the United Nations should finally take the long-debated step of placing Jerusalem under international guardianship in the face of the aspiration of some Zionists to include the city within Israel as her capital, the Irgun Zvai Leumi and the Fighters for Freedom of Israel (the Stern Group), dissident Zionist groups, are expected to resort to even greater violence than that practiced against the recent British administration here.
ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., July 25 -- A long step forward in the training program for American jet fighter pilots has just established an aviation mile-stone.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) -- The Cardinals and the Braves split a couple of close decisions today, the Redbirds taking the first game, 6 to 5, with a two-run ninth-inning rally and the Braves rallying for seven runs in the last two innings of the nightcap to win, 8 to 6.

It has long been the writer's opinion that the basic reason for poor government that the City of New York has so often experienced is the lack of a unified party behind the Mayor and the City Council. Leaders of both the Administration and the Legislature must perform the circus trick of riding five spirited horses who are not always going in the same direction.
Lions from forty-eight states and ten foreign countries roared into town yesterday to attend the thirty-first annual convention of the International Association of Lions Clubs, opening here today.

The conference of American top-level diplomats in Berlin, which is part of a series of conferences in the Western capitals that will be continued with the new French Government, is a further indication that the Western Powers are searching for a new approach to the German problem beyond a solution of the Berlin crisis itself.

GENEVA, July 25 -- A grave picture of the prospects of feeding Europe if present national plans are carried out is drawn by a report on Europe's agricultural situation released today by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 25 -- Twenty-three Catholic priests and two brothers departed for lifetime mission posts in Africa, Asia, Hawaii and South America this afternoon after receiving blessing at the thirty-first annual departure ceremony in the quadrangle of Maryknoll Seminary here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- With Communists and fellow-travelers in complete control, the Progressive party approved its "peace, freedom and abundance" platform at its final session late today after shouting down an attempt to deny formally any blanket endorsement of the Soviet Union's foreign policy.

Practical, rather than theoretical atheism, is the chief opponent of the church today, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Many of the nation's top tennis players arrived on the North Jersey gold coast today for the sixtieth Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's invitational tournament.

ROME, July 25 (AP) -- The Rev. John S. Mix of Chicago, Superior General of the Congregation of the Resurrection, said today a six-week visit he had just made to the organization's nine houses in Poland showed their activities had "suffered no interference from the Government."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Dr. Sushila Nayer, who was physician to Mahatma Gandhi from 1944 until his murder, will begin a study of the maternal and child welfare work of Anne Arundel County, Maryland, at Annapolis today.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 25 -- The Utah Meditation Chapel was dedicated today in this city's Memory Park, in a ravine near the Capitol, to all service men killed in World War II whose bodies were not recovered.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 -- After missing two 60-yard penalty shots with less than three minutes of the sixth period left, J.B. (Gilly) Gilmore sent home the winning goal in 1:56 of the sudden-death seventh chukker to enable Westbury to defeat previously unbeaten Texas, 12 to 11, before 2,600 fans at Bostwick Field today.

Using copy described as leading a trend back to buyer market realism in advertising, the W.A. Haller Corporation, Philadelphia, will study results of a new test campaign for Haller's Reserve blended whisky with a view to expanding it outside of Pennsylvania, it was announced over the week-end.

We trust that Fire Commissioner Quayle will not be borne out in his fears that any future downward revision of prices in the commodity markets will result in a "gradual and pronounced" increase in incendiarism by unscrupulous merchants seeking to get rid in this way of overstocks of goods.

New York will welcome today its largest convention of the year when Lions International holds its thirty-first annual meeting here in Madison Square Garden. From every state in the nation, the territories and nearly a dozen other countries Lions will be in New York many thousands strong.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell pitched a five-hit second game against the Phils today, giving the Reds a 9-2 victory. Kent Peterson stopped a ninth-inning Phil rally in the first contest by striking out the final two batters with the bases loaded as the Reds won, 11 -- 8.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, July 25 (AP) -- Bill Miller of Kansas City today upset Defending Champion Dick Hainline of Rock Island, Ill., 5 -- 7, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, to win the men's singles title in the Central States tennis tournament.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The United States is willing to enter into four-power negotiations with the Soviet Union, Britain and France on the entire German problem once the blockade of Berlin has been lifted, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared tonight after a two and one-half hour meeting with senior United States diplomats from Washington, Moscow and London.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Screaming, stamping and clapping in a delirium of excitment, 3,000 youths staged a ten-minute demonstration tonight for Henry A. Wallace at the opening session of the founding convention of the Young Progressives of America here.

A slim band leader 69 years old set the cadence for the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment of the National Guard as the men marched briskly yesterday morning down Park Avenue. The guardsmen had arrived at Grand Central Terminal after two weeks of training at Camp Smith, Peekskill, N.Y.

BERLIN, July 25 (Reuters) -- German women and children today placed bunches of flowers near the United States C-47 that crashed near a Berlin block of apartment buildings early this morning while bringing supplies into the city.

NANKING, Monday, July 26 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek conceded today some military reverses but said his Government was developing new armies that should change the picture. He spoke at a reception for members of the Legislative Yuan and Control Yuan.

An essay he did not want to write won for Clifford Moore, 15 years old of Danbury, Conn., an all-expense trip by air to the Olympic Games in London. Yesterday in his room at the Hotel Sheraton, Lexington Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street, Clifford put off the sightseeing he had planned for this his third trip to New York to explain how it happened.

In the South, not even scorching weather can discourage a cook from turning out a hot bread for the noon meal that still is called "dinner." But rather than baking it in an oven from which waves of unwanted heat radiate, she does the bread on top of the stove.
Today is Babe Ruth Day in New York -- by official proclamation of Mayor O'Dwyer.

W.V. Kennedy, in a letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 14, stated that "thousands of high school graduates in 1945, 1946 and 1947 patriotically postponed their college educations in order to fill the depleted ranks of all too many of our occupation and states-side units.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., July 25 (AP) -- The yacht Proton was towed to shore tonight with a shattered mast as fierce winds lashed at boats racing up Lake Michigan in the 330-mile Chicago to Mackinac Island yacht race

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The American Jewish League Against Communism today accused the Communist party of the United States of setting one racial group against another by "subtle incitation, propaganda and occasionally violence."

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Just before the adjournment tonight, the Progressive party elected Elmer A. Benson, former Governor of Minnesota, and a veteran leader of the Farmer-Labor movement chairman of its National Committee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 25 -- Members of the Building Officials Conference of America and the National Association of Home Builders from all parts of the country last night completed revision of a small-municipality building code which they describe as a model.

COPAKE FALLS, N.Y., July 25 -- A 13-year-old boy was fishing for trout today in Drum Lake instead of serving out a term in reform school for breaking into a neighbor's apartment. Another boy, 11, was waiting on table, dishing out food to cheerful campers his own size.

The Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies showed a net income of $4,600,492 after taxes and all charges in the first six months of this year, according to its report released last night.

A comprehensive program, led by Robert Lawrence, young American conductor, with Dorothy Maynor, soprano, as soloist, was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Saturday night at the Lewisohn Stadium, before an audience of 12,300 persons.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Following is the full text of the "peace" program of the Progressive party as adopted in an amendment today to the party's platform:

Abolition of "letters of commitment" from suppliers as a factor in the granting of export licenses for chemicals is again asked in a communication sent last week by the Independent Merchant Exporters Association to the Office of International Trade.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has rejected the request of Gov. Earl Warren of California for the use of a naval air base for National Guard training.

An informal canvass of the Board of Estimate revealed yesterday strong sentiment on the part of a majority of its members in favor of granting a seven-cent fare with no transfer charge to the thirteen companies now operating buses or street cars in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx.

The Supreme Court's decision last December that religious instruction in public school buildings was unconstitutional was scored last night at the Fordham College commencement by Prof. Edmond B. Butler of the Fordham University School of Law.

The quiet Ohio town of Sidney, eighty miles northwest of Columbus, the state capital, has been working hard for world peace and brotherhood. The prairie-level community of 12,000 persons with main street, public square, low office buildings and single hotel -- the Wagner -- has collected 256,000 pounds of food for hungry Germans.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 -- Last week steel consumers began paying higher prices for steel. Advances ranged from $7 to $14 a ton depending on the item, as a result, steel users at today's rate of output will pay for their supplies $575,000,000 more a year than under the old rates.

Details of two contests intended to stimulate architectural designs for low-cost housing were announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner. Architects have been invited to submit designs for a one family house for four persons and an apartment house for eighty families.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- The Athletics split a pair of games with Detroit today and dropped four percentage points behind the Red Sox in the torrid American League flag fight. Joe Coleman blanked the Tigers, 4 -- 0, in the opener, but the visitors came back to trample Philadelphia, 10 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The National Security Resources Board advised industry today to scatter its manufacturing plants and escape the paralyzing effects of a possible atomic war.

Responsibility for today's international disorder was attributed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Stamm to "lost morals" and spiritual stupidity. Dr. Stamm, who is the pastor of the First Congregational Church in Chicago, preached yesterday at the regular morning service of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 25 -- A pledge not to forget wounded veterans in time of peace was fulfilled today by District Grand Lodge 1 of B'nai B'rith when it presented the Henry Monsky Memorial Athletic Field to Northport Veterans Hospital here.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- With the July deliveries of grain out of the way grain markets are expected to reflect supply and demand factors to a greater extent than of late. Trading in July grains ceased at the close July 23 with only a moderate interest remaining open which will be settled by a tender of the actual grains between now and the end of the week.

The Baruch Committee on Physical Medicine, in its annual report issued yesterday, announced that it had achieved three major objectives -- increased the number of physicians trained to teach and use physical medicine, provided for more extensive research in physical medicine, and helped insure the proper use of physical medicine in rehabilitation and preparedness programs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 (UP) -- The Arab nations have agreed to demilitarize Jerusalem if Israel meets Arab conditions, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary General of the Arab League, announced tonight in a communique reporting the results of his conference here with Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine.

DALLAS, July 25 (AP) -- Ten Texas Democratic members of Congress, including House Minority Leader Sam Rayburn, were assured of renomination in returns to the Texas Election Burean tonight. Democratic nomination in Texas is equivalent to election.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Brown's produced two runs with two out in the eleventh inning to edge out Washington, 6 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header today after the Senators had captured the opener, 5 -- 1, behind Ray Scarborough's 7-hit pitching.

LONDON, July 25 -- Private reports from the Middle East indicated today that Arab leaders had been obliged virtually to accept the existence of the state of Israel as inevitable -- for the time being.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 25 -- Those inveterate wind-jammers who continually cut slices in Long Island Sound never seem to tire of it. A total of 175 racing craft loads evidently did not have enough competition in Larchmont race week, coming out today for the regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25 -- Soviet-Yugoslav relations have deteriorated seriously during the last forty-eight hours. Events at today's session of the fifth congress of this country's Communist party indicate that the small spark of possible compromise with the Soviet leaders may have been almost extinguished.

ATHENS, July 25 -- In a letter addressed to Premier Sophoulis and published today, nine Liberal members of Parliament threatened to withdraw their support from the coalition Populist-Liberal Government if the present fixed price of wheat, which the Government collects, were not increased.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 25 -- The plight of thousands of Palestine Arabs who fled before the Israeli Army and the strain on Arab towns caused by their influx have been indicated by two broadcasts heard here.

When Peter wrote his famed epistles 2,000 years ago the world was in a state of crisis comparable to that confronting civilization today, the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, said yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Six Government surplus property sales, including a spotbid sale of a $2,000,000 general inventory through the War Assets Administration's Bronx sales center, were announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey New York Regional Director of the WAA.

A sharp decline in prices is to be expected after the peak has been passed, perhaps accelerating in the early stages of the decline, it is declared in a study of postwar prices, released over the weekend by the National Bureau of Economic Research.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 25 (AP) -- The baseball world rallied today with offers to help rebuild the shattered Duluth, (Minn.) team of the Class C Northern League.

The Japanese Board of Trade will purchase up to 50,000 bales of American cotton from private United States shippers, it was announced over the week-end by the foreign trade New York office of the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers.

LONDON, July 25 (UP) -- Reports that Champion Gus Lesnevich was having trouble getting down to the 175-pound limit for his light-heavyweight title defense against Freddie Mills shortened the odds in his favor tonight but brought denials from the American's training quarters at Brighton.

VIENNA, July 25 -- The Soviet Army newspaper Oesterreichische Zeitung presented the nomination of Henry A. Wallace today as the leading news of the day. Other Vienna papers covered the beginning of the Progressive party campaign at Philadelphia but emphasized European news as usual, as they had at the time of the Republican and Democratic conventions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Appointment of a three-man interim executive committee to administer the current modified production of RKO Radio Pictures was revealed today by N. Peter Rathvon.

A new era in the trade relations between West Africa and the United States begins today when the Republic of Liberia marks its 101st anniversary by formally opening its new $20,000,000 deep-water harbor to serve the capital city of Monrovia, Robert Morris, secretary of the Monrovia Port Management Company, Ltd., said in a report issued here yesterday.
An upper deck on the West Side Highway was recommended yesterday after surveys had demonstrated that the artery was unable to absorb freely the present morning and evening traffic peaks.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The average life's span of people in the United States has climbed to a new mark of almost 67 years, calculated on the basis of 1946 death rates, the Federal Security Agency reported today.

A telephone call to a wire news service touched off yesterday afternoon a search of the waters of Raritan Bay for wreckage of a 100-foot boat, reported to have exploded. The search was called off several hours later when a fleet of ships and planes could find neither wreckage nor oil slicks.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Describing President Truman's call for an extra session of Congress as "pure demagogy and a political bluff," Senator Glen H. Taylor and Representatives Vito Marcantonio and Leo Isacson, the only three members of the Progressive party in Congress, joined today in announcing their program in the coming proceedings.

Heavy reorders of fall merchandise received by the wholesale apparel market here last week is a promise of a busy and prosperous fall season, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Fourteen persons were injured, three of them requiring hospitalization, when a bus and automobile collided at Beach 119th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway, Queens, at 11:30 A.M. yesterday.

READING, Pa., July 25 (AP) -- Little Ben Hogan treated the home folk to one of his typical finishes today as he rallied from a five-stroke deficit to win the $15,000 Reading Open with a seventy-two-hole 269.

A new chapter was written last week in the history of the price cycle in the United States. The Bureau of Labor Statistics revealed on Friday that the weekly index of wholesale commodity prices had risen between July 10 and July 17 from 166.8 to 168.9.
LONDON, July 25 -- The Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, will come under Government ownership at the end of next year, it was announced today.

A convoy of twenty-four army trucks and trailers, bearing an aviation exhibit that will fill five tents at the International Air Exposition opening here this week, wound into the city yesterday from Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio. It arrived at Idlewild Airport after a tortuous three-hour trip through Manhattan and Queens streets crowded with Sunday evening traffic.

LONDON, July 25 -- I have just returned from a week's visit to Germany, during which I had an opportunity to meet not only the Allied commanders and principal Allied authorities, but leading Germans in every walk of life. During my stay I visited Berlin and Hamburg as well as Frankfort on the Main and the French zone.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Henry Wallace appeared in Shibe Park last night as the climax of three hours of song, oratory and frenzied money-raising. He made a triumphal entry in a spotlighted car and rode slowly around the baseball field acknowledging the shrill cheers from 25,000 voices and followed by a long trail of whirling, waving figures in a kind of ecstatic dance.

With the exception of station agents, weary of hand-counting mountains of dimes, and a few discomfited bus passengers, there were few complaints yesterday, a little more than three weeks after the fare increase on the city's transit lines.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Federal Trade Commission warned today in a report to the special session of Congress that if the growth of monopoly and concentration of economic power through mergers was not halted in America, collectivism would triumph over free enterprise.
One of those days that usually come in June -- the kind the poets have written about -- popped up on the waning July calendar yesterday.

Quiet pervaded all sections of the foreign exchange market last week and the limited business reported produced no important price change. It was a typical summer week in which bankers and dealers confined themselves to routine requirements. Another observation for the smoothness was that with ERP finally launched there is a disposition to accept that program as a potential factor in reducing the fears which have gripped recent markets.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 25 -- Frank Parker, first in the national amateur tennis ranking, captured the Eastern clay courts singles title today on the New York Athletic Club courts on Travers Island. Seeded first in the tournament, Parker engaged William Talbert, New York star who was seeded No. 2, in the final round and proceeded to turn out a victory by the score of 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Human pride motivates many current "persecutors" of the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. James V. Kenney declared yesterday in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. A member of the New York Apostolate, Father Kenney is serving on the cathedral staff for one month.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 25 -- Cruising with a navigational accuracy of 98.5 per cent, Joseph E. Herrmann, New York shipping magnate, retained the express cruiser championship of America by winning the 41-mile predicted log race on near-by waters with his raised-deck craft, Clipper II, today.

Several nights ago I went to the Lewisohn Stadium concert to hear sweet sounds by percussion, woodwinds and strings of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and Nathan Milstein, violinist. These were on the program, and as much as I could hear was pleasing.
"Art makes you a better person; it occupies you, it is a nice pastime and a career for some. Art isn't a waste of time, although some parents think so."
The National Maritime Union, CIO, with its 60,000 members, joins the ranks of Right-Wing unions tonight with the formal announcement of the vote count in its national elections.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The armed forces will wage an all-out "war" with live and blank ammunition on the beaches of Virginia next month, the Navy announced yesterday.

Our city scout says that these face-lifting operations all over town -- and especially in the old parts of the town, where no doubt they are most needed -- result in considerable confusion for an old inhabitant in whose memory is fixed a pattern of New York which these operations pull out of shape.

LONDON -- Paraphrasing Lord Burghley, Dean Cromwell said aboard the America en route to the Olympic Games, "I do not care how fast the 800 is run. I believe the American champion can stay with the pace and win the race."

Foreign exchange receivables of American exporters in the form of deposits of the buyers' local currencies could be bought by the Economic Cooperation Administration to buy foodstuffs or other commodity requirements for Europe, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., says in a proposal forwarded to ECA Administrator Paul G. Hoffman.

PARIS, July 25 -- French technical services in the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Finances and Economic Affairs are now engrossed in following the decisive conversations in progress in the sessions of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on proposed operational measures and in its talks on the Marshall Plan.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- A cacophony of enemy base hits provided the exit march at Wrigley Field today as the curtain fell on the first road trip of the Giants under the aegis of Leo Durocher.

They gave Bill Johnson his "day" at the Stadium yesterday, but so far as 42,267 could make out it was the big fellow the Yankees play in center field who provided the major pyrotechnics as the Bombers finally got around to grabbing both ends of a double-header from the troublesome White Sox.

A birthday party was held yesterday for David Belasco, who died in 1931. The guests saw nothing unusual in a posthumous natal date celebration. They have been assembling for this occasion of good cheer and tale-swapping about "the Governor" since his death.

CARRASCO, Uruguay, July 25 -- A thirty-foot marble stele was dedicated here this morning to the memory of President Roosevelt. The monument is set in the former Carrasco National Park, in the best-known suburb of Montevideo.
There are more church members in the United States today than ever before, according to The Christian Herald's annual report on the state of the church, released yesterday.

New York will become the center of the British Overseas Airways Corporation's operations under reorganization plans described in detail here yesterday. The plans were made public last week in London by Whitney Straight, American-born head of the corporation.

Sooner or later each man must decide whether he is going to be "God-bent or hell-bent," the Rev. Dr. Jesse William Stitt, minister of the Village Presbyterian Church, 139 West Thirteenth Street, declared yesterday at the church's morning service.

PATUXENT RIVER, Md., July 25 (UP) -- A great new giant of the airways, the 180-seat Lockheed Constitution, spanned the continent today in 10 hours 19 minutes, landing at this naval air test center at 6:47 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 25 -- Plans for a European highway system capable of handling fast, heavy traffic on a continent-wide basis have been extended to cover Poland, Czechoslovakia and Britain.
There are more church members in the United States today than ever before, according to The Christian Herald's annual report on the state of the church, released yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Weather conditions of late have been almost ideal for the development of the new corn crop and the latter is well in advance of last year and somewhat ahead of normal, result-

Life in the suburbs provides a few virtues, as well as a vice or so worth a letter home. Trees and grass and flowers are pretty things, no doubt, and the sight of an occasional deer wandering along the lane, always outside the hunting season.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 25 -- Plans for a European highway system capable of handling fast, heavy traffic on a continent-wide basis have been extended to cover Poland, Czechoslovakia and Britain.

Formation of a new atomic energy division to specialize, exclusively in nuclear engineering problems was announced here over the week-end by H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders. Dr. Karl Cohen, former director of the theoretical division of the Manhattan Project Laboratory, will direct the activities of the new division, according to Wells N. Thompson, Ferguson Company vice president.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Eightieth Congress will reconvene tomorrow at the call of President Truman for one of the most unusual sessions in the nation's history.

LONDON, July 25 (UP) -- America's track and field athletes were disappointed and somewhat disgruntled today when they learned that they will be unable to work out at Wembley Stadium before the start of the Olympic games next Thursday.

TOKYO, July 25 -- Charges that the Occupation's purge of Japanese officials had been administered "as if by Communists" in violation of the Potsdam terms have been sent to Washington by Tetsuma Hashimoto, Japan's most influential political commentator.

The accord reached on Friday between Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, the new Tammany Hall leader, calls for the ending of the anti-Tammany organization that the Mayor had threatened to set up, it was learned yesterday.

The 7,000-ton freighter William Carson, from which a mutiny was falsely reported on July 12 in an SOS broadcast by a radio man of "doubtful sanity" who jumped overboard to his death soon after sending the distress call, docked early yesterday afternoon at the National Gypsum Company pier, Cak Point, near 145th Street, the Bronx.

FORT LEE, N.J., July 25 -- Twenty-two members of the Committee on Racial Equality, 7 East Fifteenth Street, New York, were arrested as disorderly persons and held in the police jail for several hours this afternoon as they resumed last summer's series of demonstrations in seeking to have Negroes admitted to the Palisades Amusement Park swimming pool here.
NEWARK, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Rolling along in high gear again, the Newark Bears swept a twin bill from Toronto today, 8 -- 1 and 6 -- 3, to run their winning streak to six.

FUERSTENFELDBRUCK, Germany, July 25 -- The first American jet fighter planes to land in Germany arrived here at 2:05 P.M. today at the end of flights of more than 5,000 miles from their base at Selfridge Field, Mich.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 25 (UP) -- A vast underground arms manufacturing plant has been constructed by Smith Wesson, Inc., beneath a filled-in swamp on the outskirts of this city, according to a reliable informant who stated that work was nearly completed on the project, begun three years ago when the company announced a plan to enlarge its old plant.

PARIS, Monday, July 26 -- Premier Andre Marie's projected national Cabinet was saved last night by Leon Blum, Socialist leader, from his party's opposition to the appointment of Paul Reynaud as Minister of Finance. The Socialists, after having heard M. Blum, voted two to one to enter the Cabinet coalition.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The big inflation trouble, the Department of Commerce said today, is that buying demand has been growing while production has stood still.
Four new films are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, July 25 -- The Olympic camp at Uxbridge was largely a deserted village today as the Americans enjoyed a day of relaxation on the first sabbath since their arrival here. Taking advantage of the warm, sunny weather, the athletes went sightseeing, taking along cameras.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today it would ask the Federal Communications Commission Tuesday for a channel to relay television broadcasts across the Alleghanies by means of a plane six miles over Pittsburgh.

LONDON, July 25 -- The stock markets here experienced another week of nervous tension in which business continued to dwindle. Considering the gravity of the situation, however, the markets displayed a remarkable calm.

ATHENS, July 25 (UP) -- King Paul of Greece tonight refused to accept the resignation of the American-sponsored Premier Themistocles Sophoulis and Government leaders went into conference seeking a solution of a new Cabinet crisis.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25 -- Marshal Tito today received former Gov. Culbert L. Olson of California, who is touring eastern Europe, and told him that the Yugoslav Government would welcome a trade agreement with the United States, provided that it did not contain political conditions.

LENOX, Mass., July 25 (AP) -- An overflow throng of 3,200 turned out at Tanglewood today for a Mozart program by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Serge Koussevitzky. Filling the concert hall were 1,100 persons, while the remaining 2,100 heard the concert from the terrace.

Oscar Edward Cesare, whose death was recorded on Sunday, was an artist of rare gifts and a man of notable distinction among the members of the newspaper craft, which he had followed in this country from his youth and for more than forty years in this city. We put it that way, not that Cesare was less an artist, but that he was al ways -- to us -- a newspaper man.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 26 -- Eural Clark of Los Angeles carded 38, 3 -- 72, two strokes over course figures, to win the amateur qualifying medal in the Ray Robinson open tournament at the Engineers Golf Club today.
The first substantial post-war decrease in the city's relief rollsh)0*0*0*iwas reported yesterday by Commissioner of Welfare Raymond M. Hilliard.

LONDON -- The big top of the Olympics is the track and field championships at Wembley Stadium, but there are people who pass the main tent by when they go to the circus. It isn't a matter of picketing. They prefer the side shows.

Alabama refused to yield to Mexico in good-will nor would Switzerland give precedence to Wyoming on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon as the Lions International paraded in an eloquent display of amity among peoples.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -William R. Ringer, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board today accorded to both sides a spell, until Sept. 8, to prepare and submit briefs in the Government's action alleging unfair labor practices against John L. Lewis.

The use of metal threads in fabric is not a fad but an extension of the weaver's palette, Dorothy Liebes, fabric designer, said yesterday. She spoke at a showing of home furnishings and fashions held at the Hotel Pierre by the Dobeckmun Company, makers of Lurex metal yarns.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- The four American girl Olympic divers, all from California, are somewhat impatient with the conservative old rules laid down by the Olympian fathers to forbid women from tumbling through the air as daringly as the men divers do.

LONDON, July 26 -- The next approach to Moscow on the Berlin situation will most likely be an oral one by envoys of the United States, Britain and France directly to Foreign Minister Molotov, it was learned from an authoritative source here today.

Virtually all the $15,000,000 estate of William Nelson Cromwell, 94-year-old lawyer who died July 19, leaving only two first cousins, will go to forty-eight educational, art, religious and philanthropic organizations here and abroad. The testament was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court for probate.

The Lewisohn Stadium concerts started their next to last week last night with one of the major novelties of the season, the concert version of Puccini's "Tosca," with Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting and Eleanor Steber in the title role.
Leo Durocher learned last night that, as ex-host at Ebbets Field, he was privileged to have the welcome mat unrolled and pulled from under his spiked shoes -- with sound effects.
Policemen of Emergency Squad 12, in Brooklyn, had to chisel their way yesterday to the rescue of Robert Martino, 6 years old, of 192 Lawrence Avenue, Brooklyn.
ATHENS, July 26 (AP) -- Greek troops jumped off this morning in a drive that may be the final push in the rugged Grammos Mountain campaign.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 26 (AP) -- George Sollitt's yawl, Onkahya, today held the cup as champion of the Chicago-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.

The state Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance will add 1,000 of its own employes to the jobless list this week. Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced that 700 employes would have to be laid off by Saturday because of a cut in Federal funds.

The 5,000 delegates to the Lions thirty-first annual International Convention, as well as 20,000 other members of the organization and their families, received an invitation from Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to "look over New York City while you are here."

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Defending champion Gardnar Mulloy, Miami Beach, advanced to the second round of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's sixtieth invitation tournament with an easy 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, victory over Gilbert Shea, Los Angeles, today.

PARIS, July 26 -- Eight distinguished social scientists, representing six countries and various political schools of thought, have agreed in a joint report that modern productive power and resources must be so planned as to create maximum social justice "if we are to avoid the kind of aggression that leads to armed conflict."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -British motion-picture producers who take advantage of a plan announced last week whereby $20,000,000 in Government money will be made available to them, will soon find Government officials standing at their elbows while their cameras click, telling them how to make their films, according to Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

The CBS network announces that its documentary program on the motion picture industry will be presented on the air during the week of Sept. 19. The hour-long analysis of the social, economic and artistic aspects of the film business will be entitled "The Hollywood Story."

ATLANTIC CITY, July 26 -- The United States Department of Commerce will initiate within the next thirty days a six-month drive among the nation's industries for scrap iron and steel to build up the country's reserves, which have been seriously depleted as the result of the war, the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., was told here today.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- With his defeat by Freddie Mills tonight beforeh)0*0*0*ia record British crowd went Gus Lesnevich's roseate hopes of fighting Joe Louis in September for the heavyweight crown, with its lucrative rewards.
LEEDS, England, July 26 (Reuters) -- With one day's play remaining in the fourth cricket test match, England has a lead of 400 runs over Australia with two second innings' wickets still to fall.

Consolidated net income of the Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $8,126,554, compared with $3,587,978 in the first half of 1947, the automotive company reported yesterday.

ATHENS, July 26 -- King Paul's refusal last night to accept the resignation of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis has put an end to expectations of an early change of Government. At the same time, the discontent voiced in some quarters against the Sophoulis Cabinet, particularly over the matter of the fixing of basic commodity prices, has not been appeased.

A century ago a child born in the United States might expect to live forty years. By 1900 the figure was fifty years. Now comes the Federal Security Agency with the news that for white females the average expectation of life at birth is 70.3 years and for white males 65.1 years.

The recent letter you printed on ownership of corporations contains, along with some valuable and important observations, this statement: "It is the stockholders and the bondholders who really own corporations. * * *"
CAMDEN, N.J., July. 26 -Agreement on a wage rise of 7 cents an hour for 28,000 production workers in the nine East Coasth)0*0*0*iyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was announced here today.

First disclosure of results of a national survey of steel f.o.b mill pricing methods among steel stamping plant operators, completed during the past month, found management executives divided in their opinions of the effects of elimination of the multiple basing point system of prices, officials of the Pressed Metal Institute revealed here yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 26 -- A far-reaching program to facilitate the peaceful settlement of disputes by the United Nations was approved today by the fifty-two member Little Assembly.

Though promises of "excellent" peace prospects sound highly reassuring, the soothing words of the President and the Secretary of State do not alter the fact that the policy of the Western powers in the German capital, and indeed in all of Germany, is a complete fiasco.
The Russians will take no part of the gigantic air show at New York International Airport at Idlewild, beginning Saturday and running for a week to mark the golden jubilee of the City of New York.

Tippy Larkin, 142 1/2, Garfield, N.J., gained a ten-round decision over Joe Lucignano, 145 1/2, Hoboken, N.J., in the feature bout at the Queensboro Arena before 3,000 fans last night. Johnny Britenbruck, 145 1/2, Brooklyn, beat Joe Martino, 147, Valesburg, N.J., in the six-round semi-final.

For a higher living standard, Ecuador must turn first to United States technicians who can pass on the techniques of production and then to United States capital, Galo Plaza Lasso, President-elect of Ecuador, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation, Rutland, Vt., received today from the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to sell $1,900,000 of first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds, Series E, due 1978, and 2,600,000 shares of common stock.
PEORIA, Ill., July 26 (AP) -Bernie Shelton, member of a Prohibitionera gang that used a tank, a plane and other weapons of a modern army, was shot and killed from ambush today.

LONDON, July 26 -- Thousands of enthusiastic British cricke fans stayed away from the historic Mitcham Grounds in London's suburbs today. This was their good fortune, for it spared them the spectacle of eleven American newswriters, exposed to cricket for the first time, in competition with a rival team of British magazine writers.

The Southern Bell Telephone Company has won almost all of its $3,715,000 rate increase proposal as the result of a seventy-page decision by the Georgia Supreme Court (5 to 2) which reinstated various expenses disallowed by the commission.

Whereas it is essential that there be maintained in the Armed Services of the United States the highest standards of democracy, with equality of treatment andh)0*0*0*iopportunity of all those who serve in our country's defense:

Lippy Leo Durocher should adopt No. 13 as his lucky number from now on. He came back to Ebbets Field last night in an enemy uniform as manager of the Dodgers' most bitter rival, the Giants, and his team romped away with a 13-4 victory in the thirteenth meeting of the two clubs.

Teddy Atkinson was back in form yesterday. The veteran jockey who suffered a fall on Saturday returned to the Saratoga-atJamaica races and rode the winner of the Yellow Hand purse, the feature event on the card. Given the mount on Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Indique, Atkinson guided the horse cleverly in the stretch to beat Earl Sande's Stage Kid by a head in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test.

The Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, announced yesterday that the full backing of the American Federftion of Labor had been promised the association in L its effort to oust left-wing Conigres of Industrial Organizations unions as bargaining agents for New York department store worke, rs.

The semi-annual report of the Phillips Petroleum Company, released today, showed a net profit for the six months ended with June of $36,481,282, more than doubling the $15,459,699 earned in the initial half of 1947.

The stock market placed itself in a neutral corner yesterday to await President Truman's recommendations to the special session of the Congress. After operating within a confined area for the greater part of the session, prices eased off in the final hour, when weakness developed in the steels, oils and rails.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 26 (AP) -Anna Roosevelt Boettiger sold the Arizona Times today to a group of Phoenix men, headed by Columbus Giragi, long-time Arizona publisher and editor, for an undisclosed amount. Mr. Giragi announced that he would take over the newspaper as publisher and editor.

SYRACUSE, July 26 (AP) -- The real enemy of private enterprise in banking is public ignorance of the parts banks play in our democratic banking system, Dr. M. Lyle Spencer, dean of Syracuse University School of Journalism, told some seventy bankers at the opening session of the Bankers School of Public Relations today.
HAMMONTON, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Justice of the Peace Warren N. Murphy held six youths without bail today on charges of arson in connection with fires that caused more than $500,000 worth of damage.

The latest rise in metal products prices may mark the final turning point on inflation because these prices are usually the last to reach their peak during an inflationary period, purchasing executives here declared yesterday following an appraisal of the latest price increases in steel brass, copper products, pig iron, scrap, coke and nickel.

An account of power politics in the White House and warring personalities in wartime has been set for September publication by Harcourt, Brace. It is "The War Lords of Washington," by Bruce Catton, who served as Director ofh)0*0*0*iInformation for the War Production Board under Donald Nelson and later as Director of Information for the Department of Commerce under Henry A. Wallace.

LONDON, July 26 -- Freddie Mills of Britain won the world light heavyweight boxing crown tonight by defeating Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside Park, N.J., the defending champion, on points. The fifteen-round fight at White City Stadium was somewhat disappointing but the result was a sensational upset.

Although the French National Assembly approved Andre Marie as the new Premier by an impressive majority, the difficulties which he finally overcame last night in forming a Cabinet and organizing support for it do not augur well for either its strength or its durability.

Roosevelt saidyesterday that although she didnot agree with Paul Blanshard'sarticles in The Nation deaiinK withthe Roman Catholic Church, shejoined a committee to fight theNew York public school ban onthe magazine because she felt thatcritical material should be madeavailable to pupils.
LONDON, July 26 -- The new brickred running track in Wembley Stadium is being watered down and rolled continually in preparation for the opening for the games of the XIV Olympiad Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -The "texts of President Truman's executive orders governing fair employment practices within the Federal establishment and setting up a committee on equality of treatment and opportunity in the armed services:
LONDON, July 26 -- Experiments with somber Victorian colors and the subtle use of seams and panels has distinguished the London haute couture collections, which opened today.

LONDON, July 26 -- Brighter conditions prevailed in most sections of the Stock Exchange today, when a general broadening of inquiry was reported. Greater hopefulness of dealers concerning the Berlin situation helped sentiment along and there were fewer sellers.

ITHACA N.Y., July 26 -- Extension of old age and survivors insurance (Social Security) to the two-fifths of the working force of the country now excluded from these benefits was called for today by Dean W. I. Myers of the New York State College of Agriculture, Cornell University.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Congressional skirmishing over the blame for the high cost of living and the housing shortage broke out between the Republicans and the Democrats today, virtually immediately after the opening prayers had marked the convening of the recalled Congress.
SINGAPORE, July 26 -- British Army reinforcements for Malaya will move soon from Britain and Hong Kong to strengthen British forces fighting Communist guerrillas in the Malay Peninsula.

The All-American Football Conference will engage in a fifty-sixgame schedule which will be inaugurated Friday night, Aug. 27, according to the list of dates announced yesterday by Admiral Jonas H. Ingram, commissioner of the circuit.

JARRETTSVILLE, Md., July 26 (AP) -- Dr. James A. Gross, veterinarian and owner of a horse that banged into the rail killing a jockey at the Cumberland, Md., race track Saturday, said today the horse was blind in one eye "but there was nothing wrong with the other one as far as i know."
Of the weird things that streaked, flared, turned, floated and tumbled in Eastern seaboard skies over the week-end and yesterday, one has been identified and removed from "flying saucer" mythology.

The first of the Casco Bay tuna to be taken on rod and reel were brought in the other day, scaling 600 and 450 pounds each, resulting in an up-surge of entries in the Maine tuna tournament, which will be held out of Boothbay Harbor Aug. 11 to 14.

If a painting is good art it will enhance any kind of room regardless of whether the artist's approach is nonobjective or highly representational, Doris Rosenthal told an audience of homemakers at the home-planning forum held yesterday afternoon at Abraham Straus.
The last-place Chicago White Sox have obtained Randy Gumpert, veteran 30-year-old right-handed pitcher on waivers from the New York Yankees, it was announced yesterday.
The American Export Lines announced yesterday that its new fortnightly passenger service in the New York-Mediterranean route would open on Sept. 21, with the departure of the steamship Excalibur.

Chief Judge John T. Loughran of the Court of Appeals has rejected an application to stay the electrocution of three men for the fatal shooting of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, in the hallway of his home, 61 Grove Street, on Jan. 8, 1947, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, July 26 -- The United States today warned countries planning extensive programs of economic development that they must look to private capital for most of the financing they expect from outside their own borders.

Recognizing an early response to fall dresses in specialty shops throughout the country, chain operators are stepping up their orders for August deliveries, it was learned yesterday. Faced with a distribution problem that involves a greater amount of handling owing to limited purchases, chain store buyers are seeking to assure a maximum of early deliveries on the numbers that appear to be slated for outstanding consumer acceptance.

ATHENS, July 26 -- United States foreign policy in the Middle East, which is still in an infantile state, faces the necessity of careful reconsideration and recasting as a result of the Palestine war and the de facto establishment of the independent state of Israel.

A young Cuban who told the police he had supported himself for the last two years by committing burglaries in the midtown area of the East Side -- sufficiently well to own a 1949 Lincoln sedan -- was under arrest last night on charges of burglary and possession of burglar's tools.

The 13,000 volume library of the Horace Mann-Lincoln School of Columbia University's Teachers College was bought at auction yesterday for $5,100 by the Experimental School, Inc. This was incorporated by parents of Horace Mann-Lincoln pupils after an unsuccessful two-year struggle to prevent the closing of the institution at 425 West 123d Street.

PARIS, July 26 -- After a three-hour talk today with Paul G. Hoffman, United States Economic Cooperation Administrator, Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced that they had agreed upon a joint undertaking to improve British methods of industrial production by utilizing United States technical advice.

Shortly after noon today the President will read his opening message of the special session of the Eightieth Congress before a joint meeting of the two Houses. It seems to be generally accepted that, while Mr. Truman will recommend legislation on a number of items that Congress did not get around to in the regular session, he will lay greatest stress on the subject of prices and living costs.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 26 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, which will wind up a special conference on Latin-American nutrition Wednesday, looked today to quinoa, an ancient plant considered as sacred by the Incas, as a possible supplementary food in the Hemisphere to combat malnutrition.

GENEVA, July 26 (Reuters) -Russia has rejected the three international conventions drawn up here last April by the fifty-fivenation Conference on Freedom of Information, the United Nations announced here today.

LONDON, July 26 -- Sir Stafford's announcement of plans for a United States-British advisory industrial council was received with surprise here tonight by United States and British officials and business men who had followed the recovery program.
ROME, July 26 (AP) -- Italy's labor forces split into two hostile camps today. The largest bloc is Communistcontrolled; the second has Catholic and Government party backing.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 26 (AP) -- William Green, president of the AFL, said today he had no hope that the Eightieth Congress, in its extra session, would redeem a record of "black reaction."

Price increases on new cars delivered in this city ranging from $151 to $206 were announced here yesterday by the Buick Motor division of General Motors Corporation. These were in accordance with the rise of 8 per cent that went into effect on all GM passenger units at the factory.
Henry A. Wallace. Progressive party nominee for President, arrived unnoticed by the crowds in Pennsylvania Station at 3:38 P.M. yesterday on a train from Philadelphia.
IRT trains all over town operated yesterday as though they were recovering from a week-end hangover.
A National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges of unfair labor practices on the part of the American Radio Association, CIO, is scheduled to open at 10 o'clock this morning at 2 Park Avenue.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. R. July 26 -- The combination of Dr. E. J. Kempf of the Shinnicock Club and Jack Mallon of the Cold Spring golf club shot a 31, 32 -63, nine strokes under par, to win the weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Rockville club today.

LONDON, July 26 (UP) -- The Gus Lesnevich-Freddie Mills fight crowd, which included many prominent Americans in London for the Olympic Games, was apparently the largest to witness a bout anywhere in the world for seven years. It was Great Britain's first big outdoor fight show since before the war.

Delays up to two and one-half hours on passenger trains between New York and Philadelphia were reported by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company yesterday afternoon and last evening, as a result of an overhead fire at Eddington, Pa.

GENEVA, July 26 -- A new postwar high daily output in the Ruhr and an upsurge of United States exports were features of Europe's coal picture during June, the Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
PARIS, July 26 -- The Paris police today arrested a French reporter who wrote of an interview with "Pierrot le Fou" -- Pierrot the Madman -- France's public enemy No. 1.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday with final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange 10 to 16 points net lower.

NANKING, July 26 -- A growing defeatism in Nanking, springingh)0*0*0*ifrom accelerated currency depreciation and continuing military setbacks, has given China's capital its gloomiest political atmosphere since the Government returned here from Chungking in May, 1946.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Eightieth Congress returned to work today in response to the July 15 call of President Truman. It did not come back happily. The first flashes of smiling greetings on reassembly soon wore off.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -The National Boxing Association today allowed a one-week postponement of the Ezzard CharlesJimmy Bivins heavyweight boxing match. The request for a postponement was made by Charles, a ranking contender for the title vacated by Joe Louis.

Streams of high-energy electrons are sprayed on natural foods to kill germs without heating in a new and effective method of food processing described in the July issue of the Journal of Applied Physics, published yesterday.
WASHINGTON July 26 (AP) -Younger men will not have long to wait for the draft even if the "oldsters" of 23 through 25 are taken first, according to statements by officials tonight.

The housing shortage here will ease appreciably in the next year, but earnest efforts on the part of Government, financiers and builders are necessary if the improvement is to continue. This is the consensus of experts, including Robert Moses, who see the situation from a variety of viewpoints.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Southerners took up today a position of entrenched desperation against the so-called civil-rights program in the resumed Congress.

The management of the Globe yesterday reported that "Escape," the Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the John Galsworthy story, starring Rex Harrison and Peggy Cummins, will not open on Saturday as previously scheduled. Instead, "Four Faces West," a Western drama with Joel McCrea, will open at the Globe next Tuesday after the run of the present tenant, "Deep Waters."

CHICAGO, July 26 -- May wheat, September and May corn and all deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal low prices on the Board of Trade today, closing well toward the bottom. Wheat lost 1/2 to 2 cents, May leading. Corn was down 2 to 2 3/8 cents and oats lost 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- In spite of frequent warnings from the rostrum, quibbling over rules technicalities and other minor matters so delayed the founding convention of the Young Progressives of America that it passed into history late today without a platform or passing upon several resolutions.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- As the big farm machinery companies in America grew to their present stature through acquisitions and mergers, the number of smaller manufacturers in the same field "steadily declined," the Federal Trade Commission said today.

ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE. Md., July 26 -- A quartet of Great Britain's Royal Air Force pilots impressed an audience of both hard-bitten fliers and wide-eyed groundlings here today with a spectacular flight display of the RAF's handsome little De Haviland jet fighter plane, the Vampire.

The choice on Washington Square is between towering apartment blocks fifteen stories high and university buildings of four to six stories in height. This situation seems to be lost sight of by certain groups which are trying to thwart the plans of New York University.

Wage and contract discussions involving the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association, and also the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators, will be resumed here today.

The American Flange and Manufacturing Company of New York has purchased the plant formerly occupied by the Triangle Thread Mill Company on West Blancke Street in Linden, N.J., from the Rothblum Realty Company of New York City. The purchase price was reported as $332,500.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Truman made a sacrifice in convening the extra session of Congress in that his own campaign was thereby slowed down, Mrs. India Edwards, director of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, declared today.
BERLIN, July 26 -- All international railway traffic to and from the Soviet zone through the Western zones of Germany was halted today by order of the United States and British Military Governments.
BANGKOK, Slam, July 25 (Delayed) -- An uneasy combination of military and political cliques rules the future of Field Marshal Luang Pibul Songgram's Government here.

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, despite a unanimous recommendation by their officers, have voted to reject a proposed contract with the Publishers Association of New York City, the union announced yesterday.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., July 26 -This community of 8,000 inhabitants is up in arms over the proposal of the New Jersey State Highway Department to build Route 100 through the town's center. The road literally would cut the community in half and put 300 families out of their homes and apartments through condemnation proceedings.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 26 -Repeal by Congress of the "unfair" excise war tax on liquor was advocated here today by John J. Bradley of Atlanta, president of the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, at the opening of a three-day national convention.
PARIS, Tuesday, July 27 -- Andre Marie, invested as Premier of France since Saturday, announced his Cabinet early today, just after midnight, after a final conference with President Vincent Auriol.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 -- Following an all-day mediation session, representatives of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and the Telephone Workers Union of New Jersey decided tonight to refer all unresolved issues affecting employment of the company's 4,600 plant workers to a five-man arbitration board.

ZURICH, July 26 -- Addressing the Diet of Baden on Friday, Finance Minister Dr. Eckert expressed alarm at the news that in neighboring countries quotation on the new Deutsche mark, first issued on June 20 in Western Germany as a stable currency, continued falling rapidly.

Retail coffee prices may go up if proposed August freight rate increases asked by steamship lines are granted, trade leaders warned here yesterday. The steamship companies have asked that the 10 per cent surtax now being charged in addition to the base rate be eliminated and a general increase of the base rate "slightly in excess of 10 per cent," varying according to the port of embarkation, be made.
TEL AVIV. Israel, July 26 -- The New City in Jerusalem, with a population of 100,000 Jews, has been declared Israeli-occupied territory.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 3 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 26 -Otis Hanover, a 2-year-old colt byh)0*0*0*iBilly Direct, Miss Betty by Volomite, owned by Elisha P. Parker of Salisbury, Md., and driven by Johnny Simpson, won the first division of the Village Farm Stake No. 14 for pacers for a divided purse of $21,487.50 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- Seventeen Los Angeles County employes tonight were discharged for refusing to subscribe to a "loyalty oath" affidavit disclaiming past or present activities alleged to be "subversive."

The City of New York cannot surrender its waterfront to the management of any non-city agency, because the city charter requires that its waterfront facilities be operated by the Department of Marine and Aviation, according to The Civil Service Forum.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Truman ordered today the end of discrimination in the armed forces "as rapidly as possible" and instituted a fair employment practices policy throughout the civil branch of the Federal Government.
Ben Oppenheim has been appointed manager of the radio electronic parts department of KrichRadisco, Inc., Newark.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 -Edgar J. Rich of Winchester, Mass., a prominent Boston lawyer, has left a large share of his estate to "bring about better relations between the North and the South." This was disclosed today when the will was filed in the Middlesex County Probate Court here.
You state in your editorial of July 19 that the Provisional Government of Israel was officially recognized by the Security Council. That is not true.

Communist influence in the American merchant marine suffered a crushing setback last night as official announcement was made that right-wing candidates had swept all offices in a three-month election among 60,000 members of the National Maritime Union, CIO.

Restoration of the competitive relationship between eastern and southern ports in the shipment of export iron and steel was urged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority in a brief filed in Washington with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Eastern Steel Tank Corporation has purchased a tract of two and one-half acres on Flushing Creek in Queens from the J. P. Duffy Company for improvement with a large one-story tank manufacturing plant. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker and title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -Coal has been losing ground to other fuels in industry as well as in home heating, and has been knocked from its once dominant position as a source of energy, the Department of Commerce said tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Philadelphia Company, Pittsburgh, asked the United States Court of Appeals today to dismiss an order handed down by the Securities and Exchange Commission directing the company to divest itself of its gas and transportation properties and dissolve.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 26 -- The MinisterPresidents of Western Germany formally accepted today the responsibility of initiating a Government for the eleven states of non-Soviet Germany, and agreed with the United States, British and French Military Governors to begin their task at once.

For years past now, first one skyscraper and then another -- still on paper -has threatened Washington Square's place in the sun. And the shadows cast before have stirred up defenders of things as they are in a quarter where things are not as they used to be, but one which is, nevertheless, cherished not entirely for the sake of a more glorious past.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 27 -- The Korean National Assembly this morning rejected by a 132-to59 vote President Syngman Rhee's choice for Prime Minister.

MANILA, July 26 -- The Philippine Government is disappointed and worried, but not yet finally discouraged, over the negligible response of "Supreme Commander" Luis Taruc and his Hukbalahaps [peasant rebels]. They have not yet complied with the agreed amnesty requirements, including registration and the surrender of firearms.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 26 (AP) -- Pennsylvanians will have a chance next month, for a $5 initial charge, to connect up their automatic voice recorder with the telephone and make a record of phone conversations. But they will have to "beep" before making the records.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -The Phillies reached out into their farm system today and moved up Eddie Sawyer to take over the reins as manager.

A net gain of $78,534,984, or 9 per cent, in savings investments during the first half of 1948 was reported yesterday by the New York State Savings and Loan Associations.
