This compared with a net increase of $60,765,085, or 7.8 per cent, for the six months through June, 1947, and an increase of $56,427,684, or 8.8 per cent for the like 1946 period.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 26 -- A spokesman for the Israeli delegation to the United Nations said today that the conditions laid down by the Arab League for the demilitarization of Jerusalem "are so absurd that they will not even provide a basis for discussion."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 26 -- The last phase of United Nations disarmament work -- the negotiations in the Commission on Conventional Armaments -- was abandoned today and the whole arms reduction controversy made ready for full debate in the General Assembly.

VIENNA, July 26 -- Both the minimum and maximum Austrian Government proposals for aid under the European Recovery Program, which have been taken to Paris for consideration by the sixteen nations, were criticized sharply here before Foreign Minister Karl Gruber departed.

LONDON, July 26 -- The British Government is prepared to surrender to Belgrade nineteen Yugoslav collaborators with the Nazis, C.P. Mayhew, parliamentary UnderSecretary, of State for the foreign office, announced in the House of Commons today.
The New York County Lawyers Association has set up a fund to aid needy lawyers and promote the sound administration of justice, it was announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 -- Edvard, J. Kardlji, Vice Premier and Marshal Tito's chief planner, announced at today's session of the fifth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party that the Yugoslav Government would continue to support the Soviet Union's foreign policy against the "imperialist powers."
Bretaigne Windust, one of Broadway's most successful directors, will return from a year in Hollywood to direct Maxwell Anderson's new play, "Anne of the Thousand Days," it was learned yesterday.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad will have a deficit of $3,613,801 from this year's passenger operations, L. V. Sullivan, the road's controller, estimated yesterday. At an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn, Mr. Sullivan said that the anticipated deficit would be the highest for any peacetime year.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) -- The Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a veteran's right to return to a union job with the same seniority ranking held when he left for war, despite union contract changes made in his absence.

By a vote of nine to two the working committee of the United Nations. Commission for Conventional Armaments approved yesterday a British-American resolution declaring that peace must be concluded with Germany and Japan before armaments can be controlled effectively.

Tammany Hall was making a final bid last night to obtain the support of the American Labor party for John A. Mullen, the compromise Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County. Its efforts were meeting no immediate success, and the prospects were that the move would end in failure.

As retail meat prices continued high yesterday, with little promise of any marked reductions in the next six to eight months, sharp differences over renewing rationing and price controls arose in the industry. Meanwhile, milk price advances of 1 cent a quart, scheduled here for Aug. 1, and a similar increase on Oct. 1, received official sanction of the Department of Agriculture in Washington.

Ease rather than fine flavor sometimes seems to be the criterion of good cookery nowadays. "How does it taste?" becomes secondary to "Is it hard to prepare?" This interest in simplification results in all manner of manufactured short cuts -- some delicious as well as quick, some just quick.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 26 -- In its sharpest comment on Dutch policy in the East Indies, the United Nations Committee of Good Offices reported today that the Netherland blockade was preventing the economic rehabilitation of the Republic of Indonesia.

LONDON, July 26 -- The Olympic track and field athletes in training at Uxbridge Stadium turned in some notably good performances today, indicating they were nearing the peak of form 72 hours before King George officially declares the games of the XIV Olympiad open in ceremonies at Wembley Stadium.

The D.W. May Corporation, appliance and television distributors, has virtually eliminated New York City from its area of operations in order to concentrate its activities in northern New Jersey, D. W. May, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board today set aside an election because of an unlawful anti-union course of conduct by the employer.

The Port of New York Authority sold yesterday a new issue of $7,500,000 refunding bonds maturing July 15 from 1949 to 1953 at an interest cost of 1.393,per cent. Proceeds of the sale will be used to help retire $14,186,000 of 2 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1973, which will be called for redemption Sept. 1 at 103.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Administration proposal to expand benefits under the old-age and survivors insurance system was placed before Congress today in a bill by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat, of Michigan.

Members of the tremendously successful "Annie Get Your Gun," a tenant of the Imperial since May 16, 1946, were taken back by the import of what they read on the call board Monday night. A notice, signed by Maurice Winters, manager of the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d offering, said in part:

A new idea for a radiator cover that not only does a good job of concealment but is attractive in its own right is displayed at the decorating shop of F.B. Arthur, which opened yesterday at 1027 First Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street.

A combined tennis team, representing England's Oxford and Cambridge Universities, bowed, 4 -- 2, to the International Lawn Tennis Club of the United States yesterday at the West Side Club in Forest Hills.

ROSLYN, L. I., July 27 -- Howard Wheeler of Philadelphia, the open champion of the United Golf Association, led the professional field during the first day of the 72-hole competition in the Ray Robinson open today at the Engineers Golf Club with a 39, 34 -- 73 card.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 -- One of the most pretentious theatrical undertakings in many months had its world premiere last night in the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera presentation of "Magdalena," a lavish operetta featuring the music of the eminent Brazilian composer, Heitor Villa-Lobos.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Federal Trade Commission appealed again today to Congress to amend American patent laws to make impossible "undue control" of patents originating in this country and American rights acquired under foreign patents.
In your editorial of July 21 on the stock market you call attention to the big increase in corporate earnings compared to the smaller rise in stock prices.

The National Maritime Union and a negotiating committee for shipping operators will resume negotiations today under the auspices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service. The union contract expired in June, and a proposed strike that would have paralyzed domestic shipping was restrained by Federal injunction.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The United States Air Force supplied an official explanation today for the absence of observers from the Soviet Union and satellite governments at the Royal Air Force jet fighter demonstration yesterday.

The Democratic National Committee was in the process yesterday of quietly opening campaign headquarters here. It started on Monday the task of moving telephones, desks, typewriters and teletype machines into a fifty-room set-up on the fourth floor of the Biltmore Hotel.

NANKING, July 27 -- Ambassador John Leighton Stuart said today that he had been authorized by Secretary Marshall to "deny emphatically" that the United States was considering a separate peace treaty with Japan.
The test of President Truman's message to Congress yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

LEEDS, England, July 27 (Reuters) -- The Australians beat England by seven wickets in the fourth of the season's test cricket matches today when they scored 404 runs in their second innings for the loss of only three wickets. The Australians now lead by three matches in the series of five.

Reports from the week-end fishing at Martha's Vineyard indicate that those who put off their trip there due to reports on cold water should have done better to use their big toe rather than a thermometer, for surfcasters had excellent luck at several beaches.
A twin-edged hoodoo was riding against the Giants last night at the Polo Grounds. But, with Leo Durocher at the helm, the Harlem clubbers have acquired the knack of overcoming even superstition.

LONDON -- You couldn't overlook him in any gathering. Of distinguished bearing and straight as an arrow to the height of six feet, Ralph Craig is one of the most interesting figures of the thousands of athletes gathered here from sixty-two nations for the games of the Modern XIV Olympiad. He is the man singled out for the high honor of carrying the American standard in the opening day ceremonies at Wembley, July 29.
KANSAS CITY, July 27 (AP) -- A new grain crisis arose here today -- the volume of wheat in boxcars awaiting unloading exceeded the remaining elevator storage space.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 (AP) -- Irvin Dorfman of New York, today scored a bitterly contested victory over young Dick Gonzales in the second round of the sixtieth annual Seabright Tennis and Cricket Club invitation tourney which saw three seeded contestants advance with little difficulty.

Prices on spring lines of worsteds and woolens that are expected to open in the next week or two will reflect the increased cost of fine wools and higher labor rates only to a very limited extent, it was predicted in the trade yesterday.

A heavy guard of New York police will protect President Truman and everything about him when he comes here Saturday to take the review of the Air Force and the naval air arm and to dedicate New York International Airport at Idlewild.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Egyptian Government has been asked for an early report on the recent killing in Cairo of Stephen Haas of Philadelphia. The request was made in a note delivered by Jefferson Patterson, the United States charge d'affaires in Cairo, the State Department announced today.

Melio Bettina, 192 1/2 pounds, Beacon, N.Y., former world light heavyweight champion, won his fourth straight victory in his comeback campaign by halting Jimmy (Shamus) O'Brien, 178 1/2, Harlem, in the fourth round of the scheduled ten-round feature at MacArthur Stadium in Brooklyn last night.

LONDON, July 27 -- The London stock markets lost much of their recent cheerfulness today and issues in most sections remainded dull. Leading industrials were a few pence easier at the start but changes were small. Gilt-edged stocks, however, were firm.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Legislation to implement President Truman's call for greater and more equitable assistance to displaced persons seeking a permanent home in the United States was introduced today within a few minutes after he addressed Congress.

The City Board of Standards and Appeals ruled yesterday that the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children could occupy the building at 110 East Seventy-first Street, and use it for offices.

The American Labor party all but closed the door to Democratic success at the polls in November, as far as electing a Surrogate of New York County is concerned, when it filed with the Board of Elections yesterday its own candidate, O. John Rogge, for that office.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 27 (AP) -- Remington Rand, Inc., reported to stockholders today that increased labor, material and other operating costs accounted for a drop in earnings in the quarter ended on June 30.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., July 27 -- A best-ball card of 29, 33 -- 62, nine under par, won top honors for the Glen Castle pro-amateur team of Pat Tiso and Hi Pilot in a one-day tournament today at the Leewood Golf Club course. The Westchester County Golf Association staged the event, in which fifty-three pairs competed.

Jack Kaplan, import and export executive, has purchased for occupancy the Hewlett Estates Normandie-style home of eight rooms and two baths at 6 Talfor Circle, adjoining Hewlett Bay Park in East Rockaway, L.I. The house is in the second group of twenty-five being erected by Arthur Bandes, builder, on a portion of the eighteen-acre former Tameling estate.

The institution of price controls at this time without similar restrictions on wage increases and transportation rate rises "would be disastrous" for the nation's industry, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.

The United States Air Force is climbing back into the "major league class," Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer declared yesterday at the thirty-first annual convention of the International Association of Lions Clubs.
Along with higher milk prices to rise a cent a quart on Sunday housewives will find increases is the cost of cream for morning coffee and for topping summer short cakes, it was announced yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 -- Israeli army "veterans" paraded today in a unique military demonstration on the forty-fourth anniversary of the death of Dr. Theodor Herzl, founder of modern Zionism.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 27 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice said today he considered it his duty to switch custody of a child if it were proved the child "is being reared under communistic influences.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Within seven hours after President Truman delivered his message today to the Congress he had called back to work on a multi-point plan for legislative action on inflation, housing, educational facilities and other matters, almost the whole of his program was thrown back into his face by the Congressional Republican high command.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 27 (AP) -- A 26-year-old Air Force veteran from Hartford, Conn., was found bound and gagged in a hotel room here today. The police sent out an eight-state alarm for two men they said had brought the man here at gunpoint from his home.
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The favored American team drew Switzerland today as its first opponent in the Olympic basketball tournament.

Hearing of a National Labor Relations Board complaint of unfair labor practices against the American Radio Association, CIO, opened yesterday morning in the board's regional office, 2 Park Avenue, before trial examiner Wallace E. Royster, who last week completed hearing of a similar case against the National Maritime Union, CIO.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- Nelson Potter, the American League discard, held the Pirates to six scattered hits and knocked in the winning run as the top-place Braves opened a 20-game home stand with a 5-1 victory tonight before a crowd of 29,031.

The granting of a seven-cent fare to private bus lines moved a step nearer yesterday when it was reliably reported that Controller Lazarus Joseph had agreed to this recommendation of Mayor O'Dwyer's special five-man committee, headed by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

PEIPING, July 27 -- The arrival in Peiping today of Roger D. Lapham, China chief of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, coincides with growing protests over alleged discrimination by the Central Government against North China.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Richard L. Hanna, Philadelphia, Pa., a trainer of thoroughbred running horses, today was suspended for life by the Illinois Racing Board. The board said he inhumanely beat two thoroughbreds with a chain on the training track at Arlington Park during the early morning workout period July 20.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- An upward trend in fish consumption in the last eighteen years was reported today by the Department of Agriculture in its first comprehensive study of the supply and distribution of commercial fishery products.

As a result of their numerous conferences, the Western Powers now appear to have agreed on a joint strategy for meeting Russian aggression. This strategy is still subject to approval by the Western Governments, in particular the new Government of France. But approval is believed to be assured, and parts of the new strategy are already being put into effect.

The cutting of prices for over-valued merchandise is as old as investment banking syndicating, but new wrinkles are developing in the practice as a consequence of deadline bidding in an uncertain or declining bond market. During this year and last it has happened repeatedly that the winning bidder was compelled to reprice the merchandise before public offering, instead of thereafter, as had hitherto been the most common practice.

A nation-wide unified movement to oppose local prohibtion and "taxes oppressive to the liquor industry" will be started early this fall by the Associated Tavern Owners of America, an association representing 15,000 taverns in twelve Middle Western and Eastern states.
SEOUL, Korea, July 27 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, in a 3,000-word statement today castigated Korean Communists and "their masters."
The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $44,295,509 after charges and taxes, equal to $3.70 a share on the outstanding stock.
TOKYO, July 27 -- The Japanese Government decided today to give immediate effect to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's ban on strikes of public employes.

Seeking to apply a recent United States Supreme Court decision, two parents have brought suit in Brooklyn Supreme Court against the Board of Education and the State Education Commissioner to end released-time religious instruction in the New York public schools.

PRAGUE, July 27 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny and Valdimir Cernik won their opening singles matches today to give Czechoslovakia a 2-0 lead over Sweden in the final of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Republican Congressional leaders began a strong attack tonight on angry Southerners over the civil rights issue. They demanded, as the first "must" of the extra session, Senate action on a poll-tax repealer already approved by the House.

Reports from the meat, butter and egg markets may tell glumly of limited supplies and high prices, but from the Fulton Fish Market comes news that is cheering. This is the season for shellfish. Lobsters, clams, soft-shell crabs and shrimp all are here in abundance.
GENEVA, July 27 -- The United States is among the sponsors of a move for new multilateral tariff negotiations to revise and expand the Geneva Tariff Agreement of 1947, it was learned here today.
BANGKOK, Siam, July 26 (Delayed) -- Siam has become an important center of post-war United States economic activity and political interest.

In anticipation of an early revival of shipbuilding in Japan under the auspices of the United States Government, the American Bureau of Shipping plans to send a technical surveyor to that country to provide on-the-spot approval of the designs submitted, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the bureau, said yesterday.

PARIS, July 27 -- Premier Andre Marie's Cabinet assumed office today, and in the National Assembly obtained the shelving of a motion for interpellations on the Cabinet membership and program. The vote was 357 to 197, giving the Government five more ballots than M. Marie obtained for his investiture last Saturday.

American citizens of West Indian origin were asked yesterday to aid the island peoples, who face varying degrees of food hardship brought on by post-war economic conditions made acute by the dollar crisis in British affairs.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Illinois borrowed yesterday $50,000,000 on thirty-year first mortgage 3 per cent bonds at an interest cost of about 2.9676 per cent. The bond issue was sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate of seventy-six underwriting houses headed by The First Boston Corporation.
The Western Electric Company assured representatives of 30,000 unionized telephone installation workers yesterday that it would be ready to make a wage offer by the end of August.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 27 -- A plea for strong legislation to permit prosecution of Communist espionage agents and known Communist conspiracies was made today by Louis F. Budenz, former Communist leader, before 118 members of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police.

Eight employes of The New Republic, 40 East Forty-ninth Street, received notice from the magazine yesterday that their services would be terminated in four weeks for reasons of "economy." They include two writers, four researchers, a promotion department worker and a typist.

Six firemen and two fire patrol members were injured early yesterday when flames, accompanied by unusually dense smoke, swept the upper two floors of the six story loft building at 191 Chrystie Street. Four alarms drew a heavy concentration of fire-fighting apparatus to the Scene.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Speculation as to what studio would be first to get James Mason for a Hollywood picture was ended today when Enterprise Pictures announced that it had signed the British star for a role in "The Best Things in Life Are Free."
The late William Nelson Cromwell, whose will was filed for probate on Monday, was the latest of several score public-spirited citizens to donate large fortunes toward the common good in recent years.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to June 30 rose $2,968,870 to $34,590,726, while for the three months to that date net income declined $1,579,010 from the $8,160,854 reported in the comparable 1947 period.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, promised today that the committee would "review the entire situation" involving the proposed International Wheat Treaty which President Truman insisted today the Senate should ratify.

Boston, Mass., borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes dated July 30 and due Nov. 10 at a bid of 1.09 per cent interest plus $62. The winning bid was submitted by Halsey, Stuart, Co., Inc. The notes were re-offered at a price to yield 1 per cent.
George E. Athana has rejoined York-Shipley, Inc., as sales manager of the New York territory.

Twenty-five girls and boys, 5 to 14 years old, were initiated yesterday as members of the Junior Park Patrol for the "sit-in" park at Austin Street and Seventy-sixth Road, Forest Hills, Queens. The group is believed to be the first children's organization here to assume monitor duties in a public recreation ground.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Allocation to the states of $58,800,000 in school lunch funds, about $5,000,000 more than last year, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

PARIS, July 27 (Reuters) -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, spent three hours this morning tramping over wheat fields and examining equipment on a "Marshall Plan in Action" visit to two French farms, at Charmy, twenty miles from Paris.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 27 (UP) -- Eugenio Castillo, United Nations observer at the Grand Colombia Economic Conference, said today that if Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama succeeded in setting up an economic entity, the United Nations would give its full support.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 27 -- A great industrial migration -- the removal of an aircraft factory from this town to Dallas, Tex. -- has been started quietly by the Chance Vought Division of the United Aircraft Corporation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 (UP) -- Five British employes of a Jerusalem company were charged before a Tel Aviv magistrate today with espionage and were ordered held for fifteen days with the promise of release if evidence was not produced.

American Negroes and Negroes throughout the world owe a debt of deep gratitude to Mayor Hubert Humphrey Jr. of Minneapolis, former Gov. Maurice Tobin of Massachusetts, Representative Anthony J. Biemiller of Wisconsin and Mrs. Esther Murray of California for their unremitting fight on the floor of the Democratic convention in Philadelphia for the adoption of the minority report of the platform committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 27 -- The United States and nine smaller nations joined today in supporting the continuance of the Soviet-boycotted Little Assembly for another year, and also in denying an Indian claim that this action would "widen political differences" between the powers.

Visiting buyers registered in the market in the week ended yesterday numbered 1,025, compared with 1,494 last week and 1,091 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 396 arrivals yesterday, against 663 last Tuesday.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The exclusion of an Italian Communist newspaper man sent to cover the Olympic games and the withdrawal of the Rumanian team raised complications today for officials of the games.

After spending a night in jail, J. DeWitt Acker, 51-year-old real estate broker of 121 Madison Avenue, was brought into Downtown Traffic Court yesterday and fined $182 on sixteen parking charges. These involved summonses issued from December of last year to July 22.

President Truman, Secretary Marshall, General Clay and other officials who took part in last week's Washington parleys on the situation in Germany emerged with statements that the chances of peace are "excellent." Talk of forcing open the land route to Berlin suddenly gave place to talk of resuming Four-Power negotiations on the whole German question.

LONDON, July 27 -- While judges and administrative officials went through a rehearsal at Wembley Stadium today for Thursday's opening of the Games of the XIV Olympiad, practice fields at Uxbridge Village and other training camps were crowded with athletes from the United States and other nations.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The text of a statement by Republicans declaring that they would complete the current session of Congress "as soon as possible" follows:

Along with inflation, President Truman identified housing as the second major problem that prompted him to summon Congress -- and then tossed in a small hatful of other matters on which he thinks the returning legislators ought to be able to take action even within "the limited time of this special session."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Political interest was attracted today to the tentative platform of the Communist Party of the United States, which will be considered at the national convention in New York City beginning next Tuesday. This platform, party documents show, is similar in thought, and virtually parallel in language, with that adopted by the Progressive Party, which had its founding convention in Philadelphia last week.

DETROIT, July 27 (AP) -- The rampaging Red Sox ran their winning streak to thirteen straight games tonight by blanking the Tigers, 8 to 0, on Ellis Kinder's three-hit pitching. Hal Newhouser gave up the first three Boston runs before departing in the third inning with a sore arm.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 27 -- The omen's Metropolitan Golf Association came up with a novel tournament today. It was a match against par, using 85 per cent of the contestant's handicap, and attracted a large field to the Duncodie Golf Club course

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The draft will begin with the 25-year-olds and work down through the ranks of the younger men in the order of their registration, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today.

BERLIN, July 27 -- After issuing a veiled threat that it sought the dissolution of the elected City Council, the Soviet Military Administration today advanced its plans for the establishment of a Berlin puppet government.
Brazil is cutting its unfavorable trade balance with the United States as a result of its new trade control laws that went into effect on May 7, it was reported here yesterday.

Sales of five residential properties in the Woodcliff and Racetrack sections of North Bergen, N.J., are reported by J.I. Kislak, Inc. Earnest Mosman, president of the New Jersey Embroidery Manufacturers Association, purchased the dwelling at 8806 Fifth Avenue from Herman Lampert.

David S. Meister bought the six-story business building at 36 West Thirty-eighth Street from the World Wide Importers, Inc., through the Cross Brown Company, broker. The property occupies a plot 21 by 98.9 feet in the block between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 27 -- The establishment of sound training in human relations in the schools and colleges of the country was urged today by Dr. Leonard S. Cottrell Jr., new dean of the Arts and Sciences College of Cornell University.

Because Terry Moore, the once peerless centerfielder of the Cardinals, misjudged a line drive, the Dodgers regained second place in the National League standings yesterday at Ebbets Field. Moore, the very last man in the game one would expect to misplay a fly, was completely fooled by Bruce Edwards' ninth - inning blow that turned an apparent 2-1 defeat into a last-gasp 3-2 victory for the Brooks.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 -- The Stamford Yacht Club, with runner-up positions in the morning and afternoon races, scored twenty points to lead a fleet of eleven Lightning Class craft in the first two events of the Commodore Robert Law Trophy junior class regatta today off Indian Harbor Y.C.

LIKE his fellow-Welshman, Owen Glendower, Arthur Machen could have said, "And all the courses of my life do show I am not in the roll of common men." Machen, who died last year at the age of 84, was one of the last of the Victorians, a minor writer who lived all his life in poverty and knew, in his sixties, only one brief flutter of critical admiration.
BERLIN, July 27 (AP) -- The United States Air Force demonstrated its growing air strength to Germans in the American zone today by flying jet fighters over several cities.

Despite a 16 per cent rise in the backlog of orders at the Glenn L. lartin' Compan3f for the first half., of 1948 from $105,000,000 on Dec. 31, 1947, to $122,000,000 on June 30, operations resulted in a net losof $719,034. Last year the company reported a net loss of $19,181,526.

LONDON, July 27 -- The inhabitants of Libya do not want the Italians back as trustees or otherwise, observers of the United States, Britain and France conclude in report made available to interested governments today.

Henry J. Sullivan, a commercial fisherman from Staten Island, is in trouble with the Government. An information filed with the clerk of the United States District Court, Brooklyn, charges him with fishing in Sandy Hook Channel in violation of the River and Harbor Act of 1894.
Friedrich Stampfer, veteran German Social Democrat and for many years editor of the old Berlin Vorwaerts, said yesterday that he planned to return to Germany for good.

An all-Negro variety show, entitled "Swingtime at the Savoy," will have its premiere at 8 o'clock tonight on NBC. The regular cast will include Lucky Millinder and his orchestra, Miller and Lee, comedians; Jackie (Moms) Pabley, comedienne, and the King Odem Quartet.

On a recent working day that was blue for a good many other reasons, including the weather, the Department of Agriculture made a routine announcement. At least, it was an announcement delivered without comment.
ATHENS, July 27 -- King Paul suggested today that if Cyprus, a British crown colony, were united to Greece his country would be prepared to offer bases in Crete or elsewhere.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 27 -- Knight Dream, owned by Armstrong and Gray of East Providence, R.I., swept both heats of the second division of the rich Village Farm Stake No. 13 for 3-year-old pacers before 12,357 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. It was the second night of the Grand Circuit meeting.
Fifty prints selected as outstanding examples in the development of pictorial photography during the past century go on exhibition today in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 27 -- The Netherlands Government denied today that it was operating a naval blockade, choking the economy of the Republic of Indonesia.

Orders for new passenger cars came piling in yesterday despite the price increase of 8 per cent announced by the General Motors Corporation. Telephones in the showrooms along Automobile Row here re-echoed with the familiar query "When wi my auto be in?" and there were only a few reports of cancellations because of the price rise.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 27 (AP) -- Fuller cooperation between bankers and newspaper men was called for today in a panel discussion before seventy bankers attending a one-week school on public relations at Syracuse University. Participating in the panel were George Mooney, banking editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES; William Bennett, banking editor of The New York Herald Tribune, and H.H. Clarke, assistant secretary of the New York State Bankers Association.

Preparatory to the reorganization of the executive branch of the Fire Department, effective Aug. 1, Commissioner Frank J. Quayle swore in a new chief, an assistant chief of staff and seventeen deputies at a brief ceremony yesterday at noon in the headquarters of Engine Company 31, Lafayette and White Streets.

A Negro union official who filed a $50,000 suit against the Southern Railway Company in Federal Court on the ground that members of a train crew had tried to force him to occupy a seat in the Jim Crow section while the train was passing through Virginia has received an out-of-court settlement of $2,000, it was disclosed yesterday.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 27 (AP) -- A Netherland Government spokesman expressed regret today at the latest Western move in the Berlin crisis.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit in the six months ended with last June of $13,836,161, which was $2,508,100 more than the $11,328,061 earned in the corresponding period of last year, Thomas J. Watson, president, reported yesterday.
LIMA, Peru, July 27 (UP) -- Nineteen Right-Wing Senators announced today that they would not attend the regular session of Congress scheduled to convene tomorrow.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 27 -- The regional conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization adopted a series of reports today intended primarily to spur Latin American governments to make the most of their own food resources.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The dispute between Yugoslavia and the Communist Information Bureau turned up for the first time today as a weapon in Western hands in a meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

"Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Universal-International comedy melodrama stars the team of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, with Bela Lugosi, Glenn Strange and Lon Chaney appearing as Dracula, Frankenstein's monster and the Wolf Man, respectively.

The following comments by Republican and Democratic members of Congress and others on the President's message to Congress were reported yesterday by the Associated Press, the United Press and THE NEW YORK TIMES:

In one of the most complex situations to arise under the Taft-Hartley Law, the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board decided yesterday to postpone indefinitely an election that was to have been held tomorrow among 480 employes in the Manhattan and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins Co.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Recent trends in the cost of doing business disclose credit as a necessary stimulant in maintaining sales to offset increased expenses, A.B. Buckeridge, manager of the Retail Credit Bureau of New York, said today.

The college girl is going to be a well-dressed, smart looking individual, according to the togs Russeks Fifth Avenue has assembled for her coming college year. Several hundred young women of college age saw them yesterday afternoon on the seventh floor.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Louis Lazare's Gallant Bull made a great stretch run today to win the featured six-furlong Belmar Purse at Monmouth Park.

PARIS, July 27 -- Paul G. Hoffman will leave Paris for Washington tomorrow night after a six-day visit, which he expects to repeat periodically, to the European headquarters here of the United States Economic Cooperation Administration, of which he is head, and to its counterpart, the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee got rid of one hot potato in a torrid, shirt-sleeved session today and squared away to cope with a second.

LONDON, July 27 -- David Lord Burghley, chairman of the British Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games, denied today reports that his committee was "bankrupt" and declared instead that 450,000 ($1,800,000) of revenue was already "in sight."

The main event at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday took more out of the winning jockey than it did out of the winning charger. Joseph Dushock's Mahmoudess won in a gallop by some five lengths and seemed willing to keep going, but Eddie Arcaro said he was exhausted when he returned to the jockey's quarters.
PRINCETON, Ind., July 27 (AP) -- Thirteen coal miners were killed in an explosion today at King's mine, three miles south of Princeton.

LONDON, July 27 -- Graceful simplicity with touches of interesting detail was the keynote of Molyneux's autumn collection, shown yesterday. It was a sober contrast to the frivolities of his spring fashions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 27 -- The United Nations Security Council today rejected a Syrian resolution under which the Council would have requested the International Court of Justice to give an advisory ruling on the international status of Palestine -- in other words, whether the United Nations had any jurisdiction over the Holy Land following the termination of the British mandate.

The ten-round bout between lightweights Jesse Flores of Stockton, Calif., and Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn, slated for Thursday night, Aug. 5, at Madison Square Garden, has been postponed until Thursday night, Aug. 12.
ATHENS, July 27 -- Fighting described by a military spokesman as "the heaviest and causing the most casualties and sacrifice" was raging tonight at two main points in the Mount Grammos theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Truman faced Congress today in an atmosphere of political conflict to demand action on a legislative program of eleven elements, topped off by a new anti-inflation plan and a low-cost housing proposal.
Much interest was centered in collars that fitted high about the throat in the Arnheimer retail and wholesale showing of furs presented yesterday at 345 Seventh Avenue.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- Grain prices were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, wheat losing 1/2 cent to 1 1/8 cents after showing moderate strength early.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Employment, excluding farm workers, totaled 44,900,000 at mid-June, record high level for the season, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor announced today.

Charging that the Sword Line, Inc., of 52 Wall Street had failed to pay charter hire exceeding $2,000,000 and was otherwise in default, the Maritime Commission served notice yesterday that it had terminated the company's fleet charter.

The stock market developed a stronger appearance yesterday after President Truman delivered his special message to the Congress with a rally in the final hour which raised the price average slightly more than a point. However, financial circles did not attach particular significance to the late upturn in relation to the White House demand for wage-price controls, rationing and an excess profits tax.

Roosevelt Hospital poured its manpower and medical resources into the first portrayal yesterday of its newly organized peacetime disaster unit. Set up to cope with civilian catastrophes, the disaster section, said to be the only one existent in a non-city-operated hospital, put on a full-dress rehearsal.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Plans for supporting the 1948 rice crop through purchase agreements and commodities loans was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., July 27 -- Passengers on five trains of the Lackawanna Railroad had to get out and walk here today. A freight train jumped the tracks this morning and plowed up the roadbed.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 27 -- The German political leaders began today to prepare for the Parliamentary Assembly Sept. 1.

New orders booked by furniture manufacturers in the first six months of 1948 exceeded those for the comparable period of last year by 11 per cent, according to the monthly report for June issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture factories.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 7 to 19 points yesterday in a quiet session.
The doors closed yesterday at the McAuley Water Street Mission, 316 Water Street, in the shadows of the Brooklyn Bridge.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 27 -- Skillful use of advertising to aid in combating a "dangerous inflation spiral" was urged here today by Frederic R. Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Plans for supporting the 1948 rice crop through purchase agreements and commodities loans was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., July 27 -- Passengers on five trains of the Lackawanna Railroad had to get out and walk here today. A freight train jumped the tracks this morning and plowed up the roadbed.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 27 -- The German political leaders began today to prepare for the Parliamentary Assembly Sept. 1.

New orders booked by furniture manufacturers in the first six months of 1948 exceeded those for the comparable period of last year by 11 per cent, according to the monthly report for June issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture factories.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 7 to 19 points yesterday in a quiet session.
The doors closed yesterday at the McAuley Water Street Mission, 316 Water Street, in the shadows of the Brooklyn Bridge.
A tenfold increase in the use of aluminum as a building product for farm construction is expected, W.G. Reynolds, vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company, said yesterday.
Twenty-six newly appointed probationary policewomen, all veterans of military service, demonstrated their physical prowess yesterday morning at the stadium on Randalls Island.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) -- Although he was tagged for a grand slam homer by Sam Chapman and wasn't around at the finish, Bobby Feller was credited with his tenth victory of the season tonight at the Indians moved into second place with a 10-5 victory over the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The three railroad unions whose threatened strike precipitated Government seizure of the roads are fighting dismissal of the permanent injunction against them while the Government is making every effort to have the order dissolved.
LONDON, July 27--The British Government has decided to resume the payments to Trans-Jordan that it has withheld recently, it became known today.

Textile export orders have dropped to the lowest level since 1941, it was learned yesterday. The steady flow of business that resulted in peak exports during 1947 and the first five months of 1948 has been cut drastically by world-wide dollar shortages, foreign import restrictions, and successful efforts of foreign manufacturers to create trade monopolies.

TRENTON, N.J., July 27 -- Fifteen hundred New Jersey National Guardsmen ended fifteen "almost perfect" days of training last week "with a bad taste in their mouths" and went without their dinner last Sunday because the heat and humidity spoiled the roast beef in their box lunches, it was revealed today by Brig. Gen. Donald W. McGowan, deputy New Jersey Chief of Staff.

An official of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, 88-06 Van Wyck Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, which has been strikebound for fourteen weeks, announced yesterday that negotiations had been started with an independent union of striking workers.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 27 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Charles Boucher, commander of the British forces in Malaya, promised the Federal Council today that guerrilla forces would hold no territory in Malaya in a few days.

LONDON, July 27 -- Representatives of the United States, Great Britain and France, meeting here today in a series of conferences, agreed on the final text and form of approach to the Soviet Union on Berlin.

BELLE GLADE, Fla., July 27 (U.P.) -- A woman on lonely Torey Island in Lake Okeechobee dropped a life-term convict with one bullet from her rifle and routed two others from her front yard last night, police reported today.

While I looked at the situation of Vietnam from an international relations angle, Harry Roskolenko -- in his letter published in THE TIMES of July 7 -- dealt with the national situation of the country. I must give full credit to Mr. Roskolenko for his close study of post-war French imperialistic activities in Vietnam. No one could be more accurate and more impartial than he
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company asked permission today to build a 1,600-mile pipeline to bring natural gas to Northern California from Texas and New Mexico.
Six couples who are celebrating their fiftieth wedding anniversaries this year were the guests of honor yesterday afternoon at a "tie-in" party.

A resolution urging all newspaper publishers to grant national advertisers at least six months' rate protection was announced yesterday by the newspaper committee of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc. The resolution will be circulated among publishers, it was stated.

ROME, July 27 -- The split in organized Italian labor was made more definite early this morning when the Communist majority in the Executive Committee of the General Confederation of Labor decided to expel all Christian Democratic members.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 27 -- Comparing the effect of the recent currency reform to the "waving of a magic wand over the German economy," Howard P. Jones, deputy chief of the British-United States zonal finance group, has asserted that the reform had exceeded all expectations.

"The Autobiography of Benjamin Rush," distinguished eighteenth century physician and signer of the Declaration of Independence, will be published this fall by Princeton University Press for the American Philosophical Society, 148 years after it was written.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 -- The Yankees' third grand offensive of the year in the West was launched in a 92-degree heat wave tonight that left the Bombers limp. So, too, did the pitching of Cliff Fannin, lean and wiry right-hander.

In a statement issued from the New York headquarters of the Progressive party, 39 Park Avenue, yesterday, Henry A. Wallace, the party candidate for President, criticized President Truman's call to Congress for civil rights legislation.

Immigration officer confiscated yesterday the passports of three American Jews who were among sixty-nine passengers seized by Lebanese authorities last May after their arrival in Beirut on the Marine Carp.

Again the New York City Mission Society is operating camps for the underprivileged in this city. Camp Sharparoon, at Dover Furnace, N. Y., is now co-educational for the first time. In each of the four periods fifty-six girls and 118 boys can be accommodated.
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 5 for $26,191,000 of temporary loan notes dated Aug. 27, 1948, and due on Feb. 27, 1949.
COLUMBIA, S. C., July 28 (UP) -- Gov. Ben T. Laney of Arkansas was named general chairman of the executive committee of States Rights Democrats today.

By a margin of 1,713 to 195, members of Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted last night in favor of a strike Monday at the Manhattan and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins Co.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- John Foster Dulles urged here today that the Little Assembly be continued at least for another year and warned that, "like life or fire insurance," the youthful United Nations organ should not be abandoned simply because there was no death or fire during its first year.

Because of a lack of cheap electrical power, the aluminum industry, which produced the metal for the largest air armada in history, is now "too small" for civilian and military needs, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, warned yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 12 -- Premier Antonin Zapotocky, speaking in Bratislava today said that as a result of the favorable political conditions in Hungary he was considering the possibility of negotiating a treaty of alliance on the basis of a definite settlement of outstanding Czechoslovak and Hungarian problems.
The Erie Railroad has installed four-way radio communication for its trains over 315 miles of main line between Marion, Ohio, and Salamanca, N.Y., the company announced yesterday.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- The Tigers put a violent end today to the thirteen-game winning streak of the Red Sox, shelling three pitcher for eighteen hits to submerge the American League leaders, 13 to 0.

ADEN, July 28 -- One of three B-29 Superfortresses on an around-the-world flight crashed into the sea within sight of this port on the south coast of Arabia last night. At least sixteen American crewmen were believed lost.
The executive committee of the Trade Union Council of the Liberal party at a special meeting yesterday endorsed unanimously President Truman's recommendations in his special message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The dictatorial control that the Soviet Union is attempting to exercise in increasing degree over its satellite states is being extended rapidly to the satellite armies, according to information from Rumania, available here.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 28 -- After a delay of thirty minutes Joseph Gagliardi, 36-year-old Larchmont lawyer and a member of Winged Foot, received a committee ruling at the final hole and finished with the necessary par 4 today to win the medal in the metropolitan amateur golf championship with 143, one under par.

NANKING, July 28 -- Premier Wong Wen-hao denounced Chinese Communists today as a "party of international spies" and asserted that they were selling out China's national interests as members of a World Communist organization. He excoriated the Communists in a message to the Chinese people, released through the Kuomintang-controlled Central News Agency.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall appointed today a committee of three citizens to study the question of whether persons have entered the country in connection with the work of the United Nations or other international organizations whose presence is inconsistent with national security.

WASHINGTON July 28 -- The Senate's embattled Southerners forced a twenty-four-hour delay today on the Anti-Poll Tax Bill and suddenly and materially improved their whole defensive position against this item in the civil rights program.

Offers of specific jobs in New York State for displaced persons whom Congress has authorized to enter from Europe have been pouring in to the State Committee on Displaced Persons, it was reported yesterday.

PEIPING, July 28 (AP) -- Counter-attacking government troops have killed or wounded 2,000 Communists in recapturing strong points around Taiyuan, besieged Shansi Province capital, press reports said today.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- The Athletics gained an even break in their two-game series with the Indians today by pushing two unearned runs across in the eighth inning to beat Bob Lemon, 4 to 3.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- Delegates and members of the United Nations Secretariat were shocked by Secretary of State George C. Marshall's announcement today that he had appointed a committee of three citizens to investigate the procedures by which United Nations personnel were admitted to this country.

Summon Euterpe, the muse of music. The Army wants a song. Headquarters of the First Army announced yesterday the start of a contest to discover a song worthy of becoming an over-all number -as differentiated from songs of the infantry, artillery and other various arms and services.

Ten hits good for nine runs gave the Police Department a 9-3 triumph over the Sanitation Department nine yesterday before a crowd of 22,674 at Yankee Stadium. A large number of the fans were youngsters who were guests of the Police Athletic League.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Two young film actors, John Agar, 27, husband of Shirley Temple, and Dean Stockwell, 12, will get their first co-starring opportunity in pictures announced today for immediate production. Agar will be paired by Argosy Pictures with the newcomer, Ben Johnson, former Oklahoma cowboy, at the top of the cast of "She Wore A Yellow Ribbon," while Stockwell joins Margaret O'Brien in "The Secret Garden" at M-G-M.

The air will be strictly bipartisan at New York International Airport at Idlewild on Saturday. Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's committee for the city's golden jubilee and dedication of the airport, of which a week-long show is a part, announced changes in program details yesterday that emphasized this fact.

Although operations have been cut approximately in half by restrictions on American exports to Russia, the Amtorg Trading Corporation, official Soviet Government commercial agency in this country, will continue to maintain offices here despite reports to the contrary, it was stated yesterday by an Amtorg spokesman.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- Receiving fine support at the plate from his mates, right-hander Vern Bickford weathered two shaky innings tonight and pitched the National League's leading Braves to an 8-2 triumph over the Pirates before a crowd of 25,446.
TOKYO, July 28 -- General McArthur's dictum that Government servants do not have the right to strike is threatening to end one of the strangest series of "strikes" in labor history.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Marino Pieretti turned in a six-hitter against his former Senator teammates before 3,168 persons today to lead the White Sox to a 2-1 triumph.

The communities of Tremont, Mott Haven and Morrisania, underprivileged areas in the Bronx, joined last night in the first major project of the New York City Youth Board, which seeks to prevent juvenile delinquency and promote social rehabilitation.
LONDON, July 28 -- The United States, Britain and France are going to propose to the Soviet Union that talks be held not only on Germany but on Austria and Trieste as well, it was learned today.

LONDON, July 28 -- Christian unity, dogma, the infallibility of the Bible and other ideals that many cherish were derided today by Dr. W.R. Inge, former dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, in an address read for him at the Conference of Modern Churchmen in Oxford.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 28 -- The newspaper Al Ahram reported today that the Arab League states were studying a plan to raise funds needed for the care of refugees from Palestine by imposing a levy upon Jewish-owned property in the Arab states.

GENEVA, July 28 -- A large-scale bargaining conference between the countries of Eastern and Western Europe aiming at a big increase in trade between the two regions is being prepared for some time this autumn, it was learned today.

Completion of a quarter-century of labor peace in the New York women's coat and suit industry was assured yesterday with the signing of a new three-year, no-strike agreement covering 47,000 members of the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers union, AFL.

BELGRADE, July 28 -- The United States delegation to the Danubian conference headed by Ambassador Cavendish Cannon arrived today aboard two aircraft. The personnel, including clerical staff, totaled twenty-six, less than half the number the Soviet Government is expected to send to the Belgrade conference, which is scheduled to open on Friday.

Candles replaced incandescent bulbs at the Alamac Hotel, Seventy-first Street and Broadway, last evening and alternating footsteps applied to the stairs supplanted electrical energy as a means of moving guests from floor to floor. The nineteen-story structure lost its motive power by a short circuit at 5:50 P.M.

PARIS, July 28 -- The Paris millinery openings confirm and develop the trends shown in the early June collections. They establish the cloche, but especially do they confirm the mixture of two types in a single hat, hats that are part bonnet and part cloche, part bonnet and part beret.
Prices of Lucky Strike cigarettes will be advanced seven-tenths of a cent a pack or 5 1/2 per cent at wholesale today by the American Tobacco Company, it was announced last night.

Since President Truman consistently opposed as inflationary the Republican efforts at tax reduction, one might suppose that in his present eight-point program to check inflation he would propose a return to the old income tax rates. Instead, he has chosen to come out with his proposal for a new excess profits tax on business and industry.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 28 -- Dr. Alan Valentine, until recently president of the University of Rochester, N. Y., and now director of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in the Netherlands, today came to the defense of the weak sisters among the European nations.
TOKYO, July 28 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's chief labor adviser threatened to quit today in protest against a new occupation labor policy for Japan.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 28 -- The senior class of the Military Academy staged its first academy award banquet tonight and presented an "Oscar" known locally as a "Dumbjohn" to Cadet John H. Saxon for his "mephitic performance" in support of Alan Ladd and Donna Reed in the coming Paramount film "Beyond Glory." Cadet Saxon appears briefly in the picture and also was technical adviser to 1Vfr. Ladd.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Much more accurate and precise than assertions in a political paper usually are is this sentence from the statement issued by the Republican leaders of the majority in Congress:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- One of President Truman's weaknesses, as he faces a recalcitrant Congress and wages the campaign for election to a full four-year term in his own right, is that no member of his Cabinet has the "grass roots" experience in national politics usually regarded as essential to serve as an effective liaison man on Capitol Hill or to add electoral strength to the national ticket in the country.
Two new issues of railroad equipment trust serial certificates totaling $10,500,000 were sold yesterday at competitive bidding to banking syndicates, headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The stock market was thrown for a moderate loss yesterday under late realizing which found some of the key issues sensitive to meager offerings. Earlier in the session, selective gains were made, particularly by the rail division, but when buying wavered losses ensued.

Thirteen Dodgers batted against the Cardinals in the fifth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, eight scored and almost quicker than one could say "Leo doesn't live here anymore," the Brooks had wrapped up their second straight victory over the Redbirds.

A Pullman porter who placed service first, "letting the tips fall where they may," received a $25 United States savings bond yesterday from the Federation for Railway Progress, which has promoted the cause of the passenger, "who always needs a break."

OTTAWA, July 28 -- Charges that the leaders of the Canadian Seamen's Union were destroying the shipping industry of this country and that they and their fellow-travelers were using labor only to further their own ends were today made by Transport Minister Lionel Chevrier in a letter to Michael Jackson, Great Lakes director of the CSU.

The State of Israel officially opened its consulate in New York yesterday by handing to Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, veteran Zionist and chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, its first visa for admission to Israel.

"On An Island With You," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical with Esther Williams, Jimmy Durante, Peter Lawford, Ricardo Montalban and Cyd Charisse, will have its local premiere this morning at the Capitol. The romantic comedy, which was filmed in Technicolor, was directed by Richard Thorpe and produced by Joe Pasternak from a screen play by Dorothy Kingsley, Dorothy Cooper, Charles Martin and Hans Wilhelm.
Progress in a Federal mediation attempt to solve the long-standing maritime labor dispute was reported last night after a day of negotiations.

RHODES, July 28 -- Arab and Israeli authorities have agreed to put the main pumping station for Jerusalem's water supply under United Nations control during the truce, it was announced here today from the headquarters of Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator.

LONDON, July 28 -- Defying a heat wave that has prostrated Londoners by its suddenness, mannequins paraded here today in winter clothes that were snug enough for a trip to the North Pole -- flowing capes, tweed-topped bootees, fur collars and, above all, the tiny corsetted waists that Hardy Amies repeats in his streamlined full-skirted silhouette.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 28 -- Teddy Rhodes of Los Angeles, Calif., personal pro to Joe Louis, retired heavyweight boxing champion of the world, cut one stroke from par with a blazing 34, 35 -- 69 today to take a four-stroke lead among the professionals in the Ray Robinson open tournament at the Engineers Golf Club.

Yankee Associates acquired from George Schaffer and others the two-story taxpayer containing seven stores and ten offices at 59 East 161st Street, northeast corner of River Avenue, the Bronx, through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker.

Of the $5,300,000,000 to be spent on the European Recovery Program during the first year, 54 per cent will be for United States products, according to an analytical chart issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Of the balance, 36 per cent will be for purchases from other countries in the Western Hemisphere and 10 per cent will be spent on administering the program as well as price adjustments.

GENEVA, July 28 (Reuters) -- Russia today coupled an attack on the Marshall Plan with an appeal to the United Nations Economic and Social Council to find a way for Communist and capitalist countries to cooperate.

PRAGUE, July 28 (AP) -- Vladimir Cernik 32-year-old Prague clerk, personally eliminated Sweden from European Zone Davis Cup play today and make it possible for his Czech mates to travel to Boston, Mass., for the next round in the world tennis competition.

The Inland Steel Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $15,008,393 for the six months ended with June. The net was equal to $3.06 a share and compares with $10,171,286, or $2.08 a share, for the corresponding half of last year, when $3,950,000 was deducted for contingencies.

Sleek upholstery coverings, smart traveling bags and babies' play pens were among the diversified products made of Lumite that were exhibited yesterday at a luncheon held by the Chicopee Manufacturing Corporation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 28 (AP) -- Two of the top-seeded players, Bob Falkenburg and Miss Dorothy Head were eliminated today in the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's sixtieth invitation tourney.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., advised Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to turn over the rehabilitation of the city's waterfront to an outside agency, preferably the Port of New York Authority. The organization maintained that although continued control of the piers by the city is desirable, it is "obviously impossible of accomplishment" because of the city's present financial plight.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 28 (AP) -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, rejected today the Bethlehem Steel Company's package wage increase offer of 9 1/2 cents.
ALBANY, July 28 (AP) -- State revenues are running $29,749,000 ahead of last year despite a surprise decline in personal income tax totals which is coming under close scrutiny of fiscal officials.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The police force of this city was divided into two factions today when Acting Mayor Frau Louise Schroeder rejected a Soviet order to reinstate Communist Paul Markgraf as police chief. Herr Markgraf had been suspended by the Magistrat, or City Assembly.

We believe there will be widespread approval of the decision reached by General Hershey in the matter of draft priorities. The question was whether (as men are needed) to draw names by lot from the entire 19-to-25-year-old list of registrants or whether to begin with the 25-year-olds and then work down through the ranks of the younger men in the order of their registration.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 28 (AP) -- In a decision of major importance a Federal judge today uphold the Taft-Harley Act's ban on political spending by labor unions.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- The Phillies cut loose with a barrage of extra base hits, including three home runs, as they defeated the Cubs, 9 -- 4, today.

Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries showed a net income of $28,935,671 for the first six months this year, after all charges including $10,900,000 provision for taxes, according to the report issued yesterday. This is equal to $6 a share and compares with $16,170,389 or $3.40 a share earned in the 1947 period when the tax bill was $5,800,000.

LONDON, July 28 -- The chief interest in the London stock markets today centered on Western African gold shares following publication of the terms of the Gold Coast Government's new mining taxation proposals. There was, however, no buying "fireworks" and brokers apparently had more watching briefs than orders to buy.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The general body of Republicans in the Senate agreed today that the extra session of the Eightieth Congress should consider only those recommendations made yesterday by President Truman which could "press a test."

Mrs. McCormick's column of July 19 on "The Part of the Audience in the Berlin Drama" comprised in effect a far-reaching criticism of American policy calling for a complete reassessment of the United States position in Germany.

ATHENS, July 28 (AP) -- Informed sources said tonight that opposition apparently had collapsed in the Greek Supreme Defense Council to changes in the Greek military set-up recommended by United States officers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- Yugoslavia complained to the United Nations Security Council today that the United States and Britain were jeopardizing the peace by a steady campaign to give the free territory of Trieste to Italy.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 28 -- Savings and loan associations should give more attention to advertising, sales promotion and public relations, it was declared here today by Dr. Kenneth Dameron, director of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising.

Julius Jay Perlmutter Associates, Inc., have leased to the Melbee Textile Company and Bobbins Fabrics Corporation the two-story and basement building at 85 Franklin Street in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 28 -- It was announced here tonight that fighting between Egyptian and Israeli forces had broken out today in the Negeb region of Palestine.

In a move to step up the sale of Japanese cotton fabrics, the New York foreign trade office of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers (SCAP) yesterday announced price reductions ranging from six-tenths of a cent to 5 cents a yard on thirteen representative constructions of cloth.

The future of the Metropolitan Opera hangs in the balance today. Negotiations between the opera management and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestral players, reached a deadline today, with no break in the deadlock in sight.

Competition by some European countries with the United States for Iran's import trade is beginning to develop, it was reported yesterday by James Somerville, first secretary of the United States Embassy in Teheran. Mr. Somerville, who is here for a series of conferences with business men wishing new market data on Iran, was interviewed at the Department of Commerce's regional office.

An account of life in Thule, Greenland, the northernmost human settlement, has been scheduled for publication on Aug. 16 by W. W. Norton. It is "Eskimo Doctor," by Aage Gilberg, a Dane, who went as a government doctor to care for the Eskimos there.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, according to the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 21:

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell granted permission to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation yesterday to amend its breach-of-contract complaint against Otis Co., Cleveland investment bankers, to ask $19,276,069 in damages instead of the $7,762,500 originally sought.

Although sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company reached a new high record of $133,045,128 in the first six months of this year, compared with $129,547,169 for the half-year of 1947, earnings were somewhat lower, Harry B. Higgins, president, reported in the semi-annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.
The Giants took another fall out of the Cincinnati Reds and another step forward yesterday at the Polo Grounds before a gathering of 9,036 fans.

The residents of the Marine Park area in Brooklyn were promised relief from two sources yesterday in their crusade to end the strong smells that have permeated their homes since the warm weather set in.

Despite the growth of transatlantic aviation "by leaps and bounds," ocean air travel has not even scratched the surface of potential business, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, declared yesterday.
It was "Girls Day" at Jones Beach yesterday and 800 of them -- all under 14 -- turned out to participate in or watch special events held in their honor.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 28 -- Unless South Africa curtails its imports from dollar areas some form of control will have to be introduced, Dr. Michiel H. Dekock, Governor of the Reserve Bank, warned at the annual meeting of stockholders here today.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -Infantile paralysis is "going up a little bit in other parts of the country" outside of the three states already hard-hit, the Public Health Service reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that a registration statement had been filed with its San Francisco regional office by the Associated Telephone Company, Ltd., of Santa Monica, Calif., proposing a public offering of 85,000 shares of $20 par value cumulative preferred stock, 5 per cent, 1947 series.

KYRENIA, Cyprus, July 26 (Delayed) (UP) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan, whose Arab Legion was the mainstay of the Arab forces in Palestine, approved the idea of peace under United Nations auspices, it is possible to report today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28 -- The fifth congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia today openly challenged the Communist party leaders of the Soviet Union and the Communist Information Bureau bloc by unanimous endorsing every policy banned by the Cominform.

A former small-time prize fighter was accused yesterday by the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of bilking Puerto Rican families of sums ranging from $60 to as low as $10 in a "shakedown racket" involving apartment leases in the Amsterdam Houses, a low-cost public housing project.

C.B. Roeder has been appointed general traffic manager of American Home Foods, Inc. Before joining the company four years ago, he was assistant director of the railway transport division, Office of Defense Transportation.

Construction work has started on the first two of fourteen dwellings planned on a six-acre tract in the Orienta section of Mamaroneck, N.Y., by the Enholm-Severin Corporation, builders and developers. The first two homes are due to be ready for occupancy on Oct. 1.

It has cost a total of $3,355,348 thus far to place the municipal transit lines upon a ten-cent and seven-cent fare basis with a combined rapid transit and surface line ride for 12 cents, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 28 -- The offshore fishing fleet streamed out of Jones inlet early this morning and streamed in again late this afternoon, but not a tuna flag was flying from a single outrigger to repay the anglers for a long day of trolling and chumming.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican candidate for President, has decided to refrain from commenting on any of the specific legislative proposals pending before the extra session of Congress, it was stated authoritatively today.
PARIS, July 28 -- France has reached agreement with the United States and Britain on the method of a new approach to the Soviet Union on the Berlin situation, official circles said today.
Gustave Ring's Master Mind, who rarely fails to get at least a share of the purse, took the largest chunk of it yesterday in the main bout of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica proceedings.

A Navy admiral whose experiments in aeronautical research have been shrouded in secrecy for reasons "important to the national security," and an Army colonel who developed the first transoceanic automatic "push-button flight" will be honored next Thursday for outstanding achievement in aviation research.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday sharp increases in sales, profits and production for both the second quarter and the first six months of 1948 in comparison with similar periods of last year.

The huge DC-6 luxury airliner that crashed in eastern Pennsylvania on June 17, killing all forty-three persons aboard, may have been an uncontrolled plane manned by two nearly unconscious pilots. This possibility, it was learned yesterday, has become the chief line of inquiry of Government and aircraft investigators of the nation's third largest air disaster.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 -- The first move by a major steel fabricator toward setting up a plant closer to the source of basic steel in order to take advantage of the new f.o.b. price was made here today when Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation announced the sale of its twenty-five-acre McKeesport works to the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company of Detroit.

Highway construction in New York State this year is lagging behind the 1947 and 1946 programs, according to a survey presented yesterday by J.R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York. Although the number of contracts awarded has increased, the volume of work has decreased, he said.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and prices declined 5 to 12 points on the day.

LONDON, July 28 -- The Conservatives were joined by a Communist member in the House of Commons today in chiding Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, over his proposed joint Anglo-American council on productivity.

PARIS, July 28 -- Street black market operators in Paris are now enjoying an enormous boom in the business of buying travelers' checks from United States tourists. The tourists get 300 francs to their dollar through legal channels and 330 from operators working more or less openly in the centers of the Paris tourist traffic.

Shooting Lions from Texas, shouting and singing Lions from Iowa, New Jersey, forty-five other states and twenty-two foreign lands started the third session of their annual convention in Madison Square Garden yesterday with a bang.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Secretary of State Marshall confirmed at a news conference today that the United States had reached an understanding with the British and the French on an approach to Moscow looking to a settlement of the Berlin crisis and said the plan would be announced in a statement.

LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany Thursday, July 29 -- At least 250 persons were killed and approximately 6,000 injured yesterday when explosions and fire wrecked the huge I.G. Farben chemical works in this French zone city. Several hundred persons were trapped and some of them still were being dug out of the rubble early today. The rescuers could hear the cries of those caught between twisted beams and under piles of brick and wood.

Roy Rogers has been booked by WOR-Mutual for a new series of programs which will combine adventure and melody in an Old West setting. The series is scheduled to open Sunday, Aug. 29, at 6 P.M. Mr. Rogers will be abetted in the weekly dramatic sequences by Gabby Hayes, who will be relied upon for homespun humor, and Dale Evans, who is to supply the heart interest.
LUDWIGSHAFEN, Thursday, July 29 (AP) -- More than 300 persons were killed in the blast that wrecked the Farben chemical works, according to a United States Army estimate.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 29 (U.P.) -- The Russian-controlled Pyongyang radio today announced Communist plans to hold "elections'' in American-occupied South Korea as well as in Soviet-occupied North Korea. This strange new twist in the Soviet-American struggle over Korea was disclosed in a secial broadcast by a committee assertedly established to run underground elections in the American zone.

A slice of lime points up the chilly look of jellied soup, floats on a tall icy drink invitingly, adds to the freshness of a fresh fruit cocktail. Nature couldn't have planned it better. Limes reach their supply peak just as summer becomes sultriest. And what is so cool as a lime?

Some of the difficulties that must be overcome before the European Recovery Program can accomplish its aims are illustrated anew by the tempest being whipped up in Britain over the proposed Anglo-American Advisory Council to increase British industrial efficiency.

TUCSON, Ariz., July 28 (AP) -- The Davis-Monthan Army air base announced today the names of fellow crewmen of Sergeant Gustafason at the time the bomber left there last Thursday. The Public Information Office said it was possible there had been some interchange of crew among the three planes since departure and emphasized the list could not be considered a list of victims.
CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 28 (AP) -- The ponies came back to Chincoteague today.

Epidemics of infantile paralysis are now regarded as "disasters" by the Red Cross and have, therefore, become a concern of the organization's disaster nursing service, Miss Gertrude Landmesser, Red Cross consultant on disaster nursing for the North Atlantic Area, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the amended dissolution plan of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation, New York, and announced that it would apply to the Federal district court in Wilmington, Del., for approval and enforcement of the plan.

A rise of 2 cents a pound in the price of lead to a new record high of 19 1/2 cents a pound, delivered in New York, and 20 cents delivered in Europe, was announced yesterday by the American Smelting and Refining Company.
