The price of Mexican lead was raised 2 cents to 19 1/4 cents a pound at Gulf of Mexico ports.

A new price bulletin, which reflects no change in price on any products the company is now producing, was issued yesterday by the Sloane-Blabon Corporation, makers of smooth surface floor coverings. Upward revisions will be made on products not in production or scheduled for later production.

Some harried family still short of living quarters may be interested in knowing that a new apartment is available for occupancy today in one of the city's midtown hotels. There is one slight drawback: the price is $100 a day.

Unless voluntary curbs are placed on the sale of liquor at or near gasoline filling stations, Federal and state restrictive legislation will be sought, the national traffic safety committee of the American Automobile Association was told yesterday at a meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, marked the 173d anniversary of the Corps of Chaplains today with praise for the way in which the corps had so "magnificently" fulfilled the spiritual needs of the Army.

A machine, originally designed by the Todd Shipyards Corporation during the recent war to cast a smoke screen over troop landings and battleship maneuvers, was put to use in this city for the first time yesterday to kill mosquitos.

LONDON, July 28 -- The British nation -- momentarily sweltering under a heat wave and depressed by Europe's problems -- will turn its attention gratefully tomorrow to the Olympic Games which Ring George VI will open in a spectacular ceremony at Wembley Stadium near London.
TRENTON, N.J., July 28 -- For nearly four hours today William McCulic, 62 years old, lived again after his heart had stopped on an operating table at a Trenton Hospital.

Meg Mundy, whose performance in "The Respectful Prostitute" sent critics into an adjectival frenzy of approval, is considering leaving that show Sept. 1 to take the leading role in "Congressional Baby," a comedy-drama by Eileen Tighe, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A shortage of skilled labor, one of the drags on the building industry, is being relieved by a substantial growth in apprentice training, latest figures showed today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- The Soviet Union served notice tonight that it would introduceI proposals for the administration of Jersualem tomorrow before the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- The Peron regime, which has become increasingly bitter over the Marshall Plan's by-passing of purchases from Argentina, is now pinning its hopes, although they are faint, on a change of administration in the United States.

A decline of only 60,000 barrels occurred in the country's gasoline stocks last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week, total supplies were 101,641,000 barrels, compared with 100,701,000 a week earlier and 85,955,000 a year before.

Veteran financiers are convinced that continued enforcement of the compulsory competitive bidding system only tends to aggravate marketing embarrassments, not only on the long side, but on the short side as well. The secret bidding system has worked notoriously of late to leave underwriters "hooked" with "turkeys."
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 28 -- Peru served notice on the United Nations today that she had decided to send an Ambassador to Madrid and "resume full relations" with Franco Spain.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -Leaders of the Republican party in Congress returned President Truman's fire by radio tonight, describing his call of a special session as unnecessary and declaring that his anti-inflation proposals would make high prices permanent.

The largest sales volume in twenty-four years was reported yesterday for Time, Inc., in the first half of 1948 by Roy E. Larsen, president. Income from subscriptions, newsstand sales, advertising, film rentals and miscellaneous sales reached $64,705,000 compared with $58,429,800 for the first six months of 1947, although increased costs slightly more than offset this increase, the report showed.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- As part of a drive against conspiracies to maintain or raise prices of food, clothing and housing, the field service of the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice will be materially expanded, Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced today.

Declaring that "every television receiver on the market today is obsolete," Commander E.F. McDonald Jr., president of Zenith Radio Corporation, informed stockholders at their meeting on Tuesday that the corporation will begin making deliveries this fall of new, novel and different television receivers.

"I suppose this is the time of the year you can relax while the critics write summer pieces about summer reading," said Mr. Snood, looking across the bay at the sailboats moving like moths on the darkening water.

With the primary aim of promoting establishment of a permanent governmental commission on civil rights, the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights has been organized by forty-eight religious, educational, civic and business leaders, it was announced here yesterday.

PARIS, July 28 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, left tonight by air for Washington after a visit that he hoped had stimulated leaders of the Marshall Plan nations to take faster and bolder steps toward European economic unity.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Alsab's Day, delivering a stretch charge reminiscent of her daddy (Alsab), made amends for recent disappointments by capturing the $28,350 Pollyanna Stakes at Arlington today.

A scholarly looking, 26-year-old war veteran was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison for violation of parole after Assistant United States Attorney John J. Donovan Jr. told Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan he had mulcted two women of more than $2,000 on his promise to marry one of them.

A new export market for vitamins, equal to the present total world market, is being built up by distribution of these products through Government and private relief activities, it was stated yesterday by J. David Hayden, Eastern sales representative of Gelatin Products Corporation, a leading producer.

While the special session of Congress was called to deal in part with the problem of rising prices, little hope for action is expected, according to the July issue of the Guaranty Survey, monthly review of business and financial conditions, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

PRAGUE, July 28 -- The National Committee of the reorganized People's party issued a protest today against the Archbishop Josef Beron's suspension of Minister of Health the Roy. Josef Plojhar from the exercise of his priestly duties.

VIENNA, July 28 -- Russian refusal to grant customary passes has made it impossible for the British to leave Vienna in any direction except along the agreed corridor to the British zone. Since Saturday, when the Russians adopted their new policy, 120 requests for permission to go to the United States zone, Czechoslovakia or Hungary have been rejected.
MEXICO CITY, July 28 (AP) -Pemex, the Government oil monopoly, confirmed tonight that the Texas Company $30,000,000 loan might not go through.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, singled out the steel industry as an example today in charging that exorbitant prices and profits are a major cause of inflation.

LONDON, July 28 -- Persistent questioning from both sides of the House of Commons today failed to draw from Foreign Secretary Bevin any statement on the possibility of British recognition of the State of Israel.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- Prices of grains advanced in the early-trading on the Board of Trade today but the market failed to hold the gains.

The board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund will meet this afternoon to pass upon the applications of ninety-nine members of the force for retirement, it was announced yesterday. This is the largest group to apply in more than a year.

The inflation spiral is usually referred to as a wage-price spiral. This fails to accentuate the most important factor in the spiral. The real inflation spiral is a price of food-wages-price of manufactured goods spiral. It is the high cost of food that forces unions to ask increases in wages.

There is much more than prestige value in the presence of the Western Powers in Berlin. To the question: Why stay in Berlin? one good answer is to be found in the current clash over the police chief. This is a highly important post in the struggle for control of the city.
The Sword Line will appeal the decision of the Maritime Commission to terminate its fleet charter agreement involving thirty-nine ships, a company spokesman announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A barrage of requests from political quarters for free radio time hit the broadcasting networks today as two of their number, ignoring time-honored industry rules, gave Republicans air time to reply to President Truman's message to Congress.

The National Labor Relations Board hearing into charges of unfair labor practices on the part of the American Radio Association, CIO, ended yesterday afternoon, with union spokesmen contending that the continued use of the hiring-hall method of employment was necessary in the maritime industry.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Bills to increase the number of European refugees who may enter the United States and to wipe out provisions of the present law called discriminatory by President Truman were introduced in the Senate today.
YONKERS, N.Y., July 28 -- A small boy and girl bound for a picnic on a tricycle crashed into a cement truck this noon at Nepperhan and Crosshill Avenues here.
OTTAWA, July 28 -- The Canadian Board of Transport Commissioners announced today that the Railway Association of Canada had applied for a 20 per cent increase in freight rates.

ATHENS, July 28 -- Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, former chief of the Office of Strategic Services and now special counsel to the committee of the Overseas Writers Club investigating the murder of George Polk, has complained to Greek Government officials that the police inquiry into the crime is too one-sided.

Army and Navy hospitals in the metropolitan district have appealed in vain, it was learned yesterday, for renewal of the wartime privilege of using state parkways to transport ill service men and relatives of service men.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 28 -- Former Gov. Robert S. Kerr, who won a fortune in oil and a national reputation in politics, is the Democratic nominee for United States Senator from Oklahoma.

With the food price index at 214.1 per cent of the 1935-39 average, consumers should be more than usually interested in the items that are expected to be abundant, and therefore relatively reasonable in cost, next month.
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- Jack Garland of Los Angeles was elected a member of the International Olympic Committee today, succeeding his father, William May Garland.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 28 (AP) -Police won a violent skirmish with pickets today in the third day of the battle with a CIO union over the reopening of the Univis Lens Company plant. Five pickets were injured.

Modern Hebrew is gaining pupils faster than any other foreign language taught in the New York public school system, it was reported yesterday at the Board of Education. Next September, with the addition of three Brooklyn junior high schools, twenty-six schools throughout the city will offer the subject.

Regulations applying to "U.S.A. Gift Parcels" mailed to Austria, Belgium, China, France, Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the Allied zones of Germany were announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- A wealthy industrialist was killed today by three gunmen who pulled alongside his car in rush-hour traffic and fired a shotgun.

The sweeping victory against leftist elements in the National Maritime Union, predicted months earlier by President Joseph Curran, offers some hope that the complicated maritime labor situation may be clarified without resort to strike action. Emergence of the Curran faction as the dominating influence in the strong sea affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations does not promise any easier going for the shipping industry.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., July 28 -- The crew from the Larchmont Yacht Club took the lead at the end of the first day's racing for the Syce Cup and the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.

As State Police confirmed yesterday that the death last Thursday of a hotel owner at Sparkill, N.Y., was owing to natural causes, an insurance company here weighed its suit for recovery of $8,000 paid to his widow upon his "death" in 1939.

The male jury -- representatives from West Point, Brown and Fordham -- invited by Arnold Constable to its showing yesterday of back-to-college fashions strongly approved neat, waist-defining suits for campus wear. They liked bright-colored soft wools for dates and put full-skirted evening gowns of rustling taffeta at the top of their lists.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A total of 18,085 volunteers joined the armed forces in the first two weeks of July in a pre-draft rush which showed an upward trend by the middle of the month and indicated that the July total would greatly exceed that for June, the Army announced today.

After the restlessness and upset conditions of the first post-war years, morale among trained nurses and prospective students is improving, Miss Mary Roberts of the American Journal of Nursing said yesterday. A survey of nursing organizations indicated strongly that the national goal of 50,000 new students this year would be reached.

Warnings that high rates of construction must be maintained for several years if the housing shortage is to be eliminated were issued yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, and Herman T. Stichman, Governor Dewey's Commissioner of Housing.

Gross Distributors, Inc., metropolitan area distributors for Stromberg-Carlson television receivers, has developed a "foolproof" plan to prevent dealer price cutting, Benjamin Gross, president, disclosed yesterday. Under the plan, a dealer who "steals" a sale from a price maintaining competitor by selling below list is forced to turn over his full gross profit on the transaction to the injured dealer, he said.

Frank Jay Gould, millionaire son of the late railroad magnate, was accused yesterday of reneging on a $400,000 check he gave to a French woman for hiding him from the Nazis during the occupation of France.

The interesting and realistic account of the Burr-Hamilton duel on the occasion of its anniversary, as featured in the "Topics of the Times" recently, deserves, from a New York historic point of view, an additional item -- the place where Hamilton died.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- An agreement between the Federal Government and the State of California to continue oil production in the tidelands of that state under present conditions for another year was announced today.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 -- Riding high once more as they did in the early days of 1947 on the strong right arm of Frank Shea, the Yankees tonight deftly polished off the Browns, 4 to 0, to make an important gain in the sizzling American League flag race.

Since private bus lines operating in New York City pay into various governmental treasuries hundreds of thousands of dollars in taxes annually, whereas the city-owned transit lines are exempt from taxation, it would seem reasonable to expect that private lines would need to charge a higher fare.

LONDON, July 28 -- The tradition of supremacy of American track and field athletes in the Olympic Games, maintained uninterruptedly since the modern revival of the ancient Greek festival in 1896, should be upheld once again in the renewal here of sports' greatest carnival.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 29 -- Idle since the war, the former Suffolk County Army Air Field near here soon will be converted in part into a large industrial training camp, it was disclosed today.

Henry A. Wallace declared last night that President Truman called the special session of Congress not with the expectation of obtaining legislation to serve the people but in the mistaken belief that he could make Congress the scapegoat for "his own inadequate and often dangerous leadership."

Deposits in the nation's 532 mutual savings banks increased $450,000,000 during the first six months of 1948, according to a report of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks made public yesterday by William L. Maude, president.

Notice of forty-four objections to designating petitions were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections and specifications are expected to be filed today. There were sixteen objections to Democratic petitions, fourteen to Republican, thirteen to Liberal party and one objection to an American Labor party petition.

Reporting on operations of United Air Lines, Inc., which resulted in second quarter net earnings of $310,682, or 11 cents a share, as contrasted to a net loss of $3,550,534 in the first quarter, W.A. Patterson president, severely criticized the Civil Aeronautics Board for its failure to establish permanent airmail rates for the company and grant adequate temporary rates.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- Overriding strong Soviet objections, the United Nations Trusteeship Council decided this afternoon to postpone indefinitely any action on the establishment of an international regime in Jerusalem. The vote was 8 to 1, with Australia, China, and Costa Rica abstaining.

The sensitivity of the stock market to moderate pressure was demonstrated again yesterday. Although volume was the smallest since Monday, the list suffered its severest setback since early last week and left several key units 1 to 3 points lower.

BERLIN, July 29 -- The future of this city's elected government became extremely uncertain today when the Communist bloc abruptly walked out of a meeting of the Magistrat, or Assembly, as the anti-Communist majority forced a vote on a resolution condemning the present Soviet blockade of Berlin.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Dr. Willis J. Potts, discoverer of one method of "blue baby" operation, emerged from one of his operations at Children's Memorial Hospital today and faced a news conference he had summoned. He flopped wearily into a chair and began.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman rejected today suggestions that had been made at the Capitol for him to inform Congress fully of the Berlin crisis.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman emphasized today that he expected all segregation of races to be abolished eventually from the armed services.

Officials of the Bethlehem locals of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, met yesterday in the Lincoln Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, to discuss the rejection by seven of the nine locals involved of the settlement reached last Friday morning. No report of the talks was made.

The romance and pathos that pulsed in old New York fifty years ago throbbed again yesterday in the stories of 192 couples married in 1898. Because each were married in that year, and because they had lived in New York since, they will receive golden wedding bands from Mayor O'Dwyer sometime during the city's golden anniversary celebration and exposition in Grand Central Palace.

The Lions closed their thirty-first annual convention yesterday by approving unanimously the election of Dr. Eugene S. Briggs of Enid, Okla., as international president, and the decision to meet in New York again next July.

The City of Seattle, Wash., borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing from Aug. 1, 1953 to Aug. 1, 1973, from a banking syndicate headed by Blair Co. and John Nuveen Co. at a bid of 98.429 for 2 3/4s. The bonds are to finance light and power installations.

Despite an increase of almost $8,000,000 in sales, the net profit of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the second quarter of 1948 was $15,099,775, or $400,000 less than the first quarter's earnings, E.G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday.
H. Bertram has ben promoted to merchandise representative of radios, television, musical instruments, records and small electrical appliances by the Associated Merchandising Corporation.

June retail home furnishings dollar volume gained 10 per cent compared with the corresponding month last year, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Retail Furniture Association. The survey covered a representative sample in all parts of the country of the association's 8,000 member stores.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 (AP) -- Yugoslav Communists replied today to demands by the Communist Information Bureau for the eclipse of Marshal Tito by re-electing him head of the Politburo.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today ordered some seventy cement companies representing 400 plants in thirty-five states to cease alleged anti-trust law violations.

LONDON, July 29 -- America's Olympic divers left little doubt in the minds of opening day crowds at Wembley Pool today that the United States would sweep the diving events both from the three-meter board and from the ten-meter platform.
CALAIS, Me., July 29 (AP) -- Her husband's death officially attributed to heart disease, Mrs. Margaret M. Marcil, 36 years old, of Schenectady, N.Y., today was freed of a murder charge.

Producers and investors in theatrical offerings are breathing easy again. The League of New York Theatres, the managerial body representing producers and owners of Broadway theatres, announced yesterday it had succeeded in obtaining a ruling from the Internal Revenue Department whereby corporation taxes do not apply to limited partnerships, the customary formula employed in financing stage projects.

Coincident with the announcement of the declaration of an increased quarterly dividend of 25 cents plus a special of 10 cents, both payable to common stock-holders on Sept. 24, the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation reported yesterday a new high record in sales and earnings for the three and six months ended on June 30.

THE NEW YORK TIMES chides me for having said that United States Steel has surrendered to inflation. My statement, unlike the gratuitous assertion of THE TIMES that I have "made a political career of baiting big business," is based upon solid fact.

The wife of a young Brooklyn bank teller inadvertently exposed her husband, whom she married a few months ago, as a forger when she attempted Monday to withdraw money from their joint bank account. Unknown to her the "bank account" was part of a scheme concocted by her husband to show her that he was a "big shot."

ROME, July 29 -- Christion Democratic leaders met this evening with representatives of the Catholic Association of Italian Workers to discuss plans preliminary to the creation of a new non-political confederation of labor.
Owners of thousands of cigarette vending machines in the New York area will be hit hard by current price increases, it was learned yesterday, but the buyer will have to pay 23 cents a pack.
It was family day yesterday at the Long Island Rail Road's main repair and maintenance shops in Richmond Hill, Queens.

MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) -- Informed sources said today that chances were good that a four-power conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers on Berlin and Germany would be arranged for Paris at about the time of the United Nations Assembly meeting Sept. 21.

Flights of military planes, including waspish jets and thundering super-bombers, were on the wing all over the United States yesterday in preparatory staging phases of an 850-plane review by President Truman. The actual review is scheduled to start at the New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, a half-hour after the President dedicates the new field.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent during the week ended Saturday as a result of lower prices for some grains and most livestock, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. At 168.2 per cent of the 1926 average, the Bureau's comprehensive index was 0.9 per cent above four weeks ago and 11.7 per cent above a year ago.

Commenting yesterday on the President's appointment of Paul Porter, former OPA head, as his adviser on anti-inflation legislation, we suggested that the move seemed almost deliberately calculated to destroy at the outset any hope of cooperation on legislation in this field.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Yankees are about to provide themselves with what they hope will be a notable addition to their pitching corps, and it won't come as the result of a deal or at the expense of one of their farm clubs.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Navy's mammoth air transport, the Lockheed Constitution, was christened today by Mrs. John L. Sullivan, wife of' the Secretary of the Navy.

Dr. Joseph Earl Snyder, who is only 30 years old, has been named director of Vanderbilt Clinic, the out-patient department for the voluntary hospitals of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, 168th Street and Broadway, and administrative assistant in charge of professional services to patients at the clinic.

Two wealthy spinster sisters, whose mild, inoffensive appearance seemed in marked contrast to charges that they were "greedy, contemptible and cold-blooded" rent gougers, were accused yesterday of having mulcted slum tenement dwellers of $4,892 in illegal rent bonuses.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works has agreed to sell to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation 500,000 shares of its authorized but unissued common stock, the two companies announced yesterday. Upon the issuance of these shares, Baldwin will have outstanding 2,375,553 common shares, of which Westinghouse, including shares previously owned, will have approximately 21.68 per cent.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- Big Bill Voiselle weathered several dangerous situations today and pitched the National League's front-running Braves to a 2-1 triumph over the Pirates, his first over the Bucs in the last two seasons.

Getting about in Manhattan traffic is tough enough, so that elimination of even momentary delays is helpful. One of the worst time-destroyers is cross-town travel, which depends solely on surface transportation. Among the worst offenders are the buses on the principal crosstown streets.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- House Republicans approved unanimously today their leadership's decision for a "soon as possible" adjournment of the extra session. They agreed, too, in closed conference that only such legislative matters that are "emergency" in character should be given any consideration at all.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- Ralph Cabellero paced an 11-hit attack with three safeties that drove in three runs today as the Phillies took the rubber contest of the three-game series from the Cubs, 7 -- 4.

The new union motor bus terminal in the Times Square Area came a step nearer realization yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder placed the Port of New York Authority in possession of the buildings on the site so demolition could proceed.

Since the beginning of the Second World War about 18,000,000 policies of National Service Life Insurance were issued to members of the armed services. Now, according to the Veterans Administration, only 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 of these policies remain in force. In New York City's five boroughs 930,000 policies were held by members of the armed forces, most of them valued at $10,000 each, and only 235,000 are now in force.

Feasibility of President Truman's request for a price rollback of cost-of-living items was strongly questioned in business and industrial quarters here yesterday. Many believed such a step under present conditions "absolutely impossible," and described the proposal as "economic nonsense."
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Four Winds, owned by the Dixiana Farm Stable, put up a tremendous stretch drive to win the $34,450 Arlington Matron Handicap at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman asked Congress today for price rollback authority and other anti-inflation powers, but the proposals ran into such angry criticism as to leave no doubt nearly all were doomed.

Seven American feature films have been entered in the Venice Film Festival, it was reported yesterday by the Motion Picture Association of America. The entries include Walt Disney's "Melody Time," Paramount's "The Big Clock," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "National Velvet," Twentieth Century-Fox's "Gentleman's Agreement," Warner Brothers' "Treasure of Sierra Madre," Universal-International's "A Double Life," and RKO's "The Fugitive."

The flame that was lighted at Olympia on July 17 and carried by runners through seven countries reached London's Wembley Stadium yesterday. Those who saw ill omen when one torch went out at Dover Wednesday night could be reassured; another, carrying the same unique and sacred fire, had been prepared for just this emergency.
Our contemporary across the seas, the Rome Daily American, takes note of complaints of the gondoliers of Venice that motor-boats in their canals are putting them out of business.

WAYNESBURG, Pa., July 29 -- Waynesburg residents sweat out July 29 today under an intense sun but did not give up hope that rain would fall. According to legend rain has fallen here on July 29 in all but four of the last seventy-one years.

The first test of whether Russia is now ready to embark on real negotiations to settle the problems of post-war Europe will be provided at the conference opening in Belgrade today to arrange for free navigation of the Danube. This conference was originally proposed by Secretary Marshall last May, in an effort to promote peace by action on specific questions in place of the general discussions which had broken down.

Chief Warrant Officer William C. White bade farewell to military life after forty-one years as an Army band leader and composer yesterday afternoon as he marched with his 321st Army Band across the parade ground at Governors Island for the last time.

TOKYO, July 29 -- The Japanese Cabinet discussed today the tentative draft of the order it proposes to issue to give effect to the terms of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's letter denying collective bargaining rights to Government employes.

LONDON, July 29 -- Wembley Stadium became a veritable Tower of Babel today as tens of thousands of Britons poured through massive entrance gates to observe the opening Olympic ceremonies and to mingle with hordes of foreigners of virtually every race, color and tongue.

LONDON, July 29 -- The British Government is considering halting its demobilization of the armed forces because of the Russian policy over Berlin, Foreign Secretary Bevin revealed to the House of Commons today.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 29 -- Sidney Hanover, 7-year-old bay gelding owned by L.L. Herrin of Charlotte, N.C., ascended to the trotting championship of the United States at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Competing in the invitation mile of the American title event against nine others, Sidney Hanover scored a convincing triumph to take the major portion of the $25,000 purse.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 29 (AP) -- George W. Ring, wealthy Los Angeles oil man and racing enthusiast, put $46,000 behind his desire to build a top turf stable today when he prevailed in a spirited bidding duel for a yearling half-sister to Cosmic Bomb.

A 3-year-old boy, Andrew Topoloft, of 401 West End Avenue, put up quite a "beef" yesterday after the judging had been completed in a doll contest for boys and girls up to the age of 14, held in the Park Department's playground at Riverside Drive and Eighty-third Street.

Getting an early lift from home runs by Roy Campanella and Gil Hodges, which accounted for five of their runs, Barney Shotton's Dodgers yesterday made a sweep of the three-game series with the Cardinals by beating them 9 -- 6, before 22,144 Ebbets Field fans, but failed to gain on the first place Boston Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended July 24, 1948, totaled 882,566 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,961 cars, or 1.1 per cent less than for the preceding week's total of 892,529; 37,362 cars, or 4.1 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, and 27,947 cars, or 3.1 per cent less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The National Safety Council reported today that deaths resulting from motor vehicle travel during the first six months of 1948 totalled 13,690, or 560 fewer than in the same period last year, and asserted that "the nation is establishing the lowest traffic death rate in its history."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman is expected to decide over the week-end whether he will start a series of radio fireside chats, such as the late Franklin D. Roosevelt made famous, in an effort to mobilize support for administration policies.

LONDON, July 29 -- Officials here could see no reason today for Yugoslavia's complaint to the United Nations Security Council that the United States and Great Britain were jeopardizing peace by trying to hand Trieste over to Italy.

Formation of the Information and Standards Committee of the Sugar Industry to represent it in food hearings and to combat unjustified claims for sugar substitutes, while "policing its own side of the fence" was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman sent to the Senate today a long list of nominations for important Federal posts despite an announced policy by Republican leaders of the Senate not to act on any more nominations until the next Congress convenes in January.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, met with the Secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force today to begin preparation of an overriding directive designed to end conflicting or controversial statements of policy by representatives of the three services.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $2,780,528, equal to 53 cents a common share, compared with $4,332,567, or 35 cents a share, in the preceding twelve months.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- Flood Town of E. Lasker's stable scored a popular victory in the six-furlong Frank Parker Purse today.
Lamb prices fell off from 2 to 10 cents a pound this week, making this meat the outstanding purchase for week-end meals.

Appointment of the first women officers for the Navy will feature the first large-scale enlistment of women, starting about Sept. 15, the Bureau of Naval Personnel announced here yesterday, the sixth anniversary of the Women's Reserve.

PARIS, July 29 -- A plan for the complete modernization of the French Army, together with details of the contributions that the army is prepared to make to Western European defense, was placed before Defense Minister Rene Mayer today by the Chief of Staff.
BERLIN, July 29 -- The people of Western Berlin have erected a memorial to two United States fliers who died last Sunday flying food to the blockaded city.

Once upon a yesterday there were two Cincinnati pitchers named Ken, one Raffensberger, the other Burkhart. Manager Johnny Neun of the Reds, it developed, got his Kens mixed, when he started Raffensberger against the Giants and shortly had to relieve with Burkhart after one out in the first inning at the Polo Grounds.

LENOX, Mass., July 29 -- The fourteenth annual Berkshire Music Festival began here at Tanglewood tonight under the most felicitous auspices -- a huge crowd, a moonlit, starlit night and, of course, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Serge Koussevitzky.

NANKING, July 29 -- More than 400,000 Communists are regrouping for new offensives in Central China, Lieut. Gen. Teng Wen-yi, Government military spokesman, said today. On the basis of past experience, he said, it usually takes the Communists two to three weeks to regroup and strike again.

LONDON, July 29 -- Damages of 6,300 (about $25,200) were awarded today to James Forbes Whiteford, American consulting engineer, against John Bowman Hunter, London surgeon, for having negligently declared in 1942 that Mr. Whiteford had inoperable cancer and would die in a few months.
Random notes.
The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday elaborate plans to mark the opening of its local television station, WJZ-TV, On Tuesday, Aug. 10.

Two months ago, five weeks after the birth of my second baby, I was found to be suffering from "moderately advanced" pulmonary tuberculosis. I should not consider this a matter of general interest did I not feel that my experience might serve as a warning and possibly save some other mother from a similar disaster.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- The United Nations Security Council called on the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia today to live up to all the military and economic provisions of the Netherlands Indies truce agreement signed seven months ago.

SCARBOROUGH ON THE HUDSON, N.Y., July 29 -- Continuing her fine play, Mrs. John Bartol of Greenwich won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association with a one-under-par 41, 36 -- 77 over the Sleepy Hollow course today.

LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany, Friday, July 30 -- Bodies were still being extricated early this morning from the twisted machinery and debris of the great I.G. Farben chemical plant wrecked in a tremendous explosion and fire Wednesday afternoon.

A 45-year-old French seaman, living in this country illegally since January 1946, was taken into custody yesterday by Federal narcotic agents as the principal contact man here of an international narcotic ring.

Felony prosecutions in Kings County totaled 1,925 in 1947, an increase of 550 cases over the previous year, according to the annual report prepared by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald and made public yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Harold E. Stassen, whose long campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination ended in failure last month, was recommended unanimously today for the presidency of the University of Pennsylvania by the board of trustees.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted yesterday that the Provisional Government of Israel would be justified in resorting to its original claim of including all of Palestine in the new state if the Arab nations do not adhere to the partition plan voted by the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A sharp increase in forest fires last year as compared with the year before was reported today by the Forest Service.

City and business leaders warned yesterday of traffic chaos when the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel is opened two years hence because construction of the southernmost link of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive has been relegated to "the indefinite future."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29 -- Establishment of a $3,500,000 county recreation center at its 850-acre Saxon Woods Park Reservation in Scarsdale and Mamaroneck was recommended by the Westchester County Park Commission today as an answer to county residents' recent complaints that outsiders, especially New Yorker, have been over-running Westchester's recreational facilities.

The Meadowbrook Colony, Inc., has sold ten more dwellings on First and Second Streets in its new development at East Meadow, L.I. Trylon Realty Company was the broker and the Home Title Guaranty Company insured the titles. Purchase money mortgages were advanced by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank.
DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Three home runs, including one by Rookie First Baseman Bill Goodman with the bases loaded, brought the Red Sox an easy 8-to-1 victory over the Tigers tonight.

Television receivers now on the market definitely are not "obsolete," Benjamin Abrams, president of the Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation, declared in an interview yesterday. He said that producers of sets already in homes are perfecting inexpensive attachments designed to meet fully any changes in television broadcasting technique and scope.
Campos is no Stymie but he made a Stymie-like run at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday to win the $5,000 Oneida purse, a mile-and-a-sixteenth contest for older horses in Class C.

Print cloth prices held firm in a quiet market, according to Worth Street sources yesterday. Eighty squares were quoted at 25 3/4 cents per yard for spot goods with some business reported consummated at the price. Other print cloth constructions have held at present levels, although trading was light. Converters catering to the dress trade appear to be mainly interested in the 80x80 print-cloths and 100x60 carded broadcloths, it was indicated.
Workers in New York City are steadily losing the battle of inflation, statistics obtained yesterday from the State Labor Department showed.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Living costs, measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, advanced 4.1 per cent between November, 1947, and mid-June, 1948. It was to November, 1947, levels that President Truman, through Paul A. Porter, asked Congress today for authority to roll back prices of essential cost-of-living items.

Repayment of loans by banks and selling of Government obligations as well as other securities by brokers and dealers produced a contraction in the earning assets position of the reporting New York member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday.

LONDON, July 29 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, assured the House of Commons tonight that the purpose of his plan for a United States-British joint council on productivity was not to carry out a broad investigation of British industry by United States specialists.

The four-story remodeled apartment building at 38-40 Sutton Place, at the corner of Fifty-ninth Street, has been sold by the Hallel Realty Corporation to Henry Hart Rice through J. Clarence Davies Inc., and Van Dam, Mordecai Co., brokers.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29 (AP) -- Clayton Heafner, husky professional from Charlotte, N.C., set the pace today in the opening round of the forty-fifth Western open golf championship.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 29 -- Eural Clark of Los Angeles, 23-year-old medalist, defeated Judson Grant, 5 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole amateur final of the first annual Ray Robinson open tournament, sponsored by the United Golfers Association, at Engineers today.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Grain markets made a firm start and a weak finish on the Board of Trade today with December, May and July corn and all deliveries of rye and soy beans selling at new seasonal low prices. September corn led the decline, losing 2 5/8 cents, with the distant months off 1/8 to 3/4 cent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday and closed unchanged to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Mrs. Eleanor Medill Patterson, who was found dead in her Maryland country home Saturday, left The Washington Times-Herald to seven of its veteran executives, her will revealed today.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 29 -- The message dropped by Stephen J. Supina over the United Nations in Lake Success last week when the 36-year-old former Air Force gunner "bombed" the headquarters was read at his arraignment in District Court here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- The United Nations Little Assembly spent an entire day today arguing on the merits of a proposal that it ask its parent body, the General Assembly, to grant it administrative and budgetary powers.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 29 -- One of the Strafaci family, Frank, winner of the metropolitan amateur championship for the last three years and one of the two golfers in the forty-eight-year history of the tournament to win the title five times, went out of the current event in the first round at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
RYE, N.Y., July 29 -- Getting away on Saturday morning from out at Scotch Caps off here, the craft in the American Yacht Club cruise will begin their first squadron run.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 29 -- Calling for roundtable discussions with the Arabs rather than mediation, Moshe Shertok, Israeli Foreign Minister, told the State Council today that there could be no peace without Arab recognition of the sovereignty of Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today to reimpose consumer credit controls and grant the board authority to raise the reserve requirements of Federal Reserve banks as a curb on inflationary pressures.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that net profit for the first half of 1948 amounted to $24,941,100, equal to $1.83 a share, compared with $21,735,442, or $1.59 a share, in the same period last year. For the second quarter of 1948 the company had a net profit of $11,805,311, compared with $10,675,247 in the 1947 second quarter.

In one of the busiest days the New York waterfront has seen this year, 3,793 passengers arrived or sailed on four transatlantic liners yesterday and another 1,960 passengers embarked before midnight on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, due to sail early today.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed with 1,987 passengers at 1 A.M. today for Cherbourg and Southampton.

Igor Stravinsky's "Firebird Suite," after exposure to Tin Pan Alley in torch song disguise of "Summer Moon," erupted yesterday in $250,000 worth of legal fireworks that were set off in Los Angeles with loud repercussions here.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- An author of the recently enacted displaced persons bill and a leading Catholic member of the House denied today claims that the law discriminates against Catholics.

The Experimental School, Inc., will be opened Sept. 20 at the 110th Street Community Center, 31 West 110th Street, Prof. Harrison S. Elliott of Union Theological Seminary, chairman of the school's board of trustees, announced yesterday. The new school has been formed by the parents and teachers involved in an unsuccessful two-year protest against the closing of the Horace Mann-Lincoln School of Columbia's Teachers College.

The city will build for its own use a two-story storage building at 134-36 Madison Street to cost $140,000, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The architect is Walter W. Jones of 327 East Eighteenth Street in Brooklyn.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, and chiefs of the Communist Information Bureau world arrived today in Belgrade for the Danubian conference, which opens tomorrow at 5 P.M. in the Kolaratz People's University building.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- At least 1,800 feet of delegates met today in the Morrison Hotel as 300 members of "Tall Clubs" gathered to discuss their problems.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 -- The elimination of a large percentage of airplane accidents through the faculties of the new "electric brain," high-speed calculating machines, was predicted today as the Bureau of Standards' new Institute for Numerical Analysis at the University of California opened a three-day international symposium of mathematical scientists.
SHANGHAI, July 29 (UP) -- Nineteen passengers and crewmen, including a United States pilot, were killed today in the crash of a China Civil Air Transport plane near Tsingtao on the Yellow Sea coast.

RIVERTON, Wyo., July 29 -- Under the impact of rising costs and new estimates for agricultural work, the cost for construction projects to harness Missouri River Valley waterways and develop the vast basin has jumped nearly $2,000,000,000 within six months.
DANBURY, Conn., July 29 -- This city of 35,000 was introduced today to what may very well be the youngest -- certainly the most audacious -- fire buff on record.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- An investigation of alleged "irregularities and improprieties" in the conduct of the Dachau war crimes trials in Germany has been ordered by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army.

Critical materials essential to the nation's military security will be stockpiled under a speeded-up program of cooperation between industry and the Munitions Board, it was announced yesterday by Earl Bunting, managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers.
The semi-annual report of the Standard Oil Company of California showed yesterday an estimated net income of $77,611,483 for the first six months of this year after all charges and taxes.

Girls 8 to 16 years old have forgotten their Sloppy Joe sweaters and have a decided preference this fall for fashions with a quaint old-fashioned flavor, gay plaids and feminine full skirts, according to the showing of Teentimer styles presented yesterday at Gimbels.

The New York genesis of free housing in Milwaukee for eleven veterans paralyzed from the waist down was related here yesterday by Arthur I. Marcus of the national housing committee of the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- When the plan to integrate the Armed Services was agreed on, largely the work of Ferdinand Eberstadt, who was directed to make a study of the problem by James Forrestal, then Secretary of the Navy, it was not widely recognized that the establishment of the National Security Council was one of the great potentials of the plan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Jack Wrather, former Texas oil man now producing motion pictures here, went back to his own state three weeks ago to supervise the filming of "Strike It Rich" and returned today with an idea for another picture suggested by a friend.
Directors of the North American Company voted yesterday to distribute to stockholders shares it owns of the common stock of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

Col. Arthur G. Syran, who recently took over as chief of the transportation division of the Economic Cooperation Administration, assured American shipping men yesterday that they would get their fair share of aid cargoes bound for foreign nations.

The Metropolitan Opera's deadline for union settlement passed yesterday without drastic action. The peaceful negotiations with the American Guild of Musical Artists and the stage hands union are continuing and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians received no notification that its stormier negotiations were ended.

The American edition of "The Sky Is Red," by Giuseppe Berto, which was a leading best seller in Italy, will be issued by New Directions on Sept. 20. It is a novel about four adolescents, two boys and two girls, in a bombed little town in northern Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted freight rate increases to the nation's railroads that will add an estimated $67,400,000 a year to their revenues. Water carriers and freight forwarders were authorized to make similar increases in their rates, but the ICC made no estimate of what their additional revenue would be.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Justice T. Alan Goldsborough today overruled the Government's request to dismiss the permanent injunction against three railroad unions -- the engineers, firemen and enginemen, and the switchmen -- which threatened a strike last May, leading to temporary seizure of the railroads by the Government.

ATHENS, July 29 -- In an interview today, Minister of Public Order Constantin Rentis expressed surprise at reports he said had been printed in the United States that the investigation of the murder of George Polk was being conducted in a "one-sided" manner.

PARIS, July 29 -- United States approval of a plan for financing trade within Europe, devised by experts of the European organization under the Marshall Plan, was given today in a letter from W. Averell Harriman, Chief European Representative.

VIENNA, July 29 -- The Austrian Government asked the Allied Council today whether factories in the Soviet zone must answer the questionnaire of Soviet occupation authorities asking the political party membership of the director chief bookkeeper and members of the works council in each.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Sigmound J. Sluszka, chairman of the Polish-American Teachers Association, today called upon Dr. Manfred Kridl to resign from the chair at Columbia University established with funds from the Polish Government.
Edward F. Healey Jr. has been appointed an assistant solicitor in the law department of the New York office of the Home Title Guaranty Company.
NUREMBERG, Germany, July 29 -- All twenty-three accused former I.G. Farbenindustrie officials were acquitted here today of charges of crimes against peace and conspiracy to wage aggressive war.

HAIFA, Israel, July 25 (Delayed) -- The extremist organization Irgun Zvai Leumi does not recognize the partition of Palestine as binding upon its supporters and is insistent that the State of Israel shall include all of the former Palestinian mandate as well as all of the Kingdom of Trans-Jordan, according to Menahem Beigin, head of the organization, who answered a series of questions posed by this correspondent.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 -- Premier-designate Karl August Fagerholm tonight announced his all-Social Democratic Cabinet, which he presented to President Juho K. Paasikivi.
WEMBLEY, England, July 29 (AP) -- For three broiling hours the United States Olympic team waited patiently in a dusty area near a tiny pond today for the parade into Olympic Stadium.

ONE question that a horse historian frequently has popped at him is: "How much do jockeys get paid?" The question-popper sometimes is astonished at the reply. Certainly half a dozen jockeys are in the $100,000-a-year class, and probably a score or more do at least as well at the pay window as the chief occupant of that big house on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, D.C.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission believes that freight moved jointly by rail and barge should continue to be handled at a charge lower than the rate for all-rail movement. It has so notified the railroads and the inland barge companies in a report on an investigation into these joint rates undertaken more than ten years ago. Generally speaking, when freight moves partly by barge and...

The first large group of American Protestant church leaders to leave for the first assembly of the World Council of Churches, to be held Aug. 22 to Sept. 4 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, prepared to sail last night aboard the Queen Mary.

SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., July 29 -- Housewives of this town undertook today to combat high meat prices by setting up a "chain reaction" by telephone. Under the plan, each woman who pledges to buy no meat for the next two weeks is to call ten of her friends, urging their support.
All officers and organizers of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, were ordered last night to withdraw from positions of leadership in the American Labor party or quit their union jobs.

One Tammany district leader, who was ousted from a city job during the recent controversy over designation of a Democratic candidate for Surrogate of New York County, was reinstated yesterday and another will be.

When President Truman and Governor Dewey meet at the International Airport at Idlewild tomorrow at the opening of the International Air Show it will mark the first time in modern American history, according to available records, that opposing Presidential candidates of the two major parties appear together at a public function and speak from the same rostrum.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- Frank A. Parker, ranked No. 1 in United States tennis, came within a narrow margin of being eliminated in the quarter-finals of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's sixtieth invitation tournament today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- During the week ended July 28, member bank reserve balances increased $31,000,000, the Federal Reserve System announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Armed Services today gave the petroleum industry one week to supply 1,700,000 barrels of motor gasoline which the military said it must have.

Control of the Towers Hotel at 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn, has been acquired by Kimmelman Zauderer through the purchase of large blocks of stock of the Towers Hotel Corporation from various individual holders. At a meeting yesterday of the Towers Hotel Corporation in the office of Kimmelman Zauderer, Milton A. Kimmelman was elected chairman of the board of directors and Irving Zauderer was elected president of the company.

Confusion in burlap resulting from consummation of a large order placed by the Argentine Government has led Calcutta shippers to withdraw spot prices from the market, it was learned yesterday. Quotations were made, however, on August shipments and these showed price advances ranging from 1/2 cent to 3/4 cent a yard.

GENEVA, July 29 -- The World Health Organization has received an indication that the United States Government might be prepared to increase considerably its contribution to the organization for operational projects.

LONDON, July 29 -- A kindly man of gentle dignity in the uniform of an admiral of the fleet stood today before a hushed assemblage of 82,000 persons in the glare of a flaming sun and spoke words that millions had waited to hear for twelve long years. "I proclaim open," he said, "the Olympic Games of London, celebrating the XIV Olympiad of the modern era."
LONDON, July 29 -- The stock markets here today were very much under the influence of a general holiday atmosphere, which was reflected in increased demands for bank notes.
BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- A major air crash that emphasized the congestion at Buenos Aires harbor took ten lives this morning.

On instructions from Washington, the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board decided yesterday to hold a collective bargaining election Monday afternoon among 480 employes in the Manhattan and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins Co.

United States Army hospitals in Germany and Austria are in excellent condition and the sick rate among service personnel had been reduced to les than 2 per cent, Maj. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Surgeon General of the Army, said yesterday.

The lure of an all-Tchaikovsky program, with those popular young artists, Carroll Glenn, violinist, and Eugene List, pianist, as soloists, brought out an audience of 15,000 for the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Enrico Leide, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium.

MOST Americans who saw something of the Solomon Islands a few years ago formed no lasting affection for them. The climate, the malaria, the jungles and the Japanese did not fit in very well with preconceived notions of South Sea islands based chiefly upon romantic fiction and memories of Dorothy Lamour in a sarong.
LONDON, July 29 -- The two London couturiers, invited to design clothes for Australian women in preparation for next year's royal tour, showed their autumn fashions today.
GENEVA, July 29 -- The Soviet Union today made a plea for a new effort to reach a common ground for solution of European economic problems despite differences over the Marshall Plan.
Brooklyn's fight against the stench that has permeated the Marine Park section of the borough now is being waged with the intensity of a Dodger campaign for the National League pennant.
The New York State Banking Board has added to the legal list investment securities with a par value of $114,660,000, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday.

Shrugging off inquiries as to his whereabouts since last week, Robert G. Thompson, New York State chairman of the Communist party, surrendered to Federal authorities here yesterday to face an indictment charging that he and eleven other Communist leaders conspired to overthrow the United States Government by force.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A clear victory for the Southern Senators at this brief session of Congress in their fight against the anti-poll tax bill seemed more than possible tonight at the end of the first day of their gravely conducted filibuster.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29 -- Chief Walter Kirchoff of New Rochelle was elected president of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police today as the forty-eighth annual, three-day conference of the organization ended here. He succeeds Chief William Miller of this city.

MANILA, July 29 -- President Elpidio Quirino clarified his lenient attitude toward the Hukbalahap rebels today. Asked when he expected them to surrender their arms in accordance with his amnesty proclamation, he said he was not so much concerned with that as with the return of the peasants to the land.
The Sculptors Guild outdoor show, which opened nearly three months ago on a vacant lot at 18 Washington Square North, will close its long run on Sunday evening.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- The Berlin crisis cropped up openly here for the first time today with a surprise Syrian demand that the Big Four throw the whole controversy into the United Nations.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 26 (Delayed) -- Egypt's Premier, Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, declared today that the Administrative Council for Palestine that was set up by the Arab League two weeks ago was "quite definitely to be regarded as a prelude to an Arab Government for Palestine."

With tragic irony, it begins to appear that the airplane crash at Mount Carmel, Pa., last month, which brought death to the forty-three persons aboard, resulted from the malfunctioning of devices installed for the very purpose of providing greater safety in flight.

PARIS, July 29 -- Paulette's cloches, like those shown in her early June collection, have wide crowns and tiny brims. Some crowns are square, some mushroom. A Havana felt crown contrasts with a black velvet brim.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 -- A further sharp advance was reflected in business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Pronounced gains were reported in most lines of business, increases in industrial production and freight shipments being the more significant.

In a letter and report sent yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer the Citizens Budget Commission recommended adoption of the plan prepared by the Department of Marine and Aviation for rehabilitation and development of the city's piers and other waterfront facilities. The plan submitted by Marine and Aviation Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti calls for an expenditure of $58,268,000 of which the city would pay $54,848,000.
PORT DALHOUSE, Ont., July 29 (AP) -- The Buffalo West Side Rowing Club, defending champion, took the lead in the sixty-sixth annual Canadian Henley today, the second day of the four-day regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will decide, following testimony by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan next Monday, whether or not to recommend extra session ratification of the International Wheat Agreement asked by President Truman.

That the two major political parties have taken united action in a bipartisan international policy demonstrates that united action of parties, in times of crisis, is not only possible but to be expected in a democracy such as ours.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 24 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

BALTIMORE, July 29 -- Designation of Dr. Detlev Wulf Bronk, internationally known physicist and physiologist, as president of the Johns Hopkins University is expected to be formally announced tomorrow afternoon by the board of trustees.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 29 -- The four-page newspaper of the United Nations, retorting to Washington assertions that subversive elements had entered this country as employes of the world organization, printed a "warning" today that 3,000 cloaks and daggers might soon be issued here to facilitate spying.
BERLIN, July 30 (AP) -- United States officials speculated tonight that the Russians might declare closed one or more of the three air corridors used to fly supplies to Berlin.
One of the most constantly uncertain things in the progress of the giant Idlewild, Queens, airport from idea to reality has been its name.

BERLIN, July 30 -- The Soviet Military Administration simultaneously tightened the screws on industrial enterprises in the Western sectors of the city today and at the same time offered them relief from this pressure.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The pending anti-poll tax bill would strike down that qualification on voting not only in the general elections but in primaries as well, wherever these involved races for the Presidency and for the House and Senate.

MACAO, Portuguese China, July 30 (AP) -- The lone survivor of a plane crash that took twenty-five lives confessed today that his robber gang had caused the tragedy by trying to seize the airliner, Police Commissioner Luis A. M. Paletti announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- For the second time this week a Hollywood star has been suspended by a major studio. Latest to have differences with the front office is Eleanor Parker at Warner Brothers. Earlier Ray Milland was removed from the payroll indefinitely at Paramount.
A sleek fun-rigged, ship from Norway tied up at Pier 6 yesterday and attracted as much attention as a mermaid.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 30 (AP) -- Michael Parco, a 33-year-old driving range operator playing in his first tournament in ten years, exploded into the lead today in the forty-fifth Western Open golf championship.

Many small and medium-sized lumber mills in the North, South and Appalachian regions are "tottering on the brink of bankruptcy," the head of an important regional lumber manufacturers trade association, disclosed yesterday. He said that the industry as a whole is not making as much money as it did last year despite record high prices for its products.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total since March and to slightly below that of the corresponding month of last year. Sales crossed the million-share mark in only ten sessions, the largest of which was 2,567,430 shares on July 19. This also was the broadest market on record.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 30 -- Zoltan Tildy resigned as President of Hungary today and cleared the way for the Communists to tighten their grip on the country. An official announcement said leaders of the Government parties had accepted the resignation and that Parliament would meet Monday to name a successor.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Government resisted pressure in the House of Commons today to withdraw a deportation order issued against Frantisek Hampl, a Czech alleged to have been implicated in the passage of valuable information to an unnamed foreign power.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- A movement for pacifism and civil disobedience to the draft was inaugurated today by a group of clergymen, Quakers and their followers. They took the name Peacemakers as they opened a three-day meeting at the Olivet Institute.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Reports reaching Tokyo indicate that the authorities again are cracking down on the black market with raids and other repressive measures. This week the Nagoya police padlocked 1,200 stores for failure to obey earlier orders to end black-marketing and confiscated their stocks.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- Republican leaders in Congress tonight labeled President Truman's extra session call a "flagrant abuse" of the Presidential emergency powers, and asserted that they would not grant his requests for price control, rationing and a new excess profits tax.

Last minute efforts to prevent a strike on Monday at Oppenheim Collins Co. failed yesterday when the National Labor Relations Board ruled the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes, CIO, off the ballot in a collective-bargaining election at the concern the same day.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Establishment of a Pacific Northwest-Hawaii airline to be operated by Northwest Airlines for five years was approved today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Republican Congressional command, facing imminent defeat on the anti-poll tax bill, now hopes to adjourn the extra session by Aug. 7 and certainly no later than Aug. 14.

MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) -- It was understood here tonight that Ambassador Smith had not intended to ask Mr. Molotov for an appointment at any specific time when he sought an interview with the Soviet Foreign Minister on the German situation earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Devices for use in concrete building construction, signaling and recording systems, test timing of watches and telegraph circuits, gunnery training and aircraft controls and in medical and surgical practice were among the 416 inventions listed this week by the United States Patent Office.

A 31-year-old woman was arrested yesterday on a charge of endangering the health of a child after she allegedly had taken 2 1/2-year-old Jackie Gheis into a bar and grill Thursday and "lent" him out overnight to a kindly truck driver.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission approved today the export of high-voltage X-ray generators to England.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Foreign Office received a report tonight from Mr. Roberts. Its contents are being kept secret but indications point to an unwillingness to sit twiddling his thumbs in Moscow while Mr. Molotov takes a vacation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Five officials of Yugoslavia's Embassy in Washington and her delegation to the United Nations have signed a violent manifesto denouncing the Government of Marshal Tito, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Department of the Army increased the pensions of 315 retired enlisted men today. This is in accordance with a bill passed by Congress last month. The measure also assures similar rises to about 1,700 other men on pension.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 30 (AP) -- More than 10,000 New York National Guardsmen and reserve troops start arriving in this northern New York military reservation tomorrow for a two-week training period.

WASHINGTON, July 30, (AP) -- Marriner S. Eccles testified today that Mr. Truman's anti-inflation proposals were futile, contradictory and did not make economic sense. He credited the Democratic-controlled Congress and Truman Administration with removing wartime controls too soon and compared the new Truman proposals to "trying to put Humpty Dumpty together again" and "trying to fill up a bathtub with the stopper out."
New York was wetter, hotter, and, believe it or not, less humid than normal for July, the Weather Bureau announced yesterday.

New York International Airport will be dedicated today to the service of the nation, and the world's expanding aviation, in ceremonies led by the President of the United States. New York and New Jersey are appropriately joining in this event, which symbolizes the partnership in which we approach development of natural resources in this port area.

HAVANA, July 30 (AP) -- It was learned authoritatively today that preliminary agreement has been reached for modification of Cuban textile import controls that brought a storm of protest from the island's merchants and United States manufacturers.

Deems Taylor is to embark on a career as "a classical disk jockey," beginning Sept. 13, it was announced yesterday. His program, which will consist of classical recordings and interviews with concert artists, will be of a half-hour's duration and will be presented by means of transcriptions on independent stations.

A new book by Le Corbusier, "Concerning Town Planning," which has been translated from the French by Clive Entwistle, will be brought out by the Yale University Press on Sept. 1. The volume gives in question and answer form the essence of the architect's ideas on the growth of cities and the problems of their planning.
New financing here in July, as in the preceding month, showed contrasting movements.

Retail trade here this week showed little change over the corresponding week last year, due possibly to the fact that most stores were taking their midyear inventories. This resulted in a slight let-down in promotional and sales activity.

Marshall Field Co. reported yesterday for the first half of 1948 net sales of $100,753,250 compared with $95,757,260 in the corresponding period a year ago. Net profit, however, declined $110,309 to $4,694,523, or $2.25 a common share, from $4,804,832, or $2.31 a share, last year.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a contract-termination notice sent to the North American Philips Company, Inc., of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., by a United Electrical Workers, CIO, local was adequate even though the local failed to notify its international, as provided by the contract.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Count Bernadotte, after reporting today to the United Nations on the blocking of a convoy bound for Jerusalem, said that as of July 26 no regular troops were engaged in Jerusalem but that sniping was continuing on a small scale by irregular forces.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 30 (AP) -- A day which began with wild picket-line fighting and tear gas ended tonight with a bare possibility that the 86-day-old strike of United Electrical Workers (CIO) at the Univis Lens Company, might be settled.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- By a 7-3 vote the Soviet-led Danubian bloc tonight refused to include the English language as one of the official languages of the Danubian Conference and would concede only that it would be one of the "working languages."
The 1948 waterfowl regulations, with increases in the length of the open seasons in the central and Pacific flyway states, have been approved by the President.

The report of the death of Dr. Leo Winter in your July 8 issue hardly touches on the tragic consequences to the thousands of poor whom he treated yearly in the public hospitals. Nor does it take into account what he meant to his colleagues and students.

The Bethlehem Steel Company advised representatives of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, yesterday that there was "no basis for any further meeting" on the recent wage review.

In spite of their apparent optimism, manufacturers and wholesalers throughout the country are carrying large percentages of "inactive" merchandise in their inventories, Jack Sobel, former surplus merchandise manager for Sears, Roebuck Co., and now a private consultant, asserted in an interview yesterday.

The possibility that diet and medication may have much more to do with the rate of convalescence of patients recovering from ailments than heretofore has been supposed is being intensively studied at St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. A new report just issued by this institution gives hope that its fifteen-year program of research into convalescent therapy will provide much-needed short cuts to recovery.

Continuing a trend that has been in effect since 1946, when the peak of such refundings occurred, the retirement of outstanding bonds before maturity dates fell in July to one of the smallest monthly totals in more than a decade. The total of $20,711,000 contrasted with $420,286,000 for the corresponding month in 1947.

ALBANY, July 30 -- The State Health Department, announcing results in the fourth phase of its state-wide nutrition survey, reported today that teen-age boys are better eaters of such staple foods as meat, eggs and milk than girls.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Truman continued today his demands on Congress for curbs against inflation, warning that avoidance of a "business collapse," which he foresaw without his program, was prerequisite to a peaceful world.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Hogs soared today 75 cents to $1 a hundred pounds to a new peak of $31 in one of the liveliest sessions in many months as movement from farms continued to fall. The new top was 50 cents above the former record established Sept. 11, 1947, and paid again nineteen days ago on July 12.

Further details were announced yesterday concerning the elaborate program, "Tanglewood on Parade," to be presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Berkshire Music Center next Tuesday at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., as the opening event in a campaign to assist European musicians.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, who thought he had learned something about politics in his 76 years, decided today that he needed more schooling.

At least seven "third parties" are running candidates for the Presidency this year, a survey yesterday showed. Almost all are sharply critical of the "third party" that has been getting most of the attention and publicity -- Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party.
LONDON, July 30 -- At the collections of Worth and Angele Delanghe the highlights, as always, are cocktail and evening dresses in rich materials, of which there is a far greater choice this season.

Filing a petition in Federal court yesterday for an arrangement with creditors under the bankruptcy act, the Sword Line, Inc., of 52 Wall Street said the action was necessary because of the termination of its fleet charter by the Maritime Commission last Tuesday.

By next June, as the Air Force expands to authorized strength, nineteen bases in the great Southwest will hum and throb again. To them for the first time will go fresh 18-year-olds; but to far more veterans, many still in service, these bases are the very stuff and magic of memory. Clovis, Enid, Hobbs, Las Vegas, Lubbock, Waco, Perrin -- here the tyro learned the hero's trade.

When President Truman granted an honorable discharge to the United Service Organizations last January he bade its officers remain on call in the event an emergency developed making it necessary to revive the organization. The passage of the new Selective Service Act constitutes such an emergency and again USO is preparing to do its job.

NUREMBERG, Germany, July 30 -- Prison sentences ranging from a maximum of eight years to eighteen months were decreed here today for thirteen former directors and officials of the I. G. Farben chemical concern. The accused had been convicted of plunder and spoliation in various countries or of the exploitation and ill treatment of slave labor.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 30 -- Bob Sweeny, who flew here from England two days before the tourney started, reached the final of the metropolitan amateur championship over the Winged Foot Golf Club course today along with Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie.
New Yorkers who turn their eyes to the skies will see in the next few days the beginnings of America's post-war air power.

LONDON, July 30 -- Foreign Secretary Bevins' statement in the House of Commons yesterday on the Berlin situation caused the stock markets to falter today. The usual pre-holiday cheerfulness was absent.

Although millinery sales at retail are down, production in the New York area is equal to or better than a year ago, trade sources said yesterday. Millinery producers will reach their full fall production in the next three weeks with particular emphasis on budget lines retailing from $5 to $10.
