GENEVA, July 30 -- The aftermath of yesterday's Russian peace offensive in the United Nations Economic and Social Council has been a wave of bitterness among European and non-European council members at the United States and Britain for having forced a showdown vote on previous Russian criticisms of the European Recovery Program.

A 13-year-old Puerto Rican girl met death mysteriously shortly before last midnight in a plunge from the roof of a five-story apartment house at 727 East 158th Street, the Bronx, directly across the street from her home at 724 East 158th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- William W. Remington, Commerce Department official accused today before a Senate subcommittee of having given wartime military information to a Russian spy, said tonight, "I am not and never have been a member of the Communist party."

LONDON, July 30 -- Men swimmers of the United States, paced by smooth-muscled Wally Ris of the University of Iowa, swept to a one, two, three clean-up in the 100-meter free-style semi-finals of the Olympics in Empire Pool today.

Two foreign films, "A Friend Will Come Tonight" at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, and "Village Teacher," at the Stanley, are today's only holdover films. "Friend," the French import with Madeleine Sologne, Louis Salou and Michel Simon, will start a fourth week, while "Teacher," a Russian production, will go into a fifth week.

To Noble Hero, 3-year-old colt owned by Leo Gerngross, went the largest share of the purse in a $5,000 added Class C handicap that was the chief item of business before the house at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- The staff committee of the United Nations, representing 2,900 employes, protested today against recent Washington charges that subversives had entered the country through the organization.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- It is now taken for granted in the Capital that the Republican Party will continue to give its support, during the Presidential campaign, to bi-partisan foreign policy on questions that involve the security of the United States.

LONDON, July 30 (AP) -- Henry Wittenberg, New York policeman, won a decision tonight as he started his campaign for the 191-pound Olympic wrestling crown. Wittenberg defeated P. L. Mekavan of Finland, but received one black mark for not pinning his foe. Two were charged against the Finn for losing.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- A small field of only six thoroughbreds will race for $88,900 in the famed Arlington Classic tomorrow.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 30 (AP) -- The August issue of the Communist Information Bureau Bulletin, published today, accuses the United States of responsibility for attempts on the lives of Communist leaders in Italy and Japan.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- The league-leading Red Sox rebounded from a six-run uprising by the Indians in the first inning and went on to edge Cleveland, 8 to 7, tonight before a crowd of 58,862. The Sox increased their margin over the second-place Athletics to a game and a half.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- It took him four years to do it, but William F. Talbert of New York finally caught up with Frankie Parker today. He bounced the nation's top-ranking amateur out of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's sixtieth invitation tourney in the men's singles semi-finals, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Tommy Henrich, the old reliable, made a heroic bid tonight to carry almost the entire Yankee cast on his back as he exploded three hits, one of them a grand-slam homer, his third of the year.

The junior athletes of the Harlem Y. M. C. A. won the honors in track competition and baseball yesterday at the annual field day for the eight branches comprising the New York District of the Y. M. C. A., in which 1,000 boys and girls, 16 years old and under, participated.

There is good cause for concern in the statement of the chairman of the national traffic safety committee of the American Automobile Association that 55 per cent of highway fatalities can be attributed to intoxication either on the part of the motorist or pedestrian. Alcohol and gasoline simply do not mix.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (UP) -- The heads of three railroad brotherhoods announced today that they would seek a ruling by the United States Supreme Court on the legality of the injunction which prevented a nation-wide rail strike last May 11.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Labor Government refused today to intervene in the quarrel between India and Hyderabad over the refusal of the Princely State to join the dominion. The issue brought out an extraordinarily sharp and heated exchange between former Prime Minister Churchill and Prime Minister Attlee in the House of Commons this morning, just a few hours before its adjournment for the summer recess.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- President Truman's message to Congress transmitting his mid-year economic report follows:

Sales of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first half of 1948 were reported yesterday at $73,232,963, which contrasts with the $53,108,028 volume shown for the corresponding half of 1947.

In a letter published in your issue of July 8, C. Montieth Gilpin, secretary of the Society for the Prevention of World War III, takes the Government of Switzerland to task for what he calls defiance of the just demands of the Allies with regard to German-owned loot and property.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The year's peak in meat prices may come late in the summer or early fall, the Department of Agriculture said today.

LONDON, July 30 -- An Australian bank clerk with an injured back dealt a jolting setback to the United States in the high jump and shared honors with a Czechoslovak army officer suffering from a stomach ache today as competition in track and field started in the games of the XIV Olympiad before 60,000 spectators at Wembley Stadium.
The new 1948 pack of canned foods will begin to appear on retail counters in three or four weeks -- and the new prices will be a little higher than the old.

PARIS, July 30 -- A high French authority said today that the new Government would keep its eye on Washington and on the European Recovery Plan and that its major goal would be to make France independent of foreign aid by the time the Marshall Plan ended in 1952. This is understood to be the policy that Paul Reynaud, Finance Minister, will insist upon following.

The Theatre Guild will produce one of its pet projects next spring -- a musical version of "The Pursuit of Happiness" adapted by Dorothy and Herbert Fields with music by Burton Lane, it was disclosed yesterday.

The device that may save millions in airport costs by permitting planes to land cross wind received its official approved type certificate at New York International Airport at Idlewild from the Civil Aeronautics Administration yesterday.
LONDON, July 30 -- Ethiopia threatened today to rearm and close her frontiers with Eritrea and Somaliland if the Italians return as trustees to those colonies.

NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- The Indian Government today froze cloth and yarn supplies in some 400 textile mills pending a new price control program to be announced shortly. With removal of rationing on cloth in April, prices skyrocketed 100 per cent or more on finer grades and 80 per cent on coarse varieties.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decision banning the basing point price system in the cement industry has thrown business into confusion, Senator Capehart, Republican, of Indiana said today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy expert, conferred today with Chairman Charles A. Eaton of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the United Nations headquarters loan and the Berlin situation.

Inflation in the United States being largely "made in Washington," it is doubtful whether either political party will have the honesty and courage to take the essential steps to curb it. Inflation is basically the result of pandering to certain groups like labor, the farmers and the leftists, and heavy government spending for ERP, national defense and domestic "public welfare" projects.

Conceived in 1941 by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and his advisers as a 1,100-acre, municipal-owned air terminal to be called Idlewild, the modern Queens airfield by its opening had grown to 4,900 acres, moved over under the control of the Port of New York Authority and changed its name to New York International Airport.

PARIS, July 30 -- The French Assembly today voted a 400,000,000 franc loan (about $1,860,000) to the French motion-picture industry to help it over its present economic doldrums. The same law also calls for an approximately 20 per cent tax on movie theatre tickets to cover the loan, which must be repaid by the end of 1949.
NANKING, July 30 -- The Communist radio instructed Red field commanders tonight to prepare their troops for "city warfare," to "carry the revolution deep into Kuomintang territories."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Gregory and Gearhart bills to make Blair House the temporary residence of the next Vice President until an official home can be built for him is likely to crash head-on with plans already afoot in Congress to make Blair House the temporary home of the President until the White House can be fireproofed and propped up.

Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, home economist in THE NEW YORK TIMES test kitchen, has discovered a new dessert. Made with dry skim milk, it's a creamless ice cream that is high in nutrients, low in calories and cost. What's more, this frozen dessert equals the richest ice cream in smoothness and deliciousness.

Five thousand dollars worth of homemade speedboat lay a charred hulk last night in the waters of the Hudson River off South Yonkers -- and with her sank the hopes of a syndicate of Bronx speed enthusiasts.

In special session yesterday the Board of Estimate appropriated $310,000 to pay the cost of a type of landfill on the Marine Park project in South Brooklyn that will eliminate the noxious odors against which 40,000 residents of the area have registered indignant complaints.

LONDON, July 30 -- The ground-work of an aggressive international labor organization to combat Communist attacks against United States aid to Europe was laid today at the final session of the International Trade Union Conference on the European Recovery Program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- The United States has been asked for arms and ammunition to defend Southern Korea against possible attacks from Soviet-occupied Korea in the north, it was announced here today by Louise Yim, the Korean representative at the United Nations.

Designated by the Attorney General's office as a "key corporation" in relation to American defense, the American Bosch Corporation passed yesterday from control of the Alien Property Custodian to the Amra Corporation, Brooklyn manufacturer of electronic devices.

A 12-year-old boy was in a critical condition last night at St. Clare's Hospital after having been struck by an automobile at Seventh avenue and Forty-fourth Street. The accident drew a large number of persons in the heavily crowded Times Square area.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 30 (UP) -- Six persons were known to be dead tonight in the explosion of a coal mine here and miners refused to enter three other pits owned by the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company's Edgewater mine which was blasted by a gas explosion earlier today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Ninety youngsters from forty-five states converged on the capital today for the third annual American Legion Boys' Forum of National Government.

The stock market slumped yesterday to the lowest levels since last April under a flurry of selling through the late morning and early afternoon. When pressure lifted there was a weak attempt at recovery which reduced some of the peak losses. The closing composite rate showed a decline of almost 2 points, but there were much wider setbacks in some groups, such as the oils.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Sale of the Government-owned part of the Todd-Houston Shipbuilding Corporation plant at Houston, Tex., to Phillips Chemical Co., for $1,400,000 cash was approved today by the War Assets Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Paul A. Porter, President Truman's inflation control advocate, returned to the Capitol today to face Republican accusations that the Administration's demands for brakes on the economy did not square with its demands for more spending money.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 30 -New York state historians, convened here for their three-day annual session, lifted the curtain today on several more epochs in ths history of the state.

Irving Poretz, admitted "master-plotter" of the $493,000 swindle perpetrated by William B. Benjamin, now in Sing Sing, was transferred yesterday from the Manhattan City Prison to start serving a sentence of three to four years in Sing Sing.

The Italian-flag liners Vulcania and Saturnia will omit eastern Mediterranean calls hereafter and operate in a direct New York-Naples-Genoa service, it was announced yesterday by the American Export Lines, agents for the Italian service.
Dire forecasts of oil supply shortages, including a gasoline famine for motorists this summer, were minimized yesterday by a check of the petroleum industry.

LONDON, July 30 -- Negotiations will begin soon between Newfoundland and Canada with a view to Newfoundland becoming Canada's tenth province. An announcement from the Commonwealth Relations Office tonight stated that Canada was willing to admit Newfoundland into confederation and that the British Government, as the responsible authority for the island, agreed with this course.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A contract ending the long wage dispute between the railroads and the unions of firemen, engineers and switchmen is almost ready for signature, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Truman's proposals to curb inflation by increasing the reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System and reimposing consumer credit controls received the full support today of John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

NEWARK, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- Bounding back from two straight defeats, Newark used the homerun trail to a double victory over Rochester tonight. Ted Sepkowski's seventeenth of the season with two on and one out in the seventh and final inning won the opener, 6 -- 5, then a three-run blast by Lou Novikoff in the first inning of the nightcap set the stage for a 5-1 triumph.
Measured by almost any standard, New York International Airport appears to be deserving of its title "world's greatest airport."

OTTAWA, July 30 -- Newfoundland's inclusion in the Canadian federation as a tenth province has been agreed to in principle by the Canadian and British Governments following the recent plebiscite of the island population that gave a majority of 6,500 for confederation in a close vote.
A "final" extension until Tuesday was granted yesterday for the Metropolitan Opera's deadline on union settlements, the Metropolitan Opera Association announced.

JERUSALEM, July 30 -- There were growing signs in this city today that the present United Nations truce would not be of long duration. Some persons said they believed the lull might not last beyond the middle of August unless some radical measures were taken by the United Nations to prevent its authority here being challenged by truce breaches.

Final arrangements for reaching the air show at New York International Airport, Idlewild, opening today, indicate that most of the spectators will depend on a special fleet of more than 400 city and Green line buses.

RHODES, July 30 -- Two landing craft loaded with arms and ammunition left Bari, Italy on Monday for Israel in violation of the truce, the Egyptian Government alleged in a complaint received here today by Count Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator on Palestine.

A rumor that the Ford Motor Company inadvertently had released four 1949 Ford models fitted with secret equipment assuring sixty miles on a gallon of gasoline was denied yesterday by Charles J. Seyffer, northeast regional manager.

Hundreds of workers toiled by searchlights' glare last night in eleventh-hour preparation of New York International Airport for dedication today by President Truman. Elsewhere on the field's 4,900 acres soldiers, sailors, pilots and their plane crews labored at arranging more than a mile of static air-arm exhibits.

THIS morning we have two books that tell their stories mainly through exceptionally striking photographs, two books that emphasize the people and their land, two books that come from places half the earth apart -- and yet together illustrate the oneness of the world.

Giant fans who used to ask whether their favorites won now take that for granted and merely inquire if the opposition scored. The answer, sad to relate, was "yes" last night at the Polo Grounds, where Leo Durocher's spirited athletes barely missed their fourth straight shutout victory, settling for a 9-1 triumph.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., July 30 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club crew won the Syce Cup and the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today after a three-day-round-robin regatta off the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

The abolition of the poll tax in seven Southern states cannot be regarded as an emergency. Even the President's Committee on Civil Rights, reporting last year, did not so treat it. The Committee recommended "prompt state action," failing which it believed that "the nation, either by act of Congress or by constitutional amendment, should remove this final barrier to universal suffrage."

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will be 70 years old on Friday. He will observe his birthday quietly at his summer home, which is in the midst of acres of woodland near Heath, Franklin County, Mass.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Gilbert Green, district chairman of the Communist party in Chicago, surrendered today to the United States marshal.

ROME, July 30 -- The Italian Government won a parliamentary victory today when Luigi Longo, spokesman for the Socialist-Communist opposition, withdrew a motion of no confidence. The motion had been submitted after the shooting of Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, two weeks ago.

HYDERABAD, July 30 (UP) -- Indian troops have wrecked one Hyderabad village and occupied another in "grave, flagrant violation of the territorial integrity of Hyderabad," the Government charged today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- New housing may price itself out of the market "in a few years at most" if present costs continue, the President's Council of Economic Advisers asserted today.

Three men, said by the police to have stolen $150,000 worth of men's and women's clothing from the Railway Express Agency in the last year and a half were under arrest yesterday charged with grand larceny and criminally receiving stolen goods.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Japan's labor unions today reached a state of revolt against Premier Hitoshi Ashida's interpretation of General MacArthur's letter of July 22, advising the Japanese administration to strip Government employes of collective bargaining and the right to strike.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved the admission of the New York securities firm of J. A. Sisto Co. into the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 30 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, initiated steps today toward the unfreezing of foreign assets in the bizonal area. This would be the first step in the program designed eventually to permit foreign investment in Germany, which at present is under a "moratorium."

VIENNA, July 30 -- The Russian representative on the Allied Council fought unsuccessfully today to check the expenditure of 300,000,000 schillings by the Austrian Government for the purpose of strengthening Austria's contribution to the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- An early objective of the Economic Cooperation Administration is to break down the almost universal dollar trading currently practiced by the sixteen European countries joined in the Marshall Plan, Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman said today.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers staged their biggest scoring spree of the season tonight as they beat the Athletics, 17 to 2, with 17 hits before a crowd of 45,996 fans.

In keeping with his plan to streamline the Fire Department, Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday the assignment of the seventeen new deputy chiefs of staff and operations, who had been sworn in last Tuesday.

LONDON, July 30 -- Eire officially withdrew her team from the swimming and diving competition of the eleventh Olympic Games today in protest against the International Swimming Federation's action in barring two Eire athletes because they had been born in Northern Ireland.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Spirsfi-I la, 5-year-old mare owned by Clifford Lussky of Louisville, led all] the vTay to defeat Joe A. Good-] win's Song Sparrow, 3--5 favorite,[ by three lengths in the $4,000! Northport Purse at Arlington Park! today. E. R. IVforris' Boat iVfan finished third in the 1-mile event that was run in 1:51 2/5. Spirsilla,: ridden by Freddie Smith, was over-i looked by the 14,249 fans and-laid $20.60.

ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) -- Rae Scarborough stopped the Browns with four scattered hits tonight and the Senators edged the St. Louis, 3 to 2. Neither Brownie run was earned. Gil Coan scored two runs for the Senators, the first on his sixth homer in the first inning.
The Bricklayers Apprentice Training School. opened last spring to provide recruits for the bricklayers' trade here, will close in about two weeks, it became known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 30 -- Joseph E. Johnson, deputy United States representative, said here today it was a "reasonable probability" that the Soviet Union and the other states of the Eastern bloc that had boycotted the United Nations Little Assembly would join it next year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 30 -- A detachment of United States Marines -- along with Belgian and French -- is expected to arrive here within a few days for assignment in the crucial Latrun area. It is there that United Nations observers have been unable twice to take through to Jerusalem a convoy on the main highway because of Arab guerrilla threats.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was a narrow, featureless affair yesterday and final prices were 3 to 10 points net lower than on Thursday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 30 -- A group of 158 night shift employes who walked out of the local plant of the Westinghouse Electric Elevator Corporation last night, protesting the firing of a shop steward, returned to their jobs at 6:30 o'clock tonight after a conference between plant officials and officers of Local 456, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, a CIO affiliate.

The board of directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, at its meeting held in San Francisco yesterday, voted a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1. The company previously had paid 30 cents in each quarter.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday it would start legal action against railroads operating in New York for having allegedl yviolated the law by instructing agents not to post-date tickets.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, the confessed former Communist espionage agent whose testimony led to the recent indictment of twelve national leaders of that party, dramatically identified a Department of Commerce official, William W. Remington, today as one of many Government aides who had given her military information which she forwarded to Russia.

A number of small fry singers, dancers and comedians, all between the ages of 5 and 14 years, participated in an amateur show held yesterday by the Educational Alliance for children living on the Lower East Side.

Veterans of World War II lined up by the hundreds yesterday to reinstate their National Service Life Insurance term policies. The deadline for reinstatement without physical examination will be midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The possibility that United States, British and French diplomats in Moscow may attempt to deal directly with Premier Stalin on the Berlin impasse was seen here tonight.

FRIBOURG, Switzerland, July 30 -- About 150 educators from seventeen countries formally adopted a constitution for the permanent organization of the International Council of Christians and Jews at a meeting here.

With the designation of Dr. Detlev M. Bronk as president of Johns Hopkins, science must reconcile itself to the retirement but not necessarily to the inactivity of Dr. Isaiah Bowman at the age of seventy. All his pedagogic and professional life Dr. Bowman has been a geographer, but not in the old narrow sense.

There was fun in Flatbush last night but neither the Dodgers nor the 31,278 fans who braved the heat and humidity of Ebbets Field had any of it. The Pirates had all the laughs, twice as many runs and twice as many hits, beating the Brooks, 10 -- 5.

Miss Sue Weddell, secretary for India and Pakistan of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, will sail next Friday on the Queen Elizabeth on a triple mission. She first will confer with mission leaders in France and England.
A boxing program that will include two world championship bouts was arranged yesterday by the Tournament of Champions, Inc., for Ebbets Field on a night during the last part of September.

After two weeks of intensive efforts, representatives of the Publishers Association of New York City and the International Typographical Union, AFL, completed work yesterday on proposals for a complete new contract between the union and twelve daily newspapers.
HAVANA, Cuba, July 30 (AP) -- In Cuba, the sugar outlook turned optimistic today.
W. B. Lockwood's phenomenal little 34-year-old Herreshoff sloop Dolphin, winner in 1947 of the Bayside Y. C.'s Block Island Race and the defending champion this week-end, may be doing it again.

Alarmed by a growing tendency on the part of the public to refuse information to legitimate marketing and opinion canvassers because of fake use of the survey approach by door-to-door salesmen, marketing groups here are working on a comprehensive program designed to effect swift counter - action against present and new instances of the "racket," it was learned yesterday.
A 39-year-old fire battalion chief riding on an IRT subway train yesterday was the hero of 350 other passengers when he supervised fighting a small blaze that broke out in the ceiling of one car.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Andy Seminick's second home run of the game, his fifth in four consecutive contests, his eighth of the season and his sixth in five days, sent the Phillies on to an 8-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

WITH TASK FORCE 19 OFF HONOLULU, July 30 (UP) -- The old battleship Nevada, survivor of two world wars and two atomic bombs, was sunk today by the combined shelling, bombing and torpedoing of Navy and Air Force might. The doughty old dreadnought, still radio-active from the Bikini atom bomb tests, rolled over and sank after torpedoes from Navy torpedo bombers smashed into her sides.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Grain prices were on the downgrade on the Board of Trade today with all deliveries of corn, oats, rye, soy beans and May wheat selling at new seasonal lows, and the markets showed little disposition to rally.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 30 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., of Baltusrol, overcoming the heat wave and a very long course, won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with 41, 40 -- 81 over the south course of Canoe Brook Country Club today.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- Dr. Almac, homebred son of Happy Argo and Sallandry, belonging to Mrs. J. V. Stewart of Elkton, Md., became a repeater at the Monmouth Park meeting when he beat seven 3-year-old rivals in the six-furlong fifth race today.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- A special Federal grand jury, which for ten months has investigated high living costs in Chicago, today returned indictments charging eight major milk companies and nine of their officers with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, and two of the companies, with eight officers, with violating the Robinson-Patman act by giving rebates to chain stores.
Lorenzo Carra, small, wiry Italian waiter at the Brevoort Hotel for the last twenty-two years, shook his head slowly.

New issues of tax-exempt obligations will figure largely in next week's new capital issues, and of these the short-term obligations of the New York City Housing Authority will have the greatest part. On Tuesday the Authority will take bids on $10,000,000 of notes, and on Thursday notes totaling $26,191,000 will be put up for sale.

With the official opening of Idlewild Airport the traffic problems of southern Queens and the south shore of Long Island will become much worse than they are -- and they are very bad indeed now. Idlewild Airport will mean more than just a few passengers traveling back and forth from Manhattan every day -- it will greatly increase real estate development of all sections adjacent to the airport.
LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany, July 30 (AP) -- French authorities officially estimated tonight that Wednesday's explosion and fire at the huge I. G. Farben chemical plant caused $15,000,000 worth of damage.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company reported to stockholders yesterday a net income of $7,968,131, equal to $4.58 a share of common stock for the twelve months ended with June. This compares with $7,738,263, or $4.43 a common share for the preceding twelve months. Gross revenues of $32,173,865, compared with $29,065,211 a year before.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Behind the gilt edged pitching of Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, who had one bad inning when the home forces scored both their runs, the Cardinals tonight defeated the Braves, 6 -- 2, before a crowd of 37,071. The triumph snapped a St. Louis losing streak at four games and ended an equally long Boston winning streak.

PARIS, July 31 -- Throughout the recent Government crisis and as Premier Andre Marie's new coalition Cabinet gets under way, there has been repetition to a high degree of talk that this is the last chance of the Fourth Republic of France.

THE New York City Opera Company and Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera are both dickering to go to Chicago for seasons at the Civic Opera House. The Chicago Opera Company is not presenting a season of its own and the other companies want to fill the void, for Chicago is used to opera in the autumn.

ANNOUNCEMENT of the beginning of construction of a 1,000-car garage at the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel was hailed by traffic experts as a major step in the right direction toward easing city traffic congestion.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- America's favored skyscrapers of the court sat on the sidelines today and watched the rest of the world battle for places in the Olympic basketball tournament.

BETWEEN the Fort Laramie Treaty and the short-lived Sioux "rebellion" of 1891 are four decades of deceit, of lies, of fear, of vacillation, and -- above all -- of complete misunderstanding. Perhaps the story of the Plains Wars will never be told objectively, but "Stanley Vestal" -- William Stanley Campbell, Professor of English, University of Oklahoma, and profound scholar of frontier history -- at least approaches objectivity.

COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY has recently established a School of the Theatre which looks forward to a career of great significance for the American theatre. This is not its first manifestation of interest in that important branch of education.

PORTENT in the Sky: Members of the Authors League are now advised to contact the Television Committee of the League before entrusting their brain-children to video. A portent indeed, for the author-of-tomorrow -- and the author of day-before-yesterday, who signed away his television rights with his first Hollywood contract.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 31. -- A fleet of 181 craft turned out today for the Echo Bay Yacht Club's two-day regatta. In addition to the regular Yacht Racing Association competition the annual Comet Class tests for the Long Island Sound title started.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP) -- The Browns outslugged the Senators tonight, 10 to 8, evening the series at a game apiece. Al Zarilla and Hank Arft drove in three runs each for the Browns and Gil Coan batted in four for the Senators.

THE diagnosis, treatment and prevention of personality disorders is a primary concern of modern man. He is aware that our Selective Service Boards of World War II rejected 1,850,000 men because they were judged poor psychiatric risks; that anxieties and neuroses hinder vocational advancement and prevent the experiencing of deep happiness and security.

With a record total of thirty-eight rookies listed the New York Giants will begin training Tuesday at Superior, Wis., for their twenty-fourth season in the National Football League. Coach Steve Owen believes that he will be starting with the best squad in the club's history.

Passing a three-story building in Brooklyn, a bricklayers union official was injured fatally yesterday when he was struck by a pile of bricks, stone and mortar that gave way from the roof of the structure.
SHANGHAI, July 31 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek flew to Shanghai late yesterday, apparently for conferences on China's growing economic crisis.

Adoption of an ordinance by the Japanese Cabinet banning strikes by Japanese Government workers, who make up more than half of Japan's 5,000,000 organized laborers, legalizes what already was a fact. Last year General MacArthur forbade such a strike.

EVER since the end of the war, the deep-rooted instinct of the English writer to escape into Europe and remote islands has been reasserting itself -- that envie d'ailleurs which Marcel Pagnol once stressed in his play, "Marius."

THIS is the best time of year to plant or move tall bearded iris. If set in the ground now, the plants will have almost a year in which to anchor their roots, develop strong foliage and otherwise establish themselves before the big effort of flower production comes round next June.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The National Farm Labor Union (AFL) today asked Federal action to tighten controls over the importation of foreign agricultural workers.

WHILE the conventionally accepted Sikorsky and Bell helicopters, with some others less well known, are demonstrating the wide range of their abilities at the New York International Airport's show this week, a young engineer is busy at Bradley Field, Windsor Locks, Conn., putting through CAA certification tests a rotary-wing aircraft that promises to do away with some of the handicaps of its predecessors.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- Every American wrestler still was in the running for an Olympic title tonight after almost two full days of continuous elimination bouts.

CHICAGO, July 3l -- The Yankees, after three successive nocturnal engagements, went back on the day shift today and there was an immediate improvement in the general deportment of the world champions, even though two of their frontline performers were sidelined with ailments.

records, memoirs of Civil War statesmen, until he had exhumed a composite portrait of the First Lady of the Civil War. According to her admirers, Miss Carroll rated full military honors for her services to the Union. Her detractors regard her deferentially as an outstanding traitor who sold the South down the river for Yankee gold and prestige.

LONDON, July 31 -- Harrison Dillard, world record-breaking hurdler turned sprinter, scored a tremendous victory of vindication today to touch off an American stampede in the Games of the XIV Olympiad.

THE Horticultural Society of New York has moved its headquarters and library to the Essex House, 157 West Fifty-eighth Street. Organized in 1900, this club for amateur, professional and commercial gardeners had been located at 598 Madison Avenue for twenty-seven years.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- The fast-stepping Phillies extended their winning streak to five straight today by toppling the skidding Reds, 4 -- 3 and 4 -- 1.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 31 -- President Truman arrived at Fairfax Airport across the Missouri River from here at 7:50 o'clock (C.S.T.) tonight (9:50 P.M. New York time) and motored immediately to his home at Independence.

MAY this motion-picture theatre exhibitor offer his reaction to Mr. Odets' plaintively voiced relief at returning to the Broadway Valhalla, from the viewpoint of a playgoer and also one who sees all of Hollywood's major product?

Sixty-one promotions and seventy-two appointments to faculty posts have been made at the Long Island College of Medicine, 350 Henry Street, Brooklyn, Dr. Jean A. Curran, president, announced yesterday. He said the additions increased the faculty to approximately 500.

Formerly a football assistant at Broom, Harvard, Connecticut and Northeastern, Major Harold W. Kopp has been appointed a member of the gridiron staff at Yale. Kopp, a graduate of Western Maryland, will report later this month to Head Coach Herman Hickman and will work with the Eli varsity.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, confessed wartime courier for a Communist espionage ring, today named Lauchlin Currie, a trusted assistant of the late President Roosevelt for six years, and Harry Dexter White, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, as two sources of secret information that was transmitted to the Soviet Union.

In Hungary's last free election, three years ago, the Small Landholders party polled 57 per cent of the vote. The Communists polled 17 per cent, the Socialists about the same. Zoltan Tildy, who helped found the Landholders party in 1930 and who had showed some fortitude by his underground activities during the German occupation, became Premier and then President.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 31 (AP) -- A shipping expert came to this repository of American maritime tradition today to plead for a merchant fleet which would carry "at least 50 per cent of our imports and exports."
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The State Department recounted today the story of a pig that nearly caused a war between the United States and Britain. It hapriod, 1859-63.

OMAHA, July 31 -- Farmers, who must plan farther ahead than most Americans, are beginning to think in terms of possible crop surpluses while their fellow-citizens gnash their teeth over sky-high food prices.
SCIENCE has come to the aid of America's ten million hay fever sufferers, who are now planning their annual escapes from pollen-heavy areas during the North's big ragweed season -- Aug. 15 to Oct. 1.

Two patrolmen captured a six-foot, 200-pound 20-year-old robber suspect after a chase yesterday afternoon on Tenth and Eleventh Avenues. He was accused of menacing a haberdasher with a pistol and taking $32 from the cash register.

"THE PLAGUE" is parable and sermon, and should be considered as such. To criticize it by standards which apply to most fiction would be to risk condemning it for moralizing, which is exactly where it is strongest. "The Plague" stands or falls by its message.
A young Brooklyn burglary gang, which started its crime career by robbing the father of one of its members, was taken into custody yesterday by police of the Classon Avenue Precinct.

The economy of Germany should be returned to the German people at the earliest possible time "under regulations imposed and administered by their elected representatives," Dr. Horace Taylor, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Thank you for the fair-minded exposition in "The ABC (or XYZ) of Abstract Art." After two world-shaking wars in a generation, artists, like leaders in economics, physics, chemistry and sociology, are seeking new answers to our problems.

The executive board of the Committee for Justice and Peace in the Holy Land charged yesterday that the recent statements of Mosche Shertok, Foreign Minister of Israel, indicated the intention of its government to expand by conquest the borders of the state beyond those recommended by the United Nations General Assembly and including Jerusalem, which the United Nations has designated as an international zone.

ELLERY QUEEN, whose prodigious output of anthologies and original detective novels, short stories and plays makes one think him not a pair of authors but a syndicate, has edited for the Living Library a collection of fourteen contemporary short detective stories and a critical check-list of the genre, "Queen's Quorum."

Battling in dense smoke a fire in the basement and sub-basement of the six-story brick loft building at 3-5 Washington Place, at Mercer Street yesterday afternoon, one fireman died and some twenty-five others suffered smoke poisoning, two seriously enough to require hospitalization.

WHEN Dusty Rhodes swung down from the train at a water tank in northern Nevada, where he was to take up a job as cowboy for the Double Seven, he stepped right into the middle of a range war. For the MR Ranch, to the east of the Double Seven, was a sheep and cattle outfit whose owners recognized no law.

ONE of the more engrossing and unpredictable pages of American collecting and taste has opened again before the public eye -- if it ever, indeed, had quite closed -- with Kennedy Co.'s show of a group of Currier Ives prints.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Civilian employment in the Executive Branch of the Federal Government was increased by 26,004 employes in June. This made a total of 2,092,301, with the increase averaging 866 a day, it was disclosed today by the Joint Comittee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures.

THE American Dance Festival, which opens on Aug. 13 at Connecticut College, New London, has added a twelfth performance, which will make its closing date Sunday afternoon, Aug. 22. Half of the twelve performances will be given by Martha Graham and her company, and the remaining six will be divided evenly between Jose Limon and his company and the Jane Dudley-Sophie Maslow-William Bales trio and their company.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens did not attend the official dedication of the new airport and opening of the nine-day International Air Exposition at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday afternoon, he announced, because he felt "snubbed" at the official luncheon held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, before the air show.

ONE of the more interesting developments in the offices of the American National Theatre and Academy this summer has been the increasing number of requests for professional players to appear in university and community theatres.

MR. HARDIN CRAIG's interpretation of Shakespeare and Mr. G.B. Harrison's elaborate, impressively annotated edition of twenty-three plays and the sonnets are scholarly and historical in orientation; yet both fortunately avoid that curious combination of scientific reconstruction and free-wheeling speculation which sometimes passes for historical criticism.

Nearly 2,000 Waves and former Waves gathered yesterday at the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel for their second annual reunion. The purpose of these women, from most sections of the country, was to form a permanent organization of former members of the Women's Reserve of the Navy.

A disservice has been done to baseball in the article, "Out Where the Boo Begins -- the Bleachers." One not familiar with the niceties of the sport might conclude that unsportsmanlike attitudes are assumed in those sections of the spectators' domain most distant from the main scene of activity, viz., the home platter.

MANY Americans know John Hancock only by his "John Hancock," that strong and bold signature to the Declaration of Independence. In a competent biography, Mr. Allan invests the signature with flesh -- flesh proud and Madeira-soaked, but patriotic and serviceable to this country.

In preparation for a possible full-scale mobilization tomorrow against the widespread Woolworth chain, thousands of members of Local 65, Wholesale and Warehouse Union, CIO, picketed yesterday 500 stores of the company in this country and Canada.

BERLIN, July 31 -- Both sides in the great political contest between East and West are moving slowly, falteringly and with many detours, toward negotiation, first, of the German problem centered around Berlin and then perhaps to related problems in Europe.

For thirteen months, beginning around June, 1947, a Federal grand jury in New York conducted a secret investigation of communism. During the hearings there were reports that the jury would accuse Communists of espionage. Instead, at the close of the investigation twelve days ago, the jury indicted twelve top American Communists on charges of conspiring to overthrow the United States Government by force.

CENTRAL CITY, forty miles west of Denver, was just a ghost of an old mining town less than two decades ago. More than 8,000 feet high in the Rockies, it had known some years of splendor in the Seventies and Eighties when it was famed as part of the richest square mile in the country.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 31 -- A fifteen-foot putt for a birdie 3 by William Govern on the first extra hole enabled him and his guest, Frank Simonson of the Cherry Valley Club, to nip P.J. McDermott and John Riley, Garden City Country Club, by 1 up in the semi-final round of the seventh annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

THIS "Defense of Modern Woman" arouses uneasy speculation about the emphasis we have placed on exhibiting a sense of humor. The question arises, Have we overdone it? The reader who receives the full impact of Ruth Herschberger's lunges with the blunt instrument of her wit will be forced to vote in the affirmative.
Your editorial about Princeton's new library described interestingly the new gift of memorabilia relating to Woodrow Wilson. It is indeed quite fitting that such a gift should have been made.

JOAN WINTER comes home from college with a burning ambition to become a professional writer, and with very little practical knowledge of how to set about it. David, the boy next door, is just out of the Army and similarly perplexed about his chosen career in the arts.

Rolling back prices to the November 1947 level as suggested by the Truman Administration as a means of reducing the cost of living would be a most difficult undertaking. In view of past experiences, such an attempt might seriously harm the nation's economy.

BRACE BEEMER came out of the badlands the other day, traveling to New York to appear on programs observing the Lone Ranger's fifteenth anniversary on the kilocycles. Within the shelter of the Hotel Plaza Mr. Beemer dropped the black mask he wears to protect his anonymity as the hard-riding foe of evil-doers in ABC's episodes on the Old West (Monday, Wednesday, Friday, at 7:30 P.M.).

The thirteen million homes in Great Britain burn about sixty million tons of coal a year -- one-third of the total British production. Now that Great Britain has to pinch and scrape in order to increase its exports, the Government is looking into the way coal is consumed, certain that wastes can be reduced.
CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP) -- Patient "X," a former electrical engineer, entered his 2,001st day in total coma at Bethesda Hospital yesterday.

It took Col. A.D. Clark and his Seventh Bomber Wing almost eight hours to fly here yesterday from their base at Carswell Field, Fort Worth, Tex. All they saw was a glimpse of the New York International Airport at Idlewild. Then they turned around and flew right back to Texas.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP) --The Athletics put together a pair of three-run uprisings today and rode to an 8 to 3 decision over the Tigers behind the effective relief pitching of Lefty Lou Brissie.

Governor Dewey, participating yesterday in the formal dedication of International Airport at Idlewild, described the new field as a monument to the idea of voluntary cooperation between states and various levels of government. It is a living example, he said, of what men of good-will can do in surmounting technical obstacles, local prejudices and even suspicion and obstruction.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, July 31 -- Working parties of representatives of the United States, British and French Military Governments have been established to plan a trizonal administrative set-up to exercise control over the projected Western German government.

THE Four Aces passenger fleet of the American Export Lines will return in September to the Atlantic run to Mediterranean ports, bearing the same names as the old ones -- Excalibur, Exochorda, Exeter and Excambion.

Dissatisfied with the present margin of profits, even after taking into account the higher revenues from the recent substantial price increases, steel leaders warned last week that the in dustry might be compelled to raise its prices again soon unless cost trends were reversed.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- The National League-leading Braves tonight edged the Cardinals, 7 to 6, thanks to Pinch Hitter Sibby Sisti's base-clearing triple to deepest right center field in the last of the ninth inning.

THE name of Paul Revere, as every schoolboy is duly instructed, would have been long remembered even if he had never performed his equestrian services for the early patriots. His excellence as a silversmith was a good deal more than the local eminence of a provincial craftsman.

IN a review of my book, "The Masquerade in Spain," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 13, Mr. Herbert L. Matthews, while calling it "an essentially sound and thoroughly honest book," condemns my account of the fall of Madrid in April, 1939, as "an outrageous travesty on the facts" and reports that my account was "evidently had on hearsay, for his bibliography lists no authoritative account of it."

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31 (AP) -- The Harvard-Yale tennis team retained possession of the Prentice Cup by taking five out of six matches from the combined Oxford-Cambridge team today for a score of 9 -- 3 in the two-day tournament.

Multiple taxation has been indulged in to a greater extent by the Federal Government than by any other taxing authority. Instead of finding new subjects to tax, the Government has, in effect, superimposed additional taxes upon bases already taxed.

Command of the Furness Bermuda Line's "new" Queen of Bermuda has been assigned to Capt. L.F. Banyard, according to word received yesterday at the company's New York offices from Sir Ernest H. Murrant, chairman of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., London.

After several months of trial service the Moore-McCormack Lines has decided to make permanent a new freight run 1,000 miles up the Amazon River to Manos, Brazil, it was reported last week by Commodore Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the company, on his return from a tour of South American offices.

BRIDGE players generally are familiar with the proper play of a suit in which dummy has K 7 6 2 and declarer has A Q 10 5. The ace is cashed, then the five is led to the king. If the hand at declarer's left shows out, a finesse may be taken to the Q 10, and without wasting an entry.

The Westchester Kennel Club, which is running its annual all-breed event at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, on Sept. 12, has adopted a policy of releasing dogs no longer needed for judging that may set a pattern for other outdoor fixtures.

AFTER careful observation of beaver ways and a study of their habits, Mr. Henderson has written this interesting story of a beaver family. Amik is an admirable, energetic little beaver, who early becomes the leader of his own brother and two sisters.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 -- Camargo galloped to an easy victory in the Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park today. Opposing only four others in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test the 4-year-old daughter of Heliopolis carved out a two-length triumph over her closest pursuer, the Cain Hoy Stable's Imprudence II.

The jeers that were his exclusive fare as a Polo Grounds alien turned to cheers yesterday for Leo Durocher. He had just piloted his Giants to second place in the National League pennant race by taking the first game of a twin bill with the Cubs under cover of the most savage assault the Harlem clan has mustered this year.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va. -- The revolutionary new central reservation bureau of the Chesapeake Ohio, situated in this bustling metropolis of the Mountain State, has just completed its first six months of operation and the results have exceeded expectations, according to D.F. O'Connell, manager of the bureau.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 31 -- Dr. Francis E. Kent, Yonkers physician and surgeon, was taken to Police Headquarters for questioning this evening after his wife, Mrs. Helen Kent, 47 years old, was shot dead in their home at 19 Heights Drive.

THE American household is on the threshold of a revolution. The Wife scarcely knows where the kitchen is, let alone her place in it. Junior scorns the late-afternoon sunlight for the glamour of the darkened living room. Father's briefcase lies unopened in the foyer.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 31 (AP) -- The Buffalo West Side Rowing Club swept to its second-straight club championship at the Canadian Henley today and retained its title in the senior eights, co-feature of the regatta's final day.

Agreement with the view that national consumer credit is "getting out of hand and adding to the national inflationary spiral" was voiced last week by the credit manager of a department store with an annual volume in excess of $60,000,000.

LONDON, July 31 -- Henry A. Wallace may be making a dent in the American body politic during the Presidential campaign, but in Europe he is regarded as either a champion of the Communists and fellow-travelers or a candidate not to be taken seriously.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The American League which Will Harridge and his efficient staff of workers so capably direct from their headquarters overlooking the deep blue waters of the lake, seems to have a couple of vexing problems on its hands, with neither involving the outcome of the current pennant race.

LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- Protests and near-fights marked today's Olympic water polo competition in the Wembley pool. The United States seven tied Belgium, 4 to 4, in what the Americans termed the roughtest game they ever had encountered.
The weights did it in the final yards of the $22,550 Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap on the final afternoon of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday.
DAMASCUS, July 31 (Reuters) -- The Arab Higher Committee in Palestine today proclaimed a decision to resume the holy war in Palestine to restore liberty and independence in Palestine.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 31 -- In the face of objections from conservation groups, some Western cattlemen have proposed that wild horses from the upland ranges of the Far West might be used as a new source of food for the hungry nations of Europe. They have informed the Economic Cooperation Administration that the wild steeds can be delivered at packing plants for 3 1/2 cents a pound on the hoof.

The Government once again has turned to private industry in its quest for the fulfillment of answers to new engineering problems. This time it is for the development of gas turbine and related jet types of engines, including guided missiles.

BASTOGNE, Belgium -- For a long time after the Battle of the Bulge, which centered here in the Ardennes three and a half years ago, Belgians groped helplessly for an understandable translation of Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe's classic reply to the German besiegers, "Nuts!"

AS a worthy rider on the Kinsey band wagon, list this new edition of Guyon's book, first published here in 1934, and brought out originally in France in 1930 under the title "La Legitimite des Actes Sexuels." Analogies between the Guyon book and the Kinsey book are surprising.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- There were some indications from Congress today that it might grant President Truman's request for a tightening of bank credit and renewed consumer credit controls during the special session. There appeared little hope, however, that Congress would do anything with the Chief Executive's request for price controls and rationing.

HOLLYWOOD is not the only place where motion-picture production is in a parlous state, and complaints of poor stories, inadequate scenario preparation and other evils attendant on mass production are not confined to the capitalistic film industry.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A week before the "turnip session" of Congress convened -- on July 19, to be exact -- the iron curtain in the White House press office collapsed, figuratively, with a deafening crash.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 31 -- The Texas poloists turned back Gulf Stream, 6 -- 1, in the opening part of a round-robin tournament on the No. 2 field at the Meadow Brook Club today and wound up victors with a plus five ranking at the end of nine chukkers of play.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--Dr. Willis J. Potts Jr., "blue-baby" surgeon, successfully underwent a gall bladder operation today despite worry over his 21-year-old son's disappearance.

SANTA MONICA, Calif.--The luxurious beach estate where Marion Davies, the motion-picture actress, entertained with house parties famous around the world, has just been opened to the public, on a limited basis, as the West Coast's most sumptuous resort hotel--Ocean House.

Current production of new low-temperature synthetic rubber, which outwears natural rubber in automobile tire treads by as much as 30 per cent, is at the rate of 1,500 long tons monthly, J.P. Coe, vice president and general manager of the Naugatuck chemical and synthetic rubber divisions, United States Rubber Company, said last week.

LIFT your eyes to the nighttime heavens now if you would see the lights of infinity. The Perseids are darting through the skies, leaving fiery trails of stardust. Somewhere out there in the tremendous depths of space the twin fires of creation and dissolution are crackling with cosmic showers of sparks.

A SUMMER on the Carolina seacoast in 1893: for Kristy Nicholson time to dream, to read and to wonder; for her five cousins a time for parties, pretty clothes and now, in their young ladyhood, gay flirtations. Kristy, more than ever before, is sensitive to the narrowness of her grandmother's belief that the Nicholson way of life is the only desirable and proper way.

IN an essay on "Ulysses" in 1923 T.S. Eliot wrote: "All that one can usefully do at this time, and it is a great deal to do, for such a book, is to elucidate any aspect of the book -- and the number of aspects is indefinite -- which has not yet been fixed."

LONDON, July 31 -- Wally Ris, 22-year-old speed swimmer from the University of Iowa, virtually snatched the men's Olympic crown in the 100-meter free-style today from team-mate Alan Ford, of New Haven, Conn., with a mighty surge of power in the last four strokes.

AMID the welter of dates, names, facts, figures and astronomical statistics on the films of David Wark Griffith which have been flooding the nation's press since the "father of film art" died on July 23, little or nothing has yet been said of the meaning of it all.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Marjorie Gladman Buck of New York and Mrs. Virginia Wolfenden Kovacs of San Francisco teamed today to win the first title in the sixtieth annual invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club -- the women's doubles event.

FROM whatever vantage one chooses to regard the modern period, loosely the last forty years, its poetic activity is dominated by the figure of Ezra Pound. Pound is the great re-animator of our time. His conversations at Rapallo with William Butler Yeats are said to have had a direct bearing on the re-invigorated style of Yeats' later poems.

STOCKHOLM -- Scandinavia's big cities are deserted by their regular inhabitants just now because it is vacation time and their places are taken by tourists among whom the foreign element this year is completely dominated by Americans.

"I WOULD have run to him, only I was a coward in the presence of such a mob -- would have embraced him but that I did not know how he would receive me; so I did what moral cowardice and false pride suggested was the best thing -- walked deliberately to him, took off my hat and said:

Although the banging staccato putt-putting of outboard motors is prohibited on Newark Bay off Bayonne until after noon today, a fleet of hydroplane pilots will yank starting cords immediately after the Sabbath morning curfew is lifted and start practicing for the northern New Jersey championships which will begin at 2:30.

Twenty Senior Girl Scouts are brushing up on foreign languages, preparing to serve as sight-seeing guides to delegates to the World Conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts who will visit here before the opening of the conference at Cooperstown, N. Y., on Aug. 13.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Southern filibuster on the anti-poll-tax bill has carried Washington this week back through the fine historical dusts of nearly a century to the spirit of the most mortal controversy that ever engaged the United States.

THE author of this book, a professor at Columbia University, is one of the many eminent scholars that contemporary Italy has given to the United States. He attempts here "to set forth the unique quality of Italian civilization.''
MILWAUKEE, July 31 (AP) -- Suzanne Froedtert, 18-year-old heiress to a malting company's millions, is honeymooning in a small, modest home of her mother-in-law, a widow of a Greek immigrant barber.

BUDAPEST, July 31 (UP) -- The moderate Liberal newspaper Vilag reported that Dr. Victor Csornoky would be accused of having sold Hungary's diplomatic code to "a foreign power," smuggled foreign currency, committed unspecified "common crimes" and given several newspaper interviews that "did great harm to Hungarian democracy."

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 31--1Vfrs. James i. Heatherton I heads the executive committee forI the annual flower show nder the i auspices of the of Garden Club Shelter Island, which vl be held i Friday afternoon ad evening at the Shelter Izland Yacht Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., July 31 -- The United Nations received a glimpse today of a Pacific paradise, where $18.46 a week will provide the highest local standard of living for those who desire to work for money, which 90 per cent of the inhabitants do not, and where labor troubles are unknown and taxes come to $5 a year (for adult males only).

Several thousand veterans of World War II made personal visits to offices of the Veterans Administration in New York and the vicinity yesterday to reinstate National Service Life Insurance term policies.

MASTIC, L.I., July 31 -- A frantic, twenty-hour search for a 28-month-old boy ended here today when he was found alive in deep grass a half-mile from his home. He was in good health, but badly bitten by mosquitoes on the face, arms and legs.

Without electric power our national industrial activity would come to a catastrophic standstill and our economy would be threatened with complete collapse. The corollary devastations in every phase of life are almost unimaginable.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- An elaborate post-Olympic Games tour of Europe by members of the United States swimming, track and boxing teams was announced today.

TOKYO, July 31 -- The Japanese Government, after a special four-hour Cabinet meeting, tonight made public a formal ordinance denying collective bargaining rights and the right of strike to public employes. This was requested in Gen. Douglas MacArthur's letter to Premier Hitoshi Ashida more than a week ago.

Chester Bowles has my whole-hearted support for the educational program which he outlined in his article, "Universal Training for Democracy." If, during a war, our Government can draft a man, give him free instruction for his job, pay his transportation around the world, give him equipment, and at least partially support his family back home, surely it can do more than it has to prepare those who wish to serve their country in peacetime pursuits.
A BRIEF survey of photographic achievement during the past 100 years opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

A 27-year-old refugee was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. The police said he had solicited more than $50,000 from Jews in this country and spent the money. According to the police, he had promised to send the money to Haganah.

The city's history during its first fifty years and a record of industrial progress of the last half century are the subjects of two exhibitions that open today and tomorrow to celebrate New York's Golden Anniversary.

Mrs. Elizabeth May Craig, correspondent for several New England papers, made the front page by asking the Atomic Energy Commission some penetrating questions. She wanted to know if "you are getting at the secret of where life begins," and "what is it that departs at death."

Encouraged by early consumer response to fall apparel lines, buyers are expected to return this month to the wholesale garment market to make additional purchases, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

With the roaring engines of 900 tactical airplanes emphasizing his words, President Truman made an earnest plea for world peace yesterday as he opened the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. The President as Chief of State expressed the nation's hope for world peace. As Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces, he witnessed a thundering demonstration of the country's capacity for war.

IN "Chrysantha" are deployed all the time-honored props of light English fiction: the lovely sleepy villages with enchanting English names like Woodford St. John and Woodford St. Peter; the minutiae of village life -- high teas, family luncheons and dinners, meetings of the local Literary Society; the vague, engaging characters including a young man who fancies himself in the role of Pygmalion, the usual college professor, the amateur botanist, the inevitable Vicar and haunted Vicarage.

NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- The United Nations Commission on the Kashmir dispute between India and Pakistan left today for Karachi, Pakistan's capital. Meanwhile, two alternate delegates, Major Francis Smith of the United States and Ernest Graeffe of Belgium, were in Kashmir visiting the various fighting fronts with Indian Army commanders whose troops are now allegedly meeting opposition by regular Pakistani Army units.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Gov. Herbert B. Maw of Utah declared today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York not only called teacher propaganda for greater pay "the biggest lie since Hitler," but exchanged sharp words with Gov. Earl Warren of California on the subject.

For the first time in the history of its four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- New York City is planning an intensive program of teacher education coordinated under one administrative head. A fifth year is to be added to the four-year course, making it possible for students to complete their professional work within the city.

RADIO'S mad insistence on giving away money finally has come in for some uproarious spoofing, specifically at the hands of Station WNEW and a program called "You Can Lose Your Shirt." For a half-hour on Monday evenings (9 o'clock) the whole idea of the current jackpot jag is made to look as ridiculous and silly as it is.

ONE version of the origin of the ancient Olympic Games has it that the doughty Greek athlete, Heracles, having diverted a couple of rivers to clean out the stables of the King of Elis, was so piqued by that worthy's unwillingness to repay him, as promised, with a tenth of his stock that he did the king in, and established the Games as a sort of celebration of his feat.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 31 -- The Workers (Communist) party accepted today a proposal by Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi that it present Arpad Szakasits, a party leader, as candidate for the Presidency of Hungary.

Pablo Picasso, the great and provocative Spanish modernist, has turned his hand to an art form new for him -- pottery. Here are the first reproductions of his work in clay to be published in the United States. Every afternoon Picasso, who is 67, climbs into his rickety old Renault in the little French Riviera resort town of Golfe-Juan where he is now living and is driven to a pottery in near-by Vallauris.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 31 (UP) -- Six leaders abandoned the Progressive party in New Mexico today, denouncing the Wallace group's attitude toward communism and Russia.

GENEVA, July 31 -- The Russian delegation to the United Nations Economic and Social Council confirmed today its willingness to accept resolutions on economic cooperation in Europe that did not condemn the European Recovery Program and promptly started blasting the Western countries on their policies in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Driving a rented chicken truck and wearing overalls, President Truman's closest friend on Capitol Hill soon will take to the road to sound out political sentiment among the farmers and average people he meets from here to Indiana.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31 -- A further step in the remodeling of Argentine education was achieved by President Peron yesterday, when the Deputies by a vote of 71 to 22 approved the general idea of his proposal to establish a national workers' university.
THE fair's the thing from Maine to Pennsylvania during the coming months. Definite dates for more than 360 state, county and community celebrations have been announced in nine Northeastern states.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- Sailors from the Chicago Yacht Club today swept two races for their fourth straight triumph and thus won the annual series with the Indian Harbor Yacht Club for the Ocean-Great Lakes Challenge Trophy.

MR. O'REILLY'S pianos are not played for music: rather, they are pools of past emotion. A piece of ice and a lighted candle placed under the keyboard of a piano in Berlin causes the cool mane of a reclining woman to undulate with the tonal waves.

GLADIOLUS are starting to to bloom. Within two weeks, radiant colors will make their flowers one of the most dominant throughout the Northeastern States. However, those who divided their bulbs into small lots for succession plantings will enjoy bloom for fully two months.
Government - owned C-4 type transports will continue to play a major role in the movement of displaced persons from Europe to the United States, shipping authorities declared here yesterday.
The "workhorses" of the Navy's new "flying fleets," some of them on display at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, are jet fighters and propeller-driven attack planes and bombers.

When shall we have smokeless atomic power plants? Will they supplant central stations that burn coal or oil? How much will they cost? In the semi-annual report it has just issued, the Atomic Energy Commission discusses these questions, but gives no positive answers. A wondering public is about where it was in 1945 when it was astonished and horrified by the news of the atomic bomb.

ALTHOUGH he prides himself on being "the radical of radio row," CBS' Goodman Ace isn't worried about a visit from the Thomas Committee. For his only "subversive" activity -- and there are some who think it is pretty low-down -- consists of trying to improve the quality of radio comedy.

RECENT discussions in these columns of the artist and sales -- or lack of sales -- of his work have elicited a considerable number of letters expressing highly diverse points of view. Communications from the lay public rather acidly make a point of the high prices demanded for desirable examples.

Patrolman Francis Hogan, who was appointed to the force on July 1 and assigned to the Police Academy, was suspended yesterday after an off-duty fight at 4:40 A.M. with six men at 1458 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. He was booked also on a charge of felonious assault.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Official observers here expect the International Monetary Fund to announce within the next fifteen days a new Mexican peso exchange value of 15 cents United States currency, but they are pessimistic about such action solving Mexico's monetary problems.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The State Department awaited tonight a report from Ambassador Smith before commenting on his conference with Foreign Minister Molotov.

"FINIAN'S RAINBOW," which has been charming quite a few customers since it began its Broadway stand eighty-one weeks ago, may be transferred to celluloid if discussions between Mickey Rooney, his bosses, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and the musical's producers jell.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- The forty-fifth Western open golf championship became another "Hogan benefit" today.

August comes in, this year, to the tune of the cicada. It's a little late; but the season hasn't exactly been normal, and it is reassuring to hear the high-pitched sibilance now. Before long the katydids will be scratching the night with their rasping sound, and we will know that August is really August.

NANKING, July 31 -- After surveying China's industrial needs under civil war conditions, the Stillman Mission has revamped the Government's plan for concentrating American reconstruction funds almost exclusively on the development of a new industrial base below the Yangtze River.

IN the press working area or "city room" of the United Nations, a press is writing his story of a Human Rights Commission meeting, and assignments are being made to "general reporters" to cover other meetings. At the "central desk" two chief press officers put the final touches on reports from Geneva on the Kashmir Commission.

DUBLIN, July 31 -- While passing through Dublin on the way to the west of Ireland for a three weeks' vacation at quiet Clew Bay, British Prime Minister Clement Attlee today signed the Irish-British trade agreement concluded in London a month ago.

The scenes of Paris under floodlights in your July 18 issue bring up the strangeness of the beauty which appears under such artificial conditions. What pass for simple architectural features in ordinary light take on greatly intensified significance.

MISS STEIN died in Paris two years ago, after a shrewdly managed professional career lasting half a century. In the course of it she wrote dozens of books, including a highly influential one, historically speaking ("Three Lives"), and a most entertaining one ("The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas").

Frederick Hazlitt Brennan's amusing and refreshing article, "Memo to the Moguls of Hollywood," pretty much hit the nail on the head, using a nail as a symbol of movie producers -- that is, something you can hang a picture on, and is driven.

PEEKSKILL., N.Y., July 31 -- With nearly half of the 2,700 National Guardsmen here consisting of recruits who joined units of the Forty-second Division in the last thirty days, emphasis by divisional, regimental and company officers this week at Camp Smith has been on basic training.

Two long American arms--with fists--were flexed at New York International Airport yesterday. The Air Force and the Navy, each in its fashion, showed what each can do by air attack before two men, one of whom may one day have to say whether they will strike in earnest.

JOHN EVANS launches his "Halo for Satan" with a fantastic and highly implausible idea and then carries it on in rapid and realistic style. A Chicago Bishop sends for Paul Pine, detective, to trace a man who has offered to sell him a manuscript said to be written by Jesus -- asking price $25,000,000.

Eight hundred guests attended the President's Day luncheon given yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Mayor's Committee for the Commemoration of the Golden Anniversary of the City of New York.

Harry Fleischman, national secretary of the Socialist party, said yesterday that Henry A. Wallace told the truth but not the whole truth in charging that John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, set off post-war inflation when he granted an increase of $5 in the price of steel in February, 1946.

JUST twelve years ago this week in this Review: A first -- and so far, last -- novel called "Gone With the Wind" was number one on the best seller list and Aldous Huxley's "Eyeless in Gaza" was in the ninth fiction place.

Easing of the housing situation in the not too distant future was seen in the announcement yesterday that the next six months would witness "the greatest sustained construction schedule in the history of New York City public housing."

LONDON, July 31 -- The news that Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov had received the envoys of the Western Allies tonight reached London when gloom and tension had touched the lowest ebb since the Berlin dispute started.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- Envoys of the Big Three Western powers received unexpected interviews with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov tonight, and gave him their latest proposals for settling East-West differences in Germany and other European areas.

FOR THIS WEEK: Weeds seem to be growing faster than flowers or vegetable plants. Keep them down by cultivating every week or ten days and, wherever possible, by mulching afterward. . .. Once a week, soak the soil around shrubs and trees planted within the last year. . .. Spray regularly with nicotine sulfate for aphids.

Hanging out of the open doors and many camera ports of a giant Air Forces photographic plane, a dozen Air Force and civilian photographers attempted yesterday to record the panoply of planes that flowed over the city's new airport.
A dramatic presentation of air power was staged yesterday along a 6,000-foot concrete midway known as runway "E" at new International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

AFTER an interruption for which the war was responsible, the process of making Virginia's Colonial capital a complete period piece is under way again, with another $10,000,000 assigned to an undertaking to which more than twice that sum has already been devoted.

BERLIN, July 31 -- The United States will maintain its basic position on a German settlement at any four-power conference resulting from the current negotiations in Moscow, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared today.

RIVERTON, Wyo., July 31 -- A definite threat to the country's public power policy is shaping through a controversy over the construction of a dam near Helena, Mont., on the upper reaches of the Missouri River.

Financial markets became highly sensitive last week to news developments, both on the domestic economic and international po1itical horizons. The momentum of the recovery effort proved sufficient early in the week to act as a buffer against some of the news headlines, but later the increasing volume of the selling forced bidders to drop aside.

The Atomic Energy Commission and the University of Tennessee are planning to establish a $250,000 agricultural atomic research project at Oak Ridge. The commission has authorized the university "to perform studies relative to the effects of radiation on domestic animals and cultivated crops."
