"ENJOY your children" has been Dr. Arnold Gesell's counsel to parents for years. He points out that when a child is slow in starting to creep, we don't say: "He ought to creep.

A NEW electronic method of designating camera lens apertures, called T stops, has been adopted by Bell Howell Company to replace the f/stop lens openings for its new 35mm Foton still camera. The Foton, the company's first still camera, is scheduled for release late this year to sell for $700.
Five transatlantic liners sailed for European ports yesterday with nearly 4,000 passengers, most of them on summer holiday tours to the Continent.
Following are the texts of addresses made at the dedication ceremonies at the New York International Airport yesterday as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BERLIN, July 31 -- Here in the rubble of what was once the capital of Germany high drama is being played. It is big drama, for the two leaders are the two most powerful nations of the world, the United States and Soviet Russia.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- With the weather man in benevolent mood, the second concert of the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood brought out a crowd that far exceeded that of the opening on Thursday. If the festival's luck holds up tomorrow afternoon, when the next concert is presented, this may turn out to be the best opening week in its history.
CLEVELAND, July 31 -- Cleveland's Indians, battling desperately to remain in the thick of the dog fight for the American

The dismissal of the "aggressive war" charges against officials of the Krupp and Farben industrial organizations in the war crime trials just completed in Nuremberg, Germany, should not be considered "a whitewash" of their guilt, according to Joseph W. Kaufman, who served as deputy chief of counsel at the trials.

THREE years and four pictures in Hollywood have brushed so little bloom off Peggy Cummins wistful, Celtic charm that a hardened New York waiter declined, the other day, to put garlic in her salad. The seasoning would have been profane, he indicated.

TOKYO, July 31 -- A general simplification of Japan's export procedure now awaits Gen. Douglas MacArthur's signature. If it is approved it will reduce the number of sheets of paper necessary to conclude a deal between a Japanese and a foreigner from the present 200 to thirty-two by making the Board of Trade a mere supervisory organ instead of a contract party.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Arlington Park, the graveyard of champions, buried another short-priced favorite in the rich Arlington Classic today as Papa Redbird galloped to a six-length victory. Shy Guy,

Seventy-five-year-old Augustus Pope, white-haired and with a white goatee, and seventy-four other men, all wearing black-and-white checkered caps, took everything in stride yesterday as powerful aircraft spelled out the nation's progress in aviation over the skies of Idlewild.

IT is one of the bitter ironies of the modern American screen that millions of contemporary movie-goers never knew who D.W. Griffith was -- never knew, that is, until the old man died the other day, still dreaming of making a "come-back," in a Hollywood hospital.

OTTAWA, July 31 -- Premier Maurice Duplessis' dramatic victory in Quebec Province [he won 82 out of 92 seats in the legislature] and the Dominion Government's decision to admit Newfoundland into the conferedation as a tenth province have made this past week a notable one in Canadian political history.

GERTRUDE STEIN has been to such an extent identified with her experiments in style that the substance of her writing is too often overlooked. An immensely practical person, she knew that style alone makes un-nourishing writing, and substance alone, like good food unseasoned and parboiled, is an unpalatable diet.

"WHEN do natives become people?" Miss Martin asks in the introduction to her fascinating book about the Mexican people. She lived in Mexico for more than four years during which she lost her "complacency" and the "looking down the nose" that are standard equipment for so many tourists including the pre-Mexican Miss Martin.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 31 (AP) -- Toronto made it two out of three in its five-game series with Jersey City tonight, taking the third game of the set, 4 to 0, behind the brilliant five-hit pitching of Lou Possehl.

In "Only Churchill Can Challenge Him" Stanley Clark states that Aneurin Bevan, being left-handed, "was persuaded to change to the use of his right hand. But from that time onward he spoke with a stammer."

Of twenty million men examined for Selective Service during the last war, more than three-quarters of a million were found to have gross physical disabilities, such as amputations, blindness, deafness, a congenitally short leg, club foot or a withered arm, disabilities requiring intensive physical rehabilitation.

I DON'T know Odets from Ocredits. All I know are his plays, some of which are poor, some middling and some excellent. As a playwright he has been hailed as the "fair-haired boy" of the theatre and, for all anyone knows, may be still.
RAHWAY, N.J., July 31 -- The favorites survived the first round matches of the second annual New Jersey P.G.A. championship held at the Oak Ridge Golf Course today.

TUPELO, Miss., July 31 -- Representative John Rankin, 66-year-old dean of the Mississippi Congressional delegation, faces the hardest campaign of his political career in the Aug. 24 Democratic primary in the First Congressional District. Observers in the district predict he will not win this year.
PARIS, July 31 -- The National Assembly is pressing the Government to improve the quality and increase the quantity of the bread Frenchmen eat.

BERLIN, July 31 -- The Social Democratic party is willing to implement the decisions of the London conference calling for the establishment of a Western German state only because "it is a good step forward," Erich Ollenhauer, deputy chairman of the party, declared today at the opening of the party's convention.

THE article which appeared in these columns some weeks ago upon the subject of orchestral pitch has aroused some interesting correspondence and by this means elicited some additional facts, not in the article referred to, which modify certain of the conclusions then reached.

"PARK your child with Charlie" has become a popular phrase in these parts, and local mothers may soon subscribe funds for a monument honoring dapper, graying Charles Pincus, who manages the Utah Theatre on this municipality's Main Street.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 31 -- Administrators of school systems are responsible for arousing the interest of the community in providing adequate support for public education, Dr. Rhea M. Boardman of the New York University summer session faculty said today.

MR. HAYSTEAD travels extensively throughout the country showing tough-minded executives how to get their farms on an efficient and paying basis. He draws heavily upon his experience and observation for this book.

LONDON, July 31 -- Copies of a German-language paper, Deutsches Flugblatt, printed in Britain for Sir Oswald Mosley, former leader of the British Union of Fascists, who was interned during the war, have been found in the British-occupied zone of Germany, according to information reaching the British Foreign Office.

MOST of us have become hardened to the knowledge that 74.4 per cent of the world's 52,701,000 automobiles are owned in the United States, with a concentration (or saturation) of one car for every 3.7 inhabitants. The latest compilation of the world's aviation situation makes it look as if the skies over the United States bid fair to be equally congested, relatively speaking, as its highways.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- New York Athletic Club swimmers set two new Adirondack District Amateur Athletic Union records today in opening events of the state men's outdoor swim championships.

POETS' imaginations, like so many peoples' figures, are liable to spread and sprawl a little as they approach middle age. The clear, sharp line wabbles into a waving curve, as a greater variety of unwise foods are stuffed into the maw. But this has not been the fate of Mr. Roethke.
President Truman dedicated the 4,900-acre New York International Airport yesterday before many thousands of persons at Idlewild in Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The death this week of former Senator James Eli Watson, the old Indiana political wheelhorse, reminded many of his friends of stories he used to tell about Uncle Joe Cannon, former Speaker of the House.

CAIRO, July 31 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator, will meet Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha and Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary-general of the Arab League, for talks on demilitarization of Jerusalem and the Arab truce conditions at Alexandria next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

THE Mademoiselle Lavalliere of this novel is not Louise, the mistress of Louis XIV, but Eve, an actress who was a younger contemporary of Sarah Bernhardt and died not so long ago. Though she won a reputation as a comedienne, her career was the prelude to a more striking renunciation.

In behalf of the Clear Pool Camp of the Madison Square Boys' Club, a dance will be held on Aug. 14 at the Carmel (N.Y.) Country Club. Various members of the community and neighborhood clubs are aiding in the plans for the benefit.

LONDON, July 31 -- More skillful application of the energy that British workmen put into their tasks is a paramount need in stepping up labor's productivity here, it was asserted today by the Trades Union Congress, central body of Britain's powerful organized labor movement.

OFFICIALS of the United States Maritime Commission and the United States Lines agreed last week that there is now an excellent chance that the flag of this country will fly over a superliner -- one that ought to bring to these shores for the first time since superliners were conceived the blue ribbon of the Atlantic, awarded for speed.

SINCE the close of the Civil War many Southerners have wandered along willow-shaded paths of remembrance to mourn at the tomb of the Lost Cause. After World War I, as a part of the cultural renaissance which has been gathering strength in the South, this interest in the War between the States became less mournful and more militant.

In the Russian dictionary "soviet" is one of the simplest words. It looks like this: COBET. The first letter is the Russian S (survivor of Greek sigma) and the B (Greek beta) has the same v sound that it has in modern Greek. The other letters are the same as in our Latin alphabet and the i is inserted to give the approximate Russian pronunciation.

IF any one of these three excellent Borzoi Books for Sportsmen could be said to have a slight advantage over the others, Mr. Annabel's would be the winner. "Hunting and Fishing in Alaska" displays a remarkable knowledge of sports and skill in writing.

VERNAL, Utah, July 31 -- After more than twenty years of wrangling, states seeking to utilize the waters of the upper Colorado River have reached an agreement that should result in full, beneficial allocation of the big stream's flow for irrigation, reclamation and power purposes.

LILY enthusiasts seem to have been more than usually disturbed this season by disease manifestations. A review of present knowledge on this subject may be enlightening to worried gardeners, albeit not too comforting. Not every unhealthy looking lily is necessarily diseased, however.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 31 (AP) -- Union members, still angered over threats to call out the National Guard the strike at the Univis Lens Company's plant here, agreed today to confer with Gov. Thomas J. Herbert and company officials in an effort to settle the eighty-six-day-old dispute.

Time-honored anniversaries are rare, yet the little Alpine country of Switzerland, within a short span, finds herself celebrating two important occasions. Today the mountainous nation, half the size of the State of Maine, observes the 657th year of democratic freedom, after having celebrated the centenary of its modern structure last June.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., July 31 -- A. Howard Fuller's sloop Gesture led the cruise of the American Yacht Club today.

A "special prayer of thanksgiving" to the United States, "stanchest of friends," was offered by Miss Louise Yim, a Korean representative at the United Nations, as she left La Guardia Field en route to Seoul for consultations with the newly-elected Government there.

A DOCUMENTARY on marriage and family life, with particular attention devoted to the increasing divorce rate, will be offered next month by NBC. It will be entitled "Marriage in Distress" and will run for a full hour, according to Ken R. Dyke, in charge of public service programs for the network.

A YEAR ago Western Europe was like a beleaguered medieval city, measuring her capacity to hold out by months and scanning the horizon for signs of possible succor. Plundered, scarred and exhausted in a long campaign, liberated at last, she saw a new foe massing in the East.

PIERRE VAN PAASSEN, American Protestant clergyman and honorary citizen of Tel Aviv, has worked for more than two decades for the establishment of Israel. In his fervent introduction to the present book he recalls the fact that such nineteenth century travelers as Ernest Renan and Pierre Loti predicted that Palestine, then the most backward province of the Ottoman Empire, would remain a ruin till the end of time.

The Danube River rises in the Black Forest in southwestern Germany and flows 1,725 miles east and south to the Black Sea. On its banks are world-famous cities: Vienna, Budapest and Belgrade. The river touches or flows through seven countries -Austria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Rumania and the Ukraine Republic.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, placed the United States, British and French delegations to the Danubian Conference today in the dilemma of having to choose between acquiescing in the Eastern bloc's plan for the future administration of the Danube or of leaving the conference.

IN the spring 1788, before he was 3 years old, Daniel Drake's parents decided to leave New Jersey and settle in Kentucky. For the next twelve years young Drake experienced a typical frontier life, living in a simple log cabin, working in the fields, caring for the younger children, walking miles through the woods for an occasional term of school.

A 7-cent fare, subject to revision after one year, will be recommended for the three operating companies of the Third Avenue Transit system serving Manhattan and the Bronx, it was learned yesterday. The 2-cent increase over the present nickel fare on the street car and bus lines of the companies will be proposed by Mayor O'Dwyer's special committee headed by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

THIS book is a collection of thirteen articles by the late Prof. Henry C. Simons. They constitute, we are told in a preface by Aaron Director, his major writing except for his work on taxation. Professor Simons occupied, according to Professor Director,

CURRENT business conditions and prospects for fall trade continue favorable. The cost of-living pinch is becoming more acute but other signs of trouble may not become dominating until 1949. High industrial activity and employment, plus increased authorizations for Europe, provide an immediate momentum that on the surface at least appears unslackened.

The Public Service Commission approved yesterday an increase of a half cent a mile on coach and Pullman fares for transportation within the state. Coach fares were raised from 2.5 to 3 cents a mile and Pullman fares from 3.5 to 4 cents.

Two outs away from a thrill-packed 2-1 victory over the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday, Hank Behrman blew up in the ninth and the Corsairs stormed through the opened gates with four runs and a 5-2 triumph. A crowd of 15,633 fans, having marveled at Behrman's superb relief work earlier, was stunned by the sudden turn in the fortunes of the Dodgers.

MR. LIEB is careful of his facts, and gives a detailed if uncolored recital of baseball's past and present in Pittsburgh. He begins with the very start of the game there in the post-Civil War days and traces it right up to the beginning of the present season when Ralph Kiner, the home-run king, shares the affections of the fans with Bing Crosby, one of the owners of the club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 31 -- How ten Greek Boy Scouts did their "good turn" for the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund by setting up a feeding station in one of the most disorganized and needy refugee camps in their country was recounted in a mission report from Athens to the fund's offices here.

OVERPRINTED on seventeen contemporary German stamps, ranging from 2-pfennigs through 84pf, is "Sowjetische Besatzungs Zone" (Soviet Zone of Occupation). These the Russians placed in use in Berlin on June 24 after decreasing the value of the old German mark. Stocks of the provisionals reached J. S. Stolow last week.

At the University of Washington a group of scientists headed by Dr. Loren D. Carlson will attempt to destroy cancer cells in a way as yet untried in this country. Ultrasounds, that is, sounds of such high pitch that they cannot be heard, are to be used. Inasmuch as such sounds can kill bacteria, there is every reason to believe that they will also kill cancer cells.

Prices on worsted cloths have reached their maximum limits at which manufacturers can hope to continue a high level of finished wool apparel sales, according to trade sources last week. Wool cloths more than any other, they said, have led textile prices upward with an increase of 14 per cent in the last twelve months, and worsteds have been in the vanguard of the rise.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 31 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today called on America to crusade for peace.

PARIS, July 31 -- Two events this week combined to illustrate the basic obstacle to the application in Europe of the European Recovery Program in the way United States officials desire. These events coincided with and grew out of the first visit by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to Paris for personal contacts with the European leaders dealing with the Marshall Plan.

PUERTO RICAN IRRIGATION--Materials and equipment have been purchased for the Southwestern Puerto Rico Project, which calls for the irrigation of 25,000 to 30,000 acres of semiarid land. The cost will be $24,000,000. About 35 per cent more land will thus be added to irrigated sections now available for agriculture.

In Moscow a foreign diplomat's visit with Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the Russian Foreign Minister, always follows a set pattern. A few minutes before the time of the appointment the diplomat arrives by car at the main Kremlin gate. There his credentials are checked, then he drives about 350 yards across the Kremlin compound to a yellow stucco three- story building.

Red Bank, which once a year piles out of its homes and either shuts up shop or lets junior errand boys take care of its offices, stores and factories while it flocks down to the banks of the North Shrewsbury (Navesink) River for its two-day speed boat National Sweepstakes, is getting eager and fidgety for 1948's big celebration.

BY a fortunate coincidence two companies offer new recordings of rarely performed works by Great Britain's dean of composers, Ralph Vaughan Williams. In each case the score deserves to be on disks and would hardly ever be available to the listener if it were not.

JAMS and preserves are used as interchangeable terms by those who make them commercially. But to the country cook, who surrounds herself in an August kitchen with wide kettles and paraffin and jelly jars, the two are quite different.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- The ore-hungry steel industry has started test drilling in northern New York State to determine if iron ore known to exist in the region is of marketable quantity and quality.

I have followed with interest the editorials you have been publishing urging adequate appropriations by the United States Congress to the United Nations' International Children's Emergency Fund which I approve and which have been approved by the voluntary agencies.

NO normal Clevelander, back in '73, doubted that the Fenno money was smart money. Most of it was invested in iron mills on the shore of Lake Erie, which were busily turning out rails (on credit) for the new railroad Jay Cooke was promoting in the West.

With the hunting season drawing near the mail bag is beginning to swell with inquiries from novices as to the type, gauge, boring and other details of the shotgun best suited to their needs, as well as letters from scatter-gun enthusiasts who have had one season in the field and are itching for an argument.

BOOKS discussing the social implications of psychiatry are of two kinds. The negative kind usually depicts the sorry state of the extant affairs of men, and then overcome by the imminence of catastrophe, closes on a note of despair.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The steady slump in grains picked up speed on the Board of Trade today, with corn dropping more than 6 cents at one time. Many contracts made new seasonal lows. Soybeans plunged 8 cents at times for the second straight day.

SHE may be a vagabond, but Perry Mason suspects she's no better than she should be. And once the baby-faced hitchhiker becomes involved in murder's "downward path," any number of unsavory items turn up. As for the neat, fleet Mr. Mason -- why, he's all right as soon as he begins looking at the window with the bullet hole in it from the side opposite the gaze of the prosecution.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Sky Miracle today won Suffolk Downs' $10,000 added Myles Standish Stakes by a half length over C. Rufi's Blue Grip.

Although police and other city agencies assigned 2,500 members to deal with every possible contingency at the opening yesterday of the New York International Airport, the day turned out to be just a routine one for them.

TRIESTE, July 31 -- The second phase of the Greek National Army's grim offensive against General Markos' inaccessible rebel stronghold in the Grammos Massif began this week, more than five weeks after the initial assault against the core of the Communist-led guerrilla forces had been launched.

WHEN a stranger's hand reached down into the rabbit hutch and pulled up Pete by his long ears, the young rabbit had no idea that soon this same hand (attached to a magician) would be pulling him out of a silk hat.

Shipyards in this country produced only seventeen merchant vessels of more than 2,000 gross tons each during the first six months of this year. This increased the privately owned seagoing American-flag fleet, exclusive of Great Lakes vessels, to 1,128 ships with approximately 14,050,000 deadweight tons.

NUREMBERG, Germany, July 31--In one of the stiffest decisions handed down by a Nuremberg war crimes tribunal thus far, eleven of the twelve defendants in the trial of Krupp munitions officials were found guilty today and received sentences that, with one exception, ranged from six to twelve years.

YOU may not be especially interested in angling, but if you like good, honest writing, "Angler's Choice" will appeal to you. Its selections cover a broad field. Charming, human interest tales are included, along with excerpts from the writings of master anglers.

CHERRYVILLE, N.C., July 31 (UP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina opened his campaign for President on the Southern States' Rights ticket tonight by warning that civil strife "horrible beyond imagination" would result from President Truman's civil rights program.
SINGAPORE, July 31 -- The Malayan Communist uprising is regarded here as pretty much a wildcat operation.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Republican leaders of the Congressional majority made it plain this week that the recalled session would be short if not sweet. As a result, the committees of Congress will have, as usual, to bear the responsibility for Congressional accomplishments during the "off-season."

New export licensing procedure is expected to make alteration or forgery of export licenses "virtually impossible," according to Nathan Ostroff, general counsel of the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce.

MACHEN died last December. or most of his long lifetime (he was over 80) his work had been neglected or forgotten. Now honor has been done. His "Tales of Horror and the Super natural," admirably edited by Philip Van Doren Stern, contains the best of his short stories, from "The Novel of the Black Seal" to a brief novel called "The Terror."

TWENTY-SIX years have elapsed since the death of Proust, and fifty-two since the publication of his first book, which now becomes available in English. Along with forthcoming translations of his letters and essays, and recent studies by Harold March and Philip Kolb, it fulfills a mounting interest which -- for this country, at least -- is rather a growth than a revival.

A research program undertaken several years ago to develop the production of synthetic mica in commercial quantities and make the United States independent of foreign sources of this strategic mineral has reached the pilot-plant stage, the Army and Navy announced yesterday.

Bryn Mawr College has opened a campaign to raise $200,000 to endow a chair of philosophy and religion. To be named in memory of the noted educator, Dr. Rufus M. Jones, the new chair will be a significant addition to the curriculum.

MR. BELLAIRS' opening sentence tells just about all you need to know concerning the jolly, civilized way in which he writes a detective story: "On the last day of her holiday at Fetling-on-Sea, Miss Selina Adlestrop rose early to buy antiques."

BACK home, Congressman J. Parnell Thomas, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, likes to retire to his private hunting lodge near Monroe, N.Y., not far from his native New Jersey. An enthusiastic hunter, he once shot three pheasants in flight in a single afternoon.

MOST gardeners literally "bog down" when it comes to doing something with that wet or marshy strip of land around their summer or year-round home. It may be a swamp-like plot created by seepage from springs, the wet ground along a creek or pool or just a boggy depression.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 31 -- Thirteen years after he won the New York State crown on Winged Foot's west course, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie captured the Metropolitan amateur golf championship for the first time by defeating Bob Sweeny, British amateur champion, by 8 and 6 today in the thirty-six-hole final.
The big question bothering the professional politicians is this: Who is putting whom on the spot in the extra session of the Eightieth Congress?

Unless rising costs and pressures of renewed demand superimpose a further major inflationary advance on the price rise of the last nine years, "there is hope that the needed and inevitable internal readjustment of prices may be effected less painfully than it was in 1920-21," according to a study of the structure of post-war prices just completed by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced today that Edmund Morris Morgan Jr., professor at the Harvard Law School, had been named chairman of a committee to prepare a modern and uniform code of military justice for the armed services.

HOLLYWOOD last week mourned the passing of its pioneering leader, David Wark Griffith, in the manner of a son who has neglected a deserving father during his lifetime, then comes conscience-stricken to weep at his bier.

John Brick of Yonkers, N.Y., has won the first of the regional fellowships offered jointly by Farrar, Straus, and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The award, which carries with it an outright grant of $2,000 and the possibility of acceptance by MGM, was made for an uncompleted novel dealing with the post-Civil War period in the Hudson River Valley.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Liquidation was on in volume in the lard futures market on the Board of Trade last week, all deliveries except September selling at a new seasonal low. Although the low prices were not maintained, the close yesterday was only slightly above the bottom, with net losses of $2.10 to $2.12 for the week.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 1 (AP) -Democrats loyal to President Truman stalked out of four county conventions yesterday after states' rights advocates won control of the meetings with test votes.

This day had begun so promisingly. There had been the happy tum-tetum in the morning shower, the hearty breakfast, a few moments with the morning paper to catch up with the news. Without doubt, there was nothing like a two-week vacation in the country to renew one's joie de vivre.

The importance of coordinating accessories with the rest of the fashion picture is receiving special emphasis for autumn. Interest in skirt silhouettes and lengths, particularly, again has focused attention on shoes and the color of stockings.
STOCKHOLM, Aug 1 (UP) -- A drawn game gave David Bronstein of Russia at least a temporary lead today in the current chess tournament. Bronstein has 7 1/2 points out of a possible 11.

CAIRO, Aug. 1 -- Explosions at two Jewish-owned department stores this afternoon injured several persons and slightly damaged the stores and surrounding buildings and sent window panes in a four-block area of central Cairo cascading into the streets.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, stated frankly today that the Yugoslavs wished to place the Danube under the complete control of the Danubian powers and to eliminate the influence of states that did not border on the river.
Officials of the New York State Federation of Labor took unprecedented action yesterday against members believed to be Communists.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Two United States Steel Corporation subsidiaries have asked Eastern railroads to reduce freight rates approximately 40 per cent on iron and steel products moving from the Pittsburgh district to the New York and Detroit areas.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- James C. Hagerty, executive assistant to Governor Dewey, labeled as "rubbish" today a statement made yesterday by Gov. Herbert B. Maw of Utah, a Democrat, that the Republican Presidential nominee had told his fellow Governors that propaganda for teachers' higher pay was "the biggest lie since Hitler."

THE most admired novel written in France since the end of the war is Albert Camus' "The Plague."* While it has undoubtedly been over-praised and is consequently disappointing, it is nevertheless an effective work and a highly pertinent tract for our times. M. Camus is a better novelist and a clearer thinker than his more widely publicized literary colleague, Jean-Paul Sartre.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians shoved the Red Sox out of first place in the American League today by administering a double drubbing, 12 to 2, and 6 to 1. Thus, plus the Yanks' twin victory, sent the Sox down to fourth place.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Contract bridge players competing for the national non-masters' team-of-four championship in the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-second annual tournament today put into experimental use a new code of contract bridge laws that will become effective on Oct. 1.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The atmosphere in the Stock Exchange here appeared calmer last week, although business remained on an extremely low level. A small recovery in prices may be attributed to the technical position of the market rather than to any notable improvement in the international political outlook.

"Apostasy from God" is the evil characteristic of today's world, the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick of the staff of St. Patrick's Catheral declared in a sermon at solemn mass yesterday. He advocated the crusading spirit of St. Ignatius Loyola. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Entries for the United States chess championship tournament to be held at South Fallsburg, N.Y., Aug. 10-31, closed officially yesterday at a meeting of the tournament committee held at the New York headquarters of the U.S. Chess Federation, 225 West Seventy-first Street.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 1 -- Moshe Shertok, Foreign Minister of the Provisional Government of Israel, said today that the Israeli Government would discuss the return of Arab refugees only as part of a peace treaty between the Arab states and Israel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The Yankees today kept themselves right in the thick of the American League's amazing first division whirlpool by downing Ted Lyons' trailing White Sox in both ends of the afternoon's double-header before a gathering of 35,332.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Husky Chuck Congdon of Tacoma, Wash., today headed back home from the western Canada open golf championship with $500 first-prize money in his pocket.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- The Bergen County Mayors Association wants the New Jersey Highway Department to turn its attention to building roads that will benefit Bergen County motorists as well as New Yorkers and other tourists.

The City Charter requires that departmental requests for the coming year's capital budget be submitted to the City Planning Commission not later than Aug. 15. Last August the requests ran to $585,714,453, and when the budget was certified at the end of the year after action by the Board of Estimate these requests had been cut to $255,982,835.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A field of 152 youthful tennis stars faced a wide-open battle for the national junior and boys' titles today, with initial action in the six-day tournament scheduled for tomorrow on the Kalamazoo College courts.

The State Mediation Board, which seeks to avert industrial warfare by conciliating employers and labor unions in dispute, is having the busiest year of its eleven-year history, the board's semi-annual report for 1948 showed yesterday.

Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 11 to 19 points last week, following restricted trading in a market that tended moderately downward. During the preceding week the market registered net gains of 1 to 12 points.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The critic Marietta Shaginyan, writing in Pravda about Soviet painting, has complained that contemporary artists are not properly depicting the working man.

"The forty-ninth parallel's century of friendship" was called the world's model for peace yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, Professor of Economics and Sociology, King's University, Halifax, Nova Scotia. He spoke at the morning service of St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, commemorating 100 years of Canadian-American accord.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Les Henderson, Ohio State sophomore, won the National Junior Amateur Athletic Union three-meter diving title on Mirror Lake today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP) -- This city opened its heart tonight to its centennial guest, Bruno Salafia, 11-year-old war orphan from Syracuse, Sicily, giving him a reception which would stir the heart of any boy. He was met by a band, received a ride in a fast car behind the screaming sirens of motorcycle police, and made a broadcast on the radio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, self-styled agent for a Communist spy ring in this country, will be asked this week to confront some of the high Government officials she has accused of passing out information that was sent on to Russia.

The six-story apartment building at 700 West 175th Street, at the southwest corner of Broadway and 175th Street, has been sold by 700 West 175th Street, Inc., to the Lenbob Realty Corporation. The price was reported to have been $342,700.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The problem of the refugees -- the Arabs of the Middle East and the Jews of Europe and Cyprus -- will be presented to the United Nations Security Council tomorrow as one more offshoot of the Palestine case.

The general public appears to be unaware that the juvenile delinquent is not lost when he is so declared by the law. The City of New York, like most enlightened communities, has set up courts staffed with trained and tried social workers known as Probation Officers.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 1 -- A team of Long Island amateurs captured the principal honors in the three-cornered golf match staged today at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.

Recognition by the Federation of Railway Progress of the services of a Pullman porter to the traveling public outside the range and realm of a tip brings to the fore the entire question of tipping -- how much, when, should we ever tip, and the effect that tipping has upon the good public servant, the general public, and the economy of the country as a whole.
An industrial fair portraying fifty years of progress in science and industry was unveiled yesterday morning at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

Three Boeing Superfortresses, the B-29's, saved a rain-ruined "day" for the United States Army Air Force yesterday at the New York International Airport. Returning to Idlewild, where they had taken off on Saturday at 6 P.M. as the last event of the President's dedication of the field, they scored the first non-stop round trip ever make between this city and Los Angeles.

The Mayor's Golden Anniversary Committee did an excellent job on the dedication ceremonies at New York International Airport. Graced by reasonably good weather, the program was well balanced as to speech-making and air spectacle. An intelligent running commentary from the loud-speaker was instructively helpful.

WESTWOOD, N.J., Aug. 1 -- A group of teen-agers here decided a year ago that stories of juvenile delinquency were giving youth a bad name and organized to prove the contrary. They announced today the raising of $4,400 for the proposed Pascack Valley Hospital.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- The United States policy on Germany has been made by the State Department on the basis of recommendations of both State Department and Military Government officials in Germany and State and Army Department experts in Washington, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared today.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- A prediction that the Soviet Union would propose a revision of the Marshall Plan to include Russian satellites, as a counterpart of a possible deal on Germany, was made today in a diplomatic article in the newspaper Combat, one of the leading morning newspapers in Paris.
Leo Durocher subscribed freely yesterday to the legend that it never rains but it pours, particularly when you don't want it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Sales by manufacturers for the first half of this year were estimated today by the Department of Commerce at $103,000,000,000, a gain of 15 per cent over the corresponding period of 1947.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Krupp war crimes trial has touched off a battle for property worth millions of dollars, it became apparent today. Perhaps only the United States Supreme Court can settle the issue.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The alert Cardinals today inflicted a 9-6 thumping on the Braves who played rather sloppy baseball as Nelson Potter, their starting pitcher, suffered his first National League defeat before a paid crowd of 26,324.
The way that great numbers of Americans spend their Sundays indicates the "haunting emptiness of their lives," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, declared yesterday.

The item in THE TIMES on July 15 told under the heading "Gone With the Wind" that the English windmills that once dotted the countryside are becoming increasingly rare and now often stand unworkable as interesting relics of the past. This serves to remind one that in your own New York State, on eastern Long Island, numbers of old English windmills, built by early settlers, are standing though in various states of disrepair.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- The secret struggle between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Communist Information Bureau has erupted again with the dismissal of Radonja Golubovitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to Rumania, despite overt signs of official cooperation between the Yugoslav and Soviet delegations to the Danubian Conference here.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 -- Steel sales executives here said today that there had been virtually no customer complaints about the recent price increases. In some cases, these customers were also faced with such a powerful demand for their product that they merely passed on the increases.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- World record holder Lennart Strand and his Swedish team-mates, Henry Eriksson and Gosta Bergkvist, who hope to sweep the first three places in the Olympic 1,500-meter run on Wednesday, arrived here today by air.

Aggregating about $70,000,000,000 more than in 1941, retail sales have maintained about the same position relative to disposable income that prevailed in the two decades preceding the war, according to a study by the National Industrial Conference Board released over the week-end.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- Without encountering the slightest "technical difficulty," Major Maxwell Miller took over the command of the Spandau prison guard from the Russian commander today. The prison houses the seven top Nazi war criminals, sentenced by the Nuremberg tribunal to serve terms varying from ten years to life imprisonment.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- The personal stamp collection of Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York today was presented to the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph. The gift is attribute to the Cardinal's aunt, Sister Mary Philomena, a member of the Congregation for fifty-four years.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 1 -- Sheikh Hassan el-Bana, head of the Moslem Brotherhood, largest of the extremist Arab nationalist organizations, declared in an interview today: "If the Jewish state becomes a fact, and this is realized by the Arab peoples, they will drive the Jews who live in their midst into the sea."

There is not much traffic on the Rhine, since the war, and less on the Danube. On the Western waterway barges and an occasional river boat ply between the broken bridgeheads, and life, although still in slow motion, appears to be beginning again. But the greater river, once the pulsing artery of eastern Europe, is dead.

Proposed new credit regulations will be welcomed by many major advertisers, it was learned over the week-end. Lately, spokesmen said, there has been a growing concern over excessive featuring of "easy terms" in much retail advertising. This not only encourages overbuying on credit, but distorts the chief purpose of advertising, which is to sell quality and value, they commented.
Rain that fell intermittently throughout the day cut attendance at the city's parks, beaches and playgrounds almost to the vanishing point yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government has abolished special excise taxes, ranging up to 25 per cent, on a broad list of durable consumer goods normally imported from the United States. The taxes were imposed last November in a move to conserve the Dominion's diminishing supply of United States dollars.

James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, decided yesterday to share the Queens Day speaking program at New York International Airport today with Grover A. Whalen, whom he criticized last Saturday for a "snub" at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

About $5,000,000 was spent here last week by the Lions during their thirty-first international convention, the first in New York, Royal W. Ryan, executive vice president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, said yesterday.

Fears of discrimination against established American importers in the Philippines because of new import controls, expected to become effective on Oct. 1, were termed unnecessary yesterday by Vincent Papagayo, president of the Commercial Distributors Company of Manila.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Censorship has barred the United States Office of Education from "exposing the tactics and dangers of communism" in the schools, John W. Studebaker, former Commissioner of Education, said today.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The surprising thing about the basketball competition in the Olympic Games is the high type of the play.
God is always the final judge of what is right, Bishop Edwin Holt Hughes declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Roger M. Kyes, formerly president and general manager of Harry Ferguson, Inc., has joined the staff of the General Motors Corporation, Detroit. He will work on special assignments, reporting to C.E. Wilson, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Merchandise sales at Army Post Exchanges and Navy Ships Service Stores are "sales at retail" and therefore subject to applicable Federal retail excise taxes, the American Retail Federation contended today in a statement submitted to Atty. Gen. Tom C. Clark, who has been requested by the Army to rule on applicability of such taxes to service stores and post exchanges.

Nations and individuals who "dethrone God as the first thing in their lives" are paving the way for the creation of a Frankenstein-like monster that eventually will destroy them, the Rev. Harold A. Cockburn, pastor of St. Michael's Church, Dumfries, Scotland, declared yesterday.

East Coast seamen of the National Maritime Union will resume negotiations with employers today in an attempt to write a new wage contract under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The northern editions of five daily newspapers, published in Manchester, will not appear tomorrow by a decision of the Newspaper Proprietors Association. The action by the publishers followed a strike of mechanical staffs that stopped the publication today of the northern editions of four of Britain's most popular Sunday newspapers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Thomas M. Buermann of the Huntington Yacht Club captured the third race of the Comet Class series to win the Long Island Sound title as the two-day regatta of the Echo Bay Yacht Club came to a close today.

Marketing of $134,000,000 of new bonds of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission -- the largest offering of revenue bonds ever undertaken -- is slated for Aug. 11, according to an announcement of the underwriting managers who have been negotiating the transaction for several months.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- London officials possessed themselves with as much patience as possible today as they awaited official information on the request made by the Western envoys in Moscow yesterday to see Premier Stalin. A long-drawn-out phase of the diplomatic struggle over Berlin is now expected.

Nine leaders of the electric household food waste disposer and dishwasher industry have formed a new group within the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, it was announced over the weekend. R.C. Cameron, manager of the dishwasher and disposal department of Hotpoint, Inc., Chicago, has been appointed chairman of the NEMA unit, which is called the Household Sink Units Section.

CLINTON, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Thirty-one miles of racing in the rain. That happened today in the second run of the American Yacht Club's cruise, the long one from Port Jefferson, Long Island, to Duck Island Roads off here.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The diplomats of the three Western powers exchanged impressions among themselves today and all three appeared in high spirits.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,368,744,871. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

READING, Pa., Aug. 1 -- Powerful United States Air Force units -- some 200 jet fighters, long-range bombers and F-49 single-engined planes -- roared through overcast skies over Reading's Municipal Airport this afternoon in salute to a distinguished former neighbor and military leader who had come home.
DAYTON, Ohio, Monday, Aug. 2 -- Univis Lens Company strikers have rejected an agreement to end their eighty-eight-day, violence-marked walkout, CIO United Electrical Workers leaders announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A giant gas turbine, once destined for loan to Russia, is soon to be installed in a locomotive laboratory at Dunkirk, N.Y. The Bureau of Mines said the big turbine will be used as part of a $2,800,000 research program promoted by nine major railroads and four coal producers.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Dr. Stephen G. Lee and Jack Poinier of Canoe Brook won the third annual Scotch-Foursome championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association at the Montclair Golf Club today with 154.

If there was any significance in the trading in the foreign exchange market last week -- it was not in the turnover, which was light, nor in the quotations, which were well maintained -- it was in the growing confidence in the pound sterling as this was reflected in the strong desire to buy in a market relatively light of supply.

MANILA, Aug. 1 -- Government health authorities seeking to remove 226 leprous patients from San Lazaro Hospital in central Manila to a Government leprosarium twenty miles to the north were confronted today with a rebellious refusal to evacuate the premises.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A research fellowship of the Mellon Institute established by the Florida Citrus Exchange in 1911 paid off in full this year as a $7,500,000 industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- Harold E. Stassen spent the week-end at his home in South St. Paul, Minn., studying books and reports on the University of Pennsylvania, the presidency of which he will assume this fall.

The feud between the scheduled domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority, it was learned yesterday, reached a new high and a new low in connection with the week-end ceremonies at the city's golden jubilee air show at New York International Airport at Idlewild.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Premier Stalin is expected to receive at a meeting in the Kremlin tomorrow night the diplomatic representatives of the United States, Britain and France who are here to seek settlement of difficulties over Germany.
The Twentieth Century Sporting Club, through its acting director Sol Strauss, indicated yesterday that it was certain to go through with a boxing show at the Yankee Stadium on the night of Sept. 22.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- President Vincent Auriol officially opened today the power house of the Genissiat Dam, a vast hydro-electric project on the Rhone River near the Swiss border.

LAKE MOHAWK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Champion Twin Ponds Belle, owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., today gained her eighteenth best-in-show trophy and second in two days. The pert little Welsh terrier was selected for the honor in the fifth annual Lake Mohawk Kennel Club fixture.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 1 -- The Greater Colombian Economic and Customs Union, composed of Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama is now expected to take ten instead of five years to complete. That opinion was formed after a week of conferences in this city.

Willingness of Argentina to make large concessions to other nations as a means of obtaining vitally needed imports hitherto purchased in her exchange-stifled trade with the United States is evident in the recently signed Argentine-Hungarian trade agreement, it was stated here last week by Nicholas L. Deak, president of Deak Co., Inc.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I. Aug. 1 -- Playing par golf for sixteen holes, William Govern and Frank Simonson of the Cherry Valley Club defeated Eddie Woodhams and George Stuhr Jr., Garden City C.C., 3 and 2, in the final of the seventh annual Charles R. Casey Memorial member-guest golf tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

The United States Coast Guard, the oldest seagoing service of the nation, will observe its 158th anniversary Wednesday with ceremonies at stations and installations in the eleven Coast Guard Districts throughout the country and Hawaii.

The freighter Gunner's Knot, now en route to Colombian and Venezuelan ports, is opening a new Grace Line cargo service between Puget Sound ports, Portland, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Barranquilla and Maracaibo, via Central America and the Canal Zone, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Recovery grants to Europe and China may reach a total of $1,000,000,000 this week.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The appointment of Paul Reynaud as Minister of Finance has caused much speculation about the measures he is expected to take to increase French exports. As a matter of fact the French trade deficit has been growing every month.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Precisely eighty-four years from the day in 1864 when it first opened for business with the running of the Travers Stakes, the Saratoga Association tomorrow will begin the "at home" portion of its six weeks of racing.

After two wet, sloppy, blustery nights and one day at sea, partly in the open Atlantic off Montauk. Point, George B. Drake Jr.'s auxiliary sloop Windoon, from the Manhasset Bay Y.C., triumphed at dawn yesterday in the Bayside Y.C.'s twenty-fourth annual long-distance race around Block Island.

Elmo Roper, public opinion analyst, this week will open "Presidential Straw Winds," which will be heard on Wednesdays at 8:30 P.M. on the CBS television network until election time. For each half-hour presentation the analyst will choose a question of general interest on which he has run a poll.

An apartment house is planned for a vacant plot on the west side of North Broadway, north of Lamartine Ave., in Yonkers, by Samuel Shear and Jacob Argel, builders, who have acquired the property from Grace E. Fraleigh through John G. Kelly, broker.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Ed Oliver came from three strokes back today to tie favored Ben Hogan at 281, seven under par, for the $15,000 forty-fifth annual western open golf championship.

A profitable partnership, begun with "The Heiress," is to be continued by Jed Harris and Fred Finklehoffe. The former is planning to stage his own adaptation of the Strindberg tragedy, "The Father," to be revived under Mr. Finklehoffe's banner.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Tommy McBride's ninth-inning single drove in the run that gave the Senators a 4-to-3 victory over the Browns today after the Browns had slugged out an 8-to-5 triumph in the first half of a double-header.
RIVERTON, Wyo., Aug. 1 -- This central Wyoming area presents both the best and the worst in land treatment.

The only dance performance in the Stadium Concerts season, with Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and Ana Ricarda as its artists, drew one of the summer's larger audiences on Saturday night, with something more than 15,000 present.

The Western Electric Company, manufacturing and supply unit of the Bell System, has leased the property at 226-66 Glenwood Avenue, in Bloomfield, N.J., through Ralph G. Schwebemeyer Co., brokers, for the repair and distribution of telephone equipment.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 -- New production facilities, especially machine tools, are essential to the success of the European Recovery Program, because without a return to production on a broad scale European countries cannot become self supporting, according to a statement made here today by Alexander G. Bryant, president of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association and vice president of Cleereman Machine Tool Company, Chicago.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- With three gold medals won in the 100-meter, the 400 hurdles and the broad jump, the United States track and field team is favored to capture the pole vault tomorrow as competition is renewed in the games of the XIV Olympiad before another sell-out crowd of 83,000 at Wembley Stadium.

ATHENS, Aug. 1 -- British Charge d'Affaires Patrick Reilly called on Premier Themistocles Sophoulis and Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris yesterday and made "strong representations" on the subject of the interview King Paul accorded to C.L. Sulzberger, chief foreign correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, last Tuesday in which the cession by Britain of Cyprus to Greece was discussed.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The first week of the Berkshire Festival ended this afternoon with another gala crowd. The weather was again what the doctor -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, the boss man here -- ordered, and the music shed was filled with an overflow throng spreading out over the lawns on all sides of the shed.

A decrease in passenger traffic on the municipal transit lines took place in July, first month of operation under the higher fare, and was greater than anticipated by the Board of Transportation, it was learned yesterday. Although no detailed figures were available, pending analysis of operating results by the board's experts, it was indicated that surface-line traffic was at least 10 per cent below original estimates and that the subway traffic decline was somewhat greater.

I well remember when the United States Weather Bureau used to publish a weather map for the general public. It was a map, for it showed the shape of things at a sweep of the eye. There were isobars, isotherms, eye-catching wind-vanes and cloudiness marks, and shaded areas of rainfall.

The Merchant Marine Veterans of America announced yesterday a special meeting at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Cornish Arms Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, to protest the drafting into the armed services of seamen who hold Certificates of Substantially Continuous Service.

While sales and earnings of General Mills, Inc., set new high records in the fiscal year ended with last May, wages and salaries also reached peak levels, according to the twentieth annual report to stockholders and employes signed jointly by Harry A. Bullis, board chairman, and Leslie N. Perrin, president.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Athletics took first place in the American League today by beating the Tigers, 4 to 2, while Boston was bowing twice to Cleveland. Phil Marchildon took credit for his eighth victory on a five-hit job, but had to have help in the ninth from Charles (Bubba) Harris when he walked three men and hit another to force a run across.

The Ballet Theatre, in spite of having a transcontinental tour booked beginning early in October, has called off all activities until early in 1949. Letters of cancellation have gone out to managers in seventeen cities which had booked the company up until Christmas.

Agencies of the city government and individuals in New York concerned with the reduction of smoke and soot, both as a menace to health and as a nuisance, can take heart from the experience of the "Smoky City" itself. Pittsburgh, according to the United States Weather Bureau, has enjoyed downtown visibility in the early months of this year 68 per cent better than last year.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Radio Station WKBS, the first in this locality, which combines a touch of the old days of Oyster Bay with the march of progress of today, will be ready to open early in September. It will be operated by the Key Broadcasting System, of which Lee Hollingsworth is president.

RHODES, Aug 1 -- The Arabs and Israeli have accepted in principle the complete demilitarizing of Jerusalem. Count Folke Bernadotte. United Nations Mediator, said today as he left for a six-day tour of the Arab countries and Israel.

OAKLAND, Md., Aug. 1 (AP) -Nearly two-thirds of a National Guard unit here was rounded up today by guard military police for failing to report for a two-week encampment which began at Camp Ritchie yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- The Screen Directors' Guild has made public a plan to honor each year with some form of awards those directors of American-made films whose work members of the organization consider the most meritorious.

Living accommodations for about 325,000 persons have been financed since the war through mortgage loans and commitments by the savings banks of New York State, John Adikes, president of the Savings Bank Association of the State, said yesterday.

The battle between a left-wing union local of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and a right-wing American Federation of Labor local over employe control in the Oppenheim Collins Co. dispute, will be resolved this afternoon in a National Labor Relations Board election.

The first Communist party national convention since 1945, when Earl Browder was removed as leader in this country, will open tonight with a rally at Madison Square Garden. The meeting, scheduled for 7:30 P.M., is expected to bring to the Garden's stage virtually all the dozen key figures in the party who recently were released on bail following indictment on charges of planning overthrow of the Government by force.

ESSEX, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Describing the reaction of Republican leaders in Congress to what he called President Truman's effort to stop inflation and bring prices to a reasonable level as "shocking," Chester Bowles, former head of the Office of Price Administration, said today that unless the extra session of Congress took action prices would go still higher.
RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 1 -- The pre-tourney favorites were ousted in the second round matches of the second annual New Jersey public links championship at the Oak Ridge golf course today.

Although substantial reorders were received for coats and dresses, the wholesale apparel market here was generally quiet last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 1 -- President Truman was back home in his "Summer White House" today, more a friendly neighbor and a private citizen than a candidate for reelection to the highest office in the land.

Two couples who won free trips to this city simply by writing what they would do here were on hand last night and all set to begin a week of sightseeing today. The women were already apportioning part of the time for shopping, and not merely the window-style.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- The Soviet campaign to win control of the city's food supplies by enticing residents of the Western sectors to register in the Soviet sector and receive supposedly abundant food supplies has failed.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Legroux proves the elegance of monochrome in her youthful cloches and berets. The great variety of colors includes dark grays and browns the tone of beaver fur, soft sulphur yellows, deep moss to palest lichen greens, pale blue to deep greenish blues, ruby and amethyst.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee asked the State Department today whether it could confirm stories to the effect that a government-controlled newspaper in Argentina had intercepted and published a dispatch being sent by private mail to the radio trade magazine Broadcasting.
Six new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Needless conflict between natural laws of growth and codes of civilized living makes a lot of needless problems in bringing up young children, according to Dr. C. Anderson Aldrich of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.
ROME, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, charged today that the attempt on his life July 14 showed there were forces in Italy trying to "spread the fire of civil war."

ATHENS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A General Staff communique said tonight that Greek troops have seized the strategically important Kleptis height in northwestern Greece. Communist-led guerrillas had put up a desperate defense of the 6,000-foot peak for weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- President Truman is expected to set in motion this week the program to bring 205,000 homeless Europeans into the United States during the next two years.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 1 -- The difficulties of Premier Thakin Nu's Socialist Government have been accentuated by an open breach with the People's Volunteer Organization. More than 100 PVO leaders have been arrested in Rangoon in the last three days.

At 3:07 A.M. yesterday the police teletype machine on the main floor of Police Headquarters became eccentric, then unintelligible and finally tapped out: "Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of the party." It was sixteen hours before the machine gave forth once more.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 1 -- Pieter Lieftinck, who is expected to return as Finance Minister in any new Cabinet, is having a hectic time trying to convince leaders of other Government departments of the urgent necessity of cutting drastically the budget to be introduced on Sept. 19.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that John F. X. Bopp has been appointed assistant office manager of the Rosenstein Agency, largest of Equitable in this state. Mr. Bopp joined the agency in 1946, and prior to this appointment he was a field underwriter.

During one of New York's most notorious political scandals a generation ago, the then "boss" of Tammany Hall was asked what he expected the public's reaction would be. "With the public," came the cynical reply, "everything is a Nine-Day Wonder."

No "across-the-board" price increases are going into effect in hardware and durable goods lines, and only a few products are being repriced upward, industrial distributors revealed in a canvass here yesterday. Recently-predicted large scale increases influenced by the rise in steel prices have not appeared, distributors reported.

The Packard Motor Car Company produced in the first half of this year the largest six months earnings since 1937, with the consolidated net income totaling $6,213,805 after taxes and all charges, its report, released today, shows.
The New York State Federation of Labor opened its annual convention here yesterday on a keynote of political action in the current campaign and opposition to Communists in its unions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue issued today a tentatively approved Form W-2, the income tax witholding form on which employers report the wages paid to workers and the tax deducted from pay checks.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 2 -- The country's economy will not enjoy the best of health "if agricultural leaders insist on arbitrary price supports, or other forms of Government aids to avoid adjustment to changed conditions," according to Dr. O.B. Jesness, chief of the agricultural economics division of the University of Minnesota.

ATHENS, Aug. 2 -- The national forces were today consolidating newly won positions in the western sector of Kleftis and an adjoining mountain, 6,663 feet high. Apparently their next move will be a thrust north and northeast across Kerasovon Plateau to join hands with confederates in the Fourka region.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Algasir, the 2-year-old that startled Trainer Jack Skirvin and the Belmont racegoers by cracking a world record in his first start in mid-June, startled a sizeable portion of the crowd at Saratoga's home opening today by romping off with the $12,850 Flash Stakes.

As the time of decision nears on what agency New York will choose to modernize its waterfront there seems to be a curious disposition in some quarters to ignore the record, and assume that the city could finance an adequate modernization itself without neglecting other pressing needs.

NANKING, Aug. 2 -- After spending three years here as a "liaison repatriation officer," Gen. Yasuthugu Okamura, wartime Commander in Chief of the Japanese forces in China, was indicted today as a war criminal.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Starting out in an overcast blow and winding up in a light air, and smoothed seas and sunshine, the fleet on the third squadron run of the American Yacht Club cruise arrived here tonight from Duck Island Roads, over on the north side of eastern Long Island Sound.

Republican opposition to the bipartisan endorsement of Representative Abraham J. Multer, Brooklyn Democrat, disappeared yesterday when Thomas A.D. Canova, who had filed in the Republican primaries against Mr. Multer, consented to dismissal of his election petitions by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- What this country needs is a seven-cent nickel, according to Representative John W. McCormack. He thinks inflation and the machine age have just about killed the old five-cent piece.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Louis F. Budenz, who turned upon the Communist party after being at one of its command posts for nine years, urged a Senate investigating committee today to ferret out more Russian spy rings in this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The United States urged today that the United Nations take up again its moribund project of bringing disarmament to the world, but Jacob A. Malik of the Soviet Union heatedly denounced the surprise proposal as a "masterpiece of demagoguery."
I believe the letter of July 5 from John H. Knickerbocker regarding the United Nations buildings is deserving of editorial comment.

Many new items to meet the trend toward home sewing were introduced yesterday at the National Notion and Novelty Show which opened in the New Yorker Hotel. High garment prices were given as the main reason for this trend.

Two next films will arrive in Broadway theatres today. At the Paramount, the attraction is "Beyond Glory," a Paramount drama, starring Alan Ladd. John Farrow directed and Robert Fellowes produced the offering, which is set against a background of West Point, from a screen play by Jona than Latimer, Charles W. Warren and William W. Haines.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company here disclosed today plans to offer $16,400,000 of convertible debentures to stockholders later this year to help finance its $45,000,000 program of major plant improvements and additions.

Two industrial plots of 25 by 100 feet each on Forty-third Avenue, between Hunter and Jackson Avenues, Long Island City, Queens, have been assembled by the Cross Brown Company, broker, for the MacFarlane Fire Prevention Corporation for improvement with a building for their own use.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Miss Ann Curtis, America's champion woman speed swimmer, failed by two-tenths of a second to win the Olympic 100-meter free style crown today. She was beaten by Miss Greta Andersen, 20-year- old Copenhagen physical culture trainee, who took the lead from the start and warded off the American girl's splendid finish to win the coveted award.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- European and oriental glass, china and pottery products are arriving in this country in increased quantities, Wallace O. Ollman, general manager of the Merchandise Mart, said today with the opening of the semi-annual gift show, china, glass and pottery market.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Treasury Ramon Beteta listed today 328 dollar transactions during the first twenty-two days of July as he explained the "flight of dollars" that caused devaluation of the peso.
Little Dickie got his baby sister yesterday from the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

The products of more than 100 manufacturers of interest to architects, builders, maintenance men, plant managers and managing agents are on display at the second annual Building Maintenance Supplies Exposition, which opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 4 per cent in July, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The sales rise in June was 9.5 per cent.

Plans for the nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building which Simon Brothers will construct at 1056-58 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-seventh Street, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Monmouth Park had its first day of racing without competition from a track in the Greater New York area today, and the occasion was deemed a successful one by the operators of the local plant. With activities in New York State confined to Saratoga, a goodly number of Gotham horse fanciers who found it too inconvenient to make the trip to the Spa charted their courses for this locality instead.

If Branch Rickey ever had an opportunity to acquire Johnny Schmitz from the Cubs the Dodger boss must regret keenly that the deal wasn't made, for with the skinny southpaw on their side the Brooks could be in first place today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- J. Donald Kingsley, acting administrator of the Federal Security Agency, today emphatically denied the censorship, Red-shielding, and partisanship charges made against that agency and its administrator, Oscar Ewing, by its former commissioner of education, John W. Studebaker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Contract bridge experts, assembled here for the twenty-second annual championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, opened play today for the masters' mixed team-of-four championship, the national men's pair and the national women's pair championships.

A network of education "patent offices," where local school systems are banding together to invent and develop new techniques in education, was described yesterday by Dr. Paul Mort, executive officer of the Institute of Administrative Research, Teachers College, Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Senate was urged today to act now on resolutions adopted in the House to stimulate United States shipbuilding, which is near a standstill.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Former President Herbert Hoover received a $70,000 birthday present today. It was in the form of monetary donations to be used as a nucleus for a continuing fund by which activities of the Hoover Library and Institute can be expanded.

NORMAN, Okla., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A state court today denied admission to the University of Oklahoma the three Negro women. Negro leaders announced they would carry the fight against Oklahoma's racial segregation laws again to the United States Supreme Court.

The stock market crept yesterday into further low ground in an extension of the reaction that set in late last week. Only a few issues managed to show major alterations, and in every case were dictated by corporate developments, the most important of which was the increased dividend voted by General Motors.

The Communist party of the United States endorses and will work for the election of Henry A. Wallace as President of the United States. This announcement, long foreshadowed by the activity of American Communists within the Wallace movement, was made last night by William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party and one of its twelve leaders who are under indictment for conspiracy to overthrow the Government by force.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Claude Harmon, Winged Foot pro. came 1 foot 10 inches from the cup on the ninth hole at Leewood Golf Club today to lead 140 players in the opening day of competition in the 1948 World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The United States Air Force has won another round in its long battle for independence. As a result of this triumph its personnel will wear white shorts instead of the olive drab worn by Army men.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Liquidation continued in the grain and lard markets on the Board of Trade today. All deliveries of corn, lard and soy beans sold at new seasonal lows, as did May wheat and December and July oats.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Malvin G. Whitfield stepped up on the pedestal with the great Negro Olympians today as the United States won two more gold medals in track and field for a total of five thus far in the games of the XIV Olympiad.
The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that an investigation had been started into an alleged "crooked gambling racket" in connection with a charity drive.

I would like to point out a measure which is pending in Congress, which has been thoroughly considered and of which action could be completed in a very short time. This bill is H.R. 2245 which would repeal federal anti-margarine legislation. The House passed this measure by a 260-to-106 vote and it has been unanimously reported by the Senate Committee on Finance.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- Dr. Stafford Warren, who headed the radiology section of the Atomic Bomb Project, declared today that in the event of a future conflict "radioactive materials will be employed in two ways: in atomic bombs and in radiological warfare," the latter involving radioactive contamination of things in common use, like food and water.

The special Federal grand jury that indicted twelve Communist leaders on charges of conspiring to overthrow the United States Government by force included three women, a banker and a Columbia University baseball coach, it was learned yesterday.

" Of Flight and Life," by Charles A. Lindbergh, an analysis of science's position in the society of the future, will be issued by Scribners on Aug. 23. He discusses the questions: "How shall we break the grip of a scientific materialism whose values and standards will lead to the end of our civilization?By what higher moral force may we control the science that now threatens to destroy us?"
Plans for the construction of a 2,000-car garage by the New York Life Insurance Company virtually have been blocked by Mayor O'Dwyer's advisers, it was learned last night.

PICTON, Ont., Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) -- World and Canadian records were set today at the sixth annual Picton Gold Cup Regatta, Roaring over a sanctioned mile course, Harold Wilson of Ingersoll, Ont., smashed the existing Gold Cup mark held by Guy Lombardo by nearly two miles an hour.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 -- Contracts were signed here today with the H. B. American Machinery Company of adjacent Pawtucket for $1,500,000 worth of textile machinery by two brothers from Moslem Pakistan. Delivery is promised for the first quarter of 1949.

Sales and earnings of the Kendall Company and its subsidiaries for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 12, last, were the largest for any similar period in the company's history, according to the semi-annual statement of Henry P. Kendall, chairman.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 2 -- The Pakistan Government is reported by the authoritative newspaper Civil and Military Gazette of Lahore (Pakistan) as having admitted officially to the United Nations Commission that regular. Pakistan troops were fighting in Kashmir.
Entries for the forty-eighth annual United States amateur golf championship opening Aug. 30 at Memphis, Tenn., closed yesterday with a record number of about 1,240 players.
Bulkheads of the old steamer Meteor that echoed the lilting waltzes of another era are throbbing to a new tune today under the pounding of wreckers' sledges.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today told Count Orsini Rosenberg, chief of the Austrian delegation to the Danubian Conference, who again pleaded for a full right to vote for Austria, that if he did not cease his tactics, "we will find a way to deal with such sabotage."

Those who would like to add a few Scandinavian tricks to their culinary accomplishments will find some interesting ideas at the House of Hilary. This shop at 312 East Seventy-second Street did only a mail order business until recently. Now at its retail establishment the shelves are stocked with a variety of wares.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 (UP) -- Allied Headquarters announced today that Chester W. Hepler of Alexandria, Va., had been named to succeed James S. Killen.
