Mr. Killen said today that he had resigned as chief of the Headquarters Labor Division because Japanese Government employes were not permitted to bargain collectively.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 2 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll toured the Deal Golf and Country Club course in 76, two over par, today to take a two-stroke lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 54-hole Jersey Shore championship.

DALLAS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- House wives in at least three Texas cities prepared today for a one-week boycott of high-priced meat. In one place, they got unexpected help as grocers promised to close their meat counters.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations today skated delicately over the issue of a future. Japanese economy, avoiding by mutual consent a debate on the fundamentals of the problem.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 2 -- President Truman dined tonight at the home of a Republican, an old friend of his field artillery days.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 4 per cent last week compared with a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 1 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- America's wizards of the court punctured any doubts of their Olympic basketball invincibility today by scoring a leisurely 53 to 28 triumph over Czechoslovakia, the best team in all Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Truman today asked the special session of Congress for a deficiency appropriation of $2,000,000, to add to a regular appropriation of a like sum, to finance the program for admitting 202,000 European displaced persons within the next two years.

As Congress entered upon a second week of its special session yesterday, it became more and more apparent that both sides were far more interested in jockeying for political advantage than they were in passing serious legislation. Perhaps this was inevitable from the nature of the situation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Browns put their nine hits to good use tonight as they downed the Senators, 7 to 5, in the only game played in the American League. The victory gave the Browns the series, three games to two.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- In an unusual action in the pattern of labor relations an employer, National Airlines, Inc., rejected today the recommendations of a Presidential Emergency Board for settling a dispute between the carrier and striking pilots.
I read with much interest your editorial, "Salvage in Europe," in your issue for July 21, and of the credit given to the Danes for their pioneering work with the BCG vaccine.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The British Government today offered to make an immediate contribution of 100,000 [about $400,000] for an emergency program for the relief of Arabs who have been driven from their homes in Israeli-controlled areas of Palestine.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 2 -- The Wisconsin CIO-Political Action Committee yesterday ousted seven labor leaders from membership. The group accused them of "misinforming CIO members" on the Progressive party of Henry A. Wallace.

The cotton trade opened the new 1948-49 season yesterday and prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were on the down grade, closing at about the lows of the day, with net losses of 20 to 32 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The first accusation by the Soviet Trade Ministry's publication evidently relates to a press conference held by W. Averell Harriman, then Secretary of Commerce, March 26, 1947. Mr. Harriman said that since March 1 all exports to Soviet Russia and her satellites had been screened by a special committee.

" Baltimore Sings," a musical program boasting the services of a forty-voice glee club, will be presented at 9 o'clock tonight on television station WNBT. The offering, to be seen for the one performance only, is produced by Station WBAL-TV in Baltimore, where it has been on the air since March. The cast of the half-hour show also will include Louise Verne and John Evans, soloists, and Marilyn Burke, interpretive dancer.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared a dividend yesterday of $1 a share on the common stock, payable Sept. 10. This compared with payments of 75 cents made in preceding quarters. The regular quarterly dividend on the preferred stock was also voted.
Through the intervention of President Truman, a 65-year-old woman from Germany was reunited with her only child, whom she had not seen for 20 years, at La Guardia Field yesterday.

People who never before had seen a four-story, thirty-five family brick apartment house crossing a street, had that experience yesterday at Van Wyck Boulevard near 101st Avenue, Queens. The building is expected to complete today its 280-foot trip to get out of the path of the Van Expressway, which will be the main highway to Idlewild International Airport.

The thirteen-story apartment house at 920 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-third Street, has been conveyed by Mrs. J. E. R. Carpenter to a cooperative group in a sale involving more than a million dollars. Among the tenant purchasers are Judge Thomas D. Thacher of the Court of Appeals, Mrs. Barron Collier, Walter Beinecke and Frank A. Howard.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had given permission to Carey Transportation, Inc., to operate temporarily a bus service from ticket offices in Manhattan, to La Guardia Field and the airport at Idlewild, Queens, as well as between the two airports.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Charged with murdering 138 Americans, sixteen Japanese went on trial today before a United States Eighth Army military commission. The group, accused in the wartime "Palawan massacre," includes two former lieutenant generals.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -The United States Olylpic forces have built up a 3-to-1 edge in points over their nearest rival during the first three days of the 1948 Olympic Games.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 (AP) -- The "name" players had their troubles today before they advanced in opening play of the Meadow Club's fifty-eighth annual grass court tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- The country's meat supply this fall and winter will be increased about 10 per cent above present supplies, R.J. Eggert, associate director of the department of marketing of the American Meat Institute, said today.

In a triple swearing-in at City Hall yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer named two new members to non-salaried posts on the Board of Education and appointed a third man to a non-salaried post on the Board of Higher Education.

The "world of the future" in international air transportation must await closer cooperation among regulatory government agencies, plane manufacturers and airline operators, Sir William P. Hildred declared yesterday at a luncheon of the World Flight Club at New York International Airport.

The United States Air Force picked up the pieces yesterday of its show that had been scheduled for Sunday and canceled by rain. Before a crowd estimated at 50,000 by officials of the city's Golden Jubilee, of which the week-long air show at New York International Airport, at Idlewild, is a part, the Air Force added some new thrills to its participation in a day dedicated to the borough of Queens and to air transport.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that he had issued a new set of subpoenas in his inquiry into milk pricing here.

BERLIN, Aug 2 (AP) -- The 40,000,000 Germans in the combined British-American zones now are getting the highest food rations since the occupation began, the United States Military Government said today.

A field of sixty-eight teams took part in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tournament at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday, in which Jack Mallon, Cold Spring, L.I., professional, played a stellar role.
A spectacular increase in Army and Air Force enlistments in July was announced yesterday by the Army's southern New York district.

The left-wing United Office and Professional Workers Union, CIO, was challenged to a test of strength yesterday by a right-wing Congress of Industrial Organizations union in a national jurisdictional fight. The stake is collective bargaining representation for 14,000 agents of the Prudential Insurance Company.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 2 -- Lowell Mason of the Federal Trade Commission resigned tonight from the Unitarian Conference on World Affairs at Star Island, charging that the "conference leadership had been used by an alien force.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 -- Ambassador James Bruce left by plane this morning for Washington, where his primary purpose will be to untangle the crossed lines of the State Department and the Economic Cooperation Administration on wheat purchases in Argentina.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Frank D. Holmes Jr. resigned today as State Director of Navigation after the disclosure that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll had relieved him of his duties on Friday.
A modest dog that once saved a sailor's life now needs a home to save his own.

Some echo of Leif Ericson's saga moats from the northern seas every time another boat-load of Balt refugees from Russia's Red rule lands on the east Atlantic coast. Exhausted, bedraggled and penniless, at least they stand once more on free soil -- intrepid men and women for whom the torch that Liberty holds aloft was first lighted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- An open letter from the Governor of Puerto Rico will be included in the Bulletin of the Office of Puerto Rico to be released on Friday to 20,000 manufacturers as well as economic and trade organizations, it was announced here today.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Events in Moscow are moving faster and better than was hoped for a few days ago but officials of the British Foreign Office are bracing themselves tonight for a possible shock and for another effort.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The Soviet Union has rejected a United States request to send observers to the Danube River Conference in Belgrade, it was disclosed here today.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation has adopted a new advertising slogan, "You Can Be Sure . . . If It's Westinghouse," it was learned yesterday. It replaces the old "Every House Needs Westinghouse," and is intended to cover the many other Westinghouse enterprises as well as household appliances.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Aubrey S. Eban today was recognized by the United Nations Security Council for the second consecutive month as the representative of the Provisional Government of Israel. Until last July Mr. Eban had been recognized only as the representative of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

PARIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Air France said tonight it was forced to concede that only some mechanical defect could explain the disappearance of its huge flying boat, which is missing over the South Atlantic with fifty-two persons aboard.

Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of Boston entered a final decree here yesterday directing the Government to return a major part of the patents and stock it seized from the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and three of its subsidiaries on May 24, 1944.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Legal problems and opposition by several county legislators today raised obstructions that probably would balk adoption this year of plans for a $3,500,000 improvement of Westchester's 850-acre Saxon Woods Park in Scarsdale and Mamaroneck as a recreational center restricted to county residents.

The importance of gold shipments and sales of earmarked gold as a source of bank reserves here will tend again to diminish within the near future, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions, published today.

The determination of the United States, Great Britain and Canada to support the United Nations to the last, despite disappointments and set-backs, as the only hope for lasting peace was expressed yesterday by those nations' principal delegates to the U.N.

A new series of hard-bound, pocket-size books, to be called Permabooks, will be issued in September by Garden City Publishing Company. The series will be composed of a variety of non-fiction titles, chosen for their permanent value and general popularity, and will sell for 35 cents each.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The lowly Cincinnati Reds made the most of their opportunities tonight and imposed a 3-1 defeat on the league-leading Braves, who flubbed most of their opportunities against the veteran left-handed Johnny Vander Meer.
Five of the top officials in the Department of Health took over new jobs yesterday as plans for the streamlining of the city agency went into effect.

Rayon producers are seriously contemplating another increase in yarn prices as the result of recent labor rises and the increased cost of dissolving pulp, it was learned yesterday. The producers have indicated that they are not inclined to absorb the added costs, but before making a decision will wait for completion of labor negotiations which are still going on between unions and some of the larger operators.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- "The Conspirators," a novel by Humphrey Slater, English writer, in which an American girl is married to an English Army officer and finds he is a spy for Moscow, will be made into a picture by M-G-M, it was learned today.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 2 -- A force of National Guardsmen under command of Col. George Schiele began arriving here tonight under orders from Gov. Thomas J. Herbert to maintain law and order.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 2 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, submitted today to the Danubian Conference the draft of a convention for the future regime of the Danube based on the principle of "the Danube for the Danubians."
BELMAR, N.J., Aug 2 (AP) -- Dredges reached Shark River inlet today to battle a sandbar creeping rapidly across the small boat channel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Administration's attempt to revive the International Wheat Agreement, only foreign policy item on the President's extra-session program, was carried forward today by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Two railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve voluntary plans of debt adjustment. The Central of New Jersey sought to quicken its final reorganization, while the Lackawanna Wyoming Valley Railroad Company wished to provide a debt structure more nearly conforming to its earning power and to provide cash for the operation of its properties.

American restrictions on exports to the Soviet Union violate two Soviet-American trade agreements, the journal of the Soviet Foreign Trade Ministry charges. These restrictions are said to have been ordered by "reactionary circles" in the United States who hoped that reduced American exports would prevent fulfillment of the Fourth Five-Year Plan.

Ten teen-age girls have flown here from Brazil to take up duties that thousands of other girls their age would go to even greater lengths to avoid -- to cook the meals, scrub the pots and keep things in order for aides to the delegates to the World Conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts opening at Cooperstown, N.Y., on Aug. 13.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- Moshe Shertok, Israeli Foreign Minister, warned the Arab states, particularly Egypt, tonight that further violations of the truce might mean war. He also asserted that continuation of the current Jewish pogroms would have a direct bearing on the peace negotiations.

Capt. Samuel Norman Groves, who was on the bridge of the American Export liner Excalibur when it was torpedoed and destroyed at the start of the North African invasion in November, 1942, will be in command of the new liner Excalibur on her maiden voyage September 21.

VIENNA, Aug. 2 -- The Austrian National Bank has protested against the United States Economic Cooperation Administration's financial policy in Austria and has notified the Austrian Finance Ministry that the administration's continued release of blocked schillings from sales of relief goods could drive the country into catastrophic inflation.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation today increased the price of all stainless steel products 10 per cent -- the first general price boost made by the company in two and one-half years.

Virtually unlimited new uses for the already widely adopted multi-wall bag are developing, or are in prospect, it was stated last week by Kenneth D. Lozier, vice president of the St. Regis Sales Corporation.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A white student may not legally be admitted to the Texas State University for Negroes, State Attorney General Price Daniel ruled today.

The decision of the Southern Democrats to elevate their filibuster above the usual level by concentrating on the powerful historical arguments and records which support their position against the Truman-Republican "civil rights" program brings back into contemporary news the Kentucky and Virginia resolutions of 1798.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Navy is building sixteen new ships in which it is incorporating the weapons and designs foreseen for a possible war of the future, it was learned today. In addition, it is converting thirty-three of its current ships for operations quite different from the original plans.
MOST sport-minded folk regard Poughkeepsie-on-the-Hudson as the scene of the intercollegiate rowing regatta, but on a golfer's map it's the home of Ray Billows.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The Western powers in Berlin have decided to release German business concerns from the economic bondage imposed by the Soviet military administration and are again threatening to cut the Russian propaganda channels into western Germany.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Mosaics recently uncovered on the northwest wall of Santa Sophia, Istanbul, were shown here today to a session of the international congress of Byzantologists in a color film presented by Dr. Thomas Whittemore, keeper of Byzantine coins and seals in the Fogg Museum, Harvard University, and director of the restoration work in Santa Sophia.

The money market was much easier yesterday, with Federal funds quoted at 1/4 of 1 per cent, against 3/4 to 1/4 of 1 per cent on Friday. The member banks here, which on Thursday night held excess reserves of $95,000,000, went through the week-end from Friday night until yesterday morning with these reserves only slightly reduced to $80,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Ezzard Charles-Jimmie Bivins boxing match, set for Aug. 9, was re-scheduled tentatively for Sept. 13 at a meeting of the District of Columbia Boxing Commission today. The fight earlier had been postponed from tonight.
The semi-annual report of the Otis Elevator Company showed yesterday a net profit of $5,344,109 for the first six months of 1948, equal to $2.57 a common share.

ATHENS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis announced tonight a shake-up in the Greek Army high command in line with recent American suggestions for speeding up the war against the Communist-led guerrillas of Markos Vafiades.

Virtually all employes of the Oppenheim Collins Co. department store here and in Brooklyn turned a deaf ear to the strike call of a left-wing Congress of Industrial Organizations union yesterday morning. In the afternoon they voted their preference for an American Federation of Labor union as their bargaining agent.
" Alas, poor Sarge, I knew him well," said the hangdog corporal yesterday, mourning the extinction of the legendary three-stripe buck sergeant.

The first Congress in 1790 approved the expenditure of $10,000 for the securing of ten cutters which, manned by "respectable characters," would enforce the Tariff Act of 1789. This Revenue Marine or Revenue Service, as it was variously called, was merged in 1915 with the Life-Saving Service to form the Coast Guard.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles, today carved two strokes off Tam O'Shanter's par with a pair of 35's for a 70 to head twenty-eight pros in qualifying for the All-American tournament.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- In a handsome wearable collection, Marcel Rochas modifies the New Look by diminishing width, discarding petticoats.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council called on Australia tonight to give to the people of the trust territory of New Guinea more schools, more chance at self-government, better medical facilities and a larger share of social and economic benefits.
Brookline, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Aug. 9 on $739,000 of sewer revenue bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1948, and due on Aug. 1, 1949, to 1978. Bidders to name the rate.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ben Hogan today added the Western open golf championship to his National open and P.G.A. crown -- the first man ever to hold the three major titles the same season.

At the moment when the envoys of the United States, Britain and France were being admitted to the presence of Premier Stalin to submit their proposals for ending the Berlin crisis and settling the problems of Germany and of Europe. the Russian delegation at the Belgrade conference published its draft for a new Danube pact. which is highly revealing of Russian purposes and policies.
OTTAWA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Canadians learned tonight that some goods would be cheaper and a few would cost more as the result of week-end Government announcements.

Two of every three persons who purchase new automobiles on the installment plan are agreeing to pay for them in eighteen months or less, the Commercial Credit Corporation of Baltimore announced yesterday. A nation-wide survey of automobile credit sales revealed that 63 per cent of all new car buyers elect to pay for them within the eighteen months' period despite the fact that financing institutions permit twenty-four months' credit on such transactions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Forest Service today accepted the bid of the Ketchikan Pulp and Paper Company to establish a paper industry in Alaska. The company agreed to buy 1,500,000,000 cubic feet of pulp timber near Ketchikan, it was reported by C.M. Granger, acting chief forester, and will establish a pulp mill costing $20,000,000 to $30,000,000 at Ward's Cove, six miles north of Ketchikan.
NANKING, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Government's top commanders from most of China's civil war areas gathered in Nanking tonight for secret conferences.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The status of women in the United States could not be compared with that of Russian women, Soviet delegate A.P. Pavlov told members of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today.

" Pirates" who cached their "treasure" in an abandoned brownstone house at 504 East Eighty-ninth Street reckoned without Dan Cole and Tom Wagner, both of 237 East Eighty-fifth Street, partners in general piracy investigation.

Samuel Wolchok, right-wing international president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, suggested yesterday to Representatives Charles J. Kersten of Wisconsin and Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey that it would be a "serious error in judgment" if they sent to jail the nine left-wing union leaders who refused to say whether they had ever been members of the Communist party.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra opened the final week of its summer season with a concert last night at the Lewisohn Stadium that attracted an audience of 6,400. Alexander Smallens was the conductor and the soloists were Frances Magnes, violinist, and Marise Regules, pianist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Gov. Ernest Gruening of Alaska asserted today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, urging the Governors' Conference to expose the teacher lobby warned that it was "propagating the lie that they are underpaid."

Awakened from a beautiful dream, in which he envisioned an endless skein of victories with a Pot o' Gold at the finish, Leo Durocher yesterday saw his Giants lose their first home game since he took over the managerial reins from Mel Ott.

Welded steel cargo containers, large boxes with a capacity of 277 cubic feet, are becoming popular with steamship companies in the West Indies trade, according to a report issued yesterday by the Dravo Corporation, manufacturer of the containers.

Gross income of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries reached a new high of $174,353,190 in the fiscal year ended with last May, according to the fifty-first annual report issued to stockholders yesterday. This was 31 per cent above the previous record of approximately $133,000,000 shown for the preceding fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Senate Republican leaders went down to defeat today in their first effort to break a Southern filibuster that is killing the anti-poll tax bill.

The medical profession, the City of New York and the nation have suffered an irreparable loss in the death of Dr. James Alexander Miller. A pioneer in the crusade against tuberculosis, he was largely responsible for the establishment of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, of which he later became president.

" Shotgun Wedding," a new comedy fashioned for Zasu Pitts by Anita Loos and Frances Marion, was scheduled yesterday for production by George Abbott. Rehearsals will begin Oct. 1 under Mr. Abbott's direction, and the show is expected to open here late in November.

JERASALEM, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Count Bernadotte had lunch today with Brig. John Bagot Glubb Pasha at Trans-Jordan Legion headquarters in the Old City. Israeli sniper bullets whined past Herod's Gate near-by while they ate.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 2 (UP) -- The Government charged today that the alleged $1,000,000 "spy-swindle" plotters arrested last month had prepared plans to govern Hungary on the assumption that foreign aid would make it possible for them to seize power.

LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany, Aug. 2 -- Victims of the Farben chemical plant explosion were mourned here today by 10,000 relatives and friends who gathered around a twelve-foot cross in the city's main square for a memorial ceremony.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- Envoys of the United States, Britain and France emerged smiling and in good spirits tonight after conferring in the Kremlin with Premier Stalin on the chances of settling East-West differences in Berlin and all Europe.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Premier Andre Marie and Paul Reynaud, Minister of Finance, spent almost the entire day receiving delegates of labor organizations, civil servants, veterans and merchants' associations. An inner Cabinet meeting took no action upon M. Reynaud's fiscal and economic plans, and it was stated that several other meetings would be called before a decision is reached, which may be put off till Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Paul A. Porter, the Administration's chief inflation control advocate, accused Congress today of stalling and playing politics with President Truman's anti-inflation proposals.

ZURICH, Aug. 2 -- Success finally has rewarded the prolonged trade and payments negotiations between France and Switzerland that were begun in Berne on June 30 and ended in Paris last week, with a signature supplementary agreement to expire on Nov. 30, the same date that the Franco-Swiss economic agreement of 1945 ends.

The 26,454-ton luxury liner America returned to private operation yesterday after six years as a Government-owned vessel, with the transfer of title from the Maritime Commission to the United States Lines.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Joe Forrington's Picket from Bay Shore slipped around the course like an eel in a bucket of grease today to give the rest of the Star Class a sound beating at the beginning of the Great South Bay Y.R.A's Race Week.

Lookin' lazy at the sea doesn't require, in these parts, shipping somewhere east of Suez. All you had to do, once upon a time, was to go down and sit under the trees on the Battery. Now there aren't any trees on the Battery to sit under -- and there's no place on the Battery where you can look at the sea.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 (AP) Japanese Communists today plastered Tokyo with posters and shouted defiance of the Government. They seized on General MacArthur's recent stand against strikes by Government workers but were careful not to mention the occupation directly.

The threat of a strike on lines of the Third Avenue Transit Company and two affiliates became imminent last night, when the company, repudiated a wage increase arrangement after its failure to win a permanent eight-cent fare from the city.
An international competition offering $20,000 in awards for the designs of an imperial palace for Ethiopia was announced yesterday by John A. Shaw, Ethiopian Consul General in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Introduction of evidence that William W. Remington, Federal government career man, knew of many aspects of the Manhattan Project overshadowed today his flat denial that he ever gave secret information to Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, confessed Communist spy.

Directors of Fajardo Sugar Company of Porto Rico declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1. In June the company paid $1, consisting of its own dividend of 25 cents and a regular of 25 cents, an extra of 50 cents declared by the Fajardo Sugar Growers Association, an affiliate in which Fajardo common shareholders have a beneficial interest.

A late survey of the Boothbay and Casco Bay waters - indicates that there will be plenty of big tuna for the anglers participating in the individuil tuna tournament to be held between Aug. 11 and 14. A record entry list is certain, according to Richard E. Reed,. Maine's Sea and Shore Fisheries Commissioner, who urges entrants to make reservations for accommodations and boats without delay.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) Jack Wallaesa's pinch single in the tenth inning gave the White Sox a 2-1 victory over the Athletics before 17,548 persons tonight. The loss, charged to Dick Fowler, his third against ten victories, tumbled the Mackmen from first place to fourth in the American League standings.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 3 -Despite a heavy downpour this morning, a field of seventy-three started in the Metropolitan Golf ?Association one-day tournament over the Greenwich Country Club course today.
OCEANPORT, lkT. J., Aug. 3 UP) --Jockey Dave Gorman stole the show today when he rode three of the first five winners on the program at Aonmouth Park.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Diplomats here who have been informed of the nature of the talk yesterday between Premier Stalin and theh)0*0*0*ithree Western envoys, said today that the head of the Soviet Union had not proposed or promised a four-power conference on Germany, but had left the door open for one.

Eliminating the need of converters in areas where only direct current (DC) is available, the first portable "universal" television receiver which operates on both alternating (AC) and direct current was demonstrated here at a preview yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 3 The distrust and suspicion that the African native has for the European at presenth)0*0*0*iis poisoning life on the Gold Coast, it was stated in the report of a British commission of inquiry, issued today.

Banking groups preparing to enter competition for the $12,000000 Philadelphia School District bond offering next Wednesday are expected to create keen bidding, according to reports from underwriting circles yesterday. One group will be led by the Chase National Bank, another by the National City Bank of New York, and one will be led jointly by Lehman Brothers and Blyth Co, Inc.

The Firth Carpet Company established a new high record in sales for the first six months of this year and has declared an extra dividend for stockholders, Harold E. Wadely, president, announced yesterday.

In THE TIMES of July 21 you published a report from Lake Success, to the effect that the Children's Emergency Fund may be compelled to substitute other products for powdered milk, in its shipments abroad, because of "a sharp rise in the cost of powdered milk, plus an unexplained shortage of milk supplies in this country."

It was Saks Fifth Avenue's turn yesterday morning to reveal what the well-dressed college girl will wear on campus, in classroom, on week-ends in town and at college dances. The showing was arranged in four tableaux presented on the stage of the assembly room in the Beekman Towers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Stockpiling of scrap or pig iron by the United States is impractical at this time, and would deprive the steel industry of greatly needed production, it was stated here today in a special study prepared for the National Security Resources Board.

NO self-tortured genius ever needed the aid of a good psychiatrist more than didh)0*0*0*iCharles Baudelaire that is the final impression left by Max White's feverish and not very convincing novel. "The Midnight Gardener." Genius is always a difficult matter to describe effectively in fictional terms. Artistic genius is particularly difficult; and the spectacularly peculiar genius of Baudelaire may well have been so extravagant and irrational that it can never be made understandable.

Department store workers of Oppenheim Collins in an election directed by the NLRB have finally shaken off the Communist control to which a House subcommittee recently called public attention. By a vote of nearly three to one they chose an AFL union, untainted with communism, to represent them in all future negotiations with management.
Two frightened teen-age boys had a Tom Sawyer adventure yesterday when they went adrift on a small wooden raft in a strong downstream current on the East River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman returned to the White House today after a three-day air trip to his home town and set himself immediately to the accumulating and urgent tasks of his office.

Having gone from one extreme to the other, with something that could be described conservatively as a record-shattering crash, Manager Leo Durocher today will try to get his Giants back on the happy medium beam in a slight variation of the old two-a-day routine.

BISLEY, England, Aug. 3 (AP) Two quiet, iron-nerved Americansh)0*0*0*ispiked the "big guns" of the shooting world today to capture first and second places in the Olympic 50-meter (55 yards) small-bore rifle championship.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Resignation of Lowell B. Mason, Federal Trade Commissioner, from the Unitarian Star Island Conference because of remarks by Prof. Goodwin Watson of Columbia University Teachers College today drew an assertion that Professor Watson's speech did not "keynote" the meeting.

VIENNA, Aug, 3 - The Soviet Union released through Tass, its news agency, today a charge that the United States Counter Intelligence Corps was using criminals to break into Communist party offices and to spy on the Soviet occupation forces.

Traffic dangers created by itinerant truckers who ignore the Interstate Commerce Commission's safety regulations were emphasized yesterday by the northeastern regional truck-leasing sub committee of the American Trucking Associations.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 3 -- Commissioner General Malcolm MacDonald, broadcasting tonight on the progress of the battle with the Communists, said they had hoped to proclaim the birth of a Malayan Communist republic today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- A favored team of contract bridge players, composed of Mrs. Helen Sobel of New York, Charles H. Goren and John Crawford of Philadelphia and Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., took a commanding lead in the contest for the masters' mixed team-of-four championship in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here today.

TI/VIER POINT, L. I., Aug. 3--I Long Island Sound, represented byj Larchmont's Euddy Rogers withI Magic, gave a thumping to the lo-/ cai talent today as the Corry Tro-/ phy series for Star Class yachts/ began as the feature of Great South Bay's Race Week.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 3 - Irrespective of whether or not his proposal to demilitarize Jerusalem is accepted, Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator will continue his efforts to establish the Holy City's permanent political future.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled unanimously yesterday for court review of Attorney General Tom Clark's refusal to release five alleged alien Communists from Ellis Island on bail while deportation proceedings were pending.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) A spokesman for eight North Atlantic ports made plans at a conference today to recover shipping business that they charge ish) 0*0*0*ibeing "stolen" by Gulf Coast ports, particularly New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 - President Truman obviously was supplied with full details of the important conversation in the Kremlin, when he returned from his trip to Missouri today, but the White House maintained the same rigid secrecy prevailing at the State Department and elsewhere in official Washington.

For the first six months of this year, Federal tax receipts from wine, beer and distilled spirits sales fell 7 per cent below the January-June, 1947, level, according to an analysis of figures issued yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

ATHENS, Aug. 3 The Greek Army announced tonight a series of gains on all parts of the front, and a concerted thrust against the main rebel stronghold and seat of the Gen. Markos Vafiades' Junta, Grammos Mountain massif itself, seemed to be well under way.

CAMP SMITH, N. Y., Aug. 3--The largest number of troops ever assembled in the sixty-seven-year history of this New York National Guard post and the largest proportion of raw recruits are experiencing stepped-up training methods perfected here since the end of World War II.

The American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that its membership had accepted 3,043 to 1,610 a contract negotiated on June 2 with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. President Truman had appointed a board of inquiry to investigate the dispute.

As an avid reader of your newspaper, and in particular its editorial page, may I take the liberty of disagreeing with the editorial dealing with President Truman's list of suggestions for Congressional action at this special session? You stated: "On five of these matters, in our own judgment, there is no good reason to rush matters at this time.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Capt. Robert L. Heaton, 27 years old, of 212 Allen Street, Syracuse, N.Y., crashed to his death on the Henry C. Phipps estate here today after skimming over the roof of Cornelius W. Dresselhuys' house nearby.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -An additional 206,000 tons of Cuban sugar may be purchased to meet consumer demands in the United States this year. h)

Two religious groups found themselves involved in labor trouble yesterday. The National Board of the Y.W.C.A., 60 Lexington Avenue, was picketed for the third time, and at the Church World Service, 214 East Twenty-first Street, laid-off warehouse employes paraded with sandwich picket signs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, liberal short covering developing in wheat following announcement that exports this season might be 75,000,000 to 100,000,000 bushels in excess of preliminary figures, despite marked improvement in the European food grain crops.

New fire insurance rates thatwent into effect on many piers inthe Port of New York last weekshowed a paradoxical risk situationbased on the statistically supportedthesis that piers with thebest fireguards had the mostlosses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Army is renaming four ships in tribute to Medal of Honor men who lost their lives in World War II.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians climbed back on top of the American League tonight with Satchel Paige fogging 'em past the Washington Senators for a 5-to-3 victory.

DAYTON, Aug. 3 -- A two-milesquare area surrounding the plant of the Univis Lens Company was an armed camp tonight following use of armored vehicles, tear gas and bayonets by National Guard troops in repelling supporters of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, at the plant gates earlier in the day.

Catering to the petite sophisticate of 5 feet 4 inches and under, Lord Taylor opened a new shop yesterday morning, known as "The 54 Shop." The coats, suits and dresses found there follow theh) 0*0*0*isame general style trends as regular misses' fashions, but have been scaled to the figure proportions of the woman of small stature.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -"Confessions of an American Communist," which was announced for production last March by John Sutherland, has been dropped by the producer. The film was to have been based upon material from the files of Brig. Gen. William (Wild Bill) Donovan's Office of Strategic Services.

PRAGUE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry charges that a man accused of trying to kill the War Minister, Gen. Ludwig Svoboda, had been instructed for the task in the presence of a dozen American officers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Britain's rule of Tanganyika was criticized sparingly today in a United Nations Trusteeship Council report that was denounced roundly by delegates on both sides of the administrative fence.

Alger Hiss, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, denied yesterday Whittaker Chambers' allegations before the House Committee on Un-American Activities that he was a former member of the Communist "underground" in Washington.

The conversations started in Moscow are likely to go on if the four governments stick to their resolution to maintain strict secrecy on what goes on inside the meetings. At this stage the exchanges are so tentative and preliminary that no one will question the wisdom of secrecy.

Cucumbers now are at the lowest price of the season and are being featured in many stores for 10 cents a pound, according to the City Department of Markets. This price is 5 cents less than that for which the vegetable was being sold a little over a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug 3 (AP) -The New Jersey Public Utility Commission and five state utility companies undertook today to force the Texas Eastern Transmissionh)0*0*0*iOCorporation to sell them natural gas.

h) 0*0*0*iLONDON, Aug. 3 -- America's mighty male relay swimming team, sparked by record-holders Wally Ris, Jimmy 1VfcLane and Bill Smith plus a newcomer, Wallace Wolf, wiped the slate clean tonight of all standing marks in the 800-meter relay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -Small business spokesmen today attacked a proposed voluntary plan to provide steel for the armed forces. They called it a blow ath)0*0*0*ismall manufacturers.

TRIESTE, Aug. 3 The Communist Information Bureau's denunciation of Marshal Tito and his Yugoslav Communist party for heresy has had the repercussion of splitting the seams of the entire Communist structure in the Free Territory of Trieste.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 3 Arab Higher Committee officials disclosed here today that plans were progressing rapidly for setting up an Arab government over all Palestine.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug 3 -Hyderabad holds the Indian embargo on medical supplies to the independent princely state responsible for the current cholera epidemic there which, according to Hyderabad, health authorities,h)0*0*0*icaused sixty deaths in three days last week.

LONDON, Aug. 3--Miel Patton, tall, lean sprinter from Southern California whom Coach Dean Cromwell of the United States team calls the world's fasest human of all time, came back from the depths of his failure in the 100 to lead Barney Ewell of Lancaster, Pa., and Lloyd La Beach of Panama to the tape in the Olympic 200-meter final today at Wembley Stadium.

Since this is vacation time, when one never knows how soon the canoe will capsize in the Hudson, it also is the open season for speculation as to life on that desert island. That is the island, it will be remembered, to which the reader may take three books of his choice.

James L. P. Rumble, of 1470 Fifth Avenue, a prospective Republican candidate for Congress in the Twenty-second District in Harlem, was disqualified yesterday by the Board of Elections afterh)0*0*0*icharges had been made that he was an ex-convict.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Congressional approval of a $65,000,000 building loan to the United Nations in the present session was virtually assured today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- An "underground" Communist organization, led by men at key posts of government and operating to infiltrate the whole establishment with its party members, was described to the House Committee on Un-American Activities today by an admitted former Communist, Whittaker Chambers, who said he served as a courier for the group.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $33,175,442, a drop of $4,039,377 from the $37,214,819 in the precedling twelve months, it was announced yesterday.

TORQUAY, England, Aug. 3 (AP) -- United States yachtsmen placed among the leaders in all classes but Europeans did the winning in opening Olympic yacht races in Torquay Harbor today. Seven races will be staged in each class with the best points for only six races counted.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The interview of the three Western envoys with Mr. Stalin provided enough material to keep Foreign Secretary Bevin and his advisers busy all today studying and analyzing it to make up their minds what attitude to take.h)0*0*0*iO

GENEVA, Aug. 3 -- In the third week of its current session theh)0*0*0*iEconomic and Social Council of the United Nations is almost hopelessly bogged down in its agenda, and leading delegates are openly expressing doubts about the usefulness of continuing the organization at all on its present basis.
The Maritime Commission has invited bids for the purchase of three vessels, including the famous old luxury yacht Nourmahal, which was formerly the property of Vincent Astor.
West Point and Hollywood pooled talents last night and came up with a production that drew thousands to Times Square, and there they found a brass band in the middle of the Paramount Theatre lobby.

Mixed price action was taken yesterday by leading, copper producers in opening books for September shipment. Two major companies advanced prices 2 cents a pound to 23 1/2 cents, Connecticut Valley base, while a third held its levels unchanged at 21 1/2 cents.

Two employers' groups and a union here are providing three more affiliated units needed by the Department of the Army as components of the Organized Reserve, it was announced yesterday by Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commanding general of the First Army.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. have amended the company by-laws, reducing the number of board members from fifteen to twelve, it was learned today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- As a strong indication of the seriousness with which the German predilection for cartels was regarded, bipartite Military Government officials cracked down today on an incipient banking monopoly seeking to establish common interest rates on individual loans.

Norway's famous "White Swan of the Seven Seas," the full-rigged training ship Christian Radich, stands out like a picture from a story book as she swings in her moorings at Pier 6, the East River, following a twenty-sevenday trip from Oslo, with a stop-over at Madeira.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- By putting on "Tanglewood on Parade"h)0*0*0*ihere today, $10,000 was raised to aid European creative artists. That sum was paid by the crowd of 7,000 who came to hear and see a series of features that began in the early afternoon and ended with fireworks seven hours later.

Oak Street police station, whoseh)0*0*0*ifour stories of sturdy brick have stood as a symbol and center of law enforcement since 1870, will see its last roll-call at 8 o'clock this morning. Like the crumbling tenements around it, it must give way to a modern, low-rent housing development named for one of the neighborhood's best-loved sons, the late Alfred E. Smith.

RUMSON, N. J., Aug 3 -- With all three leading contenders shoot-ing 7-over-par 82's, Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll'maintained her two-stroke lead today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Jersey Shore championship at the completion of thirty-six holes.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The London stock markets were quiet today after the bank holiday, although optimism that the Stalin talks would lead to settlement of the German problem was reflected in generally firm conditions. All sections closed at the best levels of the day.

A compromise agreement for modification of Cuba's stringent textile import regulations will eliminate the most obnoxious features of that measure, according to John W. Murray, secretary of the Textile Export Association of the United States.

NANKING, Aug. 3 -- Criticisms as scathing as any ever made by outside critics were leveled at the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] today by its own members in theh)0*0*0*ifirst day of the two-day closed meeting called to discuss party reforms.

" Communism -- U.S. Brand," the American Broadcasting Company's documentary on the activities of the Communists in this country, will be heard for a second time from 9:30 to 10:30 P.M. Sunday. It was presented originally on Monday night and yesterday the network reported that it was besieged by requests for a repeat performance.

A suit was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Timothy F. Dinan, chairman of the auto enginemen committee of the Civil Service Forum, in behalf of himself and 1,000 others to restrain the city from allegedly compelling them to waive rights to back pay and future benefits as a condition of receiving cost-of-living increases of $250 a year.

h)0*0*0*iA major obstacle to signing of a contract covering 2,500 composing room employes on twelve daily newspapers here was removed yesterday when the executive board of the International Typographical Union, AFL, approved a proposed agreement between Local 6 and the Publishers Association of New York City.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 3 - Richard I. Bowditch, president of the New England Council, said today that travelers on the nation's railroads "must be willing to pay rates" enabling the carriers to provide the "masterpieces" of new equipment already rolling on the lines.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UP) -- A buyers' strike against high meat prices was spreading across the nation today. Housewives from Corpus Christi, Tex., to Long Island were organizing boycotts with the sloagn, "Buy No Meat for One Week."
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP) -- United States diplomatic sources kept silent tonight on the negotiations between the Western powers and Premier Stalin over East-West differences.
OSINGAPORE, July 30 (Delayed) -- British officials here foresee a long bitter struggle with the nsurgent Chinese Communists in Malaya

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 3--Arpad Szakasits, pro-Communist Socialist, succeeded to the Presidency of Hungary today. He was sworn in immediately, taking the place of Zoltan Tildy, a member of the Small Landholders party, who resigned Friday when his son-in-law was accused of spying and treason.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- New international emphasis on health and nutrition programs for mothers and children was revealed in a joint press conference today by Dr. Thomas Parran and Dr. Martha Eliot, two of the three United States delegates to the recent initial meeting of the World Health Organization in Geneva.

In the midst of the nation's most vigorous anti-Communist drive, the American Communist high command affirmed yesterday the intention of the party to move into a major political contending role. While party statements only hinted at it, they indicated that the Communists intended to achieve this by working through the Wallace Progressive party with the 1952 elections in mind.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) The Greek freighter Alexander Koryzis was scheduled to sail from here tonight with 10,000 tons of coal for French factories but with a wage and bonus dispute of crew members still unsettled.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 3 -- A special three-judge Federal courth) 0*0*0*iruled today that a New Mexico constitutional provision denying the right to vote to Indians was contrary to the United States Constitution.

h)0*0*0*iJ. Craig Clark has been appointed executive assistant to the president of the B.V.D. Corporation, effective on Sept. 1. He formerly was with the Grey Advertising Agency as an account executive.

The latest deadline in the tense negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians passed yesterday without a final decision. The fate of the coming opera season is still uncertain this morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Two women executives of a New York store employes' union refused to tell a Congressional committee today whether they were Communists.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- German antiCommunist trade union leaders who conferred last night with David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Union (AFL), and George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks and a vice presidenth)0*0*0*iof the American Federation of Labor, assured them that they would continue to support the Western powers, despite the difficulties imposed on them by the Soviet blockade, they informed a press conference here today.

As a result ct complaints against exaggerated price-value comparisons in current retail fur advertising, the Better Business Bureau of New York will begin canvassing the trade late this week to learn dealers' attitude toward a suggested elimination of value claims, a bureau spokesman announced yesterday.

Ancient buildings of untold historic value near Baliana, Egypt surrounded by the tombs of kings and their subjects, are in danger of innundation and collapse as the result of extensive irrigation work, Amice M. Calverley, Egyptologist, reported yesterday.

Commenting on the nine "miscellaneous" matters listed by the President last week as requiring legislation at the present special session of Congress, we expressed the opinion here that with respect to five of them there seemed to us to be no good reason for rushing action.

After attorneys for several persons claiming relationship to theh)0*0*0*ilate Miss Mary Bullock Powers, wealthy recluse, had made their claims in Surrogate's Court yesterday, Surrogate William T. Collins adjourned the hearing with the remark that "it might turn out to be another Wendel case."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3--In the backstretch Gallorette had only one horse beaten in the $17,975 Wilson Stakes at Saratoga today, but in the home stretch it was a different story. There she charged to the front outside the sixteenth pole, and at the end of the mile run the closest of her nine pursuers was a length back of the worlffs No. 1 moneywinning race mare.

Arthur Garfield Hays, special counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, declared yesterday that the action of the Federal Government "in trying the Communists on the basis of what they said and wrote rather than upon what they have done to overthrow the Government," constituted the greatest present threat to civil liberties.

Stalled on the question of future wages, negotiations between the National Maritime Union and shipping operators of the Atlantic and Gulf were recessed yesterday without a date for resumption of the discussions.

Love, director of theevening and extension division, announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 Restrained optimism over the prospect of an early lifting by the Russians of the Berlin blockade was evident in informed quarters in the Western military governments tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) The United States basketball team that had been supposed to find the Olympics a breeze ran into a cyclone instead today and barely escaped with a 59-57 victory over Argentina.
There is widespread friendship for India in this country but little knowledge about it, Sir Homi Mody said here yesterday.

Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six @months ended on June 30, net profit of $6,306,658 in contrast to the $475,941 earned in the corresponding period of last year.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan reserved decision yesterday on two petitions to restrain the National Labor Relations Board from certifying an American Federation of Labor union as bargaining agent for employes of the two Oppenheim Collins Co. department stores against which a Congress of Industrial Organizations union is waging a strike.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A Navy eight-ship convoy's race to carry a year's supplies to the top of the North American Continent was blocked today, at least temporarily, by the Arctic ice pack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Republican leaders in Congress agreed tonight to take action on three points of President Truman's anti-inflation program. Their limited legislative list would include bank and consumer credit controls and housing.

For four hours yesterday the credentials committee of the New York State Federation of Labor heard testimony from twenty-six delegates whom it has barred as Communists from the federation's annual Convention here.

Walter C. Hewitt, real estate developer, has purchased sixty-seven acres of land on Florida Avenue and Shinbone Lane in Commack, L.I., from Stephen Cavagnaro. The Walter C. Hewitt Organization will subdivide the property in the near future and sell it in parcels of one and two acres, according to Mr. Hewitt.

How two men, both Puerto Ricans, battled savagely in a sixty-passenger plane, filled with men, women and children, and clawed the pilot and the steward, while flying over the ocean off the Florida Coast Monday evening, was revealed here yesterday when the plane landed at La Guardia Field.

CRESTWOOD,-N. Y., Aug. 3-First and second places in the Westchester division competition of the fifteenth World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament were taken by second-day players today. Sal Di Buono, veteran pro at Bonnie Briar in Larchmont, was first with a i foot 4%-inch shot and E. V. Treacy Jr. of Westchester 'Hills was second with a 1 foot 9 1/2-inch shot.

Your tribute on Saturday to President Isaiah Bowman of the Johns Hopkins University, was indeed merited. Many professional geographers owe much to him for his encouragement. And you do well to stress his interest in human geography. During his lifetime geography in America has come of age.

The faith of ninety-four crippled children in prayer was rewarded yesterday when rain threatened to cause the cancellation or postponementh)0*0*0*iof an outing to which they had been looking forward for many weeks.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, and Herbert Brownell Jr., his campaign manager, conferred for three hours today on plans for getting the Republican Presidential campaign under way.

PARIS, Aug. 3 -- Gowns pulled in about the knees, drapery knotted in back of the knees, a silhouetteh)0*0*0*istrongly reminiscent of the period from 1909 to 1912 is the highlight of Jean Desses' magnificent collection.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Chairman Arthur H. Vandenberg of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today said his group expects to wind up its work on the International Wheat Agreement at an executive session tomorrow.

A favorable report by the Weather Bureau on the cotton crop offset increased trade demand yesterday. Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange failed to move far in either direction and closed steady, 2 points higher to 3 points lower.

The Department of Justice filed a civil anti-trust suit in Federal Court yesterday charging that Decca Records, Inc., one of the largest manufacturers of phonograph records in this country, and Decca Records Company, Ltd., a British corporation, had engaged in an international conspiracy to control the world market for records.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The seventh-place Cincinnati Reds tonight defeated the league leading Boston Braves for the second time in a row, Belting Johnny Sain from the box early and going on to a 5-4 triumph before 19,588 disappointed fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) - Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to build a 510mile pipeline from Milpitas, Santa Clara County, Calif., to the CaliforniaArizona boundary near Topock, Mohave County, Arizona.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Roxy the attraction is "The Walls of Jericho," a Twentieth CenturyFox drama featuring Cornel Wilde, Linda Darnell, Ann Dvorak and Anne Baxter. John M. Stahl directed and Lamar Trotti producedh)0*0*0*iand adapted the offering from the novel by Paul Wellman.
An inquiry into the pricing and selling of homogenized milk will be started within the next few days, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced 'yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (;P)--United States athletes have built up a commanding 3-to-1 lead over their nearest rival during the first four days of the Olympic games. The Americans have garnered 255 points in all phases to 86 for Sweden, the nearest competitor.

LONDON, Aug. 3 Members of the United States Olympic team were included among the guests who attended a reception and garden party given by King George and Queen Elizabeth for representatives of the competing nations at Buckingham Palace tonight.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 3-Through fog of the sort that sailors call "mud" the fleet of the New York Yacht Club arrived from New London today on the first squadron run of its cruise. It was twenty-four miles from the United States Navy Challenge Cups, and twenty-seven yachts were in the competition.

Justice Frank Oliver in Bronx Special Sessions Court questioned yesterday the wisdom of making policemen pay for their own ammunition on the ground that they cannot afford to buy much of it and so get little target practice.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., had a net income of $424, 951 on sales and billings of $42,796,767 for the six months ended with last May, according to the report of Donald W. Douglas, president, released for publication today.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 3 (AP) -The Mississippi Democratic Convention approved today the walkout of the state's delegates at the National Convention, and pledged their electoral college candidates to support the States' Rights ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A $4,300,000,000 excess-profits tax, designed to aid in the fight on inflation, was proposed to Congress today by President Truman. Simultaneously, Marriner S. Eccles, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told a House Banking and Currency Committee that he was opposed to re-enactment of any such measure.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 3 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator in Palestine, today began conferences with Mahmoud Fahmyh)0*0*0*iNokrashy Pasha, Prime Minister of Egypt, and Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary General of the Arab League, at Alexandria on the demilitarization of Jerusalem.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,118, against 1,025 last week and 1,106h)0*0*0*iin the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 602 arrivals yesterday, compared with 396 last Tuesday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 3 When the Board of Education reconvenes next month it will act on a program made public today that may lift this community to a position of national leadership in the field of school-community relationship.

The crowds, the fliers -- and the gate receipts for Grover A. Whalen's committee putting on the jubilee air show at New York International Airport -- were rained out pitilessly yesterday. But the Navy and the Civil Aeronautics Administration each had something for the experts that proved of high interest.
Although infantile paralysis has reached the epidemic stage in several other parts of the country, there is no cause for alarm here, the Health Department declared yesterday.

If there is one thing above all others in our American way of life in which most thoughtful citizens take pride and in which they firmly believe, it is in the principles of civil rights enunciated in the first ten amendments to our Constitution. They were attached to the Constitution on the demand of the people of the thirteen colonies before they would accept the Constitution itself.
TOKYO Aug. 3 -- Tokyo's black market, which has shown many vagaries in the last three years, now has a new one. It has turned from black to white and undersells the official price scale.

" Man and His Works: The Science of Cultural Anthropology," by Melville J. Herskovits, Professor of Anthropology at Northwestern University, has been scheduled for Sept. 13 publication by Knopf. The 655-page volume contains descriptions of primitive ways of life and discussions of cultural relativism, historic accident and the contributions of anthropology to our knowledge of man and his world today.

The stock market lapsed yesterday into a state of inertia. Restricted again by meagre volume, due to an obvious desire by traders to await Congressional reaction to the Administration's anti-inflation proposals, as well as the results of the Kremlin conference, prices barely moved.

How religious orders in Italy are setting up rehabilitation centers for youngsters similar to Boys Town, Neb., established by the late Msgr. E. J. Flanagan, was explained here yesterday. Msgr. Andrew P. Landi, delegate of war relief services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference in Italy for four years, described the Italian work at the Empire State Club.
