The Economic Cooperation Administration "hopes" to issue supplemental regulations covering section 202 of the ECA Appropriations Act some time this week, or next, it was learned yesterday. The clause in question, interpreted as a ban on authorization of ECA bulk commodity purchases within, or outside of, the United States at prices higher than those prevailing in domestic markets, is regarded by some traders as a serious obstacle to ECA operations and financing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 -- Sir Charles Peake, British Ambassador to Belgrade and chief British delegate to the Danubian conference, protested vehemently at today's session against tactics of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister.

When the lunch-hour whistle blew yesterday at the Garod Radio Corporation, 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, under the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, 200 employes said "Time for Joe." For Joe, short for Joseph Baratz, is the blind man from the Industrial Home for the Blind at 520 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, newly operating the company's cafeteria stand.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers totalled 9,066,603 lines for July, a gain of 2.52 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotive, up 14.21 per cent; classified, 7.49 per cent, and retail, 4.88 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The favored team of Mrs. Helen Sobel of New York, Charles H. Goren and John Crawford of Philadelphia and Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., won the contract bridge masters' mixed team-of-four championship in the national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here today, after three sessions of play in which seventy-nine teams competed.

Four shiploads of war materials are being sent this week to Great Britain from the New York Port of Embarkation at Stapleton, S. I., it was learned there yesterday after the first vessel, the 7,600-ton Oglethorpe Victory, had departed. As soon as the Oglethorpe Victory left port early yesterday, morning, huge cranes started loading the second vessel, the Pvt. Joe E. Mann, also a 7,600-ton Victory ship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 28:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -The United States today allotted 1,120,000 tons of iron and steel for export in the third quarter.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Rumanian Government today barred mother churches abroad from control over their churches in Rumania.

Reflecting improved sales, in the first half of 1948, the consolidated net income of Standard Brands, Inc., and its United States subsidiaries increased 31 per cent to $5,019,241 from the $3,834,536 earned in the corresponding six months of last year, according to yesterday's report of Joel S. Mitchell, president.
Two old Manhattan holdings were among the Manhattan properties reported yesterday as having passed into new hands.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 4 -- President Syngman Rhee today announced the completion of his first Cabinet. Seven ministers were named this morning to the elevenmember Council of State.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Maj. G. B. Moore ot Chevy Chase, Md., placed second today in the Olympic modern pentathlon, won by the gritty, record-smashing Capt. W. O. G. Grut of Sweden.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the North Hempstead Country Club turned in one of her finest rounds, 37, 36 -- 73, two strokes under women par, to capture the low gross prize in the women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Huntington Country Club today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4 -- An estate estimated at $6,000,000 is disposed of by the will of Mrs. Alice Troth Drexel, widow of John R. Drexel, filed in Probate Court here today.

The Metropolitan Opera Association decided yesterday to call off its plans for a 1948-49 season. This decision was taken by the board of directors after failure to reach agreements with all the twelve unions representing the opera's employes.

The Brooklyn Tuberculosis and Health Association's new healthmobile -- an information and chest X-ray center on wheels -- was dedicated yesterday at ceremonies at Borough Hall as part of a drive to reduce the tuberculosis rate in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 Another film producing company, Rambler Pictures Corporation, today was added to the rapidly growing number of independent concerns, and its first screen play was announced as "The Whip," a Craig Rice mystery.

Friendly relations that have existed for the last century between the United States and countries ofh)0*0*0*ithe Middle East have been all but destroyed by an "incoherent policy of convenience" followed by the Truman Administration in behalf of Israel, Senator Mahamoud Abul Fath, editor and owner of one of Egypt's largest newspapers, declared here yesterday.
With two exceptions, major sterling silver flatware makers have raised prices 8 to 10 per cent and one other plans to announce an increase next week, it became known yesterday.

Two Army airmen were injured yesterday afternoon at New York International Airport in the first crack-up of the air show. A simulated air rescue became an actuality when an Army physician parachuted to the ground and administered first aid to the men.

Pickapeppa sauce, as pungent as the name implies, arrives back in the stores today after an eightyear absence. The spicy condiment was originated years ago in Jamaica, B.W.I., on one of the old sugar plantations there. That island still is the only place where it is produced.

Plans for a strike of the 3,900 employes of the Third Avenue Transit system of bus and street car lines at 4 A.M. tomorrow were pushed last night by the leadership of the Transport Workers Union, CIO. The system serves 2,000,000 daily riders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

On the site of the old, emergency accident building of Roosevelt Hospital, where a half century ago clanging horse-drawn ambulances used to dash out to handle emergencies in the neighborhood, ground was broken yesterday for the erection of a new two-story emergency center.

The country's gasoline stocks declined 1,525,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 99,116,000 barrels, compared with 100,641,000 a week earlier and 86,032,000 a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -All Indian newspapers featured today reports from London that British officers might be withdrawn from both the Indian and Pakistani Armies to avoid embroilment of the United Kingdom in the conflict over the Princely State of Kashmir.

" A Date With Judy," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer romantic musical, featuring Jane PoweU, Elizabeth Taylor, Wallace Beery and Carmen Miranda, which arrives at the Radio City Music Hall, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Richard Thorpe directed and Joe Pasternak produced the picture from a screen play by Dorothy Cooper and Dorothy Kingsley.

An increase of 15 cents an hour in base rates for 18,000 employes of the American Viscose Corporation, 350 Fifth Avenue, was announced simultaneously last night by the corporation and the Textile Workers Union of America, CIO.
George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and Charles M. Spofford, president of the association, issued yesterday the following joint statement:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Aug. 4 The British delegation said today that Sir Alan Burns, representative in the United Nations Trusteeship Council, had sent a copy of his defense of church missions in Africa to Francis Cardinal Spellman but had not complained of or "reported" any other delegate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Both wholesale and retail prices may be expected to rise several percentage points in the next few months, Garfield V. Cox, dean of the University of Chicago School of Business, said today.

After much footless heating around the bush in Congress, completion of action on the $65,000,000 loan for construction of a permanent United Nations headquarters in this city seems to be assured. Stripped of the mass of controversial matter in which it was enmeshed, the bill is now reduced to the single purpose of authorizing the grant.

For the second time in four years a Republican candidate for President is obliged by patriotic and other responsible considerations to hold to mere skirmishing his offensive operations on a major sector of the campaign battlefront -- that dealing with the foreignh) 0*0*0*ipolicy and acts of the executive in power.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Chemise frocks, slim, exquisite in simplicity, were applauded at Jacques Fath's evening showing held in his flood-lit garden. As narrow as can be, shortened to thirteen inches, they have large patch pockets on the hips, tiny belts, long tight kimono sleeves.

Just when the 20.352 fans at Ebbets Field last night were beginning to wonder which was the last-place club, the Dodgers rallied for single runs in the seventh and eighth innings, drew even with the Cubs and then tallied the winning point after two were out in the ninth.

ATHENS, Aug. 4 The national forces tonight have won virtual control of the whole Smolika mountain area, a great natural bastion protecting the southern approaches to Grammos proper. Forces coming in from the east and others attacking from the west have met, an official source said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The Israeli Government, pressing its charges that 11,000 Jewish refugees are being illegally held captive on the Island of Cyprus, called upon the United Nations Security Council today to declare that Great Britain is violating the Palestine truce.

The State Federation of Labor amended its constitution yesterday to bar Communists and all others seeking the forcible overthrow of the Government from holding office and acting as delegates to its conventions.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Tralling along the baseball beat these days, trying to remain calm, cool and collected in the midst of the most astounding pennant races in the history of the American League, one hears no end of talk about pitching. Seems everybody is talking about the present crop of pitchers, their ability, or lack of it, with reasons for same.
A feud threatened yesterday between automobile dealers and manufacturers over the excess of accessories foisted on a car-hungry public.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A telephone crusade against high meat prices mounted as hogs hit record price peaks today.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP) -Buffalo carved out a 3-2 edge in the five-game series with Jersey City tonight by sweeping a double-header, 6 -- 3 and 15 -- 1, before 4,502 fans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 -Booming far beyond the expectations of even the most optimistic leaders, the television industry should produce more than 850,000 receivers by the end of this year and have in operation more than sixty broadcasting stations, it was declared here today by Frank M. Folsom, executive vice president of the Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. (AP) -China and the United State agreed tonight to set up a join five-man commission to better economic conditions in the rural area of China.
Shipping companies engaged in labor negotiations have offered to renew old hiring hall provisions covering radio operators of the American Radio Association, CIO, it was reported yesterday.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Aug. 4 Most owners of a graceful three-masted schooner would want to sail her away from business worries. But Nathaniel T. Ewer worried today how he could bring his 148-foot boat ashore and convert her into a combined gift shop and sporting goods store.

An important step in the unification of our military services occurred yesterday when Secretary of Defense Forrestal addressed the first gathering of the Armed Forces Information School at Carlisle Barracks, Pennsylvania. Organized originally as the Army Information School, it trained many officers and enlisted men to interpret the Army to the civilian and to explain to the newly inducted civilian why he was in the Army.

Japanese silk may again be purchased in selected assortment lots of 300 bales, it was announced yesterday by the SCAP Foreign Trade Office in New York. Sales of the assorted lots were suspended early in July for a resurvey of available stocks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Herman Barron of White Plains, N.Y., 1946 champion, surged into the halfway lead of the $50,000 AllAmerican golf tourney today with a four-under-par 68 for a thirtysix hole aggregate of 136, eight under regulation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- United States, British and French envoys conferred for three hours tonight on their next step in negotiations with Russia for a settlement of the Berlin crisis and perhaps EastWest differences in all Europe.

NANKING, Aug 4 -- The two-day Kuomintang (Government) party caucus, called to discuss party reforms, ended today with the Liberals and the Old Guard in disagreement over the direction that the reforms should take.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United States' basketball team, stung by yesterday's close call with Argentina, turned loose its lightning tonight to strike down Egypt, 66 -- 28. The triumph assured the undefeated American quintet of a berth in the eight-team finals when the eliminations are completed.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4 -For the first time since 1938, when Turco-Russian trade virtually came to an end, a Russian offer to buy Turkish products has been made here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4 -- Ambassador Cavendish Cannon, chief United States delegate at the Danubian Conference, will reject at tomorrow's session the substance of the Soviet draft convention for the future regime of the Danube.

0*0*0*iOAs 30,000 to 35,000 persons thrilled to the repetition of the Air Force and Navy programs at New York International Airport at Idlewild yesterday, three men best qualified to do so applied the lessons of the demonstrations to the future in the air.

0*0*0*iOThe decision of the special Federal Court at Santa Fe holding unconstitutional New Mexico's restriction on the right of the Indians to vote removes the last specific barrier by a state against the right of these native Americans to cast their ballots. The Arizona Supreme Court on July 15 held unconstitutional the ban by that state against the Indian.
ATHENS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Two Greek columns, advancing from east and west, joined today and near Kerasovon cut in two the "Free Greece" of communist guerrilla chieftain, Markos Vafiades.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The representatives of the Soviet Union and the Ukraine indicated today that they would support a Yugoslav protest to the United Nations Security Council against Anglo-American policy regarding the free territory of Trieste.

The big vacant plot at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, boarded up since the Vanderbilt mansion was razed last fall, is now bustling with activity in another major building operation on the avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- The United States and Britain matched Soviet demands for economic supremacy in Berlin with new air supply records today as the battle for command of the city continued. In the twenty-four hours ended at 4 P.M. the United States and British Air forces were estimated to have flown 3,681 tons of supplies into the city.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 4 -- Americans will pay more income taxes, more to live -- and there will be less goods to buy within the next year, William H. Stead, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, predicted today at the closing session of the fourth annual National Forum on Labor, Agriculture and Industry at the University of Wyoming.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that despite the reorganization of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad he still retained the right to decide a loan dispute between the railroad and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

I am deeply disturbed by the perversion of the Congressional investigating machinery which has been growing up of late. We are now being treated to the spectacle of citizens and officials of hitherto unblemished repute being dragged through the mud on the testimony of a self-confessed Communist spy.
A new convention recognizing the extension of war to civilian populations will be sought at the forthcoming Seventeenth International Red Cross Conference which opens in Stockholm on Aug. 20.
The sixty-five-year history of the Metropolitan Opera Association has been a turbulent one. But only twice before has the home of the most famous singers in the world closed its doors.

TIMBER POINT, L. I., Aug. 4 Sailing in extremely light airh)0*0*0*ireminiscent of usual conditions on his home Long Island Sound, Buddy Rogers of Larchmont brought Magic in first over a shortened course today in the Corry Trophy series for Star Class yachts.

A small and discreet collection that should be a boon to the woman, young or middle-aged, who likes to dress well on a budget, came to New York yesterday from Kansas City. It is Nelly Don's. The dresses, ranging in price from $10.95 to $19.95. were shown at the Hotel Pierre.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- A magnetic device capable of detecting, from the cabin of an airplane in normal flight, the presence of rock formations deep below the surface of the earth, was demonstrated at the Westchester County Airport here today by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

MARK well the man whose picture appears more or less southwest of these words. He smokes a pipe made of metal as well as wood, thus helping to use up the world's precariously limited supply of ore and timber. The tobacco in it passed through all sorts of hands that might have been planting corn and beans. His needless coat lapels waste precious wool.
A syndicate represented by Dr. Manuel Stapen has bought the sixstory apartment house at 15 Washington Place from Eric Coupey through H. Stanley Hillyer Inc. and Joseph H. Nassoit, Inc., brokers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 4 Deadlocked twice on a 6-to-6 vote, the United Nations Trusteeship Council tonight rejected a move to support bringing South West Africa into the world organization's trust system.

Henry A. Wallace and Senator Glen H. Taylor, Progressive party nominees for President and Vice-President, will open their New York campaign officially with a rally in the Yankee Stadium on Thursday, Sept. 9, C.B. Baldwin,h)0*0*0*icampaign manager, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Efforts to ascertain the nature of conversations between Premier Stalin and representatives of the Western powers in the Kremlin Monday night proved fruitless here again today. The White House and State Department continued silent, an officer of the latter establishment saying:
The new draft law should not cause any important change in the national employment situation, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, declared yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -Miss Claudia Pinza, operatic and concert singer and daughter of Ezio Pinza, well-known basso of the Metropolitan Opera, was married here today to John Boller of New York. The ceremony was performed in the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Schumacher by the Rev. E. L. Day, executive secretary of the Christian Union Church.

Operations of the Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the first half of this year resulted in a net income of $24,879,098, which contrasted with the $13,246,116 cleared in the 1947 period, according to the semi-annual statement released today.

A group of large package goods liquor dealers and others in the metropolitan area who feel they would benefit through cut-rate operations are preparing to fight the Mitchell Fair Trade Law, it was reported here yesterday. This law, in effect since last September, makes it mandatory for all suppliers to place their goods on a fair trade basis and post prices with the State Liquor Authority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Leon J. Davis, president of the Retail Drug Store Employes (CIO) in New York, refused to say under oath today whether he was a Communist.

Amparo Iturbi, whose brother, Jose, appeared at the Lewisohn Stadium earlier this season, was the soloist there last night. She played Liszt's Piano Concerto in E flat, with Enrico Leide conducting the New York PhilharmonicSymphony.

Three men who have been jostling each other for first place in the Goldman Band's annual memory contest for seventeen years again took top honors when the contest was held for the twentysixth time last night in Central Park.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Ten New England cotton textile mills employing 9,000 workers were operating on a four-day schedule today because of lack of orders. No lay-offs were reported.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- For the third time in as many nights the seventh-place Reds tonight defeated the Braves, 4-2, before 18,916 paid fans who saw Cincinnati end the game with a fast double play to choke off a ninth-inning Boston rally after one run had been scored.
Conflicting views on the tenseness of the European situation were expressed yesterday by passengers who arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth from Cherbourg and Southampton.
Your Mr. Krock some days ago quoted "toujours l'audace" as the Napoleonic military maxim.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 4 -The first I3nited States Shooting Star jet fighters arrived here today in the transport Barney Kirchbaum en route for Germany. One officer and eight enlisted men accompanied the thirteen aircraft that preceded the main force due in Glasgow at the week-end in the aircraft carrier Sicily.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The potato support program under the Steagall amendment during the last five years has operated at a net loss of $170,169,000, the Department of Agriculture computed today. By years this loss ran as follows: 1943, $21,650,000; 1944, $3,346,000; 1945, $14,691,000; 1946, $90,963,000; 1947, $39,529,000.

The decision of the Metropolitan Opera Association to cancel its plans for the 1948-49 season will be regretted by millions of Americans. The opera has been at the heart of New York's cultural scene since its opening in 1883, and it has been closed on only two previous occasions, the last one fifty years ago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, back from a visit to Europe, said today that "if I have been an intense nationalist in the past, I am twice as much so now."
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 4 (AP) -Striking workers of the Univis Lens plant agreed late today to Gov. Thomas J. Herbert's terms for approaching a settlement of the ninety-two-day-old dispute.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Missouri's November election campaign for Governor pits Forrest Smith, State Auditor, against Murray E. Thompson, Speaker of the State House of Representatives.

LONDON. Aug. 4 -- The wealth of American track and field talent carries the Stars and Stripes to the top of all three flagpoles again today as the United States swept the Olympic high hurdles in record time before 75,000 spectators in Wembley Stadium.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Aug. 4 -- Belief that the development of the wool-processing industry in the West would first jump over the wool-producing Rocky Mountain States into California was expressed today by Sylvan J. Paley, president of the National Wool Growers Association.

In the most graceful transfer of power perhaps recorded in history, the Labor Government of the United Kingdom gained more prestige in India and earned more good-will than is conceded by those in the United Kingdom who have been opposed to Indian independence and have sought blindly and foolishly for a renewal of the "majesty of Britain as under Lord Beaconsfield and Lord Salisbury."

CAMP SMITH, N.Y., Aug. 4 -Raw recruits of the Forty-second Division, New York National Guard, proved today the efficacy of improved training methods when they surprised officers in their performance of tactical problems during field maneuvers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Republicans began to act on their limited anti-inflation program in Congress today, and President Truman rushed two Cabinet officers and one of his economic advisers to the Capitol to begin what was apparently "a last-ditch stand" on his own proposals to curb inflation.

New efforts to introduce a certain number of drug and toiletry articles into supermarkets are being watched with interest in the drug trade, but it is generally felt that they will have little effect on traditional retail outlets, it was learned yesterday.
Under the will of Mrs. Josephine A. Schwed, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, New York University will receive the entire residuary estate, estimate at $1,000,000.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Shipments of 22,309 automotive and industrial engines by Continental Motors Corporation in July made that the second biggest month since V-J Day for these types, exceeded only by the 22,532 total for the preceding month, C. J. Reese, president, announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4 -- Considerable political changes in Montenegro have been reported that appear related to decisions of the recent congress of the Communist party of Yugoslavia and its conflict with the Communist Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Nathan Gregory Silvermaster, accused by a confessed former Communist agent of heading a Soviet spy ring operating in Washington during the war, held key government positions for four years after the Office of Naval Intelligence had protested his employment, it was disclosed today.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council unanimously approved today the work of the Economic Commission for Europe and gave that organization two new jobs to do.
Religious training should be restricted to churches and homes and "not channeled" through public schools, it was argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock in Brooklyn.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4 -The amateur golfers were in the spotlight as the first day of New Jersey competition ended in The World-Telegram hole-in-one contest on the special 130-yard hole of the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

For the second time in less than a month, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company has rejected bids for an offering of 200,000 shares of preferred stock. Yesterday, the bid of 100.90 for a $4.50 dividend submitted by Union Securities Corporation, and White, Weld Co. and associates, was lower than that which the same group had prepared for submission when the offering was originally put up for sale on July 7.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Gov. Frank Carlson won the Republican renomination by about 144,000 votes over two opponents, polling 164,813 votes in returns from 2,630 of the state's 2,772 precincts in yesterday's primary election.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 4 A threat to academic standards in American universities was seen today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, in the fact that faculty salaries are being outpaced by rising living costs.

DAYTON, Aug. 4 -- Lost wages and sales due to the strike of the United Electrical Workers, CIO, against the local plant of the Univis Lens Company, now in its ninety-second day, come to more than $2,000,000, a survey indicated today.

TOKYO, Aug. 4 The departure of Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger for the United States this morning after he had laid down the command of the United States Eighth Army, which he had headed continuously since 1944, has brought out a peculiar paradox in the Allied occupation of Japan.
Winner of his last five fights, Tippy Larkin, veteran welterweight from Garfield, N.J., squares off with Willie Beltram of the Bronx in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The Standing Committee on the Berlin crisis got busy here again today putting the pieces together for the next move in Moscow. This means that the United States, British and French Governments have studied reports from their envoys in Moscow after a visit to Premier Stalin and have given preliminary reactions and suggestions on what to do now.

0*0*0*Washington, which this week became the world's only major !capital without a legitimate theatre, is now the scene of negotiations to bring the living drama into its Strand Theatre, currently showing movies. The National closed Saturday as the result of a deadlock in the controversy over Negro exclusion.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Another point harvest by United States athletes at the 1948 Olympic Games today and a reshuffle by officials of the placements in the high jump and 10,000-meter run gave the Americans a lead of almost 200 points over their nearest rival after five days of competition.

Commenting on the civil antitrust suit filed by the Department of Justice in Federal Court on Tuesday against Decca Records, Inc., charging an international conspiracy to control the world market for records, Milton Rackmil, executive vice president of the company, declared yesterday that its income from its relationship with foreign companies was negligible.

MILAN, Italy, Aug. 4 -- Three specific problems of foreign affairs are directly connected with the split between Yugoslavia and the Communist Information Bureau. These are the status of the Free Territory of Trieste, the Austrian peace treaty and the Greek civil war.

Milton Berle, who scored a personal television success as the guest master of ceremonies on the Texaco Star Theatre, has been signed to preside over the show regularly, beginning in September, it was learned yesterday. The Star Theatre is offered on the NBC video network at 8 P.M. Tuesdays.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Barrel-chested Bill Smith, Hawaii's swimming wonder, pounded the green waters in Wembley pool tonight to win the men's 400-meter free-style crown. In addition he set a new Olympic mark of 4:41.

Trussing himself with a 14-foot length of rubber air hose in a trick way he had learned to tie up Japanese prisoners to prevent them from escaping, an ex-marine committed suicide early yesterday, according to the Brooklyn Medical Examiner's office, three days before he was to have been married.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 -- Although the Economic Cooperation Administration has told Argentina that a percentage of any dollars spent here under the Marshall Plan will have to be returned to the United States to pay outstanding debts, it was confirmed today that the United States Army was increasing direct meat purchases with dollars to which no strings are attached.

ST. LOUIS. Aug. 4 (AP) -- Hard singles by Gerry Priddy and Whitey Platt with two men out in the ninth inning gave the Browns a 9-to-8 decision over the Red Sox tonight. The game started as a slugging match, then settled into a battle between relief hurlers Ellis Kinder of the Sox and Ned Garver.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- An assertion that "propagandists" have "prostituted" the Reclamation Bureau "for their own selfish bureaucratic ends," was made in the House today by Representative Forest A. Harness, Republican, of Indiana.

President Truman's legislative program involves "blowing up the economy with more inflation steam with one hand and trying to hold the lid on with more controls and more taxes with the other," the National City Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Letter, for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A shortage of funds will limit to about 40,000 the number of refugees to enter the United States in the next eleven months. Ugo Carusi, Displaced Persons Commissioner, said today.
LIVERPOOL, Eng., Aug. 4 (AP) -With police patrolling in impressive strength, an uneasy quiet prevailed today at the south end of this port city, where race riots occurred during the last three days.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4 There wasn't enough breeze today, so the New York Yacht Club's scheduled squadron run of its racing craft from Block Island to here was called off, but only after every conceivable mariner's trick in the way of stirring up the sleeping wind had been resorted to.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -The Securities Commission today gave conditional approval to a reorganization plan for the United Corporation, New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A voluntary plan under which steel producers will earmark 16,530 tons of steel a month for the oil field tank and production equipment industry went to Secretary of Commerce Sawyer today.

At the request of Oppenheim Collins Co., Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein ordered pickets yesterday to desist from shouting epithets or blocking entrances to the company's two department stores.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 4 -Considerable confusion prevailed at the Long Island Rail Road station here during the rush hour this evening when homeward-bound commuters found a strike in progress on the bus line that runs from the station to various parts of the city.

At 3:31 P.M. yesterday Lieut. Harold Connors, seated on the wooden box that alone remained of the furnishings in the Third Precinct house, telephoned Police Headquarters to announce that he was about to leave the Oak Street station.

QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 4 The Greater Colombian Economic Conference will continue as long as is necessary to complete its plans for an economic and customs union of Colombia, Ecuador, Venezuela and Panama. The delegates expect to take ten days more because many items have not yet been discussed.

From an economic standpoint the introduction of the day and night routine at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a thumping success. There were 46,890 paid admissions to the matinee-night double-header with the Cardinals, 15,361 of them at the sunshine game and 31,529 at the nocturnal skirmish, as the Giants' home attendance for the season soared to 1,007,766.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., had a net income in the six months ended on June 30, last, of $1,027,707 after all charges, including provision of $680,000 for Federal income taxes, according to the report issued jointly yesterday by L. R. Grumman, chairman and L. A. Swirbul, president.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman reported briefly to the Cabinet today on the Western envoys' talk with Soviet Premier Stalin Monday. This caused restrained and qualified optimism here.

With the Olympic track and field events -- the main dish of tile International games at London -- just past the halfway mark, United States athletes have w^n eight of the sixteen individual championships so far decided. By American scoring methods our athletes have three times as many points as the nearest competing country, Sweden.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 4 (AP) -King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan asked today for full and careful consideration of any future proposal for permanent peace in Palestine.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- An 'agreement providing for the absorption by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, of the National Association of Die Casting Workers was approved today by the international executive board of the UAW. If ratified by the rank and file about 20,000 right-wing workers formerly affiliated with the leftwing Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers will be added to the UAW.

Spokesmen for the King Kullen Grocery Company, Inc., Gristede Bros. and Safeway Stores, Inc., reported that they would produce their records on milk transactions at the office of Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh, 50 Pine Street, on Monday morning.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Gus Hall, 37-year-old Ohio chairman of the Communist party, surrendered to Federal authorities here today to face charges by a Federal grand jury in New York that he and eleven others sought to overthrow the United States Government.

William F. Van Deventer, of Laidlaw Co., bankers, has purchased the residence of Mrs. Frank Horton in Bedminster Township, N.J. The property comprises forty-eight acres of land and includes a sixteen-room dwelling, stables, garage, chicken houses and barn, a cottage and two apartments.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Phillip Cudone of The Knoll fired a two-over-par 79 through a steady rain today to annex the women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Jersey Shore championship with a fifty-four-hole aggregate of 237 at the Hollywood Club course.

TORQUAY, England, Aug. 4 (AP) -- American yachtsmen won two Olympic races today and finished high in the other three classifications. The races in Torquay Bay were the second in the series of seven to determine championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -The Association of American Railroads today estimated net income of class 1 railroads in June at $94,000,000 compared ith $44,000,000 in June, 1947.

The nature of our civilization is explosive. We are not necessarily thinking of the atom bomb. The first target for today is our rush hour subway. One mounts the "A" train at the northern tip of Manhattan Island.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The new stock exchange account which opened today brought no appreciable increase in trading on stock markets here and there was little price movement generally.

The election of former Gov. Harold Hoffman of New Jersey ash)0*0*0*ipresident of the Dexter Fellows Tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners was challenged yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Cortland A. Johnson in Queens by Otto Esselborn of 32-34 Seventy-seventh Street, Jackson Heights.

Plans for a six-story office building on the large frontage at 216-24 West Forty-eighth Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for the Normandy Development Corporation of 39 Broadway. H. I. Feldman, architect, of 415 Lexington Avenue, estimated the cost at $1,000,000.

A motion by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and a number of its officers to dismiss a stockholders' suit brought by Michael Stella on the ground that the Federal Court lacked jurisdiction and the complaint did not make out a claim on which relief could be granted was denied yesterday by Judge Vincent L. Leibell.

The St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday that payment of a dividend of $2 on the old class A preferred shares of the St. Lawrence Corporation as provided for by the recently approved reorganization plan, will be made on Aug. 25.

Lauchlin Currie, former assistant to President Roosevelt, said last night that he had been consulted in 1942 about the loyalty of Nathan Gregory Silvermaster, but had turned the whole matter over to the Army without further decision, the United Press reported.

An abrupt reversal of form was staged yesterday by the stock market, with gains of as much as 2 points in some key issues, while the price average rose 1.40 points. Signs of a technical movement were plentiful, especially in view of the gap left in the averages chart last week, but the upturn coincided with news from Washington of a possible early adjuornment of Congress.

Shoppers in the Herald Square area had a lively quarter of an hour yesterday forenoon when a man escaping after a $2,500 hold-up dashed for a block down the Avenue of the Americas and disappeared into the subway entrance at the northeast corner of Thirty-fourth Street.

Science and nature, it seems, do not always walk hand-in-hand, for despite the fact that the report of the scientific survey or the dumping of sulphuric acid waste in the Mud Hole indicates that this pollution does not adversely affect marine life, the tuna and other species previously abundant there are not being taken from that water today.

The two-story addition to the Eastern Brass Copper Company's building at 1122 East 180th Street, the Bronx, has been completed, according to Herbert Barchoff, vice president. Providing an added 50,000 square feet, the addition will be used for bright annealing equipment in conjunction with metal processing, and for expanded facilities to take care of metal shortages in many industries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate Republicans surrendered formally to the entrenched Southerners today and put aside the anti-poll-tax bill for the remainder of the Congress session now expected to end next Tuesday or Wednesday.
The Communist party's national convention here adopted a formal resolution yesterday as an answer to the testimony regarding a Communist spy-ring being heard in Washington.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Llangollen Farm's roan colt Singing Step, bred in Old Virginia, went smartly about the business of beating a quartet of stakeswinners in the main event at Old Saratoga today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Erigeron, who was purchased recently by H. B. Massey of Pittsburgh from Walter P. Chrysler Jr., registered his first stakes victory today in the six-furlong Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that nineteen local housing authorities of the nation had awarded $19,064,000 of short-term loan notes, to banking groups and investment houses on the basis of competitive bids.

Samuel J. Litt and Leo Redfield have purchased Johnnie's service station at 558-562 South Broadway, Yonkers, N.Y., from John Carrea for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $23,000. George Miller was the broker. InterCounty Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured the title.
H. B. MacMillan has been appointed auditor of Thomas A. Edison, Inc. He joined the company in 1914.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Paul Reynaud, Minister of Finance and National Economy, today presented before the inner Cabinet what he called "France's balance sheet," and tomorrow he will submit to a full Cabinet council his proposal for restoration of a sound economy.

Prospective legislation restricting consumer credit may result in discrimination against lower income consumers and in indirect rationing, the National Retail Furniture Association warned yesterday in a telegram to Jesse Wolcott, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee.

The Republican leaders in Congress have now decided w-hat their policy is to be at this session on anti-inflation legislation. They will ignore the more spectacular proposals contained in the President's eight-point program -- proposals such as that for setting up a "little OPA" and reinvoking the wartime excess profits tax -- and will confine themselves to the field of credit control.

The Israeli Government wants a stable peace and economic cooperation in Palestine but if it is forced to renew the fighting "it is confident of military success," Aubrey Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, declared last night. Mr. Eban addressed a meeting of the American Red Mogen Dovid for Palestine at the Astor Hotel.

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 4 -- Secretary of Defense James D. Forrestal opened the new Armed Forces Information School at Carlisle Barracks here today with the declaration that it has become as imperative for military commanders to think in terms of the public as of the troops under them.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 4 Counth)0*0*0*iBernadotte confirmed here today that he had urged the Security Council to affirm the "right" of Palestine Arab refugees to "return to their homes at the earliest practical date."

In the knotty tangle of disagreement between privately owned bus lines and the city over terms of a fare rise, one point at least seems clear beyond dispute. That is, that the promise of a pay rise of 24 cents an hour, retroactive to May 1, for employees of these lines must be kept.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Surrender Field, where Lord Cornwallis capitulated to Gen. George Washington in 1781, is now preserved for posterity, the National Park Service said today.

Ten thousand Gospels of St. John, a gift from American youngsters to Sunday school children of Holland, will be presented tomorrow to American delegates to the First Assembly of the World Council of Churches at Amsterdam before they sail aboard the Queen Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Navy Secretary John L. Sullivan, called before Senate investigators after three admirals refused to discuss circumstances under which William W. Remington resigned his commission, declared today only President Truman could authorize such disclosure.

Joseph Deutsch has purchased the vacant land, about 230 by 390 feet, on the block between Beach Thirty-fifth and Beach Thirtysixth Streets, and Sprayview Avenue to the Boardwalk, in Edgemere, Queens, from the Glenes Realty Service, Inc.
San Mateo (Calif.) Union High School District will offer on Aug. 17, $3,225,000 of bonds, dated June 15, 1948, and due June 15, 1949 to 1968, with an interest rate not in excess of 5 per cent
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -President Truman today sent to Congress a report showing this country furnished $18,200,000,000 in post-war foreign aid up to Jan. 1, 1948.

Trading in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was in fair volume yesterday. With orders evenly divided, prices failed to move far in either direction. The close was steady, 1 to 8 points lower on the day.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 4 The Junior Chamber of Commerceh)0*0*0*iof Montgomery will invite Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York to make a public address in this city, first capital of the Confederacy, Wilbur B. Nolen Jr., president of the Chamber, said today.

Two New York locals of the Industrial Union of Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, have split on acceptance of a new wage offer by the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard division, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, Italy, Aug. 4 -- Italy is in "permanent danger" of a Communist insurrection, Minister of Interior Mario Scelba told the Senate today. He declared that it wash)0*0*0*itherefore indispensable that the police and the carabinieri be kept at maximum efficiency and remain constantly in readiness to foil any attempt to seize the Government by force.

One of its more amusing songs, "Strictly on the Corny Side," just about epitomizes "A Date With Judy," which opened yesterday at the Music Hall. Hollywood has developed an extensive and rigid set of conventions for its unceasing stream of comedies of adolescence, and "Judy" adheres carefully to all of them.

A "significant" increase in bootlegging activities during the fiscal year 1948 is evident in the report just released by the Treasury Department's Alcohol Tax Unit, according to a statement issued yesterday by Vice Admiral F. E. M. Whiting, USN (Ret.), president of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The man who couldn't be beaten, the "surest thing" in track and field in the Games of the XIV Olympiad, met his master today in one of the greatest 400-meter races ever run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman today expressed the hope that the atom bomb eventually would be outlawed as an weapon. He made this comment in response to a question by a reporter, attending a White House press conference, who remarked that three years ago Mr. Truman gave the order to drop the first atomic bomb on Japan.

The cotton futures market marked time yesterday and price changes on the New York Cotton Exchange were due more to technical market conditions rather than any fundamental change in the situation. During the day quotations moved in a somewhat irregular manner and the close was 7 points net lower for October and 1 to 6 points higher for the later months.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The flashing blades of the United States rowing teams carried five crews to heat victories in the first round of the Olympic regatta today on the placid Thames River.

Those were not crocodile tears that the Japanese, and the men of the Eighth Army, shed when Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger boarded a transport at Yokohama and set out for home and retirement after almost three years as head of the Armed Occupation Forces in the Japanese home islands.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 -- The National Liberal Convention opened today to elect a new leader. Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King was cheered when he entered. After the National Anthem he intoned the Lord's Prayer.

The fight to enact a federal law to bar the payment of a poll tax as a qualification for voting in national elections has been lost in the special session because of the Southern filibuster. The war must go on. The poll tax is a vermiform appendix on the body politic, the last holdover of the old days of property qualification, a form of political snobbery that has no place in a democracy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 31 totaled 894,381 cars, the Association of Americanh) 0*0*0*iRailroads announced today. This was 11,815 cars, or 1.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 27,210 cars, or 3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 4,010 cars, or 0.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.
Mass migration of Jews from Europe is continuing, Maj. Reuven Dafni, recently named representative in this country of the Defense Ministry of Israel, said yesterday in an interview.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa, sinking a 10-footer on the final green of today's third round, overhauled pacesetting Herman Barron of White Plains, N.Y., to share the 54-hole leadership in the $50,000 AllAmerican golf tourney at 208 strokes.

The six-story apartment house at 612 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, accommodating eighty-two families, has been sold by the Paymil Realty Corporation to the Emerick Realty Company for cash above a mortgage of $175,000. W. F. Brunner, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Nat Greenbaum for the buyer and Hyman Bettigole for the seller.

Moishe Litwak, 31-year-old defendant in a bad check case, was held yesterday in $50,000 bail in Felony Court after Assistant District Attorney Charles J. McDonough asserted he had swindled twenty-five persons out of $48,000 on false promises of bringing displaced persons to this country.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 5 -- Laszlo Rajk, Hungarian Interior Minister, became Foreign Minister today. He is known as possibly the most uncompromising Hungarian Communist in high office and has been purging Western-oriented groups suspected of disloyalty to the present regime.

Olympic Games, Brooklyn-style, were staged yesterday to open the new rooftop playground for 1,600 youngsters at Williamsburg Settlement, 17 Montrose Avenue, Brooklyn. Even the Olympiad torch-bearing runner was there, with a slight variation.

Earl Browder, who was the symbol of American communism until he was deposed as party leader in 1945 and expelled as a member in 1946, applied on July 6 for readmission to the party on the ground that world dangers confronting the Communist movement called for party unity.

P. Lorillard Co. will break a large-scale advertising campaign in the Metropolitan area on Monday for Embassy, its new king-size cigarette. The drive will start withh) 0*0*0*i1,500-line space in eight New York newspapers, followed by additional large-space insertions weekly in these dailies.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- Alfred Cline, who killed eight of his wives and elderly benefactors, died in Folsom Prison this afternoon from a heart attack. He was 58 years of age.

A strike of the 3,900 employees of the Third Avenue Transit system's bus and street car lines in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester at 4 A.M. tomorrow was authorized yesterday by the negotiating committee of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.
MONTREAL, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Ancient Order of Hibernians tonight selected Boston for its next convention in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The oil industry apparently is on the way toward filling all military orders -- for the Berlin airlift as well as all other activities -- the Armed Services Petroleum Purchasing Agency said today.

With a $100,000,000 reduction in its bills scheduled on Aug. 12, the United States Treasury yesterday issued a 15 per cent call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks, in order to meet that and other Government expenses. The call, based on balances of Aug. 4, is payable in two installments, half on Aug. 10, and half on Aug. 12.

A step toward eliminating engine failures of airplanes in flight by the development of an intricate warning system through which crews "see" the inner workings of their power plants was announced yesterday.

Moving to complete one of its largest post-war purchases of wool cloth, the Quartermaster Purchasing Office in New York yesterday awarded contracts for 5,000,000 yards of 18-ounce serge to eighteen wool manufacturers. Those who were awarded contracts in the $26,000,000 purchase had bid from $5.19 to $5.37 per yard on the 56linch wide cloth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that changes in the tax laws passed earlier this year by Congress affecting disability retirement pay of officers did not provide for taxes on disability compensation paid to veterans.

Reductions in borrowings on United States Government obligations largely accounted for a decline of $168,000,000 in net and gross loans of the reporting New York City banks of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 5 -- Louis Budenz, former member of the national committee of the Communist party of the United States, testified today before Hawaii school commissioners that the Communist party was told in 1939 to be ready to start a civil war.

Washington Square Park will be made a safer and more tranquil place for mothers to take their infants to, the Police Department promised yesterday. The "guarantee of protection" was proffered after a delegation of seven mothers with five of their children visited the Mercer Street Station, protesting "neglected and disgusting conditions" in the park.

Tippy Larkin, veteran Garfield(N.J.) welterweight, met with no difficulty in disposing of Willie Beltram of the Bronx in the headline bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Larkin weighed 143 1/4 pounds to Beltram's 137.

The outlook for increased supplies of copper at current price levels has improved, partly because of a lessening of demand for copper for export, one of the larger sellers revealed here yesterday. The improvement should be noticeable in September, provided no interruption occurs at the mines, it was said.
A 29-year-old war veteran, who tried to effect a reconciliation with his former wife with the unproffered help of the mailman, found himself in jail yesterday on a charge of obtaining mail by fraud.

Fifty women and children barricaded East 153d Street at River Avenue, the Bronx, for forty-five minutes yesterday afternoon to protest the lack of a traffic light at that busy intersection and the use of 153d Street by motorists seeking drivers' licenses.

Merchant steel exporters are taking action to increase their allocations of steel licensed for export, because their second quarter shipments were 30 per cent below tonnages which should have been shipped according to their historic pattern.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases provided free services during 1947 at a cost to it of $598,000, or more than a third of its $1,674,854 budget for that year, Frederick Brown, its president, said yesterday in the institution's annual report.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The British Government considers that the present situation in Pakistan and India does not warrant the withdrawal of British officers serving in the armies of the two dominions, it was learned authoritatively today.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 5 -United States Attorney Isaiah Matlack today announced that the Federal Grand Jury would be convened here Aug. 23 to hear evidence in the investigation of former United States Attorney Edgar H. Rossbach.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The largest mass tuberculosis immunization program ever undertaken -- sponsored by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, the World Health Organization, the Danish Red Cross and its Scandinavian associates -- calls for the testing of between 40,000,000 and 50,000,000 children in Europe this fall, it was announced today.

ATHENS, Aug. 5 -- The capture of Steno, according to official information, was followed by a rapid advance to the northeast that resulted in the capture of Vourbiani. This is not more than about six miles as the crow flies from the reputed seat of the headquarters of General Markos at Aetomilitsa, in the heart of the Grammos massif.

The Sword Line, Inc., steamship operators, is complying with a Maritime Commission order to return to the Government agency all Federally owned vessels now employed under charter, it was reported last night.
Meat sales throughout the nation dwindled further yesterday as housewives extended their boycott against high prices, but in this city retail pork prices went even higher.

Discontinuance by the Office of International Trade of "price criteria" and the use of the "historical basis" in granting export licenses was urged last night by speakers at a meeting of the Independent Merchant Exporters Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- During the week ended Aug. 4, according to the Federal Reserve Board, member bank reserve balances increased $72,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves resulted from increases of $174,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $9,000,000 in gold stock and a decrease of $22,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $101,000,000 in money in circulation and $30,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks.
Efforts to bring about a reversal of the Metropolitan Opera Association's decision to cancel its 19481949 season were begun in several quarters yesterday.

Nathan Gregory Silvermaster, long a trusted official in Washington, appearing before the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities on Wednesday refused to tell the committee whether he was or was not a Communist on the ground that his answer might be "selfincriminating."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 5 -Willard H. Dow, president of the Dow Chemical Company, Midland,h)0*0*0*iMich., has been elected to receive the Medal for the Advancement of Research for 1948, it was announced here today by W. H. Eisenman, national secretary of the American Society for Metals, a national technical society.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council angrily tossed out of the record today a Russian charge that the Council was a willing instrument of United States foreign policy.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 5 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today that the Korean Government would seek the creation of a joint United States-Korean committee to arrange indefinite continuation of the United States military forces in Korea.

W. Foster Banks, president of the Motor Carrier Association of New York, has made public a detailed memorandum sent to all members of the organization, giving its position on the port rehabilitation plans now before the city.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 5 -- In a remarkable large-yacht race of thirty-six miles from Newport today, Rear Commodore Seth M. Milliken's yawl Thistle defeated John N. Matthews' Manxman by 5 seconds. It was a rigging-taut contest against a drying nor'easter that averaged twenty knots accompanied by a sea-lump.

Looked upon as an American classic, "Show Boat" will be on view at the City Center Sept. 7-19 inclusive. This isn't to be construed as a makeshift offering. On the contrary, it's none other than the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d revival (done with their meticulous taste) of the famous musical by Jerome Kern (score) and Mr. Hammerstein (book and lyrics), emanating from the Edna Ferber novel.

Production of wool in this country is at the lowest point in many years, having declined almost 50 per cent in the last few years, Moses Pendleton, president of the American Woolen Company, Inc., declared in the semi-annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The Philadelphia Council of the American Jewish Congress reported today that a survey of "ninety-one resorts selected at random in Eastern Pennsylvania" had revealedh) 0*0*0*ithat 72.5 per cent "use discriminatory language in selecting prospective guests."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 5 -- A plan for the virtual economic merger of the French zone with the bizonal area became known today through the announcement of an agreement establishing common export-import policies and agencies for the French, United States and British zones.

Almost daily during the summer months thousands of lucky youngsters take off to the country outdoors for a deserved vacation. Many of them, coming from deprived homes, are sent to camps as guests of various private social agencies. Yet, as they depart byh)0*0*0*itrain and bus, they leave behind many more thousands of youngsters who are doomed by tragic circumstances to remain in their tenement dwellings the entire summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--Clyde B. Aitchison, an Interstate Commerce commissioner, today issued a notice that a further hearing would be held in San Francisco on Oct. 25 on contested rail rates on steel from Geneva, Utah, to Pacific Coast points.

The State Federation of Labor yesterday adopted a resolution commending Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, for his part in barring The Nation from the public school reading lists, because of the magazine's "recent vicious attacks on the Catholic religion."

Two Long Island properties, the former estate of J. Herbert Johnston at Huntington and a tract of twenty-three and one-half acres in East Northport, have been purchased for development.

Plans for large-scale bauxite mining operations in French West Africa, involving initial capital expenditures of about $6,500,000, were announced yesterday by Aluminium, Ltd., in its mid-year statement of earnings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federation of American Scientists accused the Government today of debating the vital public issue of military versus civilian custody of atomic bombs "under a cloak of secrecy.
h)0*0*0*iTHE NEW YORK TIMES recently reported on the high cost of the potato crop to the United States Government.
Dr. Addison Boyce sold the fourstory apartment building at 950Ogden Avenue, northeast corner of 162d Street, in the Bronx, to Diana Singer. Wm. A. White Sons were the brokers in the transaction.

New York State's quota of $300,000,000 in the recent United States Security Loan drive was oversubscribed, with a total of $438,950,000, it was announced yesterday by Philip M. Light, state director for the United States Savings Bond division of the Treasury Department.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Two hundred and eight pairs of contract bridge masters, the largest group ever to enter a major tournament, began play here this afternoon for the American Contract Bridge League's Masters' Pair Championship and the $5,000 gold cup donated by Waldemar von Zedtwitz, president of the league.

Youth was not wasted on Frederickh)0*0*0*iJ. Ludwig, a local boy who made good. He became a caddy at 11 to support his widowed mother. At 22 he quit his job as high school teacher to earn more money as a policeman. Next fall at 30 he will be one of the youngest full professors of law in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -Two officers of the United Electrical Workers, (CIO), asked if they were Communists, told a House Labor subcommittee today that the inquiries were "smear questions" and invoked constitutional rights in declining to give a yes-or-no answer.

Experiments showing thatform of vitamin K, the anti-hemorrhagevitamin, inhibits thegrowth of fungi producingdiseasesin men, animals and plants are announcedtoday inthe Proceedingof the National Academy ofSciences.

Tuesz day, Aug. 17, in behalf of theAmerican Overseas Aid-United Nations-Appeal for Children. RUMER GODDEN'S seventh book, "A Candle for St. Jude,"* is out today, which should be welcome news to all lovers of good writing and all admirers of one of the most distinguished living English novelists. Of Miss Godden's seven books, only one, "Gypsy, Gypsy," is unsuccessful. One, "Thus Far and No Further," is a slight ,but enchanting collection of sketches and memories about life on a tea plantation high in the Himalayas above Darjeeling.
