WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The National Guard made room for more enlisted men today by lifting the ceiling on enrollment of commissioned and warrant officers and some veterans of World War II.

Bids on $26,191,000 of temporary loan notes, proceeds of which will be used to continue the temporary financing of two state-aided, lowrent housing projects in Manhattan were opened yesterday at the offices of the New York City Housing Authority.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc.,national chain of women's apparelstores, achieved record high unitand dollar sales as well as earnings in the six months ended withlast J.une, Hyman P. Kuchai, president, reported yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5 -- A rainy night did not prevent an audience of 6,300 from attending the fourth concert of the Berkshire Symphony Festival this evening in Tanglewood. The program provided a sufficient incentive for such attendance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- With an eye on the possibility of adjournment of the special session of Congress by Saturday, the House of Representatives passed today the limited Republican anti-inflation program by a vote of 264 to 97. It ignored a last-minute plea by President Truman for action on his proposals to curb inflation.
Negotations between port longshoremen and the New York Shipping Association have reached an impasse and both parties called yesterday for Federal intervention.

The Communist party criticized President Truman for being as responsible as the Republicans for the present anti-Communist drive in this country, but said, as did the President, that the "spy scare" in Washington was a "red herring."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 31 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

The Roberts Estate, Inc., has sold the five-story loft building with two stores at 170-4 Chambers Street to a client of Frederick L: Weisler through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The sellers were represented by Root, Ballantine, Harlan, Bushby Palmer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The plan of Republican Congressional leaders to avoid the sharpest issues on housing in the rush for adjournment was put in peril today by a revolt in the Senate Banking Committee. The possibility was thus raised that the present session might end with no action on housing and that the Republican party might be left vulnerable to Administration attacks.

LONG BEACH, L.I. -- A report by Dr. Earle G. Brown, health commissioner of Nassau County, that all ocean beaches in the city of Long Beach are safe for swimming was issued today by City Manager Morris S. Karp in an effort to dispel misinformation concerning the conditions of waters surrounding the resort city.

In a move of great constructive possibilities, Foreign Minister Shertok has requested Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations mediator, to try to arrange a peace conference for direct negotiations between Israel and the Arab states. This move, the first official proposal of its kind, is in line with the statesmanlike policy pursued by the Israeli Government since its formation and can be only welcomed, for two reasons.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Indians kept their slim hold on first place in the American League today with a 3-0 victory over Washington, but Lou Boudreau, Cleveland manager and shortstop, was injured.

The United States Coast Guard cutter Campbell has located wreckage of the missing Air France Latecoere-631 flying boat and is now searching the area in the hope that survivors of the plane may be afloat on a raft.

Negotiations by the United States with other governments to establishh universal agreement in behalf of world government was advocated yesterday by Cord Meyer Jr., president of United World Federalists Inc., as the best means of preventing "a world empire resulting from atomic war and tryrany."

The National Dairy Products Corporation attained a record in sales and net profit for the first half of 1948, according to the semi annual report of L. A. Van Bomel, president, to be mailed to stockholders today.

A dividend of 30 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1, has been declared by the Barlow Seelig Manufacturing Company. In June the organization paid 15 cents plus an extra of 15 cents. In March 15 cents was disbursed.
Forty air-minded young men from Canada arrived here yesterday to compete in a special contest tomorrow with a like number of American youths.

About half of the 195 companies that have returned questionnairesh)0*0*0*iin a survey regarding staggered working hours to reduce subway rush-hour crowds are cooperating in such a plan or have offered to do so, it was made known yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Unitedh)0*0*0*iStates, British and French envoys conferred today on their next steps in the vital East-West controversy.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- In a sumptuous collection Christian Dior inaugurates his "winged silhouette." Stiffly flared skirts spread out at one side in wings that are like flattened cornucopias.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 5 -- In its first direct official approach, Israel today invited the Arab nations to discuss peace at a round-table meeting. The request was transmitted through Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, by Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok after a general discussion here on the problems besetting both sides.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- Negotiations were still proceeding today between Count Bernadotte's representative, Belgian Consul General Jean Niewenhuys as chairman of the three-man Consular Truce Commission appointed by the United Nations Security Council, and Trans-Jordan Government authorities at Amman on the resumption of piped water supply to Jerusalem.

PARIS, Aug. 5--It was officially confirmed today that new instructions to the French Ambassador in Moscow had been sent as result of Foreign Minister Robert Schuman's report to the Cabinet yesterday on the Moscow talks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Appointment of Mrs. Charles W. Weis Jr. as associate campaign manager for the Dewey-Warren ticket was announced today by Herbert Brownell Jr., campaign manager.

NANKING, Aug. 5 -- The joint Sino-American Rural Reconstruction Commission was established here today to coordinate the drive for increasing agricultural production, improving the lot of the neglected Chinese peasant and instituting land reform measures.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 -- Ambassador Cavendish Cannon, chief United States delegate at the Danubian Conference, submitted today the United States Government's draft convention for control of the Danube. This plan would implement and guarantee the international character of the Danube, as opposed to the Soviet plan, which, in the American view, would legalize a Soviet monopoly by transforming the river into a series of autonomous lakes.

The twenty-four-family building with two stores at 53-55 East 112th Street, near Madison Avenue, was bought by the Bildav Realty Corporation, an investing group represented by Emanuel Gildberg, lawyer, from Solomon Pollack, who had just purchased it from the Signode Realty Corporation.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- United States officials on the staff of the Economic Cooperation Administration in Europe are studying with interest new evidence of progress in European self-help in the transport field.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Only three seeded players survived the fall of favorites today in the fifty-eighth Meadow Club Grass Court Tennis Tournament.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 5 (O.N.A.) -- Food sufficient for only two weeks remains on Puerto Rico in consequence of the stevedores strike which began here July 21.
Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves,wartime director of atomic developmenth)0*0*0*for the United States, saidlast night if uranium was shippedto Russia in 1943, he had no knowledge of it.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached a new high level in 1948, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. The upswing was due partly to higher industrial production and partly to heavier freight shipments; the volume of trade held about unchanged.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Red Sox downed the Browns, 8 -- 7, today with Vern Stephens, who made errors on two consecutive plays earlier in the game, singling home Johnny Pesky with the winning run in the eighth. Al Zarilla drove in Bryan Stephens in the sixth, tying the score.

For the first time in twentytwo years a Dodger player hit three home runs in one game as the Dodgers beat the Cubs, 6 -- 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday and moved into second place, one percentage point ahead of the Cardinals.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- A much-relieved United Nations received the news of the passage of the $65,000,000 world capital loan in Congress with the announcement that bids for the Secretariat building would be asked for on or about Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--President Truman denounced today the Congressional investigations into alleged Soviet spy rings and Communist infiltration into the American Government. He said that they were a "red herring" designed to detract public attention from the snubbing by the Republican-controlled extra session of his program to curb inflation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- After seven months of work without the participation of Russia and her satellites, the experimental Interim Committee of the United Nations today unanimously agreed that it should be continued. The decision to re-establish the Little Assembly will be for the General Assembly in Paris to make this fall.

Radio's growing boom in "giveaway" programs, which has seen individual listeners win more than $20,000 in merchandise for answering jackpot questions, faced sudden collapse last night. In a surprise move the Federal Communications Commission announced in Washington that it was going to study the legality of all such programs under the Federal lottery laws.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Kent Miller's Elkridge, winner of the Shillelah Steeplechase in 1944 when he was a spry 6-year-old, did it again at the age of ten at rain-soaked Saratoga today in a race that produced four spills and delayed-action finishes for three of the horses whose numbers went up on the board.

Any New Yorker who yearns to have a fat-bellied city ferryboat of his own can buy one, ready-made and waiting. All he has to do is outbid anybody else who has the same burning desire to be master of one of the three ferries open for public sale, as announced yesterday by the Department of Purchase.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Berlin uncertainties, holidays and publication of the agenda for next month's Trade Union Congress, containing resolutions attacking high prices and profits, combined today to keep down business on the Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Braves tonight rallied for two runs after two were out in the eighth inning and defeated the Reds, 6 -- 4 ending a losing streak which had extended through four games. A somewhat chilled crowd of 13,521 saw Tommy Holmes single, Al Dark poke his second double of the night and Earl Torgeson lash a triple into left center for the deciding runs.

The twelvestory apartment building at 277 Park Avenue, valued at more than $6,000,000 and for the last twenty-four years the home of 323 tenants, will be taken over by the New York Central and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads, which will become joint landlords Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- To no one's surprise tiny Sammy Lee, a Korean-American Army doctor spun, twisted and somersaulted his way into the men's high diving championship of the world at Wembley's Olympic pool today.

Industrialists of India; now engaged in a long-term industrial expansion program which has lifted their purchasing to levels twice those of pre-war days, hope that the United States Government will provide export priorities for capital goods now needed, Sir Homi Mody, a director of Tata, Ltd., Bombay, revealed during an interview at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered Standard Air Lines today to suspend its transcontinental passenger flights pending outcome of a hearing to determine whether its government certificate should be revoked.
PARIS, Friday, Aug. 6 -- Unanimous approval of the principles involved in Finance Minister Paul Reynaud's program of economic recovery was obtained at a cabinet meeting that ended after midnight.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 5 (AP) -- A Navy transport crashed and burned after a collision with a light training plane near here late today, killing ten Navy men and a woman.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Real estate and personal property valuations continued to skyrocket in New Jersey during the past year in every county.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had approved an amended plan filed by the Northern New England Company, Augusta, Me., whereby the company proposes to sell some of the preferred stock of two of its subsidiaries as the initial step in its liquidation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -"The Undesirables" today was announced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a forthcoming film, with Walter Pidgeon and Janet Leigh tentatively named for two of the major roles. The script will be derived from a story written especially for the screen by Lawrence E. Taylor, and Sam Marx will supervise its preparation.

Installation of car accessories at the plants of the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Packard Motor Car Company are based upon dealer demands, according to statements from the manufacturers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A reported 3,000 adherents of Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party picketed the White House for an hour this afternoon in an orderly demonstration protesting the abandonment by the Senate of efforts to pass the Civil Rights Bill in the face of a filibuster by Southern members.

Headed by Van Alstyne Noel Corporation and Gearhart Co., Inc., an underwriting group of ninety investment banking firms is offering to the public today 150,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, par value $20 per share, of Allen B. Dumont Laboratories, Inc.

Feeble attempts by the stock market to extend the recovery were frustrated yesterday by late realizing and prices at the close were about even with the previous day's quotations. Trading started out at a fast pace but soon slowed. Major price changes were scarcer than in earlier sessions of this week, and the composite rate slipped 0.09 point.

The air show at New York International Airport yesterday fought a dubious draw with the weather. Any attempt at the flight of large formations, like the Navy's, was abandoned as the soupy clouds and rainy haze blew in on a gusty northeast and easth) 0*0*0*iwind.
BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The first break in the Berlin deadlock appeared today when the Soviet Military Administration conceded a point to the Western powers in the currency dispute.

The Gruen Watch Company has leased the building being erected by Welsh Brothers at the southwest corner of Forty-third Avenue and Hunter Street, just south of the Queensborough Bridge, in Long Island City, Queens. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Athletics, who haven't had a home run in Chicago's Comiskey Park since 1946, today used three round trippers to win a double-header, 3 -- 0 and 7 -- 4, against the White Sox before 8,053 fans.
Consolidation of the Tri-Continental Corporation and General Shareholdings Corporation has been approved by directors of the two investment companies.

When the extended competition for ideas for a "living" memorial in Manhattan dedicated to World War II closed last Monday, some thirty new suggestions had been submitted by the public, bringing the total to 130, Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee, said yesterday.
PRAGUE, Aug. 5 -- The Ministry of Industry disclosed today that nearly all of Czechoslovak industry has been organized or was in the process of being organized into 251 state trusts.

ZION, Ill., Aug. 5 (AP) -- A merger of Zion Industries, Inc., manufacturer of cookies, candies and other products, and Illinois Industries, Inc., a new corporation, has been agreed npon by directors of the two companies.

In connection with the disposal of captured Nazi loot for the benefit of the homeless refugees of Europe, notice of the largest diamond sale in history has gone out to the trade, it became known yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The United States Army Quartermaster Market Center System today announced it had accepted bids for 3,021,000 pounds of meat and 904,725 pounds of turkey -- all from Argentina.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Bailh) 0*0*0*iwas fixed today at $50,000 each for the three Iovine Brothers, alleged Newark bookmakers accused of having as a client P. James Pellechia Jr., former Newark police judge, who admitted a $657,000 bank embezzlement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) - The Economic Cooperation Administration named today a special committee of seven efficiency experts to assist in the improvement of its program and authorization procedures.
ATHENS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Defense positions of the Communist rebels of Gen. Markos Vafiades collapsed one after another today under the impetus of a heavy forty-eighthour Government attack.

Most women who work at night do so because they need the money and because they must care for their homes and children during the day, a survey by the New York State Department of Labor shows. The study, released yesterday, covered 347 women who work until 11 P.M. or midnight in twenty manufacturing plants in the state.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Floodlights were put into use as the last of the 111 teams competing in the twelfth annual John G. Anderson memorial tourney over the Winged Foot Golf Club's west course finished in darkness tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Sharp advances for most iron and steel products were nearly offset by lower prices for farm products and foods and resulted in an increase of 0.1 per cent in primary market prices during the week ended July 31, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Assistant Secretary of Commerce was advised that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating William W. Remington for espionage three months before he was detached from his confidential post, a Senate committee witness testified today.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 5 -- The Miami City Commission yesterday passed a 1 per cent gross receipts tax on newspapers and other periodicals. The action brought plans for a legal fight up to the Supreme Court if necessary.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Nervous seizures suffered by British children as a result of the wartime "blitz" are now disappearing, Mrs. Edna Blue, international chairman of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A special Army food mission, just back from Europe, has advised the Department of the Army that diets in western Germany are too poor to enable that country to make its full and essential contribution to the recovery of Europe.

Net earnings of the Chrysler Corporation and its wholly-owned United States subsidiaries for the six months ended with June amounted to $28,467,093, representing 4.29 per cent of sales, compared with $35,112,844 or 5.41 per cent of sales for the similar period of 1947, K. T. Keller, president, announced in the report released today.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 6 -- The 230,000 residents of this atom-bombed city joined today in a plea for world peace and a prayer that atomic energy would be used "for the benefit of mankind."

Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, who will leave today for Amsterdam on the Queen Elizabeth to attend the first assembly of the world council, saw in the council yesterday "an absolute and unequivocal denial, by implication, that the Christian churches can support isolationism."

Gilbert Green, Illinois state chairman of the Communist party and one of the twelve Communist leaders indicted on July 20 on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government by force, was arrested yesterday morning at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, where he was attending his party's convention as a delegate.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Episcopal Bishop Frank Juhan of Jacksonville, Fla., said today the Lambeth Conference of the Anglican Church would condemn not only communism but capitalism "that is equally aggressive."

" Champagne Charlie," a Britishmade musical comedy, starring Tommy Trinder, Stanley Holloway,h)0*0*0*iBetty Warren and Jean Kent, will have its local premiere today at the Park Avenue Theatre. The offering a period piece was directed by Cavalcanti, produced by Michael Balcon and is being released by Bell Pictures.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 Grain markets made a tame finish after showing strength in the early trading on the Board of Trade, today, wheat losing 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents, the latter on July. Corn closed 1 cent lower to 3/4 cent higher, September showing the weakness.

Dr. George W. Ruger, assistant medical examiner, announced yesterday after an autopsy performed at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn, that strangulation had caused the death of Robert Schneider, 23 years old, of 104-15 120th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 5 (AP) Two Democratic primary candidates supported by E. H. Crump, Memphis political leader, trailed opponents in unofficial returns from twothirds of the state's precincts today during an election day marred by two killings in southeast Tennessee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Dr. Cassius Way, a veterinarian and an international authority on race horses and prize cattle, died tonight at his home, 13 Littlejohn Place, here, of injuries received yesterday while treating a horse at the Roosevelt Raceway trotting track at Westbury, L.I.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- The Yankees today held firm in the nervewracking American League flag race as they toppled the Tigers, 2 to 1, before a gathering of 17,438.

A charge that Americans "are being taken for a ride on charitable shipments" of food and other commodities to friends and relatives in Germany, through "unbelievable profits" by stores and agencies sending gift parcels, was made here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, today urged the Security Council to affirm the right of between 250,000 and 300,000 Arab refugees to return to Israeli-controlled areas of Palestine.

Housewives are not showing much interest in buying meat now, according to retail butchers. These men, in turn, are purchasing only light supplies at the wholesale markets. Despite this lack of demand, however, prices on this food are as high or higher than they were a week ago.

OCEAI^ORT, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP)--Trainer Joe Camac of Wilmington, Del., stole the show on thisrainy afternoon at Monmouth Parkwhen he saddled three winners insuccession and not one was favoredin the betting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods said today that landlords and tenants now had the same number of representatives on 440 of the 630 local rent control advisory boards.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federalh)0*0*0*iCommunications Commission, told a special House investigating committee today that he does not think radio stations should be held responsible for libelous or slanderous statements in broadcast of political speeches because Federal law prohibits stations from censoring such speeches.
In reality have we inflation? The Government is not issuing paper money. On the contrary, we reduced our debt over $7 billion last year. This would come nearer deflation than inflation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The National Education Association today made public year-by-year estimates on school enrollment increases which will result from the wartime bumper baby crop, a jump from an estimated 24,373,000 public school enrollment next fall to 33,561,000 in the fall of 1957, a 30 per cent increase.
Two thieves took over the management of the single-family dwelling at 4708 Avenue I, Brooklyn, for an hour yesterday in a vain search for a huge cache of money.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- A price increase of $75 on each of fifteen models and a slash of $5 on one was announced today by the Ford Motor Company.

The management of Oppenheim Collins Co. won yesterday a temporary injunction restraining Local 1250, Department Store Employes Union, CIO, from using more than fifteen pickets in front of the company's two stores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The House of Representatives approved today a bill authorizing a $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for the establishment of a permanent home in New York City. The standing vote was 164 to 27.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A Senate appropriations subcommittee was told today that a Government hospital cook had been preparing occasional meals for the Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing, since last November.
Because of recent price increases, cigarette vending machines here are being altered to operate on quarters, it was reported yesterday by an official of the Cigarette Merchandisers' Association, Inc.

The Long Island College Hospital, at 340 Henry Street in Brooklyn, which in 1946 was found by the United Hospital Fund to have provided more days of free care than any other hospital in the borough, has issued its newest annual report, showing that in 1947 it spent $1,769,515 to care for 21,767 patients.

PAWLING, Aug. 5 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey has invited Governor Earl Warren of California, his running mate on the Republican National Ticket, and Herbert Brownwell, Jr., who is managing his campaign for President, to Albany for a two-day conference on campaign strategy and plans starting Aug. 16.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll exercised his special powers in extradition cases today in refusing to send John Colier back to a South Carolina prison camp.
Without any fanfare, the Police Athletic League is enlarging its recreational, social and cultural programs in underprivileged neighborhoods so that youngsters will not be burdened with idle time.

The Annport Realty Corporation has bought the five-story apartment building at 68 Cabrini Boulevard from Claymont Realties, Inc. The house occupies a plot with a frontage of fifty feet and the assessed valuation of the property is $59,000.
BOLTON, Mass., Aug. 5 (AP) -Suffragan Episcopal Bishop Raymond A. Heron escaped uninjured today when fired at by a gunman who earlier had fatally axed a 17year-old youth in the clergyman's home.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., Aug. 5 (AP) Dr. Benjamin Sandler of Asheville believes that a major cause for susceptibility to polio is low blood sugar in the body. He says that a diet low in sugars and starches will control the disease.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Grain markets staged a strong rally in the late trading on the Board of Trade today, with corn closing with new gains of 2 1/8 to 2 7/8 cents.

A mid-summer lull descended yesterday on the stock market to the accompaniment of the slowest and narrowest trading since early last March. The oils, rails and steels were on the firmer side and the public utilities accounted for the bulk of the restricted business.

After long and irritating delay Congress has honored a national pledge which American public opinion insisted must be kept. The House of Representatives has now followed the Senate in approving the $65,000,000 loan for the construction of a permanent headquarters for the United Nations, and work on the East River site should start almost immediately.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- A California boy plodded barefoot through mud puddles toward the Wembley Stadium locker room tonight.

Those of us who are vitally interested in the clash between Hyderabad and India have followed with closest interest and great admiration your careful and unbiased reporting of the situation. But in your issue of July 28 your correspondent in New Delhi faithfully transmitted a statement from Prime Minister Nehru of the Dominion of India that is so preposterous that we feel some word of comment or explanation is essential.

PARIS, Aug. 6 In asking special powers to institute a sweeping program of administrative, economic and financial reforms, Paul Reynaud, Minister of Finances and of the National Economy, said today that measures must be voted to avoid French collapse when the Marshall Plan expired.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- One of the last occupation closed to Danish women has surrendered to the post-war trended equality of the sexes with the orenation of three women as pastor of the Danish church.
POINT BARROW, Alaska, Aug. 6 (AP) -- America's northernmost base looked like an invasion beachhead today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- United States, British and French diplomats met for more than three hours tonight with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov at the Kremlin in the second of their attempts to find a way to solve East-West differences.

Four hundred members of the Metropolitan Opera Company, including singers, musicians and dancers, received yesterday mimeographed notices that their services would not be required for the 194849 season. Meanwhile, efforts to get the management to reverse its decision to cancel the season were largely at a standstill, pending the outcome of Monday's meeting of the twelve unions involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Communications Workers of America, an independent group, announced today that it would begin contract-reopening moves on Aug. 16 to obtain wage increases for 87,000 employes of eight telephone companies.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- Addressing the convention of the Canadian Liberal party this afternoon for the last time as its leader, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King denounced communism as the greatest menace of our time.

The threatened strike of the 3,900 employes of the Third Avenue Transit system, scheduled for 4 A.M. today, was called off early last night by the Transport Workers Union, CIO. Cancellation of the strike order issued by the union on Thursday was announced by City Councilman Michael J. Quill, its international president, at an informal session of the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 6 -- With the width of Buzzards Bay churned by a real smoky sou'wester, twenty-one of the sailing yachts on the New York Yacht Club squadron cruise went out there today for a nineteen-mile triangular contest.
Two painters, were hurled to their deaths in Brooklyn yesterday morning when a moving truck fouled a rope dangling from their third-floor scaffold and jerked the platform off balance.

Rex Barney, 23-year-old fireball pitcher, was tapping on baseball's hall of fame portal last night but in the end he and the 31,087 Flatbush fans were well content with his three-hitter as the Dodgers beat the Reds, 4 -- 1, at Ebbets Field.

A new economical die-casting alloy made of copper, silicon and aluminum, which overcomes former problems of drilling, tapping and machining castings made from other alloys, was revealed here yesterday for the first time by J. B. Neiman, manager of the aluminum department of Federated Metals division of American Smelting and Refining Company.

Retail trade here this week showed an increase despite several days of bad weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were also up 5 per cent.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Schiaparelli introduces a cone-shaped skirt. A hoop of supple boning is run through the hem so that the skirt, though narrow, flares regularly in cone shape. It makes its appearance for late afternoon, for cocktail suits and frocks in broadcloth, dark faconne velvets, satins, shot taffeta and moire.

Coverage of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has been extended to a total of 122,000 individuals since the plan began on March 1, 1947, according to a summary announced yesterday by E. Michael White, acting general manager.

ATHENS, Aug. 6 -- The "Provisional Government" of Gen. Markos Vafiades was reported today to have fled into Albania as Greek troops laid a thirty-mile semicircle of fire around the last bit of territory held by the Communist rebels.

ON a summer morning just three years ago this week it turned out that the men from Mars had been living among the rest of us all the time. Or anyway, so it seemed as we read the newspapers that day. For there was nothing much in our experience comparable to what they had been doing -- which was developing that big pill which, taken in modestly sufficient quanti ties could abolish the world.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A new type of "iron lung" that fits like a fishbowl over a polio victim'sh) 0*0*0*ichest and allows him unprecedented freedom of movement was introduced here today.

RHODES, Aug. 6 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations mediator, who returned to Rhodes today from a six-day tour of Amman, Jerusalem, Alexandria, Tel Aviv and Haifa said here tonight that he was still occupied with the truce supervision in Palestine to the exclusion of actual mediationh)0*0*0*iwork.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Half a dozen leaders of the Democratic party over the last twenty years joined President Truman at the White House last night for a discussion of political strategy, it was learned today. It was a meeting without precedent in the years since the Democrats captured the Presidency in 1932, so far as political observers could remember.

Fifty New York high school students more than held their own intellectually during an hour-long lecture on atomic energy held yesterday in Columbia's Pupin Hall. The students are part of a group of 300 who have volunteered to serve as guides at the "Man and the Atom" exhibit to be presented at the city's Golden Anniversary Exposition Aug. 23 through Sept. 19.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -The prospects of Indian military action in Hyderabad "to keep order" was heightened tonight when the Nizam of Hyderabad reportedly rejected the last terms on which the dominion would have been likely to negotiate with the independent Princely State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The National Military Establishment was the scene of unexplained moves and counter-moves today as James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, at first issued, then abruptly withdrew, and then sometime later finally restored to its original status a report on wartime organization of the Reserve Corps calling for federalization of the National Guard.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 6 -- The Clipper Mexico, new Pan American Airways plane with a speed of 300 miles an hour, enabling it to make the flight between Houston, Tex. and Mexico City in three hours was named today by Senora Julieta Garcia Lopez, wife of the Mexican Minister of Communications.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council today approved a resolution calling on the member states of the United Nations to take all measures necessary to assure the equal economic rights of women.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- A more hopeful view about the Moscow negotiations gave a bright finish to the week on the stock market here.

Private flying has taken a nosedive during the last year, Mrs. Herbert Roth, national director of Women Fliers of America, declared yesterday at the opening of its three-day second national convention in the New Yorker Hotel. She based this assertion on the meetings of 111 delegates from eighteen states at the convention who reported on individual chapters at the opening session.

Lumber production for the week ended July 31 was 0.9 per cent below last week but was 7.6 per cent above the comparable week a year ago. Shipments were up 10 per cent compared with a year ago and orders were down 10.6 per cent according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

Overseas parcel agencies and stores here made spirited denials yesterday of charges that they were receiving "unbelievable profits" on gift packages sent by Americans to friends and relatives in Germany. The charges were made here Thursday by a former American Military Government official.

Cyril Walker, who reached the heights of greatness in golf when he defeated Bobby Jones, Walter Hagen and other stars to win the national open championship in 1924, was found dead in Hackensack early yesterday. Alone but not forgotten, he had died during the night in a cell at police headquarters, where he had come for shelter. He was 56 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Miss Ann Curtis of the United States finally produced tonight the swimming speed that has won her thirty-nine American championships. Swimming the anchor leg on the women's 400-meter relay team, she won the Olympic championship for the United States squad, establishing a new Olympic mark for the event and unofficially cracking the world record in her own 100-meter trip with a clocking of 1:4.2.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) Western European nations are stillh)0*0*0*iscaling their requests for oil too high, the National Petroleum Council has been informed.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark, announced today the filing of a civil action here in United States court for the district of New Jersey charging the Far East conference and twenty-five member shipping lines with conspiracy.
Two middle-aged women were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn on separate charges of attempting to smuggle diamonds valued at $263,480 into the United States by air.
Local 1250, Department Store Employes Union, CIO, won three legal skirmishes yesterday growing out of its strike against Oppenheim Collins Co. as the walkout passed its fifth day.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The discovery of strings attached to yesterday's Russian financial "concessions" caused the Western powers in Berlin to offer tonight to meet the payrolls of all industry and commerce in Western Berlin. The offer will take effect tomorrow.

VIENNA, Aug. 6 -- A trade agreement was concluded here today between the Austrian Foreign Ministry and the commission of the German bizonal Joint ExportImport Agency headed by John Logan for the United States and Brigadier Michael Robinson for Britain.

Plots for a dozen human comedies can be found daily among the letters sent to a small office eight floors above a piano store at 135 West Fourteenth Street. Other stories too tragic to put on paper come with the men and women who talk to Capt. Elsie Van Pelt, director of the Salvation Army Missing Persons and Inquiry Bureau.

The same New York from which thousands of citizens fled this summer for vacations abroad seemed like Paradise yesterday to fifteen foreign officials of the Girl Scouts on their way to the opening next Friday of the World Conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts in Cooperstown, N.Y.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 -- The Yankees tonight once again put their arch rival, Bob Feller, to rout, but this time they didn't beat him.

American and Canadian rights to the Italian film, "The Spirit and the Flesh," have been purchased by Variety Film Distributors, Inc., of New York. John Erskine has written English sub-titles for the picture, which is based on the novel by Alessandro Manzoni, "The Betrothed."

The Communist party closed its five-day national convention here last night, adopting a platform calling for the nationalization of basic industries, banks and insurance companies as a preliminary to Communist rule in this country.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration and the State Department, according to the best source here, are not concerned about the United States Army's buying in Argentina with "unqualified" dollars as long as the Army expenditures remain relatively small.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission affirmed today its approval of a liquidation plan for the Louisville Gas Electric Company, incorporated in Delaware.

PARIS, Aug. 2 (Delayed) -- It is often said in France that the middle class, so long the backbone of the country, is fading away, or at least not reviving. The complaint is that private fortunes cannot exist for either investment or enjoyment under the new taxes and that the educated practitioner of business or the arts is often less well off than the skilled wage earner.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 6 The Narragansett Bay Bridge Authority has signed a contract with the New York firm of Stranahan Harris Company to finance a high span bridge over the east passage of the bay, M. James Viera, vice chairman and general manager of the authority, said here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP) The increase of $30 a ton in Fontana steel prices announced yesterday by the Henry J. Kaiser Company drew varied reaction today.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Contamination by bacteria of waters at six bathing beaches on the north Jersey coast bordering Raritan and Sandy Hook bays and the Atlantic Ocean was reported today by the State Department of Health.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Consumer credit outstanding in the nation is one-third higher than its pre-war high level in 1941 and further increases are expected the remainder of this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today in the current issue of its monthly publication on business conditions.

Patrolman George H. Stevenson hardly believed his eyes yesterday when he spotted two inebriated men drinking wine from a bottle on the clubhouse stoop of the Manhattan group of Alcoholics Anonymous at 353 West Forty-sixth Street.
Lightning struck again in the National League managerial ranks last night when Johnny Neun ceased to be manager of the Reins and Bucky Walters, famous veteran pitcher, was named to succeed him.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 6 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, swept aside the United States draft convention for the Danube today without having resorted to a vote by the Danubian Conference, and he left the Sovieth)0*0*0*idraft proposals in complete possession of the field.

TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 6 (AP) -Two globe-circling B-29's landed at the Davis-Monthan Air Force Base today, cutting the world down to an unimpressive size from a military standpoint. The two super-fortresses ended the first 'round-the-world flight by the big bombers just as dawn was breaking.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 6 -- Organized labor in Tennessee and particularly in the home county and city of E.H. Crump, state political leader and for many years a "king maker" is joyous today.

More than 100 eminent churchmen, part of the largest delegation of Americans ever to attend an ecumenical congress abroad, sailed yesterday for Amsterdam, via Cherbourg and Southampton, on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.
The city's jubilee air show, rainsoaked and financially grounded, broke through some thick rain clouds yesterday afternoon.
With their lives at stake if caught by the Japanese, two Philippine clergymen smuggled food, medicine, clothing and money to American prisoners in their country during the war.

An 86-year-old Iranian woman arrived in this country yesterday to visit three sons and two daughters but she failed to recognize any of them when they met her at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, because she had not seen them for thirty or forty years.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- After many weeks of hesitation because of the delicate international situation, the United States and British Military Governments announced officially today a break with the Soviet Military Administration on quadripartite control of the giant I. G. Farben cartel.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A resolution calling on political candidates publicly to state their position on free radio was adopted today by the second district of the National Association of Broadcasters.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States basketball team rolled into the Olympic championship tournament today by defeating Peru, 61 -- 33, and immediately drew Uruguay as a first-round opponent.

" Mister Roberts," the hit play at the Alvin Theatre, underwent numerous dialogue cuts and changes about two weeks ago after the Police Department's Division of Licenses asked that its ribald language be toned down, it was learned yesterday.
Car accessories are dictated by customers, a Chrysler Corporation spokesman said yesterday, speaking for the Chrysler, De Soto, Dodge and Plymouth divisions.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora announced yesterday that he would appoint a referee to take testimony ,in a bondholder's action seeking to merge the Surface Transportation Corporation with its parent organization, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 6 -Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of former President Theodore Roosevelt, marked her eightyseventh birthday today at Sagamore Hill, her home in Cove Neck and one-time summer White House.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Today's meeting of the Western envoys with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov was considered by informed quarters here to have been the most critical yet held on the Berlin crisis.
A thorough overhauling of the organizational structure of the United States Maritime Commission has been in process in recent weeks, and the result was made public yesterday by the agency.

TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- The Japanese Government is further stiffening its attitude on labor unions of public employes following its decision to withdraw their collective bargaining rights and the right to strike on the basis of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's letter to Premier Hitoshi Ashida July 22
ST. PAUL, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen announced today that he will support Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, for re-election.

The National Broadcasting Company announced last night that it would not accept any new "giveaway" programs pending clarification of the Federal Communications Commission's proposed standards for determining the legality of such shows under the lottery laws.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- A team now regarded as Winged Foot veterans consisting of Mark Stuart, the 1933 Metropolitan amateur champion, and Tom Robbins, accounted for some of the best golf of the day to score two victories in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament over the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

The Miami City Commission has voted to place a 1 per cent gross receipts tax on the newspapers and other periodicals of that city to raise an estimated $400,000 a year. It seems more than a coincidence that the tax was voted by three Commissioners at a time when they face a recall election after the newspapers had criticized their official actions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee by a 13-to-0 vote today approved the International Wheat Agreement as the first step toward revival of the agreement.

TORQUAY, England, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Long after today's Olympic yachting competition was over, the appeal jury upheld Canada's protest against France in the Firefly Class, upheld Great Britain's protest against Italy in the Star Class but threw out the British claim against Holland in the same division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A drop in American exports for the fourth consecutive month was reported today by the Department of Commerce. Total exports from the United States in June were valued at $1,013,100,000, down about 8 per cent from the May valuation of $1,102,900,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -Industry and labor spokesmen for the anthracite industry today indorsed unanimously a voluntary plan to provide steel for maintenance and repairs in the Pennsylvania anthracite workings.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 -The Japanese were reminded today that the destruction wrought here three years ago by the first atomic bomb used in warfare was brought on by their "betrayal" of friendly nations.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- French officials said tonight they expected their Ambassador's report on the Western envoys' visit with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov today would show whether the negotiations could continue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A fire extinguishing fluid, in which castor oil is a major constituent, to control metal fires was one of 350 inventions listed this week by the United States Patent Office.

Average hourly earnings of production workers in twenty-five manufacturing industries during May recorded their twenty-eighth consecutive monthly advance, according to a survey of payroll statistics made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Following is the text of the Communist platform for the 1948 elections as adopted by the Communist convention yesterday:

MARSHALL FIELD, Kan., Aug. 6 -- A new long-distance non-stop record for standard combat Boeing B-29 Superfortresses was set today when one of three such fourengine bombers landed here to end a 5,120-mile flight that started twenty-three hours earlier from Fuerstenfeldbruck, Germany.

Hempstead, L.I., will seek bids on Aug. 18 on an issue of $2,135,000 common school district No. 5 bonds, dated July 1, 1948, and due on each Jan. 1 from 1949 to 1978,h)0*0*0*iwith an interest rate not in excess of 4 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -Pickets patrolled the San Francisco waterfront today in spite of an anti-strike injunction still in effect under cooling-off provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law. Members of the Contract Guards and Patrolmen's Union, an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, established picket lines before three major piers.

Tenants who paid excess rentals to landlords have had $130,272 refunded since Jan. 1 through suits instituted by the New York Litigation Section of the Office of the Housing Expediter, Max N. Bass, regional attorney, announced yesterday.
On the Brooklyn baseball team there are two Negro players, both very popular with the fans. Cleveland has just taken on Satchel Paige, who has also been enthusiastically received.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics, battling to remain in the thick of the American League pennant fight, dropped a heart-breaking 2 to 1 decision to the St. Louis Browns tonight before 4,600 chilled fans.

Mel Ott was a Polo Grounds visitor yesterday, the first time in his life as a non-participant. What he saw must have been pleasing to the eyes of the erstwhile manager of the Giants, who ended their three-game losing streak with a 7-6 victory over the Pirates, whose ninth-inning rally fell short before 6,544 paying fans.
MADRID, Aug. 6 -- Further restrictions on foreign films were decreed today with the publication of a ministerial order limiting the dubbing of imported pictures.
Net sales of Van Raalte Company, Inc. in the first six months this year were $11,832,589, compared with $9,871,266 in the corresponding period of last year, the report disclosed yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug 6 (AP) -- Cutbacks to a four-day week in New England textile mills are affecting thousands of workers -- but experts are not alarmed.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Unseeded Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles today scored the biggest upset of the fifty-eighth Meadow Club grass court tennis tournament by defeating top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami. The scores were 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate approved today a compromise housing bill containing no subsidies for low-rent and slumclearance projects (the measure later was passed by a voice vote and sent to the House):

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to adjust itself in anticipation of the publication of the first Government report of the season on Monday morning. Trading operations were largely of an evening-up character, with orders both ways.

Restaurant tea sales have "shown heavy increases" this summer and in many cases have doubled "normal" sales for this period, it was estimated yesterday by the Tea Bureau, Inc., an association representing principal tea producers of the world.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 6 -Buddy Rogers' Magic from Larchmont won two races today to keep her lead in the Corry Trophy series for Star Class yachts in a heavy nor'wester that made matchwood of masts, smashed rigging and capsized several of the craft taking part in Great South Bay race week.

Four new volumes in "The Invitation to Travel Series" have beenscheduled for publication by CowardlVfcCann. One, "The MagicLand: Mexico," by Ralph Hancock,will be brought out on Aug. 16.The others, planned for publicationlin the fall, are: "The Long Land:i Chile," by Carleton Beals; "Brazil,"i by Bertita Harding, and "Canada,"by Bruce Hutchison.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The King Ranch's Flash Burn took up 124 pounds today and won Monmouth's featured sixth race over a muddy track.

Yesterday Paul Reynaud asked the National Assembly for special powers to perform a major operation on the sick economy of France. He demanded drastic cuts in the swollen civil services and in military expenditures (the latter designed to save money while modernizing the army).
BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Chicago's last-place Cubs hopped off to a three-run first inning and went on tonight to shade the league-leading Boston Braves, 5 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, denied today all accusations of censorship partisanship and lack of anti-communistic zeal which were made against him by the former Education Commissioner, John W. Studebaker.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 6 (AP) -Passaic County Prosecutor Manfield G. Amlicke said today warrants had been issued for the arrest of four officials of a home building concern on charges of misappropriating funds and conspiracy to defraud.

HEATH, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, celebrated his seventieth birthday here today in the "old mill" dating back to Revolutionary days that he rebuilt some years ago into a vacation house, doing virtually all the manual work with his own hands.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan told wheat farmers today the only sure way they can get the Government-promised minimum price for the grain is to store it for future disposal.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Four "guinea pig" students at the University of Maryland who subsisted on fish only for seven weeks showed that whatever its value as brainfood, it is as good as meat for humans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- With its sights still leveled on adjournment by tomorrow night, the Senate ignored today renewed Democratic pleas for price and wage controls and began consideration of the limited Republican anti-inflation bill. The Upper Chamber agreed to vote on the measure at 4 P.M. tomorrow.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 6--The E. H. Crump political dynasty of Memphis and a lesser Democratic organization long allied with it in Tennessee went down in stunning defeat today as the final ballots were counted after yesterday's violence-punctuated elections.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -P. James Pellecchia, who resigned as a Newark police judge July 13 after confessing he embezzled $630,000 from the Columbus Trust Company of which he was vice president and counsel, has become a domino devotee in the Essex County Jail.

A mounted patrolman, who had been accused of robbing a liquor store of $3 while in civilian clothes and off duty, waived examination and was continued in $5,000 bail to await grand jury action on a charge of robbery when he appeared yesterday in Felony Court, Brooklyn.

During recent months there have been several substantial embezzlement losses in banks having deposits of $4,000,000 to $6,000,000, the New York State Bankers Association points out in its current bulletin. Citing a letter received from the National Surety Corporation, the association notes that in each case the defaulter was able to conceal the shortage for a long time by having control of the mailing of depositors' statements.

Henry Fellows, formerly manager of sales development, has been named manager of sales research and training for Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., replacing L. P. Marechal, who was named manager of passenger sales. John Logan succeeds Mr. Fellows in his former position.

Although there is a question whether a successor to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church can be chosen at this year's election, both Republicans and Democrats intend to nominate candidates for this post at their First Judicial District conventions to be held some time between Aug. 30 and Sept. 2, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Pat Seerey's fifteenth homer scored three runs in the seventh inning tonight to give the Chicago White Sox at 4-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 27,428 fans. All of Boston's runs resulted from Vern Stephen's No. 23 homer off Bill Wight in the sixth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today started an immediate investigation of the large irregular air carriers which transport passengers and freight on a contract or charter basis. As a precedent, it ordered suspension of action on applications for permits by irregular air carriers filed after 11 o'clock this morning.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- Official Egyptian sources declared today that the proposal of Moshe Shertok, Israel's Foreign Minister, for direct Israeli-Arab peace negotiations was "unacceptable, no matter how you look at it."
A survey on the lower East Side has shown that 346 children of school age have had rheumatic fever and are either actual or potential victims of heart disease, it was reported yesterday.

The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation has issued invitations for bids to be received on Aug. 17 for its proposed offering of $5,250,000 of first mortgage bonds, due Aug. 1, 1978. Representatives of the company will meet with prospective bidders in Chicago on Aug. 12 to review the information contained in the registration statement.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Alablue, 3-year-old Blue Larkspur filly who will be sold at auction this month along with eight other horses in training that were owned by the late A. C. Ernst, added to the size of her price tag at Saratoga today by running off with the $9,225 Test Stakes.

Rouben Mamoulian will return to Broadway from Hollywood soon to produce and direct "Leaf and Bough," by Joseph Hayes, it was learned last night. Co-producing this three-act love story, the first major play by the young Indiana playwright, will be Charles Heidt.

Psychiatrists, sociologists, religious leaders, anthropologists and educators from forty-seven countries are converging upon London where, on Aug. 16, they will join forces in a World Federation for Mental Health to combat, for the first time on such a wide front, the world-wide scourge of mental illness.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- New Jersey's 400 reserve officers, back on active duty here for their first field training since World War II, were briefed today on atomic defense. Results of fission tests in the Pacific were shown at a conference attended by the group.

Prior to the promulgation of the various restitution laws now in effect in Germany, the American Military Government put into effect Military Law No. 52, which the Allied Control Council in Berlin extended also to the territory of the three other occupying powers.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A new cabinet, headed by Williem Drees, was announced tonight. The cabinet, with six Catholic party members, five Labor party members and two Center party representatives, shows a definite shift to the right.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Two United States crews were eliminated today from the Olympic regatta on the Thames River. One defeat led to a short-lived fuss over a twicestarted race but tempers cooled quickly in a steady August rain.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The United Kingdom delegation insisted today that five Britons charged by the Israeli Government with espionage had been arrested in an area protected by the United Nations flag.

Twenty-five thousand letters from veterans of World War II who live in the New York area lay unopened yesterday in the local offices of the Veterans Administration because of the large volume of last-minute applicationsh)0*0*0*ifor revival of National Service Life Insurance term policies.

DENVER, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Seward Potter, manager of the S.W. Shattuck Company said today that the Army and Navy knew that the concern shipped uranium nitrate and uranium oxide to Russia five years ago and made no attempt to halt it.

Leaders of the several branches of Presbyterianism in the United States and in the Reformed Church in America will be among the delegates to the sixteenth General Council of the Alliance of the Reformed Churches Holding the Presbyterian System, to be held in Geneva, Switzerland, beginning Wednesday and continuing through Aug. 18.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 6 -Hikmet Dayur, leader of the Nation's party, Turkey's third major political party, outlined his party's foreign policy in an interview today.
I represent more than sixty owners and tenants in the block bounded by Second and Third Avenues and Sixtyfourth and Sixty-fifth Streets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Republican leaders broke today by 48 to 36 a Senate rebellion against the party's modified housing bill and then carried it quickly forward to passage.

A handy device for humid August "dog days" is Crisp-It, designed to protect cakes, cookies and bread from becoming soggy. Slip the circular holder of chemicallytreated crystals in the bread box. The crystals absorb moisture so that it won't effect the food in the container.

At the end of a sultry, sullen afternoon, when the office machinery is stilled for the night, in those few moments of skirmishing before the clock's hands signal the exodus -- when ladies rattle the contents of handbags in search of powder for toil-shined noses and gentlemen straighten soggy neckties and reach for their coats -- it will begin to rain.

Representative John McDowell is not likely to stir up much trouble by declaring that in 1943, when atomic research was at its height, Russian agents induced somebody to send 2,720 pounds of uranium "compound" to Russia. Physicists will greet Representative McDowell's revelation with a skeptical "So what?"

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 6 -- Water for Jerusalem was virtually assured tonight through one of the strangest deals yet put over in this strange war. The Arabs have agreed to give up the vital pumping station at Latrun if Israel will permit some of the trapped Arab detachments to return to their villages.

Misericordia Hospital, one of the city's oldest Catholic hospitals, ath)0*0*0*i531 East Eighty-sixth Street, has started a building fund for a badly needed hospital wing, it was announced yesterday. The money will be raised through voluntary donations and a bazaar to be held at the hospital Nov. 19 to 21.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- For the first time in the nineteen years it has been played, the Contract Bridge Masters' Pair Championship, principal event of all tournaments conducted by the American Contract Bridge League and most covetedh)0*0*0*ititle for which contract bridge experts compete, seemed to be sewed up tonight in the first two sessions of the four-session contest.

It was Viennese night at Lewisohn Stadium last night, Polyna Stoska, soprano, Mario Berini, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and the PhilharmonicSymphony under Robert Stolz peppered an audience of 8,200 with Viennese melodies old and new and added a few of Offenbach and Sousa for good measure.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa, needing a par 4 on the last hole to tie, blew up for a 6 today to pass the $5,000 Tam O'Shanter jackpot to Lloyd Mangrum with a 72-hole tally of 277 -- 11 under par.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- Walter Max Hans Rothe and Frau Martha Hildegarde Stark, self-admitted agents for the Russian secret police, were sentenced today to seven years each after their arrest in the attempted kidnapping of Dr. Walter Duisberg from his home in the United States sector.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- The entire minority bloc in the Argentine Parliament resigned early this morning after the ouster by the Peronistas of Deputy Ernesto Sam Martino. He had criticized President Juan Peron on the Chamber floor June 23.

The DuMont Television Network (WABD) announces that it will unveil a new program at 8 P.M. on Tuesday under the title of "The Family Sing" and that, if successful, it will be continued as a regular series. The program will be predominantly musical in nature, being centered about an American family which enjoys singing popular ballads, folk songs and hymns.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6--Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, told a San Francisco Harbor luncheon today of the authority's achievements.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- The entire minority bloc in the Argentine Parliament resigned early this morning after the ouster by the Peronistas of Deputy Ernesto Sam Martino. He had criticized President Juan Peron on the Chamber floor June 23.

The DuMont Television Network (WABD) announces that it will unveil a new program at 8 P.M. on Tuesday under the title of "The Family Sing" and that, if successful, it will be continued as a regular series. The program will be predominantly musical in nature, being centered about an American family which enjoys singing popular ballads, folk songs and hymns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A Cabinet member under the New Deal was implicated today in charges that materials essential to development of the atomic bomb were sent, apparently under lend-lease, to Russia in 1943 and 1945.

The Texas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an estimated net income of $68,266,915 after all charges, including a deduction of $6,000,000 as a special inventory reserve, for the initial half of this year.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Well on toward midnight in floodlighted Wembley Stadium and with only a handful of the original 70,000 spectators remaining, Robert Mathias, 17-year-old recent high school graduate from Tulare, Calif., won the Olympic decathlon championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -Hal Wallis, who recently used an outstanding CBS radio thriller, "Sorry, Wrong Number," as material for a motion picture starring Barbara Stanwyck, today acquired the film rights to a CBS comedy, "My Friend Irma."

A Federal inquiry on pricing practices of the milk distributors in the metropolitan area has been started by the anti-trust division of the United States Department of Justice, it was learned yesterday.

BENTON, Tenn., Aug. 6 (AP) -National Guardsmen with bayonets rolled into this gun-bristling southeastern Tennessee county seat today to quell continuing election strife which has left two reported dead and five wounded.
Random notes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -The Justice Department today promised "more action" on GI complaints of irregularities in the construction, sale and financing of veterans' housing.

Those who think people are sufficient entertainment for a tavern have another surprise at hand. There was the juke box, then television. Now, beginning a fight for floor space at the end of the bar, is -- and quiet drinkers must have had some foreboding -- the combination juke box and television.
