A dual pricing policy has developed in the chemical industry covering sales of by-product coke oven items, as a result of announcement by some steel companies that chemical products are being priced on an f.o.b. mill basis, purchasing sources revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- An expansion program involving an outlay of $3,525,100 at the Government's military rocket and guided missile project at White Sands, N.M., was announced today by the Army Corps of Engineers.

Ike Williams, lightweight champion of Trenton, N.J., will defend his 135-pound crown against Jesse Flores of Stockton, Calif., in a 15-round bout at the Yankee Stadium,h)0*0*0*iSept. 22. This was announced yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club which also stated it was arranging a strong supporting semi-final.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Some violations of the minimum wage, overtime and child-labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Public Contracts Act were found in more than one-half of the establishments inspected in the year ended June 30.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- A price increase ranging from $90 to $250 per model was announced today by the Ford Motor Company for its Lincoln and Mercury lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Some violations of the minimum wage, overtime and child-labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Public Contracts Act were found in more than one-half of the establishments inspected in the year ended June 30.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- A price increase ranging from $90 to $250 per model was announced today by the Ford Motor Company for its Lincoln and Mercury lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A preliminary agenda for a Congressional study of the whole field of communications was released today by Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, who will head the examining group.
The British-built Sunbeam-Talbot and Humber cars will be placed on display tomorrow at Adams Motors, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Beginning Monday sixteen Rutgers University students operating in four-man crews will ride the Central Railroad of New Jersey from Elizabeth to Cranford, Dunellen and Raritan to survey railroad conditions for the Intermunicipal Group for Better Rail Service, it was announced today by John F. Kraus, group chairman.

WITH the words "Gloria in Excelsis Deo," from the "Mass in B Minor," sung by Gastone Usigli's sixty-eight-voice Bach chorus, Carmel opened its eleventh Bach Festival here late in July. With the words "Dona nobis pacem," from the final section of the great Mass, the festival came to a close.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight named Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, and six others as winners of its annual awards for efforts to abolish racial discrimination.

AMSTERDAM -- Of the 400,000 or so Americans who are expected to visit Europe this year, a modest 10,000 will probably visit the Netherlands. If they are fond of precision, creature comforts, the orderly picturesque, and local color in a low key, they will have come to the right place.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman nominated Maurice J. Tobin of Boston tonight to be Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Senator John S. Cooper, Republican, of Kentucky, asserted today that Senator McGrath of Rhode Island, the Democratic National Chairman, had "played politics" in the failure of a Senate Committee to approve a displaced persons measure.

A long-range objective of the foreign aid program -- greater two-way trade -- is beginning to show promise of realization, it was indicated last week by an analysis of consumer merchandise imports from five major Marshall Plan countries.

Since the end of the war American colleges and universities have vastly expanded their offerings in international studies and foreign affairs. Interest in these fields has now reached an all-time high. When the new academic year begins next month, more students will be enrolled in courses dealing with international affairs than ever before in American university history.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- The negotiations in Moscow between the Western powers and the Soviet Union have struck snags that will prolong them and that have diminished the hope of a formal four-power conference, in the opinion of officials here who are in close touch with the talks in the Russian capital.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- A long route home marked the semi-finals of the John G. Anderson memorial tournament over Winged Foot's west course today, since both matches developed into keen tussles that were decided at extra holes.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 -- A United States consular guard, Joseph Przyowsky of Pennsylvania, was wounded in the left arm today when two bullets fired by snipers penetrated a car flying the United States flag in which he was traveling with United States Consul William Burdett of Macon, Ga., Mr. Burdett had a second escape during the day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Two rival telephone workers' unions teamed today for a joint wage-increase drive in the Bell System.

CONTINUING variations in state driver-license laws and in the kinds of equipment and accessories permitted on passenger vehicles are giving concern to the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators. These disparities have serious effects upon highway safety and upon the design of new automobiles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Although Social Security taxes substantially exceed current benefit payments, the time will come when payments will exceed income unless tax rates are adjusted upward, the Tax Review, publication of the Tax Foundation, reports.

The migration and resettlement of 50,000 Jews in Israel since Jan. 1 of this year, mainly because of contributions by American Jews, was announced yesterday in a report by Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

The trial of the Justice Department's anti-trust suit against seventeen of the nation's foremost investment banking firms and the Investment Bankers Association drifts further and further into the realm of 1949.

FROM New Haven sources it was learned last week why the promised 3-cent stamp in commemoration of the centenary of the poultry industry -- a postal item which the philatelic press calls "the hen stamp" -- is to receive first-day sale in that Connecticut city on Sept. 14.

With textile orders indicating that lessened consumer demand has been felt at the mill level, New England cotton goods manufacturers last week curtailed their output by about 20 per cent. Fine goods mills, taking a cue from Southern producers who went on a shorter work week, reduced their operations to four days.

WHEN P.G. Wodehouse emerged from the doghouse with still another addition to the saga of Blandings Castle, that stately home of England, it was predicted that unborn generations of scholars would mine the master's works for doctoral dissertations and learned treatises.
Allan Nevins' "The Strength of Our Political System" prompt me to tell you, of a conversation I had with my 15-year-old daughter.

Officials of forty-five nations were rapt witnesses yesterday afternoon to the silvery flashing showcase of military airpower presented on the next-to-last day of the jubilee air exposition at the New York International Airport at Idlewild.

IT is ironic that at the very height of the Kafka boom there should be a tendency to deflate his literary accomplishments. For over a decade Kafka has been one of the most cherished figures of advanced literary circles both in this country and abroad; but now that his fame has become more general there has been a greater inclination to question it.

The plans of Tournament of Champions, Inc., to stage its double-barreled championship card at Ebbets Field next month were dealt a severe blow yesterday when it was revealed that the light heavyweight titleholder, Freddie Mills, is ill and may not be able to meet Gus Lesnevich in a return match.

CALCUTTA, Aug. 1 -- Any modest attempt to bring within reasonable focus the immense canvas of the Indian subcontinent through its first year of partition; to balance degrees of achievement in face of political and economic problems that justifiably might have appalled men much more experienced in the business of government than the leaders of the two new Dominions, or to assess prospects in the measurable future must necessarily be in the broadest general terms.

The President has renewed his demands that the Government be granted increased powers to restrain and coerce the activities of the people in their effort to make and distribute the goods and services by which they live.

First Lieuts. William J. (Bill) Fenton and Robert S. (Fitz) Fitzgerald of the Mitchel Air Force base got around to a little talking yesterday afternoon about stunting in the skies over Idlewild. Three times last week, including yesterday, the young fellows had seasoned pilots and the crowds gasping because of their spine-chilling acrobatics.

RHODES, Aug. 7 -- The Palestine Arab refugee problem has reached the magnitude of the Jewish displaced persons problem in Europe, Sir Raphael Cilento, United Nations expert on relief plans, declared here today.

A PAIR of containers offers a challenge to the originality and technique of the flower arranger. One arrangement well done is a thing of beauty, but two, utilizing matching containers become a conversation piece.

THE impact of man upon history and of events upon the man who wields power is always fascinating. Here is a book that historians of World War II will have to study, since it represents a primary source of the materials that will go to make up the definitive account of the Italian campaign.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The nomination of former Gov. Maurice J. Tobin to be Secretary of Labor tonight caught Massachusetts political observers by surprise.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 -- Lines are being drawn within the Union of American Hebrew Congregations for a struggle over the question of moving the reform Jewish organization's administrative headquarters from Cincinnati to New York City.

When the Eightieth Congress convened for the extra session called by President Truman both parties stood committed by their platform declarations to the need for legislation to relieve the nation's acute housing problem.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Olympic spirit at its finest was caught by 83,000 spectators today on a sunny afternoon of stirring episodes and roaring excitement that culminated the track and field program of the Games of the XIV Olympiad in Wembley Stadium.

Retailers should strongly oppose any attempts by suppliers to use the recent Supreme Court decision outlawing the use of the basing point pricing system as a "prop to justify abandonment of competitive pricing practices," Hyman I. Fischbach, general counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, warned last week

THIS carefully documented inquiry in the history of recent European mass migration restores to its rightful place a theory fundamental to liberal economic thought in the nineteenth century: that there is a direct and crucial relationship between the movement of persons and the movement of goods, and a break in that relationship entails grave disturbance of the entire political and economic system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Republican-controlled Congress passed and sent to President Truman today a measure providing Federal loan aid to stimulate private construction of small homes and large apartment houses but omitting public housing and slum clearance.

THE vacationing amateur eager to see the results of his shooting before he gets back home may set up emergency darkrooms at any point in his travels where water is available. With today's developing facilities, darkness is needed only for loading the film into the tank, and even this step may be taken anytime by using one of the daylight loading tanks.

GEORGE MILLAR turns a post-war holiday eye on the European scene. In his factual account of a cruise from England to the Greek Islands, he combines adventure, perceptive reporting and a touch of idyll in nice proportions.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 7 -- The 23,500-ton United States aircraft carrier Sicily arrived today at King George V dock with sixty-nine Lockheed F-80 Shooting Star jet fighter planes and 387 officers and enlisted men of the Thirty-sixth Fighter Wing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman called upon Congress today to repeal a provision in the Interior Department Appropriation Act for 1949 which would deprive two high officials of the Reclamation Bureau of their jobs.

THE late Deneys Reitz, that doughty Boer of cherished memory, once remarked to me, after a safari to Lake Kivu: "The Belgian Congo is a miracle: it has everything we South Africans have, plus everything we need." Reitz was hardly exaggerating.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Two players who never before had made the final of an Eastern grass court tournament today qualified for the title match of the fifty-eighth annual Meadow Club competition.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Three husky United States crews swept into the finals of the Olympic regatta today on the wind and rain-lashed Thames River, but Jack Kelly of Philadelphia, figured to be as certain as taxes, was eliminated in the single sculls.

Artificially produced fever improves the effectiveness of the seven-and-a-half-day penicillin treatment for syphilis, say Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Chicago Board of Health, and a group of four doctors in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Army announced tonight that it would need 37,000 more officers by the end of next June.

BY inaugurating its plan for quarterly and annual awards of merit to its most deserving members, as announced last week, The Screen Directors Guild has set a precedent for the various separate groups of creative workers in the film industry.

Further cooperation with the Civil Aeronautics Association in its air education program was advocated yesterday by delegates to the second national convention of the Women Fliers of America, meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

As early as December, 1946, the problem of designing an Olympic torch arose in Britain. E.J. Holt of the Olympics Organizing Committee consulted the Fuel Research Station, which is part of the Department of Industrial and Scientific Research.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -- Although the provincial legislators of the Radical party-joined the Deputies in the National Assembly in submitting their resignations in protest against the expulsion by the Peronistas of Deputy Ernesto San Martino, the probability increased today that all the resignations eventually would be withdrawn.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- The southernmost memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt in the world of his Good Neighbors has just been dedicated at Carrasco, one of this capital's best-known beach suburbs, ten miles from the city and very near the national airport.

Despite the fact that a settlement of wage demands was reached only a few weeks ago, the railway unions have started a new movement for a further rise of 25 per cent. With the railroad wage bill this year expected to amount to about $5,000,000,000 at existing levels of pay, a further rise of $1,250, 000,000 would have a powerful influence on the nation's price structure.

Increases in industrial productivity of as much as 300 per cent per operation have been obtained by new developments in industrial refrigeration, William Switzer, commercial sales manager of the Frigidaire division of General Motors Corporation, Dayton, Ohio, asserted yesterday in disclosing for the first time a study of the rapidly expanding uses for cooling equipment in industrial processes.

The new Selective Service law passed by the Eightieth Congress will have little effect on college enrollment in the immediate future, but an appreciable decrease may be felt in September, 1949, college authorities predicted last week.

COMPETENT in several fields of art history, the German critic, William Cohn, now an Oxford don, offers an introduction to Chinese painting following the familiar Phaidon formula. The authoritative text is clear and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Congress sent a housing appropriation bill to the White House tonight after Administration supporters had tried unsuccessfully to add funds for Western reclamation projects.

THERE are countless stories about the recent war that need to be told, and little by little the men who were there and saw the action are telling them. "The AAF Against Japan," by Vern Haugland, is one of these stories; it is by no means a complete picture of the war in the Pacific, nor does it intend to be.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Bud Browning, head coach of the American Olympic basketball team, today predicted his quintet would win the court crown in the eight-team elimination championship tournament which begins Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Fifty years ago next Thursday the American flag was raised over Iolani Palace in Honolulu. The ceremony marked the formal annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to the United States.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Guardsmen of the Forty-second Division, of which the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn is the largest unit, started packing today at Camp Smith for the return to their homes tomorrow morning. Final inspections of equipment were made tonight followed by issuance of paychecks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman's political progress his struggle with the extra session of the Republican Congress has been rather like the movement of a man on stilts.

HOW is the average wage-earner bearing up under the high cost of living? To get the answer to this question, THE NEW YORK TIMES asked the State Labor Department to select a worker whose experience would be typical of the problems faced by the average New Yorker and his family in balancing income against outgo.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- In the seclusion of his 486-acre dairy farm here, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is making leisurely and detailed plans for the political campaign he confidently expects will result in his election to the Presidency.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Norman Lewis, 32-year-old New York business executive, gained the semi-final of the Olympic men's individual epee tournament today by slashing his way through two rounds of eliminations.

IT is not customary to devote these columns to private exhibitions not specifically directed at the general public. But the Henry P. McIlhenny collection on view at the Century Club through Sept. 25 is an instance of such surpassing excellence that it is difficult to refrain from a bit of special pleading.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- If the eleventh Berkshire Festival, which has been one of exceptional brilliancy, had done nothing but present the American premiere of Vaughan Williams' Sixth Symphony this evening it would have placed the nation in its debt.

THE States' Rights splinter party is self-avowedly anchored to the general and defensible theory that there should be as little Federal participation as possible in the internal affairs of the several states. As such it represents simply another projection of the traditional American debate over centralization of political power.

AT least one aspect of the future in records has been tried, and it works. Columbia's contribution to making the life of the record collector pleasanter, its "Long-Playing Microgroove Record," appears to be nearly everything the ballyhoo has claimed for it.

Last Sunday we discussed the relationship between recoil and weight, as it concerned the shotgun shooter, but instead of eliminating the task of replying to a stack of inquiries it seemed to stimulate some readers to greater efforts in their attempt to make up their mind what shotgun would best suit their needs.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Noble Hero, 3-year-old grandson of Man O' War, who has earned $24,740 in two years of campaigning, came close to achieving that figure in a single afternoon's work today when he raced to victory in the Choice Stakes before a record-breaking throng that turned out to witness the closing of Monmouth Park's third and most successful meeting.

Plans are being made for autumn theatre parties for the benefit of charitable institutions. The Prescott Neighborhood House has taken over the evening performance on Oct. 12 of "Summer and Smoke," the theatre yet to be named. Reservations may be made through Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

I AM but just returned to town, from which you may infer that I have been out of it, and I have been boxing for exercise, with Jackson, for this last month daily. I have also been drinking and on one occasion, with three other friends at the Cocoa Tree, from 6 till 4, yea, until 5 in the matin.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The glass industry faces its first major work stoppage in sixty years unless current negotiations produce a wage increase, a union official said tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Cyclists from Italy, Denmark and Great Britain reached the semi-final of the 1,000 meter (1,093 yard) sprint in the Olympic Games today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (NANA) -- The Democratic high command is planning a two-pronged campaign train tour for President Truman thate will take him barnstorming through the West and then cross-country to the Atlantic seaboard.

A new experiment in international education is being tested this summer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston. Known as the "Foreign Student Summer Project," it has brought sixty-one European graduates in science and engineering to MIT's campus for fourteen weeks of study, with all expenses paid.

MANY thousands of thoughtful citizens, pondering the implications of Hiroshima and the atomic age, have wondered what effect this revolution in technology will have upon American democracy. Atomic discoveries may well imply an entire recasting of international relationships and the world's political basis.

"DIVIDED," a novel about the Counter Intelligence Corps of the American Army of Occupation in Austria, was unanimously chosen as the winner of the 1947 Lewis and Clark Northwest Award. It is both easy and difficult to see why.

Accused of stealing a diamond dinner ring from his sister while she was doing him a good turn -- putting a patch on his trousers -- Alphonse Cinelli, 35 years old, of 761 East 133rd Street, the Bronx, was arraigned on a grand larceny charge in the Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday.

EVERYBODY is wondering whether the United States is in for a slump or for still more inflation. Speculation on this theme fills the business colums of the papers. How reliable are forecasts of economic conditions? They have a long history: experience with them in the past is not reassuring.

A ninth inning rally at Ebbets Field yesterday netted three Dodger runs and drove Johnny Vander to cover, out Harry Gumbert quelled the uprising and the double-no-hit kid chalked up his ninth triumph as the Reds outscored the Brooks, 6 -- 4, before 21,193 disappointed Flatbush fans.

THE 1,250-mile drive over the Alaska Highway from Dawson Creek, British Columbia, to Fairbanks, Alaska, is a trip that falls halfway between ordinary de luxe cross-country motoring found within the United States, and camping out.

THE batter for the second half of the baseball season now is up, and against him they are calling the usual strikes and balls. As each goes across the plate, or does not cross it, a breathless nation is invited to treat each as something slightly superior to the Taj Mahal in moonlight.

The Philharmonic-Symphony summer concert season at Lewisohn Stadium wound up in a blaze of glory last night. The season's largest audience of 20,000 jammed available seats to hear the music of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, and an estimated 2,000 persons were turned away at the gates.

In an unwonted recognition of a Navy style, the National Maritime Union hoisted a broom over the parapet of its West Seventeenth Street headquarters after the leftists had been beaten decisively in a national election late last month.

PARIS, Sunday, Aug. 8 -- Recourse to a formal vote of confidence to obtain adoption of the special powers asked by Finance Minister Paul Reynaud for his program of financial reforms became a probability today when the text of his proposals went through a severe mauling in the committees of the National Assembly.

VIENNA, Aug. 7 -- The Austrian Institute for Economic Research reports a general economic improvement in Austria, including production, employment and volume of goods available to and purchased by consumers.

Failure of the Rogers Bill, providing automobiles for blinded veterans of World War II, to pass the House of Representatives yesterday after reports became current here that it had been adopted, brought keen disappointment to the first state-wide convention of the Blinded Veterans Association at Hotel Astor.
Gen. Omar N. Bradley's recent statement about the problem of Negro manpower in the Army was in entire character with the man.
BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- The Berlin situation has worsened appreciably in the last twenty-four hours.

CRANKY because his birthday celebration must be postponed and also because his day off has been disturbed, Steve Johnson of the San Francisco police is called in on a murder case. The victim has been poisoned, run over by a taxi, has fallen off a cable car, and the coroner final ly decides, been killed by a bullet.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 7 -- The Gulf Stream poloists presented a well-balanced attack to defeat Old Westbury, 11 -- 9, in a free-scoring game on the No. 4 field at the Meadow Brook Club today.
GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- American visitors to Switzerland who have difficulty buying post-war automobiles at home find the Swiss car market almost more than they can stand.

"PEOPLE ask whether an atomic bomb is as powerful as an earthquake or a volcanic eruption or a tidal wave or a bolt of lightning," says Carl Van Doren in his introduction to "Early Tales of the Atomic Age." "These are mythological questions," Professor Van Doren continues, "not very different from ancient speculations about the power of Zeus' thunders or Poseidon's storms or the Giant's struggles in the bowels of Mount Etna."

JUST twenty-one years ago this week in this Review: A book called "We" was attracting more than casual attention, and so was its author, Charles Augustus Lindbergh, who had recently been abroad. . . . A writer who signed himself "Augur" was storing up memories for the future by advocating a united Europe vis-a-vis Russia, which was attempting to subvert the civilization of the West. . . .

Yet, whether the critic is one of the industry's cognoscenti mouthing intramural words and phrases such as import quotas, fixed studio charges and negative costs, or merely a paying customer expressing his disenchantment, the criticism generally focuses on the cinematic story.

NEW DELHI, India Aug. 7 -- Open declared war between India and Pakistan over the Kashmir dispute was averted in June by the intervention of British Prime Minister Attlee, the authoritative newspaper Hindustan Times said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Sixteen countries have laws prohibiting the unauthorized use of the flag, seal and name of the United Nations, according to the report to the General Assembly by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

IN the third volume to be published in the definitive and truly monumental series on the life and works of Michelangelo, Charles de Tolnay continues his study by covering the years 1512-34 in the career of one of the few supreme artists of all ages.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- If conditions are favorable, the annual shower of Perseid meteors will provide a spectacular display for observers Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights, when it is expected to reach its height, Dr. Charles P. Olivier, Professor of Astronomy at the University of Pennsylvania, reported today.

The Western Pacific Railroad Corporation, which is in process of dissolution, announced yesterday that it is offering on Tuesday, Aug. 10, to the holders of its preferred stock, the right to purchase 8,000 shares of its 6 per cent preferred stock at $4 a share.

THREE decades of nefarious activity have not impaired the orneriness of the Chinese superman Fu Manchu. Now he has added hypocrisy to his already bulging bag of tricks, which isn't becoming, and fools nobody.

LAKE ITASCA, Minn. -- Where the mighty Mississippi River starts its 2,550-mile journey to the Gulf of Mexico is a vacationland as beautiful as it is remote from civilization. Ol' Man River's source is Lake Itasca, a clear, pine-bordered lake with twelve miles of jagged shoreline in northern Minnesota, 225 miles northwest of Minneapolis.

THIS week's big event is the opening of the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College, New London, on Friday evening for a series of twelve performances by Martha Graham and her company, Jose Limon and his company, and the Dudley-Maslow-Bales Trio and their company.

THE American brand of communism was examined last Monday evening by the ABC network in a brilliantly successful and provocative documentary. With both forthrightness and dramatic impact, the program threw the spotlight on the party and the party-liners, leaving them exposed in all their blind obedience to the Politburo.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 7 -- State Republican organizations in the South are extremely active today, indicating that they intend to take full advantage of the furor created by the Democratic National Convention in the nomination of President Truman, endorsement of his civil-rights program and refusal to declare for states' rights.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The United States Olympic team has 450 1/2 points after the first eight days of action at London. The total is a single point less than the team picked up in the entire 1936 games to gain second place. The 1948 games end next Saturday.

A large-scale shift to hand-to-mouth buying is taking place in durable goods lines spurred by fears of sizable inventory losses if downward price adjustments occur because of improvements of supply of major industrial materials, industrial purchasing agents and distributors revealed during a canvass here yesterday.

This is open season for the individual with allergy. Newspapers now are carrying daily pollen counts, and minions of hay fever victims are carrying extra handkerchiefs, for, from mid-July to the first real frost, the season is on.

FOR several years until last season, the revue had begun to seem as neglected a stage form as the comedietta. Then came three revues, all sufficiently popular, despite heat and high prices, to be with us to this day.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Going to the front at the break, F.W. Hooper's favored Ocean Drive today ran to an easy ten-length victory in the thirteenth running of the $25,000 added Mayflower Stakes for 2-year-olds at Suffolk Downs.

AIFA. PALESTINE is a small country, but no one correspondent can cover it completely. This should rightly be a collective story, rather than my own limited experiences. WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Commander Edgar C. Corry Jr. of the American Veterans of World War II asked President Truman today to help student veterans in his home state, Missouri, retain their voting rights.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The United States Government, biggest landlord in the world, is paying out a record $59,000,000 a year to rent additional office space for its burgeoning government bureaus.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Corny Shields, in what horse racing would call a photo finish, steered his Aileen a scant half-length over the line ahead of E.J. Mosbacher's Susan today to win the International Class in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's Y.R.A. regatta.
Retail trade here continued seasonally active last week, with fairly good response to August promotions. Department store volume was estimated at about 5 per cent over the like week of last year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Jamal el-Husseini, vice chairman of the Palestinian Arab Higher Committee said today that he personally would give favorable consideration to a proposal for the establishment of a United States of Palestine.

Joseph Stalin receives foreign visitors behind a double soundproof door in a rectangular conference room of the Kremlin. On the dot of the appointed time Mr. Stalin and the visitor, along with an interpreter, sit down at a long table -- at which are ranged chairs used at meetings of the fourteen members of the Soviet Politburo.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7 -- With the exception of top-ranked Frank Parker's speedy 6-1, 6-2 victory over Richard Gaines of Edgartown, Mass., the opening day of the twenty-second annual Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club was devoted to early round matches among the tourney's unseeded players.
A current surplus of tankers is considered seasonal and temporary, and the Government is going ahead with extensive improvement of the tanker fleet of the nation, it was reported yesterday.

The Democratic voters of Memphis and of Tennessee did more than name a Governor and a Senator when they snowed under the candidates of Boss Crump in the Democratic primary. They restored the dignity of the ballot. Since 1905, when he first gained control of the Shelby County (Memphis) political machine, Mr. Crump had assumed toward that fundamental attribute of democracy a contemptuous arrogance that made a mockery of city and state-wide elections in Tennessee.

IN previous books Mr. Zim and Mr. Bronson have given us accurate accounts of elephants and goldfish, coyotes and turtles. While both these new books are probably intended for a 6 to 12-year-old group, enthusiastic parents and teachers will find large portions which can be shared with nursery school and kindergarten children.

BELGRADE, Aug. 7 -- Surface evidence of cooperation between the Yugoslavs and the Soviet-led Cominform delegations at the Danubian conference has failed to conceal the fact that the struggle between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Cominform parties is continuing unabated.

ROSALIND RUSSELL, who came to town last week to collaborate with her husband, Frederick Brisson, in midwifing the impending Broadway opening of their new picture, "The Velvet Touch," confessed that her experience with her own production company has given her a new sympathy for front offices, even though she has always had a healthy respect for the executive side of movie making.

THIS long-delayed fourth volume of "The Corpus of Florentine Painting" is devoted to reproductions of works produced in the shop or under the influence of Bernardo Daddi. It is divided into two parts showing examples of the work of his "close" and "remoter" following.

Drew Middleton, in his article, "Fourteen Men -- Not Supermen,'' detours the beetling fact that each member of Russia's Politburo is a fanatical ideologist. As the Eightieth Congress moved into the closing hours of its special session yesterday the expected had happened. President Truman had presented the legislators with a "job" that he said might be done in fifteen days "if they wanted to do it." Under the most favorable circumstances there was too much job for that or a much longer time.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The pennant-minded Philadelphia Athletics lashed back at the St. Louis Browns for a 7-to-1 victory tonight, capitalizing on the steady southpaw twirling of Lou Brissie and some solid stickwork by Ferris Fain, Pete Suder and Herman Franks.

THE things that happened to American children as a result of World War II depended on what happened to the American family and how it stood the strain. Because "strain rather than catastrophe'' was the majority experience in a country spared bombing, enemy occupation, mass evacuation, Dr. David M. Levy holds that our children's wartime problems offer implications for family living in normal times and hence for mental health.

A DEPOSED monarch (Rudolf the Third, King of Althenia) is making a personal-appearance tour along the French Gold Coast while disposing of complimentary motor cars at royal black-market prices. If Rudolf is to appear at Beaumontsur-Mer, one of the less fashionable resorts, for the minute sum of 500, says Anthony Tolworth, social adviser to the king, the best vintages and the whitest shirt fronts must be profusely in evidence.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie put Germany at the top of the list of world trouble spots today and made a direct appeal to the Big Four powers to come to agreement on the issue -- inside or outside the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A growing shortage of young doctors to look after the health of the nation's inductees may tie up the draft before it gets started.

For really 'tis so fine -- it fills one's mouth with a gushing freshness -- then goes down cool and feverless -- then you do not feel it quarreling with your liver -- no, it is rather a Peacemaker, and lies as quiet as it did in the grape.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Hogs were quoted nominally in a $21.50 to $30 range today. The market was 50c to $1 under last week's levels despite the making of a new record high at $31.50 on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Navy announced tonight that its new 65,000-ton aircraft carrier, designed to launch long-range atom-bomb planes, would be built in a private shipyard, the Newport News (Va.) Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

THE Yale Series of Younger Poets, edited in recent years by Stephen Benet and Archibald MacLeish, and now by W.H. Auden, displays in its end-pages a disheartening roster of unfulfilled renown. Not one of the forty-five poets selected by the Series' judges has moved forward to mature accomplishment in the field of poetry, yet it would be far from the truth to say that the editors (at least the recent ones) have chosen poorly.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Aug. 7 -- Arab refugees are still fleeing from Palestine to neighboring countries, which can ill afford to maintain them. Baghdad and Damascus seem to be the objectives for the current exodus, largely because Amman, Trans-Jordan, has reached its saturation point and Cairo has had its fill.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- An analysis of population figures and party strength in the Trizonal area indicates that the forthcoming parliamentary assembly will consist of seventy-four delegates, most of them Rightists with rather strong federalist views.

I hope that the American public will be indulgent enough to tolerate me to think aloud in the columns of your world-famed newspaper on a subject that is disturbing the minds of many Filipinos at home and abroad.

POINT MUGU, Calif., Aug. 7 -- This once-desolate rendezvous of fishermen and boatbuilders, jarred intermittently for the last two years by the detonation of new weapons of war, is about to begin a $30,000,000 transition into a Navy guided-missile testing center.

TOKYO, Aug. 7 -- The Allied occupation of Japan has long since ceased to be primarily a military operation. The preoccupations of the high command now center around the industrial rehabilitation of Japan, the nation's relations with its Asiatic and Pacific neighbors and its eventual place in the world scheme rather than with troop movements or battle plans.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- Strange goings on seem to be bursting into print these days along the Western fringe of the American League, where four clubs are conducting one of the most extraordinary pennant races in the history of that circuit.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the Philadelphia Phillies' $25,000 bonus beauty, pitched and batted the Phils to a 6-2 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals today before a Saturday crowd of 9,871.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Wheat moved ahead for gains extending to around 2 cents on the Board of Trade today. Dealings were fairly active, including a good deal of short covering and some buying attributed to mills and elevator houses.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Following is the text of the introduction to Secretary General Trygve Lie's annual report to the United Nations General Assembly:

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Skinny 17-year-old Jimmy McLane knifed through the water in the Wembley pool this afternoon to pick the last swimming plum off the Olympic tree. He won the 1,500-meter free style championship in the fast time -- although not a record -- of 19:18.5.

AL COLBY is a detective who gets around fast. His ground covering reads like the summer vacation section of a newspaper. He gives a great deal of interesting travel comment about Central and South America.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 7 -- A 6,000-pound bronze statue of George Washington, authorized by a Congress that overlooked voting the money to pay for it, is on the way by freighter to Glendale, Calif., where it will decorate Forest Lawn Memorial Park.

FOR nearly forty years Arnold Schoenberg has been famous mainly as the bloody but unbowed advocate of a method of musical composition known as "atonality" or "the twelve-tone system" -- a method regarded by its adherents as music's equivalent of the Einstein theory, and by its detractors as a theoretically high-sounding but actually very simple recipe for systematic noise making.

Reorders of fall merchandise were received here last week by wholesale garment markets as apparel manufacturers started fall shipments, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey. Werring Howell Co., resident buying office.

Abandonment of plans for construction of a group of privately sponsored cooperative apartment buildings in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, designed to house 600 veterans and their families, was announced yesterday by Teel Williams, president of Basic Builders Corporation.

Student editors of The Columbia Jester let the non-collegiate public in last week on its special issue lampooning Life -- a "Loose Publication" -- when 5,000 second-run copies of the fifty-page parody were distributed and sold quickly at many of Manhattan's newsstands.

In Catherine Mackenzie's article, "Prejudice Can Be Unlearned," she refers to "this data," although during my college days I was admonished always to say "these data," since data is the plural of datum.

Graduate training in education beyond the master's degree has been placed on a cooperative basis by the School of Education of Indiana University and two state teachers colleges. Students who have received a master's degree in Education from Indiana State Teachers College or Ball State Teachers College may become approved candidates for the Doctor of Education degree at the university.
IN both vegetable and fruit gardens, a number of small but important jobs should be done this month. August chores often mean the difference between mediocre and outstanding food production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- More than two-thirds of the $3,094,000 in counterfeit American money seized in the 1947-48 fiscal year was made in Europe, the Secret Service reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- When Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov saw the envoys of the United States, Britain and France in Moscow last evening on the Berlin crisis, millions throughout the Western world sighed with relief. They did not and could not know anything except the bare fact that the representatives of the Big Four powers had talked.

The excellent critique by William Lescaze of the Princeton library in THE TIMES of July 31 ended with the phrase "to educate the educators." Rather than attempt that formidable task may I ask for a little space for a word to the educated.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 20 West Fortieth Street, will refuse to support a civil disobedience program in protest against segregation and discrimination in the armed forces, Walter F. White, its executive secretary, announced yesterday.

THE bride who presents vegetables for dinner in place of meat because she is trying to be thrifty may get anything but applause for her economy from her husband. There are few men -- and almost as few women -- who can be convinced that slice of eggplant equals a slice of steak.

IT is now ten years since the Munich crisis -- a crisis recognized both then and now as a turning point in modern history. At the time it aroused violent passions: Governments, parties, societies, even families were divided against themselves. I know houses in England where fathers sent for champagne to toast Mr. Chamberlain and sons refused to drink.

The Brazilian Government, like the United States, is concerned constantly with improving conditions among the working groups, while protecting free private initiative, Dr. Nerio Battendieri, adviser of the Brazilian Ministry of Labor, declared in a statement issued yesterday through the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, 551 Fifth Avenue.

A taxicab carrying passengers while its meter flag was up aroused the suspicions of two policemen at 5 A.M. yesterday in Brooklyn. As a result four men were jailed, booked on charges of assault and robbery and violation of the Sullivan Law.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Buddy Rogers of Larchmont, sailing Magic, completed a sweep today in the five-race Corry Trophy series to send that Star Class yachting prize back to Long Island Sound, where it spent the last year in possession of Hilary Smart, currently an Olympic skipper.
NANKING, Aug. 7 -- More than 3,000,000 Chinese are homeless as a result of floods in China's three major river basins and at least 1,000,000 tons of rice were lost, according to official estimates.

THERE are hearty Walt-O-Pioneers-Sandburg poems that slap you on the back and there are coy Saint-Emily-Dickinson-Millay poems that put up their pretty little mouths to be kissed. But the main activity of Miss Cruickshank's hothouse of sensitive plants is to wince.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Gallorette, who is called "Old Mom" in the William L. Brann barn, and Trainer Ed Christmas, who answers to the tag of "Old Honesty," were back together in the winner's circle at Saratoga today for the second time in four days.

THE plan for a life of Rupert Brooke may have begun to take shape in the mind of that glorious adventurer, Richard Halliburton, as early as the days when, as Lawrenceville schoolboy and Princeton undergraduate, he first succumbed to Brooke's sub-romantic spell, and joined that magical name to those of Byron and Richard Coeur de Lion in his adolescent book of heroes.

NEITHER Peter nor Penny, those foster-brothers who have appeared in earlier stories by Miss Haywood, were enthusiastic at first about going to camp. Penny was converted by the promise of knowing a genuine Indian chief, and so began a summer of new adventures, of the kind that small boys love to recall long afterward.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- The United States, France and Britain have submitted a new draft of a convention on the gathering and international transmission of news to the Committee on Human Rights of the Economic and Social Council.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Americans might keep their heads better during the present war of nerves if they realized that the Bolshevik revolution of 1917 failed to produce a "new kind of man" in Russia, Professor Thomas A. Bailey of Stanford University told a conference of history teachers today on the Stanford campus.

New disclosures in the Congressional investigation of Communist party spy activities are expected at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow when Alexander Koral, a new key witness, takes the stand at a public hearing before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Credit the Democrats with a chance to regain control of the United States Senate in the November election. A good many leading Republicans do, even though they say it is an outside chance.

BUSINESS circles watched the anti-inflation moves in Congress last week, but questioned the effectiveness of steps to restrict installment credit and raise bank reserves. It was felt that they would hardly prove more than mild correctives in view of the basic monetary and governmental factors still creating inflation.

IF you ask the ordinary theatre-goer to name some top-notch Broadway directors, he can probably think of quite a few: Elia Kazan, Joshua Logan and Jed Harris among the older group, Mary Hunter and John O'Shaughnessy among the newcomers.

Fifteen high-speed centers are being built by the Western Union Company to switch telegrams at high speed to the right offices and so to their destinations. The first of these switching centers was formally dedicated last week in Boston. Like all the unfinished others it does away with the retransmission of telegrams by hand.

Since the article on civil rights appeared in THE TIMES Magazine on June 13, 1948 ("Created Equal?" by Herbert Mitgang), the town of Montclair has improved its position in this controversial field. The article helped to allay lingering doubts held by persons of influence in the community who had questioned the validity of a civil rights audit.

AN improved model of the Cine-Kodak Special 16 mm motion picture camera is announced by Kodak. The Model II, priced at $860 plus tax, is equipped with the new Kodak Cine Ektar 25 mm f/1.4 lens and features a new type of lens turret.

BOSTON, Aug., 7 (AP) -- In his third attempt, big Johnny Sain tonight pitched his fourteenth victory fon the National League leading Braves, who snapped out of the doldrums they have been in for a week and defeated the tail end Chicago Cub, 6 -- 3, before 20,028 fans.

Last week furnished further evidence of how insurance companies are using their funds in financing industrial organizations by direct negotiations with the borrowing companies rather than through subscriptions for new securities in the investment banking market.

Retail activity here last week was slowed up by rainy weather, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Fall coat, suit and college sportswear departments reported pre-season activity.

A new 15,000-ton luxury liner, designed especially for pleasure cruise service, has been ordered by Furness-Withy Co., for use in the New York-Bermuda run and also for special trips, according to an announcement last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Assignments of conversion jobs on thirty-three warships to Navy yards were announced tonight by the Navy Department.

PATRICK "PARKEY" RADIGAN, the tavern owner who closed the beer taps in his bar and invited the neighborhood children in to view television, is glad it's all over. His sponsorship of a "Children's Hour" in a saloon may have attracted nation-wide attention, but it also completely upset Parkey's manner and mode of living.
Your recent editorial, "Stumping the Scientists," was interesting in so far as it pointed out the inadequacies of present-day biology.

METROPOLITAN New York will have its sixth television station on Tuesday, when the American Broadcasting Company opens its New York outlet, WJZ-TV, on Channel 7. As befits the occasion, the network has arranged an elaborate program for its premiere, the proceedings being scheduled to run from 7 P.M. until near midnight.

ATHENS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Greek army troops hammered both flanks of a thirty-mile semicircular front in the Grammos Mountains today, pushing the Communist guerrillas closer to the Albanian border, a communique said.

Whatever the practical purport of Alexander Meiklejohn's commentary on free speech ("Everything Worth Saying Should Be Said"), his historical references certainly require correction. The "clear-and-present-danger" rule was not thrust upon the Court's attention for years by Justices Holmes and Brandeis with the idea of curbing freedom of speech and press but with exactly the opposite intention.

FORTY-FOUR posed portraits of famous men, which have the quality of candid impressions, are on view at the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center, through August. The work of Editta Sherman, who specializes in men's portraits, the photographs were made with a long-focus lens for truthful perspective, were lighted with soft illumination to retain texture and character, and were exposed at about 1/50th of a second to record a fleeting expression.

FOR the Negro one of the most frustrating characteristics, of life in America is that the white-dominated schools, movies and radio induce him to adopt the goals of the "American dream," while the realities of segregation and discrimination demonstrate at every turn that the dream is labeled "for whites only."

No recession in general business activity is likely as a result of any decline in capital expenditures for new plants and equipment, according to an analysis, completed last week by Management Planning of Washington, Inc., 20 Pine Street, New York.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 7 -- Ambassador Cavendish Cannon, chief United States delegate to the Danubian Conference, withdrew today the United States draft convention and accepted as a basis for discussion the Soviet proposals submitted by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Another important inboard regatta for small runabouts as well as for the super-powered Gold Cup class has been inserted into a summer schedule already bulging with a crowded program of race meets which sometimes find conflicting competitions on the limited number of week-ends.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Gov. Thomas J. Herbert of Ohio flew to this city from Columbus today to make another attempt to end the ninety-five-day-old strike at the plant of the Univis Lens Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman lost his anti-inflation battle with Congress today when the Senate passed by a voice vote the limited Republican-sponsored bill to curb inflationary pressures.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Five Detroit errors -- three of them by Shortstop Johnny Lipon -- counted heavier than the thirteen walks issued by two Washington pitchers today as the Senators wrung out a 3-to-2 victory over the Tigers in ten innings.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Carrying every foot of canvas they could spread, the racing creations of the New York Yacht Club arrived here today from Mattapoisett, over on Buzzards Bay.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- A plan to accelerate Italian reconstruction and provide employment for several hundred thousand workers was approved by the Cabinet today after two consecutive days of morning and afternoon sittings. The plan, the details of which will be published later, will be financed out of the lira fund created with the proceeds of the sale of European Recovery Program aid to Italy.

I WRITE to you, drunk with Cyprus. Nothing can be worthier of either gods or demigods; and if, as you say, Achilles did not drink of it, I am sorry for him. I suppose Jupiter had it instead, just then -- Hebe pouring it, and Juno's ox-eyes bellowing their splendor at it, if you will forgive me that broken metaphor, for the sake of Aeschylus's genius, and my own particular intoxication.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- S. Garton Churchill and Cecil Head, who had taken a commanding lead in the first rounds of the Masters Pair Championship in the American Contract Bridge League tournament here, maintained their lead tonight and virtually sewed up the championship. Their score was 620 points.

After World War I the first Communist party in the United States came into being. (There were no Communist parties anywhere, outside of Russia, before the close of that war.) The American party grew out of a left-wing secession from the Socialist party.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Margaret Osborne Dupont of Wilmington, Del., won their way into tomorrow's singles final, then teamed to reach the women's doubles final in the Maidstone Club's women's invitation tennis tournament today.

In an article to be published in its Monday issue The Law Journal will hold that the vacancy in the Supreme Court caused by the death of Justice Lloyd Church occurred on Aug. 2, even though his death at a point west of the International date line took place on Aug. 3, and that the vacancy must be filled at this year's election on Nov. 2.

TO commemorate the "Transmision del Mando y Homage al Pynandy" ("Transfer of Power and Homage to the Pynan dy")Paraguay will release special stamps on Aug. 15, the date when Juan Natalicio Gonzalez succeeds Higinio Morinigo as President.

The Police Department began on Friday a canvass of all stores selling milk at retail to determine the prices being paid for various grades and any price variations, it was learned yesterday at Police Headquarters.
BANGKOK, Siam, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The public prosecutor was ordered today to begin criminal proceedings against five persons in connection with the mysterious death of former King Ananda Mahidol.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Justice Lee B. Wyatt of the Georgia Supreme Court said that Communists in the United States should be loaded on a ship, with Henry A. Wallace as pilot, and pushed off toward Russia.

It is a truism that one of the most effective of all defenses against inflation is a high rate of production. But, like most generalizations, this one is subject to certain qualifications. For example, if increased production is inefficient production, or high unit cost production, its effects so far as rising prices are concerned may be largely or completely nullified.
I would like to commend Aline Louchheim for her article, "The ABC (or XYZ) of Abstract Art:" Articles of this sort help breach the gulf between artists and the public.
The shadows were lengthening yesterday at the Polo Grounds and opportunity was beckoning in the direction of the Giants.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Samuel Jackson Snead caught the scent of the Tam O'Shanter money trail today and raced to a 6 under par 66 for a 3-stroke lead among a dozen pros gunning for a winner-take-all pot of $10,000.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- The Soviet Union has asked the Italian Government to accelerate the delivery of warships that Italy must cede to Russia according to the terms of the Italian peace treaty. Moscow declared that to obtain early delivery it was ready to forego the article of the peace treaty that obligated Italy to put the ships into "perfect efficiency."

A pilgrimage to Rome and Lourdes by 600 Roman Catholics, including more than sixty prelates and priests, will start when the pilgrims board the Queen Mary next Friday night, it was announced yesterday. A special train will bring 500 New England pilgrims from Boston next Friday afternoon, to be joined by more than 100 from elsewhere in the United States.

WEMBLEY, England, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The American swimmers, men and women carried off twelve Olympic crowns, including an eight-event sweep of the men's competition and four of seven in the women's division.

WASHINGTON -- The motorized tourists who have been crowding into the national parks this summer need no statistical reports to confirm their suspicions that there are more vacationists in the parks this year than the park concessions can comfortably handle.
Columbia University will conduct a study of financial difficulties of most hospitals for the New York State Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The pre-election extra session of Congress, having denied to President Truman all but the merest fraction of the complex program he had sought, came tonight to a quarrelsome end.

TORONTO -- The second post-war Canadian National Exhibition will open at Toronto for two weeks on Aug. 27. This is always a major attraction for American visitors, as evidenced by the thousands of American cars parked on the grounds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Allen Gettel pitched a four-hitter against the Red Sox in sparking the Chicago White Sox to a 5-1 victory over the fourth placers here today. It was Chicago's second straight victory over the contenders from Boston.

IT is difficult to plot our position today in aeronautics and more so to project it into the future. In his nicely titled "Frontiers of Flight," George W. Gray has done that, and more. Mr. Gray, of the Rockefeller Foundation and author of "Science at War" and other books, has made the vision beyond today's cloudy horizons understandable to the reader of average intelligence and only a "gentleman's knowledge" of the sciences.

Phlox means "flame" in the original Greek, and it flames now in gardens all over America. Perhaps it is because the season is slow this year, but the phlox seems more than usually brilliant up through central New England, up Connecticut Valley way and into the old mountains that rise from the Berkshires north.

THERE is no cheering yet on the Hollywood barricades, and sound fiscal sources in the film industry claim the box office is still 6.6 per cent below normal, but Federal admissions tax figures announced last week indicate a change for the better.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Official and unofficial Washington has been profoundly shocked by the week's allegations of espionage within the Government brought out by simultaneous investigating committees in the House and Senate.

ATHENS, Aug. 7 -- Military sources said tonight that according to information obtained from rebel war prisoners Gen. Markos Vafiades, accompanied by members of his "government" had escaped into Albania from the Grammos area, his last stronghold in Greece.

Confirming an order to the S.W. Shattuck Company of Denver for uranium nitrate and uranium oxide shipped to Russia five years ago, the Chemitar Corporation of 40 Exchange Place, New York, stated yesterday through its general counsel, Manfred Wolkiser, that the purchase was made "with the full knowledge and approval of the appropriate government agencies."

FOR the past twenty years Michel Simon has tried without success to swallow the frog in his throat. "I sing off key but I hear correctly," the French film star declares, paradoxically expressing his own philosophy.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- While there was no room for candles, Mrs. Miles Perry, best known to friends and relatives as "Aunt Emely," enjoyed the traditional birthday cake and ice cream when she observed her 107th birthday today at nearby Adams Corners.

Most of the fourteen corporations operating buses at a five-cent fare under franchise grants from the city began yesterday the task of preparing higher fare tariffs to be filed next week with the Public Service Commission.

A group of more than 100 eminent churchmen, sailing from this city last Friday, represented America's participation in the first assembly of the World Council of Churches, to be held in Amsterdam. Aug. 22 to Sept. 4. Three-fifths of Christendom will be represented by laymen and clergy from 148 Protestant and Orthodox churches in forty-three countries.
MOST gardeners seldom get more than one or two pickings of cucumbers before the quality of this vegetable becomes so poor as to be of little use, or the vines may die completely.

IN terms of its permanent collection, a small museum is like a little restaurant. It cannot have an extensive a la carte menu: if it does, its offerings are apt to be tasteless. But it can concentrate on one group of specialties; it may even achieve its unique personality by featuring regional cooking.

DENVER, Aug. 7 -- The "petticoat rebellion" against high meat prices reminds the Western stockman of the thunder and lightning that booms and rolls over the mountains and horizons of the range land. It's a mighty good show, but produces only a few drops of rain.

So much of Europe's history and so much of Europe's future are bound up with the Danube that the world naturally is keeping a sharp eye on the Belgrade conference where delegates of ten nations are working on a new charter for control of the river.

Russia's Andrei A. Vishinsky spent last Sunday boating and swimming in the Danube at Belgrade, Yugoslavia. Sun-tanned and refreshed from his outing, he spent the rest of the week attending meetings of a ten-power conference in Belgrade on the future of the Danube.

Theft losses on interior parts of locked automobiles being exported by one of the largest American manufacturers have been traced to the company's practice of putting an extra set of keys under one of the fenders, it was reported here yesterday.

WITH the opening of New York International Airport, in Queens, the fleet of seventy-five airport limousines and buses, operated by Carey Airport Service, now runs three ways from the Air Lines Terminal Building in West Forty-second Street.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- United States policy on Germany is undergoing its most critical test since the end of the war. Here in Berlin and in Western Germany it is undergoing the double strain of simultaneously fending off Soviet measures to win control of Berlin and of establishing a new German state in the American, British and French zones of occupation.

Complications arising out of misunderstandings as to the applicability of the New York City sales tax have brought into question the city's right to double recovery of the tax from the purchaser as well as from the seller.

A MAINE week-end is no longer an impossibility for New York motorists, thanks to modern motor parkways that make driving through heavily populated New England a pleasant experience instead of a traffic-ridden nightmare.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today accused the Republican Congress of making a record of inaction at the extra session. And he added that Governor Dewey, by his silence, had forfeited his right to discuss most issues of the Presidential campaign.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- Striking hard and fast behind a dazzling four-hit shutout by big Vic Raschi, the Yankees today bounced right back into the thick of the American League's dizzy pennant race by downing Lou Boudreau's Indians in the second encounter of the current four-game series by a score of 5 to 0.

HINTS of the future in aviation, made visible this week at New York International Airport, are both terrifying and satisfying. These portents, witnessed by more people than ever before, are terrifying proof of the reach and deadliness of our two air arms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, Michigan, today raised the question of impeachment of President Truman by Congress. He declared in a speech in the Senate that "Congress is rapidly being pushed into the intolerable position of having either to legislate through a blind spot or compel the President to answer for his conduct in an impeachment proceeding."

Dr. Jesse Donald Stark, director of radiology of Gouverneur Hospital, has been named expert civilian consultant to the Surgeon General in the occupied European zone, it was announced yesterday. He wil! devote a nonth to visiting United States hospitals in Germany and Austria.

For the fifteenth consecutive year the American Merchant Marine conference will be held in conjunction with the annual convention of the Propeller CIub of the United States. The organizations are scheduled to convene on Oct. 13, 14 and 15.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 -- The rush of fabricators to Pittsburgh that many here expected following the change to f.o.b. steel selling has not yet materialized. Mills and civic bodies are still receiving inquiries but many are said to be based on the immediate hope of getting larger steel tonnages.

Law-respecting citizens who have shuddered at the prospect of receiving a speeding ticket will get an intimate look at the ugliness of crime at the Golden Anniversary Exposition in Grand Central Palace from Aug. 23 through Sept. 19.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Expectation of a record corn crop this year has resulted in creating decidedly bearish sentiment with the September inclined to lose ground at times compared with December.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 -- The Yankees' dash through the West, which they had hoped would sweep them into first place by nightfall, crashed in complete disaster today as the Bombers dropped both ends of their double-header with the Indians before a roaring crowd of 73, 484.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- This week's returns of the Bank of England made history in more senses than one. Not only did they include for the first time a sterling counterpart of dollars allotted to Britain to date under the Marshall Plan but it made known a fall in the ratio of reserves to liabilities to only 2.9 per cent, which is the lowest on record.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary for air, and Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Forces, arrived here today to inspect the fighting units based in Europe and the American Air transport organization engaged in supplying Berlin.
TASIKMALAJA, West Java, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Netherland forces have been struggling for nearly six months to crush an outlaw Moslem state-within-a-state in West Java.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The unbroken string of American victories in the men's swimming events at the Olympic Games, twelve swimming and diving titles that are crossing the Atlantic westward to rest on American shores till the next games in 1952 -- and our unchallenged supremacy in the high and low diving have, in the eyes of the United States swimming coaches, put the American tank stars in a somewhat embarrassing position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -The Department of Labor reported today that at least 3,000,000 American workers were covered by health-pension insurance contracts with their employers. This represents a large increase, being five times the 600,000 so protected in collective bargaining contracts in 1945.

SOUTH Orange, N. J., Aug. 8 -James Brink of Seattle, only American seeded player to see action today in the men's singles of the twenty-second Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club weathered stubborn resistance by Charlie Masterson of Brooklyn to win 10 -- 8, 7 -- 5.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 8 (UP) - Univis Lens Company officials rejected today a proposal which would have ended the 96-day strike by the United Electrical Workers. CIO.

Motivated by laudable ideals, the New Stagers are averse to resting on their oars. Since last February, when they first offered "The Respectful Prostitute," the group has been switching the curtain raiser to the Jean-Paul Sartre play. Originally it was Lennox Robinson's "Church Street," which gave way to Thornton Wilder's play with the elongated title of "The Happy Journey to Camden and Trenton."

The international air show marking the city's golden jubilee closed yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in a blaze of glory, tinged with Navy blue and gold. Officially it was Navy Day, with many high officers from Washington flying in to sit in the stands.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Russiancontrolled press reported today strong punitive measures agaist food hoarders in the Russian occupation zone. Prison sentences are being dealt to farmers and distributors who conceal their stocks or divert them into the black market.

The first public demonstration in history of the actual explosion of uranium atoms, in the process known as fission, will be staged here soon, it was learned yesterday. It will take place at Columbia University's exhibit at New York's Golden Jubilee Exposition in Grand Central Palace, which will be open from Aug. 23 to Sept. 19.

WARSAW, Aug. 8 -- The Communist leadership today turned the inaugural ceremonies of the International Conference of Working Youth, billed as a nonpolitical congress to draft a charter of youth rights, into an enthusiastic, proRussian and anti-West demonstration.
TOKYO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A struggle between Communists and moderates in union locals delayed the expected development of the Japanese national labor crisis today.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 8 -Bathing in the ocean in a one-mile area between Tennessee and Lafayette Boulevards here, was prohibited temporarily today by an order of the Nassau County Health Board.

Despite previous forecasts of a steady decline in enrollment, registrars of the city's four municipal colleges estimated yesterday that a new peak of 29,150 students would jam the already overcrowded day session classrooms next month at City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges.

Prices in the domestic cotton market again, moved lower last week with spot prices reduced the: most. At the close on Friday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 13 to 43 points below the final levels of the previous week.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 8--Spontaneous demonstrations of dissatisfaction with swiftly spiraling prices broke out all over the bizonal area last week and less spontaneous, but greater ones, are being planned for this week. In some cases the police had to be called to preserve order in market places as outraged women attacked the food sellers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The resignation of Irving R. Kaufman as special assistant to the Attorney General was announced today. He will return to his New York law firm, Noonan, Kaufman Eagan, 48 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A subcommittee reported to Congressh)0*0*0*itoday what its chairman called "a startling story of waste inefficiency and negligence" in Government auditing of war-time freight charges.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 8 (AP)--An Italian search party pressed today toward the wreckage of a United States Air Force C-47 transport plane lost eight months ago on an Alpine peak near the French-Italian border.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser became the American League's first fifteen-game winner and Billy Pierce, rookie left-hander, started and won his first game in the nightcap as the Tigers took a double-header from the Senators today, 5 to 3 and 6 to 5.

The first two volumes of a sixvolume biography of George Washington by Douglas Southall Freeman will be published by Scribners on Oct. 15. "Young Washington" will cover the background and youth of Washington and his militaryh)0*0*0*ischooling in the French and Indian Wars, terminating in 1758.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8 -Rolling in a twelve-foot putt for a birdie 3 that decided the match, Ed Vaughan was showered with congratulations tonight as he and Winged Foot partner, Bill Schappa, won the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament by defeating Ray Billows, metropolitan amateur champion, and Wesley Van Benschoten of Poughkeepsie, 1 up at the thirty-sixth hole.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--A union that was guilty of "feather-bedding" has reimbursed an employer for the first time.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Maurice J. Tobin, former Governor of Massachusetts, and one-time Mayor of Boston, said today that he had not accepted his nomination by President Truman as Secretary of Labor, and still was a gubernatorial candidate in the Bay State.

More than 150,000 organized consumers and tenants in this City will join in the nation-wide fight against high prices by supporting a boycott meat week here beginning today, Paul L. Ross, chairman of the New York Tenant Councils of Rent and Housing, announced yesterday.

Ninety-one Venezuelan naval officers, midshipmen and naval cadets attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. They were accompanied by Julio Pocaterra, Consul General of Venezuela in New York, and Comdr. Pablo Bonilla of the training ship Capana, aboard which they arrived here last week in the course of their annual cruise.

LONDON, Aug. 8 - The reply of the three Western powers to the latest Russian proposition on Berlin and on four power consultations has already gone to Moscow, it was learned today. It is expected here that the envoys will see Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov again tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -Easy Washing Machine Corporation reported today net earnings ofh) 0*0*0*i$1,470,056 for the first half of this year, compared to $1,170,075 during the same period in 1947.

Six months of negotiations between Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, and the Publishers Association of New York City were capped yesterday by the union's acceptance, by a membership vote of 609 to 414, of a contract bringing an increase of $9 weekly for composing room workers on twelve local daily newspapers.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The United States will support the application of Israel for membership in the United Nations, a spokesman for the United States delegation disclosed today.

August brings us dusty roadsides, katydids, goldenrod, blackberry cobbler, grasshoppers' staccato notes and showers of shooting stars. There are only a few desultory bird songs at dawn. Bobwhites occasionally toss their names into the moist, sticky air; phoebes sit on the telephone wires above farmyards and flip their tails as they answer the roll-call.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- A Violent storm swept the south and east coasts of England early today with boiling seas, wrenching dozens of small boats from their moorings. Waves smashed over seafronts at holiday resorts now at the height of their summer season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Grist for the political mill towered high over legislative accomplishments as the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress, recalled by Presidenth)0*0*0*iTruman on July 26, headed for home today after putting in ten working days on the broad domestic program he asked.

Landon of Kansas said in an address here tonight that the inconsistent pattern of American foreign policies and our steadily accelerating drift to an inflationary smash over a long period of years were playing squarely into the hands of the Communists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- S. Garton Churchill of Great Neck, L.I., and Cecil Head of New York won the masters' pair championship, most highly rated of all contests open to contract bridge experts, in the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-second annual tournament here today, with the highest score ever recorded for the event.
