One of the world's most famous Catholic abbeys, Maria Einsiedeln, located not far from Lake Zurich, Switzerland, in the scenic village of Einsiedeln, next month is to observe its 1,000-year anniversary. Of all the stories told about the historic abbey, none is more notable than the claim that Christ Himself consecrated the Abbey Church built by the first Abbot Eberhard over the cell of St. Meinrad, in 948 A. D.

Pointing out that a cooling off period will be needed to permit Cuban importers and manufacturers to settle differences of opinion concerning foreign textiles, William De Min, president of the Textile Export Association of the United States, urged that the Cuban Government suspend its restrictions for ninety days.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 8 (AP -With a pair of last-inning homers the Newark Bears continued to exercise their jinx over the Syracuse Chiefs by sweeping a double-header today, 5 to 4 and 2 to 1. It was the Bears' twelfth victory in fourteen games against the Chiefs this year.h)

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Stalled on disarmament and atomic control, United Nations delegations are expected to sidestep Secretary General Trygve Lie's suggestion for studying the elimination of bacteriological and chemical weapons.

NANKING, Aug. 8 -- The Government's numerical superiority over the Communist forces declined from a three-to-one ratio to twoto-one in the first six months of 1948, the National Defense Ministry announced today.

WARSAW, Aug. 8 -- Poland and Czechoslovakia have completed their plans to build a huge industrial center rivaling the Ruhr in the area between Katowice in southwestern Poland and Ostrava, Czechoslovakia. The plans were disclosed with the publication yesterday of a communique on the meeting of the Polish-Czechoslovak Economic Cooperation Council.

Iron and steel workers in the Urals and the Eastern region of the Soviet Union have reported in a letter to Premier Stalin big increases in steel production and have given pledges of still greater ones, according to Soviet press reports just received in this country.

RHODES, Aug. 8 - Arab and Israeli authorities alike in Palestine fear that the extremist Irgun Zvai Leumi is planning a surprise attack that may disrupt all truce and mediation efforts, it is learned from a reliable source.

Approximately $1,900,000 of Government surplus goods in 350 lots comprising 1,767 items will be offered for sale to commercial buyers on Monday, Aug. 16, in a spot bid sale at the WAA Customer Service Center, Eastchester Road and Haswell Street in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) The refusal of the Senate Republican leadership to confirm any of President Truman's appointments at the extra session affects hundreds of Federal officials, including a new Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities determined today to subpoena a desired witness sequestered in the Soviet consulate in New York, in pursuit of its investigation into Communist espionage rings, provided that the State Department ruled the step proper under international law.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- The back-alley war of abduction, political blackmail and threats now raging in Berlin has taken a more serious turn in the last twenty-four hours with the arrest by the Russianmanaged police of a number of policemen serving in the forces of the Western sectors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Luke Appling's eleventh-inning fly scored Floyd Baker with the winning run as the White Sox defeated the Red Sox, 2 -- 1, today in the second game of a double-header after losing the opener, 8 -- 1. Baker's run gave Chicago the series, three games to one.

An adaptation of the new FoodO-Mat vending fixtures is being planned for use in wholesale warehouses that handle orders of less than case lots, it was learned over the week-end. The wholesale fixtures, it was said, will be proportionately larger, but will work on the same gravity-feed principle as the retail fixtures.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 8 -Israelis and Arabs may reach agreement soon on the "demilitarization" of Jerusalem, it was confidentially disclosed tonight. The plan, said to have been approved by the Arabs, proposes demilitarization of a wide area around the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) -The St. Louis Cardinals stemmed a ninth-inning rally by the Philadelphia Phillies today to beat the Phils, 4 -- 3, in the second game of a double-header after taking the opener, 4 -- 1. Stan Musial blasted out his twenty-seventh homer of the season to help the Cards gain undisputed possession of second place.

Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, a teacher in a Soviet school here, whom the Russian Government desires to send home, placed himself under the protection of the United States early today and asked that he be judged by American public opinion.

In spite of the thousands of miles of trouble-free driving that most motorists experience each year, the American Automobile Association estimates that cars were stalled a total of 37,260,000 times during 1947, as compared with 36,204,000 in 1946. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 8 -- The United States delegation stands today at the crossroads of decision with the Danubian Conference entering its eleventh day. The problem facing the Americans is how much longer they can continue to discuss the Soviet draft proposal.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The deadening effect on financial activity of the tense international situation has been seen during the last weekh)0*0*0*iin a decline in Stock Exchange business to its lowest level in three and a half years, although no animation could be expected right in the depths of the holiday season.

A fouryear program for extending its television operations into more than eighty cities was announced here.yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, The CBS video network now links five cities -- New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington.

The Right Rev. John T. Dallas, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, declared yesterday morning that "once-again the church is in the process of bringing the world into unity." He spoke at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Grain markets staged a late but strong rally on the Board of Trade last week. It was preceded by bearish professional sentiment that resulted in general selling at times, with May wheat and all deliveries of corn, oats, rye and soy beans at new seasonal lows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -Senator Clyde R. Hoey of North Carolina today accused Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, of "a political tirade" in talking last night of impeaching President Truman for refusing to turn over to Congress loyalty records in the spy inquiry.

First details of a complete tenpoint employe communications plan for management executives in steel plants were revealed here last week by officials of leading industrial plants where the program of the American Iron and Steel Institute is now being installed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A marked improvement in the demand for lard, especially loose, featured the lard market on the Board of Trade last week. Leading distributors reportedh)0*0*0*ithat the usual improvement in the demand had occurred much sooner than anticipated and with a light make and indications that receipts of hogs would continue relatively small for some time to come the market advanced rapidly.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Manufacturers of air-conditioning equipmenth)0*0*0*iexpect to achieve a record-breaking business volume of $235,000,000 this year, industry spokesmen said today. Commercial installations account for a majority of the sales, but small self-contained units for home or office use are registering the largest percentage gain.

This city's horse population is going down fast, but is not yet out, a survey showed yesterday. The chief threat to Dobbin's city life is the high cost of horse living.

LENOX, Mass. Aug. 8 -- Eleazar de Carvalho conducted this afternoon's concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood. He is the second of Koussevitzky's conductor pupils to share the podium with his master during this festival.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Boomh)0*0*0*igrowth on the Pacific Coast led the United States to an estimated population total of 143,414,000 in 1947, a rise of 8.9 per cent since the 1940 census.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 8 - Dutch trade and financial circles generally believe that the composition of the new Cabinet of six Catholic, five Socialist and two Center party Ministers will make a shift to the right unavoidable, especially in economic and financial matters and possibly also in the attitude toward the Indonesian question.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The margin between revenue and expenses of the country's transit companies last year was the smallest in sixteen years, the American Transit Association said today in its annual publication, Transit Fact Book.

Percentage increases in basement sales are gradually shrinking in local department stores, basement merchandise managers disclosed last week. They explained that the spread between main store and basement store increases over last year is becoming narrower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -United States aid to European nations under the Marshall Plan passed the $1,000,000,000 mark tonight, with this country footing part of the bill for four new DC-6 aircraft for Norway and Denmark.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Unseeded Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles today won his first grass court tennis tournament with a 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3 victory over Budge Patty, also of Los Angeles, in the final of the fifty-eighth annual Meadow Club invitation event.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, gaining six strokes in eighteen holes with a record 63; Dutch Harrison. a 64-shooter, and Sam Snead with a 69, ended in a three-way tie today for George S. May's $10,000 winner-take-all golf pot.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A fourrun uprising in the seventh featuring a two-run double by Hank Majeski helped the Philadelphia Athletics to a 7-5 verdict over the St. Louis Browns today. Pitcher Dick Fowler, the winner although he needed help, hit his first homer of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 -- The triumph of a 29year-old Buenos Aires fireman, Delfo Cabrera, in the Olympic marathon brought reminders in the Government press today that he was a member of the Peronista party.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 8 -- There will be plenty of elbowroom for the 1,000 persons who are expected to turn out on the afternoon of Aug. 25 for the second annual dessert card party for the benefit of Mather Memorial Hospital, here, it was reported today by the general committee, headed by Mrs. A. Bernard Shea of Stony Brook.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Boston's National League leading Braves choked off a ninth-inning rally today and defeated the last place Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 3, before an overflow "Appreciation Day" crowd of 41,527, third largest paid attendance in the history of Braves Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -The United States is trying to find a way to settle the conflicting territorial claims made on the Antarctic Continent by at least seven nations, a State Department spokesman said today.

Nine staff members of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday their resignations from committee postsh)0*0*0*iwith the American Labor party, declaring that they had quit "under duress" in compliance with a resolution adopted by the local's executive board on July 30.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- Beneath the taut surface of life in this blockaded city, along the streets through which only a trickle of traffic rolls, Berlin housewives are maintaining their homes with a maximum of effort and a minimum of panic.

Earl C. Erickson has been appointed commercial sales manager of W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company, Fort Madison, Iowa. Formerly district manager of the commercial division, he succeeds Ned Fish, who resigned.

The board of directors of the American Bosch Corporation has been increased from seven to nine members and new directors have been named to replace those who resigned following Amra Corporation's acquisition from the Office of Alien Property of the controling stock interest in American Bosch, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -By extracting portions of Jerome Weidman's 1941 novel, "I'll Never Go There Anymore," Sol C. Siegel, producer at Twentieth Century-Fox studio, expects to develop a screen melodrama concerning itself largely with the rise and fall of an Italian banking family in New York.

ATHENS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A General Staff spokesman said today that the Greek Army was carrying the battle relentlessly to the retreating guerrilla forces of Gen. Markos Vafiaqes along the entire Grammos Mountain front.

The Kuhmarker Waxed Paper Company has leased the three-story building at 185-93 Sumner Avenue, corner of Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn, from Rosoff Friedman for ten years at a gross rental of $200,000. The lessee, now at 60 Broadway, Brooklyn, plans to occupy the building after extensive alterations have been completed.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 8 (P)--State Police continued into thethirdday today their drive tosmash upstate New York's lotteryracket.' They raided today the"nerve center" of theorganizationin this city.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The track and field Games of the XIV Olympiad, which closed yesterday before 83,000 spectators in Wembley Stadium, ran strikingly true to form. The United States, with ten first places in the men's division, five seconds and nine thirds, maintained the supremacy it has enjoyed since the modern revival of the Olympics in 1896, though it won two fewer championships than it had at Berlin in 1936.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 8 - In his first major political address since his nomination for the Vice Presidency, Gov. Earl Warren today extolled what he described as an unprecedented spirit of harmony among erstwhile rivals in the Republican party, auguring victory in November.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 -- Jack Kroll, national director of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told 1,400 delegates at a rally opening the campaign of the Ohio PAC today that to "defeat its enemies" labor would "get out 60,000,000 votes."

Featured by a wide range of articles designed to meet American tastes, the second annual exhibition of Christmas giftwares will open today at the House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Fortyninth Street. Msgr Charles E. Fitzgerald, pastor for the last six years of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family, New Rochelle, N.Y., and vice president of the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Riverdale section of New York, has been reappointed as the Spiritual Director of the North American College, Rome.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Montreal won a doubleheader from Jersey City today before 16,747 fans, taking the opener, 8 -- 1 and the nightcap, 3 -- 2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP) -Nearly complete unofficial returns from yesterday's Kentucky primary election showed Virgil Chapman, veteran United States Representative from Paris, the winner of the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 -John Potter's International Wisp, Patrick O'Gorman's Star Wahini, Willy Olsen's S craft Woodcock, H. H. Koehler's 110 Seadown and Agnew Fisher's Luders 16 Spree were among the winners today in the Y. R. A. championship regatta run by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Parnell Thomas.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 8 - Bus service was resumed late this afternoon on the lines of the Beach Transit Corporation after representatives of the twenty-eight drivers, maintenance men and supervisors, who had been on strike since Wednesday noon, and the management signed an agreement to submit the issues to arbitration.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman signed yesterday an order staying the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, from interfering with the American Broadcasting Company's first broadcast over its New York television station, WJZ-TV, tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 9 (AP) -- It was a sad day for form players today at the opening of the Atlantic City race track.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Officials of the International Refugee Organization have rejected an informal request by the Arab League that the IRO assume responsibility for Palestinian Arabs who have left their homes in Israeli-controlled territory, it was learned today.

Beatrice Walsh, 6 years old, a pretty, dark-haired child, was killed yesterday morning in the street outside her home at 79 Sutton Street, Brooklyn. She died after plunging from the neighborhood ice truck as the driver, unaware that Beatrice and a playmate were seated on the running board, started the vehicle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -Allocation of Federal funds to the states for mental health activities was announced today by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 Grain markets made a weak close on the Board of Trade today after showing fair strength early. Liquidation developed after announcement of an unexpectedly large cotton crop and, with support less aggressive than late last week, closing trades were about the bottom, corn leading.

Wage increases have been general throughout industry in the Middle Atlantic States and not confined to a few industries during the third round of increases since the war. This was indicated by a tabulation of general wage changes in May and June made public yesterday by the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --h)0*0*0*iThe full eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission has given Gen. Douglas MacArthur permission to sell whatever looted property in Japan remains unidentified.

An extensive campaign, using Sunday magazine color pages, black-and-white newspaper space and spot radio, will be started on Aug. 22 by the Glass Container Manufacturers' Institute to promote the no-deposit, one-way beer bottle, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Wood, the Institute's director of marketing.

I am astonished that Phelps Phelps should take issue with your editorial position regarding Federal aid for schools. Mr. Phelps apparently holds the views of many who do not take the trouble of a little thought. He presents some arguments for the passage of the Taft bill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The interest rate on short-term Government securities will be raised as "a further anti-inflationary move," John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, Aug. 9 -- The glittering success of American athletes in track and field and in swimming and diving in the Games of the XIV Olympiad was extended today when the Golden Bears of the University of California won the eight-oared championship, blue ribbon event of the rowing regatta on the Thames River.

Nathaniel and Hyman Roven sold the two-story commercial building at 89-15 162d Street, Jamaica, Queens, to the Highgate Realty Corporation. The Property occupies an irregular plot about 60 by 127 feet and is assessed at $31,000.

Because of rising costs and expanded service, hospitals in the United States spent $2,354,344,000 last year to provide care for nearly 18,000,000 bed patients, it was made known yesterday by the American Hospital Association. The 1948 American Hospital Directory, compiled and published by the association, also showed that hospitals in 1947 had total assets of $6,000,000,000 -- approximately $42 per person in the country.
STOWE, Vt., Aug. 9 -- The New England Governors jointly endorsed today a united industrial scrap iron drive to alleviate a critical shortage in this area.

BERLIN, Aug. 9--This blockaded city moved a long step toward complete division between the East and the West today when the Magistrat, or City Assembly, authorized the establishment of a separate food administration department in the Western sectors of the city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -The first draftees will not be in the Army until some time in November, Maj. Gen. John E. Dahlquist estimated tonight.

In a canvass of producers in this area non-ferrous metal refiners blamed national defense stockpiling yesterday for current scarcities and high prices of zinc and aluminum alloys. As continuing purchases increase, scarcities in these and other non-ferrous metals will further tighten, they explain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, filed a formal note today, demanding that the United States Government release to the Soviet authorities Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, the Russian-born teacher, who on Sunday sought the protection of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 9 -Mayor Frank H. Eggers released today a copy of a letter, to be read tomorrow in Trenton by the special legislative committee on bingo. It calls on the State Legislature to authorize a referendum on bingo at the November election.

h)0*0*0*iI read in THE TIMES of July 30 the forecast of one more threatened condition of traffic chaos on South Street when the Battery Tunnel opens and no overpass is ready for through traffic, which even now is barely able to fight its way past steamship piers and through Fulton Fish Market.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- Two Americans have been missing in the Soviet zone since Aug. 5, it became known today. They are Lieut. S. F. Turner, director of the Military Government in Bad Kissingen, and Roland M. Myers, a civilian employe of the Department of the Army.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman of the World Confederation of General Zionists, forecast yesterday that an attempt would be made at the United Nations Assembly sessions in Paris to alter the United Nations decision on partition.

Prospects for a 1948-49 season at the Metropolitan Opera looked brighter yesterday. A committee of the twelve unions involved asked the management for a meeting to discuss the cancellation, and George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of directors, said one could be arranged this week.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh announced yesterday afternoon that he was shifting the emphasis in his continuing milk-price inquiry to the question of "identical dis counts." The city official said that preliminary study of figures submitted by Borden and Sheffield -- the two major milk companies serving this area -had shown discounts to some retail stores ranging as high as 10 per cent.

Meat and milk prices are teetering at record high levels, butter sells for 89 cents a pound, and, to add to domestic difficulties, eggs also are high. On May 1 the large Grade A cost 71 cents a dozen; now they average 85. A budget is bountiful that does not feel this 14-cent rise in three months to be something of a blow.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Gallorette is the world's richest race mare ($430,535 in earnings) and Elkridge is the world's richest steeplechaser ($157,230). There's a connection between them. The "connection's" name, appropriately enough, is James Rich. He exercises Gallorette in the mornings and he was the young man astride Elkridge when the grand old jumper won the Shillelah Steeplechase here last week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The United Nations received today a strongly worded warning from Maj. Gen. Terence C. Airey, commander of the British-United States zone of Trieste, that continuation of the present administration of the port-city as a "free territory" was economically and politically impossible.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 9 (AP) -Votes by Negroes are to be cast generally for the first time in a South Carolina Democratic primary tomorrow. Indications are that they generally will vote as a bloc.

After spending four hours in a detention cell in the Federal Courthouse, Foley Square, Gus Hall, Ohio state chairman of the Communist party, was released in $5,000 bail yesterday for his appearance at a trial on Federal charges that he and eleven other Communist leaders conspired to overthrow the Government by force.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- British ship building firms have received authority from the Government to built seven oil tankers for the Overseas Tankship Corporation of New York.
Elimination of anti-Semitism in Germany will take twenty years, Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, cochairman of the International Council of Christians and Jews, declared here yesterday.

An underwriting group, headed by A. G. Becker Co., Inc., today will offer 350,000 shares of $1.20 cumulative preferred stock of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company at $24 a share. Of the total offering, 250,000 shares are being sold by the company to provide additional working funds that are to be available for its expansion and development plans, and 100,000 shares are being sold by two individual stockholders.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 9 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey expects to announce this week the appointment of the fifteen trustees who will set up and operate the State University created earlier this year by act of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -The Federal Government should retain ownership of national forest lands because of "their tremendous importance to the nation as a whole," the House Public Lands Committee said today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- The Federal Government's investigation of the official conduct of Edgar H. Rossbach, who resigned as United States Attorney in New Jersey on May 24, will be presented to a special Federal Grand Jury, it was announced today by Senior Federal Judge Guy L. Fake.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Ted Schroeder of the 1947 Davis Cup team, making his Eastern debut this season in defense of his Eastern grass court championship in the twenty-second running of the event at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, scored in straight sets today over William Madamba, Philippine star, now living in New York City, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- A Trenton ordinance barring use of sound trucks on city streets was held invalid today by Federal District Judge Phillip Forman on the basis of a similar finding in a Lockport, N.Y., case by the United States Supreme Court.
Palestine's uneasy truce is probablyh)0*0*0*ian index of things to come.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- The American Federation of Labor appealed to the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations today to continue the United Nations Appeal for Children.

A public offering of $134,000,000 of revenue bonds for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission will be made today by a nation-wide banking syndicate headed jointly by Drexel Co., B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Blythe Co., Inc., and the First Boston Corporation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- William Kinne Fellows of this city, widelyknown retired architect, died last night of a skull fracture he had suffered in a fall at his home. He was 77 years old.

Men's wear worsteds for spring of 1949 will show price increases ranging from 7 1/2 to 25 cents a yard, it was announced yesterday by the American Woolen Company. Percentagewise, the rise will amount to 5 per cent over the prices of last spring.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP)--The Olympic Jury of Appeal has postponed action on the American protest against disqualification in the 400-meter track relay until official moving pictures of the race can be seen.

New equipment alone will not solve all the problems in this city's muchcriticized Sanitation Department, but it will help. Some of the new machinery for garbage collection, snow removal and other Sanitation services ordered under the $7,000,000 program authorized several months ago will be arriving soon, and Commissioner Powell believes it should make a considerable improvement in departmental service to the city.
Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday as a result of a clash during a rally shortly after noon in front of the National Maritime Union Headquarters, 352 West Seventeenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 A loan of $12,000,000 has been granted to four Netherlands shipping companies to purchase six cargo ships in the United States, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Rumanian refugee sources reported today that Rumania would decide in a plebiscite Aug. 23 whether to become a part of the Soviet Union.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg ruled yesterday that a legitimate labor dispute existed at the two department stores of Oppenheim Collins Co. He set this afternoon for the taking of testimony on the company's motion for a temporary injunction against Local 1250 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO.

ALDERSHOT, England, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Sweden scored the first victory of the Olympic equestrian events today, winning the team dressage competition with 1,366 points. France was second with 1,269 and the United States third with 1,256.

Retail jewelry sales this year should run well over $1,000,000,000, with improvement during the coming fall and Christmas period bringing a volume equal to or exceeding that of 1947, according to reports yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan of Britain said bluntly today that any disarmament scheme would not be "worth the paper it is written on" until it was backed up by atomic control and the signing of the peace treaties.

The city of York, England, will extend felicitations to New York on the occasion of its Golden Anniversary in a special exchange broadcast at 8 P. M. Thursday over the facilities of WNYC and the British Broadcasting Corporation.

There was something familiar about our visitor, but in the first few moments of his arrival this corner searched memory's pigeon-holes in vain for his name. By the time he removed his ancient straw hat, straightened the bachelor'sbutton in his lapel and sat down, recognition had been established.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The discovery of archaeological remants indicating the existence of a civilization unkown by modern man was announced here last night at a meeting of the Academy of Inscriptions. The site of that civilization was placed near Arslan-Tepe in Turkey, and the date of its principal manifestations was estimated at about 2000 B.C.

Dr. Dilworth Wayne Woolley, 34year-old blind chemist who is an associate of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research here, will receive the $1,000 Eli Lilly Co. award in biological chemistry when the American Chemical Society opens its 114th national meeting in Washington Aug. 30, it was announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Emmons J. Bowen, assistant principal of Hillhouse High School, died today at the hospital of St. Raphael from injuries he received Tuesday in a fall from a window at the school. He was 51 years of age.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Britain's bumper harvest, predicted for this summer, has been endangered by a week of unprecedentedly heavy rain accompanied by storms, but the weatherman held out hopes today for a change. Unless the sun comes out and stays out a good deal during the next four weeks, crop hopes are going to be dashed.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 9 -- President Syngman Rhee today notified Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, that the Korean Government was "prepared to take over the functions of government" from the United States authorities.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 8 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

The six-family apartment house at 429 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y., has been sold by Wilhelmine and Olga Schlobohm to Thomas and Nancy Barca. The property on a plot 70 by 177 feet, is assessed at $22,200 and was sold subject to a of $8.500.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Enos Slaughter drove in five of St. Louis' runs tonight as the Cardinals downed the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 2, before 22,718 spectators. Ken Raffensberger, who twice held the Cards to one-hit shutouts, was the losing pitcher as Harry (The Cat) Brecheen racked up his thirteenth victory against four defeats.

Comparatively modest pressure produced sizable losses yesterday in the stock market, with widest inroads in the steels and rails. The hope that the adjournment of the special session of Congress would act as a stabilizing factor failed to materialize and attention again shifted to the international political situation.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 - Ten German children in this former German capital who have been stricken by tuberculosis meningitis may die in the next few weeks because there is not enough streptomycin available to treat them. And many others may suffer the same fate in time because of a critical shortage of this rare drug.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- Owen J. Roberts, former Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, was named dean of the University of Pennsylvania Law School today.

Committees representing three locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes Union, CIO, appeared yesterday afternoon at an executive session of the union's international general executive board in the Park Central Hotel and asked that it order theh)0*0*0*iofficers of the locals to sign and file non-Communist affidavits.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Here's how the points in the first nine days of the 1948 Olympic Games have been distributed. Although team championships are not awarded, the following table is compiled by giving ten points for each first place winner, five for second, four for third, three for fourth, two for fifth and one for sixth.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 9 -- Following virtual agreement between Israel and the Arabs that Jerusalem should be demilitarized, they also agreed tonight, largely through the efforts of Frank Begley of the United Nations, that water would start flowing to Jerusalem tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The American Veterans Committee said today that it had instigated proceedings designed to expel John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, from its membership rolls.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Two Palestinian delegates walked out of the International Amateur Athletic Federation congress today in protest after the congress had voted, by thirty-two to fourteen, with fourteen abstaining, to leave the question of Palestine's membership in the federation in abeyance.

Edward C. Maguire, generally regarded as one of the ablest men in the O'Dwyer administration, announced his resignation as Commerce Commissioner in a friendly letter made public by the Mayor at City Hall last night.
Concerned mainly with current needs, buyers of fancy linens and domestics are restricting purchases to thirty to sixty days ahead, it was learned yesterday at the National Domestics and Linen Show.

A story of six days and nights of intermittent bombing by Arab planes as his flour-laden vessel was being unloaded in the shallow harbor of Tel Aviv, Israel, was told here yesterday by Capt. Rogerio Marques, master of the freighter Jackstar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Alexander Koral, New York City school engineer through whom the House Committee on Un-American Activities hoped to prove up evidence of Soviet spy rings in this country, refused to talk today.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Officials in close touch with the Moscow negotiations said tonight they felt sure the full report on today's meeting of the Western envoys with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, not yet received, would confirm the impression here that the Russians were playing for time by prolonging the present preliminary negotiations.

Karl Drews, the Yankees' 28year-old right-hander, was sold to the Browns for the waiver price of $10,000, it was announced yesterday. The departure of Drews leaves the Yankees with twenty-four players, one under the limit, but Manager Bucky Harris did not reveal plans for filling the gap.

WEMBLEY, England, Aug 9 (AP) -- The little men of Olympic boxing teed off on each other today as first-round featherweight matches began at the Empire pool house, with winners advancing to the second round scheduled for tomorrow.
The wave of meat boycotts protesting against high prices spread yesterday but there were still no indications of any pronounced success.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Aug. 9 -- Final reports were submitted here today by university representatives from thirty-two nations on the creation of a permanent international council of higher education. The plan for such a council will be put Friday before the 350 odd professors, rectors, deans and college presidents now meeting in the twelve-day preparatory conference sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
LAWRENCE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Folks were on a pailto-dipper basis for water here today.

LAKENHEATH, England, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Seven United States Superfortresses landed here tonight, bringing to seventy-four the total of B-29 bombers in England. Another fourteen are due in the next few days for joint training with the Royal Air Force.

A stroll in Central Park yesterday was a reassuring experience to a British artist, who, since his arrival here from England a few days ago, had found the impact of the city "terrifying." Archibald Ziegler, East End London painter, in the United States for the first time, found with relief that "people sit about on the grass just as they do in London."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 - The suggestion that his functions as Military Governor were provisional until Jerusalem became part of Israelwas made today by Dr. Bernard Joseph when speaking at the opening session of the new Israel District Court.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9 (AP) -A new football season is here, but it's the same old story for toeless Ben Agajanian, the placement artist.

Tipped off by a Ridgewood, Queens, bartender, an Army agent of the Criminal Investigation Division caught up with Sgt. Harold Eastmead, 30 years old, and arrested him yesterday on charges of forgery, larceny and being away without official leave for six months.

DETROIT, Aug 9 (AP) -- The firstplace Indians moved half a game in front of the idle Athletics in the torrid American League race tonight as Gene Bearden pitched Cleveland to a 6-to-2 victory over the Tigers before Detroit's largest crowd of the year, 56,586 fans.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Ten of the nineteen minor powers that have been consulted about the disposal of Italy's former African colonies have expressed the opinion that one or more of the territories should be restored to Italy under a trusteeship.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9--The Yugoslav Government canceled today all outstanding diplomatic, service and ordinary passports, and announced that Yugoslavs holding such passports could not leave the country without re-applying for new documents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, declared today that the committee was determined to "go after" all Federal agencies and departments found "misrepresenting" cuts in appropriations.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 9 (AP) Bethlehem Steel Company's offerh) 0*0*0*iof a 7cent acrosstheboard pay increase was ratified today in a second vote by 28,000 employes of the concern's nine East Coast shipbuilding yards.
LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Tomorrow's Olympic schedule by sports, with all times Eastern daylight saving, follows:

The grays are the Marthas of theh)0*0*0*ibirch clan. They grow beside frostheaved stone walls that line quiet, twisting country roads; they grow in clumps around stone piles of upper fields and make patterns of lace against the evergreens on the mountains. Betula populifolia is happily named because of the aspen-like appearance of the glossy green, distinctly veined pointed leaves.

Private manufacture and private trade still exist illegally in Soviet Russia, despite twenty years of effort by the Government to stamp them out, according to the most recent copy of Socialist Agriculture, a Russian newspaper, to reach this country.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Aug. 9 -- Prof. Lloyd W. Taylor, head of the Oberlin College Physics Department and active Lorain County Republican leader, was killed instantly late yesterday while mountain climbing in the State of Washington.

Arnold Gray, an insurance adjuster from Jackson Heights, playing from the Clearview Golf Club, took the over-all lead in the fifteenth annual New York World Telegram hole-in-one tournamenth) 0*0*0*iat the Bayside Golf Club with a 4 1/2-inch effort with his first shot yesterday as the Long Island contingent opened a three-day stand.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey will step up the tempo of his campaign for President this week, now that the extra session of Congress called by President Truman had adjourned, it was indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The meeting of leaders of the Young Republican National Federation on Wednesday in Albany, it became known today, will mark the kickoff in a drive to swing youthful supporters of Harold E. Stassen behind Governor Dewey's Presidential campaign.
Random notes.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 9 -The Government has been warned that any attempt to introduce conscription to raise a peace-time army will be met with strong opposition from an influential group of militant trades unionists and one of the two New Zealand veterans associations.

The first Government crop estimate of the season issued by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture yesterday exerted strong influence on activity in the local cotton market. As a result, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange at one time were down about 50 to 60 points, or $2.50 to $3.00 a bale from the previous close and final quotations were 41 to 53 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Mark Ethridge, publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal, was named by President Truman today as chairman of the United States Advisory Commission on Information.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday tabled until Friday the application for a license to promote boxing bouts here by the Tournament of Champions, Inc.

The Pure Oil Company and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $20,753,000 after all charges, including $7,249,000 provision for taxes, in the first six months of 1948. This was $12,591,000 more than the earnings for the corresponding half of last year, the semi-annual report of Rawleigh Warner, board chairman, and L. S. Wescoat, president, disclosed yesterday.

Japanese products of the kind widely boycotted before the war are beginning to make their first post-war quantity appearance in local variety stores, it was observed yesterday. They are meeting some buyer resistance, but not because of the prices, sales clerks reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The National Power and Light Company, New York, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to withdraw its plan for recapitalization of the Memphis Street Railway Company. At the same time, it filed a new plan.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- A program of essential measures for New Jersey court reform, governmental reorganization and a bond issue for state construction was drawn today by Republican legislative leaders for three weeks of the session of the Legislature.
Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin remained in hiding yesterday despite top-level diplomatic representations and a police search for the Russian teacher made at the request of the Soviet consulate here.

In your edition of July 29 there appeared a story headed "Auto Safety Head Asks Liquor Curb." This story was a report on a speech by Lou E. Holland, chairman of the National Traffic Committee of the Automobile Association of America at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -Ninety-four high school girls heard Secretary of State Marshall declare gravely today that he must have "intelligent support for a position like mine."

Acting upon an unhurried and welldocumented appraisal of world conditions, Congress adopted and the President of the United States signed in June legislation to require military service of our young men on a selective basis. Their purpose was not to make war, but to make peace, a motive accepted at fun face value by all those nations that want to understand our motives.

During the depressed Thirties a group of economists achieved a dubious prominence by the "stagnant economy" thesis. According to this school of thought, the American economy had reached the end of its expansionist phase. We had, they said, exhausted our frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The chief spokesman of the Republican Congress, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, counter-attacked President Truman today on the issue of its record and declared that neither "extreme inflation" nor depression were in sight.

Add to the roster of films opening this week, "Escape," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama, starring Rex Harrison and Peggy Cummins, which will arrive at the Globe on Saturday. This adaptation of the John Galsworthy work was directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz and produced by William Perlberg from a screen play by Philip Dunne. William HartneU,Norman Wooland and Jill Esmondl are among the featured players.

After a week-long questioning of two score witnesses, the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began yesterday to present evidence to a New York county grand jury in connection with reports of crooked gambling at a so-called charity party on Park Avenue.

Max Sevin, 72 years old, and his wife won the first legal encounter yesterday in their fight to get into the home they own when Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein directed the Temporary City Housing Commission to issue to them a certificate of eviction.

In the first sale of the property in more than fifty years the three four-story store and apartment buildings at 346-350 Ninth Avenue have been conveyed by Grace E. Freeman and May L. Jones to the 350 Ninth Avenue Realty Corporation. Henry Shapiro Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Meville toward Osterman for the buyer and Guy George Gabrielson for the sellers.

One hundred and twenty-seven persons who were in the employ of the city in 1898 will be honored for their service to New York. In a special ceremony at the Golden Anniversary Exposition, to be held in Grand Central Palace from next Friday to Sept. 19, these veterans will receive recognition from their fellow citizens, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Committee for the city celebration, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Although Mme. Gres continues her lovely Greek drapery, her nipped beltless waistlines, her kimono sleeves that are crushed tightly about the elbow, there are subtle changes this season.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 9 - Just when it seemed certain that five teams would have to divide the glory in today's one-day pro-amateur tournament run by the Westchester County Golf Association at Wykagyl, each having posted a best-ball score of 64, the situation abruptly changed as the last foursome in a big field of 79 pairs left the eighteenth green and reported to the scoreboard.

A controlling interest in the General Instrument Corporation, manufacturer of radio and television components, has been acquired by a group headed by C. Russell Feldman, Detroit industrialist, and Richard E. Laux, vice president of the company, it was announced yesterday.
Whether the consulate of a foreign power is immune from the service of subpoenas or, for that matter, intervention by the police was a matter of conjecture last night.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- An indication that the Soviet Union is mustering all its pressure forces to prevent Marshal Tito from playing a stalling game in an effort to walk a tight rope between the Eastern and Western coalitions is given in a French Communist organ, Democratie Nouvelle.

With the formal signing yesterday of the new contract between the Publishers Association of New York City and Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, the weekly wage increase of $9 a week became effective for 2,500 workers in the composing rooms of twelve daily newspapers.

A.O. Dietz, president of C.I.T. Financial Corporation, said yesterday reimposition of the same installment credit terms provided in the wartime Regulation W would be "entirely unnecessary and would have a result just the opposite" of that intended by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) A fiveman Presidential Inquiry board on the maritime labor dispute will reconvene in New York Wednesday to get the latest data on the threatened all coast shipping tieup.

Recent railroad freight rate increases are forcing many produce shippers to switch to motor transport. This trend was disclosed yesterday at the opening of the fifty-fourth International Apple Association convention, which runs through Thursday, in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Any lingering doubt that 21year-old Carl Erskine is big-time timber vanished last night at Ebbets Field, when the rookie righthander from Fort Worth went all the way for the Dodgers, recording his fourth straight victory, a slick 5-hit, 2-1 triumph over the Phillies.

ITHACA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Proposed legislation to protect multiple dwelling tenants throughout New York was discussed today at a meeting of the joint legislative committee on housing and multiple dwellings, headed by Senator MacNeil Mitchell of New York.
LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The bulk of the agenda will be before the congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation tomorrow, including the much debated question of "broken time" for athletes.
The Welfare Department is reexamining all cases of veterans receiving financial aid from the city, Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday.

The new theatrical season picked up behind-the-scenes momentum yesterday when three shows went into rehearsal at the same time, doubling the number now rehearsing for the fall. The productions were "Love Life," "Town House" and "Grandma's Diary."
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The outstanding feature in the stock market here today was the strength of British Government bonds, with institutional buying lifting prices all-round up to 1/4 point.

PANAMA, Aug. 9--Unconfirmed rumors of an expected invasion of Panama from Costa Rica by forces supporting Dr. Arnulfo Arias, defeated candidate for President,were dismissed at the Panamanian Presidencia today as unfounded.
LONDON, Aug. 9 Some assistance for shipowners to meet the present huge cost of replacement was advocated today by Tomh)0*0*0*iYates, general secretary of the National Union of Seamen.

An entirely new concept for development of multi-purpose water projects by states, rather than the Federal Government, was envisioned yesterday by utility men as they discussed the recent compact tentatively agreed upon by five upper basin states -- Colorado, New Mexico, Wyoming, Utah and Arizona.

Are you quite logical when you compare the Progressive party platform to that of the Communists and infer undue communistic influence? Would it not be fairer to compare both of these platforms with the demands of liberals the world over in the last century?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture to day allocated 3,900,000 hundredpound bags of milled rice for export during the last half of 1948. This compares with 3,800,000 hundredpound bags allocated for foreign shipment in the last half of 1947.

Street gangs that have resisted the efforts of settlement house and church groups in some of the poorest sections of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan show signs of disintegrating, and many of their members are on the road to becoming Boy Scouts, the New York City Youth Board reported yesterday.

Your editorial of Aug. 3 concerning the city's waterfront rehabilitation plans calls for some clarification in so far as it relates to the two reports submitted to the Mayor by the Citizen Budget Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Truman is being subjected to increasing pressure, it was learned today, to make basic decisions on his campaign plans that will permit supporters within and without the Democratic party to swing into action in his behalf.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9 (AP) -- With little hope of success, the United States introduced today her major requirements for a new international pact on control of Danube river shipping.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Here is the text of the statement by Senator Taft summarizing the work of the extra session of the Eightieth Congress:

A study of the Supreme Court since 1937 will he brought out by Macmillan on Sept. 14 under the title "The Roosevelt Court." In it C, Herman Pritchett, associate professor of political science at the University of Chicago, tells of the court's disagreements on important issues and of the attitudes and beliefs among the justices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Advances in industrial wages and farm income pushed national personal income to an annual rate of $211,900,000,000 in June from $207,200,000,000 in the preceding month, the Department of Commerce reported today.

h)0*0*0*iOWhile diplomats confer in Moscow to ascertain whether they can find a basis for negotiating a settlement between Russia and the West, a grimmer drama of considerable bearing on their discussions is drawing to a close on the craggy mountain tops of northern Greece.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 -- At dawn today elements of the National Army's Fifteenth Division began an attack on Alevista, at an altitude of 4,752 feet, in the eastern sector, just northeast of Amouda. Artillery preparation was followed by an infantry assault supported in the first phase by tanks.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- Quietly, without any report of disorder, about 500,000 persons took a work holiday today in the French state of Wuerttemberg-Hohenzollern in a general protest against a recent dismantling order of the French Military Government.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Golf's golden boy, Lloyd Mangrum, added up a week's earnings of $22,500 today by winning the $10,000 three-way Tam O'Shanter pro play-off with a 2-under par 70.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- When the unrestricted traffic woes of New York City were compared here today with highway congestion curbs as enforced in Poughkeepsie, the foresight here was praised as an example to the apathetic attitude of the "drones of Manhattan."

Consolidated net earnings of the American Viscose Corporation for the first half of this year increased to $15,628,524 from $8,705,801 earned in the first six months of 1947, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday.

Richard Roiderer, who has fought fascism and communism since 1935 with his four-page newspaper. The Idealist, was acquitted yesterday in mid-Manhattan Court after his arrest last week in Columbus Circle for selling his publication near a public park without a permit.

BELGRADE, Aug. 9 -- The general committee of the Danubian Conference held its first session today. It was in fact a conference in miniature, with the chief delegates present around the table. The only appreciable differences were that smoking was permitted in the hall and that the small flags that had designated the countries of the various delegations were removed from the horseshoe-shaped table.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Bob Dillinger poled a triple and two doubles to lead the Browns to an 8-to-6 victory over the White Sox tonight. Pat Seerey hit his sixteenth home run for the losers.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that since the increase in the allowance of duty free imports was put into effect the airline's excess baggage revenue had shown a considerable gain. Since May 20 travelers have been allowed to import goods valued up to $400 without paying tax if they have been outside the United States for twelve days or more.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Foreign Minister Molotov himself called today's meeting at the Kremlin with envoys of the Western powers, it was learned here, and it is presumed he gave the answer to the Western Allies' counter-proposal that they expected Friday.

Cold permanent waves are safe, it became known yesterday. Twenty million women who have spent $43,000,000 for home permanent wave kits in this country and Canada during the last four years can be assured that stories about harm to their health or sight are unfounded rumors according to the Food and Drug Administration.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet-licensed trade union newspaper Tribuene urged Germans in the Soviet zone today to help track down concealed foodstuffs and consumer goods.

The small boy didn't get his traditional chance to water the elephants as the air circus folded its tents yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild. After nine days in which 750,000 people saw more of the intricacies of aviation than ever before, there were still some small boys, eager for more, on runway E as city employes and the men in charge of the exhibits crated everything from giant engines to tiny electronic tubes.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- A compromise of the principal dispute on fiscal reform had opened the way today for rapid adoption of the financial and economic program of Finance Minister Paul Reynaud when the Communists began a filibuster in the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Secretary of State Marshall predicted today there would be more meetings in Moscow between Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov and the representatives of the Western powers.

Current rumors reported from Palestine of Irgun preparations to battle in Jerusalem are being circulated to lay the groundwork for a violent attack against possible political opponents of the provisional government, Konrad Bercovici, author, said yesterday.

DOROTHY BAKER'S "Our Gifted Son"* is as impressive as a gift package from Cartier's or Tiffany's. The wrappings are wonderful. The only trouble is that there's nothing inside. Miss Baker is a gifted and painstaking novelist, as she proved with her "Young Man With a Horn," a brilliant story about the strange melodies and strange thoughts which bubbled inside a swing musician's head; and with "Trio," an unpleasant but expert little study of sexual inversion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -Mickey Rooney today announced that he had formed a new company in association with Sam H. Stiefel to operate as a producing organization in four different fields of show business -- motion pictures, the stage, radio and television.
LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Four world records and an Olympic mark were shattered today in the first two events of the Olympic weight lifting.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The number of persons arrested in New York State for major crimes mounted to 2,037 last month, 5 per cent above the average for the first six months of the year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt who hadn't been able to bag a winner on the New York circuit since the horses were running at Belmont Park in June, hit with both barrels in the main event of today's proceedings at Saratoga.

Two hundred and fifty clerks in eighty-eight New York City delicatessen stores will receive wage increases of $6 and $7 a week under a new two-year contract signed by the employers with Local 338. Retail, Wholesale and Chain Store Employes Union CIO.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 -- Political events in Sao Paulo took a turn for the worse today. The president of the State Assembly informed President Enrico Gaspar Dutra that the situation in Sao Paulo had deteriorated and urged that steps be taken to correct the situation.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 9 -Over a slightly tousled sea, and in salty but gentle air, the Astor Cup was raced for today out in Nantucket Sound, in connection with the New York Yacht Club's ninety -fourth annual regatta.

RHODES, Aug. 9 -- Count Bernadotte left Rhodes today to preside over three days of conferences in Jerusalem in an effort to bring about the complete demilitarization of the Holy City and end the present perilous situation there.

BENTON, Tenn., Aug. 9 (AP) National Guard machine guns ringed the Polk County Court House today as the Election Commission canvassed votes cast in last Thursday's general election. Results of the canvass probablyh)0*0*0*iwill not be available for hours.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The United States Olympic Basketball team entered the semi-final round here today by handing the Uruguayan combination a resounding defeat, 63 to 28.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A surprisingly large cotton crop of 15,169,000 bales was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 9h)0*0*0*i-- Denying Russian charges that Ceylon was ineligible to join the ranks of sovereign states in the United Nations, G.C.S. Corea, Ceylonese representative here, has contended his nation is fully independent.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- British and French diplomats conferred for three hours tonight with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov. They were believed to have heard Russian views on proposals for negotiating East-West differences on Germany and perhaps all of Europe.
All seagoing unions are feeling the pinch of steadily declining United States flag shipping, according to reports from leading unions here.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 9 -- Cuts in taxation were announced today by Finance Minister N. C. Havenga as he disclosed a budget surplus of 8,900,000 [about $35,000,000].
LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Weekend storms in Britain and France left at least twenty-two persons dead and considerable damage.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP) -From all indications, veteran harness horsemen are preparing to give Harrison Hoyt and the favored Demon Hanover a hard time at Good Time Track in the $60,000 Hambletonian Stake on Wednesday.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- By exchanging $25,000,000 worth of surplus Army property for real estate in France, the United States has acquired two huge buildings for its Paris Embassy and other buildings for consulates and dwellings in other French cities in Metropolitan France and overseas.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 6 (Delayed) The most complicated machine that Nazim Barangoglu had seen up to two years ago was a waterwheel.

A few days ago I had returned to me a package containing blank paper and several printed articles. This package had originally been addressed to a person in the French zone of Germany. When returned, the package had the explanation printed on it in pencil by a clerk in the New York Postoffice -- "No printed service to French zone."

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The United Electrical Workers' Local 768, CIO, voted tonight to accept a proposal of the Univis Lens Company, ending a three-month-old strife-torn strike against the company.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Today was an important one for 4,200 orphans from forty-eight orphanages in Long Island, Westchester and New York City for they were guests in the eighteenth annual orphans' day outing here.

Jacob Lomakin, Russian Consul General in New York, declared yesterday that Mrs. Oksana Kosenkina, the Russian school teacher he "rescued" last Saturday, was feeling "very well" and expressed doubt that Mikhail Samarin, the Soviet school teacher who is under a Congressional committee subpoena, was "giving himself up."

PARIS, Wednesday, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The National Assembly, remaining in session throughout the night to defeat the delaying tactics of Communist Deputies, early today approved the economic and financial reform program of Finance Minister Paul Reynaud.

At Burlingham, N.Y., in the Catskill Mountains, is a small camp called Nyda for city children suffering from diabetes. Barred from other camps because of the strict dietary and medical treatment that diabetics require, Camp Nyda is the only place where those youngsters suffering from that disease -- which most persons probably associate only with old age -- and whose parents cannot afford to send them to special camps can be properly cared for.
All the machinery that moves when the State Labor Relations Board supervises a labor election will roll into action some time in the next twenty days in "secret ballot" voting for one employe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Moves to consolidate the relations of this country with the new state of Israel are under study, it was said at the State Department today. Simultaneously, the department and the White House denied reports of a rift between President Truman and Secretary Marshall over United States policy toward Israel.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Renewed uncertainty about the outcome of the Moscow talks together with the sharp reaction on Wall Street yesterday caused the stock market here today to lose some of its recent firmness.

The New York Diabetes Association is conducting a campaign for funds to meet a 25 per cent rise in the cost of operating "America's most exclusive camp" -- a camp to which only children who have diabetes are admitted.

Whatever charges may be made in Washington about how Nathan Gregory Silvermaster headed a Soviet spy ring in wartime Washington in the Township of Long Beach, N.J., Mr. Silvermaster and his wife are enrolled Republicans.

Sabena, the Belgian Airlines, the fifth scheduled transatlantic line to transfer its operations from La Guardia Field to the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, marked the event with ceremonies at the great new airport yesterday and dispatched one of its new airliners to Brussels.

Ralph Edward Renaud came to this newspaper more than a decade ago after a brilliant and varied career in San Francisco, Washington and New York. He had been a star reporter, a dramatic critic, a successful managing editor. In his later years he was a highly valued member of the editorial staff of THE TIMES: versatile, widely and deeply informed, clear and precise in thought, pungent in expression.
The city's milk inquiry branched out yesterday in still another direction. The new phase involved possible collusion among milk companies supplying city institutions.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Baroda Legislature has accused the Princely state's ruler, long considered one of the world's richest men, of misusing nearly $10,000,000 in a six-week spending spree last spring.

The five-story apartment house at 3822-3834 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 270 Seaman Avenue Corporation, Elizabeth Schmidt, president, to the YK. Realties, represented by Seymour L. Herzog, attorney. Nehring Brothers were the brokers.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Peace came to the strike-troubled plant of the Univis Lens Company today after more than three months of negotiations, picket-line violence, court battles and National Guard intervention.

Dore Schary, new vice president in charge of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, disclosed yesterday that he expects to expand the film company's program by about 20 per cent, or five to six pictures annually, and that he will aim his productions primarily at the domestic market.

Eight buildings in and near the financial district were struck briefly yesterday by Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, but service was restored later when the managements agreed to union demands.

The thirty-family apartment house at 48-52 West Ninetieth Street, occupying a frontage of 60 feet, has been conveyed by Gisella Stern and Elizabeth Sorel to the 21 West Forty-seventh Realty Corporation.

"Man From Texas," an Eagle-Lion comedy Western featuring James Craig, Johnnie Johnston and Lynn Bari, which arrives at the Gotham, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Leigh Jason directed and Joseph Fields produced from a play by E.B. Ginty and a script by Fields and Jerome Chodorov.

LANCHOW, China, Aug. 9 (Delayed) -- Gen. Chang Chih-chung, top Nationalist military leader in northwest China, confirmed tonight reports that he had recently received a radio message from Communist Gen. Chou En-lai, emphasizing their past friendship and apologizing for the Communist invasion of Kansu Province several months ago.
The tempers of housewives and their butchers in these difficult days are rising in proportion with the prices of meat, according to peace-making city magistrates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Yoshio Higa, private secretary to the Governor of Okinawa, said today that the populations of the Ryukyu Islands, which include Okinawa, Iwo and Ie, want to return to Japanese rule.
Rex Barney yesterday paid another handsome dividend on Branch Rickey's large investment of patience and forbearance with a pitching problem child.

Mayor O'Dwyer left New York late yesterday on a visit with political overtones to Washington, though it was announced at City Hall that he had been invited to witness President Truman signing the $65,000,000 loan bill for United Nations headquarters.

New Yorkers can join in a feeling of satisfaction with Mayor O'Dwyer and Grover Whalen over the success of the superb air show which brought the scope of New York International Airport to the public consciousness in dramatic fashion as part of the Golden Jubilee celebration.
PANAMA, Aug. 10 -- President Enrique Jiminez said today that the Government of Costa Rica would not support an invasion of Panama by supporters of Arnulfo Arias, defeated Presidential candidate.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 10 -- E.W. (Skip) Etchells, who four years ago in these same waters ran off five straight triumphs in the Atlantic Coast Star championship series, took first honors today in the initial race of this year's series.

Fighting a stubborn uphill battle after a mishap to their starting hurler had helped to floor them for three runs in the first inning, the Yankees appeared on the verge of scoring a smashing victory over the Red Sox in the opener of a three-game series at the Stadium last night.
TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Price and Distribution Division chief was under suspension today, on orders from Washington, pending a loyalty check.
Mrs. Ruth Whitehead Whaley, attorney, was appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to serve as executive assistant to Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, at a salary of $8,000.
The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended with June a net profit of $28,556,437, equal to $7.89 a share on 3,560,000 common shares.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Two of the American favorites were eliminated as the twenty-second annual Eastern grass court men's singles moved into the round of sixteen at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today. A seeded foreign entry and one of the favored women also succumbed during the day's play.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,341, compared with 1,118 last week and 1,370 in the similar week of 1947, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 610 arrivals yesterday against 602 last Tuesday.

Sol Kaminsky, war amputee who switched from being helped to being a helper, has completed six months of volunteer driving for the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Dissolution of the great majority of the trade unions of government workers formed immediately after the surrender is being planned by the Japanese Government under General Douglas MacArthur's directive denying the right to strike and the right of collective bargaining to public employes, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, as chairman of the Appropriations Committee of the Senate, called on the Administration today for precise details as to every Government employe who has been assigned to some other than his normal job.

Your editorial discussion of the "Truman Tax Plan" rings with dogmatic assurance. You flatly charge in speaking of the excess profits proposal: "The fact is that this proposal is thoroughly spurious economically." You say it is obvious that the spending of corporate profits does not exert the same upward thrust on the cost of living as income in the hands of the consumer.
An admitted former Communist and a group of officials of Local 475, United Electrical Workers Union, CIO, joined yesterday in open warfare against left-wing domination of the local.

Plans to reopen wage negotiations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, employing 25,000 long lines operators in forty-two states, were announced yesterday by the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 10 -- The team of Mrs. Bernard Freeman and Miss Margaret Mackie of Inwood gained the lead in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Scotch foursome tournament over the Hempstead Golf Club course today by a margin of six strokes with a fine score of 80.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, refused categorically at today's session of the Danubian conference to permit even the slightest allusion to the United Nations Charter in the establishment of a new Danubian authority.

An additional 1,200 acres of land has been acquired by Walter T. Shirley, president of Mastic Acres, Inc., adjoining the firm's subdivision at Mastic, L.I. The property was reported acquired for $200,000 cash. It increases the Mastic Acres holding to 8,000 acres.

The name of George Herrick, once termed by the late Fiorello H. La Guardia a "tinhorn gambler," was injected into an inquiry of an allegedly crooked gambling party in a Park Avenue apartment when a witness yesterday asserted that he had identified Herrick as an operator of the affair's elaborate gaming paraphernalia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced upward revisions today in sugar import quotas of most offshore and foreign producing areas that help supply this country.
DENVER, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, said today that he thought teachers' salaries should be doubled.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Actual splitting up of this city's administration into two camps continued today when the British Military Government announced it had provided quarters in its sector for the city's Food Administration in response to an appeal by the Magistrat, or City Council, for office accommodations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Buyer attendance at the Chicago fall wholesale market, now in its second week, has been better than expected, reaching 12,000 during the first ten days, a spokesman for the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry said today. Orders, however, have been spotty.

Acting promptly on the union request for a meeting, George A. Sloan, general director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, announced yesterday that he and Charles M. Spofford, president of the association, would meet union leaders tomorrow afternoon at the opera house to discuss the future of the opera.

The Right Rev. Peter Yanigahara, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Osaka, Japan, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday on a Pan American World Airways clipper from London, where he had attended the Lambeth conference of Bishops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The United Corporation's amended plan for the retirement of its outstanding preference stock was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The SEC said it had applied to the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del. for enforcement of the plan. Judge Paul Leahy set Sept. 28 for a hearing and said objections must be filed by Sept. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- Controller of the Currency Preston Delano and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation were named defendants today in a United States District Court suit charging them with mismanagement of a closed bank in Easton, Pa., and demanding termination of Government control.

A resolution condemning trading in apple futures as "detrimental to the industry" was passed yesterday by the board of directors of the International Apple Association, now holding their annual convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 10 -- The Eastern team consisting of George Rapee, Samuel Stayman and Howard Schenken of New York, Mrs. Margaret Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., and John R. Crawford of Philadelphia defeated the Chicago team of Robert Halpin, Arthur Glatt, Ralph Kempner, Jules Bank and Oswald Jacoby in the finals of the masters' knockout team-of-four contract bridge championship last night at the Stevens Hotel here, by a score of 2,670 points.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner punched out his twenty-ninth home run of the season tonight as the Pirates downed the Cubs, 5 to 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of Hal Gregg. Phil Cavarretta homered in the seventh for the only Chicago run.

For the first time since before the war sleeper berths will be available after Sept. 1 on coast-to-coast airplanes. American Airlines announced that on its Douglas DC-6 overnight service to Los Angeles, the Mercury, leaving La Guardia Field at midnight, four uppers and four lowers would be made up in the rear compartment of the big plane.

A driverless automobile that "just took off" yesterday downhill in 187th Street near Audubon Avenue injured fatally a 3-year-old boy and hurt critically another child when it crashed into a tree under which they were playing.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- It was said on high authority here today that the Western envoys' long talk with Foreign Minister Molotov in Moscow yesterday had yielded no notable progress toward the creation of a basis for a formal four-power conference.

Forty passengers, including ten women and a number of shipyard workers, got safely out of a burning Staten Island bus on Richmond Terrace, near Stuyvesant Place, St. George, late yesterday afternoon, just a minute or two before the vehicle was engulfed in flames.
WEMBLEY, England, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A full scale rhubarb shattered the austere calm of the Olympic boxing tournament today.

America today is not "the hope of the world" in the sense it was when Herbert Hoover was a boy in West Branch, Iowa. Then it was the land of promise, for its own citizens and for people everywhere. It was not known by its movies, its skyscrapers, its assembly lines, its plumbing, the "Voice of America" or even its far-flung armies.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations in the first half of 1948 resulted in a net loss of $220,378. This was in contrast with a net profit of $6,258,355 in the comparable 1947 period.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Moscow radio lauded Soviet and United States contributions to the war against Japan today, and said that "collaboration between the two countries is just as essential today as it was during the war."

The annual individual Maine Tuna Tournament gets under way this morning, and with a record entry list and plenty of big blue-fin tuna cavorting between Bailey Island and Boothbay Harbor, tonight may see a new record for a day's catch established.

The tenants of River House, one of Manhattan's outstanding apartment buildings, have purchased the building on a cooperative ownership basis to save themselves from eviction and to prevent the structure from being remodeled into small suites, it became known last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today cast the three principal roles in its coming production of "Down to the Sea in Ships," a New England whaling story. Richard Widmark heads the list and will play his initial sympathetic screen part as the first mate. Cecil Kellaway will appear as the ship's captain, and Dean Stockwell, who is being borrowed from M-G-M, will be his nephew.

"The Original Amateur Hour," featuring Ted Mack as master of ceremonies, is to be sponsored commercially this fall on both television and radio, with different versions of the program being prepared for each medium, it was announced yesterday.
I have just returned to New York from Jerusalem, where I serve as the acting pastor of Jerusalem Baptist Church.
