RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 -- Political events in Sao Paulo took a turn for the worse today. The president of the State Assembly informed President Enrico Gaspar Dutra that the situation in Sao Paulo had deteriorated and urged that steps be taken to correct the situation.

A short circuit caused by a water main leak yesterday put out of operation 1,200 teletype circuits serving news and radio services, Government agencies, commercial houses and brokerage firms in the midtown and financial areas.

While the inflation issue continued to be debated vigorously this week by political leaders the Treasury finally got around to taking a step in the field of credit control that has long been advocated by the Federal Reserve authorities and other proponents of credit restriction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Nearly 100 high school delegates to "girls nation" walked through the long corridors of the huge Pentagon building today, but they were awed more when they toured the marble Supreme Court building.

Italy's textile trade needs American encouragement to get over a very difficult period resulting from unsettled economic and political conditions, according to Franco Scalamandre, New York silk manufacturer, recently returned from a trip abroad.
The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that it would award $3,500,000 in grants for cancer research in the year beginning Sept. 1.

Sam Minskoff Sons announced yesterday the completion of renting of their new two-story business building occupying the entire northerly blockfront on Thirty-seventh Avenue between Seventy-first and Seventy-seventh Streets in Jackson Heights.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP) -- "Repairs" to the railway link between blockaded Berlin and the Western zones of Germany were reported virtually completed today but there was no sign the Russians would reopen the line.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics bounded back to defeat the Washington Senators, 11 -- 2, in the second game of a twilight double-header tonight after they had dropped the first game, 8 -- 2. The victory kept the A's in second place, six percentage points behind the Cleveland Indians.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., chairman of the House Labor Committee, announced today at an investigation into Communist infiltration of New York department store labor unions that he would sue for libel the persons in those unions responsible for circulars attacking him for asking witnesses whether they were or ever had been members of the Communist party.
Those who feel that breaking a mirror or passing under a ladder is bad luck will see their pet superstitions treated roughly on Friday (the 13th, in case you've forgotten).

Bequests totaling $375,000 to nine Catholic and thirteen Protestant charitable organizations, and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies were announced yesterday by executors of the estate of the late Dr. Otto Sussman.

One of the few major expeditions into Africa in recent years produced proof yesterday that civilization had penetrated Africa's last holdouts of the simple life. The natives now want more money for less work and better working conditions.

The stock market broke yesterday through its previous resistance level and sank to the lowest mark on the Stock Exchange since last mid-April. Only moderate pressure again proved necessary to unsettle a vulnerable share list as prices melted on selling but slightly heavier than in recent sessions.

WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. 10 -- Herbert Hoover came back to his home town today for his seventy-fourth birthday and to tell Americans that this nation, with all its high promises, could not be conquered except by men inspired by the concepts of free spirit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A voluntary plan for allocation by the steel industry of 59,000 tons of steel sheet and strip for the manufacture of prefabricated houses was approved today by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Informed quarters disclosed today that, in deciding the future of Italy's former colonies, the Soviet Union would insist upon Libya's being treated as a whole and not partitioned. This demand might well become a major obstacle to agreement between the Soviet Union and the three Western powers.

With the cotton trade endeavoring to interpret the significance of Monday's Government crop estimate of 15,169,000 bales, the volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday declined considerably. Prices at one time were down 20 to 25 points for the active positions, but toward the close there was a partial rally and final prices for the active months were 6 to 16 points net lower, while October, 1949, was down 38 points.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Saratoga's yearling sales started off slowly tonight when forty-nine colts and fillies were offered in the Fasig-Tipton auction ring and brought a total of $120,200.

At a special meeting in Kansas City yesterday, stockholders of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., other than those representing the Hughes Tool Company, approved a proposal to convert a $10,000,000 loan given to TWA by Hughes Tool into common stock of the airline.
Benjamin A. Benedict closes his persuasive and eloquent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which he opposes conscription, with this paragraph:
The story of New York will be told in exhibit form at the Grand Central Palace starting Aug. 23 as part of the celebration of the golden anniversary of the city.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Despite the Soviet blockade of Berlin, the United Nations expects to send medical and some specialized food supplies to the former German capital as part of its $1,000,000 over-all welfare program for German children.

Henry A. Wallace will formally open his Presidential campaign on Aug. 21 with a speech in Bridgeport, Conn., it was announced yesterday at Progressive party headquarters, 39 Park Avenue. It will be Mr. Wallace's first appearance on the speaking platform since his acceptance speech in Philadelphia on July 24.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- A proposal that statesmen take psychologists and social scientists into partnership with them in their efforts to cure the ills of international society will be made at the International Congress on Mental Health, the premilinary sessions of which begin here tomorrow.

America's victory yesterday via the movies in the 400-meter relay final marked the second time that United States athletes won arguments by the use of pictures in Olympic games held in London, The Associated Press reports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The net working capital of American corporations increased another $1,600,000,000 during the first quarter of 1948 to a new record level of $62,400,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its quarterly analysis.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Miss Harriet G. Sayles, 18-year-old Wellesley College student and daughter of a Cornell University professor, was reported in serious condition today from a bullet wound.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The Sea Cliff Yacht Club's representatives, including Skipper Thomas N. Manuel and his crew of Lenard Chapman and Allen Bushing, held a 1-point lead for the Long Island Sound junior yachting championship this evening at the conclusion of the first two events in the five-race competition which started today in practically no breeze at Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Truman will preside at a series of political conferences at the White House this week, it was learned tonight. One and perhaps two gatherings of top-rank ...

The Commercial Credit Company reported yesterday a record net income for a half year period with consolidated profit of $7,789,835, after preferred dividends, equal to $4.23 a common share for the six months ended June 30. This compared with $2,858,556, or $1.55 a share, for the same period in 1947.

WARSAW, Aug. 10 -- The credentials of the International Conference of Working Youth refused today to seat Charles Haywood of New York, representative of the American organization of World Federalists.

Local sponsors of the one week meat boycott, which began on Monday, stepped up their organization plans and claimed more recruits yesterday. A sampling of retail butchers, however, reported little or no change in business, which has been generally bad for six weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Government set out today to find out why the domestic airlines, the most heavily traveled in the world, cannot make money.
An issue of $2,000,000 of New Mexico State Highway debentures, due Feb. 1 and Aug. 1, 1960, and Feb. 1, 1961, has been sold to Phelps Fenn Co. and associates on a bid of 100.17 for 2 1/2s.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- In the slowest competitive day of the Olympic games the United States added 28 points to its huge total -- 18 in weightlifting and 10 when the appeal jury ruled it had won Saturday's 400-meter relay.

The resignation of Edward C. Maguire as the city's Commissioner of Commerce, a position to which he was appointed on Nov. 6, 1947, offers an opportunity for Mayor O'Dwyer to take a fresh look at this department and decide what ought to be done with it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Truman signed today a modified version of the housing measure he requested of the special session of Congress and asserted that Republican leaders had "deliberately neglected" those large groups of people forced to live in urban and rural slums.

Good Neighbor Federation in the heart of the Puerto Rican section of East Harlem is seeking funds to reopen its doors and provide for another settlement house in an area with low-grade housing, poor recreational facilities and crowded living conditions.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 10 -- Six kinds of radiation from the sun, each significantly variable in its intensity, were listed here today by Dr. M. Waldmeier, director of the Swiss Federal Observatory. The astronomer spoke to a meeting here of the mixed commission on solar and terrestrial relationships of the International Astronomical Union, the International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics and the International Radio Scientific Union.

A study and collective portrait of American labor leaders, entitled "The New Men of Power," by C. Wright Mills, will be published by Harcourt, Brace late in September. Dr. Mills teaches sociology at Columbia University and is director of the university's labor research division of the Bureau of Applied Social Research.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Disqualification of the American team that finished first in the 400-meter relay race on the final day of the Olympic track and field games in Wembley Stadium on Saturday officially was declared to have been in error today and the victory was awarded to the United States, raising its total of gold medals in men's track and field to eleven.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- A punch in the nose -- or cheek -- is one of the recognized risks of conducting union-management relations, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Charles S. Dewey, former Congressman from Illinois and now agent general for the Joint Congressional ["watchdog"] Committee on Foreign Economic Cooperation, stressed at a press conference today the possibilities of the Marshall Plan in aiding private trade exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Navy said today that forty-eight ships and twelve aircraft squadrons won battle efficiency pennants in the first post-war fleet training contest. The heavy cruiser Helena and the light cruiser Providence also received cash prizes of more than $2,000.

ATHENS, Aug. 10 -- Elements of the Ninth Division of the National Army encountered strong resistance from the Communist-led rebel force in the area just north of the Saranta River, according to military information available here this evening.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Jeanne Lanvin shows a break with tradition, leading to a lighter touch, especially evident in the handling of the decorative element and often in the choice of less heavy fabrics.

The "Voice of America" is being stepped up from a mild information service to a full-fledged, hard-hitting propaganda machine. Considered a strong arm of the State Department, it will concentrate its chief output against the Iron Curtain.

In its semi-annual, large-space newspaper campaign in key markets, Pacific Mills' Worsted Division will use two specialized ads this fall instead of the general one of other seasons, it was announced yesterday. The schedule, covering thirty-five newspapers of twenty-seven major cities, calls for separate ads on men's and women's fabrics, beginning Sept. 15.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Thirty-four companies and individuals today pleaded innocent in Federal district court to charges they conspired to fix prices in the nation's billion dollar paint and wood stains industries.

IN February, 1936, a man died in Atlanta who was one of that city's most distinguished citizens. He was 67 years old, the president of Atlanta University, an educator with an international reputation, a great teacher, a courageous champion of many a righteous cause. Although John Hope was admired and loved by many thousands of people, his name is not generally familiar.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- Two German committees, in separate meetings, proceeded today with the drafting of a working paper for a West-German parliamentary assembly and with outlining a formula to amalgamate the three existing states in a single one to be part of a new regime.

Prospects of record grain harvests this year, as reported yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, clearly indicate that high prices, when taken in conjunction with reasonably favorable weather conditions, mean production from the American farmer. The grain markets, however, have anticipated the bumper harvests this year and prices of the leading grains now are from 30 per cent to 50 per cent below their highs reached in mid-January.
FKANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Aug. 10 -- The escape of Dr. Peter Zenkl, former Vice Premier of Czechoslovakia, into the American zone with his wife became known today.

The Department of Sanitation's 1949 capital program for improvement of its waste disposal and street cleaning operations was started yesterday when the Board of Estimate approved the construction of an 800-ton incinerator on Betts Avenue in Maspeth, Queens.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 10 -- John De Biasio, described by the authorities as "a gambler," was killed here early this morning by a volley of shots as he sat in his new automobile in front of his home, 28 South Reid Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Farmers are on a record-smashing food-production spree which may help bring down the spiraling cost of living, it is concluded from a report by the Department of Agriculture on crop conditions on Aug. 1 which was issued today. Total production this year will top any other year -- including the big war years -- by 6 per cent.

A few minutes before noon yesterday a Congressional committee subpoena was handed to Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, Russian school teacher sought by the police at the request of the Soviet Government, as he walked westward in Thirty-eighth Street between Park and Madison Avenues.

Giles Stedman, former commodore of the United States Lines fleet and later superintendent of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., has just returned from a tour of the Far East for the shipping company.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10 -- The final squadron cruise run of the New York Yacht Club back here today from the eastern coastal islands was a case of running after the wind one-third of the way instead of with it.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 10 -- A wandering street finally found a home last night just outside the city limits here.

July shipments of rayon yarn and staple fiber totaled 94,900,000 pounds, 17 per cent more than a year ago, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. For the first seven months of the year shipments of rayon totaled 632,400,000 pounds, an increase of 19 per cent over the 1947 January-July period.
Home canning on a large scale demands a spacious kitchen, a near-by garden and orchard to supply fresh produce. Neither requirement is easily met in New York.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Long shots continued to win at Atlantic City today with the featured Salt Water Purse going to Mrs. W.W. Vaughan's Briar White, a $21 for $2 outsider.

PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A group of American pastors denounced as "unbiblical, unpatriotic and un-American" today the recent call by a group of United States clergymen for a day of mourning to protest the American draft law.

Action of the special session of Congress in approving renewal of Title VI of the National Housing Act and appropriating funds for its continuance will serve as a "shot in the arm" for the rental housing industry in New York and other cities, in the opinion of Fred C. Trump, Brooklyn builder.

Although staying close to home, retail coat and suit buyers are reordering heavily by mail, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers of women's apparel and resident offices said that reorders have proven "very encouraging" in both popular-priced and higher-priced merchandise.

Radio parts distributors, through the National Electronic Distributors Association, Chicago, are taking action to protest competitive sales of radio tubes by radio manufacturers who buy at from 25 to 50 per cent less than independent distributors' costs, Aaron Lippman, president of the association revealed in a statement here yesterday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- On a grassy field with a background of tall pines, Mirror Lake and the flags of twenty-three nations, 125 Girl Scouts of New York and Westchester presented a pageant of American life this afternoon at Camp Andree, near here.

A man who was grateful for the streptomycin cure of a member of his family, a Denver hospital and a German-speaking group here responded quickly yesterday to the plea for a quick shipment of the drug for ten child victims of tuberculosis meningitis in the French zone of Berlin.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- America's fencers entered the semi-final round of the Olympic team saber tournament today with two easy victories.

The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, AFL, the organization of stagehands, assailed yesterday the temporary injunction obtained by the American Broadcasting Company in connection with last night's premiere of its television station, WJZ-TV.

At least 30,000,000 persons in the United States now require some form of mental hygiene treatment, Prof. Esther Lloyd-Jones, head of the guidance laboratory of Columbia University's Teachers College, declared yesterday. She said that every one of these persons is or has been a student in our schools or colleges and that the nation's educational institutions were failing to meet the mental health needs of the people.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A formal inter-service committee of the national military establishment recommended today, after nine months deliberation, that the National Guard be brought under Federal control, but James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, declined to support this or any part of his committee's proposed legislative program.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company awarded yesterday a $3,600,000 equipment-trust certificate issue to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associated underwriters on a bid of 99.40. The issue, due serially on Sept. 1, 1949 to 1958, carries a 2 5/8 per cent coupon.

Early birds who bought tickets in advance for train travel inside New York State will ride more cheaply today than those who pay their fare. This is the day one-way coach rates rise from two and a half cents a mile to three cents under authorization of the Public Service Commission. Commuters are not affected but there are comparable rises in first-class fares and on round-trip tickets.

Long Island defeated the Metropolitan squad, 8 to 1, and Westchester turned back New Jersey, 5 to 4, as play in the Eastern Junior Davis Cup team competition began yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Bob Feller went down to this thirteenth defeat of the season today as young Ted Gray snapped the Indians' three-game winning streak by pitching the Tigers to a 7-to-3 victory.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Stricter supervision of the uneasy truce in Jerusalem was announced today by Count Bernadotte.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Dr. Peter Zenkl, anti-Communist elder statesman of Czechoslovakia, has been smuggled to safety in the United States zone of Germany by members of a democratic underground in the Czechoslovak Army, refugee camp officials announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- If you couldn't break an Olympic or world record at the Olympic weight-lifting today you definitely were out of style. It was only incidental that the United States moved ahead of the pack in the team standing.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The United States and Britain hammered today at Yugoslavia's conduct in Trieste and renewed their call for the return of the city to Italy.
WEST BRANCH, Iowa, Aug. l0 -- The text of the address made here today by former President Hoover at his seventy-fourth birthday celebration follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 -- India outlined her case for the acquisition of Hyderabad, independent Princely State almost the size of Minnesota and sprawling across the middle of the Indian Peninsula, in a White Paper laid before the Dominion Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Maurice J. Tobin said today he will choose within forty-eight hours between an appointment as Secretary of Labor and his candidacy for Governor of Massachusetts. He said he will not join President Truman's Cabinet and campaign for himself, too, although there is no legal bar to that course.

American manufacturers of jeweled watches are still feeling the effects of Swiss competition and now have about 20-25 per cent of the United States market against a pre-war ratio of about 35-40 per cent. This was stated yesterday by J.G. Shennan, president of the Elgin National Watch Company, in an interview at the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Speculation where "Magdalena," the elaborate musical containing a score by the Brazilian composer, Heitor Villa-Lobos, would hang out its shingle was ended yesterday. At hand is an announcement from Billy Rose, owner of the Ziegfeld, saying the production, which Edwin Lester is whipping into shape on the Coast, would arrive at his theatre on Sept. 20.
A new program designed to aid 25,000 children on Navajo Indian reservations in four states has been adopted by the Save the Children Federation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The payment of at least $2,000 by a "high" representative of the Soviet Union for services in wartime by Communist espionage rings operating out of Washington was declared by the House Committee on Un-American Activities tonight to have been confirmed officially.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Grain markets broke sharply in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, all deliveries of corn and lard selling at new seasonal low prices as the result of general liquidation, with stop-loss orders uncovered on the way down.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank rolled up a definite majority over his four opponents in returns from today's Democratic Senatorial primary.

Dr. Abe R. Wexler of Jackson Heights and the Bayside Club, a dentist, moved into second position among the Long Island contestants with a shot landing 5 inches from the cup during the second day of the World-Telegram hole-in-one golf tournament at the Bayside Club's special hole yesterday.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations indicated today that the jurisdictional labor dispute at the Welin Davit and Boat Company plant here, now in its sixth week, was nearing an end.

The various investigations that have led to the indictment of twelve top Communist leaders on charges of conspiracy to overthrow the American Government and the disclosure of considerable evidence regarding a Russian spy ring have assumed a new aspect as a result of the actions of the Russian Ambassador and the Russian Consul General in New York.

Some time ago THE TIMES had a good editorial suggesting that traffic conditions in New York City would be improved if most of the taxicabs were shorter. Changes in the city regulations to bring this result were proposed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 10 -- After conferring for an hour with the Prime Minister of Egypt, Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, at Alexandria, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary General of the Arab League, announced today that "the Arabs" rejected categorically the proposal of Moshe Shertok, Foreign Minister of Israel, for a direct Arab-Israeli peace conference.

New rules on foreign aid bulk shipments, issued on Monday by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to implement the price clause in Section 202 of the ECA Appropriation Act, actually constitute "rewriting of regulations on the whole field of procurement," it was learned here authoritatively.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Selective Service headquarters have begun sending out 10,000,000 classification questionnaires that will determine which of the country's young men 19 to 26 years old will be called up for military service and when.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 -- Rates for utility services in New York State showed a net increase of $6,900,000 during 1947, the first time in seventeen years that increases have exceeded reductions, Milo R. Maltbie, Public Service Commission chairman, reported today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Gladiolus growers from New Jersey, eastern New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut displayed some of their finest blooms at the State Armory here today. The show also may be seen tomorrow from 10:30 A.M. to 10 P.M.

The history of the fighting in Palestine clearly shows in retrospect that the Arabs led from weakness and not from strength, that they sent a boy to do a man's job, and that stalemate and frustration are now, therefore, their resultant lot.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Brazil, Chile and China joined the Communist bloc today in an unsuccessful effort to exclude locally hired correspondents of foreign news media from a proposed international convention on the gathering and transmission of news.

The Far East Conference of steamship lines will meet this week to lay plans for its defense against a legal action filed last week by the Department of Justice charging monopolistic conspiracy and restraint of trade, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Democratic National Committee today announced plans for the observance of Democratic Women's Day on Monday, Sept. 27.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 10 -- Three of the five Britons, held by the Israeli authorities on suspicion of espionage, were released by the Magistrate's Court here today. The two others were remanded for trial in Jerusalem.

Members of the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to permit fourteen privately owned bus and trolley companies to apply to the Public Service Commission for fare increases from 5 to 7 cents, and a fifteenth, the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, to seek a rise from 10 to 12 cents.

TORQUAY, England, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A flurry of protests marked the fifth day of the Olympic yacht races today as competitors from seventeen nations prepared for final encounters. Only two more days of racing remain for each of the five classes before total compilations are made to determine the champions.

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- A favorite, under top poundage, and a fifth choice, under a feathery allotment, showed the way in the two divisions of the main event at Old Saratoga today. Each won with plenty to spare and each was timed in 1:12 3/5 for six furlongs over a track that still showed the effects of yesterday's thunderstorms.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Eleven of the remaining sixty-nine eligibles for the Hambletonian today were named to start in tomorrow's twenty-third running of the world's top trotting classic for 3-year-olds. Valued at $59,941, of which $32,500.15 will be the winner's share, the time-honored stake will be contested on the basis of the best two-out-of-three heats.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- A special Tchaikovsky program was given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra tonight in the music shed, with Seymour Lipkin, the pianist, who was the winner last spring of the Rachmaninoff Fund national piano contest, as soloist in the performance of the B Flat Minor Concerto.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- Leo Durocher met a desperate situation with desperate measures at Braves Field tonight, and, with the aid of some questionable playing by the league-leaders, saw his Giants loosen the Braves' grip on first place.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Rigid targets will be omitted from the long-term program that the Organization for European Economic Cooperation will start preparing here this week and report to the United States administrator next November.

London's famed Old Vic Theatre Company will come here in January for a New York engagement and a tour of this country and Canada, it was learned yesterday. The troupe's American appearance will be sponsored by Theatre Incorporated, its host during a triumphant six-week visit to Broadway during the spring of 1946.

Queens Borough President James A. Burke condemned yesterday the construction of homes on ground that has not been prepared adequately to support necessary gas and water supply lines. He called for new laws to block housing construction on such "dumps, bogs or marshland."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, offered today to support claims for redress made by any employes of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., New York, who might lose their jobs under a "reciprocal discharge" clause in the company's contract with a left-wing labor organization.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Eleven 3-year-old trotters vied for the gold and glory that accompany the Hambletonian -- the most popular and richest stake in harness racing -- today at Good Time Park. Ten should never have left their stalls.

Being an interested party, I am somewhat reluctant to comment on the charges of Americans "being taken for a ride" and "unbelievable profits," made by Earl Heinsel and published so prominently in your Aug. 6 issue. I feel, however, that your readers are entitled to know more about this "scandal," the more so as my experience in the gift parcel business might prove more valuable than guesswork and sensationalism.

The first details of a new and far-reaching venture in public health, by which the city plans to make the diagnostic skills of medical specialists available for low-income patients, were made public yesterday by Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health.

A further advance in air safety at sea was marked yesterday off Execution Rock in Long Island Sound when the Edo Corporation of College Point dropped its thirty-foot, all metal, powered lifeboat 1,500 feet on a hundred-foot parachute from a B-29.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Mad Carpentier has raised the waistline two or three inches above normal and continued barrel lines in a collection in which dark rich colors reign -- bluish greens, bronze, midnight and deep sapphire blues, violet and heather.

The 108 foreign mission boards of sixty-one Protestant denominations have approved a combined effort to finance expansion of their missions overseas for five to ten years, the Rev. Dr. Wynn C. Fairfield, secretary of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today an order issued in 1939 which held that the Associated General Utilities Company, New York, was a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, predecessors of the General Public Utilities Corporation.
A new local law to govern the use of sound trucks will be introduced in the City Council at its next meeting on Aug. 31, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The American basketball team hurdled what had been fancied the biggest obstacle in its path to the Olympic championship with a crushing victory over Mexico, 71 to 40, to reach the final round tonight. In the other semi-final, France unexpectedly defeated Brazil, 43 to 33, and will play the United States Friday night for the title in an intercontinental final.
Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an automobile use tax of $5 a year on passenger cars and $10 on trucks will be shelved when the City Council holds its next meeting on Aug. 31.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 -- Sir Charles Peake, chief British delegate to the conference on the Danube, said today that he wished to serve notice, in reply to many allusions and statements of Eastern European delegations to the contrary, that the British considered their participation in the conference to be without prejudice to their rights and privileges under the 1921 convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman signed extra session legislation today authorizing a $65,000,000 loan to the United Nations for construction of new headquarters in New York City. He said the action "demonstrates our faith in the future of the United Nations and expresses the welcome which that organization finds within our country."
Drapery and upholstery fabrics designed by Mexico's leading artists and lamps by an American craftsman living south of the border now are available to New Yorkers.
The Liberal party, which polled 309,000 votes in New York State for the Roosevelt-Truman ticket in the 1944 election, came out last night for the election of Harry S. Truman to the Presidency.
A flashily-garbed gunman invading the Sunshine Laundry, 818 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, locked five employes in a kitchen and escaped with a $10,000 cash payroll.

The Committee on Civilian Components (of the Armed Forces) has advised Defense Secretary Forrestal that the national security of the United States requires that the three services -- Army, Navy and Air -- each have one federal reserve force. As now constituted Army and Air each has two, the Organized Reserve Corps of the Army and the National Guard and the Air Reserve and the Air National Guard respectively.

For five and a half years Emilio Franco, a 35-year-old machinist and coal miner from Fairmont, W. Va., has been speechless. After one frightening ride on the Cyclone at Coney Island he can speak again. He said so himself yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- New York bankers today were given credit for the growth of Kingsport, Tenn., from a small community without rail transportation facilities prior to 1909, to an important industrial city with a population estimated at from 40,000 to 50,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Reductions in the rail rates on canned citrus fruits and juices, and canned vegetables, from Florida points to points in the northeastern section of the country will go into effect Aug. 21 as the result of action taken today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The American Guild of Variety Artists, of the American Federation of Labor, came forward today to give a "decent" burial to May de Sousa, once a noted light opera singer, who died a penniless scrubwoman.

Babe Ruth, home-run king of the baseball world, was in critical condition last night at Memorial Hospital, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street. A terse hospital bulletin, issued in the morning, said that the 53-year-old Ruth had a high temperature and that there were "pulmonary complications." In the evening another bulletin said his condition was "slightly improved," but "still critical."

BOOTH BAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 11 -- Maurice Meyers of Brielle, N.J., took the two daily awards in the annual individual Maine tuna tournament today with a 310-pound fish, one of three taken by the fifty-one entrants during the first day of the event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Grain exports from this country through the Economic Cooperation Administration will be "appreciably larger" than the 350,000,000-bushel earlier ECA estimate in view of yesterday's highly optimistic crop report, Dennis A. Fitzgerald, director of the administration's food and agriculture division, told a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Mr. Milling told the subcommittee today that there were four ways in which a minority of Communists could control a union. One of the most effective of these, he said, is use of the "commie diamond."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Registration statements covering 100,000 shares of capital stock and $2,500,000 of income debentures were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

RHODES, Aug. 11 -- Count Folke Bernadotte, the United Nations Mediator in Palestine, announced here tonight that he had asked both Israeli and Arab elements in Jerusalem to promise not to fire even if fired upon.

The deer hunting season had a head start yesterday in the Bronx. Mrs. May Bankesser, sipping her 9 A.M. orange juice at 778 Waring Avenue, saw the deer, "the size of a pony," playing "peeping Tom" through her dinette window.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- America's last chance for first place in the Olympic fencing went by the boards today after the powerful Hungarian saber team defeated the United States team in a final-round match by 10 to 6 at Wembley's Palace of Engineering.

It is hardly an exaggeration to say that the Aug. 1 crop estimates just released by the Department of Agriculture border on the sensational. These figures point to the probability of a corn crop of record size, a wheat crop second only to last year's great harvest, and new all-time highs in the production of soy beans, rice, peanuts and pecans.

A free consultation and affidavit service for irregular entrants to the United States who wish to legalize their status under a recent amendment to the Immigration Act has been set up at the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, it was announced yesterday by Isaac L. Asofsky, executive director.

The Rev. E.J. Hogan, in his admirable letter in your July 27 issue, points out with great clarity the distinction between stock ownership and corporation ownership. Theoretically, and legally as well, the stockholders own the corporation. But, in the case of very large corporations, they exercise no control.

As members of a Presidential fact-finding board met here yesterday to get the latest information, or a threatened seamen's strike, it was announced that a similar board might be named to study a contract dispute between longshoremen and employers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Conferences will begin in New York on Monday between James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, and representatives of Hollywood's Association of Motion Picture Producers regarding a new contract for film musicians to become effective Aug. 31, when the existing two-year agreement expires.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) Stanley Musical, drove in four runs today to take the lead in that department in the National League with 89 as the Cardinals downed Cincinnati, 9 to 4. He also hit a home run in the first frame with no one on to boost his total to 28, just one behind league-leading Ralph Kiner of the Pirates.
Bus drivers are servants of the public and must try to maintain a better rein on their tempers, Magistrate Morris Ploscowe warned a defendant yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court.

Rabbi Shlomo Lorentz, who arrived here Tuesday by air from Palestine on a furlough from Haganah, the Israeli Army, said yesterday that he would spend the next two months in mobilizing Orthodox Jews in the United States for the financial and moral support of Israel.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Toll roads for New Jersey will be one of the principal items on the program of the State Legislature at its special session, starting Monday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Western Long Island Sound skippers continued to show the way in the current Atlantic coast star class championship being run off in Great South Bay. Today it was W.P. O'Gorman's Wahini that triumphed in the second day of the series, emulating the victory registered by his fleetmate, Skip Etchells, who sailed Shillalah home first yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Reports from Moscow today deepened the pessimism already existing here regarding the outcome of the talks between the Western envoys and Soviet leaders. Officials in close touch with the negotiations said the chances were now against their success.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- A crisis has been reached in the Moscow talks on Berlin, it was learned on good authority here tonight, and there is a strong atmosphere of pessimism. Barring a shift by the Russians from their present intransigent stand there is every probability that the four powers will have to register an inability to agree.

Plans have been completed by the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases, East Forty-ninth Street and Rutland Road, Brooklyn, for a new department of physical medicine and an extensive rehabilitation program, it was announced yesterday by Isaac Albert, president of the institution.

Crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new high daily average of 5,504,550 barrels, an increase of 49,100 over the output of 5,455,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous peak was 5,493,900 barrels in the week ended June 26.

"The Autobiography of Sol Bloom" has been scheduled for October publication by Putnam. He tells how a theatrical manager became counselor to four Presidents, a real estate operator became chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, and a one-time song writer was chosen to draft the preamble to the Charter of the United Nations in 1945.

Your paper carries astonishing news. Unfortunately, it is also true. Today we read that the United States delegate in the United Nations Economic and Social Council was one of four who voted against a resolution carried by the votes of nine other nations providing for equal economic rights of women, "equal rights with men in employment and remuneration, leisure, social insurance and professional training."

One of the major tragedies resulting from the dislocations of this post-war era -- a tragedy which demands immediate action -- is represented by the desperate plight of the Arab refugees from Israel. Driven out by the hostilities which attended the birth of the new state, or fleeing from what they regarded as an uncertain fate, these refugees now number 250,000 to 550,000, exceeding the number of Jewish displaced persons still in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Ellard A. Walsh, president of the National Guard Association of the United States, bitterly attacked today a proposal that the National Guard be brought under Federal control, and he promised to fight it "at every turn."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Prospects of broad slashes in Federal excise taxes were dimmed somewhat today by Representative Harold Knutson, Republican, of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Mikhaii Ivanovitch Samarin, the Russian-born school teacher who has been subpoenaed by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, will receive the complete protection of the United States Government and will not be released to the Soviet authorities, despite the demand of Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin, Secretary of State George C. Marshall clearly intimated today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The new Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin of Boston, will find a department that has been reduced to a shell, its morale as low as that of an unwanted stepchild.

A modern adventure story was unfolded yesterday after Navy ships had sighted hundreds of miles out at sea a seventeen-foot converted Army amphibious truck in which an Australian major and his American wife were attempting a trip around the world.

"Festival of Song," a half-hour musical series featuring Mishel Piastro and the Symphonette, will have its premiere at 2 P.M., Sunday, Sept. 26, over the CBS network. A sixteen-voice male choir also will be heard on the program, which will offer light classical and familiar American music.

As the site for improvement eventually with a new home and workshop, the property at 147-49-51 West Twenty-third Street has been purchased by the Associated Blind of the City of New York from Morris Fein. The parcel consists of a taxpayer and six-story offices on a plot 65 by 100 feet which the group will occupy pending erection of the new structure.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and Mrs. Hogan were among 1,100 passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

Masonite Slates Record Drive The Masonite Corporation, manufacturer of hardboards, will begin on Sept. 1 a twelve-month national advertising campaign described as the largest yet undertaken by the company, it was announced yesterday. Large-space and some four-color pages have been scheduled in twenty national, home, farm, architectural, industrial and trade publications, Donald E. Allen, advertising manager, reported.
Mrs. Ruth W. Whaley, an attorney, was sworn in yesterday by Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, as his executive assistant, in his office at 902 Broadway.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Browns defeated Cleveland, 12 -- 4, in the floodlighted game of a twilight-night double header tonight after the Indians had taken the first contest, 7 -- 5. This left the Indians ahead of their closest rivals, the Athletics, by a fraction of a percentage point, though Philadelphia had a half-length advantage so far as the won-and-lost columns were concerned.
Gerardo (Kid) Gavilan of Cuba continues his quest for welterweight laurels tonight when he trades punches with Buster Tyler of Newark in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 11 -- The Long Island team of Mrs. Bernard Freeman and Miss Margaret Mackie of Inwood won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Scotch foursome tourney over the Hempstead Golf Club course with an 84 today for a 36-hole aggregate of 164.

The Yankee losing streak is mounting to alarming proportions and if Manager Bucky Harris is not able to apply the brakes immediately, his 1947 world champions are likely to backslide right out of the American League pennant race.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Gaffery, a 2-year-old filly bred and owned by William du Pont Jr.'s Foxcatcher Farms, made her racing record three for three at Saratoga today when she beat nine others in the $7,500 added Schuylerville Stakes.

A $20,000,000 issue of 200,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $4.80 dividend series, without par value, of Northern States Power Company of Minnesota will be offered to the public today by an underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co.

The children's library of the Benjamin Franklin Library in Mexico City, operated by the United States Department of State, was praised yesterday by its librarian, Miss Eva J. Anttonen, as "a concrete example of democracy at work." The library is the only free public institution in Mexico that has a complete section devoted to children, she said.

ROME, Thursday, Aug. 12 -- The Popular Front, which was created at the end of last year by the Communists in the hope of defeating the Christian Democrats in the April election, was dissolved late last night. The parties that composed it undertook, however, to consult on concerted action whenever events made such action advisable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -President Truman began issuing recess appointments today to the long list of nominees to Government posts who were not confirmed by the Senate during the recent extra session.

Sidney S. McMath, last night apparently had won the Democratic nomination for Governor in the Arkansas primary of Tuesday. He had a margin of 9,752 votes over Jack W. Holt, former Attorney General, with only 86 precincts missing, according to The Associated Press.

A one-day show of arts and crafts by 300 youngsters who have been attending sessions in religious vacation centers in Brooklyn and Queens took place yesterday in the sculpture hall of the Brooklyn Museum on Eastern Parkway.

Extravagant demands upon manufacturers for large dues payments by customer associations in the dairy industry are being questioned by a Committee on Customer Association Relations of the Dairy Industries Supply Association, officials pointed out here yesterday.

The tremendous summer passenger rush to Europe and the Mediterranean, which filled to capacity every large liner leaving here in the last two months, is coming to a close, a survey of steamship line booking offices showed yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The first of the top four players was tumbled from the twenty-second annual eastern men's grass courts tennis championship today as Victor Seixas of Philadelphia upset third-seeded Billy Talbert of New York, 13 -- 11, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2 at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Late spring floods in the Pacific Northwest were reflected in reduced production of aluminum in June, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, reported yesterday. He said that only 97,565,606 pounds of primary aluminum were produced in the United States in that month, compared with 110,900,429 in May.

"El Canto Del Cisne" ("The Song of the Swan"), an Argentine-made film, will begin a week's stand today at the Belmont Theatre. The romantic drama, which features Mecha Ortiz, Miguel Angel and Miguel Gomez Bao, was directed by Hugo Christenson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Truman told a mixed gathering of 400, including politicians, welfare officials and boys and girls today that our goal of "peace for all time" would be realized ultimately through the youth of America in whose hands its fate resides.

The garage property comprising a one and two story building occupying the Wythe Avenue block-front between North Eleventh and North Twelfth Streets in Brooklyn has been sold by the Luburt Industrial Corporation to the Yellowstone Realty Corporation, represented by Louis Horwitz, attorney. Sale was for all cash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WARSAW, Aug. 11 -- Sensitive to rumors that Wladyslaw Gomulka was in disgrace for "attempting a Tito," the Polish Government issued a communique today stating that the Vice Premier and Secretary General of the Communist party had visited the Western territories exposition at Wroclaw (Breslau) yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- About $15,000,000,000 of this year's national income will be used for protection against financial upsets, according to the Research Council for Economic Security, a privately financed Chicago organization. The council, analyzing the latest available data, found that $12,000,000,000 had been spent in 1945 under some organized plan to meet insecurity arising from death, old age, accident, sickness, disability, unemployment and other contingencies.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- An Italian mission headed by Republican Deputy Ugo la Malfa will leave tomorrow for Moscow, where it will discuss and if possible settle various economic and financial problems existing between Italy and the Soviet Union. If it succeeds in overcoming these preliminary obstacles, it will then negotiate an Italo-Russian treaty of commerce and navigation.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States weight-lifting squad, topped by John Davis' two world heavyweight records, swept the Olympic weight-lifting team competition with 63 points in a meet which ended tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey, in an informal talk with a group of young Republicans, declared today that the Republican party had been rejuvenated and today was looking forward, not backward to "the dim, departed, almost forgotten and surely never to be recovered past."

The manner in which British officials and public accepted the reversal of the field disqualification of the United States 400-meter relay team, thus giving the victory back to the Americans and taking from Britain her only Olympic track and field gold medal, was to be expected.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Attempting to avoid the complete bankruptcy of the city government in the Western sectors, the United States, British and French Military Governments ordered the City Assembly today to stop the free movement of bank holdings to the Soviet sector and to establish a new city treasury.

The Quartermaster Purchasing Office yesterday awarded contracts for 50,000 yards of 28-ounce wool velour, 56 inches wide, blue. Continental Mills, Inc., received awards for 20,000 yards at $4.74 a yard, and Hayward Woolen Company 300,000 yards at $4.875 less discount of 1 per cent, twenty days.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- Strong denunciation of the Argentine regime, which expelled an Oppositionist Deputy for having criticized President Juan Peron, has been sent to Ernesto Sammartino, Uruguayan Congress. A stenographic copy of the debate has been sent to Ernesto San Martino, expelled deputy, it was learned today.

Grinning like the cat that had just swallowed the canary after watching ms Dodgers complete a three-game sweep over the Phils and win their fourth straight, 3 -- 2, at Ebbets Field yesterday, Manager Barney Shotton took his second-place Brooks to Boston last night with first place his immediate target.

A new aircraft parking and storage plan was put into effect at La Guardia Field yesterday in accordance with orders of the Port of New York Authority, which operates the airport. Although the operation of one of the major airlines was affected to some extent, the purpose of the new arrangement was not announced.

The State Department's most conspicuous effort in the foreign information field, the "Voice of America," is being overhauled, tightened and re-aimed at its prime targets. It is scheduled for greater effectiveness, the better to combat falsehoods spread abroad about the United States, and to rearm with information the populations whose indecision is being fostered by Soviet Russia.

The college shop at Altman's was officially opened yesterday with a sprightly fashion promenade. Skirts sporting back fullness swished, up and down the runway. Weskits found special favor, amusingly ensembled with skirts and blouses and treated in varying ways.
NEWARK N.J., Aug. 11 -- Joseph O'Neal, who served as a special policeman in Newark's Third Ward for thirty-two years, died yesterday. He was 52 years old.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Human Rights Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council turned down a proposal today that would have made news media publish corrections to false reports.
The giant skeleton of the new Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn is complete and yesterday long lines of workmen were pouring concrete into its fourteenth and fifteenth floors.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States, Britain, Brazil and the Netherlands urged all countries today to admit European displaced persons to the utmost of their capacity.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 -- W. Averell Harriman in his first visit to Belgium since he was named chief European representative for the Economic Cooperation Administration praised the country today for its remarkable progress toward recovery. At the same time he issued a warning to other unnamed countries that they must make similar efforts or suffer the consequences.

A regular quarterly dividend of 10 cents plus an extra of 10 cents a common share, both payable on Sept. 10, was voted by the Copeland Refrigeration Corporation. An extra of 5 cents was paid in previous quarters.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the first six months this year, consolidated net income, after all charges but before depletion, of $25,993,779.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Heading home to face charges of "misusing state funds," the wealthy Gaekwar of Baroda was the first passenger to leave the liner Queen Elizabeth when she arrived at Southampton from New York tonight.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The United States was accused by Russia today of breaking the Russo-United States treaty of 1933 and violating the lend-lease termination agreement of 1945.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- Maurice J. Tobin announced tonight his acceptance of appointment to President Truman's Cabinet as Secretary of Labor. He withdrew as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Robert J. Kleberg of King Ranch paid $52,000 tonight at the Saratoga Yearling Sales for a California-bred brown colt by the imported Beau Pere out of Sun Lady. The bidding was spirited among Kleberg, John Amiel and Douglas M. Davis.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Out of a sea smoke with sunshine today came the sloop Djinn of Vice Commodore Henry S. Morgan of the New York Yacht Club to win the King's Cup, the premier prize in American yachting.

The majority of economists and business forecasters expect high general price levels and purchasing power to continue for "another year or so," Dr. M.P. Rasmussen, professor of marketing, Cornell University, told members of the International Apple Association, now holding their annual convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- American President Lines has transferred to Eastern officials and appointed a new general agent in Washington, George Killion, president, announced here today.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company, Ltd., and Austin Motor Company today reported a boom in sales of their small, British-made automobiles in North America.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities can legally serve a subpoena on Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina inside the Russian consulate here, according to several international law experts in this city.

One hundred twenty-five members and former members of the New York State Legislature assembled yesterday in the Rockaways, Queens, for their annual outing. It was the first such gathering in eleven years, owing to the restrictions caused by war.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Assistant Secretary of the Army Tracy S. Voorhees left for the United States this morning after a conference with Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, on the European Recovery Program for Germany.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Long Island potatoes will take on the "new look" with the opening here Saturday of a $250,000 potato washing and packaging plant. The clean, water-washed potato will then make its debut in food markets in the metropolitan area.

Indicated asset value of the common stock of the Atlas Corporation on June 30 was approximately $30.60 a share, compared with $30.01 six months earlier and $31.77 on June 30, 1947, Floyd B. Odlum, president of the investment company, disclosed yesterday in the semi-annual report.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Nassau County's assessed valuation for 1949 real estate tax purposes was established at a record high of $1,237,912,891 by the Board of Assessors, E.M. Podeyn, chairman, announced today. This is a rise of $75,921,440, or about 6 1/2 per cent.

Five Tibetans were interviewed yesterday by fourteen New York reporters on the sixtieth floor of the Empire State Building, but the meeting added as much mystery as it dispelled concerning the remote country of Central Asia.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 11 (UP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, formally accepting the States Rights party nomination for the Presidency, tonight linked Harry S. Truman, Thomas E. Dewey and Henry A. Wallace together and charged they would lead America to "the rocks of totalitarianism."
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The French Cabinet, after passage early this morning of the Reynaud financial and economic reform bill in the National Assembly, today began a study of the wage-price question.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A grand-slam home run by Sam Chapman followed a two-run double by Carl Scheib tonight as the Athletics surged from behind in a six-run seventh-inning rally that defeated the Senators, 8 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A State Department official, Herve J. L'Heureux, discounted today the idea that United States security might be threatened through suspected subversives who got into this country as United Nations officials or employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- No prospective selectee may be accepted as a volunteer after he has received "greetings" from his Selective Service Board, Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal said today in announcing rules for the peacetime draft.

With apparel chains still leading, sales of mail order and chain store companies increased 15.7 per cent in July, as compared with the same period last year, according to a compilation covering forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase is the third largest of the year and compares with a rise of 16.4 per cent for June.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Helene Krakower, 15-year-old counselor at the Bronx Day Camp for children, was killed at noon today by a New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad train at the end of the trestle bridge at Willson crossing here.

The market for bank stocks, usually quiet, reacted firmly yesterday to the news of a scheduled increase in the Treasury's short-term rate, with the prospect of a higher basic rate on commercial loans and the consequence of improved earnings.
A lonely cry of distress from five British soldiers serving with the Green Howards Regiment in Khartum, the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, reached New York yesterday.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 11 -- Britain is flying Dyaks, the headhunters of the Borneo jungles, to Malaya to help track down Communist insurgents in their jungle hideouts.

Consolidated net earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation in the six months ended last June increased to $7,516,216 or $2.07 a common share from $3,134,834 or 88 cents a share earned in the corresponding period last year, Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported yesterday.

Certification of the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, as collective bargaining agent for employes of Oppenheim Collins Co. appeared a virtual certainty yesterday because of decisions by the National Labor Relations Board and a Federal court judge.

With steel production in July amounting to 7,078,123 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the total output of the nation's mills in the first seven months of 1948 rose to 50,145,401 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Alexander Koral, a mechanical engineer in the New York public school system, who was a witness last Monday in Washington before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, was reported yesterday to be ill.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Dave Philley came home with the winning run on a wild pitch by Virgil Trucks in the eighth inning as the White Sox defeated the Tigers, 2 -- 1, tonight.

The cotton market yesterday was active and irregular, with the near positions on the New York Cotton Exchange relatively steady, while the distant months were sharply lower. At one time, the list was 7 to 87 points lower, but toward the close a firmer tone developed and final quotations from October to May ranged from 1 to 21 points higher while July and October (1949) were 25 to 50 points lower.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Renewed doubts on the outcome of the diplomatic talks in Moscow together with the overnight fall on Wall Street, had an unsettled effect on the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Public Health Service today reported the "smallest numerical and percentage increase" in weekly infantile paralysis cases since early in June. It offered no estimate of when the peak might be reached in this year's outbreak.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Chinese press reported today that Government forces had driven Communist guerrillas from a tiny village only forty miles from Shanghai. It was the closest Red approach to this city.

John Thomas has been appointed manager of the locomotive division of the American Locomotive Company. William G. Miller was appointed manager of the company's Auburn, N.Y., plant. Both appointments are effective Aug. 16.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette today assailed the Finnish Government as being made up of the "people of 1939" who led Finland into war against Russia. In the strongest attack to appear in the Soviet press since Premier Karl August Fagerholm formed his Social Democrat Cabinet last month, the Literary Gazette implied that Premier Fagerholm was likely to push the nation into the "Anglo-American camp."

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States Olympic squad scored first places in weight-lifting and canoeing today to run its staggering point total to 573 -- a gain of forty-nine points during the day.

The annual shower of the Perseid meteors, a brilliant display of "shooting stars" in the dark night skies, can be seen tonight under favorable cloud conditions after moonset, about midnight, and will be observable every night throughout the rest of this week in decreasing numbers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, confessed former courier for an alleged wartime Communist espionage ring, swore to the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that a $2,000 pay-off for her work was made to her in 1945 by Anatol Gromov, a first secretary of the Russian Embassy here.

Formation of a wholly owned subsidiary, the United States Foreign Corporation Belgium, Ltd., was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Richmond, president of United States Foreign Corporation, 761 Fifth Avenue. The subsidiary with headquarters in Antwerp, will be operated as a completely domestic Belgian company, and will enable the United States parent organization to take payment in Belgian francs.
Pretty as a picture, and pictures they are in fact, are the new candy packages that Howe Products, Inc., of Chicago, has just introduced into its offerings for young fry.

A request by Gus Hall, indicted Communist leader, for permission to travel within the continental limits of the United States in pursuit of his "normal activities" as Ohio state chairman of his party was refused bluntly yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman.

Net income of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) in the first half of 1948 rose to $13,834,073 from the $7,191,037 earned in the corresponding six months of last year, the semi-annual statement showed yesterday.
Detailed figures on city purchases of milk for school children are being prepared by the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday.
NN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Under a fairly steady downpour and with some keen competition, the 128-man field was reduced by half today in the first national junior amateur golf championship.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- In compliance with instructions from the Harrison town council, the town planning board began today a comprehensive study of an application filed last night by Mrs. Ogden Reid for a change in the residential zoning law applicable to her Ophir Farm estate in the Purchase area of Harrison.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- An appeal to Northern Ireland's great linen industry to expand and cheapen costs was made today by Sir Stafford Cripps in Belfast. He showed how vital exports of Irish linen to the United States are declining because of higher costs.
The biggest passenger ship contract ever negotiated in this country was signed yesterday.

Local 32B, Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, continued yesterday its "mopping-up" operations against owners and operators of buildings who have refused to sign contracts similar to those the union holds with other realty companies.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- An internationally known psychoanalyst asserted today that the behavior of some nations in their international relations was very much attributable to "a sense of guilt." He specifically mentioned the Soviet Union and Germany.

Arnold Gray of the near-by Clearview Club, an insurance adjuster, was adjudged as both the Long Island and over-all victor in the fifteenth hole-in-one golf tournament sponsored by The World-Telegram, which ended yesterday after three days of play at the Bayside links.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, ordered into effect today a voluntary plan for the oil industry to meet petroleum shortages next winter.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Aug. 11 (UP) -- A committee of the International Universities Conference recommended today that colleges and universities in the United states and other countries that had suffered no material war damage "adopt" schools of higher learning in war-devastated countries.

A majority of employes of the Y.W.C.A. voted yesterday to select as their collective bargaining agency the United Social Agency Employes, affiliated with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO.

The selling pace increased yesterday on the stock markets and prices backed to further new lows since mid-April, although some bidding in the final hour reduced peak losses. The late rally, on Stock Exchange, the first in two sessions, cut approximately two-thirds of the earlier inroads and allowed the composite rate to limit its reduction to 0.50 point.
TORQUAY, England, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States held an impressive lead in Olympic yachting today after winning the Six Meter and Swallow classes of a protest-riddled competition.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- By way of squaring accounts for their defeat last night and the abbreviated series at Braves Field as well, Billy Southworth's league leaders said it with home runs today as they thrashed the Giants, 4 to 3, before 18,961 cash customers.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Inspector Frank J. Mascari, 45 years old, second ranking officer of the Police Department here and head of its detective division, was shot and killed accidentally tonight by one of his own detectives.

The Actors Fund of America and several members of the theatrical profession were named as legatees in the will of Miss Horatia McVicker, a descendant of an old theatrical family, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Her estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000."

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Favorites were generally successful in the first round of the United States chess championship today at the Community Center. Among them were Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, 1947 open champion, and Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., recent victor at Baltimore.

The dual price level in the copper market was ended here yesterday when officials of Kennecott Copper Corporation announced that the company had started to sell at 23 1/2 cents, Connecticut Valley basis, in line with prices of other copper producer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- National leaders of the Truman-Barkley Clubs informed President Truman today that he and his running mate will have an aggressive campaign waged in their behalf in each of the forty-eight states.

C.S. FORESTER'S "The Sky and the Forest"* is a passable jungle tale that would probably have fewer tomtom salutes if it were not signed by the man who invented Horatio Hornblower -- that greatest Englishman since Winston Churchill. It is a novel you feel Mr. F. might have sketched with his left hand while thinking about "The African Queen" and "The General."

Jewelry orders, while under a year ago, picked up considerably yesterday at the convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association. Exhibitors said this was particularly the case in medium and popular price merchandise.

While most cotton textile items are in adequate supply, production of sheets has lagged behind civilian demand for staple numbers, it was pointed out in Worth Street yesterday. The condition was highlighted by Army purchases of 1,771,830, 140 type, 63 inch by 108 inch size, against invitations to bid on 2,267,000, owing to a lack of bids and high prices quoted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce disclosed today that the annual tax collections of all State and local governments were now more than twenty times the collections in 1890.

There are no bad boys, it has been said, only misunderstood ones. The experience of the Boy Scout leaders who have been carrying out a reclamation project among teen-age city gangs in slum areas of the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn under the auspices and with the financial aid of the New York City Youth Board would seem to bear out that evaluation.

ATHENS, Aug. 11 -- Alevitsa Mountain, a natural fortress of the utmost strategical importance that dominates the terrain between Amouda and the Albanian border a mile away, fell this morning to the National Army, according to an official announcement.

Daniel J. Tobin, elderly and politically powerful president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, twice turned down bids by Presidents Roosevelt and Truman to be Secretary of Labor, it was reported yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Gov. James C. Shannon today issued a call for an extra session of the Connecticut General Assembly to convene on Aug. 23 primarily to deal with the housing shortage and evictions.
The truce periods in Palestine -the first one of about a month's duration -- and now the second indefinite lull -- have undoubtedly benefited the armies of Israel more than the armies of the Arabs.

ISTANBUL, Aug. 11 -- Disclosure by a Turkish opposition newspaper three days ago of the terms of the Turkish-American bilateral agreement on the European Recovery Program -- hitherto kept secret by censorship -- has created some public disappointment.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- Effective Communist opposition to the Marshall Plan is being felt in the French ports, where Communist-led dockworkers have been delaying the unloading of ships carrying United States-aid goods. Experts here estimate that the unloadings have been slowed down by as much as 30 per cent and fear a virtual halt in operations if and when the Communist tactics get into full swing.

An issue of $40,000,000 of 1 1/8 per cent New York City tax anticipation notes of 1948 and 1949, dated Aug. 12, 1948, was allotted yesterday to twenty-five local banks, the Office of the Controller announced. The money is to be used for temporary financing.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Rip Sewell allowed the Cubs only three hits today as he pitched the Pirates to their third straight victory, 4 -- 2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- An over-sold condition was disclosed today in the grain markets at the opening on the Board of Trade. First prices were up as much as 1 1/2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish on September corn, general buying being in evidence despite what traders regarded as a bearish estimate of the crops issued by the Department of Agriculture.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Detroit printers baseball team out-slugged St. Louis, 10 to 7, today for their third straight in the thirty-fourth Union Printers baseball tournament.

An order to produce Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina in open court at 10 A.M. today was served yesterday on the Soviet Consul General, Jacob M. Lomakin, on the steps of the consulate where the Russian school teacher has been in seclusion since the dramatic but unclear happenings of last Saturday.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- A legal attack on the New Jersey Medical Practices Act by chiropractors and naturopaths was dismissed today by Federal District Judge Phillip Forman, who upheld its constitutionality.

Our visitor was a man seized with what the late Mr. Milton named "loathed melancholy" -- and cried "hence" 'to it. There had been a time, he said, when institutions in the heart of New York stood in groves of trees and made pleasant oases in a too-prevalent monotony of red brick and brownstone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (Science Service) -- Cottage cheese that looks and tastes like freshly made cheese after months of storage in a frozen condition is promised by a new process for which a government patent was issued today.

VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- The frustration of Austrian hopes for a resumption of fairly substantial trade with Western Germany was attributed here today to the United States command in Germany, which, the Austrians assert, slashed the originally agreed figures by half.

NEWARK, N.J. Aug. 11 -- Patrolman Herman Melcher strolled this morning past smiling residents and store owners to his traffic post at Broadway and Oriental Street. At the intersection he found a garbage can, covered with red, white and blue crepe paper.

Answers received by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York to questionnaires distributed to business concerns in the Manhattan zone between Eighteenth and Thirty-eighth Street show that 19.4 per cent of those replying are willing to cooperate in staggering working hours of their employes to relieve subway congestion during the rush hours.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 11 -Count Bernadotte tonight ordered Israeli elements to withdraw from strategic Hill 312 on the Latrun-Ramallah road where they control the Arab convoy route. Israeli authorities have indicated that only a Security Council decision would dislodge them.

Mayor O'Dwyer and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate have again reversed themselves and in face of the Reid Committee report which they approved permitted the private bus lines to proceed before the Public Service Commission with their petitions for an increased fare.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 11 -- The Australian High Court today invalidated vital sections of the Labor Government's Banking Act. The measure had empowered the Government-owned Commonwealth Bank to acquire the assets and liabilities of all privately owned banks, some of which are British-owned.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- For the first time in the Nuremberg war crimes trials, a United States court reconsidered its judgment today. It modified sentences imposed on four former SS (Elite Guard) men.

Miss Joan Schuyler Leeming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Leeming of 1035 Fifth Avenue, and High Farms, Glen Head, L. L, and Miss l~argot Kelley, daughter of Don Morrison Kelley, also of New York, and of Mrs. Hubert H. Dumont of 55 East Seventy-second Street, and Buenos Aires, A. rgeni rind. are members of the debutante committee for the Yuletide Assembly to be given at the Pierre l on Dec. 27.

In reply to a challenge from nine members of the paid staff of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, City Councilman Michael J. Quill, international union president, offered to resign his seat in the council, the union reported yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Russia jumped into Japan's explosive labor crisis today with a demand that Gen. Douglas MacArthur cancel the no-strike ban that has been clamped on Japanese Government workers.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 11 -- The Australian High Court today invalidated vital sections of the Labor Government's Banking Act. The measure had empowered the Government-owned Commonwealth Bank to acquire the assets and liabilities of all privately owned banks, some of which are British-owned.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- For the first time in the Nuremberg war crimes trials, a United States court reconsidered its judgment today. It modified sentences imposed on four former SS (Elite Guard) men.
