With the deadline for expiration of the contract between Atlantic coast longshoremen and employers only eight days away, it appeared likely yesterday that a Federal injunction under the Taft-Hartley Law would be sought to avert a waterfront strike.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- All three American representatives qualified tonight for the semi-finals of the Olympic individual saber tournament and posed a dangerous threat to the Hungarians, who have held the title since 1924.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The State Education Department announced today award of tuition scholarships at Cornell University to 150 high school seniors.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 12 -- Sir Charles Peake, chief British delegate to the Danubian Conference, challenged Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate, today to prove with maps in hand that the Soviet Union -- not including the Ukraine -- was a riparian state on the Danube in order to substantiate Moscow's claim to a seat on the new Danubian commission.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Stars and Stripes and the Red flag of Russia flew together today when James G. McDonald, first American envoy to Israel, arrived and was greeted by a crowd of several thousand Zionists.

What effect the use of salt for rapid snow removal may have on road surfaces is being studied by the State Department of Public Works, it was learned yesterday. The findings, which are expected to be announced within a few days, will determine whether the procedure is to be continued generally or restricted to bituminous pavements.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The British Government today donated 100,000 [about $400,000] worth of tents and medical supplies for the relief of more than 250,000 Arabs who have fled from Israeli-controlled areas in Palestine.

FORT ERIE, Ont., Aug. 12 -- Mayor Louis Ziff of this Niagara peninsula border town told Canadian and United States veterans today that the 135 years of peace enjoyed by the two countries had been made possible by the fact "we both believe in, and practice to the best of our ability, the democratic way of life."

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 12 -A forty-five-year-old indictment against the Dundee Water Power Company for blocking navigation on the Passaic River with an eighty-eight-year-old dam has been discovered, legally still valid, in a dusty pigeon-hole in the Passaic County clerk's office.

The six-story apartment building for forty-five families at 520-22 East Fourteenth Street has been sold by Benjamin J. and Louis V. Weil, executors of Jonas Weil, and the Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc., to a client of Benjamin Machinist, attorney.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ivan T. Tevosyan emerged today as the most important industrial executive in Russia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The United States Air Force made entrance into its officer candidate school even tougher today by tightening the requirements for eligibility.
A tense and noisy meeting of 1,200 members of the United Electrical Workers, Local 475, CIO, split last night on the issue of communism and left-wing control.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Americans smoked 345,000,000,000 cigarettes during the year ended June 30 -- another record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A plan providing for the merger of the Northern Development Corporation into the Central New York Power Corporation was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and all three are in Syracuse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Truman was the host early this evening to a group of newspaper men and other leaders of foreign language groups.

The spirit of play is as old as time itself. It is instinctive expressing itself early in infancy and unless inhibited remains throughout life. It is nature's own method of stressing exercise, developing strength, agility, stamina, coordination between nerve and muscle, and the need of relaxation, those physical traits so necessary for the survival of the animal.
In your editorial "The Price of Steel" you said: "Steel's behavior since the beginning of the latest epidemic of inflationary manifestations would seem to have been above legitimate criticism."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, affirmed today that he had sent Governors and state adjutant generals copies of the report by the Committee on Civilian Components in advance of its publication on Wednesday.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The losers in the Olympic basketball tournament continued their consolation round today as the stage was set for the championship final tomorrow between the towering United States squad and France.

Investigation of conditions in the gas supply system at Northcrest Gardens in Kew Gardens, Queens, came to a harmonious end last night, according to Assistant District Attorney J. Irwin Shapiro and Martin Allan, vice president of the Northcrest Gardens Civic Association.

Richard Barthelmess, former motion picture star, and his wife, Jessica have purchased the estate property of Mrs. Olive Wyndham Tyng at Wickapague, or Flying Point, in Southampton, L.I. The Barthelmesses, who previously have been summer residents of Southampton, are reported planning to make the property their year-round home.
Commissioner of Welfare Raymond M. Hilliard issued two executive orders yesterday designed to increase the efficiency or his department's staff.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Governor Dewey's Presidential campaign manager, announced late today that Mr. Dewey would conduct a vigorous, intensive campaign, traveling from coast to coast and making many personal appearances in various parts of the country.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Showing a liking for the sloppy track, D.F. Harrington's Chance Player never was headed today while racing to a three-and-a-half-length victory over Belrate before 12,144 at Suffolk Downs. Seven lengths farther back came Storm Hawk with the rest of the six-horse field widely spaced.

ALDERSHOT, Eng., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Capt. B.M. Chevallier of the French equestrian team led contestants from seventeen nations with a score of only four faults today in the endurance test of Olympic competition.

ACCORDING to his biographer, it was the late John Barrymore who, in a moment of great exasperation, turned and remarked: "Gentlemen, there comes a time in the affairs of men when no amount of swearing will do a bit of good."
TORQUAY, Eng., Aug. 12 (AP) -- American Yachtsmen captured the over-all championship in the Olympic regatta today with two firsts, a second and a third in the five classes of competition.

Magistrate David P. McKean, sitting in the Queens Traffic Court in Kew Gardens yesterday, reserved decision in a test case in which the attorney for an alleged speeder is seeking to show that the defendant used less than the quarter-mile permitted by law to overtake and pass a car ahead of him.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The only section to show signs of activity in the stock market here today was that for gold mines. Cape operators wanted West Witwatersrand on reports of good development, and at the close of trading a 5/16-point gain had been reported.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, expressed the solemn hope today that the Western powers would meet with the Soviet Union and "try to settle" their differences over Berlin and Germany generally.

THE boy was only 16 that evening a long time ago when he finished reading "Treasure Island" for the third time. He switched off the desk lamp and sat in darkness, staring fixedly through the window. But he did not see the moonlight or the back of the Nashes' house across the vacant lot. He saw a book, with his own name signed to it, which would be published in about ten years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Truman assailed the recent extra session of Congress today as a "do-nothing" session and stepped up his continuing attack on Republican Congressional leadership with an official White House "box score" of its legislative omissions.

Quantities of streptomycin sufficient to save the lives of ten German child sufferers from tuberculosis meningitis were prepared for shipment yesterday by organizations here and in Denver. The children to be aided were previously reported near death from the disease in the Kinder Krankenhaus (Children's Hospital) in the French section of Berlin.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- A new method of using radioactive "tracer" chemicals which may throw light on the obscure ways in which the thyroid gland influences bodily development was described today at the University of California.
Rosika Schwimmer's death comes as a shock, in spite of the long illness which she fought so gallantly for so many years.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians lost their slender hold on first place tonight when they divided a twilight-night double-header with the St. Louis Browns, losing 8 to 4, and then storming back to win, 26 to 3.

Brooklyn police were seeking yesterday a group of persons who on Wednesday night had brought to burglary a degree of diligence and industry worthy of a higher calling. In the misguided practice of these recognized virtues the thieves took 330 suits, sixty topcoats (worth at least $14,000 at wholesale), $160 in cash, some candy and chewing gum.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The United States Olympic team, picking up points today in yachting and canoeing, pushed its total to 609 at the close of the twelfth day of competition. The Olympics will close on Saturday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it would hold a hearing next Wednesday on an application by Jamaica Buses, Inc., for permission to increase fares from five to seven cents.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina yesterday added her comment on Soviet Russia to that which Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, another teacher in a Russian school maintained in this city until recently, had already made in a statement published by this newspaper.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Wally Westlake's single with the bases loaded and two out in the last of the ninth gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3-2 victory tonight over the St. Louis Cardinals. The triumph, fourth in a row for the Pirates, put them into a tie for fourth place with the New York Giants.

MOUNT RAINIER, Wash., Aug. 12 (UP) -- Four parkaclad mountaineers toiled up the slopes of Mount Rainier today, determined to pile enough rock, snow and ice on its summit to make it the second highest peak in the United States. Three California and Colorado peaks now overshadow this towering mountain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- During the week ended Aug. 11, member bank reserve balances increased $228,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12 -- They do nothing by halves on the Maine coast, and this morning a combination of rain, wind, heavy seas and fog sent the contestants in the Maine tuna tournament scurrying for the shelter of the harbor.

Cuba's colorful Kid Gavilan bolstered his status as a leading contender for Ray Robinson's world welterweight boxing title by registering a clean-cut triumph over Albert (Buster) Tyler of Newark, N.J., in a ten-round contest at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Revocation of the broker-dealer registrations of Otis Co. of Cleveland and the First California Company of San Francisco, investment banking firms and underwriters of the recent $10,000,000 common-stock offerings of the Kaiser-Frazer

To meet the scheduled redemption of $100,000,000 of its bills on Aug. 19, together with other Governmental expenses, the United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan Accounts with the Class B banks. The call, for 15 per cent of the balances at
New York City's population was estimated yesterday by the Department of Health at 8,067,000. This is the first official claim that the metropolis has passed the 8,000,000 mark.

High police officers on the East Side admitted yesterday that for the first time in three decades they were not in possession of the full details of their own case -- Mrs. Oksana Kosenkina's plunge from the Russian consulate.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Rochester swept a rain-shortened double-header from Newark tonight. The Wings won the twilight game in the last of the seventh, 3-2, then took a 2-1 decision in the nightcap when a flash flood made the field unplayable after the Bears had moved in front, 3-2, in the top of the seventh.
LONDON, Aug, 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's statement today regarding two Soviet teachers in New York, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today the 1948 tobacco marketing season has started off with a strong demand for the flue-cured type. Markets for other major types have not yet opened.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Short covering following early purchases by professional traders resulted today in a strong close in grain markets on the Board of Trade.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- President Juan D. Peron this morning addressed himself to Argentines living in the year 2006. A copy of his speech was sealed away near the base of a monument in Plaza Mayo fronting the presidential palace.

The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that it was preparing to meet any emergency situation that might arise in the next few weeks in the event of a strike affecting export cargo movements.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 -- The occupation authorities today forbade the enforcement of the recently enacted regulations in Osaka City that banned parades and demonstrations that labor groups had been planning in protest against the Japanese Government's order barring strikes and collective bargaining to public employes.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Government today fixed retail prices on eight essential foods in an attempt to halt the rising cost of living.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 12 -- W. Russell Howe and John J. Humm of Rockville, the Long Island amateur champion, scored 39, 36 -- 75 to tie with C.B. Carmichael and George Baird Jr., also of Rockville, for the lead in the first sesssion of qualifying play for the fourteenth annual Arthur Man Memorial Member-Guest Golf Tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Track Talk and Pam Light combined today for one of the richest daily double payoffs of the year, paying $1,379.80 to the holders of tickets on them in the first and second races at the Atlantic City course.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A pair of surprising 67s, something that wasn't figured to happen, boosted Jimmy Demaret, Ojai, Calif., and Henry Ransom, Ravinia, Ill., into a first-day lead in the $13,500 St. Paul open golf meet today.

ATHENS, Aug. 12 -- Tripolis, capital of Arcadia and one of the largest communities in the Peloponnesus, was without water today. During last night, according to an Army report, a small group of saboteurs disguised as shepherds, dynamited the reservoir two and a half miles northwest of the inland town.

From a normally placid Santa Barbara, there came the other day a dark little news note which may have wide significance. A young man wanting twenty-five pounds of ice placed two dimes in an ice-vending machine.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov accused the authorities of the United States Government tonight of having connived in the kidnapping of two Soviet teachers by "a White Guard gangster organization" in New York.

Moving decisively to clean house of left wing leaders of its New York locals, the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, ordered them yesterday to sign the non-Communist affidavits of the Taft-Hartley law or face removal from office and seizure of their organizations.

Charles Carbutt, a parachute jumper and former officer of the Eighty-second Airborne Division, was in Hamilton Avenue Hospital, Montciello, N. Y., yesterday, recovering from a parachute jump in which he fell the last 1,500 feet with a collapsed parachute.

Physicians of this city have long been accustomed to referring their poorer patients to the Health Department's Bureau of Tuberculosis for X-ray studies and to other bureaus for laboratory aid in diagnosing tropical, venereal, nervous, cardiac and dental diseases.

Allowances by the City Welfare Department fall short of minimum subsistence needs by 21 per cent, according to an analysis prepared by the New York City Budget Standard Service and released yesterday, in response to requests, by the Welfare Council of New York City.
The management of the Metropolitan Opera agreed last night to reconsider the cancellation of the 1948-49 season that it had announced because of wage disputes and a $220,000 deficit.
The backbone of the United States' multilingual international radio program known as the "Voice of America" is "straight" news.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Denmark Sweden and Czechoslovakia swept five events today as Olympic canoeing competition ended with a rain of protests and a man overboard.
ANN ARBOR, -- Mich., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two of the early favorites were missing today as sixteen survivors emerged from the third round of the National Junior amateur golf tourney.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Accurate throwing cut down four New York runners at home plate and gave the Detroit printers team a 3-to-1 triumph in the thirty-fourth annual union printers national baseball tournament today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A charge against Mrs. Suzanne Kremer, 23-year-old New York photographer, of creating a disturbance was withdrawn today at the request of Peter Bentley, lawyer for the Pennsylvania Railroad. Mrs. Kremer spent the night of June 10 in a police headquarters cell after her arrest in Pennsylvania Station here on complaint of railroad police.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Republican party was pledged today to soften the displaced persons law at the next session of Congress if it proved unfair to any group.

Charles B. and Agnes R. Lee, Emily F. Bradford, and Edward J. Dayhoff have purchased cooperative apartments in the building known as the Circle at 114 Morningside Drive through the Houghton Company, broker.

An indictment for first degree murder was filed yesterday in General Sessions against two men accused of slaying a Texas seaman in a midtown hotel last Feb. 6. In Felony Court, Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock dismissed a homicide charge against a third suspect after the grand jury failed to return an indictment.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club retained the Pequot Cup, symbolic of the Long Island Sound junior yacht racing championship, when Skipper Albert J. Eckhardt Jr., aided by a crew of Stanley Bell and Charles Nager, with Bill Lynn alternately sailing, completed the three-day, five-race series today with a total of 54 points.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- Ralph Branca, the sore-armed Dodger ace, wild-pitched the Braves to a 2-1 triumph and Manager Barney Shotton's well-laid plans to knock the Braves out of first place during the five-game series here suffered a serious setback tonight.

The fixing of minimum charges for the consumption of liquor in night clubs and other retail establishments was made illegal on July 20, it was learned yesterday. Minimums for consumption of both food and liquor as well as cover charges will continue to be sanctioned.

Continuing its drive to obtain uniform contracts from building owners and agents in New York, Local 32B, Building Service Union, AFL, picketed yesterday fourteen structures and won agreements from ten before the day was over.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The Olympic Games now coming to a close in London were commended today by Dr. D.R. MacCalman, professor of mental health at the University of Aberdeen, as a useful outlet for that aggressiveness that is regarded by psychologists as one of the fundamental drives of human nature.

The Disabled American Veterans has selected as "The Hero of the Month" William Mindlin of Flushing, Queens, a former first lieutenant who was wounded three times and has risen from a job trainee to a department manager with A.V. Morano Co., a New York export concern, it was announced yesterday.

Mary Browder sold the three-story apartment house with stores at 71-02 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, to Mate Angelich in an all-cash transaction. The Barwick Realty Company was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Reorders on popular-priced dresses for fall have resulted in an increase of production of more than 50 per cent over last year, it was learned yesterday from volume producers in the New York market. Manufacturers described the business as "phenomenal" in view of the low rate of initial fall orders placed in June.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A B-17 plane from the Air Force base here crashed in a farm yard and burst into flames soon after its take-off today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Pravda, the Russian Communist party newspaper, attacked the Soviet Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Higher Education today for not having stopped "reactionary trends" in biology.

The property consisting of a two-story steel and concrete shed and loading platform and two-story offices in the Pennsylvania Station area at 225-27 West Thirtieth Street through to 218-30 West Thirty-first Street has been bought by a syndicate headed by Daniel Ryweck from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee for the estate of Archibald D. Russell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 7 totaled 878,901 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,480 cars, or 1.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week. The total was 26,343 cars or 2.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 20,185 cars, or 2.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.5 per cent during the week ended Aug. 7, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index advanced to 169.2 per cent of the 1926 average, setting a new post-week peak for this index.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- Governor Dewey granted respites today staying until the week of Nov. 15 the execution of three New York City men for the slaying of Anthony Hintz, a boss stevedore.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Play among the twenty contenders for the United States chess championship stiffened today in the second round at the community center and only five decisions were recorded in the ten matches during a five-hour session. Three games were drawn.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin and Foreign Office officials awaited today still another report from British Envoy Frank Roberts on the Kremlin conferences.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Indications in London point today toward imminent open and armed conflict between the Dominion of India and Hyderabad. It is believed that India is about to go into the Princely State and take over.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- With high prices hitting politician as well as housewife, indications were mounting today that major political parties will be hard pressed to finance the 1948 Presidential campaigns.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Five Russian journalists returned to Berlin this afternoon after charging that French authorities had hampered them in their efforts to investigate the causes of the explosion at the I.G. Farben chemical plant in Ludwigshafen.

Pleas of not guilty were made yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, in behalf of three city officials allegedly responsible for the offensive odors in and around the Marine Park section of Brooklyn.

Paint manufacturers are being squeezed between higher costs of materials used in paint, and a softening market in which sales for some companies are now 10 or 15 per cent below levels for the same period last year, trade sources disclosed here yesterday.

With a backward glance at the college girl from 1900 on -- including the Gibson girl, the suffragette, the girl who took her place in the war in 1918, the flapper and the bobby soxer -- Franklin Simon opened its annual college clothes exhibit yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Finland led fifteen other nations at the end of the first day of Olympic gymnastics competition tonight at Empress Hall.

Columbia Teachers College will make a year-long survey of the educational system of Puerto Rico at a cost of $46,000, Dr. Willard S. Elsbree, executive officer of the college's Institute of Field Studies, announced yesterday. The study will start in September.

Support for the drive to turn west Twenty-first Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, into a play area came yesterday from fifty-five students of the School of Education, New York University, who have just completed a survey of children's needs in the area between Fourteenth and Twenty-third Streets, Avenue of the Americas to the Hudson River.

The Legion of Merit was presented to Dr. Russell H. Patterson, New York physician, for exceptionally meritorious service in World War II at a ceremony yesterday at Governors Island. The award was presented by Brig. Gen. Guy B. Denit, First Army Surgeon.
Streets, a school and a hospital will be dedicated to the memory of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, One World Award winner of 1947.

With style trends moving toward greater utilization of softer wool fabrics and new rayon blends in the spring of 1949, weavers and knitters will place greater dependency on fur fibers, it was predicted yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Universal-International, whose production plans for the immediate future have recently caused much conjecture, today announced that its 1948-49 program would consist of twenty-four pictures, the same number as were on this year's schedule, with six films in Technicolor.

A "thorough investigation" by Congress of the activities of Army post exchanges and Navy ships' stores was urged yesterday by the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the conclusion of its four-day convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Price tags on two cuts of pork and three "economy" beef products are 2 to 4 cents higher today than last Friday. These increases have occurred despite resistance by consumers.

Four paintings galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art presented a novel aspect yesterday. For the first time in the institution's history, old masters and contemporary pictures hung side by side on its walls.

It might be a good idea to take things easy today. Friday the thirteenth is with us and we'll have to hurdle it as best we can. There are many things that will require our attention. We are familiar with black cats and the like. But for the common safety one must keep abreast of things.

The cotton market generally appears to have assumed a waiting position pending developments in connection with the recent crop estimate of over 15,000,000 bales. Consequently, yesterday's session on the New York Cotton Exchange was feverish and irregular, closing 4 to 7 points higher for the near months and 7 to 16 points lower on the distant positions.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Detective Daniel Scannell, veteran of eighteen years' service in the police department here, was suspended today by Chief William McDonald pending a full investigation of the death last night of Inspector Frank J. Mascari, second ranking officer of the department and head of the detective division.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- The select men's field in the Eastern grass court championships rested today as early morning rains postponed action until tomorrow.

HONOLULU, Aug. 12 -- The annexation of Honolulu on Aug. 12 fifty years ago today, when Hawaii became a territory of the United States, was re-enacted at noon today in a ceremony on the steps of Iolani Palace from where the rulers of the old Hawaii monarchy had governed the people.

LONDON, Aug 12 -- The tremendous enthusiasm of Britons for athletics which resulted in the breaking of all records for Olympic receipts was manifested again today, almost a week after the closing of the track and field games of the Fourteenth Olympiad.

If medical societies have done their best to stamp out fee-splitting they have little to show for their zeal. The Better Business Bureau of Los Angeles made an investigation of the practices in its territory and earlier in the year charged that half of the 4,500 members of the local county medical association split fees with clinical laboratories.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- The sabotage early today of the Latrun pumping station for the Jerusalem water supply has set back the whole truce situation in Palestine, Count Bernadotte indicated tonight. The Count arrived in Rome this evening.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has attempted to mediate in the controversy over the nature of the World War II memorial to be erected in Manhattan, it became known yesterday.

The obvious jubilation of Vice Admiral William W. Smith, chairman of the Maritime Commission, over the signing of contracts this week for the American Export Line's two new 20,000-ton passenger liners, is shared by those who know the need for such ships under the American flag.

Within a few weeks the old nuisance of fumbling through a crowded handbag for the right charge account token will be eliminated for a million customers of eleven leading New York stores. A single small metal "Charge-plate," now being mailed out, will replace the variety long needed.
John C. Tietje, associated with the New Haven Clock and Watch Company for thirty years, has been promoted to sales manager.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Only one American -- Welterweight Horace Herring of St. Petersburg, Fla. -- entered the Olympic boxing finals today in a day of disaster for the United States team.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 12--New Jersey educational groups, strenuously opposing a plan for appointment of the Commissioner of Education by the Governor, said today they had aligned leading civic or- ganizations ir their cause.
NORTHFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Rain washed out the first day of the women's national open golf tournament today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, told a press conference here today that only "a near miracle" could keep Gov. Thomas E. Dewey out of the White House.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 12 -- Amid preparations for proclamation of the Korean Republic Sunday the police and United States military authorities are planning to deal with threatened Communist-led uprising against the Government.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 -- Defense Secretary James Forrestal's forthcoming visit to Ottawa will be entirely informal, it was said here today. Mr. Forrestal, who will arrive on Sunday, is returning the visit paid him in Washington some time ago by Canadian Defense Minister Brooke Claxton.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Three Minister-Presidents representing the United States, British and French zones met with liaison officers of the Western occupying powers here today and won extension until Oct. 15 of the date by which proposals for state boundary revisions must be made.

Two beautiful mannikins, "Fusette," the bride of 1898, and "Jane," the bride of 1948, were being prepared for shipment yesterday to Grand Central Palace, where they will be placed in the City Clerk's exhibit during Aug. 23 and Sept. 19 as part of the New York Golden Anniversary Exposition.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- United States, British and French diplomats talked today with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov in the fifth of a series of Kremlin conferences on the Berlin crisis and other East-West differences.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A torrential rain caused damage today in the southern part of Westchester County. Parkways, streets and cellars were flooded and pavements torn loose. Where sewers were inadequate, raw sewage was emptied into Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Committee on Trade Policies, announced tonight appointment of a forty-one-member advisory council to study effects of the Supreme Court's decision in the cement case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Maurice J. Tobin's acceptance of the position of Secretary of Labor met with general approval among labor leaders today. Mr. Tobin will take the oath of office tomorrow morning.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Frederic C. Dumaine Sr., 82-year-old Boston financier, took control today of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A plea to member Governments of the United Nations to adopt a "more understanding" attitude toward Europe's remaining 600,000 homeless refugees was made here today by officials of the International Refugee Organization's preparatory commission.

After some hesitation former Governor Maurice J. Tobin of Massachusetts has accepted the President's nomination to be Secretary of Labor. The hesitation was natural. Mr. Tobin was at least in the running for another Democratic Gubernatorial nomination. As Secretary he will be sure of a term of a little less than five months.

A shy, armless, 14-year-old Italian boy gazed in awe yesterday from the deck of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary at the country whose medical science may one day permit him to lead a normal, useful life.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Hundreds of thousands of workers demonstrated throughout the United States zone State of Hesse today in a double-barreled protest against high prices and the refusal of the United States Military Government to approve a socialistic measure passed by the State Parliament three months ago.

Recent Federal Trade Commission actions toward enforcement of its blanket ban on use in advertising of the word "free" when there is obligation to purchase indicate that the commission may soon begin a drive against devices designed to by-pass the ban, advertising observers reported yesterday.

Henry A. Wallace, in his first major radio address since his nomination for President on the Progressive party ticket, last night accused the House Un-American Activities Committee of trying to "drag the name of Franklin Roosevelt through the mud."

The New Haven, Conn., Housing Authority has sold $2,881,000 of temporary loan notes, series M-2, dated Aug. 17, 1948, and due March 17, 1949, as follows: To Salomon Bros. Hutzler, $2,581,000 at 1.19 per cent; Day, Stoddard Williams, Inc., $200,000 at 105 per cent plus a premium of $7.80; and Charles W. Scranton Co., $100,000 at 1 per cent.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A stricken crewman of the Navy submarine Torsk and the crew of a Coast Guard plane that crashed in an attempted rescue 400 miles at sea, were put ashore at the Charleston naval base early today.

Retail shoe sales in the first half of this year were approximately 2 per cent greater than for the same period of 1947, according to an analysis yesterday by the Tanners Council of America. This would indicate, the council held, that over-all shoe pairage sales were about equal to last year.

Because of "international questions and diplomatic status involved," Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein reserved decision yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus brought to "free" Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Russian school teacher, from the Russian Consulate at 7 East Sixty-first Street.

John Garty, Len Pinover, Mrs. Mildred Whitman, William A. Smith, Caesar Jamaro and Dr. Assis Abel, in 120125 Riverside Dr; Georgetti Palmer, Anna Rosenberg, Jacques Krausz, Daniel Gilbert, in 675 West End Ave--Harold L. Born Co, broker.

VIENNA, Aug. 12 -- Austrian trade unions have demanded participation in all parts of the Austrian administration of the European Recovery Program. A letter sent by the Conferedation of Labor to the Cabinet requests representation on the interministerial committee for ERP.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today suspended for three months the export license privilege of Swiftway Enterprises, Inc., of New Orleans because of violation of export control regulations.

Neil Agnew, president of the Selznick Releasing Organization, has resigned from the company and will leave his post Sept. 1, it was revealed yesterday by a Selznick spokesman. Mr. Agnew could not be reached for comment, and the Selznick office here had no information on his future plans, except to say that he had indicated a desire to go to France, his wife's native country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- At ease under the protection of an American subpoena, Mikhail Ivanovitch Samarin, one of the three Russian teachers who ignored orders to return to the Soviet Union last month, testified today at a closed hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

NANKING, Aug. 12 -- The Chinese Government recognized the newly formed Government of Korea today. The recognition is provisional pending discussion of the report of the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea by the General Assembly of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Soviet Russia indignantly protested to the United States Government today against the order of a Justice of the New York Supreme Court, commanding Consul General Jacob M. Lomakin to produce Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Russian school teacher, in court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Government referee took under advisement today a plea for dismissal of Agriculture Department charges that Ralph Moore, Washington commodity trader, violated the Commodity Exchange Act.

Having just returned from a refresher course instituted for Reserve chaplains at the Chaplains' School at Carlisle Barracks I must register my amazement at the call for "a day of mourning and repentance" against the draft, issued by a group of distinguished American clergymen.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 12 -- The precarious truce in Palestine was further shaken today by the blowing up of the Latrun pumping station on the water pipeline to Jerusalem in the early hours of this morning. The blast also set fire to oil tanks and the building was a complete loss.

The stock market lapsed yesterday into an apathetic state but, as it did so, prices staged the first over-all rise of the week. On the Stock Exchange stocks found their own levels on a minimum of bidding, with alterations of more than a point reserved for a few issues and the composite rate up 0.17 point on the day.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Pravda charged today that the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation had kidnapped two Soviet school teachers and declared the incident had aroused the "deep indignation" of the Russian people.
Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh charged yesterday that Borden's and Sheffield were guilty of collusion on bids to supply milk for school children.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday a reduction of the round-trip air fare between New York and London to $472.50, effective Oct. 1 on sixty-day excursion tickets. The present roundtrip fare is $630 and the new rates will save a prospective passenger $157.50.
The emotional problems of the physically handicapped will be studied in a research project at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center Institute of Rehabilitation, it was announced yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority acquired yesterday the fourth and final major commercial airport in the metropolitan area when it signed a contract for the purchase of Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, New Jersey. Acquisition of the 500-acre New Jersey air terminal leaves in private hands not a single airport in the bi-state area capable of handling big commercial airliners in volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Truman reiterated at a news conference today that he thought the spy ring hearings constituted a "red herring" designated to detract public attention from the performance on his anti-inflation recommendations by the Republican-controlled extra session of the Eightieth Congress.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- A need for large numbers of visual observations of meteors and fireballs by amateur astronomers, Weather Bureau observers and personnel at radar and navigation stations was stressed here today by the commission on meteors of the International Astronomical Union, which is now meeting here.

Although it couldn't be verified yesterday, there is talk in authoritative circles that the Theatre Guild is thinking of joining hands with Louis J. Singer in the presentation of "Sundown Beach," due Sept. 7 at the Belasco. Should both parties agree, the attraction would have the benefit of the Guild's subscription list, not an inconsequential box-office cushion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Department-store sales in the week ended Aug. 7 were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:
GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- Children held the attention today of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations on two fronts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Truman ordered a governmental study of the critical financial position of the country's airlines today with a view toward devising means of averting drastic retrenchment involving harmful economic and military potentialities.

If the people of this country continue their diet at its present high level, both in quality and quantity, by 1950 farm production on a level with 1947's bumper output will be necessary to feed them alone, leaving nothing for export. Thereafter, it will take more food than this country has ever produced just to maintain the present diet.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- France will get an increased ration of better bread beginning Sept. 1, according to an announcement made after a Cabinet meeting today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The youth of the world was urged today by Britain's Deputy Prime Minister, Herbert Morrison, to reject "dogma from dictators" and, instead, to think out world problems for themselves.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Russian teacher whom a State Supreme Court writ of habeas corpus failed to bring out of the Soviet consulate, plunged from a third-floor rear window of the building shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday.
There is pathos and education in the words of Mayor Hamai, of Hiroshima, spoken on the third anniversary of the destruction of that city by the first atomic bomb on Aug. 6, 1945.

ESSEX, Conn., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Chester Bowles, declaring he was against both "the reactionaries of the right" and "the Communists of the left," announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor.

Rising to the highest total since Jan. 8, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System advanced $103,000,000 last week, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the data issued by the Federal

The one-story taxpayer containing stores at 21 Spencer Place, Scarsdale, N. Y., recently completed by Benjamin Biegelsen and Irving J. Feder, has been sold by them to the D. N. R. Realty Corporation. Pearce Mayer were the brokers.

City departments have requested a total allocation of $657,943,946 in the capital outlay budget for 1949, the City Planning Commission announced yesterday. Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the planning agency, made public tabulations disclosing that $38,943,035 of the total requested was for new projects and $619,000,911 for pending projects.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Russia served notice today for the first time that she would probably place the United Nations disarmament debate before the Paris session of the General Assembly in September.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- Soviet military policemen and their German helpers were stoned by Soviet sector black marketeers, and Russian policemen were warned to stay out of the Western sectors of Berlin today as the struggle between the Eastern and Western halves of the city intensified.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The United States seized the initiative in the Far East today by granting diplomatic recognition to the Russian-boycotted new government of Korea. President Truman appointed John J. Muccio of Rhode Island as special United States representative to Korea with the rank of Ambassador.
A new interim order limiting picketing of Oppenheim Collins Co. to six pickets at each of its two stores was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 12 -- Outlining the program of the new Netherlands Government, Premier Willem Drees told Parliament today that with a view to allowing more freedom to business the present rationing system would be liquidated gradually and that there would be a relaxation of Government regulations.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of the telegram from the State Department asking Governor Dewey today to hold up court action involving a Russian school teacher:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Bothered by a high cross wind, only four of the 101 starters in the special invitation tournament of the National Golf Links of America were able to break 80 today in the 18-hole qualifying round.
Johnson Johnson and its subsidiaries, world's largest manufacturer and distributor of surgical dressings, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for six months ended on June 30.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A $45,000 sale of a Bull Lea colt to Ogleby and Humphrey of Cleveland highlighted the third night of the yearling sales at the Fasig-Tipton paddock tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the twelve-month period ending on Aug. 1 totaled 4,081,166 tons, compared with 3,089,590 tons in the corresponding period a year ago.

" California: A Study of American Character," by Josiah Royce, will be reissued by Knopf on Sept. 9. First published in 1886, the volume deals with California from the conquest in 1846 to the time of the Second Vigilance Committee at San Francisco in 1856.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Old Elkridge ambled along in last place in the $8,950 North American Steeplechase Handicap at Saratoga today till there was three-quarters of a turn of the course to go. Then he suddenly went to work on the opposition, picked the other six up one by one with a remarkable run through the backstretch and continued on to take the stake for the fourth time since 1942.

" Mr. Peabody and the Mermaid," which arrives at the Winter Garden, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The comedy, produced by Nunnally Johnson and featuring William Powell and Ann Blyth in the title roles, is being released by Universal-International.
Babe Ruth rallied slightly yesterday at Memorial Hospital, but his condition remained critical.
A full week of clinical segiong scussions and scientific lectures feature the fifty-third annual meeting of the National Medical ssociation, which opens at Wadigh High School here on iVionday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Spec Sanders, the big back from the University of Texas, showed how a one-man gang operates tonight, but the Buffalo Bills came back in the last three minutes to tie Sanders and his New York Yankees, 28 -- 28, in an All-America Conference exhibition football game at Ruppert Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Federal Reserve System announced this afternoon that nine of the twelve Federal Reserve banks had raised their discount rate from 1 1/4 per cent to 1 1/2 per cent, effective tomorrow.

The Burroughs Adding Machine Company continued its expansion and improvement program during the first six months of this year with resulting record unit production and sales volume and an increase of almost $4,000,000 in earnings over the 1947 period, according to the semi-annual report of John S. Coleman, president, to be released today.

For the fifth time within two weeks, the envoys of the Western Powers called at the Kremlin yesterday and conferred with Foreign Minister Molotov in an effort to find a basis for resuming negotiations on the future of Germany -- the key to any genuine peace settlement.

For the first time in many years the attitude of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York is likely to determine the nomination of a Supreme Court Justice by Tammany Hall, it was indicated yesterday. The nomination in question is that of Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien, whose term expires this year and who is a candidate for renomination.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An atomic energy expert today told America's druggists that they might be called upon to fit into a civilian defense organization "in the next six months or so."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The White House today issued the following "summary of action by the Congress on the President's recommendations at the special session":
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -Controls on installment buying probably will become effective Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Illinois Power Company of Decatur, Ill., received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell additional shares of its common stock and call for redemption its outstanding 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $50 par value.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Leroy (Satchel) Paige scattered five singles in pitching Cleveland to a 5-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox before a turn-away crowd of 51,013 fans tonight. The Indians rapped Randy Gumpert and Glen Moulder for nine hits in gaining their ninth victory over Chicago in eleven games this season.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Leaders of three anti-Communist parties and the union organization in Western Berlin asked for an economic alliance with the Western zones of Germany today in the face of mounting Russian pressure to bring the entire city under the industrial and commercial control of the Soviet Military Administration.

For the second time within the space of less than a week, I find myself the subject of derisive comment in THE NEW YORK TIMES. I was honored with an editorial on July 22 criticizing me for having said that United States Steel has surrendered to inflation.

Although dollar and unit sales of the American Tobacco Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in the three and six months ended on June 30 increased over the 1947 periods, earnings declined, the semi-annual statement showed yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13 -- The Yugoslav press disclosed today that last Tuesday night Marshal Tito was reaffirming his determination to stand against the accusations of the Communist Information Bureau in a speech at a Communist party meeting while Foreign Minister Stanoje Simitch was playing host to Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky and other delegates to the Danubian Conference at a garden party.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Atomic scientists were warned here today that newcomers into the field of investigation using radioactive substances for tracer material are making the same mistakes made ten years ago in the utilization of these chemical "spies" to disclose biological and industrial processing secrets.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- The Third Circuit Court of Appeals reversed itself today saving a selfstyled minister from serving a Federal penitentiary sentence and setting a legal precedent to guide Selective Service boards in administering the new draft law.

Success of the European Recovery Program depends upon speedy rehabilitation of production facilities, which in turn requires new machine tools in considerable quantity, Wendell E. Whipp, chairman of the board of the Monarch Machine Tool Company, said in a statement yesterday.

The biggest ship subsidy in the history of American shipbuilding appeared in prospect yesterday as the United States Maritime Commission issued invitations for bids on a superliner for the United States Lines.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley said today it will take more than $600,000,000 to modernize and repair the State's school buildings.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (UP) -An explosion ripped through the United States Bureau of Mines' synthetic fuel experimental station at Bruceton, Pa., tonight, killing two persons. Four other workers were injured.
VIENNA, Aug. 13 -- The Soviet Union launched its long awaited attack on the U.S.-Austrian Marshall Plan agreement at today's meeting of the Allied Council.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The slickest basketball team ever seen h) 0*0*0* iin England, possibly anywhere, bewildered France's cinderella kids tonight to win the Olympic cage title for the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 - Viewed from any angle, it was a noisy welcome the Phillies rolled out for Leo Durocher in his first appearance at Shibe Park as Giants' skipper.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- America's victorious Olympic track and field team arrived in Paris today from London for the Franco-American meet on Sunday and Monday. Following them this evening were members of the United States swimming team who missed the boat train in London this morning and for whom air passage was hastily arranged.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Increases ranging up to 25 per cent in the retail price of beef in Canada were freely predicted today on the heels of a Government announcement of the removal on Monday of the war-imposed ban on shipment of beef cattle to the United States.

In India's princely state of Baroda the Legislature hints darkly that the ruler, a 42-year-old Maharajah, has been wasting some one's substance to the tune of $10,000,000. The accounts are not overexplicit some unauthorized loans from the treasury, an interest in horses and wives, a six-week "spree" in which this small change was dropped.

PITTSBURGH, Aug 13 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates won their fifth in a row tonight by rallying for four runs in the eighth to gain a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Stan Musial got four hits in five trips as the Cards lost their second in a row to the rampaging Pirates.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Harrison Dillard, United States hurdler who failed to make the Olympic team in his pet race but won the games 100-meter dash, today made his first 110-meter hurdle appearance since the United States tryouts, winning from a slow international field in 0:14.7.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 13 -Purchase by the Studley Land Company of the old Industrial Trust Building in the center of Providence's downtown business district for more than $1,000,000 was disclosed here today by Daniel A. Marwell, treasurer.

Three years ago this afternoon the Swiss Ministry in Washington sent to the White House a message from the Japanese Government accepting the terms of surrender offered in the Potsdam Declaration of three weeks before. The war was over. Peace had come at long last.

Led by the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, 500 members of the National Pilgrimage to Rome and Lourdes embarked last night on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. They plan a four week tour of Catholic shrines and churches in Europe.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP) -Chicago's lowly Cubs clubbed five Cincinnati pitchers, including Ewell Blackwell, for a 10-4 victory tonight before 15,897 spectators. A five-run blast in the sixth was directed against Blackwell and Kent Peterson. Johnny Schmitz chalked up his twelfth victory against ten losses.

Several of the newly decorated rooms now on display at KresgeNewark use dark wall colors with dramatic effects. Walls of an informal, California-inspired dining room have been painted blue spruce, a rich Murphy paint that closely resembles the greenish blue color of the evergreen needles.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Yugoslavia called today on the United Nations Security Council to pass a resolution specifically condemning the United States and Britain for their policy in Trieste.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- There was only confusion -- of Olympic proportions -- tonight in the Olympic gymnastic competition.
American Airlines, biggest in the domestic field, was threatened yesterday with a mechanics' strike and picket lines around its principal offices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Maurice J. Tobin took oath as Secretary of Labor today with the declaration that "the damage that was done (to the department) by the Eightieth Congress can and must be repaired if the department is to carry out its full duties and responsibilities to the wageearners and all the people."

The proposed thirty-day extension of working agreements between stevedoring companies and Atlantic Coast longshoremen was rejected yesterday by union representatives, raising the threat of a strike within a week that would paralyze shipping from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va.
August fur promotions have fallen short of their objective to stimulate wide consumer purchases, it was learned yesterday, and fur sales are down 25 to 40 per cent from a year ago.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The request of the bizonal area of Germany for a larger share of United States credits under the Marshall Plan than allotted so far was considered a major snag to be faced by the council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation tomorrow when it will meet to decide the allocations for the year ending June 30, 1949.

Retail trade here this week made a small increase despite several days of wet weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 7 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 9 per cent.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 13 (AP) -Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., fired a blistering six-under-par 66 today to lead at the end of the second round of the St. Paul $13,500 open golf tournament.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 13 -Raced through fog out on Great South Bay from the Bay Shore Yacht Club, two more contests were held for the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class and E. W. (Skip) Etchells won both with his craft Shillalah.
ALDERSHOT, England, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A hard-riding United States Army team won the three-day Olympic equestrian championship today to give America its first gold medal in that event.

BUFFALO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, attacked the Dewey State administration's tax policy tonight for what he called "shortchanging" the cities while state revenues rose to the greatest in the state's history.

Despite the higher cost of materials, as much as 40 per cent savings in operating costs and significant savings in construction costs promise to revolutionize cost and profit ratios in lime and cement mills using a new process disclosed fully for the first time here yesterday by Joseph E. Kennedy, president of Kennedy Van Saun Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation, 2 Park Avenue.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 13 -Preliminary investigation by United Nations observers of the explosion at the Latrun pumping station yesterday as it was about to resume supplying water to Jerusalem failed to determine whether the saboteurs were Arabs or Jews.

Early additions to the fall schedule of WOR-Mutual were announced yesterday. Apparently still confident over the future of the quiz program, the hook-up has two offerings in that classification due for introduction next week on a Monday-through-Friday basis.
Although Babe Ruth was able to take nourishment "with some difficulty" and his temperature was "slightly lower," his condition remained critical yesterday at Memorial Hospital.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 13 -- The second fishing day of the Maine tuna tournament not only failed to dawn clear, bright and windless, but failed to produce a single tuna, all of which was blamed on the fact that no one looked at the calendar to see that it was Friday the 13th.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 13 -- An ancient Samaritan synagogue was discovered in the Biblical plain of Ajalon, near the Latrun monastery, during the recent military operations, it was disclosed today. This is the first record of Samaritan life to be uncovered so far south of Samaria, authorities said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Shipments of parcels by air through the United States Postoffice will begin in the United States and its territories and possessions on Sept. 1, Jesse M. Donaldson, Postmaster General, announced today.

Fourteen of the sixteen bus and street car companies that have asked the city for relief from the 5-cent fare provisions of their franchises have filed with the Public Service Commission at Albany their applications for permanent fare rises and requests for interim increases.

Some of the time-honored practices of the steamship freight conferences have been challenged in a suit filed by Attorney General Tom C. Clark in the Federal Court in Newark. The suit charges restraint of trade and monopolistic operations through the employment of the exclusive contract rate system as applied by the Far East Conference.

ROSWELL, N.M., Aug. 13 (AP) -Thirteen men died in the flaming wreckage of a B-29 bomber from Walker base, near here, the Air Force announced late today. Eight others were injured in the crackup, one critically.

WASHINGTON, Aug 13 (AP) -Mel Parnell restricted Washington to four hits here tonight in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 6-2 victory over the Senators. Parnell pitched no-hit, no-run ball for 6 1/3 innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to permit the New Haven Railroad to abandon a branch line in Connecticut and portion of a line in Massachusetts on the ground that operations are being conducted at substantial earnings and with prospects for additional increases in traffic.

The city's present and prospective financial condition provides "ample margin, for an extensive capital program" for 1949 and the five following years, Controller Lazarus Joseph reported yesterday. Mr. Joseph expressed the belief that the city could safely undertake a capital program of $194,000,000 in 1949, of which $36,000,000 would be assessable improvements:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13 - The Danubian Conference voted today to exclude the United States, Great Britain, France and Austria from the new Danubian authority.
Gray as a basic color for a college wardrobe will be stressed at 11 A.M. today at a fashion show at Gimbels, opening the College Shop.

There were any number of persons who thought yesterday, Friday the 13th, was a lucky day. Mrs. Carmilla Auriana, 35-yearold mother of four children, 2 1/2 to 7 years old, looked at the date and said: "This is a wonderful day." She had just given birth in Mother Cabrini Hospital to triplets -- all girls.

With the taxicab business reported at its lowest point since 1942, the United Taxi Council appealed yesterday to the Mayor's Committee on Administration for a speedy decision on its request for a 30 per cent fare rise.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was of comparatively small volume as operators were evening-up for the week-end. The nature of the trading was about the same as it has been for several days, namely, liquidation and hedging that was taken by mills and shorts.
Fewer than 100 young men have applied this month for the Air Force pilot training program, Maj. Clayton M. Dougherty of the Southern New York Recruiting District, 39 Whitehall Street, said yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -Gen. Raulino de Oliveira, president of the Companhia Nacional Siderurgica, controlling the Volta Redonda steel mill, announced today payment of a 6 per cent dividend for a year. Payment for the first semester will take place immediately.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- A four-way tie at 2 1/2 points for first place resulted from play in the third round of the tournament for the United States Chess Championship at the Community Center today. The leaders are Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., Isaac I. Kashdan and George Kramer, both of New York, and Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- A Belgian educator told the International Conference on Child Psychiatry today that school teachers were unfit to solve the problems of children in whom dull schools and exciting movies were breeding "aggressivity."

h)0*0*0*iONot only did he not get an apartment for which he paid $1,192.50 in bonus, painting expense and advance rent, but when the deal fell through he got a bad check as a refund, Arno Rudolphi of 281 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, operator of a butcher shop at 2080 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, complained in Bronx Special Sessions Court yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -Reuben B. Resnik, director of the Community Relations Department, United Service for New Americans, severely criticized the Eightieth Congress today for its legislation affecting displaced persons.

The Tournament of Champions announced yesterday through Promoter Andy Niederreiter that it would stage the world middleweight championship bout between Tony Zale and Marcel Cerdan at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City on Tuesday night, Sept. 21.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -- In one of the first detailed analyses of the possible genetic effects of atomic bombs, Dr. Albert W. Bellamy of the University of California, estimated today that radiation injuries, transmitted by pure inheritance, might kill as many as nine people in 10,000 in the generation following an explosion.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Sweetena, belonging to Sylvester Rich of Pittsburgh, won the Sailfish Purse, feature at Atlantic City Race Track today.

HOLDERNESS, N.H., Aug. 13 -- Col. Ralph W. Caswell, superintendent of the New Hampshire State Police, said tonight that the body of a woman found floating today in Little Squam Lake had been identified as that of Miss Anne Straw, aged 20, a Smith College student who disappeared from her foster parents' summer home here July 21, 1947.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 13 -- The rings of Saturn may be particles of ice, covered with very thin hoarfrost, and the polar caps of Mars may be ice crystals on a very cold surface, according to observations described here today by Dr. Otto Struve of the University of Chicago before the International Astronomical Union.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Criticism in the United States of Military Government policy in Germany is interpreted as "a considerable weakening of the American position" in the Moscow conversations, the Socialist Unity [Communist] party newspaper Vorwaerts reported today.

Prices on the stock markets strayed a little lower yesterday as midsummer dulliness enveloped trading and brought the smallest volume in almost a year on the stock exchange. Losses there were mostly fractional, and the composite rate was reduced 0.24 point, although the number of issues to give ground only slightly exceeded those to show gains.

Left wing locals of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, received news yesterday of a further crackdown by their parent union, which on Thursday had ordered them to comply with the Taft-Hartley law.

An organizational fight between two unions of the Congress of Industrial Organization to represent workers in the city's sample card industry has flared into open physical warfare involving alleged beatings, kidnappings and forcible detention, it was learned yesterday.

Two new films, an Anglo-American drama and a Russian documentary, will arrive in town this morning. Opening at the Globe will be Twentieth Century-Fox's "Escape," a screen adaptation by Philip Dunne of John Galsworthy's play, starring Rex Harrison and Peggy Cummins.

The hay fever "season" starts tomorrow, the Health Department warned yesterday. In their third annual fight against ragweed -- which will continue into September -- department workers offered battle advice to 400,000 New Yorkers who are allergic to the pollen grains.

The contradictory manifestations that accompany the diplomatic efforts to find a basis for negotiations between the Soviet Union and the Western Powers are simply a proof that both sides are still pursuing two policies simultaneously. It will take a long time and a nerve-racking succession of advances and retreats before the West trusts Russia or the members of the Politburo agree among themselves, let alone with the people across the table, to change their methods.
A Norwegian haberdasher who hankered to get away from the land and learn what the sea was like completed his first voyage yesterday.

The current rise in short-term interest rates spread yesterday to bankers acceptances. Following the previously announced increase in the discount rate to 1 1/2 per cent from 1 1/4 per cent, which became effective at the start of the day's business, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York raised its minimum buying rate for the acceptances from 1 1/4 per cent to conform with the higher level of the new discount rate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The charge by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov that authorities of this Government had connived in the "kidnappings" of two Russian school teachers was denied categorically by American Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith, when he conferred with Mr. Molotov in the Moscow Foreign Office, the State Department announced today.

A few minutes before midnight last night Bucky Harris and his Yankees, along with 60,745 sympathizers at the Stadium, were suddenly given every reason to believe that there is such a thing as a Santa Claus in this troubled world.
TORONTO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Toronto in both ends of a double-header tonight, 12 -- 3 and 3 -- 2, breaking the Maple Leafs' five-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- In a day-long hearing of persons accused in the Soviet spy-ring investigation, men formerly at high posts in the Roosevelt Administration denied categorically under oath today before the House Committee on Un-American Activities that they were members of, or even knew the existence of, any such rings operating out of Washington before or during the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Truman will open his campaign for election with a Labor Day speech at Detroit with both major labor organizations taking part in the celebration. Although plans are tentative as yet, the President is expected to return directly to Washington from Detroit.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The twelfth biennial world conference of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts opened here today with a colorful ceremony. Delegates from all continents, representing 3,000,000 members, arrived at the Hotel Otesaga in Scout regalia ranging from "the Anzac-type uniforms of the British Dominion groups to the tre-foil bordered saris of India."
Two foreign flag airlines followed yesterday the lead of Pan American Airways in announcing low excursion rates to and from Europe for the winter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary of State Marshall has declined to give confidential visa files to a Senate subcommittee because disclosure of their details would "embarrass the conduct of foreign relations" of the United States, and "hamper the work" of our missions abroad.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 13 -- Three hundred thousand families on farms and in the cities of the Midwest have started the importation of petroleum from the world's richest reserves in faroff Iran and Arabia, and some of the gasoline which members of cooperatives throughout this area of the United States will use in their cars, trucks and tractors next fall will come from crude oil drilled in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A drastic cut in American exports to Russia was disclosed today when Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, announced that shipments of goods to the Soviet Union during the first half of 1948 were at an annual rate of $50,000,000, about one-third the volume in 1947.

Although progress has been reported in the negotiations between unions and the trucking industry for contracts replacing those expiring Aug. 31, many business concerns in the metropolitan area are building up reserves of materials in the event of a strike, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, of Ohio, at the urging of some newspaper publishers, has called upon Government officials to bring contempt of court action against the International Typographical Union and its officers, it was learned today.

New estimates on population gains and shifts in industry will provide important additional guides for advertising campaigns now in preparation, marketing researchers observed yesterday, but census surveys in the near future are expected to have a more decisive effect on all advertising techniques.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- There is little possibility that the action of the Canadian Government in removing the embargo on meat shipment to the United States will relieve the American shortage. The production of our northern neighbor is a small fraction of what this country produces and consumes.
The Kosenkina affair was the major news item on the State Department's "Voice of America" program beamed yesterday to Russia, Russian-controlled Europe and Siberia.

A statement that Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, had visited the consulate here and sought to obtain an affidavit from Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Soviet school teacher, to the effect that she was not being held a prisoner, that she was in good health and had the utmost freedom, is in the possession of the police, it was learned last night.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it had authorized the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, which serves 93,000 customers in Brooklyn, including the Coney Island and Brighton Beach areas, to increase its gas rates by an estimated $235,000 annually.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Appointments of a new medical examiner and an assistant medical examiner of Westchester County were made today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach. At the same time he announced arrangements for revision of the county's twenty-three-year-old medical examiner system.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Hopes for good crops in Britain this year are dwindling fast as the weather continues cold, rainy and windy. So far from the bumper crops confidently expected up to two weeks ago, the prospect now is one of disaster if this terrible stretch of weather does not change.
NANKING, Aug. 13 -- The Chinese dollar is slumping after nearly three weeks of comparative stability during which the public was lulled by the promise of immediate economic reforms.

TOKYO, Aug. 13 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that he would fly to Korea on Sunday at the invitation of President Syngman Rhee to attend the inauguration of the Government of the new Korean Republic at Seoul.

RINGWOOD, N.J., Aug. 13 -- A fiery cross, made of saplings covered with gasoline-soaked burlap, was hoisted tonight up the metal flagpole on the grounds of the Nature Friends Camp, a summer holiday resort for whites and Negroes at Stonetown near here, by some unidentified persons who left a crude message threatening Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve issuance of $5,500,000 of its equipment trust certificates to meet the major part of the cost of 950 allsteel hopper cars, five steam locomotives and two diesel switching locomotives, which will cost $5,519,806.

The New York Cotton Exchange announced yesterday a reduction of $5 to $10 a bale in margin requirements effective Monday. Charles B. Vose, president of the Exchange, explained that the new margin rates are based on the Government's nonrecourse mandatory loan rates on cotton rather than the market level.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Said Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt today before the running of the American Legion Handicap: "If anyone beats Newsweekly I hope it's Miss Disco." That's the way it worked out, for at the end of the seven-furlong run the Vanderbilt-bred Miss Disco, bearing the silks of Sidney S. Schupper, was about half a length ahead of the Vanderbilt-owned Newsweekly with the two having had the race between them in the stretch.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 13 -- Most Rumanian banks were dissolved today by Government decree. The banks involved must publish their balance sheets within five days and liquidators will then be appointed to sell their assets.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk, 26-year-old star from Findlay, Ohio, "just hit the ball" today to top a field of 47 players in the opening round of the women's national open golf tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 -- The National Chamber of Deputies, which has been made up of Peronistas since the Radicals walked out a week ago, chose yesterday to pass General Organization Law to give the President unlimited powers when he believes a national emergency exists.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -R.H. Johnston's giant trotter Rodney, never out of the money in three seasons of racing, charged to the finish line first in straight heats today to win the $4,150 Trotting Derby, closing-day feature of the Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -New Jersey apple growers are switching to winter varieties in an attempt to keep up with consumer preferences, the State Department of Agriculture announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- An apparatus to produce simultaneously sheet material and tear tape sections for the individual wrapping of articles was one of 474 inventions listed this week by the United States Patent Office.

A feathered stowaway was brought ashore yesterday from the Italian liner Saturnia and quartered in the pier telephone operator's office while officials of the American Export Lines looked through Public Health Office manuals for advice on its disposal.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Victor Johnston, leader of Harold E. Stassen's unsuccessful bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, told Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today that thousands of DeweyWarren volunteers' clubs were being organized to attract new and independent voters to this year's Republican ticket.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Business was at a low ebb in the stock markets here today, being confined solely to evening up of commitments before the week-end.

More than $700,000 worth of industrial equipment has been bought here for India's steel, chemical and oil mill industries, by Tata, Inc., 90 Broad Street, and further purchases of $750,000 are contemplated for plant modernization, officials disclosed here yesterday.

" WESTWARD HA!"* is a terrifyingly jocose book. It is a fair warning of what we might be in for if the man who wrote "Innocents Abroad" accepted a return engagement in this grace-filled year. It has its rare moments -- though its rare moments are rare.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 13 -Israel's Provisional Government appeared today to be headed toward its first Cabinet crisis.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 13 -- The requirements of the European Recovery Program may force a halt in, or at least a revision of, the dismantling program in Western Germany, particularly in the Ruhr, according to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -Canada will lift her wartime ban on exports of beef cattle and beef to this country Monday, but it won't mean a noticeable increase in domestic meat supplies in the immediate future.

Repercussions from the sale of the Continental Bank and Trust Company to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company continue to appear. It was learned yesterday that a suit has been filed in the Supreme Court of New York County on behalf of four stockholders of Continental seeking damages and recovery from the absorption.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 13 -Equaling the amateur course record of 66, Jim Oleska of Shore view did a one-man job in placing his team in a tie for medal honors in the fourteenth annual Seawane Harbor Club's member-guest tourney qualifying round today.
