Uncertainty over the inclusion of jewelry in the new retail credit regulations has had an adverse effect on merchandising and advertising preparations of credit jewelers for the fall and Christmas holiday period, it was reported yesterday by William Wagner, secretary of the National Association of Credit Jewelers.

Laurence H. Victory, president of Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, announced last night that the union would meet tomorrow to consider the calling of a "lockout" at The Journal of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -President Truman may notify the country over the week-end that it faces a budget deficit this fiscal year, ending next June 30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Army Department decided today to seek revision of the Selective Service Act to require registration and induction of sufficient doctors, dentists and veterinarians to make possible the proposed Army and Air Force expansion.

Tension among tenants caused by crowded housing conditions has increased the number of psychopathic cases in the city's magistrate courts, Magistrate Morris Ploscowe declared yesterday in mid-Manhatan Court.

Addressing veterans of the Eleventh Armored Division who served with the Third Army in the Battle of the Bulge, Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, a former commander of the division in training, complimented them yesterday on their war record and urged their continued support of a program for world peace.

I can readily understand why Senator O'Mahoney would prefer discussing steel to wool. I hope, however, that he will not mind if I confine what I have to say to those parts of his letter which actually bear on the subject of my essay of July 26.
ATHENS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Greek Army troops today began closing the guerrillas' last major supply route in the Grammos Mountains to Albania, a General Staff spokesman said.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission recommended today that the International Railway Company in Buffalo and Niagara Falls either reorganize speedily or sell its property to ne winterests "who will furnish adequate service at reasonable rates."

Perhaps with an eye to the forthcoming Rosh ha-Shanah season, a local food distributor is introducing stuffed kishke, prepared in the Midwest under rabbinicalh)0*0*0*isupervision and canned for the first time. This is customary food on Jewish feast days, though traditional on no one in particular.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -A retired New York diagnostician, Dr. Benjamin Sachs, who now lives here, has written an original screen story which Paramount today announced that it had obtained for Alan Ladd, and will film as "Under the Gun."

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Senator Revercomb said today he did not blame Secretary of State Marshall personally for State Department refusal to turn over confidential visa files to a subcommittee Mr. Revercomb heads.

Along with trees and flowering shrubs, grass plots are artfully distributed among the new buildings designed in groups for multiple habitation on a great scale. About these plots as protection or, anyway, warning to spare the greensward, chains are sometimes strung on neat iron posts.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -An agent for the French Government was the highest bidder for a 78,000-kilowatt rectifier station at the former Aluminum Company of America at Burlington, N.J., the War Assets Administration announced today.

ATHENS, Aug. 13 -- The Greek Army reported today that units on the northern Grammos front, advancing west from Alevitsa to Gianochori, which they captured, were subjected to mortar fire from across the Albanian frontier. The iincident is said to be one of many observed by teams for the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan took cognizance today of the fact that while baseball may be the great American pastime, it is causing Fred Gilmour of Green Village, a small community near Chatham, N.J., loss of sleep and impairment of his health.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- September corn acted tight in the early trading on the Board of Trade today advancing 2 3/8 cents a bushel on saving headed by professional traders, part of which was regarded as closing of spreads with December.

Urging New Yorkers to "put aside provincialism" and "recognize their city as the urban capital of the world," the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects offered yesterday a long-range, detailed plan for future development of East Midtown Manhattan.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 13 -- A ten-day American dance festival under the joint auspices of Connecticut College and New York University got off to an auspicious start here tonight in the handsome Palmer Auditorium with a performance by Martha Graham and her company.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Information dribbling through to London today on yesterday's meeting in Moscow confirmed reports here that the prospects were a little more hopeful than seemed possible a few days ago. There is still a great gap to be bridged between the Soviet Union and the Western Powers on the Berlin situation but the process of building that bridge continues slowly and painfully.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Aug. 13 -- The ties between the universities of the world, torn by World War II, have been rejoined here in a ten-day conference of the world's leading educators.

New York and Washington theatrical interests are seeking to convert a movie house to legitimate shows in Alexandria, Va., just across the Potomac from Washington and well within its metropolitan area, it was learned yesterday. In effect, this would circumvent the Actors Equity ban on Negro discrimination in capital playhouses.

Somewhere east of Brooklyn, on a course for the Azores, is still bobbing along today, we hope, the seagoing truck of F.B. Carlin and his lady. They put to sea in their seventeen-foot Atlantic "liner" last Saturday. A United States destroyer found them 150 miles out on Wednesday, putt-putting along at four and one-half knots (or should it be miles?) an hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -Texas Eastern Transmission Company might be able to furnish any additional natural gas needed by the Atlantic Seaboard Company to meet Baltimore's requirements in 1951 if present applications are granted, an Atlantic official said today.
The city's two largest milk companies were challenged yesterday by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh to explain their policies on bidding for Board of Education contracts.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Coming up with two three-run innings, the first one sparked by Pee Wee Reese's two-run homer for a temporary tie, the Dodgers evened the series with the Braves tonight and reduced the league leaders' advantage to three games, with only one in the loss column by winning 6 -- 3.

That $1,000 bond has turned up again, and detectives of the Ryer Avenue station, the Bronx, are sitting tight and not asking too many questions. For six months this bond has bounced around police stations and courts, bringing the police little more than confusion.
A suggestion that the city start its third venture into free parking lots by using Park Department land adjacent to Hunter College in the Bronx was advanced yesterday by the Bronx Board of Trade.
The "American story" is being told abroad not only by a rejuvenated "Voice of America" but through a wide program of book, magazine, newspaper, motion-picture and music distribution.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Sun and form returned to the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today as the favorites in the Eastern grass court championships reached the men's semi-finals and women's final.

The business of "boy meets girl -- object matrimony" met a setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein signed an order barring Social Contacts, Inc., of 220 West Fortysecond Street, a matrimonial mailorder service, from selling securities to the public and appointed a receiver for the corporation.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- America's highly-touted basketball team swamped a hard-fighting French quintet in Harringay Arena tonight by a score of 65 to 21 to capture the Olympic laurel wreath in token of the world championship.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Advances of two miles were recorded today by the Seventy-eighth Infantry Division in an "attack" -on paper -- designed to wipe out a theoretical enemy force entrenched just south of the St. Lawrence River.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 13 -The National party, Turkey's newlyborn and rapidly growing third major political group, joined today in sharp attacks on the European Recovery Program with the charge that the bilateral TurkishUnited States agreement on the Marshall Plan was one of the factors that would bring "ruin to Turkish exports and peasants."
Two girls pushing a baby carriage in which lay their infant brother were struck by an automobile at 7:30 P.M. last night as they crossed Third Avenue between Ninth and Tenth Street, Brooklyn.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 13 -Chester Bowles, former head of the Office of Price Administration, was assured of the Democratic nomination for Governor of Connecticut as the Democratic State Convention opened here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A United States Senator disclosed today he would fly to Scotland on his vacation and try his hand as a lobster-monger.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Irrawaddy River town of Thayetmyo, springboard of the four-day-old military mutiny against the Burmese Government, was reported in the hands of the military police and "quiet," an official statement said today.

ARTISTS of the nursery set should find a new stimulus in the trials of Billy the Bunny, who set out to draw a self-portrait. He had just sketched in the torso when Penny the Puppy happened along and added a spaniel's head.

So definitely has this become a world of flight that it requires 544 pages to present the many aspects of wings around the globe in the World Aviation Annual, which has just been published by the Aviation Research Institute in conjunction with the James Jackson Cabot Professorship of Air Transportation of Norwich University.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Ferndale, N.Y., had the women's national open golf tournament in the palm of her hand today after the first fifty-four holes of play at the Atlantic City Country Club.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York City Police Department issued immediate and unqualified denials of the Moscow broadcast of the Tass dispatch, which in almost identical form was published also in the Communist party newspaper Pravda.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The situation in Burma is considered very serious, a British Foreign Office spokesman said today. The British Government is watching developments there with much anxiety. It is felt that the optimistic statements made by Rangoon are misleading.

THERE were so many fireworks when the musical resources of Tanglewood were put "on parade" recently that the cause for which the jamboree was staged was almost obscured. The United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music, which initiated the drive, hardly got mentioned.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 14 (AP) -- States Rights Democrats of Oklahoma renounced today the national Democratic party and cheered the candidacies of two Southern Governors for President and Vice President.

Reorders for early fall merchandise continued to be received by wholesale garment markets here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Favorable consumer response to many fall apparel lines, the report said, reflect the "excellent vaules" offered by manufacturers.

The University of Buffalo has enlarged its Department of Geology, renaming it the Department of Geology and Geography. "The expansion of our work in geography," the university announces, "is the result of an increased demand for more offerings in this field. Geography is a tremendously large factor underlying world affairs, and it is important to the study of international relations that we provide as full a curriculum in geography as we possibly can."

OREGON CITY, Ore., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Oregon is celebrating the centenary of the founding of the Oregon Territory today. Bearded men and girls in pioneer skirts and bonnets dot the streets of this small town which once -- until settlers disappointed it by congregating in Portland -- was expected to become the metropolis of the state.
American Federation of Labor seamen on this coast have reached a wage agreement with their principal employers that may set a pattern for other sea disputes that threaten a strike next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- An official Soviet demand for complete custody and control of Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina was rejected on the spot today by Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett for the United States Government.

THE highway from the west comes down the Deerfield Valley, the way the Mohawks came two centuries ago to harry and burn the settlements in the Connecticut Valley. Here, where the river leisures in trout pools, once stood three forts within the space of two miles to check the Indians' forays, Hawks Fort, then Rice Fort, and, at the bend of the river to the east, Taylor Fort.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Communists on the Government payroll need have little fear if they have stolen American secrets. The law provides ample protection.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 14 -- A record-breaking crowd of 25,001 saw the Baltimore-owned Isa turn back the stretch challenge of the highly fancied Rampart in the six-furlong Mermaid Handicap, the $10,000 added filly and mare special that featured the program at the seashore course.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration combed some of the snarls out of the registration procedure for the G.I. Bill's education and training program today.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Alex Jany set himself right with his public today. The champion French freestyle swimmer's total lack of success in the Olympics almost caused La Belle France to put on sackcloth and ashes as he failed to place in the 100 or 400 meters at Wembley and scratched in the 1,500. Jany said it must have been something he ate or failed to eat in rationed London.

Due largely to an abundance of institutional investment funds, in combination with high building and construction costs, accompanied by vast industrial needs for additional working capital, a new form of "sale and lease" or "purchase and lease" transactions in business property is in process of development.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 14 -- A Census Bureau estimate for 1947 which indicated some Midwestern states were declining in population evoked little pessimism in the region this week.

AMONG the notables invited to attend the funeral of Gen. John J. Pershing were high-ranking military officers as well as important figures in government. But the list also included a sergeant, almost a legendary figure, about whose name clings a tale of heroism that still lives notwithstanding the fact that the man himself has passed into comparative obscurity in the valley of Three Forks of the Wolf in Fentress County in Tennessee.
TORONTO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs whipped the Jersey City Giants, 10 -- 7 and 4-0, in a double-header today.

STRAWBERRIES can be planted in August. This is convenient for people who have more time this month to set out plants than in the rushed weeks of spring -- if, indeed, spring lasts for "weeks" at all. It is also helpful to impatient gardeners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Some relaxation of the hastily passed compromise "DP" law was foreshadowed this week when one of the prime movers of the complex statute, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, took a position in support of any needed changes when Congress reconvenes.

Play in the twenty-third annual championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association will get under way tomorrow morning when seventy aspirants tee off in the qualifying round at the Greenwich (Conn.) Country Club.

Most of the great and near-great in the dare-devil fraternity of speedboat racing will converge on Red Bank on the North Shrewsbury Navesink River this coming week-end for the sixteenth running of the National Sweepstakes regatta, the first of America's triumvirate of top-level race meets that will include the Gold Cup on Aug. 28 at Detroit and wind up with the President's Cup on the Potomac at Washington Sept. 18-19.

THE landscape in the Pacific Northwest dominates the art of the region. It is a spectacular landscape of suddenly rising mountains with a porcupine-like covering of trees, of shifting mists and of plunging waterfalls whose spray is blown into momentary dragon-shapes.

THIS new yearbook opens with a monthly summary of 1947's events, presented from a dozen different viewpoints. William L. Shirer offers the January version, as seen from New York City; other radio broadcasters follow with the picture of world affairs as they appeared from Norway, Australia, London, Holland, Montreal and other vantage points.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 14 -- From Hibbing, Minn., heart of the iron ore producing section, came figures indicative of the pressure behind department store buying. The State Tax Commissioner reported 2,255 residents of the iron mining capital last year paid total state income taxes of $111,782, an average of $49.57 per person.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The two leading contenders for the singles assignments on the American Davis Cup team, top seeded Frank Parker of Los Angeles and the defending champion, Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta Calif., will meet tomorrow afternoon in the final of the twenty-second Eastern grass courts men's singles championship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Following the Department of Agriculture's forecast on Monday that the current cotton crop would exceed any in the last eleven years, sales of cotton textiles last week fell off sharply in the primary market. Worth Street commission men said they anticipated a minimum of business for the balance of the month, and gray goods prices were withdrawn generally.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 14 -- Heavy rains during the past week have caused great damage to the cement runways of the Mexico City Central Airport and have resulted in a reduction in passenger traffic between here and the United States estimated by one air line to be between 25 and 37 1/2 per cent.

FRANKFORT, Ky. -- While it is now only mid-August, and summer still has several weeks to go, it is not too early to start planning a late summer or early autumn leisurely motor tour through lovely and historic Old Kentucky.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia won the Olympic women's gymnastic championship today in a touching setting.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- United Nations headquarters is in its last work-crammed month of preparations for the eight-to-twelve-week session of the General Assembly in Paris.

SOME gardeners who think they "know their onions" are surprised to learn that certain charming yellow, white, rose or purple flowers, growing singly or in clumps, are also members of the onion family. They are interested to note, too, that it is not only possible but easy to have an attractive grouping of these plants around the herb or rock garden or the perennial border, from May to September.

RELIEF from one of the radio listener's oldest complaints may be in sight, according to word from WOR. Charles Singer, the station's assistant chief engineer, sees promise in a device to be employed in studio control rooms which will equalize the volume of the spoken and musical portions of programs.

A NATION-WIDE survey of camera club activities has been started by Ansco to serve as the basis for an extensive program aimed at sharing progressive ideas among clubs and club groups. Detailed questionnaires which are being sent to camera clubs throughout the United States are expected to yield valuable information on how individual organizations operate in widely separated communities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, which ordinarily moves about under intermittent and alternating showers of brickbats and bouquets, is plunging through a heavy rain of both just now. The "Communist cases" have brought on the deluge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Government needs a million new soldiers and military-supply workers by June, 1949.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. THIS department, having delivered itself some weeks ago of a little high-minded advice on the matter of summer reading, now shamefacedly declines to render an itemized account of its own performance during the time of its absence.
BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- The Braves were singing "Sweet Saturday Night" and the Dodgers were warbling the blues after tonight's travesty at Braves Field before a crowd of 32,457 fans.

To work, and to look as though I were working constantly from nine in the morning till dinner, and after the evening meal until bedtime, has become a habit with me, and in that respect I am exactly like a government clerk.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- George Vico drove in seven runs with a home run, triple and a double to pace the Detroit Tigers to a 10-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns tonight. Virg Trucks turned in a sparkling one-hit relief chore after Starting Pitcher Bill Pierce was batted out in the third inning.

Milton Hanauer is a teacher in the New York public schools, and, like a good teacher, he does not talk beyond the range of the pupil's knowledge.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Alan Corey's Meadow Brook quartet, holding the opposition scoreless in the last two periods, turned back Cecil Smith's Texas poloists, 8 to 7, on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club today. In another match on No. 2 field, Roslyn halted Wheatley Hills, 8 to 5

ATHENS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The prospect of victory over the rebel forces in northern Greece precipitated today a demand within the Liberal party of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis for a new Government to replace the present coalition Cabinet.

RHODES, Aug. 14 -- The 330,000 Arabs driven from their homes by war in Palestine present the most urgent problem of the whole Palestine situation in the eyes of the United Nations' mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- Chilean-bred Beauchef, after disappointing early performances in the United States, today scored his third consecutive major stakes victory, coming from behind to win the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap before 32,685 racegoers at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- As Congressmen deserted the Capitol this week, Democrats "viewed with alarm" and Republicans described as "adequate" the curbs of inflationary pressures approved by the special session of Congress. It was the consensus, however, that Congress did virtually nothing to "put the brakes" on the spiraling cost of living.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Alaska, which may some day be a state of the Union, already can claim to be the off-shore territory with the most ambitious military future.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Following is the Moscow broadcast text of the Tass dispatch from New York on Mrs. Oksana S. Kosenkina's plunge from the Soviet consulate:

Enveloped in an aura of good will and general satisfaction that was an eloquent token of the success of the games of the XIV Olympiad in attaining the ideal of international good sportsmanship, the first group of American athletes to return from London arrived here yesterday.

"OPERATION VITTLES," the American airlift into blockaded Berlin, has been remarkably safe and successful up to now, but if it has to continue into fall and winter it may have very rough going. At any rate, the regularity of flights will be reduced.

VIENNA, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet attack on Austria's ECA agreement with the United States at yesterday's Allied Council meeting launches the one issue which has been most feared here. It is the only serious matter which could bring a clash between the Soviet Union and the United States in Vienna at this time to destroy the atmosphere of calm and almost indifference which has been in such marked contrast to the situation in Berlin.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- Australia scored 153 runs for the loss of two wickets today in reply to England's low score of 52 runs in the first innings of the fifth and final cricket test match at the Kennington Oval. Australia has captured the series with three victories and one draw.
THE line of play known as "reversing the dummy" continues to be more often overlooked, by tyros and experts alike, than any other type of play in the bridge repertory.

OTTAWA, Canada, Aug. 14 -- Canada's perpetual problem of how to maintain national unity while at the same time preserving the political, racial and spiritual rights of the provinces within that union was the dominant issue of last week's National Liberal convention when Louis St. Laurent, a Quebec Catholic of French-Irish ancestry, was elected leader of the party to succeed Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- Larger stores in the Twelfth District report a general pick-up in retail sales activity. All sections showed a percentage gain over the same period last year except Salt Lake City. Business activity in California for June is estimated at 220.2 per cent of the 1935-1939 average.
COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Roman Catholic dignitaries gathered here today for the commemoration of the 700th anniversary of Cologne Cathedral.

For almost every important event in the romantic history of the Mediterranean Sea and the quarrels of nations along its peripheries have been mirrored on this vast rock, with its dusty, hot plains, its jagged peaks and upland stretches of forest.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- After three days of conferences with his top advisors on plans and strategy for the Republican Presidential campaign, Governor Dewey spent a quiet day today disposing of state business and relaxing.

THIS book should be of interest to anyone who has ever given himself the pleasure of reading Tolstoy's "War and Peace." It is the intimate family memoirs of his wife's sister, Tatyana, who was the model for its heroine, the unforgettable Natasha Rostova, and who lived with the Tolstoys for many summers on the family estate, Yasnaya Polyana, during the writing of the novel.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called upon the Western Allies today to stand firm in their determination to organize the Western zones of Germany. So far as is known that is exactly what the envoys of the United States, Britain and France are doing in the Moscow negotiations and that is generally considered to be one reason why a sort of deadlock still exists.

HOLLYWOOD. CAROL REED, British producer-director, who last week hopped the Atlantic for talks with Hollywood's David O. Selznick, concerning the filming of "The Third Man," one of four pictures to be made jointly by Selznick and England's Sir Alexander Korda, said virtually no difficulty had been encountered in getting permission from all of the four powers currently in control of Vienna to stage much of the shooting in that city. "

WASHINGTON -- Immense potentialities of foreign and domestic travel which could be developed through inexpensive group-travel programs, supported by organizational purchasing of accommodations, are being studied by Government officials here.

In contemplating the present spectacle of almost complete United States-Soviet Russia discord, the possibility suggests itself that a significant positive element is lacking in our policy toward the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO. THE funeral bak'd meats of the New York theatre feast do coldly furnish forth our first-night tables, and until New York is satiated, Chicago starves. There's no denying some of the cold cuts are delectable, and frequently they are more appetizing when freshly garnished for Chicago than when glazed in an aspic of bad habits toward the end of a New York run.

The U.S.S.R. has about 2,000 nationals in the U.S. in connection with Government business. Of the total 346 are officials -- diplomatic, consular and commercial. The rest are teachers, cooks, chauffeurs, wives and children. All are here on diplomatic visas, which permit unlimited residence in the U.S. so long as the individuals hold their jobs, pay their bills and stay out of serious trouble.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, announced yesterday plans to erect a six-story building for its offices on the south side of Fifty-eighth Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The plot, with 110-foot frontage on Fifty-eighth Street already has been purchased.

A MAJOR work by Doris Humphrey will have its world premiere on Wednesday evening in the American Dance Festival in Palmer Auditorium, New London, Conn. This is "Corybantic," composed for Jose Limon and his company, of which Miss Humphrey is artistic director, and set to Bela Bartok's concerto for two pianos and seven percussion instruments.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The council representing the sixteen Marshall Plan countries ran full force into the expected snags when it took up today the question of dividing United States credits for the current year among the participating states.

The seventeen-day-old Danubian conference in Belgrade gives observers the impression of a stockholders' meeting at which minor shareholders, turning up as rather unwelcome guests, have their say but do not influence the meeting. The majority bloc at the Belgrade conference is made up of delegates of Russia and six Danubian countries in Russia's sphere. The minority bloc is made up of delegates of the United States, Britain and France.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians moved a game and a half in front of the American League field by beating the Chicago White Sox, 4 -- 2, before a ladies' day turnout of 11,705 here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 14 -- What was to have been a special Gold Cup curtain raising race today in advance of tomorrow's Cambridge Y.C. annual speed boat regatta fixture turned out to be pretty much of a fizzle when the only finisher at the end of ninety miles was Henry Sieck's Pearl IV, a 225-cubic-inch craft from Rockville Centre, L.I.

THE growth of costume designing as a desirable occupation has led numerous hopefuls into this field. In addition there are related careers which are often just as interesting, just as lucrative and possibly more suitable for the individual.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 -- Amid general disorder, the Chamber of Deputies voted a few minutes before three o'clock this morning to reform the Argentine Constitution, which has been in effect unchanged since 1853.

Leaders of independent and Congress of Industrial Organization telephone unions, representing several hundred thousand workers in all parts of the nation, will meet in Washington next Friday to plan a unified strategy for a wage increase campaign, it was learned yesterday.

Although retail activity got off to a good start here last week sales tapered off as the week ended, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. College shop, coat and negligee were the busiest departments, it was said.

Nation-wide promotion of foods that are plentiful and consequently low in price was urged last week by Paul Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., as a result of a national survey just completed. Food dealers can be of immeasurable aid to the national economy, the budgets of the American family and themselves by taking such action, he said.

WHATEVER the effect of the current "spy scare" on the Thomas committee, it is probably causing more amusement than excitement in the circles that really deal with intelligence. It has long since been a commonplace that Intelligence is not a beautiful countess in a slinky gown, playing the boudoir circuit for military secrets.
For the third consecutive day, Babe Ruth continued yesterday to improve at Memorial Hospital. However, his condition still was critical, according to a hospital report.

MRS. BAKER'S third novel, like her first, is about a musician, this time a gifted young Mexican composer. The novel is laid in a coast town in Mexico, a scene Mrs. Baker has done beautifully. Somnolence and stir, moonlight and sunlight, the streets, the Pacific surf, the cool large interiors, the sounds of bells and of fountains -- these things provide the pleasure of the book.

THE brave response of the few local galleries that have made the city's Golden Jubilee an occasion for hanging views, past and present, of New York has so far been a mixed blessing. The occasional satisfying statement by a Sloan or Preston Dickinson has been attended by a host of frankly illustrative, picturesque essays that, whatever their value as social history, have left much to be desired as painting.

THE role of the psychologist often being, in the eyes of his patients if not in his own, that of the Supreme Being, it is a rare event to find one who writes a book which is genuinely humble and which suggests that the author is thoroughly aware of his own fallibility.

ANYONE who writes of Newman's conversion from the Anglican to the Roman Catholic Church has to face comparison with Newman's own, masterpiece of autobiography, the "Apologia Pro Vita Sua," in which he vindicated his honor against Kingsley's charge of duplicity.

There are a few ring or planetary nebulae, that is, nebulae which consist of an incandescent sun surrounded by a luminous ring. Such formations may be stages in the evolution of a supernova that exploded eons ago. At the International Astronomical Union held last week in Zurich, Switzerland, Dr. Donald Menzel of Harvard did not dispute this view, but he explained the nature of the luminous ring.

MISS SARTON'S poetry is most successful when its content is religious and its method most parsimonious. Though her craftsmanship is usually scrupulous and deft in the handling of detail, her conception of poetry, and of the poem, is one that lends itself too readily to the wastefulness of the flat, didactic statement and not readily enough to the economy of suggestion.
