In Moscow last week one of Russia's top-ranking officials, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the U.S.S.R., was the central figure in long and secret Big Four talks.

Peacetime uses of atomic energy, including the possible control of cancer, were discussed yesterday by scientific, military and navel experts in a round-table session over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 14 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion and Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok declared today that unless the United Nations, in fulfillment of its own decision, compelled the withdrawal of Arab armies, Israel would have to do it by war.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- A canvass of retail and wholesale meat purveyors here failed to disclose any concerted move among consumers to boycott meat.

TO risk the odiousness of comparison, a recital of what Mr. Moscow's book isn't may give an idea of what it is and of its virtues. It isn't a grubby tome by a social scientist, skilled in the custom of his calling to express the obvious unintelligibly.

A FACTOR in the refusal of Justice William O. Douglas to let his name go before the recent Democratic convention was probably the fact that relatively few of his fellow Americans know much about his political views.

Dancing on the "village green" -- the Long Meadow in Prospect Park, Brooklyn -- 700 children from all parts of the borough participated in the thirty-third annual dance festival staged yesterday by the Department of Parks. About 5,000 parents, relatives and friends attended.

Reversing a trend of policy that had been in effect since the enrollment boom began, state universities throughout the country report that they will accept students from other states this fall. It will be easier now for students of New York, for example, to enter a Midwestern or Far Western state university than it was a year ago.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Chester Bowles was nominated by acclamation this afternoon as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Connecticut.

Plans for the return to the transatlantic passenger trade of the famous old Cosulich Line, which disappeared in 1932 in the Mussolini-inspired consolidation of all Italian shipping companies, were announced here last week by Giuseppe Cosulich, veteran Italian shipping executive.

A committee representing the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League sailed for Europe yesterday on the Gdynia-America liner Batory to take part in ceremonies in memory of Fiorello La Guardia, former Mayor of New York. The leader of the group was James H. Sheldon, administrative chairman of the league.

The Census Bureau reported last week that the estimated population of the United States is now 143,414,000, an increase of 8.9 per cent since the 1940 census. This is more than 2,000,000 over the figure that the demographers (population experts) had been predicting before the war. The reason for the unexpected increase is a birthrate which seems to have reversed a pre-war trend. In 1947 there were 3,700,000 births, a record-breaker.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island -- Though easily accessible to the summer traveler, this island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence has a curiously remote atmosphere. The local folk still talk about the planes that bring in the "foreign" mail, meaning the mail from the rest of Canada.

. . . For it occurs to me that the great test of brotherhood the world over is to be settled in the United States by what is to be the attitude of the majority of this country to this Negro minority. And as I think of it, the obligation to get that thing straightened out is not entirely upon the white people.

New procurement regulations governing operations under the Economic Cooperation Administration were pronounced "workable" last week following detailed study by top-level foreign trade and banking officials.

WHEN representatives of Hollywood's Association of Motion Picture Producers sit down this week in New York with James C. Petrillo and other officers of the American Federation of Musicians to thresh out the terms of a new contract for musicians employed in the film studios, it is expected here that the question of how many of the union's members the motion-picture companies must keep on their payrolls will cause sharp division.

In the very interesting article, "New Yorkers: A Gallery," S.J. Woolf quotes me as saying that David Belasco "was more an actor than a director." If I did make that statement it must have been the prattling of an ignorant novice.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 14 -- Rhode Island, first state in the Union officially to mark the anniversary of the end of hostilities in World War II, observed today as V-Day, a full legal holiday. The Legislature enacted this last year.
Connie Mack, who has lived a great many years and has noted many strange happenings, can now also authoritatively report he has seen lightning strike twice in the same place.

SOMETHING causes private detective Barr Breed to deviate from his rule of not messing about with murder cases. Perhaps it is the generous retainer offered by Paul Gibbs, who is almost certain to hang for the strangling of Caroline MacCormick unless the real killer is found.

READING, Pa., Aug. 14 -- Gov. James H. Duff opened Reading's bicentennial celebration today with a bow to the old Reading of England from which came William Penn, whose sons, Thomas and Richard, founded this Pennsylvania community.

James L. Bates, who will retire next month as chief of the Bureau of Technical Affairs of the United States Maritime Commission, has had direct supervision aver more ship construction than any other man in the country's maritime history.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- A "No Sharks Allowed" order was invoked today for the fresh waters of Lake George in the Adirondacks.

WHEN it comes to the tactics of surprise, Capt. Horatio Hornblower has nothing on his agile-minded creator, C.S. Forester. His new book is a dazzling exhibition of his storytelling virtuosity, and will appeal to those who respond to the implied idea as well as those seeking the enchantment of narrative.

The United States has an expected carry-over this year of more than 1,000,000,000 bushels of the major exportable grain crops, wheat and corn, assuring the world of an adequate "cushion" against basic food shortage next year, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Finance Minister Paul Reynaud's bill for financial and economic reform was approved early today by the Council of the Republic. The bill will now go to the National Assembly for a second reading Tuesday.

GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- An account of a week of large-scale rioting in Cairo against Europeans that resulted in death or serious injury to at least 250 Jews at the hands of mobs of Egyptians was published this week in the newspaper National Zeitung of Basle.
The collapse of an offering of stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation last winter has become a celebrated case in the history of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The United States won 38 first places in the eleventh modern Olympic Games that ended today to lead the field and far outshine the American record in the last previous competition at Berlin in 1936. Then Germany got 33 firsts, to 24 for the United States and 10 for Hungary.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the largest labor union in the United States, today pledged to the United Automobile Workers, CIO, membership of almost 1,000,000 his "complete support, my full energy" toward the formation of a new political force in America.

With the movement of cargo on the decline and competition in the shipping field in general becoming more keen, a number of port cities are branching out into new territories in their search for industrial leads.

A NEW crop of workshop books from Delta-Craft (Delta Manufacturing Division, Milwaukee, Wis.) is now available. Paper-bound and running up to 64 pages in size, they sell for 25 cents unless otherwise noted. The craftsman who works with drill press, circular or band saw, abrasive tools, lathes and/or shapers will do well to investigate booklets 4530 through 4535.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- A bankrupt empire, held in receivership by the British Army, was put up for disposal in London this week. Although the empire, once the property of Italy, has plenty of liabilities and no assets except hidden ones, bidding for properties was spirited.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet bloc would have succeeded in ringing down the curtain today on the Danubian Conference but for an adjournment motion by the Ukrainian Government.
ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- After an extensive redecoration of many months, the dignified Georgian mansion of Maj. Gen. Philip Schuyler, Revolutionary War leader, reopens to the public tomorrow.

GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK -- The only mountain-climbing school this side of the Alps is enjoying a busy season at the Grand Teton National Park, near Jenny Lake, Wyo. The Teton range has for many years attracted mountaineers.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The United States Olympic team won the 1948 games by a margin of 309 points. The Americans, second to Germany in the 1936 Olympics, compiled 662 points in the games that ended in London tonight with Sweden a distant second with 353 tallies.
PRELIMINARY plans for the Los Angeles opera center which, in or about 1953, will become the Metropolitan Opera's "Western home," were unfurled here the other day.

PRIVATE detective Max Thursday has a facility, amounting almost to genius, for sticking his neck out. Sometimes the things he does, or fails to do, appear to be mentally, morally and legally unsound, but he always provides an interesting story.

The Rev. Aloysius J. Wycislo, assistant executive director of War Relief Services -- National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared yesterday that many displaced persons were finding "every door shut to them because the standards inside are too high for newcomers to be allowed to share them."
WARSAW, Aug. 14 -- The International Conference of Working Youth ended tonight by adopting a fifteen-point Youth Rights Charter and a political resolution that followed the Communist party line.

THE fourth annual Eastern International Gladiolus Show will be held at Kalurah Temple, Binghamton, N.Y., on Tuesday and Wednesday. This is the largest show in the East devoted to a single flower, with about 20,000 square feet of floor space housing more than 3,000 entries.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 14 -- "Oscars of the fashion industry," the Neiman-Marcus awards, will be presented for distinguished service in the field of fashion at the Neiman-Marcus specialty store's eleventh fall fashion exposition Monday evening, Sept. 6, here, it was stated today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The present broad lines of United States policy toward the United Nations would be continued if Governor Dewey was elected President, according to indications today from usually well-informed sources.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, state director of selective service, announced today the location and part membership of ninety-two upstate local draft boards, which will have charge of peacetime Selective Service outside of New York City.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- Youth and experience worked in perfect harmony at Shibe Park today and the Giants floated back within striking distance of the National League's first division.
PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Fortunately for squabbling coalitions of both East and West, no new and German edition of Talleyrand has yet appeared in the rubble of the devastated Third Reich.

Retail trade here last week maintained about the same degree of activity as in recent weeks. Department store sales were estimated at about 7 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year. Response to August promotions has been spotty, with furniture events faring better than those featuring furs.

PARIS. EVER since there have been Americans, they have dreamed a dream and called it Paris. Perhaps it started in 1776, when Benjamin Franklin came here as the representative of the young Republic and was embraced by Voltaire. Ever since, Americans have been "colonizing" Paris.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 14 -- Otto Greiner, Baltimore, a virtual unknown among professional golfers, boosted himself into the lead of the St. Paul open at the end of today's third round.

INSCRUTABLE and enigmatic as ever, Reggie Fortune undertakes to investigate the death of a young woman whose bones, minus the skull, have been found on the slope of Scawgill Edge near Gilthwaite. Soon after Reggie's arrival at the scene there is an outbreak of crimes of violence involving several promising suspects for the murder of the girl, whose identity has not yet been established.

THIS slim, lightly written, abundantly illustrated book (almost every paragraph of text has an accompanying drawing) is likely to be one of the most easily perused an athletically-minded reader ever set eye on; whether it will do more, in most cases, than give him anything but a smattering of advice about the sport he's interested in is to some degree questionable.

A few years ago you printed a poem by William Rose Benet entitled, "Bread." I cut it out and have kept it ever since. As I re-read it recently it struck me how significant it still is in these times in which, after three years of peace (?), men, women and children are starving the world over.

A BOAT trip up the Hudson River can be many things -- a day's outing to escape the city's heat, a leisurely way to start a trip north or west of Albany, or a capsule course in the history and architecture in the Hudson River Valley.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. (Science Service) -- Radioactive atoms are expected to assist in solving mineral engineering problems and to lead to more efficient production of metals from ores, according to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which is starting an expanded research program.

IN THIS leafy Siskiyou Mountain town of 8,000 inhabitants, four Shakespearean plays are being presented in the Elizabethan manner this month. This is no unique event for Ashland. Since 1935 its Globe-style theatre has featured the works of Shakespeare as Shakespeare himself wrote them to be presented.

In view of the anti-inflationary moves of the monetary authorities last week, early action to increase the reserve requirements of Federal Reserve member banks is not anticipated in financial circles.

SO far as one can judge from the public attention it receives, the atomic warning is not uppermost in the American people's minds this summer. Or perhaps we have all gotten used to it and carry it around like an invisible burden, as an individual does a half-suppressed worry about his health, his business or his social relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A high Government official said tonight that the Administration would ask Congress early next year to vote a series of sweeping proposals designed to tighten the nation's espionage laws.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The first United States Air Force C-74 to span the Atlantic landed at the Rhein Main air base today and immediately was placed under a blanket of secrecy. The plane made the flight from Westover Field, Mass., in nineteen hours, thirty-four minutes.

Although abstract art has sometimes confused me, I take issue with Eliot Clark's letter in the Aug. 1 issue. He says that by adopting the cause of abstract art we "ape the effete escapism of neurotic, disillusioned Europeans."

In 1944 the towns of Kingston and Newburgh, N.Y., decided to make a thorough study of drinking water to determine the effect of dissolved fluorine in preventing or checking tooth decay. Newburgh's water supply naturally contains 0.12 parts per million of fluorine, but sodium fluoride was added to bring the fluorine concentration up to 0.8-1.0 parts per million.

The evening performance on Oct. 5 of "Edward My Son," at the Martin Beck Theatre, starring Robert Morley, has been taken over by Personal Parcels Service, AWVS, Manhattan Unit, as a benefit for that organization.

THE bettor is getting a good break at major Western gambling emporiums in this year of economic strain. The average dollar dumped in a slot machine brings a 10 per cent greater yield than hitherto. This is certainly a unique development in the entertainment and merchandising fields.

THE week's yield of recordings is mostly of a seasonal nature, with the emphasis on entertainment rather than edification. A notable exception is David Diamond's Music for Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" (Columbia, three twelve-inch disks).

DORE SCHARY, who could easily qualify as a top-flight Hollywood stormy petrel, now is back with his old studio, Metro, for what appears to be a fairly long stretch. The new vice president in charge of production, whose conferences on policy with Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., Metro's parent company, topped the week's local film news, disclosed that his contract with Metro was for a term of fourteen years.

A couple of young blades, having quaffed a few goblets in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, decided it was time for the loaf of bread that goes with wine. Their method was somewhat anti-social and the police had to take over.

Bill John's Hope took a two-second decision from Emil Mosbacher's Susan in the International Class but the rest of the class battles weren't particularly close in the Y.R.A. championship regatta run in a spanking nor'wester by the Bayside Yacht Club yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The United Nations Kashmir commission proposed today a cease-fire agreement between India and Pakistan to pave the way for a peaceful settlement of the struggle for Kashmir.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, told the ninetieth convention in his opening address today that "strikes and lockouts now in progress" would continue "regardless of size or place, and regardless of time or expenditure."

SET against a background of shirring political events in France and in America, this story of Martha Jefferson brings to life an illustrious family and a colorful era. At the death of his young wife, Jefferson turned to his oldest daughter for comfort, finding in her sympathy and companionship a lifelong source of inspiration.

LAST spring many hoped -- and some feared -- that the post-war inflation had run its course. Food prices fell, and retail sales almost stopped growing. Wages in the steel industry refused to budge. And in addition, foreign demands for our export goods seemed to be sinking from their abnormal post-war levels.

Two 33-year-old men were accused yesterday of attacking and robbing in the last three months more than two dozen persons living in the West Bronx in the vicinity of 161st and 170th Streets. The police said the victims were mugged in the hallways of their homes after they had been trailed from one of the three IND subway stations in the area.

Refrigeration and air-conditioning installations in commercial and industrial establishments are much greater in size than before the war, engineers and contractors revealed here yesterday. For example, the sixteen-acre shopping center of the Fresh Meadows, Long Island, 170-acre housing development, according to Carrier Corporation technicians, represents the first project of its size, completely air conditioned in stores, offices and a theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Henry Wallace's third-party candidacy made it inevitable that foreign policy would become an issue in the Presidential campaign, but the degree and even the nature of the coming debate rests with the major party candidates.

Those gleaming dawns that came sweeping out of the east so early of a June morning are gone. Here it is mid-August, and you can stay abed till 6 o'clock, daylight time, and still get up in time to see the sun rise. And dusk comes earlier. We've lost an hour and a half of daylight since the summer solstice.

Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the Federal Security Agency, said yesterday that the thirteenth anniversary of the passage on Aug. 14, 1935, of the Social Security Act found the concept of social security an integrated part of the American way of life.

SEMI-POSTALS to raise funds for the restoration of the cathedral in Salzburg have been received from Vienna by Leon Monosson. Only on the lowest value, 20-groschen plus 10g green, is it explained why this Austrian group was issued.

THIS volume gives detailed instructions and diagrams on the methods for reproducing a garment from any design. The process of creating a costume on the form has long been the most successful method for evolving dress styles.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said tonight the United States Government "will not be coerced" in the current diplomatic discussions in Moscow.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 14 -- Finance Minister Ramon Beteta Quintana has given his "emphatic assurance that the Mexican Government is not even considering the freezing of private dollar deposits in banks here," in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE pace of retail trade showed scant change of importance last week. Somewhat more wholesale order activity here testified to considerable confidence in fall prospects. For the most part, however, there seemed to be a tendency "to play close to the vest" in many lines in the expectation that the fall and subsequent holiday period will test demand for so-called consumer "unessential" items.

ALMOST the last step in converting the cracker-barrel grocery of the past into the supermarket of the present is self-service in meats and poultry. Does this newest wrinkle in selling food mean that shoppers do their own butchering?

Plans are under way for the sixtieth National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, opening on Nov. 2 and continuing through Nov. 9. All the evening sessions and most of the matinees will feature international military events, in addition to the civilian classes.

SHOPPING for upholstery fabrics may not seem the most delightful way of spending a hot afternoon in mid-August. But if you have a vacation still to come or expect to be away several week-ends, the living room sofa or the dining room chairs would be missed less from now until Oct. 1 than at any other time during the next twelve months.

EVEN to the inhabitants of the outside world, where everything is dollars and cents and only your favorite bar and grill is air-conditioned, it is recognized that a man's talent is a synthesis of several things rather than a big glob of just one.

A.L. ROWSE, one of the younger English historians, who combines professional scholarship with creative writing and a lively interest in the political and social problems of the day, has collected in the present volume a number of essays written by him during the last fifteen years.

Beset by steadily rising costs in almost every phase of operation, utilities throughout the country, and particularly in this state, hailed what some power and light men described as "the new thinking" contained in the remarks of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in his report for 1947 last week.

The Soviet Consulate on East Sixty-first Street, New York City, is not a part of Russian soil. The police may enter there if they have good reason to believe a crime has been committed or a life is in danger. The lawyers are not in agreement as to precisely how far the diplomatic privileges and immunities of the Consul General and his staff may run.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen, Cardinal southpaw ace, today ended the Pittsburgh Pirate jinx which had extended to seven games, as St. Louis defeated the Buccos, 6 to 3.
OTTUMWA, Iowa, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The big Morrell packing plant here suspended operations in six departments today after what the company described as "a series of sporadic sit-downs" occurred.

ONE attends the concerts of the Berkshire Music Festival and visits the classrooms of the Berkshire Music Center, and the palm goes to Koussevitzky for the force of imagination and capacity for accomplishment which in this place has so strikingly realized his purposes.

SMOKY HILL, Kan., Aug. 14 -- A cross-training curriculum that will make super-specialists of the specialists who now man the heavy bombers of the United States Air Force will be put into practical operation on this giant Boeing B-29 base tomorrow. Twenty seasoned B-29 pilots will make up the first class.

In the fifth winter Olympic Games at St. Moritz, Switzerland, from Jan. 30 to Feb. 8, Sweden's athletes topped a field of twenty-eight nations by scoring 82 points. Switzerland was runner-up with 77 tallies, while the United States was third with 73 1/4.

WITH a nostalgic excursion into vaudeville and enough ballyhoo for a movie premiere, the ABC network's local television station, WJZ-TV, took to the air last week, thereby bringing up to six the number of video outlets in metropolitan New York competing for the viewer's attention.

IT has gotten so that a fellow hardly dares turn his back before things begin to pop like a Fourth of July fireworks display. The sports scene seemed fairly placid and under control when this observer wandered away to commune with nature. Then someone carelessly dropped a match in the wrong place and there was the doggonedest commotion. Rockets and Roman candles burst into the sky and giant firecrackers went boom.
REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. -- The Delaware coast is providing a hospitable retreat for many thousands of Easterners -- and a few Midwesterners -- this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Official Soviet publications on the shelves of the Library of Congress refute the Russian claim that U.S.S.R. consular immunity has been violated in the Kosenkina case, THE NEW YORK TIMES was informed authoritatively today.
A strike that would take 15,000 workers from their jobs in this city and northern New Jersey after midnight next Thursday was voted yesterday by six locals of the Textile Workers Union, CIO.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- Elaine Hammerstein, star of the silent films and daughter of Arthur Hammerstein, theatrical producer, was killed with her husband and three friends in an automobile collision last night twelve miles south of the Mexican border town of Tia Juana.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The games of the fourteenth Olympiad drew to a brilliant close today as 80,000 spectators stood hushed in the fading sunset at Wembley Stadium to see the Olympic flame extinguished for the first time since the games began.

TO a visitor from that extramundane cosmos, Hollywood, the segments of the film industry operating in New York seem curiously different from their coastal complements. Functionaries of the movie companies here work in office buildings rather than walled-in factories called studios.

RADIO'S most extravagant and controversial spree in programming today faces a compulsory finish. If the Federal Communications Commission has its way, the broadcasters' indulgence in jackpot shows will be converted presently into an expensive hangover.

The first authentic large direct sale of German scrap iron and steel to American buyers was reported here yesterday. The German National Railways (Reichsbahn) have sold 250,000 tons of scrap to Western Steel Corporation, 521 Fifth Avenue, a New York concern which deals in iron and scrap metal.

BUENOS AIRES -- This is one of those places where the visitor from the United States can feel he has never left home. Buenos Aires, let us admit it, lacks the tropical picturesqueness of Rio, the monumental history of Lima, and the unmistakable "foreign-ness" of other capitals down South America way.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 14 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that the world eventually would "commit suicide" unless some form of global federation was evolved in which Anglo-Americans and Russians and others agreed to live in peace.

WARSAW, Aug. 14 -- A team of eight United States doctors left Warsaw today for Finland after a six weeks' tour of Poland to display and explain newest techniques and equipment to the Polish medical leaders. The tour was sponsored by the Unitarian Service Committee in cooperation with the World Health Organization.

PIERRE JANET, who died last year, was one of the pillars on which the complex structure of modern psychopathology rests. He was a precursor of Freud and a great innovator in his own right. Professor Mayo's book is in a way a historical study, not so much because he describes the work of a historical figure, however, as because his whole approach is somewhat dated.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- The Western powers have poured more than 300,000,000 Western marks into Berlin since the currency reform for the three Western sectors of the city began June 25, a reliable source said today.

Recently on a vacation a group of us got to discussing olden days. One of the topics of conversation was naturally "food." We wondered if the days would ever return when one could obtain a dinner of chicken wings with mashed potatoes, gravy, coffee and rolls, all for 20 cents.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- While Londoners were reading today about two more sex murders in Britain an American psychiatrist advocated a program of prevention to discover and treat sexual delinquents before they were able to commit crimes of violence.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho, Progressive party nominee for Vice President, said today that Soviet Russia "is in no position to threaten or fight anybody" and that its citizens were not "anxious to give their lives to spread communism over the world."

EDWIN DENBY, former dance critic of The New York Herald Tribune has collected his poems -- sonnets, lyrics, songs and verses to accompany photographs by Rudolph Burckhardt -- into this first volume. For the most part they are impressions of the New York scene, rather diffused in impact because subjectively organized as to images and tropes; but often they create a witty or revealing series of comments.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- It is increasingly apparent that the success of the European Recovery Program will depend a great deal on developments in European politics, which means much of the growth of Marshall Plan aid will hang on conditions that cannot now be foreseen with any accuracy.

Security prices sank lower last week as prospects of bumper crops vied for attention with higher interest rates on borrowed money. Three major farm products -- corn, wheat and cotton -- show indications of record-breaking harvests for the first time in the same crop year.

HOUSE plants, summering in the shade of a tree, are often neglected until the time comes to bring them indoors. Battered by summer storms and grown leggy from their struggles to reach the light, many of them are sad-looking specimens by September.

As a church officer in a congregation of a thousand members, I must sympathize with the object of securing peace which lies behind the appeal of over a hundred prominent clergymen to call for a day of mourning for the new draft law. As the father of a son who has had four years of military training at college, I know that sane people do not want to see their children go to war.

THIS story tells how Patch, a city-bred Airedale (mostly), learned about life on a Kentucky farm. It also tells how to get along with your neighbors (even one as mean and cranky as Mr. Rankin), why planting the very best kind of seed is important, what army worms really are and the damage they can do, and many other things about life on the farm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, Arthur Leff, found the International Typographical Union (AFL) and its four officers guilty today of violating three provisions of the Taft-Hartley law. His report held that a half-dozen other alleged violations had not been proved.
Out of Washington's "Communist spy ease" there emerged last week one inescapable conclusion: Someone was lying. The question was: Who?

The Transport Workers Union set up picket lines yesterday at American Airlines installations at La Guardia Field and at the lines office at 100 East Forty-second Street to protest the layoff of mechanics. The union has indicated it would strike the line unless the men were rehired.

CONFIRMING the rapidly growing interest of American photographers in press-type cameras is the recent arrival from Germany of the first shipment of the post-war Linhof, Europe's leading camera of this description. The Linhof Technika Model III retains its basic pre-war design but has many new features, most important of which is the high engineering standard maintained in its design and construction.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Six professionals carded three-under-par 69s to tie for the individual lead in the annual pro-member golf tournament of the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club today.

MAYS LANDING, N.J., Aug. 14 -- One man was killed and eleven bus passengers were injured about 7 o'clock tonight in a series of collisions involving three private cars and a Public Service bus on Black Horse Pike four miles from here.

On the outskirts of Topeka, just a few miles west of the Kansas State Capitol on U.S. Highway 40, is a medical institution that is breaking the popular concept that the finest medical care and research are to be found only in large cities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Grains recovered from an early sell-off on the Board of Trade today, in most cases moving above their previous closing prices.

Many of the adverse effects that the steel industry predicted would flow from abandonment of the basing-point system of price quotation in favor of the mill pricing method -- such as uneven distribution of steel nationally and a wide differential in prices, mostly on the up scale, in various sections of the country -- are beginning to appear, industry officials disclosed last week.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 14 -- With a one-pound loaf of bread selling for an average price of 14 cents in the United States, the cost is 20 cents at Ketchikan, 22 cents at Juneau, 25 cents at Fairbanks and 33 cents at Sitka. This is symbolic of the Alaskan cost of living which has exceeded that in the nation as a whole by from 23 to 80 per cent.

Fifteen years ago Laurence A. Steinhardt gave up a New York law practice in order to accept President Roosevelt's appointment to represent this country in Sweden. Some commentators thought this a political reward for pre-election support. It was really the beginning of a decade and a half of ill-paid but enormously valuable work.

RESERVATIONS for eastbound transatlantic passage are becoming easier to obtain. Most liners report space for practically all sailings after the middle of August. Travel westbound across the Atlantic will remain tight through September and October, according to steamship companies, with cabins available on most ships after that date.
ANYONE who is thinking of planting a hedge this year ought to consider the hemlock. No matter what the location or purpose of the hedge, this plant will prove versatile enough to suit it

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Here are important excerpts from the report by NLRB Trial Examiner Arthur Leff in the case of the American Newspaper Publishers Association vs. the International Typographical Union (I.T.U.), in which he found the union guilty of violating three provisions of the Taft-Hartley law:

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Breezing out in front like a queen bee leading her charmed swarm, the Wahini, Pat O'Gorman's maroon-colored craft, was not marooned in any sense of the word today in the fifth and concluding race of the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship at the Bay Shore Yacht Club.

Twenty-four entries have been received for the Lake George Marathon long-distance swimming championship of the world, to be held on Wednesday, Sept. 8, from Bolton Landing to the Hotel Fort William Henry pier, it has been announced by officials of the Lake George Swimming Association, which is sponsoring the event.

The players who have been chosen to represent the Soccer Football Association of Israel during a four-game tour of this country next month were announced yesterday by Chaim Glovinsky, president of the organization. The Israeli will meet the United States Olympic team at Sept. 26, at the Polo Grounds, in the opener of a two-game Metropolitan series.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 14 -- George Stuhr Jr., Notre Dame senior and captain-elect of the golf team at South Bend, teamed with his host, F.J. Palecek Jr., to win the play-off for the medal in the Seawane Harbor Club's annual member-guest tournament with a best ball score of 70.

FREQUENTLY there erupts along Forty-third Street, just west of Broadway, a minor melee that looks like a cross between a track meet and an Agnes de Mille directed ballet of urchins. Actually, those youngsters darting across the street are merely fleeing remnants of an assault wave loosed against the side doors of the Paramount.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Although the three Western Military Governments have pressed for the formation of a Western German state and German officials are speedily carrying out that plan, the Western Allies do not intend to sign a peace treaty with any but an all-German government, including a representation from the Soviet zone.
GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- As a result of a series of trade agreements concluded within the last few months, East-West trade in Europe during 1948 is expected to be very much greater than it was last year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Model Cadet and Admiral Lea, both owned by Mrs. Ada L. Rice of Chicago, stunned 27,490 spectators by running one, three in the $75,650 Washington Park Futurity today. Ocean Drive, owned by Fred W. Hooper of Montgomery, Ala., finished second, three lengths behind Model Cadet, the 7-to-10 favorite, Mr. Busher, previously undefeated, was eleventh and last.

NOW in the dog days, when the harsh sun bakes the rickety skeletons of the shattered buildings and slender pencils of yellow dust rise whirling from the rubble to dance across the ruins, Berlin has nothing to offer but courage. Trapped in the pressure between East and West, ruined by the war they started, the people of this city have no material contribution they can make.

Widespread buyers' resistance to high meat prices throughout the nation was attended last week by reports of organized boycotts in many cities. A survey conducted yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES showed that while meat sales were definitely off in many large cities, attempts to organize "meat strikes" accounted for only a small part of the narrowed demand.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Aug. 14 -- Possibilities for a good day faced the contestants in the Maine tuna tournament this morning, but as the boats will not return until late today, we decided to scurry around and dig us some information on the present and future inland fishing and hunting prospects.

The United States Government became the protector of Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kosenkina, Soviet school teacher, yesterday when the House Committee on Un-American Activities served a subpoena on her. By this means, at least technically, the woman who leaped out of the Soviet Consulate here, where she says she was held prisoner, was placed in the "custody" of the Federal Government.

TO implement Paramount's initial investment of $250,000 in screen rights to "The Heiress," William Wyler has assembled a cast decidedly to his liking (at an estimated cost of $400,000) and is now deep in the process of reconstructing New York life of a century ago on the Paramount sound stages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A political tempest of yet undefinable dimensions seemed to be blowing toward Washington this week after the publication of a National Defense Establishment report recommending the "federalization" of the National Guard.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 14 -- Specialized observatories are needed in the southern hemisphere and in the Far East if astronomers are to keep continuous records of the activity of the sun and the behavior of the earth's upper atmosphere, according to Dr. B. Lyot of France in an address to the International Astronomical Union today.

MANILA, Aug. 14 -- President Elipidio Quirino's amnesty proclamation for the outlawed Hukbalahaps has brought comparative peace to this country but tomorrow, the final day set for arms registration, will find the Government in possession of fewer than 200 surrendered firearms.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Professors George W. Elderkin of the Department of Art and Archaeology, and Lewis F. Moody of the Department of Mechanical Engineering, and Assistant Prof. Lewis R. Cary of the Department of Biology have retired from active duty on the Princeton University faculty, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

MANILA, Aug. 14 -- President Elipidio Quirino's amnesty proclamation for the outlawed Hukbalahaps has brought comparative peace to this country but tomorrow, the final day set for arms registration, will find the Government in possession of fewer than 200 surrendered firearms.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Professors George W. Elderkin of the Department of Art and Archaeology, and Lewis F. Moody of the Department of Mechanical Engineering, and Assistant Prof. Lewis R. Cary of the Department of Biology have retired from active duty on the Princeton University faculty, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Firing first to meet President Truman's expected double attack on their fiscal and living cost policies, Republicans claimed today they have saved American taxpayers nearly $6,350,000,000 by slashing Administration spending plans in the last two years.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Olaf Ulvestad of Seattle, who shared second place with Isaac I. Kashdan, the 1947 open champion, at Baltimore recently, again tied with the New Yorker today at the conclusion of the fourth round of the United States chess championship.

WHEN automotive manufacturers are asked when and where the spiraling of prices for cars will end they shake heads and admit there is no definite answer in sight. They point out that so many factors are involved in the formation of the rate structure that forecasts for the future would be baseless, but agree that prices are likely to go still higher before going down.

Heavy increases are being shown in department store mail order business, it was learned here yesterday. One of the largest stores in the metropolitan area disclosed an increase of approximately 40 per cent since the first of the year. Several stores reported their mail order business this month has been on a level with their average Christmas mail order sales.

If you pick up and comfort a screaming little baby, feed an infant when he is hungry instead of by the clock, ignore a young child's thumb-sucking (instead of applying such forms of torture as the books used to advise), someone may say you are "spoiling" your child.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 14 -- President Truman's criticism of the Washington investigation of Communists as a "red herring" is in itself "treasonable in spirit" and it gives "aid and comfort to potential enemies of the United States," Representative W. Kingsland Macy, Republican leader of Suffolk County, declared tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Despite a swerve early in the stretch that carried him out to the middle of the track as the crowd let loose with a collective gasp, the Maine Chance Farm's Ace Admiral continued to a runaway victory in the seventy-ninth edition of the Travers Stakes at Saratoga today.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet Military Administration launched new attacks on three departments of Berlin's Magistrat, or City Assembly today as the Russian campaign to dissolve this body and complete the division of the city moved toward a climax.

THE novel, when you think of it, should be wide open to novel ideas. That is what its name implies. But immensely valuable though Freud's ideas were, when the novel was being stifled by respectability over a generation ago, the big question today is whether a conflict does or does not exist between the forces that psychoanalysis and psychiatry are guiding and the very nature of the novel.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- As was expected, the Saratoga yearling sales had the best night of four at the Fasig-Tipton sales arena last night. All told, fifty-five thoroughbred yearlings went on the block and brought $477,800, for an average of $8,633.

A blunt warning that the Arabs might "throw themselves into the lap of Russia" if the United States did not stop supporting the "pretensions of the Zionists" was given last night by Jamal el-Husseini, vice-chairman of the Arab Higher Committee.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 -- Missouri may not be the pushover in the November election that some Republicans say it will be for the Dewey-Warren ticket.

In the quiz, "Mister President," Harold Heifer is wrong on two points. There have been two Presidents from west of the Mississippi, Hoover and Truman. John is not the first name held by the greatest number of Chief Execu-

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Gasoline rationing will be an accepted fact throughout the United States by 1951 if Middle East oil field transportation problems are not solved, a veteran oil man has warned housewives and motorists.

THE prospect of country life held no charms for Georgia Lane when economy forced her and her mother back to live in the Maine village where she had been born sixteen years ago. Besides her resentment at leaving Boston there was the dread of an old scandal, the suspicion of embezzlement attached to her father's memory.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The worst summer weather Europe has experienced in many years has seriously damaged vital food crops all over the Continent. Heavy rainstorms have beaten down crops, flooded farmland and blighted holiday-making along the coasts of Northwestern Europe as well as in Switzerland.

Among the various educational programs conducted at summer camps by colleges and universities in the city, Columbia University is carrying out a unique project at Camp Columbia Lakeside, Conn., "to make the students aware of the responsibilities of the engineer toward his community."

Rural schools in the United States and Canada have done so successful a job in preparing students to go to the big cities that emphasis should now be switched to training youth to appreciate the country and devise means to improve rural life.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- Money is not perhaps the root of all evil in Germany but the three different kinds of money now circulating within the country are, at least, contributing factors in the political battle which is being fought for Berlin and for all Germany.

The public is receiving no benefit from the discounts and rebates being passed out in "discriminatory fashion" by large milk distributors to chain stores and a "very limited" number of independent grocers, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, charged yesterday.

ATHENS, Aug. 14 -- Addressing local and foreign press representatives today for the first time since his arrival in Athens as United States Ambassador, Henry F. Grady stressed that the type of government any nation might have was not a consideration for its eligibility to partnership in the Marshall Plan.

Trustees of the Brooklyn Public Library will go before the City Planning Commission on Tuesday to ask that $1,385,000 be appropriated in the forthcoming capital outlay budget to complete Ingersoll Memorial branch, the central building of the borough library located opposite Grand Army Plaza. Ground for the building was officially broken in 1912.

Prospects are that there will be adequate supplies of petroleum products to meet the needs of domestic consumers next fall and winter, unless a war should develop or serious strikes disrupt transportation and refining operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A 4-3 victory over the Washington Senators put the Boston Red Sox in second place in the American League today. The Red Sox got four runs off Mickey Haefner in the eighth inning.

Higher costs of business loans, implied by the raising of the discount rate by Federal Reserve Banks, shared honors last week with the forthcoming re-establishment of retail credit control as the major anti-inflation moves thus far.

A nation sold down the river forty-three years ago into slavery to Japan was reborn yesterday in the centuries-old city of Seoul when the newly formed Korean Government formally took office. It is to our credit that we took a leading part in redressing the injury done the Koreans by the Treaty of Portsmouth.

The splendid article on the Bastogne War Memorial, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 1, deserves high praise. In an all-too-short space, your correspondent described one of the great battlegrounds of history, the heroic resistance of the Belgians, the defiant courage of our men under General McAuliffe, the successful struggle of General Patton to relieve the city and the pluck and energy of the Bastognians in meeting post-war hardships.
THE aim of all gardeners is not only to grow beautiful flowers but to have those which will boom over a long period of time. The biennial type of canterbury bell fulfills both requirements.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Aug. 15 -- Self-government came to two-thirds of Korea's 29,000,000 people today.

FOR all the gloomy omens of the months before, Broadway had some reason for optimism last week. The fourteen shows that had clung through the heat breathed more easily in the cooler weather. Backers could look the tax collector in the eye again.

HOLLYWOOD. BUSTER KEATON, who made his last Hollywood film appearance as a comedy star exactly fifteen years ago, is currently back at his favorite pastime -- doling out fun via the motion pictures to a public that he believes is starving for real laughs.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 14 -- The second event in the American Dance Festival, which is to continue through Aug. 22 in the Palmer Auditorium here, was a matinee performance today by Jane Dudley, Sophie Maslow, William Bales and their company.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- An organized boycott designed to bring down meat prices went into its fifth day here with conflicting reports of its effect.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 14 -- J. Natalicio Gonzalez will be sworn in as President of Paraguay tomorrow morning. He will succeed acting President Juan Manuel Frutos, who has served since the coup that ousted Gen. Higinio Morinigo in June.

Industrial plants seeking steel sheets are turning to "conversion deals" under which they furnish steel ingots on a customer rolling basis, purchasing agents revealed here yesterday. For obtaining ingots, steel users are turning to formerly idle War Assets Administration surplus war plants.
CLARENCE DAY, 61, died on Dec. 28, 1935, and in a column that I edited, Mr. E.B. White, in the issue of Dec. 29, wrote a poem about his friend. It contained these lines:
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14 -- The Ku Klux Klan publicly endorsed Herman Talmadge's candidacy for the Georgia Governorship as the South continued in the throes of the civil-rights controversy this week.

NORMAN MAILER, back from a stay in Paris. announces himself as still surprised by the prodigious sales of "The Naked and the Dead." (See Best Seller list on this page.) He thinks maybe the book just filled up a vacuum.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Lucille Ball's first picture under a long-term contract she signed at Columbia in January will be "Miss Grant Takes Richmond," a comedy the studio first announced for production six years ago, then shelved until last April when it was said that Rosalind Russell would star in it.

A long-awaited superhighway that will bring motorists from Northern New Jersey twenty to thirty minutes closer to Times Square is being rushed to completion. To date $10,000,000 has been spent on the project that is slated to open next summer.
PARIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Alex Jany, the big French swimmer who couldn't win in the Olympics, today scored his third victory over the United States Olympic champions in the French-American meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- President Truman predicted today that the Government would end its present accounting year with an "operating deficit" which would prevent further reduction of the $252,000,000,000 national debt.

MANAGERIAL switches have been made so fast and furiously of late that a returning stranger needs a guide to find his way around. Not quite as cataclysmic as the Shotton-Durocher-Ott game of musical chairs nor as unexpected as the beheading of Ben Chapman was the shake-up in Cincinnati. Johnny Neun was out, which was not too startling, and Bucky Walters was in, which was.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 15 -- The declaration of policy by the new Government headed by Premier William Drees made very little impression in Amsterdam's financial quarters. In their opinion the Premier said scarcely anything that would make the nation work harder.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 -- Officials of the International Typographical Union, AFL, believe that the latest finding of a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner in an ITU case lessens the possibility that the general counsel of the board will try to have the union and its officers cited for contempt of court.

Consolidated net earnings of Best Foods, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with last June increased to $9,539,395 from $5,288,095 in the preceding fiscal year, according to the annual report, signed jointly by William J. Wardall, chairman, and Leonard G. Blumenschine, president, and mailed today to stockholders.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- India's former rulers warmly congratulated her today upon the speed with which she had accomplished the transition from dependence to independence and on the compar ative success of her first year of self-government.
TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- Japan is supplementing her shattered merchant marine with extensive salvage operations on ships that were sunk by American planes and submarines during the war.

It was time that the critical financial position of the country's airlines should be examined. Last week's Presidential order to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Bureau of the Budget to undertake such an examination will be welcomed by the country and by the airlines themselves.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- American coaches and athletes who spoke to Russian observers here said they understood Soviet participation at Helsinki is a certainty. Russia is understood to have an intensive athletic program underway designed to produce a team which could beat the United States.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Holding on long enough to get 120 craft around short courses, a light northerly air of from five to seven knots enabled finishes today in the Stamford Yacht Club's only regatta of the Long Island Sound championships, the twenty-eighth in the series.

VIENNA, Aug. 15 -- Harrison Lewis, second secretary of the United States Legation here, was declared persona non grata in Hungary two months ago because he intervened last year to rescue a United States citizen from the Hungarian police.

With only one dissenting vote, members of Local 6, International Typographical Union, AFL, voted yesterday to declare that a "lockout" existed at The Journal of Commerce because of the management's refusal to grant a $9 weekly wage increase while negotiations for a new contract were carried on.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Developments in the domestic grain situation last week have convinced many members of the Chicago Board of Trade that the Government's support prices for grains are the only preventive against a decline in the market.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The little burst of optimism displayed by the stock markets a few days ago has flickered out, leaving only curiosity as to why it ever occurred. It had its origin, of course, in the fact that attempts to end the diplomatic deadlock over transportation at Berlin were being made in Moscow at the highest level and that the talks had not ended after the first meeting.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Governor Earl Warren of California, Republican candidate for Vice President, arrived here tonight for two days of conferences with Governor Dewey, the candidate for President, on campaign plans and strategy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark criticized today current Congressional investigations into Communist espionage and other alleged Communist activities as detrimental to the long-standing efforts of the Department of Justice to get at the roots of the situation and obtain a "sound basis for prosecution."

Undeterred by rough surf, nearly 2,000,000 persons thronged beaches in the metropolitan area yesterday while gentle northwest winds, low humidity and normal summer temperature made it a pleasurable day for stay-at-homes.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Home Minister Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel said today his Government was determined to use "a firm hand" to prevent the spread to India of Communist disorders sweeping southern Asia.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Singles by Hal Wagner and Eddie Mayo accounted for two runs in the top of the ninth and the Tigers downed the Browns, 3 to 1, today. Cliff Fannin and Freddie Hutchinson battled to a 1-1 tie until the two singles, plus a double by Hutchinson and a single by Dick Wakefield, broke up the game.

A recent edition of your paper carried an editorial entitled "Salvage in Europe." This gives prominence to a plan for "a sweeping, mass inoculation program to fight their common enemy (tuberculosis) and save lives" through the use of B.C.G. vaccine.

TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE, Ala., Aug. 15 -- Negro youth of high school age in attendance here at the opening of the fourteenth annual convention of the New Farmers of America were told today to hold their shoulders up because the trained farmer has as much prestige in this country as any other skilled worker.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The envoys of the Western powers held a strategy conference today while they waited for the Kremlin to arrange their sixth conference with Foreign Minister V.M. Molotov.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 15 -- The Gulf Ports Association will organize its forces at Corpus Christi, Tex., Sept. 2 to 4 for what is expected to be a freight rate fight with North Atlantic ports. This announcement was made yesterday by Henry W. Sweet, director of the Alabama State Docks in this city.

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 15 -- A medieval procession of Roman Catholic clergy and lay believers passing slowly through modern war ruins heralded today the solemn reopening of Cologne's Gothic cathedral which had not been usable since the bombings of 1944.

Your editorial "Production and Productivity" in the issue of Aug. 8 brings out relationships which many people are unaware of or ignore. Yet your article itself disappoints in its failure to emphasize the factors which prevent lower unit costs from being reflected in lower prices.

Mayor O'Dwyer expressed his hope yesterday of ending the "antiquated and annoying" use of waste materials in city landfills as he received a $44,000,000 program from Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, designed to eliminate the practice within three years.

Plans have been made to teach English to Chinese war brides at a parochial school in Chinatown, it became known yesterday. The classes will be held at a building adjoining the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration, at 29 Mott Street.

Created last summer at a constitutional convention on the University of Wisconsin's campus, the National Student Association -- dedicated in part to "promote international understanding and fellowship" -- will convene for its first Congress in Madison, Wis., next week.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society announced yesterday that it had made grants totaling $77,600 to five medical institutions to conduct medical research projects into the causes and control of multiple sclerosis.

AMSTERDAM, Holland, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Victories by Lloyd LaBeach of Panama in the 100-meter and 200-meter dashes and by Herb McKenley of Jamaica in the 400-meter run highlighted the International track meet at Olympic Stadium today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Rabbi Abba Hillel Sliver, American Zionist leader, arrived today by air in Haifa, key port of Northern Israel, and left at once for Tel Aviv.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Communist newspaper Rude Pravo outlined today points on which a Communist party loyalty check will be made between Oct. 1 and Dec. 31. It listed them as:

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Winning in thirty-seven moves from Walter Shipman, Columbia Varsity chess captain, in the fifth round, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, today went out in front of the field of twenty experts in the tournament for the United States championship at the Community Center with a score of 4 1/2 -- 1/2.

The mighty figures of the ancient world and especially of the early Christian church have become glamorized spiritually, the Rev. R.W. Hugh Jones declared yesterday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

Brig. Gen. George J. Nold, Staff Engineer of the First Army, who will take up his duties today as the new Division Engineer, North Atlantic Division, Corps of Engineers, with headquarters at 111 East Sixteenth Street.

CONCORD, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Many persons have answered the plea to preserve as a permanent museum the white frame house at 73 Main Street here where Henry David Thoreau, essayist, poet and naturalist, spent his last twelve years and prepared the manuscript of Walden for publication, it was announced yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,635,096,893. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The police in Manhattan and Brooklyn put in quite a few hours yesterday at carpentry, ladder climbing and tossing a fancy lasso around an air vent. It was all in the line of duty to rescue a couple of cats and a dog.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 -- Officials of steel companies, questioned here late last week, still declined to estimate when steel supply will equal demand. None cares to guess when this sellers' market will become a buyers' market. Privately they admit that their and other industry observers' predictions on this point have been wrong too often in the last few years.

The Burlington Mills Corporation achieved a new high sales record of $206,776,793 in the nine months ended on June 26, an increase of 25 per cent over the $163,591,875 reported for the similar period of the previous year, according to the report released today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Willis Anderson, 35-year-old Los Angeles postal clerk, won the men's singles championship of the national public parks tennis tournament today. He defeated Hugh Stewart of South Pasadena, Calif., in a five-set thriller, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7.

The Moore-McCormack Lines announced yesterday the appointment of Capt. John M. Hultman of 167 Lenox Road, Brooklyn, as staff captain of the liner Uruguay. With the Argentina and Brazil, this vessel completes the line's Good Neighbor passenger fleet operating between New York and ports on the east coast of South America.

Light from the star Alioth 300,000,000,000,000 miles away will activate a miniature atomic pile releasing atomic energy to open New York City's Golden Anniversary Exposition at Grand Central Palace Saturday at 8:30 P.M., it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Anniversary Committee.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- After six weeks of almost unbroken music-making, quietness settled on Tanglewood this evening. Students of the Berkshire Music Center gave the last of more than forty programs in the morning, and Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra closed the 1948 Berkshire Music Festival in the afternoon with a concert before 14,700 persons, largest audience to attend a single festival program.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Pirates shaded the Cardinals, 5 to 4, in the nightcap of their double-header today after the Redbirds captured the opener, 8 to 3. A crowd of 37,767 put the season attendance over the million mark at 1,029,759. Ralph Kiner got his thirtieth home run of the year in the fifth inning of the second contest.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 15 -- For the third year in a row, W. Russell Howe and Johnny Humm of Rockville, current Long Island amateur champion, won the Seawane Harbor Club's member-guest golf tournament. They scored in the final match, 1 up, today by capturing the last hole.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Latest reports forwarded today to Count Bernadotte here said that responsibility still had not been fixed for the recent blasting of the Latrun pumping station on the Jerusalem water pipeline.

The five-story building containing two stores and twenty-four apartments at 2,000 Mapes Avenue, northeast corner of 178th Street, in the Bronx, was sold by R. Schwartz to the Sterling Investing Corporation, represented by Julius Schnapper, attorney. It is assessed for $62,000.
Twenty Latin-American scholars and artists were named yesterday as recipients this year of the Latin American Fellowships of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. Their grants total $65,000.
Seven-two families, living in an area that forms part of the New York International Airport, Idlewild. Queens, found themselves confronted yesterday with acute house-moving problems.

Municipal securities scheduled for sale this week amount to $63,045,250, a rise of $26,927,550 over the $36,117,700 of such bonds and notes sold last week. The total is but $4,760,941 below the weekly average of $67,796,191 since the beginning of the year.

These are in truth streamlined days in railroading. It is not merely that the modern passenger train whisks the traveling public from place to place more swiftly, silently and smoothly than did its predecessors; even great changes in the corporate affairs of our carriers seem to move today on well-oiled roller bearings.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes overwhelmed Blind Brook, 15 -- 5, at Bostwick Field today to gain the final round of the national 20-goal polo tourney against Meadow Brook.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Estimates issued today covering 1948 crop production prospects in New York state showed that bumper harvests were expected for most grain and feed crops, and also for many fresh vegetables.

ATHENS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Greek Army, in a surprise attack on the southwest sector of its arc around the guerrillas' Grammos Mountains stronghold, occupied Orla Ridge today and began closing a trap on the defenders of the southern approaches.

While the Economic Cooperation Administration has begun to function well in Italy, success of its program will hinge in large measure on a good public relations job among civilians there, was the opinion expressed last week by Della M. Grattan, advertising executive recently returned from a two-month visit to Italy.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 15 -- Sheikh Yussef Abu Ghosh, 28-year-old Moslem feudal landlord and clan chieftain of a large area to the west of Jerusalem, said today that he ardently desired Arab-Jewish peace. He added that he himself was ready to negotiate with Israeli leaders at a round table "either in Tel Aviv or Lake Success or anywhere else."

Plans to bring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne to Broadway next January in "Speak to Me of Love" have been altered, it became known yesterday. The famous acting couple won't be seen here until the season of 1949-50 in S.N. Behrman's transformation of Marcel Achard's French comedy.
